title: WHERE THE JOBS WILL (AND WON'T) BE
description: Listed below are selected career possibilities that, from the standpoint of availibility, will provide the most and least security through the end of the century, according to projections by the United States Labor Deptpartment's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The percentage growth in the number of jobs expected through the year 2000 in each field is indicated next to the job titles. In those cases where opportunities will decline - such as for college and university faculty members - the change is shown with a minus sign. THE MOST SECURE Paralegal personnel 104 Medical assistants 90 Physical therapists 87 Physical therapy aides 82 Data processing repairers 80 Home Health aides 80 Data processing systems analysis 76 Medical records technicians 75 Computer programers 70 Radiologic technologists 65 Dental hygienists 63 Dental assistants 57 Physicians assistants 57 Peripheral data-processing workers 51 Electrical and electronics engineers 48 Computer operators 47 Dining-room attendants 46 Electrical and electronics technicians 46 Opticians 46 Restaurant cooks 46 Travel Agents 46 Veternarians 46 real-estate brokers 45 Registered nurses 44 Waiters and waitresses 44 Hotel desk clerks 43 Securities and financial salesworkers 42 Receptionists and info clerks 41 Accountants and auditors 40 Bartenders 40 Dental lab technicians 39 Licensed practical nurses 38 Physcians and surgeons 38 Lawyers 36 Nursing aides and attendants 35 THE LEAST SECURE Electrical electronic assemblers -54 Electronic semiconductor -51 Railroad conductors, yardmasters -41 Gas and oil occupations -34 Phone installers and repairers -32 Shoe sewer -32 Chemical equipment controllers -30 Farmers -28 Stenographers -28 Statistical clerks -28 Farm workers -20 Coil winders, tapers, and finishers -19 Compositors and typesetters -17 Shoe and leather workers -17 Data-entry keyers -16 Typists and word processors -14 Machine tool cutters -11 Child-care workers, private -10 College and university faculty -4

title: Kimberley Lovell Is Married to Douglas Hiscano
description: Kimberley Whyte Lovell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Lovell Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Raymond Cape, Me., was married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon to Douglas R. Hiscano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael A. Hiscano of Short Hills, N.J., and Stag Lake in Andover, N.J. The Rev. Dr. George K. Chorba performed the ceremony.

title: Composing With the Soloist in Mind
description: A concerto can come into being in different ways. Most often, an instrumentalist will approach a composer whose music he finds appealing with a request for a concerto. Occasionally, a composer will write one for a performer whose playing he admires and present it to him.

title: Mandatory Water Rationing Set for San Francisco
description: Mandatory rationing of water will begin Sunday for 2.1 million residents of the San Francisco area after two consecutive dry winters and a failure of voluntary efforts.

title: CD Players Can Smooth the Roadway
description: The arrival of May and the impending end of school put the nation in the grip of motorized wanderlust. But if your ''radio'' is still the one that came with the car from the factory, it may well require an updated sound system before it can be considered roadworthy in a musical sense.

title: Commercial Property: Kaufman Astoria Studios; A Casting Call Goes Out for Back-Office Tenants
description: In the seven years since he took over the moribund Astoria Studios, George S. Kaufman has silenced skeptics by putting Queens back on the map as a magnet for television, movie and recording work.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Madison, Wis.;
Renovating A Rail Complex
description: LEAD: THE city's most-active renovator is bringing back to life a blighted turn-of-the-century railroad complex.

title: A Rose Grows in the Hamptons
description: A RED neon rose sporting a single leaf and solitary prominent thorn glows in the window of C. J. Thorne in Bridgehampton. This sophisticated yet mellow new restaurant has one of those made-up-sounding names that usually mark yuppie watering holes.

title: Lenin and Hegel
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Russell Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Angele Russell, a daughter of Mrs. William Thomas Russell of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Russell, was married yesterday to Stephen Wright Barringer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Newton Barringer Jr. of Durham, N.C., and Myrtle Beach, S.C. The Rev. Charles C. Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: Susan J. Garfield, Loan Officer, Plans To Wed Charles Higginson Jr. in May
description: Susan Jennings Garfield, a loan officer in private banking at the Shawmut Bank in Boston, and Charles Higginson Jr., an oil trader with Catamount Petroleum in Boston, plan to be married May 28.

title: College Students Need Drug-Abuse Education
description: The article on campus drinking [ ''Campus Drinking: Colleges Confront 'Issue of the 80's,' '' April 10 ] presents some interesting information on how local colleges are struggling to regulate alcohol consumption among their student bodies, but the analysis lacks sufficient breadth to cover how the colleges are failing today to provide much meaningful education about drug and alcohol abuse.

title: Committee Procedure Defended by Senator
description: In her Feb. 14 Opinion Page article, Phyllis Elston correctly pointed out that I opposed S. 426, which granted the Legislature authority to endorse or reject the pending State Development and Redevelopment Plan. She also correctly pointed out that I was the only one of five committee members opposed to the bill.

title: Cuomo Orders Inquiry On Troopers' Testimony
description: Governor Cuomo has directed a state commission to investigate allegations that state police officers lied under oath in a vehicular manslaughter case in upstate New York.

title: Choral Singers: More Love Than Money
description: LEAD: BECAUSE he leads both kinds of singing groups, Johannes Somary is in a position to contrast the professionals with the amateurs, or ''volunteers,'' as he calls them. And the conductor of the Great Neck Choral Society, who brings his volunteers to the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point on Saturday to celebrate their 30th anniversary with a spring concert, admits there's a difference between the two, but not necessarily in quality.

title: Murky Waters
description: THE Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives gave his application for citizenship a boost last week, but it will take more than citizenship to clear the way for Jens-Peter Berndt to join the United States Olympic swimming team. Under International Olympic Committee rules, Berndt, who has been attending the University of Alabama since defecting from East Germany in 1985, needs a waiver from his native country. Since East Germany has traditionally refused to grant waivers for defectors, it appears highly unlikely Berndt will get one. Indeed, a House staffer said that Olympic officials had told the Judiciary Committee that East Germany rejected a preliminary request for a waiver.(AP)

title: 4 Companies to Sponsor New Child-Care Center
description: LEAD: IN July 1985 the General Foods Corporation approached the Child Care Council of Westchester and asked for its help in getting together some corporations in the vicinity of Route 287 that might want to participate in establishing a child-care center.

title: Evening Fashion
description: The Light Fantastic: It's Cause Enough

title: PROGRAM TRADING GETS MORE BRUTAL
description: When stock prices collapsed in October, program trading was criticized as one of the chief villains in the financial drama.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Harrison Is Updating Its Master Plan
description: LEAD: Many years ago, said Pat V. Angarano, the Harrison Town Supervisor, he was given some sage advice from one of his predecessors about rich residents who lobby for their particular community interests.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the County Chamber of Commerce misidentified the man shown. He was James P. O'Toole, the chamber's immediate past president.

title: Ted Laporte Wed To Ginna Schrum
description: The marriage of Virginia Durald Schrum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Schrum Jr. of Charlotte, N.C., to William Frederick Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Laporte of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., took place yesterday at the Myers Park United Methodist Church in Charlotte. The Rev. Dr. Bernard R. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: TRANSITCHEK, the public-private mass-transit discount program, has passed the six-month mark. And with 300 businesses and more than 10,000 workers now participating, it is well along toward its goal of encouraging commuting by public transportation.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Road Apples
description: Horse diapers! The very idea convulses public officials in New York. Horsefeathers! they gibe in response. Such reactions hastily minimize a public annoyance and ignorantly dismiss a practical remedy.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: Remember Emerson's advice about what to hitch your wagon to? The most improved and most improving colt in the country is Risen Star, wonderfully impressive overcoming a troubled trip to beat the Winter Book favorite, Forty Niner, in the Lexington. STANLEY SOLOMON New York

title:
A WORLD OF MUSIC '88;
Yankee Doodle Goes to Europe
description: LEAD: One of the surprises of this European music festival season is the number of New World composers being honored in the Old World.

title: Robert Case Wed To Susie Peterson
description: Mary-Suzanne Peterson, a securities analyst at the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Robert A. Case, a principal in mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Michael Lanning, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: God and Mammon on Park Avenue
description: THE BATTLE OF ST. BART'S By Brent C. Brolin. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: THE DATA, AND THE CLAIMS
description: Every Presidential election year provides a forceful reminder that a glass can be portrayed as half empty or half full. In 1988, the battery of figures Republicans are marshaling emphasize what the White House calls the ''significant and good news'' about the economy; Democrats are trying to accentuate the negative. The Republicans.

title: Trying to Unlock A Big Market
description: Locked-out motorists in Dover, Del., have always relied on the city police to open their car doors for nothing. The city's locksmiths say they are losing thousands of dollars each year in business to the police.

title: Asking Some Questions About Special Education
description: I read the letter from Jane Goldblatt to the Long Island editor on March 6 and was disturbed by her attitude toward educating the handicaped. I would like to offer a rebuttal, strictly addressing her need for defining education. I am a speech therapist working in special education in the public domain and have been for over 20 years.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Who knows why they've become ubiquitous, so much so that a party without one or more guests snapping away with little cameras is considered not quite in the swing of things.

title: WHAT YOU SEE IS WHAT YOU GET
description: DUKAKIS An American Odyssey. By Charles Kenney and Robert L. Turner. Illustrated. 260 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. DUKAKIS AND THE REFORM IMPULSE By Richard Gaines and Michael Segal. Illustrated. 247 pp. Boston: Quinlan Press. $17.95. CREATING THE FUTURE The Massachusetts Comeback and Its Promise for America. By Michael S. Dukakis and Rosabeth Moss Kanter. 190 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: Hit-and-Run Driver Kills Two
description: A man and a woman were killed in Manhattan early yesterday when a speeding car careered into them as they crossed the street, the authorities said.

title: New Refugees Crowd Camps In Hong Kong
description: Growing numbers of Vietnamese have been arriving in Hong Kong by boat in the past few months, crowding into refugee camps with thousands of other Vietnamese, most of whom have only a slim chance of finding new homes outside the chain-link fences of the bleak compounds.

title: Business Forum; GRAY MARKET PRODUCTS: BACK DOOR IMPORTS SHOULD BE BANNED
description: America's gray markets, also called parallel importation, are now big business. These markets arise when clever traders purchase well-known brand-name products from foreign suppliers and sell them to other domestic middlemen who are not part of the manufacturer's normal distribution chain. The practice is most likely to occur when currencies change value both substantially and quickly.

title:
A WORLD OF MUSIC '88;
WHO'S PERFORMING WHERE
description: LEAD: The following directory of music festivals is based on a survey of events occurring outside the United States and Canada and judged to be of more than local interest. It contains dates, locations, performers and program information, and where available, the range of ticket prices. In all cases, programs, performers, prices and other details are subject to change.

title: 2 Former Employees Indicted In Killing of Jersey Executive
description: Two former employees of an asbestos removal company have been indicted in the slaying of the company's president, who was shot to death in the driveway of his Rumson home.

title: 'On The Verge' Explores Time Travel
description: IN less than three years, the Boston Post Road Stage Company has emerged as a small theater of audacity and intelligence. With ''On the Verge,'' which concludes the company's second full season, it may have come up with its most challenging, offbeat play yet.

title: THEY CAN CURSE AND THEY CAN COOK
description: When the audience first meets Pale, the central figure in Lanford Wilson's ''Burn This,'' he is offstage, pounding on a stranger's apartment door, screaming obscenities at an unseen antagonist. It is well past midnight and Anna, the female character in Mr. Wilson's play at the Plymouth, looks confused and bleary-eyed switching on a light and peering through the peephole. Yet she opens the door and in tumbles Pale - a ranting, violent, drunken lunatic. Or so he appeared in John Malkovich's heated and extravagant performance.

title: Mary Elizabeth Abele Weds Michael Makurat
description: At St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Oceanside, L.I., Mary Elizabeth Abele, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Abele of Baldwin and Southold, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael David Makurat, the son of Mrs. Thomas M. Makurat of Harwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Makurat. The Rev. Thomas F. Sinnott performed the ceremony.

title: Thompson's Stamp Will Mark Team
description: WHEN Bobby Knight assembled the United States Olympic basketball team in 1984 his emphasis was on players who could adapt to his personality and conform to his system.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: Only Private Terms has the breeding and the past performances to make this one of the fastest Derbys ever run. Private Terms's dam, Laughter, was among the last offspring of Bold Ruler, America's premier sire until his death at the young age of 16. So, too, was Secretariat.

title: Constance Ann Schlitz Wed in Capital
description: Constance Ann Schlitz, the daughter of Warren J. Schlitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and the late Ann Schaffner Schlitz, was married yesterday to Worth Daniels MacMurray, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank G. MacMurray of McLean and Madison, Va. Canon Charles Martin performed the Episcopal ceremony in the great choir at the Washington Cathedral.

title: Review/Pop; Sounds of the Middle East
description: Dissidenten, a band from West Berlin, has its ears turned to North Africa. The songs the group brought to S.O.B.'s on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand, used Moroccan-style melodies, with modal scales and microtonal inflections, in settings that moved from Africa toward Europe as the early set progressed.

title: 'They Could Get to Work A Lot Quicker'
description: CHRISTOPHER A. GALLO of Shelton is the president of Connecticut Commuters Inc., a group that is trying to improve life for road and rail commuters.

title: Talking: The Elderly; Reverse Mortgages Catch On
description: Older people struggling along on limited incomes are becoming increasingly aware that reverse mortgage loans will provide them with monthly sums - $500 on average - to help meet the costs of remaining in their homes.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 27 about lost and stolen airline tickets carried an incorrect report from Northwest Airlines about its policy. The service charge for refunding a ticket is $50 for a domestic ticket and $30 for an international ticket.

title: Festivals for Stars and Listeners Alike
description: From the sounds that reach her dressing room, Carol Vaness, the American soprano, can tell a lot about the audiences that gather to hear her sing.

title: The Plight of Have-Nots in Victorian Britain in Exhibit at Yale
description: SO Dickensian is the new exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art that its curator, Julian Treuherz, might have left the title at ''Hard Times.'' But Mr. Treuherz, who is keeper of fine arts at the Manchester City Art Gallery (where the show originated) chose ''Hard Times: Victorian Social Realism'' instead.

title: Gail Cruikshank Wed To Keith Livingstone
description: The marriage of Gail Warren Cruikshank, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Lott Cruikshank of Maplewood, N.J., to Keith Eric Livingstone took place yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Livingstone, the parents of the bridegroom, in Bellevue, Wash. Judge James C. Kaiser of King County Northeast District Court in Redmond, Wash., performed the ceremony.

title: Budget Cuts Threaten Lyme Disease Research
description: LEAD: THE Smithsonian Institution, which houses many of the nation's great art treasures, is also curator of one of the world's more unusual collections: one million specimens of ticks.

title: At S.I. School, Lessons In Curbing Racial Strife
description: In 1980, a scuffle in the gymnasium of New Dorp High School on Staten Island erupted into violence. Black students were forced to flee in buses as white students hurled stones and shouted racial epithets. The school was closed temporarily, and it was days before black students returned to class.

title: Tax Law Change Irks Artists
description: FOR most Americans, April 15 has come and gone with a sigh of relief and a satisfying lick of the envelope. But for many artists, writers, composers and photographers, a tax nightmare has just begun.

title: Little League: The Sons Also Rise
description: MY 9-year-old loves baseball. He can't go into a drugstore without wanting to buy trading cards. He's a Yankees fan who knows the statistics of every player on the team, and whenever we're sitting at the table, or car pooling, he explains the subtleties of the game to me. He never tires of its intricacies, and sometimes I wonder if this love of his is in the genes.

title:
THE NATION: CITIES AND COUNTIES;
ON THE WEST COAST, IT'S A LOCAL MATTER
description: LEAD: State day-care programs are becoming common nationwide, especially as part of efforts to reduce the welfare rolls. But on the West Coast local and county governments have begun taking aggressive steps to address the needs of their own workers, to provide day-care centers and to force developers and employers to share in the costs.

title: Posting: East 30th Condos; A 421-a Trade-Off
description: Lawrence A. Smiley will be the first Manhattan developer to renovate city-owned shells for low- and moderate-income families as part of a new 421-a tax abatement program. Except he has not yet been shown the buildings. As Mr. Smiley completes work on Lexington Parc, whose 73 market-rate condominiums will benefit from the 10-year tax reduction, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development is still choosing two suitable buildings for the 22 apartments he is required to renovate. The $15 million building at 127 East 30th Street will be completed in October, and Mr. Smiley said he would begin the $800,000 renovation of the city buildings as soon they materialize. ''It's bouncing around from commissioner to commissioner,'' he said. The new condominium is being built next to the century-old Pratt Institute, a New York City landmark. Mr. Smiley purchased an air-rights easement from the United Jewish Appeal, which owns the Pratt building, and transferred air rights from three brownstones he owns on the block to build 18 floors at the site. The brick, granite and limestone tower, designed by Peter Clamon, will have one- and two-bedroom units starting at $200,000 and $300,000, respectively.

title: TROUBLE IN THE COCKPIT
description: No law now requires the airlines to advise the public of the experience and training of pilots or the conditions of the particular planes in which they are about to fly. Perhaps if such information were required to be posted at the check-in desks, airlines might focus more on the quality of their service. If building managers are required to display elevator-inspection certificates publicly, why can't airlines be made to do the same? RONALD L. KAISERMAN Philadephia

title: Warm Wrap-Ups
description: Smart wrappings for fall add warmth as well as luxury to wool suits and dresses. They are rectangular scarves bordered or appliqued with such furs as fox, sable, mink, Persian lamb or chinchilla.

title: New Arizona Governor Files Financial Data
description: Gov. Rose Mofford has filed amended financial disclosure forms to cover transactions omitted from sworn documents she filed over the last 10 years, and she has apologized for what she called an honest mistake.

title: Hollywood Comes to Starstruck Meriden
description: LARGE crowds gathered across the street and movie extras earning $50 a day stood patiently in their designated positions while a plethora of cameras, lights, cables and other movie-making gear filled the parking lot at the Uptown Garage in Meriden last Monday and Tuesday.

title: Three Times a Year, The Village Gets an Itch
description: Brimfield, Mass., is a serene New England village, the sort you might like to drive through on a Sunday. It's a one-street town with a triangular village green, a few red barns, some not too curlicued Victorian houses, a Congregational church, a blue and yellow Sunoco station, a grocery store with posters proclaiming the week's specials, a pizza parlor, a granite-faced bank and Francesco's Italian Ristorante, with a couple of cars out front. These few buildings appear the more tranquil, surrounded as they are by unusually large, flat fields - sizable stretches of barren green, untouched by tractor, horse or cow.

title: Lawsuit Over AIDS Exposure
description: Three hemophiliac brothers who doctors say were probably exposed to AIDS through blood-clotting agents are suing two pharmaceutical companies that processed the product.

title: Arrau Date Canceled
description: An appearance by the pianist Claudio Arrau, planned for May 18 at the 92d Street Y, has been canceled due to illness. The concert, which has not been rescheduled, was the last in this season's Distinguished Artists Series at the Y. Refunds are available by mail from the 92d Street Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue.

title: Former State Official Joins Race for DioGuardi's Seat
description: NITA LOWEY, a former assistant secretary of state in New York, entered the Democratic race for Congress last week, the third member of her party to seek the 20th Congressional District seat held by the two-term Republican incumbent Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi.

title: The Polish Stalemate
description: The Polish Government remains unwilling to give any recognition or legal rights to Solidarity, the union movement it outlawed. But unless it does, it cannot effectively govern the country - cannot stop Poland's slide into economic disaster.

title: Home Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: More Patients Storing Their Blood for Surgery
description: LEAD: PATIENTS scheduled for surgery are increasingly opting to store their blood for use during the operation because of fear of catching AIDS.

title: HEY, I RECOGNIZE THESE GUYS!
description: LIKE a support group of elderly widows, fans of the once-proud Baltimore Orioles have taken to consoling each other and wailing over happier days gone by. A friend called the other night, and in a broken voice described the Orioles' misadventures in loss No. 20. ''I don't even know these guys,'' he said.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FRANCO: A Biography. By J. P. Fusi. Translated by Felipe Fernandez-Armesto. (Harper & Row, $25.) This biography of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, by a Spanish historian, is dispassionately written and, most rare for the subject, without ideological discoloration. Franco, who was born in 1892 to a family of modest means, in his 30's was already a bemedaled hero of the Moroccan wars, and at 43 the acknowledged leader of the military junta that conspired on July 18, 1936, to overthrow the weak democratic Government legally elected to office some five months before.

title: U.S. Judge Challenges Sentencing Guidelines
description: A Federal judge says he will ignore recently instituted Federal sentencing guidelines on the ground they violate the Constitution's separation of powers.

title: EVICTION OF RENTERS BEGINS IN MARYLAND TOWN  States News Service
description: After four years of apartment living, Richard Sinnott spent the last two months living in his green 1978 Mustang because of a 60-year-old zoning regulation that forced his landlord to evict him.

title: Q AND A
description: Deadbeat Tenant Question: Recently I agreed to let an acquaintance stay in my apartment until next August while I work in Los Angeles. We agreed in a letter that she would pay half of the rent and the utility bills.

title: Blanton Neill Married To Kendrick T. Kelly
description: The marriage of Lola Blanton Neill, the daughter of Lucy B. Neill and Julian F. Neill, both of New Orleans, to Kendrick Thomas Kelly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick A. Kelly of Chappaqua, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Vladimir No Russian
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital: A Meditation
description: My earliest recollections of a hospital were of St. Mary's, in a town in upstate New York.

title:
INVESTING;
Casino Stocks for Conservative Bettors
description: LEAD: Many who have watched the stock market's wild swings in the last six months would probably consider an investment in gaming and casino stocks as redundant.

title: Yonkers Fight Perils Economic Plan
description: A political dispute between the new city administration and the one it replaced last November is jeopardizing participation in an economic development program.

title: Amy Sullivan Is Wed To Thomas E. Pajusi
description: Amy Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sullivan of Valley Stream, L.I., and Thomas E. Pajusi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmo Pajusi of Pelham Manor, N.Y., were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa performed the ceremony.

title: TROUBLE IN THE COCKPIT
description: On the day William Stockton's excellent piece ''Trouble in the Cockpit'' (March 27), on pilot error, appeared, I happened upon the 1981 National Transportation Safety Board's ''Annual Review of Aircraft Accident Data.'' In a compilation of accidents for the years 1970-79, causes of all accidents are compared with causes of fatal accidents. (There is no ''pilot died'' category, but it seems reasonable to assume that, in statistical terms, ''fatal accidents'' are generally equivalent to accidents in which the pilot died.) In the ''all accidents'' category, the pilot is found responsible for the accident in only 38.6 percent of the cases. However, in ''fatal accidents'' the pilot is found responsible 61.5 percent of the time.

title: 4 Arabs and Israeli Wounded in Renewed Unrest
description: Palestinian youths pelted troops with stones today in scattered anti-Israeli protests in the occupied territories, and four Palestinians and a soldier were wounded, military officials and Palestinians said.

title: GRAY DAYS AT BLACK ROCK
description: WHO KILLED CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network. By Peter J. Boyer. Illustrated. 361 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Foreign Medical Graduates May Get New Test
description: After years of battling for equal recognition, graduates of foreign medical schools may soon be able to take the same test in basic and clinical sciences that is given to graduates of American medical schools.

title: THE POLITICS OF VIOLENCE
description: REVOLUTIONARIES AND FUNCTIONARIES The Dual Face of Terrorism. By Richard Falk. 222 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton.

title: As Amnesty Ends, Aliens Crowd New York Offices
description: With the amnesty program of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 due to expire Wednesday, large numbers of aliens are now coming forward to apply in the New York region.

title: Saving Fragile Accabonac Harbor
description: LEAD: THE future of one of the last pristine areas on Long Island, Accabonac Harbor, on the eastern side of the hamlet of Springs, is being decided by the Town of East Hampton Planning Board.

title:
GARDENING;
Now Is the Time to Get the Work Done
description: LEAD: MAY is the month when gardeners really get serious, and the tasks awaiting are so numerous it may be difficult to decide what to do first.

title: ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
description: Last December's Israeli-Arab general strike indeed was a shock to many Israeli Jews. But the Police Minister, Haim Bar-Lev, reported that violence occurred in only four Arab communities, and those incidents were condemned by the strike's organizers. In contrast to the violence in the territories, the Israeli-Arab demonstrations on Land Day in March were peaceful, as was the general strike Israel's Arab citizens held in June 1987 to protest inequities in municipal services, education, housing and employment opportunities.

title: The Lessons 'Walden' Never Taught
description: I had envisioned a lusciously pastoral process - oak tenons slipping neatly into oak mortises, tankards of ale, robust laughter. My expectations about building my own house were, I admit, rather unrealistic, due mainly to reading ''Walden'' and a few too many Eric Sloane books.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 16 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $265,000 16 East 96th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; entry foyer, high-ceilings, original moldings and details; maintenance $473, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Wallach Management) Greenwich Village $675,000 77 Seventh Avenue (Vermeer) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, wrapped terrace; maintenance $1,048, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Inwood $70,200 70 Park Terrace East 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 618-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; windowed dining room, hardwood floors, high-ceilings; maintenance $447, 59% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) Kips Bay Area $155,000 140 East 28th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 720-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; manned elevator, dining foyer, fireplace; maintenance $764, 49% tax-deductible (Broker: H.H. Kleigerman Associates) Upper East Side $830,000 870 Fifth Avenue (68th St.) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevators, dining room, parquet floors, Central Park view; maintenance $1,423, 51% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. Gottesman) BRONX Dyre Avenue Area $130,000 3711 Rombouts Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, attached brick house; dining room, finished basement, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Cancro Realty) Riverdale $80,000 3875 Waldo Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; new windows, remodeled kitchen, high-ceilings; maintenance $240, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. title: CHILD CARE: THE FEDERAL ROLE GROWS IN THE 80's
description: When Vice President Bush made a campaign stop the other day to express his concern about ''major problems'' in child care, he chose an appropriate setting: the day-care center for the children of Federal workers at the Labor Department, the first of its kind when it opened 20 years ago.

title: ELDERLY LIVES AND LOVERS
description: SECOND CHANCES By Alice Adams. 257 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Divided World Health Organization Braces for Leadership Change
description: The World Health Organization is beset by unusual political conflict and anxiety as it prepares for a traumatic change in leadership.

title: A Word on Diagnosing Medical Progress
description: The scenario depicted in Penny Singer's article [ ''Diabetic Doctor Offers a New Treatment,'' April 3 ] is the stuff of old Hollywood romances: lone figure with miraculous intuitive insight struggles valiantly against his own affliction as well as against an indifferent, reactionary medical establishment unwilling to take at face value his anecdotal account of self-salvation and restoration to health.

title: Balletic Blend
description: RAYMONDA The Bolshoi Ballet, starring Ludmila Semenyaka (in photo), Irek Mukhamedov and Gedeminas Taranda. Choreographed by Yuri Grigorovitch and Marius Petipa. Music by Alexander Glazunov. Kultur. 146 minutes. $39.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Surroundings in Hartsdale
description: LEAD: WE would be hard put to remember when Sergio's wasn't on Central Avenue. This year the restaurant celebrates its 24th birthday, and like good wine the place has mellowed with age. The high stained-glass windows and the half-timbered facade have worn gracefully over the years as has the extraordinary decor: a Christmas tree and a rocking chair stuck among the rafters, an entire wall of clocks, a border of

title: STAMPS PROMOTE DISNEY AND THE OLYMPICS
description: Collectors of the popular Disney stamps issued by client states of New York's Inter-Governmental Philatelic Corporation can look forward to a new set this Tuesday from Antigua and Barbados. The set of eight stamps and two souvenir sheets illustrates Disney characters at various Epcot Center sites.

title: Miss McAndrews And T. C. Cantrell Will Marry in July
description: The engagement of Siobhan Curran McAndrews to Timothy Clover Cantrell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Cantrell of New Canaan, Conn., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James J. McAndrews of Madison, Conn. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Linda Bradshaw Wed in Maryland
description: Linda Patrice Bradshaw and David Karim Lakhdhir, associates in Manhattan law firms, were married yesterday at the Civic Center Mansion in Rockville, Md. Judge Monroe G. McKay of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Salt Lake City, and the Rev. Gary M. Gallun, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Bold, Vibrant Quilts By the Mennonites
description: Maggie Tulliver, George Eliot's heroine in ''The Mill on the Floss,'' thought making patchwork was foolish -''tearing things to pieces to sew 'em together again.'' But it would be hard to come away from a tiny shop in Toronto without being impressed by the skill and panache of 19th- and early 20th-century Ontario quilters.

title: THERE'S LIFE IN THE OLD LIEDER RECITAL YET
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVING THE VERY RICH CAN BECOME STILTED VOYEURISM
description: Whom the gods would destroy, they first make rich and famous. ''Onassis: The Richest Man in the World'' may pretend otherwise - actually, it makes quite a point of doing so -but the message comes through all the same. Aristotle Onassis, his wives, mistresses, family members, various Kennedys and even Winston Churchill all look lonely. Ashes to ashes and dust to dust, and the world's biggest yacht and the world's biggest bank balance don't mean a thing. What matters are earthy pleasures: making love, smashing crockery and dancing on mountainsides and in tavernas and pretending you're Zorba the Greek. ''Onassis,'' a two-part, four-hour mini-series, beginning on ABC at 9 tonight, suggests that only the poor are blessed. This is a mini-series with its share of guilty, junky fun.

title:
MUSIC;
Soviet Emigre Pianist At 'Y' Festival of Arts
description: LEAD: THE Soviet emigre pianist Bella Davidovich will give a recital this evening at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, as part of the 'Y's' ''Festival of the Arts'' season. The recital, which starts at 8, will comprise Haydn's Sonata No. 3 in E flat major; Beethoven's Sonata No.

title: Palmer-Barber Charge to Share of Lead
description: The General has sent out a call for his army to muster Sunday at the Onion Creek Club. Arnold Palmer is in the hunt again.

title: Turnpike Acts to Ease Delays
description: MOTORISTS using the eastern spur of the New Jersey Turnpike between Newark and the Lincoln Tunnel exit are feeling the impact of construction on the western spur, which carries traffic between Newark and the George Washington Bridge exit.

title: MODERATE-PRICED HOUSING: MUST CITY BE FOREVER SHORT OF AFFORDABLE LIVING SPACE?
description: BY even the most conservative estimate, New York City needs 230,000 more places to live. The rate of housing abandonment has slowed in recent years, but construction of new apartments and houses has remained anemic.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Hospitals Are Set On Budgets
description: AFTER nearly five months of negotiations and more than halfway through the fiscal year, general hospitals all have approved budgets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The New Demand for Manufacturing Engineers
description: Thinking Machines Inc. came up with a design for a supercomputer that could do massive parallel processing - dividing problems into thousands of pieces for simultaneous processing. The company, in Cambridge, Mass., also rounded up the venture capital it needed to develop the design into a marketable product. And according to Sheryl Handler, the company's chief executive officer, she had little trouble assembling a top-notch team of financial, engineering and marketing executives to lead the company through its start-up years.

title: Culture Shock
description: To the Editor: When I returned home from Europe on a recent trip, the one startling impression that struck me at Kennedy Airport, and as I eventually emerged into city traffic, was the sight of traffic policemen with revolvers sticking out at the ready from their holsters. Momentarily it was frightening. I felt that I had entered some strange milieu where armed might was the accepted practice. The sight was quite in contrast to what I had become accustomed in Europe where the law of the six shooter, while it probably did exist sub rosa, was far from public sight. It took me a while to recoil from the sudden jarring I received from the New York city policemen. Like the jet lag that took a little time, so the Wild West image quite readily became a facet of the home scene . . . normal and uniquely American. ERNEST R. BARRA Woodmont, Conn.

title: Administration Relaxes Curbs On U.S. Payments to Panama
description: The Treasury Department announced today that it would permit United States citizens and businesses to make some payments to the Government of Panama. The payments were forbidden under economic sanctions imposed earlier this month to force the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Julia Thomas Has Wedding
description: Julia Anne Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Thomas of Exeter, N.H., and Marc V. Johnson, a son of Anne F. Ryan and C. R. Johnson Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: KING OF THE 'TECHNO-THRILLER'
description: Tom Clancy, insur-ance agent turned supernovelist, grips the wheel of his newest toy, a four-wheel-drive GMC Jimmy, as he shows a visitor around the 80 rolling acres overlooking the Chesapeake Bay where he plans to build a dream house to replace the dream house he built several years ago.

title: 8,000 Officers Mourn a Slain Comrade
description: As strains of ''Amazing Grace'' streamed down Fifth Avenue yesterday morning, 8,000 police officers saluted the flag-draped coffin of Sgt. John F. McCormick, who was slain last week in a drug raid - a victim, many of his comrades said, in a battle without purpose and a war without end.

title: INSIDE
description: First Meal for Condor Chick Molloko, the first California condor conceived in captivity, dined on minced mouse at San Diego's Wild Animal Park. Page 27. Workers Stress the 3 R's In this age of high technology, American companies are trying to correct employees' deficiencies in reading, writing and mathematics. Page 26. 8,000 Mourn Slain Officer A police sergeant who was killed during a drug raid was eulogized by John Cardinal O'Connor. Page 44. Fans Disrupt Mets Game Fans threw debris on the field and an umpire left the game for his safety in the Mets-Reds game. Section 8. James McCracken Dies America's most successful dramatic tenor and a pillar of the Metropolitan Opera was 61 years old. Page 46. News Summary, page 2 Obituaries, page 46

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WILLIAM SAROYAN: The Man and the Writer Remembered. Edited by Leo Hamalian. (Fairleigh Dickinson University, $35.) The moment has come for a reassessment of William Saroyan, the ''Armenian Huck Finn,'' as one contributor names him in this gathering of affectionate, easygoing reminiscences. The author of ''The Human Comedy'' died in 1981.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory on Feb. 28 misstated the days on which the Emily Dickinson Homestead in Amherst, Mass., is open for tours from May through October. They are Wednesday to Saturday, in the afternoon.

title: South Africa - A Terrorist Nation
description: On April 7, Albie Sachs, a white South African lawyer who had been an active opponent of apartheid, was seriously injured in a bomb explosion as he opened the door of his car outside his home in Maputo, Mozambique. One week earlier, the African National Congress's chief representative in France, Dulcie September, was gunned down as she arrived at her office in Paris. In Lesotho last February, a member of the A.N.C. was shot to death in a hospital bed.

title: A SELF-MADE SCIENTIST
description: IN PRAISE OF IMPERFECTION My Life and Work. By Rita Levi-Montalcini. Translated by Luigi Attardi. Illustrated. 220 pp. New York: Sloan Foundation Science Series/ Basic Books. $18.95.

title: 40 Are Hurt in Electrical Fire At Radio-TV Center in Cairo
description: An electrical fire today damaged the 27-story building housing Government radio and television and sent 40 people to the hospital for smoke inhalation, officials said.

title: Chili and Cash: Aiding an Orchestra
description: AN increasing number of music lovers and some musicians have been joining forces to help the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra.

title: Low-Tech Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: POINTS OF LIGHT by Linda Gray Sexton. Little, Brown and Company. 308 pages. $16.95.

title: Here's a Little List of Some G. & S. Releases
description: Mention Wimbledon to most people and it naturally means tennis. But not to this arch-Savoyard, who spent several trips combing the British provinces in the 1960's and 70's in search not of sport but of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, which toured extensively before closing down in 1982. Wimbledon was a convenient venue - the last stop on the District Line of London's underground - and the company was often there in springtime. Even more exciting was the ornate Bristol Hippodrome, requiring a longer journey on British Rail, where I first delighted in ''Princess Ida'' (but spent the night in one of the grimmest railway hotels known to man).

title: Saudis Reject Plan For an OPEC Deal With Nonmembers
description: Saudi Arabia rejected early today a proposal that would have opened the way to unprecedented cooperation between the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and nonmember independent oil producers.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, the picture at the lower right on page 23 in of the Arts and Leisure section today is incorrectly captioned in some copies. It shows Glenda Jackson and Stratford Johns in Ken Russell's film ''Salome's Last Dance,'' which opens Friday at Cinema 2.

title: Is This the End?
description: HE hasn't even seen the doctor, but Jimmy Connors, who has been nursing a sore foot for months, has the scenario mapped out. The doctor will tell him he needs surgery and suddenly his career will be over. ''I'm finished,'' he said. ''I'd have to take six months off, then I'm 36 years old. Then it would take me six months more to get back in decent shape. I'd probably lose interest if I had to have surgery.''

title: Composting Law Hits Snags
description: LEAD: UNDER the provisions of a recycling law that took effect April 20 but whose full impact probably will not be felt until the fall, the state's 567 municipalities must collect and compost leaves and the 21 counties must designate composting facilities.

title: Elizabeth Lee Wed to Geoffrey Forman
description: Elizabeth Carol Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Lee of Wyncote, Pa., and the Sea Ranch, Calif., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Varley Forman, the son of Mrs. Benno Forman of Newark, Del., and the late Mr. Forman. The Rev. Miriam Acevedo-Naters, assisted by the Very Rev. Geralyn Wolf, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Bainbridge Street, in Philadelphia.

title: Patricia Ogden Wed
description: Patricia Perkins Ogden and John William McGrath were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley. The bride, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Perkins, is the manager of membership and major gifts at the New York Zoological Society. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of her husband. Mr. McGrath, a member of the Manhattan law firm of Lane & Mittendorf, is a son of Marion McGrath of Rye, N.Y., and the late Hugh McGrath.

title:
GARDENING;
ONEC-DESPISED ANNUALS WINNING THE BORDER WARS
description: LEAD: When the British landscape gardener Gertrude Jekyll observed the cottage gardens of England and began her grand experiment in developing the herbaceous border, it was the beginning of the end for carpet-bedding - the static Victorian style that attempted to mimic an Oriental rug. Her final result was the mixed border, in which she splashed shrubs, roses, spring bulbs, yuccas, cannas, perennials and annuals in glorious profusion.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: The sprawling grid of tract developments and shopping malls that is Fort Collins, Colo., eventually peters out miles from the city's old cow-town core amid winter-yellow fields and rolling, snow-streaked prairie. Something like half of this land, split-levels and sagebrush alike, is bought and sold through a single Fort Collins real estate company known as The Group Inc. Welcoming a visitor into his sleekly austere downtown office, Larry Kendall, The Group's co-founder, projects a cornstalk-plain, boy-next-door freshness that has remained with him since his Kansas boyhood in a town that he says was ''like 'Mayberry R.F.D.' '' The brass plaque on Kendall's desk reads: ''Life is a lively process of becoming.'' Kendall arrived in Colorado in 1973 with a new M.B.A. and a lot of ambition; today, his company employs 55 people. In 1987, it sold more than $90 million worth of Fort Collins real estate.

title: Waldheim Before the Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

title: A'S ROUT INDIANS TO CAPTURE 6TH IN ROW
description: Jose Canseco hit a three-run homer, and Carney Lansford had three hits as the Oakland Athletics extended their winning streak to six with an 11-3 rout of the Indians today.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: Switzerland has instituted an entrance fee to use its highways. They charge 40 Swiss francs (about $24) to enter the country driving a car. What is unfair is that this charge is a yearly one, so that anyone who drives into Switzerland for a visit of a couple of hours, as we did, is required to pay the fee. No provision is made for a daily trip. ELISABETH CIRILLO ROBERT CIRILLO River Vale, N.J. Editor's note: As reported in Travel Advisory on April 5, 1987, the charge is not an entrance fee but a fee for a sticker, which takes the place of tolls on Swiss superhighways. Motorists who enter Switzerland on a secondary road are not required to have a sticker.

title: Hungary Hardens Its Line Against Internal Critics
description: The Hungarian leadership is taking a tougher stand against people who criticize the Communist Government, in an action that appears designed to reaffirm central control over discussion of economic and political change.

title: A Voice Familiar With the Disease
description: The article ''New Product Is Offered to Reduce Lyme Disease'' [ April 3 ] did an excellent job in reporting information as presented by the manufacturer of Damminix, by authorities in the field of Lyme disease, by health officials, etc. Some additional caveats are in order.

title: For Poland's Priests, Labor Unrest Means Walking a Tightrope
description: When the steelworkers of Stalowa Wola ended their strike today the leaders, and a few followers, marched to a Catholic church for a rally and Mass.

title: TRAVELING BY TRAIN AND DAYDREAM
description: NOTHING TO DECLARE Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone. By Mary Morris. 250 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: AWAITING THE CRACK OF DOOM
description: NUCLEAR FEAR A History of Images. By Spencer R. Weart. 535 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.50.

title: Consumer Family Does Its Duty
description: WITH the solemn intensity of an Englishman clutching his umbrella, or a Japanese with his camera, Americans carry plastic -credit cards. Real men may not eat quiche, but real Americans do shop, and in our materialism, we determine our worth by what we own.

title: Louise Riskin Married To Eugene Messinger
description: Louise Brooke Riskin and Eugene Francis Messinger were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York yes by Rabbi Harold Swiss.

title: D. B. Park Is Wed To Sidney Allison
description: The Montview Boulevard Presbyterian Church in Denver was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Anne Sidney Allison, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Clark Allison of The Hague and Plandome Manor, L.I., to David Black Park, the son of James B. Park of Denver and Mrs. Kenneth F. Lewis of Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Glendora Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: EDITH WHARTON IN LOVE: 'MY LIFE WAS BETTER BEFORE I KNEW YOU'
description: LEAD: Edith Wharton first met William Morton Fullerton in Paris in the spring of 1907. At the age of 42, three years younger than Edith Wharton, the New England-born Fullerton had been on the Paris staff of The Times of London for 15 years. After graduating from Harvard University (where he was a classmate of George Santayana) in 1886, and a stint on The Boston Advertiser, he gravitated to England and soon found a job on The Times.

title: Review/Concert; DePriest and Philharmonic
description: James DePreist concluded his two-week visit to the New York Philharmonic with a program of lavishly scored works by Faure, Saint-Saens and Walton. Given the brilliant edge Mr. DePreist has brought to his recordings with his own Oregon Symphony lately, the last thing this listener expected from his collaboration with the Philharmonic was the kind of tepid performance he drew from the orchestra on Friday afternoon. There were occasional fireworks, and moments of lyrical beauty. But these came peeking through stretches of diffuse and tensionless playing like rays of sunlight on a dreary day.

title: First Step Is Offered In Homeless Crisis
description: The League of Women Voters of Westchester believes it is imperative to solve the crisis of homeless people in our midst - so often discussed in this section. A first step is being offered by HELP II. We support immediate action to adopt the proposed HELP II projects.

title: Landlocked Ark Caught in Storm
description: For five years, Kea Tawana, a church caretaker in Newark, put her ''heart and soul, blood and sweat'' into the project.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
For Port Jefferson, a Waterfront Revival
description: LEAD: A revitalization of the Port Jefferson waterfront, begun about seven years ago and about to enter a new stage of development, is helping to turn this village of about 6,000 residents back into a port of call, not only for boaters but also for tourists.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: EDWARD J. TRAWINSKI, a Fair Lawn lawyer, will become assistant commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development tomorrow.

title: Free the Other Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Harvest Is Random
description: Some months ago I found myself at the Quad Cinema for the first show of a film called ''John and the Missus,'' which four other people had also come to see. Under the circumstances, this was astounding. Ads for the film offered little more than its dismal title and a photograph of unidentified workmen (they turned out to be miners) in an unidentified location (it turned out to be Newfoundland). The fine print indicated that the film's writer-director-star was Gordon Pinsent, possibly a household name in his native Canada but an unknown one here.

title: Prosecutors Attack Early Jail Releases
description: LEAD: CHIEF State's Attorney John J. Kelly is taking a two-pronged approach in a dispute between the prosecutors and prison officials over the early release of criminals to ease overcrowding.

title:
GARDENING;
Now Is the Time to Get the Work Done
description: LEAD: MAY is the month when gardeners really get serious, and the tasks awaiting are so numerous it may be difficult to decide what to do first.

title: Japanese Adults, Spurning the Likes of 'Miami Vice,' Can't Get Enough Of Oscar the Grouch
description: On April 10, ''Sesame Street'' went back on the air in Japan after a seven-year absence. Its return for an hour every Sunday evening struck a blow for sound adult programming.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: My Life as a Dog Starring Anton Glanzelius, Tomas von Bromssen, Anki Liden, Didrik Gustavsson, Melinda Kinnaman, Kicki Rundgren, Ing-Marie Carlsson. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom. 1985. Paramount Home Video. 101 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG-13. Some adolescent sex play.

title: Prospects
description: After the Trade Bill After nearly three years, the Senate ratified a trade bill last week. The President has vowed to veto the legislation because it contains a provision requiring companies to give 60 days notice before plant closings. But the bill also gives authority to the President to negotiate at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and paves the way for the upcoming vote in Congress on a free trade agreement with Canada. What is the impact of the passage of this bill? C. Fred Bergsten Director, Institute for International Economics.

title: REBUFFED BY OREGON, PATIENTS TAKE THEIR LIFE-OR-DEATH CASES PUBLIC
description: One after another, the faces of Oregon citizens have been popping up on posters and in videos, begging for donations to pay for organ transplants that their state no longer finances.

title: ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
description: Ze'ev Chafets reports that in Israel there are ''more than 50 organizations dedicated to Arab-Jewish understanding.'' Query: How many such organizations are there among Israeli Arabs in the West Bank or anywhere in the Arab world? The answer is: None. That fact is only one reason why the possibility of reconciliation and peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors is, perhaps, even more remote than Mr. Chafets indicates. RICHARD COHEN New York, N.Y.

title: Ramses II Visits a Boston Museum
description: For the next three months, a 40-foot-high model of an ancient Egyptian temple will stand at the front of the Boston Museum of Science. The building is the temporary home of the imposing Colossus of Memphis, a 3,000-year-old, 57-ton granite statue of Ramses II.

title: Where Gardeners Fuel their Fantasies
description: LEAD: WITH the greening of spring, eager gardeners have been visiting seed companies, flower farms and nurseries seeking old favorites and new hybrids.

title: Business Forum; INCOME DISTRIBUTION: A GROWING GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR
description: Robert Solow, a Nobel prize-winning economist, said it best, ''Redistribution is something Americans aren't very good at.'' Instead, America's chosen weapon against income inequality has been rapid economic growth. And in fact, rapid growth is a devastating weapon against this problem, promoting rising wages and salaries and helping low-income workers in other ways. But when incomes grow slowly, as they have since the 1970's, this powerful weapon is disarmed.

title: WINFIELD TIES R.B.I. MARK AS YANKEES ROLL
description: The month ended suddenly, and when it did, Dave Winfield was there again, smiling about another incredible night and another Yankee victory.

title: SINCERELY, WOLFGANG ... AND HIS ILK
description: The craft of letter writ-ing is in a low, flickering state, historians of the form admit, kept alive only by irate people who carry on endless, fruitless correspondence with utility company computers. It was different in earlier times, when there was no telephone, or if there was one it had to be cranked each time.

title: Crash Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Now Is the Time to Get the Work Done
description: LEAD: MAY is the month when gardeners really get serious, and the tasks awaiting are so numerous it may be difficult to decide what to do first.

title: Patricia Anne Shean Marries David Paul Kelley 2d
description: At Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, Patricia Anne Shean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leonard Shean of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to David Paul Kelley 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Philip Kelley of Atlanta. The Rev. Richard F. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Air Couriers
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article on courier services (Travel, March 6) as I have flown to Europe the past two years that way - the first time with TNT Skypak and the second arranged by Now Voyager.

title: BEST SELLERS: MAY 1, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 3 2 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 3 2 26 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 4 6 2 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 5 4 7 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 6 5 7 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 7 11 4 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) What ensues when a New York socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 8 7 8 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 9 10 11 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 10 9 4 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) Book Two of the fantasy saga that began with ''Guardians of the West.'' 11 8 28 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 12 13 6 EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Nine short stories about a variety of characters and situations. 13 * 1 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. 14 14 23 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 15 12 6 S., by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A New England woman, in search of a new life, joins a religious commune in Arizona. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 51 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 2 3 2 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 2 20 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) An entrepreneur's career. 4 6 2 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 5 5 4 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of Roy M. Cohn. 6 4 13 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) The fortunes of great nations. 7 7 25 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.)
