(Norton, $16.95.) The outfielder's autobiography. 10 10 15 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science. 11 13 4 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The philosopher's life and death. 12 * 9 3 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 13 14 3 UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK, by Christopher Nolan. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The autobiography of a paralyzed young Irish writer. 14 * 12 12 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society. 15 1 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former spokesman. 16 * 1 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 17 * 45 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 18 * 15 10 OSCAR WILDE, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the dramatist, essayist and poet. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 43 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 4 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 13 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 4 5 4 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. 5 135 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) INTIMATE MATTERS: A History of Sexuality in America, by John D'Emilio and Estelle B. Freedman. (Harper & Row, $24.95.) Urbanization, war and laissez-faire capitalism got us where we are today, according to this long, careful examination of how Americans have understood sex and its place in their lives. IN THE AGE OF THE SMART MACHINE: The Future of Work and Power, by Shoshana Zuboff. (Basic, $19.95.) Ms. Zuboff, who teaches at the Harvard Business School, argues cogently that information technology blurs the distinction between labor and management as workers handle data and concepts, not things. FREUD: A Life for Our Time, by Peter Gay. (Norton, $25.) A fresh, transparent biography, based on archival material, by a professional historian who is himself trained in psychoanalysis. BLACK BOX, by Amos Oz. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) An epistolary novel about a bitter family quarrel resonates with symbolic values that reach to the structure and the dominant issues of Israeli society itself. ARABESQUES, by Anton Shammas. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) A complex autobiographical novel concerned with self-definition, originally written in Hebrew by an Israeli Christian Arab. THE DEATH OF METHUSELAH: And Other Stories, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Stories from the 1970's and 80's by the cunning artificer of Yiddish prose. MOON TIGER, by Penelope Lively. (Grove, $15.95.) A popular historian, dying, projects her own life on the rest of history in this intelligent novel, winner of Britain's 1987 Booker Prize.

title: Fresh Air, Fresh Outlooks
description: When 9-year-old DeeDee, from New York City, went on her first visit to an apple farm in Maine, she was amazed. She never knew, she said, that apples grow on trees. She thought they arrived in plastic bags. Her enlightenment came by way of the Fresh Air Fund, which offers poor inner-city youngsters free vacations in the country.

title: Second Round of Nicaragua Talks End
description: The second round of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders ended today without an accord. Government officials said a third round would begin May 12, but the contras said they had not agreed to a date.

title: Fresh Air Fund, at 112, Contends With Change
description: The Fresh Air Fund begins its 112th fund-raising campaign today. It is seeking to raise $1.3 million to give 10,000 children from New York City a taste of summertime in the country.

title: Repairing Vinyl Siding
description: VINYL siding has many advantages over wood or aluminum. However, vinyl siding can crack if struck violently (such as by a tree limb during a storm), especially in winter when freezing temperatures cause vinyl to become brittle.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
New Housing, and Hope, in Asbury Park
description: LEAD: For more than two decades residents and businesses have steadily deserted Asbury Park for areas farther to the south, leaving the once-thriving seaside resort to stagnate.

title: Post Mortem on Twin Doctors
description: Jeremy Irons, who made a major impact on American audiences with his performances in television's ''Brideshead Revisited'' and with his Tony Award-winning role in the Broadway version of Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing,'' has been particular in his selection of film roles. Mr. Irons, who will turn 40 later this year, has appeared in only seven pictures, none of them made in Hollywood and only two of them, ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' and ''The Mission,'' widely known among mainstream audiences.

title: Wendy Linder Is Wed To Steven Rosenberg
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Wendy Linder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Linder of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married last night to Steven Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rosenberg of Orangeburg, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Zion, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: HELL ON WHEELS
description: We're lucky. We have a house in the country. The house is in Massachusetts, 137.6 miles from our apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan - if we take the Taconic State Parkway north and then Route 23 east. If we take the Saw Mill River Parkway and Interstate 684 and Route 22, turning off at Wassaic and proceeding through Sharon, Conn., and Mill River, Mass., then the whole trip is 114.7 miles. Sometimes we take the Taconic Parkway only as far north as Route 44, and travel east from there through Millbrook and then Sharon, etc. 121.6 miles. There are other routes that we sometimes take, and I know the mileage for all of them as well as I know the first symptoms of car-seat fatigue from my 1-year-old daughter and, from my son, the question ''Are we almost there?'' which he begins to ask 8.4 miles into the northbound journey (in Yonkers, that is) and 6.3 into the southbound leg.

title: Chaille R. Latham Weds a Physician
description: Chaille Randolph Latham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Latham 2d of New York and Nantucket, Mass., and Dr. Gerald Edward Rodts Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodts of Dallas and Clearwater, Fla., were married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Henry Heaps performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. George F. Bardes, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: On Language; The Bloopie Awards
description: A SINISTER FORCE for solecism exists on Madison Avenue. It is the work of the copywrongers.

title: A Tribute to Finland at Katonah
description: DELAWARE started out, in 1638, as New Sweden (which also included parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania) and because old Sweden encompassed Finland at that time, the colony's settlers were as likely to be Finns as Swedes.

title: Other Musical Events Scheduled for the Week
description: Following are some other musical events around the state this week: TODAY

title: In Ohio, Unease Over Presidential Race
description: ''The best people don't run,'' said Sylke Benner, a marketing manager, ''and they're the smartest people.''

title: Mystery Deepens in New Delhi Arms Scandal
description: One year after the first disclosures of possible bribery in an arms contract, the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi remains beset by corruption charges and a deepening mystery about who received a series of illegal payments from abroad.

title: Headliners; By the Pen
description: Will Rhett Butler wish he had given a damn? Will Scarlett O'Hara find her life improved by the arrival of a new sunrise? The answers will go on sale sometime in 1990, when Warner Books expects to publish a sequel to ''Gone With the Wind.'' In the meantime, it may be presumed that the fate of Scarlett, Rhett and others from Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best seller is known only to Alexandra Ripley, the author who is to write the ''GWTW'' sequel.

title: Posting: Fulton Ferry Conversion By the Bridge
description: Living beside one of New York City's bridges may not seem the sanest idea right now, but David H. Ward says the Brooklyn Bridge and 4-10 Water Street, which he is converting into co-ops, have been coexisting serenely for more than a century. The 1860 warehouse is just south of the 1883 span. ''If you stood on the edge of the bridge and dropped a screwdriver it wouldn't fall on the roof,'' Mr. Ward explained, ''but if you threw a screwdriver . . .''

title: METS WIN; UMPIRE FLEES FANS
description: The Mets prevailed and were happy. The umpires survived and were just plain relieved. Pete Rose, whose team lost, said he was injured and incensed and somewhat unsure of what his options for protesting the game were.

title: Energy Future
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWISH SETTLERS SEEK ROOTS IN A HOSTILE LAND
description: ''Here is the heart of Samaria,'' said Ron Nachman, standing on a windswept hilltop near the old Arab city of Nablus. ''Here is the future.''

title: Elizabeth Joy Wingate Marries Joel M. Hausman
description: Elizabeth Joy Wingate, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Wingate of Hamden, Conn., was married last evening to Joel M. Hausman, the son of Mrs. Irving Hausman of San Francisco and the late Rabbi Hausman. Rabbi Herbert Brockman performed the ceremony at Temple Mishkan Israel in Hamden.

title: Blood Screening for Cancer Due
description: The American Association of Blood Banks will require testing for the human cancer virus HTLV-1 as soon as test kits are licensed by the Food and Drug Administration, a spokesman said Friday.

title: Dr. Lisa S. White Weds a Physician
description: Dr. Lisa Sue White, an oral surgeon in Methuen, Mass., and Dr. Barry Stephen Paul, a dermatologist in Boston, were married last night at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston by Rabbi Amiel Wohl.

title: Vietnam's Foreign Policy Problems Are Mounting
description: The new Communist leadership in Vietnam, preoccupied with food shortages and other severe economic difficulties, is now facing mounting foreign policy problems as well.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ALIAS MADAME DOUBTFIRE By Anne Fine. 199 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: Images That Capture the Dark World of Dickens
description: ''Hard Times'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is to painting what ''Nicholas Nickleby'' was to the theater, though on a smaller scale. It shows Victorian England in a vivid, richly detailed and often terrible light. It has heroes and heroines by the dozen, though life deals harshly with most of them. It has phantasmagorical changes of scene, from a concert for poor Italians in London to pawnshop and sweatshop, workhouse and emigrant ship, prison yard and old-clothes market. It also has a bonus unannounced in the title of the show, in that the Vincent van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam has lent not only a number of related drawings by van Gogh himself but a group of the English popular prints and engravings that he collected in huge numbers.

title: Headliners; By the Billions
description: David Packard never wanted to take his fortune with him, but he wants to be very sure of how it is used. Mr. Packard, the 75-year-old board chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company, last week disclosed his plans for transferring his $2 billion fortune to the David and Lucille Packard Foundation, making it the fifth or sixth largest in the country. A substantial amount of the foundation's $100 million a year in aid will be earmarked for child-health concerns that were of special interest to Mrs. Packard, who died last May. Other grants will go to support research in marine biology, undersea exploration and other areas of particular interest to Mr. Packard and his four children. ''I have observed that money left without special guidance is sometimes used well and sometimes not,'' Mr. Packard said.

title: FOR THE MACBETHS, MARRIAGE IS MURDER
description: Never mind if they're per-forming in a plush Broadway theater or a spidery little loft in SoHo. Never mind if they've been directed by Peter Brook or the assistant stage manager's senile great uncle. There's still a special thrill of anticipation when a major actor or actress tackles a great Shakespearean part. What will be the emphasis? How will he or she read this line, how slant that passage, how interpret the character as a whole? What, if anything, will be added to a tradition stretching back through Irving and Booth and Mrs. Siddons and Garrick to that misty era when Richard Burbage's Hamlet boggled at a Ghost played (if legend is correct) by William Shakespeare in person?

title: Color It Green
description: A LONG line of farmers and gardeners make up my family tree, but when genes for a green thumb were handed out, I was not on the list.

title: A. L. Adams Wed To Louise Rambo
description: The marriage of Louise de Clercq Rambo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Rambo of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, to Anthony Lane Adams, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lane W. Adams of New York and New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill. The Rev. Charles A. Carter 3d and the Rev. Thomas A. Pike performed the ceremony.

title: No More Meeses
description: The nonstop controversy over Edwin Meese 3d demonstrates the indispensability of an independent attorney general committed to the rule of law. Voters must insist that the Presidential candidates specify right now the criteria they would use to choose a nominee.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: EXCELSIOR. By Randall Silvis. (Holt, $18.95.) This is a typical intelligent American late-20th-century serious-satiric novel (unhappy middle-class male variety), and not much more. It gets off to an unfortunate start when the protagonist's name is revealed to be Bloomhardt. The experienced reader knows instantly that this guy has a hardt, er, heart, and that it wants to bloom, that it could bloom, that something is keeping it from blooming, and that, finally, it probably will bloom.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Lar Lubovitch's new ''Of My Soul'' is an awkward dance. It is fascinating, as well. Usually, in dance, awkwardness is undesirable.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Cold Horchata, the Cream of Valencia
description: LEAD: Who would imagine that in Valencia - land of vast orange groves - a glass of fresh squeezed orange juice is hard to find, while horchata, made from an obscure African root, is the region's most popular drink?

title: VIRTUOSITY IN ATTACK SHOULD GET PRIORITY
description: The ideal, to achieve a style perfectly balanced for both attack and defense, is seen very rarely. The games of three world champions, Bobby Fischer, Boris Spassky and Gary Kasparov, are perhaps the best illustrations of the universal man. Most of the other champions have gravitated toward the attacking pole of an Alexander Alekhine or Mikhail Tal or the defensive pole of an Emanuel Lasker or Tigran Petrosian.

title: REFUSING TO BUCKLE
description: TO LIVE AND TO WRITE Selections by Japanese Women Writers 1913-1938. Edited by Yukiko Tanaka. Illustrated. 225 pp. Seattle: The Seal Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last week's column, several words were dropped from the analysis starting with Black's ninth move. The sentence should have read: Black could not have kept his pawns unbroken by 9 ... QxB?! because 10 N-Q5, Q-Q1; 11 P-QB4 is strong, Black being unable to play 11 ... P-N5? because of 12 Q-R4!

title: Perspectives: Chelsea Offices; New Arrivals in an 'Escape Valve' Zone
description: When a business owns the property in which it is operating, it sometimes finds that it pays to move out and rent the space to others.

title: Protecting the Atmospheric Balance
description: LIKE it or not, we are living in an increasingly complex world.

title: U.S.O.C. Cutting Foreign Aid Program
description: The United States Olympic Committee's annual House of Delegates meeting ended today with no major decisions. However, one minor decision seemed to reflect a growing feeling among some members that less money should be spent on direct aid to athletes and programs of other countries.

title: Salvador Ruling Party Picks Candidate for '89
description: The governing Christian Democratic Party has chosen a wealthy businessman, Julio Adolfo Rey Prendes, as its candidate in next year's presidential elections.

title: 4 Washington City Aides Quit
description: The director of the District of Columbia's Department of Human Services and three aides have resigned after reports surfaced that the three used city funds to pay their rent and food bills, officials said today.

title: Fawn Hall and Others Named Unindicted Co-Conspirators
description: Fawn Hall, the former secretary to Oliver L. North, has been named by a Federal grand jury as an unindicted co-conspirator in the Iran-contra affair, The Los Angeles Times a reported today.

title: LILLA J. SMITH MARRIES DALE R. GONCHER
description: At St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York, Lilla Jeannette Smith, a daughter of the Rev. Elsie N. Smith and Howard Smith of Brooklyn and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Dale Robert Goncher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Goncher of Chesterland, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John S. Damm, the pastor of St. Peter's, and the bride's mother, the pastor of the Augustana Lutheran Home in Brooklyn.

title: Headliners; By the Sword
description: An Israeli judge said last week that ''there is no punishment in the rules of man that is severe enough'' for John Demjanjuk, whom an Israeli court found to be a Nazi death camp guard who helped torture and murder thousands of Jews during World War II. The judge sentenced Mr. Demjanjuk to death by hanging. Mr. Demjanjuk, a 68-year-old native of the Ukraine who settled in Cleveland after the war, was identified in 1976 as having been a guard at the Treblinka death camp in Poland, where witnesses said he was known as ''Ivan the Terrible.'' He was extradited to Israel in 1986. Mr. Demjanjuk, who says he is a victim of mistaken identity, protested that ''a very, very big mistake'' had been made. By law, his sentence will be appealed automatically.

title: SNORKS AND POPPLES
description: THE MAN WHO INVENTED SATURDAY MORNING And Other Adventures in American Enterprise. By David Owen. 215 pp. New York: Villard Books. $16.95.

title: Condor Hatches and Is Served Minced Mice
description: A tiny bundle of fluff named Molloko, the first California condor conceived in captivity, was being nurtured today by a team of human ''parents'' who served it its first meal, of minced mice.

title: Population Grew by 7.8% in 6 Years
description: GROWTH in the western part of Monmouth County contributed significantly to the county's overall 7.8 percent population increase from 1980 to 1986, according to state and local officials.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Arts and Leisure section, a short article about the American music planned at Lincoln Center incorrectly described a work by Tobias Picker. It is a five-movement composition for string quartet and bass.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Athletes' Pledge
description: LEAD: TWENTY Woodlands High School students in Varsity Athletes Against Substance Abuse have taken a pledge: no drugs or alcohol - not even a can of beer at a party - at least until school is out for the summer and, if they're still in the antidrug program, next year as well.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TALK BY SIDNEY ZION

title: TOWARD GIVING UP EGO AND GETTING TOGETHER
description: TRADE groups have always been concerned with lobbying. But today, ''the number of associations that don't have an active government relations program is so minuscule as to be almost uncountable,'' said Michael D. Lane, executive director of the Associations Council of the National Association of Manufacturers.

title: Dark Cloud Obscures Winfield
description: EVERY afternoon, the routine is the same. Dave Winfield leaves his New Jersey home, steers his luxury foreign car across the George Washington Bridge and through the congestion of the Bronx, and parks in the players' lot at Yankee Stadium. He acknowledges the cheers from the dozen or so fans who have waited patiently outside the entrance to the park. He dresses and talks with teammates, hits in the batting cage and then retreats to a quiet place where he can prepare himself to play a baseball game.

title: Glimpses of Desolation and Redemption
description: Eric Clapton now has his monument: ''Crossroads'' (Polydor 835261), a five-LP, four-cassette or four-CD set that covers the singer-guitarist's career from his first demos with the Yardbirds in 1963 to a September 1987 remake of ''After Midnight'' (commissioned, ignominiously, for a beer commercial). Like Bob Dylan's ''Biograph,'' the set mixes hits and rarities, reissuing collectors'-item singles and digging out live recordings and alternate takes from record-company vaults. Its nearly five hours of music include material from Mr. Clapton's late-1960's groups Cream and Blind Faith and his early-1970's band, Derek and the Dominos, as well as his post-1974 career under his own name; out of Mr. Clapton's considerable output, it slights only his appearances as a sideman in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Atomic Craft Aground Off Washington Coast
description: An American nuclear-powered attack submarine ran aground off Fox Island near here late Friday and stayed stuck for 10 hours, until four Navy tugs pulled it free at high tide this morning.

title: Shooting for Dollars
description: EVER since he began his National Basketball Association career in 1985 as a third-round draft pick of the Sacramento Kings, Michael Adams, has been a year-to-year player. But since coming to the Denver Nuggets in a trade with the Washington Bullets last November, Adams has been working toward the future. He went on a tear that included 43 straight games with at least one 3-point field goal, his season total of 139 3-pointers was second in the league this season and second-highest in N.B.A. history. Now he's getting his reward, his first multiyear contract, a three-year deal that will reportedly earn him $1.1 million, more than doubling his $160,000 annual salary.(AP)

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Handmade Heritage FOR many, their heritage was in the assorted shopping bags and baskets they carried into the large room at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: ONE IN A THOUSAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish and Sauces: An Excellent Spring Marriage
description: WITH the arrival of spring it is time to take a fresh look at fish. The delicate flavor of fish fillets is adaptable to all sorts of interesting sauces. White fish such as sole or flounder is ideal with cream sauces gently flavored with curry, saffron or turmeric. A stronger-flavored fish such as red snapper or sea bass goes very well with a puree of yellow peppers, seasoned with shallots, fresh thyme and a dash of balsamic vinegar. Sorrel, which has green leaves and a sharp lemony flavor, is especially good with fatty fish such as salmon or mackerel - and also with shad.

title: Native American Potters At Montclair State College
description: ACOMA, a native American pueblo on a mesa in the desert near Albuquerque, N.M., has been described as an awesome, wind-swept plateau. Said to be the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in North America, Acoma is famous today for its pottery tradition.

title: WASHINGTON'S PANAMA POLICY IS NOTABLY LACKING IN SUCCESS
description: To hear the Reagan Administration tell it, there was genuine movement last week in efforts to negotiate a peaceful exit for Panama's de facto leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But to many critics of United States policy, the Administration's retreat from its original demand that the General go far away from Panama was less a pragmatic negotiating maneuver than a tacit admission that its three-month campaign to oust him had all but failed.

title: A Bat Mitzvah Links Danbury and the Soviet
description: LEAD: A 13-YEAR-OLD Danbury girl has ''twinned'' her own bat mitzvah with a Soviet Union girl, a rite aimed at pressuring the Kremlin to allow the teen-ager's family to emigrate to Israel.

title: A Pizza Empire Strives for the Wright Stuff
description: There are buildings that are known for the architect who designed them, and there are buildings that are known for the client who commissioned them, and the new headquarters of Domino's Pizza Inc. falls firmly in the second category. It is no disrespect to Gunnar Birkerts, the architect of this unusual, nearly half-mile-long office building, to observe that his profile is somewhat lower than that of Tom Monaghan, the founder and chairman of Domino's, a national chain of pizza stores specializing in home delivery. For there are few architectural clients anywhere in the world like Mr. Monaghan. He is a man of obsessions, of which architecture is perhaps the most intense (the others are baseball, cars and, logically enough, pizza). His architectural passion focuses in particular on Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: FICTION
description: SHINE ON. By Fred Pfeil. (Lynx House/Small Press Distribution, Cloth, $14.95; Paper, $7.50.) The title of Fred Pfeil's first collection of stories suggests a transcendence his characters seldom attain. Indeed, ''Shine On'' records the peculiar diminutions of American life during the 1970's and the way a shrinking economy pinches the imagination as well as the purse. Whether they're ''scratching out a living on a Pennsylvania farm . . . [ or ] trying to be happy as a foreman at the tire plant back in Akron,'' Mr. Pfeil's men and women slog through lives that seem to resist yielding up the barest satisfaction. Two stories, ''Skeeter's Last Reflections'' and ''The Collected Works of Brown,'' telescope the lifetimes of their protagonists into mosaics of pain. In the first, an alcoholic factory worker is run over by a car in the final paragraph, while in the second a man endures a numbing 45 years as a washroom janitor. Some readers may find these small-town portraits almost schematically dreary. But as a narrator Mr. Pfeil is too sharply observant to make his characters into martyrs; instead, his heightened observation becomes a form of compassion. Several other stories examine blue-collar life from the more complicated perspective of the small-town boy who's gone to the city. The best of these, ''The Quality of Light in Maine,'' represents the author's most accomplished work. As he measures the currents that flow among a trio of lovers and friends, Mr. Pfeil's writing takes on the qualities of the light in the story's title: its clarity, its fine distinctions and the luminous surprise of its perspectives.

title: Miss Siebel Wed To J. B. Mannix
description: Gretchen Reinhard Siebel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Siebel of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to John Brian Mannix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Mannix of Arlington, Mass. Edward W. Horne, an East Hampton Town Justice on Long Island, performed the ceremony at the Siebel home in Amagansett.

title: ...and Labeling
description: To the Editor:

title: Monmouth Seeks to Channel Growth
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, what is now known as the Route 9 corridor through western Monmouth County was a scenic two-lane back road dotted with truck farms and, in season, roadside stands selling fresh produce.

title: Planning for the State's Future Energy Needs
description: SUCCESSFULLY accommodating the requirements of orderly growth takes thorough planning, perhaps years in advance. This is particularly true when developing delivery systems to provide energy supplies. Energy is essential in daily life, and public utilities have a responsibility to plan for adequate facilities to deliver energy when needed.

title: OUTSIDER'S CANDIDATE: THE FRENCH TRY TO EXPLAIN LE PEN - AND HIS APPEAL
description: France seemed to be in the midst of a boring presidential election campaign until last Sunday.

title: The Hudson and History
description: Most American tourists know that the nation's wine country can be found in California's Sonoma Valley and that the Shakers live in Pennsylvania. But if proponents of tourism in the Hudson Valley have their way, a nine-county region including Westchester will soon be known to the nation and to the world as the ''historic'' Hudson, filled with historic sites and museums waiting to be visited.

title: Labor Chief In Hartford Softens Tone
description: Eight months ago, Betty L. Tianti, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., addressed a rally of several hundred striking workers from the Colt Industries firearms plant here and passionately told the locked-out employees that their cause was just and that they should persevere.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE PEABODY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY;
Shrunken Heads and Unseen Treasures
description: LEAD: IN the basement of the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale University, a collections manager opens a file drawer labeled Ecuador. Inside a tin box in the drawer is a blackened shrunken head, about the size of an orange. The expression on the face is serious but not horrible, and the features are quite perfect, almost delicate.

title:
GARDENING;
Now Is the Time to Get the Work Done
description: LEAD: MAY is the month when gardeners really get serious, and the tasks awaiting are so numerous it may be difficult to decide what to do first.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A NEW 'SCHOOL FOR WIVES'

title: Missing Permit For Gazebo Vexes Club
description: LEAD: WHEN Richard Mintzer got married two weeks ago, he was more nervous than most young bridegrooms. He and his wife feared that an uninvited guest would show up at the Woodbury Country Club, where last September they booked this special occasion.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Getting the Most Out Of An Auction Sale
description: LEAD: AUCTIONS are an ancient business. Herodotus described them as a Babylonian custom in which village maidens were offered in marriage to the highest bidder. Closer to home and centuries later - in 1682 - William Penn and 11 associates acquired the province of East Jersey at an auction for $:3,400.

title: Innocence Abroad
description: LEAD: I envy the travelers who go on a trip well prepared, like walking encyclopedias.

title: When Chairs Were Of Sterner Stuff
description: When Barry Fried-man began to buy Bauhaus art and furnishings from the 1920's and 1930's for his New York gallery a decade ago, collectors were not yet ready to acquire these ''less is more'' originals produced by the German design school. So the art dealer stored them, studied them and became increasingly convinced of their merits.

title: Mount Laurel: Slow, Painful Progress
description: After nearly two decades of bearing witness to suits, countersuits and endless appeals, Ethel Lawrence, a 62-year-old grandmother from Mount Laurel, N.J., recites without pause the gist of complex rulings handed down by the New Jersey Supreme Court and cited in discriminatory zoning cases across the nation.

title: Inflation Is Tied to Unemployment, but How?
description: If the rules of economics operated as advertised, the United States would be suffering from inflation today.

title: Karen Goldberg Married To David Charles Berkey
description: The marriage of Karen Beth Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Goldberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., to David Charles Berkey took place last night at the Puck Building in New York. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Frances Berkey of Scarsdale and the late Benjamin Berkey, who founded Berkey Photo.

title: Myriad of Expenses Adds to Dental Costs
description: THE cost of going to the dentist has always been painful and is often considered an additional insult to needing treatment in the first place.

title: A LOT OF HELP FROM THEIR FRIENDS
description: LEAD: GETTING BETTER Inside Alcoholics Anonymous. By Nan Robertson. 298 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet's Two New Sleeping Beauties
description: Dancers stepped into new roles at performances of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Sleeping Beauty,'' presented by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday. The standard of dancing by the leads was high, with Amanda McKerrow and Wes Chapman dancing Princess Aurora and Prince Desire in the afternoon and Cheryl Yeager and Julio Bocca dancing the roles in the evening.

title: Beer's Shelf Life ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Price Tags on Art, Cont'd.
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MYSTERIOUS THOREAU
description: I stand in awe of my body, this matter to which I am bound has become so strange to me. I fear not spirits, ghosts, of which I am one . . . but I fear bodies, I tremble to meet them. What is this Titan that has possession of me? Talk of mysteries! - Think of our life in nature, - daily to be shown matter, to come into contact with it, - rocks, trees, wind on our cheeks! the solid earth! the actual world! the common sense! Contact! Contact! Who are we? where are we? - Thoreau, ''Ktaadn and the Maine Woods,'' 1848.

title: CUBS SET BACK GIANTS, 2-1, IN 13TH
description: Vance Law hit a run-scoring single with two out in the 13th inning, giving the Chicago Cubs a 2-1 victory today over the Giants.

title: Nancy Warshauer Is Wed
description: The marriage of Nancy Gail Warshauer, the daughter of Mrs. Emanuel S. Warshauer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Warshauer, to Gregory Elliot Mendel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mendel of Ocean, N.J., took place last evening at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Rabbi Mark Winer officiated. The bride was until recently a senior account executive at Liz Claiborne Inc. in New York. Her husband is a vice president in corporate finance at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York.

title: Close the Markets and Prices Will Rise
description: Last Tuesday Nathan Lewin, a partner in the law firm of Miller, Cassidy, Larroca & Lewin, argued before the Supreme Court in favor of keeping the gray markets open. The court is expected to decide on this question before it recesses in July. Mr. Lewin spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about how the consumer benefits from gray markets and why the gray markets should not be closed.

title: A Seaside City For Kings And Cockneys
description: Brighton is known as the princely resort, and for once the boosters' claim is not hyperbole. The Prince Regent's Royal Pavilion is as splendid and exotic as Kublai Khan's pleasure dome, and the Regency squares and terraces built for his courtiers and aristocratic friends are a contrast in cool elegance.

title: Art Treasures From Library Highlight Bridgeport History
description: LEAD: IN an uncommon cultural exchange that finds one institution bringing to light the treasures of another, the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport is displaying a major portion of the collection of paintings and prints belonging to the Bridgeport Public Library.

title: Lilly Shiland Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Gallagher of Chappaqua, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Gallagher's daughter Elizabeth Louise Shiland to Stanley George Shoemaker, a son of Mrs. Marshall L. Shoemaker of Saratoga, Calif., and the late Mr. Shoemaker. A September wedding is planned.

title: Falcon Gives Arkansas Edge in Relay
description: For the second consecutive day, Joe Falcon led the University of Arkansas to a major Penn Relays victory with a dazzling come-from-behind anchor leg.

title: A Convenient Bullion Storehouse
description: LEAD: Many people who want to own gold and silver are put off by the thought of buying bullion. There is often a state tax imposed on the purchase, and then there is the problem of transferring, storing and insuring the metals. So they often wind up buying mining stocks as proxies for the metals.

title: Jackson, on Stump in Ohio, Offers Criticism of Dukakis
description: It wasn't Jesse Jackson, Presidential candidate, on the hustings today. It was Jesse Jackson, adviser, offering the Democratic front-runner unsolicited counsel on how to lead.

title: Prison a Setting for Hoboken Drama
description: IN HIS new two-character play at the Renegade Theater Company, Alan Brody seems so determined to pound away at truth and reality that he has turned out an implausible play.

title: THINKING GIVES EUGENE A HEADACHE
description: THE KNOCKOUT ARTIST By Harry Crews. 269 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Going With Kids
description: To the Editor: Cynthia Samuels' otherwise excellent summary neglected one important warning. For children, looking at scenery is a crashing bore.

title: DATA BANK
description: THE ECONOMY

title: FOCUS: Maine; Growth in The Lake Region
description: TOURISTS and people looking for a country style of life near a scenic lake have combined to make this community the fastest growing town in Maine.

title: A POIGNANT VISIT WITH GRANDFATHER
description: I smile and nod as I walk by a nurse seated behind the reception desk. When I first started visiting my grandfather's nursing home a couple of years ago, I always stopped to sign the guest book in the lobby. But now I feel visiting anonymously is preferable to advertising my presence.

title: AFTER THE BRIDGESTONE DEAL, WHAT NEXT?
description: After 17 years as a Ford Motor Company manager, eight years as chief executive of the Zenith Electronics Corporation and nine years at the top of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, John J. Nevin is unsure where he is going next.

title: Spreading Sunshine
description: The new laboratory and classroom facility at the Oregon Institute of Technology in Klamath Falls was designed by Michael R. McCulloch ''to make a transition,'' he says, ''between the inside of campus and the outside, where there's a dramatic backdrop of mountains.'' So its 1,800-square-foot, crescent-shaped skylight, created by the Portland artist Ed Carpenter, is integral to the building's architectural intent. The skylight project, in fact, is one of 22 exhibits featured in ''Architectural Art: Affirming the Design Relationship,'' a show opening May 12 at the American Craft Museum in New York.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Transaction was the name of a new magazine devoted to social science. In its first issue, Irving Louis Horowitz, its founder and editor, told how it would serve the ''larger community.''

title: TAKING THE ELECTRIC POWER BUSINESS PUBLIC
description: The electric power industry is watching uneasily as the Long Island Lighting Company tries to fight off a hostile takeover by the public agency created for the purpose of reconsidering Lilco's existence.

title: THE KNICKS WALK TALL AGAINST CELTICS
description: LEAD: EVERY so often a man needs a change to generate himself for the decade ahead: the birth of a son . . . starting his own business . . . buying a new home for his family . . . the Knicks getting into the playoffs. And if it's a series against the dreaded Celtics, we New York fans are in clover.

title: An Era of Tighter Budgets and Leaner Staffs
description: America's 40,000 trade associations represent nearly every kind of trade or commercial venture found in the Yellow Pages, from abrasives to zoology. In advancing these groups' diverse interests, trade associations grapple with the key problems confronting American business, said R. William Taylor, president of the American Society of Association Executives.

title: Canada Safety Panel Split Over '85 Gander Crash
description: A dispute over the causes of the crash of a United States military charter aircraft two years ago at Gander, Newfoundland, has caused a major split in the Canadian Aviation Safety Board and precipitated the resignation of the board's chairman.

title: AS SOVIET PULLOUT NEARS, UNEASY CALM FOR AFGHANS
description: The Afghan soldier on guard in downtown Kabul looked rather smart in his green fatigues, except for one detail. He had carelessly put on his brass belt buckle so that the hammer and sickle were upside down.

title: Tom Wolfe's Yiddish
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Off the Hook: The Ticklish R.C.A. Issue
description: One of the most controversial provisions of the Fair Housing Act of 1985 was the mechanism that allows suburbs to transfer half of the housing units they were ordered to build, along with sufficient funds to help build them, to willing cities within their regions.

title: PLAYING BY THE NUMBERS
description: Former Gov. Jim Rhodes of Ohio had a favorite trick in campaign speeches: He would take out his wallet, slap it on the lectern, and shout, ''That is where elections are won.''

title: A Fantasy Flight Into Bygone Skies
description: THROUGHOUT 1987, a calendar entitled ''Ghosts - A Time Remembered'' hung on the wall of my office. A gift from my father, it reflected our shared fascination with World War II aircraft.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE PENAL COLONY. By Richard Herley. (Morrow, $18.95.) Richard Herley, the author of a Jean Auelesque trilogy known as ''The Pagans,'' here presents a traditional escape adventure. A British government of future date has wrongly convicted John Routledge for murder and transported him to the Cornish penal island of Sert.

title: Posting: Condominium Hotel; A Return to Victoriana in Chautauqua
description: A resort hotel at a resort with a season only nine weeks long needs an innovative plan to be successful. That is why developers of the St. Elmo Hotel in Chautauqua, N.Y., joined a nationwide trend toward hotel condominiums. The 63-unit, Victorian-style hotel will be among the first built exclusively as a condominium.

title: Shelly Westebbe Weds Jeffrey Kealing
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria, Va., Shelly Roxanne Westebbe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Westebbe of Washington, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Edward Kealing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Kealing of Kansas City, Mo. Msgr. Frank J. Hendrick performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STARLIGHT, by Scott Ely. (Warner, $4.50.) Tom Light, an American sniper in Vietnam, is rumored to have powers over life and death - and a rifle scope that can tell who is about to die. Last year, our reviewer, Richard Burgin, said this novel is written in ''a pared-down prose that controls and accentuates its author's fury at the war. [ The ] dialogue is assaultive and obscene but also wholly convincing.'' THE BEST OF EDWARD ABBEY, edited and illustrated by Edward Abbey. (Sierra Club, $10.95.) It is in his nature that Edward Abbey, the iconoclastic environ-mentalist, anarchist and writer, would insist on editing his own anthology. Originally titled ''Slumgullion Stew,'' the collection includes excerpts from his first, widely unnoticed novel, ''Jonathan Troy,'' his celebrated memoir ''Desert Solitaire'' and a novel in progress, ''The Rites of Spring.'' In 1984, our reviewer, Judith Baumel, said Mr. Abbey ''shows himself to be an irritating, irreverent macho man with a heart of gold, an ornery environmentalist who praises (all things in moderation) indolence, beer for breakfast and rolling a few boulders into Escalante Canyon for fun.'' SHOWDOWN AT GUCCI GULCH: Lawmakers, Lobbyists, and the Unlikely Triumph of Tax Reform, by Jeffrey H. Birnbaum and Alan S. Murray. (Vintage, $9.95.) How in the world did liberal tax reformers and conservative supply-siders manage to conspire with lobbyists (the people in Gucci shoes) to overhaul the Federal income tax laws in 1986? ''Even the hordes of Americans whose eyes glaze at the sight of a tax table will enjoy this remarkably lively account of the maneuvers and betrayals,'' Robert Lekachman said here last year. THE NORTHERN LIGHTS, by Howard Norman. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) Living in a lonely outpost in central Canada, a 14-year-old boy finds that a shortwave radio is fast becoming his closest friend. Last year, our reviewer, Ceil Cleveland, called the novel ''a striking achievement.'' THE U.S. SENATE: Paralysis or a Search for Consensus? by George E. Reedy. (Mentor/New American Library, $4.95.) During the Eisenhower years, George E. Reedy served as a senior aide to the Senate majority leader, Lyndon Baines Johnson, making him an ideal person to advise a Democratic Congress on how to deal with a popular Republican President. In 1986, Steven V. Roberts said here that every Democrat in the Senate should read the book. ''If Mr. Reedy could have a maxim chiseled in the stone of the Capitol, it would probably be this: Compromise Is Not Immoral.'' THE FORTUNE TELLER, by Marsha Norman. (Bantam, $4.50.) In this first novel by Marsha Norman, whose play '' 'Night, Mother'' won a Pulitzer Prize in 1983, a psychic uses her powers to solve a kidnapping, but she is frustrated in her attempt to keep her own daughter from being taken away. Last year, our reviewer, Amy Hempel, said the book was ''not exactly literature,'' but ''the parallel stories of missing children . . . keep us turning the pages.'' QUEEN OF HEARTS, by Susan Shreve. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) In another novel about a clairvoyant, the granddaughter of a prostitute kills her husband-to-be but has his baby anyway. Last year, one reviewer called it ''an eerily plausible parable of our times.'' SAUDI ARABIA: The Ceaseless Quest for Security, by Nadav Safran. (Cornell University, $15.95.) With its enormous oil reserves and indefensible borders, the author argues, Saudi Arabia is torn by its dependence on American protection and a desire for Arab unity. Writing in these pages in 1985, John C. Campbell called the book ''the most comprehensive, informative and reliable account of Saudi foreign policy yet written.'' BEFORE LUNCH, by Angela Thirkell. (Carroll & Graf, $4.95.) In another satire by the author of ''Pomfret Towers,'' an architect, his young wife and their relatives and neighbors are caught in a skein of crisscrossed affairs. In 1940, Louise Maunsell Field said here that the novel gives ''a fresh, altogether delightful picture of [ the ] virtues and . . . very human absurdities'' of life in the English countryside. CHOURA: The Memoirs of Alexandra Danilova. (Fromm International, $11.95.) Alexandra Danilova danced with Diaghilev and lived with George Balanchine. '' 'Choura' is crammed with delicious and revealing anecdotes,'' Jennifer Dunning said in The Book Review last year. ''As light as a souffle and as warm and faceted as a ruby, [ it ] is filled with trenchant commentary on the development and the personalities of 20th-century ballet.'' THE BROKEN PENNY, by Julian Symons. (Carroll & Graf, $3.95.) A British intelligence agent is brought out of retirement to smuggle an exiled leader back into an Eastern European country, in hopes of fomenting a revolution. In 1953, our reviewer, Anthony Boucher, called the novel ''the most exciting, astonishing and believable spy story to appear in years.'' ENIGMA: The Life of Knut Hamsun, by Robert Ferguson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) When the Norwegian novelist Knut Hamsun won a Nobel Prize in 1920, he gave the medal to Joseph Goebbels. Ever since, critics have tried to understand how a Nazi sympathizer could write novels that inspired the likes of Hemingway, Gide and Mann. '' [ Robert ] Ferguson's uncompromising, painful, curiously moving portrait attempts neither to conceal the epic contradictions of his subject's character nor to dispel them,'' Tom Clark said in The Book Review last year. ''One is left with the terrible feeling that Hamsun believed himself even when he was acting as a mouthpiece for some of the cheapest lies in history.''

title: Greenport Railroad Museum: Blowing Smoke
description: Project 39 director Jim Brehm's statement estimating that the yet-to-be-finished steam locomotive and the yet-to-even-be-started railroad museum will ''bring in 150,000 visitors a year'' is, I believe, overly optimistic [ ''Rail Museum to Displace a Furniture Company,'' March 27 ] .

title: Church Symbol Meets Modern Art
description: It is entitled ''Art of the Madonna,'' a national competition sponsored by the city's oldest Roman Catholic parish and intended to create a contemporary artistic vision of the Madonna and Child, one of the church's most timeless symbols.

description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 8 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 3 5 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) The journal of a trek into Tibet, over Mount Everest and through China. 4 * 10 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Vintage, $10.95.) Australia's gradual evolution from a penal colony to a flourishing nation. 5 62 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life as a series of losses. 6 78 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 7 10 HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A White House correspondent comments on his assignment. 8 10 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) Three generations of the Kennedy family. 9 * 33 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Dell, $3.95.) The search for a true love. 10 4 CLOSE PURSUIT, by Carsten Stroud. (Bantam, $4.50.) A week in the life of Eddie Kennedy, member of a New York City homicide squad. 11 * 9 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Berkley, $3.95.) The actress's memories and opinions. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 6 SOMETHING UNDER THE BED IS DROOLING, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 2 YOU CAN HEAL YOUR LIFE, by Louise L. Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 4 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. 4 49 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 83 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Pragmatism and Principle in Korea
description: South Koreans, blessed and maybe also a bit cursed with a limitless capacity for political surprise, put their democratic progress to a tough new test last week and wandered into wholly uncharted territory. It was anyone's guess whether the journey would turn out well.

title: Pier Redevelopment Plans Stir Concerns
description: While some New York City piers continue to receive cargo and many others crumble into the slime, Pier A awaits a restaurant, Pier 84 a permanent concert stage and Pier 10 a floating museum. A wave of development proposals washing over the waterfront also includes plans for ferry terminals, marinas, condominiums and hotels.

title: NBC's Correspondent Expelled From Jordan
description: The Government today ordered an NBC News television correspondent to leave the country after he reported that Jordan is a repressive society. The reporter, Rick Davis, was given a week to leave.

title: Feathers And Fur Fly in Farce
description: IN Edward Lear's well-known rhyme, ''The owl and the pussycat went out to sea in a beautiful pea-green boat.'' They came back, however, in Bill Manhoff's 1964 farce, ''The Owl and the Pussycat,'' which is being revived by the Long Island Stage Company.

title: Noriega Is Seen at an Advantage As Washington Shifts Approach
description: The Reagan Administration's new approach to Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is perceived in Panama as a risky move that may not resolve the country's political crisis.

title: Connecticut Bus Plant to Be Closed by Saab
description: Saab-Scania AB of Sweden has announced it will close its bus manufacturing plant here this summer, citing reduced demand for city buses as a reason.

title: Miss Efthimiou Weds S. L. Probasco 3d
description: Alexis Efthimiou, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Basil Efthimiou of Garden City, L.I., and Scott Livingston Probasco 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Probasco Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., were married yesterday at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Milton Basil Efthimiou, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos and the Rev. Ben Haden, a Presbyterian minister.

title: State Budget Leaves Some County Issues Unresolved
description: LEAD: THE state finally adopted a budget late last month, but Westchester may have to wait a little longer to see how well it fared.

title: ASSAD HAS CHANGED HIS POSTURE, IF NOT HIS GOALS
description: President Hafez Al-Assad has a well-earned reputation for rapidly changing tactics while never wavering from his strategic goals.

title: Bird Brouhaha
description: To the Editor:

title: Gym Jungle
description: HE resigned as the coach of the United States women's Olympic gymnastic team last November, and now Greg Marsden is telling the world why. The program run by the United States Gymnastic Federation, he said, has been devastated by political infighting among ''people with nothing better to do than sit around all day, get on the telephone and bother people.''

title:
ART;
Parrish Museum Show Stresses the Traditional
description: LEAD: FOR years the Parrish Art Museum's annual juried exhibition had a distinctive aura, attracting many of the talents in the East End art community. Format alterations introduced in the early 80's, including the elimination of the top prize solo exhibition, have brought changes in attitude and support, however, and there is far less participation by those with established reputations in the show's 31st edition, on view through next

title: Baseball; Relief Is Fleeting For Lowly Orioles
description: Back in the days when the notion of a Baltimore Orioles victory was nothing more than fantasy - why, it seems like only yesterday - everyone up to and including the manager wondered about the climactic moment.

title: VICE PRESIDENTS OFTEN GET ON BASE, BUT SELDOM SCORE
description: Vice President Bush's march toward the Republican nomination is carrying him into a predicament that few men in his position have overcome.

title: Legislator, Fighting for Petitions at Malls, Takes Case to Shoppers
description: Assemblyman Daniel Feldman is trying to prohibit mall owners from evicting people who ask shoppers to sign petitions. Part of his attempt, appropriately enough, involves asking shoppers in malls to sign petitions.

title: Alaskans Ask Soviet to Open Siberian Door
description: Until 1948 when the Cold War slammed shut the back doors of the United States and Soviet Union, Alaskan Eskimos crossed the Bering Strait in motorboats to visit relatives in Soviet Siberia.

title: GYPSY CABS MOVE DEEPER UNDERGROUND
description: One year after New York City launched a drive to tame the wide-open nonmedallion taxi industry by giving the Taxi and Limousine Commission jurisdiction over the cars and drivers in that business, the result has justified neither the worst fears of the car services nor the best hopes of city officials.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Refugees From Sudan Strain Ethiopia Camps
description: Thousands of starving refugees from the Sudan, fleeing drought and civil war in their country's south, are crossing the border into southwestern Ethiopia every month and severely taxing overcrowded relief camps.

title: Companies Teaching Workers 3 R's to Compete in Age of High Technology
description: When Motorola Inc. introduced a system of quality control at its plant in Arcade, N.Y., it found that many employees lacked the mathematical skills needed to understand the new statistics-based approach. In response, Motorola officials added six hours of remedial training in grade-school mathematics for all workers.

title: Forbes's Somerset Press Sells Printing Division
description: LEAD: THE commercial-printing division of Somerset Press, a Somerville-based printing and newspaper publishing company purchased last year by the philanthropist Malcolm S. Forbes, has been acquired by a Long Island company.

title: Verbatim: Koch and Blacks
description: ' Whatever the Mayor thought he was doing about what he did, I'm here to tell him, and I think the whole city community - black and white - are saying, that it didn't come out right, Ed, and it has a divisive tone to it. ' Benjamin Ward Police Commissioner of New York City, calling on Mayor Koch to apologize for his attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson before the New York Presidential primary election. ' It was never my intent to reject or insult the black community. . . . Be assured that I realize my obligations, both as a Mayor who must represent all the people and as an individual who has invested his entire life in public service and who must be true to himself. The challenge comes in striking the right balance. ' Mayor Koch

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: Private Terms is a thoroughly professional race horse who does whatever is necessary to win. He has also carried the Derby weight (126 lbs.) to victory in the Gotham and the Wood Memorial. ALAN SHUBACK New York

title: Leslie Ginway Plans An October Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Ginway of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie McDowell Ginway to Peter Craig Gambee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Gambee of Weston, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HOT MONEY. By Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) It's no secret that in the world of Dick Francis, the horse is a nobler animal than man. But nowhere in the thoroughbred bloodlines of Mr. Francis' fiction is there a family quite like the Pembrokes. The contentious, selfish and mutinous offspring of the multimillionaire gold speculator Malcolm Pembroke and his greedy wives make him rich in everything but love.

title: Pieter van den Berg, Industrial Executive, 84
description: Pieter van den Berg, chairman of North American Philips Corporation from 1948 to 1975, died of emphysema Friday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Dover Tourist Buses Stoned By Ferry Workers on Strike
description: Striking ferry workers pelted busloads of tourists with rocks and bottles today after mistaking them for strikebreakers, the police said. Later, two ferries docked at Dover as the boat company moved to crush the work stoppage.

title: Poet Wins Fight Against Silence
description: FOR William Meredith, working on his latest volume of poetry, ''Partial Accounts:

description: To the Editor:

description: Robert Maxwell comes lum-bering toward the waiting helicopter.

title: 'It's Playoff Time'
description: MARK JACKSON'S lower lip was sticking out, more in pain than defiance. He had caught a stray elbow during the horror sequence, and two of his front teeth were feeling loose.

title: Boarding School At State Expense
description: The concept - a free public boarding school specializing in science and mathematics for gifted high school students - has been in operation since 1980, when North Carolina opened the first such school.

title: 16 Design Showrooms Open in Yorktown
description: IT was the search for a new building in which to expand a long-established family-owned plumbing supply business that eventually led to the development of a new business project, the $9 million Building and Design Center at Yorktown, said Jonas Weiner, one of the owners of Best Plumbing Supply and a principal in the development of the center.

title: Susan Hunt to Marry in July
description: Susan Melville Hunt and the Rev. Mark Hollingsworth Jr., the son of Caroline J. Hollingsworth of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Hollingsworth, plan to marry in July, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt of Cambridge, Mass., have announced.

title: The Northeast and the West Are Faring Well - for Now
description: The Western United States has what some economists call a ''Swiss cheese'' economy - pockets of great prosperity and pockets of depression. While the job market has generally been improving in the last year, the precise outlook depends on the specific region and the specific industry.

title: HOW FOREIGN INVESTMENT FITS INTO AMERICA
description: John J. Nevin has an uncommon mastery of the details of his industry, say his colleagues and competitors. But the Firestone chief is also known for his interest in the big picture. Here are some of his thoughts on how foreign investment fits into America's economy:

title: Giants Are Loaded On Offensive Line
description: The Giants' demise last season began with health problems in the offensive line. Now, after the National Football League draft, the Giants face another problem with the offensive line -what to do with all those players.

title: Review/Recital; Poe Story With Cello And Piano
description: For his cello recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening, Eric Bartlett presented a pair of New York premieres sandwiched between pieces by Beethoven, Schumann and Brahms. Larry Bell's ''The Black Cat,'' based on Poe's story, proved the more unusual, if less impressive, of the two - a monodrama or dramatic recitation accompanied by illustrative music. Mr. Bell, a professor at the Boston Conservatory, served as the slow-paced narrator for this murderous tale of a man driven mad by his cat.

title: PANDEMONIUM AT THE OPERA
description: To The Editor:

title: In the Bush With Thesiger
description: To the Editor:

title: Color It Red
description: On bad days I wear red. What's a bad day? It's one when words won't come; when the typewriter is glum and unproductive; when I've burned the prunes for the second time; when the crevices in my skin make me sad - again.

title: Posting: Broker at the Bank; One-Stop Shopping
description: It may not be a giant step in the evolution of convenience merchandising, but it now is possible to shop for a co-op, condo or house in a bank and then walk over to another desk to sign up for a loan to buy it.

title: CHARLESTON
description: For years, the standard itinerary to Charleston, S.C., included touring a meticulously restored home, riding the ferry to Fort Sumter, dining on a bowl of she-crab soup and picking up a souvenir: a coiled seagrass basket, or perhaps a miniature bale of cotton.

title: Woman Slain by Man Wielding 2-by-4
description: A Harlem woman was attacked and killed by a stranger wielding a two-by-four yesterday as she and her son were on their way to church from their home on Lenox Avenue, the police said.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TULIP TIME With its roots firmly set in Long Island's Dutch past, and don't forget those 70,000 tulips to that dot the campus, Hofstra University holds its annual Dutch Festival today. This time, from noon to 5 P.M., it has a bit more than the customary walking tours of the Hempstead campus. The gardening crew will give tips on growing tulips; craftsmen will demonstrate and sell appropriate fare; there will be an outdoor pops concert at 1 P.M., and films and lectures throughout the afternoon. There's also ''People at Work: 17th Century Dutch Art,'' an exhibition of works by 44 artists, including Rembrandt and Jan Steen. Donna Barnes, the show's curator, gives a slide lecture at 1 P.M. at the Emily Lowe Gallery, and Wednesday and Thursday there's a symposium on ''17th Century Dutch Art and Life.'' For information about the symposium, which, like the festival, is free, call 560-5742. POETS GALORE

title: Next Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: 'Maybe' Is Manila
description: The euphoria of bloodlessly ousting a dictator a little over two years ago has worn off, and the grumbles have resumed. Practically every major question in the Philippines now has to be answered with ''maybe, too soon to tell.''

title: AIDS Vaccine Test Produces Immune Response in 6
description: The first American test of an experimental AIDS vaccine has produced an immune response in six volunteers, an important step toward developing an effective vaccine against the disease, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases said today.

title: FOR BUSH, ISSUES OF EARLY 80'S LIVE
description: Remember the old days? Vice President Bush asks audiences. Jimmy Carter. Malaise. Geraldine A. Ferraro. Double-digit inflation.

title: TUNISIA RENEWING TIES WITH QADDAFI
description: Since he became President in November, Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali has adopted an aggressive foreign policy of unity among Arab and North African nations that includes re-establishing strong ties to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: P.L.O. Faction Talks of More Raids From Lebanon
description: The leader of a P.L.O. faction, buoyed by the Palestine Liberation Organization's reconciliation with Syria, has announced plans to increase attacks against Israel from Lebanon. At the same time, Israeli troops have been conducting an extensive search in southern Lebanon for suspected guerrillas.

title: Nancy Susan Rose Is Wed To Donnell Robert Dufford
description: Nancy Susan Rose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zeldon E. Rose of West Long Branch, N.J., was married last night to Donnell Robert Dufford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin H. Dufford of El Cajon, Calif. Rabbi Joseph Goldman officiated at the Channel Club in Monmouth Beach, N.J.

title: Bowdoin Fraternities Assailed
description: A committee looking into the fate of fraternities at Bowdoin College has recommended that the college retain its fraternities, but it has criticized the organizations for allowing alcohol abuse, drinking by minors and sexual harassment.

title: Fewer Diplomats Scoff At a Threat by Britain
description: A new Government policy that threatens diplomats with expulsion if they do not pay parking tickets has sent foreign envoys rushing to pay fines.

title: Public Employees Don't Live High on the Expense-Account Hog

title: Nancy Rachel Stone to Wed Joel B. Poznansky in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Stone of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Rachel Stone to Joel Benjamin Poznansky, the son of Drs. Jack and Dulcie Poznansky of London.

title: Swing Low, Sweet Dollar: Exports Rise
description: IN the carrying-coals-to-Newcastle department: the first shipload of American-made Honda Accord coupes left Portland, Ore., for export to Japan last month. Honda, the fourth-largest automaker in the United States, plans to export 4,000 Accords to Japan this year.

title: Outdoors; Stocking of Raritan Angers Fishermen
description: NEW JERSEY'S stocking steelhead trout and chinook salmon in the Raritan River has infuriated the Hudson River Fishermen's Association.

title: U.S. Outslugged By Cuban Boxers
description: Cuba's amateur boxing team beat the United States squad in 10 of 12 matches today. It was the 15th time in 15 dual meetings between the countries, dating to 1977, that Cuba had won.

title: DO SURGEONS NEED MORE GOVERNMENT REGULATION?
description: Last year, when a Mexican surgical team reported that a new and potentially dangerous operation could remarkably improve the condition of patients with Parkinson's disease, Dr. Christopher Goetz, a Chicago neurologist, felt he had to offer the surgery to patients who were besieging him for help. Assuming that Federal permission would be required to perform the controversial procedure, he and other surgeons sought guidance from the Food and Drug Administration. It was then that he learned that while the Government strictly regulates what drugs doctors can prescribe, it makes no effort to control which operations they can perform.

title: FORGIVE US OUR DEFICITS
description: BALANCED BUDGETS & AMERICAN POLITICS By James D. Savage. Tables. 350 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $27.95.

title: Sinkhole Swallows House
description: A large sinkhole quickly swallowed a house and two others teetered on the edge in a subdivision near this central Florida town, the authorities said today.

title: Forrest Bess: Desire Ruled His Vision
description: Forrest Bess WAS BORN IN BAY City, Tex., in 1911. He went to Texas A. & M. and the University of Texas, studying architecture, philosophy and religion. Like his father, he worked in oilfields. He lived in Mexico. He wandered. During World War II, he served in the Army and was commended for camouflage design. In 1947 he went to live at his parents' bait camp on Chinquapin Bay, off the south Texas coast, 20 miles from Bay City. He remained there for 27 years, fishing during the day, painting irregularly at night, copying his visions in a sketchbook in the morning. The sketchbook is lost. So is his notebook of medical theories. He was committed to a mental hospital in the mid-1970's. He died of skin cancer in a Bay City nursing home in 1977.

description: ''It's very difficult, barring a catastrophe, to see any scenario that would derail the economy before the election.''

ART;
Depicting Industrial America
