Combining the immediacy of drawing with the ready dissemination of mass-produced imagery, the print was in many ways an ideal vehicle for what Mr.

title: VAN BUREN, 1836-40: LAST SITTING NO. 2 ABLE TO RISE TO NO. 1
description: There rrxhare some similarities between George Bush and Martin Van Buren, the last man to be elected President while serving as Vice President: Both spent most of their lives on the public payroll, and, as Vice Presidents, both were regarded as confidants of their Presidents.

title: 'Little Shop of Horrors' in Elmsford
description: AT An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford on Monday and Tuesday evenings, one can usually see variety attractions (Big Band shows, comedy specials) or a local theater group in the likes of a Neil Simon comedy or an Agatha Christie mystery.

title: FICTION
description: INTIMATE STRANGERS: New Stories From Quebec. Edited by Matt Cohen and Wayne Grady. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) Canadian literature remains, in this country, largely an unknown landscape, one in which only a few figures have much visibility. And so the large, robust and diverse body of work produced by the generation of French Canadian writers who came of age in the 1970's has been virtually invisible in the United States. ''Intimate Strangers'' offers a preliminary map of that exotic terrain. In their introduction, the editors of this collection, Matt Cohen and Wayne Grady, stress the extent to which these younger writers have distanced themselves from the forms of earlier French Canadian writers, developing work that depends more on the play of language and the urban experience, and less on the traditions of the folk tale and the realities of a rural existence. Victor-Levy Beaulieu, for example, presents a witty sendup of the form of the folk tale in ''The Rubber Ball,'' which features a bizarre protagonist who sets out to make a name for himself by shooting Niagara Falls in a large rubber ball. In contrast, Monique Proulx's ''Feint of Heart'' is a wry dissection of the mating habits of young urban academics. And ''The Good Old Days'' by Andre Major is a straightforward tale of male bonding and the nostalgia that haunts the middle-aged. The nine other stories demonstrate in varying degrees a quality that sets much contemporary French Canadian writing apart from current trends: the embrace of surrealism and with it a fascination with literary structure. Because of this, the stories in ''Intimate Strangers,'' although ably rendered by a number of translators, are not always easy reading. But they are uniformly strong, forming a vivid introduction to a group of challenging writers.

title: Shoreham Plant: Prepared for Operation, or Defeat
description: To an expert standing on the operating deck at the heart of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the plant looks as poised to produce energy as kindling stacked in a fireplace or water impounded behind a dam.

title: AN ANGLER'S RITES OF SPRING
description: Patricia Leigh Brown has done a service by piercing the myth of fly-fishing's most elite connotations (''An Angler's Rites of Spring,'' March 27). It's an activity that can be as simple or complex as one desires. My fly-fishing guide service in the Lake Tahoe area has attracted the ''eclectic'' cross section she mentions: a microsurgeon who was enthralled to learn that a ''triple-surgeon'' is a standard angling knot, a sheet-metal worker, a printer, a fisheries biologist on a busman's holiday, an advertising executive and an M.B.A.-turned-dental-hygienist who has since supplanted me as a fishing partner of an old fraternity brother.

title: May Day to May 7
description: Salute to Israel

title: LIFE STYLES OF THE RICH AND QUIRKY
description: LEAD: ''E'' IS FOR EVIDENCE By Sue Grafton. 227 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $15.95.

title: MONEY PINCH RAISES WORRY FOR THE PARKS
description: America's national parks expect record crowds this summer amid a widening debate over complaints that a lack of money is causing a growing and permanent deterioration of the parks.

title: Police Guard at Kean's Home Accidentally Shoots Himself
description: A state trooper assigned to guard the home of Governor Kean accidentally shot himself in the foot today while cleaning a gun in a trailer outside the Governor's house, officials said.

title: Practical Traveler; Tips for Trips With Friends
description: In ancient times when I undertook to advise two young men on significant matters, I told them firmly they should never undertake to marry anyone - well, settle down with anyone - if they had not first taken a long coach train trip with her. For two years I had traveled to college in Minnesota in coach and in that time I had discarded any number of prospective dates, some potential roommates and a few heroes. On these trips I had also founded a lifetime friendship with a woman from New Jersey who was capable of asking a sinister newsdealer outside the LaSalle Street station in Chicago: ''Which is the liberal paper, please?'' I became a believer that a day in the gritty, raspy seats of the Hiawatha to Minneapolis was a test of compatibility greater than a day in a lifeboat.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on April 17 about the pre-Broadway tour of ''Macbeth'' and an article in some copies of the main news section on March 6 about the United States visit of Prince Charles misidentified a theater in Pittsburgh.

title: Richard Chamberlain's Mini-Series Mastery
description: The king of the mini-series is tired and yearning for his beach house in Hawaii. ''I don't handle complexity very well,'' Richard Chamberlain says. ''I'm very simple-minded. It's so simple in Hawaii -watching the sunset is the big event of the day.''

title: Vickee S. Jordan And B. M. Adams To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vernon E. Jordan Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of Mr. Jordan's daughter, Vickee Sharee Jordan, to Barry Monroe Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl L. Adams Jr. of Maplewood, N.J. and Oak Bluffs, Mass. The couple plan to marry June 18.

title: Beside the Sea In Brighton, Royal Fantasy
description: Its owner was impossible, its architect impractical, its workers often unpaid; it was the wrong building at the wrong time in the wrong climate, a visionary extravagance that affronted many of its visitors and was abandoned within 30 years of its completion. And yet, today, despite restoration work and scaffolding, the Royal Pavilion at Brighton shines forth as the proof that style and imagination can indeed create the most unlikely of masterpieces.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music review last Sunday about the Juilliard American Opera Center's production of Benjamin Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' misidentified the singer in the role of Theseus. He was Scott Wilde.

title: Christina Brucia Wed To Steven Breitenfeld
description: The marriage of Christina Brucia, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. James J. Brucia of Roslyn, L.I., to Steven Breitenfeld, the son of Capt. and Mrs. Ludwig Breitenfeld of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I. The bride's father, a State Supreme Court justice in Mineola, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lanesborough, Mass.;
Enclosed Mall Put on Hold
description: LEAD: BERKSHIRE COUNTY'S first enclosed regional shopping mall is ready for customers. But the Pyramid Companies postponed indefinitely the planned early-March opening because of complex permit problems.

title: U.N. Monitoring Team Off to Afghanistan
description: Members of a United Nations team flew to Kabul today to begin preparations for monitoring the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection, in a letter to an Assembly committee last month, challenged the assertions and conclusions of a two-month-old study by an environmental group of the department's water-quality enforcement effort.

title: AS JOBS INCREASE, SO DOES INSECURITY
description: More Americans of working age are employed today than ever before in the postwar period. But the sense of well-being and security that once came with holding a job is now disappearing.

title: Nunneries Forced to Sell Off Land
description: LEAD: RELIGIOUS orders on Long Island have seen a trickle of young women entering their convents in the last 20 years. Several religious communities have been obliged to sell off part of their lands to developers to maintain their retired and infirm nuns.

title: Going With Kids
description: To the Editor: The article about traveling in Europe with children omitted one of the most interesting ways to see Europe: camping. We traveled extensively with our children (the youngest was 8) on two occasions, and each time we camped, the first time for six weeks, the second for a month. We have pitched our tents in Oslo, Copenhagen, The Hague, Munich, Lucerne, Vienna and the Bois de Boulogne in Paris. Each time we found the camp sites pleasant, clean, safe and inexpensive. The children still remember the time we camped across from a ferry landing in Norway and they woke up to lambs surrounding their tent.

title: Samuelson's Absence Leaves Lots of Room for Unexpected
description: The absence of Joan Benoit Samuelson, the best American female marathoner ever, has left the Olympic marathon trial today in Pittsburgh wide open for a handful of other runners with a legitimate chance to finish among the first three, make the Olympic team and win $25,000.

description: The Supreme Court sent a chill through civil rights groups last week with an unexpected 5-to-4 vote that left many wondering whether Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's arrival had cemented a conservative majority with an agenda for change.

title: Knicks Seek Route To Avert 2d Rout
description: A key tip-in by Dennis Johnson. A blocked shot by Kevin McHale. A foul by Kenny Walker and two free throws by Larry Bird. A few Knick turnovers, some missed shots and a tighter Boston Celtic defense.

title: Volleyball, Swimming and the Dow
description: School will be out soon. Want to make sure that your child doesn't spend the whole summer just enjoying fishing or hanging around the malls? Then send him or her to business camp. Between volleyball and swimming, the future financiers of America can spend a week sharpening their money-making skills.

title: TOBACCO MAKERS ATTACK TESTIMONY
description: Three tobacco companies accused of causing a smoker's death asked a Federal judge this week to strike much of the testimony from the record of the civil trial.

title: Marigrace Brennan to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hubert S. Brennan of Elizabeth, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Marigrace Teresa Brennan to Howard Parsons Wilkes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Wilkes of Short Hills, N.J. Miss Brennan, a first-grade teacher at the North Street School in Greenwich, Conn., graduated from Boston College. Her fiance, an account executive at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York, graduated from Denison University.

title: Julia Carlisle Married To Thomas B. Martin

The Rev. William Lloyd Fox Jr., a Unitarian minister, officiated.

description: James McCracken, the most successful dramatic tenor yet produced by the United States and a pillar of the Metropolitan Opera in the 1960's and 70's, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.
