title: Punchy
description: FAT CITY Directed by John Huston. With Stacy Keach (in photo), Jeff Bridges and Susan Tyrrell (in photo). RCA/Columbia Home Video. 96 minutes. $69.95.

title: In French Town, Le Pen Hits a Nerve
description: Last Sunday, municipal officials and war veterans in this Communist-governed town west of Paris went to the monument to the dead to remember those deported to Nazi extermination camps. As the wreaths were being placed, angry and frightened citizens voted in large numbers for Jean-Marie Le Pen, a presidential aspirant who has dismissed the camps as a ''minor detail'' in the history of World War II.

title: CARLOTTA AND THE MASTER
description: From our first meet-ing, my relationship with Carlotta Monterey O'Neill was marked by a tantalizing sense of unreality, though it profoundly influenced my entire professional life. She was the third wife and widow of the playwright Eugene O'Neill, the survivor of a dark and tempestuous 24-year marriage. Because she was dominant, our friendship mirrored her personality and took on a Gothic sheen, as fantasy and reality fused harmoniously.

title: Carley A. Miller Becomes Bride Of A. G. Sullivan
description: Carley Anne Miller and Arthur Gary Sullivan, a son of Mrs. Sidney B. Sullivan of Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Mr. Sullivan, were married yesterday at the home in Oyster Bay, L.I., of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lindley G. Miller. The bride's father, a lawyer and the Village Justice of Upper Brookville, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Biding Your Time, in Nanoseconds
description: Whoa, wait just a darned nanosecond. We've been reading more and more lately about something called zero wait states, usually in the context of computer makers bragging about their machines being better than other computers. Some machines are said to have one wait state. If that's so great, why are some computer makers - like the Tandy Corporation, the Dell Computer Corporation and Zenith Electronics Corporation - proud that their latest machines don't have any?

title: Correction
description: An article on March 20 misstated the date of the purchase of Alaska from Russia. It was 1867. A map with an accompanying article misidentified the river that flows past Fairbanks. It is the Tanana.

title: A Tight Squeeze at Video Stores
description: Ed Streit, the proprietor of Hollywood at Home in Rio Rancho, N. M., often feels embattled. When he opened his video rental store in 1984, migrating from the fast-food business, making money was automatic. Back then, as Mr. Streit explained it, ''you could put your store underneath the railroad tracks behind a granary and treat customers like dirt. But they'd keep coming back. They'd have to drive at least 20 miles to get to another place.''

title: Justice Dept. Clears Ex-Prosecutor, a Novelist
description: The Justice Department on Friday cleared one of its former prosecutors, the best-selling novelist Scott F. Turow, of allegations that he might have obstructed justice in a criminal investigation.

title: Dukakis Is Concerned About Overconfidence
description: Why does Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts speak incessantly these days about the Boston Red Sox?

title: Review/City Ballet; Images of a Painter Set in Vigorous Motion
description: As a 9-year-old in 1965, Paul Schwartz made front-page news by discovering a leak in Central Park's reservoir during a water shortage in the city.

title: With a Tune, Whiffenpoofs Pass Along a Tradition
description: LEAD: JOEL FRAM, a Yale University junior who had been chosen as next year's musical director for the singing group the Whiffenpoofs, stepped outside his dormitory room recently and greeted a throng of admirers.

title: Going With Kids
description: To the Editor: Though I enjoyed Cynthia Samuels' article on traveling with children (Travel, Jan. 24), I wish to correct two pieces of information regarding air travel that appeared in the accompanying box by Dennis Hevesi. My information is based on a trip we took to Rome last summer with our 6-month-old daughter and on several domestic trips.

title: THE LITTLE ENGINE THAT COULD
description: All the images about the withering of American industry these last few years seemed a little truer here and felt a little sadder. Bethlehem Steel and Mack Trucks, the big-name companies that once built the industrial centers of eastern Pennsylvania, were shrinking down or pulling out. Sometimes, it seemed as if the companies had turned against their towns, testing them to see whether they could take it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The impression of the I.N.S. agents and officials that Salvadorans come to the United States solely for economic gain reflect a lack of sensitivity and understanding, and derive from ignorance on the part of I.N.S. agents as to the complex motivations and situations of those who have fled El Salvador.'' - Judge David Kenyon, ruling against the Government on asylum. [ 32:1. ]

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Phoenix;
Condo Builders Fill In the Gaps
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS here are selectively rebuilding open areas by turning small lots into high-density housing in Phoenix's ''central corridor,'' a half-mile-wide strip stretching five miles northward along Central Avenue from the downtown core.

title: Elizabeth Perle Named Prentice-Hall Executive
description: Elizabeth Perle has been named publisher of Prentice-Hall Press. She was previously associate publisher of hardcover and trade paperbacks at Bantam Books, where she held positions in marketing and sales. Prior to that she was employed at Harper & Row and Times Books. The press is part of the Prentice Hall Trade Division, itself part of Simon & Schuster's consumer group.

title: Car Rentals: Medical Aid, Rates, Routes
description: AVIS EUROPE has added referrals to English-speaking doctors and dentists to its On Call Europe 24-hour phone service. By calling from Belgium, France, West Germany, the Netherlands, Italy, Switzerland or Britain, Avis renters can get the name and location of the nearest participating doctor or dentist with 24-hour call service. Callers can also get information on hotels, restaurants, shops, and police and other emergency numbers. The calls are toll-free, except for a small local charge in Germany, Italy and Switzerland. More information: 800-331-1212.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: There is no distinct standout, but the combination of Woody Stephens, Pat Day and Forty Niner will prevail and win going away in a dynamite race. HOWARD MORRIS Rowayton, Conn.

title: CERONE LIKES HIS ROLE ON TEAM HE USED TO HATE
description: NOT only do the Boston Red Sox have Roger Clemens and Lee Smith and Ellis Burks and Mike Greenwell, but they also have history on their side.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Bowling Williams Wins 2d Firestone Title: After opening with four strikes, Mark Williams beat Tony Westlake, 237-214, in the championship game yesterday to capture his second $250,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions in Fairlawn, Ohio. Williams, at 30 the oldest among the five players in the nationally televised championship round, collected his sixth Professional Bowlers Association crown and $50,000. Westlake, whose runner-up finish was worth $28,000, had to win two games to get a berth in the title game. He eliminated Brian Voss in the semifinal, 222-204, after beating Mike Aulby, 239-214. (AP) Golf Tied in Texas: Greg Norman scrambled through 36 holes yesterday before tying Curtis Strange for the top spot after three rounds of the $700,000 Independent Insurance Agent Open in The Woodlands, Tex. Norman, who led or shared the lead through the first two rounds of the rain-delayed tournament, stumbled on the back nine of his first 18 holes, finishing with a second-round 70. Norman was among 52 players who had to double up yesterday. They never teed off Friday, when rain and lightning on the course forced officials to postpone play. Norman continued to struggle for most of the third round, but ran in a birdie putt on the par-4 No. 17 hole, his 35th of the day, for a third-round 68 and a 54-hole total of 13-under 203. That tied Strange, who shot a third-round 66 and reached 13-under with a birdie on the par-3 No. 16 hole. (AP) 3 Share Lead in Sarah Lee: Deb Richard shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to tie Rosie Jones and Sherri Steinhauer for the lead after two rounds in the $335,000 Sara Lee Classic in Nashville. Jones, who won the USX Classic last week, shot a four-under-par 68, including a 25-foot birdie on the final hole, for a two-round score of seven-under 137 on the 6,242-yard Hermitage Golf Course. Steinhauer followed her opening-round 66 with a one-under 71. One shot behind the leaders at six-under were Judy Dickinson, who shot a 68 yesterday, and Lisa Walters, who had a 69.(AP) Tennis Becker Upset by Leconte: Henri Leconte of France needed two tie breakers yesterday to upset top-seeded Boris Becker, 3-6, 7-6, 7-6, and advance to the final of the $602,500 German Open tournament in Hamburg. It was the first time Leconte had beaten Becker. Leconte will face Kent Carlsson of Sweden today. The second-seeded player beat Jorge Arrese of Spain, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) Agassi and Arias in Final: Top-seeded Andre Agassi and Jimmy Arias won their semifinal matches yesterday at the United States men's clay court championships in Isle of Palms, S.C. Agassi struggled past Lawson Duncan, 2-6, 7-5, 6-4, while Arias beat Jim Courier, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, at the Wild Dunes Racquet Club. (AP) Edberg Beats McEnroe: Stefan Edberg defeated John McEnroe, 6-3, 3-6,6-3, last night to advance to the final of the $500,000 Challenge in Atlanta. Also in the final is Ivan Lendl, who beat Andres Gomez, 6-2, 6-2. (AP) Pro Basketball Patroons Win Title: The Albany Patroons capped a record-setting season yesterday by rallying from a 14-point deficit for a 105-96 victory over the Wyoming Wildcatters to win the Continental Basketball Association championship. Lowes Moore came off the bench to score 23 points and Tod Murphy, the series' most valuable player, added 21. It was Albany's second championship since it joined the league in 1982. The Patroons set a professional basketball record with a .889 winning percentage on a 48-6 regular-season record.(AP) Horse Racing Notebook Wins by 8 Lengths: Notebook dueled head-and-head with Ballindaggin through six furlongs, then pulled away through the stretch to race to an eight-length victory yesterday in the $114,400 Mike Lee Handicap for New York-breds 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Notebook, who carried high weight of 124 and Jose Santos went the mile in 1:34 on the extremely fast main track to better by 2 1/5 seconds the stakes standard posted by Landing Plot in 1986. Ballindaggin was runner-up in the field of five, a half length ahead of Novel Nashua. For Notebook, the victory was the fifth in 11 career starts. He earned $68,640 for Eugene V. Klein and paid $3.20 for $2.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Dover, N.H.: Old Mill Town Gets New Look
description: LEAD: A plan by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, the nation's fifth-largest insurer, to build a million-square-foot office complex here may set off a new business era in this former mill city of 28,000.

title: A Difficult Year for the College-Bound
description: TO the considerable relief of hundreds of Westchester high school seniors and their counselors, April is over and college acceptances have been received.

title: Stony Brook Coming of Age at 30
description: LEAD: BESET by problems that attend growth and success, and by buildings that fall too soon into decrepitude, the State University of New York at Stony Brook will mark its 30th birthday with a celebration today.

title: A Second Skin Drug Is Called Major Threat for Birth Defects
description: A drug to treat the chronic skin disease psoriasis has recently entered the market and is probably even more likely to produce birth defects than the anti-acne drug Accutane, experts have warned.

title: Miss Cunningham Is Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Name in Chicago, Kathleen Cunningham, a daughter of Joan Bennett of Arvada, Colo., and David Cunningham of Lake Oswego, Ore., was married yesterday to Robert H. Jaffee, a son of Mary Silk of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Wilton L. Jaffee Jr. of Aspen, Colo. The Rev. John R. Hall officiated. The bride, a graduate of the University of Illinois, is an assistant vice president of the LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. The bridegroom, a commodities trader, graduated from Amherst College and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

title: Kimberlee Keppler to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Burns Keppler of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kimberlee Martha Keppler to Keith Francis Overlander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Craig Overlander of Eastchester, N.Y. Miss Keppler is an analyst in global securities and foreign exchange at Chemical Bank in New York. Her fiance is an internal government bond salesman at Salomon Brothers in New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: KOCH THINKS OF SKIPPING CONVENTION
description: Although he is Mayor of the largest city in the country, Mayor Koch may not attend the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta in mid-July. It would be the first time in the memory of veteran politicians that a Democratic Mayor of New York did not go to the convention.

title: THE BITTER, AND BRACING, COURTSHIP OF IRVING BANK
description: For more than a decade, the Bank of New York Company and the Irving Bank Corporation have been eyeing one another, wondering if a combination might restore their fading status as players in the big-league of banking.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: Brian's Time. The extra eighth of a mile in the Derby will greatly benefit his style. John Veitch, his trainer, will have to work on getting Brian's Time to break more quickly from the gate and he must hope for a beneficial post position. Posts 1 and 2 and the outside posts will greatly hurt his horse's chances.

title: The False Promise of Burden-Sharing
description: Look, say the Presidential candidates: Our allies prosper while the United States strains to provide far more than its share of the common defense. The allies must be forced, the refrain goes, to do their fair share. The theme already has been reduced to shorthand: burden-sharing. Like most slogans, this one reverberates with simplicity, power - and ignorance.

title: Maine Tribe Finds Strength in Music
description: When the Passamaquoddy Indians were fighting to regain ownership of tribal lands in the 1960's and 1970's, Wayne Newell felt uncomfortable protesting against the Federal Government. It was through his tribe's music that he found strength.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Providence, R.I.: Renewal With Ethnic Flavor
description: LEAD: A victorian church renovated into condominiums is another sign of the increased interest of developers and home buyers in a Portuguese neighborhood of Rhode Island's capital.

title: Jackson Tried to Free Journalist
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who helped negotiate the release of a United States pilot who had been shot down over Syria, also played a role in freeing the journalist Jeremy Levin as a hostage in Lebanon in 1985, according to a new book.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ISRAELI JUDGE TO SPEAK Justice Dov Levin of the Israeli Supreme Court, who presided at the trial of John Demjanjuk for the murder of Treblinka concentration camp inmates, will speak Thursday at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Bergen County at noon and again in the evening.

title: Miss Mohan Wed To James Murray
description: At the Asbury United Methodist Church in Crestwood, N.Y., Lorraine Ann Mohan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Mohan of Milford, Mass., was married yesterday to James Francis Murray, a son of Mrs. James P. Murray of Tuckahoe, N.Y., and the late Mr. Murray. The Rev. William S. Shillady performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Rock; NATALIE MERCHANT: STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: Natalie Merchant, lead singer for 10,000 Maniacs, doesn't want listeners to know exactly what she's up to. Her lyrics hint and tease at their subjects, only gradually revealing their stories. And on stage Thursday at the Beacon Theater she was by turns open and oblique, graceful and awkward, sidestepping ordinary rock theatrics as if she'd never seen them.

title: High Court Ignores Alcoholism Research
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
description: Israeli Arabs need only look at the second-class status of Jews in Moslem lands to appreciate the rights and freedoms they enjoy as an increasingly hostile minority in Israel (''Arab Rage Inside Israel,'' by Ze'ev Chafets, April 3). But Israeli Arabs want it both ways: they demand full acceptance as Israeli citizens while proclaiming loyalty to an Arab state on the West Bank whose leaders are sworn to the dismantling of Israel. No responsible nation - least of all, one in as precarious a position as Israel is - can tolerate such a divided loyalty; no other nation would be asked to. STANLEY SPATZ, M.D Hollywood, Fla.

title: PLAYING A HAND BY THE NUMBERS
description: To what extent mathematics and bridge go together is an interesting question. There are indeed some high-level mathematicians who are terrible bridge-players and vice versa, but there is surely some correlation. Perhaps there is a mathematical-bridge potential that may lie partially dormant.

title: Homeless Children: Schools Struggle
description: LEAD: THE five children did not go to school last September; in fact, they did not go until November. Because they and their mother were homeless and living in emergency housing in Nassau County, the school district would not accept them until the intervention of the county's Department of Social Services.

title: Long Road's End for Reunited Asians
description: LEAD: Sarin Rom had vowed to his foster parents in Windsor, Vt., that he would not cry when he laid eyes on his mother and little brother Tuesday night for the first time in 10 years. But the instant they set foot on the airport pavement, Mr. Rom's resolve vanished.

title: Britain, With Soviet Help, Seizes Afghan Hashish in London
description: Customs investigators in London seized 3.5 tons of Afghan hashish in the first anti-drug operation involving Britain and the Soviet Union, the authorities announced Friday.

title: House Plants Need Understanding, Too
description: LEAD: The largest indoor plant in my house is a gardenia three feet tall, with an equal spread. Some years, most of its creamy blossoms open in a February rush, perfuming whatever room the plant is in. This year it staggered its sixty or so blooms, one or two flowers at a time, all through fall and winter.

title: Top-Ranking U.S. Epeeist Seeks Spot on Olympic Team
description: LEAD: AS A TEEN-AGER, Donna Stone was introduced to fencing in a township recreation program in Belleville.

title: FORMING EXPORT ALLIANCES - AND AVOIDING ANTITRUST
description: International trade is a chief concern of many trade association executives. The newest twist in such programs is the ''generic'' export trading company, introduced last year by the National Machine Tool Builders Association. This company is generic because, rather than specifically naming the partners, its export trade certificate - which allows joint trade activities to foreign markets - covers the association's entire membership, including new members as they join, said Charles G. Koella, the association's international trade director.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: COSMOPOLITAN CULTURE: The Gilt-Edged Dream of a Tolerant City. By Bonnie Menes Kahn. (Atheneum, $25.) Bonnie Menes Kahn has set herself the mammoth task of analyzing the ''cosmopolitan'' city and discovering what makes it go. She argues that the engine of a great metropolis is the outsider, the immigrant, who is the source of a city's wealth, vibrancy, tolerance, creativity - and, eventually, its decline.

title: Can a Small 'Romance' Seduce Broadway?
description: No careening chandeliers, no raving madman scurrying across a false proscenium. No roller skates, no barricade, no neon dragons descending from the heights. Just two couples in two small musical plays about grown-up love in ''Romance, Romance.''

title: Air Couriers
description: To the Editor: My first and only experience with Now Voyager was nowhere near as rosy as the piece would have newcomers believe. Having booked a trip to Sydney three months in advance, I was informed three days before my departure that the company I was traveling for had no freight to send and my services were not required. By this time, I had invested a substantial amount of planning and money in the trip, so I was forced to try to find another way of getting to Sydney in a hurry. Needless to say, I was at the mercy of the airlines and ended up paying top dollar, much more than I would have spent if I had booked further in advance. Now Voyager takes no responsibility for mishaps like this. They only refund your money.

title: Growth at the Opera
description: The New Rochelle Opera is a relatively new local institution. Started in 1982 by its artistic director, Camille Coppola, who first brought bits and pieces of operas to schools in the county, the company now has a troupe of 30 and is presenting fully staged productions.

title: Saving Art: Nice Neighbors Help
description: WHEN Ernest Hunter started collecting art during the Depression, he was one of few in his Greenwich Village neighborhood who had a steady income, from working at a local speak-easy. Many artists who lived nearby were desperate to make a fast dollar and knew that Mr. Hunter couldn't say no to their paintings and etchings.

title: Hochberg Presses Issue of Contracts
description: LEAD: COUNTY LEGISLATOR Audrey G. Hochberg says ''crude attempts to bully'' her will not silence her complaints about the county's practice of awarding certain contracts without competitive bidding.

title: NONFICTION
description: VOYAGES OF DISCOVERY: Captain Cook and the Exploration of the Pacific. By Lynne Withey. (Morrow, $19.95.) In a time of growing worry about trade with the Pacific Rim countries, the story of the opening of the Pacific itself has on the face of it a certain interest. Indeed, the possibilities for commerce as much as for knowledge led the sponsors of Capt. James Cook, a Yorkshire farm laborer's son turned sailor and scientist, to send him out three times in the decade that began in 1768. His mission was to search for a southern continent or find the Northwest Passage, to map lands and harbors and to discover peoples. An assistant director of the University of California Press with a background in history and a previous biography (of Abigail Adams) to her credit, in ''Voyages of Discovery'' Lynne Withey explores anthropology. She does a nice job examining the way in which the Europeans' moral and romantic expectations colored their reactions to and interactions with the Pacific islanders through her skillful quotation from and sensitive readings of the voyagers' own writings. A comfortable aristocrat sees ''in Tahiti a miniature version of . . . feudalism''; a young idealist observes ''a democratic society of equals''; and almost all the voyagers, everywhere they go, are torn between Christian censoriousness and a Rousseau-like belief in the corrupting effects of civilization. But with tales like these, how one wishes for maps. Only the most zealous armchair traveler will have an easy time with the sole and greatly simplified chart that occupies the inside front and back covers.

title: JIM'S ORBIT WINS THE DERBY TRIAL
description: This year's contenders for the Kentucky Derby May 7 have seemed close together in ability all year, but they have never been closer than they were today at the finish of the spring's final prep race.

title: Q And A
description: Tennis Courses Question:Do any Northeastern ski resorts run tennis schools with lodging in the summer? - F. T. S., Princeton, N.J. Answer:Many ski areas in the Northeast have tennis courts, and some - like Waterville Valley, N.H. - will have instructors on duty, but their use for summer courses with rooms included seems to be limited to Vermont. Stratton Mountain, for example, which has 15 outdoor and 4 indoor courts, has a program of schools on weekends and midweek from May 22 through September. Weekend courses offer two nights' lodging (Friday and Saturday), two days of instruction and two lunches. The accommodations chosen in four lodges and inns determine the rates, but the average is about $360 a person, double occupancy. The midweek sessions, with room for five nights (Sunday to Thursday) and four days of instruction and four lunches, cost $685. The instruction is from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and courts are available for practice afterward. More information is available from the Stratton Sports Center, Stratton, Vt. 05155; 800-843-6867 and 802-297-2200.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Lean Sends Devils to Cup Semifinals
description: John MacLean again proved to be the biggest hero of the spring for the Devils as he scored the winning goal tonight to put the Devils into the Stanley Cup semifinals.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: ANTIQUE TIME

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STEALING HOME: Israel Bound and Rebound. By Haim Chertok. (Fordham University, $19.95.) Harvey Chertok, born in the Bronx, a political radical in the 1960's, was en route to becoming part of the American melting pot when he and his wife, Marcia, settled in Coalinga, Calif., near the college where Mr.

title: Judge Tells U.S. to Stop Coercion Of Salvadorans Seeking Asylum
description: In a resounding rejection of Reagan Administration policy, a Federal district judge here ruled late Friday that the Government had coerced Salvadorans seeking asylum into leaving the country, and must stop the practice.

title: Altitude Limit Put on Older 737's Because of Accident Over Hawaii
description: The Government yesterday barred older Boeing 737's like the Aloha Airlines plane torn open over Hawaii from flying above 23,000 feet until they are subjected to a stringent new inspection.

title: Man Is First to Escape From Prison Barge
description: A man accused of burglary became the first inmate to escape from New York City's prison barge when he crawled to freedom yesterday through an air-conditioner opening behind the barge's kitchen, city corrections officials said.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Feeling Lovable Floyd Patterson demystifies boxing and shows us what it's actually like. Here he tells Gay Talese how it feels to be knocked out. This is from ''Reading the Fights,'' edited by Joyce Carol Oates and Daniel Halpern (Holt).

title: Donald Trump's $1,500 High-Roller Ringside
description: DURING the negotiations for Ali-Frazier I at Madison Square Garden in 1971, each boxer was guaranteed a flat fee of $2.5 million, then a record sum. But soon it was time to set the ticket prices. ''Some people kept telling me that we could charge $200 for a ringside seat, but I decided that $150 was enough,'' Harry Markson, the Garden's boxing president of that era, recalled with a laugh. ''I thought $200 for a ringside ticket was obscene, but looking back, we probably should've charged $200.''

title: FRENCH NAVY PARTROL BOAT FIRES ON NEW CALEDONIA SEPARATISTS
description: A French Navy patrol boat shelled a Melanesian separatist camp during a reconnaissance mission today, in the first intervention by the navy in more than a week of ethnic violence in this French-administered South Pacific territory.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

title: Correction
description: An article on April 3 about Melbourne misstated the exchange rate for the Australian dollar. It is $1.35 Australian to $1 in United States currency.

title: Adding Sparkle To City Streets
description: New York City's streets may not be squeaky clean, but they may receive a bit of sparkle with a new asphalt called ''glasphalt'' - 20 percent glass.

title:
DINING OUT;
In a Former Bank on the Banks
description: LEAD: THE Creole and Cajun food served in Louisiana has, along with the hot jazz, long fascinated visitors to this country. Until the last few years, both native-born Americans and foreigners had to go South to try the genuine article.

title: The Northeast and the West Are Faring Well - for Now
description: During the last six months, the job market in the Northeast has flourished as steadily as it has over the last several years, flouting the predictions of economic pessimists who read the October stock market collapse as a signal of impending decline. Unemployment figures are expected to remain low, and wages may rise as companies scramble to find able help.

title: IMPATIENS - POPULAR, COLORFUL AND CAREFREE
description: Snap or cut off faded daffodils to prevent the formation of seed pods, but allow foliage to ripen naturally. Fertilize roses, if they have not been fed this spring. Wait another week or two to plant corn, melons and beans. Harvest leaf lettuce and spinach. Plant perennials and new shrubs. Impatiens

title: Halfway Houses: Points of View
description: The letter by Judith Leventhal, clinical psychologist, and Susan Ueber Raymond, health planner [ March 27 ] , concerns me.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: STEVEN J. FRIEDMAN;
The New Head of Mental Health Follows a Path of Prevention
description: LEAD: ON April 15, while many of his fellow county residents were busily submitting their tax returns, Steven J. Friedman of Yorktown was officially taking over as Westchester's Commissioner of Community Mental Health. ''I'm fairly compulsive,'' he said. ''I did my taxes by President's Day in February.''

title: Working With the Right to Know
description: CONGRESS has followed the New Jersey Legislature's lead and enacted legislation that challenges industries to release their grip on chemical information. Industries' response to this challenge will reflect how much they have learned, in the decade since Love Canal, about dealing with communities.

title: Asking Some Questions About Special Education
description: I would appreciate an opportunity to answer recent letters to the Long Island editor that misrepresent my point of view.

title: Three Recitals by Pianists
description: TWO fine young Westchester pianists, and another who is already a world-renowned artist, are enhancing the recital scene this week. William Wolfram returns to his alma mater today, Cynthia Peterson presents an unusual fusion of music and spirituality on Saturday and Garrick Ohlsson, also on Saturday, closes out the season for Friends of Music.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: PORT CHESTER HIGH SCHOOL;
In Pursuit of the American Dream
description: LEAD: SEEN from a distance on a misty spring morning, the high school here is impressive and picturesque - a massive red-brick structure with columned entrances and a tall clock tower. Sweeping green athletic fields and blossoming trees surround the building, giving it the look of a college campus.

title: Delhi Aide Says Libya Conscripted Workers
description: Nearly 100 Indians who traveled to Libya for jobs in a leather factory were swept from the Tripoli airport to a nearby army camp for military training before some of them escaped and sought help from the Indian Embassy, according to a top Indian police official.

title: Review/Theater; Rock-and-Roll Music Against the Law
description: In ''Robin's Band,'' an outspoken little musical set in the near future, there is never any question of who is good and who is evil. The good guys, costumed in colorful improvised outfits that make them resemble refugees from a postpunk version of ''Hair,'' are assorted street people who have been dispossessed of their homes by greedy real-estate barons and forced to live in ''the undeveloped zone'' of an unnamed major city. The bad guys, led by the infamous MacDonald Meld (Al Rodriguez), stalk about the stage in double-breasted space suits as they fiendishly conspire to take over more property.

title: Theatrical Life on the Lower East Side
description: On a rather foreboding block of the Lower East Side, amid art dealers and drug dealers, rats and real-estate speculators, dancers are dancing, actors are acting and R. Jeffrey Cohen, the 30-year-old director of the R.A.P.P. Arts Center, has grand visions for his new multi-disciplinary arts organization.

title: Segovia Concert Planned for Saturday
description: A free concert in honor of the guitarist Andres Segovia will be held Saturday at 7 P.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral; Mr. Segovia died last year at the age of 94. The concert is part of a monthlong series of events sponsored by Casa de Espana, a cultural center assisted by the Spanish Government and the New York Chamber of Commerce.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: AS OUR species claimed dominion over the earth, we pushed incalculable numbers of plants and animals up to and over the edge of that dark abyss called extinction. We blame our unenlightened, selfish, exploitive ancestors who killed off the Labrador duck, passenger pigeon and great auk and who brought the bison and whooping crane right to the brink.

title: DISMISSAL OF CASE IS RULED IMPROPER
description: A judge may not dismiss a criminal case solely because the main prosecution witness is not in the country when the trial is to begin, the state's highest court has ruled.

title: About Men; Learning to Hear The Small, Soft Voices
description: YOU AT A WOMEN'S college?'' a friend said just after I'd been hired to teach English at Smith. ''That's a scandal waiting to happen.'' He never made it clear if I was to be the debaucher or the debauchee. Another friend, a Smith alumna, told me its students saw the young male faculty, married or not, as ''fair game.'' My mother told me to get a heavy doorstop for my office and to keep my wife's picture on my desk.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Economic Signals: The Right Mix The economy grew at a 2.3 percent annual rate in the first quarter. That was off from the 4.8 percent pace set in the fourth quarter of 1987, but economists seemed to think that was almost a good sign. What really seemed to cheer them was the mix of factors creating the rise in the gross national product, particularly the reduction in inventories of unsold goods and the vigorous growth in capital spending. The inflation indicators in the G.N.P. report also offered encouragement, with an annual rate of increase of only 3.7 percent.

title: Going With Kids
description: To the Editor: Cynthia Samuels' piece was most timely for our family, which is beginning to consider traveling with its first grandchild. It also brought back pleasant recollections of traveling with our two children when they were young (a girl 8 and a boy 5 who had his sixth birthday in Rome), and it reminded us of some preparations we made beyond those that Mrs. Samuels mentioned.

title: BEHIND THAT ANATOLIAN SMILE
description: ELIA KAZAN A Life. By Elia Kazan. Illustrated. 848 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: HUNTING THE TOADFISH
description: LEAD: THE WILDERNESS COAST Adventures of a Gulf Coast Naturalist. By Jack Rudloe. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/ E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: SHAKEN BY DOWNSIZING, THE GROUPS REGROUP
description: One way that trade associations reflect American business as a whole is that both have been shaken by the recent trend toward consolidation.

title: State Garbage Program Criticized as Inadequate
description: LEAD: EVEN though the State Legislature voted overwhelmingly to approve a statewide recycling program, that is considered insufficient to address Long Island's worsening garbage problem.

title: Children Select Their Favorite Books
description: THE votes have been counted - all 4,879 of them - and the results are official: on Friday, three local authors and an illustrator will receive the 1988 Washington Irving Children's Book Choice Awards at the Westchester Library Association's annual luncheon at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown.

title: SOVIET NEWSPAPER PRAISES DISSIDENT
description: Roy Medvedev, the independent historian whose fiercely critical books about the Stalin era have won world acclaim but have been banned in his own country, was praised this week by an official newspaper for his work and his role as a voice of conscience.

title: Bronx Murder Suspect Is Arrested in West
description: A California businessman, charged last year in the fatal shooting of his companion, has been arrested as a suspect in a 1981 robbery and shooting death in the Bronx, New York City authorities said yesterday.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MORTAL GAMES. By Pierre Salinger and Leonard Gross. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Andre Kohl, the chief European correspondent of the United States Broadcasting Corporation, has just toppled the President-elect of France by revealing that he was a Nazi collaborator in World War II. In the aftermath, Kohl is tired.

title: Golfers Ready but Course Isn't
description: LEAD: GOLFERS will not be teeing off on the anxiously awaited Town of Oyster Bay golf course this spring and may have to wait until 1989 to use Long Island's newest public links.

title: Iraqi Missile With Extended Range Is New Peril to Iran's Cities and Oil
description: Iraq has successfully test-fired a new surface-to-surface missile with a range of 560 miles, far enough to hit Iranian targets in the Strait of Hormuz and increase pressure on Iran's oil traffic through the Persian Gulf.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH VIETNAM
description: The last time I saw the then-infamous Nguyen Thi Binh was in January 1973. It was during the brief moment when Madame Binh, who was then Foreign Minister of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, took center stage with North Vietnamese negotiator Le Duc Tho and American diplomats Henry A. Kissinger and William P. Rogers during the signing of the Paris peace accords. That televised ceremony was the last time most Americans saw the tough, determined revolutionary who had been a leader of the struggle in South Vietnam.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MENDOCINO. By Judith Greber. (Crown, $18.95.) If you want a quick, enjoyable survey of the history of northern California, you'll like this saga by the author of ''The Silent Partner.'' You'll get the traditional scenes of covered wagons, the gold rush and the growth of the logging industry, plus vignettes of the region's oppressed cultures, all wrapped up in an account of seven generations of a fictional family living in a house in the woods north of Mendocino.

title: Marguerite F. Karter Wed to H. R. Elisofon
description: Marguerite F. Karter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Karter of New York, and Howard Rory Elisofon, a son of George Elisofon of Brooklyn and the late Sylvia Elisofon, were married last evening at the Explorers Club in New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipsi performed the ceremony.

title: BLACK-AND-WHITE OUTSHINES COLOR
description: Recently I was invited to select the worthy entries for a juried exhibition to which anyone with a photograph and five dollars could submit. This is called ''jurying'' a show, but to my mind it amounts to being prosecutor, judge and jury simultaneously. Not exactly a fair trial, mind you, but then no one who enters such things really expects objectivity to rule.

title: TIME STANDS STILL
description: For years, architects and designers in major cities have been restoring and renovating buildings that date from early in this century. Evident from the street are highly polished stone facades, or those freshly painted in colors reproduced from original paint chips. And inside many residential buildings, apartments are also being renovated in ways that make them appear as though they had never been prey to decades of changing tastes.

title: BURIED TREASURE IN THE CITIES OF ROCK
description: One can only imagine the astonishment of 19th-century explorers upon finding under jungle creepers and desert sands carefully worked stone figures and large, complex structures. With ancient texts as their sole guides, they must have fancied that these cities of rock had sprung from the pages of classical literature, rather than the other way around. In FOOTSTEPS: Nine Archaeological Journeys of Romance and Discovery (Salem House, $24.95), Bruce Norman profiles the courageous and sometimes rapacious adventurers who laid the groundwork for modern archeological research. In 1817, face to face with crumbling mummies, Giovanni Belzoni crept through labyrinthine Egyptian pyramids. Others found the abandoned cities of Machu Picchu in Peru and southern Africa's Great Zimbabwe. ''Footsteps,'' a lavishly illustrated companion volume to a BBC series that has been shown on cable television in the United States, uncritically accepts the travelers' accounts of ignorance and treachery among the peoples they visited. Mr. Norman, the executive producer of the series, emphasizes the many difficulties the explorers endured, including the suspicions of local inhabitants that the Europeans intended to plunder buried treasure. In the end, their suspicions proved correct. Explorers filled the coffers of European museums with priceless relics. Belzoni reported that an Arab guide, ''on hearing of my fortunate success in collecting several valuable pieces . . . observed to me, that, if I persevered in my researches, I should have my throat cut.'' Undeterred, Belzoni carved his name into all the artifacts, seeking to insure that he'd never become as anonymous as their manufacturers.

title: Charms of Old Houses Lure Buyers
description: LURED by elaborate scrollwork, heavy oak floors and stained glass windows, more and more Connecticut residents have been buying 18th- and 19th-century houses.

title: MEXICO CANDIDATE TESTS U.S. WATERS
description: Although he is several months away from becoming president of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari is already moving behind the scenes to establish lines of communication with a force that always looms large in Mexican foreign relations: the United States.

title: On Choppy Water, Penn Captures Cup
description: The men's varsity heavyweight crew from Pennsylvania defeated Navy, Harvard and the Severn River this morning to gain possession of the Adams Cup for the second time in the last three years.

title: Food; JOYS FROM BRAZIL
description: Twenty-eight hours after leav-ing New York, I've sat on two airplanes, shook from side to side in the back seat of a car, putted across a river on a canopied skiff, stood on a ramshackle wooden bus and climbed a rutted, red-clay hill. All of this has brought me, at last, to the top of a bluff in a remote coastal town of Bahia, Brazil. It is the ultimate escape.

title: New Head of Stevens Sets Goals
description: DR. HAROLD J. RAVECHE, the next president of Stevens Institute of Technology, says that the nation was built on a foundation of strong education and that ''hands-on experience and studies'' can improve the quality of its future leaders.

title: Election Fever Grips Mexico (Yes, Mexico)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Epidemic of Meningitis Strikes Wide Areas of Africa
description: An epidemic of meningitis in central and western Africa has affected thousands of people and killed hundreds, but vaccination programs are controlling the spread, according to the United Nations Childrens Fund.

title: SEXISM AND THE SUPEREGO
description: LEAD: FREUD, WOMEN, AND MORALITY The Psychology of Good and Evil. By Eli Sagan. 270 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Communist Rock: Not Dead, Not Red
description: In late January, what seems to be the most popular rock band in the Soviet Union, Avtograf, arrived in North America for an eight-city tour, including a gig at Drums, the midtown club cum disco. In February, a friend returned from a month in Canton. She brought with her a cassette of a group called Fresh Air that is apparently the rage not only in its home city but in all of China (its songs are sung in Mandarin, not the Cantonese dialect).

title: A Pastiche of American Dishes
description: CINNAMON TEALS, according to the staff of this new Danbury restaurant, is named for a duck. It is also in a shopping complex called Cinnamon Plaza. To emphasize the theme, duck decoys decorate one wall, and the menu is graced with duck drawings.

title: Preventing Child Abuse By Educating Parents
description: LEAD: WITH child abuse on the rise in Connecticut, social workers are establishing new programs to educate parents in hopes of preventing violence against children.

title: At Centers, Generations Reunite
description: LEAD: AT the poker table in the Island Park Senior Citizens Center, 67-year-old Rose Calderone's silver earrings dangled below her short gray hair as she leaned forward to sweep in a pot of pennies. Across the table, her mother, Minnie Miglino, 86, who doesn't play but likes to watch, smiled in approval.

title: Affordable Housing Needn't Be Impossible Dream
description: I WAS alone in my kitchen one recent Sunday morning, reading an interview in the Long Island Weekly with David Emilita [ ''A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality'' ] . Upon reading his words about affordable housing, I wanted to stand up and applaud.

title: Streetscapes: General Theological Seminary; Restoration Drive Begun For Chelsea Landmark
description: The General Theological Seminary, on the block bounded by 20th to 21st Streets, Ninth to 10th Avenues, is a surprise to most New Yorkers who come suddenly upon the great green double quadrangle hidden by a perimeter of century-old dormitories and classrooms.

title: Befriending the Homeless With Clothing and Caring
description: There are now two fewer friends for the homeless on Long Island. Their departure leaves a gaping hole in the distribution of children's clothing to the needy.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
description: It is not any race horse who can achieve a 7-for-7 lifetime victory record over different racetracks, at various distances, against the best horses in the East. Along with these accomplishments, intelligence, honesty and heart are necessary for greatness. My 1988 Kentucky Derby choice embodies all of these qualities. His name is Private Terms. RICHARD M. ZWIRN New York

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COIN REDESIGN BILL PICKS UP SUPPORT
description: LEAD: Support is growing in Congress for enactment of legislation which would authorize new designs for regular issue United States coins. The measure now has the endorsement of 61 senators - a substantial majority - and 85 members of the House of Representatives.

title: SCREEN TEST By LINDA WELLS
description: Going to the beach used to be sim-ple. You headed off with a towel, a paperback book and a bottle of suntan lotion under your arm.

title: POISON PILL TRIAL WINDING TO CLOSE
description: By her daughter's account, Stella Nickell put cyanide in pain relief capsules to poison her husband of 12 years in an effort to gain as much as $176,000 in life insurance benefits.

title: Olympic Ideals Are Forgotten
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: PRO & CON: HOW MUCH GOVERNMENT SHOULD DO FOR PARENTS
description: TO meet the growing need of working parents for day care for their children, states are increasingly playing a role. Local governments, too, are taking a hand. But many believe that, as with public schooling, only the Government can insure affordable, dependable programs nationwide.

title: HOCKEY IS A LOT LIKE LIFE
description: LEAD: KING LEARY By Paul Quarrington. 232 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: ONE STRIKE ENDS, BUT 2D POLISH MILL REMAINS CRIPPLED
description: Pressure eased on the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today after workers at the steel and armaments plant here accepted a Government pay offer and ended a one-day strike.

title: A Contest Of Ideology On Campus
description: Two students at the University of Massachusetts here, one of them a Communist, have been barred from taking office as co-presidents of the student government.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Lanesborough, Mass.: Enclosed Mall Put on Hold
description: LEAD: Berkshire County's first enclosed regional shopping mall is ready for customers. But the Pyramid Companies postponed indefinitely the planned early-March opening because of complex permit problems.

title: Kevin White's Students: His Latest Constituency
description: In his 16 years as Mayor of Boston, Kevin H. White reviled the press, avoided the press and took delight in pointing out its errors. These days he teaches about the press and government.

title: Review/Dance; 'Utopia' Blends Life And Stage
description: Phyllis Lamhut's new ''Utopia,'' which opened on Thursday at the Westbeth Theater Center (151 Bank Street), will not disappoint those who have come to admire this veteran choreographer's comparatively recent forays into the darkness of history and the heart. It is a powerful dance that boasts an equally powerful and ambitious score by Ben Hazard and stunning performances from its six leads that are alone worth a trip to the theater.

title: Can River Projects Be Made Fish-Friendly?
description: Many residents of the metropolitan area know that the shad and the alewives and the weakfish living in the waters hereabouts are hardy creatures because they are, after all, New York fish and thus are survivors. They have been living in New York's bays, rivers and estuaries since long before the arrival of either the Half Moon or the Staten Island ferry.

title: Floating Garages Off Hudson Proposed
description: AS TRAFFIC congestion increases on Hudson River crossings and PATH commuters scour the Hudson County waterfront for some place to park their cars, a ferry company is proposing to moor floating parking lots along the riverfront.

title: In Nursing Homes, AIDS Safeguards
description: NURSING HOMES in the state have begun to adopt Federal recommendations for infection control designed to prevent the spread of AIDS among health workers.

title: Cronyn and Tandy Hailed By American Academy
description: Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, the peerless first couple of the American theater, were honored by the American Academy of Dramatic Arts last night at a gala tribute at the St. Regis Hotel.

title: Courtesy on the Lawn
description: Standing in the special visitors gallery last Wednesday as Prime Minister Brian Mulroney arrived on the south lawn of the White House was the comedian Red Skelton.

title: Marathon; Marathoners' Times Good as Gold?
description: With four miles to go, she knew the race was hers. With 100 yards to go, she looked more like a sprinter. Crossing the finish line in the fastest time by an American woman in almost three years, Margaret Groos looked fresh enough to head straight for the victory party.

title: Dukakis Campaign's 737 Jet Passes Special Safety Check
description: The Boeing 737 being used by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the model whose roof tore off in flight in Hawaii last week, underwent a special safety check today and was declared free of hazards.

title: Business and the Law; Outlook Cloudy On Securities Bills
description: PROSPECTS for changes in takeover and insider trading laws are rapidly diminishing on Capitol Hill, according to some legislators, regulators and lobbyists.

title: Taiwan Trade Talks End
description: United States trade negotiators ended four days of talks in Taiwan Friday, saying they had reached no agreement on the vital issues of copyright, tariff cuts and access for United States financial institutions.

title: Ending the Cold War
description: Seven prominent Americans and seven prominent Soviet officials have been meeting over the last three and a half years on a project entitled: How to End the Cold War.

title: Sports of The Times; How Devils Regrouped
description: THE goal came from nowhere, a looping shot, more or less chipped into the air, rising over a diving player, obscured by two grappling players, then fluttering over the right shoulder of Sean Burke, the goalie of the New Jersey Devils.

title: Why Fear the Speech of Foreigners?
description: Americans treasure the right to speak freely -for everyone except foreigners whose views the Government considers offensive. That's because of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952, a vestige of the McCarthy era that blights the nation's willingness to be a marketplace of ideas. Congressional efforts to overhaul this objectionable law at last should get a lift from a recent ruling by a United States Court of Appeals.

title: Dr. Marleen Meyers Wed to S. M. Rogovin, Lawyer
description: Dr. Marleen Iva Meyers and Stanley Marc Rogovin were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York by Rabbi David Posner.

title: Sri Lanka Blast Kills 26 on Bus
description: A bus filled with shoppers was blown apart today and at least 26 passengers were killed when Tamil rebels detonated explosives that had been buried in the ground, military officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: Bullish on Billy Beer
description: It is going on 11 years since the brother of President Jimmy Carter entered the suds business. Billy Beer caused something of a sensation when it was introduced, but 12 months later, in October 1978, Reynolds Metals bought nearly 9 million empty Billy cans and melted them, signaling the end for the brew.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * West Germany's eight bourses reported that trading volume fell in April by nearly 28 percent, to 163.7 billion marks, or $95.4 billion, from 226.5 billion marks, or $135 billion, in March. There were only 19 trading days in April, compared with 23 in March. Also, average daily stock sales in April fell to 8.6 billion marks, or $5.1 billion, from 9.8 billion marks, or $5.8 billion, in March.

title: U.S. Escorts Gulf Tankers
description: United States warships escorted three Kuwaiti oil tankers northward through the Persian Gulf today after reports that Iranian gunboats were sighted near the Strait of Hormuz, maritime officials said. The convoy was the first since Washington announced on Friday that it would protect neutral ships in the gulf. The convoy was expected to pass through the Strait of Hormuz tonight, the officials said. The convoy was made up of the tankers Gas King, Rover and Golden Monarch, the destroyer Merrill and the missile frigate John H. Sides, the officials said.

title: Stephens: Winning Colors Will Fail
description: Forty Niner erased any doubts about his fitness for the Kentucky Derby Saturday with a fine one-mile workout this morning, and his trainer then predicted that the colt would help keep the filly Winning Colors from winning the race.

title: Question Box; Ray Corio
description: QUESTION: Why is the American League sometimes referred to as the junior circuit?

title: Review/Theater; A Small-Scale Romantic Musical Moves Uptown
description: ''Romance Romance,'' lately the littlest big musical Off Off Broadway, has made it uptown, in a slightly enhanced production that loses nothing of the charm and intelligence of the original and gains a thoroughly winning performance by Alison Fraser.

title: Market Place; Revising Realty Partnership Plans
description: SPONSORS of limited real estate partnerships are like badly wounded soldiers. Having been dealt a blow by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and by further tax changes last year, the sponsors are ever so slowly recovering.

title: Reds Fans' Assault Leaves Bad Taste
description: Three hours before the game, Dave Pallone's official blue blazer hung on the door of the umpires' dressing room in the basement of Riverfront Stadium. It was wrapped in a local dry cleaner's plastic and was stapled with a receipt showing the Reds had picked up the bill for $3.

title: Maxwell Bid Reported
description: Robert Maxwell, chairman of the Maxwell Communications Corporation, is trying to buy a West German publishing company that prints dictionaries and encyclopedias, a local newspaper said. The Saturday edition of the Mannheimer Morgen quoted a spokesman for Bibliographisches Institute and F.A. Brockhaus A.G. as saying that the company wanted to resist a takeover by a foreign company. The spokesman added that the publishing company's supervisory board would respond to Maxwell's offer by the middle of this month. No details were given on the value of the bid, which was made April 6.

title: Smokers Adjust to New York Curbs
description: Alan Dyer, a 27-year-old computer technician, walks the city streets trailing a fog of cigarette smoke because the New York City's new anti-smoking law forbids him to smoke in his office. Ed Kelly, a 52-year-old operations officer at the Israel Discount Bank of New York, regularly stands outside the bank's entrance like an underdressed doorman, puffing away at a quick lunchtime cigarette.

title: Thai Fishermen Again Brutalizing Vietnam Refugees, Survivors Say
description: Vietnamese refugees sailing for Malaysia say they are being brutalized and robbed by Thai fishermen roaming the Gulf of Thailand and the South China Sea.

title: Beijing to Close Top Ideological Journal
description: Red Flag, the theoretical journal of China's Communist Party for three decades and long a stronghold of hard-line Marxists, will shut down this summer, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: WHO RAISED WHAT
description: Reports to the Federal Election Commission tell how much money each candidate has raised. Chart showing 33 contests, page B8.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical Buildings Inc., Milwaukee, a builder and designer of health-care facilities, named Michael A. Carlson president and chief executive to replace John Lundeen, who has resigned but who will continue in an executive capacity for new-business development.

title: Killing Rent Protections Doesn't Build Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Condor Chick Doing Well
description: The first California condor conceived in captivity ate a hearty diet of chopped mice today as keepers kept a close eye on the chick that boosted the number of the endangered birds to 28. ''The appetite of the bird is very good,'' said Martha Baker, spokeswoman for the San Diego Wild Animal Park, where the chick was hatched with human help on Friday. ''So far so good,'' Ms. Baker said. ''We're not through the most critical period, which is 72 hours.''

title: A Late Starter Punches Toward Seoul
description: IT is the stuff of fantasies, something that Jerome James might daydream about while cruising the streets of Sioux Falls, S.D., in his police car.

title: Britain Studies A Time Shift
description: Britain is considering whether to synchronize its clocks with its partners in the European Community to smooth the way for European trade liberalization in 1992. The issue was addressed Friday in a debate in Parliament, but no final decision was reached.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Companies Being Acquired
description: There is a rush on to acquire sales promotion companies, and it must be a reflection of the fact that larger slices of the marketing pie are being diverted to that discipline.

title: 5 West German Groups Raise Growth Estimate
description: West Germany's five leading economic research institutes have raised their forecast for the country's growth this year, in line with Government predictions, but they foresee a slowdown in 1989 because of sagging domestic demand.

title: Baby Talk for Runners
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the reigning Olympic marathan champion and the mother of a 7-month-old daughter, will headline a pregnancy and fitness clinic in New York on Saturday, May 7. Also offering suggestions on how women can stay in shape during and after pregnancy will be Dr. MOna Shangold, author of ''The Complete Sports Medicine Book for Wome,'' Glroia Averbuch, a national-class runner and author of ''Free to Be the Complete Athlete,'' and Cameron Kelly, a specialist in prenatal exercise programs.

title: TV Notes
description: Hollywood Creatures

title: The Client Whom Ad Agencies Hate to Love
description: Pacy Markham says that someday he will write his memoirs of two decades in the advertising business, and the chapter devoted to his trauma and torment will be entitled, ''Sentenced to the Gallos.''

title: SENATE CAMPAIGNS RAISING HUGE SUMS FOR RACES IN FALL
description: Eight months before a general election that will probably include some of the most costly Senate contests ever waged, the 27 incumbents facing re-election had amassed $63 million to finance their campaigns.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who's a Terrorist, and When?
description: With remarkable speed, yesterday's terrorists turn into today's statesmen. Consider the Middle East rebellion by a stateless people against an occupying army whose soldiers were special targets in a campaign to seize world attention.

title: Gooden Silences Reds, 11-0
description: In the end, after all the increased security and worry about another outbreak of rowdyism in the stands, the Mets provided the most effective form of crowd control today. It took them barely five innings to quiet Riverfront Stadium and just one more to begin emptying it.

title: Afghan Doctor Tells of Nation's Mental Scars
description: Each Afghan refugee bears the reactions and disturbed mental life of war and exile, an Afghan psychiatrist says.

title: Ortega Denounces 'Pseudo-Leaders' of Labor
description: With Nicaragua facing its first major labor conflict since the 1979 revolution, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra denounced opposition labor organizers today as ''pseudo-leaders who receive money from the C.I.A.''

title: Devils Reaching Farther
description: THE ultimate for the Devils this season was to make the playoffs. Then the ultimate became being the Patrick Division champions. Now, the ultimate goal is to have their names engraved on hockey's most coveted prize.

title: U.S. and Japan In Farm Talks
description: Japan's agriculture minister will remain in Washington in an effort to break the deadlock in negotiations over barriers against the sale of more United States beef and oranges in Japan.

title: Federal Study to Label Nicotine as Addictive
description: An upcoming report by Surgeon General C. Everett Koop will declare that nicotine is an addictive drug, the head of the Federal Office of Smoking and Health said today.

title: Sensitive to Suspicion
description: Pentagon officials in charge of developing the space-based defense system terminated the funds for an advisory panel of computer experts just as a Senate subcommittee was about to make public the findings of an investigation into possible improprieties involving panel members and multimillion-dollar research contracts.

title: U.S. PLAN FOR LEASE IN SPACE OPPOSED
description: A group of key Senators has rejected President Reagan's proposal for government leasing of much of a no-frills space station that would be commercially developed and owned. The Senators instead ordered an independent assessment of the proposed station's merits.

title: 'PRINCESS' LABEL LINKED TO BIGOTRY
description: A year and a half ago, Michael Brodsky, president of the Hillel chapter at Syracuse University, asked Dr. Gary Spencer to speak on the topic of JAP's, or Jewish American Princesses.

title: Emphasizing Bygone Days Of Bunnyism
description: A few women displayed rabbit ears on headbands. Many wore dresses notable for their decolletage, and nearly all teetered on stiletto heels similar to those that were once part of their uniform.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about assistant chefs misstated the background of a chef at Montrachet in Manhattan and misspelled his name. The chef, Brian Whitmer, became the head chef at Montrachet without first serving as sous-chef there.

title: The Boom in Home Health Care
description: In the face of rising hospital and nursing home costs, more Americans are receiving sophisticated medical care at home, from cancer chemotherapy drugs to kidney dialysis.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; At Networks, Cheap Is Chic, So Please Pardon the Robots
description: ONE recent Saturday night, Connie Chung, the anchor of the weekend version of ''NBC Nightly News,'' was reading an urgent story about the Middle East, when she began to disappear.

title: Aliens Leave Shadows In the Race for Amnesty
description: Antonio Garcia Gonzalez has spent most of the past year shining shoes, selling Mexican newspapers and candies and smiling a nearly toothless smile outside the legalization office.

title: Jackson Says There'll Be 'No Deal' at Democratic Convention
description: For those wondering about his intentions at the Democratic National Convention, the Rev. Jesse Jackson offered this today:

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Jordan Scores 55 In Bulls' Triumph
description: Michael Jordan scored 55 points to become the first player to score 50 or more in two consecutive National Basketball Association playoff games as Chicago beat Cleveland, 106-101, today. The Bulls took a 2-games-to-0 lead in their Eastern Conference series.

title: Housing Jersey's Homeless: Counties Pushed to Bear Load
description: Almost 800 homeless families in New Jersey are facing eviction from the motels where they have been living as the state moves to enforce a limit on emergency housing.

title: Review/Pop; Up From the Malls, Tiffany on Tour
description: Last summer, Tiffany was singing 20-minute sets at shopping malls with her backup on tape. Now, after four hit singles have helped sell four million copies of her debut album, ''Tiffany,'' the 16-year-old singer is fronting a band on her first full-fledged concert tour, which came to the Westbury Music Fair tonight. Before a shrieking audience, mostly young girls with parents in tow, an ever-smiling Tiffany showed the aplomb of an adult pop star as she shook hands, received flowers and other tributes, even kissed a few toddlers. Meanwhile, she sang like a talented 16-year-old, diligent but limited.

title: Golf; Moody's Putt Wins Legends Playoff
description: Tommy Aaron, the 1973 Masters champion, produced a legendary shot today when he holed out from 115 yards at the par-4 16th hole on the Onion Creek Club for an eagle that led to a playoff in the 11th annual Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf.

title: G. E. Mylonas, 89, Archeologist Who Led Greek Excavations, Dies
description: George E. Mylonas, an internationally recognized authority on Greek archeology and a longtime teacher at Washington University in St. Louis, died April 15 after suffering a heart attack in Athens, where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: Money Managers Stress Rockefeller Expertise
description: Two members of the Rockefeller family, David Elliman and his brother, Christopher J. Elliman, have teamed up with Cynthia Flowers and Arthur S. Penn to form a registered investment advisory and management firm called Stillrock Management. Since 1981, David Elliman has been running a firm called Elmrock Inc., devoted exclusively to the financial affairs of the Rockefeller family.

title: Warmth in Waders
description: A classic boot-foot wader made of rubber is all that most fly fishermen need to complement the cache of tackle they take with them to the river. But for the sportsman who wants comfort and warmth, there's the boot-foot wader with a neoprene top.

title: No Accord By OPEC On Oil Cuts
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended four days of meetings early today without an agreement on a production cut. OPEC officials said the cartel would meet again next month. The failure here is bound to depress oil prices by at least $1 a barrel, an analyst said, because the oil markets had been anticipating some kind of decision to reduce output, which would have propped up oil prices. The lack of an agreement on production cuts is also a political triumph for Saudi Arabia over its traditional OPEC rivals, Iran and Algeria, which came here adamant about imposing such cuts on the group. Saudis Are Pleased

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Information Resources' Shopping Cart With TV
description: Information Resources of Chicago, the nation's third-largest marketing research company, is making an interesting diversification move: into TV-equipped supermarket carts. It is called ''VideOcart,'' with a capital O. That's right, carts that have 6-by-8-inch video screens mounted on the handles and cued electronically to run commercials when they pass the shelfspace of an advertiser's products.

title: Two Palestinian Groups Clash in Lebanon
description: Rival Palestinian factions renewed clashes this evening in Beirut's Shatila refugee district, Palestinians said.

title: Christian Broadcasting Unit Drops 2 Swaggart TV Shows
description: The Christian Broadcasting Network has canceled two shows produced by the Jimmy Swaggart ministry because Mr. Swaggart refused to stop appearing on them, a spokesman said today.

title: The Tie-Up of '88
description: I am writing this with an old-fashioned, user-hostile pen while riding, if that verb can be used, in a New York City taxicab.

title: Beazer Group Discloses Holdings
description: More than two-thirds of the outstanding common shares of the Koppers Company are owned by or have been tendered to the investment group that made a $1.7 billion hostile takeover bid for the company, the group said.

title: Mary Fisher Wed To an Executive
description: Mary Alice Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Agnew Fisher of Greenwich, Conn., and David Kinne Carmichael, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Carmichael of Northford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Irving Bidder Extends Offer
description: The Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had extended its tender offer for the Irving Bank Corporation until Friday, when a proxy fight is expected at Irving's annual meeting.

title: Dr. Diane Benezra and Peter Jay Kurshan Marry
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Dr. Diane Amy Benezra, a daughter of Edith Benezra of Lauderhill, Fla., and the late Max Benezra, was married yesterday to Peter Jay Kurshan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Kurshan of Woodmere, L.I., and New York. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion officiated.

title: Seattle Symphony Players Vote to Change Unions
description: In a move that could affect musicians around the country, members of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra have voted to leave the American Federation of Musicians and join a new union for representation in contract talks this year.

title: Big Board Expresses Optimism After Testing Computers
description: The New York Stock Exchange will know within a few days whether an unusual test of its computer systems was a success, according to officials for the Big Board.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Equipment Sales Increase
description: An Increase of 8.9 percent last year in consumer dollar purchases of athletic footwear and sporting goods equipment - camping, exercise, racquets, baseball/softball and inflatables - were among year-end findings of a 1987 quarterly sales trends study announced by the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association.

title: Volkswagen Price Rise
description: Volkswagen United States said it would raise the prices of its Fox models by an average of 5 percent, or $359 a vehicle, effective Monday. The company attributed the increase to economic pressures in Brazil, where the car is manufactured.

title: At a Le Pen Rally, Little Fraternite for Mitterrand
description: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the ultra-right National Front, called on his supporters today not to vote for President Francois Mitterrand on May 8, but he declined to endorse the Socialist head of state's conservative challenger, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS INCREASE IN SALES OF ARMS OVERSEAS
description: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that it wants to increase arms sales abroad substantially this year to more than $15 billion worth of weapons. This is $3.3 billion more than the United States sold to other countries last year.

title: Bridge
description: With five months remaining before the 1988 World Team Olympiad, scheduled in Venice in October, national organizations are making the moves needed to select their teams. The United States teams will be determined by playoff matches scheduled in Memphis in June.

title: Review/Television; Supreme Court Justices: America's Judicial Stars
description: The Supreme Court was once remote and mysterious, the Federal equivalent of Mount Olympus. It may even be argued that the remoteness was a source of power: Olympus could command in a way that politicians could not. A Justice had a divine calling. Divinity, however, is hard to sustain in a media age. ''This Honorable Court,'' a two-part documentary beginning on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, says Justices are human beings.

title: In Northern California, The Music Sounds Just as It Used To
description: Bustling from cult marginality into the mainstream, the original-instruments movement has attracted greater attention than any other recent trend in the performance of classical music. And no part of the United States has a more active, intensely interconnected early-music community than the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: The Money Race: 1988 Senate Candidates
