title: Now Russia Wants to Learn The Way U.S. Managers Do
description: Professors from America's leading business schools may soon be teaching Western business practices to top civil servants and managers in the Soviet Union.

title: Sports World Specials
description: A Blaze of Glory

title: Economy Increased Pace in April, Purchasers Say
description: The economy expanded at a faster rate in April after three months of slow growth, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled to be released today.

title: New Famous Amos Owner Wants Bigger Market Share
description: ''Mental real estate'' is how Jeffery B. Baer, a Denver investor and entrepreneur, described the reason for his family's acquisition of the Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookie Corporation ''It needs to be developed,'' Mr. Baer, Amos's new chairman, said after the Friday announcement. ''It's not a piece of ground, but the principle is the same.''

title: Analysts See Higher Bond Yields
description: The economic forces that have pushed up interest rates by more than three-quarters of a point since early March could become more intense this quarter.

title: National League; Cards Hammer Dodgers, 9-0
description: John Tudor, making his second start of the season, pitched six hitless innings today before he was removed for a pinch-hitter, and the St. Louis Cardinals had 15 hits en route to a 9-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Max Feldberg, Retailer, 90
description: Max Feldberg, a founder of the Zayre Corporation, a large national retail company, died of heart failure last Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 90 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Robberies Drop 26% Since Worst Year
description: Robbery, which some experts say is the best indicator of how safe a city is, has dropped 26 percent in New York City since 1981, and the police attribute the drop to new anti-robbery teams, computer tracking of robbery patterns and other recent innovations.

title: Auto Racing; Parsons Gains His First Nascar Victory
description: Phil Parsons won the first Nascar race of his career today, holding off Bobby Allison and Geoff Bodine to win the Winston 500 at Alabama International Motor Speedway.

title: USG Suitor Alters Terms Of Its Bid
description: In the latest round in its battle to gain control of the USG Corporation, Desert Partners L.P. said yesterday that it would pay $45 a share in cash for 39 million outstanding shares if a friendly deal could be worked out.

title: Standing Small in Central America
description: When Ronald Reagan took office, his advisers called for the smack of strong measures in Central America. This President wanted results, they said, not human rights reports or Panama Canal treaties. Results meant getting rid of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and crushing guerrilla forces in El Salvador's civil war. Above all, results meant making sure that the United States stood tall and won respect in the region Mr. Reagan habitually described as ''our frontyard.''

title: Review/Operetta; Sincere Zeal And Hamminess In 'Pinafore'
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan, which presents a year-round operetta season, has weathered hard times in recent years. In 1986, after the death of its founder and the loss of its theater, the company suspended operations under the weight of a hefty deficit. But a new board put LOOM's finances straight, and last June the company was reborn. Now residing at Playhouse 91, 316 East 91st Street, the troupe has just finished a run of one of its specialties, Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H. M. S. Pinafore.''

title: Olympic Notebook; Cuban Participation Remains Very Iffy
description: Expectations of Cuba attending the Seoul Olympics are changing again, in fact, this time they are diminishing.

title: INSIDE
description: House Aide Falls to Death The chief aide to a Maryland Congressman plunged from the 24th-floor of a hotel in Manhattan the day an article on his activities was published in Washington. Page B1. 26 Slain on Sri Lanka Bus At least 26 passengers were killed on a Sri Lankan bus when Tamil rebels set off buried explosives beneath it, military officials said. Page A3. Amnesty: Now or Never Tens of thousands of illegal aliens, overcoming doubt, fear or lack of money, are applying at the last minute for legal residence. Page A16. Swaggart Shows Canceled The Christian Broadcasting Network dropped two Jimmy Swaggart shows after the defrocked minister refused not to appear on them. Page B10. Deadline on Homeless Almost 800 homeless families in New Jersey face eviction from motels as the state moves to enforce a limit on emergency housing. Page B1.

title: The Metropolitan Museum's Diplomat at the Top
description: He's no longer Mr. Ambassador, though he jokes that he occasionally uses the title ''to get dinner reservations.'' Yet William H. Luers, the president of the Metropolitan Museum and a former United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia and Venezuela, still plays a diplomat's role.

title: In Vietnam, Craft Project Breaks Mold
description: Although the world has heard how resilient Vietnamese refugees have transformed neighborhoods in Paris, Chicago or Los Angeles over the last decade, the story of Thu Duc didn't get publicity.

title: Blunder Costly in Yankees' 5-1 Loss
description: It happened in the seventh inning, in a game the Yankees were already losing, on a day that was cold and dreary and mostly uneventful. And when the afternoon was done, something did not seem right.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Lendl Overcomes Edberg: Ivan Lendl came back from a shaky start to defeat Stefan Edberg yesterday in the final of the $500,000 Challenge in Atlanta. Edberg won the first set, 6-2, but Lendl took the next two sets, 6-1, 6-3, to win the exhibition tournament, held at Horseshoe Bend Country Club. Lendl won $150,000; Edberg took $100,000.(AP) Agassi Pounds Arias: Top-seeded Andre Agassi defeated Jimmy Arias yesterday to win the United States men's clay-court championship on Isle of Palms, S.C. Agassi beat Arias, 6-2, 6-2, two days after his 18th birthday. He earned $38,000. (AP) Shriver Tops Sukova: Pam Shriver defeated Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-1, to win the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo yesterday. Shriver collected $50,000; Sukova earned $22,500. (AP) Carlsson Takes West German Title: Kent Carlsson of Sweden defeated Henri Leconte of France, 6-2, 6-1, 6-4, to win the German Open in Hamburg yesterday. (AP) Horse Racing Clabber Girl Rallies for Victory: Clabber Girl came from the back of the field yesterday to carry 117 pounds under Jose Santos to a three-quarter-length victory in the Top Flight Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. The 5-year-old, Florida-bred daughter of Alydar-Jedina raced the one and an eighth miles in 1:49 2/5 to reach the wire just ahead of Psyched. Arena Football Successful Start for Knights: In Los Angeles, Jim Crocicchia threw three of his eight touchdown passes in the final quarter Saturday night to lead the New York Knights to a 60-52 victory over the Los Angeles Cobras in the first game for both league expansion teams. (AP) Marathon Brother Edges Brother: Twenty-seven-year-old Mark Whitney of Elmhurst, Queens, pulled away from his younger brother, Andy, to win the Long Island Marathon in 2 hours 30 minutes 18 seconds yesterday at Eisenhower Park, East Meadow, L.I. Andy, 26, of Stony Brook, L.I., crossed the finish line in 2:31:07. Stephanie Kessler of New York was the women's gold medalist in 3:13:07. Track and Field Title to Rutgers: Rutgers scored 147 points yesterday to win the team title in the third annual Women's Metropolitan Intercollegiate outdoor championships at Columbia's Baker Field. Virginia Young won three field events - the shot-put, the discus throw and the hammer throw - to lead St. John's to second place with 114 points.

title: 61 Scientists Are Chosen For National Academy
description: The National Academy of Sciences, often described as the nation's most prestigious honorary society for scientists, has announced the election of 61 new members.

title: Young Crack Addicts Find There's No Help for Them
description: Growing numbers of poor, young teen-agers are abusing crack in New York City, but there is practically no place for parents or social-service agencies to send them for drug treatment, according to experts in drug abuse and youth issues.

title: More Credit Is Due To Catholic Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: 100 Children to Dance
description: One hundred children from Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute will perform in ''Dancing the New Stories'' on May 10 at Alice Tully Hall. The event, directed by Mr. d'Amboise and presented by the institute and Lincoln Center's Meet-the-Artist program, will include a tribute to Irving Berlin, based on his song ''God Bless America,'' on the eve of his 100th birthday. The program will also include the world premieres of ''Sea Mother's Son,'' based on a one-act play by Eugene O'Neill, and ''Grandma's Mattress,'' drawn from the story of an immigrant woman. ''Free Rides of the Planet,'' based on a poem by E. L. Doctorow and set to music by David Amram, will also be performed. Performances are at 10:30 A.M., which is sold out, and noon. Tickets are $8; group rates are available. Information: 877-1800, Extension 547.

title: Celtics Waste No Time
description: Rick Pitino threw the coaching book at the Boston Celtics today. The Knicks trapped and they pressed. They tried a small lineup and a big lineup. They played Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, their 7-foot centers, with three guards.

title: Tennis; An Older McEnroe Just May Be Wiser
description: WITH his racquet bag slung over his shoulder, John McEnroe was in no particular hurry as he walked from the practice court to the locker room at the Horseshoe Bend Country Club in suburban Atlanta last week, pleasant surroundings on what he hopes is the road back to the top of the tennis rankings. Fans wished him well, a few politely asked for his autograph. It was the kind of random sampling of public opinion that reaffirmed McEnroe's contention that there are more people rooting for him than is generally believed.

title: House Aide Dies in Plunge From a Hotel
description: The chief of staff to a Maryland Congressman died yesterday when he plunged from a 24th-floor window of the Helmsley Palace hotel in Manhattan, the police said. They said it was apparently a suicide.

title: Publishers Add Zeros To Book Bids
description: Only a few years after vowing never again to throw big bucks after big books, the publishing industry is spending huge sums in pursuit of authors. And while the risks are as enormous as they used to be, the way the big money is spent today is significantly different.

title: Review/City Ballet; Comedy and Art in 2 New Works
description: The mood picked up Saturday night with the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival at the New York State Theater. There were two new works: ''The Unanswered Question,'' a poetic fantasy by Eliot Feld to Charles Ives's music, and ''Into the Hopper,'' a comedy piece choreographed by Bart Cook to William Bolcom's music.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Team Joins Keye/Donna To Open in New York
description: Tod Seisser and Jay Taub, one of three creative-director teams at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, have left the agency to help a Los Angeles agency try the difficult job of gaining a foothold in New York.

title: Bolinas Journal; Skateboards Ruffle A Hippie Paradise
description: Better known for defending Black Panthers, Hell's Angels and members of the Symbionese Liberation Army, J. Tony Serra has lately directed his anti-establishment advocacy toward protecting a skateboard ramp that his sons built and the neighbors want torn down.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Turns Seductive For Watches
description: HOW strange it is that an adver= tiser with a budget of only $1 million for television should be planning to use 60-second spots instead of something shorter to make the money go further - get more messages for the buck.

title: May Day Marches on 2 Sides of Berlin Wall
description: Thousands of marchers on both sides of the Berlin wall marked May Day within a mile of each other, with both groups carrying placards bearing Communist slogans and both under the watch of huge police forces, but otherwise worlds apart.

title: Fitness; Exercies and Healthy Diet Lead Crusade Against Cholesterol
description: ANYONE who is serious about fitness must eventually confront the fat, or lipids, in his or her blood. An ambitious weekly exercise effort aimed at a healthy heart can provide a false sense of overall fitness if blood lipids are out of kilter.

title: British Trade Deficit Cut
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed unexpectedly and sharply in March to a seasonally adjusted $1.61 billion from $2.48 billion in February, the Government said Friday. Nevertheless, the deficit was much wider than the deficit a year ago, which came to $703 million. Britain's total trade deficit also narrowed sharply. That figure, which includes merchandise, services, overseas investment earnings and transfer payments, showed a $478 million deficit in March compared with a $1.35 billion deficit in February and a $556 million surplus in March 1987, the Department of Trade and Industry said.

title: Agency Plays Pervasive Role in High Court Case
description: There is a little-known but powerful section of the Justice Department, the Office of Legal Counsel, that serves as the executive branch's brain trust on the most fundamental issues of Presidential power.

title: Study Is Cautious on China's Growth
description: China is fast developing into one of the world's leading exporters, chiefly to finance its growing demand for food imports, the Central Intelligence Agency reported today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Most Arabs holding jobs in Israel have showed up for work regularly, except for the most violent weeks of the Palestinian uprising, according to the Government. That frustrates the uprising's leadership. Page A1

title: Robin H. Winter Becomes a Bride
description: Robin Hally Winter, a daughter of Mrs. Howard Norton Blitman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and Dr. Leo Winter Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Erik Ferens Tinkhauser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emerich Rudolf Tinkhauser of Freeport, L.I., and Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: DUKAKIS SAYS BUSH HAS BLANK RECORD
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today assailed Vice President Bush for campaigning as if his opponent were Jimmy Carter and said Mr. Bush's record was ''a blank slate'' and therefore hard to judge.

title: A Writer Turns Shards of a Life Into a History
description: Eduardo Galeano, a novelist from Uruguay who has completed a subjective, fragmentary and unconventional three-volume history of the Americas, has what might be called a tragic sense of life.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 42.9% Gain for Quarter At Grey Advertising
description: Grey Advertising released its first-quarter earnings on Friday, and they were good enough to elicit a cautionary note from Edward H. Meyer, its chairman, who said that while he appreciated the performance, he doesn't want shareholders to expect similar percent gains during the rest of the year.

title: On Your Own: Tennis; Give Your Racquet A Tuneup for Outdoors
description: WOULD you drive off on a cross-country trip this spring or summer without getting your car tuned up first? Probably not. And you shouldn't embark on an active schedule of outdoor tennis without getting your racquet tuned up.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on April 22 incorrectly characterized the plans of Burt Sugarman's lawyer, Edward Brodsky. Mr. Brodksy said he would appear in Federal court in Richmond contesting a move by Media General Inc. to have Mr. Sugarman's lawsuit dismissed.

title: At Texas Air, Safety and Public Take a Back Seat; Poor Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Who Quit Cites Avon's Smaller Focus
description: John S. Chamberlin, who resigned last week as president and chief operating officer in an unexpected development at Avon Products Inc., said yesterday that the move was mostly the result of changes in Avon's business since he took his post three years ago.

title: At Texas Air, Safety and Public Take a Back Seat; Standards Sought
description: To the Editor:

title: Lukas's Filly Looming Large in Kentucky Derby
description: SIX months ago at Hollywood Park, D. Wayne Lukas played five aces and still kept a trump up his sleeve.

title: Rona Silver Married To Dr. Kevin Loshak
description: At Temple Beth Am in Merrick, L.I., Rona Silver, the daughter of Jean Silver of Merrick and the late Stanley W. Silver, was married yesterday to Dr. Kevin Loshak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Loshak, also of Merrick. Rabbi Ronald N. Brown officiated. Mrs. Loshak, a sales marketing planner in advertising at The New York Times, graduated from the State University at Albany, as did her husband. She is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at New York University. Her mother is a fund-raiser for the UJA-Federation of New York. Her father was the executive vice president of April Industries, a construction and agricultural concern in San Juan, P.R.

title: Roar of the Lion Echoes In Land of the Longhorn
description: In Texas, the land of longhorns and mustangs, the talk is all of lions.

title: Let the Healing Begin On the West Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in Exports Spurs Job Boom in Midwest
description: Spurred by the declining value of the dollar, a resulting pickup in exports and a rapid upgrading of its factories, the industrial establishment of the Midwest has begun almost overnight to catch up with the the rest of the country's economic recovery.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is my last chance. I know if I don't at least try, I could be sent back to El Salvador, and that is worse.'' - Maria Sanchez of Houston on the alien amnesty program that ends Wednesday. [ A16:4. ]

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 1,1988: MONDAY

title: Celtics Teaching Difficult Lessons
description: Coach Rick Pitino stood in a hall at the Boston Garden, sifting through the ashes of the Knicks' second playoff loss. Nearby, Coach K. C. Jones was explaining how his Celtics had set the fire.

title: Dr. Louis Potters Weds Dr. Lenore J. Brancato
description: At St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Dr. Lenore Jasmine Brancato, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Brancato of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Louis Potters, a son of Mrs. Milton Potters of South Orange, N.J., and the late Dr. Potters. The Rev. Stanley Moseley, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: A Buckeye's Endorsement
description: When Vice President Bush visited Ohio State University, he picked up one legendary Buckeye's endorsement from beyond the grave.

title: Bennett Misreads Stanford's 'Classics'
description: LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, who has done so much to encourage exaggerated rhetoric, recently traveled to Palo Alto, Calif., to take on Stanford University. In a speech, he claimed the university had been ''brought low by the very forces which modern universities came into being to oppose - ignorance, irrationality and intimidation.

title: Confessions of a TV Junkie
description: LEAD: For many years, I worked at Dial, a magazine about public television.

title: Laura Kavesh, a Columnist, Is Married
description: Laura Beatrice Kavesh, a columnist for The Chicago Tribune, and Dr. Steven Stern, an assistant professor of psychiatry and psychology at the Northwestern University Medical School, were married yesterday in Chicago. Rabbi Michael Siegel performed the ceremony at the Anshe Emet Synagogue.

title: For Burma, Peace Talks in a Neutral Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Robertson Backers Spark Melee at Meeting
description: A district Republican convention here turned into a melee when supporters of Pat Robertson clashed with backers of Vice President Bush, officials said.

title: East Bloc Aircraft Deal
description: Interflug Airline, the East German carrier, has agreed to buy two Airbus A-310s, but the deal needs approval from the Western alliance's agency, known as Cocom, that regulates technology sales to Communist countries, Monday's edition of the weekly Der Spiegel said.

title: West's Envoys End Boycott Of May Day Fete in Moscow
description: Western ambassadors attended the annual May Day parade in Moscow today for the first time in eight years, ending a boycott prompted by the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Winfield Trade On Hold
description: George Steinbrenner's three-way deal involving Dave Winfield, which would send the Yankee outfielder to Toronto and bring Kevin Bass to New York, may have struck an unforeseen obstacle: Lou Piniella.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: At Texas Air, Safety and Public Take a Back Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins' Tenacity Returns
description: TERRY O'REILLY, the Bruins' bully-turned-coach, actually cringed his way through the series with Montreal that earned Boston the privilege of facing the Devils in the Prince of Wales Conference championship series, which begins tonight.

title: Israeli Punished in Arab's Death
description: The deputy commander of an Israeli Army unit was suspended today after one of his men shot and killed a Palestinian in the West Bank village of Faqua, the army said.

title: Belfast Journal; The Laurels of Peace Were Green (for a Season)
description: When the two Nobel laureates lost their aura a decade ago and the throngs of peace marchers drifted away from the ghettos, there was no shortage of critics to gloat over the failure of ''the fur coat brigade.''

title: Suspect Held in Fatal Clubbing Dies in Custody
description: A man with a history of mental illness, who apparently went berserk and clubbed a woman to death with a two-by-four in Harlem Saturday, collapsed in a crowded cell at Police Headquarters yesterday and died soon afterward.

title: 3 British Servicemen Are Killed In I.R.A. Attacks in Netherlands
description: Three British servicemen were killed and three wounded in a bombing and a shooting in the Netherlands today, and the Irish Republican Army said it had carried out the two attacks.

title: American League; Athletics Win 7th Straight
description: Stan Javier drove in two runs with a bases-loaded single, and Mark McGwire doubled in two more runs during a six-run ninth inning today as Oakland rallied to beat the Cleveland Indians, 8-4, for the Athletics' seventh straight victory.

title: One Dies, 4 Hurt In Copter Crash Into East River
description: One person was killed and four others were injured yesterday when a sightseeing helicopter crashed into the cold East River minutes before it was to land at the 34th Street heliport in Manhattan.

title: Pro Football; Jets' Fences Need Mending

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Keeper of That Statistical Song and Dance
description: Samuel M. Ehrenhalt has an odd passion for statistics. Nothing sets him to dancing like a good strong quarterly report in employment. A steep trend line in new-business formations makes him break into song.

title: Treasury to Announce Size of Refunding
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed by an auction of one-year bills on Thursday. On Wednesday the Treasury is expected to announce the size of next week's quarterly refunding. Most analysts expect the Treasury will sell between $26 billion and $27 billion of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: Outdoors: Wily Wild Turkeys
description: THE pleasures of hunting wild turkeys are certainly not confined to shooting these wonderful birds.

title: Trade Bill Options: Pass, Fail or Punt

title: Furor Over Air Canada Offering
description: When the Canadian Government announced last month that it would offer 45 percent of the equity in Air Canada, the state-owned airline, to the public, it stirred a political furor. In the House of Commons, Edward Broadbent, a leading opposition figure with the New Democratic Party, denounced the move as ''a triumph of Conservative ideology over good, common Canadian sense.''

title: Rally on Knight Remarks
description: About 300 people marched on the Indiana University campus tonight, demanding that Bob Knight, the school's basketball coach, apologize publicly for his televised statement on rape and stress. The protesters also called on administrators to reprimand Knight and to make rape-awareness workshops mandatory for athletic teams.

title: New York Plans New Aid for Mothers on Welfare
description: New York State is moving to set up a program that gives thousands of poor, single mothers guaranteed child-support payments and new incentives to get off the welfare rolls.

title: 500 Clash With Police in Gdansk Amid May Day Protests in Poland
description: About 500 people clashed with the police in the northern city of Gdansk today, and official May Day parades in several other Polish cities were countered by demonstrators bearing banners of the banned Solidarity trade union.

title: County Aide in Atlanta Guilty Of Extortion in Zoning Plot
description: A. Reginald Eaves, who rebounded from a brief reign as Atlanta's public safety commissioner to win a seat on the Fulton County Commission, was found guilty of extortion Monday in connection with payoffs for zoning votes.

However, this gain was offset by other items, including a $75 million after-tax charge relating to the writedown of abatable preferred stock associated with the prior sale of Aluminum assets to Alcan, a $15 million after-tax charge associated with early redemption of debt, and an $18 million after-tax charge in connection with the planned move of Arco International Oil & Gas Co.'s headquarters from Los Angeles to Plano, Texas.

The 34-year-old left-hander, whose 138 victories are the fifth-highest total in Oriole history, had an 0-3 record with an 8.83 earned run average this season. In four starts this season, he lasted beyond the fourth inning once.

Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers has received the Schick Award for outstanding contributions to his team. . . . Bobby Brown, the American League president, upheld the two-game suspension of the Texas Rangers' pitcher Mitch Williams, who was ejected from a game with Boston April 8 after a brawl. The suspension went into effect immediately. The fight broke out after Williams and Boston's Marty Barrett got into a shouting match after Barrett had singled, gone to second on Williams's balk, and scored.

title: Population Growth
description: The growth rate of the world's population is higher than many experts predicted only a few years ago, according to a new study. The global population, now more than 5.1 billion, is now growing by about 1.7 percent a year and is expected to reach 6 billion by the year 1998, according to the Population Reference Bureau, a research organization in Washington. At the current rate, human numbers will double in about 40 years.

There were only two models and no runway, but the creations on display represented police haute couture at its hautest: a snappy new, low-maintenance uniform with permanent creases, gold-plated buttons that do not need burnishing - or buttoning, for that matter - a lighter weight jacket with space-age insulation and ''patent leather look-alike shoes'' that never need polishing.

description: The Supreme Court ordered further proceedings in lower courts today to determine whether a New Jersey man accused of helping the Nazis kill more than 2,000 Jews in Lithuania should be stripped of his naturalized citizenship.

title: Acme Spurns Offer
description: The Acme Steel Company's president, B. W. H. Marsden, said he had rejected a proposed partnership with a group of Minnesota-based investors. The partnership was suggested by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs. ''We share Mr. Jacobs's belief that the steel industry, and particularly Acme Steel, present a solid investment opportunity,'' Mr. Marsden said. ''For that reason, we believe that Acme's shareholders, its customers, employees and other constituencies are best served by the company remaining independent.''

All the parents got abnormal blood pressure and the next day, entire teams were rushed to the school nurse's office, suffering from exposure.

In keeping with the title, an artsy, informal and intimate atmosphere surrounds these Sunday afternoon concerts at Project Studios One (46-01 21st Street, Long Island City), an old school building converted into artists' studios and a gallery. And each of the works performed was introduced briefly by its composer or one of the players, not an unhealthy practice.

Bridge
description: If, in a trump contract, a declarer plays toward a K-Q combination in the dummy, many defenders step up with the ace because the declarer might have a singleton. They have it backward. Playing low may indeed mean that the ace does not score, but it holds the declarer to one trick in the suit.

title: Business and Health; Maxicare's Plan To Cut Losses
description: LIKE most big health maintenance organizations, Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the nation's largest for-profit H.M.O. company, has been squeezed between rising medical costs and stiff competition for major customers. Now, Maxicare is seeking to rid itself of about 800,000 unprofitable subscribers in a restructuring aimed at cutting losses, which hit $256 million last year. The drive to shrink Maxicare is at the behest of creditors, which raised interest rates in a renegotiation of $175 million of the company's debt.

title: USX Expects Gains
description: The USX Corporation's chairman, David M. Roderick, said today that the company would record ''materially enhanced profitability'' this year and next. The company, the parent of USS, the nation's largest steelmaker, should generate $1 billion in excess cash this year, he said at the annual shareholders meeting here today. Cutbacks in global steel-making capacity, rising orders and prices and the weakened dollar contributed to the improving business, he said. USX last week reported profits of $157 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a $72 million loss in the 1987 period.

title: Equestrians Chosen
description: The United States Equestrian Team has announced the five riders chosen for the 1988 Olympic team in the three-day event, which along with show jumping and dressage make up Olympic equestrian events. They include Bruce Davidson of Unionville, Pa., who has been on three Olympic teams, two of which won the gold medal (in 1976 and 1984) and one the silver (in 1972), and who has twice won the individual world championship. The 1984 Olympic individual silver medalist in eventing, Karen Stives of Dover, Mass., also made the team, as did Phyllis Dawson of Hillsboro, Va., Jane Sleeper of West Grove, Pa., and Ann Sutton of Midland, Ga.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Horvath Upset in Italian Open: Iwona Kuczynska posted the first upset in the Italian Open women's championships yesterday, routing Kathleen Horvath of Largo, Fla., the 12th-seeded player, 6-4, 6-0. Only three seeded players - Horvath, Isabel Cueto of West Germany, No. 10, and Judith Wiesner of Austria, No. 13 -played on the first day of the weeklong clay court event at the Foro Italico in Rome. Wiesner struggled to beat a wild-card entrant, Gabriella Boschiero of Italy, 6-3, 5-7, 6-2. Kuczynska, 27 years old, defected from Poland in 1981 and divides her time between the United States and France. She said she expected to get her Polish passport back this week to visit her ailing mother. She said she hoped to represent Poland in the Federation Cup.(AP) SOCCER Southampton Ties Liverpool: Liverpool, the new English League soccer champion, was held to a 1-1 tie by Southampton yesterday in its last home appearance of the season. Manchester United remained favored to take the runner-up spot after winning by 2-0 at Oxford United. Liverpool has 86 points in 38 games; United has 75 in 38. Everton, last year's champion, is third with 70 in 39.(AP)

title: Latin American Solution Is Seen for Panama
description: A former Venezuelan President, who has played an active role in trying to end the Panamanian crisis, has asserted that Latin American mediation now offers the best hope of persuading Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to step down from power.

Boy, 8, Drowns in Creek
description: An 8-year-old boy drowned after he slipped and fell into a creek while searching along the bank for returnable cans and bottles, the police said. The victim, Roderick Hines, who was submerged for more than an hour in Rondout Creek, was pronounced dead Sunday night at Kingston Hospital. He was walking with three other youths, one of whom tried unsuccessfully to rescue Roderick with a stick.

title: In Brazil's Northeast, Misery Molded by Man and Nature
description: Frequent rains over the last few weeks have transformed the rolling hills surrounding this small town into luxuriant sugar cane fields, dispelling fears that the perennial scourge of drought will once again strike Brazil's northeast this year.

title: Why There Are No Issues
description: The mysterious disappearance of issues from Presidential politics has agitated voters for months. Some are so upset by the very idea that, in conscientious horror, they deny it. Why of course there are issues troubling most Americans, letter-writers to The Times insist, and the thing to do is press the candidates to address them.

title: T.L. van Winkle, 65, Atomic Researcher And Priest, Is Dead
description: The Rev. Thomas Leo van Winkle, an atomic scientist who later became a Roman Catholic priest and the headmaster of Portsmouth Abbey School in Portsmouth, R.I., died of lymphoma Saturday at Jane Brown Hospital in Providence. He was 65 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court made it easier for manufacturers to stop supplying discount dealers in order to protect other merchants from price competition. Upholding a lower court ruling, the Court ruled by 6 to 2 that a manufacturer's agreement with one dealer to stop supplying a price-cutting dealer would not necessarily violate the Sherman Antitrust Act. [ Page A1. ] President Reagan denounced the plant-closing provision and other parts of the recently passed trade bill. [ D1. ] Orders to the nation's factories surged 1.6 percent in March as strong export demand and heavy military orders reversed weakness in the previous two months. The advance was the first this year. [ D6. ] Construction spending surged 1.5 percent in March, the biggest increase in almost a year. [ D6. ] Americans increased their efficiency in producing goods and services at an annual rate of nearly 1 percent last quarter. [ D6. ] MARKETS Oil prices fell sharply worldwide after OPEC backed away from cutting production in concert with other oil producers. [ D1. ] Precious metal futures prices plunged after OPEC failed to reduce production, as had been expected. [ D20. ] The stock market closed mixed, although a late rally in blue-chip issues allowed the Dow Jones industrial average to post a gain of 10.94 points, to 2,043.27. [ D8. ] Bond prices slipped in light trading, as market participants shrugged off the positive implications of falling oil and commodity prices. [ D16. ] Gold was down $5.40 an ounce, to $445.60, on the Comex. The dollar was mixed against major currencies. [ D20. ] Nasdaq fined Blinder, Robinson $250,000 and imposed other penalties, accusing the brokerage of ''excessive and fraudulent markups.'' The firm said it would appeal. [ D2. ] COMPANIES USG's board approved a recapitalization and restructuring involving the sale of some businesses and other assets, in a move to fend off Desert Partners' tender offer. [ D1. ] Allegis sold 50 percent of its Apollo system of computerized reservations to five other airlines. [ D4. ] Some Dalkon Shield claimants called for a vote against A. H. Robins's proposed reorganization plan. They said those who had suffered injuries from the contraceptive device were taking a back seat financially to the company's stockholders. [ D1. ] Banca Commerciale Italiana will seek a majority of Irving, rather than its current offer for 45 percent. The Milan bank is competing against Bank of New York. [ D4. ] A Drexel Burnham Lambert trading practice may violate Federal anti-manipulation statutes, an S.E.C. official said. [ D2. ] West Germany will sell its 60 percent stake in Viag, the giant energy, chemical and metal enterprise. [ D2. ] Gould will sell its industrial automation unit to the AEG division of Daimler-Benz for $290 million. [ D4. ] Henry Holt has named Bruno A. Quinson its president and chief executive. [ D26. ] Ms. and Sassy magazines were sold, as expected, to the president and vice president of John Fairfax. [ D26. ] McGraw-Hill suspended publication of Business Week Careers, its five-year-old magazine for college students. [ D26. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Maxicare Health Plans wants to drop 800,000 subscribers. The health-care organization is squeezed between rising medical costs and stiff competition. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Stock pickers are weighing what the economy will be like in the second half of the year. Market Place. Market Place. [ D8. ]

description: Yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding a manufacturer's ability to stop supplying a discount retailer broadens the power of producers to control the prices of consumer goods, corporate lawyers and antitrust experts say. It will also almost certainly cause some retailers to limit discounts, particularly for electronics goods and clothing.

description: The combination of saxophone, organ and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is not on the face of it an enticing proposition. But how agreeably the soprano saxophone, as played by Anders Paulsson, floated through this vast and gloomy space on Sunday evening!

title: Hein-Werner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; 'Daze,' Prisoners Of City Life
description: Nina Martin's ''Modern Daze,'' presented Saturday night at Performance Space 122, is a bright, fast-spinning pinwheel of a theater-dance piece about contemporary life in urban America. The men and women who scurry about the stage, dressed in colorful trash couture designed by Annette Zindel, may be in a daze. But the points they make are so on target they are not just funny but wrenching, due both to a knowing script by Ms. Martin and Madeleine Olnek and to the eight performers' superb acting, physical daring and vivid presences.

description: LEAD: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, although a late rally in blue-chip issues allowed the Dow Jones industrial average to post a modest gain.

title: Gas System Studies Canada Asset Sale
description: Columbia Gas System Inc., a major United States carrier of natural gas, is considering the sale of its Canadian oil and gas properties to provide more money for its domestic operations. The company said that it would not reduce its commitment to oil- and gas-related activities but wanted to focus on domestic concerns closer to its market areas.

title: Tiny Memorial Tiles of the Holocaust
description: As a 10-year-old named T. J. took up his brush and painted the words: ''Why Hate? Why Hate Kids?'' on a bisque tile, he explained earnestly, ''The whole thing probably got started because of hate and I think they got everybody else to hate too.''

title: High-Stakes Wager in Las Vegas
description: The real high-rollers on the gaudy, neon-lighted Strip these days do not have dice or cards in their hands. They are holding blueprints. The owners of this city's hotel-casinos have embarked upon a building spree that is unprecedented even for a town that has enjoyed three decades of virtually uninterrupted growth and prides itself on its Wild West boom-town mentality.

title: Two Leaders Challenge The 'Big Science' Trend
description: In a departure from past practice, leaders of eminent research organizations are beginning to suggest that many of the nation's most glamorous ''big science'' projects may have to be scaled down to permit financing of other, less visible scientific endeavors that will probably be more important in the long run.

title: 14 Die, Dozens Trapped in India As Wing of a Hospital Collapses
description: A new wing of a children's hospital collapsed today in Kashmir, and at least 14 people died in a crush of bricks and concrete. Dozens of children, their moans growing fainter, were trapped.

Boston Pops at Carnegie
description: It will not do to be severe about the current provision of music from the Boston Pops Orchestra, which came to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with John Williams on the podium and on the program. The organization exists for listeners who like the sound of a large, expert symphony orchestra and who prefer, among the various kinds of music to which that sound can be applied, Broadway and other popular songs, light-spirited concert music and scores composed for television and cinema.

title: Few Surprises Seen as Likely At Primary in Capital Today
description: Political suspense will be in short supply Tuesday when voters in the District of Columbia go to the polls for their 1988 Presidential primary. There is no serious doubt that Democrats will overwhelmingly endorse the Rev. Jesse Jackson and none at all that Republicans will back Vice President Bush.

title: A Look at Carnegie Hall From Behind the Stage
description: For those who want to know what goes on behind the scenes at Carnegie Hall, there are guided tours every Tuesday and Thursday. The tours last 40 minutes and include a film featuring artists who have appeared at the hall, among them Arturo Toscanini, Benny Goodman, Judy Garland and the Beatles.

title: Lacrosse Notebook; 4 Teams Seek 3 Lacrosse Bids
description: The major points of contention in the college lacrosse season are the ninth, 10th and 11th positions for the Division I tournament with C. W. Post, Rutgers, Virginia and Yale the contenders.

title: Sri Lanka Vote Hailed as Step Toward Peace
description: A set of local government elections in Sri Lanka, won by the ruling party of President J. R. Jayewardene, are being hailed by Indian and Sri Lankan officials as a major spur for the Indian-sponsored Sri Lankan peace accord.

title: Feeding Time for Starved Bridges
description: ''The bridge is in bad shape. What can we afford to do this year?''

title: Derby Unseats Lesser-Known
description: If loyalty had much to do with horse racing, the jockeys riding in the Kentucky Derby here Saturday would include such unfamiliar names as Jack Lauzon, Rafael Meza, Mike Smith, Chris Valovich and B. J. Walker. Each of them rode one of this year's Derby starters in his first start, but all of them will be watching the Derby on television this year.

description: Behind the return of the Pittsburgh Pirates to solid respectability, if not quite yet to true pennant contention, is a man who combines some of baseball's time-tested virtues with an inclination toward innovation and individuality.

title: BankAmerica Names New Vice Chairman
description: Robert W. Frick, a vice chairman of the BankAmerica Corporation and head of its world banking group, is resigning to pursue other interests, the San Francisco-based company said yesterday.

title: I.R.A. Attacks Make Wary Britons Even More So
description: British troops in West Germany were advised today not to cross into the Netherlands, but military spokesmen ruled out extraordinary security measures after the killings of three off-duty British airmen Sunday.

title: 5-Second End of Building, 81
description: The 10-story Corbett Building came down in five seconds Sunday after engineers set off 185 explosives inside the 81-year-old structure. It was the first time the implosion method of demolition had been used in Portland, and hundreds of people lined downtown rooftops and streets to witness the early morning blast. The Corbett Building was removed to make way for the three-block Pioneer Place project.

title: Par Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 Inquiries Focus on Suspect in Slaying Who Died in Police Custody
description: Five investigations by hospitals and criminal-justice agencies were under way yesterday into the tangled case of a man who died in police custody after clubbing a woman to death with a two-by-four and being beaten by bystanders in Harlem.

title: Review/Theater; Banker and Tyrant in a Latin Imbroglio
description: In Robert Litz's ''Domino'' (at the Perry Street Theater), one cannot tell the missile-rattlers from the revolutionaries. Everyone is equally suspect - and expediency is the key to temporary survival. Although Mr. Litz's political conscience is undeniable, his satire is impaired by familiarity and by a shortage of specificity.

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Product Is Introduced by Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers announced the creation of a new zero-coupon bond product yesterday, saying it will offer $3 billion face amount of Fico Strips, which represent principal and coupon obligations of a $750 million bond issue of the Financing Corporation.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Return to Moscow
description: The Russians may have thought they had seen the last of Richard N. Perle, the former Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy who had a reputation for hard-line positions on arms control.

title: Margo Nursery Farms reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quebec Pact Loses Support in Rest of Canada
description: A year ago, much of Canada was celebrating what many took to be the end of 20 years of uncertainty about Quebec's place in Canada. But 12 months of reflection have taken their toll, and it now appears that a constitutional agreement between the French-speaking province and the rest of Canada may never be ratified, at least not without major changes.

title: Why I'm Boycotting Oreo Cookies (Alas)
description: Bluntly and for paranoid reasons, RJR Nabisco Inc., manufacturer of Camel and Winston cigarettes and many supermarket food products, has shut its traditional advertising agency for the domestic market out of its future business. Why? The agency, Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, produced an effective television commercial celebrating Northwest Airlines' smoking ban.

title: Big Winner of TV Game Show Gets 5-Year Fraud Sentence
description: The biggest single-game winner on the television game show ''Password,'' who was arrested when a viewer recognized him as a fugitive, was sentenced today to five years in prison for insurance fraud.

title: Europe Prices Up at 2.6% Rate
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, nudging its 12-month inflation rate up to a provisional 2.6 percent from a revised 2.4 percent in February.

title: Troubled Seas: Global Red Tides of Algae Bring New Fears
description: LATE last August, off the coast of Naples, Fla., microscopic algae began to reproduce quickly, thriving and exploding in a matter of days into a huge toxic bloom that dominated the coastal environment.

title: Cracks in Metal Found on Jet in Hawaii Accident
description: Apparent cracking from metal fatigue has been found around rivets on a structural part of the Aloha Airlines jet that was torn open over Hawaii Thursday, and key sections will be flown to Washington for analysis, a Federal official said yesterday.

title: CAMPAIGN IN OHIO SEEN AS REHEARSAL OF CONTEST IN FALL
description: With Gov. Michael S. Dukakis the overwhelming favorite in the Ohio Democratic primary Tuesday, the campaign has turned into a dress rehearsal of the general election campaign as Mr. Dukakis and Vice President Bush exchanged barbs and challenges.

title: Indian Bureau Finds Its Schools Delivering a Weak Education
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs has found that Indian children score worse on tests than 79 percent of other students in the United States, and has asked Indians how the bureau can strengthen the instruction of their children.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about American policy on Panama misstated the Reagan Administration's reaction to a proposal by Jose Blandon, a former aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Calprop Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Davis Jury Selection Is Halted Over Bias Issue
description: A Bronx judge yesterday suspended jury selection for the latest trial of Larry Davis to hear charges from prosecutors that defense lawyers had been systematically excluding white people as jurors.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Reforming China: Nuts and Bolts
description: ''We are building socialism with Chinese features,'' say China's leaders. Right. But what about cooking oil? Should the Government end its subsidy? What would be the reaction from residents of the cities, whose meat and chicken prices went up 17 percent last year? Behind the grand slogans of reform, there must be people fitting together all the endless little pieces.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss on investments of $234,000. c-Includes a gain on investments of $4,503,000.

title: MARONITE PRIEST KILLED IN LEBANON
description: The killing of a prominent Maronite Catholic priest, apparently by Christians, has stunned Christian areas of Lebanon and deepened concern about growing friction between Christian factions.

title: McGraw-Hill Drops College Publication
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. has suspended publication of Business Week Careers, its five-year-old magazine for college students because of an inability to attract new advertisers. The closing last week came several months after the company had begun efforts to attract older readers.

title: Bruins Win but Aren't Happy
description: Taking a 3-0 lead against the visiting Devils tonight was easy, but restoring dominance once a Devil rally tied the game at 3-3 was not. The Bruins, suggested Rejean Lemelin, had to reach for a more volatile emotion, something approaching hate, before they could produce the sort of playoff game that insures a 5-3 victory.

title: A Higher Net Is Expected at 3M
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company expects its second-quarter earnings to exceed last year's levels, its chairman, Allen F. Jacobson said, while warning that its growth could slow later this year. The 3M Company's earnings should exceed the $240 million, or $1.05 share, report for the second quarter of 1987, he said. The company's full-year earnings are expected to be good, but profit and sales growth may shrink in the second half of 1988 because of a general slowdown in the American economy, he added.

title: 503 Held in Abortion Protest on E. 85th St.
description: A total of 503 opponents of abortion rights were arrested yesterday, carried on stetchers and taken by bus to the Police Academy after they prevented the opening of a gynecologist's office in Manhattan.

description: United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 6.90 percent in the next six months, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: Israeli, No. 157, Upsets Jaite
description: He thrust his arms in the air and rushed to the net for the traditional congratulatory handshake. It is a familiar sight at Forest Hills, which is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year, although not what you would expect to see in the first round of a tournament. For a young Israeli ranked No. 157 in the world, however, it may as well have been a final, with a full house instead of 200 or so wind-chilled fans watching.

Review/Recital; Guitarist's Mix Of 20th-Century Compositions
description: Ana Maria Rosado played an ambitious program of 20th-century guitar music at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday evening, but although her spirit was willing, her technique was often weak. At her best, she gave carefully shaded readings of Falla's ''Homenaje'' and Ponce's ''Theme, Varie et Finale,'' and she rose to the challenges of Francis Schwartz's ''We've Got (Poly)Rhythm,'' a cartoonish work that has the player indulge in vocal sound effects and exhort the audience to do the same.

description: The Devils started their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Bruins tonight the same way they started their previous two series, by losing the opening game.

description: Peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra leaders have begun to touch on key military and political questions, and the basic differences between the two sides have become more clearly defined than ever.

description: Stephen G. Bowen Jr., 44-year-old president of J. Walter Thompson USA, is shifting his base of operations to Chicago from worldwide headquarters in New York.

description: Eleven paintings, most of them 19th-century American works, were slashed at the New-York Historical Society on April 3, a museum spokeswoman said yesterday. There are no suspects in the incident.

description: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries backed away from a proposal to cut production in concert with seven other oil-producing nations.

description: Lloyd Bloom, a sports agent, pleaded guilty yesterday in Tuscaloosa, Ala., to one misdemeanor charge for his dealings with a University of Alabama basketball player. He will testify for the state at the trial of his former associate, Norby Walters.

title: Lebenthal Relinquishes His Firm's Presidency
description: ''I've torn away from myself one feather in my cap,'' said James A. Lebenthal, who is relinquishing the presidency of Lebenthal & Company, the municipal bond firm, to Peter J. Sweetser, while remaining chairman.

title: Dinosaur Eggs Yield Glimpse of Their Embryos
description: EVERY gigantic dinosaur started out as a tiny embryo in an egg, but only now have paleontologists, applying advanced medical imaging technology, discovered some of those embryos preserved inside fossilized eggs. The new findings are yielding important insights into the full life cycle of dinosaurs.

title: Rig Count Falls by 28
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by 28 last week, to 880, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 780 a year ago. Baker Hughes's rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday, not the number of rigs producing oil.

title: Cullinet Plans To Lay Off 400
description: Cullinet Software Inc. said yesterday that it will lay off about 400 employees, or 17 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring and realignment. Cullinet, based in Westwood, Mass., said the move will result in a write-off of about $8 million in fiscal 1988, ended April 30, but will reduce expenses in fiscal 1989 by about $25 million and should allow it to regain profitability after two years of losses.

title: Telecast Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

NASA Sets Priorities For Research in Space
description: The space agency has developed a master plan setting out priorities for scientific research. The outline, made public last week by the Office of Space Science and Applications, gives priority to completing existing projects and orbiting four ''Great Observatories.''

title: Plant-Notice Rule Assailed By Reagan
description: In a speech before the United States Chamber of Commerce today, President Reagan heatedly denounced a provision of the recently passed trade bill that would make companies provide 60 days' notice of plant closings or large layoffs.

Meldrum & Fewsmith Gets Yellow Pages Ads
description: The B.F. Goodrich segment of the Uniroyal Goodrich joint venture has its advertising at Grey Advertising. A week ago the Uniroyal part went to Wyse Advertising in Cleveland.

title: A New Model: Rethinking Estee Lauder
description: Estee Lauder called her son Leonard one day last week and told him he had to start coloring his hair. She had seen him on television that morning talking about the company's new perfume, Knowing, and decided that his gray hair made her seem old.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $51,212 and $70,851 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the prior year revenue has been reclassified to include net interest income instead of total interest income.

title: Appeals Court Offers Sympathy, Not Money
description: While criticizing what it deemed bureaucratic bungling, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit said today it was powerless to help a Texas woman who lost $1,100 because of bad advice from Social Security Administration employees.

title: Hurdles for Dukakis
description: Though Michael Dukakis now appears likely to be the Democratic Presidential nominee, an eclectic assortment of Democrats and political ''experts'' have suggested to me that he still needs to clear several obstacles before they'll consider him a strong general election candidate: 1. The Jackson problem. There's no precedent or tradition that makes the runner-up for the nomination necessarily the Vice-Presidential candidate. Jesse Jackson personally may not want the job. Anyway, a Dukakis-Jackson ticket, combining two Northern liberals, is hardly a formula for Democratic victory in November.

title: Not Guilty Plea In Death of Boy Left Untreated
description: A Christian Scientist couple who tried to heal their dying son through prayer rather than medical treatment pleaded not guilty today to manslaughter charges.

title: Agatha Christie Rights Change Hands
description: The mystery writer Agatha Christie and the western writer Max Brand have been dead 12 and 44 years, respectively, but their many books are still valuable publishing properties. Thus the Putnam Berkley Group announced yesterday it had purchased the publishing rights to the books of both authors - 87 of Miss Christie's, 156 of Brand's.

title: Chess
description: Considering the fine crop of young grandmasters in Iceland, it was not surprising that one of their number, 27-year-old Jon Arnason, won the 13th Reykjavik International Open Tournament. Arnason topped a strong Swiss-system field of 54 players with an 8 1/2-2 1/2 score and was awarded $9,000.

title: Timberline Software reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Unholy War
description: There is a clear path to peace in the Middle East, a road that can lead to solutions for Palestinian Arabs and Israelis. It lies there plain for the world to see.

title: Marathon Trials Raise Hope
description: The results of the women's Olympic marathon trials Sunday in Pittsburgh have resurrected hope for a medal in Seoul, where none existed after Joan Benoit Samuelson announced she would not run because of injuries.

description: The Bear Stearns Companies announced yesterday that it had dismantled its system of co-presidents and named one of them, James E. Cayne, to be president. The other, E. John Rosenwald Jr., was elected vice chairman. Alan C. Greenberg remains chairman and chief executive.

description: Ivory Coast and its commercial bank creditors have agreed to reschedule its external medium-term debt and a $150 million multicurrency loan. The rescheduling involves debt maturing between Dec. 1, 1983, and Dec. 31, 1995, with repayment between June 10, 1993, and Dec. 10, 2002, Banque Nationale de Paris said today.

title: Accident Study Cites Double-Trailer Trucks
description: LARGE double-trailer trucks, those highway behemoths with two trailers behind a single cab, are two to three times more likely to be involved in crashes as other heavy trucks, a study in Washington State has found.

After nearly five months of living in a public shelter for the homeless, the 28-year-old mother and her two daughters had a permanent home again: a bright, airy, six-room row house in a pleasant neighborhood in the Olney section of northeastern Philadelphia.

title: Hako Minuteman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Republicbank
description: The First Republicbank Corporation will propose to reduce the size of its board to 16, from 33, at its annual meeting on June 28. Albert V. Casey, the new chairman of the bank holding company, had suggested the smaller board last week, and the board backed that proposal, a company spokesman said. Mr. Casey became chairman April 12 after Federal insurers and regulators decided that a management change was necessary to rebuild Texas's largest bank holding company. Two members who would not be up for re-election are First Republicbank's president, Joseph R. Musolino, and the Texas Republican Party chairman, George W. Strake Jr.

title: Hostages Taken at A.T.& T. Get Away
description: LEAD: A man who said he had explosives in a gym bag took 14 hostages yesterday in an office in lower Manhattan, but most escaped by asking to get a drink of water or use the restroom, the police said. The man later gave himself up.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Upheld the two-game suspension of Mitch Williams, Texas Rangers pitcher, for fighting. BALTIMORE (AL) - Released Scott McGregor, pitcher. Recalled Jay Tibbs, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League. Placed Bill Scherrer, pitcher, on waivers for assignment to Rochester. Agreed with the city of Baltimore on a 15-year lease for a new stadium. CHICAGO (NL) - Recalled Mike Capel, pitcher, from Iowa of the American Association. Purchased the contract of Mark Grace, first baseman, from Iowa. Optioned Drew Hall, pitcher, and Rolando Roomes, outfielder, to Iowa. NATIONAL LEAGUE - Suspended Pete Rose, Cincinnati Reds manager, for 30 days, for pushing an umpire. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Placed Danny Cox, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Gibson Alba, pitcher, from Louisville of the American Association. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Rescinded their offer to Arthur Cox, free-agent tight end. Signed Floyd Dixon, wide receiver, to a series of three one-year contracts. Signed Ted Bates, defensive end; Mark Comalander, quarterback; Daryl Parham, tight end; Vinson Smith, linebacker, and Scott Thompson, defensive tackle, to free-agent contracts. CHICAGO (NFC) - Released Todd Bell, defensive back, and Tim Wrightman, tight end. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Milt Carthens and Jeff Holinka, offensive linemen; Doug Beaty, fullback; William Hughes, center; Mark Schmidt and Angelo Stafford, receivers; Willie Bryant, Marvin Spence and Victor Peppers, defensive backs, and Michael Johnson, linebacker, to free-agent contracts. GIANTS (NFC) - Signed Henry Brown, Mike Neal and Tommy Oliver, defensive ends; Andrew Martin, Garland Thaxton, Keenan Wimbley and Thor Salanos, linebackers; Brandy Brownlee, placekicker; James Medlock, J. R. Compton and Terry Morrow, running backs; Thomas Johnson, tight end, and Eric Oglesby, John Williams, Mike Stewart and Stanley Howard, wide receivers, to free-agent contracts. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Signed Curt DiGiacomo, center; Ike Reardon, Brett Schnitzius, Richard Van Drutten and Keith Cupp, tackles; Craig Kantner, guard; Thomas Leonard, running back; Michael Stewart and Darryl Gaines, defensive backs; and Mark Montoya, punter. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Shawn Deals and Eric Andrade, wide receivers; Jerry Beasley, linebacker; Willie Cannon and Chris Jackson, running backs; Pete Kwiatkowski and Tika Manu, defensive ends; Ed Taggert, tight end, and Ron keller, punter, to free-agent contracts. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) Signed John Mandarich, nose tackle; Mike Crow, punter, and Roger Ceron, guard, to free-agent contracts. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Signed Mark Sindlinger, center; Dwight Sistrunk, safety; Tim Calcagno, offensive tackle; Jim Dominic, defensive lineman, and Earnest Jones, running back, to free-agent contracts. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Dana McLemore, cornerback. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Todd Krumm, defensive back; Lance Carl, wide receiver; Cecil Jackson and Greg Manusky, linebackers; Chris Stewart, safety and Kent Tramel, defensive tackle, to free-agent contracts. OLYMPICS U.S. OLYMPIC EQUESTRIAN TEAM - Named Bruce Davidson, Phyllis Dawson, Jane Sleeper, Karen Stives and Ann Sutton to the three-day event team.

No wonder the hand-held portable telephone is becoming increasingly popular. According to Nynex and Metro One, which service the telephones, about 10,000 are currently being paraded around the metropolitan area. Could the talkman be replacing the Walkman?

title: From the Land Of the Proletariat, A Hedonist's Drink
description: ONE of the more curious enclaves in this Black Sea port is a turn-of-the-century French chateau, its garden now festooned with Communist Party posters and heaped with industrial racks of empty green bottles. A voluptuous stone siren presides over the arched entrance, and high above her is the oddly proletarian sign, Factory of Champagne Wines.

title: Review/Television; New York's Real Estate Debate
description: ''Metroline'' falls short tonight. The topic is beyond it. How can New York meet social needs and still keep a strong tax base? Try answering that in 30 minutes, when builders, think tanks and advocacy groups have flailed at both the question and one another for years. Nonetheless, give ''Metroline'' a medal for trying. Channel 13's weekly discussion series, at 8:30 tonight, raises one of the great issues of urban living.

title: John Paul, in Sermon, Takes Note of Unrest
description: Commenting on the labor unrest in his homeland, Pope John Paul II said today that Poland would not be independent until its people were free to determine their future.

title: Election's Price in France: Values Above All
description: The word is on every politician's lips: ''valeurs,'' or values. Sensing a popular backlash against their traditional discourse, French politicians of the right and the left are appealing to values rather than dwelling on economic or social issues The emphasis on values suggests the fluidity of a campaign in which President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, has managed to cast himself as an almost nonpartisan, essentially conservative figure. Opinion polls suggest that Mr. Mitterrand will trounce Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the neo-Gaullist standard-bearer of the French right, on Sunday.

title: South Africans Separate Twins Joined at Head

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Kohde-Kilsch Advances: Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, seeded third, overpowered Kathy Caversazio of Italy, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday in the second round of the Italian Open in Rome. Play was suspended because of rain before Chris Evert, seeded first, could play against Ni-cole Provis of Australia. In other matches, Alexia Dechaume of France scored a second-round victory over Federica Bonsignori of Italy, 6-3, 6-4, and Nathalie Tauziat of France, seeded ninth, was beaten in the first round by Angeliki Kannellopoulou of Greece, 3-6, 6-2, 6-0, and Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, seeded 11th, was de-feated by Niege Dias of Brazil, 2-6, 6-1, 7-6. Other seeded players who advanced were Raffaella Reggi of Italy, seeded fifth, and Helen Kelesi of Canada, No. 14. (AP)

title: Ingles Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
L & N Housing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the earnings and revenue increases to the inclusion in the 1988 first quarter of three full months of operations results for the Boston and Philadelphia District Steam Systems compared to about two months in 1987, as well as results of the Cleveland System acquired on Dec. 30, 1987.

title: Lecture and Chair
description: Yasuhiro Nakasone, who was Prime Minister of Japan for five years ending last October, will give a lecture on Japanese-American relations at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies on May 10. Not coincidentally, on that day the graduate school will establish the Yasuhiro Nakasone Chair in Japanese Studies, a professorship endowed by the Japan Shipbuilding Industry Foundation.

title: Jackie Mason Returns With a Doo-Wop Party
description: It was the night that Jackie Mason returned to Broadway - an evening that grew, like one of his gargantuan and convoluted monologues, to erupt in an irrepressible series of punch lines early yesterday at Sardi's.

title: Kelly Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Korea's North Politik
description: At the moment, everybody here is focusing on domestic politics, with the Government's loss of its legislative majority for the first time, and on the coming Olympics. Electric signs all over town announce the number of days until the start of the Games, now 137.

title: Standard Motor Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNR Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,100,000 and $80,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Mr. Giamatti Makes the Right Call
description: In levying the harshest penalty against a team manager in 41 years, the National League president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, has sent the right signal at the right time: Baseball will not be allowed to degenerate into chaos and disorder.

title: Galway Kinnell Lecture
description: The poet Galway Kinnell will give a lecture on ''The Form of Free Verse'' at 8 P.M. May 12 at Poets House, 351 West 18th Street. The lecture is the first Paul Zweig Memorial Lecture, an annual series in honor of the late poet; Mr. Zweig, who died in 1984, was chairman of the comparative literature department at Queens College. Admission is $3. Information: 627-4035.

title: Metro Datelines; U.S. Judge Rejects Claim of Plagiarism
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a prominent physician had not plagiarized a medical article written by a junior colleague.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks Fail
description: The United States and Japan tonight broke off negotiations over American beef and citrus exports and the United States said it would challenge Japan's import quotas under international trading rules.

title: Knicks Adopt Chaos Theory
description: They've tried it without the press and they've tried it with the press; they've played it straight and they've played combinations. The Knicks have attempted nearly everything imaginable to beat Boston in the first two games of their three-of-five-game playoff series, and all they have to show for it are bruised egos and a pair of lopsided defeats.

title: Why Democrats Can't Make an Issue of Noriega
description: On the surface, the Democrats should be eagerly awaiting each day's developments in Panama, the Reagan Administration's newest Central American policy flop.

title: 65 M.P.H. Not Costing Lives, Transportation Head Asserts
description: Raising the speed limit to 65 miles per hour on some rural stretches of Interstate highway has had no effect on the traffic death rate, Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley said today.

title: Josephson International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from repurchase of debentures of $421,000 for the quarter and $829,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $1.6 million from adoption of FAS 96. c-Net loss and after a loss of $1,793,000 from repurchase of debentures and a charge of $550,000 from reversal of tax loss carryforwards. d-After a gain of $20,910,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $1,793,000 from repurchase of debentures and a tax credit of $999,000.

title: Truce Turns Into Free-for-All In Police-Fire Feud on Divers
description: A tentative truce between the New York City Police and Fire Commissioners disintegrated into a wild free-for-all yesterday, as the two began yelling at each other in City Hall and Mayor Koch yelled back, rebuking them as if they were unruly children.

title: U.S. CITES INCREASE IN BIOLOGICAL ARMS
description: American intelligence agencies suspect as many as 10 nations of developing biological weapons, Reagan Administration officials said today. Aside from the Soviet Union, the officials refused to name the countries, saying the information was secret.

title: Zane Smith a Brave Somebody Wants
description: Lou Piniella thought he would take in a ball game and be as invisible as possible. He would go directly to the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium, avoid the press room and watch Zane Smith pitch against the Mets without anyone knowing he was there. So the first person he saw when he stepped off the elevator outside the Diamond Club was a reporter. So much for invisibility.

title: New York Schools Consider The Use of Metal Detectors
description: An increase in deadly weapons found on public school students in New York City this year has prompted the Board of Education to consider searching students with metal detectors as they enter school, a board official said yesterday.

title: AFGHANISTAN CHIEF VISITS INDIA TODAY
description: India announced today that Najibullah, the Afghan leader, would visit New Delhi for meetings with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi this week, at a time when many analysts doubt the ability of Mr. Najibullah to remain in power for long.

title: Vietnam Refugee Worries Over Fate of Sister
description: For 19-year-old Nyugen Anh Tuan, there is no fonder dream than having his family join him here.

title: The Poor Don't Think America's Decline Is a Myth; The Chip Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: American Teaching Of the Arts Is Assailed
description: A potentially controversial plan to steer arts education away from performance and exhibition and toward more disciplined study was made public today by Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Cherry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Judge Rules Davis's Lawyers Excluded White Jurors
description: A Bronx judge, supporting prosecution charges of discrimination, ruled yesterday that defense lawyers for Larry Davis had sought to exclude white people as jurors in his latest trial.

title: A Pulitzer Winner Who Can Go Home Again
description: David Mitchell sat at his rolltop desk, an old Royal typewriter to his left and a Macintosh computer to his right, and thumbed through the latest issue of The Point Reyes Light, the weekly newspaper at which he won a Pulitzer Prize nine years ago.

title: S.A.T. Trial Questions Focus of Rising Debate
description: As 360,000 high school juniors around the country prepare to take the Scholastic Aptitude Test on Saturday, a debate is heating up about whether students should have to take an unmarked section of the test that does not count in the score.

title: Tractor Sales Are Rolling Again
description: This is planting season in the upper Midwest, and for the first time in years Neil Horning is having trouble supplying all the tractors and other equipment that farmers need to get their crops in.

title: Bruins Pound 5-9 Devil
description: Judging by their play in the opening game, the Bruins have made it abundantly clear that stopping Mark Johnson and his linemates will be their main strategy against the Devils in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: The Journalism School At Columbia Is 75
description: The Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University is celebrating its 75th anniversary this week with a series of seminars on journalistic issues and reunions of old grads.

title: Hiding in the Trade Bill, a Drug Ripoff
description: LEAD: Buried in the trade bill, which awaits President Reagan's signature, is a special-interest provision that poses a grave threat to health care consumers. Even if the bill is vetoed, precedent set by the provision could damage Congress as an institution.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Homer & Durham Wins Burpee Seed Account
description: The W. Atlee Burpee Company, the venerable seed marketer, has hired a general advertising agency for the first time in memory. It is Homer & Durham.

title: Corrections
description: The headline yesterday on an obituary of William H. Van Rensselaer misstated his occupation. He was executive director of the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: TIME once again for the annual ritual of abandonment and flirtation: putting the solid, comfortable, starchy winter vegetables into the closet and taking up with those sweet, tender young things like asparagus, new peas, baby spinach, pink potatoes. If your mother were here, she would talk some sense into you.

title: Exposaic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,547,000 and $1,732,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $287,000 for the quarter and $574,00 for the 6 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $110,000 for the quarter and $374,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $334,000 and $507,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sony-Symbolics
description: The Sony Microsystems Company, Sony's Palo Alto, Calif., unit that markets technical computer work stations, said it had formed a strategic alliance with Symbolics Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., a leading supplier of work stations and software for artificial intelligence applications. Under the agreement, Symbolic will resell Sony's new work stations and act as a service organization. Later, Symbolic will offer systems based on Sony's next generation of work stations.

title: Home Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized capital losses of $2.8 million. c-After realized capital gains of $42.7 million.

title: Belgian Joblessness Falls
description: Belgium's unemployment rate improved last month from a year ago, falling to 10.5 percent from 11.5 percent in 1987, the National Labor Office reported today. The April rate, down from 10.9 percent in March, was the lowest level in the last year.

title: Acuson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Fannie Mae Makes A 2-Part Offering
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $1.2 billion of debentures in two maturities through various dealers.

title: BOLIVIAN PEASANTS PIN HOPES ON COCA
description: Despite the increased momentum of anti-drug operations in Bolivia, new plantings of coca bush dot the main growing area for the raw material of cocaine.

title: Carroll Righter Dies; Hollywood Astrologer
description: Carroll Righter, an astrologer to movie stars and a writer of a syndicated daily column for 166 newspapers around the world, died Saturday. He was 88 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Liberty Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital gain of $6,863,000. c-After a loss of $1,031,000 from discontinued operations and a capital gain of $4,303,000.
