title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LADIES OF THE MORNING I pluck a tuft of years ago nesting between Eggs Florentine and my perfumed Mimosa - a reminiscence of crumbs in bed frail coffee, jam and a gurgle up of Happy Mother's Day. JUDITH FILKER CARLUCCIO

title: Chemical in Wine Tied to Migraines
description: A TEAM of English researchers may have discovered why some red wine gives some people severe headaches. The group, headed by Dr. Merton Sandler at Queen Charlotte's Hospital in London, thinks that flavanoids, the powerful chemical compounds that give red wine its color, are partly to blame.

title: U.S. Agencies Submit Plans for Drug Testing
description: Final rules for random drug testing of Government employees ranging from the White House chief of staff to secretaries were presented to Congress today by Federal agencies.

title: Record Price for Johns Work
description: Jasper Johns's fiercely compelling ''Diver,'' from 1962, was sold last night at Christie's for $4.2 million, a record at auction for the artist. The buyer was not identified.

title: White House Confirms Reagans Follow Astrology, Up to a Point
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are both deeply interested in astrology, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today, and two former White House officials said Mrs. Reagan's concerns had influenced the scheduling of important events.

title: VTX Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been restated to give retroactive effect to the 5-for-4 stock split declared effective March 17.

title: Ernest G. Weiss, Accountant, 71
description: Ernest G. Weiss, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse, died of a heart attack Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

title: Amdahl's New Mainframes
description: The Amdahl Corporation today introduced a series of mainframe computers that it said are more powerful than any machines currently compatible with I.B.M.'s 3090 series. Amdahl, which is based in

title: A Maverick Horseman Upsets Tradition at Churchill Downs
description: Louie Roussel 3d is sometimes called King Louis III in his native Louisiana. In Kentucky, where the owner and trainer is preparing to send out Risen Star in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, he is being called ''a loose horse'': headstrong, flighty and hard to run down.

title: Grants Sought for Peace Corps Volunteers
description: For years the Pentagon has offered financial incentives to college students who agree to serve in the armed forces after graduation. Now a new bill would grant Federal aid to students who agree to serve as Peace Corps volunteers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Keystone Camera Products reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Keystone said the latest year loss was substantially because of the discontinuance of its video cassette business.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,421,000 relating to the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: The Reign Of McEnroe
description: ''BUT who needs it more, do you need tennis more, or does tennis need you more?'' Diane Sawyer asked John McEnroe on ''60 Minutes'' Sunday night.

title: 70 Held in Brazil Drug Raid
description: The police seized more than 330 pounds of pure cocaine and arrested at least 70 people in the southwestern state of Mato Grosso do Sul, a police spokesman said today. The spokesman, Carlos Geraldi, said the police discovered the cocaine, bound for Spain, in raids on private homes Monday and today. Those arrested included Brazilians, Bolivians and Paraguayans.

title: Barry Wright Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter includes a charge of about $900,000 related to costs associated with the possible restructuring of the company. Year-ago first quarter includes a net gain of about $800,000 from the sale of a building.

title: USG Is Suing Merrill Over Role With Desert
description: The USG Corporation filed a lawsuit yesterday against Merrill Lynch & Company for its role in the hostile tender offer for the company made by Desert Partners L.P.

title: INSIDE
description: Retailing as Usual

title: Review/Art; The Felicitous Output of a Tragic French Sculptor
description: The National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington has done us all a service by presenting the retrospective exhibition of sculpture, paintings and drawings by Camille Claudel (1864-1943). The show - assembled and catalogued by Reine-Marie Paris, the artist's great-niece, and Meredith Martindale - can be seen through May 31.

title: NVRyan LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: A Corridor Exchange in Feud Over Police and Fire Divers
description: Following is the exchange yesterday among Fire Commissioner Joseph F. Bruno, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward in a corridor at City Hall, as recorded by The New York Times, moments after the Mayor announced a new accord in which the Police Department will train Fire Department divers and use them interchangeably:

title: Grand Jury Clears Everyone In Fatal Philadelphia Siege
description: A Philadelphia grand jury today cleared everyone involved of criminal liability for death and destruction resulting from the city's fiery 1985 confrontation with the radical group Move. Those cleared included Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other top city officials.

title: Crowe, in Gulf, Terms Iran a Dangerous Foe
description: Iran remains a dangerous foe in the Persian Gulf despite losses in battles with the United States Navy two weeks ago, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today.

title: A Second Festival of Serious Iconoclasm
description: ''Serious Fun!,'' the experimental arts festival that brought downtown performance art to Lincoln Center for the first time last year, is to return to Alice Tully Hall next July with an expanded series of iconoclastic performance, dance and musical events.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aaron Rents Inc., Atlanta, a furniture rental and sales company, announced that Lee Hulsebus had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: McEnroe Is Upset By Perez, No. 136
description: John McEnroe understood there would be days like this, when he would stumble in his bid to become a dominant player again. On the second point of yesterday's match at Forest Hills against Diego Perez of Uruguay, McEnroe slipped and fell following his serve to the net, suffering abrasions on his leg and hand. They will be reminders of a match he would rather forget, and the sooner the better.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Biederman: Returning to Pre-TV Days
description: HAVING worked together for almost four years, Barry Biederman and John F. Kelly of Biederman & Company, see eye to eye on the future of their agency and its place in the big picture. And that's one reason Mr. Kelly, 43 years old and already chief operating officer, has just been promoted to president.

title: LAB SEEKS TO TEST GENE-SPLICED DRUG
description: A laboratory engaged in biomedical research is seeking Federal permission for tests in the wild involving a vaccine against rabies made by techniques of genetic manipulation.

title: Walker Not Buying
description: Herschel Walker, a running back for the Dallas Cowboys, said yesterday that he had considered and then abondoned an idea to try to buy the team for which he plays.

title: Pitfalls and Opportunities in Arms Sales
description: The Reagan Administration expects U.S. arms sales to reach $15 billion this year. Not long ago, that news would have touched off earnest but misleading debate on the evils of all arms exports.

title: Eastman Kodak Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 20
description: On Sept. 11, 1987, the company's board of directors declared a partial common stock split which was effected in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend to shareowners of record on Sept. 23, 1987. Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1987 have been restated to give effect to the partial stock split. The company said the 1988 first quarter results include the contribution of Sterling Drug Inc. from the effective date of its acquisition, February 23. The company also said net earnings for the quarter were favorably affected by a gain from foreign exchange transactions in 1988, compared with a loss in last year's first quarter.

title: A SOVIET WARNING ON POLISH STRIKES
description: In a sign of growing official concern here about the spreading labor unrest in Poland, the Soviet press and television warned tonight that strikes there endangered the Polish economy.

title: NBC Sells Affliate in Buffalo
description: Tak Communications agreed yesterday to buy WGRZ-TV the NBC affiliate in Buffalo, for $100 million. Sharad Tak, the company's sole shareholder, already owns four television stations in Wisconsin and one in Honolulu.

title: Worries Rise Over Crumbling Books
description: The growth of a library's collection of books, maps, manuscripts and other materials is usually a source of pride.

title: With Few Dissenters, Methodists Adopt Hymnal and Worship Book
description: The United Methodist Church has seldom been as united as it was today when its chief policy-making body adopted a revised hymnal and book of worship.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Gretzky Sets Up Oiler Victory
description: Wayne Gretzky set up three goals and the Edmonton Oilers threw a defensive shell round the listless Detroit Red Wings for a 4-1 victory tonight in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Review/Rock; Del-Lords: 60's Mufti, 80's Sounds
description: The Del-Lords started Sunday's first set at the Bottom Line with a ringing guitar chord and a wild holler, two rock-and-roll basics; the bomping drumbeat came in a few seconds later. The band members, in T-shirts and blue jeans, looked like every generation of bar-band rockers since the 1960's - but their songs, especially Scott Kempner's lyrics, are unmistakably 1980's rock. They give country-rock and rockabilly a belt of post-punk, New York adrenalin. And like a juvenile gang joining the Boy's Club in some old movie, the Del-Lords have turned their street sense and untamed spirit toward notions a little more high-minded than simple hell-raising.

title: Connecticut Senate Votes Property Tax Relief Plan
description: Under pressure from Gov. William A. O'Neill, the Connecticut Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to an $18 million property tax relief plan that does not include a $25,000 homestead exemption provision opposed by the Governor and defeated Monday in the House of Representatives.

title: Another Moor of Venice
description: To the Editor:

title: College Loan Trust Selling $450.92 Million of Bonds
description: Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers are offering $450.92 million of bonds of College and University Facility Loan Trust Two in four tranches. They are secured by loans purchased by the trust from the United States Education Department.

title: On Second Thought . . .
description: Recent reports of the imminent demise of the nomination of Bernard H. Siegan to be a Federal appeals court judge appear to have been premature.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE public relations director of a large California winery was asked recently what she considered to be the role of wine writers. She replied, in effect, ''To describe what a wine tastes like to someone who has never tasted it.''

description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes staged a small technical rally in sleepy trading yesterday.

title: Jane Byrne Joins Edelman
description: Edelman Public Relations, the nation's largest privately held public-relations agency, said today that Chicago's former Mayor, Jane M. Byrne, had joined the firm as a senior public affairs consultant.

title: A Los Angeles Sale Of Revenue Bonds
description: The Los Angeles County Transportation Commission is tentatively offering about $112 million of sales tax revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 8.088 percent for a maturity in 2018. The underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Gulf Resources & Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $16,173,000. The company said the year-ago first quarter net from operations includes a gain of $38,200,000 from the sale of investment in Imperial Continental Gas Association.

title: Dr. Philip Powers, 75, Educator and Physicist
description: Dr. Philip Nathan Powers, an educator and nuclear physicist, died of pneumonia and renal failure Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: Companies

title: Penn Square Case Ends in a Mistrial
description: The trial of a former officer of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and a former Penn Square Bank vice president ended in a mistrial today when a jury could not reach a verdict.

title: 2 Charged In Rigging Of Lottery
description: A computer expert who worked for a company that helps operate the Pennsylvania state lottery printed a fake ticket so that he and a friend could share a $15.2 million jackpot, state officials said today.

Minneapolis
description: LEAD: MINNEAPOLIS and St. Paul residents are savoring Florida triggerfish, Mexican snook, Pacific Northwest cabezon and Northeastern tautog thanks to Suzanne Weinstein. She has developed a thriving business called Coastal Seafoods to market fresh, hard-to-find seafood.

description: These figures represent the combined totals of Santa Anita Operating Co. and Santa Anita Realty Enterprises Inc.

title: Texas Electric Offering Bonds
description: The Texas Utilities Electric Company is offering $300 million of first and collateral trust bonds in two equal parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Talking Up an Idea
description: For years, President Reagan has been unsuccessfully urging Congress to give him authority to veto part of a bill while approving the rest, rather than being forced to reject a lengthy piece of legislation because of one objectionable feature. Now some of the President's conservative allies are arguing that he already has that power - or at least something approaching it.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Paul A. Bilzerian, of Florida, and a group of investors has purchased a 6.25 percent stake in Fortune Financial Group Inc. and said it might seek control of the bank holding company based in Clearwater, Fla.

description: b-Includes capital gains of $407,914 and $550 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

description: The Rural Electric Utilities-Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative is offering about $172.1 million of grantor trust certificates via Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: More Data From N.A.S.D.
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it would expand its public disclosure of the disciplinary histories of its member firms and brokers.

title: Economic Scene; Soviet Reforms Meet Reality
description: EVEN the most enthusiastic admirers in the West of perestroika predicted that the Soviet economy would slow to a crawl while enterprises retooled and learned to fend for themselves in free markets. But through miscalculation or political expediency, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, chose to sell the effort to restructure the economy and to reduce rigidity in the Soviet system as painless change. By creating expectations certain to be unfulfilled, he has made reform far more vulnerable to its domestic critics.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LAMB is the meat most closely associated with spring, but the term spring lamb is often misused by restaurants and retail shops. A real spring lamb should be less than a year old and weigh between 40 and 60 pounds. Such lamb is prized for its tenderness.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: United States and Soviet officials, who began talks today on renewing the world's biggest bilateral grain agreement with statements of optimism, said wide differences remained after nine hours of difficult negotiating.

title: Xyvision Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $7,000. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $383,000 and $1,733,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Baseball; Stewart (7-0) Keeps Athletics on a Roll
description: Dave Stewart became the first pitcher in the major leagues to win seven games, and Carney Lansford and Mike Gallego each batted in three runs as the Oakland Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 8-2, today for their ninth straight victory.

title: Pittway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
S.E.C. to Vote on Proposal To Broaden Trading Halts
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will vote on Thursday on a proposed rule that could lead to a universal ban on trading of a stock in all domestic markets when an important news announcement is pending.

title: 4 Powers Meet to Explore Ways to End Angola War
description: Representatives of the United States, South Africa, Cuba and Angola met here today for what were described as exploratory talks about ending the war in Angola.

title: Gain Seen for Bill Aiding Discounters
description: Sponsors of legislation that would make it easier for discounters to bring price-fixing cases against manufacturers and full-price retailers said today that the Supreme Court's decision on discount retailing would probably improve the prospects for their bill.

title: Yale Coddles and Shares Rare Books
description: It has been called a literary treasure chest, with jewels that include the original manuscripts of Gertrude Stein, the maps of Lewis and Clark and the musical scores of Cole Porter.

title: Utah Lawyer a Choice as Meese Aide
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, after a lengthy and embarrassing search, has chosen Harold G. Christensen, a Utah lawyer, to become his chief deputy at the Justice Department, according to an Administration official.

title: Mortgage & Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Las Vegas Journal; Envisioning High-Speed Artery to Gaming Tables
description: Twenty years ago when Howard Hughes proposed to make this desert city the hub of a futuristic high-speed rail line, the few people who listened thought the idea was as eccentric as the billionaire himself.

title: Reagan to Press Religious Freedom at Summit
description: President Reagan said today that he would call for greater religious freedom when he travels to the Soviet Union this month.

title: Pushing the Possible in Poland
description: Poland in 1988 begins to resemble Poland in past years of crisis. Again, workers challenge the Communist Party's power and legitimacy. Again, the outcome will reverberate far beyond Poland, in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: DUKAKIS STRETCHES HIS LEAD, SWEEPING OHIO AND INDIANA
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis lengthened his already formidable lead today for the Democratic Presidential nomination, winning strong victories over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Indiana and Ohio primaries.

title: 15 Indicted in Rutgers Hazing Death
description: Fifteen members of a Rutgers University fraternity have been indicted in the alcohol-related death of an 18-year-old freshman pledge at a party last February, the Middlesex County Prosecutor announced today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not exonerate the men responsible for this disaster.

Market Place; Socially Screened Funds' Favorites
description: THOSE who style themselves part of the ''socially responsible investment'' movement have argued that investors can prosper financially, as well as spiritually, if they avoid companies whose products or policies violate their moral beliefs. But that does not mean that ethically guided investors have been spared the shock of last October's market plunge, continued uncertainty about their vulnerability to program trading and fears about the economic outlook.

title: Old Spaghetti Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
With a Hand or 2, an Old-Timer Revives
description: The Sun no longer shines for all, but the lights within its elegant bronze vestige glow again, telling time to anyone who looks up at Broadway and Chambers Street.

title: A Deep-Fried Comfort Food And Sizzling Taste of Mexico
description: EACH of the electric-orange picnic tables in one of Tijuana's best-known restaurants holds a basket of deep-fried pork skins, a few small wedges of lime and a dish of salsa.

title: 400 Anti-Abortionists Held in Queens Protest
description: More than 400 anti-abortion protesters were charged with disorderly conduct yesterday after they shut the office of Dr. Farzan Shirazi at 83-06 Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Douglas Turner Moves Its Accounts to Venet
description: Because of the serious illness of its founder and president, the Douglas Turner Inc. agency of Newark has switched its accounts and key employees over to Venet Advertising of Union, N.J. The billings are about $10 million.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: SWEET custards are the quintessential dessert of childhood, and in the form of flan are inextricably linked to Spanish cooking. A decade ago, savory versions appeared under the name of quiche. Many other dishes, like the Greek pastichio, depend on custard to hold them together.

title: Bangladesh Insurgents Kill 13 Bengali Settlers
description: Tribal insurgents shot and killed 13 Bengali settlers in attacks Sunday in southeastern Bangladesh, bringing the number of dead to 36 in the last week, the authorities said today.

title: In Taiwan, Change Sweeps Out Taboos
description: This is the image of Taiwan in flux: on a sultry Saturday night in the busy West Gate market, a taxi driver stands on a flag-bedecked truck and shouts his anti-Government protest to the crowd. Nearby, shoppers continue haggling over the price of shoes and snake blood, while worshipers crowd into an open-air temple holding burning incense sticks aloft and bowing before the gods.

title: Police and Fire Divers: 2 Different Techniques
description: The New York City Police and Fire Department scuba teams use different equipment and methods that reflect contrasting approaches to underwater rescues, according to experts in both departments.

title: Network Equipment Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,155,000. c-After tax credits of $982,000 for the quarter and $2,354,000 for the year.

title: ISRAELIS SEARCH HOMES IN LEBANON
description: At least 1,000 Israeli soldiers in tanks and armored personnel carriers stormed through parts of southern Lebanon today, searching homes, questioning Lebanese villagers and distributing warning leaflets.

title: 'Cocoanuts' Extends Run
description: The Arena Stage's production of ''The Cocoanuts,'' which had been scheduled to run until June 5, has been extended at least through July 3. The production, directed by Doug Wager, received uniformly favorable reviews. It is the first staging in 60 years of the George S. Kaufman and Irving Berlin show that introduced the Marx Brothers to Broadway.

title: American Carriers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fortaleza Journal; Political Maverick Tilts at the Lords of Patronage
description: When Tasso Jereissati became Governor of Ceara last year, the freshman politician began in what seemed to be the most impolitic of ways by banning all personal favors and warning relatives and friends to expect no jobs in his administration.

title: Patten Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt of $243,000 and $1.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Cone's First Start A First-Class Job
description: David Cone and Lee Mazzilli achieved ''firsts'' last night, and both were significant for the Mets young and old.

title: Heavier Gastineau Is Happier
description: In the laid-back, suburban atmosphere of the Jets' camp, ferocious talk was going on today.

title: Panel Approves Bans on Pretoria
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved legislation today barring all American investment in South Africa and imposing a near-total trade embargo against that country.

title: Hudson Revives And Yanks Win
description: Every day, it seems, there is a new role for Charles Hudson. He has been a middle-innings relief pitcher, a ninth-inning closer, a starter. When Billy Martin has asked, Hudson has been there.

title: JACKSONS' INCOME EXCEEDED $200,000
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and his wife, Jacqueline, reported income of more than $200,000 last year and paid about 25 percent of that in Federal taxes, according to their tax returns released today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page on Monday about the Office of Legal Counsel described the Supreme Court appointment of Associate Justice William Rehnquist incorrectly. It was made by President Nixon, not President Reagan.

title: Review/Theater; Mamet's Dark View of Hollywood As a Heaven for the Virtueless
description: Hell hath no fury like a screenwriter scorned, and American culture is all the livelier for it. Out of the rage of embittered novelists and playwrights in studio backlots has come an enduring literature, nearly all of it practicing the same scorched-earth policy toward Hollywood that Nathanael West first apotheosized in ''The Day of the Locust.'' While the theater has made many contributions of its own to the genre in the six decades since Kaufman and Hart mocked the early talking-picture industry in ''Once in a Lifetime,'' David Mamet's new play, ''Speed-the-Plow,'' may be the most cynical and exciting yet.

title: Entertainment Publications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $900,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $666,000 and $1,581,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,682,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: LAROUCHE JURORS ASKING FOR RELIEF
description: A Federal district judge is considering whether to declare a mistrial in at least part of the fraud and conspiracy case against the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., six of his aides and five of his political groups. The judge, Robert E. Keeton, said he would issue a decision Wednesday.

title: New Cray Product
description: Cray Research Inc., based in Minneapolis, introduced a new series of supercomputers offering up to four times the memory at the same or lower prices than the Cray X-MP series that it will replace. The new machines dubbed X-MP EA, for ''extended architecture,'' are based on the design of the Cray Y-MP introduced in February and can run programs developed for either the X-MP or Y-MP systems. Shipments of the new machines, which are priced from $2.5 million to $14 million, will begin in the third quarter of this year.

title: Out for the Season
description: J.J. Birden, the wide received from Oregon who was the first offensive player taken by the Cleveland Browns in the draft, tore a ligament in his right knee during a minicamp and will miss the 1988 season. (AP)

title: Malibu Grand Prix Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $324,000 from disposition of property and equipment and an extraordinary gain of $1,649,000 on the restructure of debt. c-After a gain of $3,487,000 on disposition of property and equipment and a gain of $13,582,000 on the restructure of debt.

title: Moog Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,740,000 from an accounting change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $75,000 for the quarter and $116,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter included a gain of $3.2 million from the exchange of Moog's industrial division and active suspension operations. It also included the establishment of $7 million in reserves for losses anticipated in future periods on long-term aerospace contracts.

title: Washington Energy Co reports earnings for 12mo March 31
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $3,215,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split March 27, 1987.

title: How a Pathologist Reshaped Seoul's Politics
description: Unwittingly, Dr. Hwang Juck Joon helped set into motion the cycle of protest and democratic progress that has dramatically reshaped South Korean politics over the last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Group's Net Increases 21% in Period
description: The Omnicom Group, whose components include BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 21 percent, to $7.6 million, or 31 cents a share, from $6.3 million, or 26 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter.

title: Review/Recital; Romantic Songs With Emphasis On 'Little Notes'
description: Barbara Hendricks's virtues as a song recitalist begin with a delectable, shimmering voice of pure quality: a sensuous pleasure to the ear. They continue with a beautiful, deft control of quick ''little notes'' such as decorate Schumann's ''Lied der Philine'' and Rachmaninoff's ''O Cease Thy Singing''; with an understanding respect for the piano part that moves her to collaborate with soloists like Dmitri Alexeev, who played for her Sunday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall; with a commitment to the romantic song literature and fine taste in programming, and with an evident care in preparation and musicianship.

title: Staley Rebuffs Tate & Lyle
description: Staley Continental Inc. today rejected Tate & Lyle P.L.C.'s revised $35-a-share offer for the company and disclosed that it was talking with lenders for a possible recapitalization.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Solidarity warned the Government that Poland faced major unrest if it refused to commit itself to major political change. The warning came as riot policemen surrounded the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk. Page A1

title: National Presto Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Copier Line Introduced By Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced a major series of copiers, including one model that will end its years of resistance to selling low-priced personal copiers.

title: Metro Datelines; Jersey Court Extends Homeless Benefits
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, on a 4-to-3 vote, yesterday granted a 30-day extension of state emergency assistence benefits for the homeless while a lower court rules on an appeal of the state's decision to limit benefits under the program to five months.

title: Lee Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain from discontinued operations of $152,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Pact on Nuclear Plant Bonds
description: Three groups of utilities agreed today to pay $65.2 million to bondholders in the latest round of out-of-court settlements connected with two abandoned nuclear plants. The lawsuit springs from the $2.25 billion securities default on plants owned by the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: Tax Receipts In Albany Fall Short
description: New York State collected almost $500 million less than expected in income-tax receipts last month, the state budget division announced today, prompting Wall Street to raise the interest rates on the state's borrowing and Governor Cuomo to call for plans for possible spending cuts.

title: Ousted Gorbachev Critic Backs Leader's Plan
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the ousted Moscow party leader, was quoted in a Soviet publication today as offering an endorsement of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive to restructure the Soviet economy.

title: Wedtech Testimony Cites Ex-C.I.A. Deputy
description: A former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency and an Israeli general were among the officials a South Bronx military contractor dealt with, according to testimony yesterday in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi.

title: Oil Prices Stabilize on Hopes for a Production Agreement
description: Oil prices steadied around the world today as spokesmen for several oil-producing nations said they had not abandoned hope of cooperating with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on steps to reduce production and bolster prices.

title: Providence Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $434,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: San Francisco
description: IN San Francisco, the latest in eating out may be the disaster dinner. The 82d anniversary of the San Francisco earthquake on April 18, 1906, was commemorated at a five-course dinner in the newly opened Grill Room at Stars restaurant.

title: Anger at Airline Masks Deregulation Worries
description: It seems that just about everybody in Washington is after the hide of the Texas Air Corporation and its chairman, Frank Lorenzo - the Transportation Department, the Federal courts, organized labor and Congress.

title: For the Chambers Jury, 'Intent' Proved to Be an Albatross
description: To the Editor:

title: Kansas City Plan Of Holder Rejected
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said that stockholders at its annual meeting had rejected a shareholder proposal to break up the company and spin off its non-transportation operations.

title: The Pop Life
description: Steeped in the South ''Scenes From the Southside,'' (RCA), the second album by Bruce Hornsby and the Range, is so suffused with Southern atmosphere that one can practically smell the honeysuckle and feel the humidity of the Virginia Tidewater area where many of the songs are set.

title: Emerson Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday misidentified Barbara Mikulski, the Maryland Democrat. She is a Senator, no longer a Representative.

title: Canadian Oxy Buying Moore Unit
description: Southdown Inc., which is acquiring a rival cement maker, Moore McCormack Resources Inc., said it would sell Moore's energy assets to Canadian Oxy Offshore Petroleum Ltd. for $148.8 million. Canadian Oxy is a subsidiary of Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd., which is about 48 percent owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Hexcel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Britons Defuse a Bomb On West German Base
description: British forces in West Germany said today that they had discovered and detonated a car bomb in a British army base in Bielefeld.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, has resigned La Victoria Foods, City of Industy, Calif., a maker of sauces, over creative differences.

title: El Paso Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,240,000 from an accounting change.

title: New Brunswick Scientific Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Lessons
description: ''Education,'' wrote Epictetus, ''means this: To be learning what is your own, and what is not your own.'' From the discourses recorded by his student, Arrian, we know that the great Stoic teacher was talking about self-knowledge, the long and difficult journey through the psyche and the soul.

title: Dukakis's Strong Suit Turns a Bit Weak
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is campaigning for President as a strong financial manager, but management of the Massachusetts budget is giving him political headaches at home.

title: Drug Counts Dropped for Woman at Slaying Scene
description: Drug charges were dismissed yesterday against Maritza Battista, one of the two women in an apartment where a police sergeant was accidentally shot to death in a narcotics raid last week. The charges were dropped after a police laboratory report said not enough cocaine had been found in the apartment to warrant a felony indictment.

title: Parker Accused In Court Papers
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates said in a pretrial statement filed last Friday in Federal court that years of cocaine addiction reduced Dave Parker from a star outfielder to an overweight, injury-prone second-rater who didn't deserve the money he got.

title: Review/Film; 'Mala Noche' on Skid Row
description: Other people's obsessions are more often funny than tragic. As Feydeau understood, there's something innately farcical in the sight of an otherwise rational being in the pursuit of a doomed desire. It's a measure of the talent of Gus Van Sant that his ''Mala Noche,'' opening today at Film Forum 1, remains as steadfastly, honestly grim as the Portland, Ore., skid row where most of it takes place.

title: Chicago Election Board Votes To Set Special Mayoral Race
description: The Chicago election board voted unanimously today to hold a special mayoral election early in 1989 to choose a successor to Mayor Harold Washington, who died in office last November.

title: Bavaro Arrested
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' All-Pro tight end, was among the 503 people arrested Monday during a demonstration in front of an abortion clinic on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Chicago Is Untroubled By Political Sex Scandal
description: When a local television station accused the 75-year-old president of the Cook County Board of trading jobs for sexual favors, the outrage was less than unanimous.

title: Guerrillas in Colombia Kidnap Five Foreigners
description: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped four foreigners today and took responsibility for the kidnapping of a French diplomat, officials said.

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fretter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of about $630,000.

title: A 30-Year Mortgage, I Presume?
description: On a supermarket parking lot was an $87,000 car. The price sticker was on the window. $87,000. It was a small car, only two seats, and a gear shift between them.

title: The Poor Don't Think America's Decline Is a Myth; Science Diverted
description: To the Editor:

title: Discount Ruling: Slight Impact Seen
description: A Supreme Court ruling on Monday will encourage some big, traditional merchants to put pressure on manufacturers of popular consumer products to stop supplying discounters, discount store executives and consumer advocates said yesterday.

title: Henley Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included a gain of $8.4 million from sale of investment in ACI International Ltd. The company had no share earnings for the year-ago quarter because it went public last December.

title: Corrections
description: The Social Events column on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a benefit at the Joyce Theater for Dan Wagoner and Dancers. It will be held Thursday, not today. The location of the party afterward has been changed to the Tower Gallery, 45 West 18th Street.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 On IRT Are Shot In Theft of Chains
description: A gunman shot and wounded two people on an IRT train in Brooklyn while stealing gold chains, the transit police said yesterday. The robber escaped with the jewelry. The incident occurred as the transit police, citing preliminary statistics, reported that felony crimes in the subways rose 5.4 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with the same period a year ago. There were 3,117 felony crimes in January, February and March, 159 more than in 1987, according to a transit police spokesman, Albert O'Leary.

title: Amplicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time 20 cent a share tax adjustment.

title: Metro Datelines; Officer and 3 Others Held in Cocaine Case
description: A 25-year-old New York City police officer and three other people have been charged with cocaine trafficking in Queens after a seven-month investigation, the Police Department and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration anounced yesterday.

title: Mobutu Banishes 2 Zairian Foes to Internal Exile
description: The Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko has arrested and sent into internal exile two leaders of the main opposition grouping, which has called for changing Zaire's one-party state into a two-party system.

title: No-Mess Chocolate . . . And No-Risk Bubbly
description: Popping open a bottle of warm champagne that has just been agitated can send the cork rocketing away at 200 miles an hour. So Theta Resources Inc., a San Francisco industrial design company, has come up with a champagne stopper that it says could prevent such errant corks from nicking a chandelier or injuring a guest.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up 15.09, to 2,058.36
description: Stock prices spurted in late trading yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average by 15.09 points, to 2,058.36.

title: Arkansas Best Suitor Gets Takeover Lesson
description: Emanuel R. Pearlman, the would-be acquirer of the Arkansas Best Corporation, had been in the takeover business all of 48 hours when he got a strong dose of what lies ahead. The target company ignored his phone calls. The newspapers gave his $230 million deal short shrift. And he balks at the suggestion that he is a corporate raider. ''I do mind it, because we're not looking to destroy the company and fire everybody,'' said the 28-year-old former protege of Asher B. Edelman, the well-known takeover specialist.

title: The Poor Don't Think America's Decline Is a Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Walesa Calls for Major Reforms To Prevent Broader Labor Unrest
description: As riot policemen surrounded the Lenin shipyard here, the outlawed Solidarity union warned the Government today that it faced widespread unrest if it refused to commit itself to major political change.

title: Real Estate; How to Sell Retail Space In Manhattan
description: FOR nearly 10 years the developers of residential condominiums in New York City have found a receptive market for their apartments. But retail space in these residential buildings has been hard to sell despite the pressures of rising store rents in many parts of the city.

title: Eliminating The Meter Reader
description: Microelectronics has begun to change the electric meter, the device that measures electricity consumption. New meters equipped with microprocessors and other sophisticated electronics can measure electrical use in five-minute increments around the clock, and report back to the utility headquarters monthly, daily, or even on demand, all by using the customer's phone line.

title: Saudis and Iran: New Assertiveness
description: It was well past midnight when oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries emerged from the group's bunkerlike headquarters Saturday, stunned by Saudi Arabia's rejection of a plan that would have cut oil production and raised prices.

title: Proler International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss In the prior year the company adopted the FIFO method of inventory valuation, resulting in a charge of $1.2 million.

title: Reward for Unseld
description: Another coach who took over a team during this past season also had a rewarding day. Wes Unseld, who guided the Washington Bullets into the playoffs, was among four men inducted yesterday into the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: Gazing Skyward for Answers Below
description: The belief that human lives are shaped by the positions of the planets probably dates from the third millenium B.C., but, despite its great antiquity, astrology remains as entrenched in folklore as ever.

title: Review/Music; St. Martin Chamber Orchestra
description: For the second of their two Manhattan concerts this season, Neville Marriner and his Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields London chamber orchestra offered a really lovely program Monday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: SCI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Theater; Growing Up Insufferable in Two One-Act Plays
description: In the second of two related one-act plays grouped together as ''Terry by Terry,'' the title character announces that he is the author of the first play on the bill. Shifting between levels of reality, ''Terry by Terry'' has a novel Pirandello twist: a play within a playwright. The real playwright (at the Manhattan Punch Line Theater) is Mark Leib and his own possible proximity to his protagonist is one of the evening's several curiosities.

title: Bridge
description: Tournaments with cash prizes seem to be coming to the United States. After much soul-searching, the American Contract Bridge League has made plans for such an event in Atlantic City next year, and before then, in early November, there will be one in Incline Village, Nev., on Lake Tahoe. It is planned by an English entrepreneur, Paul Hackett.

title: Reeds Jewelers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes $85,000 from a non-recurring recovery of a theft claim.

title: Santucci Is Faulted in a Slaying Inquiry
description: Asserting that the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, had mishandled an investigation into the fatal shooting of a black man by white police officers, the N.A.A.C.P. yesterday urged Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor to reopen the case.

title: About New York; Seeking Stardom In 'Joe Clark, The Movie'
description: In the works was a Warner Brothers movie about Joe Clark, the principal at Eastside High in Paterson, N.J., the guy whose combative control methods got him on the cover of Time magazine, holding his Adirondack Big Stick, the Willie Mays model, flame treated.

title: Corning Officer Says Revere Deal Isn't Last
description: The acquisition by Corning Glass Works of Revere Ware Inc., its closest competitor in household cookware, marked the first outside venture for Corning in the housewares industry. But last week's deal is unlikely to be the last, said Edward T. Fogarty, who has turned around Corning's ailing consumer products division since arriving in 1983.

title: Zenith National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a realized gain on investments of $609,000 and $2,368,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. The company said results for the first quarter of 1988 and 1987 include tax benefits of $595,000 and $1,040,000, respectively.

title: Justice's Update on School Desegregation
description: To the Editor:

title: General Dynamics Pact
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has been chosen to design a new space launching rocket for military satellites and to build 11 such rockets for more than $500 million, the Air Force said today. The St. Louis-based company had been competing with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to provide the new Medium Launch Vehicle-2 rockets, the Air Force said.

title: Modine Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $985,000 for a settlement with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Robert P. Hyde, 58, Ex-Brewery Executive
description: Robert P. Hyde, a retired executive who was president of Rheingold Breweries and later executive vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died of cancer Friday at Community General Hospital in Syracuse. He was 58 years old and lived in Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: Thermo Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: 'Inspect Unto Others' Is a Good Way to Save
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Edge Spurs To Sweep Series
description: Magic Johnson had 25 points and 11 assists, and Mychal Thompson scored 23 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the San Antonio Spurs, 109-107, and advanced to the semifinal round of the Western Conference playoffs.

title: Loyola Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Gypsum Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $2.9 million resulting from the repurchase of $69.9 million face value of the company's outstanding discount debentures. The 1987 results have been restated to reflect the adoption of the Financial Accounting Standards Board's No. 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Wisconsin Public Service Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Entertainment Marketing Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,858,788 and an extraordinary gain of $1,221,944. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,035,482 from discontinued operations. The latest year includes a pretax charge of $9,829,573 from writedown of investment in Crazy Eddie Inc. The latest year loss from discontinued operations includes a net charge of $2,567,597 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Reportedly Knew of Noriega Role in Killing
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega participated in the killing of a priest in Panama in 1971, a fact that was almost immediately known to the United States because of intelligence monitoring of Panamanian military communications, according to a former United States Government official.

title: Star Turn For Chef Of Many Subtleties
description: LEAD: JEAN-GEORGES VONGERICHTEN, the chef at the Restaurant Lafayette in the Drake Hotel since 1986, is a compact, youthful 31 years old and as starched as a fresh tea towel.

title: No-Mess Chocolate . . .
description: Long years of monkeying with mousses at a Geneva laboratory has produced for the Battelle Memorial Institute a chocolate that will not melt in hot weather.

title: Moore-Handley Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter results included a tax benefit of $83,000 because of the adoption of FAS No. 96, relating to changes in deferred tax accounting.

title: Network Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tightrope Act Begins On Filling No. 2 Slots
description: Politicians are forever searching for complicated problems that they can sound thoughtful about.

title: Meese Backing of Event in Japan Investigated
description: The Office of Government Ethics started an investigation today into a letter signed by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and sent to 30,000 people encouraging them to attend a conference in Japan, the head of the office said tonight.

title: Welbilt Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Donald Byrd Offering Two Dance Premieres
description: Donald Byrd/The Group is to present two world premieres, ''Enactments in Time of Plague'' and ''Speakeasy,'' in a season today through Saturday at Symphony Space Theater, Broadway at 95th Street. Mr. Byrd's work combines ballet and modern dance, Afro-American social dance and theater dance and often deals with social issues.

title: Bronx District Attorney Race Opens, Bitterly
description: Opening what promises to be one of the most bitter primaries in years, Philip T. Foglia formally announced yesterday that he would run against Bronx District Attorney Paul T. Gentile for the right to represent the Democratic Party in the elections this fall.

title: Biden Resting After Surgery For Second Brain Aneurysm
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. underwent surgery today to correct an aneurysm in an artery that supplies blood to the right side of the brain, a spokesman for the Walter Reed Army Medical Center said.

title: ALEXANDRIA, Va.
description: CUSTOMERS stepping into the Mediterranean Bakery are greeted by the aromas of chickpeas simmering in vats and of fresh-baked pita bread. There are rose waters on the shelves, cookbooks written in Arabic and English, and copies of the Koran. Middle Easterners hungry for the tastes of their homelands know the shop as an asylum. Its patrons include diplomats, bankers and business executives from Arab countries, as well as several Saudi Arabian princes.

title: Boxing Notebook; Dokes's Comeback Perks Up
description: With his knockout of James Pritchard last Thursday, Michael Dokes re-established his credibility as a fighter much faster than has another former heavyweight champion, George Foreman, who began his comeback in March 1987.

title: ROH SET TO SHARE LEADERSHIP POSTS
description: President Roh Tae Woo is ready to share leadership posts with the opposition in the National Assembly after his party's losses in legislative elections, party officials said today.

title: Chili's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $600,000 from an accounting change.

title: Gullah Cooking: Improvising on Cultures Past
description: WHEREVER Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor is, she cooks. ''I think that's why my friends keep me around,'' she said, as she tried to find her way around a ''borrowed'' kitchen in South Carolina's low country near Charleston, not far from where she was born. ''They always say, 'Come see me and stay over,' and they want me to cook.''

title: American Biltrite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $319,000.

title: Kodak Income Climbs 46.1%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's earnings rose 46.1 percent in the first quarter of 1988, to $260 million, from $178 million a year ago, the company said today.

title: Anchor Glass
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said it would close a Tennessee container plant and a Pennsylvania mold manufacturing plant by early August as part of its restructuring. The closing could mean that about 350 employees at the Chattanooga, Tenn., plant and 100 at the Reno, Pa., factory will lose their jobs.

title: Koch Sues in Traffic-Agent Assaults
description: Seeking to discourage assaults on New York City traffic-enforcement agents, the Koch administration has joined three agents in a lawsuit against three people who pleaded guilty to separate attacks.

title: 2 Workers Slain in Robbery At a Dry Cleaners in Queens
description: Two store employees were shot to death and a third was seriously wounded last night in a robbery of a dry cleaners in Queens, the police said.

title: Vote Shows A Victory For Gillette
description: The Gillette Company declared a narrow victory yesterday in its proxy fight with Coniston Partners, but the New York-based investment firm said it would review the preliminary count and possibly challenge the final outcome.

title: Kansas Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brock Hotel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Includes tax credits of $358,000 for the latest quarter and $1,213,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said holders approved its name change to Integra - A Hotel & Restaurant Co.

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
United Brands Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed its higher earnings to substantially higher profits in its Chiquita fresh fruit operations.

title: United Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOOD NOTES
description: For Mom on Her Day Instead of sending last-minute flowers for Mother's Day, how about breakfast in bed?

title: The Joke's on Meese
description: When a high-ranking White House official asked Leonard Garment, the Republican lawyer and punster, at what point he thought the heat to quit would finally reach his friend, Mr. Meese, Mr. Garment replied, ''It all depends when Bush comes to shove.''

title: Lynam Is Re-signed
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, who failed this season to make the playoffs for the first time in 13 years, yesterday signed Jim Lynam, an assistant who took over as head coach in midseason when Matt Guokas was dismissed. Lynam, whose 16-23 record as coach was not as good as the team's 20-23 mark under Guokas, received a three-year contract. ''The 76ers organization views Jim Lynam as a top-notch communicator and motivator,'' said General Manager John Nash.

title: Guest Chef Adds Spice to College Fare
description: LEAD: WHEN students here at the University of New Hampshire get the urge to eat authentically prepared Chinese food, they usually have to travel 70 miles south to Chinatown in Boston. description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $6,912,000 on property dispositions, compared with $16,207,000 a year ago. c-Includes a charge of $1,125,000 in connection with the refinancing of certain debt.

title: Bears Release 2
description: The Chicago Bears have released a former All-Pro safety, Todd Bell, and a tight end, Tim Wrightman, a member of the 1986 Super Bowl champions. Bell, a six-year veteran, was waived. He earned All-Pro honors in 1984, sat out the Super Bowl season because of a contract dispute and has seen only part-time duty two years.

title: Lucky Discussing Sale of Some Stores
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had been talking with third parties interested in buying the Arizona and Florida stores that make up nearly a third of the chain. Lucky, the nation's sixth-largest supermarket chain, began the negotiations Monday, a spokeswoman, Judy Decker, said. She declined to elaborate.

title: People
description: * James M. Palumbo has been named senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis.

title: Beirut Christian Clash Feared
description: Lebanon's top Christian political leaders held intensive consultations today in an attempt to avert a violent confrontation between Christian militiamen and Government troops loyal to President Amin Gemayel.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the credit markets misstated the source of a request for the repricing of New York State's offering of $2.6 billion in one-year notes. The underwriters, led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, requested it.

description: For the firefighters and police officers at what they call Fort Pitt, a joint fire house and police station beside the Williamsburg Bridge on Pitt Street, the public squabble over who should be in charge of underwater rescue operations is very much a family affair.

title: POLAND'S BISHOPS NAME 5 MEDIATORS IN LABOR CONFLICT
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops, apparently acting with the approval of the Polish authorities, authorized five Catholic laymen today to act as mediators to break the deadlock in labor conflicts now in their second week.

title: House Votes to Cut Spending on Anti-Missile Plan
description: The House of Representatives, disregarding the threat of a veto, voted today to reduce the spending ceiling on President Reagan's plan for a space-based defense against missiles next year. It set the limit at $3.5 billion, $1.4 billion less than the Administration requested.

title: Plymouth Five Cents Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metro Matters; Battery Park City, And Measuring A Cuomo Friend
description: When Florence Frucher told Governor Cuomo that her daughter was debating whether to attend Harvard or Williams next fall, the Governor offered this fatherly advice: ''Nobody turns down Harvard.''

title: RJR Nabisco Test Of Cigarette Set
description: The nation's largest cigarette manufacturer, RJR Nabisco Inc., plans to begin test-marketing an almost smokeless cigarette in the final three months of the year. The plan was announced at the company's annual stockholders meeting in Atlanta. The company is not saying where the cigarette will be sold or under what brand name, said David Fishel, a spokesman for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in Winston-Salem, N.C., a RJR Nabisco subsidiary.

title: Tenneco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3 million. The latest quarter results include a one-time $25 million credit for foreign taxes related to Colombian oil operations.

title: Review/Ballet; Grandeur and Spectacle
description: A Shakespearean tragedy was transformed into dance on Tuesday House when American Ballet Theater offered the first of a series of performances of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's choreographic version of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The ballet, to Prokofiev's score, will continue for the rest of this week at the Met, and Saturday night's performance will be telecast nationally by PBS as part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series.

title: Father Serra, Founder of California Missions, to Be Beatified
description: The Roman Catholic Church has taken another step toward declaring Junipero Serra a saint by announcing that the 18th-century Franciscan missionary will be beatified by Pope John Paul II at a ceremony in the Vatican.

title: U.S. Will Mail AIDS Advisory to All Households
description: The Federal Government today began a three-week campaign to inform Americans about AIDS, focused around a pamphlet to be mailed to every household in the nation.

title: Rapist Is Sentenced to 15 Years
description: The suffering of a blind woman who was raped and robbed two years ago and who felt compelled to leave Manhattan was recounted yesterday at the sentencing of the man who pleaded guilty to the crime.

title: Ogilvy Income Soars
description: The Ogilvy Group, whose main component is the Ogilvy & Mather worldwide ad agency, had a marvelously improved first quarter. Although revenues only improved 17.6 percent from the corresponding quarter in 1987, net income more than doubled thanks to a large improvement in operating profit. Revenues were $190 million, up from $161.6 million, while net income was $3.5 million, up from $1.4 million, or 24 cents a share compared with 10 cents.

New York City Drops 3 Banks as Underwriters
description: New York City officials stunned Chase Manhattan Bank, Citibank and Chemical Bank yesterday by announcing that the three banks would no longer belong to the elite group of managing underwriters for the more than $1 billion of bonds the city sells each year.

description: Greg Walker and Ivan Calderon hit home runs tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat Roger Clemens, the ace of the Boston pitching staff, for the fifth consecutive time, 6-2.

title: Yachting's Crocodile Dundee
description: IT wasn't over, but Ben Lexcen knew it was over. Out on the blue water of the Indian Ocean off Fremantle, Australia, early last year, the 12-Meter yacht Kookaburra III was about to lose to Stars & Stripes in the third race of what would be a 4-0 sweep in the America's Cup final. Not even bothering to watch the finish through the wide windows of the press boat, the designer of the winged keel that enabled Australia II to win the cup in 1983 shook his head.

description: The LTV Corporation today outlined a broad proposal for ending its bankruptcy, the second largest in the nation's history, but its insistence that more than $2 billion in pension liabilities be terminated was immediately challenged by the Government agency that insures corporate pensions.

title: Federated Officer Quits
description: Norman S. Matthews has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Federated Department Stores, whose acquisition by the Campeau Corporation of Toronto was completed this week. Mr. Matthews said he planned to pursue other business opportunities. Before being named Federated's president in March 1987, he was a Federated vice chairman for three years.

description: Joel J. Shorin, retired president of a chewing gum company that includes baseball cards with its product, died last Sunday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Sun Microsystems Stake for A.T.&T.
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., said it would issue 879,947 shares of its common stock to A.T.&T. for about $40.6 million. The sale, which is expected to be completed in 30 days, is based on the average price for the last 20 trading days through Monday of $36.8875 a share plus a 25 percent premium, bringing the total price to $46.1094 a share.

description: Defendants in Queens drug cases are pleading guilty to felony charges at a far swifter pace since a court unit devoted exclusively to narcotics cases began operating in the borough five weeks ago, prosecutors say.

Rep. Dyson Says Smear Drove an Aide to Suicide
description: Representative Roy P. Dyson of Maryland said today that his top aide, Thomas M. Pappas, jumped to his death Sunday from a New York hotel because he felt reports that he had mismanaged Mr. Dyson's office and staff were a ''smear'' that could not be overcome.

title: Mortgage-Backed Securities Are Offered by Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, is offering $500 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Evert Wins: Chris Evert, the No. 1-seeded player, got off to a slow start yesterday in the Italian Open in Rome before beating Nicole Provis of Australia, 7-6, 6-2, in a second-round match. Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, the second-seeded player, also played her first match in the $200,000 event, advancing to the round of 16 with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Amy Schwartz, a qualifier from the United States. Both Evert and Sabatini received first-round byes. In the day's only upset, fourth-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria was beaten by Bettina Fulco of Argentina, 7-5, 6-2. In the next round, Evert will face No. 14 Helen Kelesi of Canada, a 6-0, 6-2 winner over Celine Cohen of Switzerland. Sabatini will play Niege Dias of Brazil, who beat Emmanuelle Derly of France, 4-6, 6-3, 7-5. (AP) Nystrom Upset: Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia upset Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 1-6, 6-4, 6-1, and Anders Jarryd, the top-seeded player, defeated Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-4, 6-3, to advance in the $202,000 Munich Open. It was Jarryd's first match since a knee operation 10 weeks ago. In other matches, Tore Meinecke of West Germany defeated Dave Lewis of New Zealand, 6-1, 6-3, and Hansjoerg Schwaier of West Germany beat Daren Cahill of Australia, 1-6, 6-4, 7-6.(AP) ROWING Princeton Beats Yale: Princeton's men's varsity heavyweight crew made the most of ideal racing conditions yesterday on Lake Carnegie in Princeton, N.J., rowing a 5-minute-45.8-second race to defeat Yale over the 2,000-meter course by 2.4 seconds, or just over a half-boat length. The Tiger varsity time was aided by a slight following tailwind.

title: Hospital Roommate Can Affect Recovery Time, Study Finds
description: Hospital roommates can affect the course of recovery from surgery, new research indicates. Recovery time was shorter by about a day and a half for patients awaiting surgery who shared a room with someone who had already undergone surgery, rather than someone who was also waiting for an operation.

title: Rover Bid Cleared
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. received clearance from the British Government to proceed with its $:150 million, or $279 million, acquisition of the Government's 99.8 percent stake in the car maker Rover Group P.L.C., the latest in a long line of privatization deals under the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The deal still requires approvals from the European commission and British Aerospace shareholders.

title: Concern Rises on Effect Of Meese's Many Trips
description: If you were looking for Edwin Meese 3d last year, chances were 1 in 3 you wouldn't have found him in the capital.

The first, on Tuesday evening, was a program of guitar duets with Sharon Isbin, an accomplished American player who, like Mr. Barbosa-Lima, has lately been addressing herself to classical-pop crossovers. It was to music of this kind, in duo guitar arrangements by Mr. Barbosa-Lima, that the duo devoted the evening.

description: ''Gorbachev's policy in a sense depends on the Polish situation,'' Bronislaw Geremek said. ''If the reforms fail here, it would be a sign to [ Yegor ] Ligachev and other opponents that, you see, the result is anarchy, no production, it can't work.

description: ''We applaud the changes that have taken place and encourage the Soviets to go farther.

title: Critic's Notebook; Updike's Long Struggle To Portray Women
description: Over the years, John Updike noted in a recent interview in The New York Times, readers have occasionally objected to his portrayals of women, criticizing them as being merely ''wives, sex objects and purely domestic creatures.'' In response, he said he'd been ''constantly trying to improve'' his depiction of women. ''The Witches of Eastwick,'' his 1984 novel about three sorceresses, he said, ''was a very determined attempt to write about women who did have careers of a sort''; the novel was ''one attempt to make things right with my, what shall we call them, feminist detractors.'' His new novel, ''S.,'' he added, represents another effort in that direction. A comic variation on Hawthorne's ''Scarlet Letter,'' ''S.,'' published by Alfred A. Knopf, not only updates the story of that famous adulteress Hester Prynne; but it also attempts, says its author, to tell the story from Hester's point of view.

description: A Federal judge last night ordered organizers of the Operation Rescue anti-abortion campaign being conducted in the metropolitan region this week to pay fines of $25,000 a day for each day that they continue to block access to offices where abortions are performed.

He was 73 years old.

But that is what he did after starting Replacements Ltd. in 1981; now he sells more than $9 million in replacement china a year.

title: Norman Saves Best For Last 18 Holes
description: The way Greg Norman is playing final rounds these days he only needs to be within hailing distance before the last 18 holes of a tournament to be a serious threat to win. Norman loves the challenge and has been the best at making stretch runs on the PGA Tour this year.

It said the new model features a 20-megabyte hard-disk drive and a backlit screen. The computer is capable of more than four hours of battery operation per charge.

description: There is no such thing as inspiration, the objectivists tell us. But if it wasn't inspiration that led Dan Wagoner to choreograph the compelling work he calls ''To Comfort Ghosts,'' then he must be eating something special with his Wheaties.

The chairman and chief executive of the International Lease Finance Corporation speaks five languages, a skill that has proved useful in negotiating aircraft-leasing deals with foreign customers.

title: Many Aliens Seek Amnesty on Last Day as Legal Questions Persist
description: The nation's historic program offering illegal immigrants a chance to stay in the United States came to a frantic finale yesterday as more than 100,000 applicants jammed legalization centers around the country. Meanwhile, last-minute Federal court rulings extended the application period for some aliens and added a final element of confusion.

description: DESIGN excellence, according to R. Craig Miller of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is based on many factors. Whether or not an object is esthetically pleasing is only one of them. How a piece fits into the history of design and how functional it is are also important.

Review/Concert; Aeolian Chamber Group
description: At Town Hall Monday night, the Aeolian Chamber Players introduced a brief new work by Peter Lieberson, entitled (without benefit of program-note elucidation) ''Raising the Gaze.'' It is a six-minute burst of drum-driven, occasionally jazzy energy, with sharply pointed instrumentation (flute, clarinet, string trio, piano, percussion), spiky but not dreary dissonance and an authentic rhythmic life that made it a pleasure to follow. It may be a little impractical to put on - four players and a conductor otherwise unemployed on the program assembled for its brief span - but it is probably worth hearing outside the music-school setting for which oddly constituted chamber pieces are generally designed.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Word and Image pages on Tuesday discussed NBC News's interruption of network programming to report Israeli troop movements in Lebanon. The article quoted journalists on rival networks who believed NBC had overreacted, and it quoted an NBC vice president in defense of the decision.

title: Salomon's Plan For Phibro Unit
description: Officials from Salomon Inc. said yesterday that the firm's planned purchase of an oil refinery in Texas would make its oil subsidiary a stronger player in that industry.

title: Talking Deals; Wall St. Rivals Try Cooperation
description: THE increasing tendency of Wall Street firms to throw more and more of their own financial muscle into takeover deals to help their clients outdo rival bidders has suddenly taken a new turn. Now, with the risks from these deals soaring, the firms are turning to a Wall Street tradition some had thought passe: cooperation.

title: G.M.'s Saturn Plant Is 25% Completed
description: Construction is about one-fourth complete at the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., at which the General Motors Corporation plans to turn out automobiles that can compete with imports, officials of G.M.'s Saturn Corporation subsidiary said Tuesday. Production is expected to begin in June 1989, and 6,000 people have applied for work at the plant, Saturn officials said.

title: Police Versus Firefighters
description: The scene of a tragic accident is hardly the place for the New York Police and Fire Departments to engage in a shouting match over bureaucratic prerogatives. Ultimate responsibility for the embarrassing spectacle rests with Mayor Koch, who has let the dispute behind this week's confrontation fester far too long.

title: Anchorage Journal; Flying Opens Door to a Wild Alaska
description: The sight of small, low-flying planes lifting off from this city's downtown Merrill Field and droning out toward the other Alaska, the real Alaska, is a constant reminder that there are two classes of people in this rugged state: those who fly and those who do not.

title: Review/Dance; The Human Condition In Word and Movement
description: Stephan Koplowitz choreographically acknowledged the joys and sorrows of being human in a poignant program Monday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. His works, created in collaboration with their performers, blended dance with spoken texts so adroitly that one could not imagine the movements without the words or the words without the movements.

title: Promoting Mothers and Their Day
description: Ted Kaufman was eager to hang up the phone because he had little time to waste: after all, the Outstanding Mother Awards ceremony was less than 365 days away.

title: Edberg Surviving, but It's a Struggle
description: During the breaks between games these past two days, Stefan Edberg of Sweden sat with a white towel draped on his head, as if he really did not want to see. Given a choice, Edberg said he would rather be in Europe right now, resting in his London flat or perhaps practicing on the red clay in preparation for the French Open later this month. It is nothing against Forest Hills, he said, which actually reminds him of England. It is just that the United States is not a popular tourist attraction for European tennis players this time of year.

title: Currents; Art Deco, to Adorn the Home Stage

The latest of these is F. Schumacher's Radio City Music Hall Collection. Twenty designs of printed and woven fabrics, wall coverings and borders, as well as carpet, were all adapted from the original archives. ''The tremendous appeal of Deco to our generation is that it reflects a time people still believed they could shape and influence their environment,'' said Raymond J. Chevallier, vice president of marketing for Schumacher. ''They believed in the power of technology and of the modern age.''

In his new play, ''No Time Flat'' (at the WPA Theater), the leading role is, uncharacteristically, that of a writer. The result is, in all respects, a misstep for this talented playwright and for the enterprising company with which he is most closely identified.
