description: President Corazon C. Aquino refused today to allow her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos, to return to the Philippines to attend the funeral of his 95-year-old mother, who died this morning.

title: Tenneco's Earnings Surge
description: The net income of Tenneco Inc. more than doubled in this year's first quarter, helped mainly by a one-time $25 million foreign tax credit, the company said today. The credit was related to Colombian oil operations.

title: BankVermont Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the pending sale of its Oxford Bank and Trust subsidiary reduced after-tax earnings by slightly over $500,000 in the latest quarter. The year-ago first quarter included gains on the sales of investments of about 50 percent of its reported earnings.

title: Sun Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $421,000. The company said effective Jan. 1, it changed its domestic fiscal year- end from Oct. 31 to Dec. 31. Its international fiscal year remains Oct. 31. Therefore, the statement of operations for the three-month period ended March 31 included the results of U.S. operations ended March 31 and the results of international operations for the three months ended Jan. 31, 1988.

title: Home Unity Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $325,000. c-Net income and after a gain from discontinued operations of $426,000 and an extraordinary gain of $399,000.

title: Memorial for McCracken
description: Marilyn Horne and the Collegiate Chorale, conducted by Robert Bass, are among those who are to take part in a memorial service for the tenor James McCracken on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Mr. McCracken died last Friday at the age of 61. Speakers include Lotfi Mansouri, who has been named the next general manager of the San Francisco Opera, and Edward Purrington, assistant director of the Washington Opera.

title: A Tiny Heart Pump Saves Its First Life, Researchers Report
description: An experimental pump about the size of a pencil eraser that is inserted into the heart through an artery in the leg has helped save the life of the first patient to receive it, doctors at a hospital in Houston said yesterday.

title: Unicorp American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $1.8 million from the sale of an industrial building in Bedford, Mass. The company said latest quarter results reflect the acquisition of Lincoln Savings Bank in December 1987.

title: Irving Bank's 'Poison Pill'
description: The Bank of New York Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with a majority of the Irving Bank Corporation's 15 preferred shareholders in an attempt to dismantle a ''poison pill'' provision that would make any takeover of the Irving more difficult.

title: Austron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Prenatal Test For Defects Termed Safe In U.S. Study
description: An experimental prenatal test that can identify common birth defects after 9 1/2 to 12 weeks of pregnancy is nearly as safe as amniocentesis, according to a Federal study.

title: Kansas City Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dynascan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $33,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Rowing for Lions: Urban Adventure
description: The Harlem River, which separates Manhattan from the Bronx, has been home to Columbia's crews for years. Increasingly, the river has also been the final resting spot for discarded trash, abandoned automobiles and corpses.

title: Hill & Knowlton Fills A Top Job From Outside
description: For the first time in the memory of its top executives, the 61-year-old Hill & Knowlton, a worldwide public relations concern, went outside the company to fill a top executive post.

title: TV Notes
description: Pariahs in the Studio?

title: NORWAY IS MISSING ATOM ARMS WATER
description: Norway said today that a significant amount of Norwegian heavy water was missing and appeared to have been diverted four years ago into the international black market for materials that can be used to make nuclear weapons.

title: Spring, Lapping Gently at the Hulls Of Their Homes
description: THIS month's mild breezes have given all New Yorkers a reason for cheer, but nowhere has the change in seasons met with greater relief than at the 79th Street Boat Basin.

title: Buccaneers Make Trade
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers traded a veteran offensive tackle, Ron Heller, to the Seattle Seahawks yesterday in exchange for the defensive lineman, Randy Edwards, and a 1989 draft choice.

title: Lexington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sabonis to Stay
description: The visa allowing the Soviet basketball star Arvidas Sabonis to remain in the United States has been extended for two months, the Portland Trail Blazers announced yesterday.

title: Wings West Planes
description: Wings West Airlines Inc. said that the AMR Corporation had established a deadline of next Tuesday to resolve differences over the airline's proposed acquisition of 10 British Aerospace advanced turbo-prop jets and that if an agreement was not reached, AMR would void their proposed merger. AMR offered in mid-April to buy Wings West, a regional carrier that feeds passengers to American Airlines, for $10.50 a share. Wings West is to begin receiving the British Aerospace planes in June but said it was trying to amend the order.

title: Review/Recital; Albright at the Organ
description: William Albright, the organist and composer, inaugurated the nine-week International Organ Recitals series at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55th Street, on Monday evening. His program was mostly contemporary and American, and offered an impressive overview of how composers have lately tapped the organ's considerable resources.

title: Salerno and 8 Found Guilty As Racketeers
description: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, portrayed as the boss of the Genovese crime family, was convicted with eight other men yesterday of racketeering.

title: Parent & Child
description: THEY are small acts of terrorism, at least when measured against hijacked airliners and explosions at U.S.O. clubs. The extortion payment may be milk money, the injuries limited to a black eye and bruised pride. Yet the young victims of bullies describe their ordeals in terms much like those used by adult victims of terrorism. They blame themselves as they search for a logical reason for an illogical situation.

title: Texas Instruments Offers 8 7/8% Notes
description: Texas Instruments Inc. is offering $150 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due 1993, at a price of 99.725, to yield 8.94 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: People Magazine Offers New One-Topic Issue
description: Along with the regular issue of People magazine that shows up on newsstands May 16 will be another special one-advertiser, one-topic People selling for more than twice the price.

title: New York Marine & General Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net realized investment losses of $237,710 and $118,581 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Trims Are Made in 'Chess,' Saving Time and Money
description: The Broadway play ''Chess'' has lost a few moves. The 3-hour-plus, $6.2 million musical has become a 3-hour-minus, $6.2 million musical, in a move that saves thousands of dollars a week in overtime costs on a show that received less than favorable notices and is very expensive to run.

title: Xtra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $737,000 for the quarter; the 6 months included income from discontinued operations of $872,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $301,000 and $707,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: New Position for Solomon
description: Peter J. Solomon was named yesterday to head the new merchant banking division of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which plans to invest primarily in leveraged buyouts.

title: Unum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1 million and $3 million for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Dow Off 22.05; Most of Loss in Final Hour
description: LEAD: Stock prices sagged yesterday, with most of the losses coming in the last 40 minutes of trading, as blue-chip issues were hit by program trading related to index arbitrage.

title: East Weymouth Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Improvement
description: EVEN though owning telephones, instead of renting them from the telephone company, is now commonplace, many homeowners and apartment dwellers choose to rent because they think that the installation might be too hard.

title: Snake Smuggling Is Charged
description: The owner of a wholesale tropical fish business was charged yesterday with smuggling about 700 baby boa constrictors into the United States, Federal officials said yesterday. The snakes are protected under international trade agreements. The suspect, Agremiro Espana, 43 years old, owner of the Miro Espana Company in Jamaica, Queens, was also charged with violating the Lacey Act, which outlaws interstate or foreign transportation of illegally captured wildlife. He is accused of smuggling the snakes into this country in a shipment of fish from Colombia that arrived on March 7, 1987.

title: Citizens Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kimonos to Quilts: Crafts at Armory
description: LEAD: SOME people return home after a day's labors and toss their clothing on a chair. Others, in the interest of tidiness, resort to a wooden valet.

title: Bolar Pharmaceutical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rose Looks Back
description: Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds manager, who will appeal the National League's decision to suspend him 30 days for shoving Umpire Dave Pallone, said yesterday the suspension could have been worse.

title: Women Work for the Same Reasons Men Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairfield Communities Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY NEWS;
description: The pilots of United Airlines offered $110 a share yesterday for all outstanding stock of the Allegis Corporation, the airline's owner.

title: Gregorian Is Given Public Service Award
description: Dr. Vartan Gregorian, the president and chief executive officer of the New York Public Library, is this year's recipient of the $24 Award from the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Ogilvy Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Matrix Science reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated relating to the timing of recording sales and customer returns.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES LTV outlined a proposal for ending its bankruptcy, the second-largest in the nation's history, but its insistence that more than $2 billion in pension liabilities be terminated was immediately challenged by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. In September, the Federal agency forced the steel company to administer the pension plans, citing LTV's improving profits. [ D1. ] Drexel Burnham Lambert halted a trading practice in which Drexel employees bought ''junk bond'' issues underwritten by the firm before they reached the public. The practice has been sharply criticized by members of Congress. [ D1. ] New York City officials dropped three major banks from the elite group of underwriters that sell more than $1 billion of bonds each year for the city. The banks are Chase Manhattan, Chemical Bank and Citibank. [ D1. ] United's pilots offered $110 a share for Allegis, the airline's parent, and said they needed more than $4 billion in financing. Some analysts were skeptical that they could find it. [ D5. ] Eastern Airlines will post a loss for the current quarter, in part because of the Federal safety investigation under way. [ D5. ] Levolor Lorentzen, the window-blind maker, may be sold as a result of infighting among members of the founding family. [ D2. ] Centerre Bancorp is now being sought by both of Missouri's two largest banking companies. [ D2. ] Desert Partners offered to raise its tender offer for USG to $50 a share and also proposed a merger. [ D4. ] The New York Post has increased circulation since ending its afternoon edition and becoming a morning paper. [ D24. ] Pepsi-Cola will advertise on Soviet television, the first American company to buy time to reach a Soviet audience. [ D24. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. will challenge Japan at GATT, presenting its argument for increased American access to Japan's beef and citrus markets. [ D1. ] In their search for more votes to override a trade bill veto, Democrats in the House pushed through a measure to drop restrictions on Alaskan oil exports. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY Major countries do not know the best exchange rate of the dollar, and unemployment could fall further without causing higher inflation, Alan Greenspan said. [ D1. ] Unauthorized people may have seen secret bidding information for the Government's new $25 billion telephone system just hours after they were submitted. Senator D'Amato called for an immediate halt to the bidding process. [ D1. ] Late April sales of U.S.-made vehicles fell 2.6 percent from a year ago. Analysts said the decline was misleading because last year's period was unusually strong. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices sagged, with most losses coming in the last 40 minutes of trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.05 points, to close at 2,036.31. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell in quiet trading, although the Government's borrowing needs at next week's quarterly refunding will be somewhat lower than had been anticipated. [ D19. ] The dollar was mixed against most major currencies in light trading. Gold rose $1.30 on the Comex, to $444.80 an ounce. [ D20. ] Oil futures prices slipped after a report showed larger-than-expected domestic inventories in gasoline and crude oil. [ D20. ] Yields were higher on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS More Wall Street firms are cooperating with one another to offset the risks of takeover deals. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Coleco's chairman resigned. Some analysts said the toy maker was tottering on the brink of bankruptcy. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Elgin National Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,084,673. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $421,833.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Your Stars for the 80's
description: For those born under the sign of Aquarius, here's an amazing prediction - one of you is going to be President.

title: Reagan Official Sees Hopes for Peace in Angola and Namibia
description: Pursuing a diplomatic mission that he acknowledged has become a race against time, a Reagan Administration official said today that hopeful signs had emerged from two days of negotiations on ending the war in Angola and bringing independence to South-West Africa, or Namibia.

title: Democrats' Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. Dukakis ... 1,467 Jackson ... 926 Gore ... 413 Simon ... 173 Undetermined* ... 586 Total delegate votes: 4,161 Chosen so far: 3,565 Needed to nominate: 2,081 * Includes some delegates whose chosen candidate has withdrawn. Article, page B16

title: South Carolina Federal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: New Plans For Parks At Battery
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch are expected to announce today designs for 50 acres of waterfront parks winding nearly two miles along the edge of Battery Park City and Battery Park.

title: Cerprobe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter included a one-time gain of $169,500 from an accounting change.

title: Baseball Notebook; Looking to Lefties: The Right Move?
description: Perhaps it's a Communist conspiracy designed to subvert the possibility of a Subway Series, but the Mets and the Yankees are seeing an awful lot of left-leaning opponents this season, more, in fact, than any other team in their respective leagues.

title: U.S.-Korea Talks Gain
description: South Korea has bowed to United States pressure and agreed to remove most restrictions on the sale of imported cigarettes. The step could cut the price of imported cigarettes by 76 percent, trade negotiators for both countries said today.

title: Prices of Bonds and Notes Drop
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged in quiet trading yesterday although the Government's borrowing needs at next week's quarterly refunding will be somewhat less than had been anticipated.

title: The Doctrine or the Treaty?
description: The Reagan Administration negotiated an important treaty with the Soviet Union that would eliminate Euromissiles. Now it jeopardizes that accomplishment by insisting on a novel and absurd Presidential doctrine that few senators will or should swallow.

title: Modern Art By Russians In Capital
description: The first major United States exhibition of the work of three contemporary Soviet artists will open at the Corcoran Gallery of Art on Thursday.

title: CHRYSLER REACHES PACT WITH UNION
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement today on a new 28-month contract covering about 60,000 union members.

title: Grumman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $35 million, or $1.07 a share, from the adoption of FASB No. 96. The year-ago results restated.

title: William R. Laidlaw 4th, Writer, 80
description: William R. Laidlaw 4th, a writer, died of throat cancer last Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Commando Ecology
description: Ecological concerns rated high in the Persian Gulf when the United States retaliated against Iran for mining a frigate.

title: New Ferment On the Pariah Of Perestroika
description: At the Leningrad college where Nina Andreyeva teaches chemistry, her colleagues give out her home phone number with nasty glee, throwing in a bit of gossip about the woman whose conservative ''manifesto'' prompted a national showdown over ideology.

title: Andover Controls reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
Andal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Game 3: A Joy to Knick Fans
description: There have been circuses and dog shows, hockey playoffs and indoor tennis championships, but for four years there had not been a post-season New York Knicks basketball game at Madison Square Garden - until last night.

title: Augat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pope Picks High-Level Group To Go to Moscow Church Fete
description: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II, hoping to open ''new paths'' for peace in the world, had named a delegation to attend a major religious celebration in Moscow that will be the largest group of Roman Catholic Church leaders ever to visit the Soviet Union.

title: Careercom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $2 million one-time charge to establish a reserve for the close-out losses for certain schools primarily acquired in the Jostens purchase for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Market Place; Coleco's Struggle To End a Tailspin
description: IS Coleco Industries like one of those characters in an old Western movie who is dead on his feet but hasn't yet toppled into the dust? That's the question that hangs over the battered toy maker following the announcement last night that Arnold C. Greenberg would be replaced by Morton E. Handel as chairman and chief executive and that the Hallwood Group Inc. had been retained to advise the company on the restructuring of its desperate finances.

title: New Furor On Security Of Phone Bids
description: Officials of the General Services Administration and Congressional staff members said yesterday that secret bids for the Government's new $25 billion telephone system might have been examined last weekend, just hours after they were submitted, by someone without proper authorization.

title: Williamsburg Bridge To Open, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the Williamsburg Bridge, which has been closed because of structural corrosion since April 12, could be opened ''very shortly,'' although he declined to say exactly when.

title: Air Cargo Equipment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company converted to stock ownership in November 1986.

title: U.S. Agencies Submit Plans for Drug Testing
description: Final rules for random drug testing of Government employees, ranging from the White House chief of staff to secretaries, were presented to Congress Tuesday by Federal agencies.

title: American Learning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Free Training for Aspiring Musicians in Chicago
description: Earnest young voices from the inner city sing liltingly while aspiring musicians experiment with a spectrum of styles each Saturday in a renovated train station just south of downtown.

title: Chalone Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Show Business Network Is Set
description: Home Shopping Network Inc. said this week that it would start a new cable network that will cover the entertainment industry with reports on personalities and events involving movies, television, home video, music and Broadway.

title: Poles Square Off; Solidarity Is Skillful at Using Tension To Revive Pressures on Government
description: After a respite of several years, the strikes in Poland have the outlawed Solidarity union and the men around Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski squared off again like two tired boxers.

title: First New Hampshire Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.9 million from an accounting change.

title: High Radiation Found in Plant On East 44th St.
description: Potentially hazardous radioactive contamination dating back almost 50 years has been found in a commercial building in midtown Manhattan, the head of a State Assembly committee charged yesterday.

title: BT Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Competitions: Paths of Glory
description: ''UNTIL you win an architectural competition, you don't realize there's a whole different dimension after the award,'' said Wes Jones of Holt Hinshaw Pfau & Jones, the San Francisco firm that recently won the international design competition for the Astronauts Memorial in Cape Canaveral, Fla. ''For two weeks we were the king of the hill, until we started to navigate through contracts, through the arduous, difficult process of crossing the t's, dotting the i's, actually making the deal and getting the commission. Still, it is an incredible opportunity from a marketing standpoint, and you gain legitimacy for your ideas.''

title: 'Junk Bond' Policy Shift At Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. today halted a trading practice in which Drexel employees and partnerships controlled by them bought significant portions of new ''junk bond'' issues underwritten by the firm before they reached the investing public.

title: Hostages Are Rescued In New Caledonia Raid
description: French authorities rescued 22 gendarmes and an assistant prosecutor today who had been held hostage by Melanesian separatists in a cave on Uvea island, the French Government said.

title: Review/Television; 'Top Dog,' the Search for Stardom
description: It's not entirely serious, but what did you expect? ''48 Hours,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, visits the Westminster Kennel Club Show at Madison Square Garden. A dachshund sniffs Charles Kuralt and a pointer kisses Charles Osgood. All the dogs are amiable, and, champions or not, a lot of them have that wonderfully goofy dog look.

title: Boatmen's Offer Tops Bid Centerre Accepted
description: The Centerre Bancorporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in Missouri, is now a takeover target of the state's two biggest banking companies.

title: Review/Television; An Unsparing British View of Britain
description: The contrast can be startling. American television dramas are almost dottily optimistic, constantly looking for an ending of uplift and inspiration. The British, however, seem to take delight in gloom, regularly turning out social indictments that are scathing in their bleakness. Little wonder that Margaret Thatcher rarely finds the medium comforting.

title: Beta Blockers and Mood: Are Tales True?
description: A popular class of drugs for heart problems and high blood pressure cause side effects of depression, drowsiness and mental dullness far less often then conventional wisdom holds, according to a new study.

title: Data Switch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bellow Auctioning Off 'Sammler' Manuscript
description: Saul Bellow is selling the notebooks, typescript and all papers relating to ''Mr. Sammler's Planet'' at Sotheby's on June 7. The manuscript material of the novel, published in 1970, is the first archive of a major living author's published work to be auctioned, and the first manuscript material to be sold by Mr. Bellow.

title: USA Today's Asia Plant
description: USA Today opened a printing plant here today, its third outside the United States. The newspaper will be transmitted by satellite from USA Today's Washington headquarters for printing here by Consolidated Newspapers Ltd., which is associated with Sing Tao Ltd., a publisher of English and Chinese newspapers in the British territory. USA Today, owned by the Gannett Company, has a daily readership estimated at more that 5.5 million. The paper also has plants in Singapore and near Lucerne, Switzerland, in addition to 31 plants in the United States.

title: Staley Continental Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $8.5 million due to the accelerated vesting of certain previously issued stock under executive compensation and long-term incentive plans. Without the charge, the company said it would have posted earnings of $9,825,000, or 22 cents a share. c-Included a loss of $37,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and the 6 months included a gain of $216,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $7,268,000 on early redemption of debt.

title: CityFed Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,470,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. There were no per share earnings after preferred dividend requirements in the latest period.

title: Bio-Logic Systems Corp reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
U.S. Gains and Setbacks Reported on Quality of the Air
description: Federal clean air standards for ozone, a principal part of smog, were violated last year in more areas than the year before, but the standard for carbon monoxide was violated in fewer areas, the Environmental Protection Agency said Tuesday.

title: Lawmaker Vows to Act On Tougher Ethics Bill
description: A House subcommittee chairman said today that he would act promptly on legislation that would clamp down on lobbying by former members of Congress and senior officials of the executive branch.

title: Mets Blank Astros; Yanks Rally to Win; Yankees 4, Royals 3
description: When he stopped to consider the consequences tonight, John Candelaria said he might have been wrong. He had allowed himself to become disturbed by a few questionable calls in the third inning, and by the seventh they were still festering.

title: Mistrial Declared in U.S. Case Against LaRouche
description: A Federal district judge today declared a mistrial in the fraud and obstruction of justice case against the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., six of his followers and five of his political groups.

title: Legislature in Hartford Ends Session on Time
description: An exhausted Connecticut General Assembly adjourned at midnight Wednesday after adopting a pay raise for its members in the session's final hours. But it failed to approve several key pieces of legislation, including a controversial measure that would have restored smoking on the New Haven line of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: CNA Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $72,100,000 for the latest quarter and $15,400,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Two Authors, 2 Routes to Big Money
description: The publishing industry's insatiable appetite for big books was underscored anew by two major acquisitions this week. Yesterday the Putnam Publishing Group acquired the next novel by Lawrence Sanders for $2.85 million in an auction involving eight houses, while two days ago Simon & Schuster and Pocket Books announced what is thought to be the first eight-figure agreement involving a single author.

title: Life in the 30's
description: IT seems that most of the men in my life have wanted to possess things, but not actually to purchase them. You see the problem. If I am hanging around the house and it crosses my mind that, hey, we could use a toaster oven, the next logical step in my mental progression is to go to a store where I will buy a toaster oven, tote it home and toast up a storm.

title: 3 Airlines in West Again Lead Nation In On-Time Flights
description: Three relatively small airlines that operate primarily in the West and the Southwest posted the best on-time records in March for the second consecutive month, the Department of Transportation reported today.

title: NICARAGUA DETAINS OPPOSITION CHIEFS
description: About two dozen opposition leaders were detained today as they sought to visit a union hall where construction workers are conducting a hunger strike.

title: University Bank & Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Biden's Status Satisfactory
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, was in satisfactory condition today, one day after surgeons corrected an aneurysm, or weakening on the wall of an artery that supplies blood to the right side of his brain, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said. The operation was similar to the one performed Feb. 12 on Senator Biden for a larger aneurysm. The spokesman said the Senator was expected to be hospitalized for 10 days.

title: Palestinian-American Held
description: The Israeli authorities arrested Mubarak Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolent protest, Thursday, Palestinian sources said. The Palestinian sources said the police arrested Mr. Awad during the night at his East Jerusalem home and took him for questioning. Mr. Awad, who advocates non-violent resistance to Israeli occupation, is a United States citizen. Israeli officials have been trying to deport him since his visa expired last November.

title: Cerner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Justice Dept. Inquiry Seen
description: Government lawyers are investigating possible perjury by officials during testimony about a company's charge that it was driven into bankruptcy by the Justice Department.

title: Cade Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Film; The Ripper's Return
description: The world needs another movie about a copycat Jack the Ripper as much as it needs another Ripper, unless the film has the wit of ''The Ruling Class'' (Peter O'Toole as a nobleman who believes he's Jack), or the tautness of ''Time After Time'' (the Ripper chased through time by H. G. Wells). ''Jack's Back'' offers identical twins, silly coincidences and a huge red herring - a checklist designed to take the chill out of movie crime.

title: Mets Game Postponed
description: The Mets got a rainout instead of another shutout last night at Shea Stadium. The postponed game with the Houston Astros will be made up as part of a twilight-night doubleheader July 1, a Friday.

title: Technology for Communicaions International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes the consolidation of BR Communications revenue of $3,141,000 and $6,182,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A Bensonhurst Man Is Shot At His Home by 3 Who Flee
description: A 45-year-old Brooklyn man was critically wounded last night in a gangland style shooting in front of his Bensonhurst home late yesterday, the police said.

title: India Says Afghan Would Share Rule
description: Najibullah, the Afghan leader, was described by senior Indian officials as willing to share significant political powers with Afghan guerrilla groups and prepared to accept India as a mediator in bringing about such an arrangement.

title: Survivor of East River Crash Sues Copter Owner and Pilot
description: A survivor of the helicopter crash Sunday in the East River filed a $5.1 million lawsuit yesterday against the helicopter sightseeing company and the pilot of the aircraft.

title: Imex Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Larizza Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Copyright Battle Lost by Interlego
description: The Danish makers of Lego toy bricks lost a four-year legal battle to stop Tyco Toys Inc. of Moorestown, N.J., from making Lego-like products. A British court dismissed an appeal by Denmark's Interlego A/S of a Hong Kong court ruling on copyright infringement. ''This is a tremendously significant victory for the company,'' Tyco's general counsel, Michael Kennedy, said in New York.

title: Jean Philippe Fragrances reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Clements, 34, is the C.F.L.'s second-leading career passer behind Ron Lancaster. He completed 3,807 passes for 39,041 yards and 252 touchdowns. . . . Carl Lewis, the four gold-medal winner in the 1984 Olympic Games, said he would consider retirement after his 28th birthday on July 1, 1989. title: Economic Scene; When the News Is Good and Bad
description: IT is becoming harder and harder to distinguish good news from bad news. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said this week that he was ''optimistic that the balance of trade will continue to improve in 1988 and beyond.'' That sounded great. But Mr. Greenspan quickly added that the faster the trade balance improves, ''the greater the burden on monetary policy to curtail private domestic spending,'' lest the rapidly improving trade balance, combined with strong domestic spending, accelerate inflation.

Review/Art; The Elusive Bronze Sculptures of Joel Fisher
description: Joel Fisher's slender sculptures resemble trees or figures but they resist exact definition. His current exhibition at the Diane Brown Gallery, entitled ''Subtle Delusions,'' expands on an idea the artist has fruitfully pursued for several years - copying in three dimensions various shapes derived from chance arrangements of lines on paper. Appearing to sway and prance across the gallery's floor, these latest creations exude a gentle and unpretentious grace. Mr. Fisher explores what occurs as forms metamorphose: he first makes paper, which rests on felt pads to dry; the paper absorbs bits of the felt, and these consequently appear as tiny aberrations - or like minuscule, abstract, hairline scribbles - embedded in the surface. Mr. Fisher calls the marks ''apographs.'' He discovers the random felt fibers, meticulously copies their shapes in pencil on a larger scale, and proceeds to reproduce in plaster, wax or clay what he has drawn. From this, he fashions the untitled bronze sculptures shown with the pieces of paper that act as their inspiration.

title: Pop/Jazz; Seductive String Music Strikes a Global Chord

They're found in prim halls of European high culture and in studios seductively backing soul singers. Now an integral part of Indian classical music, the fiddle defines bluegrass music in Tennessee. Be-bop, Mozart, Andalusian music from Morocco, rock-and-roll and everything in between, all share them - whooping and moaning, slinking and scraping, they're a perfect example of how cultures make anew elements borrowed from other traditions.

title: From a Team of Women

The two leading characters, struggling musicians sharing a picturesquely shabby downtown flat, are as bubble headed as they can be. This is especially apparent after fate sends a suitcase full of money their way, courtesy of a drug-dealing friend (Loretta Devine) who asks them to watch it for an indefinite period. title: Review/Film; 'Judgment,' on a Hijacking and Its Aftermath
description: ''Judgment in Berlin'' (no relation to ''Judgment at Nuremberg'') is an account of the aftermath of a 1978 hijacking of a Polish airliner by an East German seeking asylum in the West. Helmut Thiele's appearance at Tempelhof Air Force Base in West Berlin was an embarrassment to the West Germans, so they tossed the case to the equally embarrassed Americans, who had no enthusiasm for punishing a refugee from the East but were bound by international treaty to crack down on hijackings. As an American official puts it, ''State has a mess and Justice must clean it up.''

title: Review/Opera; Dame Janet Baker as 'Orfeo' in Concert
description: In 1982, Dame Janet Baker completed a retirement from the operatic stage by singing Orfeo in Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' at Glyndebourne. But she has continued as a recitalist, and Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall she appeared in the same role in a semistaged concert performance of the opera with the Oratorio Society of New York. The result - bolstered by excellent singing of the two other solo vocal parts and pleasing support from the orchestra and chorus - was a deeply moving statement of one of the greatest parts and greatest operas in the repertory.

title: AFP Imaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wisconsin Offers Bonds For $420 Million Refunding
description: The State of Wisconsin is offering $420 million of general obligation refunding bonds through a group of underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Review/Art; A Brazilian Exhibition In a Didactic Context
description: ''Brazil Projects at P.S. 1'' is one of the more ambitious and flawed shows of the season. With works by around 70 painters, sculptors, photographers, architects, video artists, costume designers and television directors, this cultural extravaganza fills all three floors of P.S. 1's exhibition space. After seeing the show, visitors are not likely to look at Brazil in the same way. Visitors are also unlikely to think the same way about contextual exhibitions.

title: Northeastern Mortgage Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $512,000 from the sale of servicing rights. The adoption of FASB No. 91 reduced lastest quarter income by $264,000. c-Net income

Who Wants a 'Democratic, Secular' Palestine?; Bir Zeit University Poll
description: To the Editor:

Jamila Writer Is Married To Dr. Philip J. Weintraub
description: Jamila T. Writer and Dr. Philip J. Weintraub were married yesterday at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park by Rabbi Lavey Derby.

title: Williamsburg Bridge Not Ready to Reopen
description: The Williamsburg Bridge will remain closed until at least next week, New York City transportation officials said yesterday. The bridge was closed April 12 as a danger to the public, and officials have made different predictions as to when it can be reopened.

title: Cardinal Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuban Riot Study Says Clues Weren't Heeded
description: Officials at two Federal prisons where Cuban inmates rioted last November failed to secure the facilities partly because early signs of trouble were not relayed to them by prison personnel, a Justice Department report concludes.

title: U.S. Proposes Drug Testing Of Workers in Rail Industry
description: The Transportation Department today proposed rules that would require random testing of railroad employees for drugs.

title: National Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $109,000.

title: Devils' Youths Grow Up Fast
description: Sean Burke and Doug Brown, who reflect the youthfulness of the Devils, were the heroes in the second game of the Stanley Cup series with the Bruins.

title: Galaxy Carpet Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After a $1,149,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes and a $563,000 gain from a change in an inventory method. c-Net income

title: Hawaiian Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Rockwell Closing
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it would discontinue operations at the plant here that its North American Aircraft division operates to make structural components for the B-1B aircraft. The company has delivered the last of the B-1B's ordered by the Air Force. Rockwell said final closing would require about 15 months. The plant employs about 1,000, down from 7,200 at the peak of B-1B production.

title: Behind the 2 Democratic Contenders, 2 Hard-Driving Campaign Managers; Gerald Austin Provides Direction And Order to Jackson's Candidacy
description: The evening before the Rev. Jesse Jackson was defeated in the Ohio Democratic primary was a peak moment for Gerald Austin, the Ohio political consultant who is Mr. Jackson's campaign manager.

title: Viacom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes interest expense of $65,101,000. Viacom is a new company resulting from the June 9, 1987 acquisition of Viacom Int. Inc. by a subsidiary of National Amusements Inc. Therefore, the year-earlier results are not fully comparable. The company said that for the three months ended March 31, it had a pro forma net loss of $54,544,000 on revenue of $234,209,000. The net loss was after net interest expense of $69,155,000.

title: Casablanca Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $2,220,000 from settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Inspection of Aloha Airlines Found Maintenance Wanting
description: An extensive inspection of Aloha Airlines last December by the Federal Aviation Administration found the airline did not have an adequate system to assure that its aircraft were properly maintained, according to agency documents.

title: Datamarine International reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Here's Looking at You
description: Employees of the Treasury Department have been puzzled by a poster that began appearing on office and corridor walls a few weeks ago.

title: Pratt & Lambert Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest-quarter results include a net gain of $285,000 from the sale of the company's Chicago distribution center.

title: Cable Consortium Formed
description: Four of the nation's largest cable television companies said today that they would form a research and development consortium to focus on developing high-definition television and other new technologies for the industry.

description: b-Net loss

Cigna Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $8 million and income from discontinued operations of $11.7 million. c-Includes realized investment gains of $30.8 million, income from discontinued operations of $16 million and an extraordinary tax benefit of $14.3 million.

title: Las Vegas Tourney Halted by Winds
description: In a rare decision by PGA Tour officials, play in the second round of the Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational tournament was suspended late this afternoon because of winds so severe that golf balls were blown off greens when placed for putting and golfers were in danger of being hit by flying debris and sand.

title: Stokely USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of 24 cents from the settlement of an insurance claim relating to a fire. The company said the latest full- year earnings were increased by a gain on the sale of assets and the insurance claim settlement, which together contributed 45 cents a share to income for the period.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 426 money market mutual funds increased $611.7 million, to $273.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 117 institutional funds increased $1.94 billion, to $76.04 billion. Assets of the 212 general purpose funds were up $85.2 million, to $82.69 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased $1.41 billion, to $114.88 billion.

title: Niagara Mohawk Yield Is 9.986%
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation is offering $200 million of 9 7/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 1998 at a price of 99.30 to yield 9.986 percent through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Information Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Greeting Ex-Captives, Chirac Sees Better Iran Ties
description: Welcoming three freed hostages home from Lebanon, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac declared today that the way had been opened for ''normal relations'' between France and Iran.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Cavalier Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROCKET FUEL PLANT FACING QUESTIONS
description: Union officials raised questions today about safety at the rocket fuel plant where a series of devastating explosions Wednesday killed one person, left one other missing and injured more than 200.

title: Northwestern Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
California High Court Rules Against Club on Membership
description: The state Supreme Court today allowed the California Coastal Commission to require that an exclusive club in the Los Angeles area pledge that it will not discriminate in exchange for permission to develop beach property.

title: Vermont Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Davis Joins Sherwood
description: Marvin David, who has been running a one-man advertising show called Davisworks with the help of the city's multitude of freelancers, has moved in with Sherwood & Schneider and has brought his four clients with him. Total billings are about $3 million, the president, Lew Sherwood, said. The clients are the Portuguese National Tourist Office, the Grow Group, Fownes Brothers & Company, glove makers, and James Edmund Inc., maker of Oleg Cassini label menswear.

title: American International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $28,012,000 for the latest quarter and $26,559,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest quarter results included a ''fresh start'' tax benefit which reduced the provision for income taxes by about $25 million, compared with about $30 million in the 1987 first quarter.

title: G&K Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Yellow Pages Appoints Top Officials
description: Robert Hickson, 61 years old, and Steven Troy, 39, have been promoted to chairman and president, respectively, of Ketchum Yellow Pages. That specialty advertising unit of Ketchum Communications grew from $13.5 million in billings in 1982 to more than $64 million this year.

title: Suspect in 50 Robberies Seized
description: A resident of a Manhattan men's shelter who is a suspect in more than 50 holdups of take-out desert shops since last November was arrested yesterday after officers followed him from the scene of a robbery of an Upper West Side cookie store, the police said.

title: On New York Walls, the Fading of Graffiti
description: Two decades after graffiti first infested New York, creating a pervasive sense that the city was out of control, the plague has quietly begun to recede, say city officials, leaders of community organizations and even many graffiti writers themselves.

title: U.S. Tax Receipts Lag
description: Government tax receipts are running somewhat behind expectations this spring, apparently dashing any remaining hopes for a second straight decline in the budget deficit.

title: Franklin Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Losses Posted in Quarter By Viacom and Turner
description: Viacom Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc., two entertainment and communications concerns, both reported first-quarter losses.

title: Occupational Medical Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter net reduced by $43,000 because of establishment of reserves to cover fourth quarter expenses.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Rally to Gain 2-0 Lead in Series
description: Mark Messier scored his second goal of the game and assisted on Craig Simpson's game-winner at 5 minutes 1 second of the third period, capping a three-goal surge that gave the Edmonton Oilers a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in Game 2 of the Campbell Conference finals.

title: Johnston Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $258,000 for the quarter and $329,000 for the 9 months. The latest periods' results are stated after the effect of the after-tax charge for the reduction in net asset value of Greater Washington Investors Inc. of $494,000 for the quarter and $906,000 for the 9 months. The amounts have been restated where applicable to reflect classifications at June 30, 1987.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in some copies yesterday about reported Justice Department appointments misidentified a Salt Lake City lawyer said to be in line for Deputy Attorney General. He is Harold G. Christensen.

title: Police-Fire Feuds: Only in New York
description: Disputes similar to those between the New York City Police and Fire Departments over who should take part in rescue efforts are unlikely to occur in most cities, police and fire officials around the country say, primarily because precise responsibilities have been established.

title: Warrant Out For the Arrest Of Sharpton
description: A Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn issued warrants for the arrest of 18 people, including the Rev. Al Sharpton and State Assemblyman Roger L. Green, after a group of them walked out of his courtroom yesterday during a hearing on charges that they obstructed the New York City government during a civil-rights protest last December.

title: F.D.A. Assailed on Approval of Drug
description: Some doctors and other witnesses charged today that the Food and Drug Administration approved a sedative related to Valium without complete information about the drug's potency or some of the deaths associated with its use overseas.

title: Timberland Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter net and share earnings are pro forma.

title: Kaisertech Says It Sees Buyout Offers Coming
description: Kaisertech Ltd. said today that it expects one or more acquisition proposals and that it had set up a committee of outside directors to evaluate the offers.

title: Jackson Renews Complaint Over His Share of the Delegates
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today renewed his complaint that his share of delegates to the Democratic National Convention was not proportional to the percentage of his popular vote. He also strongly suggested that he would not sit silent if party leaders do not heed his appeals for more delegates.

title: Officer Recounts Gunplay in Inwood Raid
description: A police officer in a drug raid in the Inwood area in which a sergeant was slain gave the first eyewitness account yesterday of the shooting, quietly testifying about the gunplay.

title: Douce F. Correa, 82; Started Fleming School
description: Douce Fleming Correa, founder of the Fleming School, died of cancer Wednesday at her Manhattan home. She was 82 years old. She founded the school, at 35 East 62d Street in Manhattan, in 1956 to provide a blend of American and French education. In fact, it was meant as an alternative to the Lycee Francais, where Mrs. Correa had taught mathematics and science for almost 30 years.

title: AFGHAN REBELS GET SUPPORT FROM U.S. FOR A GOVERNMENT
description: The United States has told the Afghan guerrillas that it would support them in an effort to form a provisional government if they consolidate their control of most of the country and meet other criteria, State Department officials said today.

title: Many Mornings After?
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, was eager to move into the Russell Building on Capitol Hill, especially since it had an office for him with a fireplace.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Joining Forces

title: Invitron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Houston Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knicks Give Celtics No Rest
description: The Boston Celtics planned to return home after Wednesday night's game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. According to a team official, the Celtics wanted to allow the players to sleep in their own beds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Selective Approach to Spirit Sales
description: CARILLON IMPORTERS, which handles such spirits as Absolut vodka, Bombay gin and La Grande Passion and Grand Marnier liqueurs, likes to put its advertising where its customers are but its competition is not.

title: 25 Go on Trial in Yugoslavia Over Financial Scandal Roles
description: Twenty-five people went on trial today in connection with Yugoslavia's Agrokomerc financial scandal, which toppled Vice President Hamdija Pozderac and caused political turmoil in the republic of Bosnia.

title: Anacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforward of $3,545,000 for the quarter and $7,120,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,148,000 and $3,500,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Martinez & Murphey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $25,500, or 1 cent a share, compared with a tax benefit of $31,602, or 1 cent a share, a year ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kirshenbaum Account
description: National Consumer Information Services, a recently formed data base company, has selected the 11-month-old Kirshenbaum & Bond of New York to handle its $2.5 million advertising account. It is the agency's biggest single assignment. The client, based in San Francisco, plans to provide consumers with product information. It screened five ad agencies; the others were from the West Coast.

title: Restaurants
description: It's really not fair the way chefs move from on restaurant kitchen to another in this town, often under cover of darkness with no public announcement so diners can keep track. Perhaps restaurateurs should be like professional sports teams and hold well-publicized drafts: ''I'll swap your Bobby (Mesquite Sizzler) LaRouche and his saucier for two pastry chefs and a first-round draft choice next year.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10 A.M. and 3:15 P.M.

title: Connecticut Legislature Adjourns in Frustration
description: Hours after the General Assembly adjourned shortly before 1 A.M. today, both Democrats and Republicans expressed frustration that the legislature had failed to settle the largest issue it faced, property-tax relief, or to take a final vote on several other fiercely debated measures.

title: Behind the 2 Democratic Contenders, 2 Hard-Driving Campaign Managers; Susan Estrich Brings Assurance And Toughness to Dukakis Drive
description: On Friday, Susan Estrich, campaign manager for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, will take her first weekend off since Christmas. She will go out to dinner with her husband. She will read novels. She will go to the movies.

title: All American Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cooper Says It Is Seeking Buyers
description: The Cooper Companies said that the board of directors had decided to seek a buyer for the whole company or for any or all of its businesses individually. The decision follows an announcement last week by the Federal Trade Commission that it will seek to block Cooper's proposed sale of its contact-lens business to the Schering-Plough Corporation because it would reduce competition in soft contact lenses. The acquisition would have netted Cooper $213 million. Cooper's share price jumped $2.125, to $14.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: George Rose, 68, Broadway Star And Winner of 2 Tonys, Is Dead; A Versatile Perennial
description: George Rose was one of the most versatile, inventive and hard-working actors on the Broadway and London stage during the last 40 years. The British-born actor, who won two Tony Awards and was nominated for three others, was known for his performances in such musical comedies as ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and ''My Fair Lady.''

title: Bridge
description: For the next five days, the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan, can claim to be the center of the bridge world.

title: Review/Film; Self-Absorbed Oblivion Before the Nazi Storm
description: In a peaceful Viennese garden, a man and woman who have recently embarked on a love affair discuss the matters they care about most. He has found a good apartment, in a building he says Mozart often used to pass; will she move in? She has an offer to travel abroad for professional reasons; will he object too strenuously? And will their liaison survive such pressures? Entirely absorbed in these questions, the lovers remain oblivious to the gathering storm.

title: Linear Instruments Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $16,700 for the quarter and $31,800 for the 6 months.

title: Two Pesos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Wells Fargo Mortgage & Eqity Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes for both periods expenses of $1,318,000 that were incurred in the termination of an agreement in principle to sell the company's assets and a proposed plan of liquidation; the 9 months also included a loss of $633,000. c-Net income and includes a gain of $636,000 and $1,131,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
CBI Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Let the Retail Price Be Right
description: Should a manufacturer have the power to tell retailers what to charge consumers for a product? The Supreme Court's recent ruling on this doesn't plow new ground but warns Congress that a majority of the Court remains uneasy with forbidding manufacturers to fix retail prices.

title: 8 Decline Olympic Bids
description: The list of players who have declined invitations to try out for the United States Olympic basketball team has grown to eight, and it could grow longer as potential Olympians choose to pursue the big money of the National Basketball Association rather than risk injury playing for a gold medal, according to Coach John Thompson of the Olympic team.

title: Review/Film; Imamura on Updating Divine Squalor
description: The robust good looks of Shohei Imamura's 1968 Cinemascope epic ''The Profound Desire of the Gods'' only heighten the perverse quality of the action, and Mr. Imamura's ribald, casually comic direction has much the same effect. This three-hour film, which will begin the Film Forum 2's Imamura retrospective, makes an ideal introduction to the maverick qualities of this film maker's idiosyncratic style.

title: Review/Film; Salome and Decadence, Via Wilde via Russell
description: Like the bee to the buttercup, like the sledgehammer to the nail, Ken Russell was bound to get around to Oscar Wilde, not the Wilde of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' or even of ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' but the Wilde of the sulphurous, rhapsodic, simile-stuffed ''Salome.'' This is the one-act play Wilde wrote in 1891 in French, the only language he thought pure enough for his vision of the primal encounter between John the Baptist and the unnamed (in the Bible) dancing daughter of Herodias, wife of Herod, King of Judea.

title: Party Roles Limited for New Yorkers
description: The vote in New York may have been critical to the Democrats' primary campaign, but when the party's convention is held in Atlanta in July to nominate a Presidential candidate the state's leading Democrats will almost certainly not play major roles.

title: Circadian Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $250,000. c-Net income

title: Superpower Proxies in Third World Deplored
description: A panel of American and Soviet public figures issued a report today suggesting ways to eliminate confrontation in the third world. But they disagreed at a news conference about their key proposal, a ban on superpower use of so-called ''proxy forces'' in regional conflicts.

title: Review/Concert; Art of Early Keyboard
description: Gwendolyn Toth, an organist (principally), brought the third season of her Art of the Early Keyboard series to a close on Wednesday evening at St. Michael's Church with an enlightening look at German church music by four of Bach's predecessors and older contemporaries.

title: Dixon Ticonderoga Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes credits from the termination of a pension plan of $32,544 and $213,945 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Review/Film; A Priest's Sex-Struck Parish
description: ''The Mass Is Ended'' begins with a young priest, Don Giulio, returning to his home in Rome after service on a picturesque island, only to find more problems than he can handle. They are mostly problems of the heart. The priest whom Giulio is replacing had to give up the pulpit when his love affair produced a child. A friend has become a recluse after breaking up with his lover. Another friend gets into trouble because of his fondness for boys. Giulio's father, who is given to pondering whether there is such a thing as ''universal love,'' leaves home to take up with a much younger woman. Giulio's unmarried sister is pregnant and intends to have an abortion. When she turns to him for comfort, the distraught Giulio tells her that if she goes ahead with her plan, ''I'll kill you first and then myself.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Polish forces crushed a 10-day strike at the big Lenin steel mill at Nowa Huta. Meanwhile, riot policemen kept the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk sealed as several hundred workers continued a four-day walkout. Page A1

title: On Stage
description: Gantry Is Alive and Preaching

title: U.S. Efforts Fail to Heal Contra Rift
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's efforts to shore up a monthlong rift in the Nicaraguan rebel leadership, the differences appear to persist.

title: House Signals Preference for Small Mobile Missile
description: The House voted today to reverse the Reagan Administration's priorities on long-range mobile nuclear missiles, increasing the budget for a program the Administration wants to cancel while sharply cutting back on the system it prefers.

title: New England Critical Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bourque Lives Behind a Mask
description: After a Bruin victory, Ray Bourque, the defenseman who balances the rarest of skills with the lunchpail mentality so highly prized among Boston Garden's athletic contingent, sits slumped at his locker.

title: Yemen Oil Exploration
description: Yemen and Southern Yemen have agreed on a joint exploration venture for oil in their border region, newspapers here reported today. They said agreement had been reached to leave an 850-square-mile area between each other's oilfields free of military installations.

title: Verticom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Class of '88
description: ''Oh, say, can you see . . .'' The anthem begins with the usual whisper, until the singers feel their individual voices are lost, until almost all are trying the difficult high notes at the end, until the 35,000 or so voices fill the huge stadium that sits like a crater in the side of a hill.

description: b-Net income

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Rockets Eliminated
description: Mark Aguirre scored 38 points, including a club-record 27 in the third quarter, as the Dallas Mavericks eliminated Houston from the playoffs, 107-97, tonight.

title: Yacht Dispute in Court
description: Michael Fay of New Zealand asked the New York State Supreme Court yesterday to rule on the San Diego Yacht Club's plan to defend the America's Cup with a multihull. A hearing is scheduled May 18 before Judge Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday COMMERCIALS AS ART

title: Stanley William Hayter, 86, Dies; Painter Taught Miro and Pollack
description: Stanley William Hayter, a widely exhibited painter and the most influential printmaker of the first half of the century, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 86 years old.

title: The Smithereens
description: The Smithereens, a rock bank, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Lucky 7 opens tonight; Cindy Lee Berryhill opens tomorrow. Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: S.E.C. Attacks Wisconsin Law
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a friend-of-the-court brief today, charging that Wisconsin's anti-takeover law is unconstitutional.

title: About Real Estate; Smithtown Making Condominiums Feel at Home
description: Smithtown, on the North Shore of Long Island, has been one of the later communities to accept condominiums. By waiting longer, however, it has devised a formula to bypass much of the opposition to them found elsewhere.

title: Train Is Struck From Behind; 20 Passengers Hurt in Jersey
description: A locomotive struck the back of an N.J. Transit passenger train on the North Jersey Coast Line today, injuring at least 20 people, the police said.

title: Walker Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Teamster Chief Taking Leave
description: Jackie Presser is taking a leave of absence from his post as president of the teamsters' union just as a jury's verdict in the trial of a New York mob leader boss has reportedly set back Federal efforts to oust Mr. Presser and other teamster leaders.

title: Review/Film; Guns and Corruption
description: In ''Shakedown,'' something fancy happens every 15 minutes or so, which is part of what makes the whole film so unremarkable. It becomes difficult to remember why the stolen police car being driven by the runaway thug, for example, has got upside-down amid the piles of burning rubble. Or why the roller coaster has run amok at Coney Island, or why the taxi has been impaled on the wrecking ball. The writer and director, James Glickenhaus, whose chief claim to fame is the earlier ''Exterminator,'' would surely be lost without the sounds of screeching brakes and spraying gunfire at regular intervals.

title: Dynatronics Laser reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: Behind Two Candidates

title: India Asserts Afghan Leader Would Share Rule With Foes
description: Najibullah, the Afghan leader, was described by senior Indian officials today as willing to share significant political powers with Afghan guerrilla groups and prepared to accept India as a mediator in bringing about such an arrangement.

title: Cosmopolitan Care reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $525,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and includes a pretax gain of $519,000 from the completion of a public offering of CCC Franchising Corp. Sales represent sales of services.

title: Cocaine Seized And 5 Arrested In Queens Raid
description: LEAD: The police seized 1,000 pounds of cocaine in Whitestone, Queens, and arrested five men Wednesday night.

title: A Symphonic Summit After Politicians Talk
description: Shortly after President Reagan joins Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the summit meeting, a Moscow stage will combine the New York Philharmonic and the State Symphony Orchestra of the Soviet Ministry of Culture.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bank of New York Company reached agreement with Irving's preferred shareholders to waive a ''poison pill'' provision that would block a takeover. It must win a proxy fight at Irving's annual meeting today to drop the remaining barriers. [ D1. ]

title: Hong Kong Stake Raised
description: Jardine Strategic Holdings announced today that it had raised its stake in the Hongkong Land Company to 33 percent from 25 percent.

title: Los Angeles High-Rise Fire Kills 1; Officials Cite Lack of Sprinklers
description: Fire ravaged the tallest building in California late Wednesday night, resulting in one death, injury to more than 30 people and questions about the construction and safety of modern skyscrapers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it plans to expand production at its Sleeper gold mine in Nevada by 20 percent, adding 40,000 ounces a year of capacity by 1989.

title: Premier of Bahamas Denies Charges He Accepted Bribes
description: The Prime Minister of the Bahamas, Sir Lynden O. Pindling, on Wednesday denied charges that he took bribes from drug smugglers.

Brawley's Lawyers Call Party Account From Youth a Hoax
description: WCBS-TV was accused yesterday of paying between $10 and $100 to a youth who told the station that he saw Tawana Brawley at a party in Newburgh, N.Y., during the four days last November when the black teen-ager has indicated she was being held by white abductors and sexually assaulted.

title: Murder Ruled Out in Death
description: Foul play has been ruled out in the death of a 22-year-old New York University student from Boston who was found dead in his dormitory room Wednesday, the police said yesterday. The body of the student, identified as Daniel Rosenberg, was discovered by a roommate at 33 Third Avenue, near Ninth Street. Officials said the possibility of accidental death or suicide had not been dismissed, but that it might be months before a complete medical report would be available.

title: Ex-Hostages Recall Beirut Ordeal And Comrade's Wrenching Death
description: ''We survived,'' Jean-Paul Kauffmann said today of his three years as a hostage in Lebanon. ''We did not live.'' Dressed in fur-lined air force jackets, Mr. Kauffmann and two other freed hostages, Marcel Carton and Marcel Fontaine, stepped off a small jet to a somber reception at Villacoublay, an air base southwest of Paris.

title: State Dept. Criticizes Jordan For Crackdown on Reporters
description: The United States criticized Jordan today for expelling an American television network reporter and for withdrawing the credentials of two local journalists working for American news organizations.

description: Declaring that the Federal Government has ''failed miserably'' at stopping drugs coming into the United States, Governor Cuomo yesterday announced that 110 state troopers are being deputized by the United States Customs Service to help seize drugs smuggled into New York State.

title: Review/Dance; Music Highlight's City Ballet's All-Robbins Night
description: If you can believe, as legend has it, that James Audubon was the ''lost Dauphin'' and that this son of Louis XVI escaped the French Revolution and came to America, then you can believe that ''Birds of America,'' a ballet related to this theme, was actually on the way to completion by George Balanchine.

title: Louis Armstrong Salute

Tickets to the tribute to Louis Armstrong are $5 and $10 (students and the elderly, $2). Information: (718) 793-8080.

title: Law School Dean Wanted: A Man for All Reasons
description: Time was when being dean of a law school was the summit of the profession, offering a chance to shape the direction of legal education and hone the next generation of legal talent. A prime example was Erwin N. Griswold who served 21 years as dean of the Harvard Law School, dominating one of America's prominent institutions, before resigning in 1967 to become Solicitor General.

title: Campaigns, Costly and Frugal
description: The rising cost of campaigning has apparently not affected State Senator Abraham Bernstein, Democrat of the Bronx. His bargain basement re-election campaign, the least expensive by an incumbent in the 1986 Senate election, cost $189.

title: Steamy Nuns and Junkies
description: When Yolanda's boyfriend dies of a dose of heroin laced with strychnine, with which she unknowingly supplied him, she seeks refuge from the police at the convent of the Holy Redeemers, dedicated to Our Lady of the Forsaken. Its motto: ''Sin is our chosen path.'' There the nightclub singer-cum-junkie finds a home away from home.

title: Quinones Punished
description: The Seattle Mariners shortstop, Rey Quinones, was placed on the club's disqualified list Wednesday and will be docked a day's pay and service time for each day he is away from the team. Without club permission, he returned to Puerto Rico Tuesday night with his wife and child following the death of his wife's grandfather. Quinones was batting .290 with a home run and 11 runs batted in after appearing in the first 27 games. (AP)

title: American Stores May Lift Lucky Bid
description: The American Stores Company disclosed that it had told Lucky Stores Inc. it was willing to pay more than $60 a share for the company if non-public information provided by the company justified a higher price. American Stores signaled its determination not to halt its battle for control of Lucky, even though the Dublin, Calif., supermarket chain has accepted a buyout offer of $61 a share, or $2.4 billion, from Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.

title: Allure of Teaching Reviving; Education School Rolls Surge
description: Ranald Jarrell was earning a six-figure income as a tax lawyer in Anchorage, but last year he forsook that life to go to New York to learn how to become a teacher.

title: George Rose, 68, Broadway Star And Winner of 2 Tonys, Is Dead
description: George Rose, a veteran comic actor who was as adept at Shakespeare as at Gilbert and Sullivan and who won two Tony Awards, was found dead early today in an overturned car near his vacation home in the Dominican Republic. The police there said Mr. Rose's death appeared to have been the result of an accident. He was 68 years old. Lieut. Col. Melchor Lara Morillo of the Dominican Republic police said the police had investigated rumors that Mr. Rose had been the victim of a robbery, but they concluded he died from head injuries after his car left the road and turned over several times.

description: Any debut in a ballet that takes three hours is a major one; in this respect, American Ballet Theater's production of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' automatically becomes a test of both artistic projection and physical stamina.

Also contributing to the company's third quarter profitability was a $610,000 federal income tax refund resulting from the settlement in the company's favor of an IRS audit for fiscal years 1982 and 1983. In addition, accrued interest income of $500,000 related to the tax refund was reflected in the company's third quarter non-operating income.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Evert Withdraws From Italian Open: Top-seeded Chris Evert withdrew because of a foot injury and Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, the No. 3 player, lost in the third round of the Italian Open in Rome yesterday. Evert, who was scheduled to play a third-round match against Helen Kelesi of Canada, defaulted because of a heel injury in her right foot. She suffered the injury Wednesday in a victory over Nicole Provis of Australia, and the pain became so severe overnight that she could not stand. Kohde-Kilsch was upset by Judith Wiesner of Austria, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, on the center court. She made several unforced errors on the slow red clay and struggled with her first serve. No. 2 Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina breezed into the quarterfinals with a 6-0, 6-2 victory over Niege Dias of Brazil. No. 7 Sylvia Hanika of West Germany beat Alexia Dechaume of France, 6-2, 6-1, and No. 8 Arantxa Sanchez of Spain defeated Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Jarryd Advances in Munich Open: Top-seeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden defeated Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $202,000 Munich Open in West Germany. In other matches, Tore Meinecke of West Germany beat Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, and Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany overcame Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 3-6, 7-6, 6-3. Hansjoerg Schwaier of West Germany was eliminated by Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-0, 6-4. Also advancing were Wally Masur of Australia, who defeated Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 2-6, 7-6, 7-5; Emilio Sanchez of Spain, who beat Roberto Azar of Argentina, 6-1, 5-7, 6-4, and Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, a 6-3, 6-2 winner over Jordi Arrese of Spain. GOLF Kobayashi Leads Konica Cup: Yoko Kobayashi of Japan shot a three-under-par 69 to take a one-stroke lead yesterday in the first round of the $360,000 Konica Cup World Ladies Golf Tournament in Inagi, Japan. Kobayashi carded four birdies against one bogey on the par-72, 6,339-yard layout. Atsuko Hikage of Japan shot a 70 and was in second place. Laura Davies, who in 1987 became the first Briton to win the United States Women's Open, shot a 72 and Jan Geddes of the United States, winner of the U.S. Women's Open in 1986, shot a 74, carding five birdies, five bogeys and one double bogey.(AP)

title: Impressionist Shows at 2 Auction Houses
description: THIS is the May weekend when bidding paddles are polished and art enthusiasts by the thousands make the rounds of New York's auction galleries. From today through Sunday, Sotheby's and Christie's will welcome the multitudes who come to view the largest exhibitions of Impressionist, modern and tribal art to be presented by the auction houses this year. The works on display will be offered for sale next week.
