title: A Paean to New York's Fetid Subways
description: The masters of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have decided to invest $1 million in an advertising campaign to tout something called ''Midday Business Service.'' The purpose is to entice ''25-to-44-year-olds with household incomes of at least $50,000'' back to the IRT. I wish them luck. But as someone in the target group, I don't need to be persuaded. I already love the subways: the IRT, BMT, IND - the sights, the smells, the works.

title: GUIDEPOST: Mortgage Indexes
description: Adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARM's, offer borrowers an alternative to fixed-rate mortgages, which now average 10.36 percent in the United States. These variable-rate mortgages rise or fall with a particular financial index. Lending institutions select their indexes based on an analysis of what best protects their loan portfolios. About half the lenders peg their ARM's to the one-year Treasury bill, but if you're shopping around for a mortgage, it's worth knowing that there are other indexes and other choices. The lender's literature may not explain all this, but loan officers will, if you ask. For the borrower, some indexes may be more favorable than others. These are the most commonly used indexes: $ Index Rate Attributes 1-year Treasury 7.07% More volatile, an attractive constant maturity yield feature when rates fall. 11th District cost of 7.50 Tracks a narrow range, funds attractive when rates rise. National cost of funds 7.11 A broader-based index that changes more slowly. Sources: Bank Rate Monitor, Federal National Mortgage Association and Dime Savings Bank

description: Two million lives are now at imminent risk from famine in Ethiopia, twice the number who died in the 1984-85 calamity. Then, the world couldn't send emergency help fast enough. This time the problem is different. It's not the lack of food, but the regime's refusal to let it reach the famished.

title: Saatchi Expansion

The purchase was the latest in a series of acquisitions by Saatchi in a drive to diversify beyond advertising and build up a global presence. Saatchi said the initial payment would be $11 million with further installments based on after-tax profits to January 1990. The total would not exceed $42 million, it said.

description: b-After a gain of $33.5 million on the sale of assets by the company's Eastern Air Lines unit and included a charge of $14.1 million for preferred dividend payments to Eastern's preferred stockholders.

title: Police Ask Brooklyn Rights Protesters to Surrender
description: Police officials said yesterday that they had received bench warrants for the arrests of the Rev. Al Sharpton, Assemblyman Roger L. Green and 16 other civil-rights protesters and that they would ask the people, through their lawyers, to surrender by next Tuesday.

title: Polish Solidarity, American Unsolidarity
description: LEAD: One has to marvel at how Americans - and especially our politicians - can strongly support the strikers and demonstrators in Poland and other socialist countries while ignoring and even denouncing strikes and demonstrations by American workers.

title: Horse Racing; Goodbye Halo Romps in Oaks
description: Goodbye Halo ran down her entrymate, Jeanne Jones, to post a 3 3/4-length victory today at Churchill Downs in the $242,600 Kentucky Oaks, the filly equivalent of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Aron Alperin, 87, Dies; Edited Yiddish Papers
description: Aron Alperin, a writer and the editor of the Yiddish-language newspapers The Jewish Day and The Morning Journal for a quarter-century, died of a heart attack Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: New Line Cinema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knicks Show Will, but Celtics Show Way and Win
description: The mood of the capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden told the story for the Knicks last night.

title: Judge Trims Utility Suit
description: A Federal judge has dismissed the damage claims of some of the bondholders suing the Washington Public Power Supply System over the termination of two nuclear power plant projects.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Dip
description: Canada's unemployment rate dipped to 7.7 percent in April from 7.8 percent in March, Statistics Canada reporteds today. The Government agency said the jobless rolls declined by only 10,000 in the month and remained over the one million mark.

title: Oncor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Colonial Commercial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
East German to Dance As Ballet Theater Guest
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, American Ballet Theater's artistic director, has invited Oliver Matz, a principal dancer with the Deutsche Staatsoper Ballet in East Berlin to appear as a guest artist with the company this season.

title: RMS International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gish Biomedical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $190,000 for the 9 months. c-Included tax credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the 9 months.

title: Xerox in Pact To Add Datacopy
description: The Xerox Corporation said it would acquire the Datacopy Corporation, a supplier of desktop scanners and image processing systems, based in Mountain View, Calif., for $6 a share in cash, or about $31 million. The Datacopy trade name will be retained, and Rolando Esteverena, Datacopy's president and chief executive, will remain as president as the company becomes a wholly owned Xerox subsidiary, Xerox said.

title: Bomb Suspect: Puzzling Journey to an Arrest
description: In his five weeks in the United States before his arrest, Yu Kikumura traveled far and wide. Before he was seized in New Jersey on April 12 with three powerful homemade bombs, the suspected member of the Japanese Red Army logged 7,000 miles on the second-hand car he had bought in the Bronx on March 14, buying wiring, batteries, gunpowder and other bomb-making materials, according to documents unsealed today in Federal District Court here.

title:
Your Money;
Picking a Broker: Cost vs. Service
description: LEAD: Discount brokers have long appealed to the sophisticated, active investor who does all his or her own research, knows the dangers of various investments, keeps abreast of the markets and is prepared to act quickly when news breaks. These investors have been able to save from 30 to 70 percent on commissions, depending on which discount broker they use.

title: Florida Cocaine Seizure Weighs In as Record
description: After three days of sawing, X-raying and weighing, officials said today that a cocaine seizure near here Tuesday was the largest in the nation.

title: Placid in Deal to Leave Chapter 11
description: The Placid Oil Company, part of the Hunt family's dwindling fortune, and 23 creditor banks today filed a court document signaling formal agreement on a deal to take the independent oil company out of bankruptcy, lawyers said.

title: Early Pace Is Theme of Classic
description: An undefeated colt, a front-running filly and a slightly tarnished champion are the favorites to win the 114th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday. Their respective chances of victory should be clear long before they reach the wire.

title: Cuomo's House Is Sold for $320,000
description: The house in Queens that Governor Cuomo and and his family have owned for almost 30 years has been sold for $320,000, aides to the Governor said yesterday.

title: Mets Win in 10
description: Darryl Strawberry had removed the radio-interview headphones and was on his way to his locker when he was yanked into an adjacent television room by Howard Johnson. He stood, watched the replay and shook his head in wonder.

title: Election Could Splinter the French Right
description: Deep and possibly momentous fissures are opening within France's loosely united rightist parliamentary majority as President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, remains a heavy favorite in Sunday's presidential election.

title: Ballet; AT THE MET, A STAR'S RETURN
description: Natalia Makarova returned to the stage on Thursday in Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' presented by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House, and made this return from semiretirement the kind of gala event one would have expected from such a seasoned showwoman. But her partner, Kevin McKenzie, gave her a run for her money, as did Johan Renvall as Mercutio, in a performance that will be repeated tonight for national telecast by the Public Broadcasting System on ''Live From Lincoln Center.''

title: Vote Affirmed, Gillette Reports
description: The Gillette Company, the subject of an April 21 proxy fight spearheaded by its largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, said yesterday that its independent inspector had confirmed that Gillette's four nominees to the board had defeated the dissident slate by 4 percent.

description: Michael Smuin, the choreographer for ''Anything Goes,'' and Herbert L. Rawlings Jr., who danced in a revival last year of ''Dreamgirls,'' are the recipients of this year's Fred Astaire Awards, given annually by the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation for excellence in dance and choreography on Broadway.

description: Questions appear on page 10.

description: Stubble covered his face and exhaustion was written around his eyes as Lech Walesa spoke to the shipyard workers whom a Government propagandist derides as ''Walesa's teen-agers.''

title: Prudential Sues Over Asbestos
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said it had sued the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas for $135 million for the cost of removing asbestos from a building in Dallas that First Republicbank sold to Prudential. In its suit, filed in Federal court in Dallas, Prudential said that the company had known about the asbestos problem in the Renaissance Tower but withheld the information. The building was actually acquired from the Interfirst Corporation, one of two bank holding companies merged last year to form First Republicbank.

title: Buehler International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.A.W. Unit Passes Chrysler Pact
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers approved a tentative contract today with the Chrysler Corporation, clearing the way for a ratification vote by 66,000 workers in the United States.

title: China Is Praised in Pravda
description: Pravda today praised changes in Chinese economic policy that have attracted foreign investment, and it called for a rebirth of the work ethic to bring similar prosperity to the Soviet Union. The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has made favorable references to recent Chinese economic experiments, but the article in the Communist Party daily was the most complimentary Soviet report on such changes in China.

title: Glenn on Vice Presidency
description: Senator John Glenn said today he would consider an offer to run for Vice President on the 1988 Democratic ticket but will not seek it.

title: U.S. QUARANTINE ON BEE MITE IS LIFTED
description: A month-old, 13-state Federal quarantine to curb the spread of tiny bee mites was lifted today because it has proved unworkable, the Agriculture Department said.

title: Courier Dispatch Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Dr. Prelinger Is Wed To Stephen Messner
description: At Healy Hall at Georgetown University in Washington, Dr. Elizabeth Anne Prelinger, a daughter of Dorothy Prelinger of New Haven and Dr. Ernst Prelinger of Killingworth, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Charles Messner, the son of Dr. Arnold E. Messner of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Barbara R. Messner. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated. The bride, an assistant professor of fine arts at Georgetown, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a doctorate in fine arts from Harvard. Her mother is a library assistant at Yale University's Art and Architecture Library. Her father is a clinical professor of psychology at Yale.

title: Irish Music
description: Jack Coen and Michael Preston on flutes and Dessie Groake on tenor banjo will perform Irish traditional music tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: BISHOPS DENOUNCE WARSAW FOR USING FORCE ON STRIKERS
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops today denounced the Government's use of force to end the strike at a major steel complex near Cracow.

description: Albert D. Wheelon, the chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Aircraft Company, has abruptly retired at the age of 59, just 13 months after taking the top posts.

Pelvas said, was to be excused from the weekly mandatory religious services at the small mining equipment manufacturing company where he worked in Eloy, Ariz., and to be allowed to spend the time working at his job as machine shop supervisor at the Townley Engineering and Manufacturing Company.

title: Proxy Fight Ends at Irving And Each Side Says It Won
description: The chairmen of the Irving Bank Corporation and the Bank of New York each predicted victory yesterday after a proxy contest at Irving's annual meeting.

title: U.S. Issues Fatality Data on 65 M.P.H.
description: Preliminary figures show that traffic fatalities on rural Interstate highways with a 65 mile-per-hour limit rose last year at virtually the same rate as on rural Interstates that have kept the limit at 55 m.p.h., the Transportation Department said today.

title: Dance; Four City Ballet Premieres, One by Martins
description: After a slow start last week, the American Music Festival at the New York City Ballet finally hit its stride Thursday night with a major new ballet by Peter Martins and three other premieres - by Laura Dean, Richard Tanner and Robert La Fosse.

description: President Reagan had harsh words today for a book written by Donald T. Regan, his former chief of staff, that discloses details of the First Family's deep interest in astrology.

description: The United States Attorney in Providence, R.I., filed criminal charges against E. F. Hutton & Company yesterday, accusing the securities firm of being involved in a money-laundering conspiracy for organized-crime figures and business executives.

description: Vice President Bush conceded publicly for the first time today that he was ''troubled by some of these allegations'' of ethical impropriety surrounding Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. He said Mr. Meese's fate should depend on the findings of a special Federal prosecutor.

description: China is planning to develop high-technology industries by setting up six ''silicon valleys,'' the official New China News Agency said today. The zones will be in Beijing, Shanghai, Canton, Tienjin, Wuhan and the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, near Hong Kong.

The Mayor, who apparently has little else to do other than rush around to his favorite bistros tacking up ''No Smoking!

description: Next week, the Koch administration will propose spending $25 million a year - six times as much as it does now - on solid-waste recycling as part of a plan to require New York City to recycle up to 20 percent of its garbage by 1996.

title: Texas Air Cites Loss For Eastern
description: The Texas Air Corporation reported yesterday that its Eastern Airlines subsidiary had a net loss of $31 million in the first quarter of the year. But some analysts said they had been told by Texas Air executives that the carrier had an operating profit of $13.8 million in the period.

title: Television; Makarova Dances Juliet, Live Tonight on 13
description: ''Live From the Met'' has now become ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents,'' acknowledging the fact that its broadcasts on PBS have been taped earlier in performance. ''Live From Lincoln Center,'' however, can still deliver what its title promises. Tonight's broadcast of American Ballet Theater's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is indeed being transmitted live from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera. What you are watching is precisely what the paying customers will be seeing at that very moment. On several levels, then, not least the artistic and economic, the event takes on a special frisson.

title: Unemployment Shows a Decline To 14-Year Low
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell a tenth of a point last month to 5.4 percent, the lowest since 1974, as the proportion of the population with jobs hit a record, the Labor Department reported today.

description: Civilian unemployment in March and April. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

R. D. Darrell, 84, Dies; Recorded-Music Critic
description: R. D. Darrell, a music critic and author who was one of the first American critics to concentrate primarily on recordings, died on Sunday at Kingston Hospital after suffering a stroke earlier in the week. He was 84 years old, and lived in Stone Ridge, N.Y.

title: Japan-Europe Trade
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan today urged an expansion of trade between the European Community and Japan. ''The importance of increased economic cooperation between Japan and Europe cannot be underestimated,'' the Prime Minister told reporters after meeting with West German officials as part of an 11-day European tour.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bucks 105, Hawks 99: Terry Cummings and Jack Sikma led a fourth-quarter rally last night as the Milwaukee Bucks beat the visiting Atlanta Hawks to even their first-round Eastern Conference playoff series at two games apiece. The fifth and deciding game will be played tomorrow in Atlanta. Cummings scored 30 points for the second straight game, including 9 in the fourth quarter; Sikma had 8 of his 23 in the final period. The Bucks trailed by 4 points in the fourth quarter, but Sidney Moncrief, Sikma and Cummings brought Milwaukee back in an 11-2 run before a raucous crowd at the Milwaukee Arena. Dominique Wilkins led the Hawks with 31 points, including 12 in the fourth quarter. Rivers added 22 for the Hawks.(AP) Tennis Sabatini Advances in Italian Open: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, stunned in the first set, rallied to defeat No. 7 Sylvia Hanika, 3-6, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday and reach the semifinals of the Italian Open in Rome. Sabatini advanced to a match with No. 13 Judith Wiesner of Austria, who upset No. 6 Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Golf Shipman Has Three-Stroke Lead: Kim Shipman, who has not won in her four years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot a career-best seven-under-par 65 yesterday to open a three-stroke lead after the first round of the Crestar Classic in Suffolk, Va. Her closest competitors were Sherri Turner and Missie Berteotti.(AP) Eagle Puts Nichols in Lead: Bobby Nichols shot a four-under-par 68 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the Vantage at the Dominion Senior PGA tournament in San Antonio. Nichols parred two of the four par-5 holes, birdied another and eagled the par-5 ninth hole, his 18th of the day. The eagle moved Nichols from one stroke back into a one-shot lead over Al Geiberger, Jim King and Walt Zembriski.(AP) Track and Field Meet Record in Girls Hurdles: Shelley Mitchell of Lakewood (N.J.) High School won the girls 400 meter hurdles in the meet-record time of 1 minute 2.28 seconds yesterday at the New York Relays. Kelvin McQueen of Uniondale High School on Long Island won the boys 400 meter hurdles in 54.35 seconds. Joe Tuttle of Moore Catholic of Staten Island beat Ramon Espinosa of George Washington in the final 50 yards to win the one-mile run in 4 minutes 23.22 seconds. Sue O'Callahan of Bronxville was the girls winner of the mile in 5:14.04.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Media Business article in Business Day on Thursday about New York City's tabloid newspapers misstated New York Newsday's circulation in Brooklyn and Manhattan. It is about 37,000 in each borough.

title: Mr. Franse Shortchanges Children
description: New York City's Board of Education needs improvement, and the Legislature is pondering changes in its size and structure. But a single change in the present membership would greatly enhance its quality: removing Stephen Franse.

title: At End, Knicks Look Forward
description: Moments after the Knicks had been eliminated from the playoffs last night, the players milled round the locker room, not sad, not happy, but more or less in a state of contented relief. They had lost, but they had won. They had fallen short, but they had also taken great strides.

title: Crooks Die Hard But So Does Cop
description: There is one scene in ''Dead Heat,'' now at the National and other theaters, that produces a cold sweat: A dead cop has a shootout with a dead bad guy. description: New York State has halted some repairs to its decaying highway bridges because of concern over possible health hazards from lead-based paint, state transportation officials said yesterday.

description: Three years ago, everyone suddenly seemed beset by a crisis in liability insurance - municipalities, day care centers, ski lifts. Premiums soared, more than doubling in some cases. Insurers imposed sharp restrictions on coverage. In many places, they canceled policies altogether.

description: Share earnings are cents a unit. Comparable year-ago results are not applicable; the company purchased First Property in September 1987.

description: The 55-to 60-mile-per-hour winds that disrupted play in the second round of the Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational Thursday dropped to a mere 35 miles this morning when 71 golf pros were able to complete their second rounds.

The reading, from the play ''The Value of Names'' by Jeffrey Sweet, will feature Larry Black, Dinah Manoff and Norman Rose, artistic director of Readers Repertory.

description: King Baudouin today asked Wilfried Martens, the caretaker Prime Minister, to form a new government, ending a 144-day political stalemate in Belgium.

title: Baseball; Cubs Take 4th Straight, 3-2
description: Ryne Sandberg and Jim Sundberg hit home runs today to lead the Chicago Cubs to their fourth straight victory, a 3-2 triumph over the San Francisco Giants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-6, 28 Poland's bishops denounced the Government's use of force to end the strike at a major steel complex near Cracow. The decision to use force indicated divisions in the Polish Communist leadership. Page 1 Lech Walesa spoke to young strikers at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk as riot police massed outside the gates. About 800 workers are left, and the Solidarity founder sought to bolster their spirits. 1 Israel ordered the deportation of a Palestinian-American who advocated nonviolent resistance in the Israeli-occupied territories. Washington objected to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's order to deport Mubarak Awad. 1 India is storing plutonium, which can be used to make nuclear weapons, in installations without international safeguards, Indian officials said. The country is proceeding with an ambitious nuclear energy program. 1 France's parliamentary majority, a loose rightist coalition, could be split if President Francois Mitterrand wins Sunday's presidential election convincingly. Private polls show Prime Minister Jacques Chirac trailing. 3 France recalled a secret agent from exile. Prime Minister Jacques Chirac infuriated the New Zealand Government by summoning home the agent, who had been convicted of blowing up a ship in Auckland in July 1985. 3 A political stalemate in Belgium has prompted King Baudouin to ask Wilfred Martens, the caretaker Prime Minister, to form a new government. Relations between the Flemish speakers and French speakers complicate the situation. 28 Nicaraguan construction workers called off a 10-day hunger strike Thursday, but have not returned to work. Workers said the Government promised to negotiate; the Government said no agreement was reached. 2 Taiwan's aging legislature blocks democracy, according to Chu Kao-cheng, a 33-year-old opposition legislator who makes his point by jumping on desks, smashing microphones and shouting at older legislators. 4 American hostages reportedly abused 3 West German asks U.S. missiles 4 German company calls transfer of heavy water proper 4 27 die in Lebanon battles 5 Afghan leader appeals to rebel moderates and issues warning 5 NATIONAL 7-8, 34-36 The nation's jobless rate fell a tenth of a point in April to 5.4 percent, the lowest since 1974, as the proportion of the population with jobs hit a record, the Labor Department reported. 1 New York's unemployment rate fell in April to its lowest level in 18 years, the United States Department of Labor reported. New York and New Jersey each recorded a seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of 3.5 percent. 8 The year 2000 may upset computers, causing malfunctions in machines whose programs fail to recognize that Dec. 31, 1999, will be followed by Jan. 1, 2000. The oddity could affect many records stored on mainframe computers. 1 News analysis: The offer of amnesty to aliens who had lived in the United States for five years or more was the result of a political compromise that imposed limits that the program may never be able to overcome. 7 Religion in the workplace is being challenged by an employee of a private company who was required to attend services at work. His case is testing whether private corporations can force employees to share a religious message. 7 Criticism of Chicago's Acting Mayor, Eugene Sawyer, has come from every quarter after Mr. Sawyer dismissed an assistant who delivered speeches attacking whites, especially Jews. 7 Workers recalled confusion in a Los Angeles skyscraper as they tried to escape from a fire in the building. It was a terrifying night for about 50 people trapped in the tower, many of whom did not speak English. 36 President angry over Regan book 7 Quarantine on bee mites lifted as unworkable 36 Congressional offices called safe despite Wright fire 36 Politics 34 George Bush said he is troubled by some of the allegations of ethical impropriety against Edwin Meese 3d. The Vice President had resisted commenting directly on the Attorney General's legal troubles until now. 1 Reagan Administration policies could affect Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign in the West. A poll in a conservative Idaho district showed Michael Dukakis, the likely Democratic nominee, with a slight lead. 34 Jesse Jackson called teen-agers who admitted using drugs to come forward at a high school in Los Angeles. About 100 heeded the Democratic Presidential candidate's call. 34 Dukakis loses court plea on National Guard 34 REGIONAL 29-32 Foster care for children with AIDS is in short supply. New York City has recruited about 75 foster parents in the last three years, but there are more needy babies than parents. 29 An independent agency for bridges in New York City will be proposed by the Koch administration. The new authority would spend $2.7 billion for repairing, rebuildng and replacing bridges. 29 A suspected terrorist traveled widely in the United States in the five weeks before his arrest in New Jersey April 12 with three homemade bombs. Yu Kikumura logged 7,000 miles in a used car he bought in the Bronx. 29 Senator Alfonse D'Amato testified that he would have helped Wedtech even without a request from Representative Mario Biaggi, who is on trial with six others charged with turning the Bronx defense contractor into a racketeering enterprise. 29 City proposes boosting spending on recycling to $25 million 31 Real-estate developer indicted in bank fraud 31 Vallone sets up action panel 31 Rights protesters asked to surrender 31 New testimony on Brawley's whereabouts is offered 31

title: Indictment Cites Improper Loan For a Developer
description: A real-estate developer in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on four counts of bank fraud in connection with a $17 million real-estate loan he received from Chemical Bank, Federal investigators said.

title: Costantino Nivola, 76, A Sculptor Of Public and Small-Scale Works
description: Costantino Nivola, a sculptor who did public commissions for buildings at Harvard, Yale and a number of other sites in the Northeast, died of a heart attack Thursday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in The Springs on Long Island.

title: Koch to Propose Special Agency For City Bridges
description: The Koch administration will propose creating an independent authority to spend $2.7 billion to repair, rebuild and - when necessary - replace bridges in New York City.

description: A recently released French hostage was quoted today as saying American hostages in Lebanon were treated brutally because they had tried to escape.

title: Why Wait? Write Today
description: First you work for a President, then you write a book. Only probably you don't write it. ''But you don't have to write it,'' says the publishing man. That's a relief, because when is the last time you wrote anything at all, even a letter to your mother? And remember what she wrote back?

title: Irish-Soviet Venture
description: Irish linen, Waterford crystal, calculators, tape decks and marmalade have gone on sale at Moscow's Sheremetyevo International Airport at a duty-free shop run as an Irish-Soviet joint venture. Young Irish women at the shop said the customers included many Soviet citizens as well as foreigners, although the shop did not accept rubles as payment. The store opened on Sunday.

description: LEAD: A method for investigating sexual assaults was patented this week for the University of Virginia Alumni Patents Foundation in Charlottesville. The method, already being used by some crime laboratories, uses a monoclonal antibody that can identify semen.

title: 9 Arrested in Gambling Raids
description: Nine people were arrested when the police broke up several sports gambling rings that netted $300 million in bets annually, the police said.

title: Murray Rejects Electrolux Bid
description: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, which makes bicycles and lawn mowers, yesterday rejected a $182 million takeover bid from Electrolux A.B. of Sweden. The directors of the Brentwood, Tenn., company called the $48-a-share offer inadequate and filed a suit seeking to bar Electrolux from taking any further action to acquire Murray. A Chancery Court granted a 10-day restraining order. Murray said the offer from Electrolux came earlier in the week and was condition upon Murray Ohio not publicly disclosing the offer before acting on it.

title: Noted Left Hand Takes Rare Turn
description: The production line was moving smoothly and silently in the makeshift Brooklyn factory yesterday afternoon when Frank LoGuidice suddenly threw a monkey wrench into the well-oiled mechanism.

title: Dancer Jumps In as Choreographer
description: Four years ago, Miriam Mahdaviani choreographed her first ballet. It was a dance for students at the School of American Ballet, and Miss Mahdaviani, a 27-year-old corps dancer at the New York City Ballet, created it in response to a school bulletin-board notice calling for new choreographers.

title: Dr. James Leland, 80, Ex-Medical Professor
description: Dr. James Liebmann Leland, a former clinical professor of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died of sepsis, a blood disease, on Wednesday on a visit to California. He was 80 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

description: Two House Democrats who are Civil War buffs moved Wednesday to protect a historic Civil War battlefield in Virginia from nearby development of a shopping center. The two, Representatives Robert Mrazek of Nassau and Suffolk County, New York, and Michael Andrews of Texas, introduced legislation for the Government to buy 600 acres next to the Manassas National Battlefield Park, where the Battles of Bull Run, known in the South as the Battles of Manassas, were fought.

title: Jean P. Hesse; U.N. Official, 85

The setting may have lacked tradition, but at least the Har-Tru clay courts were dry.

description: Coach Jim Schoenfeld angrily confronted Referee Don Koharski in a hallway after both left the ice following the Devils' 6-1 loss to the Bruins. He received a gross-misconduct penalty for his actions and could face a suspension when the league reviews the incident Saturday.

description: Molloko, the first condor bred in captivity, has begun taking its meals from a hand puppet built to resemble an adult condor, officials at the San Diego Wild Animal Park say.

description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; 8th Ave. Woes: Red Tape, Crime And a Sure Thing
description: Dan Marcus and Martin Port reached what they thought was a cool, intelligent business decision a couple of years ago in West Germany. In Frankfurt, they had found, they could make 3,000 marks a day selling pretzels in a train station that accommodated 50,000 passengers every 24 hours. What, then, were the pretzel possibilities in a place like the incredible Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, daily handler of 200,000 travelers and who knows how many live-ins?

title: YANKS FALL
description: Billy Martin spent most of tonight watching passively from the Yankee dugout, his team going down quickly to the Texas Rangers at Arlington Stadium. And then, the manager and his team suddenly and unexpectedly erupted.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: Lukas Foss is to conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic in the New York premiere of Morton Gould's ''Classical Variations on Colonial Themes,'' a work based on two Colonial hymns and a popular song of the era, Francis Hopkins's ''My Days Have Been So Wondrous Free,'' tonight at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place. The program is to also include the Beethoven Third Piano Concerto, with Emanuel Ax as the soloist, and the Brahms Second Symphony. The performance is to be repeated at 2 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: (718) 636-4120.

title: Suchard Increases Stake in Rowntree
description: Jacobs Suchard S.A., a Swiss food and confectionery maker, raised its stake in the British confectioner Rowntree P.L.C. to 29.9 percent, the maximum allowed under British law short of a full takeover bid. Jacobs Suchard has paid an estimated $:450 million (about $841 million) for the Rowntree shares, which it has acquired gradually since getting a 14.9 percent stake on April 13. It held a 23.5 percent stake on Wednesday.

title: Workers in Nicaragua End Fast, With Both Sides Claiming Victory
description: Both the Sandinista Government and union leaders claimed victory today after protesting construction workers called off a 10-day hunger strike.

The company attributed the decline in earnings from continuing operations mainly to a 54 percent drop in home closings in Sun City West and Sun City Vistoso, lowering earnings by $3 million. It also cited a $2.4 million decline in equity earnings of joint ventures and an $800,000 decrease in commercial land sales earnings. Equity earnings in 1987 included $2.1 million in profits from a land condemnation at the Foothills, a Webb joint venture commercial project in Phoenix.

title: Lay President for Duquesne
description: Duquesne University today named John E. Murray as the first lay president in the Roman Catholic school's 110-year history. The 55-year-old law professor at the University of Pittsburgh succeeds the Rev. Donald S. Nesti, who was president since 1980 and resigned in August.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Dreams That Fade at Reality's Dawn
description: LEAD: WHEN I was a child, I fantasized a lot about a future filled with fame and fortune. I dreamed of many glamorous careers. But mostly I wanted to be a dancer, a model, a cowgirl and a writer when I grew up.

title: To Avoid Dengue Fever, Take Grandma's Advice
description: OLD-FASHIONED precautions, including mosquito nets, are the latest thing for the traveler to the tropics. When I recently heard malaria and dengue fever discussed, the physicians stressed not treatments and prophylactic drugs but anti-mosquito measures. I had a kinesthetic memory of wiggling when my Victorian-style grandmother tried to get a hat and a shirt on me in the Carolina Low Country sun and recalled her urging me indoors at sundown. It's too late to improve my relations with her, but the experts showed she knew her territory.

title: Playoff Preview: Coast-to-Coast Battles Looming
description: Now that it's evident the Mets and the Yankees will win the Eastern Division championships, this is a good time to take an early look at the teams they may face in the playoffs five months hence.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Memphis
description: Memphis begins at the river, wide and brown and swollen with the rains of spring. From the bluffs in Confederate Park, at the edge of downtown, the Mississippi sweeps past in a kind of cinematic panorama: trains of barges moving slowly beneath the twin arcs of the Hernando DeSoto Bridge; small riverboats, copies of 19th-century paddle wheelers, churning upriver against the current.

title: Music; THE 'GLAGOLITIC' MASS AND OTHER CZECH WORKS
description: Michael Tilson Thomas put together a thoughtful all-Czechoslovak program for the Pittsburgh Symphony's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. And one thing that can be said right away about the performances was that the orchestra itself is sounding very good. Occasionally, when the violins ventured into their topmost range, things sounded a little stringy and acidic. But by and large this was excellent playing, both by the orchestra as an ensemble and in the solos.

title: Veterans' Suit Challenges System Of Appeals on Denial of Benefits
description: The Veterans Administration's system for reviewing veterans' appeals of denied benefits has been attacked in a lawsuit as ''assembly-line'' justice that denies fair hearings to thousands of claimants.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Brewery Makes A Comeback
description: LEAD: A PITTSBURGH native who founded his own brewing company two years ago has returned home from Europe, where he was in business, to open Pennsylvania's first microbrewery and ''tied house'' since Prohibition.

title: The Modern's Dead. Long Live the Modern
description: Every generation, or at least every art-world generation, has its own Museum of Modern Art - a complicated institution that it loves, learns to know by heart and almost invariably loses. This is because the museum has, since its inception, regularly changed and expanded. Nonetheless, every change takes some getting used to.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Minnelli Concert
description: LEAD: ''I can see clearly now the rain has gone,'' Liza Minnelli sang as she swept onto the stage of the County Center last weekend in a shimmering silver mini-dress. ''Gone are the obstacles in my way.''

title: DECIDING WHOSE BUSINESS IT IS WHEN PLANTS CLOSE
description: IT took three years of close work between Republicans and Democrats and labor and business to craft the trade bill that the Senate and House passed by large margins last month. And all sides - including the White House - appear to agree on the measure's get-tough-with-your-trading-partners thrust. But President Reagan seems certain to veto the bill because of a provision that would make companies provide 60 days' notice of plant closings or large layoffs. Last week, the debate on that issue heated up in Washington and on the campaign trail, where Vice President Bush, the inevitable Republican nominee, and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the formidable leader among the Democrats, won strong victories in the Indiana and Ohio primaries.

title: Japan's Arrogance of Power
description: LEAD: Much American criticism of Japan is ill-informed and little more than a convenient excuse for not facing up to our own problems. Japan-bashing is neither justified nor useful. Neither is America-bashing by the Japanese.

title: Black Prep School Faces Money Crisis
description: ''GOOD morning, Miss Shelley and visitor.'' In collective voice, the students of Long Island's only black prep school sprang to their feet at the sight of their school administrator.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: THEY'RE usually brief remarks, tossed off in passing, made casually without any great thought. They're not mean. They're not nasty - well, maybe a tiny needle - but what makes them absolutely maddening is that there's usually a grain of truth nestled somewhere.

title: Don't Take Entitlements From the Truly Entitled
description: To the Editor:

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: New York teams don't need guys running around in chicken suits, or other crazy antics. JACK CHVAT Maplewood, N.J.

title: His Songs Are the Scale That Measure All Others
description: To many songwriters, myself included, Irving Berlin is the American Popular Song, not only for his handsome lyrics and wonderfully accessible melodies, not only for a body of work that twines ivylike around the events of this century, but also because he has become the grid upon which all other pop songs and songwriters are positioned. In discussing lyricists, if we speak of Cole Porter's urbanity, Stephen Sondheim's intricacy or Lorenz Hart's poignancy, we are unconsciously holding their work against a ''norm'' which is, in fact, Berlin. Melodically, if we make reference to the parabolic shape of a Rodgers melody, or the chromaticism in a Gershwin tune, we speak relative to the unimpeachable ease of Berlin's music.

title: Glen Cove Playwright Uses Local Color
description: LEAD: A BEDROOM above his family's bar, beside the Long Island Rail Road tracks in Glen Cove, is where 31-year-old Frederick Stroppel writes his plays, so it is not surprising that Glen Cove place names and familiar surnames provide ready material.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'PETER PAN' EXHIBIT Early 18th-century photographs of the two boys who were the inspiration for ''Peter Pan'' and other items related to the evolution of the original stage version will be displayed at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library of Yale University.

title: NONFICTION
description: PARIS NOTEBOOKS: Essays & Reviews. By Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $17.95.) Reviewers' copies of new books commonly come with fliers from the publisher tucked in, lauding the author's previously published work. There is one such accompanying ''Paris Notebooks,'' a collection of Mavis Gallant's essays and reviews, mostly written for The New Yorker and this publication, praising her latest book of short stories. Its terms are difficult to fault. Ms. Gallant's fans know that she brings to her nonfiction the same fine-grain detail of observation that shines in her fiction. It is there, unerringly, even in her journals, represented by the first two pieces in the new book, true cahiers kept during ''The Events in May'' of 1968, capturing the humor, poignancy and utter seriousness of an entire culture's flirtation with and exasperation over change. And it is there in her critical writing, calculated and spare, as in her appraisal of the calm, unswerving voice of Marguerite Yourcenar, ''limpid pessimist,'' or her exploration of the relation between a writer's life and work (the case at hand is Elizabeth Bowen). Her mind's eye, happily, is always open. Most of the pieces in ''Paris Notebooks'' have to do with the French or France, where Ms. Gallant, a Canadian, has lived since 1950, and many of the reviews are of translations. Thank goodness for her ear, not just her eye.

title: The Slow March Toward More Trade
description: THE political thaw in Soviet-American relations is beginning to work its effect on the commercial front. This is the impression I brought back from last month's United States-Soviet Union Trade and Economic Council meeting in Moscow. This twice-postponed event brought together 500 chief executives from major American corporations and their Soviet counterparts in a four-day series of seminars and talks devoted to improving bilateral trade ties. The crowning event of the evening - and clearly the main drawing card for American businessmen - was a rousing speech by Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev designed to supply a note of urgency.

title: THE GORILLA WAS ON HIS SIDE
description: JOHN PATRICK NORMAN McHENNESSY The Boy Who Was Always Late. Written and illustrated by John Burningham. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 7)

title: Effectiveness of Abortion Protests Is Debated
description: More than 600 anti-abortion demonstrators left New York City yesterday after a week of blockades, arrests and prayer vigils, leaving behind a debate over whether they had significantly helped the anti-abortion movement.

title: SMILING AS THEY GO BY
description: WAVING A Counting Book. Written and illustrated by Peter Sis. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

title: CORRECTION
description: A dance review last Sunday about the April 27 performance of the American Ballet Theater production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' misidentified the dancer who performed the ''Gold'' solo. He was Johan Renvall.

title: Racing With Tray in Hand (Watch That Chicken!)
description: Marathon and triathalon atheletes talk about ''hitting the wall,'' that moment when they find their energy reserves depleted. For Kerry Downey, a runner in a recent quadrathalon held here, the problem was not hitting the wall but losing a beet.

title: OPERA SEEN THROUGH A PLAY OF THE SAME NAME
description: Purist music lovers - the kind who regard anything more grandiose than a chamber-music concert as borderline vulgarian -look with extreme suspicion on opera. Not only is it big and noisy and emotionally crude (they think), but it is inherently sullied by not being strictly music at all. Opera is a hybrid, a form of musical theater that partakes of both music and theater.

title: Art; ALBERS, COMPUTERIZED, AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: Why does coffee often appear to be a different color in the pot than in the cup? Why does tea look lighter in a spoon than in a cup, while milk appears to be the same color, no matter what the container?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SECOND SON. By Robert Ferro. (Crown, $17.95.) Robert Ferro's intelligent fourth novel centers on two men, both fatally ill with AIDS, who cling to each other in a bittersweet relationship. Their first meetings are set against the romantic backdrops of Venice and Rome, where the streets are strangely deserted in the wake of the Chernobyl disaster.

title: Political Marketing; Ad Man For Schrafft's Gets Ready to Sell Bush
description: It worked for President Reagan in 1984: reinforcing the political image makers with the advertising executives who promoted Alka-Seltzer and Puppy Chow.

title: Gymnast Paralyzed
description: Two days after she broke her neck when she fell while warming up for the vault competition at an international tournament in Tokyo, Julissa Gomez, a 15-year-old American gymnast, remained in critical condition yesterday, paralyzed and unable to breathe normally.

title: Are Schools Just a Line in the Welfare Budget?
description: THERE is a trend in New York State education that has not got the public airing it deserves. Perhaps that is because no one has brought it up as a specific issue.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Raising Cain Instead of Steins

title:
VIEW FROM: THE GREENFIELD HILL DOGWOOD FESTIVAL IN FAIRFIELD;
A Town's Passion for Dogwoods Becomes a Rite of Spring
description: LEAD: SCARLET tulips, azure crocuses and golden daffodils annually announce the arrival of spring. But few harbingers of the season are as eagerly awaited as the dogwood that bursts into bloom each May on Greenfield Hill, in the northwest section of Fairfield.

title: Oilers' Lead Cut to 2-1
description: Brent Ashton scored twice, including the go-ahead goal late in the second period, as the Detroit Red Wings came back from two successive losses in Edmonton for a 5-2 victory over the Oilers in Game 3 of the Campbell Conference finals tonight.

title: Freed Frenchman, Emotionally Distressed, Back in Hospital
description: A French diplomat who has said he was subjected to mock executions during the three years he was held captive in Lebanon returned to a military hospital today suffering from a nervous condition, his wife said.

title: Sizing Up The Shape of Music
description: I used to have record shelves. They held LP's and 45-r.p.m. singles, more or less alphabetized. In the late 1970's, I squeezed in 12-inch singles and a handful of cassettes, and set aside a shelf end for a novelty, 10-inch EP's. Then the 1980's came, and the Walkman. Cassettes started to stack up -cassettes with more songs than the album with the same title, cassettes of rare albums, cassette-only recordings, dance tapes.

title: LEADING THE PARADE
description: When the talk turns to songs and litling tunes that set the toes to tapping, it's time to remember the composer who set the standard by which standards are judged. The songwriter Rupert Holmes pays homage to Irving Berlin and his incomparable influence on his profession. Page 14.

title: The Need For Recycling
description: I commend Keep America Beautiful Inc. for its efforts (''Litter Is a Behavioral Problem,'' March 27). I hope the organization will now help with the massive problem of solid waste by encouraging businesses to reassess their packaging, use more glass containers and aim for a uniform plastic that can be recycled easily.

title: Miss Marple Unearths a Murderer
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Company usually offers at least one Agatha Christie mystery each season. This time around it is presenting ''Murder at the Vicarage,'' a mystery thriller with a plethora of subjects.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Stowe, Vt.;
Keeping It Pristine
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER in this still-growing ski resort is subdividing 45 acres of remote woodland into eight residential lots, and is taking steps to protect the pristine setting.

title: Alice E. Hill to Wed Mark R. Nicholson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hill of Inuvik, Northwest Territories, Canada, of the engagment of their daughter Alice Eddy Hill to Mark R. Nicholson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ian Nicholson of Canberra, Australia, and Stockholm.

title: 'Beetlejuice' Is Pap for the Eyes
description: ''Beetlejuice,'' which is quickly turning into a hit of serious proportions (it earned more than $9 million in its first three weeks of release), is a farce for our place and time. It's technically sophisticated and so amiable and well meaning that it seems rude to point out that, like some of our public figures, it is more of a bore to watch than to describe.

title: INSIDE
description: On the Border

title:
RECORDINGS;
Teena Marie's Heart Belongs to Rhythm and Blues
description: LEAD: A decade ago, Teena Marie was discovered practicing vocal warm-ups in an audition room at Motown Records by Rick James, then one of the label's up-and-coming producer/performers. She'd been signed to the company's fledgling film division as an actress; but after hearing her, Mr. James insisted on producing Teena Marie's first Motown LP.

title: Historians Give Prizes To Writers
description: Richard B. Morris, Gouverneur Morris Professor of History Emeritus at Columbia University, has been awarded the $5,000 Bruce Catton Prize for lifetime achievement in the writing of history by the Society of American Historians. The Catton and other awards were presented Wednesday evening at the Harvard Club during the society's annual meeting.

title: New York's Game
description: THERE were lines out the door in Manhattan, as poor souls from the outlying boroughs, deprived of cable television, tried to cram into bars and restaurants, where dual screens carried the defeats of the Knicks and the Devils.

title: CONTROLS WHEN SLUGS GO ON A MARCH
description: TO most gardeners, slugs are slimy, voracious pests. To Dr. Alan Gelperin, a research scientist at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., they are creatures worthy of respect. ''The degree of sophistication and complexity of their biological machinery is awe inspiring,'' he said in a recent interview.

title: Lilco Proposes Users Tighten Energy Belts
description: IF your house has an electric water heater, central air-conditioning or a swimming pool with an electric pump, the Long Island Lighting Company may want to talk to you soon about turning them off.

title: Susan Druyanoff Married
description: Susan Debra Druyanoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Druyanoff of Los Altos Hills, Calif., and Dr. Joshua Wieder, the son of Arline Wieder of Syosett, L.I., and the late Daniel Wieder, were married last evening at the Essex House in New York by Rabbi William Kloner. The bride is the assistant casting director at Myers-Teschner Casting in New York. Dr. Wieder is a senior resident in internal medicine at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., and at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Bang - You're Alive! The most enthusiastic shooting in World War II came at the very end, as if all the unexpended ammunition and aggression had to be got rid of at once. This is from ''Flights of Passage'' by Samuel Hynes (Frederic C. Beil/Naval Institute Press).

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Nassau Co-ops Offer a First-Home Option
description: LEAD: FOR buyers on a budget, housing costs in Nassau County have escalated far beyond reach. But do young couples looking for a first home need a single-family detached house like the one they probably grew up in?

title: A Different Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Day-Care Rule May Oust Hundreds of Civilian Children
description: HUNDREDS of children could be ousted from their day-care programs because of a change in policy at the Submarine Base in Groton.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SIMPLE THINGS
description: A THIEF IN THE VILLAGE And Other Stories. By James Berry. 148 pp. New York: Orchard Books/ Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: In Defense Of Zola Budd
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dance; A Humanist Approach In Byrd's Choreography
description: Donald Byrd is a choreographer who has the gift of making dancers move. He is a humanist who responds to the world around him, seeming to acknowledge it as providing a valid and valuable context for dance. His is a bold, clear, strong voice - trying to find its way through a good deal of static clutter. Or so it seemed on Friday, when Donald Byrd/The Group presented a program of four dances at Symphony Space that veered to an amazing degree between the very good and the very bad.

title: ENHANCED BY DARKNESS
description: GOOD HEARTS By Reynolds Price. 275 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Some Golf Rules Are Outdated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tolstoy's Fables
description: In 1849 Count Leo Tolstoy established a school for peasant children at his country estate, Yasnaya Polyana (Clear Glades). He also taught at the school, and wrote and published a primer that included sections on teaching reading, handwriting and arithmetic, as well as the fables he wrote for the pupils. The selections below are taken from ''The Lion and the Puppy: And Other Stories for Children'' by Leo Tolstoy, translated by James Riordan and illustrated by Claus Sievert, to be published by Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company in July. Better to Be Lean and Free Than Plump and Chained

title: Helpful Anecdotes
description: To the Editor:

title: Edible Ferns of New England
description: FIDDLEHEADS, so aptly named because they resemble a violin scroll, are as sure a harbinger of the new season as asparagus, shad or fresh morels. These tightly furled young fronds, which in spring appear at the crown of all varieties of ferns, grow throughout the world. Indeed, the woodlands of the northeastern United States are abundant with them.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NUDISTS. By Guy Bellamy. (Beaufort, $16.95.) Here is a satire of Margaret Thatcher's greedy Britain in which the characters get nicer by the page and everyone winds up rich and happy. In other words, overtones of Evelyn Waugh notwithstanding, ''The Nudists'' only poses as satire. Its subjects are champagne-swilling English yuppies.

title: Jordan Hovers Above The Rest
description: No one claims to have seen Michael Jordan walk on water, though some basketball fans are convinced he could if he put his mind to it. Many, however, believe they have actually seen Michael Jordan walk on air. Often. In a number of cities in America. With his size-13 sneakers. This they would testify to in a court of law.

title: Street Fashion; It's Not a Shirt; It Just Acts Like One
description: LOOK what burst out of their cocoons this spring: men's jackets, which have been drastically reshaped by a handful of forward-thinking designers.

title: Splitting the Check for Allied Defense
description: AS United States military spending is steadily declining, pressure is rising on America's allies to carry a larger share of the financial burden of their defense.

title: Computer Helper: Software That Writes Software
description: THE basic idea is simple enough to have attracted both computer industry giants and entrepreneurs in recent years: If computers can help design and make everything from shoes to automobiles, even other computers, why not use them to automate the painstaking, error-prone process of writing computer programs? After all, no product is more vital in the electronic age than the software that tells computers what to do and how to do it.

title: New Haven Celebrates Its Museums
description: ASK almost anyone where the Gowie-Normand House Museum is and chances are he wouldn't know. It is in New Haven and, like some of the area's 16 museums and cultural centers, is not well known.

title: Great Lake Cities Replace Gray With Gleam on the Waterfront
description: The banks of the Maumee River used to be a grimy tangle of wharves and warehouses, rail yards and parking lots, all backed up to downtown. After civic leaders cleared the waterfront in the 1970's as part of an urban renewal project, their first idea was to pave it over, with a freeway.

title: ON CAPTURING ''THE DECISIVE MOMENT'
description: ALTHOUGH auto-focusing cameras seem to be everywhere these days, they're not the only game in town. Last week, for example, I needed a lightweight, portable, 120-roll-film camera that could hang at my side while I toured the exotic avenues of Barcelona. Ever see a 120-format point-and-shoot camera with automatic focusing? Neither have I. I knew, though, that Fuji makes a camera that would fill my prescription perfectly: the Fujica GS645W. It takes 6-by-4.5 centimeter images on 120 film, weighs less than many 35-millimeter SLRs and is only about twice the size of a Leica. With a fixed, six-element lens of 45 millimeters, it offers a wide-angle view ideal for architectural subjects and interiors.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

title: TV Puppets Teach Life Lessons
description: LEAD: WILLIAM Larkin pointed toward the row of colorful puppets lining the wall of the production studio. There's Sizzle Frizzle, the bratty, selfish one, he said. There's Goof, who never keeps still. And there's Drag-On Dragon, who just can't seem to get anything done.

title: Comrades Behind the Camera
description: LEAD: THE FILM FACTORY Russian and Soviet Cinema in Documents. Edited by Richard Taylor and Ian Christie. Translated by Richard Taylor. Illustrated. 457 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $49.95.

title: PRICEY JAPAN
description: AN AMERICAN FRIEND who recently visited Japan returned home saying that when he feels like bringing back memories of his trip, he plans to take a $10 bill from his wallet and set it on fire.

title: Still Haggling on Trade
description: Senate approval of the foreign trade bill last month didn't end the legislative maneuvering that has dogged its three-year course across Capitol Hill. Normally, the bill would have gone straight to President Reagan, who is poised to veto it because he's adamantly opposed to the requirement that businesses give 60 days' notice for large layoffs and plant closings.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
REMEMBERING MR. SWEET
description: LEAD: In this essay adapted from her forthcoming collection, ''Living by the Word: Selected Writings 1973-1987,'' Alice Walker describes the origins of her short story ''To Hell With Dying,'' which has just been reissued, with illustrations, as a children's book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is the publisher of both books.

title: A Critical Mass of Merchants on Main Street
description: MOST rural development specialists decry the Federal Government's pullback from support to rural areas. Apart from burgeoning farm subsidies, Federal spending in the countryside has been trimmed dramatically since 1980.

title: The Rockies by Narrow Gauge Rail
description: BETWEEN 1870 and the early 1890's optimism about Colorado, embodied in discoveries of gold but mostly of silver, crested in the Rockies and converged with the other national sensation of the era, the steam-driven narrow gauge railroad. Along with their precious ore the trains carried ''the emotional treasure of a westering people,'' wrote Lucius Beebe, the extravagant chronicler of Colorado's railroads. A sentimental attachment persists, as every summer and fall thousands ride a smattering of old trains reorganized into excursion railroads: the Cumbres & Toltec Scenic Railroad, the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge, the Georgetown Loop Railroad and the Cripple Creek & Victor Narrow Gauge Railroad, to name at least four.

title: BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CITY, BAD ART
description: TRUST By Mary Flanagan. 292 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title:
TV VIEW;
Drama Aboard 'The Caine' Is Still Riveting
description: LEAD: Queeg still works. Thanks to Robert Altman's brilliant new version of Herman Wouk's ''Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' -based on his 1952 novel ''The Caine Mutiny'' - Lieut. Comdr. Philip Francis Queeg has returned once again to make us squirm and wince as he attempts to explain his irrational actions while compulsively fondling steel balls in his right hand.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Mamaroneck, N.Y. $330,000 205 Melbourne Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 89-year-old Victorian; powder room, covered porch, 2 fireplaces; .20 acres; taxes $2,976. South Salem, N.Y. $470,000 98 Smith Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old contemporary; master bedroom suite with fireplace, 2-car garage, 3.05 acres; taxes $5,372. Yonkers, N.Y. $232,000 38 LaSalle Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old brick and frame Cape Cod; fireplace, basement, 1-car garage, .22 acres; taxes $3,340. Brookfield, Conn. $250,000 14 Hollis Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; vaulted ceilings, hardwood floors, 1 acre; taxes not available. Ridgefield, Conn. $257,500 123 Stony Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old raised ranch; new roof, deck, 1 acre; taxes $2,359. Westport, Conn. $435,000 289 Wilton Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old antique reproduction colonial; 200-year-old hand-hewn beams, wide floorboards, 2 acres; taxes $3,258. OTHER AREAS East Meadow, L.I. $174,000 396 Avalon Place 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Levittown, L.I. $142,000 18 Rock Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Ridgewood, N.J. $252,000 555 Van Buren Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old split level; patio, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $4,144.

title: A Rescue Effort At Small Cemetery
description: LEAD: MAYOR Richard A. Flynn of Mount Kisco remembers the time recently when a friend of his literally stumbled upon the old Charlick cemetery overlooking the village's busy Route 117 commercial strip.

title: Needed: Pacific Strategy
description: Soviet foreign policy initiatives under Mikhail Gorbachev have so far been addressed mainly to the U.S. and Western Europe. A swing through four Far Eastern capitals makes it clear that there is more to come in the Pacific region.

title: HERRING ON PARADE IN HUDSON VALLEY
description: Don't call me Ishmael. Call me the herring maven. For years my son Peter's springtime shout that ''the herring are in!'' has prompted us both to dash for our rods and climb down the precipitous slope of the Croton River for an evening of often incredible angling, angling that I - let the trumpets sound as I take a modest bow - pioneered 20 years ago.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CONVERSATIONS WITH ANOREXICS. By Hilde Bruch. Edited by Danita Czyzewski and Melanie A. Suhr. (Basic Books, $18.95.) The German-born psychiatrist Hilde Bruch was among the very first to view eating disorders in the context of family dynamics. For 20 years at Baylor University in Texas, until her death in 1984, she perfected the process of consultation with anorexics and their families when treatment elsewhere had failed.

title: Sonja Feige Is Married to William Slattery on L.I.
description: The marriage of Sonja Feige, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harald Feige of New Hyde Park, L.I., to William Patrick Slattery, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Slattery of Garden City, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City. The Rev. Richard J. Neilson performed the ceremony.

title: A Weapon In Battle On Vice
description: SINCE the beginning of the year, AIDS has become one of this city's leading weapons in its fight against prostitution.

title: Steaming Through Pennsylvania
description: ONCE upon a time, Pennsylvania ran on coal, steam and sweat.

title: FROM FRANCE, BEAUTIFULLY HONED DANCERS
description: The height of the dance season is not necessarily the best time for a small foreign company, even one attached to France's national opera, to make a New York debut. There is no question that the sleek, streamlined and superb dancers of the experimental dance troupe that is part of the Paris Opera Ballet were nearly overlooked amid the attention paid to the feathers and ruffles of Christian Lacroix's very French costumes for American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Gaite Parisienne.''

title: Options Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada-France Fishing Dispute Runs Deep
description: The dispute between Canada and France has roots nearly 500 years old, and to many whose livelihoods do not depend on codfish in the Gulf of St. Lawrence it is tinged with elements of farce.

title: Is 'The Last Emperor' Truth or Propaganda?
description: The advertisements these days are proclaiming it ''the most honored film in 25 years,'' and indeed, Bernardo Bertolucci's new movie, ''The Last Emperor,'' which won nine Oscars at last month's Academy Awards ceremonies, does dazzle the eye. The film, in telling the life story of Henry Aisin-Gioro Pu Yi, the last, quivering twig on the Manchu Dynasty's venerable tree, is distinguished by its gorgeous re-creation of the lacquered, ceremonious interior of the Forbidden City, where Pu Yi was virtually imprisoned for 12 years after the tottering dynasty crumbled into nothingness in 1912.

title: Shad Are Running and Spirits Are High
description: TRAFFIC on the bridge one recent morning was, as usual, at a standstill. Hundreds of Westchester-bound commuters sat hunched in their cars, watching the rain beat aimless patterns on their windshields.

title: AMONG THE KIBBUTZNIKS
description: THE BOY FROM OVER THERE By Tamar Bergman. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 181 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: American Gothic Rides High In Atlanta's I.B.M. Building
description: ATLANTA

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: Come on, they already have them. They are Steinbrenner for the Yanks and Strawberry for the Mets, in case you've never heard of them. TAE KIM New York

title: Faulty Diagnosis
description: When physicians working for the Phoenix Cardinals determined that Ken Easley, the All-Pro defensive back the Cardinals had obtained in a trade with the Seattle Seahawks, was suffering from a kidney condition, the medical report seemed to come as a surprise to everybody concerned.

title: Line Up Local Assets, Cure an Ailing Economy

A sandwich can be humble, as in a slice of meat loaf on toasted white bread; grand, such as a sliver of velvety smoked salmon with cucumbers and beluga caviar, or grandiose, as in a listing tower of meat, cheese, lettuce and vegetables.

Petrick of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Ephram Zweig, the son of Mollie Levinson Zweig of Oroville, Calif., and Jonas Zweig of Passaic, N.J. The Rev. William J. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Alfred Landsburg officiated at the Petrick home.

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: Mascots are infantile, mindless travesties, unneeded and unwanted additions to a great game. Yes, the Yankees should have a mascot. ALAN MICHAEL SAFIE New York

title: FICTION
description: GREEN CITY IN THE SUN. By Barbara Wood. (Random House, $19.95.) An interesting tale of Africa in the stormy days before independence is buried under about 300 pages of excess verbiage and extraneous characters in this new novel by the author of ''Domina'' and ''Vital Signs.'' In ''Green City in the Sun,'' Barbara Wood chronicles life in Kenya from 1919 to the present through the experiences of two families, the English Trevertons and the African Mathenges. Two strong women stand out immediately: Grace Treverton, who has defied convention to become a doctor and establish a hospital in Kenya, and Wachera, a medicine woman who seeks to defend traditional African culture against the changes brought by the white settlers. These intriguing figures are surrounded by such stock characters as the imperialistic, insensitive Lord Treverton (Grace's brother) and his sexually repressed wife, Rose. Hovering around this cast, the plot languishes in cliched situations, marking time until a sharply defined second generation emerges into maturity: independent Mona Treverton, frustrated by her father's sexist refusal to let her run their farm; pathetic Njeri, who longs to be white; David Mathenge, torn between his love for Mona and his commitment to African independence; and David's wife Anjiru, an ardent feminist who becomes a leader of the Mau Mau. Their stories are more compelling, but the reader's interest eventually flags with the introduction of a sketchily drawn third generation. Most prominent among the latter is Deborah Treverton, the modern-day protagonist whose return to Kenya after 15 years in California opens and closes the book. Deborah never really comes to life, and the dilemma she faces seems both trite and contrived. It's symptomatic of the book's lack of focus, by the way, that the ''green city'' of the title is Nairobi, which is by no means the center of the action.

title: A HISTORY WRIT IN OIL
description: THE EAGLE AND THE LION The Tragedy of American-Iranian Relations. By James A. Bill. Illustrated. 520 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: WHEN THE PATIENT IS A PET
description: PET OWNERS SUFFER AS MUCH AS their ailing animal companions, as may be seen in these photographs taken recently in the busy, 24-hour emergency room at the Animal Medical Center. Founded in 1910 in lower Manhattan, A.M.C. moved uptown in 1961 to its eight-story, state-of-the-art quarters on East 62d Street, in the heart of New York's biomedical community. (New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Rockefeller University Hospital and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center are only blocks away; the A.M.C. often draws upon their specialized expertise.) There are 75 veterinarians among the 300 employees on the center's staff, who handle 65,000 medical visits each year and can take in up to 225 in-patients at a time. Dogs and cats, of course, comprise the bulk of the center's practice, but its exotic-pets department also treats rabbits, birds, ferrets, tropical fish, gerbils and reptiles - ''Everything,'' remarks one staff member, ''that isn't a dog or a cat.'' The A.M.C. has equipment not found in most veterinarians' offices - for example, a new, $500,000 radiation-therapy unit and a computerized tomography scanner to pinpoint the exact site of a disease. The center is also known for its research on and clinical investigation of such diseases as animal cancers and feline leukemia. Guide dogs and pets of the needy elderly are treated free.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: NEW YORK, DEC. 9, 1987: Riots have erupted in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. The networks show scenes of rampaging Palestinian youths hurling rocks and insults, Israeli soldiers firing back. Is this it? Has the pot boiled over at last? Twenty years of occupying an alien people, and now on our television screens a harvest of rage. Has the nightmare begun? DEC. 21: Everybody I talk to is as upset as I am, depressed and anguished. The Israelis can't cope. In the territories, it is spontaneous combustion. The press reports that some young Arabs have stood up to Israeli troops, baring their breasts and daring the soldiers to shoot. How can a humane, democratic society respond to such desperation?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''From an inflationary concern, we may be closer to full employment than we wis but you can't say that from a social point of view.'' - Roger Brinner, an economist at Data Resources.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article ''On Trail and Meadow'' by Linda Buchanan Allen (Travel, Feb. 28). Although the article was quite informative, I was disappointed to see that except for one small reference in the ''Tips for Skiers Headed for the Woods and Fields,'' there was no attention given to what is perhaps the greatest back-country cross-country skiing area in the Eastern United States, the Adirondack Mountains of northern New York State.

Inman of Mount Airy, N.C. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Tishman home in New York.

First was the news that health insurance premiums for millions of workers would jump between 10 percent and 70 percent in 1988. Then there was word that premiums for people on Medicare would rise 38 percent and that health maintenance organization costs would rise by as much as 20 percent in 1988.

description: Psychologists have their own view of American Presidential elections. For some, the outcome in November hinges on optimism.
