description: It was 1908 when the first 781 Japanese walked off a migrant ship to reach out for the riches promised by a wild and tropical land. Instead, they found themselves replacing recently freed slaves on coffee plantations in the interior of Brazil.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sylvester Gray and Marvin Alexander, who were dropped from the Memphis State basketball team because they dealt with an agent, will play in the United States Basketball League this summer. . . . Gary Williams, the Ohio State basketball coach, has told the Charlotte Hornets that he is not interested in taking over the N.B.A. expansion team. . . . Joan Benoit Samuelson, the Olympic marathon champion, has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park June 4. Lisa Martin of Australia, who won the 1987 race, plans to defend her title.

title: A Festival of All Those Notes in Between
description: Most Western music is based on an octave divided into 12 equal pitches. Of course, the octave can be split differently, as it is in other cultures, and as composers of the Microtonal persuasion have argued for decades. Microtonalists insist that the mathematically pure intervals yielded by, for instance, a 31-note scale, are inherently more pleasing than the slightly impure ones we are used to.

title: FICTION
description: UNDERCOVER. By Soledad Santiago. (Bantam, Paper, $3.95.) Two cops - one brutal and vengeful, the other kind and caring - patrol the mean streets of Alphabet City in this gritty first novel about the drug subculture of New York's Lower East Side. True to the schematic conventions of such crime procedurals, the ''human'' partner oozes compassion for the local criminals and their prey, who are joint victims of the rampant illegal drug economy, while the hard-nosed cop just wants to beat all the dope fiends to a pulp. The formula twist here is that Soledad Santiago makes the bleeding-heart cop a man and his tough partner a woman. ''I had come back for my vengeance,'' snarls Toni Conroy, a 24-year-old rookie who joins the force to launch a vendetta against the drug merchants responsible for the deaths of her younger brother and her child. Tops on her hit list is a slippery dealer known as The Cobra. Stymied by her partner's square-shooter style, Toni slips under cover as a hooker, tracking her quarry in the company of whores, pimps, addicts and dealers. In no time she becomes a heroin addict herself. And the deeper Toni sinks into degradation, the better Ms. Santiago's writing gets. After tripping over her tongue trying to write dialogue for straight white cops and upscale criminals, she seems to have located a fresh vein in the raw vernacular of the criminal underclass. ''Dawn on the Lower East Side is always sneaky,'' goes one of her unsentimental descriptions. ''It rises over the rooftops in one move, as if somebody had turned on a big dirty light bulb.'' Just the right light to read this book by.

title: Site in Manhattan Is Chosen For a New Ferry Terminal
description: The New York City terminal for a new Hudson River ferry between Hoboken, N.J. and Manhattan will be built at the north end of Battery Park City, a short walk from the World Trade Center, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and Battery Park City announced yesterday.

title: INTO THE KITCHEN
description: THIS IS NOT YOUR TYPICAL COUNTRY kitchen, but then the house - a three-story, brick Georgian structure designed in 1906 by the architect Charles Platt - is not your typical country house either. The 13,000-square-foot building is the epitome of the grand homes that burgeoned in communities outside of New York around the turn of the century.

title: Tony O'Reilly Astride Two Worlds; In Ireland, Publisher and Prospector
description: AT dusk, Anthony O'Reilly is strolling the grounds of his 500-acre estate, Castlemartin, surveying with satisfaction his breeding cattle, his race horses and his 18thcentury 28-room mansion house.

title: 45 Runs for College Team
description: Everything Grand Canyon College of Phoenix did Friday turned into a run. And the game turned into the highest-scoring runaway in college baseball history.

title: Open a Door for Iran
description: Iran has suffered a chain of calamities in its seven-year war with Iraq. Some stem from adroit American policy, which tilted toward Baghdad when the Iraqis seemed in danger of defeat. The tilt has helped restore the military balance between Iran and Iraq; now it's time for America to adjust its diplomacy.

title: Poland's Young Demand Change From an Unchanging System
description: FOR Lech Walesa, the head of Poland's outlawed but remarkably vigorous Solidarity trade union, they were, through most of the week, the ''kids.''

title: THE NATION: Iowa Disputes a Call; AS THE CENSUS BUREAU CHARTS THEIR DECLINE, SOME STATE PROTEST
description: IN the last two years, Iowa has added more than 60,000 jobs and increased its tax revenues by $52 million.

title: Newark Airport
description: To the Editor: When I returned recently to Newark International Airport, I learned the meaning of compound stupidity. I retrieved my car from long-term parking and went to pick up my wife, 6-month-old son and six bags from the sidewalk outside the baggage claim area. I followed the signs to Arrivals and pulled the car near where my family and luggage were waiting. A uniformed individual advised me that I could not stop along the sidewalk - it was a bus lane. I pointed to my wife and advised the officer that I had an infant and it would take only seconds to load the car. I was told that the car in front of me had received a summons and I was next if I did not move.

title: Knicks, With New-Found Respect, Look to Future
description: Through the years, the Boston Celtics have never been known as gracious winners or losers. Their feeling of superiority would never allow it. But that was not the case Friday night after the Celtics rallied in the final minutes to defeat the Knicks, 102-94, at Madison Square Garden and eliminate New York, three games to one, in the opening round of the playoffs.

title: 'CARRIE' GETS THE ROYAL TREATMENT
description: One evening more than seven years ago, Lawrence D. Cohen, a successful young screenwriter, and his old friend Michael Gore, a Yale-trained composer, attended a performance of Alban Berg's ''Lulu'' at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Cohen, who had written the screenplay for the phenomenally successful 1976 film adaptation of Stephen King's novel ''Carrie,'' and Mr. Gore, who was about to win two Academy Awards for his music in the just-released movie ''Fame,'' were hungry for inspiration. For five years they had been searching fruitlessly for a property to develop into a possible Broadway musical. And ''Lulu,'' with its brooding 12-tone score and colossal performance by Teresa Stratas, left them exhilarated, but it also pricked their frustrations.

title: Anchors for Making Strong Joints
description: THE ability to hammer nails skillfully has always been required for most carpentry tasks. But in recent years, fastening aids called construction anchors have been developed that allow strong joints to be created with less skill, particularly in toenailing, the difficult technique of driving nails at angles.

title: BYRUM PUTTS HIS WAY INTO LEAD
description: Curt Byrum sank some lengthy putts on the Spanish Trail Country Club course today to carry a one-shot lead into the final round of the $1.3 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational. He is seeking his first victory in six years on the PGA Tour.

title: White Plains Readies for Loucks Games
description: IMAGINE a city that once a year opens its homes to strangers, feeds them and is host to them in the largest on-campus high school event in the United States.

title: THE PRISON AND THE CULT OF TEA
description: LETTERS TO OLGA June 1979-September 1982. By Vaclav Havel. Translated by Paul Wilson. 397 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: TAP-DANCING ON THE EDGE OF A CLIFF
description: MEMORY By Margaret Mahy. 278 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $13.95. (Ages 14 and up)

title: WORDS THE CHINESE WERE WAITING TO HEAR
description: IN 1967, factions of zealous Red Guards fashioned a monstrous statue of their idol, Mao Zedong, and mounted it on a pedestal in front of the Beijing University library. Last month, in the dark of the night, the statue was toppled and carted off by workmen.

title: Beneath Hawthorne's Gables, Tourism Aids Needy
description: Nearly 150,000 people visit the House of Seven Gables in Salem every year, but few who tour the 17th-century house overlooking Salem Harbor, the house made famous as Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''House of Seven Gables,'' know their visits support a neighborhood settlement house that began in 1908.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: PARADE IN PRINCETON Princeton will mark the 200th anniversary of its Fire Department Saturday with a celebration that begins with a parade and ends with fireworks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: AGNES DE MILLE: EAGER AS EVER
description: When, in 1975, the American choreographer Agnes de Mille suffered a debilitating stroke, it was believed she would never again speak, never again walk and, most tragically, never again make dances. Indeed, Miss de Mille's career, spanning some 50 years, was thought to be virtually over, marking a sad end to an extraordinary chapter in dance history.

title: The Goetz Trial Reheard Before the Cameras
description: The makeup people pat Peter Crombie's face with water, so he will look just as sweaty as he did the first time they shot the confession scene for ''The Trial of Bernhard Goetz.''

title: In Managua, Not Exactly Last Hurrah
description: Shock waves spread through Nicaraguan political circles last month when Moises Hassan Morales, Mayor of Managua and a veteran Sandinista leader, was removed from his post and then announced he was quitting the Sandinista Front.

title: ARE WOMEN BETTER DOCTORS?
description: Perri Klass mentions the scarcity of women in leadership positions in medicine. Working at a university has given me the opportunity to observe this phenomenon, and to think about it.

title: Karen Merdinger to Wed
description: Karen Beth Merdinger and Mark Spencer Labe plan to marry June 12. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Merdinger of Rye, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Labe of New Milford, N.J. Miss Merdinger is a senior sales representative for Chemical Bank in New York. Her father is the president of Simplex Machinery, a machine tool importer and distributor in Hackensack, N.J. Mr. Labe is an assistant prosecutor for Bergen County, N.J. in the Hackensack office. His father is a retired restaurateur.

title: Besting a Bullet's Havoc: A Sergeant Is Honored
description: Friday was the 93d anniversary of Theodore Roosevelt's swearing in as New York City Police Commissioner. Friday was also a big day for Sgt. Clement C. Johnson of the 105th Precinct in Queens Village.

title: French Campaign Ends With Flurry by Challenger
description: Despite a spectacular last-minute offensive to turn the tide against him, President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, heads into Sunday's presidential election favored to win a second seven-year term.

title: Dr. Hans Popper, an Authority On Liver Diseases, Is Dead at 84
description: Dr. Hans Popper, an authority on liver diseases and a principal figure in the founding of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, died of pancreatic cancer Friday. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Economy Still Churns Out Jobs
description: Unemployment went down again in April, reaching a level not seen in 14 years. The April rate was put at 5.4 percent, down from 5.5 percent in March. While no doubt encouraging to the 606,000 people who found jobs last month, the steady decline in unemployment is raising concern that a tight labor market could push wages up enough to produce worrisome inflation. Those inclined to such worries were awaiting a separate report on business payrolls, fearing that a gain of 300,000 or more jobs would persuade the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The April number came in at 175,000 jobs.

title: Cindy Moelis and Robert Rivkin Marry
description: The marriage of Cindy S. Moelis and Robert S. Rivkin, both 1987 graduates of the Stanford University Law School, took place last night at Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: This is a warning to European travelers: Check carefully before renting a car, especially on a short-term basis. We rented a deluxe car from Hertz in Paris for a two-day trip to the Loire Valley. It cost almost $600, based on the five-day, unlimited-mileage rate (which was cheaper than the daily rate with mileage -about 400 miles - added) and 33Y percent tax. This is prohibitive for a 27-hour car rental. BARRIE FAHEY Fair Haven, N.J.

title: Smoking
description: To the Editor: I was amused to read of Joan Shangold's dismay (Letters, March 20) when people in the nonsmoking section at the Free Time restaurant in Paris lit up anyway.

title: Homeless Children: Strategies Shared
description: WHATEVER steps are necessary must be taken to insure that homeless children receive the education they deserve while they wait for homes, Dr. Margaret Gotti said last week at a conference at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. ''We know the housing situation is critical,'' she said, ''but in the meantime we have a lot of kids who are at risk.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CRUNCHING GRAVEL: Growing Up in the Thirties. By Robert Peters. (Mercury House, $14.95.) ''Crunching Gravel'' is a poet's reminiscence of a year in his childhood in northern Wisconsin. Robert Peters's clear-eyed memoir dispenses with the haze of nostalgia that is usually a feature of similar works.

title: Stacy Salob Weds Michael Goldman
description: Stacy Pamela Salob, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Salob of Brookville and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Michael Steven Goldman, a son of Sharon Elliot of Merrick, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Morton Goldman, were married last evening. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Martin Hurt in Bar Fight
description: Billy Martin, whose career as a player and manager has been interrupted by frequent battles with players and barroom brawls, was involved in a fight at a bar just after midnight Friday that resulted in a cut inside his left ear and required an overnight stay at a hospital, the team said today.

title: Skating for Funds
description: THE list of figure-skating champions scheduled to attend would suggest a special off-season Olympic competition. But the Playland Ice Casino is the setting for Saturday's ''Evening of Skating,'' featuring the Olympic champions Peggy Fleming and Robin Cousins as well as the United States pairs champions Jojo Starbuck and Ken Shelley.

title: In Brawley Inquiry, a Turn to Drug-Infested Streets
description: Having found only a blind alley in Tawana Brawley's assertions of racial and sexual abuse by a gang of white abductors, investigators have now turned to the drug-infested streets of Newburgh, N.Y., for fresh clues to the black teen-ager's mysterious four-day disappearance last fall.

title: Profits of New York Farmers Rose 23% in 1987
description: Profits of New York's farmers increased in 1987 for the second consecutive year, up 23 percent from 1986, according to a report from the State Agricultural Statistics Service.

title: DINNER GUESTS FROM OUTER SPACE
description: COMPANY'S COMING By Arthur Yorinks. Illustrated by David Small. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers.

title: Business Dials 1-900-PROFITS
description: DIAL 1-900-909-1234. Woody Woodpecker picks up. ''It's Woody Woodpecker,'' he says. ''Thanks for calling. Haaa-haa-ha-ha-haaa.'' Then he puts on Dinosaur Buddy who tells how the telegraph and the telephone came about.

title: Aunt Jemima
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope Fades for Panama's Economy
description: Anyone interested in seeing how quickly a political crisis can destroy an economy should pay a visit to Panama these days.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THROWING HEAT: The Autobiography of Nolan Ryan. By Nolan Ryan and Harvey Frommer. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This story of a talented pitcher's rise to stardom contains plenty of charm at its beginning. From throwing rocks at water moccasins in Mustang Bayou to lying ''in bed on those hot summer nights listening to [baseball on] the radio,'' the young Nolan Ryan was part of the natural world of Alvin, Tex., his hometown, with its simple pleasures and clear truths.

title: New Report Says 18 Monks Died in Tibet Protest
description: At least 18 Buddhist monks, including a 12-year-old boy, were killed during nationalist protests in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa in early March, according to a new report from a foreigner who went to Tibet after the violence.

title: Side Streets Getting Fashion Showrooms
description: FOR decades, it was a tradition in the garment center that most of the elite fashion designers had their showrooms in just two Seventh Avenue buildings, 550 or 530, both at 39th Street. The clothes may have been made in Brooklyn or Pennsylvania, Hong Kong or India, but the designers showed their new models to buyers from around the country in elegant settings on Seventh Avenue.

title: American Translator Wins Award
description: Gregory Rabassa, who has translated into English many of Latin America's most notable authors, is to receive the $10,000 Wheatland Prize, an annual award for a notable contribution to international literary exchange. The award is to be presented today in Lisbon, at the second Wheatland Conference on Literature.

title: Gary Lee Weds Jennifer Scheck
description: The marriage of Jennifer Jane Scheck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Scheck of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Gary Wayne Lee, the son of Mrs. James Mallicoat and Alton Lee, both of Spokane, Wash., took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Menlo Park, Calif. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

title: Japan's Favorite Tax Inspector
description: Japanese think of themselves as an honest lot, and, for the most part, the self-trust is not misplaced. Their low crime rate attests to that. But sometimes they give themselves too much credit. Take Japanese tax codes. The law allows the shopowner, the farmer, the real-estate speculator - basically anyone in business for himself - to declare his own income and expenses. Built into the system is an assumption that people will behave with integrity.

title: WHO PROFITS FROM COURT'S ANTITURST DECISION?
description: THE reaction was classic last week when the Supreme Court ruled that the Sharp Electronics Corporation could lawfully conspire with one of its high-price retailers to shut out a discounter from selling Sharp products.

title: 'GRILL ME SOME BONES!' AND OTHER DELIGHTS FROM THE TIN-POT SCHOOL OF POETRY
description: When it comes to entertaining children - your own or borrowed ones - the most rewarding activity is reading aloud to them. Almost all children prefer being read to, even unskillfully, to watching any television program, no matter how violent and flashy. We're talking post-Mother Goose and ''I'm a Little Teapot'' up through grade school here, and poetry is the subject.

title: Q and A
description: Absentee Tenant

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
The Duplex Alternative
description: LEAD: BUILDERS are turning increasingly to construction of duplexes as an attractive and affordable option for young first-time buyers unable to purchase single-family houses here that sell for an average of more than $155,000.

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: Not in my worst nightmare would the Mets bring in a mascot to Shea Stadium. (How about bringing back the organist, though?) PAMELA ROMANO White Plains

title: Cooking Seafood to Perfection
description: FISH cookery is a subtle art.

title: Tony O'Reilly Astride Two Worlds; At Heinz, a Bottom-Line Leader
description: BY textbook definition, the H. J. Heinz Company should be a pretty tense place. Its managers are constantly asked to squeeze yet another penny out of costs. Subsidiary presidents must vie at planning meetings for capital resources. Annual earnings and growth goals are ambitious, yet a good portion of each executive's compensation depends on meeting them. And the chief executive is only 52 years old, so the route to the top is fairly blocked.

title: Poverty Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $195,000 3 Cole Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; basement, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $4,900. East Meadow $174,000 396 Avalon Place 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. East Patchogue $135,000 84 Durkee Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Levittown $142,000 18 Rock Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; aluminum siding, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Wantagh $172,500 2406 Willow Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, covered patio, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. OTHER AREAS Ridgewood, N.J. $252,000 555 Van Buren Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old split level; patio, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $4,144. Yonkers, N.Y. $232,000 38 LaSalle Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old brick and frame Cape Cod; fireplace, unfinished basement, 1-car garage, .22 acres; taxes $3,340. Brookfield, Conn. $250,000 14 Hollis Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; vaulted ceilings, 1 acre; taxes not available.

title: 'Wet Carpets' at the Crossroads
description: THE FINAL show of the season also marks a new beginning for the 10-year-old Crossroads Theatre Company.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Plant and Use the Horseradish
description: LEAD: HORSERADISH is a deep-rooted perennial that is native to southeastern Europe. Planted in vegetable gardens for home use and in fields for commercial production, it may also be found growing wild in certain areas of this country.

title: Hong Kong Sees Rising Emigration as Peril
description: In a reversal, the Hong Kong Government has begun to acknowledge that rising emigration among skilled and professional workers is hurting the thriving economy of this British colony, which is due to be returned to China in 1997.

title: Recital; Songs And Arias By Hines
description: Friday's tribute to Jerome Hines at Carnegie Hall could have been better managed. Planning and promoting require more than renting a big hall; they mean making sure it is full. Mr. Hines's audience was embarrassingly small, enthusiastic though it was.

title: LACROIX OR LE CASH?
description: Patricia Volk captured my own feelings when she wrote, ''Is it Lacroix? Is it La Salvation Army? What, besides $14,950, is la difference?''

title: Jane Ellen Gifford Wed To Keith J. Lindenburg
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J., Jane Ellen Gifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Gifford of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Keith Jude Lindenburg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Lindenburg of Bristol, R.I. Msgr. Robert T. Lennon performed the ceremony.

title: D. J. Norton Weds Sarah J. DeCrane
description: Sarah Juliana DeCrane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Daniel John Norton, a son of Anne Strannahan Norton of Binghamton, N.Y. Msgr. James M. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: A mascot for the Yankees? Absolutely yes! He should be oversized and out of proportion so he can easily be seen from the far reaches of the Stadium. He should possess a large enough mouth so that he can be heard at least two sections away. The ideal mascot will also be able to involve the players in his nutty antics. And lastly, he must have an ego great enough to do silly, inane things in public, for no apparent reason, to draw attention away from the game.

title: Battling Rain In the Military
description: AFTER wrestling for two decades with a weighty problem - Should men in uniform be allowed to use umbrellas in the rain? - the Navy decided last November: Why not?

title: A DEBATE OVER DISCLOSURE TO PARTNERS OF AIDS PATIENTS
description: SHOULD doctors warn sexual partners of AIDS patients that they may have been infected, even if the patient objects? The New York Legislature will soon consider that question, and the result could be the first state law in the nation permitting doctors to make such disclosures.

title: Fireworks-Job Bidders Exchanging Red Glares
description: The Fourth of July celebration on the Mall, the nation's birthday in the nation's capital. is the stuff that fireworks makers' dreams are made on.

title: Le Hot Seat In Paris Taxis
description: MOVING to outwit robbers and muggers, Paris taxicab drivers introduced an electrifying solution in October: the ''blazing seat.''

title: A Woman Grows with Motherhood
description: THE problem with parenthood is that you never know how well you're doing until it's too late. And the problem with motherhood is that no matter how well you do, it will still be your fault if the child ends up on a psychiatrist's couch.

title: GOODBYE TO ALL THAT
description: WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR By David Brinkley. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ON THE TRAIL OF TREBITSCH LINCOLN, TRIPLE AGENT
description: I cannot say quite when I first heard of Trebitsch Lincoln. He is one of those types, notorious in their own day, who sink rapidly into obscurity after their deaths, sometimes hovering briefly in the footnotes of history. I believe that the outline of Trebitsch Lincoln's bizarre story was recounted to me some years ago in Jerusalem by the editor of the Encyclopedia Judaica, Geoffrey Wigoder, whose encyclopedic knowledge of such historical byways is unrivaled. From him I heard, with incredulity, of the birth in 1879 of Ignacz Timotheus Trebitsch in a small provincial town in Hungary, of his conversions from Judaism to various sects of Christianity and then to Buddhism, of his wanderings from Hungary to China, of his adoption of the name Lincoln (the first of more than a dozen noms de guerre), of his election to the British House of Commons and of his activity as a German spy in both world wars. But, in spite of the fantastic nature of the tale, little remained in my memory save a dim recollection that the man was somehow mixed up in something scandalous (like the man who fixed the World Series in 1919).

title: TUNISIAN FORESEES A GRAND ALLIANCE
description: Ismail Khelil, the Central Bank Governor, deals not from crystal balls, but he does have a dream that one day the poor nations of North Africa will be linked economically by their own version of the European Community.

title: Mothers a la Mode
description: In the public mind, mothers have their ups and downs.

title: MOVES TO AID SUED ACTIVISTS GAIN SUPPORT
description: WHEN Betty Blake and her neighbors tied hundreds of red ribbons around trees in Wantagh last year, they wanted to make a point: that trees are precious and are being torn down by builders to make room for houses.

title: Lucie Livingston And Seth Aidinoff To Wed in August
description: Lucie Livingston, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Livingston of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Seth George Aidinoff, the son of M. Bernard Aidinoff of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mrs. Aidinoff, plan to marry in August.

title: Amid the Finales, a Season Opens with a Piano Recital
description: WITH finales sprinkled throughout the schedule, it is comforting to report on a seasonal start. The 37th annual arts series at the Merryall Community Center began last evening with a lecture by the gossip columnist Liz Smith.

title: Dry's New High
description: KAZUYOSHI TAKEI, barkeep at a watering hole in the Ginza,'' went the bright lead on a story from Tokyo by Fred Hiatt of The Washington Post, ''admitted that the word dry used to conjure nothing but dry cleaning in his mind. That was before the 'dry boom' hit Japan, before 'the dry wars' began. . . .''

title: On His Honor
description: If Oliver North considers it an honor to have been indicted in the Iran-contra affair, as he said last week, will he be embarrassed if he is found not guilty? And, if so, would that affect any political ambitions he has? Mr. North, who is charged with conspiring to defraud the Government by diverting arms-sales profits to the Nicaraguan contras, talked about the case in a speech at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. ''The accusations are not a brand - they are an honor,'' he said. Those on hand at Liberty, which was founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, included members of a group seeking to draft him as a candidate for the Senate. A spokesman for Mr. Falwell said the evangelist would probably support a North candidacy. Mr. North, who recently retired from the Marine Corps, did not discuss his career plans.

title: 10 States to Honor Generations of Farmers
description: SIXTEEN families who have farmed their New Jersey spreads continuously for more than 200 years will be honored next month at a jubilee that will feature tributes by the Secretaries of Agriculture of 10 states from Maine to Delaware.

title: PAPER FILIGREE: AN ART FOR LEISURE
description: The colorful and ex-quisitely worked decorations in the exhibition ''Rolled, Scrolled, Crimped, and Folded: The Lost Art of Filigree Paperwork'' at the Florian Papp gallery are a wonderful surprise. Most are superb examples of a craft that was popular among women in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries but is virtually unknown today.

title: Singapore Asks Removal of U.S. Envoy
description: The Government of Singapore today accused an American diplomat of interfering in its domestic affairs and asked Washington to withdraw the envoy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sabatini vs. Kelesi in Final: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and 14th-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada advanced to the final of the Italian Open yesterday with straight-set victories in 86-degree heat in Rome. Sabatini, the heavy favorite after the withdrawal of top-seeded Chris Evert because of a heel injury, staved off a set point and needed nearly two hours to beat 13th-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria, 7-6, 6-3. Kelesi beat 16-year-old Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, seeded No. 8, 7-5, 6-3, on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico. Sabatini, at 17 the world's fifth-ranked player, reached the final for the second year in a row. She lost last year to Steffi Graf, who skipped the tournament this year. It was the first time the 18-year-old Kelesi, No. 40 in the world, had reached a major final.(AP) Svensson Gains: Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden defeated Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Munich Open in West Germany. Svensson will face Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina in the final today. Perez-Roldan made quick work of Wally Masur, defeating the Australian by 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Golf Rodriguez Leads: Chi Chi Rodriguez, the defending champion, shared a one-stroke lead at 138 with Dale Douglass and Billy Casper after two rounds of the Vantage at the Dominion PGA Seniors Tournament in San Antonio yesterday. Douglass, who started the day five shots back of first-round leader Bobby Nichols, made seven birdies on the way to a 65, one shot off the course record. Rodriguez shot a 67 that included five birdies. Casper birdied six holes and bogeyed two for a 68. Nichols, Don January, Charles Coody and Al Geiberger were next at 139. (AP) Turner Leads by 1: Sherri Turner overtook the first-round leader Kim Shipman with a four-under-par 68 for a one-shot lead over Betsy King and Missie Berteotti after yesterday's second round of the L.P.G.A.'s $300,000 Crestar Classic. Turner finished at 136, eight under par. Berteotti, without a victory in her third year on the Tour, followed an opening-round 68 with a 69.(AP) Boxing Coggi Retains Title: Juan Martin Coggi of Argentina retained his World Boxing Association junior welterweight crown in his first defense yesterday by knocking out the South Korean challenger, Sang-Ho Lee, at 1:35 into the second round. Lee suffered the second defeat of his career and first in four years. He is 45-2-0 as a professional. It was Coggi's 34th victory against one loss and two draws. He has 21 knockouts.(AP) Track and Field State Record Set: Tilden High School of Brooklyn set a New York State record in the girls' 800-meter relay yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium. Running in the New York Relays, Tilden clocked 1 minute 40.32 seconds which erased the previous state mark of 1:40.9 set by Bishop Loughlin in 1981. Kyron Agard, Saralynn Carr, Michelle Brown and Nora Ettienne were on the record-setting team. Later, in a victorious sprint medley of 4:03.49, with Renee Ray replacing Ettienne, Tilden got a second victory. Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx sprinted to victory in the boys' 800 relay in 1:28.42, the second-fastest time in the United States this year. Sam Rice, Hayes's state sprint champion, anchored the winners and was preceded by Fred Owen, Don Lyon and Vic Ferguson. In open events, Ross Donoghue, former St. John's star, won the men's 3,000-meter run in 8:14.46. Lisa Chapman of Westchester Puma was the winner of the women's 3,000 in 10:12.67. Road Racing Swiss Visitor Wins: Rainer Schenkel of Zurich, on a visit to the United States, won the New Rochelle Half-Marathon in 1 hour 11 minutes 23 seconds yesterday. Doug Hegley of Hempstead, L.I., trailed by 75 yards in 1:11.37. Gillian Horovitz of New York was the top female finisher in 1:21.51. Nancy Kelly of Scarsdale, N.Y., the two-time defending champion, was a distant third in 1:36.39. A field of 752 competed in the second in a series of five half-marathon events. Fordham Takes Title: Fordham rallied to win the 36th Annual Collegiate Conference Championships yesterday. The Rams totaled 84 points to second-place's Iona, with 76 1/2 points, and New York Tech, with 68 1/2. The Rams finished first in the 400-meter relay in 42.2 seconds and the 3,200-meter relay (7:40.9) and a second in the 1,600-meter relay in 3:14.6. Pat Lavery of Fordham won the 3,000-meter steeplechase in 9:06.8 ahead of Tom Trace of United States Merchant Marine Academy, who was timed in 9:32 seconds. In the high jump, Joe Pantginis of Fordham set a meet record going 7 feet 1 3/4 inches.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the State University of New York at Stony Brook misidentified George Bidermann. He is the treasurer of the Graduate Student Organization. The goals of some members of the Chapin Apartments Residents Association were also misstated. They are seeking a rent freeze.

title: Planning Agency Challenged on Draft
description: LEAD: NO ONE ever said it would be easy, but in recent weeks the State Planning Commission has got a much better idea of how hard it will be to resolve the conflicts surrounding - and within - the State Development and Redevelopment Plan.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Bensonhurst Co-ops; Offering Buyers a 'Handyman's Special'
description: THE ''Co-ops for Sale'' signs on the sides of multifamily buildings tell the story of housing in transition on Bay Parkway in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Apartment houses built for rental occupancy over the first half of this century are gradually being converted to owner occupancy.

title: MOTHERHOOD: VARIATIONS ON A THEME; 'There's Still a Girl Inside Me'
description: HOW can my first-born be 45 years old today when I am still in my 20's? How could she have changed so quickly from the cute little red-faced baby who was born on that icy day in January 45 years ago, when I am still the same young woman? And as I kiss her and wish her a happy birthday, I wonder if she is asking herself how that graying lady with the wrinkles here and there could have changed so soon from the dark-haired, round-faced person she remembered from her childhood.

title: 'Mothers Must Find a Support Network'
description: SUSAN HURLEY HEALY, 38 years old, of Milford is the Young Mother of the Year in Connecticut.

title: FICTION
description: BEAUTIFUL ISLANDS. By Russell Martin. (Linden/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Russell Martin's well-written first novel traces a year in the life of Jack Healy, a decent, fortyish family man whose strenuous career has put too much pressure on his marriage. This seemingly predictable material is made fresh because Healy is not a typical overworked professional but an astronaut, and because the year revolves around the real-life explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. The disaster looms throughout the story, which begins with Healy, the narrator, visiting his native Colorado, where he attempts to repair a troubled relationship with his schizophrenic brother. Back on the job in Houston, Healy carries out routine tasks for NASA and tries to deal with his wife's defection to Austin and another man; he also works at a tentative, long-distance romance with a childhood friend. The fiery shuttle accident comes as a painful personal jolt, forcing Healy to confront his feelings about his brother and his own role in the space program. Mr. Martin, whose several nonfiction books include a study of neurology called ''Matters Gray and White,'' has given ''Beautiful Islands'' a shapely structure and nicely realized settings, with convincing details on shuttle training and the view from 200 miles up. But he is less successful with his characters, who never quite break out of their carefully described lives to fully engage the reader's emotions. If Mr. Martin can acquire as solid a grip on human beings as he now has on the details of nature and technology, his future novels should be well worth waiting for.

title: Ford's Luxurious Drive Into the Future
description: Tom Wagner was the relatively new top guy at Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division when he showed up in New York earlier this year to talk about his new baby, the Lincoln Continental.

title: ISRAEL BEGINS ITS CAMPAIGN ON ONE ISSUE
description: The West Bank seems far removed from this cement-block development town just north of the Negev. But a visit from Foreign Minister Shimon Peres made clear that the Palestinian uprising is a blazing political issue for virtually every Israeli.

title: Sheboygan Route
description: To the Editor: In Travel on March 13 you carried an interesting article on Sheboygan and its bratwurst. With the article you included a map that depicted the Interstate highway system running through Wisconsin.

title: Author Recalls Golden Hollywood
description: LEAD: ROBERT PARRISH is doing something he does better than most - telling a story - as a way of replying to a question asking if he writes books about Hollywood because he misses its so-called golden days.

title: BERLIN AT 100: LIFE ON A HIGH NOTE
description: In the 1950's, when Irving Berlin com-plained that 20th Century-Fox had paid more to Rodgers and Hammerstein for ''Oklahoma'' than it was offering him for ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' Joseph M. Schenk, the studio head, tried to reason with him.

title: Good Guys, Bad Guys
description: THE UNTOUCHABLES Starring Kevin Costner (in photo, right) Robert DeNiro, Sean Connery (in photo), Andy Garcia, Charles Martin Smith, Billy Drago. Directed by Brian De Palma. 1987. Paramount Home Video. 119 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: Wife Beating and the Rule of Thumb
description: HEROES OF THEIR OWN LIVES The Politics and History of Family Violence: Boston 1880-1960. By Linda Gordon. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: OUR HEROES, OUR MOTHERS
description: MOTHERSELF A Mythic Analysis of Motherhood. By Kathryn Allen Rabuzzi. 248 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $12.95.

title: U.S. Says Polish Crackdown Jeopardizes Help
description: The Polish Government's violent crackdown on recent labor protests has jeopardized American support for the country's economic recovery plan, the State Department's second-ranking official said today.

A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 5 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. 4 50 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 * 14 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: 'Break the Cycle,' Sobol Tells County Educators
description: LEAD: THOMAS SOBOL, the State Education Commissioner, ''came home'' briefly to the county last week, urging his former colleagues to take the lead in restructuring schools and professionalizing teaching.

title: When Fairness Dictates That a Drug's Patent Be Extended
description: To the Editor:

title: Me and My Piano
description: WHEN I was a kid, like most kids, I had a million things I vowed I would never do when no one would be there to force me to do them. I wouldn't wear a sweater when it was ''chilly,'' or keep my shoes on indoors (or outdoors, for that matter). I wouldn't clean my room or swallow pills. And I would never, ever practice the piano again.

title: If Wanda Would Call Again, One Man Would Like to Talk
description: SHE hung up on me. I can't blame her; it was my fault. Now I'm paying the price. Night and day, the same questions whirl through my mind; Who is she? What did she want?

title: Lotus Is Courting Small Businesses
description: MANY PC users think of the electronic spreadsheet, of which Lotus 1-2-3 is the most widely known, strictly as a corporate tool. In doing so, they overlook its usefulness as a financial planning tool for small businesses.

title: ZAGREB BALLET STARTS TOUR HERE WITH 'SWAN LAKE'
description: LEAD: ''SWAN LAKE'' is a dark romance, a Gothic horror story en pointe in which all the elements of classical and romantic ballet come together in a collision of innocence and evil, freedom and captivity, light and darkness and romantic love and betrayal.

title: Mideast Peace Hurdle
description: To the Editor:

title: ALSO KNOWN AS S.P. EAGLE
description: SPIEGEL The Man Behind the Pictures. By Andrew Sinclair. Illustrated. 162 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: Proposed Ethics Code Provokes Dispute
description: A PROPOSED new code of ethics for the county's 8,600 employees surfaced for the first time last week before the full Board of Legislators and quickly drew angry exchanges between Democrats and Republicans over some of its requirements.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HAPPY MOTHER'S DAY Today's the day mothers get their due, and those who want to go beyond the ordinary - the card and the dinner to say you care the most - can take advantage of some offbeat ways to share togetherness on Mother's Day. For example, there's Coe Hall, the restored Gold Coast mansion that sits in the middle of the 409-acre Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Visitors will able to stroll the now-lush gardens from 1 to 4 P.M., or take the Mother's Day Rhododendron and Azalea Walk at 11:30 A.M.; tour the house, and even see Mom get a special gift. Call 922-0479 for admission information.

title: Frances Littell to Wed in July
description: Frances Littell's engagement to Adam D'Arcy Sherman Heath, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Desmond P.S. Heath of New York City and Staatsburg, N.Y., has been made known by her father, Walter D. Littell of New Haven. The couple plan to marry in July.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
A Mother's Day Lament: 'They Meant Well'
description: LEAD: IF you are the mother of teen-agers, you are probably waiting for your children to prepare your Mother's Day breakfast in bed -and gnawing on your blanket. The odds, as they say in the disaster game, are better for Long Island to sink into the San Andreas Fault than for you to eat before 1 P.M.

title: Vivian Elaine Riefberg Weds John E. Ashford
description: Temple Beth Elohim in Brewster, N.Y., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Vivian Elaine Riefberg, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Morton Riefberg of Danbury, Conn., to John Edward Ashford, the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Volney Clinton Ashford of Marshall, Mo. Rabbi Solomon Ackrish performed the ceremony.

title: POPE, IN URUGUAY, GIVES HIS BACKING TO POLISH STRIKES
description: Pope John Paul II today voiced his full approval of strikes by Polish workers, insisting that the crisis in his homeland could be solved only through fundamental political changes leading to democracy.

title: Maureen Anne Walsh Wed
description: Maureen Anne Walsh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Walsh of Cumberland Center, Me., was married yesterday to Jonkheer Ferdinand Folef Hooft Graafland, a son of Lydia Z. Hooft Graafland-Stahl of Wassenaar, the Netherlands, and the late Jonkheer Folef Ferdinand Joan Hooft Graafland. The Rev. Willem Dyckmeester performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Dorpskerk in Wassenaar. The bride is a vice president in corporate finance and the bridegroom an associate director at J. P. Morgan in London.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Demand for Mixed-Use Projects Grows
description: LEAD: THE pace of office construction and leasing throughout New Jersey is generally sluggish as developers struggle to market a surfeit of available space. But the same cannot be said of high-tech and industrial construction, which in the past year has attracted the attention of a growing number of the state's commercial developers and tenants.

title: BEST SELLERS: MAY 8, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 4 3 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 3 2 3 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 4 3 27 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 5 5 8 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 6 6 8 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 7 10 5 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) What ensues when a New York socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 10 9 12 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 12 13 2 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. 13 12 7 EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 2 1 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the celebrated performer. 3 2 3 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 * 4 3 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 5 3 21 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 6 6 14 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 7 5 5 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life and times of the New York lawyer and political figure Roy M. Cohn. 8 9 3 WINFIELD, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Norton, $16.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee outfielder. 9 7 26 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 10 12 4 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 11 8 10 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 12 16 2 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 13 15 2 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former spokesman. 14 10 16 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 5 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 4 5 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) NUCLEAR FEAR: A History of Images, by Spencer R. Weart. (Harvard University, $29.50.) In this true story of the atomic age, a physicist-historian describes how America's new fateful consciousness (and subconsciousness) of nuclear energy and its military use derives from an ancient pictorial atavism. ELIA KAZAN: A Life, by Elia Kazan. (Knopf, $24.95.) Perhaps his best film yet, it's all here in klieg-lighted cinematic confession: the creativity, compulsive womanizing, generosity and anger. SECOND CHANCES, by Alice Adams. (Knopf, $18.95.) A touching, subtle, truth-filled eavesdrop into the lives of characters who try to talk themselves into a ripeness beyond middle age. GETTING BETTER: Inside Alcoholics Anonymous, by Nan Robertson. (Morrow, $17.95.) The first serious examination of the extraordinary self-help organization, by a Times reporter and recovering alcoholic who mediates with grace and precision between the cynics and cheerleaders. WHO KILLED CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network, by Peter J. Boyer. (Random House, $18.95.) Though the villain of this piece is the former CBS News president Van Gordon Sauter, the author, a former CBS media critic who reports on television for The Times, identifies many smaller Satans. NOTHING TO DECLARE: Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone, by Mary Morris. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Mexico and Central America are departure points for a vibrant nonfiction journey into the self by a short-story writer and novelist. KING LEARY, by Paul Quarrington. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A retired Canadian hockey player skids down Memory Lane in this funny novel of beautiful extremity.

title:
ART;
Animated, in More Than One Way
description: LEAD: ''ANIMALS 'N' ANIMUS,'' the current exhibition at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's gallery at Mills Pond House in St. James, is not likely to win the endorsement of the local dog lovers' association or the cat fanciers' society. There are no portraits of dewy-eyed pooches or baskets of cuddly kittens.

title: AT A GLANCE: ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
description: History

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Sick-Building Syndrome; The Growing Problem of Air Pollution in Offices
description: THRIFTY energy habits, shrinking office quarters and sloppy maintenance are helping to pollute the air that workers breathe in many office buildings.

title: THE COMPANY THEY KEPT
description: LEAD: LILLIAN HELLMAN Her Legend and Her Legacy. By Carl Rollyson. Illustrated. 613 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title:
HERS;
Paying Homage To the Spinster
description: LEAD: NOWADAYS WHEN the hormones are stirring and teen-age sex beckons, terrified young girls go to slice-and-dice horror movies to scream away their fears. In the days of my 1950's Southern girlhood, the fear was not sex but sexlessness - or being alone - and to exorcise it we played a card game called Old

title: THE WORLD: An Unusual Reticence; LEBANON AGAIN - AND THE ISRAELIS ARE QUIET
description: MANY Israelis seemed reluctant last week to talk about their Army's latest victory. For the first time, the Israeli Army sought a direct confrontation with the pro-Palestinian Party of God in southern Lebanon, killing 40 of the Shiite Moslem militiamen and losing three of their men. The Israeli soldiers also came within a few miles of Syrian front lines in Lebanon, risking a conflict with Syria. By JOEL BRINKLEY

title: U.S. Drug Policy: Colossal Ignorance
description: The United States' war on drugs has recently led to the attempted ouster of Panama's military leader, the virtual kidnapping of a Honduran, new efforts to burn crops in Bolivia and a proposed Congressional resolution accusing Mexican officials of accepting bribes. Only a short time ago, similar actions were directed at Pakistan, Colombia, Peru, Turkey and Thailand.

title: ARE WOMEN BETTER DOCTORS?
description: Perri Klass asks if women are better doctors. The question is sexist and irrelevant. A female physician is no less able to perform open-heart surgery than a male doctor is able to tell patients, caringly, that they have cancer. Sensitivity, empathy and sincerity are not female qualities; they are human ones. ''Better'' doctors possess them, and they come in all colors and sexes.

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: The Yankees already have George Steinbrenner and the Mets could use Mayor Koch. He has been making a fool of himself lately. MALCOLM R. HALSEY Ocean, N.J.

title: Miss Stearns Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Bonne Marks Stearns and Howard Wasserman has been announced by Joyce S. Stearns of Waterbury, Conn., and Roland B. Stearns of Manhattan and Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Mr. Wasserman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wasserman of Miami. A July wedding is planned. Miss Stearns, an agent at the Deja Vu Travel Agency in Los Angeles, graduated from the Stoneleigh-Burnham School and New England College. Her father is a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FOR LAUGHS, BILL IRWIN DONS DANCING SHOES
description: Bill Irwin, as a rubber-legged, befuddled soft-shoe dancer, blows kisses into the lens of a video camera he's holding inches from his face. He desperately wants to attract the beautiful danseuse who's watching the TV monitor, where she now sees her zany suitor, in wobbly, wide-angle close-up, looking like a demented trout.

title: U.S. to Deny Visa to Vietnamese Economist
description: The State Department intends to deny a visa to an American-educated Vietnamese economist who is regarded as a leading advocate of economic liberalization in Hanoi, according to groups and individuals in the United States supporting his application.

title: It Wouldn't Be Spring Without Baseball
description: EVEN though I am a woman of considerable age, in spring my fancy always turns to baseball.

title: In Maremma, Etruscan Ghosts Linger
description: MAREMMA L'AMARA it was called, Maremma the bitter, for the harsh life of its inhabitants, their unforgiving lands, their ruined villages. Of all the well-traveled regions of Tuscany, it was the most feared and remains the least known. Yet it is the one that most captivated the Tuscan imagination - from Dante's lugubrious evocations of violent death and disease in the region he elevated to a symbol of human vanity and eternal despair, to Giovanni Fattori's desolate land- and seascapes of the 19th century.

title: A Repair Blitz on Norwalk Houses
description: AFTER 20 volunteers finished with her house in Norwalk, Dorothy Farington had not seen it looking so good in years.

title: BROUGHT TOGETHER BY THANH
description: PARK'S QUEST By Katherine Paterson. 148 pp. New York: Lodestar Books/E. P. Dutton.

title: OFFICIALS SAY BUSH HEARD '85 CHARGE AGAINST NORIEGA
description: Vice President Bush was told nearly three years ago by the American Ambassador to Panama of allegations that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was involved in drug trafficking, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Lost in the 20's On Catalina Island
description: EVER since childhood Santa Catalina Island has rung in my head like an old tune - or maybe an old movie.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND: How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Are tribal arts as high-minded as paintings by the old masters? Is Beethoven no better than the Clash? Allan Bloom believes that creeping relativism is eroding society - and that it's partly Nietzsche's fault. Last year, our reviewer, Roger Kimball, called the book ''an unparalleled reflection on the whole question of what it means to be a student in today's intellectual and moral climate.'' THE CURIOUS CASE OF SIDD FINCH, by George Plimpton. (Charter, $3.95.) Trained in the Himalayas in the ways of Zen, an English orphan shocks the major leagues with his ability to throw a baseball 168 miles per hour.

title: Miss Milano and C. L. Burgess Jr. Wed
description: Maurren Patricia Milano, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael R. Milano of Teaneck, N.J., and Carter Lane Burgess Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burgess of Roanoke, Va., were married yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Thomas R. Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. robert Morisseau, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Finch Weds Peter G. Coe
description: Dr. Elizabeth Lathrop Finch, the daughter of Elizabeth J. Finch of New York and Quogue, L.I., and Edward R. Finch Jr. of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Goodwin Coe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Coe of Bassett, Va. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Plant and Use the Horseradish
description: LEAD: HORSERADISH is a deep-rooted perennial that is native to southeastern Europe. Planted in vegetable gardens for home use and in fields for commercial production, it may also be found growing wild in certain areas of this country.

title: Elaine M. Stately; Indian Leader, 57
description: Elaine M. Stately, a co-founder of the American Indian Movement, died of cancer April 27. She was 57 years old.

title: Women Demand Place On Vietnam Memorial
description: WITH help from a Connecticut Congressman, another effort is being mounted to add a statue of a servicewoman to the Vietnam Memorial in Washington.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our family room is stained and discolored because the toilet overflowed in the bathroom above this room. Will it be necessary to replace this ceiling, or will it eventually dry out so it can be repainted?

title: Europe Opens Up, and the I.R.A. Walks In
description: THE Irish Republican Army took advantage of the shape of things to come on the European mainland when it killed three British soldiers and wounded three others last weekend in separate car-bomb and gun ambushes in the Netherlands. The men were relaxed in civilian clothes amid the off-base nightlife of Dutch border towns, far, but not far enough, from the Irish troubles. In the last decade, a dozen similar forays have been made by the I.R.A. on English soldiers and officials on the continental mainland. But police officials worry that such stealth is getting easier because European border controls are being increasingly relaxed. The relaxation has come in advance of the 1992 deadline for finally achieving the grand goal of a single, open Western European market.

title:
MUSIC;
Guarneri Artists Join Rutgers Staff
description: LEAD: TWO MEMBERS of the Guarneri String Quartet - the violinist Arnold Steinhardt and the violist Michael Tree - will join the music faculty of Rutgers University's Mason Gross School of the Arts in September.

title: Holly Curtis Becomes Bride
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Hilary Whittaker Curtis, the daughter of William G. Curtis 4th of New York and the late Roberta Lamm Curtis, was married yesterday to William George Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hartman Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. Msgr. Henry J. Mansell performed the ceremony.

title: The Elusive Penguin
description: TO walk among the penguins has been a dream of mine ever since I learned that they existed. The idea beckoned from my subconscious like an Art Deco vision, tantamount to stepping into an elegant black and white film filled with men in top hats and tails where everything would be clean and cool.

title: In Nebraska, Presidency A Secondary Race in '88
description: Over the years, Nebraska's Presidential primary has often generated excitement.

title: Negotiations Gap
description: To the Editor:

title:
DANCE;
3 Choreographers To Get a Showcase
description: LEAD: UMBRELLAS and chairs take on symbolic weight in the fifth annual Choreography Showcase of the State Council on the Arts, a five-performance series at which the recipients of state choreography grants will join 1988 Fellows in a festival of mostly modern dance.

title:
DINING OUT;
New Role for an Old Church
description: LEAD: NIBBLING on barbecued chicken and cornbread, with side dishes of collard greens and creamy black-eyed peas, all to the beat of a jazz combo, it is hard to believe that you are not somewhere in the Deep South. Instead, the setting is a spacious dining room carved out of a converted brownstone church on West Market Street in

title: Gentlemen, Start Your Engines
description: IT IS, SO TO SPEAK, A CHIP OFF the old engine block. Conceived as a successor to the British-built Cosworth engine that has captured every Indianapolis 500 since 1978, the Chevrolet-Ilmor V-8 was initially designed, in fact, by two former Cosworth engineers. ''We ran it in one of our spare cars in 1985,'' says Derrick Walker, vice president and general manager of Penske Racing, which, along with Chevrolet, financed the endeavor of the two designers, Mario Illien and Paul Morgan. ''In '86, we ran it for most of the year. For the '87 season, it was offered to other racing teams, too.'' More powerful than the Cosworth, the new engine has had great success in shorter races; efforts over the winter were aimed at improving its durability. Last year, a fuel-system failure in the waning stages at Indianapolis cost Mario Andretti a victory. ''It's done well,'' says Walker. ''But it hasn't won Indy.''

title: Beth Ackerman and Bruce Bolander Are Married
description: Beth Laurie Ackerman and Bruce David Bolander were married yesterday afternoon at Petit St. Vincent, a resort on St. Vincent Island in the West Indies, by Bertham Richardson, the Minister of Marriage, who performed a civil ceremony.

title: Headliners; In the Stars
description: Nancy Reagan needed no soothsayer to anticipate that a memoir by Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's former chief of staff, might embarrass the First Family.

title: Gulch Captures Carter
description: Gulch, trained by D. Wayne Lukas, who saddled the Kentucky Derby winner, Winning Colors, took the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The horse took full advantage of the extremely fast racing surface to carry 124 pounds and Jose Santos seven furlongs, tying a stakes record of 1:20 2/5. Afleet, the favorite, was runner-up in the field of eight. Gulch's clocking duplicated that of King's Bishop, who posted the stakes standard in 1973. It was only one-fifth of a second slower than Dr. Fager's track record of 1:20 1/5, established in 1968.

title: Pair of Lungs Transplanted Into Carolina Congressman
description: Surgeons completed a double-lung transplant on Representative Floyd Spence of South Carolina early today.

title: Executive Wed To Lisa W. Cross, Psychotherapist
description: Lisa Warren Cross, a daughter of Mrs. Regis Gignoux of Bedford, N.Y., and Champtoce, France and Theodore Cross of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dickon Pownall-Gray, a sone of Willoughby Pownall-Gray of Saliisbury, England, and the late Felicity Pownall-Gray. Judge Richard Owen of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: LIVING WITH A VOLUNTARY LAW
description: URGING President Reagan to accept the plant-closing provision of the trade bill, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis points to a law enacted in his own state in 1984.

title: IN MOTHER'S QUILT, IN FATHER'S FIELD
description: YONDER By Tony Johnston. Illustrated by Lloyd Bloom. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers.

title: Devils Are Facing Their Toughest Challenge
description: The Devils approached their first playoff appearance as if assigned to an experimental classroom. Everything was new to them, but everything on the playoff syllabus seemed possible to study, comprehend, and eventually master before moving on to the next lesson.

title: Memory Is Last Shackle As Salvadoran Is Freed
description: After years of assaults and intimidation in her native El Salvador, then months in a detention center fearing deportation, Telba Dora Erazo was granted political asylum this week in a cinder block courtroom in this sun-baked border town.

title: Saving Up for the College Dollar Crunch
description: AS many high school seniors rejoice over college acceptances, their parents worry about meeting next fall's tuition bill. Unfortunately, there isn't much they can do between now and September to amass an education fund other than to take out a home equity loan.

title: Off Base
description: Professional baseball managers often engage in lively debate with umpires, commonly questioning their eyesight and ancestry. They are forbidden, however, to lay angry hands upon them, as Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, did last weekend while vehemently disputing a play at first base. Two days after Rose pushed Umpire Dave Pallone, A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president, suspended the Reds manager for 30 days and said Rose would be hit with a ''substantial'' fine. It was the most severe punishment ever levied against a manager for an on-field offense. Mr. Giamatti said the league would not ''countenance any potentially injurious harassment'' of umpires. Rose said he was ''shocked'' at the length of his suspension.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A WORLD OF RUGS ''The Life, Love and Compassion of the Orient Through Rug Design'' and ''Mystical Icons of Oriental Rug Designs'' are the subjects of two lectures to be given at 8 P.M. Friday and 10 A.M. May 18, respectively, in connection with a sale of hundreds of rugs at the Rye Arts Center. Parviz Morewedge, a philosophy professor at the City University of New York and an expert on Middle Eastern floor coverings and Islamic culture, will be the speaker.

title:
INVESTING;
Why the Drug Stocks Are Lagging
description: LEAD: CONCERN about the proposed Catastrophic Health Insurance Bill has put a cloud over the drug stocks in recent weeks. Because investors are so unsure how the bill may affect drug company earnings, they have avoided the stocks.

title: Music; Schoenberg, Bruckner And Mehta
description: This week's New York Philharmonic concerts were to be an all-Mussorgsky program, with Martti Talvela, the Finnish bass, as the soloist. But Mr. Talvela was ill, so Zubin Mehta revamped the program, offering instead the original chamber version of the Schoenberg ''Kammersymphonie'' No. 1 (Op. 9), and the 1878-80 version of Bruckner's Fourth Symphony.

title: Mary McManus, A Nurse, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Mary Alice McManus, a daughter of Mrs. John Herbert McManus of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. McManus, to Dr. Richard L. White Jr., a son of Mrs. John H. Keating Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and the late Dr. White, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Washington. Msgr. James F. Montgomery performed the ceremony.

title: BLISSFULLY WREAKING HAVOC
description: GRANDMA GETS GRUMPY Written and illustrated by Anna Grossnickle Hines. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books/ Ticknor & Fields. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Vermont Ski Areas Post Second-Best Year
description: Preliminary figures show that Vermont ski areas enjoyed their second-best season on record despite lower-than-average snowfall.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo's Private Moments Go Public, Sort Of
description: Without ''conceding a legal obligation to do so,'' the Cuomo administration today made public the Governor's ''private'' schedules for the last five years after several news organizations requested them under the state's Freedom of Information law. There was only one catch. Everything private was missing.

title: At City Hall, More Than the Usual Ill Will
description: MAYOR KOCH is criticized by his own Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, for his unfettered attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson before the New York Presidential primary. He stammers like an exasperated parent as Mr. Ward and the Fire Commissioner, Joseph F. Bruno, all but come to blows in public. And he calls the chief engineer of his own Transportation Department a ''dummy'' for failing to warn of the rotting underside of the closed Williamsburg Bridge, the latest symbol of municipal neglect.

title: What They Owed to the Scandal Sheets
description: LEAD: BENEATH THE AMERICAN RENAISSANCE The Subversive Imagination in the Age of Emerson and Melville. By David S. Reynolds. Illustrated. 625 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
'NO I WON'T HAVE FUN WITH THE BABY-SITTER'
description: LEAD: THE GOOD-BYE BOOK By Judith Viorst. Illustrated by Kay Chorao. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 5)

title: Suffolk Expands Export Drive
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY EXECUTIVE Patrick G. Halpin's promised foreign trade initiative, designed to expand Long Island's exports, will get under way tomorrow amid growing pressure for the county to step up its efforts.

title: Hope Gittis Wed To Robert Sheft
description: Hope Susan Gittis, a daughter of Sondra Gittis of Philadelphia and Howard Gittis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Robert Sheft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Sheft of Roslyn Heights, L.I., were married last evening at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi David Wice performed the ceremony.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW GRADING SERVICES ARE THE KEY INGREDIENTS
description: LEAD: PERHAPS the most important development in the coin marketplace has been the establishment of several new grading services, notably the Professional Coin Grading Service and the Numismatic Guaranty Corporation of America.

title: Woven Wools From Sardinia
description: THE island of Sardinia, off the west coast of Italy, is swept by eight different winds, and its sheep battle not only the elements but also the briny Mediterranean bush and scrub clinging to pink rocks in their pasturelands. Their wool is rough, wiry and waterproof, not for delicate cashmere shawls or even Shetland sweaters. But out of this rough orbacce, which wears forever, shepherds' hooded jackets have been made for centuries. The soldiers who were sent off to the First World War wore bulky greatcoats made from the wool of Sardinian sheep. And since remotest times, the wool woven in little hamlets all over the island has above all been made into carpets and hangings of infinite variety and often of exceptional artistic merit.

title: Serving Seafood, Not Stereotypes
description: THEODORE'S in Oyster Bay doesn't serve clam chowder, shore dinners or breaded fried shrimp, yet it bills itself as a seafood restaurant. Which goes to prove that there are seafood restaurants and seafood restaurants. Theodore's calls itself unique, and is. Here, smoked shark, fish soup Provencal, snapper en croute and bouillabaisse tempt fish fanciers.

title: 'Waldheim: The Missing Years'
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTHERHOOD: VARIATIONS ON A THEME; Motherhood: Variations on a Theme
description: A FEW years ago I had a bumper sticker on my car that asked ''Have you hugged your stepmother today?'' Everyone who saw it laughed.

title: LACROIX OR LE CASH?
description: Patricia Volk's article ''Lacroix or Le Cash''? (Hers column, April 10). Priceless. VIOLET M. KING Gelview, Ill.

title: 'Import Substitution' - or Buying from the Neighbors
description: LAST Christmas, merchants in Gregory, S.D., subsidized low-interest loans for shoppers at local lending institutions, provided the money was spent with Gregory merchants. To make sure that it was, the lenders issued ''Gregory Bucks,'' redeemable only with participating merchants in the town of 1,500.

title: A Show Equal To an Artist Larger Than Life
description: There's a new man in town in Washington and for someone born in 1848 he's looking remarkably fresh. With his high-crowned astrakhan hat, his dark blue overcoat with its prominent gold buttons, and his white-gloved, silver-ringed hand clutching a cane carved by himself, he cuts an unmistakable figure. Even in a city filled with full-time verbalizers, he stands out as an incisive, not to say combative talker with an exceptional command of words and a driving, day-and-night need to explain himself.

title: Special Flair For the Young
description: MRS. TAKI'S KIDS is a new line of children's clothes that is stylish enough to appeal to grown-ups. It is from Takihyo Inc., which brought us Anne Klein, Anne Klein II and Donna Karan, and it takes its design inspiration from those lines.

title: POSTINGS: Factory Conversion; South Slope Pioneering
description: Park Slope traditionalists recognize nothing south of Eighth Street, but Stephen Mandell insists the Brooklyn neighborhood includes the South Slope area where his 24-unit condo conversion is nearing completion. It has the right sounding address - 279 Prospect Park West - but its location between 17th and 18th Streets leaves it closer to Greenwood Cemetery than Prospect Park. Still, Mr. Mandell said, his is the fourth building on the block to be renovated, and the city plans to refurbish nearby Bartel Pritchard Square, a park entrance. ''There is a lot of activity on this part of the Slope,'' Mr. Mandell said, ''because the rest of the area is exhausted.''

title:
INVESTING;
A High Yield and Rising Profits
description: LEAD: A RETURN of 12.5 percent is nothing to sneeze at, especially when some of it may be tax deferred.

title: A Haven Fit For a Queen In Scotland
description: LEAD: THE Scottish brogue of Mr. Hudson, the butler in ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' can be heard on British television these days advertising a time-sharing operation near Balmoral Castle. The message is that ordinary folk can enjoy the same hunting, shooting and fishing holidays as the royal family, and that they'll be in good company if they invest in the valley known as Royal

title: Eva Soltys Is Married To William Clarke Jr.
description: Eva Marie Wypijewska Soltys, a financial marketing associate in the New York office of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, was married yesterday at the Westover Episcopal Church in Charles City, Va., to William Turkington Clarke Jr., a bond broker with J. F. Hartfield in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Marian K. Windel, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Majeski, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Putting East Bloc Cars on the Road
description: EVERY Sunday morning, several acres of an old military airfield west of Warsaw become, for a few hours, the city's most active automobile salesroom. At what appears more like a county fair, with hot charcoal grills wafting the scent of browning kielbasa, enterprising buyers browse among dumpy little Polski Fiats (the locally assembled Fiat subcompact), new Mercedes Benz sedans and occasional old Pontiacs or Chevrolets that have often been brought into the country by Polish migrant workers.

title: Tudor Runs Week's Hitless-Innings Streak to 13
description: Terry Pendleton hit a sacrifice fly with one out in the ninth inning to score Willie McGee as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1, today after John Tudor pitched seven hitless innings.

title: Q and A
description: Turkey

title: Bush Calls Jackson 'Hustler From Chicago'
description: Vice President Bush has characterized the Rev. Jesse Jackson as a ''hustler from Chicago.''

title: DATA BANK: May 8, 1988
The Many Guises of 20th-Century Opera
description: It might seem something of a stretch to discuss new recordings of Alberic Magnard's ''Guercoeur,'' Kurt Weill's ''Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny'' and Leonard Bernstein's ''A Quiet Place'' in one article. Yes, all three are 20th-century operas, although Magnard's barely qualifies, having been completed in 1900. Yet in their very differences, they make for a piquant contrast.

title: John Sloan's Bygone New York Depicted in All Its Splendor And Squalor
description: There is a German say-ing that could serve as a motto for much of the work of the American artist John Sloan: ''The air of the city makes you free.'' No doubt city air can also oppress, and Sloan's art finds room for some of its harsher and more desolating effects. But the sense of freedom is what comes across most strongly - freedom to be yourself, to stay up at all hours, to share the life of the street; freedom to stroll around and observe.

title: Nature Is Saluted in Fair Lawn Show
description: ALTHOUGH debatable as an idea, ''Painting Is Silent Poetry'' sounds right as the title for the Kornbluth Gallery's current show by four artists.

title: POSTINGS: Mount Vernon Condos; Geographical Compromise
description: Stephen Weiss and Stuart Berelson build for ''dinks,'' and ''dinks'' go both ways, which makes southern Westchester County a good place for them. ''Dinks'' are dual-income couples without kids, and commuting ease often is the prime factor in where they settle.
