Southern Westchester can be a geographical compromise between a spouse who works in Manhattan and one who works in White Plains.

title: Watching Over 'Dum-Dum' Robins
description: WE first noticed the robins preparing to build on June 23 last year. That was late, so we assumed it was their second nest. What had happened to their earlier home -whether it met with some natural disaster or its occupants were successfully fledged - was none of our human business.

title: 62 Die as Shiites Battle to Control Beirut Suburbs
description: The southern suburbs of Beirut were a battlefield today as rival Shiite Moslem militias fought for a second day for control of the area, using artillery, tanks and rockets. Police and hospital officials said 62 people were killed and twice that many were wounded.

title:
DINING OUT;
A View of the Moon in Ardsley
description: LEAD: AT is hard to believe that the Water Wheel has been around for at least 30 years. Its most recent face-lifting, however, has done much to pull the place into the 80's - dark green floral wallpaper recalling William Morris designs so popular today, balloon draperies, pink linens, subdued lighting. But it takes more than pink napkins and a sprinkling of sun-dried tomatoes on the food to turn this dowager into a young thing.

title: CASANOVA'S BIG NIGHT
description: LEAD: BALZAC'S HORSE And Other Stories. By Gert Hofmann. Translated by Christopher Middleton. 200 pp. New York: Fromm International. $16.95.

title: Black, White and Young Together Black, White and Young Together
description: I'VE heard the complaints of white people who grew up in the predominantly black village of Roosevelt, about the difficulties they faced as children because of the color of their skin.

title: James Joseph Pinto, an Investor, Wed To Dale Whiteman, a Cornell Alumna
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Dale Rollins Whiteman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Whiteman of Rye and Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to James Joseph Pinto, a son of Mrs. John H. Pinto of Bel Air, Calif., and the late Mr. Pinto. The Rev. Brian Frawley performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
Ellsworth Kelly Prints at Neuberger
description: LEAD: ELLSWORTH KELLY is the American master at manipulating abstract forms and giving them alacrity. He follows more in the tradition of Jean Arp and Brancusi, in whose art there is an underlying basis in nature, rather than in the tradition of minimalism to which his art might at first seem related.

title: 'The Price' Is Right For Emelin's Plans
description: ALTHOUGH ''The Price'' by Arthur Miller never made a big dent in the commercial theater, it has had a flourishing regional afterlife. Now, 20 years after its Broadway premiere, the play holds up as a work of masterly craftsmanship, psychological validity and emotional force. For the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, which is striving to gain a professional theatrical foothold in the county, ''The Price'' is an ideal, soul-satisfying choice.

title: A DECLINE OF INTEREST AMONG THE STUDENTS
description: A recent issue of the American Contract Bridge League's Bulletin brings bad news for the future of bridge in North America, but also a ray of hope. A survey of student interests, conducted at nearly 400 colleges and universities by a group at the University of California at Los Angeles, showed bridge to be at the bottom of a long list.

title: To Pare Expenses, Ration Services
description: One method of cutting medical costs is to ration services. Robert H. Blank, author of the book ''Rationing Medicine,'' and associate director of the program for biosocial research at Northern Illinois University, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about some of the choices society must make to contain medical costs.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Cemetery Odyssey

title: Verbatim; Teaching Is Hot
description: 'This year's class really blew our socks off. Our applications were up 50 percent. We originally planned to accept 55 students, but the quality was so good we increased the class size to 75. ' Katherine K. Merseth Director of teacher training, Harvard Graduate School of Education, where a rush of new applicants reflects the revived allure of teaching among college students.

title: RICHARD FORD'S WORKSHOP
description: I was a student in Richard Ford's writing workshop at Princeton in 1981 (''Richard Ford's Uncommon Characters,'' by Bruce Weber, April 10). At the first meeting, he told us that he wasn't going to read anything that wasn't important, that we shouldn't write anything that wasn't important and that we shouldn't waste the time of our classmates with anything that wasn't important. He meant it.

title: 'Freaky Deaky'
description: How dearly Elmore Leonard loves a scam, a con, a slippery scheme. How fond he is of the schemer, especially the schemer who thinks big. What a master criminal Mr. Leonard would make if he got tired of writing thrillers and changed professions. The plot of ''Freaky Deaky'' races along, constantly changing course and doubling back on itself, like a cunning fox in front of the hounds.

title: Nancy Friedman Marries R. J. Gross, Fellow Lawyer
description: Nancy Ellen Friedman and Robert Jonas Gross, trial lawyers in the torts branch of the Justice Department in Washington, were married last evening at the Annapolis (Md.) Hilton Hotel. Rabbi Stuart G. Weinblatt officiated.

title: Joyner-Kersee Sets U.S. Mark
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, competing in the 100-meter hurdles for the first time this year, set an American record tonight by winning the women's event in 12.70 seconds at the S&W Modesto Invitational track and field meet.

title: Decorating Challenges Of a Room for Display
description: FOR AMS Interiors Inc. of Greenwich, designing a children's sitting room goes beyond dollhouses and teddy bears, especially when it is in the Kips Bay Show House in Manhattan.

title: Kathleen Hughes Wed in California
description: Kathleen Freeman Hughes, a daughter of Eileen L. Hughes of New York and the late Emmet John Hughes, was married yesterday to Philip Stimson Murphy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Murphy of Los Gatos, Calif. Jean Davidson of the Universal Life Church officiated at the couple's home in Los Angeles.

title: FAITHFUL JAMES FELL OFF HIS PERCH
description: THE WIDOW AND THE PARROT By Virginia Woolf. Illustrated by Julian Bell. Afterword by Quentin Bell. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: From Fresh Air Visits, Longtime Friendship
description: Ana Torres studies Spanish and plays with a pit bull named Princess in a third-floor walkup in the South Bronx. Betsy Langan studies French and plays with a poodle named Popper in a ranch house north of Philadelphia.

title: Ms. Liu, a Medical Student, Weds Dr. Edward Trimble
description: Cornelia Liu, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Darrell T. Liu of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Edward Lloyd Trimble, a son of Mrs. I. Ridgeway Trimble of Baltimore, and the late Dr. Trimble. The Rev. Edwin Coleman performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Nashville.

title: A SPRING SHRUB KNOWN FOR FRAGRANCE
description: LAST call to prune forsythia; work hard on overgrown shrubs by cutting out to ground level at least one-third of the old wood. Spray fungicides on fruit trees, peonies and dogwoods to discourage fungus diseases later in the season. Transplant spinach and lettuce seedlings to a thumb width apart in garden rows. Indoors keep tubers of caladiums and tuberous begonias moist, but do not plant them outside until later in the month. Lilacs

title: Company for the Long-Distance Rider
description: LEAD: ROB and Mary Ann Meyer have a weekend athletic ritual that brings to mind Neddy Merrill, the protagonist of John Cheever's ''Swimmer,'' who covered the eight miles from a party to his house by splashing his way through a string of his neighbors' pools.

title: Blast in Nevada Cut Off Supply Of Fuel Element
description: The explosion that destroyed a rocket fuel plant in Nevada last week has cut off the nation's supply of a vital ingredient used to power military missiles as well as the space shuttle, at least temporarily.

title: Quagmire Is Really Not a Dirty Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Trailblazing a New Appalachian Route e
description: A GOOD hiking trail is more than a path people have walked on a lot. Nature, and boots, need help, which is just what is being provided for the new western route of the Appalachian Trail.

title: SEARCHING FOR OURSELVES IN THE CLASSROOM
description: AMERICAN EDUCATION The Metropolitan Experience 1876-1980. By Lawrence A. Cremin. 781 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $35.

title: Koch Proposes Doubling of Capital Spending for New York Schools
description: Mayor Koch proposed doubling capital spending for the New York City school system yesterday, saying he would seek $5.2 billion over the next 10 years.

title: Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
description: A Yankee Stadium mascot would be consistent with at least two other ways the Yankee management is already debasing the game: first, using the home run to sell beer during broadcasts and second, the traditional but painfully outdated use of excessive organ playing during the game, with a guaranteed rendition of the Campbell's Soup theme each time a Yankee draws a base on balls.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you are given the chance to work on the most difficult issues of the period in which we live, it has to be a privilege to swing at these toughest pitches.''

title: POSTINGS: 200-Acre Tract; Preserving Woodlands, Fields and Ponds in Pawling
description: While most condominium associations own an exercise room and maybe a sundeck, residents of Squire Green in Pawling, N.Y., will share West Mountain, not to mention South, West and East Lakes. The mountain, actually a low ridge, and the lakes, really ponds, are part of a 268-unit town-house colony that will preserve over 200 acres of woods and fields. This development in southeast Dutchess County is closer to the Appalachian Trail than the Taconic State Parkway, but most of the condominiums sold so far will be trade-up, primary residences, not country homes. ''You can live in a resort atmosphere and still be able to work,'' said Clay Fowler, a principal with Equinox Development II, which is building the $40 million project with PNY Development Ltd. and Anthony J. DeLuca.

title: YOU CAN THANK THE BEAVERS
description: Natural history is so much more exciting than our clay-footed human variety. Glacial invasions, global migrations, the decline and fall of great ecological orders - whether the actors are tiny plankton or colossal mountain ranges, the scale of events is epic. Yet we scarcely give nature a nod as we dutifully keep trying to learn how to take charge by studying and restudying the Roman Empire, Napoleon and Henry Ford. Isn't it time to pay more attention to the rest of life on the planet? A good starting point is LIFE IN THE BALANCE: Companion to the Audubon Television Specials (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $29.95), an intelligent guide to environmental conservation, elegantly written by a nature writer, David Rains Wallace. More than a rehash of the television series it was written to accompany, it is also more than the familiar platform on behalf of whales, wolves and other endangered species. In illustrated chapters that describe the earth's major geographical features, Mr. Wallace shows how the natural world we take for granted is continually shifting and changing. The gentle, lush North American landscape of fields, ponds and streams that European settlers found was most likely created by abundant beaver colonies, building log dams that gradually tamed the fierce, gravel-washed rivers left behind when the polar glaciers receded. In judging the often disastrous environmental consequences of modern industry and agriculture, the author very occasionally confuses his priorities. He observes that game laws don't always work well in the third world: ''In recent years, birds have been machine-gunned by the thousands in Lebanon.'' Not only birds, unfortunately. But over all, this is a thoughtful and lively attempt to square economic progress and ecological well-being.

title: 'The Story of My Wife'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Foundation Selects a New President
description: After an eight-month search, the Rockefeller Foundation has named Peter C. Goldmark Jr. as its new president, choosing a corporate executive with a 20-year career in public service and a reputation in New York State and New York City government as an ingenious problem solver.

title: LORDING IT OVER ENGLAND
description: IN A NATION THAT CALLS ITSELF democratic, an unelected House of Lords is, of course, a splendid impertinence. For years there have been clamors for reform, even for abolition, but their lordships refuse to go quietly.

title: Ann Shoemaker, Legal Assistant, Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Elizabeth Shoemaker and Charles Montgomery Meredith 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith 3d of Quakertown, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's mother, Barbara May Shoemaker, of Erdenheim, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

title: Science and Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Comes In But Bet Doesn't Pay
description: Kentucky Derby Day at Churchill Downs got off to a strange start with a series of mix-ups surrounding the day's first race. A bettor made a winning $20,000 bet by accident, then thanked track officials for canceling it for him.

title: Activities for Vacationing Children
description: LEAD: WITH summer around the corner, parents in the county are getting ready to explore the options in activities for their children during the school vacation. In addition to private day camps, there are numerous community-recreation programs and camps as well as general-interest camps sponsored by organizations such as the Scouts and local

title: Pro Racing Starts in the Fast, Unruly Ultimate 30
description: The recent marriage between yachting and professional sports has produced its first offspring: an unruly child called the Ultimate 30. One of these racing boats was christened late last month in Noank, Conn., and it already has a mind of its own.

title: Mainers Strike Compromise on Ferry
description: Spring, it appears, has finally come to this island off Maine and so has a sense of calm. Islanders spent much of the winter grumbling about a new ferry they deemed unreliable, poorly designed and, all in all, just not what they needed.

title: U.S. Reported to Seek More Philippines Aid
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking support for a multi-nation aid plan for the Philippines, according to Administration officials and Congressional aides.

title: Julie Larson Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Julie Joy Larson and Thomas Gaylord Brown, both assistant buyers at Macy's New York, took place yesterday at the Woodlands Inn in The Woodlands, Tex. The Rev. Charles C. Hendricks, pastor of the Woodlands Community Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

title: GIVE US YOUR TIRED, YOUR POOR, YOUR NAZIS SCIENTISTS
description: BLOWBACK America's Recruitment of Nazis and Its Effects on the Cold War. By Christopher Simpson. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: The Right to Smoke Vs. the Right to Breathe
description: Alice Schultze complains in her recent article [ 'An Office Casualty: My Right to Smoke,'' Opinion Page ] that ''No smoking in the workplace is the latest form of discrimination.''

title: Social Events; Muses for Many Causes
description: Understudies' Big Night May 8 - As understudies, they are usually anonymous, waiting in the wings to perform in place of an absent star. Tonight is their night, as they sing the songs they have rehearsed but usually do not perform each night in ''Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Anything Goes,'' ''Into the Woods,'' ''Me and My Girl'' and other current Broadway shows. Dinner at 6 P.M. and cocktails after the show with the understudies, all at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street at Greenwich Street, will benefit ChildrensFare, a theatrical program for children. Tickets $200, or $30 and $50 for the performance alone, at the door; 212-618-1980. Terpsichorean Evening May 9 - Founded in 1975 as an exchange program between Britain and the United States, the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation has arranged visits across the Atlantic by dance companies, individual performers, conductors, choreographers, teachers and students. A benefit for the foundation will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets $250 or $175 for those 30 and under; 212-737-9010. Briefly Noted: May 9 - Apollo Muses, a showcase for young talents, will benefit from a black-tie Champagne reception and performances on the deck of Bargemusic under the Brooklyn Bridge on the Brooklyn side at 7 P.M. Tickets $100; 212-628-1778. May 9 - Cocktails at 5:30 P.M., dinner at 6:15 at Sardi's followed by the performance of ''Chess'' will benefit the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club, which has been a home away from home for servicemen and servicewomen since 1919. Tickets $37.50 for cocktails and dinner and $125 or $150 for the show; 212-683-4374. May 9 - The Jewish Association for Services to the Aged will celebrate its 20th anniversary with a formal dinner-dance at the Plaza. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets $350; 212-724-3200. May 9 - The Bide-a-Wee Home, which has found homes for pets for 85 years, is holding a dinner-dance at Tavern on the Green from 7 to 10 P.M. Tickets $150; 212-532-6358. May 10 - Ravi Shankar and Philip Glass will be the guests of honor at a benefit dinner at the Parker Meridien for the World of Music Institute, a research and production organization for contemporary music. A dancer from India will perform. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets $100, or $185 per couple; 212-988-8934. May 10 - Henry A. Kissinger will be the keynote speaker at the American Jewish Committee's Herbert H. Lehman Award dinner at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. Peter A. Cohen, chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson Lehman Hutton will receive the award. Black tie. Cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets $1,000; 212-751-4000. May 10 - The Chinese Mission to the United Nations will be the host of a 6 P.M. cocktail party, buffet dinner and Chinese dance demonstration at the mission headquarters at 155 West 66th Street. The evening will benefit the Port of Entry Program of Queensborough Community College, which helps graduate students and visiting scholars from China adjust to life in the United States. Tickets $100; 718-631-6351. May 11 - There will be an opportunity to watch three artistic groups in one performance at the City Center when Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane & Company, the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians and Bill Irwin & Friends appear at a 7:30 P.M. benefit for the Center. The three groups will be appearing individually through May 22. Supper at ''21'' follows. Tickets $250, or $35 for performance alone; 212-247-0430. May 11 - The New York Philharmonic Ball, ''A Night in Venice,'' which is the orchestra's biggest fund-raising evening of the year, starts with cocktails in Avery Fisher Hall. Guests then move into a tent in Damrosch Park for dinner and dancing to music by the Philharmonic conducted by Zubin Mehta. White tie. Tickets $750; 212-580-8700. May 12 - Two black-tie parties will be held at the Plaza to benefit the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The Mayfair Ball in the ballroom starts with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. followed by dinner and dancing, while the 35 and under crowd will be in the Terrace Room for a dance starting at 9. Tickets $350 and $500 for the ball; 212-523-7800. Tickets for the dance alone, $65, may be purchased at the door. May 12 - The National Council of Jewish Women New York Section is sponsoring cocktails at 5:30 P.M. followed by dinner at the Lincoln Center Library and Museum for the Performing Arts. This will be followed by an 8 P.M. performance of the New York City Ballet with premiere works by Peter Martins and Paul Taylor. Tickets $200, or $125 for the performance alone at the New York State Theater; 212-535-5900, extension 25. May 12 - ''La Fete du Printemps'' to benefit the Irvington Institute for Medical Research will be held at Place des Antiquaires, 125 East 57th Street, from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. Black tie. Tickets $75; 212-758-8250. An African Evening May 12 - The diplomatic corps will be out in force at one of the United Nations' most colorful celebrations, which will be held in the Delegates' Dining Room starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. African music and dancers as well as Western music by Saku Sillah and the African Connection will highlight the dinner-dance, which will benefit the African student programs of the the Phelps Stokes Fund, a 77-year-old educational organization. Black tie or national dress. Tickets $150; 212-427-8100, extension 320.

title: Turnpike Redecking on Schedule
description: REDECKING of the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike north of Newark is proceeding on schedule.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Symbolic Wound
description: LEAD: THE RITUAL FRAMEwork for circumcision -still traditional in much of the world despite heated medical controversy - is complicated and varied. But the tradition best known in the United States is the Jewish one, set forth in Genesis. God speaks to Abraham in no uncertain terms: ''. . . and he who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin shall be cut off from his people, for he has broken my covenant.

title: A Planto Ease the Housing Crisis
description: FOR ALMOST 15 years, the National Housing Institute, based in Orange, has worked to improve housing conditions and opportunities for both tenants and homeowners.

title: Caroleigh Ritz Will Marry Edwin Evarts in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Ritz of Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroleigh Ritz, to Edwin Denison Morgan Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove, Vt. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Dani Hutchins Weds
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., Dani Jayne Hutchins, the daughter of Mrs. Dan E. Hutchins of New Canaan and the late Mr. Hutchins, was married yesterday to David James Mollenkamp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Mollenkamp of Apple Valley, Calif. The bride, a cum laude graduate of Bryn Mawr College, is a management consultant at General Electric Consulting Services in Somerset, N.J. The bridegroom, an independent computer specialist, graduated from Haverford College.

title: Katherine Howard, a Director of Sales For a Hotel Chain, Weds W. B. Bolton
description: Katherine Howard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Howard of Marblehead, Mass., was married there yesterday to William Bingham Bolton, a son of Mrs. Edward L. Meister of Waite Hill, Ohio, and the late United States Representative Oliver Payne Bolton. The Rev. George A. Westerberg performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: Increased Hunting Of Deer Proposed
description: LEAD: THE Board of Legislators is considering whether to encourage more hunting as a way of managing the county's growing deer herd.

title: Hard-Line Coach
description: He may work in Washington, but that doesn't mean that John Thompson, the Georgetown basketball coach, has been caught up in the thaw in Soviet-American relations.

title: Instruments of 17th Century Prevail
description: THE literature for string quartet is usually thought of as beginning with the works of Haydn, Mozart and the other classical composers, which leaves such earlier masters as Byrd, Purcell and Gabrieli out in the performing cold. To remedy that situation, ''original instrument'' quartets were formed, in New York and Boston, the players using members of the viola da gamba family.

title: IN SOVIET, CHANGE STRUGGLES TO EMERGE
description: The Soviet Union is embroiled in a turbulent struggle against its own authoritarian tradition.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE RESCUE OF THE DANISH JEWS: Moral Courage Under Stress. Edited by Leo Goldberger. (New York University, Cloth, $40; Paper, $20.) The Danish Jews' experience during the Holocaust raises the same questions about anti-Semitism, courage and collective responsibility as does the slaughter of the Jews in other European nations.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 23 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $505,000 32 Washington Square West 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room, fireplace, 3 exposures; maintenance $1,600, 31% tax-deductible (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) SoHo $320,000 31 Mercer Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar loft-co-op; open kitchen, Corinthian columns, high-ceilings; maintenance $521, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Upper East Side $2.2 million 784 Park Avenue (74th St.) 3-bedroom, 4-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room, library, 2 maids' rooms, fireplace; maintenance $1,800, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Upper West Side $245,000 275 West 96th Street (Columbia) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, health club, pool; common charge $360, taxes $1,800 (Broker: Thomassian Realty) Washington Heights $160,000 120 Cabrini Boulevard (Castle Village) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 875-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, den, sunken-living room, Hudson River view; maintenance $633, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) Washington Heights $100,000 900 West 190th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, partial Hudson River view; maintenance $378, 55% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Morris Park $110,000 609 Van Ness Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, frame house; dining room, large kitchen, rear deck, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Riverdale $64,000 4705 Henry Hudson Parkway (Windsor) 450-sq.-ft postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, separate dressing area, terrace, pool, Hudson River view; maintenance $239, includes gas and electricity, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Stephen Eldridge Realty) BROOKLYN Bedford Stuyvesant $50,000 354 Quincy Street 7-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, 4-story, attached brownstone, dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, original moldings and details, 16- by 40-ft. lot; taxes $490 (Broker: Century 21/Joseph T. King Realty) Midwood $80,000 1620 East 2d Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 586-sq.-ft. prewar condo; windowed kitchen, high-ceilings; common charge $119; taxes $275 (Broker Gala Realty) QUEENS Forest Hills $250,000 70-20 108th Street (Continental) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, c/a; maintenance $572, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Jackson Height $307,000 b 71-19 34th Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, brick house; dining room, large kitchen, balcony, additional kitchen in basement, 20- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $966 (Broker: Century 21/ Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Eltingville $171,500 32 Bent Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, full basement, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: George K. Wonica) New Brighton $106,000 80 York Avenue 2-family, attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; 1-car garage, 17- by 50-ft. lot; taxes $260 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty)

title: Prospects; Regulating for Safer Skies
description: Since airline deregulation in 1978, traffic has almost doubled, putting strains on the system. An increase in near misses, allegations against the Boeing Company of poor quality control, and last month's damage to an Aloha Airlines jetliner, have intensified concern over safety. What changes will be made in the way the skies are regulated? Norman Y. Mineta Democratic Representative, 13th California Congressional District; chairman of the subcommittee on aviation.

title: Next Week; Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: NORTH AND SOUTH
description: NANOOK OF THE NORTH Directed, written, photographed and edited by Robert J. Flaherty. 1922. The Classic Film Collection/Home Vision. 69 minutes. $29.95. LOUISIANA STORY Produced and directed by Robert J. Flaherty. Music composed by Virgil Thomson. 1948. The Classic Film Collection/Home Vision. 79 minutes. $29.95.

title: MYTHS OF THE AUDIO WONDERLAND
description: In wonderland, the White Queen told Alice that it only takes practice to believe impossible things. ''Why, sometimes,'' she said, ''I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.''

title: Staging an Edith Wharton Novel In 19th-Century Genre-Painting Style
description: Eight years ago, Donald Sanders, the founder of the collective known as the New York Art Theater Institute, had an esthetic revelation. While visiting the Hudson River Museum, the director and writer, whose work had always been strongly influenced by changing trends in contemporary painting, found himself overwhelmed by the mystical landscapes of the 19th-century painter Thomas Cole.

title: Honoring a Memory: Aiding AIDS Victims
description: FIVE minutes before, her husband had died. In the intensive-care unit at Washington (D.C.) Hospital Center, Lucie McKinney took comfort in the people around her.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 8, 1988
No Headline
description: THE vibration of the gong washed over the tones of the other instruments. Suddenly, the drummer reared his head and the pace became frenetic. Dynamics and density escalated. The wooden hammers struck the bronze keys relentlessly, in perfect synchronization. Rhythmic patterns repeated and repeated; melodic lines interlocked precisely. Then, as the music receded and settled into a dreamy monotony, the tension went out of the musicians' faces, replaced by a complacent expression. They were mesmerized by their own music making.

title: Fisher Is Out
description: He got off to a great start, but after pitching his way to a 3-0 record and helping the Pirates challenge the Mets for first place in the National League East, Brian Fisher, a former Yankee, is going to be sidelined for a while. Fisher, who strained his right shoulder in his last start, against San Diego April 29, was placed on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Showdown Time At Cowboy Shrine
description: TORN by internal feuding and saddled with millions in debts, the National Cowboy Hall of Fame, some folks said, was headed for the last roundup in Oklahoma City.

title: ECUADOR CHOOSES A PRESIDENT TODAY
description: After a turbulent campaign dominated by the rabble-rousing style of one of the candidates, Ecuadoreans choose in a runoff presidential election Sunday between two men with similar political views and dramatically different personalities.

title: THE PRICE IS RIGHT
description: YOU KNOW THAT feeling you get when, after a couple of hours at a crowded, noisy party, you step out on a porch or balcony for a bit of quiet and fresh air? That's the feeling I get every so often when, to get away from the overheated discussions of $40 cabernets and $50 Bordeaux and $100 Burgundies, I open the mail and find the latest copies of my old friend Art Damond's Wine Discoveries.

title: NATIONAL GRIDLOCK
description: LIKE COUNTLESS OTHER STREETS and highways around the world at that very moment, the Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles was an instant catastrophe, the lines of cars jerking to a halt, the traffic congealing in the fuzzy Southern California sunlight. A television camera was watching somewhere overhead. Magnetic sensors embedded in the pavement measured the speed and density of passing cars. Blank electronic billboards stood ready to offer guidance to the morning's motorists. None of it helped. Officially, rush hour was long since over, but a single stalled truck had pushed the system across an invisible threshold, raising the collective blood pressure of motorists backed up for miles.

title: As Route 35 Traffic Grows, So Does Call For Regional Planning
description: LEAD: WHAT began as a county land-use and traffic study of the corridor along Route 35, a major northern thoroughfare stretching from Lewisboro on the Connecticut border to the Hudson River in Peekskill, is being viewed by local officials as an impetus toward a regional approach in planning.

title: Morris Schreiber; Mathematician, 61
description: Dr. Morris Schreiber, a theoretical mathematician and professor at the Rockefeller University, died of congestive heart failure on April 30 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Smoking Bans On British Air

title: Jeanette Kelleher Married To Gregory Stein, a Lawyer
description: Jeanette Marie Kelleher, an assistant economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, and Gregory Michael Stein, an associate at the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, were married yesterday at the Back Bay Hilton in Boston. Rabbi Allan L. Press and the Rev. John MacInnis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Contamination at Kodak
description: The first state testing of ground water at the Eastman Kodak Company's industrial park has found chemical and metal contamination, officials said. An analysis by the Department of Environmental Conservation showed that at least 12 chemicals and five heavy metals were present in ground water in and around the site in amounts that exceed state levels. Environmental officials earlier had said ground water at the site was being contaminated. The tests confirmed similar reports by Kodak.

title: Brief Encounters: Agassi Advances Easily
description: On the surface he appears to be a series of contradictions, a flamboyant teen-ager with a punk hairdo and blue denim designer tennis shorts, who waved to an appreciative crowd after his match yesterday, but said he has not been particularly influenced by growing up in Las Vegas, the ultimate showtown. Andre Agassi is bold, bordering on brash, yet politely applauds his opponent's winners, tapping his racquet strings with his hand.

title: NAJIBULLAH IN NEW DELHI
description: PRESIDENT rrxhNAJIBULLAH of Afghanistan emerged from relative silence last week and, on an official visit to India, appealed to ''moderates'' among the anti-Communist Afghan insurgents to join his Government, which is supported by the Soviet Union.

title: WATCHING THE TOWN COME TO LIFE
description: LEAD: THE AVENUE, CLAYTON CITY By C. Eric Lincoln. 288 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: 40 YEARS LATER, BUT IT'S NEVER TOO LATE
description: When he was in his 20's Harold Shapero was thought by many to be the young American composer most likely to succeed. He had everything going for him. He was an impressive pianist. His music displayed an inspired ability for tune making and technique to fashion works intricately detailed yet cohesive. Stravinsky admired the music. Leonard Bernstein, a close friend, was influenced by it. Aaron Copland, surveying the American scene in 1949, called Shapero the most gifted composer of his generation, and he predicted in an article that once the young composer threw off his influences and struck out on his own, ''the whole musical world will sit up and take notice.''

title: THE WOLF INSIDE
description: As a member of the medical advisory board of the Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Foundation, I was pleased to read Dr. Stone's article. However, he may have created additional stress for people with lupus. He states that 60 percent of the patients have a rash on the face that is ''similar to the facial markings of a wolf.'' However, I can recall not a single such wolf in my practice; the rash for most people is mild and fleeting.

title: THREE DECADES OF LABOR UNREST
description: In Poland, the Government's attempts to raise prices have often triggered resistance. 1956 - Workers at engineering factory in Poznan strike over wages, food and working conditions and attack nearby prison. Authorities respond with tanks; as many as 70 people are killed and hundreds are injured. 1970 - Government announces steep price increases for food, leading to protests in Gdansk, Gdynia and Szczecin. Official death toll is 45; unofficial count is higher. Wladyslaw Gomulka resigns as Communist Party leader and is replaced by Edward Gierek. 1971 - Strike in Lodz, led by textile workers who demand and win rollback of 1970 price increases. 1974 - Dockyard workers and miners strike successfully for wage increases. 1976 - After food-price increases of up to 60 percent are announced, strikes sweep country. Communist Party headquarters is set afire in Radom. Prices remain at old levels. 1980 - Government attempts to raise meat prices by as much as 100 percent. Strikes break out, virtually paralyzing Baltic coast region and closing most coal mines in Silesia. Strikers in Gdansk demand free trade unions; Government gives in and also grants workers the right to strike. 1981 - Increase in prices of food and tobacco announced. Wildcat strikes erupt to back various demands, including an end to harassment of Solidarity members. Martial law is imposed in December. 1985 - Government announces price rises for many basic goods. Solidarity issues call for general strike but withdraws it when Government modifies the increases.

title: SERENDIPITY OFTEN ATTRACTS COLLECTORS
description: BURIED in a dealer's bargain box at this year's New York International Stamp Exposition were two postcards that, despite their lack of bulk, are referred to hereafter as The Altoona Papers.

title: 'Strange Games': Lanyon Retrospective
description: IT'S nice that Middle America has given its name to all that's average and respectable when it has been the stomping ground of so many weird artists. One of the earliest and weirdest was Ivan Albright, who could make anything -from flesh to flowers - look as if it was in the last stages of putrefaction.

title: Kidney Transplants Are to Begin at the County Medical Center
description: THE County Medical Center has secured state approval to become the first hospital in the Hudson Valley region to perform kidney transplants.

title: Athletics Extend Streak to 12
description: The Oakland Athletics extended their winning streak to 12 games today as Carney Lansford and Ron Hassey had four hits each to pace a 19-hit attack and lead the Athletics past Cleveland, 14-3.

title: U.S. LEARNS IT'S NOT EASY TO TURN OUT THE P.L.O.
description: WHEN Congress passed a law prohibiting anyone in the United States from operating an office on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization, its purpose seemed clear and simple. It wanted to close the P.L.O.'s observer mission to the United Nations because it had found the P.L.O. was a terrorist organization. But enforcement of the statute has proved much more complex, because it raises novel and delicate questions of constitutional and international law. The result has been a legal battle that could last for months.

title: Failure of Fraternity
description: After James Callahan died in a fraternity hazing incident at Rutgers University in February, some students rationalized his death as being the 18-year-old freshman's own fault. After all, he consented to the hazing; he just got in over his head. Indictments this week of 15 fraternity members send a different message, one that may prevent more senseless tragedies.

title: Talks to End Strike Begin in Gdansk
description: The management of the big Lenin shipyard met today for the first time with workers striking for higher pay and for the legalization of the Solidarity trade union.

title: Luxury Yacht Is Seized With Bit of Marijuana
description: A $2.5 million luxury yacht was seized today after a Coast Guard search turned up less than a tenth of an ounce of marijuana on board.

title: DUKAKIS
description: IN A PUERTO RICAN COMMUNITY center in the South Bronx, its walls tattooed with graffiti, the crowd is jammed into every available space, anxiously awaiting the candidate. Outside, a chill rain is falling, splattering the chunks of broken cars in an adjacent vacant lot; the noise of an elevated subway train rumbles through the room.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 24 about the Westchester County Hispanic Advisory Board misidentified George Castellanos. He is the board's chairman.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: FROM the town of Delmont, an unobtrusive collection of houses flanking Route 47 in Cumberland County, a sign will direct you south. It reads: Heislerville/East Point Light.

title: Rental Upgrading
description: To the Editor:

title: The Winfield Fiasco Is the Last Straw
description: Even for the most devoted Yankee fans who have been distracted but not deterred by his management techniques, George Steinbrenner has raised the specter of total alienation by threatening to trade Dave Winfield for a Houston Astro named Bass. After years of brushing aside Steinbrenner's obnoxious handling of Yankee personnel because of the team's consistently superior performance, I will not follow the Yankees this year, or any other baseball team, if Steinbrenner trades Winfield for Bass.

title: Withn the Mother-Grandmother Lives, Forever, the Little Girl
description: MY WHOLE family lives with me in a multigenerational array. The images of loved ones, frozen in time, live here in my home, displayed behind glass-fronted frames and - more deeply - locked in my memory.

title: State Tightening Its Rules For Farmland Tax Status
description: DEVELOPERS, gentlemen farmers and other owners of woodlands who qualify for farmland tax breaks must begin working their acreage in earnest this year if they want to retain their special farmland status.

title: Heidi Ann Jensen To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Charles Jensen of New York and Mystic, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Ann Jensen, to Charles L. Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Young of Shrewsbury, Mass. A July 3 wedding is planned.

title: THE WOLF INSIDE
description: In his poignant article ''The Wolf Inside'' (Body and Mind, April 3), John Stone showed great sensitivity for the suffering and pain of lupus patients. The outlook has indeed improved since Flannery O'Connor was diagnosed in the early 1950's, but there are still too many lives cut short by this pernicious and complex disease.

title: Shamir Defends Deportation Of a Palestinian-American
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office today defended the decision to deport Mubarak E. Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolent protest.

title: Signs of Success in 'Poster Pollution' Crusade
description: A. J. Buttler, a man with a consuming aversion to untidiness, regularly walks the night streets of Manhattan, ripping down posters and handbills as he goes.

title: Many Officers in New Haven Call in Sick to Protest Delay
description: Numerous New Haven police officers called in sick today, apparently in protest of stalled contract negotiations.

title: Yanks and Mets: Stranger than Fiction
description: Even in the off season you knew it would be a year of destiny: ours, theirs, New York's. Both teams had power and speed to burn - the pitching needed only continued health, or a little shoring up. October was in the air before spring arrived. We were ready to tell the commissioner to have Series tickets printed. Queensboro, Triborough, Grand Central, Major Deegan, Flushing line, Woodlawn line. Subway Series. Yankees vs. Mets. Even in the dead of winter you could see that fate would tangle these two teams from start to finish. It all began when the Yankees, needing infield defense, swapped some prospects for the Mets' superfluous shortstop, Rafael Santana, a quiet Dominican.

title: Matthew Boyse And Miss Kuhn To Wed Aug. 13
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kuhn of Salisbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanore Hopkins Kuhn, to Matthew Gordon Boyse, the son of Mrs. W. E. Boyse of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late Mr. Boyse. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN REVIVING RURAL AMERICA Looking for a Batch of 2 Percent Solutions
description: THE farm woes of the 1980's overshadowed a far more widespread rural crisis, a depression that decimated mining and lumber towns in the West and textile communities in the South. The damage was so severe that more than half the nation's non-metropolitan counties lost population from 1983 to 1986, the Census Bureau says.

title: Power-Guzzling Homes Trouble Utilities
description: REAL ESTATE developers across the country are coming into conflict with utility companies over the rising electric energy consumption of new homes, and some state and utility officials are calling for penalties against builders who put up the residential equivalents of gas-guzzlers.

title: Four Men on a Filly at the Kentucky Derby
description: It's as if Martina Navratilova won the Wimbledon men's singles. As if Nancy Lopez won the Masters. As if Jackie Joyner-Kersee won the men's Olympic decathlon.

title: First Maryland
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Old Days Gone for Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Home Care
description: LEAD: They may be parents, or perhaps a husband, wife, brother or sister who are elderly and living and being cared for in the home.

title: THE RIGHT NONSTUFF
description: A BOX OF NOTHING By Peter Dickinson. 110 pp. New York: Delacorte Press.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GOLDENROD. By Peter Gault. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) Reviewing Peter Gault's first novel - which he wrote and published himself in Canada in 1984, when he was only 23 - is a bit like reviewing one's youth. The energy is wonderful, but the pacing isn't; the candor is refreshing, but the technique is often crude.

title: Rejecting Relativism; How the Methodist Church Reflects a New Mainstream
description: THE Methodists have been called the most American of American churches. Once the nation's largest religious group, their 9.5 million members now rank behind the 52.5 million Roman Catholics and the 14.5 million Southern Baptists. But the denomination, which became independent of the Church of England when the colonies became an independent nation, remains a sensitive barometer of American culture.

title: Spring, Suspended
description: The cool, wet weather that hung on for so long had its constructive side. It has slowed spring down.

title: Miss Farrell Wed to F. D. Campbell
description: Bridget Elizabeth Farrell, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. S. Farrell of Brooklyn and Point Lookout, L.I., and F. David Campbell, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle R. Campbell of Syracuse and Tully, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Justice Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: A Glimmer of Hope
description: Gen. Jannie Geldenhuys, Chief of Staff of the South African Defense Force, stepped aside with Gen. Ulises Rosales del Toro, Chief of Staff of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Cuba. For an hour and a half they talked.

title: Barry Rawlinson Marries Mary Cunniff, Executive
description: Mary Cunniff, a daughter of Dr. Charles L. Cunniff of Jersey City and the late Margaret Norton Cunniff, was married yesterday to Barry Rawlinson, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Rawlinson of Hove, England. Capt. Carl Ruthberg, a Salvation Army minister, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.

title: Avery Fisher Awards
description: The 1988 career grants of the Avery Fisher Artist Program have been awarded to Pamela Frank and Ida Kavafian, violinists; Andrew Rangell, pianist, and David Starobin, guitarist, each of whom will receive $10,000.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FEDERICO FELLINI: Comments on Film. Edited by Giovanni Grazzini. Translated by Joseph Henry. (The Press at California State University, Paper, $11.95.) Federico Fellini is the subject of an extended interview in this book by the Italian film critic Giovanni Grazzini, published here in a serviceable translation.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Glen Ridge $400,000 89 Ridgewood Avenue 3-bedroom, 4-bath, 48-year-old colonial; fireplace, Jacuzzi, pool, oak woodwork; taxes $8,896. Millburn $238,000 17 Greenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, flagstone porch, basement; taxes $3,413. Ridgewood $252,000 555 Van Buren Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old split level; patio, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $4,144. South Orange $358,500 478 Berkeley Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; fireplace, sun room, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,707. Springfield $187,500 174 Baltusrol Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old colonial; screened porch, formal dining room, fireplace; taxes $2,749. Wayne $200,000 31 Old Homestead Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old split level; deck, eat-in kitchen, c/a, 1-car garage; taxes $2,696. OTHER AREAS East Patchogue, L.I. $135,000 84 Durkee Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Yonkers, N.Y. $232,000 38 LaSalle Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, basement, 1-car garage, .22 acres; taxes $3,340. Brookfield, Conn. $250,000 14 Hollis Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; vaulted ceilings, hardwood floors, 1 acre; taxes not yet available.

title: LACROIX OR LE CASH?
description: Patricia Volk's arithmetic explained: A 10 percent discount after New York City sales tax nets out to about 2 percent. Fifty Lacroix dresses ($750,000) less 2 percent discount equals one Lacroix ($15,000) free (no discount, no sales tax, dated register receipts and price tags required). FRANK J. CASO Flushing, Queens

title: From Drama Thesis To Production Company
description: WHILE the emergence of an original full-scale musical, even with a title like ''Last Tango in New Wango,'' may not be uncommon for a drama student's thesis, it isn't every semester that a production company is formed as part of the project.

title: Janice Facibene Weds Environmental Lawyer
description: Janice Ann Facibene and Christopher Robert Carpentieri, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the New York Yacht Club. The Rev. Harris Riordan, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: A.I.A. Convention; Tours for All
description: Next Sunday, 10,000 architects from Maine to Guam will converge on New York City and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for the 120th annual national convention of the American Institute of Architects. Besides professional workshops and seminars, the four-day event will afford New Yorkers who have never craned their necks at a New York building the chance to see them in the company of some rather astute visitors.

title: Reagan's Legacy in Space: More Reach Than Grasp
description: IN assessing the state of the nation's space program as the Reagan Administration nears an end, experts inside and outside the Government often use two words: muddle and disarray. President Reagan, one of the biggest space enthusiasts to occupy the White House, will leave behind a host of costly projects and innovative policies. But these have produced little achievement in the heavens and little peace on earth.

title: It's Becoming Easier to Find Places to Laugh
description: THE heavy-set young comedian with a style bordering on the manic-depressive was on the stage of the Treehouse Cafe and Comedy Club in Westport on a recent ''open mike'' night, and things were not going well.

title: Use of Temporary Profesionals is Rising
description: A COMPANY in White Plains in the throes of reorganization recently needed a controller. Rather than spend several weeks interviewing for the position, which pays a salary of $60,000 to $80,000 plus benefits, the company hired a temporary employee.

title: Newark Hospitals Forming AIDS Unit
description: FACED with the strain of a constantly increasing number of AIDS patients, this city's five major hospitals -University, St. Michael's Medical Center, Columbus, Beth Israel and United Medical Center - are forming a consortium to open a nonacute-care facility for such patients. It would provide a level of treatment similar to that of a nursing home.

title: Harley's Hogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Seafood of the East and West
description: THE Restaurant at Stamford Landing, another addition to Stamford's ever-expanding dining scene, has a novel idea: In a setting overlooking Mill River, it presents a menu that combines fresh seafood with the products of a Japanese sushi bar. The best of two seafood-loving worlds, one might think. It would be, if the Western selections on the menu were as successful as the oriental ones. And while many items sounded creative and inviting, all too often, they failed in the execution.

title: Theater; Comedy About a Reluctant Saint of Central Park
description: Hugo DePew, the protagonist of Jeffrey Kindley's mild little comedy ''St. Hugo of Central Park,'' is that stock literary figure, a poor misunderstood youth crushed by the evil material world. Any parallels between the life of Christ and the character's eventual martyrdom are purely intentional.

title: Mary O'Callaghan Weds
description: Mary Anne Elizabeth O'Callaghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. O'Callaghan of New York, and Thomas Francis McElroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James McElroy of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Queens of All Saints in Brooklyn by the Rev. Anthony M. Rucando.

title: A New Campaign; NOW, TO GET NEW YORKERS TO TURN OFF THE FAUCET...
description: Recollections of a drought disappear as fast as a flash flood fills a gully, and with the memories go the habits of conservation. At a time when New York City's reservoirs are brimming, Mayor Koch has begun what he calls ''the first permanent water conservation campaign in city history.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bedford
description: LEAD: LIKE ancient Gaul, the Town of Bedford is divided into three parts - the hamlets of Bedford Village, Bedford Hills and Katonah - each inhabited by fiercely loyal residents.

title: BULLS AND BEARS
description: JAY SPIELER SAYS HE'S STILL PARTIAL TO the vivid shirts, paisley ties and plaid suits he wore in the giddy days before Black Monday. Spieler, a broker with Drexel Burnham Lambert, insists last October's market collapse hasn't caused him to change his image by a thread. ''In other words, '' he jokes, ''I'm not wearing a hair shirt.'' Despite a still-edgy market, a fair number of Spieler's Wall Street compatriots, some of whom display large portions of their incomes on their backs, are inclined to agree. Most say they see no reason to alter their style, and cling to their New & Lingwood suede slip-ons, their Jermyn Street shirts and their heavy gold timepieces with an almost fanatical ardor. But others, still feeling last October's aftershocks, are trading in their showy plumage for something more subdued.

title: THINGS THAT GO BAA IN THE NIGHT
description: THE DREAM FACTORY Written and illustrated by Nurit Karlin. Unpaged. New York: J. B. Lippincott. $12.95. (Ages 2 to 6) SLEEPERS Written and illustrated by Dayal Kaur Khalsa. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $7.95. (Ages 2 to 5)

title: Ojeda and the Mets Have Fun on a Beautiful Afternoon
description: With two out in the seventh inning and Bob Ojeda tiring slightly, Dave Johnson, the manager of the Mets, walked solemnly out of the dugout. Almost instantly, Gary Carter took the mound in the bullpen and, smiling broadly, quickly signaled he was ready if needed.

title: ARE WOMEN BETTER DOCTORS?
description: Since our daughter Victoria was born in March 1987, with major heart defects, we have had ample opportunity to observe both male and female doctors (''Are Women Better Doctors?'' by Perri Klass, April 10). We were overwhelmingly impressed by the quality of her medical care -by women and men doctors. However, we were struck by the differences in attitudes of male and female doctors at her hospital of primary care.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Plant and Use the Horseradish
description: LEAD: HORSERADISH is a deep-rooted perennial that is native to southeastern Europe. Planted in vegetable gardens for home use and in fields for commercial production, it may also be found growing wild in certain areas of this country.

title: College Tours: Another Way of Checking Out the Campuses
description: LEAD: WHEN students are shopping for a college, there's more to look at than curriculum. Are fraternities and sororities big on campus? What kind of ''look'' do the students have - casual, punk or preppie? Do they party hard or focus on studies?

title: Correction
description: Because of a distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 19 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give an incorrect date for the opening of James Bruce's horror movie ''The Suicide Club.'' It will open at neighborhood theaters on Friday, May 20, not May 13.

title: Review/Theater; New York in the 1870's, From Wharton Novella
description: Edith Wharton endured a lonely childhood, an unhappy marriage and occasional shortsightedness on the part of critics. But nothing she suffered in her lifetime is comparable to the misfortune inflicted on her by Donald T. Sanders at the Public Theater.

title: Federal Panel Pushes Cuomo On Shoreham
description: A Federal nuclear licensing board has told Governor Cuomo and the Suffolk County Executive that they must either prepare their own emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant or say how they would cooperate with the Long Island Lighting Company in any crisis.

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Ouster Appealed A Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence appealed Israel's order expelling him, and an Israeli judge gave the Government three days to prove its case. Page A3. Aircraft Retirement Age A jet's accident over Hawaii has drawn attention to the issue of how to prevent the aging of aircraft from leading to crashes. Page A15. Rethinking in Nebraska More than 70 public officials in Nebraska have faced ouster votes in recent months. Recall petitions need no reason, just signatures. Page A14.

title: At an East Side Bank Branch, A Pianist Soothes the Thrifty
description: Dorothy Denny Scardino has been playing the piano for 18 years. In a bank.

title: Watch for Safety
description: It looks like a wristwatch, but it doesn't fell time. Trip the yellow lever on the wristband, and out pops an inflated pillow designed to help keep a person afloat.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; In Stormy Markets, Safe Havens Sell
description: If it weren't for the stock market collapse last fall, Robert N. Gordon might still be struggling to earn his first $10 million before he turns 40. But Mr. Gordon has handsomely profited from the turmoil on Wall Street as investors have sought a money manager who can earn a double-digit rate of return without the heartburn caused by the dramatic fluctuations in the market.

title: International Multifoods Names New President
description: Anthony Luiso, who spent 15 years as an executive at Beatrice Foods, has been named president and chief operating officer of the International Multifoods Corporation, effective July 1.

title: Review/TV; A View of Thailand From a Balloon
description: ''The Great Sky Elephant'' won't hurt you. It is a big balloon that gets deflated and inflated and occasionally drifts in free flight. Malcolm Forbes, the publisher of Forbes magazine, took it to Thailand in 1985; the documentary, on Channel 13 at midnight tonight, memorializes his adventure.

title: Wendy Schack, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Alan M. Forrest
description: The marriage of Wendy Gail Schack, a corporate counsel for Group Health Inc. in New York, to Alan Michael Forrest, a lawyer for the Clark Boardman Company, a publisher of law books in New York, took place yesterday at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation. Rabbi Israel Miller, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Ascendant Agassi Wins Tournament
description: The young man in a hurry would have to be brief in his postmatch interview. There was a plane to catch to Rome, site of the Italian Open, where word of Andre Agassi's latest exploits will doubtlessly precede him. By the time he plays his first-round match there, he will have moved up a place or two in the ranking and probably stolen the headlines from the established order.

title: Mother Is Held in Death Of Battered Infant Boy
description: A 26-day-old boy was found dead in his family's Bronx apartment Saturday night and his mother was charged with second-degree murder yesterday, the police said.

title: Review/Music; Mixing Opera and Pop in 'Regina'
description: Today's proponents of a fusion between opera and Broadway are hardly pioneers. One of the most notable early instances of the movement was Marc Blitzstein's ''Regina,'' which opened on Broadway in 1949, enjoyed respectful but somewhat puzzled reviews, and closed after 56 performances. It was subsequently taken up by the New York City Opera and other opera companies, but tonight it was revived for a run through June 12 by the Long Wharf Theater, thus bringing it back to its theatrical ambiance and roots.

title: Annual Ballet Awards Presented in Denmark
description: The first Hans Christian Andersen Ballet Performance Awards were presented during an international performance at the Danish Royal Theater on Saturday, with the top awards going to Sylvie Guillem of the Paris Opera Ballet and Irek Mukhamedov of the Bolshoi Ballet.

title: Dome Buyout Delay Sought
description: Two Dome Petroleum Ltd. shareholders who oppose terms of a takeover by the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company will appear in an Alberta court on Monday in an effort to delay the transaction.

title: Valerie Rosenson Wed To Russell D. Robbins
description: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., Valerie Tina Rosenson, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, was married yesterday to Russell Dana Robbins, a fourth-year medical student at New York University. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and two cousins of the bridegroom, Rabbi Donald Gluckman and Cantor Ellen Math.

title: British Group Buys Retailer
description: The British retailer, Sears P.L.C., sold its Lewis's Stores unit to a group for $137.6 million, Midland Montagu Ventures Ltd. said on Sunday.

title: Patrick Hogan, Artist In California, Is Dead
description: Patrick Hogan, an artist who achieved renown as a painter in Los Angeles despite a handicap that allowed him only the use of his mouth to hold a paintbrush, died of respiratory failure on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old, and had moved to New York two years ago to pursue his painting career.

title: Cathay Pacific Financing
description: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. has asked Paine Webber Asia Ltd. to arrange $100 million in financing for aircraft leasing, The Hong Kong Economic Journal quoted the bank as saying. It said the money will be used to finance a Boeing 747-300 jumbo jet to be delivered in July. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly described the status of the proposed acquisition of Farmers Group of Los Angeles by B.A.T. Industries of London. The Arizona Insurance Department has not acted on the issue yet.

title: U.S. Bond Sales Fell in April
description: Sales of United States savings bonds dropped in April for the first time in eight months, falling 6.4 percent, to $661 million.

title: Shaping Up
description: It shouldn't surprise anyone that the United States ski team's major emphasis for the next year will be on physical fitness. Last season, no fewer than 15 of the women and 5 of the men on the team suffered injuries that kept them out of competition.

title: Chinese 'Silicon Valleys'
description: China is planning to develop high-technology industries by setting up six ''silicon valleys,'' the official New China News Agency said Friday. The zones will be in Beijing, Shanghai, Canton, Tienjin, Wuhan and the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, near Hong Kong. They will concentrate on such businesses as computers, robots, microelectronics, optical-fiber communications and lasers.

title: Ex-Aide Cleared In Scalping Case
description: A former University of North Dakota assistant men's basketball coach was acquitted of a charge that he tried to scalp tickets for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four tournament, authorities said.

title: Review/Music; In Queens, a Tribute to Louis Armstrong
description: The first half of Friday's tribute to Louis Armstrong at the Louis Armstrong High School in Elmhurst, Queens, was graced with Mr. Armstrong's sense of economy. The show started with a recording of Mr. Armstrong singing and soloing through ''Dream a Little Dream of Me,'' moved into a film clip of Mr. Armstrong playing a blues, then neatly segued into his favorite song, ''Sleepy Time Down South,'' performed by a group that included Eddie Preston on trumpet, Harold Ousley on tenor saxophone, Bill Davis on piano, Kim Clarke on bass and Walter Perkins on drums.

title: Budget Chief's Baptism by Shortfall
description: It was a short honeymoon. Two weeks ago Thursday, Dall W. Forsythe, head of the Governor's Office of Management and Productivity, received a call from Governor Cuomo asking him to be his next state budget director. He said yes. On Monday, the departing director, R. Wayne Diesel, called to tell him that the state was looking at a $300 million shortfall in income tax receipts.

title: Politicians Count on Computers
description: There were dozens of typewriters and three computers in the campaign office when Michael S. Dukakis ran for governor of Massachussetts in 1982. His 1988 Presidential campaign headquarters has dozens of computers and three typewriters.

title: Metro Matters; A Rotting Bridge And Who Takes The Blame for It
description: The headline told the whole story: ''Say Williamsburg Bridge Is Unsafe.''

title: A Court of Last Resort for Golfers
description: THE phone rang late on a Friday afternoon at Golf House, the headquarters of the United States Golf Association in Far Hills, N.J. It was a rules question from a tournament in Georgia, but all the rules experts had gone home. The call was put through to Frank Hannigan, the U.S.G.A.'s senior executive director. That's a little like calling the I.R.S. with a tax question and having Ronald Reagan pick up the phone.

title: Review/Concert; Lark Quartet Plays Bach (P.D.Q. Variety)
description: Pity Peter Schickele! There is an authentic compositional talent there, but we will never know just what its true merit is, because nobody living today can listen to this music with wholly uncluttered judgment. For 23 years Mr. Schickele has been ''finding'' music by P.D.Q. Bach (he can't stop, and behavioral therapists can't cure him). So let him dare, in a straight-faced work like the String Quartet No. 2 played by the Lark Quartet Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, the least touch of pastiche or humor, and we not only chuckle, but we spend the next few bars thinking of the ''Concerto for Horn and Hardart'' or the ''Echo Sonata for Two Unfriendly Groups of Instruments.''

title: Quarterly Refunding Begins Tomorrow
description: The first part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding will begin tomorrow, just a part of the heavy schedule of Treasury financings set for this week.

title: The Complete Bechet
description: Even for many people who are not jazz aficionados, names like Louis Armstrong and Bix Beiderbecke are familiar. But Sidney Bechet, who is usually ranked with Armstrong and Beiderbecke as an innovator and soloist in the early years of jazz, has, for a number of reasons, been much less well-known.

title: Merciless Athletics Are on a Rampage
description: MARK McGWIRE wears his feelings across his chest these days, beneath the white, green and gold uniform of the Oakland Athletics. He cannot wear those feelings on his sleeve. That space is occupied, for the first time in more than two decades, by the playful elephant that has followed the franchise from Philadelphia to Kansas City, and finally, 20 years after the team's arrival on the West Coast, to the East Bay.

title: Review/Rock; The Fall's Mixed Messages
description: Some of the best 1980's rock blares out thoroughly mixed messages -pleasure melded with irritation, bad news delivered with a joyous kick, orderly songs proclaiming chaos and desperation. Beyond their volume level, the Fall and Soul Asylum have little in common, but both bands forged 1980's ambivalence into fierce rock when they shared a bill Friday night at the Ritz.

title: John J. McNamara, an Architect And Theater Designer, Dies at 90
description: John J. McNamara, an architect who designed and renovated some of the best-known theaters in New York City, died April 26 in Raleigh, N.C., his home in recent years. He was 90 years old.

title: Japan-Europe Trade
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan today urged an expansion of trade between the European Community and Japan. ''The importance of increased economic cooperation between Japan and Europe cannot be underestimated,'' the Prime Minister told reporters after meeting with West German officials as part of an 11-day European tour.

title: Varig Survives in Difficult Region
description: Given the troubles of airlines across Latin America, Helio Smidt seems remarkably confident that Varig will emerge unscathed from the inflation, recession and labor unrest buffeting the region.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Argentina's cost-of-living index rose 17.2 percent in April after a gain of 14.7 percent in March, the national statistics institute said. The index showed a rise in the year to April of 247.8 percent, compared with 206.9 percent in the year to March. Inflation in the first four months of the year was 62 percent. Wholesale prices increased 16.8 percent in April.

title: A Floral Craft Booms in Thailand
description: In a country where supermarkets sell orchids in bunches and no public occasion is complete without cascades of blooms, Thais were bound sooner or later to turn their love of flowers into something exportable.

title: New Jersey Mob Figure Is Missing From Home
description: John DiGilio, a reputed leader of the Genovese crime family in New Jersey, was reported missing by his wife from their apartment in Holmdel, N.J., officials said early this morning.

title: Public TV Smorgasbord
description: During five days of screening last week, nearly 700 public television professionals viewed an international smorgasbord of some 80 programs representing 60 broadcasting companies from 30 countries. It was the llth annual International Public Television Screening Conference, which is held in the United States every four years. This year it was at the Annenberg School of Communications at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Critic's Notebook; Appraising Ballet Music
description: Hearing more than 40 American composers being danced to by the New York City Ballet these last two weeks has been a provoking, sometimes puzzling, experience for a music critic. With a generosity and optimism so agreeably American, the company has been celebrating its own in grandly hectic style - mounting ballet after ballet, night after night, all to music from this country. For one whose training makes him more comfortable with sound than with sight, impressions of this American Music Festival begin with and return to music. Critics are presumptuous enough in their own fields without taking on someone else's.

title: Alison Fraser Reflects On 'Romance Romance'
description: Barefoot and surrounded by Teddy bears, Alison Fraser sat in her dressing room at the Helen Hayes Theater, effervescent over the success of her first Broadway starring role.

title: Cholesterol Control Is Only One Step to Health
description: WHERE fitness is concerned, we live in an age of numbers. We measure our weight, the resting and exercising pulse rates, the caloric intake at meals and even blood pressure. But in terms of preventing heart disease and possibly living longer through regular exercise, such numbers pale in importance when compared with the four values that reflect the fats found in our blood.

title: Pressure Builds for Rate Rise
description: Conditions in the fixed-income markets are putting further pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates, market participants said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Fed is under increasing pressure to raise interest rates, the latest squeeze coming from the release of April employment data. Some analysts took heart from the fact that payroll employment increased by only 174,000 jobs, but others were concerned about inflation because unemployment had fallen to its lowest level in 14 years and the total number of hours worked had risen sharply. Credit Markets. [ Page D1. ] The free-trade agreement with Canada is on track, with Congress likely to approve it before the August recess, analysts think. The clash between the White House and Congress over broad trade legislation has apparently failed to derail the accord. [ D1. ] COMPANIES The resignation of a top officer at Equitable Life was forced, according to financial industry officials familiar with the incident, apparently because of concerns about the company's financial difficulties. The departure of Leo M. Walsh Jr., Equitable's chief operating officer, was announced without explanation last Tuesday. [ D1. ] Casio Computer has put on hold its plan to introduce digital audio tape recorders in the United States. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Among Latin American airlines, Varig stands out. The Brazilian carrier is the region's largest airline and one of the 20 biggest in the world. But in a region where airlines' difficulties are growing, it faces some hard challenges. [ D4. ] The market for Thai artificial flowers has quadrupled in four years, manufacturers say. Consumers and interior designers in the United States are the most important customers. [ D4. ] Japan and the U.S. are expected to explore jointly developing an airliner that could fly between Tokyo and New York in two and a half hours, a Japanese Government spokesman said. [ D2. ] West Germany is planning to alter shopping hours in an attempt to raise consumer demand and aid economic growth. [ D4. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS MTV is undergoing a fundamental transformation, embracing methods identified with traditional commercial television. The maverick video channel has introduced a dance show and a game show, and in the coming months it will try a critics' review show and a late-night talk show. [ D8. ] Clay Felker, Manhattan,inc.'s editor, is determined to broaden the magazine's range beyond New York. He would like the magazine to have a New York focus but national appeal. [ D8. ] Agents at International Creative Management may benefit from the proposed leveraged buyout of the talent agency's parent company, Josephson International Inc. [ D8. ] Marketers are turning their attention to ''latchkey children,'' the millions of boys and girls between 5 and 13 who are routinely left unsupervised before or after school. Ad Scene. [ D8. ] Reader's Digest assigned its international trade advertising to Mojo New York, a recently established outpost of a major Australian ad agency network. Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A 35-year-old supersalesman has profited handsomely from the turmoil on Wall Street as investors have sought a money manager who can earn a double-digit rate of return without the heartburn caused by market fluctuations. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Millions of Americans will need to fill out W-4 forms again this year to adjust their withholding because of additional tax changes. I.R.S. officials say they will be less forgiving this year of those who fail to have enough tax withheld from paychecks. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Last week's public offering by Bethlehem Steel is seen as a sign not only of the attractiveness of steel stocks but also of the relative prosperity of basic industry. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales April Friday Producer Price Index April Inventory-Sales Ratio March

title: Japan May Join Air Venture
description: Japan and the United States are expected to explore the possibility of jointly developing a supersonic airliner that could fly between Tokyo and New York in two and a half hours, a Japanese Government spokesman said.

title: New York City and Police Reach Pact
description: New York City officials and the police officers' union nnounced yesterday a tentative agreement on a contract that would provide a 6 percent pay increase in each of the next three years, for a total cost of $394.5 million to the city.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: New Agency for Booth
description: North Castle Partners in Greenwich, Conn., had a good haul last week. Its new client, with $4 million in billings, is Booth Food Products of Portsmouth, N.H., a division of National Sea Products. The brands to be promoted are Booth and Fisher Boy. The previous agency was the Leo Burnett Company of Toronto.

title: The Bruins Lament Officiating and Loss
description: The night didn't begin routinely, and someplace between a dream and a nightmare, two teams with the Stanley Cup on their minds had to cope with a game that threatened to disintegrate before it ever began.

title: TV Notes
description: Biting for the Camera

title: After Rebellious Youth, MTV Tries the System
description: From the moment it arrived on Aug. 1, 1981, the cable-television music network MTV was everything the rest of television was not. It was fast, it was loud, it was scary to parents and, mostly, it was hip. Even the time it went on the air - one minute past midnight - was a kind of anti-television statement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bishop Inc., which is engaged in the marketing and distribution of engineering and design products, appointed Kenneth J. Kay executive vice president and chief operating officer and Dennis K. Tsuyuki controller and principal accounting officer.

title: Art and Dance to Benefit From Painter's Will
description: The wife of the painter and collagist Romare Bearden plans to set up a foundation named for her husband that will aid art students and art institutions.
