title: Ouster Tied To Declines At Equitable
description: Concern about poor earnings and growing financial difficulties led some outside board members to force Leo M. Walsh Jr. to resign last week as chief operating officer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, financial industry officials familiar with the situation said.

title: New Silver Association Picks Margeotes Shop
description: Silver International, founded Jan. 1 by six North American silver mining companies to promote silver products to consumers, has chosen an agency: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

title: 'Had to Be Some Horsemanship'
description: WHEN his alarm clock buzzed at 3:30 yesterday morning, D. Wayne Lukas's first thought upon waking was not that one of his horses, the filly Winning Colors, had finally won the Kentucky Derby.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At one point, I kept a color-coded calendar on my desk (numerals highlighted in green ink for 'good' days, red for 'bad' days, yellow for 'iffy' days) as an aid to remembering when it was propitious to move the President of the United States from one place to another, or schedule him to speak in public, or commence negotiations with a foreign power.'' - Donald T. Regan, former White House chief of staff. [ A1:2. ]

title: For Children Home Alone, A Word From the Sponsor
description: SOME of the nation's largest consumer-products companies have begun to pursue one of the youngest markets: ''latchkey children,'' the perhaps seven million boys and girls between the ages of 5 and 13 who are routinely left unsupervised before or after school.

title: Police Killing in Queens : Search for a Mastermind
description: More than two months after a police officer was slain in Queens, detectives report no breakthroughs in the hunt for evidence that would permit charges against someone for having ordered the murder.

title: Tax Watch; Many Need to File W-4 Forms Again
description: IT may seem a cruel imposition in view of last year's anguish, but millions of Americans will have to fill out new W-4 wage withholding forms this year.

title: April Output By OPEC Up
description: Oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries rose to 18.2 million barrels a day in April from 17.7 million barrels in March, the International Energy Agency said Friday.

title: Weighing Four Seasons as Landmark
description: Answering a request from the owners of the Four Seasons, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission may grant landmark status to that cool and hushed modernist restaurant on East 52d Street.

title: Casio Delays Its Recorders For Digital Audio Tapes
description: Casio Computer Ltd., which was expected to become the first company to sell digital audio tape recorders in the United States, has put its plans on hold, indicating that the American introduction of the controversial product will be delayed yet again.

title: Revlon Work Expands For Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam, which is rarely satisfied with just one bite, has gotten another mouthful of the Revlon business. This time it is adding to last month's nibble with agency-of-record status for all spot television and print buying, some $30 million worth that was formerly handled by Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Coast-to-Coast Runner Not the Retiring Type
description: SAM FREEMAN can tell you a great deal about Central Park. He can give you an exact number of lampposts on the east side of a reservoir, recount the total of park benches in a six-mile stretch and rattle off a precise figure of garbage cans situated in a designated area.

title: Irving Offer Extended
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had again extended its $1.16 billion offer for shares of the Irving Bank Corporation. The offer is now scheduled to expire Friday at 5 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: Market Place; Blue Skies Seen In Steel Industry
description: THE Bethlehem Steel Corporation's announcement last week of a public offering of 10 million of its common shares at $19 each is viewed as a sign not only of the attractiveness of steel stocks but also of the relative prosperity of basic industry.

title: Fred Knapp, Private Eye, Scourge of Illegal Tenants
description: Sam Spade, he's not. Fred D. Knapp is a modern private investigator, skilled in the use of the computer modem and the art of searching public records. Because he operates in New York City in the late 1980's, his prey is a particular local species: the illegal rent-regulated tenant.

title: Brewers Climb With 9 Victories in Row
description: Mike Felder drove in two runs as the Milwaukee Brewers scored four times in the 10th inning today, beating the Kansas City Royals, 6-2, for their ninth straight victory.

title: Mojo Office In New York Wins 2 Jobs
description: MOJO NEW YORK, a recently established outpost of a major Australian ad agency network, has won the international trade advertising account of the mighty Reader's Digest even though it was a latecomer to the competition.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the National Hockey League semifinals, if Detroit eliminates Edmonton and Boston eliminates the Devils, then the Red Wings and Bruins, two of the six pre-expansion teams in the N.H.L., would meet for the Stanley Cup. When was the last time the final round did not include an expansion team? How many times has this occurred since the 1967 expansion?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 8, 1988: MONDAY Pitney-Bowes Inc TUESDAY Chicago Pacific Lockheed Corp Enserch Corp Russ Berrie & Co Gallagher & Co United Industrial Greyhound Corp WEDNESDAY Alco Standard Corp Newell Co Baltimore Bancorp Sysco Corp CBS Inc USG Corp Current Income Shs USLife Inc Fd Household Intl Inc Wynn's International THURSDAY Arco Chemical Louisiana Genl Svcs Carpenter Technology Mapco Inc Champion Intl Maytag Corp General Nutrition Pacific Amer Inc Shs Guardsman Products Plains Petroleum Intl Flavors & Fragrances Sears Roebuck Landmark Bancshares FRIDAY Ecolab Inc Washington Water Pwr State Mutl Securs

title: Speed Limit
description: One of the more persistent beliefs in sport is that the thoroughbred, while indisputably the fastest of horses, is also the fastest possible horse.

title: Outdoors: The Attractions of Making Lures at Home
description: PROMPTED in the main by frugality, I have been turning out striped bass and bluefish surf-casting lures, both jigs and popping plugs, in my home workshop.

title: Far Afield
description: Ivy League schools rarely venture outside of the Northeast in booking opponents. In recent years, though, a number of the Ivies have scheduled exhibition games abroad during the summer. But no school has done so on a grander scale than Yale is doing this year. Indeed, before the fall semester begins, Yale teams will have played this summer in Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Korea, Ireland, Canada, England and perhaps China.

title: Upturn Seen in Norway
description: Norway's economy, plagued by high costs, inflation and trade imbalances, is on the road to recovery, Finance Minister Gunnar Berge said Friday. He said the gross national product would grow by just five-tenths of a percent this year, virtually half the 1987 growth rate, but added that an agreement with labor unions to limit wages had helped cut costs. He said he expected a budget surplus of 4.1 billion crowns (about $664 million) this year.

title: Review/Concert; A Symphony Of Greek Music And Greek Voice
description: Musical expression is related to personality and character, but not in a direct correspondence. Moving embodiment of the highest moral aspirations can spring from the pens of people whose lives are depressing studies in expediency, and witty people can write music that is earnest and bland.

title: Shop Hours In Germany
description: After a long and heated debate, West Germany is planning to alter shopping hours in an attempt to raise consumer demand and bolster economic growth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about unhappiness among Bolivian priests about the number of foreign bishops misstated the background of the Aymara Indians. They were conquered by the Incas in the 15th century.

title: Railroad Boom Brings a Parking Crunch
description: A surge in rail ridership across the metropolitan region has created a new obstacle for a growing number of commuters: no place to leave their cars at the station.

title: Gauchos vs. Russians: Revenge in the Bronx
description: The Russians took revenge on the Americans Saturday night in a crowded gymnasium in the heart of the South Bronx.

title: Gilsdorf Again Working With a Tarlow Agency
description: Russell P. Gilsdorf is rejoining a former associate, Dick Tarlow, as executive vice president, director of marketing services and the media, at the new Tarlow Advertising.

title: Manhattan,inc. Sees a Future Beyond Manhattan
description: There was Joe Jamail, the tough-talking Texas lawyer who ''stomped'' Texaco, on the March cover of Manhattan,inc. One might wonder what a Texan was doing on the cover of a local New York business magazine. But Clay Felker, Manhattan,inc.'s new editor, is determined to give the monthly a range beyond New York.

title: Heublein Acts On Charges
description: Heublein Inc. has agreed to pay $300,000 to settle Federal charges of unfair trade practices, an official of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said.

title: Penta Hotel's Agency
description: Kirshenbaum & Bond has been named the agency for the New York Penta Hotel, which older New Yorkers may remember as the Pennsylvania or Statler Hilton, at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. According to the agency, the hotel is part of a 16-unit chain operated out of West Germany as a joint venture by Lufthansa, Swissair and British Airways. Its previous agency, James Parry Inc., went out of business.

title: The Martin Affair: Questions Emerge
description: A number of significant discrepancies surfaced today between Billy Martin's public version of an incident at a local nightspot early Saturday morning and the report Martin filed with the police. However, the Arlington police said they were convinced the Yankee manager was blameless in the incident.

title: Books of The Times; Memoirs of a 'Chamberlain' in the White House
description: For the Record From Wall Street to Washington By Donald T. Regan 397 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.

title: Koch Increases Earnings, Drastically
description: Gary Koch, who lost his exempt status on the PGA Tour last year because he was 175th on the 1987 money list, today won the $250,000 first prize in the sixth Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational. This is the second largest winning payoff on the tour behind the $360,000 at the Nabisco Championship.

title: Repeal of New York City Mayoral Primary Runoff Falters in Albany
description: With many leading New York City Democrats favoring the present system of mayoral primary runoffs, a politically significant bill to repeal it appeared to be in serious trouble over the weekend.

title: Yanks Lose Third Straight
description: If the Yankees wore the mask of a beaten and weary team this weekend, it was not because of events that transpired off the field. Don Mattingly, their first baseman, said they simply failed to capitalize on opportunities, that the eight runs they totaled today should have been enough to stop any team. But they were not. With Rickey Henderson and Dave Winfield out of the lineup - and with Chris Chambliss making his first appearance as a player since the 1986 season - the Yankees were dealt a 10-8 beating by the Texas Rangers at Arlington Stadium.

title: Steinberg Companion Willing to Testify in Girl's Death
description: Hedda Nussbaum is willing to end her silence and testify against Joel B. Steinberg in the death of Lisa, the 6-year-old child they had raised, the woman's lawyer says.

title: Suspension of Devils' Coach Causes Uproar, Delays Game
description: It was the Stanley Cup playoff game that almost wasn't. When it finally began, just over an hour late, it featured impromptu and ill-dressed substitute officials, over-anxious players, and a sheet of overheated ice.

title: Review/Architecture; Grand Designs of Paris, At the Custom House
description: Is it mere happenstance that an exhibition about major new architecture in Paris has made a stop in its world tour to touch down in one of New York's greatest Beaux-Arts structures, the old United States Custom House in lower Manhattan?

title: Stewart Goes to 8-0; A's Streak Hits 13
description: There is a sense of inevitability about the Oakland Athletics. Not the type that takes success for granted and turns winning teams into October disappointments. It is a day-by-day inevitability, the sense that sooner or later, an opponent will commit a mistake and soon that mistake will become costly.

title: 3-Hitter by Darling Lifts Mets Over Reds
description: On the first hit, Tim Teufel just couldn't get the ball out of his glove. On the second, a sprinting Darryl Strawberry couldn't quite grab the ball. On the third, everyone stood and watched as a bunted ball refused to come up off the infield grass.

title: Buyer of Johns Painting
description: The buyer of Jasper Johns's fiercely compelling ''Diver,'' from 1962, which brought $4.2 million last Tuesday at Christie's, was Jeffrey Deitsch, a Citibank vice president, who represented an unidentified buyer. The price was an auction record for a work by any living artist.

title: Horse Racing; Filly and Forty Niner Set for Rematch
description: ''It looks like it's going to be the Woody and Wayne Show again,'' was D. Wayne Lukas's prediction last month about the Kentucky Derby. It turns out he called it just right, and that the show is far from over.

title: Review/Dance; New Works for City Ballet Music Festival
description: It was Hit Parade night at the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival on Saturday when Peter Martins presented the premiere of ''Black and White'' and William Forsythe, the American director of the Frankfurt Ballet in West Germany, offered his own premiere, ''Behind the China Dogs.'' Set to pop-influenced commissioned scores, both are New Wave ballets, exciting the audience through their sophistication and aggressive energy.

title: Jane Whitney and Lindsey Gruson Wed
description: Jane Whitney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo C. Balzereit of Jupiter Island, Fla., and Jenkintown, Pa., and Lindsey Gruson, the son of Flora Lewis Gruson of Paris and Sydney Gruson of New York, were married yesterday at the Horticulture Center in Philadelphia. Representative Bob Edgar, a Democrat from Pennsylvania who is a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Ronald L. Walfish.

title: Ruth Lebovitz, Professor, Weds Robert L. Markovits
description: Dr. Ruth Myra Lebovitz, an assistant professor of psychology at La Guardia Community College of the City University of New York, was married yesterday to Robert L. Markovits, a lawyer in Middletown, N.Y. Rabbi Frederic Margulies officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York.

title: Pistons Win Series On Tough Defense
description: The Detroit Piston defense smothered the high-scoring Jeff Malone and led Detroit to a 99-78 victory over the Washington Bullets today in the fifth and deciding game of their first-round playoff series.

title: The More Feet, the Merrier
description: The Examer Bay to Breakers road race in San Francisco May 15 is a populist's fitness fantasy. Now in its 77th running, the 7.5-mile race throught he streets of San Francisco attracts 100,000 entrants and has been designated the largest footrace in the world by the Guinness Book of World Records.

title: Michael J. Shaara, 58; Pulitzer Prize Winner
description: Michael J. Shaara Jr., whose book on the Civil War, ''The Killer Angels,'' won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction in 1975, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 58 years old.

title: Designer Names Arnell For International Task
description: Arnell/Bickford, an agency that is extremely conscious of style, has been named the agency for Christian Lacroix, the French designer noted for his romantic and fanciful clothing.

title: Bridge
description: A strong international field continued play yesterday in the annual Invitational Charity Pairs at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Two American Records Broken: Tom McCants and Jerome Carter set an American high jump record and Ramona Pagel set an American mark in the shot-put at the sixth annual Jesse Owens Classic in Columbus, Ohio. McCants and Carter, who train together, each cleared the bar at 7 feet 9 1/4 inches. McCants, of the University of Alabama, cleared the height on his second attempt while Carter, from Edgewood, Md., missed on his first two attempts before tying McCants. The effort by McCants and Carter broke the mark of 7-8 1/2 set by Jim Howard in 1985. Pagel, a resident of San Diego, put the shot 64-2 1/2 to eclipse her own American record of 63- 3/4 set in 1987. (AP) McLaughlin in Comeback: Willie McLaughlin, a three-time winner of the IC4A outdoor 400-meter title when he was an undergraduate at Manhattan College from 1981 to 1985, made a successful comeback effort when he won the 200-meter dash in 21.71 seconds in the New York Relays at Randalls Island Stadium. McLaughlin would like to qualify for the Olympic 200-meter trials, but must run a 20.67 or better. Jackie Brown of Brooklyn was a double winner in the women's sprints. She took the 100-meter in 12.28 seconds and the 200 in 24.69. Oral Selkridge of the Anderson T.C. scored his second victory in the three-day meet when he won the 400 meters in 48.09 seconds. TENNIS Sabatini Wins Italian Open: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini wore down Helen Kelesi, 6-1, 6-7, 6-1, yesterday to capture the Italian Open women's championship. The 17-year-old Argentine found the range with her deep topspin groundstrokes in the third set to win the $200,000 clay-court event in Rome.(AP) VOLLEYBALL 3d N.C.A.A. Title for Trojans: Jen-Kai Liu led top-ranked Southern California to a hard-fought 15-17, 14-16, 15-10, 15-11, 15-9 victory over California-Santa Barbara Saturday night as the Trojans won their third National Collegiate Athletic Association men's volleyball championship. The Trojans took national titles in 1977 and 1980. They had finished second the last three years. Ball State placed third with a 14-16, 15-13, 15-9, 6-14 victory over George Mason at Memorial Coliseum in Fort Wayne, Ind.(AP) HORSE RACING Upset Victory for Avie's Gal: Jorge Velasquez rode Avie's Gal, carrying 114 pounds, to an upset victory in the $88,800 Comely Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. Topicount was a fast finishing runner-up with the D. Wayne Lukas-trained entry of Over All and Classic Crown, the odds-on favorites, fourth and seventh in the field of eight. ROWING Brown Wins Governor's Cup: Brown overtook Radcliffe yesterday in the closing strokes of the Eastern Association of Women's Rowing Colleges championship regatta to win the Governor's Cup for varsity eights. The outcome of the varsity race was not decided until the final 20 strokes, when Brown outsprinted Radcliffe to secure its victory, its first in the regatta's 10 years. Brown defeated Radcliffe by 2.1 seconds, or a half boat length, in the time of 6 minutes 23.2 seconds. Yale finished third, one-tenth of a seconbebehind Radclif, with Princeton Cornell and Wisconsin closing out the six-boat final.

title: Buyout May Mean Raises for I.C.M. Talent Agents
description: Tom Wolfe, Meryl Streep and Willie Nelson will not be directly affected if a proposal to take International Creative Management private receives Government approval. But their agents, and those representing 2,600 other agency clients, could be. They stand to be paid much more if the proposed leveraged buyout of I.C.M.'s corporate parent, Josephson International Inc., is successful.

title: Improvisation Lies at the Heart of Arena Football
description: ''ANYBODY here who thinks he can kick?''

title: Approval of Canada Trade Pact Seen
description: The clash between the White House and Congress over broad trade legislation has failed to derail a free-trade agreement with Canada.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Dip
description: Canada's unemployment rate dipped to 7.7 percent in April from 7.8 percent in March, Statistics Canada reported Friday. The Government agency said the jobless rolls declined by only 10,000 in the month and remained over the one million mark.

title: Lorimar Officer Quits To Avoid Move West
description: Michael Garin, the Harvard philosophy graduate who co-founded a television syndication company a decade ago, has resigned from the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, where he had been a member of the office of the president and a director.

title: Carbide Plea to India Judge
description: Lawyers for the Union Carbide Corporation have asked District Court Judge M. W. Deo to remove himself from hearing India's $3 billion suit against the company. The suit charges negligence in the 1984 Bhopal gas leak disaster.

title: Jordan and Bulls in 2d Round
description: For all of the praise, it has been a source of irritation for Michael Jordan that the Bulls have never survived the first round of National Basketball Association playoffs. The irritation has not been so much the losing, but in suggestions that for all of his talent - a 35.5 points a game playoff scoring average, a memorable 65-point outburst against Boston in 1985 - Chicago couldn't win with Jordan.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an operation in South Africa to separate twin girls joined at the head translated the name of one girl incorrectly.

title: Drabek Prevails On Near No-Hitter
description: Doug Drabek pitched eight hitless innings today before a pinch-hitter, Randy Ready, led off the ninth with an infield single as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the San Diego Padres, 6-2.

title: Devils Top Off a Hectic Night With Crucial Victory
description: On a hectic night that involved litigation, the Devils evened their Stanley Cup semifinal series against the Bruins at two games apiece with a 3-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Reece Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Vestar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Conmed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
Israeli Makes Surprise Visit to Hungary
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel today ended an unexpected overnight visit to Hungary, the first visit by such a senior Israeli leader to any of the Communist countries that broke relations after the 1967 Middle East war.

title: Party Urged to Pick Women
description: The National Organization for Women today released a list of prominent Democratic women and said the Democratic Party should consider them for key convention roles as well as for the Vice Presidential nomination.

title: Post-Traumatic Stress: Biological Clues Found
description: Vietnam veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder were less sensitive to pain after seeing scenes from a war movie, according to a new study that gives a glimpse into the complex biology of the disorder. The finding may also be a step toward new treatments, scientists said.

title: Legal Abortion Under Fierce Attack 15 Years After Roe v. Wade Ruling
description: Fifteen years after the United States Supreme Court ruled that women have a constitutional right to abortion, groups on both sides of the issue say that right is increasingly vulnerable to attack.

title: Ferrofluidics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $204,000. The year-ago periods have been adjusted to reflect the sale, during the year-ago third quarter, of the company's Japanese and Israeli subsidiaries.

title: A Soviet Day To Remember Past Victories
description: When he left Moscow to fight in Germany more than 45 years ago, Vasily Bakumenko knew why he, then just 16 years old, was going to war. ''For Stalin, for Stalin,'' said the veteran, now 61 years old. ''We were so sure. We wrote it on our tanks and our helmets. For Stalin.''

title: Ex-Illinois Governor Stricken
description: Former Gov. Richard Ogilvie apparently suffered a heart attack today and was in critical condition at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, officials said.

title: Fire Causes Airport Delays
description: A weekend fire at an Illinois Bell switching station kept telephones idle for 35,000 customers in Chicago's western suburbs today and caused delays at major airports.Crews at the Federal Aviation Administration's control center in Aurora were using a backup phone system, but the lack of full service meant controllers had to stagger the arrival of flights by 20 miles. Firefighters battled the fire at the Hinsdale station, west of Chicago, for three hours before it was brought under control Sunday evening.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday about summer activities for vacationing children gave an incorrect telephone number for Pace University's ''Gateway to Journalism'' program. The number is (914) 681-4134.

title: A Trading Halt Won't Calm the Market
description: To the Editor: Closing down the New York Stock Exchange to ''calm the market'' after a threshold of turbulent trading is crossed would be like restoring depositors' confidence by closing down the banks. Anyone who does not find it immediately obvious that such actions would make both investors and depositors rush for their cash need only recall Stephen Leacock's wonderful story:

title: Puerto Rican Cement Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from Thursday, May 5, editions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about Raffoler Ltd., a mail-order house, misstated the number of packages the Lillian Vernon company sends by mail. The company sent 3.6 million packages in its last fiscal year, 200,000 of them by parcel post.

title: Flamemaster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; Washington Ballet Adapts French Film Classic
description: The Washington Ballet has just presented an unusual work at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The ballet is Michael Smuin's ''Hearts,'' inspired by the great French film classic ''Les Enfants du Paradis'' and set to music that consists mainly of songs associated with Edith Piaf.

title: Children's Discovery Centers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Fairly Safe Bet
description: The National Basketball Association has called a news conference for today to announce its rookie of the year. Among the guests invited to Tavern on the Green are Dick Evans, president of Madison Square Garden; Jack Diller, the Garden's vice president; Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager, Coach Rick Pitino and several Knick players.

title: Academy Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $642,000 for the latest quarter and $568,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Western Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Consolidated-Tomoka Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When the Baby Is Late: Obstetricians Search for the Safest Approach
description: DESPITE dramatic advances in obstetrics, doctors still have no idea what strategy is safest for the late, or postmature baby. When should birth be induced artificially, and when is it best just to wait?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Tax-exempt organizations face new taxes on some commercial activities under Congressional proposals endorsed by the Administration. Advocates of change say the issue is fairness, not revenue, and complain that small businesses are at a competitive disadvantage in competing with not-for-profit groups. [ Page A1. ] A very good year in commercial banking seems in the offing if first-quarter results are an indicator. The biggest banks rebounded with healthy earnings, benefiting from belt-tightening, moderate interest rates and gains in the trading of securities. [ D1. ] Little likelihood of rigidly fixed exchange rates was predicted by Richard G. Darman, the former Deputy Treasury Secretary who shaped much of the Administration's current dollar policy. [ D2. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average fell below 2,000 as stock prices declined for a fourth straight day. Volume remained lethargic as the Dow fell 10.11 points, to 1,997.35. The last time the Dow closed below 2,000 was April 21. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in sluggish trading as market participants prepared for the start of the Treasury's $26 billion quarterly refunding, which begins today with the $8.75 billion sale of three-year notes. A sharp increase in commodity prices and signs that the Federal Reserve may be tightening monetary policy helped to push down note prices. [ D1. ] The pound rose sharply on unfounded rumors that the Government's key advocate of currency weakness was preparing to quit. Gold rose $3.60 an ounce on the Comex, to $447.30. [ D18. ] Prices of precious metals futures rallied on fears that South Africa would react to further United States economic sanctions by reducing its exports of platinum and gold. [ D18. ] INTERNATIONAL The Paris Bourse rose strongly and the franc held its own the day after France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, won re-election. [ D1. ] Saudi Arabia is drafting a new charter for Aramco, cutting its legal ties to the U.S. But it is seeking joint ventures with the four American oil companies that formerly owned the oil giant. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Burt Sugarman raised his bid for Media General to $70 a share, from $61.50. [ D22. ] Mohasco accepted a takeover by MHS. The deal is valued at more than $507 million, or $36.50 a share in cash. [ D4. ] General Mills will soon select the successful bidders for its Eddie Bauer and Talbots units. [ D4. ] Sales of the nation's leading black-owned industrial and service businesses rose to a record $4.1 billion last year. [ D3. ] Staley Continental has begun negotiating with one or more parties to sell all or part of the company. [ D4. ] Talks ended between Western Publishing and Gulf and Western about a merger. [ D22. ] Random House named Gloria Steinem a contributing editor. She will be involved in acquisitions and marketing and take part in editorial meetings. [ D22. ] Cooper agreed to buy RTE, formerly Rural Transportation and Equipment, for $45 a share, or about $371 million. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The underwriting business will grow increasingly competitive as more investment houses adapt to a difficult market, says Roger M. Vasey of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Talking Business. [ D2. ] The price of soybeans is rising - along with the fear of inflation - because the supply appears to be dwindling. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Pioneer Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $51,000 and $31,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Teacher Shortage Termed Most Critical in Inner-City Schools
description: LEAD: While enrollment in teacher education programs is rising, the vast majority of those students have no intention of working in urban school districts, where the need for new teachers is most critical.

title: Bilingual Plan Backed in Los Angeles
description: The Los Angeles School Board has approved a master plan for bilingual education that is expected to tilt the national debate strongly toward teaching non-English-speaking students in their own language.

title: Jury Weighs Charges Against Nine in Mob Killing
description: A jury today began deliberating the fate of Nicodemo Scarfo, a reputed underworld figure who is accused, along with eight associates, of killing a mob rival in 1984.

title: Smithsonian Accepts Indian Museum's Move to Custom House in New York
description: The Smithsonian Institution today appeared to have accepted a shift of the Museum of the American Indian from the Washington Heights section of Manhattan to the Custom House at the Battery. The Smithsonian had hoped to establish a new museum site on the Mall in Washington.

title: Picturetel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cyprus Unit's Sale
description: English China Clays P.L.C. said a conditional agreement had been reached for the $74.25 million purchase of the calcium carbonate business of the Cyprus Mines Corporation, a subsidiary of the Cyprus Mineral Company, which is based in Englewood, Colo. Cyprus produces a range of fine-ground marble products.

title: Banque Nationale Offers 9 7/8% Notes
description: The New York branch of Banque Nationale de Paris is offering $225 million of 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 at 99.719 to yield 9.92 percent through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Chrysler Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would extend its buyer incentive program with several revisions. It includes about two dozen models and offers cash rebates ranging from $400 for the Plymouth Reliant and Dodge Aries to $1,500 for the Dodge Daytona Pacifica and the Chrysler Conquest. Most vehicles carry rebates between the two extremes. As an alternative, buyers may choose low-rate financing from 5.8 percent for loan contracts of 48 months to 9.8 percent for 60 months.

title: Sandata Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Taro Vit reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss U.S. dollar figures for both periods have been translated at the rate of $1 to 1.56 new Israeli shekels.

title: United Savings & Loan Association reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparable fourth quarter and year share earnings are not available; the company went public April 2, 1987.

title: Budd Taking Rest
description: Zola Budd, the center of an international track controversy, said last night in London that she would follow medical advice and not participate in international competition ''for a substantial period'' while she recovers from nervous exhaustion. Budd said in a statement to the British domestic news agency Press Association that she needs a ''substantial period of recuperation along with the support of my family and friends to regain my health.'' She said she was not well enough to continue fighting claims that she was involved in a sports meet in South Africa last June, a move in violation of the spirit of the rules of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, track and field's governing body. The South African-born Budd is currently the subject of a special committee of inquiry set up by the British Amateur Athletics Board. The inquiry was established after the federation demanded that she be banned for a year from taking part in international track and field events because of her purported involvement with the sports meet. The board was scheduled to announce its decision regarding the ban demanded by the federation on May 21. (AP)

title: Unigene Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wespercorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $60,000 for settlement of lawsuits. c-Includes a loss of $660,000 for settlement of lawsuits.

title: 'Pink Sheet' Listing Plan
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it plans to request Government approval to publish an electronic ''bulletin board'' listing quotations of thinly traded stocks often referred to as ''pink sheet'' issues.

title: New Theories on Early Europe Cite Migration, not Conquest
description: WORKING independently and using analytical techniques that challenge widely accepted methods, scholars in Britain and the Soviet Union are suggesting a new starting time and place for one of the most mysterious and important events of antiquity: the spread of Indo-European language and culture across a vast area from the Ganges to Iceland.

title: Workers Don't Have 'Parachutes,' Mr. President; What Trade Reform?
description: To the Editor: A news story on the trade bill (April 29) concludes that ''the United States has signed on to the notion of defending fledgling and foundering industries.''

title: Atlantic Financial Federal reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from repurchase of convertible debentures of $672,000 and $1,191,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $2,813,000 for the quarter and $7,280,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $5,120,000 for the quarter and $9,972,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sierra Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $69,000 and $199,000 from tax credits for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Soviet Change vs. the Worker's Scrutiny
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new economic reality visited this Black Sea port city last year, passing like an unexpected tremor through the rock-stable lives of longshoremen, crane operators, mechanics and clerks.

title: Senate Primary Race Divides G.O.P. in Nebraska
description: Hand outstretched, head thrust forward, a determined smile on his face, Representative Harold J. Daub bounced from table to table, greeting the mostly Republican members of the Norfolk Rotary Club in the mostly Republican northeastern part of this predominantly Republican state. Again and again, he was greeted with restrained smiles.

title: Desert Partners Drops a Request
description: At a hearing today in Federal District Court here, Desert Partners L.P. withdrew a request to delay the USG Corporation's annual meeting on Wednesday.

title: Just the Right Touch
description: COMPUTER keyboards, more than any other computer components, are subject to the Goldilocks syndrome. The user goes from one to the next trying to find the one that is just right. This one is too hard, that one is too soft. This one is too crisp, that one is too mushy. This one is too loud, that one is too quiet. This one is too big and clunky, that one is too light and cramped.

title: Israeli Court to Hear Arab-American's Appeal
description: Israel's High Court turned down prosecution and defense requests today and ordered that Mubarak E. Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence, be kept in jail for two weeks until a hearing can be held on his expulsion.

title: Metro Datelines; Baby M's Mother Gives Birth to Boy
description: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould, who lost the custody battle for Baby M, gave birth yesterday to a boy, hospital officials said.

title: Soviet Bloc Writers Clash at a Conference
description: A dramatic confrontation between writers from Central and Eastern Europe and those from the Soviet Union startled an international literary conference that ended here today.

title: ABC Tries to Tap Magic of 'Roots' a Second Time
description: At a time when television viewing is declining, producers are understandably searching for sure-fire hits. To many of them, the safest approach is to find a way to recycle the most successful programs of the past.

title: Automated Language Proessing Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the increase in revenue came primarily from acquisitions of Translation Service Companies, including Interlingua-TTI, a British provider of Technical Translation Services with 14 U.K. offices as well as offices in Barcelona, Hong Kong and Singapore.

title: HMSS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $127,000.

title: Trimedyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Kleinwort in U.S.
description: Kleinwort Benson Ltd. said today that it had been negotiating with the Fuji Bank Ltd. for several months to sell a 24.9 percent stake in Kleinwort Benson Government Securities Inc., its Chicago-based primary dealership. A United States primary dealership is a government securities firm with which the Federal Reserve trades directly. Published reports in Tokyo have said the Fed is opposing a purchase by Fuji.

title: Construction Inquiry Rescued in Koch Budget
description: Mayor Koch yesterday revived an expanded investigation of racketeering in the New York construction industry, providing $1.7 million in his budget.

title: Review/Concert; Chamber Group and Cello
description: Gerard Schwarz and the New York Chamber Symphony began Sunday afternoon's concert at the 92d Street Y by doing a service for a work most of us have underestimated, Aaron Copland's ''Dance Panels'' of 1959 (revised 1962). One thing about Mr. Copland's music: you can always recognize it. The man has a true style and a true voice, and this ''abstract'' ballet score - produced at a time when interest in the composer was distinctly waning and largely neglected -speaks authentically. The Pas de Trois is eloquent in its simple melancholy, and the fast sections have an unforced rhythmic life.

title: Metro Mobile reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,734,000 from the reversal of unrealized losses on marketable securities recorded in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Associated Hosts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gasoline Evaporation Termed a Pollution Factor
description: Evaporation of gasoline from fuel systems while cars are running may be making cities significantly smoggier than previously predicted, but new regulations could clear up the problem, according to several analysts.

title: Steinem Gets A Random House Post
description: Gloria Steinem, the feminist writer who was a founder of Ms. magazine, was named a contributing editor of Random House Inc. yesterday.

title: Santa Cruz Journal: Surfing Museum Far East of Hawaii
description: Long before the Beach Boys sang about it and Gidget nearly drowned trying to do it, this seaside town of 47,000 residents about 70 miles south of San Francisco had already established itself as one of the most important centers of surfing outside Hawaii.

title: Transtech Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $17,925,042 and $970,413 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Robert A. Heinlein Is Dead at 80; Renowned Science-Fiction Writer
description: Robert A. Heinlein, a former aviation engineer whose clever interweaving of imagination and technical expertise helped make him one of the country's most successful writers of science fiction, died Sunday morning at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 80 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Catch the Moon Captures Kingston: Catch the Moon came from far back in the field of 14 to gain a half-length victory yesterday in Aqueduct's closing day feature, the $128,600 Kingston Handicap for New York-breds 3 years old and up. Wanderkin, the favorite, led in midstretch, but failed to last. Catch the Moon, who carried 119 pounds and was ridden by Robbie Davis, was making his first start of the year. He went one and one-sixteenth miles on the good turf course in 1:45 1/5 to earn $77,160 for Tanrackin Farm. He paid $33.60 for $2 to win. Aqueduct concluded its 109-day meeting with a 5.2 percent increase in daily average handle. Racing shifts to Belmont Park tomorrow, with first post time at 1 P.M. The opening-day feature will be the $100,000-added Withers Stakes, which offers a field of seven, including the favored entry of Tejano and Tsarbaby.

title: North Hills Electronics Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $124,206 and $153,497 for the latest and prior years, respectively; the latest year also includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $83,281.

title: Harvey Mansfield, 83; Taught at Columbia
description: Harvey C. Mansfield, the Ruggles Professor Emeritus of Public Law and Government at Columbia University, died of stomach cancer last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Anti-Apartheid Paper Fights Government for Its Right to Fight
description: A liberal weekly newspaper that has consistently challenged the white-run South African Government is fighting for its life.

title: Market Place; Soybean Supply Draws Attention
description: SOYBEANS have long been termed the ''invisible commodity,'' which consumers hardly ever see but which they use every day.

title: Gateway Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $439,000 from an accounting change. The company went public in June 1987.

title: Technology Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bond Trading Quiet on Eve Of Note Sale
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in sluggish trading yesterday as market participants prepared for the start of the Treasury's $26 billion quarterly refunding, which begins today with the $8.75 billion sale of new three-year notes.

title: Callahan Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dorsett Encouraged
description: Tony Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys' running back, said he was encouraged he would be traded to the Denver Broncos as team officials continue negotiating a deal to free the veteran player from financial obligations. ''There are a lot of conversations going on right now between my people and the front office of the Denver Broncos,'' Dorsett said. Dorsett said he didn't know how far along the negotiations were, but he told KXAS-TV in Dallas, ''It's very encouraging.'' The Cowboys' president, Tex Schramm, said Dorsett has made a proposal to resolve obligations to the Cowboys, who lent him money when the former Heisman Trophy winner fell into tax and investment problems in 1986. Unhappy with his role behind Herschel Walker, Dorsett has requested a trade.(AP)

title: Soy Ink for Newspaper
description: The Champaign-Urbana News-Gazette will be printed with ink made from soybean oil, starting June 1, the newspaper announced today. Its editor, John Foreman, said a ''commitment to the farm economy'' was a major reason for becoming the first Illinois newspaper to do so.

title: Decades Later, Theories Still Hold
description: IN 1893, Santiago Ramon y Cajal, the Spanish neuroanatomist, outlined a general theory of memory that, in its essence, is almost identical to the one emerging today. Learning, he suggested, leaves its mark by making connections between neurons.

title: A Trading Halt Won't Calm the Market
description: To the Editor: The New York Stock Exchange is now considering a halt to all trading any time the market declines a specific amount, still to be determined. This will almost guarantee declines of the set amount as sellers rush to get out before the shutdown when there appears to be a major sell-off. This approach is just one more Band-Aid to help a seriously ill patient.

title: Grand Met Optician Deal
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain said today that it was buying a chain of optician superstores in the United States for $32 million. The 38 Eye and Tech superstores, in the Southwest and West, will be part of its Pearle Health Services unit, which is a retailer of eye-care products worldwide. Grand Met, a diversified company whose interests include hotels and beverages, said the purchase would complement its acquisition earlier this month of Vision Express, which runs 27 superstores in the Middle West. Eye and Tech had sales of $32 million in its last financial year.

title: Tecogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING Loss of a Library
description: Journals are being thrown out and two of seven employees have been transferred at the Department of Health and Human Services' Library and Information Center.

title: General American Investors Co reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The figure for March 31 is after capital gains distributions of $1.33 a share paid in December and 21 cents a share paid in February, and after income dividends of 34 cents a share paid in December and 1 cent a share paid in February.

title: Verit Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $583,000 and $554,000 from a litigation settlement and provision for possible losses regarding a dispute over the value of merchandise for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: United Insurance Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $123,000 and $195,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Is to Decide Today on Davis Jury
description: The judge in the trial of Larry Davis, who is charged with the attempted murder of nine police officers, said yesterday that he would rule today on how jury selection is to proceed.

title: Refinery Worker Identified
description: Forensic specialists identified another body today from the Shell Oil Company refinery explosion, and emergency crews searched for a final missing person, company officials said. The dead man was identified as Roland Satterlee, 35 year old, of LaPlace, said Sarah Colletti, a Shell spokeswoman. Six Shell employees are known dead and 42 were injured when the gasoline-refining unit blew up here and caught fire before dawn Thursday. A seventh Shell worker has yet to be found.

title: Indentix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
La Quinta Realty reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings are in cents a unit.

title: Federal Aid for Destitute Reaching Just Half of Those Eligible
description: A Federal program for the destitute is reaching only about half the elderly, blind or disabled people who are eligible, according to lawmakers who have studied it.

title: Maputo Journal: In Marx's Garden: Atheism Wilts, Faith Blooms
description: At the corner of Vladimir Lenin and Mao Zedong Avenues, hundreds of Mozambican students swarmed noisily out of classes, happy to be out in the sunshine after an afternoon spent memorizing a universal doctrine.

title: Echo Bay Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. Corrected from Thursday, May 5, editions.

title: Alternative to Bus Terminal: Food and a Place to Relax
description: It took a couple of hours for the word to get out on the street that a new drop-in center for the homeless had opened in the red-brick storefront across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan.

title: Capital Southwest Corp reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. Year-ago results are restated for cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Laurentian Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital gain of $461,000. c-Net income and after a capital gain of $784,000.

title: Poland's Avoidable Crisis
description: LEAD: The current round of protests and strikes in Poland may be entering the final stage. Even so, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski can hardly sigh with relief. To most Poles, the unrest is proof that he has failed to deliver on his promises of genuine economic and political reform, and his recourse to force is a chilling reminder of the methods used to suppress social upheavals.

title: Scientists Identify 'Gate' in Brain as Crucial to Memory
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, in the early morning hours after a coronary bypass operation, a retired California postal worker suffered a sudden loss of blood to his brain. Although he survived with most of his faculties intact, the patient - known in the annals of neurology as R. B. - lost his ability to form memories.

title: Metro Datelines; Livery Driver Killed In Robbery in Bronx
description: A livery taxicab driver was shot to death in the Bronx yesterday in an apparent robbery, the authorities said.

title: Devils' Coach Finds Support
description: Coach Jim Schoenfeld of the Devils did not feel exonerated today when the National Hockey League rescinded his suspension.

title: Senate Hopeful Greets Leaders Of Republicans
description: Hoping to avoid a debacle in the New York Senate race that could affect the Presidential contest, Vice President Bush's brother backed a little-known lawyer when the hopeful was introduced today to Republican leaders as their likely United States Senate candidate.

title: Clemens Strikes Again
description: Roger Clemens pitched a three-hitter tonight, striking out 16 and retiring 24 in a row at one point, as the Boston Red Sox beat Mark Gubicza and the Kansas City Royals, 2-0.

title: Graphic Packaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Restroom Inequity: Evidence and Solution
description: AS any woman who has tried to use restrooms in airports, movie houses and theaters knows all too well, men's and women's lavatories are not allocated according to need and use patterns. Now, a Cornell engineering student has carefully documented this inequity and developed a computer program to help future designers prevent the lines outside women's rooms.

title: Joule Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-After a gain of $700,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: Maxtor Offers Erasable Drives
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer hard disks, today introduced two erasable optical disk drives that it said offer the highest capacity and performance available. Scheduled to be shipped in September, the drives are priced in quantity at $1,000 for the 3 1/2-inch model and $2,500 for the 5 1/4-inch model, both industry-standard sizes for hard disks.

title: American Fructose Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing Clean as a Whistle
description: Attention, whistle blowers! Somebody out there appreciates you -somebody named Michael Cavallo, a money manager who lives in Cambridge, Mass. He has created a foundation to reward people who report wrongdoing in government and business with $10,000 prizes.

title: Norway Cuts Key Rate
description: Norway's central bank cut its major interest rate by half a percentage point today amid signs that the country's trade and inflation difficulties could be receding. The central bank cut its overnight lending rate to commercial banks to 13.3 percent from 13.8 percent and said it expected the banks to pass on the lower rate of borrowing to customers. The banks' high lending rates have been discouraging investment in Norwegian industry.

title: Alfa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $588,058 for the latest quarter and $357,359 for the year-earlier period.

title: Dow Ends Day Below 2,000 Level
description: Stock prices fell broadly for the fourth session in a row yesterday in continued lethargic trading and the Dow Jones industrial average fell below the important 2,000 level.

title: Sentence in Freeway Killing
description: A motorist who fired on a pickup truck in one of several highway shootings in the Los Angeles area last summer was sentenced today to serve up to life in prison for murder. The man, Ronald Elam, 28 years old, was sentenced by Superior Court Judge Madge Watai in connection with the death of Debbie Ann Scott, a 26-year-old mother of three, who was a passenger in the pickup.

title: Rebel Kurds Reportedly Kill 25 Turkish Villagers
description: In a dramatic resurgence of violence, Kurdish separatist guerrillas were reported today to have killed at least 25 civilians in two remote southeastern villages over the last three days.

title: House Leaders Call for Swift Passage of a Bill to Fight Illegal Drugs
description: Democratic and Republican leaders of the House of Representatives said today that they would try to win passage this year of a bill to combat the spread of illegal drugs in the United States.

title: Eye-Care Concern May Receive a Bid
description: Three members of the Sturman family who hold a combined 9.5 percent stake in the Cooper Companies said they were considering a proxy fight for control of the eye-care concern based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Continuing Care Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $18,000 for the year.

title: Koch Asks Smaller Cut In Arts Agency Budget
description: After meeting with his new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Mayor Koch reduced by a million dollars the $7 million cut he had earlier requested of the arts agency's budget for fiscal 1989, but the Commissioner, Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, said today that she still finds the results ''exceedingly distressing.''

title: Walshire Assurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $27,490 and $23,459 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: LEADERS OF SENATE POSTPONE DEBATE ON MISSILE TREATY
description: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders said today that the new missile accord will not be brought to the Senate floor until the United States and the Soviet Union resolve important differences over monitoring compliance with the pact.

title: Japan Growth Outlook
description: Japan's gross national product is expected to grow at a rate of 4.1 percent in the fiscal year ending March 31, 1989, compared with the official target of 3.8 percent, the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. said in a statement.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Works by Sierra
description: Roberto Sierra's music has earned attention in competitions and worthwhile commissions have come his way, but his cause was not ideally served by the Bronx Arts Ensemble concert of his works Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The bulk of the program was devoted to the chamber opera ''El Mensajero de Plata'' (''The Silver Messenger''), first performed two years ago by the Opera de Camara of Puerto Rico.

title: Athletics Capture Their 14th Straight
description: Jose Canseco hit his league-leading ninth home run and Bob Welch allowed four hits in eight-plus innings tonight as the Oakland Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 3-1, to extend their winning streak to 14 games, the longest in the major leagues in 11 years.

title: Oak Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,282,000 from a change in accounting principle and also included an $838,000 gain from discontinued operations.

title: Shrinking Companion For Very Fast Pulsar
description: A VERY rapid pulsar, a pulsating star that spins 622 times a second, has a companion that regularly eclipses the pulsar and itself appears to be ''evaporating,'' Princeton University scientists have found.

title: West Virginia Contests Put Presidential Bids in Shadow
description: There is no mistaking the season in Boone County, a coal-mining community just south of here where politics is practiced with gusto.

title: France's Financial Markets Now Unfazed by Mitterrand
description: When Socialist candidates win big in Europe, stock markets usually nose-dive, but the Paris Bourse bucked that historical tide and rose strongly today, the day after France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, won election to a new seven-year term.

title: Duriron Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company went public in June 1987.

title: General Employment Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NONPROFIT GROUPS FACE BROADER TAX ON SOME VENTURES
description: Despite protests from museums, hospitals and hundreds of other not-for-profit groups and institutions, the Reagan Administration today endorsed Congressional proposals to tax more income-producing activities carried on by tax-exempt organizations.

title: Tennis Notebook; European Swing A Break for Agassi
description: From the Italian Open this week through the men's singles final at Wimbledon on July 3, the focus of tennis will be in Europe. And that may be the best thing that could happen to Andre Agassi. There will undoubtedly be many more Americans jumping on the 18-year-old's bandwagon after he followed his victory in the United States clay-court championships with one in the Eagle Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills on Sunday.

title: Brinkmann Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Saudis Reportedly Map Changes for Aramco
description: Saudi Arabia is drafting a new charter for the Arabian American Oil Company, cutting its legal ties to the United States but seeking joint ventures with the four American oil companies that formerly owned the oil giant, an oil newsletter reported today.

title: U.S. Hostage Is Said to Fear a Rescue Effort
description: The greatest fear felt by Terry A. Anderson, one of nine Americans held hostage in Lebanon, is that commandos will attack his captors, an action that would lead to his death, a Frenchman who shared a cell with Mr. Anderson said today.

title: South Africa Suspends Another Publication
description: South Africa today suspended an anti-apartheid newspaper for a month under censorship laws.

title: Flow General Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter included a gain of $1,025,000 from the sale of a unit.

title: Confusion Reigns In Hockey Fiasco
description: IN the confusion of a Stanley Cup playoff game where the National Hockey League's own president could not be reached and the fill-in linesmen were wearing yellow warm-up jerseys, SportsChannel worked hard Sunday night to bring sanity to the craziness. At the end, though, the overall effect was that their announcers mirrored the confusion. Television may give us instant pictures, but it doesn't always provide instant answers.

title: Immunex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Philip Morris Offers 9% Issue
description: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $350 million of 9 percent notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.50 to yield 9.11 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

description: b-Net income

title: Sparton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fetisov Gets a Go-Ahead
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, perhaps the world's best hockey defenseman, has reportedly received permission from the Soviet national hockey coach, Viktor Tikhonov, to play in the National Hockey League.

title: Patterns
description: Charvet at Saks The house of Charvet, the grand old Parisian shirt maker, has reached an agreement with Saks Fifth Avenue to carry its line of men's shirts, ties and robes in New York and later in most Saks branches. The deal has been especially quiet and has surprised the fashion industry, because for many years the house has had an exclusive arrangement with Bergdorf Goodman, which will continue to carry Charvet goods.

title: Modern Bridge Design Attacked As Too Vulnerable to Corrosion
description: A FUROR has erupted in the world of bridge engineering over the long-term reliability of an innovative design that has come to dominate the modern generation of great bridges, all but replacing the traditional suspension bridge.

title: Careplus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $111,000.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Sounds of South Africa
description: Malombo, a South African trio led by Philip Tabane on guitar, finds worlds of music within the simplest structures. Most of the pieces Malombo played Friday night at Greenwich House would set a handful of chords and a melodic phrase or two over quasi-traditional rhythms from the Venda people of northern South Africa; Oupa Monareng played a set of standing drums and Raymond Phale added rattles, bells and other percussion. The drums, made from trunks of baobab trees, are used in Venda ceremonies to honor ancestral spirits; ''malombo'' means ''spirit.'' In the trio, however, the drumming is a backdrop for Mr. Tabane's poised, playful, cheerfully experimental guitar playing.

title: Workers Don't Have 'Parachutes,' Mr. President
description: To the Editor: The legitimacy of a government depends to a large extent on its ability to appear fair and evenhanded. A nation will accept a great deal of suffering if its citizens perceive that this suffering is both necessary and evenly distributed. When, however, an administration violates this rule of legitimacy, when it becomes the captive of a small, privileged interest group, its days are surely numbered.

title: Mesa Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shultz Plans New Middle East Peace Effort
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is going back to the Middle East in another effort to promote peace talks between Israel and its Arab neighbors, the State Department said today.

title: 3 Sizable Accounts For Symon & Hilliard
description: Symon & Hilliard has popped up with three new $1 million accounts. The General Electric Company, a client for eight years, has assigned it the GE Automotive business, which serves the auto industry. GE Automotive previously had no agency.

title: Constitutional Law Is Full of 'Contradictions'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hinderliter Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $86,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 9 months. c-Included tax credits of $400,000 for the quarter and $2.6 million for the 9 months.

title: Reputed New Jersey Mob Figure Is Reported Missing by His Wife
description: The wife of the reputed mob boss John DiGilio has reported him missing, and the authorities said today that his possible disappearance could be a result of organized-crime strife, punishment for his outspokenness or a ploy in connection with his approaching sentencing for a loan-sharking conviction.

title: G.M. and Toyota Join in Australia
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation have signed agreements to join forces in Australia. The Australian divisions of the Japanese and United States giants will share several models to be sold under their brands - a move forced by the Government's decision to restructure the country's auto industry.

title: Harper Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reagan View on Pardons Related
description: A newspaper columnist says President Reagan told him he had ruled out the possibility of pardons before trial for any of the defendants in the Iran-contra case.

title: Suffolk Legislators Set to Vote on Video-Terminal Bill
description: Suffolk County legislators, facing stiff opposition from business leaders who fear companies may flee Long Island, are expected to vote on a bill Tuesday that would regulate the use of video-display terminals in the work place.

title: A.T.&T. Displays Midsize Computer
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced a new mid-range computer as well as some enhancements to its Starlan computer communications network. A.T.&T.'s new 3B2/700 mid-range computer could support up to 80 users at once and it could process up to nine million instructions a second, company officials said at a news conference. They also said the new software for the Starlan local area network would allow the communications system to respond twice as quickly to user commands.

title: Murray Ohio's Chief In Another Struggle
description: John L. Duncan, president and chief executive of the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, had finally solidified his position last year as the company's leader only to see the bicycle and lawn mower manufacturer put into play last week by a bid from A.B. Electrolux.

title: MDT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $82,000 for the quarter; the year includes a tax credit of $472,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $114,000 and $418,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said results reflect the acquisition of Castle Co. on July 2, 1987, and represent record sales and net income for any quarter and fiscal year.

title: Farr Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $338,000 from sale of property.

title: Owen Epstein, Lawyer, 36
description: Owen Epstein, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Meibach & Epstein, died of a brain tumor Saturday at New York University Medical Center, said Martha Katz, a spokeswoman for the firm. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Home Owners Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,742,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Ford's New Hiring Is First Since 70's
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was hiring new hourly workers at several United States plants for the first time in a decade. A spokesman, Tom Foote, said Ford had a ''smattering of new hires'' at plants in Plymouth, Wixom and Milan, Mich., and in St. Paul. He said the auto maker was running out of laid-off workers who have first rights to any jobs that become available.

title: Advantage Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $138,000 for the latest quarter and $21,000 for the year-earlier period.

description: b-Includes a gain of $600,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Edward van Westerborg, Publisher, 88
description: Edward van Westerborg, the founding publisher of Facts on File, died Saturday at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif., after suffering from cancer. He was 88 years old.

title: Three Reputed Mob Figures Are Being Tried Again
description: In opening statements at the second trial of Gene Gotti and two co-defendants, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday that the defendants were major figures in a racketeering and drug-trafficking operation. They were accused of supervising, managing and controlling heroin and cocaine distribution and sharing in the profits.

title: Badger Meter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Top Wings For 3-1 Series Lead
description: Jari Kurri's second goal of the game, his playoff-leading 12th, at 11 minutes 2 seconds of overtime tonight gave Edmonton a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. The victory put the Oilers one game away from the Stanley Cup final.

title: Atico Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results of operations for the latest quarter included the July 31, 1987 acquisition of 100 percent of Pan American Mortgage Corp. common stock and the Aug. 31, 1987 acquisition of 93 percent of Intercontinental Bank common stock.

Jack Henry & Associates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Champion Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-After charges of $829,000 and $2,973,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from a writeoff of prepaid income tax benefits.

title: INSIDE
description: White House Stars Cross Nancy Reagan will continue to consult her astrologer, but no one has to read the stars to know why the White House is angry at Donald T. Regan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., a holding company engaged in oil and gas, chemicals and fibers, said it had begun operating a pilot plant to make substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons that do not deplete the ozone.

title: Reverberations Felt as Regan Book Hits Market
description: Donald T. Regan's explosive book has lent a whole new meaning to the term ''Star Wars,'' and the sounds of battle continue to echo through the capital.

title: BHA Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eldorado Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect the 10 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 4, 1987.

title: United Healthcare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In Lizards, Eggs' Heat Linked to Behavior
description: ZOOLOGISTS have known for several years that the sex of certain reptiles is determined by the temperature at which they are incubated in the egg. But in a new development, University of Texas scientists have found that incubation temperatures can profoundly influence adult behavior as well.

title: Olympic Notebook; Korean-American Worries About Site
description: Insook Bhushan, America's best female table tennis player, is uncomfortable about competing in the Seoul Olympics this year. But unlike other athletes, who have expressed concern about North Korea and terrorism, she is worried about South Korea and nationalism.

title: 13 Hostages Are Freed By Rebels in Colombia
description: Leftist guerrillas today released 13 of the 15 foreigners and journalists they kidnapped last week. The rest were expected to be freed soon.

title: Professional Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $116,000 and $97,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Astronomers Peer Deeper Into Cosmos
description: PEERING deeper into space and time, astronomers are detecting galaxies and hints of galaxies at distances where, in theory, they should not be, raising troubling questions about a concept that seemed to explain so much about the early universe.

title: The Candid Way to Defeat a Deficit
description: Mayor Koch, who won negative national notice for bombastic extravagance in the New York primary campaign, now serves himself and his city far better with fiscal frugality. The austere $25.2 billion 1989 New York City budget he proposed yesterday shows the outspoken Mayor at his candid best.

title: Bridge
description: The massed ranks of North American experts have always beaten back foreign invaders at the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs, but did not do so this year.

title: Kentucky Central Life Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $545,334. c-After capital gains of $767,491 and a tax credit of $954,176.

title: Gdansk Workers Reject Polish Offer to End Strike
description: Striking shipyard workers rejected a management compromise offer today, delivering a severe setback to Government efforts to peacefully end the week-old strike at the Lenin shipyard here.

title: U.S. Forest Service Ordered to Promote California Women
description: A Federal district judge today found the Secretary of Agriculture, Richard E. Lyng, in civil contempt for failing to carry out a plan for promoting women in the United States Forest Service in California.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,100,000 and a tax credit of $12,100,000.

title: First Fidelity
description: The First Fidelity Bancorp is offering $150 million of 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.925 to yield 9.765 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Noncallable, the notes yield about 96-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.&P.

title: U.S. Banks' Global Role
description: Robert Heller, a Federal Reserve Board governor, is urging United States banks to reverse a trend of shrinking their activities in international markets.

title: Patriots Cut Collins
description: Tony Collins, the veteran running back, was waived yesterday by the New England Patriots. No reason was given for the release of Collins, still the Patriots' best all-round running back. Collins was a patient in a drug rehabilitation clinic last year and was in one again last month, according to The Boston Globe. Collins, 28, became a free agent when his contract expired after last season. He is the third leading rusher in team history with 4,647 yards. Last season, he was the first Patriot regular to report to work during the National Football League players' strike and led the team with 474 rushing yards and 44 receptions.(AP)

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING Subway Advertising
description: And, speaking of White House books: just as interest in Donald Regan's revelations is peaking, an eye-catching advertisement for the unflattering book about the Reagan family by Michael Reagan, the President's adopted son, is appearing on more than 500,000 of the fare cards used by passengers on Washington's Metro subway system.

title: Mohasco Accepts Bid Valued at $507 Million
description: The Mohasco Corporation, a manufacturer and distributor of carpeting and furniture, announced yesterday that it had agreed to a takeover by the MHS Holdings Corporation in a deal valued at more than $507 million.

description: b-Includes income of $100,000, or 7 cents a share, related to a 1986 grant by the company of a non-exclusive licensing agreement for neodymium technology. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect the company's March 25, 1988, 1-for-3 reverse stock split.

title: Green Mountain Power Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was a moment, a mood, when I felt we were broken. But the mood is changing; people are coming back. Wives are listening to the radio, and telling their husbands: 'You cannot leave them alone. Go back, go back.' '' Lech Walesa, addressing strikers in Gdansk. [ A10:1. ]

title: Careers; High Grades A Corporate Fetish, Still
description: ''WE want only the best and the brightest.'' This has become a cliche whenever corporate personnel directors look for new graduates with a bachelor's or master's degree.

title: Redeem New York's Bottle Bill for Litter Control and Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Burial Site to Remain Intact Under a New Federal Policy
description: An 18th-century graveyard on the grounds of a new United States Forest Service campground will be left intact because of a trial policy adopted this year to recognize the religious views of American Indians.

title: A JEW IS ELECTED AT UNION SEMINARY
description: Union Theological Seminary yesterday named Peggy Tishman, a leader in Jewish philanthropic work, as the first non-Christian trustee since it was founded in 1836 as a Presbyterian school.

title: Identifying Crime Suspects
description: False identifications in police lineups could be reduced by as much as 50 percent if witnesses viewed the possible suspects one at a time instead of all at once, according to a new study.

title: Darman Foresees No Return of Fixed Exchange Rates
description: Richard G. Darman, the former Deputy Treasury Secretary who shaped much of the Administration's current dollar policy, said today that he sees little likelihood that countries will return to the old system of rigidly fixed exchange rates.

title: Publishing Schedules Speeded on Regan Book
description: The disclosure in Donald T. Regan's new book that Nancy Reagan regularly consulted an astrologer about the scheduling of major Presidential activities would likely have created headlines whenever the news broke. But when Newsweek reported it last week, it not only generated headlines but caused considerable scrambling at Time and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.
