title: Gdansk Strikers Reject an Offer
description: Striking workers at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, rejected a management compromise offer yesterday, delivering a severe setback to Government efforts to end the week-old shipyard strike peacefully.

title: Eldec Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $1,153,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Rutgers Players Mourn a Teammate
description: Doug Kokoskie looks for answers in his dormitory room at Rutgers University, but they are not there. He peers out the window, stares at the ceiling and finds nothing. He is not alone. It is difficult, if not impossible, to explain the death of a young person.

description: Watching the changing images of ''Arrivals and Departures'' was like dreaming, or remembering. And dreams and memories were among the subjects of the enigmatic and often beautiful mixed-media event presented Friday night at La Mama.

General Mills To Pick Bids For 2 Units
description: Within the next week, General Mills Inc. will select the successful bidder or bidders for its two retailing divisions and concentrate its attention, for the first time in years, on its basic businesses of manufacturing cereal and operating restaurants.

title: Panama Banks Reopen Under New Constraints
description: Banks here opened under close restrictions today in an effort by the military Government to make enough cash available to the public to permit a limited return to normal of economic activity.

title: Education Secretary to Depart in Mid-September
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, a frequent critic of low standards in the nation's schools and colleges, announced today that he would leave the Cabinet in mid-September.

title: Charles Pollock, Abstract Painter And Brother of Jackson, Dies at 86
description: Charles Pollock, a distinguished painter and teacher and the oldest brother of Jackson Pollock, died of complications following a stroke Sunday in Paris. He was 86 years old.

title: Diamond-Star Output
description: Diamond-Star Motors will begin production of its new sports coupe in the first week of September, two months ahead of schedule, officials said today. Construction at the new $650 million Diamond-Star plant - a joint venture of the Chrysler Corporation and Mitsubishi Motors - was completed several months early, the company said. The plant will build a coupe for the 1989 model year. Prices for the car, which Chrysler will market as the Plymouth Laser, will start at less than $10,000.

title: Rolls-Royce U.S. Sales
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that United States sales of its Rolls-Royce and Bentley luxury cars jumped 6.4 percent in the first four months of the year. The British company's American subsidiary said it had sold 349 cars in the United States, up from 328 in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Senators Want U.S. To Fight 'Crisis' of Drunken Driving
description: Ninety-nine senators asked Surgeon General C. Everett Koop today to declare drunken driving a ''national crisis,'' but Dr. Koop said he believed the problem was most effectively handled locally.

U.S. JURY CONVICTS 4 IN A FATAL SIEGE
description: A Federal jury today found four members of a polygamist clan guilty of 21 of 23 counts stemming from the bombing of a Mormon chapel and a 13-day standoff with the police that left an officer dead.

description: A Brooklyn woman who was arrested yesterday on drug charges was found to be carrying a duffle bag containing 5.6 pounds of crack, which had a street value of $300,000, the police said. The suspect, Eunice Palmer, was seized by undercover narcotics officers in front of 20 East 31st Street in the Flatbush section. She was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance, the police said.

title: John Calhoun, 88; A Longtime Fighter For Rights in South
description: John H. Calhoun, a civil rights leader in the South whose activism dated to the 1940's, died of respiratory failure in his sleep Friday at his home in Atlanta. He was 88 years old. Mr. Calhoun, who was an Atlanta City Councilman from 1974 until 1978, devoted most of his political energies to grass-roots organization among black people. To support himself and his family he held a variety of jobs, from janitor, dock worker and headwaiter to hospital administrator, insurance salesman and real estate broker. But his passion was politics.

description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Labor's Lost Power: 5-Year Decline of Strength Shows as Wages Barely Rise Despite a Falling Jobless Rate
description: In years gone by, an announcement that the civilian unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4 percent would have signaled the coming of big wage increases - sparked by growing competition among employers for a dwindling supply of workers. But clearly times have changed: despite some shortages, wages are barely rising and there are no signs that they will begin to soar.

title: 13,667 at Garden: Arena Foothold?
description: Madison Square Garden was two-thirds filled last night as a boisterous crowd of 13,667 spectators greeted Arena Football, played there for the first time.

title: Europe Sees Market Gain
description: Abolishing trade barriers within the European Community could bring a short-term increase in unemployment but more jobs, higher growth and lower prices thereafter, according to a study published today by the community's executive commission.

Forgiveness Becomes a Strategy in Hockey Imbroglio's Aftermath
description: The misadventures of Jim Schoenfeld, the New Jersey Devils' coach, and the National Hockey League continued yesterday afternoon. The league rescinded the suspension that Schoenfeld, with help from a New Jersey judge, was able to ignore the night before.

title: Sales Exceed $4 Billion at Top 100 Black-Owned Concerns
description: Bolstered by the results of a large New York investment concern, sales of the nation's leading black-owned industrial and service businesses rose to a record $4.1 billion last year, according to an annual survey being released today by Black Enterprise magazine.

title: Talks on Park End
description: Owners of the Chicago White Sox and representatives of the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority broke off negotiations yesterday without reaching agreement on a new stadium for the team. Vincent Petrini, a spokesman for deputy Gov. James Reilly, said the state had asked the White Sox owners, Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn, to put their negotiations with St. Petersburg, Fla., on hold. Officials of that city are working hard to lure the White Sox into a domed stadium being built there. (AP)

title: Typing for Adults
description: IF you've ever wondered why the names of so many computer products use nonstandard capitalization or punctuation, like WordStar, Compute! and dBASE, now we have an answer. It's a conspiracy to improve our typing skills.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of short-term floating-rate notes due on Nov. 10 at a price of par through various securities dealers. The size of the financing was increased from the original $350 million because of good investor demand.

title: Review/Music; San Francisco Virtuosi's French Flavor
description: Merkin Concert Hall became a curious geographical crossroads on Sunday afternoon - two Soviet emigres from San Francisco joining a New Yorker in music of late 19th- and 20th-century France. Those worrying whether Igor Shochetman (piano) and Leo Igudesman (violin) would bury French style under dour Soviet determination had only intermittent cause. Mr. Igudesman was usually able to adapt to this brighter, more pointed material. He is not an overpowering technician, but one admired the calm yet personal approach to the Franck Piano Sonata. The third movement's recitativo was deeply touching.

title: Moderate Quake in Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake struck parts of south-central Alaska early today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported. The temblor, which occurred at 8:33 A.M., measured 4.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion, the center reported, and was centered 20 miles northeast of Valdez.

description: Handsomely re-elected, President Francois Mitterrand now faces the hazardous challenge of anchoring France's politics at the center-left, softening the confrontation between his Socialist Party and a right that has been sundered in defeat.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 The new missile accord on medium- and short-range weapons will not be brought to the Senate floor until differences are resolved with Moscow about monitoring compliance, Senate leaders said. Page A1 The Soviet tradition of job security has not been shaken by Mikhail Gorbachev's new economic policies. Profits are still second to labor peace at a Black Sea port, where managers spent savings to placate workers. A1 Striking workers in Poland rejected an offer by management to end the strike at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk. The leadership of Solidarity appealed to Polish workers for actions in support of the strike. A10 Shimon Peres left Hungary after an overnight visit. Israel's Foreign Minister was the first top Israeli official to visit the Communist country since it broke diplomatic relations with Israel in 1967. A3 News analysis: Francois Mitterrand, re-elected to a second term as President of France, will seek tactical alliances between his Socialist Party and a slender conservative majority in the National Assembly. A3 Pope John Paul II warned bishops in Bolivia to protect Roman Catholics from evangelical preachers. He arrived in Bolivia for a five-day visit,the longest stop on his four-nation tour of Latin America. A19 Cash payments to the contras inside Nicaragua are planned by the Reagan Administration. Nicaragua has blocked deliveries to the rebels of food, clothing and medicine authorized by Congress. A17 A rebirth of religion in Mozambique, where an experiment with atheism failed to suppress a deep spirituality, is part of a wider reconciliation between church and state in other former Portuguese colonies. A4 American cigarette sales in Taiwan soared after Taiwan dropped stiff restrictions on foreign cigarettes. Taiwan says American advertising encourages teen-agers to smoke, but American companies deny the charge. D1 Syria says it will quell warfare outside Beirut A7 Kurds reportedly kill at least 25 Turkish civilians A8 Liberal South African paper fights for survival A10 NATIONAL A20-29, D24-25 Plans to end the tax-exempt status of some ventures run by charitable organizations were endorsed by the Reagan Administration. Not-for-profit groups are against the proposals, which a Congressional panel is considering. A1 News analysis: Wages are rising only slightly, despite low unemployment. The bargaining power of American labor has been so reduced that no one knows how low unemployment must drop before workers can demand and get higher pay. A1 Half of the destitute eligible for Federal aid are not receiving it, lawmakers who have studied the problem said. The number of people 65 years and older in the program, Supplemental Security Income, is declining. A21 The right to an abortion is vulnerable to challenge, according to opponents and proponents, who cite the changing makeup of the Supreme Court as the most obvious sign of that vulnerability. A20 Teacher shortages in urban schools have not been eased by rising enrollment in teacher education programs. Vacancies in inner-city schools are three times greater than in suburban and rural districts. A28 Santa Cruz journal: Surfing museum far east of Hawaii A20 Education Secretary to depart A26

title: Our Towns; Policing Odors With Fervor In 3,000 Malls
description: Whoever is in charge is making a mess of this spring, but Sure Air Ltd. is doing its best to keep weather condtions inside the malls lovely. Seven days a week, 24 hours a day, the company's 50 employees work the phones here, analyzing heating, air-conditioning, plumbing and electrical emergencies for 25,000 stores in 3,000 malls across this great nation.

title: Anticipating a Cabinet May Hurt a Candidate
description: To the Editor: I appreciate A. M. Rosenthal's suggestion (''One More Question,'' column, April 19) that Presidential candidates indicate what sort of people, or even name some specific people, they would want to head up important cabinet posts should they be elected. For a voter this would be important information about the candidate and could conceivably affect his voting decision.

title: Review/Music; Seattle Grabs Spotlight: New Play, Renewed Musical
description: Why should a New York theatergoer travel clear across the continent to see plays about the travails of being young, gifted and spoiled in chi-chi Manhattan? The answers are plentiful on Seattle's stages, where both the young playwright Richard Greenberg and the long-time musical-theater collaborators Stephen Sondheim and George Furth are on the verge of bringing their respectively stinging views of New York strivers, ''Eastern Standard'' and ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' to bracing fruition.

Now a prospective buyer has emerged, setting off a wave of local concern by announcing plans to turn the 28-room, tile-roofed villa into a corporate headquarters.

description: When Thomas J. Matthews took over as vice president of human resources for Eastern Airlines last June, he moved quickly to bring a more congenial atmosphere to labor relations.

title: Foyt's Ban Lifted
description: A six-month suspension imposed on A. J. Foyt was lifted by Nascar yesterday, eight days after the penalty was leveled following a fender-banging incident in the Winston 500. Les Richter, Nascar's vice president for competition, announced the decision following a review of an incident late in the race at Talladega, Ala. Richter was unavailable for comment on the reversal. While the suspension that would have sidelined Foyt for the remainder of the Nascar season was lifted, a fine of $5,000 was increased to $7,500, a statement by the organization said. Foyt, a part-time Nascar racer, was suspended and fined after a fender-banging incident with Alan Kulwicki under a caution flag. Both were black-flagged into the pits under Nascar's ''penalty box'' rule, which is designed to cool heated tempers. Foyt was black-flagged two more times, nearly hit a race official on pit road in a pass through the pits, and locked up his brakes and spun as he got near the exit to the garage area after being black-flagged for a third time.(AP)
