title: Reagan Endorsement of Bush Expected
description: Having adhered to his vow to remain neutral in the Republican Presidential campaign as long as the nominee was in doubt, President Reagan is expected to endorse Vice President Bush on Wednesday.

title: Corrosion on the Williamsburg Is Mainly on Approach Roads
description: The corrosion on the Williamsburg Bridge, while serious enough to keep the bridge closed after four weeks of inspections and repairs, is concentrated in an area that many people may not consider part of the bridge at all: the approach roadways.

title: Thrifty Rent-A-Car Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fairmount Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two Agencies Work Together In Water Rescue
description: A week after the New York City Police and Fire Departments erupted into a bitter dispute over their roles in a water rescue operation, the two departments worked together, with the Coast Guard, Sunday night to save a man who had thrown himself into the East River.

title: To-Fitness Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Review/Television; Dividing Up the Friends During a Divorce Ordeal
description: There's enough biting humor left in ''Who Gets the Friends?'' to indicate that still another made-for-television movie has been mangled in the network homogenization mills. This particular exercise in prime-time diversion, on CBS at 9 o'clock this evening, was made for CBS Entertainment Productions. Lila Garrett was producer, director and, with Sandy Krinski, co-writer of the film. Jill Clayburgh (''An Unmarried Woman'') stars as Vikki Baron, who discovers that her husband, a doctor, wants to leave her for a Scandinavian beauty half her age. Vikki and Buddy (James Farentino) have been married for 17 years and have one precociously level-headed daughter.

title: U.S. Oil Rig Count Up
description: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs rose by 17 last week, to a total of 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 767 a year ago, Baker Hughes said.

title: Edward A. Kelley, Consultant, 54
description: Edward A. Kelley, a pharmaceutical marketing consultant, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 54 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is it that spiders don't get caught in their own webs? A. Nobody knows, because nobody has investigated it thoroughly, according to Dr. Herbert Levi, professor of zoology at Harvard University. ''I don't know of anybody who has worked on this,'' agreed Dr. William Mitchell Masters, assistant professor of zoology at Ohio State University, who has studied how fast spiders can run across their webs and how well they detect vibrations through the web. ''I'm not sure why no one has studied it,'' he added. ''It's an interesting question.''

title: Music Noted in Brief; A Sylvan Anniversary
description: The Sylvan Winds were founded in 1976, but on Friday evening at Town Hall the ensemble offered what it called its 10th-anniversary gala - apparently counting its age from the first time it offered a formal subscription series rather than from its birth. The group's playing, fortunately, is more precise than its math, and about as creative.

title: Kaneb Energy Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Cabaret; A Torch for Harold Arlen
description: Jill Corey is a singer who stretches songs to their emotional breaking point but stops just short of turning heartbreak into histrionics. Miss Corey, who opened a two-week engagement singing an all-Harold Arlen program at Danny's Skylight Lounge (346 West 46th Street) last Thursday, is nothing at all like the perky ingenue who arrived on the pop scene in the mid-1950's chirping trivial novelties like ''I Love My Baby (My Baby Loves Me).'' Her voice has darkened and ripened, acquiring a vulnerable maturity that evokes an interesting mixture of Judy Garland and Rosemary Clooney.

title: The Captive Nation
description: The essence of what is going on in Poland, the root reality, is plain to see and known to every Pole. But outside Poland, in the stories and analyses and political dissections, it is almost never mentioned anymore. Why is that? Poland is a captive nation. Once, not long ago, that was not only known to Poles but acknowledged by the free nations, a fact accepted as a fact.

title: Dentsu Remains on Top Of Worldwide Rankings
description: Advertising Age yesterday published the rankings of the world's ad agencies for 1987, and Japan's Dentsu was again on top with $884.5 million in gross income and $6.78 billion in billings. Both figures were up more than 25 percent from 1986.

title: Cheever's Widow Suing to Stop Publication of Story Collection
description: Mary W. Cheever, the widow of John Cheever and the executor of his estate, said she would file suit this week in both Federal District Court and State Supreme Court in Manhattan to keep a small Chicago publishing house from bringing out ''The Uncollected Short Stories of John Cheever'' in September.

title: Beazer Clarifies Koppers Offer
description: In an effort to decrease opposition to its proposed takeover of the Koppers Company, Beazer P.L.C. yesterday provided details of its job-guarantee offer. It said last week that it would protect the job of every employee of the Pittsburgh-based company except senior management if Koppers agreed to a quick merger.

title: Koch Plans Cuts For Sanitation, Fire and Police
description: In a budget that could have implications for the mayoral election next year, Mayor Koch proposed a spending plan yesterday that would reduce the number of police officers, firefighters and sanitation workers but increase the number of employees in social services and education.

title: Treasury Chief Presses Bush Themes
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, a close but informal adviser to Vice President Bush, urged serious consideration today of proposals to prolong the school year and to let people work as long as they like before retiring.

title: 'Good' Mothers Feel Dark Urges
description: LEAD: It seems like every week now we hear of another young mother assaulting or even murdering her infant. A woman in the Bronx over the weekend, one in Brooklyn late last month. The incidents may seem inexplicable to many people, but not to me.

title: Quake Looms Off Alaska
description: Within 20 years a very large earthquake, rated magnitude 8.3 to 8.5 on the Richter scale of energy release, is likely to occur in a zone 125 to 150 miles long in the Shumagin Islands south of the Alaska Peninsula, according to scientists at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory. The earthquake that struck Anchorage and neighboring areas in 1964, killing 131 people, was rated magnitude 8.4. The findings by the scientists, a group led by Thomas Boyd, are described in the April 26 journal, Eos, of the American Geophysical Union.

title: Porta Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lucky Stores Gives Data to American
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had provided confidential information to American Stores Inc. in exchange for an agreement that American would sweeten or end its hostile takeover bid by May 17.

title: Civilization And Billy Martin
description: IT'S like feeling the earth tremble beneath your feet, and wondering if the entire sphere is about to crumble and swallow up all of civilized man, and some of the rest of us, too.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Protection for Dukakis

title: India-Penney Sales Drive Set
description: India, seeking to increase its share of the garment market in the United States, will soon begin its biggest American sales promotion drive ever, an Indian official said today. The executive director of the

title: Chicks Don Glasses for Vision Study
description: IF baby chickens wear ''defocusing'' eyeglasses, their eyes change shape as they grow to correct for the lenses' distorting effects, Cornell researchers have found.

title: Grubb & Ellis Realty Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
China to Issue 100-Yuan Bills
description: China will issue larger denomination bank notes, overcoming an eight-year fear of fueling inflation.

title: Yanks May Hire A Guard for Martin
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he was giving thought to providing Billy Martin with a full-time bodyguard on road trips, although he said his first concern was Martin's judgment. Steinbrenner questioned Martin's decision to patronize a topless bar, where the Yankee manager reported being beaten last weekend in Arlington, Tex.

title: Advanced Polymer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Unusually Large Output
description: The current issue of Books in Print, a catalogue of authors and titles, credits 64 books to Robert A. Heinlein, one of the country's most successful science-fiction writers. An in-print listing of 64 books is unusual, although some books are represented on the list more than once.

title: Modern Controls Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sikhs Battle Indian Soldiers In Temple and 5 Are Killed
description: Security forces fought a four-and-a-half-hour gun battle today with Sikh militants inside the Golden Temple here and more than 2,500 Government troops surrounded the 400-year-old Sikh shrine, the police reported.

title: New Top Editor at The Post Is Said to Have Been Chosen
description: Jane Amsterdam, founding editor of Manhattan,inc. and a senior editor at Alfred A. Knopf since January, will be named editor of The New York Post today, people at the newspaper said.

title: For Geoffrey Beene, 25 Years at the Top
description: Geoffrey Beene is the quiet one. He speaks slowly, in the mellifluous tones of his native Louisiana. Of medium height, with a shock of white hair, he fits nobody's image of the typical fashion designer. He has a tendency to fleshiness, intensified by his love for good food. He could be a professor at an obscure university or the doctor he once planned to be.

title: Ventrex Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mets' Mistakes Prove Costly
description: Gary Carter looked over in the direction of Sid Fernandez's locker and, politely as he could, confessed that he didn't have a clue as to what was going on in the young pitcher's mind lately. The look of concern on Carter's face, though, made it clear that he suspected what was going on in Fernandez's mind was probably a lot like what had taken place on the mound in recent weeks. In other words, not much that was good.

title: Lilco Seeks Albany's Help In Effort to Block Takeover
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company met limited success here today as he sought support for a negotiated settlement that would allow Lilco to remain a private, investor-owned utility in return for abandoning its $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: CR-PL Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Music Noted in Brief; Sevgi Tekin on Piano
description: Sevgi Tekin found her stride part way through the first movement of Schumann's big G minor piano sonata Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall, and what had begun as a well-schooled reading took on some momentum and inner rhythmic life. Miss Tekin, a native of Turkey who came to America following her graduation from the State Conservatory in Ankara five years ago, has a crisp, precise technique; she does not employ much variety of touch or color, but the mechanical challenges of Ravel's ''Gaspard de la nuit'' hold few terrors for her.

title: Jackson Looks Back at Insults Endured
description: It was shortly before 6 A.M. today, and slivers of sunlight seeped across the valley. An unemployed coal miner, Junior Cook, and his wife, Rebecca, had just completed breakfast in their frame house with an overnight guest.

title: RJR Nabisco Trims List Of Agencies
description: RJR NABISCO, one of the nation's leading advertisers, has consolidated its accounts at five agencies, from seven, with most of the cookie, confection and food business going to its tobacco agencies.

title: 15 Prime Minutes
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Utility to Freeze Its Rates
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, upstate New York's largest utility, has agreed to freeze electric rates until 1990 and to refund $14 million to its customers, the Cuomo administration said today.

title: G.O.P. Senate Hopeful Urges Meese To Resign
description: Pete Dawkins, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, called today for the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Staley Says It Has Begun Sale Talks
description: Staley Continental Inc. said yesterday that it had begun negotiating with one or more parties to sell all or part of the company. In addition, a Federal court issued an important ruling in the company's favor on Delaware's takeover law.

title: Chester Schwimmer, Ex-G.O.P. Leader, 75
description: Chester Schwimmer, a former leader of the Queens Republican Party, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, today at Deepdale Hospital in Queens. He was 75 years old and lived in Freeport, L.I.

title: City College Lacrosse Shock
description: Hector Munoz squinted through the dust, searching for a yellow flag resting among the many rocks on the City College lacrosse field. It had been nine years and 92 games since City had won a lacrosse match, and Munoz, the team's coach, just wanted to make sure he didn't celebrate prematurely.

title: Reviving the Art And Ritual of Tea
description: AMERICANS were tea drinkers before the Revolution.

title: Dataproducts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest year included costs of $8.1 million related to the acquisition of Imaging Solutions Inc. last July. The losses for the latest fourth quarter and year include one-time charges of $15.8 million reserved in the quarter for the planned relocation of the company's serial printer business and changing the company's foreign earnings reinvestment policy.

title: Police Evidence Counters Martin's Story; Yankees 17 White Sox 3
description: At 8:36 P.M., in the third inning of the Yankees' 32d game, on the third pitch of his 125th time at bat, Don Mattingly hit a home run last night. Finally. Ordinarily, a Mattingly home run would be nothing unusual. He had, after all, hit 123 home runs in his first five seasons, including 96 in the last three. That record, however, made his drought this season highly unusual.

title: Diagnostic Medical Instruents reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary credits of $4,000 for the quarter and $35,000 for the 6 months.

title: Burger King Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in cents a unit.

title: Dismissal Is Upheld In New Yorker Lawsuit
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the dismissal of a libel suit against The New Yorker magazine brought by a man who said he was unfairly portrayed in an article about another libel case.

title: Schoenfeld Upset By League Decision
description: Jim Schoenfeld left his disciplinary hearing after three hours, still uncertain of his coaching status, hustled to the visitors' locker room at Boston Garden to give his team the usual pre-game call to action.

title: Ciba Vision Gives Job To McCaffrey & McCall
description: McCaffrey & McCall, part of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, has become the first consumer agency for the Ciba Vision Corporation's Aosept, the country's best-selling contact lens disinfectant.

title: U.S. Panel Upholds a Shoreham Plan
description: A Federal licensing board today upheld a Lilco plan to use three centers as evacuation sites in case of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: Landmarks May Get New Rules
description: Sweeping changes in the way New York City designates landmarks will be proposed today by the Koch administration, which says that its new system would increase protection of potential landmarks and give owners a more certain idea of their properties' status.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Upset in Rome: Thierry Tulasne of France, ranked 67th in the world, defeated third-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday in a first-round match of the Italian Open.

title: Cargoes Adore a Vacuum
description: One of the best insulators against heat flow is a vacuum. The familiar thermos uses the principle: A vacuum is created between two walls of glass. This greatly reduces heat flow into or out of the bottle, keeping soup hot and apple juice cold.

title: Corvus Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,735,000 for the quarter and $3,239,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $1,114,000 and $2,557,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: 'STUFF AND NONSENSE!'
description: IN the Lewis Carroll wonderland of the National Hockey League, things get curiouser and curiouser.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charles Shackleford, the 6-foot-10-inch, 225-pound junior center at North Carolina State, announced yesterday he would give up his final season of college eligibility to enter the National Basketball Association draft in June. . . . In special ceremonies honoring the first class of inductees into the G.T.E. Academic All-America Hall of Fame yesterday at the Hotel Pierre, the athletic honorees were Pete Dawkins of West Point and Donn Moomaw of U.C.L.A. from the 1950's, both former football players; Bill Bradley of Princeton (basketball) and Merlin Olsen of Utah State (football) from the 1960's; and Pat Haden of Southern Cal (football) and Tom McMillen of Maryland (basketball) from the 1970's. . . . Bob Cousy, who had been director of operations for the International Basketball Association, has dropped his association with the league because, he said, his ''time and commitments'' won't permit him to remain involved. The I.B.A., a league for players under 6 feet 4 inches, originally had 10 teams.

title: Rugged Route for Pistons
description: During their first quarter-century representing the Motor City in pro basketball, the Detroit Pistons evoked bad jokes about flat tires, stalled engines and lemons from the assembly line.

title: Anthropologist, Retracing Steps After 3 Decades, Is Shocked by Change
description: Clifford Geertz, the anthropologist, tells the story of visiting a family in a Javanese town in Indonesia recently when his hosts, remembering that a young American had attended the wedding of their daughter three decades before, showed him a photograph of that event.

title: Consolidated Capital Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included a gain of $4,906,000 on the sale of property. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $579,000 and a gain of $1,336,000 on the sale of property.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on April 26 about the Eating Well column in The Living Section of April 20 misstated the amount of fat in three and a half ounces of beef sirloin. It is nine grams.

title: Impresario Is Back in Moscow, for Now
description: One of the most prominent Soviet cultural figures forced into exile for challenging artistic orthodoxy has returned to Moscow this week to help stage a play at the theater he founded.

title: Greek Violinist Wins Competition at Carnegie
description: Leonidas Kavakos, a 20-year-old resident of Greece, has been named winner of the Naumburg International Violin Competition. The finals took place Monday at Carnegie Hall.

title: About New York; On Each Lapel, A Small Badge Of Distinction
description: The badge of the conventioneer in midtown Manhattan is the name tag, and most of them tend to bore. Either they run along the strictly business lines of, say, ''Maurice Tiddlewhipple, Boise Cascade,'' or they take the casual, howdy approach, as in, ''Hello, I'm Sharon, Bayou La Batre.'' Given the dreariness of the usual identifications, then, it was arresting earlier this week to run across people festooned with chest labels that marked their achievements, such as ''bass fisherman'' or ''grower of largest squash'' or ''bubble gum blower.''

title: Sharpton Arrested in Queens on Warrant Stemming From Court Walkout Last Week
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a minister active in racial issues, was arrested in a Queens courthouse yesterday for having walked out of a Brooklyn courthouse last week during a hearing on charges stemming from a civil-disobedience demonstration.

title: First Home Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter earnings included a $119,436 gain on the sale of an apartment complex.

title: Police Dispute Martin Claim
description: Billy Martin's claim that he was assaulted in a bar last weekend was discounted by the police. Page B9.

title: Akzo-Du Pont Deal Ends 11-Year Fight
description: The Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V. and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced a surprise deal today ending what Akzo called ''the biggest industrial patents battle of this century.''

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor Big 3 Auto Stocks
description: Despite surprisingly robust car and truck sales so far this year and some stronger-than-expected earnings, investors have largely been undervaluing the shares of the Big Three domestic automobile companies, according to a growing number of analysts who follow the industry.

title: Edgcomb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,637,000 from an accounting change. The company said the latest first- quarter earnings improvement was because of improved selling prices in all major product groupings and resultant improved gross profit margins, which increased to 25.3 percent after a LIFO charge of $1,500,000 from 23.6 percent in the year-ago first quarter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., the aerospace, electronics and engineering company, appointed John W. Barter senior vice president for planning and finance. He will succeed Donald R. Kayser as chief financial officer when Mr. Kayser takes early retirement on July 1.

title: Entwistle Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Data Measurement Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Television; Lenny Bruce, on Stage Toward the End
description: Lenny Bruce can be seen on public television this evening, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock. That simple fact is bursting with social and cultural reverberations. Back in the 1960's, Mr. Bruce was embroiled in - his fans would say hounded by - a series of widely publicized obscenity trials that effectively ruined his career. ''The Lenny Bruce Performance Film'' was taped in August 1966, before an audience at Basin Street West in San Francisco, the one city where he was found not guilty. It was the performer's next-to-last stage appearance. Not long after, he died of a drug overdose at age 42.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Business Day on May 2, with a brief article about the week's major debt financings, incorrectly described a $64 million tax-exempt offering in Tennessee. The financing was by the Nashville and Davidson Counties Metropolitan Government.

title: Agency Orders Planes Examined for Cracks
description: The Government has ordered inspections for commercial Lockheed-382 cargo planes after tests on military versions of the plane, the C-130, found wing cracks that could cause the aircraft to crash.

title: Official Says Arafat Ordered Attacks Against U.S.
description: The United States has received reports that Yasir Arafat approved terrorist attacks on American targets in retaliation for the assassination of his top aide, a senior State Department official said today. Mr. Arafat denies the charge. The official, Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said the United States sent messages through several Arab governments, including Saudi Arabia and Jordan, warning Mr. Arafat not to attack American personnel or installations abroad in reprisal for the death of his top aide, Abu Jihad, the Palestine Liberation Organization's military commander. Abu Jihad was killed by unknown assailants, widely assumed to be Israeli agents, in Tunis last month. Reports Were Discussed

title: Bhopal Issue Of Sabotage
description: A report from a consulting firm hired by the Union Carbide Corporation said today that sabotage by a disgruntled employee, not negligence, had caused the deadly gas leak at a subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.

title: Tigers Snap Athletics' Streak
description: The longest major league winning streak in more than a decade came to an end at 14 tonight when the Oakland Athletics lost, 8-2, to the Detroit Tigers.

title: Audi's Goal For Japan Set
description: Volkswagen A.G.'s luxury car subsidiary, Audi A.G., said today that it plans a campaign to increase its Japanese sales.

title: 'Mail' to Close Saturday
description: ''Mail,'' a musical with book and lyrics by Jerry Colker and music by Michael Rupert, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street. The play, directed by Andrew Cadiff, will have run for 20 previews and 36 performances.

title: Shultz to Press Soviet on Arms Pact
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is taking his top arms control experts to Geneva for an intense effort to resolve verification issues blocking Senate approval of the new accord on medium-range nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: Global Natural President Quits
description: Global Natural Resources Inc. said John R. Dempsey, its president and chief executive since 1985, had resigned from both posts on Monday after an internal investigation begun last week uncovered what the company called ''a misuse of assets.''

title: KEY RATES
Warner in Deal to Acquire Lorimar
description: After several months of on-again, off-again negotiations, Warner Communications Inc. yesterday agreed to acquire the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the movie and television studio, in a stock transaction valued at $1.2 billion.

title: Allen Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of about $2.2 million for employment termination costs. c-Net income and after net of $12,000 from discontinued operations. In year-ago quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Books of the Times; The Little Traps of Life in Carver Story Collection
description: Where I'm Calling From New and Selected Stories By Raymond Carver 393 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

title: LeFrak Passage Out of Trump Book
description: Following a protest from Samuel J. LeFrak, Random House has excised a two-sentence reference to the developer from future printings of ''Trump: The Art of the Deal'' by Donald J. Trump and Tony Schwartz.

title: Romulus Journal; From Air Disaster, a Roadside Shrine
description: There is a wooden cross on the hillside, covered now with spring dandelions, and a small circle of tattered floral arrangments: drooping plastic floral sprays, a pot with an Easter lily, a handful of red carnations tossed loosely in the grass.

title: Calgene Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain of $188,000 from operating loss carryforwards for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Colgate Will Get A Part of Cotelle
description: Henkel KGaA and the Colgate-Palmolive Company will split up the French company Cotelle S.A. between them after a proposed joint venture failed. Henkel's board chairman, Helmut Sihler, told reporters that the French authorities would not allow each company to own half of Cotelle since they already had a joint share of almost 80 percent of the French household detergents market. The two groups had announced their intention to set up a joint production and sales venture in France last September.

title: Yields Rise In Treasury Note Sale
description: Bond prices rose and interest rates moved higher in the credit markets yesterday as the first part of the Treasury's three-part $26 billion mid-quarter refunding was met with less-than-enthusiastic demand.

title: Hyde Athletic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Medical Care International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $922,000 and $382,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Advance Reported in Superconducting Fibers
description: Stanford University scientists have developed tiny superconducting fibers that can carry fairly large electrical currents, a development that is another small step toward the commercialization of the new materials that conduct electricity with no loss to resistance.

title: Mercury General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $84,000 and $18,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE versatile leek is one of the oldest known cultivated vegetables. There is much dispute about its origin, but it is known that leeks were grown by the ancient Egyptians, and evidently were much revered. The food historian Waverly Root recounted that an Egyptian of the time wrote, perhaps jocularly, that ''onions are adored and leeks are gods.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Do Not Disturb
description: The lawmakers working on the trade-accord legislation are not the only ones who are keeping the door shut.

title: Among Records, A Record Holder
description: IT was a sweltering day in the Peruvian jungle last year when Ashrita Furman jumped into the Amazon River with his pogo stick and made history. Unperturbed by reports of piranhas nearby, for 3 hours and 40 minutes he bounced from the river's clay bottom to its surface, eight feet above, setting a world record in aqua pogo.

title: Douglas & Lomason Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an accounting change that increased net earnings by $660,000, or 32 cents a share.

title: Campeau Reportedly Seeks Cutbacks at Bloomingdale's
description: Urging all Federated Department Stores divisions to streamline their operations, Robert Campeau has ordered Bloomingdale's to reduce its annual operating costs by $60 million through various economies, including staff cutbacks, executives in the retailing industry said yesterday.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE Bordeaux wine trade, faced with a backlog of wine and mounting price resistance from American consumers and importers, is dropping prices for the 1987 vintage an average of 30 percent below 1986 vintage levels.

title: Comdial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Diversified Investment Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wilfred American Educational reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thermedics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $317,000 and $96,000 from repurchase of debentures for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Bridge
description: Most of the players in the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs last weekend had enough of the card tables after two days of intense competition. But some persevered Monday night in the Cavendish Charity Teams.

title: Car Imports Up in Japan
description: Sales of foreign cars in Japan rose 40.1 percent in April from a year earlier, to 10,675, marking the 52d successive monthly year-to-year gain and a record high for the month, an official of the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.

title: Basix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $21,678,000 for the quarter and $30,282,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,272,000 and $499,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest fourth- quarter loss included a $1.4 million writedown in the value of oil and gas properties and a $3.6 million charge for reversal of long-term prepaid taxes. Prior year loss included a $21.6 million writedown in the value of oil and gas properties.

title: Handy & Harman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $2.8 million gain from adoption of FASB No. 96, which is accounting for income taxes.

title: Zayre Names Chairman For Its Troubled Stores
description: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that it had named Herbert J. Zarkin chairman of its largest unit, Zayre Stores.

title: Knight Moves?
description: Bobby Knight, the Indiana basketball caoch, traveled to the University of New Mexico yesterday to talk with school officials there about the vacant coaching job, an Indiana official said.

title: Equicor's President Moves Into Top Post
description: William T. Hjorth has been named chief executive of Equicor, a joint health-care venture of the Hospital Corporation of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: Making Computers Compatible
description: The barriers that separate different brands of desktop computers, like the Macintosh and I.B.M. PC, are being torn down by a new type of software that permits one computer to emulate the functions of another.

title: 'Colonus' to Close
description: ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' a musical by Lee Breuer based on Robert Fitzgerald's version of Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus,'' will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The show, directed by Mr. Breuer, with music by Bob Telson, will have run for 15 previews and 61 regular performances.

title: A Degas Sets Price Record: $10.2 Million
description: Edgar Degas's ''Little Dancer at 14 Years of Age,'' a bronze of the artist's 1881 wax sculpture of a bold young dancer in a relaxed pose, was sold last night for $10.12 million, a record at auction for the artist and for any sculpture. The buyer, was identified only as a Euorpean.

title: Double Standards
description: To The Living Section:

title: Soviet Loan From West
description: Moscow has arranged a new loan for 3.5 billion marks, or $2.1 billion, from the West and is likely to make additional requests for help in modernizing its industries, the head of West Germany's largest commercial bank said today.

title: Beverly Sills Announces She Will Retire on Jan. 1
description: Beverly Sills, who has revitalized the New York City Opera since she became the company's general director in 1979, announced yesterday that she would retire from the post effective Jan. 1.

title: Esprit Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Somalia Loans Barred
description: Somalia was added today to the list of countries that may no longer borrow from the International Monetary Fund because of overdue payments on previous loans. The East African republic owes the fund about $37 million. Other countries on the list are Vietnam, Liberia, Peru, Sierra Leone, Guyana, the Sudan and Zambia.

title: Public Administrator Is Chosen
description: The two Surrogate Court judges in Manhattan have chosen Ethel Griffin, a member of the State Assembly's legal staff, as public administrator of New York County, a court official said yesterday.

title: Garan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Activated Don Aase, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Released Tito Landrum, outfielder. SEATTLE (AL) - Called up Edgar Martinez, infielder, from Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. Placed Mario Diaz, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. PHOENIX (PCL) - Announced the retirement of Ed Lynch, pitcher. YANKEES - Activated Neil Allen, pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list. Placed Chris Chambliss, first baseman, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. BASKETBALL PHOENIX (NBA) - Named Cotton Fitzsimmons head coach and Paul Westphal assistant coach. WORLD BASKETBALL LEAGUE -Announced that Bob Cousy, director of basketball operations, has ended his association with the league. COLLEGES ARIZONA STATE - Named Lovie Smith outside-linebackers' coach. BROWN - Announced the resignation of Jean Elliott, sports-information director, so she may take the same position at William & Mary. ILLINOIS - Extended the contract of Lou Henson, men's basketball coach, through the 1989-90 season. NEW YORK UNIVERSITY - Announced the resignation of Mike Fouchet, assistant women's basketball coach. WISCONSIN-EAU CLAIRE-Named Lisa Anderson women's basketball coach.

title: Sentence in Freeway Killing
description: A motorist convicted of firing on a pickup truck in one of several highway shootings in the Los Angeles area last summer was sentenced Monday to serve up to life in prison for murder. The man, Ronald Elam, 28 years old, was sentenced by Superior Court Judge Madge Watai in connection with the death of Debbie Ann Scott.

title: Perini Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jazz Stun Lakers
description: Karl Malone scored 18 of his 29 points in the second half tonight to lead the Utah Jazz to a 101-97 upset of the Los Angeles Lakers in .their Western Conference semifinal playoff.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS Five large Wall Street firms suspended program trading for their own accounts, in a move intended to restore investor confidence in the stock market. The firms involved are Morgan Stanley; Salomon; Bear, Stearns; Paine Webber, and Kidder, Peabody. Index-arbitrage trading has come under intense criticism as a leading cause of volatility in stock prices. [ Page A1. ] Bond prices rose and interest rates moved higher as the first part of the Treasury's three-part refunding met with a less-than-enthusiastic reception. The new three-year notes were auctioned at an average yield of 8.23 percent, up from 7.91 percent a year ago and the highest since 8.74 percent on Nov. 19, 1985. [ D1. ] Trading in stocks was cautious and slow, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining enough to put it barely back above the 2,000 level. The Dow rose 6.30 points, to close at 2,003.65. Volume was 131.2 million shares, the fourth-lowest this year. [ D6. ] The dollar weakened against most currencies in quiet trading and the British pound continued to climb. Gold prices rose again, closing at $450.10 an ounce, up $2.80, on the Comex. [ D14. ] Soybean futures advanced in price for the fourth straight session. [ D14. ] COMPANIES Warner Communciations will acquire Lorimar-Telepictures in a stock transaction valued at $1.2 billion. Lorimar is a leading producer of prime-time television programming and also has considerable clout in international television distribution. [ D1. ] First Boston and Credit Suisse are talking about a revamping of their joint venture, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. ''A global investment banking firm'' and a restructuring of ownership are being considered. [ D1. ] Bloomingdale's was ordered to cut costs by $60 million a year, as the new owner of Federated Department Stores urged all divisions to streamline operations, industry executives said. [ D1. ] A new player entered the battle for Allegheny International. Bennett S. LeBow, the chairman of Western Union, said he would cooperate with others in a takeover attempt. [ D1. ] A court ruled that U S West engaged in discriminatory pricing to win Government phone contracts. [ D3. ] The New York weekly 7 Days appears to be passing its initial tests after its first seven issues. [ D16. ] Du Pont and Akzo have ended an 11-year patent battle over the superstrong aramid fiber. [ D3. ] Affiliated Publications Inc. reported a loss of $14.4 million for the first quarter. [ D16. ] The attitudes of consumers over age 50 are being misjudged by marketers, a survey has concluded. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY Criminal charges will not be sought against Fernand St Germain, the chairman of the House Banking Committee who has been under investigation over his relations with lobbyists. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL The trade bill will go to the White House today, the Congressional leadership agreed. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY Barriers between brands of desktop computers are falling. A new type of software permits one computer to emulate the functions of another. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Has Mikhail Gorbachev fallen victim to voodoo economics? His goal of bringing about change without harming living standards is proving impossible. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Shares of the Big Three auto makers are undervalued, in the view of a number of analysts who contend that investors have not taken account of changes in the industry. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Lacrosse Notebook; Deciding on Teams for the Tournaments
description: After Middlebury beat Williams, 11-6, to win the New England small-college championship last Sunday, the Panthers' coach, Jim Grube, had no time to celebrate.

title: GardenAmerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $662,000 from an accounting change.

title: Tootsie Roll Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Uncertainty Over Astrologer
description: The White House said today that it has been ''a couple of months'' since Nancy Reagan was last in touch with her astrologer, and that it was uncertain whether Mrs. Reagan would be in touch with the astrologer again.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Speech is the basic skill overlooked by many who urge a return to the Three R's. The ability to speak clearly and persuasively, and to think on one's feet, can be as vital to success as reading and writing. Beginning with the job interview, speech classifies a person.

title: Laurence Sickman, Scholar and Expert In the Art of China
description: Laurence Sickman, a connoisseur and scholar of Chinese art who built one of the world's best collections of Chinese paintings, sculpture and furniture at the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery and Atkins Museum of Fine Arts in Kansas City, Mo., died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City. He was 81 years old. It was in the early 1930's, as a recent graduate of Harvard University, that Mr. Sickman established himself in the field. In those years, he traveled throughout China, seeking out and buying the works of art that have since made the museum a leading center for study.

title: Liggett Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect the pro-forma effect of the acquisition of Liggett Group by L Holdings Inc. as if the acquisition had occurred April 1, 1986, instead of Oct. 27, 1986, and to reflect the subsequent public stock offering as if it had occurred in October 1986 instead of Oct. 8, 1987. The historical net income for the 3 months was thus increased by $1.5 million. The prior year results are presented pro forma in connection with the acquisition of the company by L Holdings. Historical net income was thus increased by $8 million.

title: Expeditors International of Washington reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Havana Journal; The Castro Report Card: 'Shows Improvement'
description: A little more than a year and a half ago, when Elizardo Sanchez made the mistake of talking to two foreign journalists about human rights in Cuba, he was taken off to jail. The reporters were expelled.

title: The I.N.F. Treaty: Moscow's Move
description: A thicket of problems suddenly threatens the U.S.-Soviet pact to withdraw medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe. The pact, a centerpiece of Reagan Administration diplomacy, may die in the Senate if the latest dispute cannot be resolved by Secretary of State Shultz and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in Geneva this week.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Secret Law?
description: Writing laws is something that Congressional committees almost always do in open session. An exception is occurring this month as the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance committees are meeting with Reagan Administration officials to draft legislation to carry out the Canadian Free Trade Agreement, which both governments signed last January.

title: What's Next for the Corporate Woman?
description: NOT long ago, Rennie Roberts was rummaging through a stack of books she had accumulated over the years. She picked out a dusty copy of ''Games Mother Never Taught You,'' Betty L. Harragan's 1976 best seller, which gave women hoping to move up the managerial ladder tips on such concerns as how to dress, when to drink with colleagues and how to handle intraoffice relationships.

title: Zygo Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Weigh-Tronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
E.P.A. to Relax Rules on Microbe Tests
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing new rules that would be the first tentative steps toward relaxing restrictions on small field tests of living, genetically altered microorganisms.

title: Democrats Begin Debating Platform
description: The Democratic Party set to work today on a 1988 platform but quickly ran into disagreement between the camps of its Presidential candidates on how detailed the document should be.

title: Jackson Is Top Rookie
description: In the 35 years it has been given out, the National Basketball Association rookie-of-the-year award almost always went to a player who was a high first-round draft choice, and, in recent years, usually one with a rich long-term contract.

title: Making Reservations
description: To The Living Section:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: The Pop Life
description: A Sondheim Surge

title: Xerox to Eliminate 800 Marketing Jobs
description: The Xerox Corporation, the giant copier company, said that its United States marketing group would eliminate about 800 jobs. The company said that as many employees as possible would be reassigned to other Xerox operations and that it hoped to avoid layoffs.

title: For the Michelin, A Secret Mission In West Germany
description: ''THE paprika sauce,'' said the luncheon guest, dropping his voice and glancing around, ''is of a thin consistency.'' His companion nodded sympathetically. ''The rabbit is not very exciting,'' he whispered back.

title: Mexican Inflation Slows
description: Prices in Mexico rose 3.1 percent in April, which was less than the 5.1 percent increase in March, the Banco de Mexico reported today. Inflation in the 12 months ended April 30 was 161.3 percent, the central bank added.

title: Casting Out a Plague of Speculation
description: LEAD: Since Oct. 19, we've reaped a rich harvest of generally excellent reports on what caused the crash on Wall Street.

title: SINHALESE GROUP TO END INSURGENCY
description: The Government signed a peace accord today with an ethnic Sinhalese group that has conducted a guerrilla campaign in which at least 260 people have died, officials announced.

title: Review/Performance Art; Beckley Runs in Place
description: The Winter Garden is a vast new indoor public space that is part of the still uncompleted World Financial Center at Battery Park City. Since March, the center's arts and events program has been sponsoring a series of free lunchtime and early evening performance events of various sorts there. Yesterday at noon the composer, painter and performance artist Connie Beckley presented a piece that will be repeated this evening at 6 o'clock.

title: Rebels Leave Mozambique A Bloodied and Fallow Land
description: When the East African sun sinks below the savannah, workers at a cotton mill here vanish into the elephant grass, fleeing the invisible shadow of a brutal rebel group that has reduced this town and this land to dependence on foreign charity for survival.

title: American Travellers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lincoln Logs reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Ad Industry Faulted on Over-50's
description: Advertising agencies and consumer products companies routinely underestimate the willingness of consumers over the age of 50 to try new products and overestimate the effectiveness of many marketing techniques, according to a survey released yesterday by Donnelly Marketing, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.

title: FHP International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Joyce Brown Faints At Manhattan Hotel And Is Hospitalized
description: Joyce Brown, the former homeless woman who challenged the Koch administration's effort to remove her from the streets against her will, was hospitalized yesterday after collapsing in the residential hotel where she lives.

title: Two Views on a Schism in the Middle East
description: The drama of Israeli-Arab relations is played out every day on American television. Bits and pieces emerge in sound and color. ''Worldview,'' on the CUNY cable channel today and tonight at 11 A.M., 4 P.M. and 9 P.M., tries to make the bits and pieces fall in place. It makes no concessions to viewers; some stretches are long and leaden. Stay with it the full two hours, however, and you will be enriched.

title: Heart Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Customedix reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $322,550 and $500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $209,000 for the quarter and $836,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary gain of $1,394,959 from a debenture exchange. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9 months included a $1,013,000 benefit reflecting a change to FIFO accounting method at Jeneric Industries, which was acquired Dec. 29, 1986.

title: Elcor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $208,000 for the quarter and $619,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $695,000 and $3,638,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Fabricland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Barnwell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; Ralph Lemon's Stories
description: The idiotically entitled ''3-D'' series opened last night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) with a performance by the Ralph Lemon Dance Company that suggested this two-week series, featuring 11 other companies, may be a serious contender in the current dance fray.

title: North Refuses to Give Panel All of His Notes
description: Oliver L. North invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination today in refusing to turn over to Congressional investigators nearly 3,000 pages of notes he made while he was a key White House operative in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Affiliated Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's loss was after booking Affiliated Publications' $25,272,000 share of losses at McCaw Communications Cos. Before booking its share of McCaw's losses, Affiliated reported income from consolidated operations of $10,895,000, or 32 cents a share, compared with $10,999,000, or 31 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The company said a year-ago it's share of McCaw's losses reduced its net by $2,231,000.

title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution To Condemn the Israeli Raid
description: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have condemned what it called the ''invasion by Israeli forces of southern Lebanon'' for two days last week. It also would have called for the ''immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces'' from southern Lebanon.

title: Upper Peninsula Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tylan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $476,000 of equity in income of joint venture, compared with a similar loss of $1,771,000 a year ago. c-Net loss and includes for the quarter $1,388,000 of equity in loss of a joint venture and non-recurring losses of $2.8 million, including a Nippon Tylan writedown of $1.4 million.

title: Afghan President Plans Visit To Arms Conference at U.N.
description: The Afghan leader, Najibullah, will come to New York next month for a General Assembly session on disarmament, a United Nations official said today.

title: Prosecutors Allowed to Fight Ruling on Jurors in Davis Trial
description: The trial of Larry Davis was adjourned yesterday until Monday to allow the prosecution to appeal a judge's decision on jury selection.

title: Lear Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1.1 million attributable to the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Food Notes
description: Cajun Recipes in Braille

title: Makeup: Out of the Bathroom, Onto a Bus
description: MASCARA wands in hand, women are increasingly puncturing the rules of etiquette by applying makeup en route to jobs and appointments. No form of transportation seems to be exempt, no place too public, say observers of social behavior.

title: Quantum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $13,200,000 representing 5 1/4-inch disk drive capacity. c-Net income

title: Image of a Senator: D'Amato Sticks to Local Interests
description: Two years into his second term, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, confident, brash and popular, appears to be redefining what it means to be a New York Senator.

title: U.S. Says Laos Government Is Deeply Involved in Drugs
description: Federal officials in New York expressed concern yesterday about mounting evidence that the Government of Laos was heavily involved in the production and export of heroin, including highly pure Southeast Asian heroin that has been flooding the New York market for two years.

title: Incstar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $27,000.

title: Seaboard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Boston In Talks on Swiss Unit
description: First Boston Inc. announced yesterday that it is holding talks with Credit Suisse about a restructuring of the ownership of their jointly held European unit, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston.

title: Compaq-Digital Technology Deal
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation said they had reached a technology exchange agreement to insure the connectibility of their respective products. The agreement, which follows a similar pact between Digital and Apple Computer Inc. in January, formalizes support for customers connecting Compaq personal computers in networks with Digital's minicomputer products.

title: TV Campaign to Begin For California Magazine
description: California magazine, based in Los Angeles, is about to break its first television campaign and its first advertising will come from Hal Riney & Partners.

title: Scherer, RP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,340,000 and $3,738,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $867,000 and $1,420,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BLACKS HOLD SIT-IN ON HARVARD HIRING
description: About 50 black students at the Harvard Law School occupied the dean's outer office today, demanding increased efforts to recruit faculty members who are women or from minority groups.

title: One Dies as Bomb Explodes At a U.S. Bank in New Delhi
description: A time bomb hidden in a briefcase exploded in the foreign-exchange area of Citibank headquarters today, killing one person and wounding 14, the police said.

title: Assembly Speaker Denounces Koch's Budget Plan
description: The Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, today denounced key elements of Mayor Koch's budget proposal, including the creation of a new authority to oversee bridge repairs.

title: Algorex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $638,000 for expenses associated with the anticipated sale of Algorex's headquarters in Hauppauge, N.Y., and the writeoff of certain computer equipment. c-Includes a one-time charge of $3,950,000 for the phase out and disposal of Algorex's New Hampshire manufacturing operation.

title: House Approves Bill On Copyright Treaty
description: The House of Representatives passed legislation today to permit the United States to join the Bern Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, an international copyright treaty to which 76 other nations subscribe.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,271,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Trade Bill, Facing a Veto, Goes to White House Today
description: A sweeping trade bill, cleared by both houses of Congress last month but delayed by procedural wrangling over Alaskan oil, will go to the White House Wednesday, the Congressional leadership agreed today.

title: Eating Well
description: GREAT ideas start from the simplest needs. Joanne Guy of San Diego had trouble staying on the Weight Watchers diet because she worked and did not have time to buy the ingredients and prepare the dishes. She looked for a service that would do the cooking for her, without success.

title: U S West Loses Case On Pricing
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that U S West Inc., the Denver-based regional telephone company, had engaged in discriminatory pricing to win contracts to provide the Government with computerized switching service for the Federal phone system.

title: Nord Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., an airline holding company, said that a management group trying to acquire the company had agreed to take no action for three years unless a competing bid came along.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT

title: The Pain of Change
description: The strains of attempting limited reform in Communist countries these days provoke reflections on old political and even deeper human issues. Change is necessary and inevitable, but it always brings pain. Violent revolutions make subsequent change even harder, not only because they concentrate power beyond civil challenge, but also because they instill such an attachment to order, stability and predictability, and such a fear of risk.

title: NATO Foes Lead in Cloudy Danish Vote
description: An election that focused on Denmark's full participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization failed to produce a definitive answer today, but Prime Minister Poul Schluter asserted that the anti-NATO forces had been weakened.

title: Hugh Laing, Specialist in Ballets By Antony Tudor, Is Dead at 77
description: Hugh Laing, one of the finest dramatic dancers of 20th-century ballet and a former star of both American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. A spokesman for Ballet Theater said Mr. Laing had been suffering from cancer. He was 77 years old and lived in New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Seaway Food Town Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-Includes gains of $1,085,000 from an income-tax accounting change and $5,886,000 from the reversion of pension assets.

title: Topics of The Times; A Check on the Beer Slobs
description: Disappointed by team owners' diffident response to rowdiness at ballparks, the New York Legislature is moving sensibly to curb stadium drinking. A bill sponsored by Senator John Dunne and Assemblyman Richard Brodsky and approved by the Senate would set aside 6 percent of the seats in all sections as alcohol-free. Fifteen percent more would be ''no vending'' areas where alcohol could be consumed but not sold.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Comunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kodak-Immunex Pacts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Immunex Corporation said today that they had expanded the activities of their partnership, which was formed in 1986 for drug research activities. The new agreements cover an advanced drug development process and the division of marketing rights. Also, Kodak will invest an additional $20 million in Immunex and Immunex will buy out Kodak's share of the joint venture's manufacturing plant. The two companies are involved in new research on conventional drugs that mimic or inhibit the activities of proteins.

title: Affiliated Posts $14.4 Million Loss
description: Affiliated Publications Inc., the owner of The Boston Globe and Billboard Publications, yesterday reported a first-quarter net loss of $14.4 million, largely because of losses from the company's investment in the McCaw Communications Companies.

title: Misery Rises in Philippines' Swollen Slums
description: Two weeks ago someone apparently knocked over a kerosene lamp and, in what seemed a nightmare out of the last century, more than 1,000 flimsy homes were burned to the ground within five hours.

title: Another Suspension For Devils Coach, This Time for Real
description: Jim Schoenfeld, the embattled New Jersey Devils coach whose on-again, off-again suspension after an altercation with a referee last Friday has overshadowed his team's pursuit of the Stanley Cup, finally had his say this afternoon.

title: Traditional Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mike Shula Retires
description: Like his father and his older brother, Mike Shula has announced his retirement as a professional football player at a young age in order to get started as a coach in the National Football League. The 22-year-old reserve quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers said Monday he would make the switch to assistant coach, as an offensive aide to Ray Perkins, the Buccaneers' coach, who was also Shula's boss when he was a quarterback at Alabama.

title: How to Groom Your Children for College; Striving for Credentials
description: To the Editor:

title: Spell Out the Meese Case
description: James McKay, the independent counsel investigating conflict of interest charges involving Attorney General Edwin Meese, has publicly stated he probably won't seek an indictment. But he also must report to the court that appointed him, and much public speculation now focuses on the content of that report. To hope that it will either explicitly exonerate Mr. Meese or force his resignation, however, is to misunderstand the limited function of the independent counsel.

title: Official New York Stands in the Way of Upgrading 42d Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Tejon Ranch Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Topics of The Times; Impaired Vision at CBS
description: Three of every four players in the National Basketball Association are black, including most of its biggest stars. And unlike big league football and baseball, the N.B.A. even has several black head coaches. But when CBS, which broadcasts N.B.A. games, convened all its basketball commentators on camera recently to discuss the playoffs, there wasn't a black face in sight.

title: Alaska Oilfield Report Cites Unexpected Harm to Wildlife
description: An unreleased preliminary report by officials of the Fish and Wildlife Service says oil development in northern Alaska has caused far more environmental damage than the Government predicted.

title: Mitterrand Selects Moderate Socialist as Prime Minister of France
description: President Francois Mitterrand today designated Michel Rocard, a moderate Socialist, as France's next Prime Minister, giving him the difficult mission of forming the first minority Government in the 30 years of the Fifth Republic.

title: Ford's Probe Gets Fast Start
description: The sporty 1989 Ford Probe, built for the Ford Motor Company by its Japanese partner, the Mazda Motor Company, will make its debut this week with enough advance orders to fill production schedules until October, Ford officials said today.

title: Cone Raises His Record to 4-0
description: When he was given the chance to start, David Cone said he would do everything he possibly could to make it difficult for Dave Johnson to tell him to stop. Cone has made more than good on his word, and as a result Johnson has been left uttering only one: more.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago first quarter results have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB 96.

title: Placer Dome reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes special gains of $500,000 and $17,800,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds. Year-ago figures were restated.

title: Justice Agency Ceases Inquiry into St Germain
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not seek criminal charges against Representative Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, who has been under investigation for months over reports that he improperly accepted meals and entertainment from Washington lobbyists.

title: Boxing Notebook; Cayton and King: A Preliminary to Tyson-Spinks
description: Don King spent some time with Mike Tyson in Los Angeles last week, which raises a couple of questions. Was he protecting the interests of Tyson's manager, Bill Cayton, as he insisted he was doing last month when he visited with Tyson in Los Angeles? Or, as the rumor that filtered back to Cayton had it, was he seeking to persuade Tyson to sign a promotional agreement with him?

title: Ex-Argentine General Faces Trial in 39 Political Killings
description: A cashiered army general who was Argentina's most-wanted military fugitive has been brought home to face 39 murder charges in connection with the so-called dirty war that the military waged against leftists in the 1970's.

title: Nebraska and W. Virginia Pick Dukakis in Landslides
description: Michael S. Dukakis won sweeping victories over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in Democratic Presidential primaries in West Virginia and Nebraska yesterday.

title: CRIMINAL INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON DRUG
description: A Congressman said today that he would ask the Justice Department to investigate whether a drug company delayed giving the Government information about a sedative linked to at least 36 deaths.

title: Swift Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 IN FINANCE CLUB GIVEN LIFE TERMS
description: Two members of a former social and business club in Los Angeles, the Billionaire Boys Club, were sentenced here today to life in prison without parole for the kidnapping and murder of the father of one of the defendants.

title: Gandhi Under Pressure to Oust Sikhs From Temple
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government came under pressure today to oust dozens of armed Sikh militants from the Golden Temple of Amritsar after a shootout inside the shrine Monday between the Sikhs and the police.

title: Alan Paton Opposed Tutu on Disinvestment
description: To the Editor:
