Ensource Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $1,775,000 from an accounting change.

title: Bruins Stand Out as Lamoriello Stands In for Devils
description: With Coach Jim Schoenfeld, their spiritual leader, missing from his customary position behind the bench, the Devils didn't have a prayer against the Bruins.

title: Avondale Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $3,028,000 from discontinued operations. The company said share earnings for the latest quarter equals less than one cent a share. The first quarter 1987 loss from discontinued operations resulted from the sale of six of the company's operating divisions in March 1987.

title: Pepitone Term Set
description: Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee first baseman, will report to court Monday to begin a six-month sentence for his conviction on two misdemeanor drug charges, his lawyer, John Kelly, said yesterday.

title: Urban Dining: An Empire Built on Savvy And Intuition
description: MICHAEL WEINSTEIN is showing off the rooftop cafe of one of his restaurants in New York, pointing to the crumbling wall of the adjoining building and gleefully recounting a story. It seems that the neighbor, pleased by the gentrification signified by Mr. Weinstein's restaurant, offered to fix up his property so it would fit in better with its glossy new neighbor. Aghast, one of Mr. Weinstein's partners urged that the wall remain untouched. ''You don't understand,'' she told the neighbor. ''Michael likes urban decay.''

title: Democrats Prepare to Turn Attention to Jersey Primary
description: Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson will begin campaigning in earnest for New Jersey's support at the state Democratic convention in South Orange on Sunday.

title: SPREAD IN ABUSES IS SEEN IN PANAMA
description: The military regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is using sexual humiliation, threats, imprisonment, beatings and punitive fines to intimidate its opponents, according to human rights investigators, diplomats and opposition leaders.

title: Old Novel Returns to Haunt a Current Musical
description: It began as the case of the ''Phantom'' author and the phantom author; it has become a battle of words over the words ''inspired by'' and ''based on'' - over which ones are appropriate to describe the novelist Gaston Leroux's contribution to the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical version of Mr. Leroux's ''Phantom of the Opera.'' The dispute could even affect planned productions of the musical, which has been nominated for 10 Tony Awards, in Paris, Vienna and Hamburg, West Germany.

title: INSIDE
description: New Premier for France

title: Chip Indicator Shows Gains
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to improve in April, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported orders in excess of $1.2 billion for the first time in four years. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Conner Peripherals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in April.

title: Pre-Paid Legal Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gorbachev Asks Editors to End Perestroika Debate
description: Warning of confusion and divisiveness reaching into the highest levels of the Communist Party, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called on Soviet editors to temper the bitter crossfire in the press over his program of political and social change.

title: NASA Is Urged to Develop Space Platforms
description: The National Academy of Sciences recommended yesterday that the nation develop small unmanned space platforms ''as soon as possible'' as a bridge to a larger and more elaborate space outpost planned for the 1990's.

title: In Madrid's Mercados, a Barrio Flavor in an Urban Setting
description: Like any major conurbation in Spain, Madrid is a sort of small town reproduced many times over. It is a series of microcommunities or barrios whose residents are as familiar with each other's living patterns and deep-rooted life styles as they are with the lives of their own families. And just as the small towns have shops that serve up personal service along with freshly baked breads, produce, fish and meats, so every Madrid barrio has its mercado, or market.

title: 5 Wall St. Firms Move to Restrict Program Trades
description: In a move intended to restore investor confidence in the stock market, five large Wall Street firms announced yesterday that they had suspended computerized program trading for their own accounts.

title: Behind Every High Brow
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Oil & Gas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,922,000 from a judgment awarded in a 1985 lawsuit. c-Net loss

title: Belden & Blake Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Congress; Judicial Impeachment: Is Process Antiquated?
description: The power of impeachment, the procedure devised for placing public officials suspected of wrongdoing on trial by elected lawmakers, was given to Congress by the framers of the Constitution 200 years ago. But now, as two Federal judges face possible impeachment, a debate is under way on Capitol Hill over whether the procedures make sense today.

title: Man in the News; Free-Market Socialist; Michel Rocard
description: When Michel Rocard alienated himself from most of France's Socialist Party a decade ago by calling Francois Mitterrand's left-wing economic policies ''archaic,'' he probably never dreamed that Mr. Mitterrand would someday name him Prime Minister.

title: How to Groom Your Children for College
description: To the Editor:

title: American Standard Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter included $30 million in investment banking and legal fees associated with the Black & Decker tender offer.

title: Review/Television; Goetz Trial as Drama
description: Bernhard Goetz again. The very thought is likely to induce groaning. For more than two years, the Goetz case preoccupied the public. From editorial pages across the nation to chic Manhattan cocktail parties, it became an almost obsessive center of attention. The trial ended last June with Mr. Goetz being acquitted of the more serious charges in connection with his shooting of four teen-agers he said had menaced him on a subway car in Manhattan. He is still appealing a prison sentence of six months for criminal possession of a weapon. Recently, on a television news report, Mr. Goetz could be seen, stilted and awkward as ever, accepting an award from a local gun club.

title: The Fine Art of Hollywood Fund Raising
description: In Hollywood, fund-raising dinners are incessant and interminable. There are at least 40 chances a year to honor some worthy actor, producer or studio head and to raise money for some worthy charity or solemn organization usually referred to by its initials.

title: U.S. Subpoena In Hughes Case
description: Albert D. Wheelon, who resigned last week as chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, has been named in a subpoena related to a Justice Department investigation of the Los Angeles-based military equipment contractor, a person familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: Mondale Gives Warning on Picking Running Mate
description: Walter F. Mondale says the interviews he held four years ago with prospective running mates proved a ''damaged strategy'' and adds that Michael S. Dukakis ought to find a different way of selecting the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee this year.

title: Market Facts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Happier Mothers' Days
description: Norma Downey did something of a turnabout for Mother's Day: She came to Washington to present her son, Representative Thomas J. Downey, with a new study on the economic situation of older women in the United States.

title: Beirut Captivity: A Frenchman's Story
description: It might never have happened if Jean-Paul Kauffmann and Michel Seurat had not missed the bus at the airport on May 22, 1985, the day the two men arrived in Lebanon. A few minutes later, a Mercedes-Benz blocked the way in front of their taxi on the road to Beirut.

title: Do Real Women Ride Motorcycles? 440,000 Say Yes
description: THEY'VE heard it before from mothers, friends, brothers and opinionated others: ''Proper ladies don't ride on the backs of motorcycles.''

title: Dublin's Theater: Lively Enough to Export
description: Alas, there have been no theater riots thus far this season by ungrateful customers to signal fresh Irish drama classics of the sort that once stirred William Butler Yeats to rebuke philistinism from stage center. But still, much of this year's make-believe beyond the footlights seems lively as Dublin theaters enjoy what Joe Dowling, one of their more exacting creative artists, terms a ''quite healthy season.''

title: Irving Berlin, Still on the Charts
description: ''Blue Skies'' was a show-stopper when Belle Baker first sang it in the musical ''Betsy'' in 1926. Al Jolson kept it going in ''The Jazz Singer.'' In 1941, a Tommy Dorsey recording made it No. 1 on the Hit Parade. Fritz Kreisler, the concert violinist, recorded it. The comedienne Beatrice Lillie did, too. Willie Nelson's 1978 rendition is still on the charts, a contemporary classic. So is the man who wrote ''Blue Skies,'' Irving Berlin, 100 years old today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a unit of Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., is offering $200 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds with a four-year maturity through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which won the account in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: DROPOUT RATE OFF FOR BLACK PUPILS
description: The Census Bureau today reported a significant decline in the dropout rate of black high school students over a 10-year period.

title: Keystone Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $76,000 for the quarter and $523,000 for the 9 months. Keystone is a development stage company.

title: Endevco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Polaroid Displays Printer and Camera
description: The Polaroid Corporation previewed new products that include a cigar-box-size printer that can create high-quality color photos in minutes from a television picture or any other digital source. The new device, still in the prototype stage, is seen by the company as the forerunner of inexpensive, compact instant printers that work with a variety of cameras.

title: Bedeviling an Arms Pact: The Details
description: By any objective standard, the treaty on medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles is one that should have made its way easily from the negotiating table to ratification. The accord enjoys overwhelming official and public support in the United States, the Soviet Union and in Europe. And in the grand scheme of superpower relations, arms control experts on both sides regard its primary significance as political rather than military.

title: 9 Are Acquitted of Murder in Philadelphia
description: A jury today acquitted Nicodemo Scarfo and eight associates on all charges in the slaying of Salvatore Testa, who prosecutors said was an underworld rival.

title: Suffolk Approves Video-Terminal Bill
description: Over objections from business leaders, a sweeping measure aimed at protecting workers who use video-display terminals was passed today by the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: Fetisov Closer to Being a Devil
description: The Devils reacted with delight today to a newspaper report that Vyacheslav Fetisov, one of the world's top defensemen, was a step closer to joining their team.

title: Lessons
description: There is no defending the Greek way, as college fraternity and sorority life might be called. It is self-selecting and therefore discriminatory; it is exclusionary and therefore anti-democratic. Those qualities of faculty and administrative life aside, colleges are supposed to be islands of virtue. They cannot officially sanction less in behavior than they demand in thought.

title: Bell & Howell Debentures Are Priced to Yield 12 7/8%
description: The Bell & Howell Group is offering $225 million of 8 1/4 percent senior subordinated debentures, due in 1998, at a price of 88.80 to yield 12 7/8 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. Originally the size of the debt issue was planned at $205 million, but it was increased because of good investor demand.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: KATE COLBORN of Brooklyn is waiting for the traffic light to change at the corner of Third and Atlantic Avenues. Alongside her is a small, frail elderly woman. The woman is clutching a cane and, it is apparent, is quite concerned about crossing against the aggressively turning traffic. Ms. Colborn smiles in understanding, takes the woman's arm and escorts her - slowly, gently - across the intersection. In front of the Doray Tavern, Ms. Colborn helps the woman up the curb, wishes her a pleasant afternoon and starts off.

title: Wheat Estimate Up 4%
description: The Agriculture Department said today that 1988 winter wheat production is estimated at 1.62 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's harvest of 1.56 billion bushels. Officials said the average yield, based on indications as of May 1, was estimated at 40.7 bushels an acre, compared with last year's 39.8 bushels. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the following summer. It makes up about three-fourths of total United States wheat production.

title: CJI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an adjustment to valuation allowances reflecting a recovery in the market value of the marketable equity securities portfolio equal to $3,929,000 after tax. c-Net income and includes a gain of $217,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the 1988 first quarter results include the operations of Triangle Industries since March 1, 1988, the effective acquisition date. CJI Industries acquired 31.6 percent of Triangle's common and common equivalent shareholders' equity (representing 63.5 percent of Triangle's voting power) and, accordingly, accounts for Triangle as a consolidated subsidiary with a 68.4 percent minority ownership.

title: Beer (Soon) for Icelanders
description: After a yearlong debate, Parliament voted today to end 73 years of prohibition by legalizing beer with an alcoholic content of about 2.25 percent.

title: HOUSE VOTE BACKS A PLASTIC-GUN BAN
description: The House today passed, 413 to 4, a bill that would ban the manufacture, sale or possession of any plastic firearm that could evade detection by X-ray machines or metal detectors.

title: Canadian Occidental Petroeum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Plymouth Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $351,000.

Price Pfister reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Outsider' Who Stirred Emotions at Dartmouth
description: When James O. Freedman became president of Dartmouth College last July, he brought an outsider's perspective to this insular campus.

title: Limited Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
After Acclaim, The Controversy
description: Zola Budd burst into international prominence in 1982 more as a curiosity than a prominent runner. Here was this wisp of a teen-ager, barely 5 feet 4 inches and 95 pounds, who ran barefoot.

title: Dixie National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Imagine if you didn't see your family for years. Imagine your love for them, for the streets, the house you grew up in, the place you were born in and grew up in. That's exactly what I feel and it's always painful to talk about it.'' - Yuri Lyubimov, the exiled Soviet director, on returning to Moscow. [ A1:2. ]

title: Citicorp Rates At an '88 High
description: Interest rates rose moderately yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. It marked the second consecutive rise in rates in as many weeks and produced the highest average rates thus far this year.

title: Stewart Sandwiches Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Includes a $143,025 gain from unusual items.

title: Loral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The prior year included expense of $406,000 as a result of a $17.8 million writeoff from a production program and a $17.4 million gain from sale of securities.

title: Wainoco Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $18.8 million. Year-ago earnings are restated for the accounting change.

title: Dow Rises 6.30, to 2,003.65; Trading Slows
description: Trading in stocks was slow yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average managing enough of a gain to put it barely back above the 2,000 level.

title: Damon Creations Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Penchina's Morale Gets a Lift
description: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ, a creative little agency in the $20 million class, has just finished a project for the mighty Unilever United States that has been very good for morale.

title: 5 Metro-North Workers in Crash Showed Drug Traces, U.S. Says
description: Tests on five employees involved in the fatal crash of a commuter train in Mount Vernon last month - the engineer, three tower operators and the dispatcher in Manhattan - showed traces of drugs after the accident, the Federal Railroad Administration said today.

title: Economic Scene; Soviet Reforms: A Need for Time
description: HAS Mikhail Gorbachev fallen victim to his own brand of voodoo economics? Few Western analysts ever believed Mr. Gorbachev could meet his self-imposed goals for perestroika, restructuring a failing economic system, without even a temporary reduction in living standards. And the latest evidence bears out their skepticism. According to the Central Intelligence Agency, Soviet growth and the production of consumer goods are lagging behind population increases.

title: Series of Fatal A-6E Crashes in Trials Prompts Navy Investigation
description: Alarmed by six plane crashes and 10 deaths in the last 16 months, the Navy today began an investigation into the training program for A-6E jet bombers based at the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station north of here.

title: What Line-Item Veto Power Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Latest Israeli Weapon: Bureaucracy
description: Thousands of Palestinians grumbled and sweated, but most seemed resigned as they stood in long, slow-moving lines today to comply with the Israeli Army's order that they obtain new identity cards.

CMI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: A New Owner For L.A. Style
description: L.A. Style, with 50,000 circulation among affluent Los Angeles households, has been acquired by the American Express Publishing Corporation, Thomas O. Ryder, president of the division said yesterday.

title: In a Quiet Setting, U.S. Concludes Its Biggest Drug Trafficking Case
description: Inside a Federal courtroom today, as a jury watched raptly, United States Attorny Robert Merkle turned his attention to one of the thousands of exhibits introduced as evidence over the past six months in the drug trial of Carlos Lehder, accused of being the mastermind of a Colombian drug ring.

title: Impact Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $443,000. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $405,000 for the quarter and $973,000 for the year.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $26,000. c-Net loss

title: Richard B. Ogilvie Is Dead at 65; Illinois Governor From '68 to '72
description: Richard B. Ogilvie, who served as Governor of Illinois from 1968 to 1972, died yesterday a day after suffering a heart attack and undergoing emergency bypass surgery at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 65 years old.

title: Police Evidence Counters Martin's Story; He Is Blamed For Altercation
description: The Arlington Police Department has concluded that Billy Martin's claim that he was assaulted in the restroom of a topless bar early Saturday morning was unfounded. The police said that Martin, the Yankee manager, threw the one and only punch in the incident and that he was injured when he was thrown out of the bar.

title: Budd Goes Back To South Africa
description: Zola Budd, the South African-born runner who had jeopardized Britain's participation in the Seoul Olympics, returned to South Africa suddenly today, effectively ending her chances for participation in the 1988 Games and possibly ending her career.

title: Investor Enters Battle Over Allegheny
description: Bennett S. LeBow, the chairman of the Western Union Corporation, announced yesterday that he had agreed to cooperate with a brokerage firm in a hard-fought battle to take over Allegheny International Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A report yesterday in the Campaign Trail column misidentified the Governor of Delaware, elected in 1984. He is Michael N. Castle, a Republican.

title: Aon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hard Times for Retail Brokers
description: LEAD: The stock market eked out a small gain yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average is holding doggedly to the 2,000 level. But with trading volume in a slump, thousands of brokers are singing the blues.

title: Conston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Net income

title: About Real Estate; How to Add Office Space Amid Strict Rules in Rye
description: Over the last three decades Rye, N.Y., a rural-looking city of 15,000 people on Long Island Sound, has remained predominantly residential. Many of its municipal neighbors, in the same period, were allowing room for the sort of commercial development that has made Westchester County a major office center.

title: Moore Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2

After 7 Weeks, Publisher of 7 Days Sees Success
description: Leonard N. Stern, whose fledgling weekly 7 Days has now published its seventh issue, declared last week that he was certain of success for the publication, which is delivered free to 50,000 of Manhattan's most affluent households.

description: b-Net income

description: * Patrick H. Joyce has been elected chairman of the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute.

How to Groom Your Children for College
description: To the Editor:

title: Elusive Liver-Disease Virus Is Isolated, Researchers Say
description: Scientists at a California biotechnology company said today that they had isolated an elusive virus that causes liver disease in thousands of people who undergo blood transfusions each year.

title: Dukakis Quietly Trying To Gain Black Support
description: After largely ceding the black vote to the Rev. Jesse Jackson for most of the primary season, the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts is quietly and cautiously trying to build some bridges.

title: Country Lake Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no year-ago share earnings because the company had not yet gone public.

title: VLSI and Hitachi In Technology Deal
description: VLSI Technology Inc., the San Jose, Calif., semiconductor company, has formed a long-term technology exchange agreement with Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo. According to the agreement, VLSI will provide Hitachi with application-specific integrated circuit, or ASIC, technology, while Hitachi will make its process and manufacturing technology available.

title: Loan Given to Rebuild a Harlem Hospital
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday announced a $150 million loan to rebuild the financially beleaguered North General Hospital in Harlem, the only minority-owned hospital in the state.

title: Safety Board Blames Pilots for Detroit Crash
description: The failure of two Northwest Airlines pilots to follow required checklist procedures before takeoff led to the crash last August at Detroit Metropolitan Airport that killed 156 of the 157 people aboard, a Federal report concluded today.

title: Dow Chemical Sets Venture With BOC
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it would form an equal joint venture with BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain to separate oxygen and nitrogen from air and supply the gases to industrial users around the world. A spokeswoman for the company, based in Midland, Mich., said it would contribute its membrane filter technology to the venture, while BOC would offer both technology and its marketing network for industrial gases.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: First Federal Savings & Loan (East Hartford) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in June 1987.

title: Japanese Official Fires New Furor on the War
description: A Cabinet minister who caused a stir with recent comments about Japan's wartime role embroiled himself in fresh controversy today by saying that the Japanese invasion of China five decades ago was not a war of aggression.

title: One of Our States Is Missing
description: Senator Moynihan, whose public duties include trying to save the country from coming to a complete standstill, says that by the year 2020 Interstate 95 will have to be 44 lanes wide to carry the traffic between Fort Lauderdale and Miami.

title: Essex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: On Helen Suzman, Enemy of Apartheid
description: LEAD: Whenever I am downhearted and depressed at the course of events in South Africa -and which of us can honestly say that our courage never flags or fails? - I have only to think of Helen Suzman, and of all she has done and endured and achieved over the last 35 years, to feel a resurgence of confidence, determination and faith.

title: Coradian Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $186,000 gain from a legal settlement with a former supplier.

title: Riverside Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suns Pick Fitzsimmons
description: The Phoenix Suns named Cotton Fitzsimmons yesterday to replace John Wetzel as coach. Paul Westphal, 37 years old, a former All-Star guard for the Suns, was hired as Fitzsimmons's assistant until he is ready to take over the coaching reins.

title: Everest & Jennings International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $283,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $270,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Man in Police Custody Suffers Seizure and Dies
description: A 34-year-old Brooklyn man who had heart problems and epilepsy died in police custody Monday night, the police said, after he became violent, bit a paramedic and bruised another, and was restrained with handcuffs.

title: KEY DEMAND UNMET
description: Workers at the big Lenin Shipyard here ended a nine-day strike tonight and grimly marched out of the yard behind a wooden cross and a portrait of Pope John Paul II.

title: Kirby Exploration Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $220,267 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $560,000. c-After a loss of $281,775 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,004,622. The year-ago first quarter is restated to reflect the company's oil and gas operation as a discontinued business since the sale of substantially all of the oil and gas assets was completed April 25, 1988.

title: The Taking of Car No. 4776: Homeless Men Find a Haven
description: The Grand Street Shuttle pulled into the station at its last stop late yesterday morning, but none of the passengers in subway car No. 4776 got off. Nine men lay sprawled on the seats on this particular five-minute trip from West Fourth Street, and nine went back, slumped and ragged, in postures of exhaustion or intoxication.

title: Levitt Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Edgar H. S. Chandler, Chaplain, Dies at 83
description: The Rev. Edgar H. S. Chandler, a United Church of Christ minister who directed the refugee services of the World Council of Churches after World War II, died Saturday at the Havenwood retirement community in Concord, N.H. He was 83 years old.

title: Washington National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1,252,000 and $6,752,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Circle Express reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses of $31,000 and $13,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: North American Biologicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $117,000 and $114,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the selection process for Vice Presidential nominees misstated a 1968 election result. In that year Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine was the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate and the Democratic ticket indeed carried Maine.

title: In Poland, the Only Solution Is Political
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro-Iranian Group Appears to Gain in Beirut
description: Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem fundamentalists appear to have gained the upper hand in Beirut's densely populated southern suburbs after six days of heavy fighting against the Syrian-backed Amal militia.

title: Radiation Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter results included $120,000 for a loss on project abandonment of a facility in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Martin Gains Support
description: Despite a police report that labeled Billy Martin's version of a weekend fight in Texas as unfounded, George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he accepted his manager's version and planned no action against him.

title: Marietta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Daniel Peterkin Jr., 82, Ex-President of Morton
description: Daniel Peterkin Jr., former chairman of Morton-Norwich Products Inc., now Morton Thiokol Inc., died from complications of heart disease Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 82 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Forest Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Television; Bringing the Invisible People of AIDS Into Focus
description: The patient is dying. Gathering for the death vigil, family and friends self-consciously try to comfort the patient and one another. It would be a rather commonplace scene except that in this instance the patient has AIDS and just about all of his friends are gay. And there is something else unusual about ''A Death in the Family,'' being shown this evening at 9 on Channel 13. It deals candidly and sympathetically with a disease that has ravaged the homosexual population. Almost predictably, it was not made in the United States. The film comes from New Zealand, a small country that seems to make a habit of taking courageous stands on big issues.

title: Why the Rush to Tax Nonprofits?
description: Should the local ''Y'' be permitted to run an expensive health club, but not pay taxes on the profits? Should tax-exempt college bookstores compete with stores that sell everything from tennis rackets to Beatles tapes? No, say some members of the House Ways and Means Committee. With Reagan Administration support, they propose to tighten the tax rules on the unrelated businesses of nonprofit organizations.

title: Migrant Farm Workers' Unexpected Worry: New Alien Law
description: Migrant farm workers, still America's most afflicted class of laborers despite slowly improving working conditions, are now grappling with problems from an unexpected source: the 1986 immigration law.

title: Statue of Nurse Supported
description: Legislation authorizing a bronze statue of a female Army nurse at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial was approved by a Senate committee today over a dissenter's protest that the memorial might become a sculpture garden for special interest groups.

title: American Equine Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thrift Unit Notes Issued in Michigan
description: First Federal of Michigan is offering $100 million of floating-rate notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes' initial interest rate, or coupon, is 7.26 percent. The underwriters said the notes would be offered to the public at various prices.

title: Literary Luminary Gets His Diploma After 57 Years
description: Robert Giroux showed up at Regis High School in Manhattan two nights ago to accept the Campion award given by America magazine for service in the cause of Christian letters. While he was there the Rev. James J. Fischer, the president of the Jesuit school, had a surprise for him: the diploma he had forsaken when he dropped out of Regis 57 years ago, two months before graduation.

title: Review/Recital; Five Works for Organ
description: Marilyn Mason has spent the last 41 years commissioning and performing new concert works for the organ, and so when she was named International Performer of the Year by the New York Chapter of the American Guild of Organists, it was natural that she should select the program of her award recital - given Tuesday evening at Riverside Church - from the repertory she has brought into being.

title: Bridge
description: Foreign invaders, who captured the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs title Sunday, seemed on the way to another victory in the Cavendish Teams. But when play ended Tuesday night the winners were Cliff Russell of Miami, Larry Cohen and Dan Rotman, both of Los Angeles, Brian Glubok of Manhattan, Marty Bergen of White Plains and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J.

title: General Physics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is an 84 percent owned subsidiary of National Patent Development Corp.

description: b-Includes a capital loss of $146,000 for the latest quarter and a capital gain of $128,000 for the year-ago period.

Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the credit markets misstated the direction of bond prices in some copies.

title: Schoenfeld Regrets The Commotion
description: Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, said today that he regretted the incident that caused his suspension and the publicity it has attracted.

title: Sports People; A Dash of Spice
description: The sprinting jrivals Ben Johnson of Canada and Carl Lewis of the United States will compete head to head in the 100-meter dash at a French meet on June 27, their first showdown since Johnson's world-record performance last September during the world championships in Rome.

title: Allis-Chalmers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,714,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Dance Groups Join Forces for an Uptown Series
description: Two noted modern-dance companies joined hands with each other and with a theater group last night, when the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians appeared on the same program with Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and Company and Bill Irwin and Friends in the gala opening of the two-week New Contemporary Masters series at City Center.

title: Record U.S. Fish Catch
description: United States fishermen had a record catch of 6.9 billion pounds of fish and shellfish last year, breaking the previous record of 6.5 billion pounds set in 1980, the Government said on Tuesday. The 1987 catch, valued at $3.1 billion, was 865 million pounds higher than the 1986 total, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. Fishermen received an average of 45 cents a pound for their fish last year.

title: Two Forks Journal; Coloradans Anxiously Await Decision Over a Proposed Dam
description: While the construction of Two Forks Dam on the South Platte River 25 miles southwest of here has been on the drawing board for decades, Coloradans have spent the last few weeks debating whether Denver and its suburbs need the 550-foot-high dam, now or ever.

title: A Broadside in Favor Of Aid for the Young
description: The Reagan years have been hard on disadvantaged youths, in the opinion of liberal critics. High budget deficits have resulted in the underfinancing of existing social programs, they say, and discouraged new efforts. Especially harmful to those with nowhere else to turn, the critics contend, is the Reagan philosophy that government is largely part of the problem of poverty instead of the solution to it.

title: Sports People; White Sox Progress
description: Chicago White Sox owners have agreed not to move their team if Illinois lawmakers approve a revised lease on a new stadium, saving the team up to $60 million over 10 years, Gov. James R. Thompson said yesterday. ''They have given us their word that if we pass this bill, they'll stay,'' Thompson said at a news conference. ''Better than that, I can't ask.'' In Chicago, the White Sox issued a statement saying they were pleased with the development and Thompson's ''efforts to expedite legislative approval of the plan.'' Thompson said he hoped legislative action would begin next week.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our wood deck appears to be made of cedar. There seems to be no sealer or finish, and when people walk or sit on it, a gray-brown dust gets all over clothes and shoes. What can we put on the deck to prevent this? A. First clean the wood thoroughly with one of the special wood restorers or cleaners that are sold for rejuvenating old wood siding and shingles. Scrub thoroughly according to directions on the package; then let the wood dry and apply two coats of a decking stain (not a shingle stain, but a stain made for wood decks). This should seal the wood and prevent the powdering. Q. The previous owner of our 75-year-old house put down carpet over the beautiful hardwood floors. The carpet, which is in poor condition, has foam backing and is glued down. After taking up a few square feet we tried lacquer thinner, ammonia, paint remover and various cleaners to clean the adhesive off, but have been only partly successful, while contending with terrible fumes. How can we get back to the original hardwood? A. Your best bet is to scrape up as much as possible with a stiff putty knife or a long-handled scraper used to remove ice from sidewalks. Use a floor sanding machine to get the rest off and to get down to the bare wood. Then the floors can be refinished properly. In most cases three sandings are required: one with coarse grit to get the floor clean; one with medium to get rid of the scratches left by the coarse paper; one with fine, for final smoothing. Machines can be rented from most hardware stores and tool rental agencies, or you can hire a floor finisher to do the whole job. Q. For safety, we want a bar or hand grip on the wall above our bathtub. The walls are covered with thin vinyl tiles (vintage 1958) which we cannot replace, so we must work carefully. What is the best way to make the holes in this plastic tile, and what precautions should we take? A. The plastic tiles are easily drilled with an ordinary twist drill bit. First, scratch a small X with the end of a small file to keep the tip of the bit from skipping around and scratching the tile.

One can be seen regularly at the Bottom Line, the other at Caroline's at the Seaport. title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IT'S interesting to note the way medical miracles can go from brave new world to simple acceptance almost overnight. Once it was a major news event when a heart from one person was placed in the chest of another. Once it stopped the presses when a baby was born of an egg fertilized outside a woman's body. Today, there have been many heart transplants and many babies conceived in vitro, and people speak knowledgeably of donating organs, or of infertility.

title: Review/Music; Faure Requiem Restyled For Chamber Orchestra

Mr. Rutter, a composer and choir conductor from Britain, brought to Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening his own reconstruction of the score, one that called for a chamber ensemble rather than full orchestra and that most faithfully conforms, he says, to the composer's intentions.

title: Van Gogh's 'Adeline Ravoux' Is Sold

description: Black students at Harvard Law School ended a 24-hour occupation of the dean's outer office today after the school administration promised to continue to give high priority to hiring faculty members from minority groups.

title: Irving Berlin, Absent, Is Much the Star of Carnegie Tribute

From Frank Sinatra to Willie Nelson, from Ray Charles to Marilyn Horne, they represented an array of American musical styles as rich and varied as the songs of the man they were honoring - songs that have become so embedded in the texture of American life that they seem inextricably woven into the country's history.

Mavec & Company, Stockspring Antiques and Ursus Prints -have organized the tiny May Antiques Fair. It opens today and displays their wares in an intimate setting.

title: Knight Reported Going
description: Bob Knight returned to Indiana today, reportedly to tell his team and university officials that he has accepted the coaching job at New Mexico. The Dallas Times-Herald, quoting unidentified ''sources close to Knight and the Lobos' program,'' reported in Wednesday's editions that Knight reached an oral agreement on a five-year, $350,000-a-year contract with New Mexico. The deal also calls for a $150,000 house. ''It's a done deal, Knight's coming,'' the newspaper quoted its source in Albuquerque as saying. ''All he has to do is sign the contract.''

title: Mets Score 3 in 9th, Beat Astros in 10th
description: Terry Leach saw the ball that Tim Teufel hit in the ninth inning clear the wall and bang solidly off the concrete above it. His view from the bullpen was clear, his angle good, his opinion unshakable. ''It was a home run,'' Leach said. As Leach, who eventually would be the winning pitcher, soon learned, tonight's 10-inning, 9-8 comeback victory over the Astros was a game that required you to forget your allegiance to usual definitions of reality and any other reasonable sets of expectations.

description: Williams-Sonoma Inc., a retailer of cookware and home furnishings based here, said it had agreed to develop free-standing Ralph Lauren Home Collection retail stores in the United States. Under the agreement, the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation will supply its proprietary line of home furnishings, which ranges from towels and bedding to upholstered furniture, while Williams-Sonoma will own and operate the stores. Williams-Sonoma will open one Ralph Lauren Home Collection store in Palo Alto, Calif., this fall and plans to open two to four more in the next two years.

Results Plus

Lendl, the top-seeded player, overcame Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 5-7, 6-1, on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico. Wilander, seeded second, took nearly two and a half hours to beat Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, in his second hard-fought match in a row. Agassi, the American seeded ninth, continued his impressive run by battling back to beat Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden, 3-6, 7-6, 6-3.

title: Queens Jewelry Thief Charged After a Car Chase
description: As cinema, it had everything: a brazen jewelry thief, an outraged victim, a fearless retired detective, gunfire, a car chase, a foot race, a stolen vehicle, a severed ear, a traffic accident, an innocent bystander struck down, a heroic but anonymous civilian - even the United States Army. But it was no movie. It happened yesterday morning in Ozone Park, Queens.

description: ''The Koppel Report'' separates itself from ''Nightline'' by giving us more of Ted Koppel. The program tonight, the first in a quarterly series, begins and ends with him in the pew of small country church; the rest of the time he's in an auditorium with 7 evangelists, 4,000 Christians and a large choir. Mr. Koppel has always been a distinguished interviewer; on the new ABC program, at 10 o'clock, he's a star.

description: MATTIA BONETTI and Elizabeth Garouste, a Paris-based design team, believe in contradictions. In their new collection of tables, chairs and lamps, which is being shown at Furniture of the Twentieth Century beginning Saturday, they combine primitive imagery with sophisticated design; rough-hewn materials like wrought iron or cast bronze with lacquered wood or sandblasted glass.

title: Review/Ballet; Violette Verdy Premiere
description: The New York City Ballet's American Music Festival continued Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with a program that featured two well-crafted new works: Violette Verdy's ''Set of Seven'' and Peter Martins's ''Tea-Rose.''

title: Talking Deals; Why Sterling Did Not Move
description: NO American city is more expensive than New York for doing business, says the conventional wisdom in real estate. That, however, did not stop one real estate man from persuading a $2 billion pharmaceutical company that it could actually save money by staying in New York.

title: Cali Charged By S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Cali Computer Systems Inc. and three of its senior officers with filing false and misleading financial information about the company in a two-year period from 1983 until 1985.

title: REAGAN ENDORSES BUSH AS SUCCESSOR
description: President Reagan ended one of Washington's longest-running and least suspenseful political dramas tonight when he endorsed Vice President Bush as his successor.

title: Keeping a Secret
description: The messages in dispute were secretly exchanged 17 years ago between Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, and Kenneth Rush, the United States Ambassador to West Germany.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a theater chain, announced the resignation of Ron D. Leslie as president and chief operating officer. Stanley H. Durwood, chairman and chief executive, will take over as president, and William B. Doeren will become chief operating officer.

title: Korea Shipyard Decline
description: South Korea's shipbuilding orders have dropped by 41.3 percent this year, compared with the 1987 period, because of the national currency's appreciation in foreign exchange, officials said today. The value of the South Korean won has risen 7.43 percent against the United States dollar since the beginning of the year. A higher won makes South Korean exports more expensive abroad while lowering the prices of imports.

title: New Bank Product
description: Into the hotly contested New York City consumer-banking market, the Chemical Bank has introduced a product aimed specifically at recent college graduates. Although other local banks have offered low-cost checking, Chemical is apparently the first to offer a product specifically for recent graduates. Called ''Chemplus Banking for Young Professionals,'' the product combines free checking for six months, free checks and a line of credit for people with a firm job offer but no work history.

title: Transplant Patient, 3, Dies After Organs Fail
description: Tabatha Foster, a 3-year-old who was the world's longest survivor of a five-organ transplant, died today after an infection caused her heart, kidneys and liver to fail.

title: Review/Concert; Harrell and Ashkenazy
description: The cellist Lynn Harrell and the pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy are unquestioned front-runners in the classical music business, and their sonata recital at Avery Fisher Hall Monday evening offered several reminders of the reason why. Mr. Ashkenazy has technical security to burn. When the music gets too fast and too difficult for the average pianist to play with ease - as it did in the finale of the opening Shostakovich Sonata (Op. 40) and some points thereafter - you can't miss the difference.

title: Winston Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Manila Frets Over Export Of Its Women
description: After years of abuse, the Philippines is trying to regulate what is described here as one of its most successful exports: its women.

title: Study Finds Fewer Defects In Condoms on U.S. Market
description: Fewer defective condoms are showing up on the United States market, although more than 33 million condoms were recalled or rejected in the last year, a Federal study reports.

title: Sports People; Keenan Dismissed
description: Mike Keenan of the Philadelphia Flyers, who had the best winning percentage (.638) among active National Hockey League coaches and one year remaining on a three-year contract, was dismissed yesterday. Keenan and Bob Clarke, the general manager, were unable to resolve contract differences. Keenan, the coach of the Flyers for four seasons, demanded a contract clause that would let him leave for a general manager's job elsewhere in the league, if one were offered. Clarke, who hired Keenan and says he considers him a friend, dismissed Keenan. ''I think for us to move forward in the proper direction, we need a change,'' said Clarke. ''So I released Mike Keenan this morning. Throughout the year and since the season ended, I've watched the team and evaluated it. I was not pleased with what I saw. But now we are headed in another direction and need different leadership.'' (AP)

title: Financier's Dream: High-Yield Garden
description: MICHAEL STEINHARDT'S well-worn briefcase sat open on the kitchen table. Inside were copies of Barron's and The Wall Street Journal and computer-printout schedules.
