title: Gabriel Kirschenbaum, Army Colonel, 87
description: Dr. Gabriel Kirschenbaum, a retired Army colonel, died Tuesday of congestive heart failure resulting from leukemia at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: The Struggle to Keep Family Time Quality Time
description: ALTHOUGH her family's daily routine is already ''pretty hellish,'' said Sharon Marshall, she and her husband, Edward Willinger, scramble to be able to eat dinner with their two children in their Brooklyn home at least five days a week. The result, however, is not always worth the valiant effort. At the table, Ms. Marshall, 34 years old, and Mr. Willinger, 33, often dodge bits of food that the baby is tossing and cajole the oldest to eat anything at all.

title: DEAL WITH NORIEGA REPORTED DRAWN
description: The Reagan Administration has formulated a proposal under which it would drop all drug-related charges against Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in exchange for his speedy departure from the country, Administration officials said today.

title: All in the Family
description: For years, conservative groups have been emphasizing their dedication to a cluster of what they call family issues, chief among them a campaign against abortion. Now moderates and liberals are serving notice that they do not intend to give right-wing groups title to family matters.

title: British Coal Industry
description: The British Government said today that it would like to sell the state-owned coal industry to private investors, but not for several years. Energy Minister Michael Spicer said at a seminar that there were no plans to sell off state-owned British Coal before the next general election, due by 1992, but his speech marked the first time the minister had publicly said the Government planned to sell the coal industry.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Datron Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Raytech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $696,000.

title: Swiss Urged to Lift Barriers
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said today that the Swiss Government must be prepared to allow British companies to make takeover bids in Switzerland without legal restrictions if Swiss companies expect to be able to buy British concerns.

title: Post Editor Gets Pledge of Autonomy
description: Peter S. Kalikow, owner of The New York Post, said his new editor, Jane Amsterdam, has been given strong assurances of editorial autonomy in a three-year contract she signed late Monday.

title: Cordero in Hall of Fame
description: Angel Cordero Jr., Angel Penna and the horses Majestic Prince, Chris Evert and Emperor of Norfolk have been elected to thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame.

title: Health; Psychologists and Psychiatrists Clash Over Hospital and Training Barriers
description: The long battle for patients between psychologists and psychiatrists has reached a new intensity, as psychologists try to break down barriers at hospitals and at some psychoanalytical training institutes.

title: Stalking Delegates for the Dukakis Camp
description: This was supposed to be the year of the broker, who would wheel and deal against the threat of a deadlocked convention to produce a Presidential nominee. Instead, a more appropriate emblem for the season is Tad Devine, a lanky and bespectacled lawyer, bent over his personal computer in his cluttered office in the campaign headquarters of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Mr. Devine, 32 years old, is the director of delegate selection for the Dukakis campaign. His goal is insuring that Mr. Dukakis has at least 2,081 delegates on the morning of June 8, the day after the California and New Jersey primaries, when the long Democratic nominating process will be over. That would insure Mr. Dukakis the nomination on the convention's first ballot, rule out the possibility of a brokered convention, and make the intense young Mr. Devine and his candidate two very happy men. An Attractive Suitor

title: Dover Journal; Will the Port Boom Again? Just You Wait and See
description: For 14 weeks, this port town with its white cliffs has been the center of a strike by British seamen who work on English Channel ferries. It is the bitterest industrial conflict in Britain since Rupert Murdoch crushed Fleet Street's print unions in early 1986.

title: Cushman Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $142,000 from termination of the company's pension plan.

title: The G.O.P. Can Win Blacks
description: Political experts say it's a pipe dream for Republicans to win black and other minority votes in any significant numbers in 1988, whether the Rev. Jesse Jackson is on the Democratic ticket or not. Nonsense.

title: Lay Off the Layoff
description: ''We've got to be out of our minds,'' says a Republican pol. ''Here we are with the blue-collar vote up for grabs, and we hand Dukakis his dream issue -notification of plant closings. We're for the bosses, he's for the workers. Whatsamatter, can't Reagan count?'' Certainly it seems a peculiar place to draw a line in the sand. The trade bill is about to be vetoed because it requires businesses of more than 100 employees to notify workers 60 days in advance of plans for layoffs or plant closings.

title: Monitor Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Theater; An Appalachian Fling
description: You worry that you have not seen everything? You might try ''The Yellow Dog Contract'' by Ed Setrakian at the Apple Corps Theater. About two hours into the play you might conclude that Mr. Setrakian has thrown every imaginable bafflement into it except resurrection. Don't be hasty; that, too, will come.

title: Metropolitan Opera Schedules Park Series
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 22d annual summer series of free opera performances - in concert version - in parks in and around New York City will begin June 21 on the Great Lawn of Manhattan's Central Park with Donizetti's ''Elisir d'Amore.'' The opening-night cast will include Kathleen Battle, Luciano Pavarotti, Paolo Coni, Giuseppe Taddei and Dawn Kotoski, with Marcello Panni conducting.

title: Humana to Buy Maxicare H.M.O.'s
description: As part of a previously planned $120 million restructuring, Maxicare Health Plans Inc. agreed to sell its health maintenance organizations in Kentucky and San Antonio, representing 143,000 members, to Humana Inc. for undisclosed terms.

title: Air Crash Laid to Fuel Leak
description: A fuel leak has been found in the engine of a Horizon Air commuter aircraft that caught fire and crash-landed last month at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, injuring 19 people, investigators said. The leak occurred because a ring was out of place in a fuel filter assembly, and the filter was not seated properly, Ted Lopatkiewicz of the National Transportation Safety Board said.

title: Review/Concert; Ancora Chamber Group
description: The Ancora Chamber Ensemble brought a New England-oriented program to Merkin Concert Hall Monday night. Unfortunately, about the most piquant aspect of the evening was that a group with ''ancora'' - Italian for ''again'' - in its title would offer four world premieres.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm going to work as hard as I can to make Vice President George Bush the next President of the United States.'' - President Reagan [ A33:1. ]

title: Gerber Is Selling Furniture Group
description: The Gerber Products Company said it had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. to help it sell its furniture group, whose annual sales of more than $100 million have accounted for about 11 percent of total revenue.

title: Richard Tucker Award Goes to Richard Leech
description: Richard Leech, a 31-year-old American tenor, is the 1988 winner of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation Award, which this year amounts to $25,000 - the country's largest cash offering for a career in music. Mr. Leech is to take part in the annual Tucker Foundation concert, which is to be held this year on Nov. 13 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: RJR Picks Chairman At New Del Monte Unit
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. announced yesterday that it was creating Del Monte Foods to stand as a separate major business, alongside its tobacco and Nabisco Brands operations. It named Robert J. Carbonell chairman and chief executive of the new unit.

title: McCormick Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York Area Store Sales Off
description: Sales of several large New York retailers dropped by an average of 6.7 percent in the city in April from the period a year earlier, while the stores' overall sales in the metropolitan area fell 7.8 percent, a spot-check found.

title: Buck Clayton Big Band
description: The jazz trumpeter Buck Clayton, a Count Basie alumnus, is to appear with his big band on May 12 at 8 P.M. at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 La Guardia Place. The concert is the last of the Highlights in Jazz series at the university. Also appearing are to be Marty Napoleon, pianist; Harold Alden, guitarist; Spanky Davis, Randy Sandke and Paul Cohen, trumpeters, and Loren Schoenberg, a tenor. Tickets are $9 ($6.50 for students). Information: 998-4999.

title: Health: Clinical Advances; Confident Obstetricians Discovering New Frontiers of Prenatal Diagnosis
description: With growing confidence in their abilities to perform delicate procedures, obstetricians are pushing the limits of prenatal diagnosis, offering tests at times in pregnancy when the tests had been thought too dangerous.

title: Laidlaw's Chief Sells Big Stake
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd.'s chairman, Michael G. DeGroote, unable to attract a buyer for his entire company, said today that he had sold his controlling stake in North America's largest school bus operator to Canadian Pacific Ltd. for $500 million (Canadian), or about $404 million.

title: 'Rapist's Voice' Trial Ending in Shouts
description: In deliberations that have turned into shouting matches, a jury here is grappling with an unusual and emotion-charged case - a masked rapist who terrorized Long Island's South Shore, leaving a string of victims who say they can identify him not on sight, but by his taped voice.

title: Reuter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Into the World With a Learning Difficulty
description: Sam Clinton, 17 years old, likes to prepare Korean dishes for his family and talks about working someday as a chef or restaurant manager. He could study the restaurant business at a junior college, but his mother, Dr. Elizabeth Dane, worries about his chances for success.

title: Home Office Reference Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Technical Tape Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $460,000.

title: Corrections
description: The Foreign Exchange table in Business Day last Saturday misstated the value of the dollar in South Korean won for Friday's trading. It was 735.90 won to the dollar.

title: Aerosonic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Aifs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months included about $400,000 of non-recurring gains from foreign currency transactions.

title: A GARDENER'S WORLD
description: I WAS just beginning to relax a bit, as last fall's planting rewarded me with some attractive new wild tulips and as this spring's planting was almost finished. Then something gruesome turned up in my garden and I suspect in a good many others in the Northeast. It bears an ugly-sounding name, plasmolysis.

title: A Feasible End Run For Food to Ethiopia
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamilton Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports People; Defending Budd
description: One day after Zola Budd abandoned her bid to run in the Olympic Games for Britain and returned to her hometown of Bloemfontein in South Africa, saying she was angry and bitter but too exhausted to continue fighting against critics, newspapers in South Africa took to the defense of Budd. The Citizen, a pro-Government daily in Johannesburg, said to Budd's foes: ''You have inflicted the grossest persecution on a young and world-renowned athlete, and if you have destroyed her international career -and we doubt whether she will ever run again overseas - you will stand condemned as bigots, blackmailers and political bullyboys.''(AP)

title: Doughtie's Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Central Vermont Public Servce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texan Charged With Plot to Slay Mayor of San Antonio and Others
description: The police here have arrested a former Congressional candidate of the Libertarian Party on a charge of plotting to have Mayor Henry Cisneros and other public officials assassinated.

title: In Gdansk, Elders Watched as the Young Struck
description: They stood there in the faded blue denim of Poland's working class, broad men with their hands dug deep in pockets against a chill wind off the Baltic Sea.

title: Business Men's Assurance Co of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $807,000 from investment losses. c-After investment gains of $1,389,000 and a tax credit of $383,000.

title: 'Ridiculous' Game Just Fine With Mets
description: Dave Smith, the Houston closer who couldn't finish off the Mets Wednesday night, had no problem today describing the game.

title: Child Care Crisis Cries Out for Federal Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Baltek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Paris Gives Only a Few Posts to Centrists
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard announced the formation of a Cabinet today whose weightiest portfolios went to members of his Socialist Party. Only a few posts were given to independents and centrists.

title: Restaurants
description: Mezzogiorno If you are addicted to the buoyant northern Italian fare at Mezzaluna on the Upper East Side but rarely find a free table in its dollhouse-size dining room, an alternative is the new SoHo branch, called Mezzogiorno. The menu at this casually sophisticated trattoria is similar to that of the original: sprightly carpaccios and salads, vivid pastas and excellent brick-oven pizzas.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings for the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. are $3.52 for the latest first quarter, compared with $2.54 for year-ago period. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings are $1.94 and $1.40 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Sales represent sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Health of Vietnam Veterans
description: A Federal study finds that Vietnam veterans are as physically healthy as other veterans but that they have more emotional problems. Page A13.

title: Dr. Carroll Daugherty, 82, Dies; Economist Shaped Pension Plans
description: Dr. Carroll Roop Daugherty, a distinguished economist, labor arbitrator and educator, died of liver cancer Wednesday at the Scripps Memorial Hospitals in La Jolla, Calif. He was 87 years old and lived in La Jolla.

title: Duckworth Honored
description: Kevin Duckworth, the 7-foot center who nearly tripled his scoring average and helped lead the Portland Trail Blazers to 53 victories, has been named the National Basketball Association's most improved player, receiving 33 of the 80 votes from a national panel of news-media representatives. Duckworth, who was traded from the San Antonio Spurs to Portland for Walter Berry midway through his rookie season in 1986-87, averaged 15.8 points and 7.4 rebounds this season. (AP)

title: The Shows and Where to See Them
description: The coming of the American Institute of Architects convention to New York has unleashed a virtual torrent of architectural exhibitions, tours, events and displays in the city. This is a summary of those that will be open to the public. Hours and dates vary; telephone ahead. EXHIBITIONS AMERICAN CRAFT MUSEUM, 40 West 53d Street (956-6047). ''Architectural Art.'' INTERNATIONAL DESIGN CENTER/NEW YORK, 30-20 Thomson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens (718-937-7474). Four exhibitions: ''Architects Inside,'' ''Architectural Transformations: The Photographs of Judith Turner,'' ''Art in Public Spaces,'' and ''School Architecture: U.S. Earthquake Program in Southern Italy.'' (Opening Sunday.) URBAN CENTER, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street (935-3960). ''Student Work From the Moscow Institute of Architecture'' and ''10 on 10: Directions in New York City Architecture in the 80's.'' JACOB K. JAVITS CONVENTION CENTER, 11th Avenue between 34th and 37th Streets (216-2000). ''The Exceptional One: Women in American Architecture,'' and ''Student Work by New York City's Five Schools of Architecture.'' (One-day pass to convention floor, available at registration desk,required.) ARSENAL GALLERY, 64th Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park (360-8244). ''A Tale of Two Fairs.'' NATIONAL ACADEMY OF DESIGN, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 90th Street (369-4880). ''The Experimental Tradition: 25 Years of American Architecture Competitions, 1960-1985.'' (Opens May 17.) CUSTOM HOUSE, 1 Bowling Green. ''Grands Projets: Paris 1979-89.'' MAX PROTETCH GALLERY WAREHOUSE, 214 Lafayette Street (226-8957). ''New York Architecture.'' NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400). ''The Rise and Fall of New York'' and ''Artistic Houses.'' NEW YORK SCHOOL OF INTERIOR DESIGN GALLERY, 155 East 56th Street (753-5365). ''The Rockefellers' New York.'' BATTERY PARK CITY, lobby of 1 World Financial Center, corner of Liberty and West Streets (416-5300). ''New York's New Riverfront: The Many Parks of Battery Park City And Beyond.'' BROOKLYN MUSEUM, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000). ''A New Brooklyn Museum: The Master Plan Competition.'' PAINE WEBBER ART GALLERY, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street (713-2885). ''Infill Housing: Reweaving the Urban Fabric.'' STOREFRONT FOR ART AND ARCHITECTURE, 97 Kenmare Street (431-5795). ''From Destruction to Construction by Kawamata.'' TWINING GALLERY, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street (431-1830). ''Genus Loci.'' HOYA CRYSTAL GALLERY, 450 Park Avenue, at 57th Street (223-6335) ''Architecture of Glass.'' COOPER-HEWITT MUSEUM, 2 East 91st Street (860-6898). ''The Art That Is Life.'' MAX PROTETCH GALLERY, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street (966-5454). ''Bernard Tschumi.'' STATEN ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM,, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. (718-448-2500). ''Building Buildings.'' MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street (534-1034). ''City Play.'' MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, 11 West 53d Street (708-9400). ''Designs for Independent Living.'' NEW YORK SPACE OF FENDRICK GALLERY, 216 Lafayette Street (226-3881). ''Sculpture in Architecture.'' TOURS

title: I.B.M.'s New Line
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new line of high-performance products that allow customers to turn their typewriters into modified word processors. The Wheelwriter 10, 30, 50 and 70 all include spelling aids while the 50 and 70 have 25-line screen display. They include options to expand memory to 720,000 bytes with a diskette drive. The typewriters, to be manufactured at I.B.M.'s Lexington plant, carry suggested retail prices ranging from $599 for the Personal Wheelwriter to $1,795 for the Wheelwriter 70.

title: Votrax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Marcor Development reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $783,916 from tax credits. c-Includes a loss of $273,886 from discontinued operations, a gain of $526,832 on reorganization of debt, and a gain of $939,110 from tax credits.

title: Ambulance Crew Backed in Inquiry on a Death
description: Reports that a mortally wounded man waited 40 minutes on a Brooklyn street for an ambulance Monday were exaggerated by at least 15 minutes, the police and the Emergency Medical Service, which operates the city's ambulance system, said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was surprised by the news reports that have said my endorsement last evening of the Vice President was 'lukewarm.' I am enthusiastic, fully committed and, as I have said, will go all out to make Vice President Bush the next President of the United States.'' - President Reagan. [ D17:4. ]

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cineplex Odeon Corp., Toronto, a film production, exhibition and distribution company, said it would form a new unit to build and acquire 100 movie screens in London. It said the unit would spend about $:50 million ($94.2 million).

title: Specialist Rule Gains Approval
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a New York Stock Exchange rule requiring specialists on the exchange floor to maintain a higher permanent level of capital to make markets in stocks.

title: Inspiration Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included equity in losses of unconsolidated affiliates of $2,095,000- -IRC's 50 percent interests in two gold affiliates. The year-ago first quarter's results have been restated to reflect two accounting changes adopted in the 1987 fourth quarter: the full consolidation of IRC's leasing subsidiary and a change in accounting for agribusiness inventories from the LIFO to the FIFO method.

title: Genesco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Lancer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies on Wednesday about workers leaving the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, misidentified the portrait they carried. It showed the Black Madonna of Czestochowa.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Taffetas

title: Foiled, Car Bomber Sought To Prevent Blast on Cyprus
description: The driver of a car rigged with explosives that blew up in Nicosia Wednesday was racing to warn an accomplice not to detonate the bomb, Interior Minister Christodoulos Veniamin said today.

title: Andre-Michel Schub
description: Andre Michel-Schub, the pianist, is to be the soloist with the Queens Symphony Orchestra in the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4 tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Colden Center, Queens College, at Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, in Flushing. The program, to be conducted by Arthur Fagen, will also include Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 and Prometheus Overture, and is to be repeated on Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $14 to $19. Information: (718) 275-5000 or (718) 293-8080.

title: Economic Scene; Behind Rate Rise, The Fed's Hand
description: THIS week's jump in the prime rate by half a point, back to the 9 percent pre-crash level of October, troubled the stock market, but it was no surprise. The prime usually lags behind other interest rates, most of which have been climbing for the past two months, and its rise was overdue.

title: Koch Seeks New Rules On Nightclub Closings
description: The Koch administration yesterday proposed sweeping changes in New York City's zoning law that would fundamentally alter how the city controls the type and amount of music and other entertainment allowed in bars and restaurants.

title: Proposal to Dismiss Charges Against Noriega Is Assailed
description: An Administration proposal to drop all drug-related charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega if he leaves power in Panama was sharply criticized today by members of Congress, law-enforcement officials and Panamanian opposition leaders.

title: On Economy, Dukakis Recasts Mold
description: In planning how to manage the nation's economy if he becomes President, Michael S. Dukakis is relying on a loose and growing circle of advisers who, like the Governor, have cast aside many of the policies of earlier Democrats that allotted Government a major role that required high spending and high taxes.

title: Lindal Cedar Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mixing Ballet With the Blues Of Ray Charles
description: AS the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival draws to a close this weekend, the final two evenings will feature an audacious collaboration that brings together the formality of ballet with the spontaneity of rhythm-and-blues.

title: INDIAN TROOPS KILL 4 SIKHS AT TEMPLE
description: Government troops shot and killed at least four Sikh militants early this morning when they tried to flee a siege of the Golden Temple here by Government forces, police officials said.

title: Shows Celebrate New York Architecture
description: IT goes without saying that New York City, just by itself, is one of the great architectural shows in the world. So how to add spice to it to celebrate the arrival of between 10,000 and 14,000 people expected this weekend for the annual convention of the American Institute of Architects? The city has not played host to the nation's professional architects since 1967, and New York's local architects, determined to give their colleagues from around the country something more than just the buildings that are here every day, have decided to use the convention as a chance to reach out to a public that in recent years has become more and more involved in architecture.

title: Durakon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that if the operations of DFM Corp., acquired Sept. 1, 1987, had been included in the first quarter 1987 results, net income and sales on a pro forma basis would have been $1,033,000 and $28,994,000, respectively.

title: MAN FOUND GUILTY IN 2 OF 16 DEATHS
description: A man accused of killing 16 people last December was convicted of two of the slayings today and was sentenced to death.

title: Market Place; Behind the Rise In Texaco's Stock
description: MOST oil stocks move primarily on oil prices. But Texaco in the last few weeks has been jumping in anticipation of a bid for control by Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, as well as an anticipated round of asset sales. Those sales seemed imminent when Texaco emerged two months ago from a year in bankruptcy, but shareholders are still waiting.

title: Boos Turn Into a Barrage
description: At Byrne Meadowlands Arena, where acts of civil, and uncivil, disobedience have become something of a playoff trend, the fans got into the act tonight after the Bruins scored a second-period goal that produced a 2-2 tie in a game the Devils won, 6-3.

title: Citrus Entrepreneur Buys a Stake in Coffee
description: Randon A. Samelson may be thinking about putting coffee alongside his orange juice.

title: Accel International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $5,000 on the sale of investments and a tax credit of $50,000. c-Included a gain of $410,000 from the sale of investments and a gain of $325,000 from the partial sale of a unit. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 5 percent common stock dividend paid in May.

title: Royal Palm Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Brazil and Banks Seem Close to New Debt Pact
description: Negotiations between the Treasury and major international banks over a restructuring of most of Brazil's foreign debt are ''close to a breakthrough,'' the banks' chief negotiator said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Looking for a Home
description: Charles Blitzer, the newly appointed director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, is already itchy to move. He notes that the Wilson Center is being cramped by crowded quarters in the Castle of the Smithsonian Institution on the Mall.

title: Jury Strips 2 Concrete Racketeers of Their Assets
description: A jury decided yesterday that two businessmen must forfeit millions of dollars in assets to the Federal Government because they took part in the racketeering activities of the Genovese crime family.

title: Applied Spectrum Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Public Service Co of New Mexico reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Blinding Cruelty Of Laser Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauda Inaugural Flight
description: Niki Lauda, the former racing car champion, flew a new Boeing 767 to Hong Kong Wednesday on an inaugural flight for his Vienna-based airline, Lauda Air.

title: Wall to Wall Sound & Video Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $712,000 from cumulative effect of a change in accounting. The company said that in May 1987 it changed its fiscal year-end to the last day of February from May 31. Therefore, there are no comparable figures for the year-earlier period.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY AN ANIMATION OCCASION

title: Seacoast Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago periods per share earnings are not available; the company went public in March 1987.

title: Olympia & York
description: Canada's Olympia & York Developments Ltd. has agreed to acquire a 33 percent stake in Stanhope Properties P.L.C. for $:137 million ($258 million), the British real estate group said. Olympia & York is developing London's Canary Wharf.

title: Introducing Low-Alcohol Ball Parks
description: Major league baseball executives, concerned and confused by the ugly episode last month at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati, nonetheless maintain that ball parks across the country are generally safer, more civilized and more uniformly sober than in recent years.

title: Mor-Flo Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $1,737,000 from an accounting change.

title: A State Agency Curbs Philadelphia Hospital
description: The state Health Department closed all but two units of a Philadelphia hospital today, saying inadequate care might have caused 12 deaths in the last year.

title: Ford Sets Strategy to Diversify
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would invest more heavily in products and manufacturing technology, strive to increase the share of its profits from financial services and develop a third business sector, probably in electronics.

title: Possible Bidder Signals Jefferies
description: Jefferies Group Inc. said today that it had received an unsolicited takeover inquiry from an unidentified third party and had adopted a ''poison pill'' defensive measure. Jefferies is the parent of a

title: Teacher Tells Committee Of Ordeal by Bureaucracy
description: A 24-year-old teacher who had long dreamed of teaching a first-grade class in New York City's public schools told yesterday how three months at the mercy of the Board of Education's bureaucracy and an elementary school's hierarchy forced her to quit.

title: Cubs Top Padres in 10 Innings
description: Damon Berryhill, a rookie, doubled home the winning run with two out in the 10th inning today, and the Chicago Cubs beat the San Diego Padres, 2-1.

title: American Fiber Optics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arias at Carnegie Hall
description: Veronica Tyler, a soprano, is to sing arias by Handel and Verdi, songs by Strauss, Faure, Rodrigo and Poulenc, and a group of spirituals, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 8 P.M. Her accompanist will be Margaret Singer. Tickets are $7 to $17. Information: 247-7800.

title: Review/Film; Australian Victory at Beersheba
description: ''The Lighthorsemen'' is a technically elaborate, artistically clumsy Australian film that tries to celebrate the heroism of 800 Australian mounted soldiers who triumphed over thousands of Turks and Germans at Beersheba, in southern Palestine, on Oct. 31, 1917. The battle was a key to the eventual Allied victory in the Middle East in World War I.

title: U.S. Halts Funds to Develop Self-Contained Heart Implant
description: The National Institutes of Health announced yesterday that the Federal Government would no longer finance the development of an artificial human heart. The decision does not halt all artificial heart research, but it deals a blow to the half-century-old dream of building a mechanical pump to replace a heart that no longer functions.

title: Greenspan Asks Caution
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, today urged a cautious approach to regulatory reforms in the financial markets.

title: Grenada Sunburst Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included securities gains of $480,461 for the latest first quarter and $822,788 for the year-ago period.

title: Program Trade Move Downplayed by Merc
description: Top officials of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange are seeking to play down the effect on the exchange of a decision by major brokerage firms to halt a popular form of program trading for their own accounts.

title: How to Neutralize Exit Polls
description: Recently, NBC television began backing away from its policy of not projecting election winners until the polls have closed. This will certainly increase pressure on the other networks to do the same thing, and will resurrect a problem that appeared in the 1980 Presidential election. That year, the TV networks announced election outcomes before all eligible voters had voted.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Parable, by Valenti
description: For some years now, Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has been inveighing against what he perceives as the cable television industry's perpetration of rampant evil, the common denominator of which he calls ''monopoly.'' He was doing his own version of ''Hooray for Hollywood'' again Wednesday in a hearing on the video marketplace before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance.

title: Systems Engineering & Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: GWC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the fight for control of Allegheny International Inc. misstated the movement in the company's stock and investor reaction to the entry of Bennett S. description: Soviet troops have begun moving out of positions in eastern Afghanistan in preparation for their first withdrawal from a major Afghan city this weekend, Afghan and Western diplomats said today.

Harley-Davidson's chairman, Vaughn L. Beals, in a speech to the Milwaukee World Trade Association on Wednesday, said exports were the key to the company's return to profitability.

description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Tracy Jones, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Leo Garcia, outfielder, from Nashville of the American Association. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Bill Buckner, first baseman-designated hitter. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Sent Mike Maddux, pitcher, to Maine of the International League for injury rehabilitation. TORONTO (AL) - Placed Manny Lee, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Nelson Liriano, infielder, from Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL MIAMI (USBL) - Announced that Robert Massone has purchased the franchise. Named George Edis general manager; Paul Castells marketing director; George Whittaker head coach and Mike Weiss assistant coach. COLLEGES COLUMBIA - Named Shawn Ladda women's soccer coach. GEORGE MASON - Named Ernie Nestor basketball coach. SAN JOSE STATE - Annoucned that they are dropping its track-and-field, cross-country and wrestling programs, and women's field hockey at the end of this academic year. STEPHEN F. AUSTIN - Named Pete Smith baseball coach. WEST TEXAS STATE - Named Steve Graf football coach. WISCONSIN-STEVENS POINTS - Dismissed D. J. LeRoy, football coach. FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Mickey Pruitt, safety, and Phil Solatka, defensive lineman. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Reggie Northrup, defensive back; Jim Smith, defensive tackle; Jeff Pegues, linebacker; Limbo Parks, offensive guard; Dale Dawson, kicker; Joey Charles and John Adams, running backs, and Mike Akiu and Ron Ingram, wide receivers. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed Ray Butler and Jimmy Teal, wide receivers; Andre Hardy, fullback; Bruce Mathison, quarterback, and Randall Morris, running back. HOCKEY QUEBEC (NHL) - Signed Joe Sakic, center. SOCCER MAJOR INDOOR SOCCER LEAGUE -Announced that the league's headquarters will move from New York to Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 1.

Rico and his best friend, Banana (Laszlo I. Kisch), have been busily running an ingenious movie-pirating operation, but even when he isn't working, Rico is apt to be glued to the set watching an old movie or perhaps the Academy Awards. As Daniel Helfer's ''Record'' begins, it appears as if this is enough to keep Rico happy.

title: Bid for Rowntree Arouses Anxiety

British politicians have strongly objected to Nestle's bid of $:2.1 billion ($3.9 billion) for Rowntree, which makes Kit Kat candy bars, saying they want the company to remain British. They expressed anxiety this week when the Government decided not to block the General Cinema Corporation, a United States concern, from holding a stake in Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.

The year 1988 excludes sales from 1,000 convenience stores and the business units being divested; 1987 excludes sales only from the business units being divested. 1988 includes the amortization of the excess of cost over fair value of the net assets acquired in the merger, the second step of the LBO, as well as other LBO-related non-cash expenses.

title: Defense Ridicules Charges in Colombian's Cocaine Smuggling Trial
description: The defense ended its closing arguments today in the cocaine smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, ridiculing prosecutors for trying to make the Colombian appear responsible for the drug problem in the United States.

title: Marsh Seeks Return
description: Terry Marsh, the former world light welterweight champion, wants to return to the ring eight months after being diagnosed as an epileptic. The unbeaten Briton said yesterday that he believed the diagnosis was wrong and that the blackouts he had been suffering may not have been symptoms of epilepsy. Marsh plans to apply for a fighter's license, primarily for sparring purposes but even competitively if the price is right. John Morris, general secretary of the British Boxing Board of Control, said Marsh would have to produce conclusive proof of his fitness from three doctors before he would be allowed even to spar. Marsh won the International Boxing Federation title by stopping an American, Joe Louis Manley, last year and defended it once before his sudden retirement in September.(AP)

Auden, and Ralph Vaughan Williams's ''Dona Nobis Pacem,'' a setting of Walt Whitman's Civil War poetry, at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street, on Sunday at 7 P.M. Nancy Bergman, a soprano, and Richard Christopher, a baritone, will be the soloists in the Vaughan Williams work, which is to be accompanied by David Graf, an organist. Charles Pilling will conduct. Tickets are $7. Information: 383-0808.

The latest second quarter loss is after an unrealized gain of $8.2 million recorded to increase the carrying amount of the company's portfolio of marketable equity securities to market. description: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that its shareholders had approved an amendment to the company's charter that affirms the power of Katharine Graham, the chairman and chief executive, and her family to accept or reject any acquisition proposal.

description: A juror at the center of a dispute in the case of a woman found guilty of causing her husband's death by tampering with a product has told a local newspaper that she herself was the victim of earlier product tampering.

title: Wooing White Sox
description: Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida last night agreed to meet today in Tallahassee with Eddie Einhorn and Jerry Reinsdorf, the owners of the Chicago White Sox. Earlier yesterday, Martinez canceled the breakfast meeting after he heard reports that the White Sox would not be moving to Florida, but would probably keep playing in Chicago. Martinez agreed to reschedule the meeting after being asked to by State Senator Curt Kiser. A state House committee approved a $30 million package to lure the team to Florida, but a corresponding Senate committee failed to include the money in its version of the annual state budget. The White Sox said Wednesday that they had agreed not to move if Illinois lawmakers approved a revised lease on a new Chicago stadium, saving the team up to $60 million over 10 years. ''They've given us their word that if we pass this bill, they'll stay,'' Gov. James R. Thompson said. ''Better than that, I can't ask.'' Under the Illinois proposal, the team's attendance would determine its rent on a $120 stadium to be built by a state authority near aging Comiskey Park, the team's home. The White Sox would not be required to pay rent in any year in which the team's attendance does not reach 1.2 million customers, and would split $4 million in annual operating costs with the Illinois state authority. Thompson, who said Illinois legislative leaders and Mayor Eugene Sawyer of Chicago had endorsed the proposal, hopes to begin legislative action next week. ''We don't want to take a back seat to St. Petersburg, Florida,'' he said. ''If this were a factory, we wouldn't let it go to Florida.'' (AP)

title: Black Publishing Firms Subject of Conference
description: A free daylong conference on the issue of black-owned publishing houses will be held tomorrow at the City College of New York, North Academic Center, Convent Avenue and 138th Street. It begins at 10:30 A.M. with a discussion on the history of black publishing houses over the last 70 years. The future of such publishing houses will be the topic of a talk at 1:30 P.M. A book fair is also planned from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: Moderate Inflation Seen
description: Inflation in the most-developed countries is likely to remain moderate through 1989 while growth is likely to slow, the Bank of England said today. In its quarterly bulletin, the British central bank predicted consumer prices in major nations would rise 3.2 percent this year and 3.7 percent in 1989. Last year, consumer prices in the developed world rose an estimated 3 percent. The bank also forecast that major countries' economies would grow by 2.7 percent this year and 2.0 percent in 1989. Last year, they grew by an estimated 2.9 percent.

title: Review/Theater; The Telekinetic 'Carrie,' With Music
description: Those who have the time and money to waste on only one Anglo-American musical wreck on Broadway this year might well choose ''Carrie,'' the new Royal Shakespeare Company co-production at the Virginia Theater. If ''Chess'' slides to its final scene as solemnly and pompously as the Titanic, then ''Carrie'' expires with fireworks like the Hindenberg. True, the fireworks aren't the greatest; the intended Stephen King pyrotechnics wouldn't frighten the mai-tai drinkers at a Polynesian restaurant. But when was the last time you saw a Broadway song and dance about the slaughtering of a pig? They've got one to open Act II of ''Carrie,'' and no expense has been spared in bringing the audience some of the loudest oinking this side of Old McDonald's Farm.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: The man was 58 years old, out of work and broke. So, despite degrees from Dartmouth and New York University Law School, he found himself driving a limousine. But as much as he hated the work, things could always be worse: the next passenger could be one of his former partners.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: MBNA Credit Card Trust is offering $500 million worth of asset-backed securities with a final maturity in 1993 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The securities are backed by credit card receivables from Maryland Bank N.A. and have an estimated average life of 2.51 years.

title: AIDS Inmates Get Poor Care, Report Says
description: New York State prison inmates who have AIDS often receive inadequate medical care and are segregated with little to do in overcrowded, makeshift infirmaries, a report released yesterday by a nonprofit group says.

description: Vice President Bush attacked the Democrats as weak on national defense today but found himself on the defensive about the strength of President Reagan's support for him.

description: Most accounts have portrayed Donald Regan's memoir ''For the Record'' as little more than an unattractive ''kiss-and-tell'' account of Nancy Reagan's fixation with the occult. That underestimates a book profitably read on several levels.

title: Connecticut Resumes Lottery After Repairs
description: About 75 percent of the state's lottery terminals were back on line today, two days after a new computer system developed a glitch that allowed tickets to be purchased after the winning numbers were announced, forcing the system to be shut down.

title: Buckner a Royal
description: Less than a week after his release by the California Angels, Bill Buckner agreed to contract terms yesterday for the remainder of the season with the Kansas City Royals. Buckner, 38 years old, will be used primarily as a designated hitter, the Royals said. Contract terms were not announced. Buckner, who has played the outfield and first base for four teams in a 17-year career, was hitting .209 with 9 runs batted in after 19 games with the Angels. He has a .292 career average with 2,607 hits, most among active players.(AP)

title: Study Ties Teen-Age Suicide To Abnormalities in the Brain
description: Depressed teen-agers intent on killing themselves show chemical abnormalities in the brain that appear to predispose them to suicide, according to a study released today.

title: 2d Officer Cleared in Hit-Run That Injured Bicycling Child
description: A former New York City police officer was acquitted yesterday of charges that he ran down a bicycle-riding child in an unmarked police car, then fled the scene and tried to cover up the hit-and-run by falsifying records.

title: Treatment for Common Type of Fish Poisoning Is Discovered
description: Doctors have discovered a simple but apparently effective treatment for severe cases of the most frequently reported form of fish poisoning affecting people.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Last Sunday, the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point announced it was forfeiting its share of last year's National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics national football co-championship and the rest of its 1987 schedule because it unknowingly used two ineligible players from Dallas who had transferred last fall. This week, one of the ineligible players, Keith Majors, a fullback, said during a radio broadcast that Coach D. J. LeRoy was aware that he and Aarton Kenney, a wide receiver, were ineligible because they had not listed on their records a college they had attended at which they had played football. Yesterday, LeRoy was dismissed by Chancellor Philip R. Marshall. (AP)

description: Extensive medical examinations show that the physical health of veterans who served in Vietnam is not significantly different from that of soldiers stationed elsewhere, according to a major Federal study released today.

title: Medex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Film; Terror and Haunting, Through a Child's Eyes
description: Ghosts are rarely as intriguing as the people they haunt, so ''Lady in White'' has a shrewdly chosen focus. Its sympathetic, engaging, haunted hero is Frankie Scarlatti, a 9-year-old boy who sees the ghost of a murdered 10-year-old girl. Frankie is locked in a spooky school cloakroom on Halloween night in 1962, when he sees the apparition of Melissa and is nearly strangled himself. Though he is rescued, in the next months Melissa reappears, and their mysterious attacker, suspected of killing 11 children in a decade, is still on the loose.

title: Tass Hails Philby as 'Heroic'
description: Tass eulogized H. A. R. (Kim) Philby today as a master spy who carried out heroic and seemingly impossible feats to protect the Soviet Union from Western agents.

Second Genetic Code Deciphered, Solving a Protein Synthesis Puzzle
description: Scientists have deciphered a second genetic code that has eluded molecular biologists for two decades. The code directs one of several steps in the synthesis of proteins inside cells, the basic process of life.

title: Big Client Pressed 2 Firms To Halt Program Trading
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. and Morgan Stanley & Company, two of the Wall Street firms that suspended their program trading on Tuesday, had been warned just days before that they would not get the investment banking business of a large corporate client unless they halted the controversial practice.

title: Units of Travelers
description: The Travelers Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer its Canadian subsidiaries for sale. The properties to be sold include Travcan Ltd. and two of its insurance subsidiaries, Travelers Life Insurance Company of Canada and Travelers Indemnity Company of Canada. The company, which is based in Hartford, said it would concentrate on its United States insurance operations and use the capital from the sale to finance long-range business goals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY A new method of regulating long-distance telephone rates was proposed by the F.C.C. The plan could save callers $1.6 billion in the next four years, the agency said. The new system would allow A.T.&T. and local phone companies to set their own rates for long-distance calls and access charges as long as they do not exceed new price ceilings. [ Page D1. ] Retail sales fell 0.6 percent in April, the first setback in six months. But economists said they were not particularly concerned because the March figure was revised upward significantly. [ D2. ] Representatives of the semiconductor industry reached an accord with the Pentagon that will clear the way for a computer chip consortium to receive $100 million from the Government. [ D4. ] COMPANIES A team led by G.E. was chosen by the Pentagon for one of the largest contracts yet for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The initial contract, to serve as architects for a system of interceptor missiles, sensors and communications links, is worth $236 million. The G.E. group beat out one led by General Dynamics. [ D1. ] A large client warned Salomon and Morgan Stanley that it would withdraw its business if they did not halt their program trading. The warning came from Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of American International. [ D1. ] Chicago Merc officials are seeking to play down the effect of the program trading halt. [ D4. ] Gruner & Jahr has lured back Elizabeth Crow to serve as president of its American division, Gruner & Jahr U.S.A., only a month after she resigned as editor in chief of Parents magazine, its flagship publication in the United States. Ms. Crow had accepted the editor in chief's position at Conde Nast's Self magazine. [ D1. ] Ford will invest more heavily in manufacturing technology, strive to increase the share of its profits from financial services and develop a third business sector, probably in electronics. [ D3. ] Irving Bank said three independent directors might talk with its suitors, Bank of New York and Banca Commerciale. [ D4. ] Marvin Davis has written to Lorimar-Telepictures, saying that he is weighing a $15-a-share all-cash offer for the company. Lorimar has agreed to be acquired by Warner. [ D14. ] A Textron subsidiary became the first U.S. company to win a major airframe contract for the Airbus. [ D3. ] Jefferies Group has received an unsolicited takeover inquiry from an unidentified third party. [ D3. ] MARKETS The Treasury's quarterly auction ended on a modestly successful note, as investors purchased $8.5 billion of new 30-year bonds at yield levels a bit lower than had been expected. Analysts said demand from Japanese investors was surprisingly brisk. Domestic demand, on the other hand, was said to be light. [ D1. ] The stock market failed to shake off its worries about interest rates and inflation, although the Dow Jones industrial average gained 2.15 points, to close at 1,968.00. The Dow had dropped 37.80 points on Wednesday. [ D4. ] The dollar finished slightly lower against most other currencies in U.S. trading after rising marginally in Europe. Gold was up $2.20 an ounce on the Comex, to $451.90. [ D11. ] Soybean futures' five-day rally ended as forecasts of rain prompted profit-taking. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL Negotiations over Brazil's debt are ''close to a breakthrough,'' the chief negotiator for commercial banking creditors said. An agreement is expected next week. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Federal Reserve does not like to explain in clear English what it intends to do, lest it lose flexibility and give the markets a fixed target to shoot at. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Texaco's stock price has been climbing in anticipation of a bid for control by Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, as well as an anticipated round of asset sales. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: The Shoreham Syndrome
description: New York's politicians propose cutting a deal to scrap the completed, ready-to-run Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island. That folly could threaten the nation's security, not just Long Island's, by further eroding public confidence in nuclear power. Its cost will become clear enough when brownouts or even rolling blackouts hit Hempstead this summer, and when oil prices once again rise sharply.

title: Devils Tap Survival Instincts
description: It was a case of survival of the wiliest, and the Devils, for the first time in this Stanley Cup semifinal, outwitted the Bruins. The Devils kept their playoff crusade intact with a 6-3 victory that was the first indication, through six games, that they might be capable of subduing the Bruins.

title: Integrated Generics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $7,991 for the quarter and $60,901 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $184,806 for the quarter and $322,144 for the 6 months.

title: Self Loses Editor Before She Starts
description: Gruner & Jahr, the West German publisher, has lured back Elizabeth Crow to serve as president of its American division, Gruner & Jahr U.S.A., only a month after she resigned as editor in chief of Parents magazine, its flagship publication in the United States.

title: Review/Ballet; Clark Tippet Premiere
description: Clark Tippet, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has choreographed his second ballet and named it after his choice of composer and score - ''Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1.'' There is no need to search for a verdict on the premiere: downright terrific will do.

title: Demolition Plays the Palace (But the Theater Plays On)
description: As startling as it is to behold, the latest demolition spectacle on Broadway - involving the ''Valhalla of Vaudeville'' - is actually a little less than meets the eye. Although the Palace Theater Building is being torn down, the theater itself is to be spared.

title: Pro-Med Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it has no year- ago quarter comparison figures because it had been reporting earnings on a semi-annual basis. The company also said the FASB 91 accounting rule change resulted in a 1-cent-a-share reduction of first quarter income.

title: Molson Companies reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 426 money market mutual funds decreased $3.2 billion, to $270.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 117 institutional funds decreased $3.65 billion, to $72.43 billion. Assets of the 212 general-purpose funds were up $217.1 million, to $89.94 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $237.6 million, to $115.9 billion.

title: William Sunners, Author, 84
description: William Sunners, who wrote more than 100 books on how to win prizes in contests, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Zimmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit or $270,000 and also includes charges of $8,740,000 from the writedown of carrying values of properties held for sale and inventories, as well as gains of $7,203,000 recognized on the sale of businesses divested during the year.

title: Accounting Merger
description: Laventhol & Horwath, the nation's ninth-largest accounting and consulting firm, announced that it would merge with Stuart Becker & Company, accountants and consultants in New York. Laventhol & Horwath said the combined New York office would have 550 employees and revenues of $70 million. Laventhol & Horwath is based in Philadelphia and has offices in 50 American cities. Mr. Becker, who started his company in 1977, is a former vice president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

title: Safeguard Health Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
B. Cobbey Crisler, Biblical Scholar, 55
description: B. Cobbey Crisler, a Biblical scholar, educator and author, died of a heart attack on April 25 at his home in Carmel Valley, Calif. He was 55 years old.

title: Dukakis Builds Congress Ties
description: Behaving very much like the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today picked up two major endorsements on Capitol Hill and tried to present himself as a executive who knows how to work with legislators.

title: New Jersey Plans U.S. Arts Convention
description: New Jersey will be the host for a National Arts Convention in October, Governor Kean announced yesterday. Some 300 delegates from arts institutions across the country are expected to attend and will try to develop a consensus on national goals.

title: Marion Hartshorne, Professor, 78
description: Marion Holmes Hartshorne, the Harry Emerson Fosdick professor emeritus of philosophy and religion at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., died of a malignant brain tumor Tuesday at Community Memorial Hospital in Hamilton. He was 78 years old and lived in Hamilton.

title: 10 Years as Practitioner, None as Lawyer
description: The Chicago law firm of Sonnenschein Carlin Nath & Rosenthal appeared before a Federal judge here last week with a very unusual motion. The firm wanted to withdraw one of its partners from a civil case because the partner, a highly regarded trial specialist, had never been licensed to practice law.

title: Fitchburg Gas & Electric Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
United Insurance Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $123,000 and $195,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Acmat Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $310,700. The company said the year-ago quarter net from operations included a gain of $1,050,000 relating to the sale of a portion of shares held in an affiliate.

title: Viner, E A Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the 1988 first quarter earnings include the business and operations of Fahnestock & Co. since Feb. 3. Fahnestock was merged with Edward A. Viner & Co., a subsidiary of E. A. Viner Holdings Ltd.

title: A Food-Filled Festival, And Larks in the Park
description: A MILLION strolling gourmands on Ninth Avenue and several parks full of celebrators can mean only one thing: New York's festival season has begun. The appearance of the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, You Gotta Have Park Festivals in Central and Prospect Parks and a host of smaller outdoor festivities this weekend are as telltale signs of spring as the crack of a bat at Yankee Stadium or the year's first warm breeze over a newly green lawn.

title: Fighting in South Beirut Subsides As Syria and Iran Broker a Truce
description: A cease-fire brokered by Syria and Iran took hold today in southern Beirut after six days of fierce street battles between rival Shiite militiamen.

title: Concurrent Computer reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Integon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized losses of $5,878,000. c-After realized gains of $3,734,000.

title: Industrial Nations Criticize U.N. Proposal on Latin Debt
description: The United States and other industrialized nations criticized a United Nations proposal for easing Central America's foreign debts today at a special General Assembly meeting, saying the plan would set a dangerous precedent.

title: Review/Art; 'Painters by Painters' at the Academy of Design
description: The first thing to be said about the new exhibition at the National Academy of Design is that although everything in it comes from the Uffizi in Florence, it is not made up of masterpieces. Of the 30 paintings on view, 2 or 3 at most deserve that appellation.

title: Retail Sales Declined 0.6% in April
description: Retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the first setback in six months, but economists said they were not particularly concerned because the March figure was revised upward significantly.

title: First American Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a one- time transitional tax benefit of $8,996,000, or $1.62 a share.

title: Taiwan Grants Asylum to Two Who Hijacked Mainland Jet
description: Two Chinese men, seeking to defect, hijacked a domestic airliner from the mainland to Taiwan on Thursday. They were granted asylum, and the jet took the other 116 people aboard back to China early today.

title: Sharp-Shooting Devils Extend Series to a 7th Game
description: Inspired by the return of their coach, the Devils performed with intensity tonight and prevented elimination for the second time in their first trip to the playoffs.

title: Slugger Long on Patience
description: LEAD: At historic old Muzzy Field in Bristol, Conn., where the Big East tournament gets under way next week, a towering stand of trees rises behind a right field fence alluringly within striking distance of left-handed hitters.

title: Review/Film; Tax Cheats and a Japanese Nemesis
description: ''A Taxing Woman'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 26, 1987. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Wilander Upset: Ronald Agenor of Haiti shocked the defending champion, Mats Wilander, 6-3, 7-5, last night in the Italian Open championships in Rome. In today's quarterfinals of the $825,000 clay-court tournament, Agenor will face No. 9 Andre Agassi of the United States, who beat Thomas Muster of Austria, 6-4, 7-5, for his 14th straight victory. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, overcoming the loss of six of seven games in one stretch, advanced with a 6-3, 3-6, 6-3 victory over unseeded Guy Forget of France. In another upset, unseeded Jaime Yzaga of Peru beat seventh-seeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-1, 7-5, to advance to a match against Lendl. No. 4 Yannick Noah of France coasted to a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia. The 23-year-old Agenor, ranked 45th in the world, outplayed the second-seeded Wilander in the 1-hour-42-minute match.(AP) Mandlikova Loses: Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia upset Hana Mandlikova, 7-6, 7-5, in the German Open in West Berlin. The tournament's top-seeded player, Steffi Graf, defeated a fellow West German, Silke Meier, 6-2, 6-1, and third-ranked Claudia Kohde, also of West Germany, beat Mercedes Paz of Argentina, 6-2, 6-3. In other matches, Sylvia Hanika of West Germany defeated Isabel Cueto, 6-2, 6-4; Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia beat Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 6-3; and Sandra Cecchini of Italy downed Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 6-1, 6-1.(AP) GOLF Wiebe Leads: Mark Wiebe, a runner-up two years ago, shot a six-under-par 64 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the $750,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic. Wiebe, playing in the afternoon, when the spiked-up bent grass greens were fastest and trickiest, held a one-shot lead over Brandel Chamblee, a former University of Texas player who has yet to win on the PGA Tour. Chamblee, playing in the last group, birdied the 18th hole for a 65.(AP)

title: Offshore Logistics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,459,000 from debt forgiveness. c-Includes a gain of $16,374,000 from a restructuring.

title: F.C.C. Sets Phone-Rate Revision
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed a new method of regulating long-distance telephone rates that it said could save callers $1.6 billion in the next four years.

title: Angolans and South Africans In Congo for Talks on Peace
description: Senior Angolan and South African officials arrived here tonight for direct talks to explore a regional settlement to the conflict in Angola and the dispute over neighboring South-West Africa.

title: First United Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: Devils Force 7th Game

title: Our Towns; In Custody Case, Hiding Elephants Is the Easy Part
description: For four years, Arlan Seidon and two female elephants, Tory and Duchess, have been fugitives from the New Jersey police. ''I realize this looks like a story about an old kook who took two elephants and ran away,'' Mr. Seidon said in a rare phone interview from some place; he wouldn't say where. ''But I couldn't let my girls be abused. Sorry, I always refer to them as my girls. They're like family.''

title: First Banc Securities reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; The Omen
description: Ronald Reagan has often been accused of confusing his movie roles with his real-life experiences. But no one has suggested that he follows plot lines from novels or, more specifically, that life imitates science fiction. Until now. The capital is humming this week over the rediscovery of ''Stranger in a Strange Land,'' a science fiction novel written by Robert A. Heinlein in 1961 that concerns the chief executive of planet Earth, a man named Joseph E. Douglas.

title: The Law; Bare-Knuckles Litigation Jars Many in Dallas
description: There is a story making the rounds here of the businessman seeking a lawyer to handle his multimillion-dollar lawsuit. He went from one plush office suite to the next, giving written psychological tests to the city's best lawyers.

title: In Poland, a Draw and a Challenge
description: Police action, church mediation and the calming counsel of Solidarity veterans have combined to halt Poland's latest labor revolt. The last workers left Gdansk's Lenin Shipyard neither broken nor victorious. The Jaruzelski Government bargained with them, but conceded little.

title: Inter-City Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Stand Firm Against School Surrender
description: During seven months of contract negotiations, New York City's Board of Education has tried to break the stranglehold of the school custodians. The board president, Robert Wagner Jr., has now issued a bold ultimatum: Unless ''significant progress'' is made toward a new contract by next week, the board will hire private contractors to clean the schools. It's a strong step on his part; he deserves strong public support.

title: Forest Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred stock dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago first quarter.

title: N.H.L. to Discuss Game 4
description: The Boston Bruins' grievance over the strange proceedings in the fourth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Devils here last Sunday will be discussed at the National Hockey League's board of governors meeting, which is scheduled for next month.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The New York City Industrial Development Agency yesterday announced plans to issue more than $166.5 million worth of bonds, more than three-fourths of them on behalf of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking firm.

title: Hewlett-Packard Strategic Alliance
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had formed a strategic alliance with Northern Telecom Inc. to provide corporate-wide networking systems incorporating distributed computing and telecommunications. The new organization, known as the Corporate Networks Operation, will be based in Santa Clara, Calif., and will be financed and managed equally by the two companies.

title: Build, Don't Bleed, Economies
description: LEAD: When the complexities are cut away, the international debt problem reduces to a simple choice: bleed or build.

title: Traffic Agents Confront the Angry City
description: Without the efforts of people like Yvonne Sanders and Maria Figueroa, the 1.7 million vehicles oozing into Manhattan each day would long ago have coalesced in motionless gridlock. They pass out parking tickets for a living.

title: Kuwaiti Request for 40 F-18 Jets Gets Mixed Washington Reviews
description: With a request this week for 40 F-18 warplanes, Kuwait has joined a growing list of Middle Eastern countries seeking sophisticated weapons from the United States, and the Reagan Administration has shown increased willingness to make such sales.

description: Mulgrew Miller Music

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SAY MISSILE PACT ISSUE HAS BEEN RESOLVED
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have resolved their outstanding differences over verifying the new missile accord, clearing an important obstacle to Senate approval of the pact, American and Soviet officials said today.

description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $28,000 and a tax credit of $64,000 and included a reduction in pension cost of $19,000 resulting from a change in accounting for such cost.

title: Other Merrymaking
description: In addition to the Ninth Avenue Food Festival and You Gotta Have Park, outdoor celebrations will be found elsewhere in New York City and its environs. On the Upper West Side, three schools will be holding street fairs tomorrow. The McBurney School brings 100 vendors to West 75th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, from noon to 6 P.M. Information: 247-2770. The Sarah Anderson School (P.S. 9), at 100 West 84th Street, will hold an outdoor fair and an indoor puppet show. Information: 362-5029. And the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School brings foods, crafts and other things to buy to West 94th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: 749-6200.

title: A Man of Words and Francs
description: GASTON GALLIMARD A Half-Century of French Publishing By Pierre Assouline Translated by Harold J. Salemson. 430 pages. Illustrated. Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $35.

title: Textron Subsidiary Wins Airbus Contract
description: A subsidiary of Textron Inc. today became the first United States company to win a major airframe contract for the European Airbus, the airliner project that the United States Government says is unfairly subsidized.

title: 4 Houses Seized as Drug Dens
description: Federal marshals in Queens yesterday seized four private houses described as drug-sale locations, three of them in the area of a two-month-old city, state and Federal drug-enforcement program called the Tactical Narcotics Team, which is intended to curb the crack trade in southeast Queens.

title: Russell W. Lavengood Jr., Urologist, 63
description: Dr. Russell W. Lavengood Jr., a Manhattan urologist whose patients included actors, writers and politicians, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: A New York Sound and Light Show
description: Changing the spectacular array of illuminated skyscraper tops that has become a trademark of nighttime New York may fall into the category of fixing what isn't broken. But the event planned for the opening of the American Institute of Architects convention is intended to be a one-time effort to correct what the architects feel is the only thing wrong with the city's nightly display, which is that it looks the same from the moment the buildings light up at dusk to the moment the lights go off in the middle of the night. So this Sunday, to welcome thousands of the nation's architects to New York, owners of roughly 40 buildings will coordinate their nighttime lighting, turning the regular illumination off and on to create a citywide light show.

Bomed Medical Manufacturing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: New Chrysler Contract Is Narrowly Approved
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers have ratified a two-year contract with the Chrysler Corporation by a margin whose narrowness one union official attributed to anger toward the company.

title: Chicago Aldermen and Police Seize Portrait That Blacks Deem Offensive
description: Like several other aldermen here, Allan Streeter was incensed when he learned that a portrait of the late Mayor Harold Washington, depicted in frilly lingerie, was hanging among an exhibition of student works at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: Sports of The Times; A Snapshot Of Jonathan
description: IT'S a family snapshot like millions of others: a smiling little 4-year-old boy with his cousin and one of his sisters.

description: LEAD: Thousands of documents and photographs about Orthodox Jewry in the 20th century were destroyed last Friday when a fire swept through the office of the National Orthodox Jewish Archives.

Soviet Survivor Relives 'Doctors' Plot'
description: To wait was Yakov Rapoport's way, and his only weapon. His memory wound itself protectively around the days in early 1953 that took him from the top ranks of Soviet medicine to a prison cell and back. When he returned, he kept silent, he kept waiting, and he kept remembering.

title: Andover Controls reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
Horse Racing Notebook; New Triple Crown Trappings
description: When the Triple Crown races were incorporated three years ago and then gained the sponsorship of the Chrysler Corporation last year, race officials promised that tradition and good taste would be upheld. They haven't changed the name of the Kentucky Derby to the Chrysler LeBaron Derby quite yet, but the hand of big business has repainted the Triple Crown scene.

title: Data Med Clinical Support Servics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results for the prior year included the period from Feb. 6, 1986. Revenue for the prior is subsequent to the May 22, 1986 acquisition of assets of a predecessor company.

title: Trouble Still Goes With Tyson's Car
description: When Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, crashed his $180,000 silver Bentley convertible into a parked car in lower Manhattan Sunday, two Port Authority police officers offered to help. And Tyson offered them the car, saying, ''I've had nothing but bad luck and accidents with this car.''

title:
About Real Estate;
Former L.I. Golf Course To Be Site of 210 Houses
description: LEAD: The population of North Hills, L.I., has swelled from 300 to 3,500 in the last 12 years as developments, many of them town-house communities, have replaced the estates once occupied by a privileged few.

title: WR Lazard Acquisition
description: WR Lazard & Company, a minority-owned securities firm, announced yesterday that it would acquire Kuhns Brothers & Laidlaw and create a new firm, Lazard & Kuhns.

title: Representative Faces a Charge Of Harassment
description: Representative Floyd H. Flake, a Queens Democrat and the pastor of an African Methodist Episcopal church, has been accused by a former church employee of forcing her to resign after she ended an affair with him.

title: KEY RATES
Arrest in Japan Raises Fears Of Terrorism at the Olympics
description: The Japanese police say a radical arrested here last week may have traveled to North Korea several times in the last two years, fueling speculation that he was planning a terrorist attack at the Olympic Games in Seoul.

title: Dutch Plan Insider Law
description: The Dutch Government has toughened its proposal for countering insider trading by making all such trades illegal even if they fail to generate profits, a Finance Ministry spokeswoman said this week. The move is expected to win wide support in Parliament, and the new law could come into force at the end of this year. It will set fines and prison sentences for investors guilty of using information not generally available to the public.

title: DBA Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $373,510 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $124,398. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $408,054 for the quarter and $786,875 for the 9 months. Year-ago periods have been restated to account for the divestiture of the company's commercial products division.

title: Pedestrian Killed by a Bus
description: A Manhattan woman, Anita Escuadra, 68, was hit and killed by a bus near Eighth Avenue and 50th Street yesterday. No summons was issued against the driver, Michael Janifer of the Gold Line bus company of Maryland.

title: G.E. Wins 'Star Wars' Contract
description: The Defense Department, awarding one of the largest contracts yet under the Strategic Defense Initiative, today chose an industry team led by the General Electric Company to play a leading role in the development and initial deployment of defenses against ballistic missiles.

description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Arqua

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Picks 2 Britons for Group Post
description: Terry Bannister and Roy Warman, both from England, have been elected to the board of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company and have been named joint directors of operations for the Communications Group. That group is made up of the giant company's advertising agencies, public relations firms and marketing services firms.
