title: Just a Few Feet From Victory
description: Tammie Green hasn't won on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. But everyone expects the 29-year-old from Ohio to get her first victory soon if she just starts dropping some of those 10- and 15-foot birdie putts.

title: TV Weekend; Beryl Markham, a Wonder in Kenya
description: In ''Out of Africa,'' Meryl Streep portrayed the young Isak Dinesen having an adulterous affair with Denys Finch Hatton, the romantic adventurer played by Robert Redford. Now, in television's ''Shadow on the Sun'' - a four-hour production getting under way Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS - Stefanie Powers can be seen as Beryl Markham, still another remarkable woman on the Kenyan landscape, who apparently lured Finch Hatton away from Dinesen. This time the poetry-spouting lover is depicted by Trevor Eve. In fact, he is little more than an intense but passing incident in Mrs. Markham's long and extraordinary life.

title: Paraguay Rebuff 'Astonishes' Vatican
description: The Vatican expressed ''astonishment'' today at Paraguay's cancellation of a papal encounter with civic leaders as tensions continued to build between the Roman Catholic Church and the Paraguayan leader, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

title: In Guatemala, A Restiveness On the Right
description: Guatemala's civilian Government weathered a coup attempt this week but remains seriously threatened by disgruntled army officers allied to far-right groups, Guatemalan politicians and diplomats here say.

title: Dominican Police Say 4 Men Killed George Rose
description: The police in the Dominican Republic said yesterday that the Tony Award-winning actor George Rose was killed last week by four men, including his adopted son.

title: Talks on Euro-Currency
description: Finance and economic ministers from the European Community will meet Friday and Saturday to discuss an idea that some key observers say may be an impossible dream: creation of a single European Community currency.

description: Share earnings are restated to reflect implementation of an accounting change by the company's Nevada Savings Unit.

title: TV Drama Shows Clash of Religion and Medicine
description: It may not be unprecedented, but it is certainly unusual for a television drama to criticize religion. And ''Promised a Miracle,'' which will be shown on CBS next Thursday, does raise some criticisms of fundamentalist religion.

Expanding a League's Scope
description: Annie Dwyer hit one up the middle and headed to first base using only one crutch. A coach held the 11-year-old's arm and carried the other crutch. A helmet hid her face, except for the smile.

description: The Defense Department and representatives of the semiconductor industry signed an agreement today that will clear the way for the Government to release $100 million for Sematech, the new consortium in the computer chip industry.

title: T. Ward Cleary, Lawyer, 71
description: T. Ward Cleary, a lawyer and educator, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 71 years old.

Judge Denies Lilco Bid for a July Rate Hike
description: An administrative law judge today rejected the Long Island Lighting Company's request that the State Public Service Commission act on its application for a rate increase by July.

title: Review/Art; 2 Sides of Constable: Classic and Romantic
description: Although John Constable (1776-1837) has been generally recognized as one of the giants of English art, it has not always been apparent why. There were classic and romantic sides to him, and his attitude toward them changed. Occasionally he reached for a synthesis, and when he succeeded, his paintings have a soaring, earthy power. Other times, he seems almost to have been happy the split existed, for it enabled him to pursue the romantic side in peace. Somewhere he knew what his age knew, that romantic and classical ways of seeing are fundamentally incompatible.

title: Jackson Assails Dukakis as a Bush Twin
description: According to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the politician whom Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has begun to resemble most is Vice President Bush.

Senate Factions Search for Way To Widen Military Role on Drugs
description: Senators pressing for a major expansion of the military's role in the fight against narcotics battled with one another and the Secretary of Defense today over an acceptable approach, then moved toward agreement but broke off just short of reaching it.

title: Obviously, the Fault Isn't in Our Stars
description: LEAD: The chief of state, by all accounts a kindly and conscientious man and a devoted husband and father, lacked both the intellectual and emotional stature to fill the position into which providence had cast him. title: Righetti Is Stuck In Limbo
description: Last winter, the debate centered on this question: Should Dave Righetti continue to be a relief pitcher or should he become a starter again? At the moment, Righetti doesn't seem to be either. Instead of being in the bullpen or in the rotation, he is in limbo.

title: Boston Celtics LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,525,774 from proceeds the company received as a result of the expansion of the National Basketball Association. Year-ago 9 months' share earnings is not available; the company went public December 1986.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on May 5 about Peat Marwick Main & Company's resignation as auditor of Bombay Palace Restaurants Inc. misstated the reasons for the action.

title: Bulgarian Instruments And Vocals
description: To American ears, the sound of Bulgarian music can be bracing - or shocking. Voices peal out in full-throated, penetrating tones, developed through the centuries to carry for miles across open fields, or they harmonize in close intervals that are dissonant in Western music. The melodies follow exotic scales, elaborately ornamented with quavers and yelps; the dance tunes are in odd, asymmetrical meters. Yet for all its alien traits, Bulgarian music leaves few listeners unmoved. Its virtuosity, its eerie beauty and its sheer intensity are instantly memorable. Lately, in fact, an album of Bulgarian choral music, ''Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares'' (Nonesuch), has become an unlikely success on college radio stations.

title: Shen Congwen, 85, a Champion Of Freedom for Writers in China
description: Shen Congwen, a novelist, short-story writer, lyricist and passionate champion of literary and intellectual independence, died Tuesday in Beijing, his relatives reported. He was 85 years old.

title: Lintas:Campbell-Ewald Resigns Rockwell Work
description: Lintas:Campbell-Ewald resigned yesterday as the companywide agency for Rockwell International a week after Rockwell said it was reassessing its advertising program.

title: Review/Art; From Camera to Paint: New Style for Wegman
description: William Wegman has forged a major career by striking consistently minor, even off-key notes in a number of media. In a body of work that has so far included video, photography and drawing, Mr. Wegman has repeatedly thwarted our expectations of artistic mastery, ambition and unity. He has drawn badly, produced videotapes that make the average home movie look like Oscar material and taken as his main photographic subject a Weimaraner in an array of strange costumes and situations. The Wegman look is always a bit slapdash; the art always laced with generous doses of wit, verbal and visual double-entendres and popular culture.

title: Mets Wait for Aguilera to Make the Call on Return
description: On Wednesday afternoon, Rick Aguilera sat at the table in the clubhouse playing cards with his teammates. He won a couple of hands with good cards, several more with shrewd bluffs. Aguilera's mind is a tough one to read, perhaps never more so than when the only thing he has in his hand is a baseball.

title: U.S. Natural Gas Supply
description: The nation has a 35-year supply of recoverable natural gas at prices below $3 per thousand cubic feet, the Energy Department said today. A price increase to $5 would encourage the development of only another 10 years' supply, the department said. The nation uses about 17 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year. The average wellhead price last year was $1.83.

title: A Doctor Mourns His Loss of Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Pollock, 86, Former N.Y.U. Dean
description: Thomas Clark Pollock, former dean of arts and sciences at New York University, died of pneumonia yesterday at Duke University Hospital in Durham, N.C. He was 86 years old and lived in Durham.

title: Vie de France CorpO) reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Includes gain from an accounting change of $156,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Japan's Military Past Comes Back to Haunt Again
description: The Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman said today that Japan's relations with its Asian neighbors had suffered ''quite severe'' damage as a result of repeated incidents in which senior officials played down Japanese wartime aggression.

title: Danger on the Railroads
description: Every now and then the newspapers and TV report a local story that takes hold of the country. The stories startle us, not because they are bizarre, but because they force us to face plain dangers that come with the way we live, but which we usually manage to push out of our minds. Two planes collide in the sky, a subway rider whips out a gun and opens fire.

title: Gerber Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,520,000 for the quarter and $31,384,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,340,000 for the quarter and $6,012,000 for the year.

title: May Department Stores Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: During the latest first quarter, the company completed the sale of three parcels of excess real estate that resulted in pre-tax gains aggregating $10 million, or 4 cents a share, and also recorded a pre-tax charge of $9 million for estimated costs of relocating one of its data-processing centers and other closing costs. Latest quarter represents a 13-week period. The company said that all adjustments, consisting only of normal recurring adjustments, necessary for a fair statement of the results for the interim periods have been included; however, certain items are included based on estimates for the entire year. Also, operating results of periods which exclude the Christmas season may not be indicative of the operating results that may be expected for the full fiscal year.

title: Review/Art; Nature's Influence, at the Whitney
description: ''Vital Signs,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, bites off a small but substantial chunk of an almost ridiculously ambitious subject - the influence of nature on art. Organized by Lisa Phillips, an associate curator at the museum, the show addresses nature's varied impact on American abstractionists. It begins with paintings and sculpture from the early part of this century by Arthur Dove, Robert Laurent and Joseph Stella, and concludes with works by various contemporary artists, among them Elizabeth Murray, Robert Therrien, Nancy Graves and Terry Winters.

title: Treasury's Auction Ends On an Upbeat
description: The Treasury Department wound up its quarterly note and bond auctions on a modestly successful note yesterday, as investors purchased $8.5 billion of new 30-year bonds at yield levels that were a bit lower than had been expected.

title: Teleprobe Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $41,000 for reversal of anoperating loss carryforward; the 9 months include a $1,180,000 gain from an operating loss carryforward. c-Net income and includes a gain of $36,000 and $179,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from an operating loss carryforward.

description: At the moment, there are two places that Ponca City residents call home.

description: * Case-Hoyt Corp., Rochester, a printer of sales promotion material and one of the BCE Publitech companies of Bell Canada Enterprises, appointed James J. Curtis president.

description: b-Includes a gain of $88,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Alexander Fried, 85, California Arts Critic
description: Alexander Fried, a widely respected critic of music, dance and art in San Francisco for 51 years, died of a heart attack Monday morning at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 85 years old. Mr. Fried's plain-spoken, gentle, supportive criticism was practiced mainly at The San Francisco Examiner, but he also lectured and was a host of San Francisco Opera radio broadcasts and a master of ceremonies at San Francisco Symphony youth concerts. He was a key force in encouraging both the symphony and San Francisco's art museums to upgrade management and budgets.

title: BIW Cable Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2.2 million from the sale of the company's corporate headquarters.

title: American Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a provision for discontinued operations of $150,000 and research and development expenses of $684,194. c-Included research and development expenses of $723,013.

description: b-Net loss

title: Davis May Make a Bid for Lorimar
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, which has agreed to be acquired by Warner Communications Inc., said yesterday that it had received a letter from the oil entrepreneur Marvin Davis stating that he is contemplating making a $15-a-share all-cash offer for the company.

title: Pope Urges Bolivian War on Drugs
description: Preaching at a major crossroads of cocaine traffic, Pope John Paul II pleaded urgently today for Bolivians to combat a drug trade destroying their society with corruption and murder.

title: The Elastic Price Tag: Why Clothes Cost More
description: This is no time to need clothes, especially if you're a woman. Not only are the fashions confusing, but prices are giving shoppers a case of sticker shock. If you're a man, stock up now; experts say the price of men's wear is headed up the same path.

title: Universal Medical Buildings L P reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are in cents a unit.

title: NBC, Back in First, Has Top Nine Shows
description: NBC returned to first place in the ratings last week and became the first network in more than seven years to claim the top nine shows, according to figures released by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Giants Shut Off Mets, 3-2
description: The Mets brought their rousing act to the West Coast tonight, but this time it didn't play.

title: Robert H. Lehman, Philanthropist, 79
description: Robert H. Lehman, a retired investor and philanthropist, died of complications after heart surgery Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: Gordon D. Sterling, 53, Chairman of Formica
description: Gordon D. Sterling, chairman of the Formica Corporation, died after a heart attack Wednesday at Walkill (N.J.) Borough Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Vernon, N.J.

title: Girl Fatally Struck; Driver Is Arrested
description: A 7-year-old girl died last night after being struck by a van as she crossed a street near her home. The driver of the van was arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: About New York; Noteworthy Improvement On School Song
description: Many, many years ago they held a contest to find an alma mater for Brooklyn College, and the winning composer, hands down, was a young woman named Sylvia Fine, who didn't get along with the head of the music department, who decided he would accept her music but not her lyrics, and therein lies a bitter tale that worked out sweetly more than a half century later, which is to say the other day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just see what kind of friendship will blossom between Reagan and Gorbachev. They will be like brothers. That's what the stars show me. It's my prediction. Mark my words.'' - Dzhuna Davitashvili, who reads the stars from Moscow. [ 4:4. ]

title: Hershey Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: 8 Killed in a Bombing In Afghanistan Capital
description: A truck bomb exploded early this morning near reviewing stands being prepared for farewell ceremonies for Soviet troops. The police said at least 8 people were killed and 20 injured.

title: Orioles End Stewart's Streak
description: It took the Baltimore Orioles to prove that Dave Stewart can be beaten.

title: Review/Jazz; Dorothy Donegan, Unclassifiable Mixture
description: As the members of Dorothy Donegan's trio were taking their bows at the end of their first set at Sweetwater's, 170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 68th Street, on Thursday evening, Miss Donegan's veteran bassist, Arvell Shaw, stirred by the steady billowing waves of enthusiastic applause, proclaimed her ''one of the world's greatest pianists - without category.''

title: Stocks Post Broad Gain; Volume Low
description: LEAD: The stock market rallied broadly yesterday, although trading was again anemic.

title: Conviction of Queens Judge For Wire Fraud Is Dismissed
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed 9 of the 26 counts on which William C. Brennan, a former State Supreme Court justice, was convicted and sentenced. The nine counts dealt with making interstate telephone calls to commit fraud, and the dismissal was in line with a 1987 United States Supreme Court ruling.

title: Versar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' losses included a $1,158,000 pre-tax charge from the writedown of a division. The year-ago periods' results are restated to include the operation of Arix Corp.

title: Mistrial in Agent's Case
description: A mistrial was declared today as attorneys tried to work out a settlement in the case of Norby Walters, a New York sports agent charged with illegal dealings with University of Alabama basketball stars.

title: Method of Delivering Money, Unregulated, Up to Company
description: No regulations governing how armored-car or payroll services transport money are on the books in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut, officials for all three states said.

title: Far Too Many People on Capitol Hill
description: LEAD: The staffs of Congressional offices and committees are far too large, and the sheer quantity of staff members is a major reason that Congress's legislative work is approaching paralysis. It is true that in a real crisis, or when the pressures to act are enormous, Congress moves with lightning speed.

title: Avatar Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ZG Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Iran-Backed Shiites Gain Ground on Syria's Allies in South Beirut
description: After gaining control of two-thirds of Beirut's southern suburbs in nearly a week of bitter clashes, Shiite Moslem fundamentalists of the Party of God made new advances today, seizing additional positions from Amal, the rival Shiite militia.

title: Cup Challenger Leaves
description: New Zealand's challenger for the America's Cup left here today after its departure to the United States had been delayed for two days by a strike of British seamen. The container ship Discovery Bay left this afternoon with the yacht New Zealand on board.

title: 6 Guatemala Officers Seized In a Coup Plot That Failed
description: The Guatemalan Defense Ministry announced today that it had arrested six officers and sanctioned four others implicated in an aborted coup this week.

title: Tone in the Senate Turns Upbeat As Obstacles to Arms Treaty Fade
description: The Senate leadership and key committee chairmen gave all but final approval today to the agreements reached this week in Geneva on the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces, essentially clearing the way for the Senate to begin debate on the treaty early next week.

title: Watch Your Toes
description: Now, when the grass is growing rapidly, mowing is a weekly chore. Most homeowners use power mowers, and the Outdoor Power Equipment Institute, a trade group, wants them to be used safely. The Consumer Product Safety Commission reported that 70,000 injuries associated with outdoor power equipment were treated in emergency rooms in 1986.

title: KEY RATES
Honor for Jordan
description: By leading the N.B.A. in scoring with an average of 35 points a game, Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls won recognition for the second consecutive season as the league's top offensive player. Yesterday, he was also named the league's 1988 Defensive Player of the Year.

title: Sea Containers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $40 million gain on the sale of the company's office development property in London. c-Net loss

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 4 about reports of a worldwide increase in development of biological weapons characterized a Defense Department research program incorrectly. The research is intended to develop defenses against biological warfare, not to develop weapons. The United States has forsworn the development, possession or use of biological weapons.

title: Business Sales Up 1.9% As Inventory Rise Slows
description: Business sales climbed by 1.9 percent in March, the largest increase in more than a year, while the buildup of business inventories slowed.

title: Offer Is Made For Amfac Unit
description: In another step toward completing its restructuring, Amfac Inc. said a group including management and an unidentified financial instituition plans to buy the company's wholesale pharmaceutical business for $120 million. The hospital and chain store distributor is the fifth of eight operations that Amfac, based in Honolulu, plans to sell. So far, Amfac has made deals worth about $470 million, or 67 percent of the $700 million expected to be raised in the sale of its distribution, food and mainland resort operations.

title: Telephone & Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Atlanta Banks Offer Loans Aimed at Blacks
description: Atlanta banks, acting to counter reports of racial bias and to head off a Federal investigation into lending practices, announced a series of programs Friday to provide $65 million in low-interest, low-cost loans to borrowers on the city's predominantly black South Side.

title: Decide Civil Rights From Facts, Not Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Film; Troubled Charter Voyage Of a Blind Ophthalmologist
description: Of all the infirmities that actresses can suffer on the screen, blindness is one of the best. It affords the chance to be nobly cheerful even when, say, the star's husband is embracing one of his cute young employees right before the star's unseeing eyes. And the potential for suspense can be boundless, as ''Wait Until Dark'' made clear. So it's possible to understand what Faye Dunaway is doing playing a neglected wife in ''Midnight Crossing,'' even though there's nothing but glaucoma to make the role worthwhile.

title: Ex-Reagan Aides Draw Fire From Shultz on Disclosures
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today sharply criticized kiss-and-tell books by former Reagan Administration officials, calling them violations of Presidential trust.

title: Navy Will Not Appeal Ruling Freeing Doctor
description: The Navy decided today to forgo an appeal in the involuntary manslaughter case of Dr. Donal M. Billig, making the former heart surgeon a free man once and for all.

title: Frontier Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from sales of investments of $108,000 and $87,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively. The company said the ''fresh-start'' provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 reduced federal income tax expense by about $271,000 in the year- ago first quarter.

title: Bush's Fight Against G.O.P. Committeeman Heats Up
description: An embarrassing fight among New York Republicans that could affect the Presidential campaign in the state is heating up.

title: Don't Wound Branch Libraries
description: Since the fiscal crisis in the 1970's, the New York Public Library has periodically suffered budget cuts that have forced service reductions at some of its 81 branches. Mayor Koch has now proposed another cut, of more than $2.4 million, from the branches. This retrenchment would cause even shorter library hours and other service reductions and ignores the important value branch libraries play in the city.

title: Integrated Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas Bank Halts Payment
description: The First Republicbank Corporation, the Texas banking company that is receiving emergency Federal aid, said today that it had suspended payments on $1.3 billion in long-term debt, which will save $78 million in annual interest costs.

title: Dukakis Shrugs Off Jackson Views
description: Campaigning almost serenely in California and Oregon this week, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis brushed off a barrage of criticism from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, chided the White House for its reported reliance on astrology and assailed the Reagan Administration for contemplating a deal with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama.

title: Citadel Holding May Revise Bid
description: The Citadel Holding Corporation, constrained from buying a 39 percent interest in Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said it was considering revising its months-old $18.50-a-share, or $107 million, takeover bid for the thrift institution.

title: DeBartolo and Bilzerian Under S.E.C. Scrutiny
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., the nation's largest developer of shopping centers, secretly aided takeover bids by the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian by buying shares on his behalf and providing other support.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

Tokyo Cabinet Official Resigns Amid Furor
description: A Cabinet minister who had repeatedly minimized Japan's wartime aggression succumbed tonight to intense Government pressure and submitted his resignation.

title: Philadelphia Hospital Is Restricted by State
description: The State Health Department has closed all but two units of a Philadelphia hospital, saying inadequate care might have caused 12 deaths in the last year.

title: 3 Southern States Seek Progress Together
description: The Governors of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi, aboard a barge floating in the sluggish Mississippi, today signed wide-ranging agreements to coordinate their efforts to improve conditions in one of the nation's poorest areas.

title: Color Systems Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Your Money; More People Seek Credit Counseling
description: When Luther R. Gatling opened a credit-counseling service in New York City 11 years ago, most of his clients had blue-collar jobs and earned relatively low wages.

title: Microbilt Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said year-ago first quarter has been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: PRODUCER PRICES SHOW MODEST RISE OF 0.4% FOR APRIL
description: The likelihood of a sharp rise in the inflation rate in the next month or two has lessened, the Government reported yesterday. But longer term, an acceleration of the inflation rate seems more of a threat than ever.

title: The Russians, Too, Embrace 'Secret Silliness' of Astrology
description: In a one-room clinic a few paces from Moscow's most popular pedestrian mall, Dzhuna Davitashvili, celebrity psychic healer, gesticulates over the head of a deaf and blind man, as if pulling invisible weeds from his cranium.

title: Novo Industri A/S reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and were translated at the March 30, 1988 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dkr. 6.4075. The share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS).

title: Larry Coryell Quartet
description: Larry Coryell, a guitarist, is leading a quartet with Stanley Cowell on piano, Buster Williams on bass, and Billy Hart on drums tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Franklin Telecommunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said all net income figures are equal to less than one cent a share.

title: Barry E. Gell, Watch Executive, 56
description: Barry E. Gell, senior vice president of the Citizen Watch Company, died of a heart attack Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Staley Accepts Offer by Tate & Lyle
description: Successfully ending a five-week pursuit, Tate & Lyle P.L.C., the large British sugar refiner, said tonight that it had reached an agreement to buy Staley Continental Inc. for $36.50 a share, or $1.48 billion.

title: Review/Critic's Notebook; Jack Lang: Star of Cannes Festival
description: The big news at the 41st Cannes International Film Festival this morning was not Patty Hearst, who is here, or Clint Eastwood, who is arriving any day, but the appointment of Jack Lang as the Minister of Culture in President Francois Mitterrand's new Government.

title: Soviet Nuclear-Powered Satellite Expected to Hit Earth in Summer
description: A crippled Soviet nuclear-powered satellite is expected to fall to Earth in August or September, threatening to spread radioactive debris. Yesterday both Soviet and American officials said they were monitoring the situation.

title: Red Wings Apologize
description: Saying the incident was a blemish on the entire organization, Coach Jacques Demers issued an open letter to the fans yesterday as a public apology for the six Detroit Red Wing players he said he and his assistants caught drinking long after curfew hours last Tuesday.

title: Harlem Troupe Captivates Moscow
description: The fairy tale of the firebird is told over and over here, the fabled bird's magical powers to bring lovers together recounted by many writers. Tonight that story was told anew to a Moscow audience that came to see the Dance Theater of Harlem's Soviet premiere.

title: Failure to Clarify in Denmark
description: Frustrated by years of parliamentary nitpicking about Denmark's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Prime Minister Poul Schluter called Tuesday's general election in the hope of forcing a clear up-or-down verdict. Instead, the vote leaves Denmark's relations with NATO as unclear as ever.

title: Family Hints Brawley Might Talk
description: Acting on a hint that Tawana Brawley might finally cooperate with his investigation, the chief state prosecutor looking into her claims that she was sexually assaulted has asked her lawyer to clarify the circumstances under which the Dutchess County teen-ager would break her five-month silence.

title: Inquiry Is Widened Into Epileptic's Death
description: A spokeswoman for the New York City Medical Examiner's office said this week that a severe neck injury found during an autopsy of a man who died in police custody could have been caused by medical workers, rather than by police officers. But she stressed that a final determination was weeks away.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9 months are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January 1988.

title: GUIDEPOST: FLASHLIGHTS
description: Vacation equipment often includes a flashlight. Today's models range from disposable plastic ''squeeze'' lights that can be attached to key chains and carried in a purse or pocket to Mag-Lites, aluminum flashlights with rechargeable batteries, adjustable beams, belt clips and Krypton bulbs. The Mag-Lites are the costliest, but they are versatile and provide a bright light. After the battery is recharged in an electric outlet, it holds its charge indefinitely until used. The Mini-Mag, which provides a small but very bright beam, requires standard alkaline batteries. Once in a flashlight, alkaline and lithium batteries will last 3 to 10 years. Here are some suggestions about which flashlights to use and where: $ MODEL COST USE Keychain, penlight, $3 to $17 Illuminating locks on doors, Mini-Mag cars Standard battery $10 to $20 For home, car emergencies (usually alkaline) Mag-Lite About $145 Outdoors, camping Source: Consumers Union

title: Famous Players
description: Famous Players Inc., a unit of Gulf and Western Inc., said it would spend $50 million (Canadian), or about $40.5 million (United States), over the next three years to build eight movie theater complexes in the Toronto area. The company said it had chosen three sites in downtown Toronto and was negotiating for additional locations. A number of the theater complexes will contain office and retail space, the company said.

title: Atkinson, Guy F Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two Are Shot In Robbery Of a Payroll
description: At least three gunmen, apparently lying in wait at a lower Manhattan office building yesterday morning, robbed a payroll service of nearly $400,000 in cash and shot a security guard and a cashier, the authorities said.

title: Cuomo Panel to Refer Extortion Case of a Former Thruway Official to U.S.
description: Saying it had found evidence of ''a conspiracy to commit extortion,'' the State Investigation Commission said today that it would refer to Federal prosecutors a case involving actions by Alexander A. Levine while he was executive director of the State Thruway Authority.

title: Judge Finds S.E.C. Attorney Was Sexually Harassed at Job
description: LEAD: A Federal judge in Washington ruled today that senior officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission were responsible for ''creating and refusing to remedy a sexually hostile work environment'' at its Washington regional branch between 1979 and 1984.

title: Service on Channel Ferries Restored as Picketing Ends
description: Most Channel ferry services were restored today as the National Union of Seamen told its members to stop picketing in support of workers staging a 14-week strike against one company.

title: Review/Pop; The Brazil Projects Opener Has Songs of Global Reach
description: Caetano Veloso, one of the world's great singers and songwriters, opened the Brazil Projects concert series with a winning concert Wednesday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Mr. Veloso and his band played pop songs with a global reach, embracing and personalizing musical ideas from both hemispheres, and putting across complex emotions with a particularly Brazilian mixture of playfulness and sophistication.

title: Le Peep Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Atari Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,893,000. Results for the latest quarter includes Federated Group Inc., which Atari acquired on Oct. 4, 1987.

title: Pickens Asks Mesa Changes
description: T. Boone Pickens has proposed a series of amendments that would broaden the rights of unit holders of the Mesa Limited Partnership, the billion-dollar oil and gas concern of which he is general partner, and also greatly increase the compensation he could earn.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $463,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Atlantic-Prism Merger
description: Atlantic Entertainment Group, the largest private independent film and television company in the United States, said today that it had agreed to merge with the Prism Entertainment Corporation, a publicly owned video distributor. The merger will create a $70 million full-service entertainment company. Spokesmen for the companies, which have headquarters in Los Angeles, would not give details of the deal. In addition to distributing videos, Prism is a worldwide television syndicator through its Fox-Lorber subsidiary.

title: Energynorth Inc reports earnings for 12mo to March 31
K Mart Overseas
description: The Australian retailer Coles Myer Ltd. said it would bring K Mart discount department stores to New Zealand. Coles's chairman, Brian Quinn, said the first store was expected to open in the Auckland area later this year. Coles acquired sole rights for New Zealand from the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer in the United States. Coles Myer operates 131 K Mart stores in Australia.

title: Painting The Lilies: Cosmetics For Babies
description: Cosmetics companies are going after a new market: young children. The industry is courting the upscale cradle set with fragrances, soaps, mousse baby shampoos, sun blocks and even a scent for those born yesterday.

title: Tyranny Yields to Democracy in Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: American National Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,229,000 for the latest quarter and $1,704,000 in the year-earlier period.

title:
Patents;
Development In Ultrahigh Conductivity
description: LEAD: A superconductive material was patented this week for the Energy Department.

title: Taiwan Shift Jolts U.S. on Trade
description: The United States may preach the virtues of democracy, but in its efforts to push Taiwan to reduce its trade surplus, Washington is finding that the people's will can be more difficult to deal with than a family dynasty.

title: 11-Hour Concert to Mark Atlantic Records' 40 Years
description: By any standard, the 11-hour celebration of Atlantic Records' 40th anniversary, starting at 1 P.M. today at Madison Square Garden, is an extraordinary convention of American and British music. Ranging from the urbane 1950's soul of Ruth Brown (Atlantic Records was once known as the House That Ruth Built) to the blow-dried conventionality of the teen-age pop singer Debbie Gibson, the show will pay tribute to one of the great independent rhythm-and-blues labels and will underscore the changing nature of the music industry.

title: Criticism Over Dukakis Is Softened by Jackson
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that his criticisms of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis were part of a fight for control of the Democratic Party's approach to policy and did not mean that he believed Mr. Dukakis was a philosophical ''twin'' of Vice President Bush.

title: Review/Music; Stern Plays Maxwell Davies Concerto
description: Sir Peter Maxwell Davies composed his Concerto for Violin and Orchestra with a specific soloist and a specific performance milieu in mind. In that respect, at least, it is in the tradition of the great Baroque, Classical and Romantic masterpieces.

title: Symphony Milestone for Brahmins
description: There are certain things that proper Bostonians simply do. They are born, they go to school, they get married, and they go to Symphony, not necessarily in that order.

title: U.S. Says It Will Deliver Cash to Contras for Food
description: The Reagan Administration will begin providing the contra guerrillas inside Nicaragua with food and cash to buy food, the Agency for International Development announced today.

title: Iceland Currency Halt
description: Iceland's central bank stopped all foreign currency transactions today as the Government began talks on a devaluation, Government officials said. They said the freeze was necessary because of increasing currency speculation amid rumors that the currency, the crown, would be devalued.

title: Collapse of Mexican Factory Kills 14 and Injures Dozens
description: At least 14 people were killed and about 70 were injured on Thursday when a furniture factory collapsed in central Mexico, the Red Cross said today.

title: Corporate Intrigue and Colorful Characters at CBS
description: Who Killed CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network By Peter J. Boyer 361 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $18.95.

title: Gunnar Nicholson, 94, Paper Industry Leader
description: Gunnar W. E. Nicholson, a chemical engineer and paper industry executive for more than half a century, died of heart failure Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title:
Patents;
A Method to Improve Resource Allocation
description: LEAD: Scientists at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., were granted three patents this week for methods of improving the efficiency of allocation of industrial and commercial resources.

title: SENATE VOTES 83-6 TO GIVE MILITARY ANTI-DRUG POWERS
description: Responding to election-year pressure, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to expand the military's role in efforts to reduce the flow of narcotics into the United States. The vote was 83 to 6.

title: Atari Profits Decline 62.7%
description: The Atari Corporation today reported that first-quarter earnings had a steep decline, which the company attributed primarily to the consumer electronics retailing unit it acquired last summer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 14, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Most of Big Plane Order Seen Going to Boeing
description: The Boeing Company has been able to gain most of a plane order worth more than $4 billion that is expected to be announced by the International Lease Finance Corporation on Monday.

title: Envoy's Account on Noriega Surprises Three He Briefed
description: An American Ambassador who has said he did not have the evidence to tell Vice President Bush of drug allegations against Panama's military leader at a meeting in 1985 briefed a Congressional delegation about the charges 17 days later, according to three witnesses to the later meeting.

title: Brazil's Blacks Feel Bias 100 Years After Slavery
description: The descendants of African slaves make up half of this vast and racially mixed nation, and the religions, food and music brought by their ancestors have molded a vital part of today's Brazil.

title: Federated Lays Off 92 at Home Office
description: The Campeau Corporation yesterday laid off 92 members of the headquarters staff of Federated Department Stores, in Cincinnati. Those let go ranged from senior management to clerical staff members.

title: A Strong Man Runs Amok
description: There was an intriguing half-minute during a showing of ''Maniac Cop'' yesterday, when the film broke. The flaring orange on screen at least livened up this amateurish effort about a monstrously strong uniformed policeman - or is he a civilian in costume? - who roams the streets of New York killing innocent people. The acting is stiff, the dialogue is stiffer and the action scenes are laborious. Even the presence of professionals like Sheree North and Richard Roundtree, in small roles, tend to diminish them rather than improve the film.

title: Williamsburg Bridge To Open in 3 Phases Starting in 3 Weeks
description: The Williamsburg Bridge will remain closed at least three more weeks and will then gradually reopen - first to cars, then to subway trains and, finally, in August, to trucks, transportation officials said yesterday.

title:
Patents;
Surgeon Designs Glove To Resist Puncturing
description: LEAD: A surgical glove designed to resist penetration by sharp needles or instruments has been invented by Dr. Arnold S. Seid, a surgeon in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: South Africa and Angola Agree to More Talks
description: After 13 years of hostilities, South Africa and Angola met for three hours here today and agreed to another meeting with Cuban and American representatives in attendance.

title: Sales of Domestic Vehicles Climbed 36.3% in Early May
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 36.3 percent in early May from the comparable period in 1987.

title: Bruins Are Talking Tough
description: The Boston Bruins, in bewildered tones, said all the right things late Thursday night after suffering the 6-3 defeat that sent their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Devils back to Boston for a sudden-death finale tonight.

title: Israeli Patrols Keep West Bank Quiet
description: The Israeli Army had predicted major demonstrations in this Arab city and other spots around the occupied territories today, the last Friday of the monthlong Moslem holiday of Ramadan.

title: Chinese Music Is Topic Of Columbia Conference
description: Twenty Chinese composers - 10 from Taiwan and 10 from China - will take part in a weeklong conference at Columbia University in August on the history and future of Chinese music.

title: Twists and Turns Of the Knight Story
description: These were professionals in Marianne Mitchell's graduate-level counseling class at Indiana University, not 18-year-olds whose mission in life includes the frequent humiliation of Purdue. Mitchell was conducting an evening class this week in Indianapolis, about 40 miles from the Bloomington campus, when a television report was erroneously interpreted to mean that Bob Knight had resigned as the basketball coach.

title: And Him a Gramps!
description: Certain sportswriters are propounding the silly proposition that grandfathers should stay out of topless bars. I assume they are very young sportswriters, for only a very young man would presume to think he knows something about life that grandfather doesn't.

title: Bonray Drilling reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Celtics Take a 2-0 Lead Despite Bird's 16
description: Scott Hastings, an Atlanta Hawks' forward, watched the Boston Celtics run off 6 consecutive points in 50 seconds tonight to break open what had turned into a close game. He shook his head and said, ''These guys just have too many weapons.''

title: Blockers Gets Permit
description: CA. Blockers Inc. said today that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had granted the company's Keeney Tobacco Corporation a tax permit allowing it to make and sell cigarettes. The company said it would now be able to start production of its cigarette containing the additive N-Bloctin, which is intended to block the cancer-causing action of nitrosamines from cigarette smoke. Blockers said it would start production in June.

title: Chrysler Price Rise
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had raised the price of its imported 1989 Eagle Medallion cars by an average of 4.2 percent over comparably equipped 1988 models.

title: Devils Eager for Showdown
description: The Devils are in the seventh and deciding game of the National Hockey League semifinals after never having made the playoffs before this spring. But when they gathered here this morning to depart for Boston, they acted like an experienced playoff team.

title: ICOT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $350,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income and the 9 months includes a tax credit of $2,330,000.

title: Risky to Heat Liquids in the Microwave
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some Shoppers, A Purchasing Backlash
description: Shoppers don't need the Consumer Price Index to tell them that clothing prices have gone up.

title: I.R.S. Eases Rules on Deductions After Artists and Writers Protest
description: In response to a storm of protest from authors, painters, photographers and other creative artists, the Internal Revenue Service today eased the rules on deduction of freelance artistic expenses that were imposed under the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: A Red-Light District Loses Its Allure
description: Difficult times have fallen on Hamburg's red-light district. All along and around the Reeperbahn, the mile-long stretch of sex establishments near the teeming harbor, the fear of AIDS has sent business plummeting.

title: Mediq Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,029,000 and $1,201,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the quarter includes an extraordinary gain of $102,000 and the 6 months includes a gain of $3,449,000 from the purchase by Mediq of its $20,771,000 of 7 1-4 percent convertible subordinated debentures at a discount. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $32,000 and $212,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said 1987 figures were restated for the reclassification of certain operations as discontinued operations.

title: Drugs, and Death, Ride the Rails
description: Evidence of drug abuse by an engineer who died in a Metro-North crash last month further strengthens the overwhelming case for routine drug testing of rail employees. Yet their unions, with surprising sympathy from an appellate court, stand in the way of a sensible testing policy.

title: U.S. Aides Optimistic on a Noriega Deal
description: Senior Administration officials today sounded a new note of optimism over prospects for a deal to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Why Give Crooks New York Pensions?
description: A rash of investigations of public officials in New York State and New York City has drawn attention to a practice that allows corrupt public officials to continue cheating the public long after they are out of office.

title: Ex-School Employees Charged in Sex Case
description: A Roman Catholic priest and a Marist brother are facing charges involving sexual abuse of students at a parochial preparatory school in the Bronx with which they were formerly connected, the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, announced yesterday.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Acceptance Insurance Holdngs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $25,991. c-Includes realized investment gains of $462,564.

title: Lower East Side Housing: Plans and Conflict
description: The buildings, both vacant, stand side by side on East Ninth Street between Avenues C and D, symbols of the contrasts and complexities of housing on the Lower East Side.

title: New Exchange Head
description: John J. Wallace, the president of a brokerage firm, Park Avenue Securities, has been elected chairman of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. Mr. Wallace was named acting chairman on March 22 to replace Martin L. Longstreth Jr., who died of cancer on March 7.

title: National Intergroup Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $24 million on a provision for the sale of the Luxembourg plant for the quarter and year; the quarter also included a pre- tax charge of $7,637,000 to eliminate a deferred gain previously recognized in income on the sale of a 55.3 percent interest in Permian Partners L.P. and after-tax losses from discontinued operations of $920,000 and from an extraordinary item of $908,000; the year was after losses from discontinued operations of $1,866,000 and gains of $92,000 and $2,655,000 from an extraordinary item and from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,568,000 for the quarter and $3,824,000 for the year.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Worried Over Meese
description: Senior Republicans on Capitol Hill say they are increasingly alarmed that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is undermining the operations of the Justice Department and damaging party prospects for the fall.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Smith, a center for the Buffalo Sabres, faced surgery yesterday at Ottawa Civic Hospital for injuries he suffered in an automobile accident May 8. He has fractures in his left shoulder area, the most serious being a fractured scapula, a wing bone in his back. . . . Joe Sakic, voted Canada's outstanding junior hockey player for the 1987-88 season, has signed with the Quebec Nordiques. He had 78 goals and 160 points to win the Western Hockey League scoring title for the Swift Current Broncos. . . . The Chicago Cubs have placed Calvin Schiraldi, a pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Schiraldi was working on a shutout Thursday when a Padres pinch-hitter, Carmelo Martinez, lined a single off his left knee. X-rays showed no breaks, but he did suffer a deep bruise.

title: P&F Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: As Airport Delays Decrease, Jet Noise Infests the Suburbs
description: More than a year after aviation officials increased the number of flight paths into and out of the metropolitan region's major airports in an effort to ease airline delays, the roar of jetliners over Katherine Cowperthwaite's home here is echoed by an uproar on the ground.

title: Harold Gordon, Publishing Executive, 61
description: Harold Gordon, vice president of business operations for Simon & Schuster Inc., died of cancer Tuesday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Southern Indiana Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings for period ending in 1987 have been restated to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split effective March 11, 1988.

title: Rocard Hints Strongly at Assembly Election
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard indicated strongly today that the National Assembly would soon be dissolved in order to give France a Government with a stable parliamentary majority.

title: Officers Chose Not to Give Aid At Shooting Site
description: Six white police officers who responded to the fatal shooting of a black Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn this week decided against administering first aid during the 24 minutes it took for an ambulance to arrive ''because they were afraid they might cause more harm to the victim,'' a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Settlement in Arborcide: $100,000 in Young Trees
description: A verdant settlement has been announced by Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern in one of the ''arborcide'' cases that have been plaguing New York City.

title: James Bliss Dies at 85; Ex-Window Designer
description: James Albert Bliss, the former head of the Bliss Display Company, died of complications from cancer of the pancreas Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 85 years old and had residences in Manhattan and on Fire Island.

title: Ford Unit's Records Sought
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its aerospace division had received a subpoena in late April for records of its dealings with consultants as part of a Government investigation of former executives at Intelsat, the communications satellite consortium.

title: Continental Information Sysems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Continental Information Systems acquired three companies during fiscal 1988.

title: Think of Afghanistan As a Soviet 'Spain'
description: LEAD: When the Soviet Union sent troops into Afghanistan in 1979, many of us predicted that the involvement would be that country's ''Vietnam.'' As Soviet troops begin their withdrawal, that assessment would seem to have been confirmed. But there is an even more apt historical analogy for the attempted Soviet subjugation: Afghanistan has been the Soviet ''Spain.

title: Treaty Postscript: Dotting i's and Crossing t's
description: In diplomacy as in other sports, it's not over until it's over. And, as it turned out, one of the verification disputes over the new missile treaty was not quite over Thursday night, as American and Soviet officials had said early in the evening.

title: Joseph Shipley, 94, Drama Critic And the Author of Many Books
description: Joseph T. Shipley, a drama critic in New York for more than 60 years, a writer, an editor and a member of the first faculty of Yeshiva College, died of a stroke Wednesday on a visit to London. He was 94 years old and lived in New York.

title: Bridge
description: If Rip Van Winkle had been an expert rubber bridge player when he fell asleep, and been faced with duplicate competition a century later, he would have had trouble adjusting to the march of bidding. One can assume, however, that his card play would rescue him in some unfortunate contracts.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet Acts as Host To Paul Taylor's Troupe
description: There was no dearth of guest artists at the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. The entire 18-member Paul Taylor Dance Company dropped in for a visit to perform the premiere of Mr. Taylor's ''Danbury Mix,'' an eerie and affecting modern-dance work to Charles Ives's equally eerie and affecting music.

title: Tony Bird
description: Tony Bird, a songwriter from Malawi, will perform at 8 and 10 o'clock tonight at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street (219-2527). Tickets are $10.

title: Lillian Vernon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: The company said net income results for the full year are pro forma. The company terminated its S corporation tax status in August 1987. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes was made for the first six months of the fiscal year.

title: Bellevue's Prison Ward Requires Psychiatric Professionals
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus decreased in April for the 12th straight month, the Government announced today, but private economists said further reductions would be harder to achieve because of surging exports.

title: Year-Old Mystery Solved as Police Identify Body Found in East River
description: From the detective's standpoint, it was one of the toughest kinds of mysteries: the body of a nameless man found floating in the East River, badly decomposed after months in the water, without fingerprints or a face or other identifying characteristics.

title: The Best Way to Punish Illegal Building
description: New York City's Board of Standards and Appeals must decide whether to legalize a new 31-story building on Park Avenue and 96th Street, where the zoning law limits height to 19 stories. The developer has no serious claim to a variance, even if one accepts his assertion that the 12 excess floors resulted from an honest mistake. Yet the punishment should be constructive. The structure was put up after the New York City Department of Buildings erroneously approved all 31 floors. A recent rule change had increased permissible building heights immediately south of the site. But the map issued to illustrate the change suggested that building heights on the site had also been increased. That led to error in the architect's plan, and faulty acceptance.

title: Troops in Punjab Enter Sikh Temple Complex
description: Indian paramilitary forces entered the Golden Temple complex tonight and took over two strategic buildings a few hours after scores of Sikh militants besieged in the complex rejected an appeal to send out more than 20 women and children staying with them.

title: Two Party Insiders to Lead Jackson's Convention Drive
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to make major changes in the structure of his Democratic Presidential campaign, giving new responsibilities to two black Democrats who have excellent relations with the party's leadership.

title: Orion Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $491,000 because of the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for taxes.

title: Germ Warfare Research Safe, Pentagon Says After a Study
description: After what it called a comprehensive review of environmental risks, the Pentagon has concluded that its research into defenses against biological weapons is virtually free of significant danger to people or the environment.

title:
Patents;
Inventor Offers Device To Clean Fingernails
description: LEAD: A new way to clean fingernails was patented this week by Arnold A. Buehler of Oak Lawn, Ill. Patent 4,742,836 was issued for a receptacle with a nozzle that directs cleaning fluid at the fingertips in a high-velocity, fan-shaped stream.

title: Water Only On Request: That Could Be an Order
description: Even with the reservoir system nearly full, getting a glass of water at a restaurant in New York City this summer could take a little more effort.

title: The Promise of a 'Citizens Corps'
description: Can a generally prosperous America at peace with the world be roused to service, sacrifice and civic obligation? The Democratic Leadership Council thinks so and last week offered a plan of national youth service.

title: Growing Benefit Seen in AIDS Drug
description: Evidence has mounted that the drug AZT, on the market in the United States for a year, prolongs life for patients with AIDS and related conditions, researchers with the company that developed the drug said today.

title: Ex-Argentine Officer Denies Role in Deaths
description: A former Argentine Army general extradited from the United States this week has declared in court here that he was not responsible for political murders committed under his command a decade ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Austin Rover Group Ltd., Coventry, England, said it had acquired the 51 percent interest in Austin Rover Cars of North America held by Norman Braman Enterprises, which, with the 49 percent previously held, gives it total ownership. Terms were not disclosed.

title: I.C.H. Is Seeking Partnership Deal
description: The I.C.H. Corporation, an insurance holding company with about $8.7 billion in assets, said that its senior managers would seek partners to buy all of the company's outstanding stock and take it private. I.C.H., which in December backed away from a planned merger with the Southmark Corporation, a Texas real estate and financial services company, reported a first-quarter loss of $16 million, compared with a profit of $10.8 million a year earlier. I.C.H. said the loss was primarily a result of increased claims paid in its health insurance lines.

title: Basic American Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1.5 million. c-Net loss

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included an after-tax provision for restructuring of $4 million. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Gould Investors L P reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $595,000 from the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments for the quarter and $1,689,000 in the 6 months. c-Included a gain of $145,000 from the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments.

title: Canadian Sentenced for Holocaust Booklet
description: A Canadian court today imposed a nine-month jail term on Ernst Zundel, a 49-year-old German-born graphics artist charged with spreading false news in a pamphlet that described the Holocaust as a hoax.

title: A Death Penalty Bill Is Vetoed by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday vetoed restoration of the death penalty in New York, making it 12 straight years that capital punishment has been blocked by the state's chief executive, six by Mr. Cuomo.

title: COPING/With Traffic Tie-Ups
description: Whether because of road crews repairing the ravages of winter or weekenders crawling bumper-to-bumper toward beaches, now is the season for traffic tie-ups.

title: More Tennis Fame
description: Althea Gibson and Arthur Ashe, both winners of United States and Wimbledon singles championships, headed the first group induction in the Eastern Tennis Association Hall of Fame last night at the Marriott Marquis Hotel. Gibson won the women's singles crown at Wimbledon in 1957 and 1958 and the United States women's championship in the same years. Ashe, the only person to win the United States nationals and the open in the same year (1968), also won men's singles at Wimbledon in 1975.

title: Late Home Run Sinks Yankees
description: The one bad pitch that Cecilio Guante threw last night, a fastball down the middle, hung over Billy Martin like a dark cloud. He thought long and hard about it, and then he finally said he could not fault the pitcher. It was simply the wrong pitch at the wrong time, nothing more.

title: Corporate Leaders Toast Good Times, and Fret a Bit
description: Business is good and getting even better, say the heads of the nation's biggest corporations.

title: Robbery Suspect Ordered Freed
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday ordered the release of a defendant held without bail for 32 months on charges involving a 1983 Wells Fargo robbery in Connecticut.

title: Elron Electronic Industries LTD (Israel) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the loss in the year-ago quarter includes a $13,500,000 provision for the investment in Elscint Ltd.

title: Chet Baker, Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 59 in a Fall
description: Chet Baker, a jazz trumpet player who was also a whisper-voiced, romantic singer, died Friday after falling from the second-floor window of a hotel in Amsterdam. He was 59 years old.

title: Article 092388 -- No Title
description: Setting the stage for what could become the largest Federal bailout of a savings institution, the Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas apparently lost close to $1.2 billion in the first quarter, industry experts said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7, 32 Debate on the new missile accord on intermediate-range nuclear weapons may begin in the Senate as early as next week. The Senate leadership gave all but final approval to the agreements reached in Geneva. Page 1 Soviet officials reopened verification terms on the missile accord after Secretary of State George Shultz said all problems had been worked out. Negotiators finally resolved the point. 5 A nuclear-powered Soviet satellite is expected to crash in late summer, the Soviet news agency said. Coincidentally, a Soviet official and American scientists called for a ban on nuclear reactors in orbit about the Earth. 4 Mysticism in Soviet society is serious business for many people, including members of the intelligentsia. One psychic healer in Moscow has a state business license and clients from all walks of life. 1 A century after Brazil ended slavery, the country is involved in wide-ranging discussions of the problems confronting blacks. Attention has been focused on poverty and discrimination many face. 1 Pope John Paul II urged Bolivians to fight the drug trade as a matter of Christian duty. The Pope made his remarks in Santa Cruz, which police say is the country's largest transit point for cocaine smuggling. 3 Brothels in Hamburg are closing as fear of AIDS keeps customers away. Some have shifted to other forms of entertainment. Businesses unrelated to prostitution are also moving into the red-light district. 4 Fighting continued in Beirut as Shiite Moslem fundamentalists of the Party of God seized additional positions from Amal, the rival Shiite militia. The fighting broke the latest cease-fire. 7 Some top American aides are optimistic on a Noriega deal 3 Indian troops enter Sikh temple 4 Israeli patrols keep West Bank quiet 7 National 8-11, 54 The military's role in stopping drugs from entering the country would be expanded under a measure approved by the Senate as an amendment to the defense authorization bill. The vote was 83 to 6. 1 An ambassador who denied briefing Vice President Bush about charges that Panama's military leader was involved in drug trafficking told a Congressional delegation about the charges 17 days later, three people at the meeting said. 10 A sharp rise in inflation is not likely in the next month or two, but increased inflation in the longer term is a threat, according to the performance in April of a Government index on producer prices, which rose moderately. 1 Tax rules for artists were revised by the Internal Revenue Service after writers and artists protested changes in the rules on deducting expenses. Lobbyists said the revisions did not go far enough. 1 AIDS has hit a chorus for gay men, killing 35 members of the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus since 1982. Founded 10 years ago, the singing group has achieved stature in the city's artistic community. 1 Confidence in the Justice Deparment is undermined by the continued presence of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, according to some Republican members of Congress who want Mr. Meese to step down. 9 Three lowly states seek progress together 8 Where symphony is a matter of inheritance 8 Pentagon says germ warfare research is safe 54 Politics 10 Jesse Jackson plans to appoint two black Democrats with excellent relations to the party's leadership to major positions in his campaign as part of his strategy for the national convention. 10 Jesse Jackson said his criticism of Michael Dukakis is part of a fight for control of the Democratic Party's approach to policy and that he did not mean to equate Mr. Dukakis and Vice President Bush philosophically. 10 Michael Dukakis appeared confident as he campaigned for the Democratic Presidential nomination in California and Oregon. The trip seemed almost to be a preview of the general election campaign. 10 Regional 33-36 The Williamsburg Bridge will be shut at least three more weeks and will then gradually reopen, city officials said. Cars will be allowed on it first, then subway trains and trucks. 1 Republicans are fighting in New York and that could affect the Presidential campaign. Vice President Bush's younger brother, Jonathan, and the national committeeman, Richard Rosenbaum, are at odds. 33 Two people were shot and robbed of nearly $400,000 in cash, the police said, when at least three gunmen accosted them as they delivered the money to an office building in lower Manhattan. 33 How companies deliver money is not regulated by state laws 36 Delays in a city redevelopment plan for the Lower East Side of Manhattan, announced four years ago, have been caused, in part, by disputes among city officials, developers and neighborhood groups. 33 Noise from jetliners in New Jersey grew louder over some communities after the number of flight paths into airports was increased to ease air traffic congestion. Residents are angry. 33 The identity of a man found floating in the East River was discovered a year after his body was found. The police credited luck, detective work and a circumstance of Jewish tradition. 35 The case of a former state official has been referred to Federal prosecutors by the New York State Investigation Commission, which said the retired head of the State Thruway Authority conspired to commit extortion. 35 Brawley's family hints she might testify 34 Settlement announced in ''arborcide'' case 35 Wells Fargo robbery defendant is ordered released 36

title: THE HIGH PRIEST OF HOOP HYSTERIA
description: About a year ago some people connected with Indiana University sought to obtain use of the basketball arena for a charity function one night, a night that would not confict with the basketball season. The school administrator in charge of sanctioning such arrangements listened and said, ''Sounds fine to me, but we'll have to get Coach Knight's blessing.''

title: Lopez on Target Despite Putting
description: Dee Darden, a 58-year-old retired Air Force lieutenant colonel, has been Nancy Lopez's caddie for the last four years. Before he picked up her golf bag, Darden watched Lopez play a lot while he caddied for other pros, like Beth Daniel.

title: Chapman in the Draft
description: Rex Chapman, who led Kentucky in scoring for the last two seasons, announced yesterday he would forgo his final two years of college eligibility and make himself eligible for the National Basketball Association draft June 28. The deadline for underclassmen making that declaration is midnight tonight.

title:
Patents;
Installation of Reactors Revised by 4 Germans
description: LEAD: Four inventors in West Germany were awarded a patent this week for a method of installing a nuclear reactor. Patent 4,743,424, granted Claus Elter and associates, is assigned to a West German subsidiary of the European energy conglomerate Asea Brown Boveri A.G.

title: Nordstrom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Expansion Set For Thrifty
description: In a bid to expand into the Pacific Northwest, the Thrifty Corporation, a drugstore and sporting goods chain that is owned by Pacific Enterprises, said today that it plans to acquire 110 Pay'n Save drugstores and 37 Bi-Mart discount department stores for stock worth $232 million. The deal provides for an added $225 million cash payment to Pay'n Save Inc. should earnings of the chains being acquired increase eighteen-fold over five years.

title: Delaware Otsego Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Big Gains in Treasury Issues Pared
description: Treasury note and bond prices posted sharp early gains yesterday that were pared by afternoon bouts of profit taking. Dealers attributed the early gains to relief that the Producer Price Index rose an unexpectedly moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in April.

title: VSE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Navistar Plan Cited at Trial
description: The Navistar International Corporation's sale of its money-losing Wisconsin Steel unit in 1977 was part of a strategy to leave the steel business, not an attempt to avoid pension obligations to workers, according to a company lawyer.

title: Cooper Adds To Its Board
description: The Cooper Companies said today that it had agreed to let certain major shareholders join its board and the special committee that has been formed to pursue the sale of the company's principal businesses. Cooper, which is pressed for cash, last week announced its intention to seek a buyer after the Federal Trade Commission moved to block its plans to sell its contact lens business to a unit of the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Crenshaw Takes Lead: Ben Crenshaw shot a five-under par 65 yesterday to take the second-round lead at the $750,000 Byron Nelson Classic in Irving, Tex. Crenshaw had a six-birdie, one-bogey round for a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 131. He had a two-shot lead over Jeff Sluman and Mark Wiebe and was three shots up on Craig Stadler and John Cook, who had the day's best round with a 64. Arnold Palmer withdrew from the tournament because of pain in his right side.(AP) Gray Leads Seniors: Quinton Gray, a former minor league baseball player who turned to golf at age 28, shot a three-under-par 67 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the $225,000 United Hospitals Senior Championship in Malvern, Pa. Bruce Devlin, Bobby Nichols and Mike Rhyan were next at 69.(AP) Track and Field Injury Stops Sprinter: Ben Johnson, the world sprint champion, was forced out of the 100-meter dash halfway through the event by an injury yesterday at the Japan Air Lines international meet in Tokyo. His coach, Charlie Francis, said Johnson felt a slight strain in his left leg. Marty Krulee of the United States won the race in 10.32 seconds, followed by Japan's No. 1 sprinter, Hiroki Fuwa, in 10.48.

title: Prison Term in Abuse of Boys
description: A former New York City teacher who pleaded guilty to sodomizing and sexually assaulting numerous young boys was sentenced today to 10 to 30 years in prison. Judge Abby Boklan in Nassau County Court said the defendant, Arnold Friedman, 56 years old, of Great Neck, L.I., was a ''menace to society.'' Mr. Friedman, a teacher at Bayside High School in Queens for 20 years, had pleaded guilty in March to 42 counts of sexually abusing and sodomizing 9- to 11-year-old boys. He had also pleaded guilty in Federal court to distributing pornography through the mail. He was sentenced in March on those charges to 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines.

title: In Face of AIDS, a Chorus Stands Taller
description: Stooped and thin, shivering despite a bulky winter coat, Dennis Haney was barely recognizable to his friends in the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus when he auditioned last week for the new season.

title: Quixote Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,060,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $576,000 for the quarter and $1,203,000 for the 9 months.

title: GUATEMALAN ARMY ARRESTS 6 OFFICERS
description: The Guatemalan Army high command appears to be moving quickly to suppress the internal dissent in the military that diplomats say led to a failed coup attempt on Wednesday.

title:
FOCUS: Preservation;
Reviving Neglected Terminals
description: LEAD: AFTER the defeat of two bond issues in March, city officials and preservationists here are again wrestling with the problem of what to do with with a once-glorious railroad station.

title: Leasing Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Hostas: Some Advice From the Experts
description: LEAD: LEARNING plant names is difficult for some of us, and it is made even more difficult by name changes carried out by systematists trying to make botanical names conform to the rules found in the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. Take the plantain lily, for example.

title: Talks Are Held on Settling Backlog Of Violations Against Supermarkets
description: In an unusual move to clear up a backlog of thousands of disputed food-packaging violations by supermarkets, a New York City agency is negotiating a mass financial settlement with a supermarket trade association.

title: Shalala Finds Celebrity on New Turf
description: Donna E. Shalala left the presidency of Hunter College in New York City to become Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison only four months ago, but she is already one of Madison's leading celebrities.

title: No-Lead Gas
description: To the Editor: I have noticed in several letters that many readers are going to Europe via Icelandair to Luxembourg. We have just returned by this routing and enjoyed it very much.

title: Democracy and Disappointment in Ecuador
description: AFTER the tension stirred up by weeks of campaigning and rumors of a coup, Ecuadoreans were understandably relieved that the Presidential election last Sunday proved to be an anticlimax. There was no violence, no cry of fraud, no rumble of tanks and, above all, no surprise victory for Abdala Bucaram Ortiz, a rabble-rousing populist who had come to personify political instability here.

title: Bridge Hed; A Bear Wins at the Cavendish Invitational
description: FOR many years the Russian Bear has been a cause of concern to the United States. In the past decade there have been problems with Swedish bears. First Bjorn Borg, whose first name means ''bear,'' arrived to plague our tennis courts and now Bjorn Fallenius is doing well at our card tables. A week ago he and his partner, Magnus Lindquist, became the first players from another continent to win the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs in the 14-year history of the event.

title: Six to Receive Medallion Awards
description: LEAD: ON May 24, at the 16th annual Medallion Awards dinner, the Foundation for Westchester Community College will honor six community leaders for excellence in their fields and for service to the community.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: UNFREE LABOR: American Slavery and Russian Serfdom. By Peter Kolchin. (Belknap/Harvard University, $25.) This eye-opening book, one of the winners of the two 1988 Bancroft Prizes in American history (see review at right), indicates eerie similarities and unsettling differences between American slavery and Russian serfdom.
