title: On Exhibit: Example of Grass Roots Restoration
description: Margaret Mead Green is a scraggly strip of city-owned parkland on Columbus Avenue between 79th and 81st Streets, a sort of side yard to the American Museum of Natural History. Its grass has been rubbed bare by the dozens of dogs and their owners who use it regularly. Tree roots are exposed. The soil is so compacted that when it rains the park becomes a huge mud puddle.

title: Jersey Man Sues Officials Over '83 Drug Raid
description: A drug raid in 1983 in which investigators shot at two bystanders has resulted in a lawsuit accusing former top Essex County officials of covering up their involvement by filing inadequate reports and destroying evidence.

title: HER SAGA OF A GIANT ISLAND
description: THE GREENLANDERS By Jane Smiley. 558 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Phantoms of the Philharmonic
description: THE guests were arriving in limos rather than gondolas, but their destination did look like a ballroom in Venice. Actually, it was Lincoln Center, which was all gussied up last Wednesday night for a masked ball. The occasion was a benefit for the New York Philharmonic, to whose music a dazzingly bedecked group of about 900 swirled the evening away. Zubin Mehta led the orchestra in the opening dance, a formal polonaise, which was followed by exuberant Strauss waltzes.

title: Sade's Offences
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Discloses That Reagan Planned To Kill National Endowment for Arts
description: The Reagan Administration planned to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts when it came into office in 1981, but dropped the plan when its special task force on the arts and humanities discovered ''the needs involved and the benefits of past assistance,'' according to a forthcoming book by Livingston Biddle, who was chairman of the endowment at the time.

title: Jazz Festival Tickets Are to Go on Sale Today
description: Tickets go on sale today for the JVC Jazz Festival New York, which is to run from June 24 through July 3, with more than 800 artists taking part in over 40 events.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Ferries to Link Vineyard And Boston

title: 'Strange Games' in Stamford
description: IT is nice that Middle America has given its name to all that's average and respectable when it has been the stomping ground of so many weird artists. One of the earliest and weirdest was Ivan Albright, who could make anything -from flesh to flowers - look as if it was in the last stages of putrefaction.

title: Syrian Troops Appear Poised to Try to End Fighting in South Beirut
description: Syrian armored troops gathered at the approaches of Beirut's southern suburbs today, apparently preparing to move in to try to end nine days of bitter fighting between the Shiite Amal militia and the Iranian-backed Party of God.

title: Behind the Blinds at Levolor
description: HANS PHILIP LORENTZEN, who has been cut off from the family business - Levolor Lorentzen Inc., the window-blind maker based in Parsippany, N. J. - talks about the family feuding that led to his disinheritance and to the company's disarray.

title: Strategy for a Weekend of Easy Meals
description: THERE ARE TWO KINDS OF COUNTRY-house hosts: the worriers, who plan every last detail in order to be calm when the guests arrive, and the naturally relaxed, who prefer to plan menus as they're pushing their shopping carts down the supermarket aisles and their friends are pulling into the driveway.

title: Allen Keyes Eastman; Stockbroker, 69
description: Allen Keyes Eastman, a stockbroker, died of a heart attack Thursday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 69 years old and lived in South Norwalk.

title: Nursing Must Be Made More Attractive as a Profession
description: NEW JERSEY is a rich and prosperous state. However, it is becoming a state in which quality health care will be available only to the rich and prosperous.

title: Ms. Rosner Weds John G. Klimchuk
description: The marriage of Marianne Rosner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan L. Rosner of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Becket, Mass., to John Garth Klimchuk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Klimchuk of Houston and Calgary, Alberta, took place last evening at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony.

title: In the Philippines Today, Marcos Is No Longer an Issue
description: AN informal poll was printed in a newspaper last week asking whether former President Ferdinand E. Marcos should be allowed to return to the Philippines from exile for the burial this week of his mother, who died 11 days ago at the age of 95. Few people supported his return, which has been barred by President Corazon C. Aquino. But the most interesting finding was that almost half the respondents said they really did not care whether he comes home or not.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FIRST LIGHT: The Search for the Edge of the Universe. By Richard Preston. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) With the notable exception of Carl Sagan, professional astronomers are usually obscure figures whose daily pursuits are utterly foreign even to well-educated laymen. ''First Light'' is a remarkably readable and illuminating account of contemporary astronomy, as exemplified by a team of researchers at southern California's Mount Palomar Observatory.

title: Allison Waring Cutler And Francis Fox Wed
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Allison Waring Cutler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Newton Cutler Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Francis Edward Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Fox of Ardmore, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Ray Dlugos, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Uproar Over Odor Persists Despite Plans to Close Fish Plant
description: Donna Peabody doesn't mind smelling the sewage treatment plant or the dump, but the fish rendering plant near her home is another matter. So when the plant's owners announced last month they were closing in the fall, she should have been ecstatic.

title: A Full-Fledged Alternative in Newark
description: ALTERNATIVE spaces are proliferating so rapidly in the tri-state area that it may be time to find an alternative to the term alternative.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; The Artificial Intelligence Industry Is Retrenching
description: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow.

title: In Lebanon, Resistance to Iran's Agents Grows Bloody
description: LIKE living marionettes locked in a dark room with unknown hands pulling their strings, the hostages of Beirut may be wondering how the savage fighting in the streets during the last week might affect their fate.

title: A Week of Advice On Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: BETTY GROSS said that for the first time in five years she is going to plant a garden at her Irvington home. She made that decision after spending 20 minutes in her backyard last Sunday - the first time this year she had worked up the courage to go there at all. ''And I was very careful,'' she said.

title: Lucky Streets of Moscow Dressing for Reagan Visit
description: President Reagan, the residents of Vorovsky Street thank you. They salute you on Voyevodin Lane, too, and on the roads leading to the Danilov Monastery.

title: CLOSE-MOUTHED BUT FLAMBOYANT
description: THE WICKEDEST WOMAN IN NEW YORK Madame Restell, the Abortionist. By Clifford Browder. Illustrated. 217 pp. Hamden, Conn.: Archon Books/Shoe String Press. $25.

title: Ex-Justice in Vermont Cited for Misconduct
description: The State Judicial Conduct Board has asked the Vermont Supreme Court to discipline a retired Associate Justice of the court for five instances of judicial misconduct, all involving a colleague.

title: Cost of Reviving Draft Put at $1 Billion a Year
description: A consulting company advising the Defense Department has concluded that it would cost the United States more than $1 billion a year to return to military conscription while maintaining a force as qualified and effective as that of today.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: Not only was it fair, it was important.

title: Shortage of Nurses Worsens
description: The nation's nursing shortage worsened last year, temporarily closing some emergency rooms and delaying admissions and operations, the American Hospital Association says.

title: Camps Alerted to Drug Abuse
description: LEAD: AS THEY prepare for another season, youth camps in New Jersey face the prospect of having to deal with problems associated more with urban America than with rustic retreats.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: Pete Rose's suspension was 100 percent fair. Pushing and shoving belong in hockey, not in baseball. ALEX TIRSCHWELL Brooklyn

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles;
Constructing A Compromise
description: LEAD: AFTER a decade of debate, Center West, a 22-story office tower, is finally beginning to rise in the Westwood section of Los Angeles. It is the result of an unusual compromise between its developer and residents who had opposed the project.

title: Artistry and Family Histories Combine in Handmade Quilts
description: LEAD: QUILTS can be viewed from several different angles -as works of art, as documents in history, as glimpses into the lives of the quiltmakers who designed and stitched them.

title: IN THE NATION: Foreign Investors Step Into More Active Roles
description: They came, they saw, they bought. From the beaches of Hawaii and Florida to the downtowns of Seattle and New York, foreign companies, usually as investors but increasingly as construction partners and independent developers, are seeking new opportunities in hotels and resorts, malls and office buildings.

title:
GARDENING;
Hostas: Some Advice From the Experts
description: LEAD: LEARNING plant names is difficult for some of us, and it is made even more difficult by name changes carried out by systematists trying to make botanical names conform to the rules found in the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. Take the plantain lily, for example.

title: Dr. Mabee Wed To Timothy Bell In Washington
description: Dr. Marcia Sprague Mabee, a daughter of Martha B. Mabee of Lexington, Mass., and the late Irving H. Mabee, and Timothy Harwell Bell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Tartt Bell of McLean, Va., were married yesterday at the Woodrow Wilson House in Washington. The Rev. Harry Quiett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: A Former Reagan Press Aide Named Ambassador to Syria
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Edward P. Djerejian to be Ambassador to Syria, the White House announced Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A response in the Q & A column on Jan. 24 about retirement in Mexico gave an incorrect address for the Retire in Mexico Corporation. The correct address is Avenida Americas 1297-101, Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico.

title: Victory Cigars For the Knicks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BACKUP WHERE IT BELONGS
description: A musical arrangement in pop is like air: It's necessary for survival, and it's usually only noticed when it's bad. The topography of a composition, propped up by varying rhythms, dynamic changes, instrumental combinations or a vicious, prominently displayed bass line is constantly overlooked, rarely questioned and laden with significance. Often, it's the key to deciphering music's intent.

title: 100 Years Old, And the Ship's Still Steaming
description: ''BEAUTIFUL water in a high place'' - the most commonly accepted translation of the Indian name Winnipesaukee -is on target in describing the sprawling New Hampshire lake. With its lovely vistas of mountains and 274 habitable islands, Lake Winnipesaukee has been attracting vacationers for two centuries. Indeed, Wolfeboro, perhaps its most charming port, touts itself as the first summer resort in America.

title: O'Rourke Acts to Fill Vacancies
description: LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke has formed a search committee to help find someone to run the county's solid-waste program, following the retirement earlier this month of Calvin E. Weber.

title: For the Tropicana, A Long Mambo To a U.S. Tour
description: On a lush tropical estate outside Havana, there's an open-air extravaganza six nights a week at the Tropicana, one of the world's best-known nightclubs. Two thousand people regularly jam the place to dine and dance, to hear mambos, cha-chas and newer Cuban music and to watch more than a hundred dancers in feathers and sequins as they strut through glittering routines. The Tropicana will celebrate its 50th anniversary next year, and long after the Cuban revolution, its glamour endures. ''People get off the plane and ask, 'Where is the Tropicana?' '' said Tomas Morales, the club's artistic director, by telephone from Havana.

title: PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
description: Doesn't it occur to the biologist James W. McKearney that the animal he concludes is racing toward the anticipated shock is, instead, frantically trying to speed past it? After failing to do so, it is wearied by its extra efforts and by the shock itself, so it rests before it has to go through the whole tortuous routine again.

title: Miss Kelley Weds Thomas Witschi
description: Gretchen Sue Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Kelley of Saddle River, N.J., and Thomas Phillip Witschi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Witschi of Bern and of Norwich, Vt., were married yesterday. The Rev. Stephen Geckeler performed the ceremony at the Westside Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, a Congregational minister.

title: Pushing the Envelope
description: ''I ALSO WANT TO FIND the edge,'' said the comedian Will Durst to Stephen Holden of The New York Times. ''I keep pushing at the envelope.''

title: Correction
description: An article on May 1 about an increase in self-directed blood donations misstated a statistic attributed to the Red Cross. The statement should have read: ''The Red Cross said the rate of blood donors testing positive for the AIDS antibody is 1 in 20,000,'' not a 1 in 20,000 chance of receiving an AIDS-infected pint of blood. Blood testing positive is destroyed and not used for transfusion.

title: Rare Film Said to Be Imperiled
description: When the American Film Festival is held in Manhattan May 23-28, a film conservator from this Bergen County borough will be there, as he says, ''yelling,'' ''waving red flags'' and ''putting up signs.''

title: Temple Is Upset In Regatta Final
description: Florida Institute of Technology ended Temple University's five-year reign as the men's varsity heavyweight rowing champion of the Dad Vail Regatta, defeating the Owls today in the eight-oared final to win the Tom Conville Cup.

title: Review/Dance; Three Pieces by Laura Dean Troupe
description: Laura Dean continues to be an amazing choreographer. She certainly demonstrated that Friday night when her company, Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians, performed at the City Center.

title: Paul B. Kusserow And Serena Reed, A Teacher, Marry
description: Serena Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and Paul Berthold Kusserow, a son of Suzanne Kusserow of Underhill Center, Vt., and the late Dr. Berthold Kusserow, were married yesterday. The Rev. Neely Paul Towe performed the ceremony at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Wanted: More Focus On Local Efforts
description: The article titled ''Homeless Projects: Setbacks and Optimism'' [ April 24 ] primarily featured the attempts of Andrew M. Cuomo to do something about homelessness, and mentioned several times his name along with that of the county executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Just Distinctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Co-op Parking Garage

title: Murray Will Return
description: He has a respectable regular season record, 283-192-68, in seven years as coach of the Washington Capitals, but in postseason play, Bryan Murray hasn't done so well. He has never led the Capitals past the Patrick Division final, and that has stirred periodic talk that he might be due for replacement. After the Capitals were eliminated in the division final by the Devils this year, there was further speculation about Murray's future.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer Wimbledon Captures Cup: Lawrie Sanchez scored in the 36th minute yesterday as Wimbledon upset Liverpool, 1-0, in the final of the Football Association Cup before a crowd of 98,000 at Wembley Stadium. Sanchez, a member of Northern Ireland's national team, headed a free kick from Dennis Wise and sent it past Bruce Grobbelaar. Liverpool, the English League champion, had an opportunity to tie the score 16 minutes into the second half when John Aldridge was pulled down by Andy Thorn inside the penalty area. But Aldridge's penalty kick was stopped by Dave Beasant, who dived to his left and knocked the ball away. Wimbledon, appearing in its first Cup final, dealt Liverpool its fourth loss of the season. The Princess of Wales presented Beasant, the first goalkeeper to be captain of an F.A. Cup winner, with the Cup after Beasant climbed Wembley's famous 39 steps.(AP) Big Year for Celtic: Glasgow Celtic completed the Scottish Cup and league double in its centenary year by beating Dundee United, 2-1, yesterday at Hampden Park in Glasgow. It was another come-from-behind victory for Glasgow, which won on two late goals by Frank McAvennie. Dundee United took the lead on a goal by Kevin Gallacher three minutes into the second half. But Celtic, which had struck twice in the last three minutes of the semifinal against Hearts, again rallied. McAvennie provided the equalizer in the 75th minute. And, with extra time looming, the Scottish international striker headed the winner only seconds remaining in regulation play. It was Dundee United's fifth defeat in as many final appearances.(AP) Auto Racing Senna and Prost Again: Ayrton Senna of Brazil and Alain Prost of France made it two straight front-row starts as they clinched the top positions for the Formula One Monaco Grand Prix with the top times in yesterday's qualifying session. The McLaren-Honda turbocharged cars were as dominating as they were two weeks ago in the trials for the San Marino Grand Prix. Senna, who is the defending champion on the street circuit in Monaco, powered his car to a 1-minute-23.998-second clocking on the twisting 2.068-mile course. It was the third straight pole position in three races this season for Senna and the 19th of his career. He was almost one and a half seconds better than Prost, who was clocked in 1:25.425. Gerhard Berger of Austria was another second behind with a time of 1:26.685.(AP) Golf Looking for a Victory: Jeff Sluman, who has never won on the PGA Tour, birdied the last hole with a 20-foot putt yesterday to take a one-shot lead over Ben Crenshaw and Bruce Lietzke after 54 holes of the Byron Nelson Classic in Irving, Tex. Sluman shot a three-under-par 67 for a total of 200, 10 under par, over the Tournament Players Course at Las Colinas. Crenshaw shot 70. Lietzke had a 66. (AP) Crampton Leads: Bruce Crampton shot a five-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the $225,000 United Hospitals Senior Classic in Malvern, Pa. Crampton was at 136. In second place were Lou Graham and Billy Casper. Both shot 67 at the Chester Valley Country Club. (AP) Track and Field Surprises at White Plains: There were two surprise winners yesterday in the boys' and girls' 1,600-meter runs in the 21st annual Loucks Track and Field Games at White Plains High School. Phil Hemery, a 16-year-old junior from Archbishop Molloy in Queens, overtook Kevin Krause of Longwood, L.I., with 50 meters to go and won the boys' 1,600 in 4 minutes 16.87 seconds. The time was a personal best. Dana Dougan, an 18-year-old senior at Suffern High School, ran the fastest 1,600 meters of her career in winning the girls' race in 4:58.97. Kathy Moloughney of Notre Dame on Staten Island was second in 4:58.97. Kyron Agard, a sophomore at Tilden in Brooklyn, posted the second-fastest time in the United States this seaso. Rutgers Wins Title: Rutgers University's track team won the Metropolitan Intercollegiate men's track and field championships yesterday, scoring 138 1/2 points. Manhattan was the runner-up with 97 points. The meet was held at Columbia University.

title: Halpin Steers a Middle Course
description: THE Democratic administration of Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin is taking shape after four months and is leaving an impact on a government of 12,000 civil servants and a county population of 1.3 million.

title: Off the Beaten Track to Study Law
description: Jonathon Chase, the late former dean of Vermont Law School, liked to joke that this was the only town in America ''with a law school and no stop light.''

title: Israel Opens Gaza After 29-Hour Blockade
description: The Israeli Army reopened the occupied Gaza Strip today after a 29-hour closing imposed to prevent Palestinians from reaching Jerusalem for prayers on the last sabbath of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Cranford $166,000 15 Cayuga Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; c/a, rec room with bar, 1-car garage; taxes $1,703. Neptune $160,000 1009 Old Corlies Road 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 58-year-old Cape Cod; patio, dining room, partially finished basement; taxes $1,956. Plainfield $399,000 966 Mayfair Way 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $4,872. Short Hills $416,000 54 Cambridge Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2 half-bath, 42-year-old colonial; den, c/a, 2-car garage, porch; taxes $5,935. South Orange $204,000 122 Prospect Place 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 54-year-old Victorian; wrap-around porch, brick fireplace in kitchen, dining room; taxes $3,078. Wayne $242,000 25 Harmer Terrace 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1-year-old ranch; rec room, lawn sprinkler system, patio; taxes $2,886. OTHER AREAS Ronkonkoma, L.I. $85,000 99 Pleasure Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old cottage; eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $650. Cos Cob, Conn. $295,000 11 Grove Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; new kitchen, oversized living room with fireplace; taxes $1,797. Hawthorne, N.Y. $280,000 424 Pythian Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,670.

title: THE NATIONAL CONVENTIONS IN 1948
description: Like Reuven Frank of NBC, I, too, have sweaty memories of those three political conventions at Philadelphia in 1948 - no air-conditioning in the auditorium, hotel rooms, or television ''studios,'' which were simply rooms hung with white sheets (''1948: Live . . . From Philadelphia . . . It's the National Conventions,'' April 17). The electric bulbs exuded heat as well as light, and the facial makeup - which, we thought, was to make us prettier, not to correct the distortion caused by the lights - melted into one's collar. (Let it be asserted and revealed right here that it was not Richard M. Nixon's makeup that ruined him in the 1960 debates with John F. Kennedy, but the lighting, which is the most unstable factor in televison-studio technology.) Mr. Frank recounts how the civil-rights speech by Mayor Hubert H. Humphrey of Minneapolis made him a national figure and drove the Southern Democrats out of the convention and into the Dixiecrat Party. But a recurrent itch compels me to record a memory. The left-liberal Democrats argued all night in a suite in Rittenhouse Square about the civil-rights plank of the platform. I left about 4 A.M., after Humphrey promised to call me at my hotel as soon as a decision had been made.

title: The Death of Investor Confidence
description: LAST Thursday, John W. Bachmann, chairman of the Securities Industry Association, and John J. Phelan, Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, discussed only one topic over their lunch: how to restore investor confidence in the stock market.

title: 'Custom Tailored' for Immunity Without Side Effects
description: THE new generation of genetically engineered vaccines, unlike their earlier counterparts, does not contain live or killed disease organisms, which have been linked to side effects. Instead, they make use of only portions of infectious organisms, like surface proteins called antigens, which arouse immunity but seldom cause side effects.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: East Providence, R.I.;
Oil Tanks Yield To Residences
description: LEAD: A BOSTON developer has begun site preparation for a $150 million community he plans on a 41-acre shoreline site along the Providence River that was once dominated by oil-storage tanks.

title: Bush Denies Being Told in 1985 Of Noriega Role in Flow of Drugs
description: Vice President Bush today denied that a United States Ambassador told him in 1985 about drug trafficking by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's leader. But Mr. Bush said he could not recall exactly what was discussed at the meeting, held in December 1985 with Everett Ellis Briggs, then the United States Ambassador to Panama. Mr. Bush's comments, in response to questions at a news conference, were his fullest statement so far on the meeting.

title: Recapturing The Spirit Of Steamboats
description: In the late 1800's thousands of passenger boats powered by steam plied America's waterways; today there are only a handful, according to David Crockett, president of the Steamship Historical Society of America. Happily, nostalgic travelers can still sample the flavor of the era in the Northeast. Short excursions are available on vintage boats (some now converted to run on diesel fuel) or recently built steamboats in a few locations; more common are replicas that aim to recapture the spirit of the steam age.

title:
ART;
A Pair of Enigmas: Jasper Johns and Samuel Beckett at Yale
description: LEAD: JASPER JOHNS recently commanded the highest price ever at auction for a work of a living artist, and his value is matched by the enigmatic nature of his art. Even at the lowest rung of the art-making ladder - printmaking -he gives you a run for your money.

title: Sharing a Passion to Make Things
description: TWO artists I knew and respected died recently. One was internationally known, Louise Nevelson, age 88; the other, little known but much appreciated, Charles Balth, 95.

title:
IN THE NATION: San Diego;
An 'Emerald City' for a Growing Skyline: Six Green Towers in a Hotel-Office Center
description: LEAD: THERE is little doubt that the Emerald-Shapery Center, scheduled for completion in 1990, will have a dramatic effect on this city's downtown.

title:
MUSIC;
3 Choral Ensembles Offer Novel Works
description: LEAD: THREE of the state's choral ensembles will present unusual programs this week, including a United States premiere and a world premiere.

title: LONG ISLAND FOLLOW-UP
description: Nassau Plastics Ban?

title: Violence Hurts Clean Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Hostas: Some Advice From the Experts
description: LEAD: LEARNING plant names is difficult for some of us, and it is made even more difficult by name changes carried out by systematists trying to make botanical names conform to the rules found in the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. Take the plantain lily, for example.

title: DATA BANK: May 15, 1988
A Different View Of 'Doubles'
description: My wife and I spent a very enjoyable evening at the Studio Theater viewing the play ''Doubles.'' This play was as good a presentation as any we have seen in suburbia.

title: Pentagon Agrees to Curtail Electromagnetic Experiment
description: The Defense Department has settled a lawsuit brought by two environmental groups by agreeing to curtail research into a high-power electrical phenomenon, electromagnetic pulse.

title:
IN THE NATION: Atlanta;
Portman in the Suburbs: The $1.2 Billion Northpark
description: LEAD: FOR more than 30 years, John C. Portman Jr. has called downtown home. The Atlanta architect and developer has built major office and hotel complexes in such cities as Atlanta, San Francisco and New York, often bringing new vitality to the nation's decaying downtown areas.

title: Morrissey's Poison-Pen Letter to the World
description: In ''The Ordinary Boys,'' one of the most bluntly self-revealing songs on ''Viva Hate,'' the first solo album by Steven Patrick Morrissey, the former lead singer of the Smiths bitterly remembers being persecuted by his peers as an adolescent. Picturing his hometown of Manchester, England, as a wasteland of ''cold small streets,'' he looks back on his schoolmates as ''empty fools, happy going nowhere in their rattling cars.'' Ending the song on a note of half-suppressed hysteria, he exclaims, ''They're so lucky, so lucky, so lucky!'' It is a measure of the singer's honesty that along with his towering contempt for his tormenters, he harbors some residual envy.

title: Repairs to Be Made on Two Key Bridges
description: REPAIRS on the George Washington Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike's Laderman Bridge over the Passaic River will restrict late-night traffic this week.

title: Hanoi, Citing Famine Fears, Seeks Emergency Aid
description: As many as three million people in northern Vietnam may be facing starvation, according to Hanoi's official radio and to reports from international aid organizations, which have been asked for emergency food supplies.

title: Safety in Childbirth
description: ADVOCATES for a more natural birth experience have had a major impact on the hospital care of mothers and newborns in the last decade.

title: A Cinch in Time
description: COLORFUL six-inch suspenders called Mini-Grips are spanning the generations in popularity. Mothers wear them to clasp cardigans and anchor scarves, while daughters use theirs to create mock Mary Janes out of plain flats. The suspenders also shorten hems for a scalloped effect on skirts, T-shirts and pants, and can cinch waists like a belt. They join cropped tops to skirts and bind bicyclists' cuffs.

title: After the Tag Sale, the Garbage
description: REAL men like me don't brake for garage sales. We don't hop to flea markets. Real men pick trash, and we're proud to admit it. Spring is our season. We feed off everyone else's ritualistic desire to shed the household clutter that accumulates all winter.

title: DANCING, EATING AND OTHER PATRIOTIC ACTS
description: FESTIVALS AND THE FRENCH REVOLUTION By Mona Ozouf. Translated by Alan Sheridan. Illustrated. 378 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

title: Price Tags on Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Savoring the Season's Fresh Tastes: In Desserts
description: EVEN AT THEIR SIMPLEST, DESSERTS are especially dazzling in summer, thanks to an abundance of fresh fruit. For decoration and seasoning, there is also a generous harvest of delicate blossoms and feathery herbs.

title: Pamela Webb Married To Matthew B. Dawson
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York, Pamela Webb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bryan Webb of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Brayton Dawson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dawson of Dover, Mass. The Rev. Ernest E. Hunt 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Democrats Needn't Avoid Noriega Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Verbatim; Sinatra on Berlin
description: ' What makes an Irving Berlin song special?

title: For Summit Planners, Image Counts
description: During the four-day summit meeting in Moscow later this month, President Reagan is expected to leave the confines of official government buildings at least three times to mix with Soviet citizens who reflect the country's changing religious and intellectual climate.

title: Headliners; Posthaste
description: ''There is nothing in the record that says this man is entitled to a break, nothing,'' said the prosecutor in the case of Ronald Gene Simmons, accused of killing 14 members of his family and two other people in Russellville, Ark., last December. Concurring with the prosecutor last week, after a jury had convicted the 47-year-old retired Air Force master sergeant of two of the murders, were the judge, who sentenced him to death, and Mr. Simmons himself, who asked that no one interfere in his behalf. Asked whether he wanted an early execution date, Mr. Simmons replied: ''Absolutely.'' He still faces trial in July in the deaths of the 14 other victims found shot or strangled in or near his house after a 45-minute rampage.

title: Women Lead Men's Crew at Yale
description: LEAD: As practice for the Yale University Men's Crew Team began, a female voice was shouting orders: ''Heads up! Hands on! Walk it out!''

title: School Clinic Plan Draws Opposition
description: CONCERNED that Long Island adolescents are not receiving proper health care, officials are considering opening health clinics in some schools. But many of the proposals are running into opposition, including from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, because they would offer counseling on contraception.

title: With Vacancies Rising, Watchword Is Caution
description: A HAZE of caution has been hanging over the Manhattan office market ever since last October's stock market crash. And the forecast for the rest of the year looks - at best - partly sunny.

title: THE WORST THING ABOUT A SPITBALL
description: LEAD: REMEMBRANCE OF SWINGS PAST By Ron Luciano and David Fisher. Illustrated. 309 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: HOW ANTIQUE IS ANTIQUE?
description: No subject is of greater interest to antiques collectors than how to detect fakes and repairs in period furnishings. In FAKE, FRAUD, OR GENUINE? Identifying Authentic American Antique Furniture (New York Graphic Society/ Little, Brown, $29.95), Myrna Kaye, a former consulting curator of furniture at the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities in Boston, describes scores of ways in which American antique chairs, tables, chests and sideboards are not all that dealers and auctioneers claim them to be. One of the more popular scams, of course, is selling modern works as antiques; these pieces of furniture are either made of old wood or else crafted as reproductions and then aged. The author urges shoppers to question everything, pointing out that antiques are frequently enhanced for profit. She tells how an undecorated drawer on a high chest is transformed with a boldly carved shell, how a fraudulent label is added to the underside of a desk and how two old Chippendale-style chairs are combined to produce a rare form - a double-backed settee. The primary focus of Ms. Kaye's book, which contains more than 200 illustrations, is on 18th-century American furniture. That is understandable, because the period is a favorite of collectors and there exists plenty of relevant documentation on forgeries and doctored furniture. Those in search of guidance on the 19th-century revival styles must look elsewhere. The author's chatty style and sweeping generalizations detract from the merit of many stories - especially those in which the participants are not named or, when they are, have not been allowed to respond to Ms. Kaye's statements.

title: Largent Staying Put
description: At the age of 33, Steve Largent of the Seattle Seahawks is getting a bit long in the tooth for a National Football League receiver. Because he has already made his mark - he holds the league receiving record with 752 career catches - it would seem to be time for Largent to start thinking about retirement.

title: 14 Steps To Billy's Future
description: In this new Age of Aquarius, Joan Quigley missed her big chance to analyze the nation's most debated issue: What's in Billy Martin's future and did or did not the Yankee manager punch that dogie in the Texas topless bar? The confidante of Nancy Reagan is not listed in the San Francisco phone book. And assuming that neither the First Lady nor the White House switchboard would disclose her number, an alternative astrologer was discovered behind a second-floor window with a neon star and several leafy plants on East 31st Street, just off Lexington Avenue.

title: SHE CONSIDERED BOYS FOR ABOUT 5 MINUTES
description: AFTER DELORES By Sarah Schulman. 158 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: ALL THE COMFORTS OF DICKENS
description: If I were stranded alone on a desert island and had to choose one author's works for company, I would take not the collected plays of Shakespeare, but the Oxford Illustrated Dickens in 21 volumes, which was published a few months ago by Oxford University Press. While Shakespeare is certainly the greater writer, I would choose Dickens because on a desert island I would wish for, more than anything else, a teeming, colorful evocation of the world I'd lost.

title:
DINING OUT;
Waterside in Cold Spring
description: LEAD: THE search for harmony has always led diners to particularly pleasing combinations - fresh strawberries nibbled on a spring lawn, hearty stews beside a winter fire. When properly prepared seafood is found by water's edge, one feels a certain rightness in the order of things.

title: Nantucket's Lightship Baskets
description: OF COURSE you've seen them, hanging casually from the arms of fashionable and stylish women on the Cape, in the Hamptons, on Fifth Avenue and in Palm Beach. To most people in America these curious little rattan handbags with woven covers and swinging handles are known as Nantucket baskets, but to people on Nantucket they are known as lightship baskets.

title: Landfill May Become a Park
description: LEAD: JAY PITTI has a dream about a landfill: he wants to turn a 42-acre, 125-foot-high former dump in Merrick into a nature preserve.

title: The Wrong Villains on Wall Street; Quick Fixes Distract From Real Reforms
description: Pressed by corporate clients, Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley & Company finally caved last week. They announced that they, along with three other large firms, would give up program trading for their own accounts. This delighted Wall Streeters, desperate for ways to prove that the demon had been slain and that it's safe for investors to test the market waters again.

title: Regen Horchow, Teacher, To Wed R. D. Pillsbury Jr.
description: Regen Horchow and Rockwell Dole Pillsbury Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pillsbury of Dallas, plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Roger Horchow of Dallas have announced.

title: Enrollment Rising In Catholic Schools
description: LEAD: ROMAN CATHOLIC schools here, especially elementary schools, are experiencing an increase in non-Catholic enrollment that exceeds the national average.

title: THE ALLURE OF THE OLDER WOMAN
description: Noel Perrin's article omitted all the reasons that my husband married me. Twelve years my junior, he succumbed to my ''beauty, wit, awesome sexuality and joyous nature'' (his words, not mine). LUCY GARNETT New York, N.Y.

title: New Voice Joins Debate On Auto Insurance
description: FOR YEARS, the debate over how to repair New Jersey's expensive automobile-insurance system has been depicted as one between insurance companies, which blame high litigation costs, and the trial attorneys, who say insurance company greed is to blame.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 9 of the Travel section today about the steamer Mount Washington, which sails on Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire, omits the address and telephone number for information about the vessel's summer schedule and fares. It is available from Winnipesaukee Flagship, Post Office Box 367, Weirs Beach, N.H. 03246; the telephone number is 603-366-5531.

title: On Critics: Dialogue Or a Diatribe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hindu Community Gathers at Temporary Temple
description: LEAD: EVERY other Sunday afternoon, the main meeting room of the Ethical Humanist Society in White Plains is transformed into a Hindu Temple.

title: Everything but a Body in Murder Trial
description: For the crowd that gathers inside Superior Court here each day to watch the trial of Richard B. Crafts, the lure is a crime as intriguing as a Philip Marlowe mystery and as grisly as the movie ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.''

title: Gay Rights Groups Question Dukakis on Foster Care Issue
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was sharply questioned and at one point was hissed in an appearance before members of a gay rights political coalition here today.

title: Time to Get the Picnic Basket Ready
description: WITH Memorial Day coming soon, it is time to think about foods suitable for summer picnics. Sandwiches and salads are the obvious choices. Tastes in sandwiches can run the gamut from the classic chicken or tuna salad, deli meats and peanut butter to stylish contemporary concepts such as mozzarella, basil and sun-dried tomatoes on crusty Italian wheat bread or slices of teriyaki steak with shiso leaves on sesame bread.

title: An Antiquing Picnic
description: IT WAS 7 ON A SPLENDID MANHATTAN MORNING, and the five young fashion and arts professionals who arrived at Lyssa Horn's East Side apartment were greeted with the welcome aroma of steaming coffee and hot muffins. Despite the early hour and a yawn or two, Ms. Horn's friends were in high spirits and ready for adventure.

title: THE NATION: Chrysler and the U.A.W.; A Union Pact to Restrict Executive Privilege
description: MANY corporations have tried to become more efficient by imitating Japanese management techniques, but the rules for compensating executives have remained strictly American. In the United States auto industry, top executives were paid 12 to 18 times as much as the average blue-collar worker, according to a University of Michigan study published in 1984. Japan's leading automotive executives got only about six to eight times as much as their employees.

title: Lopez Establishes One-Stroke Lead
description: Nancy Lopez got up and down from a bunker alongside the 18th green today to save par and preserve a one-stroke lead over Alice Ritzman going into the final round of the 13th annual Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

title: THE MYSTERY OF MARIO CUOMO
description: MARIO CUOMO LIKES TO play games, and on this day in April the game is baseball, the opening of Pilot Field in Buffalo.

title: JOYCE, NORA AND THE WORD KNOWN TO ALL MEN
description: ''Chance,'' James Joyce once said, ''furnishes me what I need. I am like a man who stumbles along; my foot strikes something, I bend over and it is exactly what I want.''

title: For the Adventurous Griller
description: SINCE MANKIND HAS BEEN cooking food over glowing embers at least since Prometheus, the technique, by all rights, should be at a very high level. But there is one major impediment to achieving this degree of skill - that typically American failing, lack of patience.

title: John C. Bullitt, 62, an Ex-Treasury Official
description: John C. Bullitt, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President Kennedy, died of cancer yesterday at his farm in Princeton, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: Old-Style Performance Is Becoming a New Concert Hit
description: MORE crumhorns and sackbuts are showing up at Connecticut concerts these days. And audiences cannot get enough of them.

title: Leasing Brokers
description: To The Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Troubled Projects and Their Rescue
description: LEAD: TWO East End developments now on the market after years of delays illustrate how projects can go awry even when they have merit and meet the needs of the marketplace.

title: Five Centuries Of Exports: Oriental Notions Of Western Taste
description: Asian arts and crafts made over five centuries for export to the West -porcelains, silver, ivory, lacquer, furniture and paintings - are now increasingly appreciated for their historical and esthetic value. Just why these art works and objects are of enduring interest can be seen in the impressive displays that went on view yesterday in the new Asian Export Art Wing of the Peabody Museum of Salem here. It is the first museum anywhere to focus solely on decorative arts made in the East to trade with the West from the 16th century through today.

title: Ford's Presidency: Brief but Well Run
description: Throughout this summer, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will strive to define the kind of Presidency they would create if given the chance. While voters undoubtedly have their own ideas about the ideal Presidency, I would like to suggest a standard of comparison: the Ford Administration.

title: STREETSCAPES: Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive; Institutions Use Air Rights Over a Multilevel Marvel
description: NEW YORK CITY and the state are jointly rehabilitating the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, a project expected to be completed by the mid-1990's. Widely known as the East River Drive, it is certainly one of Manhattan's great public works, particularly the section between 53d and 92d Streets, a dizzying stretch of dips and rises, views and tunnels, sun and shadow.

title: Denver Judge Sentences Rapist to 376-Year Term
description: A man who served as his own attorney and confronted victims on the witness stand at his trial has been sentenced to 376 years in prison on 14 counts of rape and burglary.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Elmont $147,500 147 Circle Drive East 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 16-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $2,200. Farmingdale $190,000 42 Miller Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; fireplace, basement, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Hempstead $240,000 21 Clark Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; dining room, den, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $3,300. Hicksville $117,000 231 Blueberry Lane 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old ''handyman's special'' ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Northport $240,000 58 Gildare Drive 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,800. Ronkonkoma $85,000 99 Pleasure Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old cottage; eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $650. OTHER AREAS Cos Cob, Conn. $295,000 11 Grove Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; new kitchen, oversized living room with fireplace; taxes $1,797. Hawthorne, N.Y. $280,000 424 Pythian Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,670. Plainfield, N.J. $399,000 966 Mayfair Way 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $4,872.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CURIOUS WORLD: A New Yorker at Large. By Philip Hamburger. (North Point, $19.95.) What a curious world, indeed, especially when filtered through the eyes and pen of the New Yorker writer Philip Hamburger, who here offers a wondrously rich collection of 19 essays from his nearly 50 years on the magazine's staff.

title: Miss Mullen Has Wedding
description: At St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Cornwall Bridge, Conn., Elaine Patricia Mullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Mullen of Bronxville, N.Y., and Warren, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Thomas McCreanor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. McCreanor of London. The Rev. Randall Blackall performed the ceremony.

title: Counselors Have Fun On the Job
description: Derrick Lopez, a tall, brawny 22-year-old teacher at a private boarding school in Westchester County, cried in front of some of his own students as he led a recruiting session this year for Fresh Air Fund camp counselors.

title: Nassau County's Role In Helping Young Parents
description: The April 17 article ''Young Parents Learn Job Skills'' fails to include the very important contribution of the Nassau County Department of Social Services in identifying and referring potential participants to the Comprehensive Employment Opportunity Support Center project (''Crossroads'') operating on a grant from the New York State Department of Social Services.

title: Review/Film; Animated 'Light Years'
description: In the itty-bittiest print imaginable, the ads for ''Light Years'' indicate that Glenn Close, Christopher Plummer, Jennifer Grey and John Shea appear only in ''starring the voices of'' capacities. In other words, this is an animated film, and it wasn't made with these particular actors in mind.

title: ART FOR MONEY'S SAKE
description: REMBRANDT'S PORTRAIT A Biography. By Charles L. Mee Jr. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: City Ballet's New Look Is Cut From Dark Fabrics
description: Many of the premieres in the New York City Ballet's continuing American Music Festival look grim rather than pretty and are danced without tutus. This virtually tutu-less festival, with its tendency toward gloom, offers an esthetic image of the City Ballet that is significantly different from the one we customarily expect.

title: First Employer Is Fined in an Illegal-Alien Case
description: LEAD: WITH the end of the nation's immigrant amnesty program, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has moved into a second phase: punishing employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens.

title: When Guests Invite Calamity
description: THE REAL PROBLEM with entertaining is that it can't be done without guests. And the real problem with guests is that you never know what they'll get up to. They are, after all, only human - they can't be timed like roast beef, arranged like flowers or turned off like a cassette. Sparkling house, fabulous food, a list of friends that sounds terrific - it can all come to nought if someone drinks too much, begins an argument or monopolizes the conversation. And that, as they say, is only the tip of the iceberg.

title: An Afternoon By the Pool
description: THE INVITATIONS WERE INFORMAL, delivered by telephone: ''If you're not busy, come around for lunch by the pool on Saturday. And bring the kids.'' The occasion was nothing special, just the chance for Allan and Joan Burns and their two sons, Matthew, 20, and Eric, 23, to get together with good friends. The food was simple - kebabs assembled by the guests and cooked over the outdoor grill, and a couple of tasty salads - all easily prepared ahead and set out for everyone to help themselves. But it turned into one of those spontaneous successes that hosts and hostesses always hope for.

title: Controlling Our Population Growth
description: Susan S. Gold's giddy joy over her third pregnancy (''The Magic of Babies Makes Three a 'Perfect Number,' '' April 10, Opinion page) should not blind her to the demographic consequences of her actions.

title: Prince Edward Island
description: AS our family discovered last summer, there is an island gem north of Maine. It is the Canadian province of Prince Edward Island, and although it is relatively isolated, we reached it easily by driving to New Brunswick and taking a 45-minute ferry ride across the Northumberland Strait from Cape Tormentine, to Borden.

title: ALL THE PRESIDENTS MEN
description: SPEAKING OUT The Reagan Presidency From Inside the White House. By Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95. REVOLUTION By Martin Anderson. Illustrated. 486 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: ASTROS' KNEPPER (5-0) STOPS CUBS
description: After perhaps his most frustrating year in baseball and a controversial spring training, Bob Knepper of the Astros, a left-hander, is at peace with himself and has forgotten the past.

title: Germans Argue Over a Museum That Will Offer A Probing Look At Their History
description: It is something of a given in a land where history is a sensitive subject and self-scrutiny a national affliction that an attempt to found a museum of German history will be controversial - especially if the initiative comes from the Government.

title: Kae E. Konen to Marry
description: Kae Ellen Konen, the assistant vice president of sale promotion for Sotheby's, and Charles Robert Ledford Johnsons, a senior analyst at Salomon Brothers, are planning a June wedding. The parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Elvin R. Konen of Naples, Fla., and Lincoln, Mich., have announced the engagement.

title: Aging and Suicide: Officials Troubled By High Incidence
description: LEAD: SO SHATTERED were her fellow residents of the Orange Park Apartments, a complex for the elderly in Orange, after an 82-year-old woman killed herself there last spring that the management called in suicide experts from Rutgers University to help them cope with the shock and grief.

title: IS AMERICA IN DECLINE?
description: I cringe every time I hear respected historians sounding alarms whenever they perceive parallels with past events. Those who see cycles have fertile imaginations or, worse, are using history to legitimize their social agendas. Either way, they sound more like astrologers than scholars.

title: Pope Begins Visit to Peru; Guerrillas Stage Offensive
description: Pope John Paul II began a 40-hour visit to Peru today amid a rising wave of political violence by Maoist guerrillas who have opened a terrorist offensive to exploit the Pope's presence.

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday about Vice President Bush's plans for television commercials in the Presidential campaign misstated the role of the New York advertising agency of Messner, Vetere, Berger & Carey. As the article said, two partners in the firm declined to say whether the agency would create commercials for Mr. Bush in the fall.

title: Victoria Moran Weds Dr. Juan C. Echevarria
description: Victoria M. Moran, a daughter of M. Frances Hubert of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late George B. Moran Jr., was married yesterday to Dr. Juan Carlos Echevarria, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Antonio Echevarria of Lima, Peru. Diane M. Crehan, a Connecticut justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and her stepfather, Ralph Hubert.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Illusion and Reality We travel not to places, but to illusions, which make every arrival both an anticlimax and a beginning. Here is Mary Morris in Mexico, from ''Nothing to Declare: Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone'' (Houghton Mifflin).

title: Good Medicine, Better Business
description: THE SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION was looking for just the right advertising symbol to sell physicians on new diagnostic equipment to use in their offices. It chose a goose with a golden egg.

title: No One Has Proved Yet That There's Nothing to Astrology
description: To the Editor:

title: Step by Step, Lendl Moves Out of the Shadows
description: For almost 11 years now, Ivan Lendl has been known mostly for his demeanor on a tennis court, brutally efficient and businesslike, lacking real passion, those terms all becoming synonymous with his name. They painted a one-dimensional portrait, but it was all that Lendl was comfortable revealing about himself, the only personality traits the fans and news media were allowed to see.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: Umpires should be respected. In the court of law of baseball, the umpire is the judge, the manager the lawyer. If he isn't persuasive in his argument, a shove or push could mean a contempt citation. Surely this law will be upheld after its strict interpretation. SYLVAN STRETCH Stamford, Conn.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: DOOM FOR DISCOUNTERS?;
Let Consumers Choose Where to Shop
description: LEAD: FOR those who have followed the development of antitrust law in the courts, the Supreme Court's decision in Business Electronics Corp. v. Sharp Electronics Corp. came as little surprise. The decision simply made explicit what has been implicit under the antitrust law for over a decade. The decision stands for the unremarkable proposition that because most agreements between manufacturers and their dealers, involving terms other than prices and price levels, may actually benefit consumers, the courts should not automatically condemn them.

title: 3 Targeted Suburbs Fight a Novel Plan to House Westchester's Homeless
description: Last October, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, and Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, introduced a plan to ease the county's growing homeless problem that they thought communities would quickly accept.

title: Deciding Which Profits Should Be Tax Exempt
description: TAX-EXEMPT organizations such as museums and universities have been ill at ease for almost a year over issues being explored by a House subcommittee. But it is one thing for a few Congressmen to talk about taxing a wider range of the profit-making ventures of not-for-profit organizations and quite another when the White House gets involved.

title: The French Agree to Be Centrist - More or Less, for Now
description: WHEN a humbled Jacques Chirac submitted his resignation last week to President Francois Mitterrand, France formally ended two novel years of ''cohabitation'' between a Socialist head of state and a Prime Minister chosen by the rightist majority in the National Assembly. In the aftermath of Mr. Mitterrand's stunning re-election to a second seven-year term, the two years of cohabitation are looking less like an odd parenthesis and more like the springboard to an even bolder political experiment.

title: THE ALLURE OF THE OLDER WOMAN
description: Noel Perrin may believe he is singing the praises of older women in his article ''The Allure of the Older Woman'' (About Men, April 17). In reality, his left-handed homage only objectifies women in the familiar image of the eternal nurturer. In his view: it is the woman who is counted on to assume the role of mother, teacher and therapist; the woman is merely a way station on the road to manhood; she herself is of consequence only insofar as she can help the younger man cultivate his own inchoate sense of self. JOY ALTER HUBEL New York, N.Y.

title: Subaru Series Begins
description: A field of 85 men and 85 women, including many racers who will compete this summer for positions on the 1988 United States Olympic cycling teams, is expected to start today in the Subaru National Criterium Championships in White Plains. The races are the first in a series of seven Subaru-sponsored events over five months.

title: New Britain Sox Gain Amenities
description: THE New Britain Red Sox are playing in the same ball park this year. But it isn't the same old ball park.

title: Forecast of '89 Congress: The Democrats, Again
description: Democrats seem likely to retain control of Congress this fall, whatever happens in the Presidential election.

title: Seeing Dollar Signs In Searching the Stars
description: LYNNE PALMER mentioned that versatility is important if you're a professional astrologer. You could see that right away in her Manhattan living room. In one nook, she had a tape recorder set up to record her client readings. Lying on the coffee table was a sampling of the 14 books she had written, including ''Use Astrology and Change Your Name'' and ''Nixon's Horoscope.'' There was a poster promoting an astrology video she had starred in. There was some literature on horoscope pendants she sold that purportedly cause the wearer to think subconsciously about money. Those thoughts should then attract pleasing sums of cash. First, however, you must part with some money. The pendants are $14.40; an extra $5 gets you a chain. If you supply the time, date and place of your birth, Ms. Palmer will work up your horoscope chart and, in a two-hour chat, give you a good idea of what's coming up. Precision counts. ''If you're two minutes off on your birth time,'' she explained, ''then your reading will be off by six months. Eight minutes means two years.''

title: Suspended Probation Chief Blames Lack of Funds
description: THE first department head to be suspended in the five and a half years of the O'Rourke Administration said last week that problems in the Probation Department had resulted from the county's failure to provide enough financial support, not from a lack of leadership on his part.

title: 50 Radio Stations to Join in an AIDS Broadcast
description: IN SUPPORT of an effort by 50 of the state's more than 80 radio stations to simultaneously broadcast a phone-in AIDS television show, Governor Kean has declared Thursday as ''New Jersey AIDS Helpline Day.''

title: The Price of Occupation
description: The Palestinian uprising, now in its sixth month, has not moved the Government of Israel a visible inch toward any greater willingness to withdraw from the West Bank and Gaza. To the contrary, Prime Minister Shamir has become increasingly emphatic in saying that Israel will keep those territories forever.

title: How Good Is Medicine?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jean P. McGavin, Designer, Engaged to Daniel Eldridge
description: Jean Pamela McGavin plans to wed Daniel Myers Eldridge in July, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Alfred McGavin of Arlington, Va., have announced. Her fiance is the son of Ronnie Myers Eldridge of New York and the late Dr. Lawrence O. Eldridge. He is the stepson of Jimmy Breslin, the Daily News columnist.

title: Review/Recital; Chilean Anthem Variations
description: After an initial rush of attention, Frederic Rzewski's hourlong pianistic tour de force ''The People United Will Never Be Defeated!'' (1975) seemed to settle into a sort of limbo rarely encountered in recital programs. But this season Barry Hannigan did it in February at Merkin Concert Hall, and on Wednesday night David Holzman - coatless, with a bandanna from the Spanish Civil War around his neck to honor his father and ''all those who fought against Fascism'' - made it the climax of his program at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss. Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling. We hired a painter who scraped and sanded, then painted with an oil paint, but now the walls and ceiling are flaking again. Can you help me solve this problem?

title: 'I DON'T STOOP. I MERELY CONQUER'
description: LEAD: WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY, JR. Patron Saint of the Conservatives. By John B. Judis. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Affirmative Action Upholds Academic Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Meagher Weds T. C. Davis
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., Patricia Ann Meagher, a daughter of Martha E. Meagher of Darien and the late Thomas R. Meagher, was married yesterday to Timothy Converse Davis, the son of Joan V. Davis of Darien and the late Donald B. Davis.

title: A Musical Version Of 'Little Foxes'
description: ONCE, the notion of opera in a legitimate theater was forbidding and so ''Regina,''

title: School Ruling Challenged
description: THE TOWN of Englewood Cliffs, which wants to stop sending students to the heavily black and Hispanic Dwight Morrow High School in neighboring Engelwood, has filed with the state's Commissioner of Education its objections to a decision recommending that it not be allowed to pull out.

title: Dr. Hillary Hart Is Wed To Dr. Anthony Alofsin
description: The marriage of Dr. Hillary Hart, a daughter of Louise Cadby of Northampton, Mass., and the late Richard C. Hart, to Dr. Anthony Alofsin, the son of the late Frederick Alofsin and the late Eleanor Alofsin, both of Memphis, took place yesterday in Austin, Tex. Judge Jon N. Wisser of State District Court performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

title: French Telepolitics Lessons
description: Francois Mitterrand's strategy has never changed, says Claude de Kemoularia, a French banker, former ambassador and astute political observer. He analyzes the plan in four stages: first, to create an electable alternative to the old Gaullist majority; then to smash the Communist Party; then reform a Socialist base into a non-Marxist social-democratic party; and finally, to smash the right, leaving a solid foundation for France to be governed from left-center.

title: THE NATIONAL CONVENTIONS IN 1948
description: Reuven Frank's article brought back a flood of memories, as I was an ABC-TV director at that time.

title: Holocaust: Repetition Dulls the Horror
description: Often the very person who deplores the depiction of violence in movies and on television endorses the vivid recounting of the ghastly horrors of the Holocaust to children. Cui bono? What would we have done to prevent the Holocaust if we had remembered the Inquisition?

title: A July Wedding For Ms. Hodgson
description: The engagement of Amanda Elissa Hodgson to John Thomas Hompe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. S. Hodgson of Port Washington, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harold Hompe of Stanley, Wis. A July wedding is planned.

title: Review/Dance; East German Dancer Makes Ballet Theater Debut
description: American Ballet Theater's first ''Don Quixote'' of the season Friday night - with Susan Jaffe in the ballerina role - also offered a historic first in the person of a 25-year-old virtuoso and guest artist from East Germany, Oliver Matz.

title: Tenant Drops Apartment Suit
description: A TENANT whose fight to keep possession of his family's rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan appeared likely to set an important legal precedent has agreed to give up his legal battle and leave the apartment in an out-of-court settlement with his landlord.

title: A Fall Wedding For Ruth Lebed
description: The engagement of Ruth Lebed to Peter Kevin Rofes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Rofes of Commack, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Lebed of Woodbourne, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: Gallaudet U. Praised for Successful Protests
description: For the first time in the 124-year history of Gallaudet University, a deaf president and a deaf chairman of the board presided over commencement exercises for the graudates at the nation's only college for the hearing impaired.

title: Crusty Voice Quitting After 24 Years
description: After 24 years as the sole operator of the only radio station in this quaint fishing community, Simon Geller has sold WVCA-FM with considerable glee and eager visions of the apartment he hopes to buy on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: MEESE REPORT SAID TO REVIEW INQUIRY
description: The independent prosecutor's report on Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is not likely to make broad conclusions about Mr. Meese's conduct but instead will offer an exhaustive review of the evidence gathered, according to people with knowledge of the yearlong inquiry.

title: PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
description: By divorcing addiction from the circumstances in which it occurs, James McKearney's research does a disservice to addicts and to those who try to help them. There are understandable reasons why people may turn to drugs when they feel unable to cope with economic hardship, stress, psychological or physical abuse or discrimination. This is not to say that substance abuse is ever anything but destructive or to deny that some people take drugs out of boredom or for kicks.

title: Urgent Call From the Wild to Boycott Ivory
description: Warning that the elephant population in Africa is declining at an alarming rate, the African Wildlife Foundation has called on Americans to help save the great mammals by refusing to buy ivory or ivory products.

title: Country Houses Of a Lucky Few
description: JUST as tulips are giving way to irises and the commuter traffic on the Long Island Expressway is swelled by the Friday flight to houses on the East End, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton is presenting ''The Long Island Country House, 1870-1930.''

title: New Rules for New Genes
description: The Environmental Proctection Agency is preparing new rules for field tests of genetically altered microorganisms that are expected to relax restrictions on certain tests. The power to approve tests is expected to be moved from the E.P.A. to regional Environmental Biosafety Committees. How will these changes affect commercial genetic engineering? Donald L. Emlay Director of regulatory affairs, Calgenes Inc.

title: THE ALLURE OF THE OLDER WOMAN
description: It is true, as Noel Perrin says, that Benjamin Disraeli and Mary Anne Wyndham Lewis had a happy marriage. It is true that he became Prime Minister, and that they ''lived devotedly together. . . .''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Xavier McDaniel of the Seattle Supersonics will face six weeks of rehabilitation after undergoing successful arthroscopic surgery on his right knee. . . . Felix McGrath and Tamara McKinney, both Alpine specialists, were among 33 hopefuls named to the United States Ski team for the 1988-89 season.

title: Affirmative Action Upholds Academic Values; Autonomy of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Previn as Composer and Conductor
description: As part of a three-concert swing through Manhattan, the Los Angeles Philharmonic presented a program Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall that offered two insights into Andre Previn.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GOOD-BYE, MY WISHING STAR By Vicki Grove. 128 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. BORROWED CHILDREN By George Ella Lyon. 154 pp. New York: Orchard Books/ Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 12)

title: Caribbean
description: To the Editor: In your ''Summertime: Savings Time'' box about off-season rates in the Caribbean (Travel Advisory, March 27), 9 out of 12 of the hotels listed were over $100 a night. My wife and I would like to point out that there are quite a few small hotels in the Caribbean, including ours, the Waves at Cane Bay on St. Croix, where a first-class or deluxe accommodation, directly on the ocean, is available for $60 to $70 a night for two people. Compared to hotel prices in the rest of the world, these are real bargains, and the vacationing public should be told that an off-season holiday in the Caribbean does not have to be expensive. JOHN A. SILANDER Kingshill, St. Croix, V.I.

title: Michelle DeMuth to Wed William W. Gay Next Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Dennis L. DeMuth of Ida, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Denise DeMuth, to William Wingate Gay, a son of William K. Gay of Mahwah, N.J., and Mrs. E. Virgil Conway of Bronxville, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BY LAND, BY SEA. By William Hoffman. (Louisiana State University, $16.95.) The title of this short-story collection comes from its two locales: Virginia's tobacco and horse country near Lynchburg, where in the dry season ''the red soil split like a cracked clay pot,'' and the state's Chesapeake Bay coast, with its salt-water spray, whispering reeds and crying gulls.

title: The Supermole
description: A suitable epitaph for H.A.R. (Kim) Philby was written long ago, in 1947, by Rebecca West. In ''The Meaning of Treason,'' she wrote of the peculiar allure of the world of spies and counterspies:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ON A WOMAN'S PLACE A new translation of ''Tutta Casa, Letto e Chiesa,'' a 1970's feminist play by Dario Fo and his wife Franca Rame, is to be presented at 9 P.M. Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in the Frances Ann Cannon Workshop Theater of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. The title, ''All House, Bed and Church,'' refers to woman's traditional place in the house, in her husband's bed and in the church - a serious theme treated comically in four monologues.

title: Too Slippery to Characterize
description: TO give a logical description in general terms of the strategy of any opening without getting involved in rank contradiction is impossible because each comprises possibilities for diverse strategies.

title: After 12 Days, Righetti Reappears and Gets Save
description: In the days that passed between games in Chicago and New York - between his last failed pitching appearance and yesterday's shining success - Dave Righetti sat in the Yankee bullpen and wondered. There had been a string of lost chances, a succession of nights without work, and a tender left elbow that had left him unavailable for a time.

title: SPEEDY SOLUTIONS
description: The alarm blares at 6:30, and the morning hustle begins - the half-hour for exercise, the five-minute shower, the quick strokes of moisturizer, mascara and lipstick. Then, a bowl of cereal and a dash for the door.

title: Miss Shane Is Married To Joseph F. O'Dea Jr.
description: The marriage of Carol Ruth Shane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lawrence Shane of Swarthmore, Pa., to Joseph F. O'Dea Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Dea of Rydal, Pa., took place yesterday at the Swarthmore Presbyterian Church. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd and the Rev. David W. Givey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Health Agency Fills Watchdog Role
description: LEAD: WHEN a potential outbreak of shigellosis, a form of dysentery, was reported in New York last year, New Jersey epidemiologists became alarmed that it might hit the state during the camping season. By spring, just as camps were opening, one case was reported, at a camp in northern New Jersey.

title: THERE WAS NO 'INDIAN SIDE'
description: EMPIRE OF FORTUNE Crowns, Colonies, and Tribes in the Seven Years War in America. By Francis Jennings. Illustrated. 520 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: What's at Stake Is Control Over the Building Process
description: Beginning this afternoon, some 3,000 architects will descend on New York for the 120th annual convention of the American Institute of Architects. It is expected to be the largest gathering of the profession ever - not a bad way, perhaps, to make up for the fact that the association has not chosen to meet in New York since 1967, preferring instead to gather in such architecturally significant cities as San Antonio, Kansas City and San Diego. Although the official explanation for most of this 21-year absence from New York was that the association was awaiting the completion of I. M. Pei & Partners' Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, it is hard not to feel that there was an equal share of small-town hesitation about the big city.

title: IN THE NATION: Wilmington, Del.; An All-Suite Hotel to Meet Needs Of a Growing Bank Community
description: WORK is progressing here on the city's first major hotel construction in a decade, the Pickett Suite Hotel, a $28 million, 230-suite accommodation just three blocks from the reigning hostelry, the Hotel du Pont.

title: Headliners; Post-Retirement
description: It is no insult to Beverly Sills to say that her retirement from the stage a decade ago was one of the best things that ever happened to the New York City Opera. As general director of the company, Miss Sills proved to be as talented a fund-raiser as she was - and remains - a soprano. By all accounts, her fund-raising abilities were the main factor in the growth of the City Opera budget from $9 million in 1978 to a projected $26 million in the 1988-89 fiscal year. With the company now solidly in the black, Miss Sills announced last week that she would retire as general director Jan. 1 and step up to the post of president of the City Opera board. Miss Sills, whose 59th birthday is this month, said her immediate plans included a vacation with her husband, Peter B. Greenough, ''to see if he can remember what my first name is.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Music Copyists: Dwindling Breed, But a Hardy One
description: LEAD: Like many another craft, the ancient one of music copying is feeling the relentless pressure of electronics.

title:
GARDENING;
Hostas: Some Advice From the Experts
description: LEAD: LEARNING plant names is difficult for some of us, and it is made even more difficult by name changes carried out by systematists trying to make botanical names conform to the rules found in the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. Take the plantain lily, for example.

title: Designating Landmarks: Beware Hidden Agendas
description: THE city of White Plains is reportedly in the process of drafting historic landmark-preservation legislation, and I want to offer a few personal thoughts on the subject. The rush to place plaques in front of so-called historic sites in Westchester about a century ago left us with some rather strange heritage, including a number of markers to events that did not even occur here.

title: POSTING: Urban Food Court; 5-in-1 Downtown
description: In six months, the former American Bank Note building will be a ''department store restaurant.'' The five-story Corinithian-columned structure at Broad and Beaver Streets in lower Manhattan will be gutted to make way for four fast-food outlets on the ground floor and a full-service restaurant on the second and third floors. Seating for fast-food customers will be in the basement, with kitchens in the top two floors, said Murray Reise, who purchased the building with his brother, Irvin, for $3.5 million. With over 300 food outlets, the Reises are New York City's largest restaurateurs and pioneers of the urban food court. They operate franchises here for Pizza Hut, Roy Rogers and others.

title: From Simplicity to Complexity
description: IF something starts out simple, you can bet it will become complicated sooner or later. So it is with point-and-shoot cameras, which were originally designed to make 35-millimeter picture taking as simple as pointing and shooting.

title: Dating Services Surge in a Busy Age
description: DEBORAH and Leonard, Leigh and John and Sue and Mark met through dating services in Connecticut. Deborah and Leonard are to be married in June; Sue and Mark, in October, Leigh and John were wed a few years ago and now have a toddler.

title: PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
description: Dr. Bennett's comparison of ''the absolute amount of pleasure anyone can get from gulping a cup coffee . . with having an orgasm . . . '' brings to mind the celebrated anecdote about Lady Astor's temperance speech: ''I would rather commit adultery than drink a glass of beer.''

title: Joy and Fear at an Eighth-Grade Graduation
description: NEXT month, I will attend the eighth-grade graduation of my 265 sons and daughters. They will march ceremoniously before the crowd and receive diplomas.

title: James S. Mooney, 66, Ex-Police Inspector
description: James S. Mooney, a retired New York City Police Inspector, died after a heart attack Tuesday at North Shore Hospital on Long Island. He was 66 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Sergei Gorshkov Dies at 78; Admiral Built Soviet Navy
description: Adm. Sergei G. Gorshkov, who transformed the Soviet Union into a global sea power during 29 years as chief of the Soviet Navy, died on Friday in Moscow, the official Tass press agency said on Saturday. He was 78 years old.

title: The Cruel Face of Genius
