description: SELECTED LETTERS OF RICHARD WAGNER Edited and translated by Stewart Spencer and Barry Millington. 1,030 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $35.

title: POSTING: Brewster Project; A Mix for Growth
description: Realizing that suburbs do not grow by condominiums alone, Mark Grebler, along with David Camhi and Alvin Lefkowitz, has begun construction of a 30,000-square-foot, retail-and-office building near Brewster, N.Y. The southeastern Putnam County village (pop. 1,650 in 1980) is part of the Town of Southeast (pop. 14,000). The quiet area has become popular with residential developers recently, and a 170-unit condominium colony is nearing completion across Route 6 from Mr. Grebler's commercial project.

title: Review/Opera; 'Giulietta e Romeo,' a Riccardo Zandonai Rarity
description: It was Riccardo Zandonai's bad luck to have been a successor in an age that preferred revolutionaries. The publisher of his operas, Ricordi, proudly announced him as Puccini's heir,and so perhaps he was. In a long life that ended in 1949, Zandonai took Puccini-esque declamatory style and prettied it up considerably, but never discarded its character. The least ''offensive'' parts of 20th-century music were incorporated into his operas - Strauss's orchestration, for example, and Debussy's whole-tone language. A more striking departure from Puccini's inspired directness was the use of orchestra that in Zandonai's operas competed strongly with the stage for dramatic importance.

title: INSIDE
description: Top Soviet Admiral Dies

title: Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel Tube Is Closed After Truck Mishap
description: The westbound tube of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel was closed for more than six hours yesterday after a dump truck ripped down about 200 feet of ceiling tiles, the authorities said.

title: The Magic of Attaining Art Collector Status
description: Life in an ''art store'' - not always prominent in the news - has received some notoriety [ Opinion Page, April 24, ''Art or Not? Anyway, Now It's Mine'' ] . Letter writers to the Arts and Leisure section were 3 to 1 in favor of the recent Department of Consumer Affairs ruling requiring posting of prices in art galleries. In the Long Island Weekly section, art Collector (uppercase) Reynold S. Welch wrote of the uncertainties of his new status.

title: Tuned In
description: To the Editor:

title: Hidden Issue Dates Challenge Hobbyists
description: THIS is a test.

title: THE NATION: Pro & Con - Extending Welfare's Reach; Should Government Aid the Two-Parent Family, Too?
description: THE overhaul of the nation's welfare policy that is working its way through Congress reflects agreement on the part of both parties that work is the solution to dependency, and training and job placement are the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle. But as always, efforts to define how and how far the Government should help the poor arouse fierce debate. Indeed, a dispute over only one of the proposal's many provisions is deep-seated enough to have intensified the threat of a Presidential veto.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE RISE OF AMERICAN AIR POWER: The Creation of Armageddon. By Michael S. Sherry. (Yale University, $29.95.) It is a sobering idea Michael S. Sherry pursues in this book, which won the 1988 Bancroft Prize in American history. In the 1920's and 30's it was assumed that the prospect of bombing cities was so horrifying it might make war obsolete. When World War II began, bombers were first sold to the public and Congress as precision weapons against military targets, but in the popular imagination they soon became dark angels of vengeance, and the few voices that raised moral objections to bombing noncombatants were muffled. Mr. Sherry, a Northwestern University historian, is hardly a graceful writer (and his publisher has left many typographical and grammatical errors in his text), but his book demands to be read. Most of the material comes from published sources, but here it is focused on moral questions, making history uncomfortably personal. As the bomber force grew, targets had to be found, and they were - cities, even though the strategic value of destroying them was not examined. Even a few generals objected, but civilian leaders overruled them. Technological fanaticism seized the nation and a vast cadre of civilian experts grew up around the Air Force, advising, evaluating and making weapons for the bombers - the napalm that fried the population of Tokyo and then the atomic bomb. The actors in this tragedy soared from triumph to triumph, and to Hiroshima. The tragedy continues - the final catastrophe, or resolution, is to come - and now we are the actors.

title: Celebrating a Century of Offering Refuge
description: WEN Mary Fisher first proposed the idea to the fashionable ladies gathered at Mrs. Vincenzo Botta's weekly reception in New York City one day in 1888, one guest was appalled. ''A home for old authors and artists?'' she exclaimed. ''My! What a company of cranks! What will you do with them?''

title: WIRED FOR STRESS
description: LAST OCT. 19, A DAY THAT ONLY A stress researcher could savor, a 48-year-old stockbroker named Gianni Fidanza happened to be wearing a little metal box on his waist when he went to his Park Avenue office. It was wired to a cuff on his arm that measured his blood pressure and pulse every 15 minutes. The device came from the cardiovascular center at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where scientists, led by cardiologist Thomas G. Pickering, are using this new technology to record stress directly in the workplace. Black Monday gave them a wonderfully tidy result: the Dow Jones industrial average correlated inversely with Fidanza's blood pressure and pulse.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: IT'S OPEN SEASON ON GAME OFFICIALS;
UMPIRES DESERVE OUR RESPECT
description: LEAD: A child of the Great Depression, I never booed an umpire. Surely, this was not for any want of fiery enthusiasm. That I had aplenty. Perhaps it was because we respected institutions more in those days than is the case today. I doubt that our commonwealth is better off for the change. That respect may be why

title: N.F.L. Officials Are Exemplary
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Home, a Stop on a Collegian's Itinerary
description: ONE Thursday I answered the phone and was greeted with, ''Mom, there's no school tomorrow and I thought I'd come home for the weekend. I really want to see you guys.''

title: NONFICTION
description: THE IMPERFECT ART: Reflections on Jazz and Modern Culture. By Ted Gioia. (Oxford University, $16.95.) This is an unusual jazz book for two reasons: it deals with the music not just on its own terms but in a broader cultural and esthetic context, and it was written by a musician. Ted Gioia, a young pianist who teaches jazz history and performance at Stanford University, has chosen a formidable theme for his first book: ''how peculiar jazz is in comparison with other arts'' and what makes it that way. He works some dazzling, quirky variations on this theme in seven essays, some previously published, the titles of which (''Jazz and the Primitivist Myth,'' ''What Has Jazz to Do With Aesthetics?'') indicate both the scope of his vision and the self-importance that occasionally trip him up. Much of what Mr. Gioia has to say is thoughtful and thought-provoking, but a number of his observations are debatable at best. For example, his claim that ''jazz has evolved away from the firm ground of composed music towards the terra incognita of complete improvisation,'' while it may have been true 10 or 15 years ago, ignores the increased emphasis on composition that has characterized much of the jazz created over the past decade. What is most unusual about ''The Imperfect Art'' is the apparent inner conflict it reflects: while the musician in Mr. Gioia obviously loves jazz for its spontaneity and directness, the esthetician in him seems uncomfortable with its intensity, its ''inherent tendency towards excess'' and its capacity to bore listeners - the latter being, he suggests in one perceptive essay, a dirty little secret most critics would rather not discuss.

title: Sarina R. di Bonaventura Married to Philip S. Birsh
description: Sarina Rosaria di Bonaventura and Philip Steven Birsh were married yesterday in a private civil ceremony at the Greentree estate in Manhasset, L.I., the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. John Hay Whitney.

title: McEnroe Shows Signs of Control
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IT'S not the most wonderful feeling in the world, but it's pretty great. It happens after a morning, afternoon or complete day of what is loosely called free time, or even after several hours stolen at the end of a workday. You've finally done a lot of things that you've been meaning to do for months and put off for various reasons or that you knew you'd hate to do and therefore didn't. Now they're done, and you feel, if not euphoric, at least virtuous.

title:
ART;
Dutch Masters' Work Shows People at Work
description: LEAD: DUTCH artists of the 17th century emphasized realism, expanded subject matter, delighted in everyday detail and were masters of both light and texture.

title: Out of the Memory Hole
description: There's stunning news from Moscow: George Orwell's ''1984'' is to be published soon in the Soviet Union. Excerpts already have appeared in a Moscow magazine, Literaturnaya Gazeta, prefaced with an acknowledgment that Stalin's despotism helped inspire the 1949 novel. That Winston Smith; the Ministry of Truth; Newspeak; Big Brother; and the memory hole, where wrongthink documents were vaporized, are to make a licit appearance on Soviet bookshelves is the best evidence yet that a fresh wind is blowing in the East.

title: J. S. Swensen, Banker, Weds Cynthia Sharrah
description: The marriage of Cynthia Kay Sharrah, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marion L. Sharrah of Naples, Fla., to J. Scott Swensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Swensen of Denver, took place yesterday at the United Methodist Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. James Jay Benson performed the ceremony.

title: It's a Bad Time To Cut Consumption
description: ''LET'S cut consumption'' has taken on the sound of an idea whose time has come although its practicality has yet to be examined. This catch phrase has jelled into the consensus for remedial action to fix all that's gone wrong with the economy. Prof. Paul Kennedy, in his New York Times response to complaints that his best-selling book, ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' expressed a passivity toward America's decline, replied that we could always cut consumption.

title: Few Clues Left in Wake Of Pair's Disappearance
description: A secret marriage, an abandoned car that was out of gas, a telephone that rings but no one speaks when an anquished mother answers: these may be clues, but so far they have led nowhere in the disappearance of two college students.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss. Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling. We hired a painter who scraped and sanded, then painted with an oil paint, but now the walls and ceiling are flaking again. Can you help me solve this problem?

title: Jun Makihara, an Investment Banker, And Mimi Oka Plan to Marry on July 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Takashi Oka of Tokyo and Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter Megumi Oka to Jun Makihara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Minoru Makihara of Tokyo and New York. A July 9 wedding is planned.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: DOOM FOR DISCOUNTERS?;
The Court Is Winking at 'Price Fixing'
description: LEAD: PRICE competition is the basis of the American retail economy and a first principle of the antitrust laws. Yet the Supreme Court's recent decision in Business Electronics Corp. v. Sharp Electronics Corp. threatens to erode that competitive system by weakening protection for price cutting and discounters.

title: IS AMERICA IN DECLINE?
description: If the argument for the decline of the United States were based only on historical analogy and recent economic and political facts, then Senator Bill Bradley's response that ''decline'' is ''needlessly provocative'' would have considerable force (''Taking Stock: Is America in Decline?'' by Peter Schmeisser, April 17). But there is a factor, briefly mentioned in the article, that strongly supports the argument for decline. This is the state of education in America.

title: Splashy Settings
description: ENTERTAINING BY THE POOL OR on the patio no longer means plain paper plates and boring plastic cups. The newest stars on the outdoor entertainment circuit are vibrantly colored, innovatively textured and often sturdy enough to be used over and over again.

title: Dizzy Dames on a New Whirl
description: There's a brief scene in ''Sticky Fingers'' in which a woman is tinkering with a shelf on a window ledge that already holds a row of flowerpots. She's the kind of woman who giggles and shrieks and chatters too much while this job is being done. When it's finished, she steps back to admire her handiwork and, of course, the expected thing happens. She's been incompetent, and the flowerpots go splat.

title: Croquet, A Parade And Food: A Fair Day
description: The Ninth Avenue Festival is the time when a New Yorker's fancy turns to strolling up and down the street, eating messy food from a flimsy plate.

title: Review/Film; A New 'Friday the 13th'
description: The ''Friday the 13th'' series may have started as a slasher film and become a teen-age cult favorite, but somehow it has turned into a long-running serial about an odd but familiar neighborhood. Like the evil twin of Lake Wobegon, Crystal Lake is the little town that time forgot, where all the men are dead, all the women are dead and all the teen-agers are above ground - but not for long. Guest corpses come and go, but the malcontented star remains the same -Jason, the mass murderer in the hockey mask. This crazy kid tends to get chained at the bottom of the lake a lot, but he always surfaces in the summer to kill young lovers in the woods.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Change Their Tactics but Not Their Goals
description: A vegetable garden is tucked into the yard of nearly every home in this Palestinian village, watered by perforated black rubber tubing. Rabbits and chickens are fattening in handmade cages as a defense against expected hard times to come.

title: Lackawaxen's Favorite Sons
description: IN Lackawaxen, Pa., an unprepossessing little town on the banks of the Upper Delaware River, stand monuments to two very different kinds of genius. Downstream from the pebbly point where the Lackawaxen River tumbles through a murmuring riffle and is lost into the broad Delaware, there looms a bridge of obvious antiquity and anomalous design, its three midstream stone piers draped with a graceful sweep of cables and spanned by wood framing for high side walls.

title: Next Week; Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Fresh Glimpses Of Prokofiev's 'Romeo' Ballet
description: ''To each his own. To one it is given to sing of the love of Romeo and Juliet, to another to depict the frenzied screeches and comical capers of monkeys.'' Such is the ironic indictment of Prokofiev by V. Kolomyitsev in 1916, quoted by David Gutman in notes to the CD reissue of the Lorin Maazel recording of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' We, of course, wiser by hindsight, now treasure the exquisite evening-length ballet the composer wrote two decades later on that very theme, an astonishingly vivid score of almost symphonic concentration, coherence and cogency.

title: Three More Suspects Are Held in Payroll Robbery
description: Heavily armed teams of law-enforcement officers arrested two suspects in New Jersey late Friday and early yesterday in the robbery of a payroll service in lower Manhattan Friday morning. Another suspect surrendered last night in New Jersey.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: East Providence, R.I.;
Oil Tanks Yield To Residences
description: LEAD: A BOSTON developer has begun site preparation for a $150 million community he plans on a 41-acre shoreline site along the Providence River that was once dominated by oil storage tanks.

title: Review/Rock; Happy Political Reggae
description: Three songs into her first set at S.O.B's on Wednesday, Sister Carol, dressed in a silver dress and dark glasses, pointed to various audience members and sang ''This song's for you.'' She meant it: the Jamaican singer, who made her first impression in America by singing a reggae version of ''Wild Style'' in the movie ''Something Wild,'' is nothing if not a giving performer.

title: Laborers Learn the Hazards of Asbestos
description: MIKE DILLON remembers the last time he handled asbestos.

title: Capt. Williamson Planning to Wed a Fellow Officer
description: The engagement of Capt. Annesley Jeanne Williamson and Maj. Jonathan Hunter Jaffin, both of the Army Medical Corps, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Wilmajeanne B. Williamson of Stamford, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: U.S. Opens a New Center for Homeless Veterans
description: The Veterans Administration formally opened in Brooklyn the city's first Federally financed drop-in center for homeless veterans, stepping up its commitment to the former servicemen.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: The Champion Club  Americans get finanicial help from a compnay based in South Korea; Foreign Aid for Americans
description: Almost all Olympic hopefuls have the same opinion about sponsors: It's better to have one than not have one. Take it from Mike McCarthy, a member of the United States national cycling team.

title:
DINING OUT;
Deceptive Appearance in Wharton
description: LEAD: GOOD FOOD can be found sometimes in the most unexpected places. Take, for example, Heslin House in the Morris County community of Wharton. Although the exterior of the building is attractive, the simply decorated, pub-like interior might lead one to expect food typical of that found in most such places.

title: A City Clambake
description: THE TRADITIONAL NEW ENGLAND-style clambake is a labor-intensive but rewarding ritual that I usually perform once a year on the beach at my home on eastern Long Island. City dwellers, of course, do not have the opportunity to stage this oceanside event. But there is no reason why the essence of a clambake cannot be simulated by assembling the ingredients in a deep pot or steamer and cooking them on a stove top. Served with a creamy mussel soup and a refreshing grapefruit and cassis sherbet, a clambake makes a wonderful meal for a summer party.

title: Glimpses of Grandfather: Scars and Strength of the Heart
description: I AM walking down a blue tiled corridor. Room 205, 206, 207.

title: New World's New Order
description: LIKE their competitors throughout Hollywood, the top executives of New World Entertainment Ltd. will be sitting fretfully by the phone this week and next, awaiting word from the television networks on which of their current shows and pilots will be picked up for the coming season.

title: Golden Slippers
description: THE RED SHOES Starring Moira Shearer, Anton Walbrook, Marius Goring, Leonide Massine, Robert Helpmann and Ludmilla Tcherina. Written, directed and produced by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger. Paramount Home Video. 136 minutes. $19.95.

title: B. R. Williamson Jr. Weds Caroline Crook
description: Caroline Costner Crook, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cletus Beatrix Crook Jr. of Albemarle, N.C., was married there last evening to Benjamin Robert Williamson Jr., a son of Mr. Williamson and Mrs. Zack Hampton Bacon Jr., both of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Harold McDonald peformed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church.

title: Extra Burden On Hockey Officials
description: Hockey is the most exciting game in the world but at the same time it is one of the most potentially violent. This is particularly so given the speed at which it's played, the equipment used and the degree of physical contact. More importantly, hockey, unlike other contact sports such as football and basketball, regulates, instead of prohibits, fighting. In this regard, hockey is unique. This uniqueness places a heavy burden on game officials by requiring of them a very special ability to control the game.

title: 'Voice of the Prairie' At Becton in Teaneck
description: REMEMBER radio? Sitting around the console was a time of listening, of paying sustained attention.

title: Psychiatrist and Patient: How Close?
description: For Betty Sprague, falling in love with her psychiatrist, with what she believes was his encouragement, was no cure for her depression and emotional distress.

title: Jessica Spohn Engaged To Clifford S. Kayhart
description: The engagement of Jessica Anne Spohn to Clifford Scott Kayhart has been announced by the future bride's parents, Roberta Spohn of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., and Dr. Herbert E. Spohn of Topeka, Kan. A July wedding is planned.

title: Tainted Water Supply: A Way Out
description: I HAD gone to Sanibel Island, on the Gulf Coast of Florida, to look at its potable-water processing plant. Sanibel and adjacent Captiva share a narrow strip of land divided into two islands by a small river. Together, they are shaped like Long Island and are, in many ways, a microcosm of it.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A KISS OF FIRE. By Masako Togawa. Translated by Simon Grove. (Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) From its very beginning, ''A Kiss of Fire'' is an infuriating maze, as Masako Togawa deliberately leads the reader down one blind alley after another. The words ''coincidence'' and ''fate'' occur on page after page, apparently to justify a flimsy plot that links three main characters who, at age 5, were accused of setting a fire that killed the father of one of them.

title: City Plan to Sell TriBeCa Tract Protested
description: NEGOTIATIONS to sell a tract of municipal land in lower Manhattan to Drexel Burnham Lambert have triggered a fresh round of complaints about the New York City policy that encourages large scale real estate development in the TriBeCa area.

title: In Russia, Some Ideas Are Still More Equal Than Others
description: THEY are leftists and libertarians, democrats and anarchists, believers in God or the avant-garde, in Hare Krishna or simply in human rights. They are divided by generational gaps and personal rivalries, tactical disputes and political inspirations, not to mention a vast geography and unreliable telephone service. They are not a community but a cacophony. And yet the political polymorph known in the West as the dissident movement has one common bond - official hostility, which, under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has waxed and waned but not disappeared.

title: Mamet's Hollywood Is a School for Scoundrels
description: In an essay entitled, ''A Playwright in Hollywood,'' David Mamet said that he was not asking for altruism on the part of movie producers, ''just a little creative venality.'' His uproarious new play, ''Speed-the-Plow,'' makes it clear that hypocrisy and greed are no assurance of profit and that art is less than a by-product in Hollywood. Even as he himself has mastered the medium (as the screenwriter of ''The Untouchables'' and as the auteur of ''The House of Games''), he has never forgotten that the people in the movies are ''interested solely in making a buck on the buck they put out.'' Assailing Hollywood, Mr. Mamet speaks with authority, and in ''Speed-the-Plow'' he spites the hand that needs him. Hollywood can and will take it. He is too valuable to ignore.

title: Political Marketing; Quest for Ideal Campaign: No Tears , No Domestic Spats, No Candidate
description: For many political consultants in the age of electronic politics and constant questions about the character of candidates, the perfect campaign is one with a fat budget, a compelling message and no candidate.

title: John Ahrens Wed To Robin I. Riley
description: Robin Isabel Riley, a daughter of Isabel Cooper Riley of Manhasset, L.I., and the late John Bennet Riley, was married yesterday to John Christopher Ahrens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Charles Ahrens of Toledo, Ohio. The Rev. Thomas Lamont performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Manhasset.

title: Dr. Ilona E. Karka Wed at Columbia
description: At St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University yesterday Dr. Ilona E. Karka and Dr. Louis Guy Cornacchia 3d, who both received medical degrees last year from New York University, were married by the Rev. Philip Fabiano, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Lisa Bankoff Marries
description: Lisa Rachelle Bankoff, a literary agent with International Creative Management, a talent agency in New York, and Richard D. Simms, the director of motion-picture development for Goat Cay Productions in New York, were married last evening by Rabbi David Posner at Temple Emanu-El in New York. The bride is a daughter of Bella G. Bankoff of New York and the late William M. Bankoff. The bridegroom is a son of Martha A. Simms of Lexington, Ky., and the late Bernard G. Simms.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Hotels Help Revive Harbor
description: LEAD: A 622-ROOM hotel opened here last month, further strengthening this city's revived Inner Harbor.

title: Congress Plans Sanctions to Force Change in Haiti
description: Six months after a massacre halted presidential elections in Haiti, United States officials and lawmakers say that there has been no progress toward democracy in the impoverished Caribbean country and that Congress will take new steps to force change.

title: A Beach to Revere
description: TODAY my idea of a sophisticated beach is an intimate little stretch of sand or shingle tucked into a cove beneath Mediterranean mountains, but when I was a kid I had different ideas. In those days Revere Beach, just north of Boston, a New England counterpart of Coney Island, was the height of sophistication for me. The place was filled with people I envied: sailors strolling along with their arms around disreputable looking girls, sports who didn't seem to care how many dimes they gambled away on Pokerino, liberated kids who had a lot more cash - and leeway - than I ever did to patronize the amusements and the refreshment stands.

title: Ms. Vizcarrondo Weds T. J. Burke
description: At Santa Teresita Roman Catholic Church in Santurce, P.R., Nellie Marie Vizcarrondo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julio E. Vizcarrondo Jr. of Guaynabo, P.R., was married yesterday to Thomas James Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Burke of Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. Robert Pelton performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FESTIVE SUNDAY From Freeport to Yaphank with a stopover in Huntington, today's the day for Long Island festivals. In Freeport, to celebrate the opening of its new preserve, complete with bird-watching tower and marked trails through the marshland, Cow Meadow Park has a Family Nature Festival on tap. From 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. there'll be demonstrations, guided walks, kite flying, poetry readings, music and an exhibit of nature photos, ''A Celebration of the Coastline.'' Everything is free at the Nassau County park, at the foot of South Main Street. In keeping with the theme, visitors are asked to come dressed in costumes depicting their favorite marine plant or animal. Seaweed, anyone? In Huntington, it's Sheep-to-Shawl Festival time, courtesy of the Huntington Historical Society, which, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., turns its Kissam House and Barn at 434 Park Avenue into a haven for yesterdays. There'll be wool shearing and spinning demonstrations, crafts exhibits, early American music, such old-time games for children as washday races, and tours of the 1795 Federal mansion. Admission is $2; 75 cents for children.

title: Upholding Haute Italian Standards
description: JERICHO'S Capriccio Restaurant shattered stereotypes 18 years ago when it burst upon the Long Island dining scene. It became the rage, receiving rave reviews and introducing a type of Italian cooking unknown to many. This was no homey Italian family restaurant awash in red sauce. Rather, it was haute Italian: light, elegant, imaginative.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Welter of Weeklies ''IT'S the talk of the industry,'' said a former editor of a Long Island weekly newspaper.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Cos Cob, Conn. $295,000 11 Grove Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; new kitchen, oversized living room with fireplace; taxes $1,797. Darien, Conn. $385,000 57 Echo Drive North 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, updated kitchen, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,937. Stamford, Conn. $420,000 69 Winding Brook Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; large kitchen with fireplace, pond setting, 1 acre, taxes $3,674. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $260,000 12 Ash Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year old town house; patio, brook, 1-car garage, walk to schools and shopping; taxes, 5,156. Hawthorne, N.Y. $280,000 424 Pythian Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,670. Purdy's Station, N.Y. $356,250 Route 116 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; hardwood floors, 3 decks, patio, walk to station, 2-car garage, 2.37 acres; taxes $5,459. OTHER AREAS Ronkonkoma, L.I. $85,000 99 Pleasure Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old cottage; eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $650. Plainfield, N.J. $399,000 966 Mayfair Way 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $4,872. Short Hills, N.J. $416,000 54 Cambridge Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2 half-bath, 42-year-old colonial; den, c/a, 2-car garage, porch; taxes $5,935.

title: Review/Dance; Film Clips to Celebrate Irving Berlin's Birthday
description: Continuing its American Music Festival at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet celebrated Irving Berlin's 100th birthday Tuesday night with a cinematic tribute to this great songwriter. It was a day for celebrations, for Tuesday also happened to be Martha Graham's 94th birthday.

title: Craig Claiborne's Fail-Safe Beginner's Menu
description: FOR SOME PEOPLE, ESPECIALLY THE young, the inexperienced and the super-busy, nothing provokes more anxiety than the thought of giving a dinner party. They become exhausted merely contemplating all the chores they would have to do: shopping for decent place mats, removing the books from the living room floor, fixing the broken chair.

title: COLUMBIA RECOVERED
description: IN MANY WAYS IT LOOKED LIKE A TYPICAL college reunion. People who hadn't seen each other in 20 years were embracing, trading stories of their lives, peering at snapshots of their children - or at the children themselves, for there were lots of kids along: this was a generation that had its children late. Their parents were not only casually dressed, in good 60's fashion, but wore red armbands and flaming red name tags that identified them with buildings on the Columbia University campus - Hamilton, Low, Fayerweather, Math.

title: Miss Vincent to Wed William F. Gerry
description: Gay Caroline Vincent and William Farrish Gerry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Gerry of Mill Neck, L.I., plan to marry in September, the future bride's parents, Elizabeth von Furstenberg Reynolds of New York and Guy A. Vincent of Sherman Oaks, Calif., have announced.

title: More Monkey Business
description: The yacht Monkey Business, which ferried Gary Hart to the Bahamas with Donna Rice, was seized today when Coast Guard officers found a gram of marijuana on it, officials said. The 82-foot yacht was boarded in a routine search about 22 miles northwest of the Bahamian island of Bimini, said Petty Officer Dan Vogeley. The four people on board, whose names were not released, have not been arrested, he said.

title: THE REGION: City and State Plans; For Lack of Options, New York Gets Serious About Recycling
description: THERE are only three things to do with trash: Dump it, burn it or find a new use for it. For years, New York State and New York City have relied on the first two options, paying little more than lip service to the third. But with landfills rapidly filling up, and pollution experts finding disturbing problems with incineration, officials are looking again at recycling.

title: TALKING: Refinancing; Bigger Is Better For Co-ops
description: THE refinancing of a co-op building's mortgage poses some tricky issues for its board - when to do it, how to find a good lender, how much to borrow and for how long.

title: U.S. Neglecting Economies Of Latin Nations, Study Says
description: A University of Miami study has asserted that the Reagan Administration, Congress and the two political parties have neglected Latin America's growing economic difficulties ''to the detriment of our national objectives and well-being.''

title: Michelle Berman, A Writer, Marries
description: Michelle Berman, the daughter of Dr. Lewis H. Berman of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Prof. Deborah Weissman-Berman of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Dennis Love, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Love of Anniston, Ala. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of the bride's father and her stepmother, Amanda Berman.

title: '95 Percent of the Victims Are Women'
description: ANNE MENARD is executive director of the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence, which was formed in 1976. The coalition represents 18 programs across the state that provide services to women, who are the primary victims of domestic violence.

title: Mary Ballard Adler Marries
description: Mary Ballard Adler, a daughter of Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York, was married yesterday at the Metropolitan Club in New York to Vikram Malhotra, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jagdish C. Malhotra of New York and Bombay, India. A Hindu ceremony performed by Pandit Hemanand Trivedi was followed by an Episcopal ceremony performed by the Rev. Thomas H. Bowers, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: Hynes Seen As Candidate, But for What?
description: Charles J. Hynes, the state's special prosecutor who handled the Howard Beach case, is increasingly being mentioned as a potential challenger to Mayor Koch, but some politicians believe he would prefer to be the district attorney in Queens or Brooklyn.

title: Surf's Up!
description: LEGENDS OF MALIBU Music by The Beach Boys, Surf Raiders, Surfaris Frontline Video. 45 minutes. 1987. $24.95.

title: Pamela Fried Is Wed At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I.
description: Pamela Gail Fried, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart J. Fried of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to David Alan Picon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Picon of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal officiated. The bride, a sales manager at Dynamic Designs, a clothing manufacturer in New York, graduated from Emory University. Mr. Picon, an associate in the New York law firm of Shea & Gould, graduated from Emory and cum laude from the Georgetown University Law Center.

title: Girl and Kite: Spirits Soar as Feet Stay Put
description: A 70-pound girl whose kite took her on an unscheduled flight in March returned today to her liftoff site. This time, she managed to stay on the ground as she flew the first kite under a new set of safety rules.

title: Balk Record Is Broken
description: Baseball's record for most balks in a season was broken tonight when Rick Mahler of the Atlanta Braves committed the 357th balk of 1988.

title: Afghan Vacuum: The U.S. Is Wary of Rushing In
description: With Soviet troops poised to begin their withdrawal Sunday, Afghanistan faces a period of turmoil in which the United States is preparing to play an ambiguous military and political role.

title:
Long Island Interview: Donald M. Blinken;
SUNY Chairman: Pursuing Excellence on a Budget
description: LEAD: DONALD M. BLINKEN, the chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York, likens public higher education on Long Island to a miniaturized version of the 64-campus State University system, the nation's largest.

title: Amy Beth Marion to Wed D. J. Bobley in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Marion of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Marion, to Douglas J. Bobley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Bobley of Old Brookville, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Transporting Hazardous Material
description: BEHIND today's headlines, the difference between a 10-line story about a tie-up on the turnpike and front-page coverage of a major disaster often is determined by the ability of local emergency service personnel to respond quickly.

title:
IN THE NATION: Battle Creek, Mich.;
Kellogg Foundation Comes Back to Town After Two Decades in a Suburban Campus
description: LEAD: THE W. K. Kellogg Foundation, one of the nation's largest philanthropic organizations, is about to give the breakfast-food capital of the world substantial nourishment. It is moving its headquarters back into the heart of this city of 56,000 residents from the Kellogg Community College campus on the outskirts of town, its home for more than two decades.

title: Little Engine
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA UPDATE: May 15, 1988
WHEN GOD INTERRUPTS THE BARBECUE
description: REVELATION By Peggy Payne. 314 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Tuition Rise Asked at Massachusetts Schools
description: The Massachusetts Board of Regents of Higher Education has voted to raise tuition 8.5 percent this fall for the 180,000 students at the state's 29 public colleges and universities.

title: Barbara McClenahan Weds Evan Sheppard
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Barbara Leith McClenahan, the daughter of Marilyn Van Syckel McClenahan of New York and the late Richard L. McClenahan Jr., was married yesterday to Evan Hays Sheppard, the son of Sarah Frances Hays of Madison, Va., and Michael Bazel Sheppard of Washington. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: O'KEEFFE PORTRAYED Eileen Heckart portrays one of America's most celebrated artists in ''A Conversation With Georgia O'Keeffe'' on Friday in Westport.

title: Frank Hixon Jr. Marries Ms. Lee
description: Marguerite Lammot Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis V. Lee of Charlestown, R.I., and Frank Perkins Hixon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hixon of Franklin, Tenn., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. V. Alastair Votaw.

title: IS AMERICA IN DECLINE?
description: Paul Kennedy expounded the same thesis he pushes in ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' in a conversation on my patio in West Berlin in the summer of 1984. His book ignores or misrepresents the most basic facts. Our defense budget today is 7 percent of the gross national product. In 1961, it was 9 percent. Far from being ''bloated,'' it has shrunk, while the Soviet Union's consumes 15 to 25 percent.

title: 6 Flee Besieged Sikh Temple and 3 Are Killed
description: Six men, most of them old and shaken, fled through militant gunfire at the Golden Temple today during a half-hour cease-fire by Government security forces.

title: POSTING: Visiting the Past; Williamsburg Tour
description: The people of Williamsburg never did want that bridge. The operator of the ferry between Manhattan and Brooklyn said it would kill his business, and genteel residents on the Brooklyn side said they would be overrun by immigrants from the Lower East Side. For a time, it seemed they were right, but now the ferry is running again, the neighborhood is rebounding and it is the bridge that is ailing.

title: Low Salinity Devastates Mecox Oysters
description: LEAD: FIRST it was striped bass. Then clams and scallops. Now it is oysters.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday about Abdi Bile, the Somalian runner, gave an incorrect world record for the 400 meters. The record, set by Harry Reynolds of Ohio State, is 44.10 seconds.

title: Hispanic-Americans Are Part of Society Too
description: With reference to the April 10 Opinion Page article ''A Divided Society Is an Unjust Society,'' I was keenly disappointed that Stan Lipton referred only very peripherally to our large and growing population of Hispanic-American ancestry. We may talk with a bit of an accent, but I would reassure your readers that we are also part of God's human family, and wish to live in peace and brotherhood with all other Americans. Thank you for learning to treat us as equals in your eyes. MARGARITA GRASING Executive Director Hispanic Brotherhood of Rockville Centre

title: A New Look At Taking A New Look
description: Musical tastes ebb and flow, though not nearly so predictably as the tides. There is no telling just when it will again be seriously argued, for instance, that the blander music of Telemann is as relevant to our times as that of the great artificer Bach. The last serious Telemann revival that I recall came in the 1950's, when the arrival of the long-playing record permitted us to hear a representative selection of his immense but on the whole mediocre oeuvre.

title: THE REGION: In the Village; Learning How to Take Out the Trash
description: APARTMENT dwellers are notoriously short of space, but the city is trying to persuade the tenants of four Greenwich Village buildings to use some of it to store bottles and cans, as well as newspapers, for recycling.

title: Judith Landzberg, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Judith E. Landzberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Landzberg of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and Laurence Matthew Friedman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Friedman of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and St. Croix, V.I., were married yesterday. Judge Kenneth H. Lange of Westchester County Court performed the ceremony at the Estherwood estate in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: 25% OF RUSSIANS IN AFGHAN FORCE WILL LEAVE IN MAY
description: The commander of Soviet military forces in Afghanistan said today that a quarter of Soviet troops would be pulled out of the country by the end of this month, and he vowed that their withdrawal would not be greatly impeded by attacks from insurgents.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: The fans that night in Cincinnati made a messy problem impossible. Pete Rose is paying for their sins as well as his.

title: Accord Viewed as Near on Medicare Bill
description: House and Senate conferees have reported significant progress on a bill to protect 32 million Medicare beneficiaries from exposure to financial catastrophe because of illness. They say they hope to complete their work in the next two weeks.

title: Bet Twice Scrambles to Capture Pimlico Special
description: Bet Twice, the forgotten horse of the racing world, boldly reclaimed his stature by outfinishing Lost Code, Cryptoclearance and Alysheba to win the $600,000 Pimlico Special today at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Program Trading
description: To the Editor:

title: A Farewell to Toyland
description: I REMEMBER VIVIDLY the last time I played with my toy soldiers. It was a wet summer afternoon a week or two before the start of eighth grade, and I was 12 years old. Most of that summer had been spent playing baseball, exploring Philadelphia's vast Pennypack Park and pedaling my bicycle wildly through the neighborhood streets playing ''ball tag on bikes.''

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE SALVATION ARMY ADULT REHABILITATION CENTER;
Men's Shelter Packages Old Clothes and Renewed Dreams
description: LEAD: SUNLIGHT floods the warehouse of the Salvation Army Adult Rehabilitation Center as it might a cathedral, with great beams pouring down from high windows. Trucks back in through its doors and disgorge their contents -clothes and furniture no longer useful in other homes - and men set to work hoisting and sorting them.

title: Writing Program 'Publishes' Works
description: LEAD: LIKE many authors, Kristina Peterson says the best thing about writing a book is ''looking back when it's all over and seeing what I've done.'' Kristina is only 11 years old. The books she publishes have cardboard jackets covered in wallpaper; their bindings are sewn by her mother and the mothers of her schoolmates.

title: Russians Uncertain
description: For two star hockey forwards who have spent their careers as low-paid members of the Soviet Army, Vladimir Krutov and Igor Larionov should presumably be eager for the chance to make $1 million playing in the National Hockey League.

title: F.B.I. Spy Program Bothers Librarians
description: LEAD: LIBRARIANS across Long Island are expressing concern over the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Library Awareness Program, in which F.B.I. officials have approached library personnel and asked them to be on the lookout for spies from the Soviet Union who might be seeking to recruit intelligence agents.

title: Dirty Laundry Takes to Road
description: TOURISTS visiting Cape Cod this summer may wonder: who are those angry-looking motorists whizzing down Route 6 with piles of dirty socks in their back seats?

title: Morisot, a Neglected Impressionist
description: Why don't we know Berthe Morisot better? That question is raised by a show drawing record crowds to the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum here. Titled ''Berthe Morisot - Impressionist,'' it is a rare major retrospective of the work of the vanguard French painter, relatively neglected by scholars and collectors and even scanted in comparison with that of the American expatriate Mary Cassatt, Morisot's contemporary and only woman colleague in the Impressionist movement.

title: Jai Alai Players to Vote on Joining a Union
description: The National Labor Relations Board has granted striking jai alai players in Hartford and Newport, R.I., the right to conduct union representation elections.

title:
MUSIC;
Spoleto Festival Takes Up The Case for 'Rusalka'
description: LEAD: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. has never really gone for the tried and true. One of last season's main attractions, for example, was an 18th-century Rameau opera-ballet, ''Platee,'' which turned out to be a box-office hit. But the 12th Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., which begins on Friday, is even more out on a limb than usual.

title: Sounds of Youth, Salutes to the Old
description: ''YOUTH is full of pleasance, age is full of care,'' Shakespeare said. Westchester audiences will find several engaging young people's events this week, along with two thoughtful salutes to musicians in ''the golden years.''

title: Giants Are Having Trouble Backing Up Craig's Prediction
description: As difficult as repeating has become, Roger Craig might have made the task of the San Francisco Giants even harder. In so doing, he created comparisons of his team with the 1986-87 Mets.

title: Yugoslavia's Leader Rejects Call to Resign Over Economy
description: Prime Minister Branko Mikulic today defied calls for his resignation made by Yugoslavia's two most Westernized republics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are in a struggle that doesn't have a timetable. It is a long process.'' - Dr. Mahdi Abdul Hadi, on the Arab uprising in the occupied territories. [ 16:3. ]

title: Grumman: Experience Counts for Something
description: I would like to comment on the letter of James McNicholas [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, March 20 ] concerning Grumman and the A-6 program.

title: On Land, Sea and Ice
description: Evening Cruise

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PARACHUTE. By Richard Lees. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) A letter is usually less awkward than a phone call. So JJ and Lynn, married 12 years, have turned to the postal service to ease their strained communications. ''Parachute,'' Richard Lees's first novel, is an ''is-it-love?'' story told in letters that fly furiously back and forth, East Coast to West, Central Park West to SoHo.

title: Bonnie Teschemacher Wed in Jersey
description: Bonnie Eyring Teschemacher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Teschemacher of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to John Alfred Hamilton Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton of McLean, Va. Msgr. William F. O'Donnell performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Gordon H. Tremaine, an Episcopal priest.

title: La Guardia Arts High School Opens Its First Stage
description: More than 20 years after New York City announced plans for a new high school of the arts, and four years after it finally opened, the last episode in the creation of Fiorello H. La Guardia High School has ended.

title: Flavor Lives In His Barbecue
description: WHEN the 80-year-old founder and namesake of Arthur Bryant's Barbecue, a landmark restaurant in Kansas City, Mo., died in December 1982, devoted customers across the nation wondered what would happen to the restaurant they had come to love for its hickory-smoked ribs, beef, ham, mutton and renowned spicy sauce.

title: A Rustic Resort In Mountains Of Carolina
description: LEAD: HIGH HAMPTON INN and Country Club in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina is the last major resort in the southern Appalachians to cling to its old ways. Long ago its contemporaries, the Greenbrier, the Homestead and Asheville's Grove Park Inn, built additions, installed air-conditioning, acceded to the public taste for huge beds and armoires concealing television sets, and hired decorators to update their lobbies and rooms.

title:
WINE;
Sampling of 9 Bottles From Land of the Alps
description: LEAD: LOGICALLY, Switzerland should produce superior wine. Much of its terrain and climate are comparable to those in bordering areas of France, Italy and Germany that are known for premium vintages. Yet relatively few Swiss labels appear on local shop shelves or county restaurant lists, and even the most savvy consumers are more knowledgeable about Swiss cheese and chocolate than wines of Vaud or the Valais (major wine producing regions in Switzerland).

title: Susan Sidd, Law Student, To Wed Dr. Marc Odrich
description: Dr. and Mrs. James J. Sidd of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Sidd, to Dr. Marc Geoffrey Odrich, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald B. Odrich of Riverdale, the Bronx. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Johnson Does It Again For Celtics
description: Remember Game 1 of the recent Knicks-Celtics series? It was late in the third quarter at Boston Garden and the Knicks led, 74-71, when Dennis Johnson stepped forward as he has done so often during crunch time in the playoffs.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DO NOT GO GENTLE. By Gordon Stevens. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) This bone-chiller about the morass of Middle Eastern politics is set mostly in Europe, where the extremist Palestinian commander Abu Nabil has masterminded a trail of terrorist actions leading to a cleverly orchestrated hijacking. But there is something unusual about this hijacking: when the terrorists make their demand, the authorities cannot believe how meager it is.

title: Headliners; Post Time
description: The New York Post, which has had several editorial incarnations in its 187-year history, will now be aiming for ''the highest possible journalistic standards and practices.'' So said the newspaper's new owner, Peter S. Kalikow, last week in announcing the appointment of Jane Amsterdam as the Post's new editor. Mr. Kalikow said Ms. Amsterdam's contract included strong assurances of editorial autonomy. Ms. Amsterdam, 36 years old, is a former editor of the American Lawyer and New York and New Times magazines and was the founding editor of Manhattan, Inc. At the Post, she will become the sixth woman editing an American newspaper with a circulation of more than 100,000. Asked about that, she referred to the horse that won the Kentucky Derby last weekend.

title: MOM AND DAD UP ON THE SCREEN
description: LEAD: ON THE OUTSIDE LOOKING IN By Michael Reagan with Joe Hyams. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Zebra Books/Kensington Publishing.

title: Mears Moves To Pole Spot
description: Rick Mears muscled into the pole position for the 72d Indianapolis 500, setting one- and four-lap speed records today as he mastered a slippery track. The team owned by Roger

title: THE ENIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has identified a possible new source of the plastic garbage that all too frequently washes up on New Jersey beaches: the shoreline itself.

title: Cost of Borrowing Is Heading Upward
description: The prime rate went up by half a percentage point, to 9 percent. After weeks of increases in other rates, the move by banks to raise their base lending rate was no surprise. Nevertheless, the financial markets took it as confirmation of a discouraging trend. At 9 percent, the prime is where it was before the stock market crash of October. The prime influences the borrowing costs of small and medium-size businesses and consumers. The Federal Reserve influences the borrowing costs of the banks, and there were signs of a squeeze. The highly sensitive Federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks edged up to 7 1/8 percent, from slightly below 7 percent.

title: The Lost Skyscrapers of Bygone New York
description: IT is easy to point out the important skyscrapers on the New York skyline - like the Woolworth (1913), tallest in the world until 1930; the Chrysler (1930), the Art Deco masterpiece, and the Empire State (1931), which superseded the Chrysler as the tallest. But there are also buildings significant in the history of the skyscraper that one never sees on a walking tour or a Circle Line cruise - because they have been demolished.

title: Replying to Statements On Diabetes Treatment
description: On May 1 you published a letter by Dr. Herbert Ross which challenged much of the material in Penny Singer's article about me [ ''Diabetic Doctor Offers a New Treatment,'' April 3 ] . The purpose of my letter is to clarify some of Dr. Ross's distortions and inaccuracies point by point. 1.

title: I.B.M. Offers Reassurance to Town
description: In ''A Town Pays a Price for Indifference'' (April 24, Opinion page), Southbury resident Alvin Laster expressed concern about the impact I.B.M.'s new Southbury facility will have on the ambiance of the town. We want to assure Mr. Laster that the International Business Machines Corporation cares about Southbury, too. We have worked closely with the community and state to resolve many of the concerns he raised.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: New Jersey;
575,000 Sq. Ft. in Ocean County: Shops, Offices and a Hotel, Too
description: LEAD: OCEAN COUNTY, a one-time resort turned bedroom community, is now being transformed into a commercial hub, with office buildings, hotels and retail centers sprouting in clusters throughout its 638 square miles.

title: Becca Davies Has Wedding
description: Dorothy Rebecca Stewart Davies, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Davies of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeremy Rafael Kramer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kramer of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Heidi Hudnut-Beumlen, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated at the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: Article 262488 -- No Title
description: A $5 million interpretive center for the Catskill Mountains is to be built next year to encourage tourism and economic development.

title:
INVESTING;
Inflation Hedges, Tankers to Timber
description: LEAD: INFLATION is not a hospitable environment for most stocks. But some companies stand to do better than others if, as some believe, a period of increased inflation is beginning. Though a return to the double-digit inflation of the late 1970's seems unlikely, many experts suggest that individuals consider arming their portfolios with a few defensive assets.

title: Reducing Liability Risks
description: THE liability issue ''is a tremendous cloud'' hanging over vaccine developers, said Mr. Rotheim, the analyst. Certainly, companies have good reason to be wary. The average award paid out in the 1970's for injury claims stemming from the swine flu vaccine was more than $100,000. Injury awards for the DPT (diphtheria-pertussis-tetanus) vaccine during the early 1980's averaged several times that amount.

title: Honoring the Phonautograph
description: Edison's ''talking machine'' with its tinfoil cylinder uttered its first croaking words in 1877. But the flat phonograph record as it is known today came a little later. It was first heard a hundred years ago, almost to the day.

title: Vast Parched Stretches of U.S. Await Hot Summer
description: In southwestern Texas, the streams have turned to dust and the grass to tinder, and ranchers are knocking thorns off prickly pear cactus so cattle can get to the moisture inside.

title: PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
description: Traditional theories of addictive personalities, disease models of drug abuse and claims of genetic involvement have not brought us much closer to understanding, treating or preventing addictive behavior. Dr. Bennett has admirably suggested that the problem may be the addictive behavior itself. A considerable advance can be made by studying how addiction is influenced by the variables Dr. Bennett reviews. H. D. SCHLINGER JR. Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: Dillon's Abortion Stand Roils Party
description: LEAD: THE long tenure of Denis E. Dillon as Nassau County's highest-ranking Democratic officeholder is coming under scrutiny over the issue of abortion, one of the most contentious subjects on Long Island.

title: A Bribe's Tale
description: DESPITE A RATHER healthy dose of doubt where marriage was concerned, I had always had a fairy-tale image of weddings. Satin shoes at the Drake Hotel, or mossy bliss beneath a waterfall. Of course, I'd always assumed that someone else would take care of the plans. I was mired in the sweet innocence of youth, when weddings seemed to spring forth mysteriously through spontaneous generation.

title: Program Trading
description: To the Editor:

title: Tommy Lasorda's Family Tradition
description: FOOD, INSISTS TOMMY LASORDA, THE well-fed manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, is the only weakness he has not been able to conquer. He recalls taking a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, staring at it, deciding he was stronger than the cigarettes and throwing the pack away, never to smoke again. He quit drinking in a similar manner. However, he also recalls the time he stared at a clam on a plate and demanded to know, ''Who's stronger, you or me?'' The clam stared back, according to Mr. Lasorda, ''and right then I knew I had met my match.''

title: Boy, 10, Is Suspended From School for Preaching
description: A 10-year-old preacher who said he would rather be rewarded in heaven than get an education on earth was suspended from school Friday after refusing to stop proselytizing and go to class.

title: Laughton as Quasimodo: Epic Agony
description: The following excerpt about the making of the 1939 version of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' is from ''Charles Laughton: A Difficult Actor,'' by the British actor Simon Callow, to be published later this month by Grove Press.

title: THE CLOISTERS: NEW TREASURES AND PLEASURES
description: My first knowledge of a place called the Cloisters came with a part-time job in a curious picture-book school building far in mood and distance from my South Bronx James Monroe High School. It was my ungrateful duty to soothe excited, recalcitrant children into bed moods; their older teachers were too exhausted for this last task of a long day.

title: LEGISLATION AND FAMILY MATTERS
description: THE Reagan Administration has long emphasized its dedication to the family.

title: Irish and British End An Extradition Dispute
description: After a five-month disagreement over procedures, Ireland has agreed to resume extraditing people suspected of terrorist acts to Britain, the British Attorney General's office said Friday.

title: The Unspeakable Is Debated: Should Drugs Be Legalized?
description: Exasperated by the seemingly endless deaths, crime and corruption generated by the world's illicit drug trade, a growing number of public officials and scholars in recent weeks have begun to call for debate on what for years was politically unspeakable: making drugs legal.

title: A Fan's Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors; Better Habitat For Woodcock
description: A reclusive bird that even the most dedicated hikers rarely see, the American woodcock, is in trouble, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service, which estimates that for the last decade and a half its numbers have been declining at the rate of about 2 per cent a year.

title: Port Villages With a Past Preserved
description: IN the middle of the 18th century, while traveling and preaching in the ''ungospelized wilds'' of North Carolina, the evangelist George Whitefield made several visits to the busy port town of Bath. As legend has it, Whitefield ended one of his stays with ill feelings toward Bath's residents. He walked out of the town, shook the dust from his feet and laid a curse on Bath that stifled its prosperity for all time.

title: Foes of Shoreham to Continue Struggle for Lilco Board Seats
description: EVEN if a settlement between the state and Lilco is announced before the utility's annual shareholders' meeting Tuesday, the Long Island Power Authority will continue its proxy battle for three seats on Lilco's board.

title: 'Cat's Cradle,' Mystery Set in English Village
description: ''CAT'S CRADLE,'' by Leslie Sands, is a psychological mystery thriller now having its New York premiere at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. This 1983 British drama takes place in Waverton, a small English village in which, 12 years before the time of the play's action, a 6-month-old baby boy was kidnapped.

title: There's Opera, And Art, Too, In Cooperstown
description: CULTURE in the country is always an appealing proposition. Add to that an exceptionally pretty little town on the edge of a lake, two small museums dissimilar in everything except quality, and the newest opera house in the United States, and it will become clear that Cooperstown, N.Y., the home of the Baseball Hall of Fame, is indeed worth a visit.

title: MARK MORRIS: YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHER POISED TO SOAR
description: LEAD: Mark Morris stands behind Gladys Celeste, one of American Ballet Theater's rehearsal pianists, following the score as she begins playing. Twelve years earlier, he had turned pages for her during an Eliot Feld performance. Mr. Morris beats out the rhythm with one hand, a can of beer in the other. ''Do you hear that?

title: Ann P. Duffy Married To Nicholas C. Hanna
description: Ann Peters Duffy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Duffy of Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Nicholas Cooke Hanna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Hanna Jr. of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quiogue, L.I.

title: Devils Absorb Painful Lesson
description: After a season of hurtling past obstacles that had stymied them before, suddenly all that really mattered to the Devils tonight was the one leap they failed to make.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: INHERITANCE. By Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) ''Inheritance'' is one of those books you run out to buy for an ailing friend but wind up reading yourself. It's the latest offering by the husband-and-wife writing team known as Judith Michael, who also produced ''Deceptions.'' When Laura Fairchild's parents are killed in a car accident, she and her brother move in with their older half brother and support themselves by stealing.

title: Newark is At the Heart of a Television Reporter
description: WHEN Sandra King talks about Newark then and Newark now, the fire in her eyes intensifies and diminishes, but it never goes out.

title: Guards Held Hostage in Riot at Oklahoma Prison
description: Inmates at an overcrowded state prison held three guards hostage today after a fiery uprising that left one dormitory gutted and two others damaged, officials said. One guard and one inmate were injured.

title: Souvenir
description: To the Editor: While snorkeling off the Beach Club in Grand Case, St. Martin, recently I spotted what looked like a piece of play money on the ocean floor. Removing my mask, I dove down and retrieved it. Sure enough, it was a real $10 greenback. Dried out, it looks as good as new - if a little pale - and I expect to keep it as a treasured liquid asset. JACK OSGOOD Boston

title: PERSONAL FINANCEA Cautionary Look at Affinity Cards
description: FOR about a year now, banks and other financial institutions that issue credit cards have been pushing cards with a cause. These so-called affinity cards are issued in conjunction with a nonprofit organization, everything from the League of Women Voters to the National Rifle Association. Under the typical arrangement, the nonprofit group gets a small cut each time the cards are used to charge a purchase.

title: Killer Bees? They're No Joke in Texas
description: Three or four times a day, panicked residents here telephone local pest control agencies with a chilling message: the killer bees have arrived.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Medal to Honor a Songwriter
description: LEAD: AN appealing new medal is among the birthday tributes to songwriter Irving Berlin, who turned 100 last Wednesday. The medal was conceived and designed by sculptor Alex Shagin of Los Angeles.

title: Affair of State Is Captivating Venezuelans
description: With Venezuelans as transfixed as they might be by a steamy television soap opera, a long-running drama of passion, politics and power set in the Presidential Palace of Miraflores here is at last building towards its denouement.

title: TALKS IN MANAGUA FRUITLESS, INDIAN REBELS SAY
description: Leaders of Miskito Indian rebels failed to reach agreement with the Sandinista Government after six days of talks here and the negotiations were called off on Saturday night.

title: Review/Dance; Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane & Company
description: The question implicit in the New Contemporary Masters festival was answered on Thursday when the series formally opened at City Center for its two-week run. Can ''downtown'' dance, with an esthetic that is often anti-establishment, be transplanted successfully to the dance equivalent of a Broadway theater? The answer provided by Bill T. Jones/ Arnie Zane & Company was a resounding yes.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 30 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area $143,000 330 Third Avenue (23d St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, hardwood floors, southern exposure; maintenance $391, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Greenwich Village $470,000 69 Bank Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. condo in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, fireplace, tiled-terrace, high-ceilings; common charge $397, 100% tax-abated (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Madison Square Area $400,000 45 East 25th Street 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, balcony, windowed kitchen; common charge $100, taxes $600 (Broker: Molk Associates) Upper East Side $1 million 29 East 64th Street 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, large kitchen, high-ceilings, hardwood floors, Central Park view; maintenance $1,075; 30% tax-deductible (Broker: M.J. Raynes) Washington Heights $108,000 870 West 181st Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, windowed kitchen, high-ceilings; maintenance $377, 47% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Riverdale $138,000 601 Kappock Street (Presidential) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,150-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, terrace; maintenance $570, includes gas, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) Wakefield $235,000 4054 Edson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached ranch; dining room, large kitchen, den, full basement, 89- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,640 (Broker: Sterling Realty) BROOKLYN Cobble Hill $295,000 327 Clinton Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. duplex co-op in a 4-story brownstone building; dining area, fireplace, high-ceilings, roof rights; maintenance $635, includes heat and hot water, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Dowling & Peltz) Park Slope $590,000 552 4th Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, attached 3-story brownstone; dining room, large kitchen, deck, four decorative mantels, original moldings and details, 17- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,499 (Broker: F.J. Kazeroid) QUEENS Kew Gardens $247,500 82-14 Austin Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, attached, brick Tudor; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, front and rear gardens, 18- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Terrace Realty) Jamaica Hills $62,000 164-20 Highland Avenue (Highlander Hall) 500-sq.-ft. postwar, alcove-studio; part-time doorman, separate kitchen; maintenance $272, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Glenjay Realty) STATEN ISLAND Oakwood $175,000 319 Chesterton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, full basement, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate) Port Richmond $165,000 87 Palmer Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached, colonial; dining room, large kitchen, den, full basement, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: George K. Wonica) Snug Harbor $405,000 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached center-hall colonial; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, 1-car detached garage, 130- by 109-ft. lot; taxes $1,700 (Rand Properties)

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss. Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling. We hired a painter who scraped and sanded, then painted with an oil paint, but now the walls and ceiling are flaking again. Can you help me solve this problem?

title: Campaigns, Cameras and Beauty Contests
description: The presidential campaign is at a lull. The candiates are taking a breather. They are still on television every night, but they are not being covered or reported on with the saturation, intensity and breathlessness of last winter. Vice President Bush has won the Republican nomination; almost everyone concedes the Democratic prize to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Westchester; Marriott Taps No-Frills Market With Two Hotels
description: A COZY Spanish-style hotel opened in Tarrytown in January and one just like it opened in Rye in March, even though established hoteliers have complained that there are already too many hotel rooms in Westchester County.

title: Ris Miller Is Wed To James Howard
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Stephen the Martyr in Edina, Minn., Marissa Harris Miller, a daughter of William R. Miller of New York and Lawrence, L.I., and the late Nancy McClain Harris Miller of Paris, Ill., was married yesterday to James William Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Howard of Gill, Colo. The Rev. David B. Joslin performed the ceremony.

title: Giamatti Chose to Ignore Rose's Sacred Right
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Keystone Bridge Reopens
description: LEAD: AFTER months of waiting, residents of North Salem finally have one more bridge to cross.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Northeast Journal column last Sunday about a conflict over the anthem of the University of Maine at Orono referred incorrectly to the university president, Dale Lick. He is a man.

title: Designs in Nature
description: AT A CERTAIN level of speculation about the body and its diseases, medical science begins to sound like myth. Flesh talks, blood listens. The body wants things, genes know things, immune systems see things, diseases have secrets that go back to once upon a time in the primeval forest.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Pearl River
description: A YOUNG boy parks his bicycle and enters a pizza parlor on Central Avenue in Pearl River, but does not lock the bike. In fact, he does not even have a lock. ''What do I need a lock for?'' he says in response to a question.

title: Preston Bastress Weds
description: Jane Preston Bastress, a daughter of Dr. E. Karl Bastress of Washington and Anne Wasson Harney of Lincoln and East Chop, Mass., was married yesterday to Johan Pieter Westenburg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Westenburg of Windsor, Conn. Betty A. Bryant, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at Lambert's Cove Inn in West Tisbury, Mass. The bride, known as Preston, is the bookings editor at Vogue magazine. Mr. Westenburg is the assistant manager in the art-handling department at the Pace Gallery in New York.

title: Apartheid Isn't Sporting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lilias Bostwick Married on L.I. To J. S. Noesen
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., Lilias Margarite Bostwick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, was married yesterday to John Stanley Noesen, a son of Nancy Noesen of Flat Rock, N.C., and the late Stanley J. Noesen. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: One of the purposes of a referee in a sports event is to establish and maintain order on the field. Mr. Giamatti is well founded in his refusal to tolerate ''any potentially injurious harassment of any kind of the umpires.'' However, the same sense of order which protects an umpire must restrain him. Dave Pallone mimicked and poked Pete Rose. It was Pallone who was responsible for the ''degeneration'' of that game; it is Pallone who should receive the disciplinary action. MATTHEW STOLL New York

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 24 with a listing of bicycle tours misidentified the French chateau shown. It is the Chateau d'Usse.

title: Special Today; Entertaining/Magazine Part 2
description: * Challenging recipes for grillers.

title:
INVESTING;
LTV: Bonds Yes, Stock No
description: LEAD: THERE is nothing quite like the feeling of owning a stock or bond when the bankruptcy courts decide there is not enough money left to spread around.

title: Amnesia, of a Sort, Is Widespread
description: AT the height of the Spring Comdex computer show in Atlanta last week, officials of AST Research Inc. discovered, to their horror, that they had forgotten to lock up their memory boards. Sometime during a cocktail reception in the AST showroom Tuesday night, someone walked up to a display of the memory cards and slipped out eight slender banks of memory chips, each about the size of a cigarette.

title: The Height Report
description: LEAD: Politics' favorite indoor sport will soon be the Great Vice Presidential Naming Game. With the Presidential nominations, for all practical purposes, in the bag, there is no other burning issue to preoccupy us. We have already begun to see long lists of names of candidates with elaborate rationales for each.

title: An Operatic 'Little Foxes' at the Long Wharf
description: ONCE, the notion of opera in a legitimate theater was forbidding and so ''Regina,''

title: Sara Carrier to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Clarke Carrier of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara Louise Carrier to Robert Lanston McKeown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Anderson McKeown of Short Hills, N.J. Miss Carrier, a graduate of DePauw University, is enrolled in the master's program in nursing administration at Loyola University of Chicago. Her fiance, a sales representative for Bulkley Dunton, a paper company in New York, graduated from Lafayette College.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM: Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney, by John Taylor. (Ballantine, $9.95.) Almost from the beginning, the Disney entertainment empire was bitterly divided as the disciples of Walt lorded it over the followers of his lesser-known brother, Roy. John Taylor's story of how Roy's son took revenge in the early 1980's, with the help of Ivan Boesky and other financiers, is ''a tale of raw corporate power,'' David McClintick said in The Book Review last year. It captures ''the supreme importance of egos and personal relationships in the governance of business, particularly show business.'' MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK, by Saul Bellow. (Dell, $4.95.) Despite their intellectual powers and vast learning, Kenneth Trachtenberg, a specialist in Russian studies, and his uncle, Benn Crader, a world authority on lichens, are miserable failures when it comes to love. ''The exploration of [ their ] relationship, with its widening ripples of betrayal, deceit and self-deceit, of conspiracy, of sex confused with love and, inevitably, money as stakes in a bruising confidence game, is the material of [ a ] brilliant new novel,'' our reviewer, William Gaddis, said last year. ''We welcome back the calamitous wit of 'The Adventures of Augie March' and 'Herzog' among people diligently struggling to rearrange one another's lives in their efforts to rescue or simply to define their own.'' A GUARD WITHIN, by Sarah Ferguson. (Pantheon, $7.95.) After suffering a series of losses and disappointments, a woman is pushed over the edge when her psychiatrist dies. In 1974 our reviewer, Joseph McElroy, said this autobiographical account is written in a way that evokes the author's ''sickness of need'' so that, for the reader, it is ''overwhelmingly felt.'' SKINNY ISLAND, by Louis Auchincloss. (St. Martin's, $3.95.) Spanning the last century, these short stories of the idle rich are ''set like vertebrae on the expensive backbone of Manhattan,'' Peter Cameron said here last year. But the book ''is more than a record of how the other half lived, and continues to live. It is first and foremost elegant fiction.'' MORTAL CHOICES: Ethical Dilemmas in Modern Medicine, by Ruth Macklin. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) An ethicist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine uses medical case histories to show how philosophers can help doctors make difficult moral decisions. Last year Rayna Rapp said in these pages that the book ''provides a lively and useful primer for the rapidly expanding field of bioethics.'' THE MOON PINNACE, by Thomas Williams. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $8.95.) Unsure whether he should marry the girl next door, a young World War II veteran leaves New Hampshire to explore California on his Indian Pony motorcycle. In 1986 our reviewer, Howard Frank Mosher, called the novel ''a timely, powerful antidote to the low-risk, low-intensity minimalist fiction so much in vogue these days.'' The same publisher has reissued three more of Mr. Williams's novels of life in New England, each priced at $8.95.
