THE HAIR OF HAROLD ROUX, which won a National Book Award, is about Aaron Benham, an academic of the 1960's who is writing a novel about student life in the 1950's. In 1974, The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said that Mr. Williams's novel was much better than the imaginary one it contains, but that he found Benham himself ''absorbingly complex. He shows us how the man of inaction transmutes his paralysis into a fiction of action.'' Beginning in the years after the Depression, WHIPPLE'S CASTLE tells of a family whose members all must overcome unique physical limitations. In 1969 our reviewer, R. M. Adams, said that while the novel was flawed, ''there are pages on end where the sweep and fluency of [ the author's ] style, its special gift for rendering the rub of ordinary experience, seem like sufficient ends in themselves.'' In TOWN BURNING, which was published in 1959, another World War II veteran comes to terms with himself and his family by helping battle a fire that threatens to destroy his hometown. BROTHER ENEMY: The War After the War, by Nayan Chanda. (Collier/Macmillan, $12.95.) Since the fall of Saigon, Vietnam has shown that it is much better at waging war than at maintaining peace. This account by the Washington bureau chief of the Far Eastern Economic Review ''offers much insight about why the Vietnamese victory over the United States is proving to be so bitter,'' Robert Manning said here in 1986. ROSIE THE RIVETER REVISITED: Women, the War, and Social Change, by Sherna Berger Gluck. (Meridian/ New American Library, $8.95.) During World War II, women were recruited by the Government to work in munitions factories, but after armistice they were expected to resume more traditional roles. Last year our reviewer, Rosalyn Schram, said this oral history ''tells more of the story than labor force statistics alone can reveal. . . . This book presents a solid lesson in the interconnectedness of public policy and women's private spheres.'' THE ORTON DIARIES, edited by John Lahr. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) From Christmas 1966 until he was murdered by his homosexual lover less than a year later, the British playwright Joe Orton recorded his bitter observations about life. Last year, Benedict Nightingale said here that this book ''shows how the plays reflected the man, and how both plays and man excited jealousies that turned lethal. . . . Under Orton's own companionable charm there was something hard and callous. . . . His sympathies are few, his objects of scorn many.''

title: Earthy Attitude
description: He grew up on a tobacco farm in North Carolina, so it should come as no surprise that Todd Welborn takes a chaw on a plug now and again. But Welborn, a relief pitcher for the Mets' Class AA farm club in Jackson, Miss., insists that tobacco never passes his lips.

title:
DANCE;
Serendipitous Ballet To Make Its Debut
description: LEAD: WITHOUT a bit of serendipity, Jeff Satinoff's ''Short Symphony,'' a ballet to the Aaron Copland music of the same name, might not be having its premiere Thursday at the George Street Playhouse here.

title: Panel Belittles Role of Drug Tests
description: LEAD: ''RANDOM mandatory drug testing for workers in non-sensitive positions may not be worth the trouble it causes,'' said Dr. David F. Musto, chairman of a group that studied testing for a year and a half.

title: Young and Old Join for Ridgefield Concert
description: ''YOUTH supplies us with colors,'' wrote Samuel Johnson, ''age with canvas.'' Put them together, and you have a portrait in accomplishment. You also have the 17th Joint Concert by the Ridgefield Symphony and the Ridgefield Youth Orchestra today.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MOB STAR: The Story of John Gotti. By Gene Mustain and Jerry Capeci. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) The readers of ''Mob Star'' - a book about the reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, John Gotti - must be even more patient than the police officers who spent countless hours monitoring the taps and bugs that provide the only surprise in this dreary account of murder and mayhem.

title: 'Interesting Numbers' for the Manufacturers
description: NEW technology, particularly genetic engineering, is reviving interest in vaccines - agents that induce immunity to diseases. After a 20-year slump that saw the number of vaccine producers shrink by half and fundamental advances slow to a crawl, the pace of development is quickening.

title: Mecham Wins Spot at G.O.P. Convention
description: Former Gov. Evan Mecham was elected today as a delegate to the Republican National Convention in August.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 19 of the Travel section today about Cooperstown, N.Y., omits the location of the Glimmerglass Opera House. It is on Route 80, on the west side of Otsego Lake, about eight miles north of the village.

title: Tracing Fashions in Black and White
description: LEAD: BLACK and white has through the ages sparked the design of dramatic fashions, settings and gala celebrations. At the Bruce Museum here, the combination is used as a catalyst for an exhibition called ''An Elegant Contrast: Fashions in Black and White.''

title: Tuned In
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: MAY 15, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York. 2 1 10 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 3 2 4 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 4 3 4 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 5 4 28 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 6 5 9 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 7 6 9 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 8 9 6 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) What ensues when a New York socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 9 8 10 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 10 * 10 13 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 11 11 30 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 12 * 1 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 13 12 3 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. 14 * 7 6 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) Book Two of the fantasy saga that began with ''Guardians of the West.'' 15 15 2 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 2 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the celebrated performer. 2 5 22 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 3 1 53 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 4 3 4 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 5 4 4 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 6 6 15 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 7 9 27 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 8 8 4 WINFIELD, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Norton, $16.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee outfielder. 9 12 3 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 10 10 5 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 11 7 6 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life and times of the New York lawyer and political figure Roy M. Cohn. 12 * 11 11 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 13 14 17 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 14 15 6 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. 15 13 3 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former spokesman. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 45 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 6 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 6 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program. 4 3 BEING A WOMAN, by Toni Grant. (Random House, $17.95.) Balancing feminism and femininity. 5 * 5 137 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 6 * 4 2 WHAT'S NEXT? by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $14.95.) An economist's advice. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) MARY McCARTHY: A Life, by Carol Gelderman. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) A nicely paced, well-balanced account of a remarkable American life that avoids sycophancy and psychobabble. LILLIAN HELLMAN: Her Legend and Her Legacy, by Carl Rollyson. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Lavishly dishy and teeming with arresting detail, the story of this rule-bending ''walking Medea'' is as fitfully irritating as it is interesting. BALZAC'S HORSE: And Other Stories, by Gert Hofmann. (Fromm International, $16.95.) In writing of sustained excellence, a West German author coaxes a comedy out of the distance between his characters' energy and the straits in which they find themselves. GOOD HEARTS, by Reynolds Price. (Atheneum, $18.95.) Twenty-six years later, the family in ''A Long and Happy Life'' is older but the rich voices are even stronger and the storytelling superb. TRUST, by Mary Flanagan. (Atheneum, $17.95.) The strength of this fine first novel is that it makes the ways we treat one another seem supremely important. BENEATH THE AMERICAN RENAISSANCE: The Subversive Imagination in the Age of Emerson and Melville, by David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An original argument, that the subsoil of America's mid-19th-century literary flowering was eroticism, bizarre fantasy and radical impulse, gives the canon a shaking. NUCLEAR FEAR: A History of Images, by Spencer R. Weart. (Harvard University, $29.50.) In this true story of the atomic age, a physicist-historian describes how America's new fateful consciousness (and subconsciousness) of nuclear energy and its military use derives from an ancient pictorial atavism.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
The Winston Property Wetland Dispute
description: LEAD: AT least one aspect of a longstanding dispute over 16.9 acres of land that Harry Winston, the late New York jeweler, gave to his home village of Scarsdale, may finally be nearing an end.

title: Homey Italian Fare in Darien
description: EVERY diner likes to have in his repertory a pleasant, inexpensive restaurant as a cozy retreat for an informal meal with the family. Alla Bettola in the Goodwives Shopping Plaza in Darien is such a place.

title: Clemens Does It Again, 3-0
description: Roger Clemens pitched a three-hitter and struck out 10 today en route to his fourth shutout of the season as the Boston Red Sox beat the Seattle Mariners, 3-0.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Louisville, Ky.; More Growth For Suburbs
description: PLANS are advancing for a research and office park that would bring another 1.2 million square feet of commercial space to the rapidly growing suburbs near downtown.

title: Review/Piano; Berenice Lipson-Gruzen
description: Fragments of satisfaction and fragments of disappointment - placed side by side - made up Berenice Lipson-Gruzen's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night, and one's piecemeal response to her playing was actually a metaphor for the playing itself. Its highest moments were the Debussy pieces - the three ''Estampes'' and the isolated Prelude from Book One called ''What the West Wind Saw.'' The coloring was lovely, and the disruptive phrasing that troubled so much of the music before and after seemed largely absent.

title: In a Hotel Ballroom, A Dressy Boxing Card
description: IT was a far cry from the basement arenas where a fighter could hardly see his opponent because of the thick cloud of cigar smoke.

title: Gandhi's Arms Buildup Is Questioned At Home
description: FEW dissenting voices were heard in recent years as India undertook an ambitious military buildup. Many Indians seemed to agree with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi that questioning the need for more spending was unpatriotic.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'MACK AND MABEL'

title: Susan Reiner Marries Jonathan Albert Berg
description: In the chapel at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan, Susan Ann Reiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Reiner of Mount Carmel, Pa., was married yesterday to Jonathan Albert Berg, a son of Noyon Berg of Atherton, Calif., and the late Daniel E. Berg. The Rev. Margot Gross performed the ceremony.

title: Hated Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark's New Terminal: Relief Is in Sight
description: LIFE at Newark Airport may never be like an afternoon in the lounge of a deluxe hotel, but the opening of a new terminal should be a first step toward taking the airport out of the bottom of the class. It has been lodged there for 15 months or more because of the pressure on the main terminal used by Continental Airlines.

title: No One Has Proved Yet That There's Nothing to Astrology
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Investors are frightened. They don't know when the other shoe is going to drop. Myself, I'd be in C.D.'s.'' - Lawrence Weiss, president of Odd-Lot Securities, a discount broker.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: EAST LYME;
A Town Gains Its Fame for What It Does With Its Garbage
description: LEAD: EAST LYME is a town with many attributes: nice beaches, attractive, well-manicured neighborhoods and good schools. But they are not what have put this shoreline town of 15,000 on the map.

title: Pistons Apply Some Muscle to Bulls
description: After playing two uncharacteristically polite games with Chicago, the Detroit Pistons, who have become known for their brutish style of play, took off the kid gloves this afternoon and handed the Bulls one of the worst losses in their playoff history.

title: Marriage and Other Astonishing Bonds
description: WHERE I'M CALLING FROM New and Selected Stories. By Raymond Carver. 393 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

title: Reassessments Hit Homeowners Hard
description: NOT even in gentrifying Hoboken can Henry Wurtz imagine that his quirky little rowhouse - only 10 feet wide - is worth $212,200, the value recently put on it by a firm doing the city's new tax assessments.

title: Host's Guide to Outdoor Cafes
description: IT IS OFTEN SAID THAT RESTAURANTS TODAY are part sustenance and part showmanship, not always in equal proportion. And nowhere is the theater of dining more vibrant than in outdoor cafes, whether on a bustling urban thoroughfare, in a salt-sprayed seaside village or deep in a sylvan glade. An outdoor terrace or garden can make an ideal setting for warm-weather entertaining. While in general the quality of food is in inverse proportion to the view at such places (a hypothesis borne out by airplane fare), happily there are outdoor spots around the country that combine delightful atmosphere with food to match. The sampling here, based on 15,000 air miles, with stops in New York City, Chicago, Key West and Los Angeles, includes everything from French and Italian cuisine to Southern fare and even Western game. LOS ANGELES FOUR OAKS RESTAURANT 2181 North Beverly Glen Boulevard (213) 470-3623 or (213) 470-2265

title: Town Facing 60% Tax Rise
description: FOR MORE than a century, the gray buildings, shaft houses and crushers of a 71-acre zinc mine stood high on a ridge above this two-square-mile Sussex County hamlet in the Wallkill Valley, tangible evidence of the community's most valuable economic asset and major tax ratable.

title: PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
description: In his article ''Patterns of Addiction'' (Body and Mind, April 10), William Ira Bennett says that ''Even addiction to street drugs may be at least partially explained as a craving for a certain schedule of sensations, as much as for the drug itself.''

title:
IN THE NATION: Pleasant Prairie, Wis.;
A Utility's Industrial Park Grows In the Cabbage and Corn Fields
description: LEAD: A UTILITY based in Milwaukee that has a huge tract of land here and a power plant looking for customers is attempting to coax Illinois industry across the state line.

title: Art School Apologizes for Painting of Mayor
description: An art school apologized in advertisements appearing in Sunday newspapers here for exhibiting a student's portrait of the late Mayor Harold Washington in lingerie.

title: U.S. May Agree to Let Noriega Run for President
description: An arrangement that American officials are negotiating with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega would require the Panamanian to step down as head of his country's armed forces, but might allow him to run for president in an election scheduled for next May, Panamanian opposition leaders and senior Latin American diplomats said today.

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: The excessiveness of Pete Rose's suspension is appalling. Mr. Giamatti has demonstrated that he is not qualified to serve as league president. PETER MOUND Secaucus, N.J.

title: Images From Winogrand's Mosaic of Life
description: It would be no great exaggeration to say that over the last 10 years, the art of photography has split into two irreconcilable camps. On one side are the post-modernists and their allies, who see photography as a particularly useful and provocative means of making images that address the issues of art in our times. On the other side are those who hold to the more traditional view that photographs are connected not merely to the world of art, but to life itself.

title: Dining Alfresco, New York Style
description: FOR ALL THEIR POTENTIAL PLEASURES, outdoor cafes have their distinct perils - especially in such congested urban centers as New York City. They include everything from flies performing kamikaze dives into your gazpacho to exhaust fumes, gawking passers-by, airborne napkins, cold food, street noise, sudden weather shifts and confused canines who mistake table legs for spindly shrubs.

title: THE BAD NEWS AT CBS
description: PRIME TIMES, BAD TIMES By Ed Joyce. 561 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Brokers' Surveys; Why Vacancy Rates Vary Widely Within Markets
description: REAL ESTATE BROKERAGES that publish office-market surveys are an unruly bunch - setting their separate rules, crunching their separate numbers and releasing a jumble of conflicting market indicators.

title: Boat Owners Ahoy! Welcome Ashore
description: YOU'VE seen the reports about the increasing numbers of pleasure boats along the Connecticut coast, and what they portend. Plans to build more marinas are viewed with alarm. Mid-channel moorings raise legal questions. Dredging proposals threaten bottom life. But amid the worry about all that, is a little-noticed positive factor: people like me have acted to limit the potential problem.

title: Affirmative Action Upholds Academic Values; Small World
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopian Region Goes to the Root of Hunger
description: People in this rugged eastern region of Ethiopia are struggling to transform devastation into development.

title:
GARDENING;
Discoveries on the New-Old Property
description: LEAD: COUNTLESS old houses - and their gardens - change hands every year. But it is not until the spring and summer months that new owners are confronted by their plots of land.

title: Brookhaven Debates Limits on Dogs
description: LEAD: AN ordinance that would restrict dog owners from having more than 10 dogs in residential areas is expected to attract opposition at a Brookhaven Town Board meeting Tuesday.

title: Franklin Stone Weds David Howard Wenk
description: Franklin Harvey Stone, a daughter of Franklin Brockinton Stone of Richmond and the late Robert Lecky Stone, was married yesterday to David Howard Wenk, the son of Mr. and Mrs Howard Arthur Wenk of Mountain Lakes, N.J. Judge Michael Bernard Mukasey of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss. Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling. We hired a painter who scraped and sanded, then painted with an oil paint, but now the walls and ceiling are flaking again. Can you help me solve this problem?

title: GOINGS ON IN NORTHEAST
description: FOOD FESTIVAL

title: Music; Summer Music Festivals Throughout the Land
description: Alaska BASICALLY BACH FESTIVAL: Anchorage, July 7-17. One concert basically Bach; the other four offer no Bach. Fiora Contino conducts Handel's ''Samson.'' FAIRBANKS SUMMER ARTS FESTIVAL: July 24-Aug. 6. America's northernmost arts festival gives concerts on the University of Alaska-Fairbanks campus, both jazz and classics. Guest artist-teachers include Chris Calloway, Louis Moyse, the Boston Jazz Pops Ensemble. SITKA SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 3-24. Chamber music by music director Paul Rosenthal, Nancy Allen, Edward Auer, Jerome Lowenthal, Toby Saks, others. Arizona FLAGSTAFF FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS: July 9-31. Orchestral and chamber concerts as part of a multi-arts program. Guests include Skitch Henderson, Jerome Lowenthal. GRAND CANYON CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Sept. 3-17. A post-season event in the Shrine of the Ages, with John Corigliano composer-in-residence. Weekend concerts by music director Robert Bonfiglio, Ida Kavafian, Nathaniel Rosen, Ronald Roseman, Edward Auer. SEDONA CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 18-26. Concerts by the Blair Quartet, guests. Arkansas MUSIC FESTIVAL OF ARKANSAS: Fayetteville, June 9-26. Orchestral, chamber, jazz concerts, Carlton R. Woods music director and conductor. Margaret Hillis presents Haydn's ''Theresienmesse'' and directs the Second Annual Choral Institute. California ART FARM FESTIVAL: Sonoma, June 4-12. Four chamber concerts by the Art Farm Ensemble. BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL: San Francisco, June 13-July 2. First the Guarneri Quartet, then the San Francisco Symphony under Herbert Blomstedt. Vladimir Feltsman appears. CABRILLO FESTIVAL: Santa Cruz, July 21-31. Repeatedly cited by ASCAP for adventuresome programming, the festival celebrates Irving Berlin's 100th birthday, Olivier Messiaen's 80th, Leonard Bernstein's 70th. Dennis Russell Davies is music director, Heinz Winbeck composer-in-residence. Participants include the Kronos String and Rascher Saxophone Quartets, Ursula Oppens, Paul Zukofsky. CARMEL BACH FESTIVAL: July 11-31. Sandor Salgo conducts ''Fidelio,'' Mozart's Requiem, Bach's St. Matthew Passion. Featured artists are Janice Taylor, Bin Wang, Jean-Louis Steuerman, Stephanie Chase, Judith Davidoff, Jesse Read. CHAMBER MUSIC/L.A. FESTIVAL: Los Angeles, May 15-22. A tribute to Jascha Heifetz by Carol Neblett, Pierre Amoyal, Christiaan Bor, Nathaniel Rosen, Brooks Smith and others, directed by Yukiko Kamei. CHAMBER MUSIC WEST: San Francisco, June 6-23. Concerts given by the San Francisco Conservatory featuring Bay Area musicians plus William Parker, Michael Webster, Andre Emelianoff, Robert Helps, the Cleveland Quartet. John Harbison is composer-in-residence. CONCORD PAVILION: June 3-Oct. 16. The outdoor amphitheater in the foothills of Mt. Diablo hosts the Oakland and Diablo Symphony Orchestras, Roberta Peters, John Denver, Andy Williams. The Concord Jazz Festival celebrates its 20th anniversary Aug. 14-21 with Dave Brubeck, Oscar Peterson, others. E. NAKAMICHI BAROQUE MUSIC FESTIVAL: Los Angeles, June 22-26. The second in U.C.L.A.'s biennial series. Nicholas McGegan presents Stefano Landi's path-breaking opera ''Il Sant'Alessio,'' with Judith Nelson, Julianne Baird, Drew Minter, David Thomas and the New York Baroque Dance Company. Other performers include Frederick Hammond, Paul O'Dette, Stanley Ritchie, Daniel Stepner. HIDDEN VALLEY MASTERS FESTIVAL OF CHAMBER MUSIC: Carmel Valley, June 27-July 4. Performances by artistic director Julius Baker, John Mack, Lisa Emenheiser, Marc Shapiro, the Cleveland Orchestra String Quartet, jazz flutist Ali Ryerson. HOLLYWOOD BOWL: Los Angeles, July 12-Sept. 17. The Los Angeles Philharmonic is conducted at its summer home by Andre Previn, Edo de Waart, Jesus Lopez-Cobos, Eduardo Mata, John Nelson, Leonard Slatkin, Yuri Temirkanov, John Williams, others. Visitors include the Pittsburgh Symphony under Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, Andre Watts, Barry Douglas, Cho-Liang Lin, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, James Galway, Ella Fitzgerald, Mel Torme, George Shearing, Lionel Hampton. First comes a preview week, July 3-9, with two Andy Williams concerts, three Mozart programs. LAKE TAHOE SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Tahoe City, July 8-Sept. 3. Restructured and expanded for its sixth season, the festival offers concerts by a new Lake Tahoe Summer Music Festival Chamber Orchestra at various North Tahoe locations; an ''American Opera Festival of the Sierras'' in the Squaw Valley Theater, featuring ''The Ballad of Baby Doe,'' ''Plump Jack,'' ''White Election,'' ''Amelia Goes to the Ball'' and ''The Old Maid and the Thief''; and ''The Pirates of Penzance'' in Homewood's Topol Pavilion. MIDSUMMER MOZART FESTIVAL: San Francisco and environs, July 13-Aug. 7. George Cleve directs orchestral concerts. Soloists include Frederica von Stade, Claude Frank, Mitsuko Uchida, Steven Lubin and Hermann Baumann. Also a chamber series. MONTEREY JAZZ FESTIVAL: Sept. 16-18. In its 31st season, the oldest continuous jazz festival in the nation presents Joe Williams, Benny Carter, the Count Basie Orchestra, others. MOZART IN MONTEREY: Monterey, Carmel, June 14-19. Concerts conducted by music director Oleg Kovalenko, chamber concerts, a recital by artist-in-residence Lydia Artymiw. MUSIC ACADEMY OF THE WEST: Santa Barbara, July 5-Aug. 20. Faculty-performers include Russell Sherman, Jerome Lowenthal, Stephen Kates. Artistic director Lawrence Leighton Smith conducts Mahler's Fourth Symphony; Bodo Igesz stages Britten's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' MUSIC FROM BEAR VALLEY: July 30-Aug. 14. Orchestral concerts led by Carter Nice, ''The Barber of Seville,'' other events. Soloists include Garrick Ohlsson, Joshua Bell. OJAI MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 3-5. Nicholas McGegan, the new music director, brings his Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra for a performance of Purcell's ''King Arthur'' and a Baroque concert. Peter Maxwell Davies, composer-in-residence, figures prominently in the other concerts, and his children's pantomime ''Cinderella'' is presented free. PAUL MASSON SUMMER SERIES: Saratoga, June 2-Sept. 25. Some 115 performances, musical and otherwise, featuring the Juilliard and Emerson String Quartets, Ray Charles, Dave Brubeck, Lionel Hampton, Dizzy Gillespie, Roy Orbison, Chuck Berry. REDLANDS BOWL SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 28-Aug. 26. A 65th season of free events, featuring ''The Music Man,'' ''The Mikado'' and ''Madama Butterfly'' and various classical, jazz, folk and pop artists. SAN FRANCISCO OPERA: May 21-June 30. Recitals by Leona Mitchell and Luciano Pavarotti, concerts and an Opera Center Showcase premiere of Hiram Titus's ''Rosina.'' In July and August the Merola Opera Program offers ''L'Italiana in Algeri'' at Stern Grove, ''Madama Butterfly'' at Saratoga. SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY POPS: July 21-Aug. 4. SAN LUIS OBISPO MOZART FESTIVAL: Aug. 1-7. Concerts at 10 sites around the county. Participants include Christopher Hogwood, Malcolm Bilson, Jeffrey Kahane, the Classical and Franciscan String Quartets. A week of lectures precedes the festival. STERN GROVE FESTIVAL: San Francisco, June 19-Aug. 21. Free Sunday concerts by the San Francisco Symphony under Andrew Massey, Midsummer Mozart Festival Orchestra under George Cleve, San Francisco Opera forces under Ian Robertson, Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Mongo Santamaria, others. SUMMERFEST '88: La Jolla, Aug. 20-30. The La Jolla Chamber Music Society, Heiichiro Ohyama, artistic director. Participants include Ani Kavafian, Thomas Zehetmair, Ralph Kirshbaum, Jeffrey Kahane. Colorado ARTSFEST '88: Boulder, July 9-17. The University of Colorado sponsors a ''Boulder Celebration'': ''Ruddigore'' and ''H. M. S. Pinafore'' from the Colorado Gilbert and Sullivan Festival; events from the Colorado Music Festival; the Queen City Jazz Band; others. ASPEN MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 24-Aug. 21. In the festival's 40th season, celebrations of the 60th birthday of Jacob Druckman, and the bicentenary of Australia, with works by Peter Sculthorpe, Vincent Plush and Andrew Ford. Composers figure prominently, with Earle Brown, Earl Kim and Bernard Rands among those in residence, others appearing for the Fromm Week of New Music, Aug. 5-9. Conductors are music director Jorge Mester, Sergiu Comissiona, James DePreist, Lawrence Foster, Yoel Levi, Claudio Scimone, Jerzy Semkow, Murry Sidlin and others. Along with the resident American Brass Quintet and American, Cleveland and Emerson String Quartets, performers include Jan DeGaetani, Elmar Oliveira, Midori, Matt Haimovitz, James Galway and Terra Australis Incognita. ''Don Giovanni'' and ''Falstaff'' are staged, ''Dido and Aeneas'' and ''Salome'' given in concert. BRAVO COLORADO: Vail, Beaver Creek, July 2-Sept. 4. A new organization coordinating performing arts activities in the Vail Valley. Central is the classical and jazz series ''Masters of Music,'' July 29-Aug. 14, with Lydia Artymiw, Ida and Ani Kavafian, Walter Trampler, Richard Stoltzman, the Gary Burton Group, others. Additional concerts feature the Colorado Springs Symphony, Denver Chamber Orchestra, Amy Grant, Chuck Mangione, the Supremes. CENTRAL CITY OPERA: July 9-Aug. 13. For an expanded season, the repertoire comprises ''The Ballad of Baby Doe,'' unveiled at Central City in 1958, ''Macbeth,'' ''The New Moon.'' COLORADO MUSIC FESTIVAL: Boulder, June 23-Aug. 5. Music director Giora Bernstein and guests Robert Craft, Eduardo Marturet and Nicholas Goldschmidt offer symphonic, chamber and operatic concerts in the historic Chautauqua Auditorium and elsewhere, including a series ''New Musical Perspectives.'' Among visiting artists are Garrick Ohlsson and the American String Quartet. COMPOSER-TO-COMPOSER: Telluride, Aug. 19-21. A weekend festival of performances, demonstrations and panels follows a new three-day international gathering of composers for private discussions on the state of music, directed by Charles Amirkhanian and John Lifton. Participants include John Adams, Lou Harrison, Sarah Hopkins, Gordon Mumma, Terry Riley, Peter Sculthorpe, Morton Subotnick. The Sheridan Opera House offers premieres, works-in-progress. FOUR CORNERS OPERA: Durango, July 6-10. An American musical theater revue alternates with performances of ''Tosca.'' INTERNATIONAL GUITAR WEEK: Denver, July 9-15. The University of Denver hosts concerts and master classes by Ricardo Iznaola, Jorge Morel, Bucky Pizzarelli. KEYSTONE MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 11-Sept. 4. The Summit Brass opens the season, then the youthful National Repertory Orchestra moves in for more than 70 concerts under music director Carl Topilow, Otto-Werner Mueller and Mark Russell Smith. Soloists include Lucy Shelton, Nathaniel Rosen, Carol Wincenc, Gary Graffman, Doc Severinsen. MUSIC IN OURAY: June 11-25. A historic community between Durango and Grand Junction presents a fifth season of concerts. Daniel Epstein, pianist of the resident Raphael Trio, is artistic director. MUSIC IN THE MOUNTAINS: Estes Park, June 26-Aug. 21. Concerts at the Rocky Ridge Music Center by the Monte Verde String Quartet, symphonic and choral ensembles, resident and visiting artists. SYMPHONY IN THE SAN JUANS: Durango, May 28-30. Two concerts by the New Mexico Symphony at the Tamarron resort. Connecticut CHARLES IVES CENTER FOR AMERICAN MUSIC: New Milford, Aug. 15-20. A focus on percussion, with Raymond DesRoches's New Jersey Percussion Ensemble in residence. CHARLES IVES CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS: Danbury, July 3-Aug. 21. Conductors are Michael Barrett, Skitch Henderson, Jens Nygaard, Constantine Kitsopoulos. Also jazz, ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' CHESTNUT HILL CONCERTS: Madison, Aug. 5-26. Friday programs ranging from Baroque to modern, Ransom Wilson music director. CONNECTICUT EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL: Mystic, New London, Noank, June 10-26. John Solum and Igor Kipnis offer concerts, including a Bach St. John Passion led by Albert Fuller. Featured performers are Judith Nelson, Charles Bressler, Robert White, William Parker, Daniel Stepner, Michel Piguet. CONNECTICUT FESTIVAL OF AMERICAN MUSIC THEATER: Stamford, Westport, July 7-31. Concerts by Martin Josman's National Chorale range from ''Sweethearts'' and ''Candide'' to ''Sunday in the Park with George.'' HARTT SUMMER CONCERTS: West Hartford, June 12-July 22. The University of Hartford's music school presents the Greater Hartford Youth Orchestra, Walter Hautzig, Kodaly Summer Institute choirs, others. LEVITT PAVILION: Westport, June 21-30. Free, the Drifters in a ''History of Rock 'n' Roll,'' Neil Sedaka, the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra under Thomas Crawford, others. MUSIC MOUNTAIN: Falls Village, June 11-Sept. 11. Weekend concerts by the Manhattan, Sibelius Academy, Brodsky, Leontovitch, Meliora and Brunswick String Quartets. NEW HAVEN JAZZ FESTIVAL: July 9-Aug. 6. Saturdays with Angela Bofil, Spyro Gyra, the Glenn Miller Orchestra, others. NEW HAVEN SYMPHONY: New Haven and environs, June 3-July 3. Murry Sidlin conducts nine outdoor concerts. NORFOLK CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 1-Aug. 6. Concerts from the Yale Summer School of Music. Featured are the Tokyo String Quartet, the New York Brass Quintet, the Seraphim Trio and the Norfolk Chamber Orchestra, as well as singers from New York's two major opera houses in an evening of arias and ensembles. Schubert's music gets heavy play, and the Litchfield County Choral Union offers Durufle's ''Requiem.'' OAKDALE CONCERT SERIES: Wallingford, June 16-Sept. 16. Victor Borge, Bernadette Peters, Harry Belafonte, Pete Seeger, Arlo Guthrie, Dionne Warwick, many more. OPERA THEATER OF CONNECTICUT: Clinton, Aug. 12-21. ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' on weekends. STARLIGHT FESTIVAL OF MUSIC: New Haven, June 28-July 19. Tuesdays in the Yale Law School courtyard, fiddler Marie Rhines, the Bridgeport Chamber Orchestra under Yuval Waldman, others. SUMMER MUSIC: Waterford, New London, Norwich, July 16-Aug. 20. Classical music and jazz in Harkness Park and elsewhere, featuring Richard Stoltzman, Hermann Baumann, Empire Brass, the Manhattan String Quartet, Odetta, the Dukes of Dixieland. Delaware DELAWARE VOCAL ARTS FESTIVAL: Newark, June 1-4. The fifth in a series sponsored by the University of Delaware. Phyllis Bryn-Julson, Glenda Maurice, Tom Krause and Graham Johnson give concerts, master classes. District of Columbia CAPITOL WEST LAWN CONCERTS: May 29, July 4, Sept. 4. Free performances by the National Symphony, with Mstislav Rostropovich and Erich Kunzel among the conductors. KENNEDY CENTER: May 15-Sept. 30. Four programs from New York's Mostly Mozart Festival, July 6-9, amid numerous concerts by the National Symphony, including a performance of Mahler's ''Symphony of a Thousand'' by Mstislav Rostropovich. The Los Angeles Philharmonic appears under Andre Previn, the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta. Also ''Les Miserables'' ballet. LIBRARY OF CONGRESS SUMMER CHAMBER FESTIVAL: June 14-28. Free concerts in the Coolidge Auditorium, including works by Americans Amy Beach, William Bolcom, Bruce Saylor. Florida MUSIC FESTIVAL OF FLORIDA: Sarasota, May 29-June 18. Chamber and orchestral concerts by Joseph Silverstein, Samuel Baron, Dale Clevenger, Robert Levin and other faculty members. Paul Wolfe is artistic director and conductor. TAMPA BAY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER: July 1-Sept. 5. The summer program begins with Chick Corea and Herbie Hancock, ends with a Labor Day weekend of Dixieland jazz, featuring Al Hirt, the Ink Spots. Hawaii KAPALUA MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 3-12. Seven weekend concerts at the Kapalua Bay Hotel on Maui, Yizhak Schotten music director. Performers include the Fine Arts Brass Quintet, Michele Zukovsky, Sadao Harada. Idaho ELKHORN MUSIC FESTIVAL: Sun Valley, Aug. 2-21. Free chamber-orchestra concerts conducted by the festival's founder, Carl Eberl, with guests. FESTIVAL AT SANDPOINT: July 24-Aug. 14. Established to train musicians, the festival offers concerts on the shores of Lake Pend Oreille. Artistic director Gunther Schuller brings his New England Ragtime Ensemble; the Spokane Symphony is in residence. SUN VALLEY MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 25-July 24. Classical music and jazz, with the New York Chamber Soloists, Orford String Quartet, McKim Piano Trio, Electric Phoenix. Illinois GRANT PARK CONCERTS: Chicago, June 24-Aug. 28. Free concerts by the Grant Park Symphony. Principal conductor Zdenek Macal leads Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony in memory of Harold Washington, ''Ma Vlast'' to mark the 20th anniversary of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. Other conductors include George Cleve, David Amram, Nicholas McGegan, Hugh Wolff, Mitch Miller. Among the soloists are Roberta Alexander, Sergiu Luca, Hermann Baumann, Andre Watts and Alexander Toradze. Giorgio Lamberti stars in ''Otello,'' conducted by Leonard Slatkin. RAVINIA FESTIVAL: Highland Park, June 24-Sept. 4. The Montreal Symphony opens the season at the Chicago Symphony's summer home, under Charles Dutoit. The Chicago arrives in July, going operatic: festival music director James Levine conducts concert versions of ''Die Walkure,'' Act I, with Jessye Normann and Gary Lakes, and ''Don Giovanni,'' with Kathleen Battle, Thomas Hampson and Renato Capecchi. Guest conductors are Dennis Russell Davies, Yuri Temirkanov, Edo De Waart, David Zinman, James Conlon and, with an early-instrument ensemble, Christopher Hogwood. Soloists include Benita Valente, Aprile Millo, Alicia de Larrocha, Leon Fleisher, Shura Cherkassky, Vladimir Feltsman, Itzhak Perlman, Shlomo Mintz, Midori, Mel Torme and Doc Severinsen. Also a visit by the Israel Philharmonic under Kurt Masur, a ''New Perspectives'' survey, a series by the Tokyo String Quartet, chamber concerts, recitals, dance, a jazz and contemporary-music series. Indiana BALL STATE UNIVERSITY SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Muncie, June 12-July 7. Eight free concerts by faculty artists. FIREFLY FESTIVAL: South Bend, June 25-Aug. 6. Musical variety outdoors, including ''Hello, Dolly,'' the Glenn Miller Orchestra, Newton Wayland leading the Midwest Pops. INDIANA UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MUSIC SUMMER FESTIVAL: Bloomington, June 29-Aug. 6. Opera Theater presentations of ''A Little Night Music'' and ''The Barber of Seville,'' orchestral and band concerts, performances by Karen Shaw, the Amadeus and Beaux Arts Trios and Fine Arts Quartet. SYMPHONY ON THE PRAIRIE: Indianapolis, June 25-July 30. Concerts by the Indianapolis Symphony on the grounds of Conner Prairie Pioneer Settlement. Conductors are Raymond Leppard, William Henry Curry, Joel Levine. Iowa DES MOINES METRO FESTIVAL OF OPERA: Indianola, June 17-July 10. ''The Barber of Seville,'' ''Turandot'' ''The Magic Flute.'' Maine ARCADY MUSIC FESTIVAL: Bangor and environs, July 24-Aug. 31. Concerts by Kenneth Cooper, Carol Wincenc, Julius Baker, others. ATLANTA VIRTUOSI AT BATES COLLEGE: Lewiston, July 15-Aug. 1. Concerts directed by Juan Ramirez. BAR HARBOR FESTIVAL: July 15-Aug. 14. Chamber concerts and recitals by Judith Burbank, the Annapolis Brass Quintet, Cassatt String Quartet, others. Artistic director Francis Fortier conducts string orchestra concerts, including one in Acadia National Park. BAY CHAMBER CONCERTS: Rockport, July 7-Sept. 1. Thursday and Friday concerts, Thomas Wolf artistic director. Four programs with the Vermeer Quartet and guests, others with Leonard Hokanson, Jeffrey Kahane, Ruth Laredo, Leslie Parnas. BOWDOIN COLLEGE: Brunswick, June 25-Aug. 6. Chamber performances by faculty and resident artists, including Edward Auer, Syoko Aki, Paul Doktor, the Aeolian Chamber Players, Bowdoin Trio and Vermeer Quartet. Composers-in-residence for the Gamper Festival of Contemporary Music, July 20-23, are Alvin Brehm, Glen Cortese, George Crumb, Robert Rodriguez, Elliott Schwartz. KNEISEL HALL SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Blue Hill, June 26-Aug. 14. Weekend faculty chamber concerts. Guests include Leslie Parnas and the Stanford and Vermeer String Quartets. Artistic director Seymour Lipkin and Artur Balsam play post-season Beethoven recitals, Aug. 17-21. MT. DESERT FESTIVAL OF CHAMBER MUSIC: Northeast Harbor, July 12-Aug. 9. Tuesday concerts with an expanded roster of artists for the 25th-anniversary season, including Sahan Arzruni and Henry Schuman. PIERRE MONTEUX SCHOOL FOR CONDUCTORS AND ORCHESTRA PLAYERS: Hancock, June 19-July 28. Sunday concerts directed by Charles Bruck. SACO RIVER FESTIVAL: Cornish, July 7-Aug. 15. Chamber concerts and recitals with the Atlanta Virtuosi, Portland Brass Quintet, New England Piano Quartette, Mannheim Quartet, Peter Sykes, Frank Glazer. Maryland NATIONAL ORCHESTRAL INSTITUTE: College Park, June 10-July 2. Concerts by participants in the University of Maryland training program under resident conductors Andrew Litton, Jorge Mester, David Zinman. SUMMERFEST 1988: Baltimore, July 9-30. David Zinman leads the Baltimore Symphony in five concerts of mostly Beethoven, followed by one of mostly Johann Strauss 2nd. UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND INTERNATIONAL PIANO FESTIVAL AND WILLIAM KAPELL COMPETITION: College Park, July 14-23. Recitals by Nelson Freire, Claude Frank, Bella Davidovich, Oleg Maisenberg, Joseph Kalichstein, others. The final competition round is at Washington's Kennedy Center with the Rochester Philharmonic under Stanislaw Skrowaczewski. WORLD CELLO CONGRESS: College Park, June 7-11. The first such international event, with symposia, lecture recitals, exhibitions and concerts at the University of Maryland. Congress president Mstislav Rostropovich conducts two concerts in Washington: a concerto event with the National Symphony at Kennedy Center, an ensemble evening at Constitution Hall. Massachusetts AMHERST FESTIVAL: July 10-23. Faculty of the Dorothy Taubman School of Piano and guest artists in recital. ASTON MAGNA: Great Barrington, July 9-23. Saturday concerts of 17th- and 18th-century music on period instruments. Artistic director John Hsu conducts; performers include Malcolm Bilson, Louis Bagger, Stanley Ritchie, Stephen Hammer. BERKSHIRE CHORAL INSTITUTE: Sheffield, July 9-Aug. 13. Performances of ''Elijah,'' ''The Creation,'' Beethoven's ''Missa Solemnis,'' others, under Amy Kaiser, Charles Dodsley Walker, Raymond Harvey, David Stivender and Robert Page. BERKSHIRE FRIENDS OF BAROQUE MUSIC: Great Barrington, July 30-Aug. 13. The Boston Museum Trio in Saturday concerts. BERKSHIRE OPERA COMPANY: Lee, July 8-Aug. 14. A gala benefit followed by ''La Perichole'' and ''Il Matrimonio Secreto.'' BOSTON POPS: May 15-July 4. The traditional Symphony Hall affairs and free concerts on the Charles River Esplanade. Conductors include John Williams, Harry Ellis Dickson, Erich Kunzel and John Mauceri. CAPE & ISLANDS CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Hyannis, Wellfleet, Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard, July 31-Aug. 20. Samuel Sanders is artistic director, George Tsontakis composer-in-residence. Performers include Ruth Laredo, Stephanie Chase, Ransom Wilson. CHILMARK CHAMBER PLAYERS: July 11-Aug. 16. Monday and Tuesday concerts directed by Caroline Worthington and Delores Stevens. COMPOSERS CONFERENCE, CHAMBER MUSIC CENTER AND SINGERS WORKSHOP: Wellesley, July 31-Aug. 14. Free concerts by staff members at Wellesley College. Mario Davidovsky directs the Composers Conference; Fred Lerdahl and George Walker are guest composers. GREAT WOODS CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS: Mansfield, July 13-Aug. 11. At its summer home, the Pittsburgh Symphony gives 12 concerts. Michael Tilson Thomas is music adviser; other conductors are Gerard Schwarz, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Andrew Davis, John Dankworth and Michael Lancaster. Soloists include Leontyne Price, Vladimir Felstman, Midori and Cleo Laine. Kurt Masur appears with the Israel Philharmonic. Also jazz and dance throughout the summer. JACOB'S PILLOW NEW MUSIC SERIES: Becket, July 3-Aug. 24. Terra Australis Incognita, the Even Orchestra, World Saxophone Quartet. MARBLEHEAD SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 10-Aug. 14. Sunday concerts by the Cambridge Chamber Players, Robert Stallman artistic director. Guest performers include D'Anna Fortunato, John Gibbons. MARTHA'S VINEYARD SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Edgartown, July 6-Aug. 31. Chamber music and jazz by the Paradise City Jazz Band, Evolutionary Jazz Ensemble, others. MOHAWK TRAIL CONCERTS: Charlemont, July 8-Aug. 13. Weekend chamber concerts by Bolcom and Morris, Arnold and Victor Steinhardt, Michael Newman, others. The series is preceded by chamber-orchestra concerts under Abba Bogin in Shelburne Falls and Greenfield, June 11 and 28. MONOMOY CHAMBER ENSEMBLE: Chatham, Wellfleet, July 27-30. The group celebrates its 20th anniversary with a new work by Stanley Babin, who performs with artistic director Eleanor Lawrence, Galina Heifetz, Eugene Moye. NORTH SHORE MUSIC THEATER: Beverly, June 13-Sept. 18. Productions of ''My One and Only,'' ''Dreamgirls,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''The Desert Song''; concerts and shows by the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Barbara Cook, Judy Collins, Harry Belafonte, others. PROVINCETOWN PLAYHOUSE MUSE SERIES: July 1-Aug. 31. Concerts by Dave McKenna, Tom Paxton, Odetta, others. ROCKPORT CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 2-26. Concerts by the Manhattan and Meliora String Quartets, Scarborough Chamber Players, An die Musik, others. SEVENARS CONCERTS: Worthington, July 10-Aug. 7. Directed by Rolande and Robert Schrade, this festival celebrates its 20th anniversary with returning artists, including the Colorado String Quartet and Charles Neidich. SOUTH MOUNTAIN CONCERTS: Pittsfield, Aug. 20-Oct. 2. A 70th season of chamber music, featuring the Guarneri, Tokyo and New World String Quartets, Beaux Arts Trio. SUMMER'S WORLD: Worcester, June 4-Aug. 24. This service program celebrates its 20th anniversary with various events, including free concerts by the Pro Jazz and Symphonic Brass Ensembles, others. TANGLEWOOD: Lenox, June 25-Aug. 28. Marking the 50th anniversary of the music shed, a ''season of celebrations,'' notably a series honoring Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday, conducted by Mr. Bernstein, Seiji Ozawa, Michael Tilson Thomas, John Williams and John Mauceri. Among the season's other conductors are Yuri Temirkanov, Hugh Wolff, Helmuth Rilling, Roger Norrington, Leon Fleisher, Charles Dutoit, Gunther Herbig. Soloists include Vladimir Feltsman, Emanuel Ax and Claudio Arrau. The Indiana University Opera Theater stages Mr. Bernstein's ''Mass''; Hildegard Behrens sings ''Elektra'' in concert; Jiri Belohlavek conducts ''Ma Vlast.'' A festival of contemporary music, Aug. 4-10, features works of Elliott Carter and Hans Werner Henze. Also chamber concerts, recitals. Michigan ANN ARBOR SUMMER FESTIVAL: June 25-July 17. In its fifth year, the festival presents Sarah Vaughan, the Count Basie Orchestra, Dukes of Dixieland, Western Wind, a Baroque organ series. INTERLOCHEN ARTS FESTIVAL: June 28-Aug. 21. Faculty and students at the National Music Camp perform. Visiting professionals include the St. Louis Symphony under Leonard Slatkin, Canadian Brass, Alexander Toradze, Chuck Mangione, Crystal Gayle. MATRIX:MIDLAND FESTIVAL: Midland, June 1-18. This multidisciplinary affair celebrates its 10th anniversary with concerts by Karen Beardsley, Crystal Gayle, others. The Detroit Symphony and Empire Brass combine under Stephen Stein in a commissioned work by Michael Torke. MEADOW BROOK FESTIVAL: Rochester, June 16-Sept. 7. The Detroit Symphony plays at its summer home, the campus of Oakland University, under Gunther Herbig, Jerzy Semkow, Julius Rudel, Sixten Ehrling, John Nelson, Varujan Kojian. Among the soloists are Sherrill Milnes, Claudio Arrau, Ruth Laredo, Itzhak Perlman and Ida Haendel. Kurt Masur appears with the Israel Philharmonic, David Zinman with the Chicago Symphony. Also ''Carousel,'' Herb Alpert, Cleo Laine, Bobby Vinton. NORTHWOOD ORCHESTRA FESTIVAL OF THE LAKES: Petoskey, Harbor Springs, July 19-Aug. 5. The festival celebrates its 10th anniversary under founding director and conductor Don Th. Jaeger. Jose Feghali appears. Minnesota MIDSUMMER: Bloomington, June 17-26. Purportedly ''the largest musical event in Minnesota history,'' this new biennial event will feature the music of a different country each time. Here, despite the presence of Al Jarreau, Harry Belafonte and others, it's Sweden. Two performances of Mahler's ''Symphony of a Thousand'' deploy something near the specified number: Neeme Jarvi conducts the resident Gothenburg Symphony, the Minnesota Orchestra, a 600-voice Festival Chorus, childen's chorus and soloists. Also on hand, Elisabeth Soderstrom, Nicolai Gedda, Abba, Swedish fiddlers, Viking horn blowers. ORDWAY MUSIC THEATER: St. Paul, July 8-Aug. 6. The Minnesota Opera offers 35 performances of ''Oklahoma.'' SUMMER NIGHTS AT ORCHESTRA HALL: Minneapolis, May 26-Aug. 9. Concerts by the Minnesota Orchestra, including a Pops series, June 1-July 3, and a Viennese Sommerfest, July 13-Aug. 6. Leonard Slatkin, artistic director of Sommerfest, serves variously as host, demonstrator, pianist, conductor. He leads a concert version of ''Tosca,'' featuring Leona Mitchell and Vasile Moldoveanu. Artists-in-residence are Joseph Silverstein, who conducts four concerts, John Browning, Jeffrey Swann and Lynn Harrell. Murry Sidlin, Robert Marcellus and Jere Lantz conduct. Also free outdoor concerts in surrounding cities, chamber music, recitals, master classes. Missouri CITICORP SUMMERFEST: St. Louis, May 27-June 18. Raymond Leppard is principal guest conductor for the Powell Hall series ''Mozart: The Music He Wrote for the Women He Loved.'' Guest artists include Sylvia McNair, Ursula Oppens, Ilana Vered. OPERA THEATER OF ST. LOUIS: May 21-June 19. The repertoire comprises ''La Boheme,'' ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' ''Oberon,'' and a 30th-anniversary production of Barber's ''Vanessa.'' With the St. Louis Symphony in the pit, music director John Nelson, Roger Nierenberg, Hal France and Joseph Rescigno conduct. Singers include Joan Gibbons, Susan Graham, John David DeHaan, Gaetan Laperriere and David Hamilton, all also featured in Monday noontime concerts at Christ Church Cathedral. ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY QUEENY POPS: June 28-Aug. 13. Richard Hayman is principal conductor in Queeny Park. Guests include Carol Channing, Roger Williams, Doc Severinsen. Montana BIG SKY MUSIC FESTIVAL: Aug. 1-13. A new event created by Fredrica Mann Friedman. Performers include Daniel Heifetz, William Wolfram and the New World Symphony. Proceeds benefit Yellowstone National Park. New Hampshire HOPKINS CENTER: Hanover, June 16-Aug. 27. Sprinkled amidst assorted events at the Dartmouth College auditorium, concerts and recitals by the Hutchinson Family Singers, Odetta, Mozart on Fifth, others. MONADNOCK MUSIC: Greenfield, Jaffrey, July 23-Aug. 24. The festival moves to a new home, a tent atop Crotched Mountain, for its gala series, including a concert performance of ''Don Giovanni.'' James Bolle conducts. Some of the Wednesday recitals, which feature Russell Sherman, Virginia Eskin, Christopher O'Riley and others, are in Jaffrey, a traditional locale. Also traditional: free performances throughout the region in August. MUSIC AT KING RIDGE: New London, July 7-Aug. 25. Thursday concerts by the New Hampshire Music Festival Orchestra under Thomas Nee, the John Gibbons Group, Brodsky String Quartet, New York Consort of Viols, Anton Kuerti, others. NEW HAMPSHIRE MUSIC FESTIVAL: Plymouth, Gilford, July 14-Aug. 19. Thursdays in Plymouth, Fridays in Gilford. Music director Thomas Nee, Jack Graham and Catherine Comet conduct. The several premieres include Hovhaness's ''Loon Lake.'' NORTH COUNTRY CHAMBER PLAYERS: Sugar Hill, Loon Mountain, July 8-Aug. 6. Friday and Saturday concerts. PRESCOTT PARK ARTS FESTIVAL: Portsmouth, July 4-Aug. 14. Musical attractions include the Metropolitan Brass Quintet, ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' barbershop quartet singing, the Hutchinson Family Singers, folk guitar and fiddling. WATERVILLE VALLEY FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS: July 8-Aug. 13. Weekend concerts rang-ing from Russian choral music to country, by the Boston Museum and Wakefield Trios, Carnegie Chamber Players, Count Basie Orchestra, Tammy Wynette, others. New Jersey APOLLO MUSES: Gladstone, July 3-31. A fifth season of Sunday art, theater and chamber music. GARDEN STATE ARTS CENTER: Holmdel, June 29-Aug. 25. Four concerts by the New Jersey Symphony under Victor Borge, Michael Pratt, Hugh Wolff, Serge Fournier. The surrounding season at the center features the Beach Boys, Harry Belafonte, Tom Jones, Johnny Mathis, Dionne Warwick, others. JUNE OPERA FESTIVAL: Lawrenceville, June 5-28. The festival celebrates its fifth anniversary with an expanded season. Following a Gershwin concert, music director Michael Pratt conducts ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' and Britten's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' NEW JERSEY FESTIVAL OF AMERICAN MUSIC THEATER: various cities, July 1-Aug. 4. Martin Josman's National Chorale presents programs in Ramapo, Madison, New Brunswick, Bridgewater and Princeton, including ''Bernstein at 70,'' ''Operetta Tonight'' and ''A Salute to Broadway.'' NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY SUMMER POPS: Princeton, New Brunswick, Madison, July 4-10. Outdoor concerts led by Michael Pratt. RUTGERS SUMMERFEST: New Brunswick, June 16-Aug. 7. In this ambitious arts festival's second season, musical attractions include Charles Wuorinen, Alicia de Larrocha, Nelson Freire, Shura Cherkassky, Abbey Simon, the Tokyo and Colorado String Quartets, Music from Aston Magna, the Metropolitan Opera's outdoor ''Turandot'' and the New Jersey Symphony under Hugh Wolff. On the faculty of the Boxley Institute for piano and chamber music, July 9-31, are Glenn Dicterow, Felix Galimir and Karl Ulrich Schnabel. WATERLOO FESTIVAL AND SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Waterloo, Princeton, June 17-July 25. Orchestral concerts at Waterloo, orchestral and chamber concerts at the Richardson Auditorium in Princeton, all stressing 20th-century and American music. Samuel Lipman is artistic director, Gerard Schwarz principal conductor. Other conductors are Maxim Shostakovich and James DePreist, featured soloists Vladimir Feltsman, Andre Watts, Rudolph Firkusny and Nathaniel Rosen. Elgar's ''The Dream of Gerontius'' is scheduled. New Mexico MUSIC FROM ANGEL FIRE: Angel Fire, Taos, Red River, Raton, Aug. 15-Sept. 5. Ida Kavafian is artistic director, Bruce Adolphe composer-in-residence for the fifth-anniversary season. Performers include Joseph Villa, Fred Sherry, the Gary Burton Group, McLain Family Band. SANTA FE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 10-Aug. 22. Morton Subotnick, composer-in-residence, directs a forum exploring the interaction of man and computer, July 29-30. Performers include Marvis Martin, James Buswell, Ursula Oppens, Alicia Schachter, Igor Kipnis and the Mendelssohn String Quartet. The ''Music of the Americas'' project focuses on Brazil and Villa-Lobos. A three-season Beethoven survey ends; a two-season study of Slavic music begins. SANTA FE DESERT CHORALE: Santa Fe, Albuquerque, June 16-Aug. 23. Five programs, ranging from Byrd to Rochberg, in 25 concerts. SANTA FE OPERA: July 1-Aug. 27. New productions of Penderecki's ''The Black Mask,'' ''Der fliegende Hollander,'' ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' and a Richard Strauss double bill, ''Feuersnot'' and ''Friedenstag,'' as well as a revival of ''Die Fledermaus.'' Conductors are general director John Crosby, Edo De Waart, George Manahan and Richard Bradshaw. TAOS MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 18-Aug. 6. From the Taos School of Music, concerts by students, resident artists Robert McDonald and the American String Quartet and guest Michael Tree. New York ADIRONDACK FESTIVAL OF AMERICAN MUSIC: Saranac Lake, July 4-31. Artistic director Gregg Smith offers choral, orchestral and chamber concerts and, in various Adirondack parks, pops events. Ross Lee Finney attends Meet the Composer Week, July 11-17. ADIRONDACK FESTIVAL OF TRADITIONAL MUSIC: Ticonderoga, July 8-Sept. 4. On Fridays, blues, bluegrass, jazz, other genres. ADIRONDACK LAKES CENTER FOR THE ARTS: Blue Mountain Lake, June 4-Sept. 4. Classical, bluegrass, jazz, folk. ART AWARENESS: Lexington, July 23, Aug. 27. Appearances by Kenny Burrell and the Lexington Chamber Music Society are musical highlights of the multi-arts center's season. ARTPARK: Lewiston, June 29-Sept. 11. In its 15th season, the festival presents ''Gotterdammerung,'' the final installment of its Wagner ''Ring'' cycle. Also on stage are ''Tosca,'' ''Peter Pan,'' ''42nd Street.'' Christopher Keene, president and music director, conducts the Buffalo Philharmonic. Other performers include Leontyne Price, Tony Bennett, Victor Borge, Pearl Bailey, Roy Clark. Also dance. ASTON MAGNA AT BARD: Annandale-on-Hudson, July 8-22. Three Friday performances (see Massachusetts listing). BACH ARIA FESTIVAL AND INSTITUTE: Stony Brook, Roslyn, New York, June 13-27. The Bach Aria Group and assisting artists perform choral, orchestral, solo and chamber works. Samuel Baron is music director. BARGE MUSIC: Brooklyn, all summer long. Chamber music, Thursdays, Sundays. BAROQUE 26: Greenfield Center, Saratoga Springs, July 12-31. Directed by Robert Conant, the festival offers a performance of Bach's B minor Mass, preceded by an open rehearsal and forum; a return appearance by August Wenzinger. BINGHAMTON SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 4-Aug. 9. An expanded season of 20 events on the State University campus. Performers include the New Jersey Symphony under Hugh Wolff, Orchestra of St, Luke's, Jaime Laredo, Harry Belafonte, Tony Bennett. BRIDGEHAMPTON CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: August 6-14. Founding artists Marya Martin, Ani and Ida Kavafian, Fred Sherry and Andre-Michel Schub celebrate the festival's fifth anniversary with the premiere of a commissioned work, Rorem's ''Bright Music for Five Players,'' other repertoire. BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC: July 2-Aug. 7. Concerts throughout Brooklyn conducted by David Amram, Tania Leon, Anton Coppola. BUSCH BLUEGRASS FESTIVAL: Malone, July 2. Six hours at the Ballard Mill Center. CARAMOOR MUSIC FESTIVAL: Katonah, June 25-Aug. 21. The resident Orchestra of St. Luke's is conducted by John Nelson, festival music director, Michael Feldman, Jaime Laredo, Julius Rudel and Raymond Leppard. It also plays chamber concerts, as do the Tokyo, Emerson and Guarneri String Quartets. Soloists and recitalists include James Galway, Richard Stoltzman, Vladimir Feltsman, Rudolf Firkusny and Ruth Laredo. Other attractions are Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg, the Waverly Consort, Canadian Brass, Count Basie Orchestra. CATSKILL CONSERVATORY SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Oneonta environs, Aug.-Sept. Catskill Chamber Players with guest composers. CHAUTAUQUA INSTITUTION: June 25-Aug. 28. Joseph Silverstein conducts most orchestral concerts, including a Verdi ''Requiem'' with the Pittsburgh Mendelssohn Choir. Soloists and recitalists include Andre-Michel Schub, Vladimir Feltsman, Elmar Oliveira. Opera productions are ''Tosca,'' ''The Desert Song,'' ''Susannah,'' ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'' Also Bonnie Raitt, Nancy Wilson, Chuck Mangione. CLASSICAL JAZZ: New York, Aug. 5-10. Concerts in Alice Tully Hall featuring artistic director Wynton Marsalis, Max Roach, Jon Hendricks, Jimmy Heath. CLEARWATER'S GREAT HUDSON RIVER REVIVAL: Valhalla, June 18-19. A landfill near the old venue has been designated a hazardous waste site, so the festival moves inland to Westchester Community College. Jazz, blues, country, folk and ethnic, including Pete and Mike Seeger, the OK Bayou Cajun Band, Laurie Lewis and the Grant Street Band. C. W. POST SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Brookville, July 18-Aug. 5. The Pierrot Consort, ensemble-in-residence at Long Island University, and participants in summer educational programs give chamber and chamber-orchestra concerts. DOBBS FERRY CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 5-26. Four Friday concerts featuring artistic director Ruth Glasser Sommers, Lucy Shelton, Kenneth Cooper, David Oei, Ani Kavafian, Toby Hoffman, Charles Neidich. FRIENDS OF THE ARTS: Oyster Bay, July 3-28. Concerts at the Planting Fields Arboretum by the Israel Philharmonic under Kurt Masur, Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Count Basie Orchestra, Judy Collins, Arlo Guthrie, others. Starting Aug. 26, a Beethoven Festival. GLIMMERGLASS OPERA: Cooperstown, June 25-Sept. 4. ''Don Giovanni,'' ''The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein,'' ''Beatrice and Benedict.'' GOLDMAN MEMORIAL BAND: New York, July-Aug. A 71st season of free concerts, in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, and in Seaside Park, Brooklyn. Ainslee Cox conducts. GUILD HALL SUMMER MUSIC SERIES: East Hampton, May 29-Aug. 28. Concerts featuring the Emerson String Quartet, Robert Taub, Dick Hyman; cabaret evenings with Cissy Houston and others. HUDSON VALLEY CHAMBER MUSIC CIRCLE: Annandale-on-Hudson, June 4-25. Saturday concerts at Bard College by the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, Franciscan String Quartet, William Black, Peter Oundjian. INTERNATIONAL ART OF JAZZ FESTIVAL: Islip, Aug. 27-28. Dave Brubeck, Joe Williams and others at the State University at Stony Brook. JAZZ IN JULY: New York, July 19-28. Midweek concerts at the 92nd Street Y, under the direction of Dick Hyman. Performers include Maureen McGovern, Dorothy Louden. JVC JAZZ FESTIVAL NEW YORK: New York and environs, June 24-July 3. George Wein offers a typically impressive array of stars, including Ella Fitzgerald, Sarah Vaughan, Mel Torme, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis, Wynton Marsalis, Lionel Hampton, Dave Brubeck, Ahmad Jamal and Toshiko Akiyoshi, in halls around the city and at sites in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. LAKE GEORGE OPERA FESTIVAL: Glens Falls, July 16-Aug. 4. Productions of ''The Merry Widow'' and ''The Barber of Seville,'' a gala concert, apprentice showcases, the traditional Opera-on-the-Lake cruises. LAKE PLACID CENTER FOR THE ARTS: June 30-Sept. 2. ''Zorba the Greek,'' ''Godspell,'' American music, the Maplewood Baroque Ensemble. LAKE PLACID SINFONIETTA: July 10-Aug. 14. Sunday performances at the Center for the Arts as well as free park concerts and special events. David Gilbert conducts. L'ENSEMBLE: Cambridge, July 2-Aug. 28. Concerts in a restored 1837 barn. Performers include Robert McDonald and Marian Hahn. LIGHT OPERA OF MANHATTAN: New York, May 15-Sept. 18. The company's summer season includes a new production of ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' revivals of ''Iolanthe,'' ''Naughty Marietta,'' ''The Red Mill,'' ''Give My Regards to Broadway.'' LINCOLN CENTER OUT-OF-DOORS: New York, Aug. 3-31. Some 100 free performances by classical, jazz, folk, dance and theater artists. Tributes to John Cage, Leonard Bernstein, Morton Gould. LONG ISLAND MOZART FESTIVAL: Oyster Bay, May 28-June 5. The Festival Orchestra, Sea Cliff Chamber Players and guests offer concerts and recitals at the Planting Fields Arboretum. MAPLEWOOD MUSIC FESTIVAL: Elizabethtown and environs, July 9-Aug. 28. Baroque and Classical chamber music played on period instruments. MAVERICK CONCERTS: Woodstock, July 3-Sept. 4. In its 73d season, the Sunday series features the Colorado, Emerson and Tokyo String Quartets and other groups. METROPOLITAN OPERA: June 21-July 9. Concert versions of ''Turandot'' and ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' free in Metropolitan area parks and at New Jersey sites. MILLER GENUINE DRAFT CONCERTS: New York, Wantagh, June 15-mid-September. At Manhattan's Hudson River Pier 84 and at Jones Beach, Julio Iglesias, James Taylor, Roy Orbison, Chicago, others. MINNEWASKA CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY: Roslyn, July 9-30. Saturday concerts of classics and jazz at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art. MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL: New York, July 12-Aug. 27. Orchestral, choral and chamber concerts and recitals, Gerard Schwarz music director. David Willcocks leads the Westminster Choir in Mozart's ''Requiem.'' Other guests are Frederica von Stade, Vladimir Feltsman, Christopher Hogwood, the Israel Philharmonic under Kurt Masur and, for a Haydn week, H. C. Robbins Landon. MUNICIPAL CONCERTS: New York boroughs except Manhattan, July 6-Aug. 1. Free concerts in parks and community centers by the Julius Grossman Orchestra. MUSIC AT FISHS EDDY: Aug. 7-28. Mostly early music on original instruments at the Old Pioneer Church on Sundays, Joyce Lindorff artistic director. Performers include Kenneth Cooper and Ensemble Chanterelle. MUSIC IN THE MOUNTAINS: New Paltz, July 3-30. The Festival Orchestra under Gundaris Pone and Festival Chamber Players under Peter Alexander focus on 20th-century music, largely American. On July 23, Vladimir Feltsman appears in recital. NATIONAL CHORALE: New York, June 30-Aug. 5. Martin Josman's group gives 15 concerts throughout the metropolitan area, from Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, to Kensico Park, Westchester. NAUMBURG ORCHESTRA: New York, July 2, July 30. Two free concerts in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, conducted by Jens Nygaard. NEW YORK CITY OPERA: July 6-Sept. 11. The summer segment of the company's season offers two new productions, ''Rigoletto'' and ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'';includes a week-long run of ''The New Moon''; and ends with a two-week run of ''Naughty Marietta.'' NEW YORK GRAND OPERA: July 7-28. Vincent La Selva's company celebrates its 15th anniversary in the Central Park Bandshell with Verdi operas on Thursdays: ''Rigoletto,'' ''I Masnadieri,'' ''La Traviata,'' ''Un Ballo in Maschera.'' NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS: June 11-July 11. The first in a biennial series, this enormously ambitious festival celebrates art and artists of the 20th century, uses most of the city's choice performing spaces and overlaps with several other festivals. Musical attractions include the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta, Gennady Rozhdestvensky and Pierre Boulez, Chicago Symphony under Leonard Bernstein, Philadelphia Orchestra under Yuri Temirkanov, St. Louis Symphony under Leonard Slatkin, Montreal Symphony under Charles Dutoit; the Ensemble InterContemporain, London Sinfonietta, Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society, Juilliard, Chilingirian, Orford and Bartok String Quartets; seven international competition winners in separate recitals; Placido Domingo in Central Park. NEW YORK OPEN CENTER: May 21-Sept. 10. Varied weekend evenings stressing the avant-garde and exotic, featuring Pauline Oliveros, Tony Bird, Steve Gorn and David Darling. NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC: Aug. 1-16. The annual free concerts in metropolitan area parks are conducted by James DePreist, Andrew Davis, Zubin Mehta. OLD SONGS FESTIVAL: Altamont, June 24-26. Traditional music and dance from Ossian, the Green Mountain Cloggers, others. PEPSICO SUMMERFARE: Purchase, July 8-31. Though cutting back to 11 events, the festival remains adventurous. Musical highlights include the American premiere of Cage's ''Europeras 1 & 2''; a new Peter Sellars production of ''The Marriage of Figaro''; a weekend of contemporary British music, attended by composers Harrison Birtwistle, Nigel Osborne, Robert Saxton, Simon Holt and George Benjamin, with performances by the London Sinfonietta, open rehearsals, discussions; Craig Smith conducting Haydn's ''Paris'' Symphonies. Also theater, dance. RIVERSIDE PARK ARTS FESTIVAL: New York, July 1-Sept. 4. Free at the 79th St. Rotunda, classical, contemporary and ethnic music, jazz, dance. Performers include Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers, Mel Lewis, William Duckworth. ROXBURY CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 5-31. The Roxbury Chamber Players perform at various sites in Delaware County. SARATOGA PERFORMING ARTS CENTER: Saratoga Springs, June 15-Aug. 27. The New York City Opera, now the festival's third resident company, opens the amphitheater's season with ''Die Zauberflote,'' ''Madama Butterfly'' and ''The Merry Widow.'' Then come a weekend of Newport Jazz and the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival, July 5-23. Itzhak Perlman joins Dennis Russell Davies, the classical-music program director, in launching the Philadelphia Orchestra season with a tribute to Eugene Ormandy, Aug. 10. SCHROON LAKE BOATHOUSE CONCERTS: July 2-Aug. 27. Weekly concerts of American traditional and bluegrass music. SERIOUS FUN: New York, July 14-Aug. 4. A mixed bag in Alice Tully Hall, including the New York premiere of ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat'' and appearances by Laurie Anderson, Rhys Chatham. SKANEATELES FESTIVAL: Aug. 11-Sept. 3. Chamber and chamber-orchestra concerts. Performers include David Zinman, Jonathan McPhee, Paul Hersh, Steven Doane. SPENCERTOWN CHAMBER MUSIC CONCERTS: June 18-Aug. 27. Concerts by Arnold Steinhardt, Jules Eskin, Yehudi Wyner, Stephen Hough, Lydia Artymiw, the Mendelssohn String Quartet. SUMMER EVENINGS AT SARAH LAWRENCE: Bronxville, June 11-July 3. Concerts featuring the Laurentian and Tokyo String Quartets, New York Consort of Viols, Billy Taylor Jazz Trio, Electric Phoenix, others. SUMMER FESTIVAL AT HUNTER MOUNTAIN: June 30-Sept. 5. Festivals devoted to Italian, German and Celtic music as well as to American traditions: ''golden oldies,'' country, polka, and Indian music. SUMMER PERFORMING ARTS FESTIVAL: East Meadow, June 25-Aug. 7. Free outdoor performances, featuring the Metropolitan Opera in a concert ''Turandot,'' the National Grand Opera in ''Madama Butterfly,'' the New York Philharmonic under James DePreist, others. SUMMERPIER: New York, July 9-Aug. 6. Free Saturday concerts at Manhattan's Pier 16, coupling classical with jazz or new age. SUMMERPO: Canandaigua, July 4-Aug 28. At its summer home, the Finger Lakes Performing Arts Center, the Rochester Philharmonic offers ''Pops'' and ''Favorite Classics'' series under Peter Bay, Jerzy Semkow, Mitch Miller, John Dankworth and Joseph Silverstein. SUMMERSTAGE: New York, June 18-Sept. 4. Free at the Central Park Bandshell, New York Grand Opera (see separate listing), new folk, blues, new music, ''world music.'' Performers include Anthony Davis, Marion Williams, Johnny Copeland, Dissidenten. VANDERBILT COURTYARD CONCERTS: Centerport, July 9-Aug. 20. Stephen Pomerantz conducts the Master Players of New York. WASHINGTON SQUARE FESTIVAL: New York, July 19-Aug. 16. Tali Makell, Henry Schuman, Johannes Somary and Abba Bogin conduct free Tuesday concerts in Washington Square Park. Jazz with the Dean Pratt Big Band. WESTBURY MUSIC FAIR: May-September. John Davidson in ''The Music Man,'' Rex Smith in ''Carousel,'' Mel Torme and Leslie Uggams, Bobby Vinton, Tom Jones, others. WESTCHESTER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Crompond, July 9-Aug. 20. Saturday concerts by the Westchester Chamber Virtuosi, Emanuel Vardi director, with Paula Robison, the Manhattan String Quartet, Lawrence Feldman Jazz Trio, others. North Carolina AN APPALACHIAN SUMMER: Boone, June 20-Aug. 27. At Appalachian State University, the North Carolina Symphony under James Ogle, Broyhill Chamber Ensemble, others. BREVARD MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 22-Aug. 7. Henry Janiec conducts the Music Center Orchestra, David Becker the Transylvania Symphony. Guest soloists include Hildegard Behrens, Elmar Oliveira and Marian McPartland. ''Don Giovanni,'' ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' ''Il Trovatore,'' ''Kismet'' and other works. CULLOWHEE MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 11-25. Western Carolina University hosts orchestral, chamber, solo and operatic performances and a chamber-music competition, with Robert Hart Baker artistic director and guest conductor. The Bowdoin Trio is in residence. EASTERN MUSIC FESTIVAL: Greensboro, June 18-July 30. A summer school on the Guilford College campus offers numerous concerts. Artists-in-residence include Josef Gingold, Franco Gulli, Peter Zazofsky, Heidi Castleman, Nathaniel Rosen, Ruth Laredo. HIGHLANDS CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 17-Aug. 9. Concerts by the resident Alexander String Quartet, others. Ohio BLOSSOM MUSIC CENTER: Cuyahoga Falls, May 25-Aug. 28. The Cleveland Orchestra celebrates its 20th anniversary at its summer home, starting June 17. Among the conductors are Christoph von Dohnanyi, Yuri Temirkanov, Yoel Levi, Jahja Ling, David Zinman, Vladimir Ashkenazy, Leonard Slatkin. CINCINNATI MAY FESTIVAL: May 20-28. James Conlon, music director of this 116-year-old choral festival, conducts all performances: concert versions of ''Luisa Miller'' and ''Treemonisha''; Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony; choral works by Rossini and Stravinsky; sacred music at the Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption in Covington with the new May Festival Youth Chorus. CINCINNATI OPERA: June 23-July 16. The repertory includes ''Carmen,'' ''Susannah,'' ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' ''La Boheme.'' CINCINNATI SYMPHONY AT RIVERBEND: June 10-Aug. 2. Celebrating its fifth anniversary at the Riverbend Music Center, the orchestra is conducted by Jesus Lopez-Cobos, Erich Kunzel, James DePreist. LAKESIDE SUMMER CHAUTAUQUA: June 25-Sept. 4. The Lakeside Symphony performs Aug. 3-26 under Robert Cronquist. The surrounding performing arts festival includes a performance of ''Hello, Dolly.'' LYRIC OPERA CLEVELAND AL FRESCO FESTIVAL: June 30-Aug. 13. With a third production added, the 15th-anniversary season includes ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' ''The Abduction from the Seraglio,'' Cavalli's ''Calisto.'' OHIO BELL JAZZ FESTIVAL: Cleveland, Cuyahoga Falls, June 1-5. Carmen McRae and Ramsey Lewis perform in Severance Hall, Sarah Vaughan, Mel Torme, Dave Brubeck, Lionel Hampton and others at the Blossom Music Center. OHIO CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Columbus, July 9-16. Saturday concerts by the Pro Musica Chamber Orchestra under Timothy Russell. OHIO LIGHT OPERA: Wooster, June 8-Aug. 7. The 10th-anniversary season at Wooster College offers ''Orpheus in the Underworld,'' ''Fra Diavolo,'' ''The Count of Luxembourg,'' ''The Chocolate Soldier,'' ''The Mikado,'' ''The Gondoliers,'' ''Ruddigore.'' PERFORMING ARTS AT OBERLIN: June 12-Aug. 13. A third year of performances stemming from institutes and workshops at Oberlin College, including concert versions of ''The Threepenny Opera'' and Keiser's ''Die edelmuthige Octavia.'' Oklahoma JAZZ IN JUNE: Norman, June 9-12. Outdoors free, and in clubs and restaurants. OK MOZART INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL: Bartlesville, June 10-18. Ransom Wilson, artistic director, and Jahja Ling conduct the resident Solisti New York, with soloists Andras Adorjan, Manuel Barrueco, Joseph Swensen, others. Oregon CASCADE HEAD FESTIVAL: Otis, June 4-19. Weekend classical and jazz concerts in a rustic fire hall by artistic director Sergiu Luca, Atar Arad, Bolcom and Morris, others. CHAMBER MUSIC NORTHWEST: Portland, June 27-July 30. Music-director David Shifrin is joined by Jeffrey Kahane, David Oei, Ida and Ani Kavafian, Walter Trampler, Nancy Allen, Ransom Wilson, David Jolley, others. OREGON BACH FESTIVAL: Eugene, June 19-July 3. At the University of Oregon, Helmuth Rilling music director. Laced with music of Bach, the fare includes Penderecki's ''Polish Requiem,'' conducted by the composer, Brahms's ''German Requiem,'' Verdi's ''Requiem.'' OREGON COAST MUSIC FESTIVAL: Coos Bay, July 15-30. Chamber and symphonic music, bluegrass. PETER BRITT GARDENS MUSIC FESTIVAL: Jacksonville, June 24-Aug. 29. ''Evita,'' Rita Coolidge, Lionel Hampton, Ramsey Lewis, Chuck Mangione. James DePreist becomes music director of the classical season, Aug. 5-22. Pennsylvania AMERICAN MUSIC THEATER FESTIVAL: Philadelphia, June 15-26, Sept. 21-Oct. 2. In 1989, what used to be a fall festival will move to spring. Now in transition, it presents Telson's ''The Warrior Ant'' at the end of spring, Glass's ''1001 Airplanes on the Roof'' at the end of summer. BEDFORD SPRINGS FESTIVAL: Bedford, July 2-Aug. 7. Weekend concerts on the grounds of the historic Bedford Springs Hotel. Soloists include Joseph Silverstein, Barry Snyder, Kathryn Selby. Jacques Brourman conducts. BETHLEHEM MUSIKFEST: Aug. 20-28. In its fifth year, the festival offers more than 500 free performances, others with admission fees. Featured are the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, Marshall Tucker Band, David Amram, Chuck Mangione, Rita Coolidge. MANN MUSIC CENTER SUMMER FESTIVAL: Philadelphia, June 21-Aug. 5. Free concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra. Conductors are Riccardo Muti, Yuri Temirkanov, Leonard Slatkin, Charles Dutoit, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, Zubin Mehta, Sergiu Comissiona, others. MELLON JAZZ FESTIVAL: Philadelphia, June 17-26. Dedicated to Dizzy Gillespie, whose professional career began in Philadelphia. More than 35 events, with Mr. Gillespie, Miles Davis, Lionel Hampton, Dave Brubeck, Wynton Marsalis, B. B. King, Philadelphia players. MUSIC AT GRETNA: Mt. Gretna, June 10-Sept. 4. Chamber music and jazz at the 85-year-old Chautauqua Playhouse. Performers include the Audubon Quartet, Leonardo Trio, Jorg Demus, Ruth Laredo, Larry Coryell, Gary Burton. MUSIC AT PENN'S WOODS: University Park, July 2-23. On the campus of Pennsylvania State University, weekend orchestral concerts conducted by music director James Paul, chamber concerts. PHILADELPHIA FOLK FESTIVAL: Schwenksville, Aug. 26-28. Concerts by Buffy St. Marie, Maria Muldaur, Taj Mahal, the McClain Family Band, others. WILDFLOWER FESTIVAL: White Mills, June 15-Aug. 13.
