Seven Saturday concerts at the Dorflinger-Suydam Wildlife Sanctuary, with the Northeastern Pennsylvania Philharmonic Chamber Players under Hugh Keelan, the Janus Trio, Ethel Ennis, Billy Taylor, others. Puerto Rico CASALS FESTIVAL: San Juan, June 4-18. Mstislav Rostropovich conducts his visiting National Symphony and plays cello solo with the Puerto Rico Symphony. Other participants include music director Odon Alonso, Jerzy Semkow, James Conlon, Eugene Istomin, Nicanor Zabaleta, Anne-Sophie Mutter. Rhode Island NEWPORT MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 11-24. Following a preseason presentation of ''Il Viaggio a Reims'' on July 9, the festival celebrates its 20th anniversary with three concerts daily. Hakan Hagegard appears, honoring 350 years of Swedes in America, and Tatiana Nikolayeva makes her American debut. South Carolina SPOLETO FESTIVAL U.S.A.: Charleston, this Friday through June 5. Music director Sprios Agiris conducts ''Rusalka,'' Richard Strauss's ''Enoch Arden,'' Mahler's Fifth Symphony. Also noteworthy are stagings of ''Herod and the Innocents,'' by the New York Ensemble for Early Music, and Graun's ''Montezuma.'' Tennessee SEWANEE SUMMER MUSIC CENTER: June 25-July 31. Orchestral and chamber concerts by students and faculty at the University of the South. Guest artists include the Blair String Quartet, Sidney Harth, Steven Doane. SUMMER LIGHTS: Nashville, June 2-5. Featuring musicians who call this city home. Texas AMERICAN GUILD OF ORGANISTS NATIONAL CONVENTION: Houston, June 27-July 1. Concerts and recitals around the city, with appearances by King's College Choir, Cambridge. HOUSTON GRAND OPERA: May 25-June 4, July 8-15. As part of its spring festival, free outdoor performances of ''Lucia di Lammermoor.'' In July, the premiere of Philip Glass's ''The Making of the Representative for Planet 8.'' INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL-INSTITUTE AT ROUND TOP: June 10-July 16. Orchestral, chamber, vocal and solo programs featuring artistic director James Dick, Donald Weilerstein, the Colorado String Quartet. Guest conductor is Heiichiro Ohyama. SAN ANTONIO FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS: June 2-19. Highlights are ''Herod and the Innocents'' by the New York Ensemble for Early Music; ''The Impresario'' coupled with P. D. Q. Bach's ''The Stoned Guest''; five concerts by the Third Coast New Music Project. Utah GINA BACHAUER INTERNATIONAL PIANO COMPETITION AND FESTIVAL: Salt Lake City, June 1-25. Free nightly recitals on Temple Square, June 1-12, by David Buechner, Michael Gurt, Martin Jones, Nelita True, Blanca Uribe, others. Vermont CARNEGIE CHAMBER PLAYERS SUMMER FESTIVAL: Norwich, Aug. 2-11. Concerts at the Congregational Church. CHAMBER MUSIC CONFERENCE AND COMPOSERS' FORUM OF THE EAST: Bennington, July 31-Aug. 28. Faculty and participants give concerts and recitals at Bennington College. CRAFTSBURY CHAMBER PLAYERS: Burlington, Hardwick, July 13-Aug. 18. A midweek series supplemented by a preseason event, July 6-7. DISCOVER JAZZ: Burlington and environs, June 9-12. The city teems with jazz, in streets and parks, in restaurants and clubs, on buses and ferries. The Dizzy Gillespie Quintet plays. MANCHESTER MUSIC FESTIVAL: July 4-Aug. 14. Student and faculty concerts at the Southern Vermont Art Center. MARLBORO MUSIC: July 16-Aug. 14. Weekend chamber concerts by Rudolf Serkin's select group of young and experienced artists. Also a Bach choral concert by the Brattleboro Music Center under Blanche Moyse. SUMMER SONATINA LAWN CONCERTS: Old Bennington, June 23-Aug. 4. Programs featuring participants in the piano camp. VERMONT MOZART FESTIVAL: Burlington and environs, July 17-Aug. 6. Concert sites for the festival, in its 15th season, include a cathedral, a ferry boat and a mountaintop. Featured are the New York Chamber Soloists, Festival Winds, Angele Dubeau, Paul Dunkel, others. ''The Mikado'' in concert. YELLOW BARN MUSIC FESTIVAL: Putney, July 3-Aug. 7. Concerts and special events, featuring resident artists, Eric Rosenblith and David and Janet Wells, and guests, the Classical Quartet and John Cage. Virginia ASH LAWN-HIGHLAND SUMMER FESTIVAL: Charlottesville, June 26-Aug. 28. Chamber concerts at the home of James Monroe by the Washington Chamber Society, Garth Newel Chamber Players, Albemarle Ensemble and Monticello Trio. Productions of ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' ''The Elixir of Love'' and ''Cenerentola,'' all outdoors. FESTIVAL WILLIAMSBURG: May 19-22. The Festival Williamsburg Chorus makes its debut in Schubert's Mass in E flat. Judith Pierce, the Norfolk Pro Musica, others. GARTH NEWEL SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: Hot Springs, July 2-Sept. 4. The Garth Newel Chamber Players and guests in weekend concerts. HAMPDEN-SYDNEY MUSIC FESTIVAL: May 30-June 12. Weekend chamber programs by Eugene Drucker, Aaron Rosand, Raphael Hillyer, Yehuda Hanani, Seymour Lipkin and Edward Auer at Hampden-Sydney College. WOLF TRAP: Vienna, June 2-Sept. 6. The National Symphony plays under Mstislav Rostropovich, Hugh Wolff, James Conlon and Jerry Goldsmith, the Philadelphia Orchestra under Yuri Temirkanov, the Israel Philharmonic under Kurt Masur. The Wolf Trap Opera Company offers ''The Love for Three Oranges,'' ''Don Giovanni'' and ''The Rape of Lucretia,'' and the New York City Opera adds ''New Moon,'' ''The Magic Flute'' and a ''Cavalleria Rusticana''/''Pagliacci'' double bill. Joel Grey appears in ''Cabaret.'' Washington NORTHWEST FOLKLIFE FESTIVAL: Seattle, May 27-30. Traditional and ethnic music. OLYMPIC MUSIC FESTIVAL-CONCERTS IN THE BARN: Quilcene, June 25-Aug. 21. Concerts by the Philadelphia String Quartet and guest artists Bayla Keyes, Thalia Moore, Paul Hersh, Justin Blasdale, others. SEATTLE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL: June 27-July 22. Concerts involving Ken Noda, Jon Kimura Parker, Stephanie Chase, Marcus Thompson, Ronald Thomas, James VanDemark, others. Toby Saks is founder and artistic director. Wisconsin MILWAUKEE SYMPHONY: July 4-Aug. 7. Indoor and outdoor concerts. Zdenek Macal conducts Beethoven's Ninth Symphony; JoAnn Falletta takes over for evenings with Marvin Hamlisch and Cab Calloway. Robert Merrill and Erich Kunzel are guest artists. PENINSULA FESTIVAL: Fish Creek, Aug. 3-20. Nine orchestral concerts, guest soloists. SUMMER EVENINGS OF MUSIC: Milwaukee, July 3-24. Sundays at the Pabst Theater with the Fine Arts Quartet. Wyoming GRAND TETON MUSIC FESTIVAL: Teton Village, July 6-Aug. 20. Ling Tung, music director, conducts a 100-member orchestra; Lionel Party directs Baroque programs. Canada BANFF FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS: Banff, Alberta, June 4-Aug. 20. Highlights include Britten's ''Albert Herring'' and ''The Rape of Lucretia,'' and numerous recitals featuring faculty of the Banff Center School of Fine Arts, such as Ruth Laredo, Gilbert Kalish, Menahem Pressler, Robert Aitken, Alan Civil. FESTIVAL INTERNATIONAL DE JAZZ DE MONTREAL: Montreal, Quebec, July 1-10. More than 1,000 musicians in 250 concerts. FESTIVAL ORFORD: Orford, Quebec, June 30-Aug. 13. Some 40 concerts, classical and jazz, featuring the Radio Canada Sinfonietta, Idel Biret, Jean-Louis Steuerman, the Modern Jazz Quartet, Oliver Jones Trio, others. GUELPH SPRING FESTIVAL: Guelph, Ontario, May 19-June 5. Sydney Hodkinson conducts his jazz-based opera ''St. Carmen of the Main.'' Other performers include Nancy Argenta, Beverley Johnston, Robert Aitken, Richard Stoltzman. VICTORIA INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL: Victoria, British Columbia, July 14-Aug. 27. Concerts in five different venues. Featured artists include Daniel Heifetz, Harvey Shapiro, Gary Karr, Bonita Boyd, Han De Vries, Robin and Rachelle McCabe and Bela Siki. Canada Opera Piccola offers ''Cosi Fan Tutte.''

title: Putting Public Works in Quasi-Public Hands
description: IF the 10-year capital spending plan proposed by Mayor Koch last week meets all its goals, New York City should be able to build garbage disposal plants, highways and bridges more quickly and cheaply than before. The key to this minor fiscal miracle would be the creation of three independent authorities, one to supervise the construction and financing of each kind of project.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Long Island;
Sophistication Heads East in a Huge Suffolk Project
description: LEAD: FOR corporations in search of high visibility, a location directly on the Long Island Expressway, the region's main west-to-east artery, is always in demand if the building is also outstanding in its architecture and amenities.

title: Miss Cook Weds Lawrence J. Platt
description: The marriage of Carleen Durand Cook, the daughter of Laurens Irving Cook and Elizabeth Cook McCabe, both of Boston, to Lawrence Jay Platt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervyn Platt of Trenton, took place yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Forrester Church, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: A GENIUS FOR FREINDSHIP AND A TALENT FOR HATRED
description: LEAD: KATHERINE MANSFIELD A Secret Life. By Claire Tomalin. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Greensward Care Without Pesticides
description: FINISH planting crops such as lettuce, chard, beets, carrots; harvest peas just before cooking for best flavor. Check ornamentals for immature insect pests and control, if found. Prepare soil well before planting young shrubs and perennials. Snap off faded flowers from daffodils and tulips to prevent seed pods. Transplant self-sown seedlings to flower borders for summer display. Lawn Care

title: Suburbs Losing Ground In Battles for Tenants
description: THESE are not the best times for developing suburbs. Conceived as havens from the ailments of crowded central business districts, the suburban office centers, from riverside to corporate countryside, are going through a period of adjustment in which they are becoming more like urban centers.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lake Moxie, Me.; Preservation, With Houses
description: A DEVELOPMENT partnership is selling large tracts for single-family houses overlooking several scenic lakes near here, and is taking the unusual step of imposing land-use restrictions more stringent than those required by state law.

title: Sade's Offenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday about Abdi Bile, the Somalian runner, gave an incorrect world record for the 400 meters. The record, set by Harry Reynolds of Ohio State, is 44.10 seconds.

title: Savoring the Season's Fresh Tastes: In Wine Drinks
description: SUMMER FRUITS COMBINE beautifully with wine to make elegant cocktails, refreshing coolers and punches and even seductive dessert drinks. The possibilities are infinite.

title: Mamaroneck Day Care
description: Plans are under way to begin the county's first municipally run, all-day child-care facility for working parents. With the aid of $10,000 appropriated by the Trustees of the village of Mamaroneck, the day-care center will open in January 1989.

title: COSMIC CONNECTIONS AND EROTIC SALVATION
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF OCTAVIO PAZ 1957-1987. Edited by Eliot Weinberger. Translated by Eliot Weinberger with Elizabeth Bishop, Paul Blackburn, Lysander Kemp, Denise Levertov, John Frederick Nims, Mark Strand and Charles Tomlinson. 669 pp. New York: New Directions. $37.50. CONVERGENCES Essays on Art and Literature. By Octavio Paz. Translated by Helen Lane. 303 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Sports of The Times; From Little Eva to Whale Walters
description: There was once a catcher for the San Diego Padres named Gwosdz, called Eyechart by his teammates, though he was known to his family as Douglas.

title: WHAT'S DOING ON: The Eastern Shore
description: The bumper sticker reads ''There's No Life West of the Chesapeake Bay,'' and the philosophy behind it is at the heart of life on Maryland's Eastern Shore.

title: U.S. Prepares To Cite State For Violating Clean-Air Act
description: FEDERAL officials have taken the first step toward putting the state on a list of areas that have not met clean-air standards, a move that could result in sanctions this year.

title: Q and A
description: Touring China

title: A Billion Potential Customers at Risk for Malaria
description: SOME of the greatest opportunities for new vaccines will be in developing countries. There could be up to a billion potential customers for a malaria vaccine alone in the years following its introduction. The problem, said Mr. Ratafia, the market researcher, is ''third world countries just can't afford to pay much for vaccines.''

title: Cleaning Fireplaces
description: MOST fireplace owners know the importance of having chimneys cleaned regularly. Doing so prevents the buildup of sooty deposits inside them, which can cause a fire, and also keeps fireplaces functioning efficiently and with less smoke.

title: A Fashion Exhibit in Black and White
description: LEAD: BLACK and white has through the ages sparked the design of dramatic fashions, settings and gala celebrations. At the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, the combination is used as a catalyst for an exhibition called ''An Elegant Contrast: Fashions in Black and White.''

title: Liza Donnelly, an Artist, Is Wed to Michael Maslin
description: Liza Donnelly, a writer and illustrator of children's books for Scholastic Inc., was married yesterday to Michael Maslin, a cartoonist for The New Yorker, at the Oswego Friends Meeting House in Moore Mills, N.Y.

title: Giants Perk Up Against Mets As Krukow Outduels Darling
description: There are some things apparently that not even the mighty Mets can control. The strange fate that stymies Ron Darling. The strange spell that makes Mike Krukow the master of the Mets. The swirling winds of Candlestick Park.

title: Family Finds Cocaine In a Box of Macaroni
description: A box of Kraft macaroni whose cheese packet contained a pink balloon filled with cocaine was found by a Watertown family in what officials believe is an isolated incident.

title: A Clarifying Word, Literary Division
description: I must commend Lynne Ames on her article on The Hudson Group of freelance writers in Westchester [ ''Freelance Writers Find Familiarity Breeds Contentment,'' April 24 ] . Her article in general catches the flavor of this unique group.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Brideshead Revisited Starring Jeremy Irons, Anthony Andrews, Diana Quick, Laurence Olivier, John Gielgud, Claire Bloom, Mona Washbourne. Directed by Charles Sturridge and Michael Lindsay-Hogg. 1982. Virgin Vision. Six cassettes of 98 minutes each; Not rated.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The 10-Year Plan; Broadening the City's Housing Agenda
description: IN contrast to the paltry role of the Federal Government and New York State in housing, New York City has an ambitious long-term housing production program. It relies on a modest amount of state support, assumes no Federal contribution and depends upon huge amounts of spending from the city's capital budget.

title: Michael Weller's Landscape of the Heart
description: Since 1971, when ''Moonchildren'' had its premiere at the Royal Court Theater in London under the title ''Cancer,''

title: Longer Seasons and Shorter Fuses
description: WHENEVER there is an unusual run of violence or near-violence in professional sports, it attracts the anguished attention of various moralists and concerned parents. Their worry is that sports is reflecting the worst in our national character - the itch to kill thy neighbor - or providing nasty role models for Little Leaguers.

title: High Inflation Is Weakening Turkish Chief
description: The newspapers here are no friends of Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, and so it seemed the norm when an editor compared the Turkish leader's fortunes to those of a fairy-tale magician well past the hour when miracles turn to mush.

title: Mitterrand Dissolves Assembly and Calls Elections
description: President Francois Mitterrand today decreed the dissolution of the National Assembly and called fresh parliamentary elections for next month that his Socialist Party is favored to win.

title: Amy Avellone to Wed Dr. Jeffrey J. Viscardi
description: Amy Barrett Avellone, an assistant account executive with Kallir, Philips, Ross in New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Joseph Viscardi, a resident in ophthalmology at the State University Health Science Center at Brooklyn, plan to be married in September.

title: SAVED BY THE TV CREW
description: THE DAY OF CREATION By J. G. Ballard. 254 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Nancy Adams, an Editor, To Wed Bruce Dexter Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winn Adams of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Lee Adams to Bruce P. Dexter Jr., a son of Mrs. Dexter of Prairie Village, Kan., and the late Mr. Dexter. The couple plan to marry July 9.

title: Panny Thomas and Mac King Are Wed in Jersey
description: Leeanne M. Thomas, a daughter of Leeds Mitchell Jr. of Barrington, R.I., and Mrs. Guy B. Mercer of Bristol, R.I., was married yesterday to Richard M. King, a son of Phillis Mader of Bismarck, Ark., and the late Richard M. King of Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Meredith Hutchison performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Rutherford, N.J.

title: THE F.B.I. ON THE DEFENSIVE ONCE AGAIN
description: THINGS WILL NEVER GET OUT OF hand again the way they did under Mr. Hoover, but you can believe what your suspicions tell you: there is still a conservative, right-wing mentality among some agents working security. Paranoia is rampant. It scares me.''

title: Chemical Company Convicted of Illegal Dumping
description: A chemical distribution company with a long record of pollution violations has been convicted on criminal charges of illegally storing and dumping hazardous wastes at its plant here.

title: Albany Board Seeking a Law Barring Brokers as Assessors
description: To prevent conflicts of interest, the State Board of Equalization and Assessment is pressing for legislation that would bar real-estate assessors from holding jobs as real-estate brokers or appraisers in their home towns.

title: Double Vision' Examines the Cultural Identity of Artists
description: THE questions seemed never to have come up in Paris during the 19th and early 20th centuries, but today seem never to stop coming up in New York and other American cities: Can minority artists make the mainstream and keep their cultural identities? Is it possible or even desirable to cultivate these identities in what amounts to a hothouse atmosphere?

title: Was Pete Rose's Suspension Fair?
description: Pete Rose was falsely penalized for misconduct committed by all managers and players over the last 20 years. Let's be honest. For Rose, 10 days would have hurt more because he would have the message and, along with the fine, considered it just. WANDA GREENER River Edge, N.J.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
New Sports Hall of Fame
description: LEAD: The celebration of the reopening of the County Center enters another phase next weekend with ''Citifest at the County Center,'' a three-day festival featuring marching bands, choral and orchestral performances, ethnic food and the dedication of a new Westchester Sports Hall of Fame.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Facade Easements on Historic Buildings
description: LEAD: EVEN as development pressures continue to surge around them, historic buildings are being saved by owners and developers who use a preservation and tax-saving tool known as a facade easement.

title: Bettina Dabney to Wed
description: Bettina Bigelow Dabney and George Allan Abe, graduates of Trinity College in Hartford, plan to marry Aug. 20. Mrs. William R. Waters of Miami and Hyannis Port, Mass., and Lewis S. Dabney of Boston have announced their daughter's engagement to Mr. Abe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Abe of Westport, Conn., and Tokyo. Miss Dabney is a test coordinator at Children's Hospital in Boston. Mr. Abe is an acoustical engineer for Bolt, Beranek & Newman Laboratories in New London, Conn.

title: Review/Dance; Mark Taylor and Friends
description: Mark Taylor, an assured and accomplished modern-dance choreographer, seemed to strive primarily for neatness in a program of new and recent dances presented by Mark Taylor and Friends on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. Neat joins and interlocking body parts were the order of the night, part of the ongoing 3-D at the Joyce festival, as well as neat small surprises and neat abstractions. ''Don't know what I'm doing here,'' a singer intones in the accompaniment to one piece. Mr. Taylor knows too well.

title:
TELEVISION;
Blake Edwards: The Small Screen Can Be Funny
description: LEAD: At the scene of the crime, the bungling cops keep tripping over one another a moment too soon and the newspaper photographer keeps clicking his flash a moment too late.

title: POSTING: Stamford Condos; Victorian Gables Among Glass Boxes
description: A few blocks north of the jumble of glass boxes in the office district of Stamford, Conn., says Leonord W. Cotton, Grove Street was once lined with Victorian gingerbread. Not all the houses were lost. Mr. Cotton, president of Cotlyn Enterprises, patterned the nine buildings of his $7.3 million Cambridge Court, a 25-unit condominium colony he is building at No. 118, on a gabled house across the street. ''Everything else in Stamford is aluminum-siding, condominium architecture,'' he said.

title: Special Today; Commercial Property/Section 13
description: * Foreign investors step up the pace.

title:
THEATER;
A Meditation On Death Gets a New Life
description: LEAD: ''It's the most delicate thing in the world, to do what I did,'' says Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival. What Mr. Papp did was temporarily close down Harry Kondoleon's newest play, ''Zero Positive,'' after a week of previews, 11 days before its scheduled opening night. Within two days, both the leading actor and the director had been replaced.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; Pentagon Plan: The Battle to Mechanize the Military Mind
description: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow.

title: No Headline
description: We gotta get out while we're young 'Cause tramps like us baby we were born to run. - Bruce Springsteen, ''Born to Run''

title: Mice and Men in The Bronx
description: The Bronx Zoo, one of the best things that ever happened to New York, has opened a Mousehouse. A Mousehouse is a place where a visitor may observe 28 varieties of rodent at play.

title: Bruins Win Series to Halt Devils' Ascent
description: The Devils' dream season came to an end tonight after 20 playoff games. They fell one victory short of the Stanley Cup finals by losing to the Boston Bruins, 6-2, in the seventh game of their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Bush as Heir Underlines a Paradox for Republicans
description: WHEN the leader of a democratic society lays his hands on the person he would have as his successor, the gesture can mean everything or nothing. For Vice President Bush, it could end up meaning both.

title: What's a Spa For? Keeping in Shape or Yakking Away
description: ''DO YOU have varicose veins in your legs?'' a fellow middle-aged spa member asks as she enters the whirlpool. I am submerged up to my neck in hot, swirling delight. Flustered and annoyed, I mutter: ''Well . . . I do have a few little spidery veins around the knees.''

title: Playland Report Finds All but One Ride Safe
description: LEAD: ALL but one of the 46 rides at Playland, the county-owned amusement park in Rye, are in safe operating condition, according to an independent consultant's report.

title: Women's Trial Should Be on TV
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elizabeth Scott to Marry David B. Allison in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederickk Corya Scott of New Cannan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizeabeth Anne Scott, to David Bowers Allison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Leslie Allison of New Canaan. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Writer Renews His Hamptons Ties
description: LEAD: WHILE it may be true that one can't go home again, in the literary sense, Lee Davis is willing to give it a try.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Georgia's Onion Without Tears
description: DUE west of coastal Savannah, among pine forests and dusty crossroad towns with names like Santa Claus, Stanleys Store, Jordan, Ohoopee and Daisy, the flat, flourishing fields yield a mild, succulent delicacy. The Vidalia onion - promoted as having a higher sugar content than Coca-Cola, another famous product of Georgia - is squat, thin-skinned, pale and loaded with sweetness.

title: America's New Regional Brews
description: One OF THE MORE INTERESTING attractions in the wine country of Mendocino County, Calif., has nothing to do with wine at all. It's an unprepossessing-looking tavern in the appropriately named town of Hopland, about 90 miles north of San Francisco. An old-fashioned sign announces that it is the Hopland Brewery. But, in fact, Hopland is more than a simple brewery; it's a brewpub, a restaurant and brewery combined. The stainless-steel brewing vats, which everyone can see from the bar, produce 40 barrels of beer each week. Bills of fare posted on the restaurant walls announce which styles are currently available.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Connecticut; Rural East Lyme Lures Within-State Businesses
description: AN office park under construction on a quiet stretch of shoreline in East Lyme is an early indicator of a tilt in Connecticut's commercial space market to the east. There land is still available and demand is growing from in-state companies rather than from relocating New York City corporations.

title: A Critique of Environmental Efforts
description: LEAD: A REPORT that sharply criticizes the county's role in environmental protection and recommends a new department to oversee environmental programs elicited strong reactions last week from county officials, who said the study overlooked successful efforts.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 15, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 2 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.50.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 3 10 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's. 4 3 FLIGHT OF THE OLD DOG, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) Meeting Russia's challenge after it has mastered Star Wars technology. 5 1 DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.50.) A private eye's search for a missing cat takes him on a trip through space and time. 6 2 THE SISTERS, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The rivalry of two sisters, a best-selling novelist and a renowned actress. 7 7 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) An Australian town where men dominate but women rule. 8 2 WINTER HAWK, by Craig Thomas. (Avon, $4.95.) Thwarting a Soviet plot to launch a Star Wars weapon. 9 10 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 10 8 WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Two creatures - one good, one evil - emerge from a secret government laboratory. 11 3 DOOM OF THE DARKSWORD, by Margaret Weis and Tracy Hickman. (Spectra/Bantam, $3.95.) Second volume of a fantasy trilogy. 12 8 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A star jockey has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an arms-selling intrigue. 13 1 SATISFACTION, by Rae Lawrence. (Pocket, $4.95.) Four Radcliffe roommates and the man who shared their lives on the way to fame and fortune. 14 * 24 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 15 * 7 VOWS, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $4.50.) A feisty young woman's romance with her father's business rival in a 19th-century Wyoming town. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 238 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 2 2 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 3 2 GRACE, by James Spada. (Dell, $4.95.) The life of Princess Grace of Monaco. 4 16 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Avon, $4.95.) A professional writer on ''intelligent nonhumans.'' 5 3 ACROSS CHINA, by Peter Jenkins. (Fawcett, $4.95.) The journal of a trek. 6 * 2 INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Changing patterns in love. 7 64 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life as a series of losses. 8 * 12 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Vintage, $10.95.) Australia as a penal colony. 9 80 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 10 * 5 CLOSE PURSUIT, by Carsten Stroud. (Bantam, $4.50.) Life on a homicide squad. 11 * 11 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Berkley, $3.95.) The actress's memories and opinions. 12 * 11 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) Three generations of the Kennedy family. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 8 SOMETHING UNDER THE BED IS DROOLING, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 4 YOU CAN HEAL YOUR LIFE, by Louise L. Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 51 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 4 * 15 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 * 6 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A BLUE MOON IN POORWATER. By Cathryn Hankla. (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) This first novel by the poet and short-story writer Cathryn Hankla opens in 1942 with a young boy hiking barefoot through the snow in hopes of catching a train that's rumored to deliver Christmas toys to mountain children. He wants dolls for his sisters, but ''knows he can stand it, though, if the train does not come; this was the only way he would allow himself the journey.

title: Centenarians Prove To Be Life of the Party
description: LEON BURNESS likes to brag about his family. One son is a doctor and one is a dentist.

title: Deer Isle: Granite, Spruce And the Sea
description: DEER ISLE looks on a map, in the words of a local historian, Vernal Hutchinson, ''like a figure eight drawn by a very shaky hand.'' At high water the sea all but meets at Long Cove and Northwest Harbor and divides the island. Countless coves and inlets run along the island's jagged coastline. Scores of smaller out islands, some no more than pink granite outcrops where cormorants spread their wings to dry, whorl about the shore.

title: On Critics: Dialogue or Diatribe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Coles, Stage Manager, Marries Matthew Aldredge
description: Alison Reed Coles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Coles of Larchmont, N.Y., and Shelter Island, L.I., and Matthew Warren Aldredge, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George N. Aldredge of Dallas, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Isle in Shelter Island by the Rev. Virgil Power.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; A Parable of Computers And Brains
description: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow.

title: Airport Carts
description: To the Editor: I recently read about the introduction of Smarte Cartes at Kennedy International Airport. While I sympathize with the porters who are losing tips, I am delighted that their monopoly has been broken. It is, after all, the needs of the traveling public that should come first.

title: Newark Arts School Marks Its 20th Year
description: LEAD: THE premiere of the ballet ''And Still the Snowflakes Fall'' at Symphony Hall here this afternoon, and its performance tomorrow for 2,800 Newark schoolchildren, mark the 20th anniversary of the Newark Boys Chorus and the Newark Community School of the Arts, which commissioned the work.

title: Yes, the County Still Has Land for Sale
description: LAND, the lack of it, the price of it, the restrictions on it, is the major cause of the soaring cost of new construction in the county, say the brokers who deal in land sales. The most frequently heard aphorism when land is discussed is ''when it's gone, they can't make anymore.'' That sentiment was recently voiced by Anthony Cassetta, head of Cassetta Frank, a Hawthorn-based concern that specializes solely in land sales. According to Mr. Cassetta, however, there is still a surprising amount of vacant land in Westchester.

title: Thruway Bridge To Open May 27
description: MORE than a year after a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed into the rain-swollen Schoharie Creek near Amsterdam, N.Y., the Thruway officials say a replacement bridge is nearing completion and all four of its lanes will be open to traffic by May 27.

title:
IN THE NATION: Springfield, Mass.;
A Crown Jewel for the City's Downtown: The $111 Million, Mixed-Use Monarch Place
description: LEAD: MONARCH PLACE, a $111 million, mixed-use project that is the largest real estate development in the history of this city of 154,000 residents, is nearing completion amid a new sense of optimism about Springfield's economic future. The final phase, a shopping mall, is scheduled to open Sept. 1.

title: Bound for Posterity
description: ACCORDING TO A RECENT study by a private foundation, the Council on Library Resources, at least 10 million irreplaceable books in America's research libraries are, through the ravages of old age, in danger of disintegration. One man doing something about it is Jan Sobota, a Czech-born bookbinder and restorer. The more than 3,000 rare and historical volumes in the Cleveland Health Sciences Library (affiliated with Case Western Reserve University) are in his care. Sobota, who emigrated to the United States from Switzerland in 1984 and speaks English with difficulty, practices his craft in a decidedly Old World, low-tech fashion, restoring one volume at a time, page by page.

title: Diana McCabe Is Married
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Diana O'Rourke McCabe and Mark Boyd Jacoby, who are partners in Philip Colleck of London Ltd., a New York antiques firm specializing in English furniture, were married yesterday by the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins. The bride is the daughter of Thomas O'Rourke of Naples, Fla., and the late Ann L. O'Rourke. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom is a son of Kathleen Jacoby of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Gene Jacoby.

title: Lendl Cruises Into Italian Open Final
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, looking sharp after a rain delay that lasted more than five hours, powered into the final of the Italian Open tennis tournament tonight by beating fifth-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden, 6-3, 6-3.

title: Hanzlik's Heroics Give Nuggets 1-Game Lead
description: Bill Hanzlik scored 4 of his 9 points in the final 35 seconds, including the game-winner with three seconds to play, rallying the Denver Nuggets to a 107-105 victory over the Dallas Mavericks in their National Basketball Association playoff series today.

title: Dr. Miller Wed To a Radiologist
description: Dr. Holly Dara Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Algernon M. Miller of New York, and Dr. Eric A. L. Meary, a son of Dr. Odette Meary of Paris and Talloires, France, and the late Dr. Robert Meary, were married yesterday at the Faculty House at Columbia University by Acting Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bruins Are Ready to Take the Final Step
description: Late Saturday night, plastic replicas of the Stanley Cup were flung onto the ice at Boston Garden as Bruins fans, who haven't had a real cup of their own since 1972, celebrated their team's ascent to the final round of the playoffs. There were still 24 seconds remaining in the game against the Devils, but once Ken Linseman lofted a short-handed flip shot into New Jersey's empty net to give Boston a 6-2 lead, it became clear that the Devils' National Hockey League playoff odyssey had ended while that of the Bruins would continue in Edmonton.

title: Iran Dissidents Enter Gulf War
description: The ground war between Iran and Iraq, which is approaching its ninth year, has taken a small but politically significant turn with the first major attack by dissident Iranians against positions held by troops loyal to the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Liberty Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a credit of $661,000 from an accounting change.

title: Palestinians Stage General Strike, But the Territories Remain Quiet
description: Palestinians in Israel's occupied territories staged a general strike today, and all Arab businesses were closed. But the West Bank and Gaza Strip were quiet this weekend, even though Israelis and Palestinians alike warned that there was likely to be large-scale violence.

title: 146 Sikhs Surrender at Golden Temple
description: About 146 people, most of them Sikh militants, surrendered at the besieged Golden Temple complex here today during a cease-fire called by the Indian police.

title: In France, a Pendulum Swings From the Left
description: To the Editor:

title: China Looks for Help to Keep Its Oil Flowing
description: Out where the lazy, muddy Pearl River empties into the South China Sea, the Chinese Government hopes foreign oil companies will find oil - lots of it.

title: North European Oil Royalty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Revenue represents royalty income and the share earnings are in units.

title: Dr. Marisa Lawrence Weds Dr. S. M. Martin
description: Dr. Marisa Lawrence and Dr. Stephen M. Martin, surgical residents at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green in New York. The Rev. Mathew Pravetz, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Blair Heath, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Tennis; Lendl Overcomes Spectators and Foe
description: Ivan Lendl overcame a tenacious opponent and a raucous crowd today, beating 18-year-old Guillermo Perez-Roldan in five sets to capture the Italian Open tennis championship.

title: Morton Downey Jr. Is Taking His Abrasive Style Nationwide
description: Sean Morton Downey Jr. - Sean to his friends, ''Mort, Mort, Mort'' to the adoring, T-shirted fans crowding the New Jersey television-studio audience - smoked and paced and spewed venom.

title: US Intec reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results reclassified to conform with 1988 presentation.

title: Ever-Chaotic World of Thai Politics Becomes Even More So
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, flying to Moscow Monday for his first visit there, leaves behind him a political climate more unsettled than at any time since an abortive coup in September 1985.

title: Business and the Law; Concern Mounts On Product Suits
description: AN explosion of product-liability cases has hit the courts, according to a recently completed study that will be released later this month.

title: Falcon Oil & Gas Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago first quarter earnings are restated to include a gain of $62,199, or 4 cents a share, form the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Kelley Oil & Gas Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge players have often shown themselves willing to help one of their own with special problems.

title: Inmate Rebels Agree to Surrender
description: About 20 inmates at a medium-security state prison released one of their three hostage guards late today and tentatively agreed to surrender Monday morning, prison officials said.

title: An Instrument of Mirth
description: Bassoonists have long learned to live with it: when thrust into the limelight, the bassoon tends to sound - well, funny. Just think of the solo in ''The Sorcerer's Apprentice.'' There is even a bassoon line in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony that is almost always transferred to horns, lest giggles spread through the orchestra.

title: Review/Music; A Neglected Symphony
description: In the 1940's, Harold Shapero was nominated for prominence in this country's musical future. But those who said they knew soon forgot. Mr. Shapero took on a quiet but distinguished career as a teacher in Boston, and his music has more or less disappeared from the concert stage. Was Aaron Copland's original assessment of his gifts too high? Did Mr. Shapero perhaps lack the diplomatic and business skills to smooth his path toward a big composing career? Or was it that he just wrote good music people didn't want to hear? Saturday's concert by the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall did not solve the mystery of the missing composer, but it fattened his file a bit.

title: Jackson Honors a Personal Example
description: Gertrude Brown, a child of the underclass, yearned to lift her family from poverty.

title: Soviet Trade Is Rated High in U.S.
description: The Soviet Union gets high marks as a trading partner in a survey of American companies that do business there.

title: Official Puts More Urgency In Savings-Fund Warning
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been warning the banking and savings industries that if the long-term problems of the insolvent savings and loan insurance fund are not resolved soon, the next President might come up with some very unpalatable solutions.

title: In a Surprise, Voters Say They're Watching a Lot
description: For all the talk about how voters have been turned off by boring candidates engaged in confusing contests, more Americans say they are paying a lot of attention to the Presidential campaign this year than said so in 1984.

title: Michel Camdessus (Reuters); Latin Frustration With I.M.F. Grows
description: When the Latin American debt saga began in 1982, the International Monetary Fund took the lead in trying to prop up the region's ailing economies and prevent a flurry of defaults from damaging the international financial system.

title: Afghan Rebel Vows Assault
description: An Afghan guerrilla leader said today that his fighters would attack Jalalabad as soon as it was free of Soviet Army troops.

title: St. Michael's
description: Eugene Lang, who received national acclaim in 1981 after promising a sixth-grade class in Harlem that he would pay their college tuitions, discussed matching one's ideals with one's life in his address today to the graduating class of St. Michael's College.

title: American League; Mariners Rally, Beat Red Sox
description: The Seattle Mariners scored four runs after two were out in the ninth inning today against Lee Smith, the Boston relief ace, and snapped a four-game losing streak with an 11-7 victory over the Red Sox.

title: Gretzky & company: Older, Smarter, Better
description: EARLY in this decade, when the Islanders were Stanley Cup champions and the best team in the National Hockey League, the Edmonton Oilers were refugees from the disbanded World Hockey Association, a team full of fresh kids who were full of fresh talent.

title: Golf; Lopez Fires a 66 To Win by Eight
description: Nancy Lopez turned in a round as close to perfect as she has had and won the 39th L.P.G.A. tournament of her spectacular career more easily than any of her previous 38 triumphs.

title: National League; Cards Rally to Win, 7-6
description: Willie McGee's two-out, pinch-hit single in the bottom of the ninth gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-6 victory today over the Atlanta Braves.

title: International Totalizator Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax loss carryforwards of $115,000.

title: Michael Plofker Weds Robin Paula Gitomer
description: The marriage of Robin Paula Gitomer, a senior interior designer for LCP Associates in Manhattan, to Michael Steven Plofker, an architect and associate at Fox & Fowle, a Manhattan architectural firm, took place yesterday. Rabbi Michael Klayman performed the ceremony at the de Seversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Stony Brook
description: Carl E. Schorske, a former professor of history at Princeton University and the winner of the 1981 Pulitzer Prize in general non-fiction, addressed the 28th commencement of the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: First Family Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $130,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes. c-Net income d-Net loss Year-ago 9-month loss included a non-recurring aftertax charge of $2.6 million from the company's withdrawal from the California market.

title: Moscow's Convention
description: Are you looking forward to the summit? When that question is asked of Georgi Arbatov, the Soviet propagandist, he sighs and substitutes a less enthusiastic verb: ''We're waiting for the summit.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 15, 1988: MONDAY

title: Images of Coney Island in Scenery and Dance
description: Dancers of all ages, from youngsters to the elderly, will take part in the National Dance Institute's ''Event of the Year'' on June 12 and 14 at the Felt Forum, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. ''A Day in the Life of Coney Island'' is the theme of the annual event, which will feature scenery and dances that re-create the atmosphere of the seaside amusement park.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Sandinistas see the contras falling apart, and they see the United States not disposed to help them. They feel that they now control the situation, which means there's no reason to compromise on anything.'' - Luis Sanchez Sancho, a leader of the Socialist Party in Nicaragua. [ A1:6. ]

title: Stealth Bomber Takes Shape: A Flying Wing and Crew of 2
description: After eight years of secrecy, a public portrait of the Stealth bomber is taking shape: an airplane with the range and sophistication to roam elusively over enemy territory for repeated attacks with only two fliers aboard.

title: Eleanor R. Berger Wed To Thomas P. Mueller
description: The marriage of Eleanor Ruth Berger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Berger of Great Neck and East Hampton, L.I., to Thomas Peter Mueller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Mueller of Milwaukee, took place yesterday in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at Harrison House.

title: Group Plans To Challenge A.T.&T., Sun
description: An international group of computer manufacturers plans to defy an effort to set a software standard initiated last year by the American Telephone & Telegraph Company and Sun Microsystems Inc. The group's challenge could be announced as early as tomorrow.

title: Gemco National Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $81,000 for the latest quarter and $91,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Jamie L. Kreitman Wed To Joseph Alan Cohen
description: Jamie Lauren Kreitman, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Benjamin Z. Kreitman of Brooklyn, and Joseph Alan Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Cohen of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Congregation Emunath Israel in New York. The bride's father and Rabbis Kenneth Auman and Mayer Leifer performed the ceremony.

title: Tanker Owners Seeing End to an 8-Year Slump
description: Tanker owners see signs that the eight-year-old slump in their industry is coming to an end, as the amount of surplus capacity and the number of tankers being scrapped fell in 1987 to their lowest levels of the 1980's.

title: Oklahoma City Journal; Square-Dancing as Steps on a Road
description: Hours from now, there would be 6,000 people here in the Myriad Convention Center, the women's skirts round as mushroom caps, the dancers bobbing to the beat as they responded to orders to ''swing your partner'' and ''do-sa-do.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 4 Promotions At Spielvogel
description: Four executive vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates, all of whom were in on the founding of Backer & Spielvogel in 1979, have been promoted to new responsibilities, further solidifying the smaller merger partner's hold on top management.

title: THREATEN CONTRAS
description: Apparently convinced that the contra guerrilla army is collapsing, the Sandinista Government is taking a new and harder line against opposition groups in the country.

title: Hadson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Immucell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Exchanging Marine Dress Blues for Tomes on the Law
description: Oliver L. North, who on behalf of the White House dealt for high military and political stakes on several continents, is now mastering the law. On May 1, after 20 years of service, he retired with the rank of lieutenant colonel from the Marine Corps at the age of 44 to face a future that could include criminal conviction for his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Clearly Wrong on Eyeglasses
description: Q: What's the difference between $60 reading glasses prescribed by an optometrist in New York and a $12 pair from Woolworth's in New Jersey? A: $48.

title: Review/Dance; Muna Tseng Miniatures
description: Muna Tseng Dance Projects brought choreographic miniatures to the Joyce Theater on Thursday night. Even an odyssey was only a tiny epic. ''A Little Odyssey'' was the appropriate title for a new work collaboratively choreographed and performed by Ms. Tseng and Cydney Wilkes that proved to be a journey into fantasy. Slide projections by the painter Kenny Scharf -who has often used imagery derived from science fiction - depicted strange polyps, tendrils and goblin faces. If only the choreography had been as whimsical.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; The Profit Motive Was Not Motivation
description: After a string of jobs in the public sector stretching over two decades, Peter C. Goldmark jumped across the line into private business in 1986 to take a senior management job with the Times Mirror Company. Now, after only two years, he is leaping back out of it, this time to experience the world of private, nonprofit organizations as president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: Greed Is Raising Apparel Prices, Not the Decline of the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Robotic Vision Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Alaskan Oil Data Dispute
description: The Chevron Corporation has won the first round of a legal battle to keep state officials and its competitors from seeing confidential data on the first exploratory well in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Sara Louise Nolan, Editor, Is Married to Peter Arnell
description: Sara Louise Nolan, an assistant editor of Vanity Fair magazine, and Peter Eric Arnell, a co-chairman of Arnell/Bickford Associates, an advertising agency, were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Saugerties, N.Y., by the Rev. Alden Barnes.

title: Robert Shaplen, 71, Writer for New Yorker, Dies
description: Robert Shaplen, a correspondent and staff writer for The New Yorker magazine whose authoritative articles and books on Asia over many years made him one of the deans of American journalism, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: 3 Nuclear Storage Depots to Close as B-52 Missions Change
description: The Air Force has notified Congressional leaders that it plans to close three depots where nuclear weapons are stored at air bases as some B-52 bombers are converted to carrying only conventional bombs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Growing Demand for Name Lists
description: FEW people got excited when Young & Rubicam announced last fall that Wunderman Worldwide, its direct marketing network, was entering into a joint venture with the CCX Network. The venture was to be called Focusmaster.

title: Financings Limited to Short-Term Bills
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: Yanks Club Angels, 9-2
description: In the morning, Charles Hudson woke up and wondered if he would spend the afternoon on the bench or on the pitcher's mound. There had been no word, no small hint from the manager, about his assignment.

title: Steel Starts Early Push On Quotas
description: The gathering of steel company executives in Washington tomorrow for the annual conference of the American Iron and Steel Institute promises to serve as the beginning of an intensive lobbying effort to extend import- protection measures.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Among all the professional teams in baseball, basketball, football and hockey, which one has the longest ongoing string of consecutive winning seasons?

title: A Rosier Outlook?
description: Domestic rose growers are keeping their fingers crossed that this year's trade bill in Congress will not die. There is a provision written into the legislation that could give them long-sought protection against Caribbean and South American growers.

title: In Jersey, Two Sides of the Campaign
description: Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson presented sharply different faces today to New Jersey Democrats as the two candidates began their personal campaigning for the state's 118 delegates to the party's national convention.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Shrinking Nighthawks

title: Women's Club Challenges CUNY on Hiring
description: The City University of New York's hiring practices, which some have criticized as being discriminating against women, is being challenged again, this time by a nonprofit women's group.

title: Retired Executive Is Named Quaker State's Next Leader
description: Jack W. Corn tried the pasture for a while, but he is back at the Quaker State Corporation and has been designated the motor-oil company's next chief.

title: Electric Fence Kills Woman
description: A 77-year-old man has been charged with manslaughter in the death of a neighbor who died when she tried to free one of her pet dogs from the man's electrified fence. The police said James J. Kahl had failed to install a regulator that would have sent a pulsating current through the wire instead of a steady flow of 110 volts that killed his neighbor, Bertha A. Brittingham, 73, on Tuesday. He is free on his own recognizance pending a court hearing.

title: Nasta International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter were not given because the company did not go public until June 1987.

title: Marjory D. Fisher Wed To Eric Michael Kraus
description: Marjory Diane Fisher and Eric Michael Kraus, lawyers in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, were married yesterday at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Dov Shapiro performed the ceremony.

title: Patrick Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Charles W. Gerber Wed To Maria Silvia Matera
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, Maria Silvia Matera was married last evening to Charles Waas Gerber by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

title: 7 Are Reported Killed in 2 Attacks in Sudan
description: Gunmen killed at least seven people, most of them foreigners, in simultaneous attacks today against a hotel and a club frequented by foreign aid workers and diplomats in central Khartoum, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ownership Is Changing At Richmond's A.M.W.
description: Richard E. Athey, the 54-year-old chairman, chief executive officer, chief creative officer and - most important - majority stockholder of Athey Martin Webb in Richmond has retired from the agency for health reasons. Stephen H. Martin, 43 and president, is buying him out and will become chief executive of the 16-year-old agency.

title: Six Firestone Plants Struck; No Negotiations Scheduled
description: About 4,700 United Rubber Workers members struck The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company plants in six states today, and 15,000 other union members are poised to strike The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company at noon Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: MSI Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Brothers in Cooper Deal See Shareholder Victory
description: The Sturman brothers, three real estate developers from Mount Vernon, N.Y., are not ones to treat their investments passively. After taking their first major stake in a public company, they have ended up on the board to see that shareholder values are at their maximum.

title: Review/Television; Families and Sentiment Are Hot in New Series
description: It is a truism that there is nothing like the humiliation of being in the ratings cellar to stimulate a television network's creative juices. Not too long ago, NBC was languishing at the inglorious (but never unprofitable) bottom of the weekly Nielsen lists. That's when the network began reaching out to innovative series like ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''Cheers.'' Now on the top, NBC displays distinct signs of playing safe. Its best new series in the past few months has been ''In the Heat of the Night,'' based on the old film. There's an increasing reliance on established formulas: more ''Perry Mason'' movies or, next Sunday, ''The Incredible Hulk Returns.''

title: East Harlem Pastor Is Arrested as Rapist Of Girls, 14 and 16
description: The 59-year-old pastor of an East Harlem church was arrested yesterday and charged with rape and sodomy in sexual attacks on two teen-age members of his congregation, the police said.

title: Rates Seen Stable for Near Term
description: Barring an unpleasant surprise, interest rates should remain close to their current levels for the near term, credit market analysts say.

title: California Real Estate Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The trust said the loss for the latest quarter resulted primarily from $358,000 of expenses associated with its proposed transaction with Culpepper Properties and Roebling Investment Co., which was terminated March 22, and expenses related to direct negotiations with Roebling Investment Co., which are continuing.

title: Couple Shot to Death In a Brooklyn Project
description: A man and a woman who the police said were apparently involved in drug dealing, were shot and killed in a Brooklyn housing project last night, officials said.

title: Farm Export Rise Foreseen
description: A new Government study projects continued increases in the volume and value of United States farm exports in the next 10 years, declining inventories of grain and steadily rising prices. The report by the Food and

title: State University of New York at Albany
description: Instead of setting out to acquire wealth, make something of your lives and ''hope you get rich in the process,'' Andy Rooney, the television commentator, told 2,800 graduates yesterday in a commencement address at the State University of New York at Albany. ''We have more rich people than we need right now,'' said Mr. Rooney, of the ''60 Minutes'' program. ''We are very short on people who know how to do anything. So please don't set out to make money. Set out to make something and hope you get rich in the process.'' Mr. Rooney returned to his hometown to receive an honorary doctorate. Other honorary degrees were presented to Dr. Alvin Poussaint, a psychologist and consultant to the television program ''Cosby Show;'' Jay W. Forrester, a computer designer, and James W. Mayer, a Cornell University scientist.(AP)

title: Resource Exploration Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Aunt Charged in Death of Nephew, 1, in Bronx
description: LEAD: A Bronx woman was charged with murder Saturday night in the death of her 1-year-old nephew, who was found bruised and unconscious by officers responding to a report of child abuse, the police said yesterday.

title: Literary Masterpieces Of the Berg Collection
description: From the first Western printing of Homer in 1488 to a handwritten poem by Richard Wilbur, poet laureate of the United States, dated 1988 - 500 years of British and American literature are represented in the magical cases of the Berg Collection, in a show opening today at the New York Public Library.

title: American Integrity CorpO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $22,000.

title: Horse Racing; A Look at Pimlico: Is Paradise Lost?
description: Pimlico Race Course, where the 113th Preakness Stakes will be run Saturday, has long held a reputation as a front-runner's paradise because of its supposedly tight turns and fast surface. So a horse who can win the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs from start to finish, as Winning Colors did nine days ago, is supposed to have an even easier time of it in the Preakness, especially since the race is a sixteenth of a mile shorter.

title: Bruhn Dance Prize Given
description: Errol Pickford of the Royal Ballet and Rose Gad Poulsen of the Royal Danish Ballet have won the first Erik Bruhn dance prize, and will share $11,250. The award, established in a trust fund by Mr. Bruhn before his death in April 1986, is to be given annually to the best male and best female dancer between the ages of 18 and 26 who are members of the Royal Ballet, Royal Danish Ballet, American Ballet Theater or National Ballet of Canada - the companies with which Mr. Bruhn worked most closely.

title: Canada Plans New Ministry
description: The Canadian Government, moving to bolster the country's research efforts, has introduced in Parliament a bill to establish a new ''superministry'' to promote development of science and technology.

title: Syracuse University
description: Four people were awarded honorary degrees yesterday at the 134th commencement at Syracuse University.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Saudi Arabia will spend $14 billion to develop the city of Mecca over the next 20 years, Okaz, a Jiddah-based newspaper, reported yesterday. Mayor Fouad Omar Tawfiq said a number of projects would turn Mecca into two cities: one for pilgrims and the other for residents. As Islam's holiest city, Mecca is the host to millions of pilgrims each year. Mr. Tawfiq said $5.6 billion had already been spent on tunnels, roads and bridges.

title: Silvercrest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credit reversals of $184,000 for the quarter and tax credits of $22,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Included tax credits of $502,000.

title: Giants Win, 5-1, To Sweep Mets
description: It may not shake empires or even shake the balance of power in the National League, but the Mets lost to the San Francisco Giants again today, 5-1, and for the first time since last July were swept in a three-game series.

title: Southlife Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $812,135 for the latest first quarter and $355,888 for the year-ago period.

title: Outdoors: Fly Casting for Shad
description: ANGLERS have long known that the American shad does not feed during its spring spawning run, that it seizes lure or fly for some other reason, perhaps irritation at repeated intrusions into its procreative odyssey by small, shiny creatures from another world. If this be so, Joe Purcell and I were unable to irritate any of them during two and one-half days of fly fishing on the Delaware River.

title: Asia's Touchy Tiger
description: Someone shrewdly described Singapore as a capitalist society run by a Leninist party. That's the People's Action Party, whose unquestioned boss is Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. For 29 years, Mr. Lee has been a largely benevolent autocrat, helping guide Singapore's 2.6 million people to the third-highest living standard in Asia, with an annual per capita income of $7,000. But more recently, the regime seems to have lost its balance, indulging in ugly police-state repression.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Split-Level Schooling
description: Carol Lockhart, a 20-year-old senior, had desperately wanted to transfer to Bronx Regional High School. As one of New York City's 16 alternative high schools, Bronx Regional normally attracts students who have dropped out of or had trouble in other schools. But Carol's reason for going there was the Eleanor Roosevelt LYFE Center, an infant care center where she could leave her 13-month-old daughter, Shatara, while she completed her education.

title: Windsor Life Insurance Co of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $2,261. c-Net income and after capital gains of $239,450.

title: Soviet TV, Accenting the Positive, Offers Heavy Coverage of Pullout
description: The beginning of the Soviet Union's withdrawal of military forces from Afghanistan was given unusually prominent coverage today in Soviet newspapers and on the prime-time television news.

title: Denning Mobile Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it does not report revenue because it is still in the development stage.

title: Duratek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Personal Ensign Is Back
description: Personal Ensign overcame a slow start and a seven-month layoff to remain undefeated by scoring a 1 3/4-length victory over Clabber Girl in the $170,100 Shuvee Handicap for older fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: The Press; Media General Fight Raises Questions of Vulnerability
description: BURT SUGARMAN'S battle to take over Media General Inc., the Richmond-based communications conglomerate, is being watched by many in the communications industry with the fascination due a portentous struggle.

title: Soviet Penal Institutions: See for Yourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dracula of Medical Technology
description: The Federal project to create an implantable artificial heart is dead. During its 24-year life this Dracula of a program sucked $240 million out of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. At long last, the institute has found the resolve to drive a stake through its voracious creation. ''The human body just couldn't seem to tolerate it,'' explains Claude Lenfant, the director of the institute.

title: Robert D. Emmerich, Composer, 83
description: Robert D. Emmerich, a pianist and composer who played with the Tommy Dorsey band and wrote songs for Fats Waller, died Friday at Florida Medical Center here. He was 83 years old.

title: Australia Becomes a Stand-In for Hollywood
description: Six years ago, the miniseries adapted from Colleen McCullough's best-selling novel ''The Thorn Birds'' - the most popular Australian story of this generation - was filmed in the Simi Valley, northwest of Los Angeles. The producers decided it was cheaper to simulate the Australian settings than to film Down Under. Now the economic situation has been reversed. Rising production and labor costs in the United States and the relative weakness of the Australian dollar have made it advantageous to film in Australia.

title: New York City's Economy Booms, and the Poor Begin to Profit
description: After years of economic growth and declining unemployment in New York City, researchers have detected the first signs that the benefits are beginning to spill over to some of those living in poverty.

title: Cycling; Olympic Prospects Emerge in Race
description: From the lost generation to the last generation, amateur bicycle racing has always had to put up with images. Hemingway, a bullfight and big game enthusiast, poked fun at the soft life of cyclists in his novel of the 1920's, ''The Sun Also Rises.'' In the recent movie, ''Breaking Away,'' the sport was framed by the poignancy of class conflict and shady racing tactics.

title: Transcon Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Results Plus
description: Golf Lietzke Wins Byron Nelson: Bruce Lietzke, who hadn't won a tournament in four years, sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole yesterday to beat Clarence Rose and capture the windswept $750,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic in Irving, Tex. The victory was worth $135,000, more than doubling Lietzke's winnings of $101,157 before the tournament. His last victory was in the 1984 Honda Classic. Players struggled all day with 29 mile-and-hour wind and slick, hard greens. (AP) Crampton Takes Playoff: Bruce Crampton birdied the first hole of sudden death to beat Billy Casper and take the United Hospitals Senior Classic at the Chester Valley Country Club in Malvern, Pa. Crampton's first prize of $33,750 made him a millionaire on the Senior circuit with a total of $1,001,441. (AP) Auto Racing Frenchman First in Monaco: Alain Prost of France took advantage of Ayrton Senna's misfortune to win the Monaco Grand Prix yesterday. It was Prost's 30th Formula One victory of his career and his second in three races this season in his McLaren-Honda. In taking the Monaco event for the fourth time, Prost covered the 78 laps around the tight 2.068-mile circuit in 1 hour 57 minutes 17.077 seconds. Gerhard Berger of Austria and Michele Alboreto of Italy were second and third, respectively, in Ferraris. Senna, of Brazil, the pole-winner and Prost's teammate, was on his way to an easy triumph after leading from the start. However on the 67th lap, with a 54-second lead over Prost, he swept into the barrier just before the tunnel. He got out of the car to watch Prost pass and go on to a 20.453-second victory over Berger. (AP) Crawford, Rahal Qualify: Jim Crawford of Scotland and Bobby Rahal, a former winner of the Indianapolis 500, were the only qualifiers yesterday for the May 29 race. Crawford, who suffered severe ankle and leg injuries in a crash on the opening day of qualifications last year, took to a tentative spot in field with a four-lap, 10-mile average of 210.564 miles an hour. That was the 10th fastest speed among the 21 drivers who have made it into the tentative lineup. The rest of the 33-car field will be filled in time trials next Saturday and Sunday. Rahal, who won here in 1986, had a run of 208.526 m.p.h.(AP) Road Racing Mexican Triumphs: Pacing a record horde of 100,000 runners, Arturo Barrios of Mexico won the 7.5-mile Bay to Breakers footrace in San Francisco. It was Barrios's second consecutive victory in the race. In the women's division, the winner was Lisa Martin of Australia. Winners won $24,000 BMW convertibles and round-trip tickets to Hong Kong. (AP) Record in Queens: Russ Jones, the New York Biathlon Series defending champion, broke his own course record in winning the Queens Biathlon over a 26-mile stretch of Alley Pond Park in Bellerose and the Cross Island Parkway yesterday. The 33-year-old postal worker from Collingswood, N.J., finished the two 3-mile runs in the park, and a 20-mile cycling leg race on the parkway in 1 hour 16 minutes 57 seconds. Debbie Brunelle-Tirrito, a 33-year-old nurse and data base analyst from New City, N.Y., was the first female finisher in 1:28.47. Lacrosse Hobart 19, Roanoke 6: Bill Miller, a freshman, scored two goals and had a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament record seven assists to lead Hobart College to a semifinal victory over Roanoke. (AP) Rowing Headed for Seoul: A 29-year-old financial analyst from Concord, Mass., qualified for the Olympic rowing team in women's single scull yesterday. Anne Marden, who works for J. P. Morgan Investment Company in London, covered the 2,000-meter trial course in 8 minutes 4 seconds, beating five other finalists. Six Olympic competitors emerged from a field of 36 in the four-day trials at Mercer Lake in Hamilton, N.J. Angie Herron, 26, of Philadelphia was second in 8:13.3. Marden was a silver medalist in the four-woman scull in the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles and won a bronze last year in a double scull in the women's world championships in Copenhagen.(AP)

title: Marti June Schiff Wed in Hartford
description: The Old State House in Hartford was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marti June Schiff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lee Schiff of Avon, Conn., and Dr. Minas S. Constantinides, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Spiros Constantinides of Narragansett, R.I. Justice of the Peace Edward Jack Brooks of Newington, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: A Wasteful Law Arouses Too Little Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Police vs. Guerrillas: Gary Busey in Action
description: When the opening credits announce ''Gary Busey is Bulletproof,'' you pretty much know what to expect. One of those daredevil cops who can only survive on film, Mr. Busey jumps into a shoot-out with a room full of gunrunners. They have piles of automatic weapons, he has a handgun, yet he escapes with a single bullet in his shoulder. Then he heads home to pluck the teeny bullet out with his tweezers. This is a fairly routine event for him, so he must also be infection-proof, but that medical mystery does not seem to interest the makers of ''Bulletproof.''

title: Finding Oil in Doors and Lights
description: The search for new sources of oil in the United States continues to focus on deep ocean waters and regions like the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, where oil exploration is pitted against environmental concerns. But some energy experts are successfully prospecting for oil in such places as windows, ceilings and doors.

description: A New 'Omnibus'

description: As a Harvard law professor and labor arbitrator, Derek C. Bok exalted the role of labor unions in the work place. But since then he has become president of the university, and in that capacity he appears to have modified - some say abandoned - his earlier views.

description: b-After a loss of $126,000 and a gain of $849,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations; a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $304,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and tax credits of $74,000 for the quarter and $112,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $855,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $838,000. d-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $431,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $838,000.

title: Dues and Costs Rise For Club Membership
description: Membership rolls were flat, while revenues from dues and operations rose a bit, but not quite as much as costs.

description: In a nation where most Government officials, socialist or conservative, are graduates of elite professional schools, Pierre Beregovoy, France's newly named Finance Minister, is a notable exception.

title: Review/Television; On U.S.-British Relations
description: ''An Ocean Apart'' traces 20th-century United States-British relations. That may sound academic and dusty; the seven-part series, however, is not. It is generally imaginative and often evocative; old newsreel film recalls a world that no longer exists. The series starts on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Arthur Miller, 71, Law Professor
description: Arthur Selwyn Miller, a retired law teacher and an authority on constitutional law, died of a brain tumor Friday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: Market Place; Unlocking Values In Hotel Stocks
description: THE lodging industry rises and falls with the economy. When the economy sparkles, more people travel. As it softens, individuals and business travelers tend to stay home or at cheaper hotels. Even though the economy is relatively stable now, the hotel industry is suffering from overcapacity, the result of overbuilding that ended when the tax laws were changed in 1986.

title: Notre Dame
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta urged graduates at the University of Notre Dame to become politically aware and volunteer their skills to the needy.

title: C.I.A. Is Criticized Over a Turncoat
description: From the day Edward Lee Howard was dismissed as a Central Intelligence Agency officer in 1983, senior officials of the agency concealed clear indications that he was a security risk who could well become a Soviet spy, a new book contends.
