Decline in New York's Poor Researchers see signs that the city's economic growth is helping some poor people. Many others stay mired in poverty, they say. Page B1.

title: Baruch-Foster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Botanic Garden in May: As Pretty as a $100 Picture
description: Hang Ching Lam, the owner of the Dragon Garden restaurant in the Poconos, was married in Chinatown yesterday. But the hours before his wedding found him with his bride, Hau Hung Yim, smiling for cameras on the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Turtle Island.

title: Hungarian Opposition Meets Days Before the Party Does
description: With a long-awaited special conference of the Communist Party only five days away, Hungary's organized opposition displayed its vigor this weekend with an unusual series of open meetings.

title: It's Official: Rap Music Is in the Mainstream
description: Rap, the music that began in the nation's black urban ghettoes, enters the mainstream commercial music world in earnest this morning when 1,250,000 copies of Run-D.M.C.'s new album ''Tougher Than Leather'' go on sale.

title: Louvre Courtyard Set for July Opening
description: The Cour Napoleon at the Louvre -the seven-acre courtyard that contains the controversial pyramid designed by I. M. Pei - will open to the public on July 3. But the 71-foot glass pyramid itself, which is to become the main entrance to the museum, will not open until late November or early December, according to Pierre-Yves Ligen, the French official in charge of the museum's expansion project.

title: WPP Chief to Be Geller Witness
description: The four-week-old hearing in a legal proceeding between the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency and a rival agency formed by defectors from Lord, Geller is expected to take a dramatic turn this week with the testimony of Martin Sorrell.

title: Fitness; Swimming Conditions Heart, Mind and Body
description: FEW human athletic endeavors are as beautiful as an accomplished swimmer gliding through the water, a study in grace and precision of movement. For such people, swimming appears to come naturally. For others of us, bullied into the deep end of a pool by a physical education teacher long ago, swimming is an ungainly struggle, a battle to breathe correctly and stroke efficiently.

title: 'Speed-the-Plow' Stars Talk Things Over
description: Scenes from an interview with Ron Silver, Joe Mantegna and Madonna, the co-stars of David Mamet's new hit play set in Hollywood, ''Speed-the-Plow.''<n Scene 1

title: Albany Plans Tougher Penalties For Possession and Sale of Crack
description: The penalties for possession of crack in New York State would be significantly increased under an agreement announced yesterday by Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers.

title: SYRIANS SEAL OFF SUBURBS OF BEIRUT TORN BY FIGHTING
description: Syrian forces sealed off the southern suburbs of Beirut today and ordered rival Shiite Moslem gunmen who have fought fiercely over the last 10 days to lay down their arms.

title: Eastover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $275,000 for the latest quarter and $188,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Tate & Lyle Outlines Staley Plans
description: Neil M. Shaw, chairman of Tate & Lyle P.L.C., the big British sugar refiner that reached an agreement late Friday to buy Staley Continental Inc., said in an interview yesterday that he intends to begin talks quickly to sell Staley's food services division, name new managers and cut operating costs.

title: Soviet Formally Pulls First Troops Out of the Long Afghanistan War
description: A long convoy of tanks, trucks and happy Soviet soldiers rumbled through a narrow mountain pass and into this capital city today as the first official step of the withdrawal of 115,000 Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: Bando McGlocklin Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Publication Aimed At Patients of Dentists
description: Dental Learning Systems of Newtown, Pa., plans to publish a quarterly for patients.

description: A number of accounts found new homes on Friday.

title: Keeping OPEC Off Balance
description: LEAD: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to many people a forgotten artifact of the energy crisis, could give the United States the power to stabilize the oil market and put an end to various OPEC schemes to drive up prices. Unfortunately, Federal law forbids us to use this enormous weapon.

title: More Training for Guards Is Urged In Study on Use of Force in Jails
description: The New York City Department of Correction should double the training it gives its officers, stop mandatory overtime and create a panel to investigate allegations of brutality against inmates, according to a study by correction experts on the use of force in the city's jails.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ADC Telecommunications Inc., Minneapolis, said Fredrick R. Boswell had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director to pursue other opportunities. His duties will be assumed by Charles M. Denny Jr., chairman and chief executive. Mr. Boswell will serve as a consultant for an interim period.

title: 10 South Africa Miners Die
description: Ten gold miners fell to their deaths Saturday after an elevator hit an obstruction in the mine shaft, management said. The accident occurred at the Harmony Gold Mine, near the town of Virgina in the Orange Free State.

title: Texas International Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $265,000.

title: On One Issue, No Dispute: L.I. Electric Rates to Rise

description: The Detroit Pistons didn't deserve to lose today, Isiah Thomas decided. And largely because of him, they didn't.

title: Navy Officer and Instructors Charged in Death of Recruit
description: The officer in charge of the Navy rescue swimmer school and five instructors face military charges in a recruit's death at Pensacola Naval Air Station, the Navy says.

Corporate loyalty was constantly reaffirmed during the program, which was telecast live in its entirety by the British Broadcasting Corporation and for its last five and a half hours by Home Box Office, with HBO repeats and a possible network broadcast still to come.

title: Pipeline Blast Laid to Rebels
description: Leftist guerrillas blew up Colombia's main pipeline Saturday as Latin American and Caribbean oil-exporting countries ended talks in the Caribbean resort of Cartagena, Government officials said.

Scott High School reunion, which was held Saturday night at the Matterhorn Hotel in East Hanover, N.J.: how many balloons of red and silver, the school colors, were floating above the banquet tables, and how many helium tanks did it take to inflate them?

description: One of the most difficult challenges health care teams face is advising young men who have hemophilia and also carry or are likely to carry the AIDS virus. Should they have sexual relationships? Should they tell women they are dating that they are infected with the AIDS virus?

title: Long Island University
description: Richard D. Heffner, host of ''Open Mind,'' a public-television interview program, delivered Long Island University's 31st commencement address yesterday. ''We have made imagery, not substance, the hallmark of our society, rewarding the image-maker with a kind of obscene idolatry, rewarding him financially, politically, even academically,'' Mr. Heffner said in a speech critical of the influence that the media have had on society's thought. A total of 1,152 bachelor's degrees and 1,101 master's degrees were awarded, as were six honorary degrees.

title: The Basics of Setting Up Boat Moorings
description: AS dock space in the nation's harbors becomes increasingly expensive and hard to find, yachtsmen are turning to moorings as a place to keep their boats. When set up properly, the harbor anchorages are as safe as a dockside berth, and often less wearing on the boat. In fact, in a storm, moorings often are preferable.

title: Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion
description: Twenty-one graduates were ordained as rabbis and eight invested as cantors yesterday at the ordination and investiture ceremonies of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

description: Quinn's Book By William Kennedy 289 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: World Oil Price Outlook
description: World oil prices may not strengthen as fast as many think in the next decade and could remain low and unstable until the mid-1990's, the managing director of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today. Speaking to an oil and gas symposium sponsored by the Dutch Government, John Jennings said the world oil surplus might last longer than first thought, depending on non-OPEC production. Oil demand will also be a factor, since Shell predicts long-term requirements of the principal oil consuming nations will grow slowly or remain stable. Many oil companies and governments expect prices will begin to rise in the middle of the next decade as non-OPEC production.

title: In Fashion World, the Trend Is Away From Drugs
description: In the world of high fashion, it's no longer fashionable to be high. Interviews with designers, photographers, editors and executives in the wake of Calvin Klein's statement last week that he has entered an alcohol and drug treatment program - the first major fashion figure to do so publicly - reveal an industry that has been moving quietly toward sobriety.

title: Review/Theater; Adolescent Yearning In 'Evening Star'
description: Sitting at a table in their backyard, an elderly man and his granddaughter go through their nightly routine. As he reads aloud from the obituary columns, she crosses off names of people in the telephone book. The grandfather, who operates a discount stand, explains that he is simply cutting down on the cost of his business mailing list. As he says, ''All the big companies do it - Ford, General Motors.''

title: Pope Celebrates Mass in Peru for 1.5 Million
description: Guarded by a small army of policemen and soldiers, Pope John Paul II celebrated a solemn Mass today for one of the largest crowds to attend a papal event in recent years.

description: Ah, the home court in the National Basketball Association. The home players know the floor better and the rims are friendly for them. The shots that normally roll in for their opponents roll out.

title: Pretoria Squeezes The Press
description: LEAD: Many Government ministers, well aware of the symbolic power a free press holds in influential circles in Europe and America, have boasted that South Africa has ''the freest press in Africa.'' The freedom the ministers cite falls within limits -and those limits inexorably are being squeezed tighter.

title: McDonnell Sued by U.S.
description: The Government has joined in a lawsuit contending that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation overcharged the Army by as much as $175 million in developing the Apache attack helicopter.

title: Metro Matters; Astrology Quiz: Will the Reagans Hurt Business?
description: ''Business has been very slow,'' said Elaine, who reads palms for $15 above a Chinese restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. ''Since the book, I think people are just shying away.''

title: Fiery Crash Kills 27 in Kentucky As Truck and Youths' Bus Collide
description: Federal investigators today began looking into a fiery collision late Saturday between a pickup truck traveling the wrong way on an interstate highway and a bus returning from a church youth outing. Twenty-seven passengers on the bus were killed.

title: Review/Dance; Ray Charles at a Peter Martins City Ballet Premiere
description: Ray Charles took the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival by storm Saturday night with a most unusual personal appearance.

title: Charlottetown Journal; Isle of Green Gables: Just Another Coney Island?
description: Few inhabited spots in North America have as pristine an image as this island province.

title: Slaught on Disabled List
description: The news was not good, but Don Slaught seemed to accept it as little more than an unfortunate break at an inopportune time.

title: Lakers Top Jazz, Even Series
description: For the last five days, it seemed as if time and fatigue had overtaken the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Randi S. Roth Is Bride Of John Devers Hursh
description: The marriage of Randi Susann Roth, the daughter of Marna Roth of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Morton Roth, to John Devers Hursh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Hursh of Rochester, took place yesterday at the Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Judge Ira P. Block of the First District Court in Hauppauge, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Consultant Shows Way to Business Success
description: If you doubt that private enterprise is beginning to make headway in the Soviet Union, Vladimir Yakovlev suggests you try to find a plain white T-shirt in a Moscow department store.

title: Iraq Claims New Tanker Raid
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes hit another supertanker off Iran's coast, and Teheran accused the United States Navy of jamming radar and radio to aid Iraqi jets in a devastating raid on a vital oil terminal.

title: The Koch-Albany Battle; Political Realities Have Limited the Impact Of Tensions Between Mayor and Legislators
description: Mayor Koch spent much of the winter trying strenuously but unsuccessfully to alter the course of legislation affecting New York City by attacking the State Legislature, first over a plan to increase pensions to city workers, then over the city's share of state education aid.

title: Give That Man an 'L'
description: Jose Oquendo has played every position but catcher in his major league career. Now he has a new claim to fame: he's the first non-pitcher in 20 years to get a decision.

title: Sports of The Times; Devils Made Their Points in Semifinal Series
description: PUT away the Mickey Mouse ears, Edmonton fans. The New Jersey Devils are not coming to town.

title: Joseph Zambelli, Pyrotechnist, 80
description: Joseph Zambelli, who put together fireworks displays for Presidential inaugurations, the Statue of Liberty centennial and other national celebrations, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Don't Let Prison Space Be the Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Dip in Tourism Has Israelis Worried
description: The Palestinian uprising has caught up with Israel's tourism industry, the nation's largest source of foreign capital.

title: Gunmen Kill 3 in Belfast Bar
description: Three people were killed and nine others wounded today when gunmen burst into a bar in a Roman Catholic section of Belfast, the police reported. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: Devils Don't Lose Their Spirit
description: Only a handful of the faithful could have expected the Devils to be in the playoffs this year under a new president and general manager, and with a coaching change in midseason.

title: Europe Plans Fighter Plane
description: West Germany, Britain and Italy today signed an accord to build 750 Eurofighters for $47 billion, the biggest West European military contract since World War II. Spain is also expected to sign the agreement soon.

title: Kansas City Journal; Soviet Tour Reaches America's Warm Heart
description: More than 50 Russians touring the United States with a cultural exchange exhibition have reached the heart of America. To no one's surprise, it seemed, they found it open, friendly and warm.

title: Allegheny Meeting Delay
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Pittsburgh yesterday issued an order temporarily blocking the annual meeting of Allegheny International Inc., at which a proxy fight led by a New York brokerage firm was to take place.

title: International Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $273,000 on the sale of a business property. The company said 6-month figures are not comparable to a year earlier; there were only four months in the year-ago period because of the company's acquisition.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Is Losing Its President
description: Peter F. McSpadden, the top Saatchi & Saatchi DFS executive on both the RJR Nabisco and Northwest Airlines accounts, will be leaving the company around September, a highly placed agency executive confirmed yesterday.

title: Philharmonic and Mehta Plan a European Tour
description: The New York Philharmonic will play 16 concerts in 10 European countries this summer, the orchestra has announced. Some 150 musicians and 20,000 pounds of instruments and equipment will leave New York on Aug. 18 and return Sept. 10. Zubin Mehta will conduct all the concerts on the tour, which is to be sponsored by Citicorp/Citibank.

title: Mack Trucks Unit Offers Dual Issue
description: The Mack Trucks Receivables Corporation, a unit of Mack Trucks Inc., is offering $122.1 million of debt securities backed by truck loan receivables through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: New Stock for Affiliated
description: Shareholders of Affiliated Publications Inc., the owner of The Boston Globe, yesterday approved creation of a new class of stock with 10 times the voting power of its common stock.

title: Cuomo Voices Hope on Shoreham Talks
description: Governor Cuomo said today that negotiations with the Long Island Lighting Company presented the best and cheapest way to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Uniworld Group Lures Essence Programmer
description: Gene A. Davis, formerly vice president of programming for Essence television, has joined the Uniworld Group, one of the largest black-owned ad agencies, as executive vice president of the its new unit, Uniworld Entertainment.

title: Ally of Bush Drops Out Of Race for G.O.P. Post
description: Vice President Bush's brother, Jonathan, suffered a serious political setback yesterday when his candidate for New York Republican national committeeman withdrew rather than engage in a party-dividing fight with Richard M. Rosenbaum, the incumbent.

title: Firms May Merge
description: The Wedbush Corporation and the Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner Capital Corporation said they were discussing a merger of the two securities firms. The companies said if a merger was completed, the combined firms would have more than $75 million in capital and more than $500 million in assets.

title: India Acts in Carbide Case
description: The Government of India reissued summonses today against the Union Carbide Corporation and its former chairman in an effort to make them appear in court on homicide charges in the 1984 Bhopal gas leak.

title: New Publisher At Law Journal
description: James A. Finkelstein will be named publisher of The New York Law Journal on May 23, succeeding his father, Jerry Finkelstein, who has been publisher for 25 years.

title: From PC's to Nodes
description: THE personal computer is dead; long live the node.

title: Bush Seeks to Balance Oil and Environment
description: Vice President Bush, campaigning in the Northwest, has been urging greater domestic oil production and arguing that it can be achieved without endangering the environment.

title: Students in Debt: Society Pays a Price, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Space Prescription: Artificial Gravity for Long Flights
description: The accumulated experience of Soviet astronauts on long space flights suggests that any manned mission to Mars or beyond should be made in a craft that has a centrifuge to provide artificial gravity, according to the country's top expert on space medicine.

title: Black Labor Congress Plans to Challenge Pretoria
description: South Africa's major black trade union federation is to hold a three-day work stay-away next month, apparently in defiance of Government restrictions.

title: Bull Run Gold Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Surgeon General Asserts Smoking Is an Addiction
description: The Surgeon General of the United States warned today that nicotine was as addictive as heroin and cocaine and recommended the licensing of those who sell tobacco products and tougher laws prohibiting their sale to minors.

title: Majority Stake Bought In Hasselbart & Mitten
description: Leo J. LeFort, William C. Waldman and John Ragsdale, the key executives of Hasselbart & Mitten Advertising and Arocom Marketing Group of Fairlawn, Ohio, which collectively bill more than $50 million, have acquired the majority interest in the companies from the estate of the late Robert Mitten, founder and chief executive, who died in January.

title: Sequa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $336,000. Latest first quarter includes results of Atlantic Research Corp., acquired at the end of 1987.

title: Jail Barge To Change Rivers
description: New York City's $19 million prison barge will be moved this summer from the East River to a Hudson River pier next to the West Village, the Correction Department has announced.

title: Hawks Even Series With Celtics, 2-2
description: The Hawks sensed that the Celtics were in trouble tonight in the first 19 seconds of the game, when Dominique Wilkins hit his first shot, an 11-foot jumper on a pass from Glenn (Doc) Rivers.

title: Trading Carelessly in Trade Figures
description: On April 14 the stock market dropped 101 points, the dollar plunged and interest rates surged, all because of one unreliable statistic - the Commerce Department's report that the foreign trade deficit had got worse again in February. Well, today's the day for the March figures, and perhaps another spasm of speculation. But whatever the numbers indicate, the best advice is, don't panic.

title: Irving Wins Vote On Board
description: The Irving Bank Corporation defeated a hostile takeover bid by the Bank of New York Company in a proxy fight whose results were announced yesterday.

title: Skyscrapers Attract Imperiled Falcons
description: High above the downtown area, two wild peregrine falcon chicks pecked out of their shells in a nest on a skyscraper ledge.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Toronto Blue Jays yesterday placed the outfielder Jesse Barfield on the 15-day disabled list with wrist problems. . . . Doug Moe of the Denver Nuggets has been selectedthe N.B.A.'s Coach of the Year in a news media poll. . . . Don Koharski, the National Hockey League referee, has invited Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, to attend his celebrity golf tournament near Toronto in August to raise money for the mentally retarded. ''I don't hold any grudges,'' Koharski said, alluding to his confrontation with Schoenfeld in the playoff series with the Bruins that resulted in a one-game suspension of the coach.(AP)

title: PATTERNS
description: Fashion Barometer

title: Chief Lightens Load At Laidlaw Transport
description: Michael G. De Groote became a millionaire and lost it all in a bankruptcy while still in his 20's. Undaunted, he tried again and became one of Canada's most successful businessmen.

title: Pasternak Retreat to Be a Museum
description: Boris Pasternak's posthumous journey from the outlaw reaches of Soviet literature back to the embrace of the establishment was completed a few days ago as the membership of the Soviet Writers' Union was told Pasternak's woodland retreat would become a memorial museum.

title: A Powerful XT Clone
description: PERHAPS the most important single element in determining the personality of a computer is its central processing unit, the chip that orchestrates the show. That bit of silicon sets the speed of the computer, its memory capacity and the general efficiency of the entire system.

title: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Depot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Legalize Drugs? Not on Your Life.
description: The escalating drug crisis is beginning to take its toll on many Americans. And now growing numbers of well-intentioned officials and other opinion leaders are saying that the best way to fight drugs is to legalize them. But what they're really admitting is that they're willing to abandon a war that we have not even begun to fight.

title: T. E. Stephens, Eisenhower Aide And G.O.P. Strategist, Dies at 84
description: Thomas E. Stephens, a lawyer and former appointment secretary to President Eisenhower, died Sunday at the Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Environmental Fears Cast Pall Over Riis Park Project
description: A $55 million redevelopment proposal that would add a performing-arts amphitheater and water rides to an oceanfront Queens park has been thrown into doubt because of vehement opposition from community and environmental groups.

title: Back-to-School Days: Jet Rookies Hear Bell
description: Just when the Jets' rookies thought school was out, it's back.

title: Washington Talk: Memoirs; Clark Clifford, in No Hurry, Takes the High Road
description: In contrast to Presidential aides who thunder into print as soon as they depart the White House, Clark M. Clifford, an adviser to the last four Democratic Presidents and Secretary of Defense at the height of the Vietnam War, has waited more than 40 years to write his Washington book.

title: Chambers Tape Depicts a Party Before His Trial
description: In a videotape broadcast last night, Robert E. Chambers Jr., who pleaded guilty in March in the strangulation of Jennifer Levin, playfully acted out a story in which he accidentally broke the neck of a doll.

title: In Quest for Fusion Energy, 2 Rival Techniques Fight for the Spotlight
description: FOR decades the costly field of controlled nuclear fusion has been rocked by ups and downs, promise and problems. But scientists are now confident enough of success to embark, albeit cautiously, on building a new generation of machines that would ignite fusion fuel for the first time, releasing controlled bursts of energy.

title: Graham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $450,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Inside
description: The Two Faces of Lying Psychologists find that specific kinds of lies are linked to personality problems, but that lying also plays a positive role. Science Times, page C1. Murder Charged in Crash The driver of a pickup truck that crashed head-on into a church bus in Kentucky was charged with 27 counts of capital murder. Page A16. Syrian Message for Iran Syria has sent a signal to Iran that it cannot go too far in challenging Syria's role as a power broker in Lebanon. News Analysis, page A12. The $7 million musical ''Carrie'' became Broadway's most expensive flop when it closed on Sunday. The question is: Why? Page C15.

title: Guerrillas Say Support for Cambodia Government Is Eroding
description: Support for the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia is eroding steadily among both civilians and Government troops, guerrillas operating from bases on the Thai border say.

title: Skier Retires
description: Debbie Armstrong, who may be best remembered for her unrestrained glee after winning a gold medal in the giant slalom at the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, has announced her retirement from the United States Ski Team. In two of the last three seasons, she was bothered by leg injuries, and she finished 13th in the giant slalom at Calgary in February. ''In terms of my ski career, it is time,'' she said in a letter to John McMurtry, the United States Ski Team Alpine program director. For the last several months, Armstrong has been working for a television station in Seattle. She plans to enroll in college as a communications major.(AP)

title: O.E.C.D. Is More Upbeat on Growth
description: The world's growth outlook is better than expected, but trade imbalances are being reduced more slowly than predicted, officials of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: Equitec Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes net of $166,000 from discontinued operations. The company changed its fiscal year end to Dec. 31 from April 30, effective at the end of 1987. Year-ago first quarter is restated to reflect the change to the calendar year end.

title: Monster Robots Bash Paradise in Mock Battle
description: Weather permitting, tonight at 9 o'clock, the parking lot at Shea Stadium will be the site of an hourlong battle involving flame throwers, artillery, explosives and anthropomorphic metal machines that crush everything in their paths.

title: Dear Mr. Rakhmanin
description: Ivan Rakhmanin Office of the Procurator Moscow, U.S.S.R. Dear Mr. Rakhmanin,

title: Stars to Go reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $134,000.

title: Spending Cut By Brazil
description: In a step toward obtaining a $1.5 billion standby credit from the International Monetary Fund, the Brazilian Government tonight announced a series of new spending cuts aimed at reducing its huge budget deficit.

title: Occidental Sets Share Offering
description: Saddled with high debt from recent acquisitions, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced a new stock offering today. Occidental has about 210 million shares outstanding and would offer 45 million common shares in June. The proceeds would be used to reduce debt and for general corporate purposes.

title: U.S. Finances Dolphin Study
description: A project to study dolphin deaths along the East Coast is receiving a cash infusion from the Navy and the National Marine Fisheries Service.

title: U.S. WELCOMES PULLOUT
description: The White House today welcomed the start of the withdrawal of Soviet troops as a first step in the pursuit of ''independence and self-determination'' for Afghanistan.

title: Patriots' Settlement
description: In a settlement af a dispute that arose when Brian Holloway, a three-time All-Pro, was traded by the New England Patriots to the Los Angeles Raiders last Sept. 2, the Patriots agreed yesterday to pay Holloway an undisclosed sum. The National Football League Players Assocation said it would drop charges before a National Labor Relations Board administrative judge that Holloway had been traded because of union activities. Holloway was traded the day after he appeared on national television and criticized N.F.L. management for a breakdown in labor talks. He was a union vice president and the Patriots' player representative at the time.Club officials said his skills had deteriorated, making him expendable. Patrick Sullivan, the Patriots' general manager, said that the union's initial request had been for $20,000 and that a ''modest settlement'' had been negotiated.(AP)

title: Carroll Kowal Is Dead; Housing Aide Was 59
description: Carroll Kowal, a social worker and longtime advocate of adequate housing for the homeless and disabled, died of intestinal cancer Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: After Seven Years And $7 Million, 'Carrie' Is a Kinetic Memory
description: More than seven years after its authors first began work on it, the critically lambasted musical ''Carrie'' has closed after 5 regular performances and 16 previews, making the more-than-$7 million show the most expensive quick flop in Broadway history. ''Rags,'' a musical about the Jewish immigrant experience that starred Teresa Stratas, ran for only four performances in August 1986, but cost less: $5.25 million.

title: Bush Assails Kerry on Drug Issue
description: Vice President Bush today accused Senator John Kerry of disclosing potentially ''slanderous'' information implying that a Bush aide had knowledge of drug dealings involving the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BELGRADE ADOPTS AN AUSTERITY PLAN
description: The Yugoslav Government imposed ceilings on wage increases today under a new program worked out with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Students in Dept: Society Pays a Price, Too; Ferret Out Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Prize Recital Sung In English
description: Julia Davidson, winner of the 1987 Center for Contemporary Opera vocal competition, chose a program all in English for her prize recital Friday at Weill Recital Hall. She met the first qualification for such an undertaking handily: texts to most of her selections were printed in the program, but only three or four times in the whole evening was it necessary to glance at them to learn what had been sung. The idea that sung English can't be understood persists as part of conventional wisdom in the classical music business; Miss Davidson takes her place among the honorable group of artists who prove that the conventional wisdom is bunk.

title: Governor of New Hampshire Bars Drive for Re-election to 4th Term
description: Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire announced yesterday that he would not seek a fourth two-year term.

title: A Judge Orders New Jury Panel For Davis Trial
description: Acting on his earlier finding of racism by the defense in jury selection at the trial of Larry Davis, a Bronx judge yesterday removed the six jurors who had been seated and ordered a ''completely fresh'' trial.

title: General Energy Development reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $475,000 from the settlement of certain natural gas contract disputes. Share earnings represent units.

title: Advanced Marketing Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Imre Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it had no revenue for the year-earlier period.

title: Wilshire Oil of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vari-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Excerpt From Report by White House Panel
description: Following is an excerpt from the introduction to the interim report on the financial markets released today by a White House working group:

title: Dread Locusts: An Appreciation, Almost
description: For they covered the face of the whole land, so that the land was darkened, and they ate all the plants in the land and all the fruit of the trees which the hail had left; not a green thing remained, neither tree nor plant of the field, through all the land of Egypt.'' Exodus 10:3.

title: Boeing Gets $3.69 Billion Plane Order
description: As expected, the International Lease Finance Corporation today awarded the Boeing Company three-quarters of a $5 billion airliner order, the largest order ever for commercial jetliners. The European consortium Airbus Industrie won the remainder.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Little progress has been made on ending farm subsidies, officials of the leading industrial democracies say as they prepare to meet in Paris. The U.S. wants countries to set a firm date for ending protectionism. But the European Community maintains the U.S. is as much at fault as anyone else for slowing down the elimination of barriers. [ Page A1. ] The world's growth outlook is better than expected, but trade imbalances are being reduced more slowly than predicted, O.E.C.D. officials said. ''The risk of inflation remains under control,'' one official of the group said. [ D1. ] Private banks are jeopardizing an international strategy for resolving the third world debt crisis, the World Bank asserts. But the banks say the World Bank complaint is unfair. [ D11. ] MARKETS Changes that would alter trading only slightly were recommended by the White House working group on the stock market crash. Members of the group acknowledged that their proposals would not necessarily protect investors from losses. [ A1. ] Stock prices rallied late in the day, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average 17.08 points, to close at 2,007.63. Volume continued to be lackluster. [ D6. ] A sharp rise in commodity prices pushed Treasuries narrowly lower. The increase in commodity prices provoked additional concern in a market that is already nervous about inflation. [ D16. ] Soybean and corn futures soared by their daily limits, reflecting dry weather over the Grain Belt, dwindling crop surpluses, inventory building by food processors and speculative buying. [ D18. ] The dollar drifted higher in quiet trading in advance of today's report on the U.S. trade deficit for March. Gold rose $2.70 an ounce on the Comex, to $454.90. [ D18. ] COMPANIES Irving defeated a hostile takeoverbid by the Bank of New York in a shareholder vote whose results were announced yesterday. Bank of New York's failure to replace Irving's board means it cannot dismantle poison-pill defenses. A friendly takeover of Irving by Banca Commerciale Italiana is now expected to proceed. [ D1. ] International Lease Finance awarded Boeing most of a $5 billion airliner order, with the rest going to Airbus. It was the largest order ever for commercial airliners. [ D1. ] Eastman Kodak will set up a $150 million program to compensate consumers who bought Kodak instant cameras. [ D2. ] Texaco and Carl C. Icahn are talking over their differences. Neither side would provide details. [ D4. ] Giant Group will sell its cement and waste-burning business to Environmental Treatment and Technologies for $110 million in cash plus warrants for Environmental Treatment stock. [ D4. ] The annual meeting of Allegheny International was blocked by a Federal bankruptcy judge in Pittsburgh. [ D4. ] Farrar, Straus & Giroux is optimistic that two best sellers will help it compete more vigorously for new properties. [ D20. ] THE ECONOMY Output rose 0.7 percent at U.S. factories, mines and utilities in April after two months of virtually no growth. It was the biggest advance since October. [ D1. ] The F.C.C. has authority over cable TV's technical quality, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously. The Court turned down an appeal by New York City and other local governments. [ D1. ] The Surgeon General called tobacco an addiction and recommended the licensing of those who sell tobacco products. [ A1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Information on the safety and cost effectiveness of medical technology has been compiled in a 700-page directory by a joint industry-government program. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Brokerage houses are raising margin requirements for some customers. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Savin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $605,000 tax credit. The company said its latest first quarter revenue was affected by reduced levels of copier, accessory and facsimile volumes in dealer operations as many dealers stockpiled product in December to avoid previously announced January price increases.

title: Minstar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,606,000. The company said that it has completed the sale of its energy services segment to an undisclosed buyer. Minstar said it received net proceeds of $143 million after the assumption of $8 million of long-term debt by the buyer.

title: Roanoke Electric Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Prices of Soybeans and Corn Are Up Their Daily Limits
description: Dry weather over the Grain Belt, dwindling crop surpluses, inventory building by food processors and speculative buying combined yesterday to send soybean and corn futures prices soaring by their daily permissible limits.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Workouts Offer a Peek at the Preakness
description: Yesterday morning, it seemed like the Preakness Stakes was being held in New York instead of Baltimore: three of the favorites had their major Preakness tune-ups yesterday at Belmont Park. Winning Colors, Forty Niner and Brian's Time all had important and impressive workouts and will be vanned to Pimlico tomorrow for the Preakness on Saturday.

title: Review/Theater; Bill Irwin's Adventures as a Post-Modern Hoofer
description: As usual, Bill Irwin's show - in this case, ''Largely/New York'' at City Center Theater - begins with no overture or fanfare. The clown is by himself on stage. Holding a remote control, he points it up at the curtain and slowly the curtain rises, revealing another curtain. Abashed, he pushes the button again. The second curtain rises and behind it is . . . another curtain. Two (or was it three?) curtains later, with a look of perplexed bemusement, he is standing alone on an empty stage.

title: Cleanup for Closed Landfill
description: Federal authorities have reached an agreement with 226 companies that calls for the firms to pay $4.98 million in cleanup costs at the now-closed Kin-Buc Landfill in Edison, N.J., the United States Attorney's office said today. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has identified at least 22 cancer-causing or suspected carcinogenic substances at the former landfill.

title: Griffith Consumers Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chess
description: In capturing the $20,000 first prize in the inaugural World Cup Tournament in Brussels, Anatoly Karpov achieved the 70th tournament victory of his career. The former world champion from the Soviet Union now has a leg up in the competition for the $150,000 prize that will go to the overall winner of four of the six World Cup tournaments. FINAL STANDINGS Player ... Pts.

title: Dole Opposes Deal on Noriega Indictments
description: The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, served notice on the Administration tonight that the Senate would protest if the United States dropped drug indictments against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama as part of a deal to force the ouster of the military leader.

title: 23 Killed in Punjab; Police Battle Sikhs
description: The police said today that at least 23 people had been killed and more than 30 wounded in attacks across Punjab state attributed to Sikh militants.

title: Olson Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,254,000.

title: Long Island Lighting Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,324,110,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Cancer and Early Diet
description: A new study of more than 1,000 Wisconsin residents suggests that frequent childhood consumption of fresh vegetables - especially broccoli, cauliflower and salad - is associated with a reduced risk of developing colon cancer later in life.

title: Bill Seeks Cadavers for the Training of Police Dogs
description: To help train police dogs to track missing persons, two state legislators have introduced a bill to make cadavers available to law-enforcement agencies.

title: Soviet Relinquishes Afghan Province
description: Soviet officials said today that Russian troops had completed their withdrawal from a key eastern Afghan border province that has served as a buffer protecting the area around this capital city from guerrillas based in Pakistan.

title: Books of The Times; On Clear Duplicity and Doubtful Consequence
description: The Secret Lives of Trebitsch Lincoln By Bernard Wasserstein Illustrated. 327 pages. Yale University Press. $27.50.

title: U.S. Clinches Olympic Berth
description: The United States qualified for the soccer competition at the Seoul Olympics when Trinidad and Tobago beat El Salvador, 1-0, Sunday in a qualifying match.

title: Tofutti Brands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a tax benefit of $14,000. There were 13 weeks in the latest quarter, compared with 14 weeks a year ago.

title: Tele-Optics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Television; Program Links C.I.A. to Drug Trafic
description: Does the Central Intelligence Agency assist and even encourage drug smugglers? ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, says it does. Secret wars and the narcotics trade apparently go together. Drug lords have helped finance clandestine operations, the program charges, for 40 years.

title: Artists to Take Part In Tibet House Benefit
description: Laurie Anderson, Philip Glass and Suzanne Vega are among the artists who plan to take part in a benefit performance on May 25 to establish Tibet House, a nonprofit educational and cultural organization that will be supervised by the Dalai Lama.

title: No, PEN Decides, It Won't Invite the Pope to Join
description: It looks as though Pope John Paul II will not be invited to join PEN after all.

title: Appointments At Federated
description: Federated Department Stores, owners of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and other leading stores, announced its first high-level executive appointments since it was acquired by the Campeau Corporation two weeks ago.

title: Addington Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
28 Injured in Cable Car Crash
description: A crowded cable car heading downhill in light rain rammed the rear of a truck stopped at a red light today, injuring at least 28 people.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I suspect, therefore, that members of our society will be shocked to learn that the Court, the ultimate guarantor of liberty, deems unreasonable our expectation that the aspects of our private lives that are concealed safely in a trash bag will not become public.'' - Justice William J. Brennan, in dissent on a ruling that permits the police to freely search through garbage. [ A1:4. ]

title: Candela Laser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Verify, Clarify, Ratify
description: The Senate rightly held back on ratifying the treaty on medium-range missiles in Europe when Soviet-U.S. verification differences sprang up. Now Secretary of State Shultz is back from Geneva with the differences resolved.

title: London Journal; Broken but Unbroken, a Quiet Enemy of Racism
description: Albie Sachs, now the most durable of South Africa's exiled dissidents, sits freshly maimed and hiding in a hospital bed somewhere in Britain, his right arm blown away, his left hand resisting his efforts at conversion to the pen, still his only weapon of protest against apartheid.

title: A LATIN SPECIALIST QUITS WHITE HOUSE
description: A senior White House official responsible for Latin America policy will resign at the end of this month because of differences with a colleague, Administration officials said today.

title: Critics Honor 'Joe Turner'
description: August Wilson's ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' was named the best new play of the 1987-1988 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. ''The Road to Mecca'' by Athol Fugard was named best foreign play, and the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' was named best new musical.

title: Continental General Insurnce Company reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $35,946. c-Includes a capital gain of $275,664.

title: Medco Containment Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What Jeane Says About Don . . .
description: LEAD: Since the first leaks about Donald Regan's memoirs, there has been a rush to denunciation, not of his lack of discretion but of astrology itself. Every night on television, scientists have vied with one another in declaring such study to be empty superstition, while certain religious leaders have excoriated it as unscriptural and unholy.

title: 'Killer' Bees? Get Serious.
description: The equatorial sun bore down on the forested mountainside and the three beekeepers had already broken a sweat inside their protective garb. They had hiked a good quarter-mile up a trail to the hives, isolated because this Venezuelan apiary was no backyard operation: it contained Africanized, ''killer'' bees.

title: U.S. Rig Count Down
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 14 last week, to a total of 883, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 744 a year ago. The rig count reached a peak of 4,500 in December 1981, at the height of the oil boom.

title: Giant Group Ltd. Acts To Sell Cement Unit
description: The Giant Group Ltd., the entertainment and industrial products company controlled by Burt Sugarman, said today that it was negotiating to sell its cement and waste-burning business to the Environmental Treatment and Technologies Corporation for $110 million in cash plus warrants for Environmental Treatment stock.

title: K Mart Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: The latest quarter includes a pretax LIFO charge of $35 million, compared with $22.5 million in the year-ago first quarter. The company said as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the effective tax rate was lower for the latest quarter, 36.5 percent, compared with 40.2 percent for the comparable period last year.

title: Natalie Wales Winslow, Author, 58
description: Natalie Wales Winslow, an author of novels, articles and poetry, died of cancer on May 5 at her home in Winchester, England. She was 58 years old.

title: Sister Mary Beck, 82, Ex-College President
description: Sister Mary Celeste Beck, the president of Molloy College in Rockville Centre, L.I., until 1972, died Saturday at the Queen of the Holy Rosary residence in Amityville, L.I., after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived at the home, the mother house of the Sisters of St. Dominic of Amityville.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet Completes Its Unpredictable Festival
description: Fireworks lighted up the stage if not the sky, and intimations of Old Glory - stars and blurry tones of red and blue - were projected against a backdrop as the New York City Ballet closed its three-week American Music Festival on Sunday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Illinois Seeking Hambletonian
description: A bid by the state of Illinois to bring the Hambletonian harness race back to southern Illinois will include a possible $1 million bonus for the winning horse, an aide to Gov. James R. Thompson said today.

title: Olympic Braodcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Syrian Threat: Warning Signal to Iran
description: Syria's threat to use its army against a pro-Iranian militia in southern Beirut is a signal to Iran that it cannot go too far in challenging Syria's role as a power broker in Lebanon.

title: Biaggi Is Endorsed By Bronx Democrats Despite a Conviction
description: Representative Mario Biaggi was endorsed for renomination yesterday by Bronx Democratic leaders as part of a strategy to retain control over his Congressional seat, which has been threatened by his racketeering trial, a prior conviction and the threat of expulsion from the House.

title: Sea of Paper Work On America's Cup
description: The future of America's Cup yacht racing has become quantifiable. It amounts to more than 15 pounds of legal documents being filed this week with the New York State Supreme Court.

title: Topics of The Times; The Fragrance of Infants
description: The cosmetics industry has flourished by stoking the vanity of the baby boom generation. Now it is at work on babies. Under names like Eau de Senteur and Eau de Toilette, it is selling perfume, soaps and other cosmetics for babies and young children, at prices like $30 for 3.3 ounces. Actually, the targets of this marketing ploy are not ''upscale'' children but their parents. Says an industry consultant: ''It seems to be for guilty yuppie parents who work all the time.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Diamond Crystal Salt Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,648,000 for the quarter and $2,543,000 for the year, and a gain of $4,007,000 from the sale of the sale division for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $256,000 for the quarter and $421,000 for the year. Latest quarter loss from continuing operations reflects a $1,828,000 writedown of investment in a partnership.

title: Bartels & Carstens Adds Associates to Its Name
description: Four people have joined Bartels & Carstens Advertising, which has prompted it to change to Bartels & Carstens and Associates.

title: ALGERIA TO RESUME TIES WITH MOROCCO
description: Algeria and Morocco announced today that they had decided to restore diplomatic relations after 12 years of bitter political dispute.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Harrowing Task
description: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, brought new definition to his career today as he explained how he wound up with a harrowing task behind the White House press podium rather than at harrowing work in the fields of his father's farm.

title: Guidry Says He's Ready to Join Yankees
description: Ron Guidry's corner of the Yankees' clubhouse was back in business yesterday. The pitcher and co-captain, apparently ready to return to work this week after spending the last three months rehabilitating his left shoulder under the Florida sun, could return to the roster within days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International Agricultural trade is not freer, despite promises by officials of the leading industrial nations to begin withdrawing aid to farmers in exporting their crops. Washington is pressing for progress. Page A1

title: Dryclean USA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Saudi Oil Tied to Spot Price
description: Saudi Arabia has informed crude oil customers that its current market-related pricing arrangements will be extended until the end of July, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: Iroquois Brands Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the lower revenue was due to the previously reported sale of Chase Chemical Co., completed during the first quarter of 1988.

title: Senate to Begin Its Debate on Missile Pact Today
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, announced today that the Senate would begin floor debate on the new missile accord on Tuesday because all verification issues had been resolved.

title: Maxxam Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increase in income was the result of the recovery of about $26,400,000 of net unrealized losses on marketable securities during the first quarter of 1988 compared to about $13,200,000 in the year-ago period. Also cited for the rise was an increase in interest income that was principally the result of an increase in investments in cash equivalents.

title: Knight Decides to Stay With Indiana
description: After meeting with the Indiana University president whose recent criticism had troubled him, Bob Knight today ended an obsessive tug-of-war between states by turning down an offer from the University of New Mexico and remaining as basketball coach at Indiana.

title: Forecasts Vary On Trade Data
description: Perhaps the best evidence of skepticism about the monthly trade figures, related both to compilation difficulties and the ''lumpy'' nature of trade flows, is the wide range of forecasts.

title: Syrians Delay Move in Beirut
description: The Syrian Army delayed its deployment in southern Beirut today while Syrian and Iranian officials met in Damascus to discuss ways to avert a head-on collision between the Syrians and the Iranian-backed Party of God.

title: Repurchase Plans Enlarged by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had completed the repurchase of five million class E shares, which reflect the earnings of its Electronic Data Systems Corporation subsidiary, and had authorized a program to repurchase another five million shares.

title: Mowry's Mulligan in Life
description: FOR nearly a decade, the Senior PGA Tour has kept Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, Chi Chi Rodriguez and dozens of other cherished golf names out there on display. It's been their ''mulligan'' in life, a second tee shot from age 50 on. But none of the touring senior pros has hit a longer, straighter mulligan than a new name, Larry Mowry, who suddenly found himself walking onto the final green with Palmer and Player at last year's Pepsi Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga.

title: Treasury Prices Decline Narrowly
description: A sharp rise in commodity prices pushed prices of Treasury notes and bonds narrowly lower yesterday.

title: Prism Entertainment Corp reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $179,000. The company said lower earnings for the latest year were the result of lower sales, an increase in advertising and selling expenses and year-end adjustments of more than $1,200,000 for bad debt expense, inventory writedowns and writeoff of royalty advances. The company also said it has agreed on the principle terms of a merger with Atlantic Entertainment group, a privately held independent film production and theatrical distribution company. The agreement is subject to the approval of the boards of directors of both companies. the company had announced last mongh that it was holding merger discussions with atlantic Entertainment.

title: Devils Aim to Join The N.H.L.'s Elite
description: Although the Devils fell a game short of playing the Edmonton Oilers for the Stanley Cup, they are still quite a distance from the upper echelon of the National Hockey League.

title: Cineplex Odeon reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Police May Search People's Trash Without a Warrant, Court Rules
description: The Supreme Court, over an impassioned dissent, ruled today that the police may freely search through garbage bags and other refuse containers that people leave outside the home for collection.

title: White House Group Recommends Only Limited Changes in Markets
description: The White House working group on the stock market crash recommended changes today that would only slightly alter the way trading is conducted on the nation's exchanges.

title: QVC Network reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A J.W.T. Executive Gets Expanded Duties
description: Donald G. Sullivan, the 47-year-old vice chairman of J. Walter Thompson/USA, has been put in charge of strategic planning, administration and finance by James Patterson, chairman and newly named chief executive.

title: Valhi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,111,000. c-Net loss and includes a tax charge of $7,876,000.

title: Making Trade Data More Precise
description: In addition to the traditional work of foiling drug smugglers and collecting more than a half-billion dollars a year in import duties, A. Robert Beikirch has a new priority: helping to improve America's trade statistics.

title:
Market Place;
Standards Vary For Margin Calls
description: LEAD: THE brokerage customer was miffed. His stock position had been eroding, and he had just received a margin call from his brokerage firm asking for more money. He argued that the equity in the account still exceeded the firm's 30 percent maintenance requirement, that is, his original investment still represented more than 30 percent of the value of the stock.

title: Topics of The Times; Don't Kill the Runoff
description: The New York State Senate recently approved an ill- advised bill to abolish New York City's runoff election system, and persuaded Governor Cuomo to lend his support. The lawmakers' idea apparently was to frustrate the re-election hopes of New York City's Mayor, Edward Koch, since some believe he would benefit from the runoff system. It's up to the Assembly to block this meddling.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sunbelt Savings Head Recalls Better Days
description: LEAD: Thomas J. Wageman, chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association in Dallas, the savings institution that has epitomized the loose lending practices of Texas's boom days, said he always wanted to go West.

title: New Fluid Thickens In an Electric Field
description: A UNIVERSITY of Michigan physicist has invented a fluid that thickens in response to an electric field, and he believes the material is destined to change technology as radically as the transistor.

title: Cajun Electric Power Co-op Places Top Yield at 10 1/8%
description: Cajun Electric Power Co-op Inc. of Baton Rouge, La., is offering $200 million of noncallable cooperative utility trust certificates in a three-part financing through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The issue is supported by loans that were bought by Cajun Electric from the Agriculture Department's Rural Electrification Agency.

title: Baseball; A's Keep Rolling, Shut Out Red Sox
description: Dave Parker hit a two-run homer and Storm Davis worked out of two early bases-loaded jams tonight, leading the Oakland Athletics to a 3-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Rating Upgraded For Dow Chemical
description: The rating on about $4 billion of debt issued by the Dow Chemical Corporation and its units was increased yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Excerpts From Koop Report on Smoking
description: Following are excerpts from Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's report on smoking: Nicotine: Pharmacokinetics, Metabolism and Pharmacodynamics

title: Pepitone to Begin 6-Month Jail Term
description: Joe Pepitone, visibily nervous, was led out of a Brooklyn courtroom in handcuffs yesterday to begin serving a six-month jail sentence for his 1986 conviction for possession of Quaaludes and drug paraphernalia.

title: Senate Vote Indicates Support for a Death Penalty in Drug Killings
description: Continuing its campaign to get tough on drugs, the Senate today signaled strong support for a Federal death penalty for drug-related killings.

title: KEY RATES
Voters Near Denver Will Decide Today on Airport
description: Adams County residents vote Tuesday on whether to allow Denver to annex 44.7 square miles of farmland to build what is described here as the largest airport in the world.

title: Artificial Heart in Turmoil
description: A permanent, fully implanted artificial heart has been one of medicine's most ambitious and controversial goals, and the Federally financed research project in pursuit of it has run a rocky course from its start 25 years ago.

title: National Heritage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
By Design; Flowers and Fresh Greens
description: Some fashion successes are easy to fathom, while others are not. The fabric flower, fastened to a barrette, has replaced the bow as this season's most popular hair ornament, store spokesmen say. Other fashion observers report spotting scarves, skirts and shirts blooming with big floral prints all over town, even on the formerly clad-all-in-black downtowners.

title: Perron Resigns
description: Jean Perron resigned yesterday as coach of the Montreal Canadiens, who finished second in the overall National Hockey League standings but were eliminated from the playoffs by the Boston Bruins in the Adams Division final. In making the announcement at a news conference, the Montreal general manager, Serge Savard, reported that Perron ''said he found the pressures of the job were quite difficult for him, and especially for his family.'' There were several publicized incidents between Perron and his players in the season. ''He was criticized openly by the players, and it may have affected him,'' Savard said. Perron, 41 years old, will not remain with the organization. He coached the Canadiens for three seasons, leading them to the Stanley Cup championship in his first year.(AP)

title: Pope Lectures Paraguay Leader on Human Rights
description: Visiting Gen. Alfredo Stroessner in the presidential palace from which he has ruled Paraguay for 34 years, Pope John Paul II delivered a tough lecture today on human rights and political freedoms.

title: 3 Are Killed And 20 Hurt In Bus Crash
description: Three people were killed and 20 others were injured yesterday afternoon when a school bus carrying mentally handicapped people overturned on a sharp downhill curve, hit a utility pole and slid down a wooded embankment in northern Dutchess County, the authorities said.

title: Gooden Is Hit Hard, but Mets Hit Harder
description: Dwight Gooden pitched ragged ball for the third straight time tonight, but still won his seventh game without a loss when Gary Carter hit a three-run home run in the seventh inning to beat the San Diego Padres, 7-4.

title: Inquiry Into a South Bronx Group Becomes an Issue in Gentile's Race
description: In an action that has become an issue in a primary campaign, the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, did not pursue theft and forgery charges against officials of a South Bronx community group last year after a grand jury had voted to indict them.

title: Kinnard Investments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a supplier of products and services for aviation, appointed Richard D. Tabery vice chairman, effective June 1.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Opinions on Searches of Curbside Trash by Police
description: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supeme Court's decision today that the police may freely search through garbage left outside homes for collection. Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Harry A. Blackman, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. dissented, joined by Justice Thurgood Marshall. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy did not participate. FROM THE MAJORITY OPINION By Justice White

title: Pentagon Says Drug War Will Cost $2 Billion
description: The Defense Department has begun gearing up for an expanded role in the war on drugs, and senior Pentagon officials have warned Congress that the effort will cost $2 billion.

title: Poll Shows Dukakis Leads Bush; Many Reagan Backers Shift Sides
description: Michael S. Dukakis is capitalizing on deep public doubts about Vice President Bush and the Reagan Administration's handling of key issues and has emerged as the early favorite for the Presidential election in November, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Students in Debt: Society Pays a Price, Too; Banks vs. Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Bridge is perhaps the only sport or recreation in which players can put their expertise in cold storage for a decade or more and return to action successfully.

title: Lane Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Yankee Call: Getcha Fresh Shrimp!
description: Robert Brown was getting a pregame snack at Yankee Stadium last weekend. For the first time in stadium history, he had lots of choices - sandwiches, pizza, hamburgers, chicken fingers, egg rolls or french fries. He could drink an imported beer, like Dos Equis. He could even eat clams or shrimp, served from a raw bar in little plastic boats.

title: Wearing Spielberg Down To Put 'E.T.' on Cassette
description: ''We finally wore Steven Spielberg down,'' said Gene Giaquinto, president of M.C.A. Home Entertainment, in explaining why ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' is to be released on video cassette in October.

title: Driver Charged With 27 Murder Counts
description: The driver of a pickup truck that was driven the wrong way on an interstate highway and slammed head-on into a church bus was charged today with 27 counts of capital murder, one count for each person killed in the fiery crash near here Saturday night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Armtek Corp., New Haven, and Pirelli S.p.A. said they had signed a stock purchase agreement for the sale of Armtek's Armstrong tire business to Pirelli for about $197 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Crowds at the Capitol
description: Because of security precautions and a great increase in visitors, guided tours of the Capitol have been sharply cut back, according the the Capitol Guide Service.

title: Industrial Output Rose 0.7% in April
description: Output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in April after two months of virtually no growth, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the biggest advance since a 1.1 percent surge in October.

title: Soviet Television Broadcasts Censored Film About Stalin
description: A two-hour documentary film held back by Soviet censors for eight months was shown on television tonight, drawing together critics and defenders of Stalin to put his leadership on trial.

title: Inmates Release Last 2 Hostages, Ending 3-Day Siege in Oklahama
description: Inmates at a medium-security state prison released their last two hostages today, ending a three-day prison riot in which they seized eight hostages.

title: Honduran Envoy Held On a Cocaine Charge
description: A Honduran diplomat was ordered held without bail today after he arrived at Miami airport with almost 26 pounds of cocaine in his luggage, Federal authorities reported.

title: G.&W. Buys Quercus Corp.
description: Gulf and Western Inc. announced yesterday that it had acquired the Quercus Corporation, a junior and senior high school special education publisher. Quercus will become part of the Globe Book Company, a unit of the Secondary Education Group of Simon & Schuster.

title: Gulf Insurance Rate Cut
description: Lloyd's of London has cut war-risk rates for general cargoes in much of the southwest Persian Gulf, it said today. The new rate for non-oil cargoes, which took effect Thursday, is 0.25 percent of the cargo's value, down from 0.30 percent. The rate for oil cargoes remains unchanged at 0.375 percent.

title: Convest Energy Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
College Baseball Playoffs
description: The Big East Conference double-elimination baseball playoffs will begin today at 5 P.M. a with a doubleheader at Muzzy Field in Bristol, Conn. In the opener, top-seeded Villanova (16-2 in league games, 30-20 over all) will play St. John's (9-9, 23-16-1). In the second game, Seton Hall (12-6, 38-14) will play Providence (12-6, 22-27).

title: Our Towns; Imagine a Light On Your Head At the Y.W.C.A.
description: The Women's Network has been meeting at the Y.W.C.A. here for years. Eighty percent of the women are college graduates, 40 percent have advanced degrees. Two-thirds earn more than $40,000, 20 percent more than $75,000. At the start of meetings, these businesswomen introduce themselves. They work for Texaco, Merrill Lynch, New York Telephone, I.B.M. One said, ''If you want to buy any buildings, get in touch.''

title: Israeli Troops Kill Protester in Gaza
description: Two Palestinians died and at least seven others were shot and wounded in renewed demonstrations across the occupied territories today. But this evening the Israeli Army tried to determine if one of those killed, an Arab youth said to have been shot by soldiers, had actually died of natural causes.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up by 17.08 Points
description: Stock prices rallied late yesterday in continued lackluster trading, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average over the 2,000 mark.

title: Korea Eases Gold Curb
description: South Korea plans to lift import restrictions and slash taxes on gold to help end widespread smuggling, Government officials said. At least 20 to 30 metric tons of gold a year have been smuggled into South Korea, compared with about 24 tons imported legally, economic planning officials said Saturday.

title: Television Reflects No Alien Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: European Output Up 2%
description: Industrial production in the European Community increased by 2 percent last year, compared with 3.8 percent in the United States and 4 percent in Japan, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. The increase was marginally bigger than output growth of 1.9 percent registered in 1986.

title: U.N. Ends Aid to Camp Held by Khmer Rouge
description: A United Nations agency assisting Cambodian refugees along the Thai-Cambodian border has stopped deliveries of food to a civilian camp under the control of the Khmer Rouge.

title: Business and Health; Guide Assesses New Technology
description: COPIES of a 700-page directory intended to facilitate the search for information on the safety, efficacy and cost effectiveness of medical technology have been arriving at offices around the country in recent weeks. The directory's publisher, the Council on Health Care Technology, is a Government-private group that hopes its Medical Technology Assessment Directory is just the beginning in dealing with an intimidating health-care delivery problem.

title: United Companies Financial Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALLIES FALTERING IN EFFORT TO END AID FOR FARMERS
description: A year after promising to begin a process of withdrawing aid to farmers in exporting crops, officials of the leading industrial countries concede that they have made no real progress and do not hold much hope for any soon.

title: Suspect in an Officer's Death Is Held
description: A 28-year-old parolee, tracked to an apartment in northwest Philadelphia by New York City investigators, was captured in a police raid at dawn yesterday and held in connection with the slaying last month of a young housing police officer in Brooklyn.

title: Shultz, in Talks With Peres, Rejects 'Status Quo'
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel discussed Middle East peace prospects and the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories today as he met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and members of Congress.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS U.S. Edges Switzerland: The United States came from behind yesterday to edge Switzerland, 2-1, in the opening round of the $750,000 World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, West Germany. In the other match in the eight-team competition, Argentina and France were tied at 1-1. That match will be completed today. Switzerland took an unexpected 1-0 lead over the Americans when Jakob Hlasek, coming off a four-month layoff after an auto accident, upset Tim Mayotte, ranked 10th in the world, 6-2, 4-6, 6-2. But the United States evened the match after a rain delay when Aaron Krickstein trounced Roland Stadler, 6-3, 6-0. Ken Flach and Robert Seguso then defeated Hlasek and Stadler in the doubles, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, to give the United States the match. In the Argentina-France matches, the second singles was delayed because of the late arrival of Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, who had lost in five sets to Ivan Lendl in Sunday's final of the Italian Open in Rome. Argentina's Martin Jaite had little trouble with Guy Forget of France, defeating him by 6-2, 6-3. In the doubles, Forget teamed with Tarik Benhabiles to beat Jaite and Eduardo Bengoechea, 6-4, 6-7, 7-6. (AP)

title: Beene's Way With Furs: Masterly and Irreverent
description: With equal helpings of originality and exuberance, seasoned with frivolity, Geoffrey Beene got the week of fall fur showings off to an exciting start yesterday. He mixed fur with feathers and fabrics, dyed some pelts unlikely shades like taxicab yellow and tomato red and even lined sober sable with wildly patterned silks.

title: New Process Saves Books
description: A book preservation technique developed by the Library of Congress shows promise, but alternatives should also be considered, according to a study by the Federal Office of Technology Assessment.

title: Nestle Formalizes Bid for Rowntree
description: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. formalized its offer of $:2.1 billion ($3.97 billion) for the British candy company Rowntree P.L.C. amid speculation that Jacobs Suchard A.G. would make a counteroffer. Nestle's managing director, Helmut Maucher, said in a letter to Rowntree shareholders: ''We are convinced that a merger of Rowntree and Nestle's chocolate and confectionery business is in the best long-term interests of both companies.''

title: Lane Enters Draft
description: Jerome Lane of Pittsburgh has decided to skip his final year of college eligibility and has made himself available for the National Basketball Association draft. He joins Rex Chapman of Kentucky, Rod Strickland of DePaul, Tito Horford of Miami and Charles Shackleford of North Carolina. Lane, a 6-6 forward from Akron, Ohio, averaged 13.9 points and 12.2 rebounds last season, becoming Pitt's third leading career rebounder and eighth leading scorer.(AP)

title: Doctors Can Sue In Peer Reviews, Justices Declare
description: In a case of great importance to the medical profession, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that hospital peer review committees are not absolutely immune from antitrust suits brought by the doctors they penalize.

title: Frontier Texas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Angolan Affirms Wider Cuban Role
description: Rejecting comparisons with the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, Angola's President said today that the Cuban force here had been reinforced.

title: Clayton Fox Nenno, Priest, 69
description: The Rev. Clayton Fox Nenno, a Jesuit priest and a former teacher at St. Peter's Preparatory School in Jersey City, died of heart failure Thursday after surgery at Arden Hill Hospital in Goshen, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived at the Gonzaga Seven Springs Jesuit Community in Monroe, N.Y.

title: Student's Suicide Stirs Protests in South Korea
description: A student committed suicide Sunday to demand the release of political prisoners and the reunification of Korea. The death set off protests today by hundreds of students, who hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police here.

title: Texaco Says It Is Talking With Icahn
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it was engaged in talks with Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, in an effort to resolve their differences over the company's future.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Hutton Pays Fines to U.S.
description: E. F. Hutton, now part of Shearson Lehman Hutton, today paid $1.01 million in fines for a money-laundering scheme in which $1.5 million in cash was hidden from the Government for clients, some of them members of organized crime.

title: International Recovery Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results have been restated for the acquisition of Resource Recovery of America Inc. on Jan. 4, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Omnicom Preparing for Acquisitions
description: THE tumultuous events in adland in the last 18 months were felt yesterday at the annual meeting of the Omnicom Group, whose shareholders voted to allow the board to issue more stock so as better to compete in the acquisition marketplace with the deep-pocketed British companies.

title: National Gallery to Show Jasper Johns Drawing
description: The National Gallery of Art plans to mount a retrospective of the drawings of Jasper Johns in mid-May 1990 for his 60th birthday, something it has rarely done for the works of a living artist.

title: Benny Goodman Archive Releases First Recording
description: ''The Benny Goodman Yale Archives, Volume 1,'' 12 previously unavailable selections from the clarinetist's private tapes, was released yesterday on the Musicmasters label. It is a sampling of the material from Mr. Goodman's musical archives, which he bequeathed to the Yale Music Library. He died in 1986.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about new anti-crack legislation in New York State misstated the scope of the bill.

title: Visa and Sony Turn to Soviet
