description: Pepsi-Cola got a considerable amount of publicity from its announcement May 4 that it would become a television advertiser in the Soviet Union starting yesterday. But it is not the only company buying such advertising.

title: Swept Out in Storm but Offered Refuge
description: Terry Eastland has spent much of his working life on the editorial pages of various newspapers across the South. But he caught the eye of true believers in the conservative movement with his essays on constitutional issues for a variety of national publications.

title: Manslaughter Charge Filed In Killing of Police Sergeant
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted a woman yesterday on charges of second-degree manslaughter in the shooting death of a New York City police sergeant, although the fatal shots were fired by another officer.

title: Jackson Seeks a Strong Oregon Vote
description: The voters of Oregon have a reputation for upsetting Presidential front-runners, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson is asking them to do it again in Tuesday's primary.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about the New York State Investigation Commission's finding evidence of possible extortion by Alexander A. Levine, the former executive director of the State Thruway Authority, characterized the commission incorrectly. It was established by the State Legislature.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Drug Tests Likely?
description: Bus drivers, subway operators and other mass transit workers may soon be required to submit to random drug testing.

title: Kodak to Compensate Instant Camera Owners
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had agreed to set up a $150 million compensation program for the millions of American consumers who bought Kodak instant cameras before the cameras and their film were taken off the market in 1986.

title: Telemundo Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company noted that the television broadcasting business is seasonal with the first quarter generally contributing the lowest level of revenue. The company said increased revenue and reduction in interest expense resulting from the recapitalization of the company in August 1987 was partially offset by the increased costs associated with the expansion of the company's network operations. The company bought station KTMD serving Houston-Galveston in April 1988 and added several affiliates to its network line-up.

title: Milton U. Copland, 79, Executive for Builder
description: Milton U. Copland, for many years a top officer of the Uris Buildings Corporation, a major developer of Manhattan office towers, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: German Trade Surplus
description: West Germany's trade surplus fell 21 percent in February, to 8.2 billion marks, or $13.8 billion, from 10.4 billion marks in the period a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The surplus came to 8.5 billion marks in January. The February trade report had been delayed for six weeks because a new reporting system based on European Community guidelines went into effect.

title: MEESE DISMISSES CHIEF SPOKESMAN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has dismissed his chief spokesman, Terry Eastland, provoking further turmoil in a Justice Department already torn by resignations and concern over investigations into Mr. Meese's affairs.

title: Iverson Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Crown Brands Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said the increase in sales was mainly due to the inclusion of the sales of I. Rokeach & Sons Inc. and its subsidiaries for all of 1987 as compared with only five months of 1986. The company also said the loss resulted from a number of factors, including extraordinary professional fees of almost $500,000; interest expense of about $1,370,000; and additional selling, general and administrative expenses.

title: World Bank Criticizes Lag in Third World Aid
description: The international strategy for resolving the third world's debt crisis is being jeopardized by the refusal of private banks to cooperate and by lower-than-expected economic growth in the industrial world, according to a World Bank report.

title: Spinks to Sign Pact
description: Michael Spinks and Butch Lewis, his promoter-adviser, are scheduled to sign contacts today for Spinks's fight against the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, on June 27 in Atlantic City. Milton Chwasky, Lewis's attorney, reported their plans to sign the pacts. Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager, said all other parties in the fight had signed contracts. The delay in signing contracts by Lewis and Spinks involves changing the contract language involving HBO, which is suing Lewis over withdrawing Spinks from its televised heavyweight championship unification series in 1986.(AP)

title: Hard Lessons in Grief To Absorb So Young
description: Charlie Jones, the principal of the Radcliff Middle School, thumbed through the dark blue 1988 yearbook today, pointing out 16 of the children who died in one of the worst bus accidents in United States history.

title: Police Officer Is Suspended
description: A 27-year-old probationary police officer was suspended yesterday on charges that he used unnecessary force in subduing an emotionally disturbed patient at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens, the police said. Officer Stephen Benner, appointed to the force in July 1987, struck the patient, a 24-year-old woman from Jackson Heights, Queens, in the face after she spit at him, the police said. The patient, who was not identified by the police, suffered facial lacerations.

title: Iceland Lowers Currency Value
description: Iceland devalued its currency, the crown, by 10 percent today to help its fishing industry, which has been suffering from falling prices abroad.

title: SBK Acquires Stake in Cinecom
description: SBK Entertainment World Inc. has acquired a substantial interest in Cinecom Entertainment Group, an independent film production and distribution company, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Telecom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: LTV Gets an Extension
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York today granted the LTV Corporation a 90-day extension to file a reorganization plan for the company and its 65 subsidiaries. With the extension, LTV has until Aug. 18 the exclusive right to present a reorganization plan to the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The court in February extended the deadline to May 20 from Feb. 20 at the steel and aerospace giant's request. LTV filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in 1986.

title: Chemistry of Seeing
description: USING pulses of laser light that last for only six millionths of one billionth of a second, scientists have directly observed a fundamental chemical reaction that permits animals to see.

title: Healthways Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Poland Is Said to Free Some Leaders in Strike
description: Communist authorities today released Janusz Onyszkiewicz, a spokesman for the outlawed Solidarity union, and 11 strike leaders jailed in connection with Poland's recent wave of unrest, opposition representatives said.

title: Bring Students and Their Mentors Together More Efficiently
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Affirms F.C.C. Control Of Quality of Cable Signals
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a Federal Communications Commission rule that bars state and local governments from imposing more stringent standards for the technical quality of cable television signals than those established by the commission.

title: Clark's Homer Seals Victory
description: First there was the home run. Then the standing ovation. When the night was over, Billy Martin sat behind his desk in the Yankee clubhouse and smiled.

title: Careers; Liberal Arts: High Road to 'Bottom Line'
description: A NEW study of liberal arts graduates in the business world is optimistic. The study, ''Liberal Education and Corporate America,'' was prepared by Prof. Michael Useem of Boston University.

title: Reviews/Music; Springsteen at the Garden
description: ''There comes a time when you've got to take the past and put it behind you,'' Bruce Springsteen said at Madison Square Garden last night during the opening show of his ''Tunnel of Love Express Tour.'' Mr. Springsteen's reflection was part of a monologue that introduced a powerful, hard-edged new rock song, ''Spare Parts,'' about young love, pregnancy and abandonment, but his words also evoked the transitional position in which America's quintessential rock hero finds himself.

title: Jackson, Citing 'Fairness,' Asserts He Expects Role in Picking Ticket
description: With a hint of anger, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he expected to play a powerful role in the selection of the Democratic Presidential ticket as well as in writing the party's platform.

title: Favorite in May Is Favorite in Fall, Too
description: While polls taken six months before the election cannot be taken as predictive of the ultimate outcome, surveys by The New York Times/CBS News Poll since it was established in 1976 suggest that the candidate whom the electorate loved in May was also its favorite in November.

title: For Travelers, Milk From Immunized Cows
description: SCIENTISTS have devised ways to enrich cow's milk - in the cow - with antibodies that may prevent traveler's diarrhea, according to a new study.

title: Farrar, Straus Thrives On Success of 2 Novels
description: The backbone of publishing is backlist books, those that will still be around years after this season's best sellers have been remaindered. But best sellers are also important, providing not just prestige but help for a publisher's large overhead.

title: Politics Hasn't Yet Swayed the High Court
description: To the Editor:

title: DeBartolo Case Delayed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing in Federal court in Washington with attorneys representing the real estate developer Edward J. Debartolo Sr., his son and his company had been indefinitely postponed because of an agreement by the attorneys to cooperate fully with the Federal agency.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does a magnet lose its power over time?

title: Lacrosse Notebook; Strong Finish Earns Cornell an N.C.A.A. Tournament Bid
description: Cornell was invited while Hofstra, C. .W Post and Rutgers were not. In essence, that was the selection process for the 12-team field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: Home Loan Agency's Rates
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks will set interest rates today for a three-part bond offering totaling $3.18 billion.

title: Lies Can Point to Mental Disorders or Signal Normal Growth
description: WHILE recognizing that lying is a universal lubricant of social life, psychiatrists are seeking to determine when it becomes destructive and just which kinds of mental problems it can typify.

title: New York City Asks State And U.S. for AIDS Help
description: New York City, facing a dramatic rise in AIDS cases, will be unable to deal with the epidemic without more help from Federal and state agencies and the full participation of voluntary and private hospitals and clinics, a city report released yesterday said.

title: Union Narrowly Wins Tough Battle to Represent Harvard Workers
description: Harvard University's office, service and technical workers voted narrowly today to accept union representation.

title: Albany Panel Backs Work Limits For State Employees in Campaigns
description: A legislative commission recommended yesterday that employees of the Legislature be barred from working on election campaigns while on the job and from using state computers, mailing lists and cars for campaign purposes.

title: Fireproof Crates Called for on Jets
description: Prompted by the crash of a South African Airways Boeing 747 last November, the National Transportation Safety Board on Monday urgently recommended requiring fire-resistant containers for cargo carried on main passenger decks of airliners.

title: Forum Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year includes a gain of $1,354,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: The Limits of Mubarak Awad's Moderation; A Voice of Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Bipartisan Reading
description: It is not too often these days that the Senate majority and minority leaders find themselves in agreement. It is even more unusual for an author to find his work praised in a Senate debate, as happened in a debate on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The work in question is a new book by Clyde V. Prestowitz, former counselor to the Commerce Secretary and a negotiator on trade issues with Japan.

title: USR Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Education; Words to Sentences, Mystery for Linguists
description: A baby learning to talk tackles a task that might be compared to learning a foreign language without a translator or a dictionary or even a command of a native language to use as a base. Yet virtually all children understand scores of words and can speak simple sentences by the time they are 3 years old.

title: Howard Nemerov Named 3d U.S. Poet Laureate
description: Twenty-five years ago, Howard Nemerov held the chair of consultant in poetry to the Library of Congress, a title that has since been redesignated and glorified by Public Law 99-194, enacted in 1985. As of September, Mr. Nemerov will become poet laureate consultant in poetry, or, more simply, the poet laureate of the United States.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Iglesias and Wonder

title: Sbarro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
description: The company said that effective Jan. 1, it changed from a 12-month fiscal year ending on Dec. 31, to a 52- week fiscal year ending on the Sunday nearest to Dec. 31. As a result, the company's 1988 sedond, third and fourth fiscal quarters will end on July 17, Oct. 9, and Jan. 1, 1989, respectively.

title: Solentiname Journal; Font of Lush Paintings, Inspired by a Rebel Priest
description: The peasants on this pristine archipelago raise cattle and grow rice and beans like peasants everywhere in Central America, but unlike others, they are also artists whose paintings have been exhibited around the world.

title: PARTY RULES CITED BY JACKSON CAMP
description: In a move that sets the stage for a potential fight over delegates at the Democratic National Convention, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign plans to send a letter to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis charging that the nomination process is ''inequitable,'' ''demonstrably unfair'' and ''distorted by rules that favor insider politics.''

title: Blues Dismiss Coach
description: The St. Louis Blues, dissatisfied with the team's early exits from the National Hockey League playoffs the past two seasons, dismissed Coach Jacques Martin yesterday. ''Over the past two seasons we have had a dramatic infusion of young talent into this hockey club,'' General Manager Ron Caron said. ''The measure of that talent influx has not been matched in results. Over Martin's tenure we were less than .500 and won only one of three playoff series.'' The Blues' record the past two seasons was 66-71-23. Martin was hired June 26, 1986, after Jacques Demers left for a lucrative contract with the Detroit Red Wings. Martin, 35 years old, had no experience in the N.H.L. and was the youngest coach in the Blues' history. ''I think that whatever I've accomplished, I'm a better man now than when I came here,'' Martin said. (AP)

title: Placid Oil Will Sell Properties to Nerco
description: The Hunt brothers' Placid Oil Company has agreed to sell its oil and gas interests in the Black Lake field in Louisiana to Nerco Inc., a natural resources company in Portland, Ore., for $150 million in cash. Nerco has also agreed to acquire other Placid properties, including a pipeline from Louisiana to Texas, a company spokesman said.

title: First Russian Column Leaves Afghanistan
description: The first Soviet troop convoy to withdraw from Afghanistan crossed the border into the Soviet Union this morning.

title: Cut in Gains Tax Doubted
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Lloyd Bentsen, said today that Congress is not likely to cut the capital gains tax unless other taxes are raised. Such a cut is one of Vice President Bush's proposals in his Presidential campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the credit markets incorrectly described the Kimberly-Clark Corporation's new three-year notes.

title: Texfi Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,084,000 and $1,896,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,036,000 and $2,360,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sports of The Times; What Do You Really Think?
description: THE imprisonment of Joe Pepitone on drug charges is another example of why sports fans and particularly parents should not expect every athlete to be a hero.

title: Kent Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The company completed a public offering on July 8, 1987.

title: Bronx Drug Adviser Shoots Supervisor and Kills Himself
description: A counselor at a Bronx methadone clinic shot and wounded a supervisor yesterday and killed himself as patients and staff members barricaded themselves behind locked doors.

title: More Hutton Laundering Is Suspected
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which pleaded guilty earlier this week to charges that an E. F. Hutton & Company branch had laundered money, disclosed today that it had uncovered further instances of possible money laundering at several New York City branch offices of E. F. Hutton.

title: Review/Theater; 'Spoils of War,' in a Family, Life and the World
description: In ''Spoils of War,'' Michael Weller's wrenching new play at the Second Stage, a 16-year-old boy named Martin will stop at nothing to mend the pieces of his broken household. The time is the Eisenhower 1950's, and Martin (Christopher Collet), a precocious only child, is all too keenly aware that the era's promised ideal of the model home has eluded him. His much-married mother, Elise (Kate Nelligan), is a free-living radical who parks him in a progressive boarding school. His father, Andrew (Larry Bryggman), hasn't been heard from in ages. Yet Martin clings to the dream that he can somehow bring his parents back together. The boy imagines that if only his father saw his mother again he ''would see what he was missing'' and take her ''dancing on the roof of that hotel in Brooklyn, like the old days.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about locusts in Africa gave an incorrect citation for a Biblical quotation about the insects. The correct verse was Exodus 10:15.

title: Giants Plan to See More of Top Rookie
description: Eric Moore was in the first grade when his father walked away and never came back. The experience left him hurt, but not devastated. And it surely prepared him for the time when, a decade later, college football recruiters did the same thing.

title: 2 Styles That Couldn't Be More Different
description: After six weeks of playoff eliminations, two teams remain in contention for the Stanley Cup, teams that have had identical springtime success despite the fact that they don't resemble each other in the least.

title: Sailor's Death Spurs Review of Training
description: The chief of Navy training, Vice Admiral N. R. Thunman, said today that he had ordered a thorough review of training procedures that involve risk. He said he was acting to prevent another death like that of Lee William Mirecki, a sailor who drowned in an air-sea rescue exercise.

title: Pennsylvania Bond Yields Range From 5% to 7.65%
description: The largest competitive deal yesterday was a $155 million Pennsylvania general obligation bond offering, which was awarded to an underwriting group led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell & Howell Co., Skokie, Ill., said its shareholders had approved a proposal for a management-led group to take the company private at $64 a share.

title: Review/Music; Metier of Modern Dance
description: There is music that demands to be danced - almost anything by Tchaikovsky, for instance - and other music that dancers must bend to their purposes. Many works of the latter sort, such as the aleatory pieces by John Cage that Merce Cunningham has often found useful, function as sound backdrops against which apparently unrelated choreography plays itself out. There is yet another type of music that, while not actually setting out to discourage dancing, may severely strain the connections between the two art forms.

title: Warner Signs Lorimar Pact
description: Warner Communications Inc. and the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation announced today that they had signed a definitive agreement for Warner to acquire Lorimar, producer of ''Dallas'' and other hit TV shows, in a stock swap.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $10,100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $10,199,000 for the quarter and $39,662,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes extraordinary charges of $29,253,000 related to restructuring. The company said the latest third quarter loss is after a tax credit of $2,900,000. There were no common share earnings on the year-ago final 9-month net income because it did not cover preferred dividend requirements. The company also said that because of its recently completed restructuring the financial results are not comparable with a year-ago.

title: PLM International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was consolidated from 21 limited partnerships Feb. 1.

title: Landlords Rally to Protest Rent Laws
description: In what has become a springtime ritual here, more than 1,000 landlords rallied outside the State Capitol today and then fanned out through its corridors to lobby against a variety of rent-regulation bills.

title: Searle Disputes Infertility Claim
description: Medical records do not support a woman's contention that the Copper-7 intrauterine device caused her infertility, a lawyer for the IUD's manufacturer, G. D. Searle & Company, told a Federal jury today.

title: Inland Gold & Silver Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are not available because the company, which was formed in January 1987, and went public in July, did not begin production until the fourth quarter last year.

title: Chances Are Slim, But This Jet Is Not
description: When the Jets surprised Albert Goss of Jackson State by taking him as their final selection in the draft, they also wound up with the heaviest player in their history: 348 pounds.

title: Baldwin & Lyons In Filing on Uslico
description: Baldwin & Lyons Inc. disclosed that it had filed for permission from insurance regulators in various states to increase its stake in the Uslico Corporation from 9.8 percent, to up to 20 percent. The filings are necessary because Uslico, a financial services holding concern in Arlington, Va., has two divisions engaged in life and property and casualty insurance. Several states require regulatory approval of purchases of more than 10 percent of an insurance company's shares outstanding.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 3 P.M.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: CHICAGO
description: ''YOU have exported your fast-food chains to our country,'' said Alfonso Ornelas, personnel manager for a chain of Mexican restaurants called Chon y Chano. ''Now we have given Chicago one of Mexico City's fast-food taquerias with our own particular style.''

title: Ms. Cooper, a Writer, Marries Paul R. Noble
description: The marriage of Paulette Marcia Cooper, an author and travel columnist, to Paul Ronald Noble, a television producer, took place yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Neil Cooper, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Beman Quits Playing
description: Commissioner Deane Beman of the PGA Tour has decided to abandon his role as an active player. ''I simply do not have the time necessary to prepare for competition if I am to continue as commissioner, and I intend to do that,'' Beman said by telephone from his office in Ponte Vedra, Fla. ''I will not compete in Europe this summer. I will not attempt to qualify for the U.S. Open. And I will not enter the Seniors Open.'' Beman, 50 years old, competed in foreign tournaments in 1986-87 and played in the Legends of Golf in Austin, Tex., two weeks ago. His participation prompted mild criticism from some other players.(AP)

title: Experience Profits a Promoter
description: In 1984, when Evander Holyfield, the Olympic bronze medalist, was considering which promoter he would fight for as a professional, he turned down an offer from Josephine Abercrombie's Houston Boxing Association, even though the association offered more money than he got from the promoter he chose, Dan Duva.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FIRM-FLESHED, meaty halibut, which is entering its peak season in Northeastern waters, is one of my favorite fish for outdoor barbecuing and broiling. Its mild flavor can be enhanced in limitless ways with herb marinades.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page in some copies yesterday about Clark M. Clifford omitted the name of the person assisting Mr. Clifford with his memoirs. He is Richard C. Holbrooke, a former Assistant Secretary of State, who is continuing his duties as a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the New York investment bank.

title: Merger Will Create No. 1 Bank in Spain
description: The chairmen of two leading Spanish banks announced plans today to merge their institutions and create Spain's biggest commercial bank. Alfonso Escamez, chairman of Banco Central, and Mario Conde, chairman of Banco Espanol de Credito, appeared on Spanish television after their boards had approved the deal.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Animed Inc., Roslyn, L.I., a veterinary clinical service and diagnostic company, appointed Larry P. Rapp chief financial officer.

title: Why 'Circuit-Breakers' Will Backfire
description: LEAD: Stock market ''circuit breakers,'' proposed this week by the Administration's second heavyweight panel on the stock market crash, will exacerbate the problem of market volatility they are purported to solve.

title: Review/Film; The Many Kinds of Division in Israel
description: In its exasperatingly prolix and tendentious way, ''Shattered Dreams'' accents the growing political, economic, social and religious divisions that are putting dangerous strains on Israeli democracy. The painfully timely British-made documentary, which opens at Film Forum 1 today, is filled with confrontations between Arabs and Israelis, hard-liners and Peace Now demonstrators, religious zealots and people who drive on the Sabbath. The sympathies of the movie makers, Victor Schonfeld and Jenifer Millstone, are never in doubt. They are for peace and against zealotry. They like scenes of Jews and Arabs singing and dancing together.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: THE Chino Farm, 25 miles north of San Diego in a lush valley called Rancho Santa Fe, has taken on something of a cult status among food lovers across the country. When you mention its name to those in the know, a look of reverence crosses their faces and they wax rhapsodic about the perfect carrots, succulent strawberries and juicy tomatoes.

title: Court Upholds Tougher Fuel Ratings
description: Displaying a bitter ideological split, a Federal appeals court today backed changes in fuel economy ratings that could cost the nation's two largest auto makers $300 million in penalties.

title: Heileman Division
description: The Australian owner of the G. Heileman Brewing Company agreed to sell Heileman's baking division to RT Group S.A., a privately held Belgian sugar producer. Terms were not disclosed. BBH US Inc., a subsidiary of Bond Corporation Holdings of Australia, which last year bought the Wisconsin brewer for $1.26 billion, said the Heileman Baking Company has 12 bakeries in five states in the Midwest. Heileman's brands include Old Style, Colt 45, Lone Star and Carling Black Label.

title: Investors at Lear Oppose Stock Plan
description: A group of investment partnerships that controls 10.4 percent of the preferred stock of the Lear Petroleum Corporation said they would oppose the terms under which the British Petroleum Corporation has agreed to redeem Lear's preferred shares. The redemption is part of BP America's merger agreement with the Dallas-based natural gas transport concern.

title: Dukakis Defeats Jackson In Oregon Presidential Vote
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts strengthened his claim to the Democratic Presidential nomination today by defeating the Rev. Jesse Jackson in Oregon's primary.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: New York City plans to sell about $200 million in general obligation bonds by competitive bidding no later than June 30, according to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: 'Windsor Fallout': Jewels as Investment
description: LAST October, two days after the stock market plunge, a 64.83-carat diamond was sold at Christie's for $6.4 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a gem. Last month, that record was broken by the sale of a 85.51-carat diamond for $9.13 million at Sotheby's. The same Sotheby's auction set records with the prices fetched by a pink diamond ($4.73 million) and a cultured pearl necklace ($1.265 million).

title: Theologian Rejects Catholic U. Proposal To Settle Suspension
description: A theologian who was suspended by the Catholic University of America charged yesterday that the action was tantamount to dismissal and said he would pursue a suit charging the university with violating his rights as a tenured professor.

title: New Irving Proposal By Bank of New York
description: Rebuffed in its attempt to replace the Irving Bank Corporation's board, the Bank of New York Company yesterday announced a new step in its eight-month battle to acquire Irving.

title: A Deadline Is Looming In Texaco-Icahn Talks
description: As negotiations between Texaco Inc. and its largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, continue over a restructuring of the company, both sides apparently feel a deadline looming.

title: Caution and Reagan Link Seen as Bush's Problems
description: After using his association with President Reagan to secure an easy path to the Republican nomination, Vice President Bush is now having to decide just how close he wants to remain.

title: Witness Says Wedtech Offered Stock to Biaggi
description: A former Wedtech executive said yesterday that company officials had offered stock to Representative Mario Biaggi because they were behind in legal fees to the Congressman's former law firm.

title: Citicorp Rates Up for 3d Week
description: Interest rates were up at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It was the third consecutive increase in as many weeks.

title: Trashing Privacy
description: A man's home is his castle, but is his trash can part of that protected domain? No, says the Supreme Court by a 6-to-2 vote, it's abandoned property left for the municipality. The police may search it for evidence without a warrant or even a reason to suspect that it contains something incriminating.

title: Seized Honduran Faces Hearing
description: A Honduran diplomat was in a local jail today awaiting a hearing on Federal charges of cocaine possession after his arrest by United States Customs agents at Miami International Airport.

title: Dollar Up on Trade Report; Pound Drops With Rate Cut
description: The dollar advanced against all major foreign currencies yesterday on an unexpectedly sharp drop in the nation's trade deficit in March, while the pound plunged after a cut in the British base lending rate.

title: Lawmaker Killed in Robbery
description: A western Pennsylvania lawmaker returning from a late-night card game with his colleagues was slain and his body left in a street, District Attorney Richard A. Lewis said today. The slain Representative, William Telek, 64 years old, of Johnstown, the father of seven children, was apparently struck on the head and his wallet taken, Mr. Lewis said. An adult and two juveniles were later arrested driving the automobile Mr. Telek had leased. They were held on theft charges.

title: Like a Real Candidate, Tanner Falls Flat in Hollywood
description: The Democratic Presidential candidate Jack Tanner came to Hollywood recently for the usual purpose - to raise money.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Italian Food on S.I.

title: What's in a Name?
description: Edmund Morris, the authorized biographer of President Reagan, has a concern. In a capital where the chief of state is commonly referred to as Ron, or even Dutch, where the Speaker of the House goes by Jim and the Senate minority leader Bob, Mr. Morris has raised his voice against ''the unasked-for abbreviation of our proper names.''

title: Club Considers Change
description: The 110-year-old, all-male Cosmos Club finally appears to be seriously considering the admission of women. Earlier this month, the Board of Management presented the 3,000 members with a proposed change in the bylaws, striking the word ''man,'' and inserting ''individuals of distinction, character and sociability.''

title: Soldier Reprimanded In a Fatal Shooting On the West Bank
description: An Israeli military court reprimanded a soldier today for ''improper firing'' in a shooting incident Monday that resulted in the death of a 15-year-old Palestinian youth. The soldier was given a suspended 35-day jail term.

title: Education; 'Tom Sawyer' Still Tops Reading List
description: The winner and still the heavyweight champion of the books most read by American children in their free time is Mark Twain's ''Tom Sawyer.''

title: Sidney M. Davis, 69, Aide to Senate Panels
description: Sidney M. Davis, a Manhattan lawyer and counsel to investigating committees in Washington and Albany, died of heart disease Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Article 097488 -- No Title
description: The New York City Sanitation Department ordered record penalties yesterday against the owners of the landmark Ansonia Hotel in Manhattan, charging that a worker illegally removed asbestos, exposing tenants and passers-by to the deadly fibers.

title: Georgia Pacific
description: The Georgia Pacific Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 1/8 percent notes, due in 2000, at a price of 99.85 to yield 10.146 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers. Noncallable for seven years, the notes yield about 1.07 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

title: About New York; Sour on the City: A Product Of the Streets
description: It was 1983 and Ken Garber was on the move around the city a lot, selling medical electronics - patient monitors, EKG machines, that sort of thing - when he began to notice pushcarts were getting fancier. All of a sudden lightning struck in the form of a full-blown idea (it happens this way with entrepreneurs) and Mr. Garber thought, ''Wow! That's inspired!''

title: Correction
description: A recipe and a chart with the Microwave Cooking column in The Living Section on May 4 gave incorrect instructions for sweet custard. In step 2 of the recipe, the mixture should be divided among four custard cups. The times given in the chart are for cooking in the four custard cups, not in a four-cup measure.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Reverence, and a Joke, for the Pope
description: Although Pope John Paul II is on his 37th overseas trip, he still travels with the stubborn gusto of a man adding new entries to his record book and finding himself cast in new roles.

title: Hyundai Car Tops Imports
description: The Korean-made Hyundai Excel, the top-selling import in the United States in 1987, was again the import sales leader by a wide margin in the first four months of 1988, industry figures showed today.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Peripherals column in Science Times yesterday referred incorrectly to computers containing Intel 80286 chips. They are AT computers by I.B.M., as well as clones produced by other manufacturers.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News report in Business Day on Saturday about the I.C.H.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Given 3 Andy Awards
description: Ogilvy & Mather stole the show last night at Roseland, where the 24th annual Andy Awards were distributed by the Advertising Club of New York.

title: Connors Withdraws
description: Jimmy Connors, the fifth-ranked player in the world, has withdrawn from the French Open, which starts Monday, because of an injured right foot. Connors, 35, first suffered the injury before the United States Open last August. He aggravated the injury three weeks ago. The French Open is the only Grand Slam tournament he has failed to win. (AP)

title: Computer Associates Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $1,439,000 for the quarter, and a loss of $1,483,000 after a loss from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit. The company said the results for all periods include those of Uccel Corp., which was acquired by Computer Associates on Aug. 19, 1987 and treated as a pooling of interests. Shares oustanding are fully diluted.

title: Missouri Couple Held on Charges Of Plotting to Assassinate Jackson
description: Federal authorities charged yesterday that a member of a white supremacist organization and his wife conspired to kill or injure the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Millions Missing From German Jewish Fund
description: The leader of West Germany's main Jewish organization said today that tens of millions of marks were missing from a fund intended for Jewish victims of Nazism and that his predecessor might have taken them.

title: McFarland Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Contract Ruling Backs A.T.&T. On U.S. Work
description: A General Services Administration appeals panel ruled today that agency employees had discriminated against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in awarding contracts for telephone switching equipment to its rivals.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT'S one of those things about which, once it is done, everyone asks, ''Why wasn't it done a long time ago?'' People have been arguing for years over the relative merits of French and American wines. Now, Christian Brothers has taken the next logical step: it has combined the two.

title: Critic's Notebook; Great Evil Embodied In a Man
description: The cinema literature of the Holocaust has again been enriched by Marcel Ophuls, whose ''Sorrow and the Pity'' still points the way for anyone who would attempt to comprehend the subject on film.

title: Trading Curb Called Months Off
description: Though the White House working group on the market crash has won the rere ment of majoexexchanges to stop rarading when theoDow Jones indusiaial average drops 250 points in one day, entmtment of such a ''ciritit breaker'' could be months away, exchange and regulatory officials said today.

title: David L. Guyer, 62, Diplomat and Head Of Save the Children
description: David L. Guyer, a former diplomat and president of Save the Children Federation from 1977 until last year, died of lymphoma of the brain Saturday in Honolulu. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: General Microwave Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: EXPORTS A RECORD
description: In a performance that exceeded even the most optimistic predictions, the United States exported a record amount of goods in March and shrank its monthly trade deficit to $9.7 billion, the lowest level in three years.

title: Education: The College Reject; Several Factors Are Behind Growth In Number of Disappointed Students
description: A senior at the Bronx High School of Science, one of the most selective high schools in the country, has a 93 average, three varsity letters, 1,490 out of a possible 1,600 on his Scholastic Aptitude Tests and has never missed a day of school. Yet this New York student has just been rejected by Harvard, Yale, Stanford and Cornell. He made the waiting list at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Keystone Camera Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $295,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Ragen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $119,000 and $2,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and and includes a gain of $59,000 and $94,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: First Chicago Blocks Theft
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, a unit of the First Chicago Corporation, said today that it had thwarted an attempt by an employee to embezzle $70 million from three customer accounts.

title: Denver Airport Plan Is Passed
description: Adams County voters today solidly approved a plan to let the City of Denver annex land for a new $3 billion airport that could become the nation's second-busiest within 12 years.

title: Brazil Program Backed
description: All but two of Brazil's powerful state governors have given their support to President Jose Sarney's economic austerity program aimed at winning an accord with the International Monetary Fund, officials said. They said 22 state governors threw their support behind official policies at a meeting with Mr. Sarney on Monday. The centerpiece of the program is a plan to cut the state deficit from 5.5 percent of the gross domestic product in 1987 to 4 percent this year.

title: Real Estate; Fifth Avenue Abuzz From 34th to 42d St.
description: UNTIL recently the stretch of Fifth Avenue between the Public Library at 42d Street and the Empire State Building at 34th Street had been overlooked by developers of large office projects.

title: America Finds Sheep's Milk Cheeses to Call Its Own
description: LEAD: WONDERING what the next food-trend meteor to come sizzling through the atmosphere will be? Sheep's milk, my friend, sheep's milk. Get a ton, make it into cheese, sell it to a cheese boutique and baaaaa happily as the greenbacks march into your pocket.

title: The Embarrassment of the Bronx
description: By endorsing the re-election of Representative Mario Biaggi this week, the Bronx Democratic Party reinforces its reputation for sleaze and embarrasses New York.

title: Education; Lessons
description: College administrators can be much more than just the plotters of policy and budgets. Stripped of title and office, the presidents, vice presidents, deans and division heads of the academy are at the core teachers and their daily routine of administration should, ideally, be a campuswide lesson in the management of human affairs.

title: Tipping for Wine
description: To The Living Section:

title: Tudor City Given Status As Landmark
description: Tudor City, the towering residential enclave from the 1920's that brought 16th-century England to the eastern edge of mid-Manhattan, was declared a historic district yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Coast Guard Fighting Off 'Yacht Club' Image
description: Here at the United States Coast Guard Academy, the cadets bristle at suggestions that their school is as casual as Topsiders, a virtual yacht club where the curriculum centers on how to rescue capsized weekend captains.

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Fall
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell by as much as a point in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to the implications of a report showing a big drop in the nation's merchandise trade deficit in March.

title: Distressing Signals From the Court
description: The Supreme Court's 5-4 decision to reconsider the rights of minorities to sue private parties for racial discrimination under a 19th century law signals bad news for the rights of blacks.

title: Centex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,100,000 from an accounting change.

title: World Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,200,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $3,671,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Japan's Faulty Memory
description: If he had been a German official, or a stiff-backed President of Austria, everybody would have been up in arms. There would have been a clamor for wide-ranging debate, for TV documentaries and films, for programs in the schools, for a basic review of textbooks.

title: Horticulture May Be Sold
description: Carter F. Bales, a management consultant who specializes in media companies, is expected to buy Horticulture magazine, an 84-year-old monthly for amateur gardeners, people familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: Agency Halts Oil Exploration in Florida Preserve
description: The Interior Department halted oil exploration in Florida's Big Cypress National Preserve last week after conservation groups filed a suit charging that department officials had pushed for drilling despite unresolved environmental concerns.

title: Review/Art; Amid Ageless Repose, a Cloisters Gallery Is Renewed
description: The Cloisters may be only 50 years old, but it seems to have been there forever. On the northwest edge of a city of speed and movement, it almost makes people slow down. With its esthetic of synthesis and balance, with its odd yet successful blend of medieval and modern stone, and with its formidable collection of medieval objects that are very much about contemplation, it is one of very few institutions in New York that help people shed obligation and just be.

title: Site in Hiss-Chambers Case Now a Landmark
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel, rejecting the opinion of an advisory committee, granted landmark status today to a key site in the celebrated espionage case involving Whittaker Chambers and Alger Hiss.

title: Federal Insurance Urged for Long-Term Care
description: A Brookings Institution study recommended today that Federal social insurance replace charity care in paying for the rising cost of long-term health care for elderly people who are disabled.

title: A Way to Neutralize Toxic Waste Sites
description: Toxic waste sites are often difficult to clean up, particularly when the wastes have seeped deep into the ground. The Environmental Protection Agency, working with two private companies, recently demonstrated a technique to neutralize PCB's at a site at Hialeah, Fla., by boring holes into the ground and injecting a neutralizing chemical and cement.

title: Awards to Be Given For Writing on Theater
description: The George Freedley Memorial Award for excellence in writing about the theater is to be presented tonight to Charles Shattuck for ''Shakespeare on the American Stage, Vol. II: From Booth and Barrett to Sothern and Marlowe'' (Folger Books/Associated University Presses). The award is from the Theater Library Association, which is to also present its award for excellence in writing about film, television or radio to John Canemaker for ''Winsor McCay: His Life and Art'' (Abbeville Press), a work about the first master of film animation and comic strips. Each author will receive $250.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hole in Arctic Ozone Is Feared
description: A Canadian researcher says that a hole in the ozone layer may be developing in the stratosphere near the North Pole each winter just as a similar hole is created over the South Pole.

title: Canadian Agency Wins Top Prize for Billboards
description: For the first time in the 46-year history of the Obie Awards for outdoor advertising, a Canadian agency has received the top prize, for its billboard for McDonald's of Montreal.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's question-and-answer session with reporters in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The Associated Press and The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some things you have to keep to yourself when you're arguing with someone else.'' - President Reagan on U.S. negotiations with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. [ A1:1. ]

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Italian Banker Is Eager For New Irving Role
description: LEAD: Enrico Braggiotti, the chairman of Banca Commerciale Italiana, Italy's second-largest bank, has a reputation as one of Europe's most determined and dynamic bankers, with a strong international outlook.

title: As Concern Rises, President Restates Confidence in Meese
description: President Reagan said today that he retained complete confidence in Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d despite growing concern in Congress and among conservative leaders that Mr. Meese's legal troubles had undermined the work of the Justice Department.

title: Macmillan Gets a Bid From Bass
description: The Robert M. Bass Group of Texas said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to acquire Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publishing and information services company, for $64 a share, or about $1.6 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday misidentified the Senate committee before which Secretary of State George P. Shultz testified. It was Foreign Relations.

title: James Dean Twiname, Store Executive, 88
description: James Dean Twiname, a department store executive, died May 5 at the Life Care Center in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 88 years old and lived in Scottsdale.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Marvin D. Waldman, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam New York, has been named a group creative director.

title: 50% Success Rate in $1 Billion Infertility Fight
description: Americans spent $1 billion last year to combat infertility, and half of them ended up conceiving a child, the Government reported today.

title: Intermec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cone, Myers Stop Padres
description: David Cone, who pitches for the Mets mostly when it's nobody else's turn, pitched his fifth straight victory tonight and it was a tour de force: five singles and no runs in seven innings, 12 strikeouts and a 1-0 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: JEWISH EMIGRATION FROM SOVIET UNION CONTINUES TO RISE
description: More than 1,000 Jews, having been permitted to emigrate, left the Soviet Union in April. It was the highest monthly total since 1981.

title: A Newark Councilman Is Charged With Graft
description: A City Councilman has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he obtained kickbacks from a businessman in return for helping him purchase city-owned properties for rehabilitation, the authorities said today.

title: INDIAN COMMANDOS CLOSE IN ON SIKHS
description: Indian commandos smashed several Sikh fortifications in the Golden Temple complex and trapped several militants in an underground bunker today in the fiercest assault of the nine-day blockade of the temple.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: LOS ANGELES
description: FOR the past year, a homemade cookbook newsletter - with neither recipes nor photographs - has been firing the imaginations of many of the nation's food writers. Grace Kirschenbaum, the creator of the newsletter, World of Cookbooks, has been reading and remembering cookbooks for 35 years.

title: Casino Is Sponsor For a Temple Game
description: Temple's basketball game next December against the national champion, Kansas, in Atlantic City has stirred some controversy.

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,143,000 and $2,838,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $23,532,000 for both periods. c-Net loss and includes the reversal of a tax credit of $2,707,000 and income from discontinued operations of $3,447,000. d-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $3,730,000 and a tax credit of $4,693,000. Year-ago results include Brazilian operations through Sept. 30, 1986.

title: Why Bush's Campaign Needs Nancy Reagan
description: To the Editor:

title: Graduate Student In Indiana Charged in Threat on Reagan
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a graduate student today on charges he threatened the life of President Reagan and other public officials in letters and telephone calls.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: COLQUITT, GA.
description: LEAD: ''EVERYBODY knows mayhaw jelly is the best jelly in the world,'' said Betty Jo Toole, who - with her friends Joy Jinks, Pat Bush and Dot Wainright - owns and operates Mayhaw Tree Inc.

title: Blast Reported at Soviet Plant That Makes Vital Missile Part
description: An explosion has destroyed several buildings at a Soviet plant that produces rocket motors and fuel for long-range missiles, the Defense Department reported tonight.

title: Use of Industry Capacity Rose to 82.7% in April
description: The nation's industry operated at 82.7 percent of capacity in April, the highest level in more than eight years, the Government announced today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Golden Wind
description: Trying to think of the perfect title:

title: Reagan Asserts He Won't Retreat On Negotiations to Oust Noriega
description: President Reagan said today that he would not retreat from negotiations with Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, despite increasing opposition to a deal that would require the United States to drop drug-trafficking charges against him.

title: Alatenn Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wedbush Leader Sticks To Traditional Business
description: Edward W. Wedbush did not follow the traditional path of many securities executives. Instead of selling stocks at a small firm after graduating from college, in 1957 Mr. Wedbush and a high school friend, Robert Werner, started their own brokerage house with their pooled savings of $10,000.

title: U.S. Links Men in Bomb Case To Lebanon Terrorist Group
description: Three men arrested last October as they tried to bring a bomb into the United States are members of a Lebanon-based terrorist group and were planning an attack in America, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LUNCH hour on a lovely spring day. The Pulitzer Memorial Fountain in front of the Plaza. The crowd is contented. Some people lazily remove sandwiches from paper bags. Others simply observe the horse and carriage trade. There are readers and there are dozers and there are those obviously eager for an early tan. Sybil Taylor rises from a bench and strolls over to a pay phone on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Just as she reaches it the telephone starts to ring.

title: Ford Motor Credit Has 5-Year Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is issuing $250 million of five-year notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Not a Slave to the Zodiac, Reagan Says
description: President Reagan declined today to say whether he believed in astrology, saying he did not know enough about the subject to assess its validity.

title: Coalition Is Set For Software
description: A United States and European coalition of seven rival computer makers said yesterday that it would create a new software standard that may make it possible for users to mix and match computer hardware and software from different vendors.

title: Backers Fail to Get Lethal Injection Bid On California Ballot
description: Backers of a measure that would allow the terminally ill patient to request a lethal injection from a physican have failed to gather enough signatures to place the measure on the November ballot in California.

title: Florence Salomone, Newspaper Executive, 43
description: Florence Salomone, vice president and general manager of The Rockland Journal-News in West Nyack, N.Y., since 1982, died of a heart attack yesterday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. She was 43 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: New AIDS Virus Test Reduces Blood Risks
description: Scientists said Monday that they had developed a new AIDS virus test that should reduce the slight remaining risk of tainted blood transfusions by revealing if people are infected long before they develop antibodies to the virus.

title: Carson Pirie Scott & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $3,492,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Robinson: Ship To Shore to Seoul
description: LEAD: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch former all-American from Navy, will be returning to a familiar port of call this week when the Olympic basketball trials get under way in Colorado.

title: The Limits of Mubarak Awad's Moderation
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelers Is Hurt in Real Estate
description: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest insurance company, is struggling to limit the damage from a growing portfolio of troubled real estate loans that is already depressing its earnings.

title: Bridge
description: Those who play duplicate have an advantage over the followers of almost all other sport or recreation: In almost any city in the world they can walk into a bridge club, receive a warm welcome, and make new friends.

title: Rouse Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Europe Energy Use Up
description: Total energy use in the 12 nations of the European Community rose nine-tenths of a percent in 1987 from 1986, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today. Eurostat said the increase was well below the growth rates of its gross domestic product and industrial production.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone In European Joint Venture
description: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS, a company with a venerable American heritage, is going to form an alliance with Publicis S.A. of Paris, that includes shared equity, an exchange of board members and the creation of an European joint venture with $2 billion in billings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Released Damaso Garcia, second baseman. Signed Jerry Royster, infielder. COLLEGES ARMY - Named Ray Bosse men's and women's swimming coach. GRAND CANYON - Named Bill Westphal basketball coach. HOLY CROSS - Named Jim Stewart assistant hockey coach. NEW JERSEY TECH - Named T. J. Kostecky soccer coach. ST. THOMAS AQUINAS - Named Thomas Donohue cross-country coach. SALEM - Announced the resignation of Corky Griffith, football coach. Named Rich Rodriguez interim football coach. SOUTHHAMPTON - Named Luke Clarke basketball coach. SOUTHWESTERN LOUISIANA -Named Butch Pierre assistant men's basketball coach. WISCONSIN-STEVENS POINT - Announced that Don Amiot, athletic director, resigned to take the men's athletic director job at Mankato State, effective July 1. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Wayne Radloff, center, and Joe Costello, linebacker. HOUSTON (AFC) - Named Mike Holovak assistant to the general manager. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Named Jerry Smith scout for the West Coast area. JETS AFC) - Signed Phil Alferie, defensive end; Leon Hall, defensive tackle; John Garrett, center; Orlando Brown, running back; Greg Calcagno, quarterback; Dave Brown, Bruce Hatfield, Phil Forney and Greg Johns, linebackers; Kelly Averitt, Thomas Godek and Kelvin Davis, offensive tackles; Harold Collins, Rickey Flowers, Doug Green, Kwante Hampton and Jamie Harris, wide receivers; Byron Davis, Donald Douglas and Ray Farris, defensive backs, and Todd Frain and Jeff Fallimore, tight ends. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Cut Derek Holoway, wide receiver; Chad Craig, offensive tackle; Mike Knutson, guard, and Toran Schonyers, linebacker. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Signed John Jackson, tackle. Signed Keith Mattioli, wide receiver, to a free-agent contract. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed David Evans and Rodney Bellinger, defensive backs; Tommy Clapp, defensive lineman; Dan Coleman, nose tackle; Van Tiffin, placekicker; Gary Ford, tight end, and Clay Whitehurst, Danny Smith, Ed Frazier and Randy White, wide receivers. HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Named Ron Ryan executive vice president. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Dismissed Jacques Martin, coach. WASHINGTON (NHL) - Announced that Baltimore of the American Hockey League will serve as the minor-league affiliate.

title: Arts Exhibit Dispute Splits Miami Cubans
description: Once again the arts have become a battleground in the Cuban-American community here, a contest between forces of free expression and those of political ideology.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Barely Get By Jazz
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who trailed Utah two games to one just four days ago, took a 3-2 lead tonight with a 111-109 victory over the Jazz. Michael Cooper hit his only field goal with seven seconds left to put Los Angeles ahead to stay at 110-109.

title: Women Are Liberating a Citadel of Male Power
description: This capital, which was traditionally a man's domain in matters of power and influence, is now a woman's city, too.

title: Ontario Defiance Threatens Canada-U.S. Pact on Trade
description: The Canadian Government appears to have failed in a last-ditch attempt to persuade the Province of Ontario to comply with the free-trade agreement reached last year with the United States.

title: Review/Television; Ladies Of Theater Perform
description: When it comes to Presidential showcases and photo opportunities, few have been constructed more shrewdly than the public television series ''In Performance at the White House.'' Taped in the East Room, these periodic specials star the President and Mrs. Reagan as just plain Ron and Nancy having a few select friends over for a character-building exercise in arts appreciation. The President is invariably enthusiastic; the guests keep glancing at the Reagans to catch their reactions, and the performers are naturally delighted to play the White House. From every angle, it's a press agent's dream.

title: A Suspicious Storeroom Fire Forces an Evacuation at Saks
description: A small fire broke out in a storeroom at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday, forcing the evacuation of the department store and the suspension of business for about 90 minutes. No injuries were reported.

title: Sexton's Poetry: Better as Poetry Than Therapy
description: Selected Poems of Anne Sexton Edited by Diane Wood Middlebrook and Diana Hume George 266 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95. I am filling the room with the words from my pen. Words leak out of it like a miscarriage. I am zinging words out into the air and they come back like squash balls. Yet there is silence. Always silence.

title: Doctors in Massachusetts Are Embittered by Dukakis Policies
description: If Massachusetts doctors had their way, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential bid might be dead on arrival.

title: Boy Scouts Find Success Blazing Inner-City Trail
description: One by one, and mostly with great timidity, a handful of boys, residents of the Prince George, a Manhattan welfare hotel, entered the cellar of a midtown church for the kickoff meeting of a new Boy Scout troop.

title: Westphals Switch
description: A week after Paul Westphal resigned as the basketball coach at Grand Canyon College in Phoenix in order to accept a position as assistant coach with the Suns, his older brother, Bill, accepted the job Paul left. Bill, who is expected to sign a three-year contract today, has a career coaching record of 169-149 and was 25-27 the past two seasons at Occidental College in Eagle Rock, Calif. Bill, 44, said it would be difficult following his 37-year-old brother, who led the Antelopes to the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics championship in his second season. ''Coming in behind him is like following John Wooden,'' he said, referring to the former U.C.L.A. coach. (AP)

title: EATING WELL
description: IT is confusing enough to decide what your diet as an adult should be: we are told to eat more fiber and less fat, to drink skim milk and not to eat eggs more than twice a week.

title: Lilco Pact Seen as Ending 'Uncertainty'
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company, speaking today at the utility's annual shareholders meeting, all but endorsed a settlement with New York State that would result in the abandoment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Penney, J C Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter results include provisions totaling 55 cents a share for the costs of relocating the company's headquarters to Dallas. The company also said that its effective income tax rate was 34.1 percent for this year's first quarter ended April 30, compared with 41.9 percent in the year-ago quarter, reflecting the reduction in the federal statutory rate. Also, income tax expense in this year's first quarter was reduced by $6 million due to the payment of a portion of the taxes on installment sales previously deferred at higher tax rates. As of the end of the quarter, the company said it had purchased 18.6 million of its common shares at a cost of $863 million; this is a major protion of the ongoing stock buyback program totaling up to 20 million shares.

title: Vanzetti Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Market Place; Analysts Size Up Specialty Insurers
description: WITH the stock market unable to gain much momentum above the Dow industrials' 2,000 level, diehard investors are being forced to search further afield for stocks to buy. Specialty insurers are among those that some analysts and investors say deserve more attention.

title: Dow Falls 21.22, to 1,986.41; Trading Slows
description: LEAD: Stock prices slumped in desultory trading yesterday, after the Government reported a surprisingly strong improvement in the nation's balance of trade.

title: 3 Retailers Post Lower Earnings
description: Five of the nation's leading retailers yesterday reported lower profits or losses in the period ended April 30, principally because of weak sales in apparel.

title: Tejano Is Out Of the Preakness
description: Tejano will not run in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday, his trainer told track officials today.

title: Colombian Mayor Shot Dead
description: A member of a leftist Colombian party who was elected to a mayor's office two months ago has been assassinated in the city of Medellin, the police said Tuesday. Elkin de Jesus Martinez of the Patriotic Union, mayor of Remedios, a mining town in the northeastern province of Antioquia, was shot to death Sunday in a Medellin hotel lobby by two killers who escaped in a waiting car.

title: Tidewater Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $13.5 million from the sale of the company's interest in Indonesian production sharing contracts. Results for the prior year include a writedown of $1.4 million from the sale of one of the company's operations.

title: Coated Sales Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Far-Flung Gobs of American Military Gravy; A Base That Belongs
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Paying for Wider Health Insurance
description: COMPETENCE is what counts, insists Michael Dukakis, not charisma. And the Massachusetts Governor's supporters may have hit on the issue to make the case. They are touting the state's new mandatory health insurance plan as vintage Dukakis: liberal government at a cost conservatives can love.

title: George Sklar, 79, Dies; Playwright and Author
description: George Sklar, a playwright and novelist, died of cardiac arrest Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Saying that boxing was in his blood, a former three-time world champion, Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico, will make a comeback July 20 at Miami against an opponent to be named. Gomez, 31 years old, who held the World Boxing Council super bantamweight and featherweight titles and the world junior lightweight crown, said he was seeking the W.B.C. lightweight championship. . . . Francesco Damiani, the European heavyweight champion who is unbeaten in 21 pro fights, will oppose Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia in a 10-round bout in Italy July 3. The bout will be a rematch of the Los Angeles Olympics heavyweight final, which Biggs won on a decision. . . .The Atlanta Braves have released the second baseman Damaso Garcia and signed a free-agent utility player, Jerry Royster, who earlier spent nine seasons with the club. Garcia, twice an All-Star in the American League, was acquired from the Toronto Blue Jays in a 1987 trade. He injured his left knee early in the year and did not play last season. This season, Garcia appeared in 21 games, hitting .117. . . . Ray Bosse, a 1977 graduate of the United States Military Academy and assistant coach the past six years, has been named men's and women's swimming coach at West Point. Bosse succeeds Jack Ryan, who is retiring after 29 years.

title: A Comeback for the Vacuum Tube
description: In their endless quest for faster and more efficient electronic devices, scientists are borrowing from a technology many considered moribund 30 years ago: the vacuum tube.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sweden Tops West Germany: Sweden beat West Germany, 2-1, and Czechoslovakia downed Spain, 2-1, at the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany, yesterday. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-1, 6-4. Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany upset Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 7-6, 6-1. But Edberg teamed with Jarryd to beat the West German pair of Jelen and Patrick Kuehnen, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) McNeil Advances: Second-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston defeated Hester Witvoet of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in first-round play at the $100,000 Geneva European Open. Top-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria beat Celine Cohen of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-4, and Isabelle Demongeot of France upset sixth-seeded Patricia Tarbini of Argentina, 7-6, 6-4. The tie-breaker score was 7-2.(AP)

title: On West Coast, a Newly Vital Judaism
description: As recently as the 1950's, the San Francisco Bay area was considered a backwater of American Judaism. Of its 4 million residents then, about 100,000, or 2.5 percent, were Jews. Most had been assimilated into the culture at large and lived a secular existence, as had many of the German and Eastern European Jewish pioneers who migrated to California during the Gold Rush.

title: Home Loan Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering $3.18 billion of bonds separated into one-, three- and five-year maturities, through various securities dealers. The bonds are priced at par. A $1.25 billion issue of one-year securities, due in 1989, yields 7.75 percent; $1.14 billion of a three-year issue, due in 1991, yields 8.50 percent, while $790 million of a five-year issue, due in 1993, yields 8.90 percent.

title: American Raises Offer To Buy Lucky Stores
description: The American Stores Company said today that it had sweetened its offer for Lucky Stores Inc. to $65 a share, or $2.5 billion, topping a $2.35 billion leveraged buyout deal from Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen to which Lucky agreed last month.

title: Bronx Jury Clears Police In '87 Death
description: A 28-year-old Bronx woman who spent the last six days of her life in courts, jails and city hospitals waiting to be arraigned received woefully inadequate medical care while in detention and died needlessly, according to a grand jury finding described yesterday by the Bronx District Attorney.

title: The Trans-Atlantic Numbers Game
description: There is a trans-Atlantic numbers game going on, and anybody who can spell ''North Atlantic Treaty Organization'' can play. First you tally the percentages, and you discover that the United States devotes six percent of its gross national product to its military while the West Europeans collectively spend only three percent. Then you do fractions and point out that America allocates three-fifths of its defense budget to NATO, and what do you get?

title: Organogenesis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Robinson Hurt
description: Manager Frank Robinson, who has a ruptured disk in his back, was hospitalized in Baltimore yesterday and will not be back to manage before Saturday. Elrod Hendricks, the Orioles' bullpen coach, will guide the team over the next four games. Hendricks, 47 years old, has been in the Orioles' organization for 18 and a half years as a player and a coach. His first game as replacement manager, against California, was rained out last night.(AP)

title: On the Origin of Venus
description: To the Editor:

title: 3d Howard Beach Trial Possible
description: An effort to avoid having two additional trials in the Howard Beach racial-attack case may have been undermined by a defense lawyer's commitment in another court, parties involved in the case indicated yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Rocket Plant Blast

title: Diet Advice: Eat, Drink and Don't Worry
description: EVERY day - but especially as bathing-suit season nears - millions of Americans gird themselves to embark on a diet, riveted by the fantasy that life would be better if they were lighter and slighter.

title: Palo Alto Journal; 'Deadheads' in an Idolatrous Pursuit
description: Tie-dyed from head to toe and fuzzy with marijuana, the young men and women paraded up and down Campus Drive outside the Frost Amphitheater at Stanford University. ''One, just one,'' they crooned, with index fingers raised high, begging for tickets to a recent Grateful Dead concert.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: SEATTLE
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, in the dark ages, the king salmon that returned to the Copper River in Alaska were harvested at the mouth of the river, transported to processors in Cordova, Alaska, and canned. It was a tragic situation for anyone who loves the flavor of fresh wild salmon.

title: Bonn to Try Accused Hijacker in Juvenile Court
description: Mohammed Ali Hamadei, a Lebanese who is accused of hijacking an American jetliner in 1985, will be tried by a West German juvenile court since his age at the time of the crime remains in dispute, the court announced today.

title: Israel Overreacts to Nonviolence
description: Israel's effort to expel Mubarak Awad, a Palestinian-American known for his espousal of nonviolence, raises fundamental legal and political issues. The case is so unusual that Israel's High Court of Justice has agreed to a rare review of an expulsion order charging that Mr. Awad has lived illegally in Israel since last November.

title: Review/Folk Music; The Songs of Bulgaria
description: Wondrous, and not always invidious, are the ways of fashion. Bulgarian folk music, and especially that country's keening, nasal, dissonant women's singing, has been a staple of record collectors for decades. But in the last year, two disks were released in the United States - Nonesuch's ''Mystere des Voix Bulgares'' and Hannibal's ''Balkana'' - that became all the rage among pop stars, college radio stations, alternative weeklies and magazines and other arbiters of hip. The result was a nearly sold-out Town Hall on Sunday night when eight musicians, all of whom are on ''Balkana'' and some of whom are on the Nonesuch disk, appeared in concert.

title: Yankees Can't Hit Or Field, Can't Win
description: Two seasons ago, Billy Swift came within four outs of pitching a no-hitter against the Yankees. One season ago, he underwent surgery on his right elbow. Last night, he proved he had come full circle for the Seattle Mariners.

title: Harold Lief, Teacher, 85
description: Harold Lief, who taught business law and accounting for 45 years at the former Haaren High School in Manhattan, died of complications after surgery for an aneurism Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Athletics Win 22d In Last 26 Games
description: Carney Lansford and Walt Weiss had three hits apiece, and Mark McGwire hit his 11th home run tonight as the Oakland Athletics won for the 22d time in their last 26 games, a 12-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Senate Begins Debate on Missile Treaty
description: After months of political skirmishing and a series of last-minute negotiating crises, the Senate today began formal consideration of the arms treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.

title: Th D p tm t of J st e, Cont.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese had the right to dismiss Terry Eastland as his public relations chief. Mr. Meese may even have been right to want him out if he thought his aide was privately commenting on Mr. Meese's plight with not wholly flattering candor. What's astonishing about the firing is its insensitivity. It shows Ed Meese at his clumsiest, giving himself another needless hotfoot - and piling more embarrassment on a President who has plenty of that at the moment.

title: Zayre Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $20,536,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in inventory accounting.

title: Dr. Herbert Ayers Jr., 79, Dentistry Teacher
description: Dr. Herbert D. Ayers Jr., a teacher of dentistry at Columbia University for almost half a century, died Saturday at the University Heights Nursing Home in Albany after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Roslyn Estates, L.I.

title: 'Les Mis' Brightens Day for Outcasts
description: Randy Graff - long-haired, graceful, a luminary in the musical ''Les Miserables'' - glided across a broad stage yesterday and belted out her part's best lyrics: I had a dream my life would be so different from this hell I'm living/So different now from what it seemed/Now life has killed the dream I dreamed.''

title: Feedlot Cattle Up 4%
description: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of May 1 in the seven leading beef states totaled 7.5 million head, up 4 percent from a year ago and 6 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department said on Monday. As of May 1, feedlot inventories were larger than a year earlier in five states and down in two.

title: An Old Combination
description: To The Living Section:

title: U.S. Civil Rights Commission's Stake in the AIDS Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Notebook; Time Running Out For North Koreans
description: Whatever possibility remained that some events of the Seoul Summer Olympics would be held in North Korea has apparently ended.
