Appearing in a television debate in Seoul Monday night, Park Seh Jik, the president of the South Korea organizing committee, rejected the idea by saying that to split the Games would violate the Olympic charter.

title: Causes Sought In Bus Accident That Killed 3
description: Police and transportation officials searched here today for clues to the crash Monday of a bus carrying mentally handicapped workers that left 3 people dead and 20 injured.

title: Education; Study Finds Unions Aren't Obstacles
description: A study commissioned by the Education Department says teachers' unions have not been a major obstacle to efforts to improve schools, contradicting frequent charges made by Education Secretary William J. Bennett and other critics.

title: A Capitol Chorus
description: Some 100 members of the House of Representatives are scheduled to stand on the steps of the Capitol at 9:30 A.M. today to help honor Irving Berlin, who turned 100 years old last week, with renditions of ''Happy Birthday'' and the composer's own ''God Bless America.'' The performance is to be part of a CBS-TV special on Mr. Berlin scheduled for May 27.

title: Andrew Duggan, an Actor on TV, Stage and the Screen, Dies at 64
description: Andrew Duggan, a movie and television actor, died of throat cancer Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 64 years old.

title: REAGAN IS LAVISH IN PRAISING PERES
description: President Reagan met today with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, lavishly praised him for supporting American efforts to revive peace negotiations in the Middle East and indirectly criticized Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: Dayton Hudson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the latest first quarter results include a pretax charge of $12.4 million for the LIFO inventory accounting method, compared with a pretax LIFO charge of $8.9 million included in the year earlier quarter's results.

title: Israel Awaits Modern Plague
description: Israel set up emergency telephone hot lines Tuesday and prepared insecticide-spraying planes to fly into action against a possible plague of locusts, the desert insects dreaded since biblical times. Only a small number of locusts were sighted in southern Israel and the Jordan River valley, but officials warned of a possible larger invasion from the south.

title: Charity Often Begins With a Fete for the Well-Fed Crowd
description: LEAD: FOOD and charity are, historically, quite cozy. Many a good cause has benefited from the barbecues, bake sales and pancake breakfasts held in towns and cities across America.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The trade deficit dropped in March to $9.7 billion, the lowest level in three years, as the United States exported $29 billion worth of goods, a 23 percent increase and a record for any month. Page A1

title: Conferees Back Bill Curbing Device to Detect Lies
description: Compromise legislation that would prohibit most polygraph, or lie-detector, tests for private employees and job applicants was approved unanimously today by House and Senate negotiators.

title: KEY RATES
A Taste of America, A Meal for Comrades
description: When three of the best young chefs from Seattle made lunch for 25 people at the Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel here today, they were also making history.

title: Far-Flung Gobs of American Military Gravy
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Backs Film Makers Over U.S.
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down the Government's attempt to limit tax-free export of documentary films that advocate a cause, calling regulations drafted by the United States Information Agency a ''virtual license to engage in censorship.''

title: Angolans Besting South Africa in a Remote Battle
description: South African gunners are firing only 40 artillery shells a day into the ruins of this farming town, a sign to entrenched Angolan and Cuban soldiers here that a pivotal battle for the future of southern Africa is turning in their favor.

title: Payout Cut, Issue Set By Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday announced a sharp dividend cut and plans to issue about 15 million new shares of stock to help finance its previously announced $700 million capital investment program.

title: Big Series at the Stadium
description: THEY look a little like the old Oakland Raiders, with their broad shoulders and their long frames, and a little like a traveling chorus, with their identical herringbone sports jackets.

title: A Single-Parent Home That Sponsors Dreams
description: Like many newly divorced parents, Julie Sharp faced a problem: how to afford a home and day care for her 3-year-old son and still continue her college education.

title: Cooper Cos. to Pay Proxy Fight Costs
description: The Sturman brothers of Mount Vernon. N.Y., disclosed that the Cooper Companies had agreed to reimburse up to $900,000 of their expenses in preparing for a proxy fight against the medical equipment concern based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Edward R. Jobson, 65, Publishing Executive
description: Edward R. (Ted) Jobson, retired executive vice president of the Jobson Publishing Corporation, died of intestinal cancer Friday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Meritor Financial
description: Meritor Financial Group's drive to restore profits is being slowed by rising interest rates, Frederick S. Hammer, chairman of the troubled savings and loan institution, said. After today's annual meeting, he said that if current interest rates held, ''we are not going to make it.'' Mr. Hammer declined to predict when Meritor would return to sustained profitability but said that ''we are flirting'' with the break-even level.

title: Nature's Bounty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $173,696 and $180,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $77,000. d-Net loss and includes a tax-related charge of $44,875.

title: Court Upholds Defendant's Use of Classified Data
description: A schoolteacher charged with illegally shipping guns from Washington State to Pakistan for Afghan rebels can use classified documents to support his contention that the United States Government encouraged his activities, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Rested Henderson Restless
description: Rickey Henderson paused a moment from the dominoes game that occupied his attention and flexed his left hand. He wanted to show that it was nearly healed, that the sore ring finger no longer really bothered him and that when Friday arrived, he would be ready.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Old-Guard Spanish Banker Gives In to Age of Mergers
description: LEAD: When Alfonso Escamez started as a messenger at a little bank in eastern Spain 60 years ago, the business was small-town simple, and as recently as last year, he stood solidly with the old guard that opposed bank mergers and defended Spanish banking as viable and competitive.

title: Leucadia National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $2.4 million for the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said latest first quarter net included net securities gains of $12,623,000, compared with $10,239,000 for year-ago period. The latest first quarter's results included Phlcorp Inc. as a consolidated subsidiary and in year-ago period Phlcorp was accounted for under the equity method of accounting.

title: Giant Rookie Blends Speed and Ability
description: Sheldon White majored in accounting in college. Numbers, evidently, don't overwhelm him. The memory of one, though, still irks him considerably.

title: Funds of Pastor Charged in Rape Are Studied
description: A Harlem minister charged Sunday with raping two teen-age members of his Pentecostal church has been the target of an investigation into his finances and style of living, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Pact With School Custodians Is Near, Wagner Says
description: The New York City Board of Education, which has been pressing school custodians for major concessions that would improve the upkeep of schools, appeared close to an agreement on a new contract with the custodians' union last night, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said.

title: SCHOOL BUSES GET HIGH SAFETY MARK
description: Despite the crash that killed 27 people in Carrollton, Ky., on Saturday, school buses are the nation's safest mode of surface transportation, according to Federal, state and independent safety experts.

title: Hewlett Net Rises by 25%
description: Buoyed by strong sales of its new products, the Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that earnings were up 25 percent in the quarter ended April 30.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Pistons Take Series
description: Detroit advanced to the Eastern Conference final tonight as Bill Laimbeer scored 13 of his 19 points in the fourth quarter to lift the Pistons to a 102-95 victory over the Chicago Bulls. The Pistons won the series, four games to one.

title: Accounts
description: * Dana Perfumes to Favara, Skahan & Tabaczyk for an assignment for Canoe men's cologne.

title: Maxwell Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Merchants of Death
description: When the Surgeon General reported this week that nicotine is as addictive as heroin or cocaine, the tobacco industry's response was given by Brennan Moran, assistant to the president of the Tobacco Institute.

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tax-Exempt Tightening
description: Representative J. J. Pickle, chairman of a House subcommittee that has been considering plans to tax more types of income-producing activities of tax-exempt organizations, said today that his panel would come up with a package of legislative proposals ''in the next week or two.''

title: Du Pont Assailed on Pay Plan
description: A House subcommittee chairman said today that he would investigate a plan by the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to use $75 million in Federal funds to pay severance benefits to 6,500 workers at a nuclear weapon plant even though most of them will keep their jobs under new management.

title: TRIAL OPENS TODAY FOR EX-GOVERNOR
description: An Arizona Supreme Court justice refused today to delay the Thursday start of former Gov. Evan Mecham's criminal trial based on allegations he concealed a campaign loan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about women in positions of influence in Washington omitted the identity of the person who said such women are ''a hidden resource.'' She is Susan Peterson, a former network television correspondent who now heads a media speech-training company, Susan Peterson Productions.

title: Australian Trade Gain
description: Australia's trade picture improved dramatically in April, with the current account deficit narrowing to a smaller than expected $396 million (Australian), or $302 million (American), the Statistics Bureau said today. The deficit in March stood at $1.09 billion (Australian), which was revised from $1.18 billion.

title: Shift on Campaign Financing by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo, increasing the chances for adopting public financing of statewide election campaigns, has agreed to consider legislation that does not include public financing of legislative races, but that simply lowers contribution limits for those contests, his aides said today.

title: American Academy In Induction Ceremony
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters inducted more than a dozen official and honorary members and honored about 40 writers, painters, architects, musicians and other artists yesterday at the arts organization's annual awards ceremony.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: A Steel Quota Divides the Industry
description: Big Steel and Little Steel bickered over import protection at today's session of the annual gathering of the American steel industry.

title: New Plan for Media General Seeks Broadcasting Spinoff
description: Media General Inc. yesterday received a recapitalization proposal that would involve a spinoff of its broadcasting and cable operations into a new company.

title: 1,200 Pounds of Cocaine Seized; 9 Held
description: A supply line that would have brought nearly eight tons of cocaine into the Hamptons for the resort season was cut off by undercover agents who confiscated the first shipment, faked a delivery and made nine arrests, the authorities said today.

title: Natchez Journal; A City Longs for the End of the Road
description: Fifty years ago this week, Congress authorized the building of the Natchez Trace Parkway along the trail that first the Indians and then white settlers traveled north from the Mississippi River here to the early trading post of Nashville.

title: Derwent Prizes to Estabrook and Wong
description: Christine Estabrook, who played the retarded Sheila in ''The Boys Next Door,'' and B. D. Wong, who made his Broadway debut in ''M. Butterfly,'' are the winners of the 1987-88 Clarence Derwent Award, which was announced Tuesday. The award, which is named for the actor and former president of the Actors' Equity Association, has been made each year since 1944 to ''the most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene.''

title: Materials Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Fined Billy Martin, manager of the Yankees, an undisclosed amount for a May 6 incident with Umpire Tim Welke. CHICAGO (AL) - Traded Leon Durham, first baseman, to Cincinnati for Pat Perry, pitcher, and an undisclosed amount of cash. YANKEES - Transferred Ron Guidry, pitcher, from the 20-day rehabilitation list to the 21-day disabled list. COLLEGES MISSOURI VALLEY CONFERENCE - Named Doug Elgin commissioner. NEW MEXICO - Named Dave Bliss men's basketball coach. SETON HALL - Named Pam Roecker FOOTBALL CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Scott Cepicky, punter, and Steve Dickinson, safety. HOCKEY PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Dismissed Clement Jodoin, assistant coach. HORSE RACING NEW YORK STATE RACING AND WAGERING BOARD - Suspended the license of Robert DeBonis, trainer, for his attempt to commit a fraud in connection with racing and breeding. TUESDAY BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Released Damaso Garcia, second baseman. Signed Jerry Royster, infielder. COLLEGES ARMY - Named Ray Bosse men's and women's swimming coach. GRAND CANYON - Named Bill Westphal basketball coach. HOLY CROSS - Named Jim Stewart assistant hockey coach. NEW JERSEY TECH - Named T. J. Kostecky soccer coach. ST. THOMAS AQUINAS - Named Thomas Donohue cross-country coach. SALEM - Announced the resignation of Corky Griffith, football coach. Named Rich Rodriguez interim football coach. SOUTHHAMPTON - Named Luke Clarke basketball coach. SOUTHWESTERN LOUISIANA -Named Butch Pierre assistant men's basketball coach. WISCONSIN-STEVENS POINT - Announced that Don Amiot, athletic director, resigned to take the men's athletic director job at Mankato State, effective July 1. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Wayne Radloff, center, and Joe Costello, linebacker. HOUSTON (AFC) - Named Mike Holovak assistant to the general manager. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Named Jerry Smith scout for the West Coast area. JETS AFC) - Signed Phil Alferie, defensive end; Leon Hall, defensive tackle; John Garrett, center; Orlando Brown, running back; Greg Calcagno, quarterback; Dave Brown, Bruce Hatfield, Phil Forney and Greg Johns, linebackers; Kelly Averitt, Thomas Godek and Kelvin Davis, offensive tackles; Harold Collins, Rickey Flowers, Doug Green, Kwante Hampton and Jamie Harris, wide receivers; Byron Davis, Donald Douglas and Ray Farris, defensive backs, and Todd Frain and Jeff Fallimore, tight ends. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Cut Derek Holoway, wide receiver; Chad Craig, offensive tackle; Mike Knutson, guard, and Toran Schonyers, linebacker. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Signed John Jackson, tackle. Signed Keith Mattioli, wide receiver, to a free-agent contract. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed David Evans and Rodney Bellinger, defensive backs; Tommy Clapp, defensive lineman; Dan Coleman, nose tackle; Van Tiffin, placekicker; Gary Ford, tight end, and Clay Whitehurst, Danny Smith, Ed Frazier and Randy White, wide receivers. HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Named Ron Ryan executive vice president. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Dismissed Jacques Martin, coach. WASHINGTON (NHL) - Announced that Baltimore of the American Hockey League will serve as the minor-league affiliate.

title: Welfare Reform Bill Needs Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Bogert Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Board Member Quits At Television Bureau
description: Peter B. Desnoes, 45, who was to become the next chairman of the Television Bureau of Advertising, resigned abruptly from its board after a meeting in Bermuda last week.

title: General Mills Will Sell Talbots and Bauer for $585 Million
description: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Talbots women's apparel chain to the Jusco Company, a large Japanese chain-store retailer, for $325 million in cash. It will be the first major purchase by a Japanese company of an American retailer.

title: McEnroe Edges In
description: John McEnroe, once accustomed to being at the top of any seeding list, yesterday moved - courtesy of two late withdrawals of ranked players -into the 16th and last seeded spot for the French Open tournament, which begins Monday. Jimmy Connors, No. 5, pulled out because of a foot injury, and Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, No. 7, dropped out because of a neck problem. They were replaced by Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina and McEnroe. (AP)

title: A C.I.A. Man Inflames The Contras' Dispute
description: The already deeply divided contra movement has been further shaken by the intervention of a C.I.A. agent in its dispute.

title: Sikhs Surrender to Troops at Temple
description: With their hands held high, 46 Sikh militants filed slowly out of the Golden Temple today and surrendered to Indian security forces, ending a 10-day Government blockade of the shrine.

title: Jamesway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The sales figures do not include sales by leased departments of $4,590,000 for latest first quarter and $4,664,000 for year-ago period.

title: Aero Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: The Editorial Notebook; Bread on the Table, Rust on the Span
description: Too bad New York City's Williamsburg Bridge can't march on City Hall, cultivate the news media or go to the polls. As it symbolizes neglected infrastructure, the bridge, unable to speak for itself, also symbolizes a city's long commitment to people over objects.

title: Nichols, S E Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said that net income and several other balance sheet accounts for fiscal years 1987 and 1986 were restated to reflect a material discreptancy between the company's general ledger accounts payable account and the accounts payable subsidiary ledger. It was further determined by management that the discrepancy, which totaled about $5.5 million, initially arose in the fiscal 1986 period in connection with the company's conversion from an outside service bureau to its own internal computer system in fiscal 1986 and effected the results of operations for both fiscal years 1987 and 1986. The previously issued consolidated statements for fiscal 1987 and 1986 have been restated to reflect the effects of the above matter and, with respect to fiscal 1987, to reflect $674,000 of previously unrecorded letter-of- credit purchases and liabilities. Due to the restatement of fiscal 1987, comparative quarter results for both fiscal years have not been shown.

title: A Word for Confusion
description: The Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which arrived on the Senate floor Tuesday, has on occasion encountered bizarre negotiating obstacles - for example the flap over ''osnashcheniye,'' a Russian term that can mean ''armed,'' ''armament,'' ''equipped'' or ''equipment,'' depending, it seems, on who does the translating.

title: Review/Ballet; Stretton McKerrow And Gregory
description: Major cast changes resulted in fresh nuances of interpretation in two works offered by American Ballet Theater Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Koch, the 'Entertainer,' Gets Mixed Review
description: Given a chance yesterday to discuss civic design with hundreds of architects from around the nation, Mayor Koch chose to savage critics of his development policies as ''idiots,'' lampoon the New York State Court of Appeals and take a fresh swipe at Donald J. Trump.

title: Dest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $54,000 charge from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. The latest quarter includes pretax restructuring costs of $3.4 million.

title: Vehicle Is the 1,000th Seized in Drug Effort
description: A white 1986 Lincoln Continental being used by two men to peddle cocaine on the Lower East Side in Manhattan yesterday became the 1,000th vehicle to be seized in the Police Department's crackdown on illegal drug traffic, officials said.

title: In Beverly Hills, a High-Stakes Land Rush
description: In a money-is-no-object land rush, big egos and bigger budgets are tearing down grand but aging estates on some of the world's highest-priced real estate to make room for lavish new mansions.

title: Yellow Pages Units Merging
description: Two of the three trade associations representing the advertisers and publishers of the Yellow Pages directories will merge July 1.

title: Preakness Notebook; Smaller Field Suits the Filly
description: The field for the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday has shrunk to eight or nine, which is good news for Winning Colors, the front-running filly who won the Kentucky Derby May 7. The two latest dropouts, Once Wild and Din's Dancer, are the colts who were expected to challenge her for the early lead Saturday.

title: International Microelectronic Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
U.S. and Europe Seek End of Farm Impasse
description: The United States and the European Community are deadlocked in their negotiations on how to eliminate the more than $200 billion spent each year on farm subsidies around the world.

title: BTR Realty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas Banks' Improvement Seen
description: Losses continued to rise among Texas banks in the first quarter, but L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that the industry's fortunes in the state should improve next year.

title: Kiddie Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Regan's Book Gives Harcourt a Lift
description: The huge success of Donald T. Regan's ''For the Record,'' which a week after its official publication date has jumped to the No. 1 spot on the best-seller list, could not have come at a better time for its publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: 3 Couples Who Heard The Call of the Inn
description: THE dream of operating an inn has seduced all kinds of people over the years. In recent decades innkeeping has been perceived as an escape from the high anxieties of corporate life. Some have been wise to follow their dream, others not, as the stories of Rabbit Hill's three most recent innkeepers attest.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Vice Raids Baffle Manila, an Exuberant Town
description: Policemen moved quickly through the Flamingo nightclub the other evening, plucking young hostesses from the couches where they sat with customers and hustling them quietly out to a waiting van.

title: General Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Wedtech Paid $1 Million Fee For 'Payola,' Ex-Official Says
description: The former president of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that a $1 million fee paid to two financial associates of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was to have been used, in part, ''for baksheesh, which means payoffs.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Oregon Primary Tally
description: Unofficial vote count from Tuesday, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting. $ DEMOCRATS Dukakis 207,512 (56%) Jackson 142,382 (38%) Others 20,442 (6%) REPUBLICANS Bush 189,189 (73%) Others 69,363 (27%) Source: The Associated Press

title: Arthur Long, 61, Consultant on Takeovers
description: Arthur F. Long, a consultant on investor relations, died of cancer Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 61 years old, lived in Garden City, L.I., and also had homes in Quogue, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Deal in Texas To Rescue 4 Saving Units
description: Federal regulators will provide at least $2 billion to the Southwest Savings Association, a Dallas savings and loan, to help it acquire four insolvent Texas savings institutions in a deal worth $4.4 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Man Charged in Plot on Jackson Suggested Others Were Involved
description: A law-enforcement official said today that a Missouri man who is accused of plotting to kill the Rev. Jesse Jackson made a statement to an informer implying that others had done the high-level planning.

title: Cancel the Stealth Bomber
description: LEAD: How can the Pentagon save $50 billion over the next decade without sacrificing military capability? By canceling the Stealth bomber - a feasible step for the next President.

title: Reviews/Music; A Puerto Rican Touch
description: Yomo Toro brought the cuatro, a 10-string miniature guitar, out of Puerto Rican jibaro, or hillbilly, music and into modern dance halls. With his electrified cuatro, which sounds like a mandolin that's been pumping iron, and his speed-demon technique, he makes the cuatro a lead instrument for salsa and hybrids of other pop styles from all around the Americas. He brought his band -congas, bongos, trap drums, bass, violin and two singers - to S.O.B.'s last Thursday to play music from his new album, ''Funky Jibaro,'' filling the dance floor as he has for decades.

title: Nautical Accessories For Ship or Shore
description: YOU don't have to own a boat to enjoy the soothing sound of ship's bells. Ship's bell clocks and other nautical instruments are being snapped up by homeowners and interior designers ''when they're looking to do a den or something in a nautical way,'' said Ken Maisler, secretary-treasurer of the 75-year-old New York Nautical Instrument and Service Corporation in lower Manhattan.

title: Joint Chefs' Head Skeptical on Noriega
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff predicted today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, would not give up power as early as Washington wants.

title: Brazil Halts Debt Talks With Foreign Bankers
description: Brazilian negotiators suspended talks with foreign commercial banks today amid reports of differences over whether a new debt restructuring package should be linked to an agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Baseball Notebook; Banged-Up Cards Showing Signs of Life
description: If Whitey Herzog can find the man with the voodoo dolls and the pins, the St. Louis Cardinals may be able to present at least a mild challenge before the Mets completely run away with the division championship.

title: Sage Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter results include a gain on the sale of four of its radio stations in Wisconsin in excess of $1 million.

title: Review/Rock; Angry Political Funk
description: Wherever there's a standard approach in rock, Midnight Oil goes its own way. Midnight Oil's bald, 6-foot-6-inch singer, Peter Garrett, looks like no other performer, flapping his arms and contorting his face like an agonized cheerleader, with his legs pumping rhythms or suddenly carrying him around the stage. His messages, too, are anything but typical: ''Did you read the history book?,'' he admonished the crowd Friday night at the sold-out Beacon, and ''Did Mr. Bush used to work for the C.I.A.?'' Mr. Garrett's voice is dry and raspy, and he doesn't disguise his staccato Australian accent. But within the band's tuneful, asymmetrical songs he puts across some of the strongest political messages in rock.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday showing the number of epople on welfare in New York City carried an incorrect explanation. The figures referred to the number of welfare cases, not individuals on welfare.

title: 60 Years of Technique From Martha Graham
description: Dancers who have performed with Martha Graham from the 1920's through the present are to participate today in ''Sixty Years of Martha Graham Technique,'' at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.

title: Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no share earnings figures because Curtis Industries is privately held. The company said CI Holdings Corp., a newly formed corporation, acquired Curtis Industries in August 1986 from Congoleum Industries Inc.

title: Ethics Inquiry on Speaker of House Is Urged
description: The watchdog group Common Cause called on the House today to investigate some financial activities of the Speaker, Jim Wright, for possible conflicts of interest.

title: Calendar: Bird Walk and Guided Tour
description: Bird Walk, Wave Hill, 249th Street at Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx; 212-549-2055.

title: Electrolux Pursuit Of Toro Disclosed
description: Sweden's A.B. Electrolux considered buying the Toro Company, a lawnmower manufacturer in Minneapolis, before it decided to pursue the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company last month, it was disclosed in a United States court hearing. The disclosure was made by Neil Anderson, a lawyer for the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, whose relationships with Electrolux and Murray, based in Brentwood, Tenn., are under scrutiny.

title: Consolidated Capital Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The losses are after provisions for possible losses of $2,386,000 in the latest quarter and $1,350,000 in the year- earlier quarter.

title: Yields Rise In Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, lifted by fears of inflation and last week's half-point increase in the banks' prime lending rate.

title: Bangor Hydro-Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Conran's, Writ Larger
description: CONRAN'S, an American retail chain that revolutionized home furnishing retailing a decade ago with simple, moderately priced designer furniture, will open a flagship store next Wednesday in the former RKO Keith's theater building, at 81st Street and Broadway. The 34,000-square-foot, four-story outlet will be Conran's third in Manhattan and its 16th in the United States, and one of the largest retail stores ever to open on the Upper West Side.

title: Plenum Publishing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Air Midwest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Missile Fuel Wasn't Involved in Factory Blast, Soviet Says
description: A chemical-factory explosion killed three people but did not involve fuel for a new long-range nuclear missile, as the Pentagon reported, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Market Place; Japanese Portfolio Insurance Grows
description: THE Japanese are known for copying American fads and the latest to appeal to them is portfolio insurance, which was cited as a chief contributor to the selling panic on Wall Street last October.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comfed Bancorp, Lowell, Mass., a holding company for Comfed Savings Bank, which has retail branches in Massachusetts and Connecticut, elected as a director Thomas D. O'Malley, chairman and chief executive of Argus Resources Inc., an investment and trading company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Floyd Patterson, the former world heavyweight champion, will receive an honorary doctor of humane letters degree at Marist College on Saturday. . . . Art Still, a 10-year veteran left end, has been told by Jim Schaaf, the general manager of the Kansas City Chiefs, that he no longer fits into the team's plans and would not be with the team in 1988. (AP)

title: Candiotti Finishes 6th Game
description: Joe Carter hit a two-run double in the eighth inning tonight and Tom Candiotti pitched his sixth complete game as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sox, 2-1.

title: Beijing Journal; Where the Price of Vegetables Only Feeds Despair
description: At the Yong An Li food market in eastern Beijing last Saturday, lines of anxious shoppers stretched into the street. Inside, harried shop assistants shouted at customers and at one another in an effort to cope with the panic buying that engulfed the Chinese capital before sharply higher food prices took effect.

title: A FIRST SOVIET UNIT QUITS AFGHANISTAN
description: With the foreign press looking on, the first brigade of Soviet soldiers to withdraw formally from Afghanistan returned home today for a welcome by their Government, tears from their families and traces of bitterness and regret.

title: Longs Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
4 Men Arrested in Chicago Bank Embezzlement Attempt
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested four men today in connection with a suspected attempt to transfer about $70 million from three large customers of the First National Bank of Chicago to accounts in Austrian banks.

title: Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. $ DEMOCRATS Dukakis 1,643 Jackson 962 Gore 389 Simon 172 Undetermined* 525 Total delegate votes: 4,161 Chosen so far: 3,691 Needed to nominate: 2,081 $ REPUBLICANS Bush 1,433 Robertson 45 Undetermined* 235 Total delegate votes: 2,277 Chosen so far: 1,713 Needed to nominate: 1,139 * Includes some delegates whose chosen candidate has withdrawn.

title: Big O Tires Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pentagon Awards 2 Contracts on MX
description: The Westinghouse Electric Company and the Rockwell International Corporation won Pentagon military contracts to build a railroad car and computer software to mobilize the MX nuclear missile. A contract for $167 million went to Westinghouse to design and build a railroad launching car for the 10-warhead intercontinental missile by mid-1992, the Air Force announced. At the same time, Rockwell International got a $161.7 million contract to design a launching-control system for the rail-mounted missile.

title: Gold Output Up in 1987
description: Gold production in the non-Communist world rose 4 percent last year, to a record 1,341 metric tons, Samuel Montagu & Company said today. Mines in North America and Australia accounted for the increase from 1986's 1,290 tons. South African output, affected by strikes, declined.

title: Media News Picks President
description: Michael H. Heath, president and chief operating officer of Macromedia Inc., has been named president and chief operating officer of Media News Group Inc. and Media News Holdings Inc., company officials said today. The Dallas-based Media

title: Editor of Brooklyn College Paper Caught in Imbroglio Over Content
description: As a student at Brooklyn College and editor of a weekly newspaper at the college, The Kingsman, Michael Golub has been receiving an education about the newspaper business.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I HAVE noticed that there are a great many more young people around than there once were. By young people I do not mean people who are children, or who are not elderly, or who have not reached the age of consent. I mean those people who are egregiously, aggressively young, the kind of people who tell you, bright-eyed, that they would like to do what you do when they grow up, or who treat you with respect and call you ''ma'am,'' or who see fit to mention that their parents often listen to the Beatles, too. The kind of people whose youth threatens to run up and bite you on the nose.

title: Baker Says He Has Not Seen Reagan Swayed by Astrology
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said today he had never seen President Reagan make a policy decision based on astrology or the influence of Nancy Reagan.

title: At Columbia, Crowd Reaction Counts
description: Columbia University ended its 234th academic year yesterday outside in the rain. The university president, Dr. Michael I. Sovern, cut short his speech about the threat of an impending shortage of professors, but went ahead and conferred degrees school by school as a steady drizzle turned into a downpour.

title: Mason Sees Cover-Up In Death of a Detainee
description: A lawyer for a Bronx woman who died after six days in jails and city hospitals called on Governor Cuomo yesterday to name a special prosecutor to look into the police role in the case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS The stock market continued its sharp retreat amid growing concern over higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial averaage fell 35.32 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,951.09, the lowest level since early February. Broader market indexes also fell and declining stocks far outnumbered advancing ones. [ Page D1. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved lower again in light trading. [ D17. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D11. ] The dollar finished lower against most major currencies as a rally inspired by U.S. trade figures petered out. Gold rose $1.80 an ounce on the Comex, to $457.30. [ D16. ] Prices of oil futures declined, following an industry report that showed swelling inventories of crude and heating oil. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY Four insolvent savings and loans in Texas will be acquired by a Dallas savings institution as part of the Federal plan to rescue the state's ailing industry. [ D1. ] Losses continued to rise among Texas banks in the first quarter, but the F.D.I.C.'s chairman said that the industry's fortunes in the state should improve next year. [ D7. ] Construction of single-family homes fell in April as higher mortgage rates seemed to be taking a toll on building. Over all, however, construction rose 0.5 percent because of a 23.3 percent rise in the building of multifamily units. [ D5. ] COMPANIES The chill between Irving and Bank of New York deepened as leaders of the two banks met for 20 minutes and broke off talks. Each side apparently expected the other to present new proposals. A few hours after the meeting, Bank of New York said that irregularities in the proxy vote at Irving's annual meeting - in which Bank of New York sought to oust Irving's directors - raised questions about the validity of the vote. [ D1. ] Jusco will buy Talbots from General Mills for $325 million -the first major purchase by the Japanese of an American retailer. Spiegel will buy General Mills' Eddie Bauer for $260 million. [ D6. ] Union Carbide will sharply cut its dividend and issue about 15 million shares to help finance its capital investment program. [ D5. ] Donald J. Trump and Merv Griffin opened talks on patching up their Resorts International deal, which fell apart last week. [ D5. ] A recapitalization of Media General was proposed. It would involve spinning off broadcasting and cable operations. [ D18. ] Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has received a much-needed boost from the success of Donald T. Regan's ''For the Record.'' [ D18. ] Ford and G.M. face $300 million in penalties after a Federal appeals court backed changes in fuel economy ratings. [ B28. ] INTERNATIONAL Final enactment of the free-trade pact with Canada is expected this summer after two important Congressional committees approved legislation to put the treaty into effect. The legislation makes American laws conform with the changes in tariff, regulatory and other practices called for under the pact. [ D1. ] Brazilian negotiators suspended talks with foreign banks amid reports of differences on whether a new debt restructuring should be linked to an agreement with the I.M.F. But Brazil and bankers both said the six-month-old talks had not broken down. [ D2. ] The U.S. and the European Community are at an impasse in their talks on how to eliminate the more than $200 billion in annual farm subsidies around the world. That is not surprising: both sides are clinging to positions taken before the talks began. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Texans hope for a turning point in capital inflow with the bid for the developer of a Dallas real estate project. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Portfolio insurance is catching on among the Japanese, even though it has been criticized as a contributor to the selling panic last October. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Lucky Stores' Net Is Off 46%
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said today that its net income declined about 46 percent in the first quarter ended May 1. Earnings from continuing operations rose 3.9 percent, however, despite $4.4 million in unusual expenses in connection with competing takeover offers for the 486-store food chain, based in Dublin, Calif.

title: Groundbreaking Set for New Denver Airport
description: City officials said today that ground would be broken for a huge $1.6 billion airport next spring now that voters in nearby Adams County have overwhelmingly approved Denver's annexation of 45 square miles of high prairie.

title: Marion Abeson, Songwriter, 75
description: Marion Abeson, a writer of songs for children, died of colon cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old.

title: Soviet Closes a Magazine Extolling Openness
description: The editor of the independent magazine Glasnost said today that the authorities had confiscated his printing equipment and destroyed his files and manuscripts, leaving the future of the best-known Soviet dissident journal in doubt.

title: Facet Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $626,000 for the quarter and $860,000 for the 6 months. c-After a tax benefit of $112,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Helen of Troy (Co) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $782,000.

title: Dart Group Buys 50% of Jumbo Food
description: The Dart Group Corporation announced it had acquired 50 percent of the stock of Jumbo Food Stores Inc., which operates 18 discount grocery stores in Maryland and Virginia. Dart Group, which has unsuccessfully tried to acquire some of the largest retailers in the country in the last several years, did not disclose the cost of the stock.

title: The Fears of Children: Is the World Scarier?
description: IN an era of homelessness, AIDS, drug abuse and ozone-layer depletion, at a time when preschoolers are taught about child abuse and kidnapping, parents and child-development experts are raising new concerns about children's fears.

title: Basix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $1,793,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: Lilco Accord Facing Foes; Unanimity Is Ending Over Shoreham Issue
description: On Monday, Governor Cuomo endorsed ending his battle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant by negotiating with the Long Island Lighting Company to abandon the $5.3 billion plant.

title: McIntyre Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes share of a special gain reported by Falconbridge Ltd. of $6,081,000. The company had no revenue because its primary business is its holding in Falconbridge Ltd.

title: 2 Die in Kuwait Blast Near Airline's Offices
description: An explosion rocked an area close to the downtown headquarters of the Kuwait Airways Corporation today, killing two people and destroying a car that was apparently the source of the blast, witnesses said.

title: Teheran Claims Gains in Northeastern Iraq
description: Iranian gunboats attacked a Japanese-owned tanker in the Strait of Hormuz today and Iran said its forces killed or wounded 2,000 Iraqis in a new offensive in a rugged part of northeastern Iraq.

title: Wings' Coach Pact Extended
description: Coach Jacques Demers has been given a two-year extension of his contract that lengthens his agreement with the Detroit Red Wings through the 1992-93 season, the club announced today.

title: A Computing Magazine Changes Name Again
description: In September 1985 Scholastic Inc. began its first publication for readers outside the school environment. The magazine was called Family Computing. As the magazine's perception of its audience changed, so did its name, which became Family & Home Office Computing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an increase in Soviet Jewish emigration misstated the figure given by the National Conference on Soviet Jewry for April departures. It is 1,088, not 1,086.

title: Jackson, in Bid to Heal Rift, Meets With California Jews
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, saying that the field was more fertile for healing here than in New York, held a conciliatory meeting with a group of rabbis and other Jewish leaders from Southern California today.

title: Syrians Suspend Move Into Suburbs of Beirut
description: Syria said today that it was suspending plans to deploy troops in Beirut's southern suburbs, the scene of 13 days of fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.

title: Union's Victory at Harvard Seen as Spur to Labor Drive
description: Union organizers at Harvard University, riding high after winning the right to represent the university's 3,400 clerical and technical workers, are moving to the next phase: planning for contract talks.

title: Fehr Wants Expansion
description: Don Fehr, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, accused the club owners of making franchises artificially scarce and insisted today that they immediately consider expansion.

title: New Residents, New Life in Hamilton Hts.
description: WHEN he was 17 years old, Leonard Brian Philip would walk by the red-brick house on Hamilton Terrace in the Hamilton Heights section of Manhattan and think of it as his dream house.

title: Review/Television; Viewers Are Let In On Gossip
description: We are one big classless society; everyone knows everyone else. ''M and W Men and Women'' encapsulates us all in the same gossip column. The ABC special, on Channel 7 at 9 o'clock tonight, roams the world without ever leaving the hairdresser's. It is shallow, silly and pretentious; it is also energetic, wry and funny.

title: Chartwell Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Toys 'R' Us Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Big Sale, Big Flap
description: When the entertainer Art Linkletter was named United States Commissioner General to help Australia celebrate its 200th birthday, the appointment was celebrated by a company for which he acts as spokesman by holding a sale on a contour chair dubbed the Ambassador. The Government was not amused.

title: Republic Pictures Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canadian Treaty Advances
description: Two Congressional committees approved legislation that is needed to put into effect the free-trade agreement with Ottawa. Page D6. Glimpse of a Cosmodrome

title: Autodesk Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Currents; Fine Craft, as Piecework
description: THE ancient Egyptians were very good at it, as were many Italian Renaissance artists and 17th-century French furniture makers. These days, a number of artists are interested in marquetry, a woodworking technique in which images are created of pieces of wood veneers like pieces in a puzzle.

title: Bush Reports He Got $100,000 From Trust
description: Vice President Bush received more than $100,000 in income from a qualified trust and $20,773 in a distributions from a limited petroleum partnership in 1987, according to papers made public Tuesday.

title: F.C.C. Approves Atlantic Cable Plan
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved plans by an international group of telecommunications companies to build a new trans-Atlantic undersea cable that would go into service in 1991. The fiber optic cable, known as TAT-9, will carry 80,000 simultaneous telephone calls, or about twice the capacity of the TAT-8 cable scheduled to go into operation between the United States and Europe this year.

title: Rate Fears Send Dow Down 35.32
description: LEAD: The stock market continued its sharp retreat yesterday amid growing concern over higher interest rates.

title: Barr Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $358,000 due to debt extinguishment of bonds prior to maturity for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Focus on First Ladies And Expected Byplay
description: Relations may have warmed between President Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev since their first summit meeting in Geneva but, as public perceptions go, relations between Nancy Reagan and Raisa M. Gorbachev remain closer to the spirit of the cold war.

title: Profit Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Booth at TKTS Site
description: Amid swarms of umbrellas and hundreds of theatergoers eager to buy tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows, the Theater Development Fund opened a new, redesigned half-price TKTS booth in Duffy Square yesterday morning.

title: Blondell Cummings's Ode to a Taxi
description: Blondell Cummings's keen sensibilities as an actor, dancer, choreographer and observer come to the fore in '3'3B49,'' a powerful and imaginative new work presented by Blondell Cummings and Company at the Joyce Theater on Saturday in the 3-D at the Joyce festival.

title: License Revoked
description: The thoroughbred training license of Robert DeBonis has been revoked by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. The license was revoked for ''attempt to commit a fraud in connection with racing and breeding,'' according to an announcement yesterday by Richard Corbisiero Jr., the board's chairman. The action confirmed the recommendation of John Dailey, the hearing officer in a five-session investigation, who found that DeBonis ''filed false information with the New York State Thoroughbred Breeding and Development Fund when he attempted to register four foals of 1985 as New York-bred thoroughbreds.'' Dailey ruled that the criteria for the designation as New York-bred foals had not been met and that ''such fraudulent conduct justifies a revocation of DeBonis's license to own or train thoroughbred horses engaged in parimutuel racing, categories requiring the highest degree of trust and honor.'' DeBonis, whose horses earned more than $2 million in 1981, can apply for reinstatement in 1989.(AP)

title: Martin Nielsen Rasmussen, Telescope Builder, 92
description: Martin Nielsen Rasmussen, an engineer and machinist who built the Junkyard Telescope on display at the Smithsonian Institution, died Saturday. He was 92 years old.

title: Eritrean Rebels Accuse Ethiopia of Atrocities
description: Rebels in the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea have accused Government troops of killing 400 civilians by shooting them or crushing them with tanks.

title: Reviews/Dance; Emphasis on Live Music By Mark Morris Troupe
description: Mark Morris is not a great choreographer but he is a fluent and entertaining one. His work, in its joining of energy and classical music, belongs to the same corner as Paul Taylor's and Lar Lubovitch's. As Tuesday night's opening by the Mark Morris Dance Company proved again at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place), he is still finding his way - to the great enjoyment of the audience.

title: Hollywood Sends Talent Scouts to (Film) School
description: John C. McGinley is an actor on the rise. After appearances in ''Platoon'' and ''Wall Street,'' and fresh from shooting his third Oliver Stone film, ''Talk Radio,'' he is starring in ''The Buddy and Al Story,'' an offbeat comedy about two brothers who dream of winning back the nightclub their mother lost when they were just show-biz kids.

title: Hills Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
May Plans to Close Three Ayres Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company said it would close and sell its three remaining Cincinnati-area L. S. Ayres department stores by June 15 because the chain is trailing competitors in the market. Two months ago, May announced it was closing the chain's downtown Cincinnati store.

title: Currents; Sampling British Design At London Show House
description: SHOW HOUSE fever seems to be spreading abroad. From next Thursday to June 19, Chelsea Old Town Hall on King's Road in London will be the site of the British Interior Design Exhibition, a 21-designer event.

title: A Mutilated Display Prompts Middlebury To Punish Fraternity
description: A Middlebury College fraternity was placed on suspension for one year today over the display of a mutilated female mannequin that hung from the fraternity's balcony in two days of parties May 7 and 8.

title: Applied Materials Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Net loss

title: On Death ad te Job of Getting There
description: In her new novel, ''Second Chances,'' Alice Adams describes one character's thoughts: ''Death, the idea of death, is not what she so much minds . . . dying will be a fairly simple matter, she believes, a losing of consciousness, quite possibly welcome, like sleep. But the stages on the way to death, the ways that the world has now worked out for people to die, there's the real horror: hospitals, surgery, anesthesia.''

title: Bridge
description: For several years the American Contract Bridge League's Bulletin has carried a popular monthly series entitled ''Tips for Tops.''

title: Review/Music; From a Westernized Japan
description: Michio Miyagi's career as a composer belongs to the era when Japan was taking its first firm steps out of a closed culture and into an international one. Westernization - or so it has been called - is a traumatic process for Japanese music in particular. For what could be further apart in method or in purpose than the classical style of 18th-century Japan and the corresponding Classicism of Mozart, Haydn and Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach?

title: Books of The Times; A Frustrated Hunter on the Trail of J.D. Salinger
description: In Search of J. D. Salinger By Ian Hamilton 222 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Comstock Offers $1 Billion in Shares
description: Comstock Partners, a management investment company run by a former chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, Stanley D. Salvigsen, offered more than $1 billion worth of stock yesterday in a new closed-end fund, Comstock Partners Strategy Fund.

title: Louis Glenn Fields Jr., State Department Aide, 58
description: Louis Glenn Fields Jr., a former State Department lawyer and arms control negotiator, died of intestinal cancer Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 58 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: May Flowers by Shipment, Not Shower
description: NOW that the spring orgy of azaleas and dogwoods is upon us, the most frantic time in a busy gardener's life is at its end. I mean the plant-shipping season, which starts in early March, peaks in late April and slows almost to a standstill by the second week of May. Every three or four days during this time, the postman or the U.P.S. truck arrives at my gate, bringing packages of plants I ordered in January or February.

description: The company said the main reason for the sales increase was the acquisition of the resistor business of Corning Electronics in November 1987.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Hawks Win to Close In on Upset
description: The ''I HATE L.A.'' T-shirts have already been displayed by the entrepreneurs on Causeway Street. Inside the Boston Garden, the Celtic fans were aware that the Detroit Pistons had concluded their playoff series tonight. There were bad guys to take on across the country.

description: In GATT talks, the United States has proposed a way to liberalize trade in service industries, delegates said today. The proposal was submitted

title: U.S. Hopes for 3 Modest Pacts On Arms at Moscow Summit
description: The United States hopes that several modest agreements on providing notice of missile tests and on nuclear testing will be signed at the summit meeting in Moscow, senior Administration officials said today.

description: The company said it changed its fiscal year end from Sept. 30 to March 31.

description: b-Net loss

description: Against a background of exploding interest in advertising - interest both wanted and unwanted - the American Association of Advertising Agencies began its annual meeting here this afternoon at the stately old Greenbrier.

title: Children Of 2 Lands In Search Of Home
description: Growing up in Vietnam, Vinh Doan came to expect rejection. His father was a black American soldier whom he never met. His Vietnamese mother spent years telling him he was ugly because he looked like his father, then gave him to a neighbor when he was 7 years old.

title: Parent & Child
description: ABOUT one of every seven children in the United States has emotional problems that need psychotherapy or professional counseling, according to a 1986 report by Office of Technology Assessment, a research arm of Congress.

description: A Minister of Internal Affairs who was a close friend of Leonid I. Brezhnev plundered state funds to enrich himself and his family for more than a decade, according to a leading Soviet journalist.

title: Metro Matters; On Bronx Juries, Minority Groups Find Their Peers
description: When she practices in Queens, a Manhattan negligence lawyer jokes, she goes by her married name. But when she appears before juries in the Bronx, she gives her maiden name instead.

description: Ethnic tensions have flared anew in recent days in two Soviet southern republics that were shaken by violent confrontations and mass demonstrations earlier this year, a Soviet radio broadcast said today.

title: Correcting the Record on Israel
description: It certainly looked as though President Reagan was trying to influence the Israeli election next fall. During Tuesday's White House visit he unstintingly praised Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, whose ''positive attitude toward peace'' he contrasted with the negativism of other, unnamed world leaders who ''consistently reject new ideas.''

title: Helms Fails in an Effort to Block Arms Pact
description: The arms treaty that President Reagan hopes to take to Moscow this month overcame its first hurdle on the Senate floor today as Senator Jesse Helms lost in his effort to block consideration of the pact on the ground that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, had no authority to sign it in the first place.

Conservative PAC Bankrupt
description: The Fund for a Conservative Majority, a political action committee that raised $5.1 million to promote the election of President Reagan in the 1980 campaign and $5.4 million in his 1984 re-election effort, filed for protection under the bankruptcy code last week.

description: Construction of single-family homes fell in April, providing evidence that higher mortgage interest rates may be dampening building activity.

title: Review/Jazz; A New Big-Band Identity
description: In the 15 years since some New England college students formed a band that mixed rock, swing and rhythm-and-blues and named it the Widespread Depression, the group has gone through a slowly developing series of changes. It has shifted its focus to the black big bands of the 1930's and 40's, changed its name to the Widespread Jazz Orchestra and gradually built a nucleus of musicians who no longer depend on role models from the Swing Era but play with strong musical personalities of their own.

description: Switzerland's financial markets will take a technological leap forward Thursday with the opening of the world's first fully automated options and futures exchange. Unlike similar exchanges in

description: If the nation's economy is performing so well, why are the Republicans, specifically George Bush, not doing better?

title: Reds Get Durham
description: The Chicago Cubs traded their veteran first baseman, Leon Durham, yesterday for the Cincinnati Reds' Pat Perry, a left-handed relief pitcher and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: As Some Shake It, Others Are Shaken
description: Every few years, it seems, a dance erupts from America's black culture that gets young people everywhere moving, and older people shaking their heads. The 60's had the twist, the 70's the freak, the 80's break dancing. Now there's da butt.

Quotation of the Day
description: ''Right now, I feel beautiful, because I am waiting to see the Soviet people.'' - Igor Lukyanchuk, a 19-year-old soldier returning from Afghanistan. [ A10:6. ]

title: Currents; Modern Landmarks Suitable for Nibbling
description: WHEN Ken Walker wanted to create a product that could be sold through the Museum of Modern Art, he tried to think of something that would reflect his interests in architecture and architectural history, and yet be a bit humorous. The result: Genuine Architectural Cookie Cutters, which are modeled after modern landmarks.

title: Alcott and Lopez At Top of the Tour
description: Amy Alcott promised two things today on the eve of the Mazda Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship.

title: Paul J. McNulty, Dean, 57
description: Dr. Paul J. McNulty, vice dean for academic affairs at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business from 1984 until last month, died of occlusive coronary artery disease Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: City Council Leader Opposes Koch on Realty Tax Increase
description: Warning that New York City homeowners already face a dramatic state-mandated property tax increase in 1990, the City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday that he opposed the Mayor's request for a $150 million city property tax increase starting July 1.

title: U.S. Reporters Get Firsthand View of Soviet Space Launching
description: Soviet space officials opened this sensitive launching site to American journalists today in what space experts said was the first visit by reporters from the United States.

title: With Teller Distracted, Man Takes $100,000 From Bank
description: A man robbed a bank here of $100,000 today after a teller's attention was diverted, allowing him to walk out with a bag of money that had just been delivered by armored car, the police said.

title: Health Center Chief Says He Is Seeking
description: The executive director of the Soundview Health Center in the Bronx announced yesterday that he would challenge Representative Robert Garcia in the Democratic primary this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a videotape showing Robert E. Chambers Jr. misidentified a lawyer for the family of Jennifer Levin, who was killed in Central Park nearly two years ago by Mr. Chambers. The lawyer is Jeffrey Newman.

title: Reviews/Dance; Charles Moulton's Merry Manias
description: Everything the Charles Moulton Dance Company did Sunday night at the Joyce Theater was absolutely ridiculous and lots of fun. Mr. Moulton's dances were merry manias.

title: New Mexico Hires Bliss
description: Dave Bliss of Southern Methodist University was named today as the basketball coach at New Mexico. The hiring, announced in a statement released by the school, came two days after Bob Knight decided to stay at Indiana.
