Venice Sending Gondolas As Prelude to Arts Festival
description: Gondolas from Venice as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts? That's right, says Martin E. Segal, the festival's founder and chairman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS U.S. Gains Final: The United States defeated France, 3-0, yesterday to advance to the final of the $750,000 World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, West Germany. The Americans clinched the victory when Tim Mayotte defeated Thierry Tulasne, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2, and Aaron Krickstein beat Tarik Benhabiles, 6-4, 6-7, 6-2, in singles. Switzerland also advanced, rallying to defeat Argentina, 2-1. Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina downed Roland Stadler, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, but Jakob Hlasek, who was born in Czechoslovakia, came back to even the score for the Swiss, easily defeating Martin Jaite, 6-4, 6-0. Stadler and Hlasek then defeated Bengoechea and Jaite in doubles, 6-0, 6-0.(AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL St. John's Wins: Trailing by 6-0 in the fifth inning, St. John's rallied to eliminate Providence, 14-6, at the Big East tournament in Bristol, Conn., last night. The Redmen scored a tournament-tying record eight runs in the eighth inning to seal the victory for Glenn Bratteng, pitching in relief. The St. John's right fielder, Robert Lambria, led the Redmen's 16-hit attack with three hits, including two doubles and a two-run homer. He drove in five runs.

title: Currents; When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Cafe table by Kevin Walz for Arc International, 1986. B. Triangle Up-Triangle Down table by Richard Chillcott for the Richard Chillcott Design Group, 1987.

title: B.P. Unit Seeks Quick Merger
description: BP America, a unit of the British Petroleum Corporation, put pressure today on the Lear Petroleum Corporation and a group of dissident shareholders by releasing a letter to Lear. It said that the proposed merger between the two companies must be completed promptly, if at all, because of ''ongoing deterioration'' of Lear.

title: Notes and Bonds Continue Retreat
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved lower again yesterday in light, nervous trading.

title: Suffolk's Unusual Legislature: Incubator or Just a Hothouse?
description: For nearly two decades, the Suffolk County Legislature has been an incubator of ideas ranging from bottle deposits to smoking bans. Sometimes first, sometimes far out, it has also considered less-successful proposals, such as one to establish a county navy.

title: Review/Television; When Pratyer Is Fatal
description: The man is in a hospital bed, his hand resting on a radio tuned into a religious program. Suddenly he gets up and, before astonished nurses, begins walking, all the while chanting ''Thank the Lord, thank you, Jesus.'' So begins ''Promised a Miracle,'' the television movie on Channel 2 at 9 tonight. Based on a 1973 incident, this is the true story of Lucky and Larry Parker, who truly believed that the Lord would cure their diabetic son. They wound up being tried for involuntary manslaughter.

title: Consolidated Capital Special Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The losses are after provisions for possible loan losses of $1,265,000 in the latest quarter and $1,241,000 in the year-earlier quarter.

title: No-Frills Oilers Take 1-0 Lead
description: The Oilers promised they wouldn't and couldn't use ''razzle dazzle'' to carry them past the Boston Bruins to a Stanley Cup, and as their series commenced tonight in Edmonton, they showed themselves to be as committed to an unadorned style as their opponents.

title: Army Reports Problems in Its New Beretta Pistol
description: The Army says it stopped accepting deliveries of its new 9-millimeter Beretta pistol last November because of cracking in the frame and that it is now investigating a second problem involving the gun's slide mechanism.

title: Times Sq. Gunman Tied to Connecticut Shooting
description: Police officers who went to the scene of a fatal shooting near Times Square early yesterday seized a man from Connecticut who confessed not only to killing the unidentified man sprawled nearby, but also to wounding another in Meriden, Conn., less than 36 hours before.

title: Fremont General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,472,000 from discontinued insurance operations and an extraordinary credit of $249,000. c-After a gain of $4,461,000 from discontinued insurance operations.

title: Rise in Black Applications Reported by Many Colleges
description: Many colleges are reporting sharply higher numbers of applications from blacks this year, suggesting more blacks may be on campus next fall after several years of intense recruiting of black high school students.

title: Hal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Triple Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Dealers Rush To Sign Soviet Artists
description: In a burst of international entrepreneurship, American and European art dealers are traveling to the Soviet Union in search of contemporary painting that they hope will capture the fancy - and the dollars - of collectors in the West.

title: Scientists Seek Ways To Limit Lasting Harm Of Hepatitis Infection
description: Scientists have begun research that they hope will provide the first treatments to limit the liver damage caused by chronic infection with hepatitis viruses, a major global health problem.

title: News Corp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from extraordinary items of $60,906,000 and $1,560,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. c-Includes income from extraordinary items of $9,851,000 and $2,969,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. d-Net income Figures are in U.S. dollars and the share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts with each ADR representing two of the company's ordinary shares.

title: American Century Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Western Tele-Communicaions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of about $1,842,000 from the sale of the company's security position in TCA Cable TV. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $328,000.

title: Roscoe Moss to Pay Fine
description: Government regulators said today that the Roscoe Moss Company had agreed to pay a record $500,000 civil fine to settle charges that it had failed to comply with Federal antitrust rules from 1984 to 1986.

title: Allegheny & Western Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about accusations of improper asbestos removal at the Ansonia Hotel in Manhattan misstated the penalty involved. The New York City Sanitation Department is seeking a record $400,000 fine against the hotel owners, but no penalties have been imposed.

title: Ojeda Keeps Padres at Bay on 2 Hits in 8Y Innings
description: The Mets made it three straight over the San Diego Padres tonight with one more pitching extravaganza.

title: TV Notes
description: A Burnett Retrospective

title: 15 Playwrights Invited To the O'Neill Center
description: Fifteen dramatists have been invited to participate in the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's 1988 National Playwrights Conference in Waterford, Conn. The conference, to be held from July 3 to 31, is devoted to the development of talented writers.

title: Some Meese Aides Dispute His Reasoning on Assistant's Dismissal
description: A number of angry Justice Department officials today sided with the department's former chief spokesman, Terry Eastland, in a dispute with Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d over the reasoning behind the spokesman's dismissal.

title: TJX Cos reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,689,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in inventory accounting. The company went public last June.

title: Home Improvement
description: EXPOSING an interior brick wall can bring warmth and character to a room. Removing plaster from the brick is within the abilities of many homeowners, and is not as difficult as might be imagined. However, dust and rubble must be kept under control, or the project can quickly become impossibly messy.

title: Advance For Canada Trade Pact
description: Two Congressional committees have overwhelmingly approved legislation that clears the way for final enactment of the free-trade agreement with Canada.

title: Glenmore Distilleries Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income and includes a gain on the sale of the marketing rights for Amaretto Di Saronno, which amounted to about $25 million after taxes.

title: Continental vs. the Labor Unions: A View From the Cockpit
description: To the Editor:

title: American Shared Hospital Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said financial results of Curcare Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary acquired by the company in October 1987, are included in the company's first quarter 1988 revenue and net income.

title: Will RU 486 Spur New Abortion Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Biosearch Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $379,000. c-Net loss and after a tax benefit of $134,300.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Office Gets Some New Faces
description: Jay Schulberg has been busy recruiting since joining the New York office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. The agency announced some names of new people on Tuesday.

title: Craftmatic-Contour Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Univar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss The company said the results for the fiscal 1987 year include the combined operations of Univar and McKesson Chemical Co., whose net assets were purchased by Univar on Nov. 1, 1986, from the Feb. 28 date forward, and may not be comparable with the corresponding period of the subsequent year.

title: Cocaine Jury Sees Tapes
description: The jury in the cocaine-smuggling case of Carlos Lehder Rivas asked today to see two videotapes of the defendant, including one in which he called drugs a weapon against imperialism. Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton allowed the review, on the jury's sixth day of deliberations. Mr. Lehder, 38 years old, and his co-defendant, Jack Carlton Reed, 57, of San Pedro, Calif., are charged with conspiring to smuggle 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States from Colombia from 1978 to 1980.

title: Chapman Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a credit for forgiveness of debt of $239,030 and a tax loss carryforward of $105,300 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about Geoffrey Beene's fall fur collection carried a misplaced line at the top of the third column. The line should have been in the second column; the sentence should have read, ''The sporty look of luxury furs is emphasized by Calvin Klein's designs for Alixandre, which include sable, fisher and mink coats.''

title: Bush the Underdog
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll shows George Bush trailing Michael Dukakis by 10 points; a Los Angeles Times poll shows the Republican trailing in California by 17 points. Mr. Bush can now lay claim to being the underdog, and can accuse his opponent of being the front-runner.

title: Pope, Ending Trip, Urges Justice in Paraguay
description: Ending his Latin American tour, Pope John Paul II traveled today to this nation's most revered religious shrine and issued a fervent call for social justice in Paraguay.

title: Agents Discover a Cartridge On Jackson Campaign Plane
description: Secret Service officials said today that they had found an unfired 9-millimeter cartridge for an automatic weapon aboard the aircraft chartered by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about an investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office misidentified a political opponent of District Attorney Paul T. Gentile.

title: Judge Demands Panel Drop Impeachment Inquiry
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami demanded today that a House subcommittee dismiss allegations of misconduct brought against him by fellow judges after his acquittal on bribery conspiracy charges five years ago.

title: MMR Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Battles Erupt in South Korea As Protesters Mark Uprising
description: Thousands of protesters calling for the overthrow of President Roh Tae Woo fought police with firebombs and rocks today as rallies were held to mark the eighth anniversary of the anti-Government uprising in the southern city of Kwangju.

title: The Seasoning Process
description: A large factor in American Ballet Theater's current upswing stems from the way once-new dancers have settled into the company and sparkled in this season's debuts. A perfect example was Alessandra Ferri's first appearance as Kitri in ''Don Quixote'' on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. She was matched excitingly by Danilo Radojevic, who has returned as guest artist after leaving the company last year.

title: Ecogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results reflect the company's continuing transition from a development company to a manufacturing and marketing company. The company said the latest first quarter revenue includes $585,000 from its first marketed product, Dagger G. a Biofungicide.

title: Navistar International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $14.8 million from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $112.8 million from the retirement of debt.

title: Clean Up New York's Scandalous Voting Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Ship Fire Toll Is 11
description: The death toll in a fire on the Soviet cruise liner Priamurye reached 11 today, with 35 people injured. The 4,870-ton Priamurye, sailing from Vladivostok with 129 crew members and 295 passengers, was in Osaka harbor on a three-week tour of Japan when the fire broke out. Japanese firefighters struggled for 11 hours to put out the fire. The police said they were investigating.

title: Louise A. Wood, 78; Ex-Head of Girl Scouts
description: Louise A. Wood, former chief executive officer of Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., died of cancer Monday at her home in Aurora, Calif., about 60 miles east of San Francisco. She was 78 years old.

title: Award for Gilbert
description: Rod Gilbert, the former Ranger, has won the Canadian Society of New York Hockey Achievement Award for 1988. The award, established in 1983, is given for outstanding contributions to hockey. Previous winners were Clarence Campbell, Gordie Howe, Maurice Richard, Bobby Hull and Jean Beliveau. Gilbert, who played his entire career, from 1960 to 1978, with the Rangers, is the leading scorer in the history of the franchise. He had 406 goals, 615 assists for 1,021 points in 1,065 games. He was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1982 and the Madison Square Garden Hall of Fame in 1984. He is the only Ranger to have his uniform number (7) retired. (AP)

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Tuning In on Summit
description: Speaking yesterday of his hopes for improvements in information exchanges with the Soviet Union, Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, said the agency's broadcasting services were planning saturation coverage of the Moscow summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the end of the month. Mr. Wick addressed the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.

title: Palmroth Eligible
description: Tero Palmroth of Finland passed the final phase of his Indianapolis 500 rookie test yesterday, while Harry Sauce withdrew and Dale Coyne was told by the United States Auto Club he would not be allowed to drive.

title: Orbit Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Currents; Visions of Bygone Greece and Turkey
description: THE easel is draped with a pair of antique Turkish pants; 19th-century weapons on loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art are arranged in the vitrine; pieces of 16th-century horse armor are displayed on the mantelpiece. The dusty pink walls have been delicately stenciled by James Huniford. The decor is by Stephen Sills, below left, an interior designer who was given the unusual commission by Michael Ward, a gallery owner, below right, of creating an ambiance for an exhibition of lithographs by Louis Dupre. The French artist traveled to the Middle East in the late 19th century. ''The decor came out of the prints, which are very dramatic,'' said Mr. Ward, the gallery owner. Mr. Sills, who based the setting on the lavish clothing shown in the prints, said, ''I wanted the plaids, florals and stripes to be entwined here as they are in the Turkish costumes.''

title: Joseph J. Tomlin, League Founder, 85
description: Joseph J. Tomlin, the founder of the Pop Warner football program for youths, died Monday after a brief illness. He was 85.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Decline
description: Total sales of stock, bond and income mutual funds plunged to $26 billion in the first quarter of 1988 from $72 billion a year earlier because of the aftershocks of the October crash, the chairman of the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: Now, Enforce the 65 M.P.H. Limit
description: Secretary of Transportation James Burnley was at least half right in assessing the effect of the 65-mile-per-hour speed limit on safety: Aggressive enforcement is essential to keep fatalities down, no matter what the limit. But by suggesting that the switch to 65 from 55 had had no effect on the traffic death rate, Mr. Burnley sowed confusion and gave opponents of the higher limit a stick with which to beat him and it. By his own department's judgment, his statement cannot be substantiated.

title: Too Much Rest Prolongs Muscle Pain, Study Says
description: The conventional medical wisdom on treating some muscle pain, such as backache, may actually play a major role in turning such problems into long-term disabilities, new research indicates.

title: For Russians And Japanese, Is Thaw Near?
description: The approaching summit conference in Moscow has underscored for Japan the fact that it is the only country in the Western alliance that has not appreciably improved relations with the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: 8 Reputed Members Of Genovese Family Indicted by U.S. Jury
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday announced the indictments of eight reputed members and associates of the Genovese crime family, including Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and Matthew (Matty the Horse) Ianniello, on charges of extortion and racketeering stemming from the 1984 takeover of an Edgewater, N.J., gravel company.

title: Lucky Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $22,158,000 and a $5,907,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest quarter results included after-tax expenses of $4.4 million related to tender offers by American Stores and Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen. The latest quarter net also included a $2,574,000 LIFO charge. The year-ago first quarter results included net of $2,496,000 and sales of $245,690,000 from the company's Eagle Food Stores division, which was transferred to a newly formed limited partnership in November 1987. The discontinued operations included the gain on the sale of Yellow Front and the operating results of Hancock Fabrics prior to the pro rata distribution of its stock to Lucky Stores' stockholders. The year-ago quarter's net from continuing operations included a LIFO charge of $3.7 million.

title: Rise in False Alarms Prompts a Study of Scrapping Fire Callboxes
description: Faced with recent increases in false alarms, New York City is considering eliminating one of the urban landscape's most venerable communications fixtures, the street callbox, in favor of a comparative upstart, the telephone.

title: Consolidated Hydro reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest 9 months includes a non- recurring charge of $420,000. The company said results for the quarter were adversely affected by accounting for the sale and leaseback of Consolidated's lachute projects. Net income was reduced by about $200,000 because of accounting requirements to treat the transaction as a capital lease rather than an operating lease.

title: Review/Dance; Slow Unfolding Of a Nightmare World of Horror
description: Sin Cha Hong put her audience through a lot when she presented her new ''Seraphim'' on Friday night at the Joyce Theater, performed by her Laughing Stone company in the 3-D at the Joyce festival. Hers was a look at humanity, ironically or sadly the highest angels of the dance's title, that unfolded at such an uncompromisingly slow and repetitious pace to a score of such uncompromising horror that she lost a good part of the audience by the time ''Seraphim'' had reached its eerie conclusion. But for those who stayed, there was the perilous but considerable reward of confrontation with a rigorous esthetic and a glimpse into a nightmare world rendered with purity and daring.

title: Reviews/Music
description: An Argentine Organist

title: Robert James Lewis, Investment Banker, 89
description: Robert James Lewis, a retired investment banker, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan after a series of strokes. He was 89 years old.

title: Democracy, With Gusto, at Co-op City
description: Nobody is waving a bloody shirt in this year's campaign for the board of directors at Co-op City, but mysterious stains in the laundry are a key rallying point.

title: Review/Jazz; Quintet's Bop Standards
description: The Metropolitan Bopera House, a virtually unknown jazz quintet, deserves more attention than the notoriety it has attracted as a result of being sued by the Metropolitan Opera Association over its name. The group's members - John Marshall on trumpet, Ralph Lalama on tenor saxophone, Tardo Hammer on piano, John Weber on bass and Tom Melito on drums - are revivalists on a mission: they want to restore the overlooked compositions of jazz's hard-bop era to their proper place. It's an idea that's in the air. John Zorn, the composer and saxophonist, always an accurate barometer of the zeitgeist, has also recently been performing his interpretations of hard-bop classics.

title: The Navy's in Schools To Share, Not Enlist
description: To the Editor:

title: Practice Nepotism, But Affirmatively
description: Loved her, hated him.

title: Delmed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $31,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $842,000 for disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes a gain of $38,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $3,184,000.

title: Israelis Say U.S. Praise of Peres May Backfire
description: The unusually warm praise of Foreign Minister Shimon Peres by the White House on Tuesday, and the indirect criticism of his chief political rival, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, set off partisan bickering here today. But on at least one point both sides seemed to agree.

title: News Corp. Reports Loss
description: The News Corporation, the media company based in Sydney, Australia, that is owned by Rupert Murdoch, yesterday reported a loss of $18 million for its third fiscal quarter ended March 27.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I have a tiled ceiling that was stained by a water leak in an ice storm last winter. Because of the cost, I cannot replace this ceiling, but would like to paint it. What will cover the water stains?

title: A Peek at History On Governors I.
description: Governors Island - erstwhile fortress, Civil War prison and remote outpost for a pageant of historical characters - has played a wide variety of roles over the last 350 years. But only once a year is it a free open house for the public.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BSN S.A., Paris, the biggest food group in France, agreed to acquire Saratoga Sparkling Mineral waters from Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Death Penalty Amendment Delays Pentagon Budget Bill
description: The Senate was still trying today to work its way out of a legislative snarl that has blocked final action on Defense Department budget legislation while the House overwhelmingly approved a bill that would appropriate $9 billion for military construction programs in the next fiscal year.

title: International Seaway Trading Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $38,000. c-Net loss

title: Talking Deals; Texans Welcome Outsider's Capital
description: TEXANS in banking and real estate hope that last week's bid for the developer of the sprawling Las Colinas complex northwest of Dallas will mark a turning point for badly needed fresh capital to flow into dozens of debt-burdened projects in Houston and Dallas.

title: FRANCE RESTORING ITS TIES WITH IRAN
description: President Francois Mitterrand ordered the Socialist Government today to restore diplomatic ties with Iran, fulfilling a pledge made by the previous Government for Iran's help in winning the release of the last three French hostages in Lebanon.

title: Bank of New York, Irving Break Off Talks Abruptly
description: The rancor between the Irving Bank Corporation and its hostile suitor, the Bank of New York Company, reached a new level yesterday as leaders of the two banks met for 20 minutes and broke off talks.

title: Howard Beach Judge Negotiating Plea Deals
description: The judge in the Howard Beach case has been negotiating plea deals with defendants and without the prosecution, people familiar with the case said yesterday. They said he has tentatively reached such a deal with at least one defendant.

title: New Jet Defensive Backs Fly
description: The Jets looked sensational today, from the new corps of defensive backs batting away passes, to the top draft selection not allowing anyone to cross the offensive line, to 365-pound Albert Goss, who blew opposing centers away as if they were toothpicks.

title: REAGAN AND BUSH PLACE NEW STRESS ON THE DRUG ISSUE
description: Apparently sensing political trouble, both President Reagan and Vice President Bush yesterday called for stronger efforts to combat drugs and said it was time for the two parties to come together on finding solutions to the problem.

title: Utilitarian Chairs Gone Wild and Witty Are Abloom in Cooper-Hewitt's Garden
description: LEAD: MORE than just an opportunity to sit and relax in a garden, ''The Outdoor Chair,'' an exhibition of 30 interpretations of outdoor seating at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, provides unexpected ideas about the chair and its place in the contemporary landscape. Surprise and delight can be found at every turn.

title: F.B.I. Accuses Soviet Of Spying at Libraries
description: The Soviet Union has directed a vast espionage operation against United States libraries in an effort to gain sensitive technical knowledge and recruit agents, according to a report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Trump, Griffin In New Talks
description: Donald J. Trump and Merv Griffin said yesterday that they had begun new talks on giving the Manhattan real estate figure full control of the giant Taj Mahal hotel and gambling casino being built in Atlantic City and allowing the former talk-show host to take over Resorts International Inc., which now owns the casino.

title: Companies Hold Off On Price Increases
description: Despite inflationary pressures in the American economy, many companies are holding back on price increases for finished goods, a spot check shows.

title: F.C.C. Votes ON Exclusive TV Reruns
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved rules intended to reduce the number of syndicated reruns on television by allowing broadcasters to negotiate exclusive programming contracts.

title: Genisco Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $161,240 for the quarter and $289,240 for the 6 months.

title: Carolco Pictures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter includes $110,000 from its share of the operations of Lieberman Enterprises Inc., and International Video Entertainment. The year-ago first quarter has been restated to reflect the results of Orbis Communications which was acquired in a pooling of interests transaction in 1987.

title: Learonal Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Hewlett-Packard Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dukakis Wins 27 More Delegates in Oregon Race
description: Michael S. Dukakis gained his 15th primary ulection victory Tuesday with a solid triumph over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in Oregon and pushed his delegate total to 1,643, or 438 short of the 2,081 needed to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Bamberger Polymers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stock Exchange Loses Economist to Kaufman
description: Roger Kubarych, who became chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange two years ago, has left to become an economics analyst with Henry Kaufman & Company, a consulting firm.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Lakers and Celtics Struggle
description: The Los Angeles Lakers will be the first team since the Celtics of 1969 to repeat as the National Basketball Association champion.

title: Willem Drees Dies at 101; Postwar Dutch Leader
description: Willem Drees, Prime Minister of the Netherlands in the period of postwar recovery from 1948 to 1958 and architect of the nation's comprehensive welfare system, has died, the Government announced today. He was 101 years old.

title: New Head Sees Growth At Minnesota Exchange
description: The Minneapolis Grain Exchange, a regional cash and futures commodities market, has named James H. Lindau president and plans to embark on a period of growth.

title: Fiat Earnings Up in '87
description: The Italian auto maker Fiat S.p.A. reported today that its 1987 earnings rose 9.8 percent on the strength of higher sales. The results for Italy's largest private company included the recently acquired Alfa Romeo unit and Snia-BPD, the textile and military group. Fiat reported earnings of 2.37 trillion lire, or $1.9 billion, in 1987, up from 2.16 trillion lire a year earlier. Revenue rose to 38.43 trillion lire, from 29.33 trillion lire in 1986.

title: Varitronic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Allegheny Ruling Voids 90-Day Delay
description: In the continuing battle for control of Allegheny International Inc., a Federal District judge in Pittsburgh overturned a lower court's ruling yesterday that could have postponed the company's annual meeting for 90 days. According to officials from Allegheny, as a result of yesterday's ruling, the company's annual meeting will be held tomorrow. A proxy fight led by Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage firm, will take place at the meeting.

title: Deb Shops Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Theater; Kay Ballard Flies Solo
description: Kaye Ballard, at age 61, still bubbles with the enthusiasm of a starstruck teen-ager. For her, the era of vaudeville and of stars like Judy Garland and Mabel Mercer looms perennially fresh. Her new one-woman show, ''Working 42d Street at Last'' at the tiny Kaufman Theater (534 West 42d Street) is an appropriately charming anachronism - a sophisticated 50's nightclub act expanded into a 100-minute evening that weaves together songs, jokes and impressions.

title: Why Chess And Not Bridge?
description: Graybeard former undergraduates who, in the 30's, majored in Benny Goodman and minored in bridge will be dismayed to hear what the Aquarian Age has done to their sport. Alan Truscott, The Times's bridge columnist, recently reported on a study showing that for every bridge player on campus now, there are eight chess players. The ''me'' generation insists on going it alone. Partnerships are out.

title: Comstock Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Aide Invokes Privilege On '85 Session About Panama
description: A top aide to Vice President Bush invoked executive privilege today when asked what was said about narcotics when Mr. Bush met with the United States ambassador to Panama in 1985.

title: Cuomo Urges Developers To Fight Graft
description: Warning that New York City's multibillion-dollar construction industry was ''infected'' by corruption and racketeering, Governor Cuomo yesterday urged developers and contractors to have the courage to help clean up the industry.

title: KEY RATES
Uncovered Short Sales Are Up by 4.8% on the Big Board
description: Both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported gains in short interest for the month ended last Friday.

title: Trans-National Leasing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Baker Urges Changes In Monetary Structure
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d wants to improve the system of floating exchange rates by refining economic coordination.

title: Dow Gains 7.63 as Stocks End Day Mixed
description: LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as blue-chip stocks rallied strongly. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.63 points, to close at 1,958.72, after being sharply lower early in the day.

title: TV's Doomed Effort To Examine the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; 'Wonderful Town'
description: When Betty Comden and Adolph Green wrote the lyric ''Life is gay, life is sweet/Interesting people on Christopher Street,'' they were looking back to the idealized 1930's, when Greenwich Village was a crossroad between Ohio and Paris. The tone of ''Wonderful Town,'' one of two New York musicals the lyricists wrote with Leonard Bernstein - the other, of course, is ''On the Town'' - is suffused with joyful innocence. In its engaging revival at the Goodspeed Opera House, the 1953 musical is a celebration not only of a more tuneful time in the life of Broadway, but also of those earlier days when Ruth McKenney and her sister Eileen first arrived in New York.

title: Koch Patronage Inquiry Told of Altered Records
description: Several former New York City employees have told investigators that Koch administration officials ordered the alteration or destruction of some personnel records to delete references to patronage affiliations of job applicants.

title: About Real Estate; Rentals in Princeton Area Get Country Club Setting
description: Traveling through East Windsor, N.J., a visitor might be forgiven for assuming that the attached homes just completed along One Mile Road are the usual suburban-style condominium developments that offer residents a country club setting with a plethora of recreational goodies.

title: Readings to Honor Maxwell Anderson
description: The Rockland Center for the Arts is paying tribute to one of its founders, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwirght Maxwell Anderson, tonight on the occasion of the centennial of his birth.

title: Spiegel President Sees Bauer as a 'Great Fit'
description: John J. Shea, president and chief executive of Spiegel Inc., sees a ''great fit'' of the Eddie Bauer specialty retail operation with Spiegel's catalogue enterprise.

title: Review/Film; 'Palace,' a South African Drama
description: Shot in the stark, underpopulated style of a drama seen on public television, the South African film ''Saturday Night at the Palace'' serves as a primer for the roots of that country's racial strife. It is, however, a very obvious and oversimplified work, essentially a three-character play that sustains a one-note quality all the way through. What gives the film energy is the sheer force of the inevitable, since it's clear from the first scenes that the three principals are on a collision course. Luckily, there's also a modicum of surprise to the film's violent and appalling resolution.

title: Syms Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Director of 92d Street Y Gets Jewish Committee Post
description: Ira Silverman, who until recently was the director of the 92d Street Y.M. & Y.W.H.A., has been named executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee.

description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Adrienne

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day Gets 3 Golds At Art Directors Club
description: Chiat/Day, New York, won all three gold medals for television advertising awarded last night at the 67th annual awards presentation of the Art Directors Club. They also won two of the five silver awards.

title: Intermark Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $7 million loss on extinguishment of debt. c-After a $1,134,000 gain from discontinued operations. The company said the strong showing in the latest quarter is attributable to a $40 million gain realized by its 42 percent owned partner company Triton Group Ltd. from the sale of Simplicity Pattern Co.

title: North Atlantic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $547,000.

title: Arbitrage Move Reassessed
description: Bear, Stearns & Company announced yesterday that it was re-examining its suspension of stock-index arbitrage trading. The firm suspended such program trading both for its own accounts and for its customers last week.

title: Boeskys Win Part of Liquidation
description: A Delaware judge has ruled that Ivan F. Boesky, along with his wife, Seema, and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., must receive part of the proceeds from any liquidation of a partnership formed by Mr. Boesky.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday comparing electricity rates on Long Island with those elsewhere gave an incorrect unit of measurement. The figures were per hundred kilowatt hours.

title: Pop/Jazz; The Return Of Strayhorn And Carter
description: In the last five years, the art of Benny Carter and Billy Strayhorn, two of jazz's greatest composers, has begun to reassert itself, center stage, after decades of benign neglect.

title: Chrysler Air Bags
description: The Chrysler Corporation has begun installing driver's-side air bags as standard equipment on three of its models and will add them this week to three more, becoming the first United States auto maker to make air bags standard equipment. Federal safety regulations require increased use of passive restraints, such as air bags, which inflate in event of a collision, or automatic seat belts. Twenty-five percent of 1988 vehicles must have air bags, 40 percent in 1989 and 100 percent by 1990. Chrysler said it had begun installing driver's-side air bags on Dodge Daytona, Chrysler LeBaron coupe and LeBaron convertible models after May 1.

title: Novar Electronics Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $504,400 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: New York City Fire and Rescue Department
description: To the Editor:

title: Edelman Group Has 7.6% of Payless
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said that he and Sutherland Lumber-Southwest Inc. of Kansas City, Mo., headed a group of investors that had acquired 2.56 million shares, or 7.6 percent, of Payless Cashways Inc., an operator of a chain of building materials stores, also based in Kansas City. Documents showed that the stock cost about $49 million, or $19 a share. The group said it was considering whether to seek control of the company. On the basis of yesterday's market price of $21.625, which was up $1.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, Payless is already worth $728 million.

title: At the Movies
description: Mariel Grows Up

title: Sports of The Times; Oh, the Old Celtics
description: ELIMINATION? The Celtics? In only the semifinals of the Eastern Conference playoffs? Why, they've been in the National Basketball Association finals for the last four years running, and it appeared only last week that they might do it again.

title: Book Notes
description: Trump Reaches for Pen

title: Reagan vs. Regan
description: The dispute between President Reagan and Donald T. Regan, formerly White House chief of staff, broke three cardinal rules of politics in the capital, in the view of one expert. The first rule, ''Keep your Enemies in Front of You,'' was broken by the President, according to Christopher Matthews.

title: Brawley's Mother Gets Grand Jury Subpoena
description: A grand jury investigating the Tawana Brawley case has subpoenaed the teen-ager's mother, Glenda Brawley, according to Mrs. Brawley and a family adviser, the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Cellular Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an aggregate gain of $1,657,000 on the sales of a partnership interest in California and on the company's shares of American Cellular Network Corp., and after an extraordinary loss of $807,000 related to the extinguishment of notes.

title: Uncommon Recognition
description: The Veterans Administration recently broadened its program of paying for inscriptions citing valor awards on military headstones and markers and, as a result, a Medal of Honor winner from New Jersey is about to acquire his due.

title: At The Bar
description: Thirty years ago Bruce Bromley, the legendary litigator of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, regaled some Federal judges with tales from his early days in practice. He recounted how he would exhaust the opposition by dragging out even the simplest cases ''almost to infinity,'' and how what was good for the client was also good for Cravath. ''My firm's meter was running all the time, every month for 14 years,'' he boasted of a case.

title: Qubix Graphic reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PROSECUTION LOSES A WEDTECH RULING
description: In a blow to the prosecution, the judge in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi reversed an earlier ruling yesterday and permitted the defense to question a chief Government witness on the disappearance of his second wife.

title: Bridge
description: The vast difference between ''single dummy'' and ''double dummy'' can be illustrated by the diagramed deal. It was supplied by Bruce Bell of New Zealand, one of the world's most respected bridge journalists.

title: Beazer Extends Bid for Koppers
description: BNS Inc., seeking to take over the Koppers Company for $1.7 billion, extended its hostile tender offer until midnight Wednesday and said it controls more than three-quarters of the Koppers shares. BNS, led by Beazer P.L.C., a British construction company, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said about 73.2 percent of outstanding common shares and about 68.7 percent of outstanding preferred shares had been tendered as of Wednesday.

title: Sonora Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was not in production in the year-earlier period.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Feb. 23 article by Sergei I. Grigoryants, chief editor of Glasnost, a now-closed independent Moscow-based magazine, mistakenly attributed a remark critical of Dr. Georgi V. Morozov, director of the Serbsky Institute of Forensic Psychiatry, to Mr. Grigoryants. The author's manuscript attributed the remark, ''the criminal is defending his right to murder,'' to an American human rights worker.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the decision of Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire against seeking re-election misstated the date of a conversation between him and Vice President Bush.

title: Southern Union Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: c-After a loss of $276,000.

title: Bregman Halts Multifoods Talks
description: Bregman Partners, an investment group led by the Bregman and Belzberg families of Canada, said it had terminated its talks with the International Multifoods Corporation about the possible acquisition of certain operating divisions of the food processing concern based in Minneapolis.

title: Great Western Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Film; Manic Film Noir Thriller as Midnight Cult Film
description: Billed as ''a film noir in living color,'' ''Kiss Daddy Good Night'' offers the expected seamy, noirish life that inevitably leads to murder. But its unexpected heroine is a more threatening version of Susan Seidelman's harmlessly crooked downtown women. Laura's life of petty crime owes something to ''Smithereens'' and ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' though she has an unusually intriguing modus operandi. She assumes an elaborate new identity, goes to clubs or art galleries, and puts the moves on the richest-looking man in the room. Back at his place, she slips something soothing into his drink, and while he's knocked out, she walks off with a few valuables - a 17th-century Italian dagger, a painting cut out of its frame, the cat.

title: Yonkers Loses a Bid To End Housing Pact
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a request by Yonkers to withdraw an agreement it made to build 200 units of low-income housing in mostly white neighborhoods and rebuked elected officials for ''nurturing the hope that the housing will never be built.''

title: Pupils Steal Rabbits To Prevent Slaughter
description: Two teen-age students stole a pair of rabbits to save them from being killed as part of a agriculture science class and apparently succeeded in ending the practice.

title: Guy Lumia, 51, Violinist
description: Guy Lumia, a violinist and one of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra's two concertmasters, died of liver failure due to diabetes Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 51 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Oh, but to Be Able to Administer Sunny Justice
description: In compiling a list of desirable judicial posts, an ambitious lawyer might well look first to New York, the acknowledged center of the legal world. Washington, with its regulatory and political challenges, would certainly make the list, along with Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston and Miami, to name a few.

title: Referee Says He's Bitter
description: Dave Newell, the National Hockey League's senior referee, said he was angry because he was not chosen for the Stanley Cup finals and believed that the league was retaliating.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 12 P.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Federal Committee To Examine Plight Of Elderly Workers
description: A special Labor Department committee will study the problems facing elderly workers, Secretary of Labor Ann McLaughlin said today.

title: Alexander Hirschfeld, Psychiatrist, Dies at 73
description: Dr. Alexander Herzog Hirschfeld, a psychiatrist who was a leader in the field of occupational medicine, died of respiratory failure Wednesday at the Marin General Hospital in Green Brae, Calif. He was 73 years old and lived in Mill Valley, Calif.

title: Bullet Trains Can Unclog Air and Land Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Sunday about the Riverside Opera Company's production of Zandonai's ''Giulietta e Romeo'' omitted the date of the final performance. It will be at 3 P.M. this Sunday at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73d Street.

title: Market Place; Farmers Group's Unusual Defense
description: IN its bitter battle to thwart a $4.3 billion takeover attempt by a British conglomerate with tobacco holdings, Farmers Group Inc. is resorting to an unusual takeover defense. It is emphasizing social issues.

description: Latest 9-month results include an extraordinary gain of $1,069,000, or 10 cents a share, from the repurchase and retirement of the company's convertible debentures.

description: As the deadlines draw near for the Bank of New York Company's hostile bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, neither company shows signs of giving up.

title: Howard Beach Suspect Appears in Closed Court
description: A defendant in the Howard Beach racial-attack case appeared at a closed court proceeding yesterday, and lawyers for other defendants expressed concern that the teen-ager who appeared had secretly pleaded guilty.

title: School Custodians, Under Control
description: The Board of Education's settlement with school custodians marks a big step forward in regaining control of New York City's school buildings. The tentative contract agreement announced yesterday gives school officials greater authority over custodians and makes schools available for wider community use.

title: Chemical Leaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hoquiam Journal; Motivational Program Lifts a Town's Spirits
description: For more than a decade the two most important resources of this wet coastal town, timber and young people, have been leaving in droves. The logs go to the Orient. The young go anywhere they can find work.

title: Citicorp Notes To Yield 9.17%
description: Citicorp is issuing $200 million of 9 1/8 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.85, to yield 9.17 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: New York Taxi Commissioner Is Reported Ready to Resign
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commissioner, appointed less than two years ago by Mayor Koch, is expected to resign today to take a job in private industry, city and taxicab-industry officials said yesterday.

title: Mid-South Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Avant-Garde Movies And Hollywood Oldies In Alternative Theaters
description: THE frustrations of standing in a movie line, paying $7 a ticket and then being squeezed into a shoebox-sized theater might drive anyone to dream of a better way to go out and see a movie in New York. There are several. Beyond the 300 or so screens in commercial movie theaters in the city is an alternative network of museums, libraries, specialty film institutions and an assortment of other organizations that show classic Hollywood and foreign features, new and experimental films and a host of other movies from countries and film makers whose works rarely if ever make it to the neighborhood multiplex. Many of these institutions have long been known to filmgoers, while others in this network are new or expanded endeavors.

title: James River Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
New Mexico & Arizona Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
McCarran-Walter and the Ghosts of Fear
description: For 36 years, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed the United States to bar foreign visitors whose ideas the Government finds offensive. The law itself offends the spirit of free speech and inquiry, and in recent months Congress and the courts have shown a welcome willingness to re-examine it. Yet the Reagan Administration insists on using the act in ways that perpetuate its paranoia and pettiness.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Terry Cummings, the forward who led the Milwaukee Bucks in scoring this season with a 21.3 average, has signed a four-year contract ... Steve Bedrosian, the Phillies reliever who won the Cy Young Award last season, wil be activated on Friday. He has been sidelined since March 7 with pneumonia an dpleurisy.

title: London Journal; But for the Young, a Gypsy Would a-Traveling Go
description: Bubbles Brazil is a matriarch with a mission that gleams like her gold earrings. She is a leader of the Gypsy traveling folk who linger in odd macadam patches of outlying London districts, like Abbey Wood. She is a proud Romany with a Cockney accent who loves the wanderer's life but has begun compromising lately for the grandchildren.

title: Man Kills Robber and Is Arrested
description: A man and his wife walked into their Queens apartment yesterday afternoon and surprised two burglars, one of whom was shot to death by the man when the burglar attacked the couple with a long screwdriver, the police said.

title: Japan Auto Export Limit
description: Japan plans to end its voluntary limit of automobile exports to the United States effective next April, according to a news report disputed by the Government.

title: Soybeans and Grains Climb On a New Surge of Buying
description: A new surge of buying hit the soybean and grain futures pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, lifting all the expiring spot May soybeans and soybean products to contract highs. The expiring wheat and corn contracts also posted sharp gains.

title: Airgas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $558,000 and $619,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary gain from a bond repurchase of $167,000. c-After losses of $19,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the year both from discontinued operations.

title: Review/Film; Australian Vagabond Comedy
description: Not every road movie sends its characters off to do their rambling in a Bentley, but then ''Rikky and Pete'' is substantially out of the ordinary. A charmingly offbeat comedy from Australia, it breaks the road-movie tradition at every turn. The title characters are not runaway lovers or freewheeling pals; instead, they're a well-heeled brother and sister who've simply run out of options in Melbourne for the time being. So they take their mother's car and strike out for parts unknown. ''I can remember when all of this was just open land,'' remarks Pete (Stephen Kearney) as they drive across an absolutely barren, dirt-brown desert.

The seven-figure budget will go toward consumer and trade advertising, with a print campaign expected to get under way by summer.

title: John Kennedy, 90, Led The Opera in St. Louis
description: John Kennedy, who directed the productions of the St. Louis Municipal Opera from 1941 to 1967, died last Friday in Vancouver, British Columbia, after a brief illness. He was 90 years old.

description: b-Net income Preferred stock dividends exceeded net in the year-ago period.

title: Cuba Seeks Extension
description: The executive committee of the International Baseball Association has granted a request from the Cuban Olympic committee to extend by one week the entry deadline for teams that will participate in the Summer Olympics, an association official said.

title: SmithKline to Acquire Stake In a Drug Research Concern
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $49 million in the Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, a small research-oriented drug company based in Baltimore.

description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $1,649,000 on restructuring of debt.

title: As the Pressure Mounts, Leiter Keeps His Calm
description: Outside, the pressure kept dropping, which made it harder for Al Leiter to keep it from building inside. Out of the rain and inside the clubhouse, Leiter, the rookie left-hander for the Yankees, worked at remaining relaxed. He watched television, prepared for his rubdown and kept to his usual routine even as the steady shower showed no signs of breaking.

title: Iranian Boats Attack Tanker
description: Iranian assault craft today launched their second tanker attack in two days in the Strait of Hormuz in waters far from United States warships.

title: Hazel Corbin, Health Expert, Is Dead at 93
description: Hazel Corbin, retired general director of the Maternity Center Association in New York City and a pioneer in maternal and infant health care, died of cardiac failure Wednesday at her home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. She was 93 years old.

title: Ingram Takes New Angle on 2d Season
description: Mark Ingram remembers being engulfed by his family, friends, reporters and television cameras in his living room back in his hometown of Flint, Mich. Ingram remembers draft day last year, that glorious afternoon he felt like a giant and that wondrous moment he actually became one.

title: Lucky in Talks
description: Lucky Stores Inc., the subject of a $2.5 billion unsolicited takeover offer from the American Stores Company, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it was holding talks with an unidentified party over the sale of its 37 Arizona supermarkets. Those stores represent about 8 percent of its 481 stores, most of which are in California. Before making a final deal, the food retailer, based in Dublin, Calif., must obtain the approval of Gibbons, Green van Amerongen, which agreed to acquire Lucky in a $2.35 billion leveraged buyout, or of American if it accepts its sweetened offer. Lucky has not responded to the latest American Stores offer.

title: Review/Music; A Survey of Cuban Song, in Tropicana Revue
description: Tradition and kitsch, salsa and showgirls swirl together in the giddy Tropicana revue at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, through Sunday. More than 60 dancers, singers and musicians from the Tropicana are appearing in New York for the first time since the Havana nightclub was founded in 1939 - and to judge by its export company, the Tropicana mixes tourist attractions with a cultural conscience. Encompassing Cuban music from Yoruba chants to ''Besame Mucho,'' and presenting it with kilowatts of glitter, miles of leg and bared navels by the dozens, the Tropicana revue is a pop marvel. A closing song described it as ''the pride of every Cuban.''

title: Quanex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $792,000 from the extinguishment of debt for both periods, a reversal of a tax credit of $498,000 for the quarter, and a tax credit of $256,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Review/Art; The Provocative Contradictions of Markus Raetz
description: Markus Raetz will represent Switzerland in next month's Venice Biennale. His work is provocative, contradictory and perverse. It asks us both to slow down and to keep moving. It appears to be anti-dogmatic, yet it is insistent upon an esthetic, one of incompleteness. It makes a point of its openness, but it is every bit as controlling as the masterpiece mentality it is reacting against. It seems modest and unassuming, yet it is very ambitious. It is a challenging, not always successful mix.

title: Greyhound Notes
description: The Greyhound Corporation is offering $150 million of speculative-grade 13 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of par through a group of underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Noncallable by the company for three years, the notes are rated B-2 by Moody's and B by S.&P.

title: Jury That Cleared U.S. Judge Unaware He Lied, Panel Told
description: The trial jury that acquitted Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of conspiracy charges five years ago never knew he lied under oath about crucial phone calls and submitted false papers to conceal his involvement in a bribery plot, a House impeachment panel was told today.

title: Allegheny Meeting Delay

description: THE news this week that the United States trade deficit fell dramatically in March, to $9.75 billion, sent the stock market reeling. A month earlier the unexpected news that the trade deficit soared in February, to $13.8 billion from $12.4 billion in January, also made the market fall.

title: No Indictment in Harlem High-Rise Fire That Killed 7
description: A Manhattan grand jury said yesterday that widespread negligence and a flawed response by the Fire Department led to the deaths of seven people in a Harlem high-rise fire last year, but said there was not enough evidence to hand up criminal indictments.

title: A Gloomy Report on F.S.L.I.C.
description: The General Accounting Office said today that the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation was likely to need a new infusion of capital to deal with the more than 500 savings and loan institutions now insolvent.

title: Alternative Movie Houses and Screening Rooms
description: Here are some of the many places where movies can be seen in New York City other than in movie theaters. THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, Astoria, Queens (718-784-4520). Screenings have been suspended until its new quarters open in September. When the museum's two small, new theaters open, it will present a film series called ''Glorious Technicolor'' and a video series, ''The Media and the Vietnam War.'' THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street (769-5650). Showings of ''Grand Canyon -The Hidden Secrets'' and ''Chronos'' in its large-screen Naturemax Theater, daily at 10:30 and 11:30 A.M., 12:30, 1:30, 2:30, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M. Tickets: $3.50; $2.75 for the elderly and $1.75 for children. Double features Fridays and Saturdays at 6 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $5.50; $4.50 for the elderly and $3 for children. ANTHOLOGY FILM ARCHIVES, (505-5181). Intends to open a new two-screen theater at 32-34 Second Avenue (near Second Street) in October for daily screenings of avant-garde and classic films. THE ASIA SOCIETY, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street (517-2742). Presents thematic series such as a recent one on Hollywood in Asia, as well as ones devoted to films of Asian countries. (It has even shown Sri Lankan and Vietnamese films.) Afternoon and evening screenings are held once or twice a week in the society's auditorium. The next major series will be in the fall, when Asian-made films from the Hong Kong Film Festival will be screened. THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000, ext. 232). Presents about five annual feature and documentary film series in its third-floor lecture hall, as well as monthly Saturday morning children's films from November to May. The two current series are Films in the Humanities, with screenings Saturdays at 2 P.M. through June 4, and Architecture on Film, with screenings Sundays at 2 P.M. through May 29. Tomorrow, ''Do Not Enter: The Visa War Against Ideas,'' a 1986 documentary about artists denied visas to enter the United States, will be shown. ''Arata Isozaki,'' a film about the Japanese architect, will be shown Sunday. Films in both series are free with museum admission, which is $3; $1.50 for students; $1 for the elderly; free for members and children. THE BROOKLYN PUBLIC LIBRARY (718-780-7700). Presents features and documentaries for adults and children during afternoons, evenings and weekends in most of its 58 branches. ''With These Hands,'' a profile of eight folk artists, will be shown Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Greenpoint branch, Norman Avenue at Leonard Street (718-383-6692), and coming attractions this week include ''The Golden 20's'' at the Borough Park branch, 43d Street near 13th Avenue (Tuesday, 2 P.M.; 718-435-3375), and ''Lawrence of Arabia'' at the Windsor Terrace branch, East Fifth Street at Fort Hamilton Parkway (Thursday at 1:15 P.M.; 718-853-7265). Monthly calendars are available at each branch. CASA DE ESPANA, 314 East 39th Street (689-4232). Free screenings of Spanish films, with subtitles, from October through April on Saturdays and Tuesdays. THE CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133). Silent films will be shown during the summer, with accompaniment by Lee Erwin, an organist. The Lon Chaney version of ''Phantom of the Opera'' is scheduled June 8 through 10 at 8 P.M. Tickets From July 14 to Aug. 25, more organ-accompanied silent classics - including D. W. Griffith's ''Broken Blossoms'' and ''Intolerance,'' Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis'' and ''Thief of Bagdad'' with Douglas Fairbanks Sr. - will be shown every Thursday night at 8. Tickets are $5. CHARAS TEATRO LA TERRAZZA, 360 East 10th Street (982-0627). An organization called Films Charas has screened independent, Spanish-language, third-world and political films here since 1981. While raising money to build a 125-seat theater, Charas continues to show films Tuesday nights at 8. Tickets are $3; $1.50 for members. This Tuesday's program is ''An Evening of Latino Film,'' and on May 31, Michael Gray's ''Murder of Fred Hampton'' will be shown. COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY, Broadway and 116th Street (280-3574). Frequent series at various locations on campus, including international films at Casa Italiana, Maison Francaise and Deutsches Haus. Columbia's summer-session series of movie classics runs May 31 through Aug. 11, with free outdoor screenings Thursday nights at 9 on Lewisohn Lawn (near the northwest corner of campus), and Tuesday evening shows in Earl Hall at 7 and 9:30. (Tickets are $3; free for Columbia students.) THE COLLECTIVE FOR LIVING CINEMA, 41 White Street (925-2111). Shows a mixture of rarely screened foreign movies, old Hollywood films, and new works by avant-garde film makers. The 120-seat theater has daily screenings, with tickets generally $5 for nonmembers. Children's programs, Saturdays at 11 A.M., are $1; $2 for adults. This weekend: Kembra Pfahler will present two new films tonight at 8; and two programs of third-world works by British film makers associated with the group Sankofa and the Black Audio Film Collective are scheduled tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. THE FRENCH INSTITUTE/ALLIANCE FRANCAISE, 22 East 60th Street (355-6100). Shows French films with English subtitles on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, generally at 12:30, 3:15, 6 and 8:45 P.M., in its Tinker Auditorium. Next week's feature is Andre Techine's ''Rendez-vous.'' This Cine Club series, which runs every month except September, moves into the institute's new 400-seat Florence Gould Hall, at 55 East 59th Street, on June 8, after which screenings will be only on Wednesdays. The institute's summer series runs from June 8 through Aug. 31, opening with Marcel Carne's ''Portes de la Nuit'' (1946), and featuring a Marcel Pagnol retrospective in July and August. Tickets are $3.50; $2.50 for students and the elderly, and free to members. THE GOETHE HOUSE NEW YORK, 1014 Fifth Avenue, near 82d Street (744-8310). Shows German films in connection with exhibitions or lectures. Screenings are free, with tickets distributed an hour in advance. Several short films relating to the exhibition, ''Resistance, 1933-45,'' about German opposition to Nazism, will be shown tomorrow at 1 P.M. THE JAPAN SOCIETY, 333 East 47th Street (752-0824 or 752-3015). Presents about five yearly series devoted to particular themes or individual Japanese directors. Japanese Comedy, the current series, continues through June 17 with Friday screenings at 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. ''Tora-san Goes North,'' the 38th work in Yoji Yamada's series of comedies about a wandering street vendor named Tora-san, is scheduled tonight. Tickets are $6; $4.50 for members. THE JEWISH MUSEUM, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (860-1863). Presents films in conjunction with exhibitions, as well as thematic series having to do with the Jewish experience. Coming films to be shown in connection with ''A Century of Ambivalence: The Jews of Russia and the Soviet Union'' are: ''The Partisans of Vilna'' on May 31 at 7 P.M.; ''The Fall of the Romanov Dynasty'' on June 5 at 4 P.M.; ''Krasnodar: The Trial of 1943'' on June 7 at 7 P.M., and ''The Fixer'' on June 12 at 4 P.M. Tickets are $6; $4 for students and the elderly. A festival of 20 recent American films and videos called ''A Contemporary Lens on Jewish Experience'' will be presented on seven Tuesdays and Wednesdays at 7 P.M. between June 1 and June 29. Each program will include discussions. Tickets are $5. THE KITCHEN, 512 West 19th Street (255-5793). Presents free video shows in its third-floor viewing room, Tuesdays through Saturdays from 1 to 6 P.M. Shows change each month, and visitors can stay as long as they wish. This month, ''Video in the Academy: Dead or Alive?'' includes 11 works by students and instructors at American universities. In June, political and social documentaries will be shown. THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART (570-3949 or 535-7710). Presents almost daily films and videotapes about particular artists or artworks in its Uris Center Auditorium or Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, as well as frequent series of feature films. Today and Sunday, for example, films about Rubens, Rembrandt and Vermeer will be screened at noon and 4 P.M. During July, the museum will show films of Bette Davis on Tuesday nights; ones by Billy Wilder on Wednesday nights, and about baseball on Thursdays. And in August, a series of features made in China will be screened. Art films and screenings in the China series are free with museum admission, which is $5; $2.50 for students and the elderly. (Tickets for films in the three July series are $5.) THE MILLENNIUM FILM WORKSHOP, 66 East Fourth Street (673-0090). This 22-year-old nonprofit media-arts center presents about 75 programs of primarily experimental, 16-millimeter films on weekends from October to mid-June, and offers classes in film making and film theory. Tickets are generally $4. Several Australian films - Corinne Cantrill's ''In This Life's Body'' (1984) and five shorts by Paul Winkler - will be shown today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, 11 West 53d Street (708-9490). Presents one to four screenings of feature films every day the museum is open in its two theaters. The museum's many film series range from one devoted to early Frank Capra films, running through May 31, to a Russian series called Stories From Siberia in June and one on films of the performing arts, June 23 to July 10. Films are free with museum admission, which is $5 ($3.50 for students and $2 for the elderly), and tickets for these popular screenings are distributed at the lobby information desk after 11 A.M. for afternoon shows and after 1 P.M. for evening shows. This weekend's schedule of Capra films: ''Forbidden'' (1932), today at 1:30 P.M.; ''Platinum Blonde'' (1931), today at 4 P.M.; ''It Happened One Night'' (1934), today at 6:30 P.M.; ''Lady for a Day'' (1933), tomorrow at 12:30 P.M.; ''Dirigible'' (1931), tomorrow at 3 P.M.; ''American Madness'' (1932), tomorrow at 5:30 P.M.; ''That Certain Thing'' (1928), Sunday at 2:30 P.M., and ''So This Is Love'' (1928), Sunday at 5:30 P.M. Information: 708-9490. THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY. Most of the 81 branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island show free films on weekdays and weekends. Offerings range from Hollywood features to documentaries to special children's programs. One of the most active film programs is at the Donnell Library, 20 West 53d Street (621-0618), where three current series in its 262-seat auditorium focus on cinematic views of Paris, behind the scenes in Hollywood and short films. This weekend, the 96th Street branch, at 112 East 96th Street (289-0908), will show ''Dodes Kaden'' tomorrow at 1:30 P.M., and the St. Agnes branch, 444 Amsterdam Avenue near 81st Street (877-4380), will show ''The Adventures of Robin Hood'' tomorrow at 2 P.M. The many films scheduled at various branches during the rest of May range from ''The 39 Steps'' and ''The Rules of the Game'' to ''Annie Hall'' and ''An American in Paris.'' Monthly systemwide calendars are available at every branch. NEW YORK UNIVERSITY. A two-day series of the best films made by students in the Tisch School of the Arts, Year-End Showcase, will be held tonight and tomorrow from 6 to 11:30 in Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place. Tickets are $5. Information: 998-1795. Throughout the school year, Maison Francaise, 16 Washington Mews, presents French films; this year's last screening is tonight at 7, and features Jean-Pierre Mocky's ''Cite de l'Indicible Peur'' (''City of Unspeakable Fear,'' 1964). Tickets are $1. Information: 998-8750. THE 92D STREET Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (996-1100). Presents a number of annual film series that usually include post-screening discussions with directors, actors or other film professionals. The next series - with commentary by film scholars and critics - is The Forbidden Film. It begins June 2, and includes eight Thursday evenings of censored or controversial films and television programs, ranging from Mae West's ''She Done Him Wrong'' and John Schlesinger's ''Midnight Cowboy'' to a documentary on X-rated movies. Tickets are $8. (The series is $56.) THE PUBLIC THEATER, 425 Lafayette Street (598-7171 or 598-7150). Presents film series dedicated to works by individual directors or broadly grouped into particular themes, as well as limited runs of new films, six days a week. ''Tent of Miracles,'' a Brazilian film based on a novel by Jorge Amado and directed by Nelson Pereira dos Santos about a mulatto scholar who becomes a national hero, will be shown today through May 26 (no screenings on Mondays). Later shows through next Thursday are: ''The Record,'' a Swiss-German film about a television fanatic, and Clare Peploe's ''High Season.'' And a two-week survey of other recent and classic Brazilian films, The Return of Brazilian Cinema, begins May 27. (No films are screened Mondays.) Tickets are $5; $4 for students and the elderly. Documentaries are shown at no cost nearly every Saturday and Sunday at 2 P.M.; ''As If It Were Yesterday,'' about the World War II Belgian Resistance, will be shown through June 12. THE QUEENS MUSEUM, New York City Building in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (718-592-2405). Films relating to current exhibitions are screened almost every Saturday, generally at 2 P.M. A four-week series of experimental documentary films, called New York, New York, begins tomorrow and continues through June 11. Tomorrow, four short films will be screened: Hilary Harris's ''Organism'' (1975), Frank Mouris's ''Coney'' (1975), Francis Thompson's ''New York, New York'' (1957), and D. A. Pennebaker's ''Daybreak Express'' (1953). May 28: ''Memoirs of a Movie Palace.'' June 4: ''Metropolitan Avenue.'' June 11: ''New York in the Twenties'' and ''City of Contrasts.'' Films are free with museum admission, which is a suggested $2 for adults; $1 for students, children and the elderly. THE QUEENS PUBLIC LIBRARY. Relatively recent and classic Hollywood features, travelogues and other documentaries are shown in its Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, in Jamaica (718-990-0700), as well as at all 60 branches. Among the library's many free, and more or less regular, series are ones on Monday afternoons at Central Library; Wednesdays at 2 P.M. at the Richmond Hill branch, 118-14 Hillside Avenue (718-849-7150); Thursdays at 2:30 P.M. at the North Forest Park branch, 98-27 Metropolitan Avenue (718-261-5512); alternate Saturdays at the Glendale branch, 78-60 73d Place (718-821-4980), and every other Friday at the Hillcrest branch, 187-05 Union Turnpike in Flushing (718-454-2786). A film festival celebrating Irving Berlin's 100th birthday concludes at Central Library on Sunday at 1 P.M., with ''There's No Business Like Show Business.'' Schedules are available in each branch. THE WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART, Madison Avenue and 75th Street (570-0537). Now showing 16 films and film excerpts made by Andy Warhol during the 1960's in its second-floor video gallery through June 5. Several daily screenings are presented, Tuesdays through Sundays. Today and tomorrow, ''My Hustler'' will be shown at 11:30 A.M., and ''The Chelsea Girls'' will be screened at 1:30 P.M.; on Sunday, the two films will be shown at 12:30 and 2:30 P.M. Tickets are free with museum admission, which is $4; $2 for the elderly, and students, children and members are free.

title: Sri Lankan Official Is Shot
description: The General Secretary of Sri Lanka's ruling United National Party, Nandalal Fernando, was wounded today by gunmen on a motorcycle, the police said. Members of a Sinhalese Marxist group, Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, were suspected. Mr. Fernando was rushed to a hospital.

title: Another Diarist, Another Albany Power
description: There's another Cuomo in the Governor's mansion besides the man with the baggy eyes and the well-placed voice. Her name is Matilda, and she, too, keeps a diary.

title: Greek Orthodox Chiefs To Shun Moscow Rites
description: The Ecumenical Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church and other Orthodox leaders have decided to protest recent decisions of the Russian Orthodox Church by not taking part in celebrations in Moscow next month marking the 1,000th anniversary of the establishment of the Orthodox faith in Russia.

title: 17 of Suffolk's Legislators Denounce a Shoreham Deal
description: All but one of Suffolk County's 18 legislators today denounced as an ''economic bailout'' the negotiated settlement being discussed by the Long Island Lighting Company and the State of New York that would result in a shutdown of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.
