title: Faradyne Electronics Corp reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Results Plus
description: Tennis Fernandez Withdraws: Third-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami withdrew with an injury yesterday from her second-round match against Mariana Perez-Roldan of Argentina in the $100,000 Geneva European Open tournament. Fernandez, ranked 20th in the world, called for a doctor after falling behind, 4-5. Limping, she won the next two games but finally stopped in the tie-breaker, complaining of pain in the big toe of her left foot. In other second-round matches, fifth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden defeated Adriana Villagran of Argentina, 6-1, 7-6, 6-2, and Barbara Paulus of Austria upset seventh-seeded Niege Dias of Brazil, 6-1, 6-2.(AP) American Upsets Kelesi: Susan Sloane, a former United States junior champion, provided the biggest upset in the $100,000 Strasbourg tournament in France, beating Helen Kelesi of Canada. Sloane, a 17-year-old from Lexington, Ky., defeated the fourth-seeded Kelesi, 4-6, 7-5, 6-3, in a second-round match. Top-seeded Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, the 1987 world junior champion, advanced with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Silke Meier of West Germany. Sandra Cecchini of Italy, seeded second and a finalist last year, also won, 6-3, 7-6, over Catherine Suire of France.(AP) Sweden, West Germany Gain: Sweden clinched a victory over Spain while West Germany beat Czechoslovakia in the rain-plagued $750,000 World Team Cup tournament yesterday in Dusseldorf, West Germany. The Sweden-Spain matches were moved to an indoor clay court after rain washed out most of the day's schedule at the Rochusclub outdoor courts. Stefan Edberg, ranked second in the world, struggled to beat Emilio Sanchez, 7-6, 7-6, then Anders Jarryd assured Sweden's victory, defeating Javier Sanchez, 6-2, 6-4. (AP) Golf Five Share Lead: Lanny Wadkins birdied two of the last three holes on the way to a three-under-par 67 and a share of the first-round lead yesterday in the Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth. Wadkins, a winner earlier this year in Hawaii, was tied for the lead in the $750,000 event with John Inman, Scott Hoch, Jodie Mudd and Clarence Rose. Buddy Gardner, Mark Calcavecchia and Ed Fiori were a stroke back. Two former Colonial champions, Ben Crenshaw and Lee Trevino, were in a large group at 69. Bruce Lietzke, winner of last week's Byron Nelson Classic in Dallas, was at par 70. Players had trouble with the narrow fairways, small greens and swirling wind. Tom Kite shot a 75, as did the defending champion, Keith Clearwater. (AP) Horse Racing Slew City Slew Wins: Slew City Slew, ridden by Jose Santos, raced to a front-running one-length victory in the $47,000 Dancing Gun Purse for yesterday at Belmont Park. My Big Boy, with Pat Day up, was runner up,two and a quarter lengths ahead of Peppy Le Pew, ridden by Julio Pezua. Slew City Slew ran the mile and sixteenths on a muddy track in 1:44 3/5 to record his second victory in eight starts. The 4-year-old colt by Seattle Slew and Weber City Miss earned $28,200 for his owner and breeder, Joseph Allen, and returned $4.60 for $2 to win (AP).

title: TV Weekend; Incredible Hulk Meets Mighty Thor
description: From 1978 to 1982, ''The Incredible Hulk'' was a series that, unlike its competition, did not find the label of ''comic strip'' insulting. The title character, created by Stan Lee for Marvel Comics, is registered as a trademark of the Marvel Entertainment Group. Mr. Lee was a consultant to the television show. Now, demonstrating that prime time is insatiable when it comes to cartoonlike characters and plots, NBC is presenting - at 9 P.M. this Sunday - ''The Incredible Hulk Returns.''

title: Sugar Output Forecast
description: World sugar production in 1988-89 is expected to be a record of about 103.9 million metric tons, slightly more than the 103.8 million tons produced in 1987-88, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The latest estimate was revised downward from the department's first forecast issued on May 4, which indicated production at 104.1 million metric tons in 1988-89. A metric ton is about 2,200 pounds.

title: Weaver Arms Deal
description: The Weaver Arms Corporation will make semiautomatic rifles in China that are similar to the Israeli Uzi. Weaver, based in San Diego, will sell the first shipments of its 9-millimeter Nighthawk carbines in the United States and plans to sell the guns to American police agencies, private citizens and the military in developing nations, Robert Weaver, company president, said. The initial production agreement, which the company said had been approved by the State Department, prohibits sale of the guns to China, but the company hopes eventually to open that market, Mr. Weaver said. Weaver expects to begin its Chinese production within 90 days, with the first shipment of 10,000 guns planned by January 1989.

title: Reviews/Film; 'I Don't Give a Damn'
description: ''I Don't Give a Damn'' is a soapy Israeli movie composed of the residue of better movies past. It is about handsome Rafi (Ika Sohar), who is wounded in battle and loses the use of his legs. ''My story ends here in the hospital,'' says Rafi. Promises, promises. There is at least an hour more to go, which he spends raging against his condition, breaking things and being mean to the people who want most to help him - relatives, friends, other patients and, especially, pretty Nira (Anat Waxman). This fellow is a world-class nudnik.

title: Man Convicted in Series of Rapes On the Basis of a 'Voice Lineup'
description: A man accused of terrorizing the South Shore of Long Island in a four-year series of rapes and assaults was convicted today of 31 counts of rape and burglary, with his voice as the chief evidence against him. It was the first time in New York State that a conviction was obtained based largely on a recorded ''voice lineup.''

title: 12-Chef Farewell Meal for Claiborne
description: Twelve of the country's leading chefs prepared a dinner at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan on Tuesday night to honor Craig Claiborne, who recently announced his retirement as food editor of The New York Times. The dinner - organized by Paul Kovi and Tom Margittai, owners of the Four Seasons, and Pierre Franey, a columnist for The Times and Mr. Claiborne's collaborator for nearly 30 years - was attended by 75 friends and colleagues of Mr. Claiborne.

title: Soviet Strengthens Economic Links to Northern Afghanistan
description: Some towns and villages in these arid northern Afghan plains have already been connected to the Soviet Union's electrical power grid. The landscape is dotted with fertilizer factories, irrigation canals and natural gas pumping stations built with Soviet aid.

title: Review/Art; Arte Povera Installations: Engineering and Alchemy
description: Gilberto Zorio, whose work is on view at the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo, is a practitioner of Arte Povera, the unusually elegant and poetic installation art that emerged in Italy in the late 1960's and early 70's. Like their American counterparts - such artists as Richard Serra, Robert Smithson and Robert Morris - the ''poveristi'' avoided portable, studio-made sculpture. They opted instead for work that was concocted, often quite casually. on the spot and that routinely incorporated impoverished or deliberately unesthetic materials. The Americans favored uninflected and, if possible, virtually unstructured presentations. Smithson's combinations of rocks and mirrors from the early 70's - called ''non-sites'' and the subject of an exhibition at the John Weber Gallery earlier this season - exemplify the American attitude. But the Italians let a great deal of literary and historical consciousness wander into their work, and a highly charged imagery often resulted.

title: Love Moves Ex-Polish Leader From Warsaw to Rego Park
description: Seven years ago, he was a prominent Polish politician, a pro-Soviet hard-liner who helped crush the Solidarity movement. Today, Stefan Olszowski lives an anonymous middle-class life in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Unicycling Jugglers
description: Experts and amateurs will be taking part in the First New York Festival of Juggling and Unicycle Arts, tomorrow from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. at the Naumburg Band Shell in Central Park, at 72d Street. The free event is sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, the Internationl Jugglers Association and the International Unicycle Federation. There will be competitions for those more advanced in the arts and workshops for those who wish to pick up some pointers. In addition, there will be appearances by members of the Ringling Brothers Clown College and the Big Apple Circus School. The rain date is Sunday. Information: 360-8157.

title: Teacher's Flaws Bring Months More of School
description: A class of fourth graders must go to summer school before the pupils can be promoted, says their principal, who unsuccessfully tried to dismiss their teacher.

title: Augustin Francis Oakes, Printer, 81
description: Augustin Francis Oakes, a retired printer, died of brain cancer Wednesday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 81 years old.

Good News on the Trade Deficit. But . . .
description: LEAD: This week's trade deficit news was a pleasant surprise, the first single-digit deficit in many months. Analysts applauded, exporters waxed enthusiastic and President Reagan expressed satisfaction over the very sharp decline from February to March in the trade deficit. Yet, in the face of this encouraging report the stock market fell sharply, and interest rates rose significantly.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advest Group Inc., Hartford, a financial services concern, and Col onial Realty will form a national joint real estate venture.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $420,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Step Taken In Talks on Farm Aid
description: The United States and the European Community took a step forward today in resolving their dispute over reducing the world's farm subsidies. How big a step is a matter of dispute.

title: OVERSEAS SPENDING BY U.S. COMPANIES SETS RECORD PACE
description: The weak dollar, which has reduced the cost of manufacturing in the United States relative to that in other countries, should in theory be prompting American companies to halt or scale back expansion of their factories abroad, and even close some of them.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Stalinist mood is still strong. Conservative moods dominate among the greater part of the party leadership.

title: Fay's Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Samsung America to Milton Samuels Advertising, Fort Lee, N.J. for magnetic tape and telecommunications.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
10 Poles Die in Train Crash
description: Ten soldiers were killed and 16 injured today when a military transport train crashed in the northwestern Polish town of Pila, the official press agency said.

title: Baseball; Cardinals Top Cubs For Fourth Straight
description: Cris Carpenter pitched a four-hitter today for his first major league victory and the St. Louis Cardinals won their fourth consecutive game, a 5-1 decision over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Douglas E. Moran, 49, Publishing Executive
description: Douglas E. Moran, a vice president and the controller of Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information services company, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 49 years old.

title: Review/Music; The Mozart Requiem In Alternative Version
description: Mozart the man remains as much an enigma today as he must have been in his lifetime. The exact size and cut of his musical genius are clear, but all the evidence as to his character and his deepest beliefs adds up to fog and ambiguity. It is therefore fitting that his great final work, the unfinished Requiem, continues to be a maze of contradictions and blind alleys. Musicologists periodically wander into it in hopes of settling, once and for all, the question of how much of it he actually composed.

title: Review/Cabaret
description: A pop singer who returns to the cabarets after 30 years of retirement is bound to be affected by such a long absence. But while Monica Lewis, who is in Danny's Skylight Room at the Grand Sea Palace on West 46th Street) through tonight, is not the same singer that she was 30 years ago, she has skillfully retained her basic qualities as a performer.

title: U.S. Accuses Benin of Abetting Libyan Terrorism
description: The United States has accused the West African nation of Benin of allowing Libyan agents to use its territory to foment acts of terrorism, State Department officials said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Shavuoth, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Instrument Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $625,000 for the quarter and $1,925,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 and $96,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $1,372,000 for the quarter and $2,530,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month also includes a loss of $1,502,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Review/Dance; Surreal Urban Themes
description: Audiences at the 3-D at the Joyce festival receive blue and red viewing glasses with a picture of a gorilla. If you scratch the front, the scent of bananas wafts into the air.

title: Sterivet Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Computer Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,000 for the quarter and $237,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $136,000 and $204,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reviews/Film; Terror by Telephone
description: ''Call Me,'' the wrong number now at the Baronet and other theaters, is about Anna, who gets a panting phone call one night (''I want you, I want you, I want you.''), which soon develops into an aural relationship as she and the caller share their fantasies about imaginative uses for an orange. The dirty talk is the more wholesome slice of Anna's story. The rest of the tale is about several creeps who are chasing her in the mistaken belief that she stole their money.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, appointed James W. Otto executive vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Robert Yoder, who resigned for personal reasons.

title: Indonesia's Debt to Rise
description: Indonesia's total external debt is projected to hit $50 billion this year, with debt repayments by Southeast Asia's largest nation forecast to rise sharply, the World Bank said today. But it said that a Government program to wean the economy away from dependence on oil was working, with non-oil exports expected to increase rapidly, and that the debt picture was not as serious as in many other heavily indebted nations.

title: Review/Film; 'Willow,' a George Lucas Production
description: Today's films have a way of being supplanted overnight. However bright or ground breaking it may be, a new film can be followed in a flash by another that copies and comments on the first, and this process can repeat and repeat itself. So five or six stages of fantasy film making separate the 1977 ''Star Wars'' from the new ''Willow,'' although George Lucas made his plans for both projects at roughly the same time. Even if the two sets of raw material had been of equal worth, ''Willow'' would inevitably lie under the long ''Star Wars'' shadow.

title: Drexel Challenges Book On Its 'Junk Bond' Role
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has squared off against Simon & Schuster Inc. and The American Lawyer magazine in a verbal battle over a soon-to-be-published book that is highly critical of the huge investment firm.

title: Reviews/Jazz; Adam Makowicz, His Piano and Friends
description: The pianist Adam Makowicz began a series of four varied, nightly concerts at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening with a program of the music of Irving Berlin. Mr. Berlin's music has been inescapably ubiquitous since celebrations of his 100th birthday began last week, but Mr. Makowicz managed to give a notably distinctive flavor to his performances.

description: b-Net loss

DUKAKIS IS TERMED EXTREME LIBERAL
description: Some Republican supporters of Vice President Bush, troubled that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is succeeding in his effort to appear as a moderate, have begun to paint Mr. Dukakis as extremely liberal.

title: Using Rules Tactic, Helms Stalls Senate Approval of Arms Treaty
description: Senator Jesse Helms succeeded today in delaying action on the new arms treaty by refusing to bring forward amendments that he and other treaty opponents seek.

title: Bush as His Own Man: A Minuet on an Uncertain Tightrope
description: With a one-sentence statement in a speech laying out parts of his drug policy, Vice President Bush embarked on a journey that aides today justified as necessary if he is to be elected President.

title: Christopher Gore, 45, Screenwriter of 'Fame'
description: Christopher Gore, a writer who was nominated for an Academy Award for his screenplay of ''Fame,'' died Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 45 years old.

title: AGS Computers
description: AGS Computers Inc. of Mountainside, N.J. said it had ended talks about acquiring C3 Inc., a computer systems integration company based in Herndon, Va. It gave no reason for the decision. AGS had agreed in principle in March to acquire C3 for $15.75 a share, or about $157.5 million. C3's shares fell $2.875 yesterday, to $10, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Amfac, in a Big Shift, Considers Buyout Bid
description: In a surprise move, Hawaii's largest company, Amfac Inc., said today that it was halting its restructuring plan in midstream and was considering a management buyout proposal of $41 a share, or $913 million.

title: Yes, Big Science. But Which Projects?
description: To govern is to choose, and when it comes to spending big bucks on science, the Reagan Administration is doing neither.

title: Fordam President Named to Election-Law Board
description: The Koch administration has named the president of Fordham University to head the review board charged with administering and enforcing New York City's new law on public financing of municipal election campaigns, senior officials said yesterday.

title: Sports People; Daniels Is Released
description: Lloyd Daniels, who played basketball at four New York City high schools but never earned a diploma, has been dismissed from the Waitemata team of Auckland in the New Zealand Basketball Federation on grounds that he missed practices and engaged in heavy drinking.

title: Self Magazine Editor Is Named
description: Anthea Disney, editor of US magazine, has been named editor in chief of Self magazine effective July 5, Conde Nast Publications Inc., Self's parent, announced yesterday.

description: Fei Yi-ming, a Hong Kong publisher who was one of China's top advisers in this British colony, died of a stroke Wednesday, his newspaper reported today. He was 80 years old.

title: Times Expects Profit to Be Flat
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected its second-quarter profit to be about the same as a year earlier, largely because of weaker retail advertising in The New York Times.

title: Treasures in Tableaux at Library Fete
description: It's a challenge to please New York's diehard benefit-goers near the end of the social season.

description: The Seattle Seahawks announced today that they have signed a former University of Miami wide receiver, Brian Blades, their first draft pick.

title: Dominion Textile
description: Dominion Textile (USA) Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Dominion Textile Inc., is offering $150 million of 9 7/8 percent notes due 1995 at a price of par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Noncallable for the life of the issue, the notes yield about nine-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is backed by an irrevocable letter of credit issued by the New York office of Barclays Bank P.L.C. and is rated triple-A by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

Dispute Is Watched for Omens for Mexican Presidential Vote
description: To celebrate their mayoral candidate's 296-vote victory, supporters of the Institutional Revolutionary Party rallied last weekend with banners, festive music and speeches in the main plaza of this steel and mining center.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Ideas For Paying Agencies
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 19 - Members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies who are meeting here at the Greenbrier Hotel consider the matter of compensation a vital one, especially since the traditional 15 percent media commission has long been under attack.

title: Tax Reform Has Dealt a Blow to Public Housing; Hurdles of Local Origin
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Ilya Kabakov Portrays Communal Soviet Life
description: ''Ten Characters'' is the title of an exhibition by Ilya Kabakov, a Soviet artist, at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts. It has an amazing experience to offer. Hardly are we inside the door than we are reminded of the Moscow Art Theater in its heyday, long years ago. A complete environment is set before us, intact in its every last detail and yet shaped by a guiding imagination.

title: A.T.&T. Computer Sales Are Rising
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's sales of computers are on the rise, ending more than a year of stagnant or declining sales, the new president of A.T.&T.'s Data Systems Group said. Robert M. Kavner said in an interview that the group's sales were ''growing dramatically'' and that the business was ahead of its financial plan for 1988.

title: Bonds and Notes Halt 3-Day Slide
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved slightly higher in lethargic trading yesterday, braking a three-day slide.

title: Court Is Asked to Act On Sentencing System
description: The Reagan Administration urged the Supreme Court today to use an expedited procedure reserved for cases of ''imperative public importance'' to decide the constitutionality of the new Federal system for sentencing convicted criminals.

description: The company said in the latest 6 months it adopted FAS No. 96, which resulted in a one-time $250,000 reduction of its tax accrual.

Pontiac No. 2 at G.M.
description: The Pontiac Motor division has replaced Oldsmobile as the General Motors Corporation's No. 2 car-selling division, behind Chevrolet. Pontiac has also become the third-best-selling nameplate in the auto industry, behind Chevrolet and Ford. According to G.M.'s latest sales reports, through May 10, the Pontiac division's sales have increased 3.9 percent for the 1988 model year, while Oldsmobile's sales have fallen 12.9 percent in the same period.

title: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $514,000 for a writeoff of the cost of technology acquired during fiscal 1987 from Monoclonal Technology Ltd., a research and development limited partnership.

title: Sports People; Johnson-Lewis Races
description: Ben Johnson of Canada and Carl Lewis of the United States, the premier sprinters in international competition, are scheduled to meet twice this summer in 100-meter races: at Paris on June 27 and at Zurich on Aug. 17. Primo Nebiolo, the president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field, said yesterday in Rome that the elite sprinters may also meet in a 200-meter race in the Italian seaside resort of Cesenatico.

title: National Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $457,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Reviews/Film; Images of Veiny Eyeballs And Desperate Goldfish
description: ''White of the Eye'' could be described as a film about everything -about men and women, guilt and innocence, freedom and destiny - but then it could also be described as a film about nothing. It's the work of Donald Cammell, well known in 1970 as the co-director of ''Performance'' and best known as (in the words of one British journalist) an ''occluded talent'' since then.

title: Our Towns; They Scramble To Reassemble Their Nest Eggs
description: Inside the auditorium at the Long Island Lighting Company's annual stockholders meeting this week, money was foremost on everyone's mind. Would they ever get their money back? Most of the 1,300 stockholders who showed up were retirees. They thought they had invested in a sure thing: a utility providing electricity to a booming suburb. But they were done in by a bend in history.

title: Israeli High Court Overrules Rabbis by Installing Woman
description: The Israeli Supreme Court overruled the nation's rabbis today by ordering the appointment of the first woman to a religious council that administers synagogues and ritual baths.

title: Company Items On Cable TV
description: Investors News Release Watch, a new service that will offer corporate news briefs four times a day on cable television, was announced yesterday by PR Newswire and the Financial News Network, which will provide the service.

title: NEW YORK REACHES A TENTATIVE PACT WITH CUSTODIANS
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday reached a tentative settlement with the school custodians' union, and board officials say they believe it will lead to major improvements in the physical conditions of dilapidated school buildings.

title: Filly Gets Post 5 in Preakness
description: Nine 3-year-olds were entered today for the 113th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday, where eight colts will try to keep Winning Colors from becoming the first filly to win the first two legs of thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown.

title: In Poland, Rumblings of More Liberalization
description: Poland's Communist leadership appears to be facing increased pressure from within its ranks to step up the pace of change, following the resolution of strikes at major industrial installations last week.

title: Chronar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures were restated to reflect a $266,531 inventory reduction.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Ads Up 12.6%
description: The Television Bureau of Advertising reported that commercial television advertising in the first quarter of this year rose 12.6 percent, to $5.74 billion, from $5.1 billion in the period last year. Network television advertising, which reflected expenditures of the Winter Olympics, totaled $2.46 billion in the first quarter, up 17.3 percent from $2.09 billion during the period in 1987.

title: Comecon Pact Seen Near
description: The European Community and the Soviet bloc's trade council are close to establishing official relations.

title: Energy Ventures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $1,974,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said no revenue was recorded in the 1987 first quarter following restatement for the change in reporting entity for the company's oil and gas investments. Results include the company's subsidiary, EVI Inc., which was formed on March 6, 1987. The company also said that for the latest first quarter, EVI Inc. generated net income of $415,000 on revenue of $9,908,000.

title: West of Chicago, Waiting for a Dial Tone
description: At the Adams & Myers Real Estate office here, the only reliable telephone Wednesday seemed to be the one inside Meryl Adams's car, parked at the curb and hooked up so the horn would bleat rhythmically whenever a call came in.

title: Campbell Soup Company reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $32,500,000 from accounting changes. The latest third quarter included pre-tax charges of $51.6 million related to the early retirement program and asset restructuring.

title: Review/Dance; Season's First 'Bayadere'
description: The American Ballet Theater production of ''La Bayadere'' has proved to be one of the company's most popular staples. And on Tuesday, when Ballet Theater presented the work at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season, the three-act spectacle received a fine performance from Martine van Hamel as Nikiya, the young temple dancer or bayadere, Kevin McKenzie as Solor, who loves and is loved by her, and Cynthia Gregory as Gamzatti, the Rajah's daughter and Solor's fiancee. The evening was dedicated to the late Patrick Bissell, a noted Solor.

title: Showtime Buys Film Rights
description: Showtime/The Movie Channel agreed yesterday to pay an estimated $100 million to $150 million for a five-year distribution agreement with Carolco Pictures. The amount will depend on how much the films make in theatrical release.

title: Utility Seeks Grant to Burn Coal Cleanly
description: An application to build the world's first full-size electric plant with a new system for burning coal cleanly is among the proposals that the Energy Department will begin evaluating next week.

description: Stan Rapp, 62 years old and the chairman and co-founder of Rapp & Collins, an Omnicom company, has decided to retire from the agency to go on the lecture circuit and finish a second book.

200,000 Reportedly Gather At Rally in Armenian Capital
description: About 200,000 people gathered peacefully in a square in Yerevan today in the second large demonstration in the Armenian capital this week, an Armenian dissident said.

title: Alcott Aims for L.P.G.A. Slam
description: Pat Bradley is the only active member of the L.P.G.A. Tour to have a career grand slam, at least one victory in each of the four women's major tournaments. The events are the Nabisco Dinah Shore, the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship, the United States Women's Open and the du Maurier Classic of Canada.

title: U.S. AIDE HOPEFUL ON ANGOLA TALKS
description: The leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union may make progress toward resolving the conflict in Angola when they meet later this month in Moscow, a State Department official said today.

title: Mavericks Gain Final; Jazz Ties Series; Mavericks 108, Nuggets 95
description: Rolando Blackman scored 9 consecutive points in the fourth period tonight to lead the Dallas Mavericks into their first Western Conference championship series with a 108-95 victory over the Denver Nuggets.

title: Black Lawyers Joining the Chase for Big Money
description: When Curtis A. Wood, Paul T. Williams Jr., Thomas R. Rafalsky and Homer L. Harris decided to relocate their law practice three years ago, the distance they traveled was far longer than the miles separating their old suite in mid-Manhattan from their new offices near Wall Street.

title: Sports People; Robinson in Shape
description: John Thompson, the head basketball coach of the United States Olympic team, said yesterday in a telephone news conference that he was impressed with the physical condition of David Robinson, the 7-foot 1-inch former Navy center.

title: Zapping The Myth Of TV's Power
description: LEAD: Myths often thrive in inverse proportion to their accuracy.

description: The share earnings are in cents a unit and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Restaurants
description: There are a handful of restaurants in town that, because of their view or viewpoint, capture the unflagging vitality of this metropolis - Windows on the World, the ''21'' Club, Four Seasons and River Cafe among them. To this list must be added the Sea Grill at Rockefeller Center, a sophisticated subterranean setting facing the ice-skating rink (at this time of year, the area has become a graceful outdoor cafe). The Sea Grill is the most ambitious operation in a three-restaurant complex - including the humdrum American Festival Cafe and an annex called the Bar Carvery - and until recently it was more alluring for its fancy address than its fish.

title: Capital Cities Says Ad Drop Will Hurt Radio-TV Profits
description: Weakening demand for national advertising is expected to hurt profits in television and radio operations for the rest of the year, Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. executives said yesterday.

title: At Golden Temple of Sikhs, the Debris of Battle
description: Shattered glass, marble and pieces of brick were scattered across the silent Golden Temple complex this evening as bomb disposal squads and Red Cross teams searched its rooms and shrines for explosives, weapons and bodies.

title: Fiscal Squeeze Renews Debate on Arms Burden
description: By almost every measure, the United States carries a greater military and financial share of the burden for the common defense than does any ally or combination of the nation's allies in Europe and Asia.

title: 8 3/4% Offering Set By Xerox Credit
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, is offering $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.95, to yield 8.77 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

description: LEAD: Getting Better Inside Alcoholics Anonymous By Nan Robertson 298 pages. William Morrow & Company.

title: Zimerman Recital
description: The pianist Krystian Zimerman will give his only New York recital of the season Sunday at 3 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $20, $15 and $10. Center Charge: 874-6770.

title: Sasson Jeans Settlement
description: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland yesterday approved a 100 percent repayment plan for creditors of Sasson Jeans Inc., despite the objections of Paul Guez, the company's founder.

title: Darling Shares in Mets' Sweep
description: The Mets finally treated Ron Darling to a share in prosperity today, and they did it on a day when he felt so queasy from the flu that he took a two-hour nap in the locker room before trying to pitch.

title: Crane Company reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $972,000 from segment held for distribution-Medusa Corp. c-After cumulative effect of a change in accounting-pension reversion of $5,673,000 and included a gain of $2,967,000 from segment held for distribution-Medusa. Year-ago share earnings reflect adjustment for a 3-for-2 stock split in 1987. Shares outstanding are fully diluted. Results include the Medusa Corp.

title: In Taiwan, the Towering Chiang Image Is Losing Its Luster
description: Even in death, Chiang Kai-shek still towers over this nation. A vast marble memorial to the former President stands in the heart of Taipei. At the center, poised high up a flight of stone steps, his robed figure smiles down beneficently.

title: Steel Industry Sees Decline
description: Executives of several steel companies predicted today that industry shipments and profits would decline slightly in the second half of this year, saying they expected weaker overall demand from the automobile, appliance and home construction markets.

title: German Jewish Group Seeks To Trace Its Missing Millions
description: A West German Jewish organization asked a French bank today for financial records to trace millions of dollars earmarked for survivors of the Nazi genocide that were reportedly embezzled by the group's former leader.

title: Sports People; N.H.L. Award Finalists
description: Wayne Gretzky, who has won the Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player in each of his first eight seasons, is in the running to get it again. Gretzky, along with the Oiler goalie Grant Fuhr and the Pittsburgh center Mario Lemieux, are finalists for the award. Kelly Hrudey and Bryan Trottier of the Islanders and Jan Erixon of the Rangers were named as finalists for other awards. Hrudey is a contender for the Vezina Trophy, given to the league's top goaltender. Also in the running are Fuhr and Buffalo's Tom Barrasso. Hrudey led the Islanders to the Patrick Division championship and posted a 22-17-5 record with three shutouts. Trottier, the Islander center, was nominated along with Gretzky and Lanny MacDonald for a new award, the King Clancy Trophy, for on- and off-ice leadership. Erixon, the Rangers' 25-year-old Swedish forward, is a finalist, along with Guy Carbonneau and Steve Kasper for the Frank Selke Award as the best defensive foward. ''I never thought I'd have a shot at this award,'' said Erixon, whose play-ing time was severely curtailed at the start of the season before he finally impressed Coach Michel Bergeron.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marsteller Gains
description: Burson-Marsteller has received the go-ahead from South Korea's Mnistry of Finance to open an office in Seoul, which brings its offices in Asia to seven. The public relations firm had set up a small staff in Seoul a few years back to take care of the Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee account.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Karen Akers

title: Review; Review/Art Biomorphic Profiles Both Abstract and Real
description: DeWitt Godfrey gracefully molds, bends and sandblasts steel into shapes that resemble mushrooms and plants and, in one case, a limp gramophone speaker. The young Houston-born artist's latest show at the R. C. Erpf Gallery includes four objects and two large-scale charcoal drawings depicting the sort of irregular, rounded forms that Mr. Godfrey favors in three dimensions. The artist creates sizable works that cut curious, off-kilter profiles in space, and he brings to these forms a refreshing confidence and a bold hand. His terrain is an elusive area between realism and abstraction.

title: Rose's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed some distribution of The New York Times. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Morgan Keegan & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Federal Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On Stage
description: Stritch as Apple Annie

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 425 money market mutual funds increased $3.70 billion, to $274.12 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 116 institutional funds increased $2 billion, to $74.44 billion. Assets of the 212 general purpose funds were up $1.05 billion, to $83.9 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $651.6 million, to $115.78 billion.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Patience Pays Off for Oilers
description: Patience has finally become a virtue in Edmonton. The Oilers, eager to gain a fourth Stanley Cup, seem to have begun the process of neutralizing their ultimate playoff opponent, the Boston Bruins, with a hockey commodity flaunted by all their other fallen opponents but rarely attributed to them.

title: Times Says Driver Slowdown Has Hampered Distribution
description: A series of slowdowns by unionized truck drivers who deliver The New York Times has caused severe distribution problems and sales losses for the newspaper throughout the Northeast and in parts of the metropolitan area, spokesman for the newspaper said yesterday.

title: The Year of the Actor On and Off Broadway
description: DEPENDING on the extent of one's Anglophilia, this could be seen as the season that Andrew Lloyd Webber ruled Broadway as well as Britannia (with three simultaneous bonanzas, ''Cats,'' ''Starlight Express'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera'') or as the season that the British musical armada finally struck rocky shoals (with ''Chess'' and ''Carrie''). Similarly, one could say that this was a time when theatergoers sat back in their expensive seats and were stimulated by scenery, or when theatergoers were lured out of their seats and interfaced with the scenery (as in the walk-through, cuisine-art entertainments ''Tamara'' and ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding'').

title: The Preakness Stakes; An Upset Won't Be Much of a Surprise
description: The Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday is being widely billed as a rematch of the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, where the filly Winning Colors held off Forty Niner by just a neck at the finish. But five colts who finished behind them are making another attempt, and a case can be made for any of the five to spring an upset, especially since the race is likely to be run over a sloppy track.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Maleeva Upset in Geneva Open: Unseeded Isabelle Demongeot of France upset top-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Geneva Open. ''I've never beaten a top 10 player in my life,'' said Demongeot, a 21-year-old from St. Tropez, after defeating Maleeva, the world's sixth-ranked player. Barbara Paulus of Austria, ranked 91st in the world, defeated Iva Budarova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2.(AP) Mancini and Duncan Advance: Top-seeded Alberto Mancini of Argentina and eighth-seeded Lawson Duncan of the United States reached the quarterfinals of the $126,000 City of Florence tournament in Italy. Mancini beat Christian Miniussi of Argentina, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, yesterday in a second-round match on the clay courts of the Cascine Tennis Club. Duncan, of Asheville, N.C., defeated Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Baseball St. John's Beats Villanova: St. John's defeated Seton Hall and Villanova yesterday in the Big East tournament at Briston, Conn., to move into a championship game against the Wildcats today at Muzzy Field. In an afternoon game, the Redmen, behind the six-hit pitching of Tom Migliorri, a freshman, defeated Seton Hall, knocking the Pirates out of the tournament. In the night game, Mike Weinberg of St. John's hit a three-run home run in the seventh inning to lead the team to an 8-6 victory over previously unbeaten Villanova, the Big East Southern Division champs. Golf Eagle for Wadkins: Lanny Wadkins scored an eagle-3 in a round of 68 that left him in a three-way tie for the lead yesterday at the halfway point of the $750,000 Colonial National Invitation tournament. Wadkins was tied at five-under-par 135 on the Colonial Country Club course in Fort Worth, Texas, with Clarence Rose and Scott Hoch. The three were part of the five-man group that shared the first-round lead. Hoch and Rose, a playoff loser last week in Dallas, also shot 68's.(AP)

title: GUIDEPOST: Barbecue Starters
description: Barbecue equipment is coming out for the season, and it's time to choose a way to light the fuel, usually charcoal or briquettes. Lighter fluid (liquid or gel; the gel is safer) is the most popular method, but it can flavor the food, as can briquettes or plastic starters treated with lighter fluid. Let the fuel turn ash gray to burn off as much of the chemical as possible. An electric starter, the safest igniter, should be plugged into a properly installed and grounded outdoor outlet. Chimney starters work fast; they are cylindrical metal canisters with two compartments (one holds coals on top; the other holds crumpled newspaper for kindling on the bottom). Read and follow safety precautions on the package. Some ways to start a barbecue: PRODUCT COST HOW TO START Treated charcoal $3-$4 With long matches briquettes (8-lb. bag) Lighter fluid or gel Under $2 Put on fuel and light (8-oz. can) Treated solid $2-$3 Put on fuel and light starters Electric starter $10-$20 Place in fuel until fuel ignites Chimney starter $10-$15 Fill with fuel; light newspaper in bottom section (Source: Clorox Company, grill products division)

title: Regents Pass Rules for Schooling The Children of Homeless Families
description: The Board of Regents, ending years of disputes among suburban school districts over who is responsible for educating the children of homeless families, approved regulations today that let parents choose where their children will attend school.

title: Brawley Mother May Be Charged With Contempt

title: DEMOCRATS DIFFER ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: A group of prominent Democratic politicians urged their party's platform writers today to emphasize a strong defense, even if it meant more military spending. But they were challenged by liberals who said that grassroots Democrats wanted to cut the Pentagon's budget, not increase it, The debate, which took place at a forum sponsored by the Democratic Party platform committee, turned on a concern among conservative Democrats that the party and its Presidential nominee might be labeled ''soft on defense'' by the Republicans in the general election campaign, But the reaction of the audience suggested that an emphasis on a strong military might be hard to sell at the Democratic National Convention in July., Special to the New York Times

title: Robbery Suspect Released

While awaiting trial with 15 other defendants, Mr. Ojeda must wear an electronic bracelet that the authorities will use to monitor his movements. He will not be able to leave Hartford.

description: Charles Dawson Butler, the voice of Yogi Bear, Huckleberry Hound, Quick Draw McGraw and dozens of other cartoon characters, died Wednesday of a heart attack at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was 71 years old.

title: Sister of Drug Trafficker Is Killed in Firebombing
description: The invalid sister of a major drug dealer was killed early yesterday morning when their mother's home in Queens was firebombed, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This market has hurt some people over the last month or two. It's like a stampede on a worm farm. This market stays like this, and you'll lose another 25,000 people out of the brokerage business.'' - Michael C. Aronstein, a money manager, on the sluggish market. [ 37:5. ]

title: Beirut Shiites Step Up Fight; P.L.O. Factions Clash Anew
description: Clashes between rival Lebanese Shiite Moslem militias intensified in southern Beirut today and were compounded by new fighting between opposing factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Slayer Found Dead After Attack on School Kills Boy, 8
description: A woman wielding a pistol walked into an elementary school in this wealthy Chicago suburb today and opened fire apparently at random, killing an 8-year-old boy and critically wounding five other pupils.

title: Gantos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,224,000 from an accounting change.

title: Easy Opener for Lendl
description: Barring upsets, Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, could have a fourth-round meeting with John McEnroe at the French Open, setting up a possible replay of their memorable final four years ago.

title: Ca Blockers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gleason's Revives Era Of Small Fight Arenas
description: The small fight club that used to be an essential part of the boxing scene is by now mostly a historic remembrance.

title: Argonaut Group
description: Officials of Argonaut Group Inc. said that the company had received and rejected takeover inquiries but that the insurer was not for sale at this time. Last year, Argonaut, based in Los Angeles, backed out of a $620 million leveraged buyout with Gibbons, Green van Amerongen after failing to come to terms over an unsolicited offer from Clarendon Group Ltd., a Bermuda insurer. Some analysts say Argonaut continues to be an attractive target because of its strong earnings. The company's statement came in response to a Wall Street Journal article that said Argonaut was without suitors, a spokesman for the company said.

title: Honeybee Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter included $395,000 of expenses related to the purchase of a majority ownership of Honeybee by Spiegel Inc., and to a proposed merger of Honeybee with a Spiegel unit.

title: CONFEREES REACH ACCORD ON DRUGS IN MEDICARE BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators today resolved a dispute over prescription drug benefits, the major obstacle to an agreement on a bill to protect 32 million Medicare beneficiaries from the expense of catastrophic illness.

title: Gymnast to Head Home
description: A little more than two weeks after she suffered what may be permanent paralysis of her arms and legs during an accidental fall while warming up for a vault competition in Tokyo, 15-year-old Julissa Gomez will begin her return home to Blue Springs, Mo., today in a respirator. Her parents, Ramiro and Otilia Gomez, who arrived in Tokyo two days after the accident, will accompany her, as will two doctors from the United States who made the flight arrangements after consultation with Japanese doctors.(AP)

title: Guitarist at the Seaport
description: Charlie Byrd, a guitarist, is to lead a trio tonight at 8 and 10 at Jazzport, 210 Front Street, at the South Street Seaport (608-7889). Tickets are $18.50.

title: Review/Film; Directors' Daydreams Become the Stuff of Opera
description: Giuseppe Verdi never cried out ''I want my MTV,'' but he's gotten it anyhow. So have Wagner, Puccini and the other composers whose work has been given the rock-video treatment by 10 opera-loving film directors in ''Aria,'' the composite film that opened yesterday at the Regency. The best of ''Aria'' isn't any more than cheerful kitsch, and a lot of it is junk. But the underlying idea, that of unleashing these film makers and encouraging them to set their flakiest daydreams to beautiful music, is at least as amusing as it is profane.

title: New British Films Made By Blacks
description: Isaac Julien, a 28-year-old graduate of the St. Martin's School of Art in England, is one of a new generation of young black British film makers. This month, two full-length movies and three short works by Mr. Julien and his compatriots begin a nationwide tour here.

title: Coping/With Summer Driving
description: If your summer calls for a lot of driving, now is the time to plan strategies for making your time in the car more pleasant. Summer traffic can turn an easy ride into a nightmare.

title: A Janacek Cantata
description: The Collegiate Chorale and orchestra will perform Janacek's cantata ''Amarus'' and Verdi's Four Sacred Pieces at 8 o'clock tonight at Carnegie Hall. Soloists are Curtis Rayam, tenor, and Karen Williams, soprano; Robert Bass conducts. Tickets are $27, $22, $18 and $13. Carnegie Charge: 247-7800.

title: Mets Continue to Show Their Might by Defeating Dodgers
description: Some of the mystery of Sid Fernandez was shed tonight when he pitched the Mets into the seventh inning with a three-run lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers in his longest performance of the season.

title: Security Tightened in Aruba As Drug Fugitive Is Arrested
description: Security on the Dutch Caribbean island of Aruba has been tightened to prevent the escape of a Colombian wanted by the United States for his role in a major cocaine ring, an Aruban official in the Netherlands said today.

title: Appeals Judge Temporarily Halts Closed Sessions on Howard Beach
description: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case was directed by an appeals court justice yesterday not to hold further closed proceedings until the appeals court rules on their legality.

description: A company that calls itself Suicide Productions Inc. really seems to be asking for it. ''The Suicide Club'' won't really prove them wrong, but this Mariel Hemingway vehicle is not the truly terrible film you might expect. It appeared without advance press screenings after a couple of delayed opening dates.

title: Marion G. Romney, 90, President Of the Mormon Council of Twelve
description: Marion G. Romney, a high official of the Mormon Church, died yesterday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 90 years old. Church officials said his death resulted from ''causes incident to age.''

Budget Help for the President-to-Be
description: While George Bush and Michael Dukakis continue to duck the biggest issue likely to face the next President - the budget deficit - a new National Economic Commission has already started work that could help the winner. Congress created the commission in hopes that the endless deficit deadlock might finally be broken by bipartisan compromise. Success or failure will depend on the willingness of the new President and Congress to heed painful advice.

title: New York Plans to Add Welfare Hotel Services
description: Services for thousands of homeless families living in welfare hotels across New York State would be stepped up under regulations proposed yesterday by Social Services Commissioner Cesar A. Perales.

title: Political Marketing; Independent Groups Join TV Chorus
description: While the Presidential candidates pitch their claims to the White House on television this fall, groups outside their campaigns will spend millions of dollars to add their voices to the electronic chorus in the hope of influencing the election, or at least the political debate.

title: 200 Hurt in Protests on Taiwan
description: More than 200 people were injured and scores were arrested on Friday night during battles between police officers and rock-throwing demonstrators, the police said today.

title: Koch Defends Muslim's Right To Give Speech
description: Mayor Koch, in the latest of a series of gestures aimed at salving his relations with blacks, yesterday defended the Rev. Louis Farrakhan's right to speak at a kosher catering hall in Queens tonight and condemned those who would try to block the Black Muslim minister's appearance.

title: Colombia's Cocaine Lords: Conviction in U.S. Poses Little Threat to Power
description: The dominant Colombian groups that control the world's cocaine trade, often called the Medellin cartel, are unlikely to be deterred by the conviction of one of the cartel's founders, experts on drug trafficking say.

title: For Canada's Art, a Home of Its Own
description: As if Canadians could never quite persuade themselves that their art was worthy of a building of its own, governments here procrastinated for more than a century before heeding the urgings of the National Gallery of Canada for a permanent home. Having started in a walk-up over a fishing exhibit in the 1880's, the gallery spent half a century sharing space with another museum before moving to a converted office building in 1959.

title: Metromedia Wins Control of Orion
description: Ending months of speculation about a possible takeover fight for the Orion Pictures Corporation, John W. Kluge, chairman of the Metromedia Company, has reached a deal to take control of the movie and television production concern.

title: IN FURS FOR FALL, A SHOCK OF PINK OR BLUE
description: The basic coat for fall is 48 to 52 inches long, stops just above the ankles, swings easily from broad shoulders and is made of dark mink skins, most furriers agree. Shorter coats, 38 to 48 inches long, are destined for the woman who already owns a fur coat, is not too tall, feels overwhelmed by the longer styles, or is fashionably addicted to short skirts. Furriers call these shorter styles three-quarter coats or jackets, but they are long enough to cover completely cover most above-the-knee skirts.

title: Poland Cuts Sentences for Solidarity Figures
description: Three Solidarity figures jailed for labor unrest this month won reduced sentences today in appeals courts, apparently as part of a Government promise to follow a nonrepressive policy.

description: LEAD: President Reagan and other American politicians who visit the Soviet Union should appreciate the depth of hostility to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's admirable reforms that is present not only in the Politburo but also among millions of Soviet people as well.

description: One would expect advertising executives to be jaded, to have seen it all. But at a major industry convention this week, they laughed, cheered and sighed like starstruck fans at the work of their peers and competitors.

title: Gregory Huffman, 35, a Dancer
description: Gregory Huffman, a leading dancer in the Joffrey Ballet from 1972 to 1983, died of complications resulting from AIDS yesterday at New York University Medical Center. Mr. Huffman, who had been ill with pneumotoxis pneumonia for the last two months, was 35 years old. He lived in Manhattan.

title: Testimony on Bush Meeting With Panama Ambassador
description: A senior aide to George Bush said today that he and the Vice President emerged from a December 1985 meeting with the Ambassador to Panama with ''the sense'' that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega may have been involved in drug trafficking.

title: Bobbie Brooks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Waterloo Music Festival
description: A chamber music concert featuring works by Bach, Brahms, Poulenc and Schubert is to open the 13th Waterloo Festival and School of Music on June 17 at 8:30 P.M. at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. The Waterloo Festival is to run through July 25 and feature appearances by Vladimir Feltsman, Rudolf Firkusny, Andre Watts, Nathaniel Rosen and Dmitri Sitkovetsky; the conductors are to include Gerard Schwarz, James DePriest and Maxim Shostakovich. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: Long Shots Out Front at Cannes
description: With only three days left in the 41st Cannes Film Festival, two extremely dark horses have emerged as leading contenders for the Palme d'Or, which will be awarded to the best film here Monday night.

title: Music Zubin Mehta Conducts His First Mahler Ninth
description: There are ways for a parachutist to prepare for his first jump, but at some point it is necessary to step out onto air and pull the rip cord. Zubin Mehta, who had never in an extensive career conducted Mahler's Symphony No. 9, took the plunge with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening. Any trepidation he may have felt in advance could easily be understood: the Philharmonic has a Mahler tradition dating back to the composer himself and under Leonard Bernstein played a major role in bringing these massive symphonies to their present state of popularity. Many of the Philharmonic musicians, furthermore, know the Mahler Ninth at least as intimately as those who conduct it, which must be a little intimidating.

title: At the Bottom Line
description: The John Cale Band featuring Chris Spedding on guitar and Strange Cave is to play a rock double bill tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: Servico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: b-Net income The company said revenue for the latest 9 months includes a $6,439,000 gain on the sale of a hotel and $6,100,000 from the collection of a mortgage acquired by the company at a discount; less $6,200,000 of reserves for potential losses on the disposition of one hotel and other long-term investments. The company also said that year- ago 9-month revenue includes a gain on the sale of hotels of $22,435,000. Year-ago 9 months also include a pretax $3,700,000 write-off of an investment in a non-consolidated joint venture, $2,900,000 in write-offs of long-term notes and mortgages receivable, and a one-time pretax expense of $6,400,000 due to a change in accounting for minority interests in joint ventures.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,000,000. The company attributed the decline in net income to a reserve provision of about $500,000 recorded as a charge to 1988 first quarter earnings, a change in accounting method resulting in an earnings reduction of about $600,000 and a reduction in the accretion of loan discounts.

title: Zinc Price Up in Europe
description: The price of zinc, a metal used mainly in galvanizing steel, hit a three-year high on the London Metal Exchange today as big European producers raised their official prices, citing increased demand. French, Belgian and West German producers set their base prices at $1,100 a metric ton, up from $1,070. On the London Metal Exchange, the price of zinc for delivery in three months was $:630 a ton, equivalent to $1,174, the highest level in nearly 14 years.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Lifetime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $552,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $181,000. The company said the increase in revenue reflects the company's acquisition of Quality Care Inc. in September 1987. title: 'Junk' Phone Calls: Danger on the Line?
description: When a child collapsed not long ago in his home in Amsterdam, N.Y., his mother grabbed the telephone to call an ambulance. She could not get a dial tone. All she heard was a recorded sales pitch that kept on playing even after she hung up and tried to dial again.

title: Samuel Foosaner, 81, Tax Lawyer and Writer
description: Samuel J. Foosaner, a tax lawyer, writer and philanthropist, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and had formerly practiced in Newark and Millburn, N.J.

title: About New York; Crown and Brim: A Serious Search For a Chapeau
description: Say a man wanted to buy a hat. Except for a little humid spell yesterday afternoon, it feels as though it has been raining in this town since about 1947, and the man had had four umbrella wrecks in three days, and though he had grown accustomed to being gouged in the pocketbook he felt he should not be made to put up with a sharp stick in the eye. A hat would give him mobility, room to dodge.

description: Sally Quinlan celebrated her 27th birthday on a golf course today by taking the second-round lead in the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship.

description: American Airlines is considering buying about 100 Boeing 757 airplanes, an order that could be valued at more than $4 billion to the Boeing Company.

description: The Israeli Government said today that it had written a stern letter to Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser, warning him not to take archeological artifacts out of Israel without a permit.

description: The Museum of Cheese - which to some symbolizes much that is bad in government and to others much that is good - opened here Thursday night after more than two years of upstate-downstate bickering and the spending of $175,000 in state money.

description: New York Telephone, like other regional telephone companies, is offering customers a way to avoid unnecessary service charges - for a price.

title: Col. Peter J. Ortiz, 75, Legendary Marine Officer
description: Col. Peter Julien Ortiz, a legendary officer in the Marine Corps, died of cancer Monday at the Veterans Medical Center in Prescott, Ariz. He was 75 years old and lived in Prescott.

title:
Patents;
Method of Assessing Cattle Characteristics
description: LEAD: A system to measure animals, intended primarily for determining the physical and genetic characteristics of beef cattle, has been invented for Applied Genetics International Inc. of Cody, Wyo. Norman J. Hayes of Cody was granted patent 4,745,472 this week.

title: WROTE ABOUT LOS ANDGELES BARRIO
description: Daniel Lewis James, who startled the literary world when he was revealed to be the author of a prize-winning novel about a Mexican-American family in a Los Angeles barrio, died Wednesday at the Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula in Monterey, Calif. He was 77 years old and lived in Carmel Highlands, Calif.

title: THE NAME OF THIS GAME IS CONFUSION
description: LEAD: What we have is name inflation.

title: Soviet and South Korea
description: The Soviet Union wants to open a trade office in Seoul soon after the Olympic Games, which end Oct. 2 in the South Korean capital, a Korean electronics company executive said today. Koo Yong Su, a senior official at the Goldstar Company, told reporters that an official of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce had told him of the plan. Mr. Koo recently attended an electronics exhibition in Leningrad. South Korea has no diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and trade between them is conducted through third countries.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Company News report in some editions of Business Day on Thursday, about the Meritor Financial Group, omitted the context for a pessimistic remark by the company's chairman. In saying ''we are not going to make it'' if current interest rates hold, he was referring to the company's prediction of steady operating earnings by the end of the year.

title: U.N. Will Urge Ethiopians to Allow Food Aid
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will seek to persuade the Ethiopian Government to allow the return of the International Committee of the Red Cross and other famine relief agencies it expelled last month, United Nations officials say.

After a seven-hour hearing on Thursday, Judge James Yacos said the utility was entitled at least to a four-month extension because ''the first 120 days have been used for organization in a rather unique case.''

Ausimont's shares jumped $4.625 today, to $31.50. The 17.2 percent gain was the day's largest on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Senate Rebuffs Foes of the Missile Treaty
description: In a series of votes signaling the breadth of Senate support for the new missile treaty, senators today rejected by wide margins the first wave of ''killer amendments'' offered by opponents of the arms accord.

description: Jurors who on Thursday convicted the reputed leader of a Colombian drug ring decided today that the Government should confiscate from him millions of dollars in Bahamian real estate and several airplanes.

title: Corrections
