title: Boston Barely Steers Clear of Exit
description: According to the schedule, one game remains to determine whether the Boston Celtics or the Atlanta Hawks will advance to the Eastern Conference final of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 32 A deal with Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, may be close, and it would remove him from power, officials said. The chief U.S. negotiator flew to Washington for consultations. Page 1 Propaganda billboards in Moscow are being removed. The campaign against the signs, which trumpet the virtues of Communism, has been under way over a year and is part of the larger struggle against bombast in public life. 1 The Senate rejected amendments to the new arms treaty by wide margins. But the votes to kill the amendments, brought approval of the treaty only slightly closer. 3 Fighting sharpened in Beirut between rival Shiite militia groups in southern Beirut. Fighting also broke out between opposing factions of the P.L.O. 2 Colombian cocaine traffickers, whose dominant groups are often called the Medellin cartell, are unlikely to be deterred by the conviction of Carlos Lehder Rivas, one of their number. 5 U.S. may confiscate drug trafficker's island 5 Return of relief workers to Ethiopia will be sought by the United Nations. But U.N. officials in Ethiopia say the Government, which expelled the relief agencies last month, is opposed to letting them return. 32 The accordion capital of the world, Castelfidardo, Italy, was hurt when rock-and-roll music became popular. But competition from foreign companies with lower labor costs forced the town's largest accordion factory to close. 4 Israel chides State Dept. aide 2 South Korean students attack the U.S. Embassy 3 25 killed in Punjab attack 3 Hungarian party opens talks 4 NATIONAL 6-11 Medicare will payfor drugs under an agreement reached by House and Senate negotiators. The bill would protect Medicare recipients from the expense of catastrophic illness. 1 Drug treatment for breast cancer should continue after the initial surgery, even if there is no evidence that the cancer has spread, according to a new recommendation from the National Cancer Institue. 1 Cancer institute chose mail, not media, for big news 11 The Pentagon's anti-missile plan, commonly called Star Wars, is moving toward fundamental changes that would reduce spending and place weapons in space more gradually than previously planned. 1 Consumer prices rose in April by four-tenths of 1 percent, one-tenth less than the increase in March, the Government reported. The rise was driven by sharply higher prices for apparel. 1 Consumer prices in the region rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Goverment said. It was the largest monthly increase in four years in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area. 38 The stock market had its slowest day of 1988 as the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,952.59, down 6.13 points. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange - 120.6 million shares - was the lightest since Dec. 29. 37 Conflicts of interest in corporate law have increased. The rise in corporate takeovers has put many top law firms in a bind for representing new clients whose interests compete with other or former clients. 1 A woman opened gunfire at a school in Winnetka, Ill., killing an 8-year-old pupil and critically wounding five other pupils. She fled to a house and wounded an occupant there. After an eight-hour seige, police stormed it and found her dead. 6 Incineration plan fans flames in Maryland town 6 Hepatitis A found increasingly among drug abusers 11 Politics 8 Jesse Jackson raised $1.9 million in April, equal to the amount collected that month by Michael Dukakis, the front-runner in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination. 8 Michael Dukakis stressed morality as he campaigned in California. He assailed the Reagan Administration for contemplating a deal with Panama's leader that would involve dropping drug charges. 8 Democrats debated the defense issue at a meeting of the party's platform committee. Liberal Democrats, who want cuts in the military budget, opposed calls that the party should emphasize a strong defense. 8 An aide to Vice President Bush said that after a 1985 meeting with the United States Ambassador to Panama, he and the Vice President had ''the sense'' that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega may have been involved in drug trafficking. 8 Political Marketing: independent groups join TV chorus 8 REGIONAL 33-35 Transit police are cutting back and will no longer ride every subway train at night under changes announced by the Transit Police Department. Only 76 percent of the trains will be covered between 8 P.M. and 4 A.M. 33 Homeless parents may pick schools for their children under regulations for homeless families adopted by the New York Regents. The rules address a large problem in counties near New York City. 33 A debate on the Museum of Cheese, which opened in Rome, N.Y., to great fanfare from city officials, continues with critics asking whether the museum was the best way for the state to spend $175,000. 33 Closed hearings were halted by a judge until an appeals court rules on the legality of the action in a case arising from the Howard Beach racial attack. 35 Two police officers were arrested and suspended from the New York City Police Department after they were indicted on charges that they beat a homeless man in February during a fight while they were off-duty. 35 Ex-Koch aide identified in patronage inquiry 33 Perales proposes to add services for the homeless 34 Wedtech witness says friend of Meese offered help 34 Sister of reputed drug figure dies in firebombing 35

title: George Washington Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $22,484. c-Net income and includes capital gains of $43,220.

title: Athletics Continue Their Winning Ways
description: The Oakland Athletics, whose monuments are in the middle of the batting order rather than beyond the outfield wall, hit and scored in double figures last night in pounding out an 11-3 victory over the Yankees at the Stadium.

title: View of French Tennis Open Served by Information Boom
description: France has been in the midst of a communications revolution for a while, and the French Open tennis tournament, which begins here Monday at Roland Garros Stadium, has steadily made its way into the new information age with the rest of French society.

title: KEY RATES
Peter Dean, Singer, 77
description: Peter Dean, a singer and former artists' representative, died of cancer Tuesday in Anna Maria, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: John E. Bowman, 67; Led Exchange Group
description: John E. Bowman, a former executive director of the Council on International Educational Exchange, died of cancer yesterday at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title: Polifly Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Polifly Financial is the holding company for Polify Savings & Loan Association. Polifly Savings converted to a New Jersey-chartered stock savings and loan association effective April 7, 1988.

title: Chevron Sells Stake in Amax
description: The Chevron Corporation said it had sold all of its 15.16 million shares of Amax Inc. for $23 a share, or $349 million, in cash plus limited future appreciation rights. Chevron said that proceeds of the sale would be used to reduce debt.

title: Koch Urges Ethics Panel To Call Aide
description: Mayor Koch yesterday urged the State Commission on Government Integrity to allow his special assistant to rebut allegations that the aide altered or destroyed city personnel records to delete references to patronage affiliations.

title: Gencor Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fish Tale: Mississippi To Moscow
description: With a deftness born of four years on the filleting line of the Delta Pride Catfish Company plant in Indianola, Miss., Elizabeth Smith fluidly cut into a two-pound farm-bred fish. The leftover bone dropped away and the prime pinkish-white meat went onto a conveyor belt, carried away to another part of the chilly plant to be frozen for shipping.

title: Comcast Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results include the effect of consolidating Comcast Cablevision of Maryland Limited Partnership, acquired Feb. 4, 1988.

title: More Mortgage Data Required
description: Savings institutions will be required beginning Oct. 1 to offer prospective borrowers a clear and concise description of their adjustable-rate mortgage programs, the Government said today. The Federal Home Loan

title: Bridge; The opening leader's partner may do well by signaling 'count.'
description: Experts have varied opinions about the best signaling procedure for the partner of the opening leader.

title:
Patents;
Improved Use of Plastic To Fill Deserted Mines
description: LEAD: A method of filling abandoned mines and other underground cavities was patented this week for the Washington Penn Plastic Company of Washington, Pa.

title: Crown Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Electronics That Do Everything but Huff and Puff
description: This year more and more people are shaping up for summer on high-tech exercise machines at home.

title: Music; A Trio Plays the Basics, Plus One Novelty
description: The Yuval Trio, which appeared Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, counts as an Israeli ensemble, but it has strong ties to New York. It was founded in 1969, and consists of Jonathan Zak, a pianist who studied at the Juilliard School; Uri Pianka, another Juilliard graduate and currently concertmaster of the Israel Philharmonic, and Simca Heled, a cellist who was formerly principal cellist of the Israel Philharmonic and who now runs the Concerts Plus series at the Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Activision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $312,000 and $1,852,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: AOI Coal Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fan Teasers
description: Some baseball fans in the Midwest yesterday were teased by a fleeting suggestion they become part owners of the Chicago White Sox. Others were encouraged to buy and preserve the 76-year-old Tiger Stadium in Detroit.

title: Jazz; Benny Carter Improvises, But Not the Usual Way
description: The great saxophonist and composer Benny Carter opened his two-week stay at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets, on Tuesday night with Cole Porter's ''You'd Be So Nice to Come Home To.''

title: COMMENCEMENTS
description: The Juilliard School

title: Settlement Reached on 'Missing' Lawsuit
description: A settlement has been reached in an unusual lawsuit that was filed two years ago by the author of ''Missing'' - the story of an American who disappears during a coup in Chile -against the book's hardcover and paperback publishers.

title: Chemclear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Easley Plans to Retire
description: Kenny Easley, a five-time All-Pro safety for the Seattle Seahawks, said at a fund-raising dinner Thursday night that he planned to announce his retirement from professional football in two months. Easley was diagnosed as having a serious kidney condition when he failed a physical examination for a trade to the Phoenix Cardinals.

title: Farmers Head Sees Victory
description: Leo E. Denlea Jr., chairman of Farmers Group Inc., told shareholders today that he expects to defeat a proxy contest that urged holding acquisition talks with the hostile suitor B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. The British concern has made a takeover bid of $4.3 billion for the Los Angeles-based insurer. B.A.T,'s chairman, Patrick

title: To House the Poor, First Help Basic Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Ormand Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 073688 -- No Title
description: In a deal that will create the nation's largest grocery store chain, Lucky Stores Inc. agreed today to accept a sweetened takeover bid from the American Stores Company for $65 a share, or $2.51 billion in cash.

title: International Microcomputer Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chandler Readmitted
description: After suffering his second small stroke in a week, A. B. (Happy) Chandler, the former commissioner of baseball, was readmitted to the University of Kentucky Medical Center Thursday. Chandler, 89 years old, a former Governor of Kentucky and a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, was released from the hospital early Thursday after he had apparently recovered from a mild stroke he suffered Tuesday.

title: Television Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $15,058 for the quarter and $10,265 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Wedtech Figure Says Meese Ally Offered Aid
description: The former lawyer for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d offered legal assistance to four Wedtech Corporation executives in late 1986 when they were being investigated by Federal prosecutors, one executive testified yesterday.

title: National Gas & Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter are restated for a 7-percent stock dividend in December 1987.

title: Trivial Pursuit Taken From Coleco
description: Coleco Industries, which is battling to avoid bankruptcy, has lost its license to market the popular Trivial Pursuit board game. The West Hartford toy maker also faces the possibility of losing its valuable license to market Cabbage Patch Kids products and dolls.

title: Sports of The Times; Her Master's Voice
description: Two days before Gary Stevens rode Winning Colors in the Kentucky Derby, the 25-year-old jockey stopped by the 3-year-old filly's stall on the Churchill Downs backstretch.

title: Total Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Police Cheer, Killer of Officer Draws 50 Years
description: After reading aloud from a letter from the widow of a police detective, who declared that the man convicted of killing her husband ''must never be able to attack again,'' a Brooklyn judge yesterday sentenced the 41-year-old defendant to 50 years to life in prison.

title: Castelfidardo Journal; Poud Craft Fades to a Foreign Beat
description: Nothing has been the same in this little town since the Beatles started turning young men's thoughts to electric guitars.

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Top U.S. Bond Yield Rises to 9.34%
description: Treasury securities dealers marked down prices of bills, notes and bonds yesterday in a largely futile effort to attract investors. While the mood was decidedly bearish, dealers noted that sellers were almost as scarce as buyers.

title: Dow Drifts 6.13 Lower On Slowest Day of '88
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday and even a late flurry of trading was not enough to keep the New York Stock Exchange from recording its slowest session of the year.

title: MCO-Maxxam Tie
description: Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston investor, completed the consolidation of two companies that he controls by merging MCO Holdings Inc. and Maxxam Group Inc. The combination had been delayed because of shareholder litigation over the proposed terms. Under the revised terms, MCO, a Los Angeles-based real estate and energy company, agreed to increase by $1 a share the cash that shareholders will receive. Maxxam shareholders now are to receive $6 in cash, a quarter share of MCO stock and a note with a face value of $6, bearing 13.5 percent interest, giving the deal a value of about $125.8 million for the 61.8 percent Maxxam stake MCO does not already own.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Fashion and the Liberal Arts
description: Accountants and lawyers now fill the high-rise factories in central Manhattan where garment workers once produced $18.95 knock-offs of Hattie Carnegie's ''little black dress.'' Yet the city still has a fashion industry. To catch its beat, one need only walk a few blocks south of 34th street to the crisp concrete buildings of the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: 45 Killed and 100 Wounded in Attacks in Punjab
description: At least 45 people were killed and more than 100 were wounded on Friday in attacks blamed on Sikh extremists in Punjab and the neighboring state of Himachal Pradesh as the situation across northern India worsened.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Fed Decided in March To Push Rates Higher
description: Top policy makers at the Federal Reserve, worried about growing inflationary pressures, decided in late March to push interest rates slightly higher, according to a record of the discussions released today.

title: Steady Alcott Takes a Two-Stroke Lead
description: When a golfer is playing for victory in a tournament, coming out of trouble to save a par on a hole can be more important than getting a birdie. A save allows the subsequent birdies to have considerably more meaning and can prevent loss of ground.

title: WHERE THE SUN SHINES, SOLAR ACTIVITY IS STILL BRISK
description: Nearly 10 years have passed since President Carter committed the nation to achieving a 20 percent reliance on solar and other renewable energy sources by the year 2000. His 1980 budget included $597 million for solar research, and for symbolic measure, Mr. Carter had solar panels installed in the White House roof to heat the water.

title: TV Docudramas Go One Step Beyond Reality
description: Perceiving that TV docudramas exploit is much like realizing that water is wet. So what else is new? Desperate for material to fill its prime-time needs, television long ago discovered that there were fortunes to be had in ''based on fact'' dramas. Usually, these are adaptations of nonfiction books. But increasingly, as the race to get there first accelerates, there is the phenomenon of scripts culled from a combination of trial transcripts, interviews and journalistic accounts. Tonight, as it happens, examples of both the book and transcript techniques are available. ''Like Father, Like Son,'' on CBS at 9, is based on the book that Adm. Elmo Zumwalt Jr. wrote with his son Lieut. Elmo Zumwalt III. ''Baby M,'' on ABC at 9 (and continuing tomorrow at 9), was ''re-created'' from court transcripts, news reports and research connected with the custody battle that focused attention on the issue of surrogate motherhood.

title: Carole B. Kerr, Executive, Weds F. E. Guest 2d on L.I.
description: Carole Baldoff Kerr, a daughter of Ann Baldoff of Pittsburgh and the late John C. Baldoff, and Frederick E. Guest 2d, a son of the late Helena McCann Charlton of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Winston F. C. Guest of Roslyn, L.I., were married yesterday at Old Westbury Gardens in Old Westbury, L.I., by the Rev. Herbert H. Beardsley, an Episcopal priest.

title: Farms Defy Trade Sense
description: Obviously food is the most basic human need. There is an underlying shame that in a world where some 10 million face starvation and hundreds of millions suffer malnutrition, the most abrasive trade problem is agricultural surpluses.

title: Singapore Releases 3 Held as Political Detainees
description: The Government of Singapore last week released 3 of 11 people detained without trial since mid-April under the country's Internal Security Act.

title: The Hartford Gives Moilere a Modern Look
description: WHAT, in modern times, is one to make of a play in which a middle-aged man sets standards for the perfect wife like simple-mindedness and submissiveness?

title: THE PROMISE OF WIND AWAITS A NEW ENERGY CRISIS
description: The fierce spring winds now whipping through California have brought little cheer to the hearty band of entrepreneurs who turn nature's power into electricity. Thousands of turbines, some shaped like eggbeaters, some like huge propellers, are humming now, driven by the winds that sweep across California's Central Valley, through Tehachapi Pass and into the Mojave Desert below. The wind farms here feed electricity to homes as far away as Los Angeles, 110 miles southwest. But few new turbines are being built, a trend that even some environmentalists do not bemoan.

title: How Many Air 'Czars' Does It Take? One.
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT BY BECHTEL
description: FRIENDS IN HIGH PLACES The Bechtel Story: The Most Secret Corporation and How It Engineered the World. By Laton McCartney. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: What's Bad for Glasnost Is Bad for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev to Ask U.S.-Soviet Mars Trip in Talks
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will ask President Reagan to approve a joint United States-Soviet unmanned flight to Mars during their summit meeting in Moscow next week, according to an interview with the Soviet leader that appears in The Washington Post for Sunday.

title: How Tyranny Creeps
description: When American reporters and editors talk about freedom of the press, some people react skeptically. The press is self-important, they say. It exalts its own freedom above others'. At the slightest inconvenience it cries out that the First Amendment is falling.

title: Canoeist Crosses Massachusetts in Pursuit of Idea
description: Denny Alsop says he made a 33-day trip across the state by canoe to implore all who would listen to clean up and preserve the water.

title: Brooke Lilley Marries Geoffrey Cutler
description: Brooke Carol Lilley, a daughter of William Lilley 3d and Beverly Knight Sullivan, both of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Ilsley Cutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Cutler Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Edwin M. Ward, headmaster of St. Stephen's School in Alexandria, Va., performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington Cathedral.

title: Cello and Piano Duo
description: Karen Buranskas and Masako Hayashi make up an exceedingly fine cello and piano duo. They have an understanding of the duo form (and of each other) unusual for its subtlety, and at Weill Recital Hall last week they gauged the acoustics of this presumably unfamiliar space with professional ears.

title: Broadway's New Realpolitik
description: When the Soviet Arms negotiator in ''A Walk in the Woods,'' Andrey Botvinnik, decides to leave Geneva, his younger American counterpart, John Honeyman, reacts with the alarm of a rebuffed lover. ''Don't go,'' pleads the otherwise stiff Honeyman. ''I'm still your friend,'' the avuncular Botvinnik replies.

title: Russia's Ring Of Towns Crowned With Golden Domes
description: AS you approach Suzdal on a sunlit day, one thing stands out from afar: the dome over the entrance gate of the Convent of the Intercession, a lone patch of gold that seems to catch the sunlight and send it, shimmering, into the long, level distance.

title: Bush Remark on Armenians' Deaths Stirs Debate
description: Statements by Vice President Bush characterizing as genocide the deaths of more than a million Armenians in Turkey in the early 1900's have rekindled a debate in Congress and made it appear that Mr. Bush is taking a position different from that of the Reagan Administration.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE DEVELOPMENT GAP;
Help the Third World Catch Up
description: LEAD: SOMETIME this fall yet another new car, the Proton Saga, will hit Main Street U.S.A. This newest competitor for a share of the vast American automobile market will come from Malyasia - a country that most Americans would be hard pressed to find on a map. The arrival of the Proton Saga probably will increase

title: Community Colleges And Tuition Costs
description: In response to the article ''Concern Growing on College Costs'' on March 20, I would like to point out that Norwalk Community College and 11 other members of the Connecticut system of regional community colleges offer low-cost alternatives to rocketing college tuition increases.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Basking Ridge $640,000 25 Stoneridge Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-month-old French provincial; c/a, fireplace in family room, 2-car garage; taxes $8,349. Butler $215,000 21 Western Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 63-year-old farmhouse; newly renovated, porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,723. Livingston $279,000 16 Sycamore Terrace 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; family room, full basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,449. Millburn $220,000 33 Greenwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, c/a; taxes $3,155. Reddington Township $178,000 Farknoll Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; full basement, 2.9-acre wooded lot; taxes $1,600. South Orange $219,000 233 Montague Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; deck, screened porch, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $3,587. OTHER AREAS Holbrook, L.I. $125,000 28 Knickerbocker Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,900. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $325,000 11 Deerfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 64-year-old brick colonial; fireplace, basement playroom, enclosed porch, patio; taxes $3,621.

title: Long Island Sound: Profiles by Computer
description: SCIENTISTS are collecting thousands of soil, water and marine-life samples in an effort to develop computer models of Long Island Sound.

title: A Winning Combination Named Beverly Sills
description: Beverly Sills has never been the retiring type, so let's avoid the word and say that she is stepping aside. Her scheduled departure at the end of this year as general director of the New York City Opera will not take her out of the company's picture - she becomes president of the board, after all. But even if a credible replacement can be found to run the day-by-day, night-by-night operations, the gap that her decision leaves in the front office will not be easily filled. There is little hope that the company will find another such winning combination: an instantly recognizable celebrity with a gift for spotting and promoting vocal talent, a firm grasp of and affection for the company's 44-year history and - most incredibly - a knack for balancing budgets.

title: Works bythe New and by the Eccentric
description: CONNECTICUT has not lacked for up-to-date art: the Matrix Gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum and the alternative space Real Art Ways have seen to that for a decade or more. All the same, new heights have been scaled with the appointment of Klaus Ottmann as curator of exhibitions for the Zilkha Gallery, at Wesleyan University, in Middletown.

title: Correction
description: A listing of summer music festivals in last week's Arts and Leisure section incorrectly described the schedule of the Dobbs Ferry Chamber Music Festival series. The concerts take place on Sunday. The dates indicated - June 5, 12, 19 and 26 - are correct.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: Horticulturist Is Wed To Felicia B. Garrow
description: Felicia Blanche Garrow and Manuel Wilfredo Guzman-Valiente were married yesterday at the Stella Maris Roman Catholic Church in Condado, P.R. The Rev. Jose Angel Borges performed the ceremony.

title: Lenses That Saw the State the Way it Was
description: LEAD: WHEN Roy Emerson Stryker, the director of the historical section of the Farm Security Administration, sent photographers around the country in 1935 to witness poverty and despair in rural America, he said he did not want any ''big people or big events.''

title: 'NO, NO, NANETTE' REVIVAL
description: If the 1925 musical ''No, No, Nanette'' has a message for the 1980's, it is the reminder that today's climate of rampant greed is hardly a new phenomenon in American history.

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: The delicate and beautiful balance of the game has been upset by the ease of base stealing. Pitchers should be given more, not less opportunity to hold runners on. When every single, walk and hit batter turns out to be the same as a two- or three-base hit, the game is distorted. The baserunning game should be high drama. Now, it is soap opera. The balk rule, of course, has become farce. MICHAEL SPIELMAN The Bronx

title: KING PARADE: ONE MAYOR, NO MARSHALLS
description: The list of no-shows among New York City's black elected officials at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Parade last Sunday seemed almost as long as the 21st annual parade itself.

title: For Taiwan, China Looms Ever Larger
description: After 40 years of hostility and separation, China and Taiwan have never felt so close to each other.

title:
GARDENING;
The Subtlety of Silver Will Accent Containers
description: LEAD: PLANTS with silver leaves add stunning effects to containers. They are worth exploring, especially when the pots, tubs and window boxes are in hot, dry locations.

title: Kings Tenements
description: To the Editor:

title:
OLYMPIC PROFILE: Brent Goulet;
Soccer Leader Interrupts an Exile
description: LEAD: THE Yank. That has been Brent Goulet's nickname since last November. It was given to him by his teammates - in England.

title: Brakeman Killed, Engine Derailed As Conrail Trains Crash in Jersey
description: A railroad brakeman was killed and the engine of a freight train derailed early yesterday in a head-on collision between two Conrail trains in Fair Lawn, N.J., railroad officials said.

title: Headliners; Voice of Justice
description: The wrong head rolled in the Justice Department last week, in the view of critics of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Mr. Meese dismissed his chief spokesman, Terry Eastland, saying, ''We could use some new leadership'' in the agency's public affairs department. Mr. Eastland, who is popular in conservative circles, said he was fired because Mr. Meese considered him insufficiently aggressive in defending the Attorney General from ''any and all criticism,'' of which there has been rather much since Mr. Meese's dealings with the scandal-scarred Wedtech Corporation came under investigation. After Mr. Eastland's dismissal became known, the conservative Washington Times called for Mr. Meese's resignation and predicted that Mr. Eastland would have ''a lot longer career in Washington than Ed Meese.''

title: How to Repair Concrete Steps
description: CONCRETE steps outdoors frequently crack and chip. Concrete is brittle and requires stable support from beneath as well as reinforcement within to withstand even moderate stress. Particularly damaging are rapid temperature fluctuations in spring.

title: Hard Lessons From the Arab Unrest
description: When the Israeli authorities begin reopening Palestinian schools on Monday, they may find that one major strategy for crushing the Palestinian uprising has backfired.

title: Jackson Beats Dukakis In Vermont Convention
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson edged out Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the state Democratic convention's preferential vote today, earning seven delegates to Mr. Dukakis's six. One uncommitted delegate to the national convention was also elected.

title: Peers Strive to Prevent Addiction
description: ''I had a friend who started smoking cigarettes, then pot, and then he started doing coke,' Steven Scarola told the class of restless seventh graders.

title: Where Rural Jews Can Get Together
description: There are no synagogues in this tiny rural community, no kosher butchers or bakeries, and barely enough Jews to make a minyan. Yet R. D. Eno is working to make his wood-heated log home the center for the Jewish community of rural New England and Quebec.

title: U.S. Aides See Summit Pomp, Not Substance
description: President Reagan, heading a contingent of about 600 Americans, will meet five times with Mikhail S. Gorbachev during next week's Moscow summit meeting, which is expected to be heavy with symbolism and ceremony.

title: The Celtics Lose on Wall Street
description: THE Boston Celtics have usually been winners on the basketball court but on Wall Street the team has been as well-received as an air ball.

title: THE NATION: The People's Concern; ILLEGAL DRUGS ARE AN ISSUE NO POLITICIAN CAN RESIST
description: When Vice President Bush split with the White House last week over a plan to drop narcotics charges against Panama's Gen.

title: Planning, for Vermont: A Tough Balancing Act
description: Elaine Park of the town manager's office says about half of Williston's 4,291 people want a 400,000 square foot shopping mall in their town and the other half fear such a mall will change Williston's character.

title: Florence L. Buchanan Weds Steve Spelman
description: Florence Leggett Buchanan, a daughter of George H. P. Buchanan of London and the late Janet H. Buchanan, was married yesterday to Steve Nelson Spelman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest N. Spelman of Westfield, Mass. Acting Justice Robert M. Haft of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Cafe in Grand Central Terminal.

title: Linda Eglin Wed To Cole E. Harrop
description: Linda Hilliard Eglin, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Wilson Eglin of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late Mr. Eglin, was married yesterday to Cole Edmund Harrop, a son of David C. Harrop of New York and Yolanda W. McPhee of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers performed the Presbyterian service in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville School.

title: Dr. Dr. Dr. Dr., May I Call You Freddie?
description: THE first time, during my two-year stay in Austria, that I saw a letter addressed to Professor Dr. Dr. So-and-So, I thought the secretary's finger had slipped. But it was I who was in error. I was in for a lesson in protocol that to this day I have not mastered.

title: Another Big Year for New York Cheese: 647 Million Pounds
description: For the 12th year in a row, cheese production in New York State rose to a record level in 1987, according to figures released this week by the New York Agricultural Statistics Service.

title: Behind the 'Crocodile' Smile Lie Australia's Tears
description: Australians like to see themselves as the dancing boys and girls of the Southwest Pacific, innately honest, able to deal with anyone on the level of their humanity. You see that knockabout side of the Australian character even in Australian politics. People on the street and in shopping malls, encountering the Prime Minister, the personable Bob Hawke, call him by his first name. Cabinet ministers of the federal government travel around in the front seats of their ministerial limousines chatting with the driver and calling him mate. It is not really that the power game is played much differently in Australia, but the rules are heavily influenced by myths and rituals that have to do with signaling mateship and equality.

title: Beach Access Waning as an Issue in the State
description: LEAD: THE public's right to use New Jersey's ocean beaches is becoming less of an issue from season to season, says Stephen Brower, a Deputy State Attorney General, because state aid has been used to prod shorefront towns to stop playing favorites.

title: Tighter Federal Drug Dragnet Yields Cars, Boats and Protests
description: The Federal Government's two-month-old policy of seizing boats, cars and other vehicles on which even small amounts of illegal drugs are found is causing dismay among civil libertarians and howls of protest from those whose property is confiscated.

title: John R. Cavanagh Is Wed To Deborah Anne Nichols
description: Deborah Anne Nichols, a daughter of Mrs. Clement Nichols of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Nichols, was married yesterday to John Raymond Cavanagh, the son of John J. Cavanagh of Upper Greenwood Lake, N.J., and Placida, Fla., and the late Anne Cavanagh. The Rev. Barry Andrews, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: An Opportunity to Talk the Cold War to Death
description: ONE week from today, when President Reagan arrives in Moscow for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the evolution of Soviet-American relations will have completed a dramatic cycle. From a surge of cooperation in the early 1970's and then into a tense period of frozen hostility, the two powers have now emerged into what may prove to be the healthiest relationship in their postwar history.

title: Golf; Charles Shoots 67 For 3-Shot Advantage
description: After setting a course record with a seven-under-par 63 on opening day, Bob Charles of New Zealand shot a three-under-par 67 today at the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative tournament.

title: Ups And Downs
description: CHINTZES BLOOMING WITH CABBAGE roses, lilies or carnations have flowered into overabundance during the past few years, but decorators are now looking to quieter, more subtle patterns.

title: Christine Wainwright, an Executive, Is Married to Douglas Fernald Stone
description: Christine Wainwright, the daughter of Mrs. Nicholas Biddle Wainwright of Gwynedd, Pa., and Douglas Fernald Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Stone of Greenwich, Conn., and Paris, were married yesterday. The Rev. Vincent Liddle performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Gwynedd.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Sound Advice
description: LEAD: A recently published manual for the public describing how people who live in Sound Shore communities can help clean up pollution in Long Island Sound is available through the office of State Senator Suzi Oppenheimer in New Rochelle.

title: Public Safety Officers' Role on Campus
description: I would like to respond to the recent article on the drinking problem on college campuses today [ ''Campus Drinking: Colleges Confront 'Issue of the 80's' '' ] and, more specifically, the role of public safety departments in the ''administration of penalties'' for infractions of campus alcohol regulations. Comments made by two C. W. Post students are quite distressing in that they show an ignorance of the function served by a college's public safety department and the difficulty of a public safety officer's job.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: MUSIC IN MONTCLAIR The flamboyant Canadian Brass quintet will combine forces with the Salvation Army Band of Montclair for a concert Friday evening at Montclair High School.

title: Auto Racing Program Helps To 'Keep Good Kids Straight'
description: DAVID ROSENBLUM can remember the day he called his parents for help. It was New Year's Day of 1983, and they had dropped in on him, bearing bagels ''like good Jewish parents,'' only to find his house, and his life, in disarray.

title: Biden Is Out of Hospital
description: Senator Joseph Biden was released from a hospital today after surgery to correct an aneurysm near his brain. The 45-year-old Delaware Democrat underwent surgery May 3 at Walter Reed Medical Center for his second aneurysm since February. Mr. Biden, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, dropped out of the Democratic Presidential race before the first aneurysm was discovered.

title: Correction
description: The Executive Computer column last week misstated the capacity of two computer storage devices. A 256K dynamic random access memory chip, or D-RAM, holds 256 kilobits of data. A one-megabit single in-line memory module, or SIMM, holds 1,000 kilobits of data.

title: KOCH ADVISER GETS JUDGE NOMINATION
description: Stella Schindler, Mayor Koch's chief adviser on homeless issues, has been nominated to serve as a judge on the Family Court.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we teach math to elementary students, now for numbers we have them count the homes the Israelis have demolished or the number of Palestinians they've put in prison.'' - Mahdi Abdul Hadi, a former Palestinian educator. [ 3:2. ]

title: County acts to Stem Crimes of Bias
description: FOUR months ago, after a spate of anti-Semitic vandalism in and around Westchester County, government officials met with Jewish and other religious leaders to coordinate a response to the racial and religious crimes.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Someone to Watch Over Me Starring Tom Berenger, Mimi Rogers, Lorraine Bracco, Jerry Orbach, John Rubinstein, Andreas Katsulas, Tony DiBenedetto. Directed by Ridley Scott. 1987. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 105 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: FOCUS: Lexington; Intruders In Famed Bluegrass
description: FOR almost three decades the thoroughbred horses at the 600-acre Mill Ridge Farm just outside Lexington, Ky., were surrounded by nothing but bluegrass. But these days the serenity of an area known as a breeding ground for Kentucky Derby winners is being disturbed.

title: State Gets Suffolk Tax Plea
description: LEAD: ACTING to advance a major environmental program, officials in Suffolk County have asked the State Legislature to extend a quarter of a penny increase in the county sales tax through the end of the century.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Albertson $252,500 17 Wood Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old ranch; den, enclosed patio, above-ground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $2,000. Carle Place $178,500 312 Rushmore Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Holbrook $125,000 28 Knickerbocker Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,900. Lake Ronkonkoma $136,000 9 Lake Park Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,500. Sayville $175,000 54 Crosby Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old high ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,200. Williston Park $250,000 60 Sheridan Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; legal 1-bedroom, 1-bath, rental apartment; finished basement, patio; taxes $2,400. OTHER AREAS New Britain, Conn. $118,000 28 Barnard Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, vegetable garden, 60- by 123-foot lot; taxes $1,471. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $325,000 11 Deerfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 64-year-old brick colonial; fireplace, basement playroom, enclosed porch, patio; taxes $3,621. Basking Ridge, N.J. $640,000 25 Stoneridge Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-month-old French provincial; c/a, fireplace in family room, 2-car garage; taxes $8,349.

title: ACCORD IS SOUGHT BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON MENTAL WARDS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are moving toward an agreement that would allow American psychiatrists to visit Soviet mental hospitals to determine if dissidents are being imprisoned in the hospitals, according to a top State Department official.

title: NONFICTION
description: EVE AND THE APES. By Emily Hahn. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $17.95.) Intentionally bypassing famous female primatologists (such as Jane Goodall and Dian Fossey), Emily Hahn, who herself has owned a number of apes, focuses in this book on a second tier of women who have had a particular fascination with these animals. Ms. Hahn, a writer for The New Yorker, explores the stories of nine individuals and their charges. She writes of Belle Benchley, an early director of the San Diego Zoo, and, in one of the most captivating chapters, of Penny Patterson and her success in teaching sign language to gorillas. Perhaps the saddest story involves Augusta Hoyt, who in 1931 went with her husband to French Equatorial Africa to collect (kill) a large gorilla specimen for the American Museum of Natural History. After Mr. Hoyt shot a large male, the couple watched horrified as Africans speared the rest of the gorillas - except for Toto, a struggling, biting baby that was thrust into Mrs. Hoyt's arms. The creature clutched her, and ''that was that.'' Later, Toto was treated by the best pediatricians in Paris. After 10 years, she was sent to the circus, with the stipulation that the gorilla be housed in the style to which she had become accustomed. Mrs. Hoyt felt forever guilty over the fate of Toto's family, but to many people she was merely an indulgent rich woman with a spoiled exotic pet. This book is a fascinating introduction to primatology, by a woman who identifies so closely with her primate cousins that occasionally it is difficult to tell whether she is referring to man or ape.

title: Q and A
description: Emptying an Apartment

title: Weighing The Options On Glen Island
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials are pondering their next move at the Glen Island Casino following a series of legal proceedings this month that left them temporarily sharing a business interest in the New Rochelle supper club with both the Federal Government and a convicted racketeer.

title: 'NO FAMILY HAD BEEN SO VEXED'
description: THE GIRL FROM CARDIGAN By Leslie Norris. 164 pp. Layton, Utah: Gibbs M. Smith/Peregrine Smith Books. $15.95.

title: Pro Football; Marshall Sparks a Dormant Fire
description: HE plopped onto the concrete steps in front of the Washington Redskins offices, gaining a brief respite from a long, sweaty morning of minicamp practice. The sun's rays dazzled as he squinted his right eye and then his left one. A Concorde jet blazed overhead, leaving a trail of booming clatter. Quickly, his thoughts shifted. Wilber Marshall was reminded of home, of Titusville, Fla., and nearby Cape Canaveral.

title: Verbatim: Nicotine Addicts
description: 'The pharmacologic and behavioral processes that determine tobacco addiction are similar to those that determine addiction to drugs such as heroin and cocaine.' - C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General, in his annual report on the health consequences of smoking.

title: Portrayer of the Intimate Copes With Celebrity
description: ON a May morning, the sense of well-being on the quiet tree-shaded street of Tudor homes in Hamden where the author Maggie Scarf lives with her husband, Herb, seems to run counter to the malaise in American domestic life she has documented in her two best-sellers, ''Unfinished Business: Pressure Points in the Lives of Women'' and ''Intimate Partners: Patterns in Love and Marriage.''

title: Aspiring to Life in the Slow Lane
description: LONG ISLAND commuters show a special, spiritual quality.

title: Louise R. Hoppe Marries John Finnerty in Virginia
description: Louise R. Hoppe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hoppe of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to John D. Finnerty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Finnerty of Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Palke performed the ceremony at the Immanuel Lutheran Church in Alexandria.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PASSAGE FROM INDIA: Asian Indian Immigrants in North America. By Joan M. Jensen. (Yale University, $32.50.) If, over the years, many immigrant groups have found strings attached to America's reputation as the land of opportunity, people from India seeking entrance to North America have found nets.

title: Jets Trade Carter
description: THE Jets closed down their minicamp Friday and yesterday they traded Russell Carter, a first-round draft choice out of Southern Methodist in 1984, to the Los Angeles Raiders for a conditional sixth-round draft choice in 1989. The condition is that Carter must make the Raiders. Carter the 10th player chosen over all in the 1984 draft, has been plagued by a series of injuries mainly to his legs, hamstring and calf muscles. He played in 40 games for the Jets, 35 as a starter and mostly at right cornerback.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Can Hartford Beat the Housing Squeeze?
description: HARTFORD has an office vacancy rate of just 8 percent, one of the lowest in the country. But this upbeat market has its down side. The city has a severe housing shortage and monumental traffic and parking problems caused by the 125,000 commuters who pour into a square-mile business district each day.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINON
description: I REMEMBER the study where the Beaver went to receive the wisdom of the ages given to him by Ward Cleaver, his father. I do not remember any of the pearls that this sage cast before the boy but I do remember the study and the magical maleness that emanated from that room and its surroundings. I have always wanted a room like that for my own.

title: Public Space Gets a New Cachet in New York
description: There was a strange mix of hype and glory to the announcement earlier this month by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch that a 50-acre waterfront park system would be created at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. The parks themselves aren't hype; they are among the best public spaces designed for New York City in a generation. But they have actually been around for a while, since they were all part of the much-acclaimed master plan for Battery Park City drawn up in 1979, creating its system of riverfront parks and esplanades, several sections of which are already complete. The 50 acres of parks that the Governor and the Mayor announced were the same parks that have been underway for all of this time - they were just repackaged to mark the opening of an elaborate exhibition called ''New York's New Riverfront: The Many Parks of Battery Park City and Beyond.''

title: Mozzarella Comes To Moscow
description: HOW do you say ''half mushroom, half pepperoni, extra cheese on both'' in Russian?

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Ill-Fitting Auden It's interesting to see a famous, eccentric poet in an unfamiliar role. In ''The Poet Auden: A Personal Memoir'' (Weidenfeld & Nicolson), A. L. Rowse describes an Americanized Auden in an Army uniform.

title: Two New Movies Suggest That Shock Tactics Are Best Muted In a Work of Art
description: One of the minor obsessions of the British writer Cyril Connolly was the murder of Lord Erroll in Kenya in 1941. But fascinating though he found the case (and officially, it has never been solved), there came a point when he couldn't help noting down his distaste for most of the characters involved.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction in this space last Sunday incorrectly identified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time. The record is 43.86 seconds and it was set by Lee Evans of the United States in the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.

title: Commission Urges All Judges Be Appointed
description: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity, in a new report, has recommended that all judges in the state be appointed, not elected. But it also conceded that an appointive system does not ''necessarily produce more qualified judges or fewer corrupt ones.''

title: Discipline for Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Tastes Grow for Herbs And Edible Flowers
description: LEAD: NURSERIES across the state are getting more requests for fresh herbs and edible flowers to use as garnishes or in salads.

title: Anne Axline Marries
description: Lieut. Anne Elizabeth Axline of the Navy Nurse Corps, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Axline of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Lieut. Comdr. William Lawrence Howe 2d of the Navy Medical Corps, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Howe of Clearfield, Pa. The Rev. George Coxe Bland Jr. performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield. The bride is a nurse at the Naval Hospital in Corpus Christi, Tex., where the bridegroom practices family medicine.

title: Theater; Hoping for a Cataclysm on a Rainy Day at Shea
description: Considerably dampened by rain, the Survival Research Laboratories presented its post-apocalyptical performance piece ''The Misfortunes of Desire'' Thursday night in the parking lot at Shea Stadium. This was, first of all, an exercise in audience survival techniques.

title: Lakers Put End to Upset Bid
description: Less than 48 hours after being humiliated by Utah, the Lakers, rejuvenated and apparently bent on revenge, eliminated the Jazz today from the National Basketball Association playoffs, 109-98. The victory was the first seventh-game triumph in a decade for the Lakers and bailed them out of a series they'll not soon forget.

title: COPING WITH CALIBAN
description: ARIEL By Jose Enrique Rodo. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. Prologue by Carlos Fuentes. 156 pp. Austin: University of Texas Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: Julia Anne Kosasky Wed To William Lane Hallisey
description: Julia Anne Kosasky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Kosasky of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to William Lane Hallisey, the son of Col. and Mrs. William Joseph Hallisey of Riverside, Calif. Bishop John B. Coburn, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer.

title: A Lifetime of Upstaging by Little Brother
description: TWENTY-SIX days after my glorious fourth birthday an unpleasant hired lady, who had just arrived at our St. Louis home, took me by the hand and led me to my parents' upstairs bedroom. She said she had a wonderful surprise for me.

title: White Horses
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Susan Spano Wells's article, ''Tracking Wiltshire's White Horses'' (Travel, April 10). A number of years ago, while motoring through the Berkshire Downs, I was startled by the appearance of a giant white equine on a distant escarpment. It turned out to be the Marlborough Horse, one of the hill figures mentioned.

title: Fostering the Memorial Day Tradition
description: JOSEPH SLOBODA is a World War II veteran who saw action in the Pacific when his Navy Seabee unit participated in both the battle of Okinawa and the capture of Admiralty Island.

title: Student to Be Wed To Ms. Shlufman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Shlufman of Plainview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Joy Shlufman, to Mitchell Schuster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schuster of Dix Hills, L.I.

title: 'Patty' Launches a Major Star
description: Just 19 years ago Vanessa Redgrave, perhaps one day to be known as the mother of Natasha Richardson, won the Cannes Film Festival's best-actress award for her bravura performance as Isadora Duncan, the dancer and all-American romantic who had a fatal fondness for long scarves. The film was Karel Reisz's ''Isadora.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE BRIDE WHO RAN AWAY. By Diana O'Hehir. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Should 19-year-old Grace Dowell go through with her wedding to her ''weird'' though attractive older cousin Steve? This is the question posed at the outset of Diana O'Hehir's gentle and doleful second novel, ''The Bride Who Ran Away,'' which is set in a small northern California town in the 1950's.

title: Once More Into the Videotex Breach
description: IT takes special courage to enter the videotex market, a graveyard for many bold projects of brave and strong companies. Yet the idea of videotex - a service that harnesses the power of the personal computer to bring electronic shopping, information and entertainment into the home - remains so compelling that the International Business Machines Corporation, the nation's largest computer maker, and Sears, Roebuck & Company, the largest retailer, have formed an alliance to try to resurrect the market once again.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Basel
description: In the heart of Switzerland's second city, the Rhine turns resolutely from a westerly course toward the north. Local people call the bend in the big river its knee - a dramatic curve that marks the waterway's transition from an Alpine river into the throbbing artery of one of the continent's most heavily industrialized regions.

title: Jennifer Slingluff Is Wed in Jersey
description: At St. George's-by-the River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., Jennifer Grant Slingluff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haines Slingluff Jr. of Rumson, was married yesterday to Patrick Malone Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Miller Robinson Jr. of Nashville. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony.

title: Having a Stuffed Koala as a Grown Woman Is Not the Same
description: YOU see it everywhere these days. The koala bear. First, the Qantas

title: Amy Trapp Wed To Robert Young
description: Amy Sayre Trapp, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Trapp Jr. of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert C. Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Young of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. C. Leslie Hughs performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: With Visions of Tree Houses, A Sign-Up for Fresh Air Fund
description: For 8-year-old Carlos Toro and his friends, the good times growing up in Jamaica, Queens, are usually overshadowed by fear of the neighborhood's rampant drug trade and flashes of violence.

title: India Sending More Troops to Punjab as Toll Rises
description: Hundreds of paramilitary troops are being transported to Punjab state to strengthen security forces after more than 190 people were killed this week in attacks attributed to Sikh extremists, police officials said today.

title: HOW LABOR BROADENED ITS BEACHHEAD IN THE IVY LEAGUE
description: Labor leaders had called it the watershed white-collar organizing drive of the decade, but the narrow union victory last week at Harvard University did not convince outsiders that efforts to organize private-sector office workers will be all downhill from here. ''Harvard was a very significant event,'' said Joel M. Douglas, who heads the National Center for the Study of Collective Bargaining in Higher Education and the Professions at New York City's Baruch College. ''But can it be transposed, can it be replicated in other sectors? That's the unknown.''

title: A New Direction For the Retarded
description: WHEN I started working with the retarded in 1974, it was before group homes in the suburbs. Many of the retarded lived in large institutions. In those days, big gates and vast grounds kept them at a distance from the outside world.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE RESTLESS EYE
description: LEAD: Marc Riboud is a consummate photographer-observer in the tradition of Henri Cartier-Bresson, who discovered the amateur photographer's work in the early 1950's. As we see in MARC RIBOUD: Photographs at Home and Abroad (Abrams, $40), the younger man gracefully received the mantle of Mr. Cartier-Bresson's vision: a balance of pristine geometry and human drama interlocking to compose the portrait of a moment.

title: Yes, A Faster Network, but Which One?
description: Most experts agree that an Integrated Services Digital Network is needed to handle the huge volume of data that will be transmitted over the nation's telecommunications networks in the future. But according to Kenneth L. Phillips, chairman of the Committee of Corporate Telecommunications Users, the I.S.D.N. standards now proposed are inadequate for the volume of data expected during the coming ''information age.'' Mr. Phillips talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about the type of I.S.D.N.'s required for the future.

title: CHINA STRAINS FOR OLYMPIC GLORY
description: China may strain for Olympic glory, but so does the United States - with the help of ''instant Americans'' (''China Strains for Olympic Glory,'' by Trip Gabriel, April 24). Special legislation has been introduced to obtain citizenship for the tennis star Ivan Lendl in time for the 1988 Summer Games.

title: Clown Takes Act To Soviet
description: SCRUNCH, squeak, pop! From bursts of air into a handful of string balloons, a shy swan slowly emerges as its creator's stubby fingers work with the delicate dexterity of a surgeon.

title: Headliners; Voice in Evidence
description: Scott Carroll denied that he was ''the South Shore rapist'' who terrorized a wealthy section of Long Island for four years, but compelling evidence against him came from his own mouth. Mr. Carroll was convicted last week of 31 counts of rape and burglary, largely on the basis of a ''voice lineup'' in which victims identified his voice as that of the man who attacked them. In all of his crimes, the attacker wore a ski mask and left no conclusive physical evidence. The jury deliberated 10 days before voting for the first conviction in New York State based mainly on a comparison of recorded voices. Mr. Carroll, who is 27 years old, is to be sentenced June 22 and faces a maximum of life in prison. His lawyer, who maintained that the police arrested the wrong man, said the conviction would be appealed.

title: The Siren Song Of Broadway Is a Warning
description: Since I function both as an engaged theater practitioner and as a detached observer of the theater scene, I sometimes find myself in contorted positions, juggling refractory problems. Perhaps the most knotty of these is how to preserve personal principles while trying to nurture a practical theatrical operation, congenial to all its members. From that perspective, I think it might be useful to explain why I, an artistic director of a resident repertory company who has watched some of its offerings move to the Broadway stage, find the present methods of transferring subsidized productions to the commercial theater somewhat alarming.

title: Months of Unrest Led to Leaders' Ousters
description: The dismissal yesterday of the Communist Party leaders in the neighboring Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan was preceded by repeated outbreaks of unrest in the last three months. Feb. 13 - School boycotts and street demonstrations by Armenians break out in the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region of the Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan. The protesters demand that Nagorno-Karabakh be united with the neighboring republic of Armenia. The population of the region is 75 to 80 percent Armenian, but has been governed by Azerbaijan since 1932. Over the next two weeks, similar protests take place in Yerevan, the capital of the Armenian republic. Feb. 27 - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meeting with protest leaders in Moscow, promises to study their demands. Returning to Yerevan, the leaders address a crowd in the city's opera house square, recommending that the protests be suspended for a month. Feb. 28 - Reports that two Azerbaijanis have been killed by Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh provoke riots in the Azerbaijani industrial city of Sumgait. Soviet officials say 32 people are killed, 26 of them Armenians. Armenians say the toll is much higher.

title: SHOULD NEW YORK TAKE JUDGES OFF THE BALLOT?
description: New York is one of only 14 states in which voters still choose some or most of their judges in partisan elections. Bar associations and other groups are urging the Legislature to switch to a system of appointment known as merit selection. Their campaign gained the support last week of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, created by Governor Cuomo last year.

title: THE ELDERLY AND THE POLITICS OF HEALTH CARE
description: The graying of America has become an indisputable fact of political life.

title: Ridgely Trufant Becomes a Bride
description: Ann Ridgely Trufant, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Adams Trufant 3d of New Orleans, and Theodore Small Brooke, a son of Ann Short of San Francisco and Howard Adams Brooke of Milton, Del., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles S. Temple, assisted by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Otis Carl Edwards, at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan.

title: The Bentham Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: INTO THE HEART OF OLD ALBANY
description: QUINN'S BOOK By William Kennedy. 289 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Should Baby Read?
description: THE IMAGE OF A 2-YEAR-OLD reading aloud from ''The Cat In the Hat,'' and laughing at the silly parts, warms the hearts of many young parents. Parents who are themselves intellectual and upwardly mobile want their children to have all the privileges they have had - and then some. How better to assure their children's success than to get them started early, to teach them to read during that brief shining time when kids absorb knowledge as naturally as they breathe? If children can read before they're out of diapers, many such parents think, whole worlds will open up to them - worlds they'll be exposed to not only during their childhoods, but for the rest of their lives.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage. What caused this problem and what can be done to correct it?

title: Eliot W. Berry Is Wed To Gloria S. Signorelli
description: Gloria Susanne Signorelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Signorelli of Newton, N.J., and Eliot Ward Berry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rynn Berry of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick Hoesli at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Skyway Work Set for Today
description: THE Pulaski Skyway's northbound lanes will be closed today from 6 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the installation of sign posts. Also, motorists using Route 46 in Parsippany-Troy Hills will find the ramp from Route 46 East to Interstate 80 East closed until mid-June.

title: A Stalwart for the Summer Months
description: PRUNE suckers from magnolias and water sprouts (upright shoots) from dogwoods. Plant geraniums, begonias, ivy, petunias, vinca, impatiens, torenia, salvia, marigolds, zinnias and other showy annuals in tubs, planters and window boxes. Set out started seedlings of peppers, tomatoes, eggplants, melons and sow cucumbers and sweet corn in hills. Geraniums

title: U.S. Articles on Prewar Jews Of Germany Found Wanting
description: The banner headline in The Chicago Tribune on June 14, 1942, announced that the SS had killed 258 Jews in Berlin after accusing them of a ''bomb plot'' against the Third Reich.

title: When the 'Dead Countries' Come Alive for Collectors
description: DEAD countries, in the parlance of stamp collectors, once existed as stamp-issuing nations but exist no longer. Dead countries have a way of maintaining their identities, however, rekindling collectors' interest.

title: SPREADING THE GOSPEL AT HARVARD
description: GOSPEL MUSIC blared from amplifiers, and Chagall paintings with symbols of Christianity and Judaism flashed on the wall above the stage as hundreds of young people crowded into the hall. It was not an intellectual revival meeting, but Harvey Cox's class on ''Jesus and the Moral Life,'' the hot course at Harvard.

title: Teachers Must Earn Their New Salaries
description: Our 702-student high school budget for next year is projected at just under $6.7 million, representing an increase of almost 12 percent. Such double-digit increases in educational budgets, commonplace throughout Fairfield County, are incurring strong resistance by Boards of Finance and by the taxpayer.

title: Political Peril of Using the Military in the Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Easy Does It
description: THERE ARE TIMES WHEN even the most devoted cook looks for a way out of the kitchen. Clearly, plenty of shortcuts exist today, but these have more to do with getting a meal on the table in a hurry than creating pleasurable dishes. Fast food, however, doesn't have to look or taste that way. It can be as simple as grilled fish, poultry or meat, or it can give the illusion of complexity.

title: Fiscal Changes Urged at Playland
description: LEAD: A REPORT prepared by one of the nation's leading accounting firms faults Playland's management for circumventing established county fiscal checks and for playing down the importance of appropriate operational controls.

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: I pay to see Mookie Wilson run out a triple. I don't go out to Shea to see the ump wave his arms like a traffic cop. JEREMY EPSTEIN Brooklyn

title: Liverpool Gets Tate Branch
description: TWENTY years ago the Beatles enlivened the world with their exuberant Mersey sound, born and bred in the northern England port of Liverpool. The city had been declining since World War II but George Harrison, John Lennon, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr spurred Liverpool's rehabilitation as a cultural center. Now, the city's international stature is further enhanced by the opening this week of the Tate Gallery of the North.

title: Stacie Bowman Is Married
description: At the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y., Stacie Ann Bowman and Cary Pincus, graduates of the Georgia Institute of Technology, were married yesterday by Msgr. Donald Pryor, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Lindell Bowman Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y. Her father is an executive vice president of Doral Hotel and Resorts Management. Mr. Pincus is the son of Roberta Pincus of Wantagh, L.I., and the late Don Pincus.

title: THE WORLD: Pizza, Pepsi and the President; The Russians Indulge Their Taste For American Taste
description: THOSE who believe in the eventual convergence of the Soviet and American systems could take heart last week. An ''Astro Pizza'' truck from New Jersey, parked on the Moscow river embankment, was doing a brisk business selling pizzas at stratospheric prices. The score from ''Porgy and Bess'' blared from car radios Wednesday afternoon, and each evening, slick American commercials, translated into Russian, splashed across television screens promoting Pepsi-Cola and Visa credit cards. The imminent arrival of President Reagan seemed to throw Moscow by plan and happenstance into a fit of Americanization. While some Muscovites were bemused, particularly by the debut of commercials for television sets and credit cards that are as yet unavailable, the encroachment of American culture also intensified ambivalent feelings about the United States.

title: NONFICTION
description: CARL SANDBURG: His Life and Works. By North Callahan. (Pennsylvania State University, $29.75.) ''A biography, Sirs, should begin with the breath of a man when his eyes first meet the light of day,'' Carl Sandburg once wrote. Adopting this philosophy in covering Sandburg's 89 years, North Callahan has written a creditable biography of the writer and the man, often using his own extensive recollections of the poet whose ''reckless ecstasies of the language'' have become part of the American tongue. Sandburg was a man of various talents and inclinations: musician as well as poet, biographer of Lincoln, Midwest wanderer and Chicago journalist, to name a few. Any author would have his hands full attempting to synthesize a life of such breadth and prolific diversity in a relatively spare 258 pages. Mr. Callahan brings to his effort the requisite scholarship - he is professor emeritus of history at New York University and the author of 15 books on American history and literature, including a biography of Sandburg published in 1970 - and a wealth of personal insights culled from years of contact with his subject. (The two men shared a deep interest in the Civil War and the way it changed the nation.) He has enhanced this work with telling anecdotes that give the man from Galesburg, Ill., a dimension beyond the printed page. In his early years, Sandburg wrote of how ''life is more vast and strange than anything about it - words are only incidentals.'' But his ''incidentals'' - novels and biography and poems alike - became Americana. Mr. Callahan's book does Sandburg justice.

title: AT THE MERCY OF APPARATCHIKS
description: LEAD: CHILDREN OF THE ARBAT By Anatoli Rybakov. Translated by Harold Shukman. 685 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Grow Versatile Tree-Form Plants
description: LEAD: STANDARD or tree-form plants like roses or bougainvilleas are eye-catchers that can be used in many ways. When placed in the center of a round bed, a standard becomes its focal point. Rows of standards along garden paths form miniature alleys that create illusions of distance, and standards are ideal tub plants to decorate a patio or to frame a doorway.

title: Bolivar's Treasures Go Home to Venezuela
description: In his lifetime, Simon Bolivar was a known as a military hero, a political dreamer and a legendary lover. But since his death in 1830, the Venezuelan-born Liberator has gradually assumed the stature of a demigod in the country that he helped to free from Spanish rule.

title: U.N. RIGHTS EFFORT: CARROT AND STICK
description: This spring the United Nations is sending the Vice President of Burundi's Supreme Court on a four-week course to study human rights and is also sending a team of French-speaking police officers to help train Togo's police force.

title: After 4 Months, Yonkers Must Still Pick Low-Income Housing Sites
description: Four months after Yonkers agreed under pressure from a Federal court to build low-income housing as part of a desegregation plan, the city's leaders have yet to settle on construction sites.

title: Laura R. Hopkins Is Wed in Florida
description: Laura Rowland Hopkins and Stephen Barrington Baxter were married yesterday at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Braddock, Pa.;
Town Houses For the Needy
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION of 110 town houses is scheduled to begin in October for the residents of Talbot Towers, who will vacate their dilapidated public housing complex in this steel town on the Monongahela River, eight miles upstream from Pittsburgh.

title: Off the Beaten Path In a Changing Nation
description: WHEN a group of Western newspaper correspondents crisscrossed Far Eastern Siberia last year on a tour of gold mines, reindeer farms and hydroelectric dams, they were occasionally startled to discover that officials in the most godforsaken outposts wanted to discuss prospects for tourism. Tourism? In a place where the 40-below winter is interrupted only long enough for mosquito season?

title: Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor: To your list, in Q & A (April 24), of small gifts to take to the Soviet Union should certainly be added picture postcards of American sights and landscape. We were asked for these everywhere we went - mostly by children and teen-agers, who always were ready with postcards for us. Sew-on patches (not those with political motifs) would also be highly regarded. CARLA DAVIDSON New York, N.Y.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bethesda, Md.;
High Taxes Imperil Market
description: LEAD: RISING property taxes could imperil the Montgomery Farm Women's Cooperative Market, once a lifeline for Depression-era farmers and a fixture here for almost 60 years.

title: 'Master Harold' Moves Into McCarter Theatre
description: TO ONE who has attended a half-dozen performances of '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the boys,'' it is amazing how Athol Fugard's masterpiece still has the power to startle.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THIS ONE'S ON ME: The Sixth Volume of the Bandy Papers. By Donald Jack. (Doubleday, $16.95.) If you really knew Bartholomew Bandy, you'd strangle him - out of frustration or a sense of duty. In ''This One's on Me,'' the Canadian humorist Donald Jack's sixth novel in a series dubbed ''The Bandy Papers,'' the narrator of these outrageous memoirs is devious, arrogant, stubborn and often drunk.

title: Federal Judge Slain by a Gunman in Westchester
description: A 56-year-old Federal judge was shot and killed yesterday afternoon at his Westchester County home by an assailant who pursued him from garden to house with a blazing gun and then shot himself to death, the police reported.

title: Seeking the Elusive Entry-Level Worker
description: ASK any employer about problems in the workplace and chances are the scarcity of entry-level employees will be mentioned immediately. Even as managerial and white-collar jobs disappear because of layoffs and mergers, the demand for entry-level workers at Westchester companies has never been stronger, said Richard Schaab, director of program operations for the Westchester County Association, a business group whose members represent large companies and corporations.

title: 'I Can Always Find Time to Do This'
description: EVERY Saturday morning, 8-year-old Shaunta Matthews waits eagerly in her Milford apartment for her Big Sister, Michelle Polhemus. Once Ms. Polhemus, a 22-year-old volunteer for Big Brothers-Big Sisters of America, arrives from New Haven, the two ''sisters'' hop into the car and do anything from flying a kite, going to the movies or roller skating to simply taking a ride and having a heart-to-heart talk.

title: With Race Largely Over, Jackson Lets Up Only a Bit
description: The race for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination is effectively over, but the Rev. Jesse Jackson carries on, motivated by practical politics, broad philosophy and personal drive.

Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 3 11 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 4 4 FLIGHT OF THE OLD DOG, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) Meeting Russia's challenge after it has mastered Star Wars technology. 5 3 THE SISTERS, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.95.)
