These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: 'Slaughterhouse Rock'
description: ''Slaughterhouse Rock'' brings together the usual suspects of teen-age horror films: murder, rock music, sex, low budgets. Alex, a college student, is possessed by the spirit of a cannibal-ghost buried beneath Alcatraz, released from his grave by a dead rock star. In order to exorcise the spirit from his dreams, Alex and a half-dozen of his most foolhardy friends head for Alcatraz in the middle of the night, where they stumble over skeletons, corpses and many live rats. Alex's brother sprouts vampire fangs, the better to kiss his unsuspecting girlfriend.

title: Mark in IC4A Long Jump
description: Ray Humphrey of Georgetown University won the long jump with a last-round jump of 26 feet 10 1/2 inches, a meet record, at the IC4A track and field championships at Yale University today. Humphrey's jump carried him past Ray Hawkins, who had set a meet record of 26-6 1/2 on the previous jump.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Grow Versatile Tree-Form Plants
description: LEAD: STANDARD or tree-form plants like roses or bougainvilleas are eye-catchers that can be used in many ways. When placed in the center of a round bed, a standard becomes its focal point. Rows of standards along garden paths form miniature alleys that create illusions of distance, and standards are ideal tub plants to decorate a patio or to frame a doorway.

title: Belmont Plot: Stevens vs. Stephens
description: WEARING only a towel around his middle, Gary Stevens was talking about what he considered to be the moment of truth in yesterday's Preakness for Winning Colors, the filly that won the Kentucky Derby.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
May Madness Before the June Swoon
description: LEAD: QUICK: What is black and ecru and read all over in May? Right: June wedding invitations. It is no accident that they are sent out six weeks in advance. It takes that long for the guests to get ready.

title: Those Hot Pizzas Are Burning Up the Road
description: TO hear Sharon Bulova tell it, it's enough to scare the most fearless adult. ''Domino's delivery people are running out of their stores, jumping out of their cars and tearing out of the parking lots,'' said Ms. Bulova, who is the elected supervisor of the Annandale district in Fairfax County, Va. ''The potential for mishap is huge.''

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: Baseball has been vastly improved by the enforcement of the balk rule. PAUL ADAMSBAUM Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Memorial for Divine
description: A memorial service for the actor Harris Glenn Milstead, who was known as Divine, is scheduled for 6:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. today at the Tunnel, 12th Avenue and West 27th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Milstead died March 7. Excerpts from some of his films will be shown. The memorial is open to the public. Donations will go to the Northern Lights Alternatives, a nonprofit organization that provides help for children with AIDS.

title: Haunting Chronicle of a Death Foretold
description: ''If I don't get no relief,'' said the condemned murderer Edward Earl Johnson, looking at a date circled in black on his wall calendar, ''they're gonna kill me.''

title: Penelope Bryant Wed to Grady Catterall in Capital
description: Penelope L. R. Bryant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. M. Bryant of Rockport, Mass., and Washington was married yesterday to Grady Clopton Catterall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Catterall 3d of Dallas. The Rev. Caroline S. Pyle performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Caroline Meade Rudd to Be Married To Nicolas Woolworth Combemale
description: Caroline Meade Rudd's engagement to Nicolas Woolworth Combemale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of New York and Winthrop, Me., has been made known by her parents, Julia Meade Rudd and O. Worsham Rudd, both of New York and Cape Neddick, Me.

title: David Chapin Married To Diana Helene Wolff
description: Diana Helene Wolff and David Emerson Chapin were married yesterday at their home in Clifton, N.J., by Judge Philip Freedman of State Superior Court in Newark.

title: 3d-District Race Could Be Costly
description: THE RACE to replace the late Representative James J. Howard in New Jersey's Third Congressional District could easily be the most expensive House campaign in history.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST SHIP. By William Brinkley. (Viking, $19.95.) In ''The Last Ship,'' the unnamed captain of the Nathan James, a United States destroyer that has been involved in a nuclear war, gives a gripping account of how his ship, on diminishing fuel, food and supplies, crisscrosses the seven seas in search of uncontaminated land on which to begin repopulating the planet.

title: Federal Judges, Nassau Politics
description: ''We've been seeing an interesting evolution with Al D'Amato,'' a political analyst, Norman Ornstein, said the other day. ''He's moved up in the Senate, he's gained stature, he's become a lot sharper and more sophisticated.'' New York's junior Senator has indeed come some distance from the political machine in which he started. But his two latest choices for the Federal bench on Long Island are untimely reminders of clubhouse politics. The politics of picking Federal judges belongs on a higher plane.

title: A Born Recycler, in Tune With the Environmental Times
description: I GUESS you could say I'm a born recycler.

title: GRACE'S ENVIRONMENT CHIEF: Hugh L. Carey; An Old Pol Tackles a New Post
description: WHEN W. R. Grace & Company hired New York's former Governor, Hugh L. Carey, in December to head its new Office of Environmental Policy, the move caused barely a public ripple. But speculation has been lively among competitors and shareholders. Why, they wonder, would Grace, which has endured more than its share of depressed profits and job cuts this decade, fork over $400,000 a year to a 69-year-old lawyer with no recent corporate experience?

title: Reagan Sees Bush and Top Aides On Merits of Talks With Noriega
description: President Reagan met at length with senior advisers at the White House today for what officials described as a complete assessment of whether the United States should continue to seek a negotiated settlement with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military ruler.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AMONG the books topping the list for good summer reading is ''The Politics of Inclusion'' by Thomas H. Kean (Free Press, New York, $17.95), a thoughtful and often provocative work by the Governor about himself and his political career.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SWEET DEATH. By Claude Tardat. Translated by Linda Coverdale. (Overlook, $15.95.) Some years ago, a woman I knew committed suicide. She had taken pains with her wardrobe, arranging to be found in a stylish red silk dress and slippers, not realizing that death through a drug overdose would not render her a pretty sight.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: An Exchange of Words ALTHOUGH the summer season isn't officially here, there have already been fireworks in Westhampton. At the finale of the Westhampton Writers Festival last Saturday night, Budd Schulberg took on Dakin Williams, brother of the late Tennessee Williams.

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: The balk rule is serving only in slowing the game without really tackling the reason for its institution. More balks appear to be called when the pitcher pitches to the batter than when he throws to first base to eradicate a troublesome man on base. The rhythm of the pitcher is unnecessarily interfered with, and the resultant confusion serves only to make the game less enjoyable. HENRY G. SIMMONS New York

title: A Rule Change for Cable
description: Last Wednesday the Federal Communications Commission ruled that reruns of network programs carried by cable companies must be ''blacked out'' if a local station has purchased the exclusive right to broadcast that program in the same area. How will the ruling affect local broadcasters and cable system operators? John Siegel President, KBHK-TV, San Francisco.

title: Eileen Stafford Kenny Wed To William Araskog on L.I.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Dominic in Oyster Bay, L.I., Eileen Stafford Kenny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kevin Kenny of Locust Valley, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William Roy Araskog, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rand V. Araskog of New York and Kinnelon, N.J. The Rev. Luke L. Travers, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Nestled in the Suburbs, a Spread of Cattle
description: LEAD: BY the time his neighbors are darting to the commuter train or speeding to their office parks each morning, Joseph J. Stahl 3d has already tended to the welfare of a herd of a 100 cattle and scanned some of the 350 acres that provide hay, corn and pasture for them.

title: A QUESTION OF COSTS: OREGON PREFERS TO CARE FOR THE AGED AT HOME
description: Oregonians have always prided themselves on their maverick streak.

title: LOVING JONROBERT
description: IN THE SHADOW OF THE PEACOCK By Grace Edwards-Yearwood. 279 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company.

title: Dr. Amy H. Sherman Weds Anesthesiologist
description: The marriage of Dr. Amy Hope Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Sherman of Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. John Gerard McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah McCarthy of Mitchelstown, County Cork, Ireland, took place yesterday in Amagansett, L.I. Shepherd Frood, a retired town justice of East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Sea Breeze Inn.

title: JULIO BOCCA IN 'BAYADERE' DEBUT
description: Julio Bocca, the young Argentine dancer who joined American Ballet Theater last year, is at only the beginning of his career. Yet an astounding ability to transform himself in every role, to understand characterization and style, bespeaks a performer blessed with inborn maturity.

title: W. S. Straus Wed To Ms. Weinstein
description: Lynne Jaeger Weinstein, a photo reporter for Life magazine, and William Sachs Straus, a vice president of the Manhattan Recording Company, were married yesterday at the New York Academy of Art. The Rev. Janice Garrett performed the nondenominational service.

title: Maple Sugar Season: Quality Over Quantity
description: Maple syrup production was up by 225,000 gallons this year, but producers did not have the banner year they had been hoped for. The auality was what counted most, a Federal official said.

title: Diverse Moods on Guitar
description: John Johns, a guitarist on the faculty of Vanderbilt University, played in Weill Recital Hall Monday night and showed himself a first-rate performer in almost all respects - the ''almost'' only because he stops short of the technical virtuosity that can put a crowning touch on a recital. One hardly felt the lack as his sure fingers and firm musical sense made such a stylish thing of the opening Suite in A by Robert de Visee and traced the quickly shifting moods of Richard Rodney Bennett's short Impromptus.

title: 3 Youths Die in Queens Car Crash
description: LEAD: Three teen-agers died and four others were seriously injured early yesterday when their car smashed into a support pillar beneath the IND elevated tracks in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said.

title: Rebecca Kelly Company
description: Rebecca Kelly is not afraid of big themes. Alienation, euthanasia and capital punishment were only a few of the topics with which the Rebecca Kelly Dance Company concerned itself when it performed Thursday night in the 3-D series at the Joyce Theater. Yet Ms. Kelly's choreographic earnestness was not always accompanied by an equally high level of imagination, for she often left provocative ideas undeveloped.

title: PLOTTING A THEORY OF THE BRAIN
description: IT IS NEAR THE END OF A THREE-HOUR conversation that Dr. Gerald M. Edelman leans across the conference table and looks me in the eye.

title: A Novelty Search Is Endless
description: NO game other than chess puts such a premium on novelty. That is what the relentless search to produce a new move, a new plan, is all about.

title: Smithsonian Adjunct Is the Ultimate Attic
description: One Friday afternoon in 1973, when the Smithsonian Institution was fairly groaning under the strain of its enormous holdings, Porter Kier, the director of the National Museum of Natural History, remarked to one of his curators that he would like to decorate his office with a zoological specimen ''a little bigger'' than the stuffed groundhog perched on his desk.

title: NEW JERSEY OPINIONThe Future Is in Good Hands
description: AS A former press aide to Assemblyman Chuck Hardwick, I was asked to speak to a ninth-grade class on the ''how-to's'' of political campaigning.

title: South Jersey Divided Over Hunting on Reserves
description: THE opening shots in a civil war of sorts have been fired over a Federal proposal to open two National Wildlife Reserves to hunting. The dispute pits resident against resident and even animal protectionist against animal protectionist.

title: Curbs Sought on a Big National Guard Camp
description: Citizens angered by expanded use of the nation's largest National Guard training base are pressing ahead with legal action to restrain activities at Camp Grayling here, invoking the name of a local lumber baron who donated some of the land 75 years ago.

title: CARDS TOP ASTROS ON PENA'S HOMER
description: Tony Pena hit a three-run homer with one out in the 11th inning, lifting the Cardinals over the Houston Astros, 7-4, tonight.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Police Still Unraveling Trail Left by Woman in Rampage
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation knew about Laurie Wasserman Dann. So did prosecutors in three states. So did her neighbors and her former husband and in-laws.

title: At Leading Harlem Church, an Opening for Change at the Top
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Proctor, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, one of New York City's most influential black institutions, plans to retire in June 1989, and has proposed as his replacement his assistant, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, according to church officials and members.

title: Nuclear Power License
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has unanimously approved a license to the Commonwealth Edison Company for the second reactor at its nuclear power plant in Braidwood, Ill., near Chicago, to operate at full power.

title: Lilco Deal Disappoints Hard-Line Opponents
description: AS elements of a negotiated settlement between the state and the Long Island Lighting Company fall into place, it appears likely that Long Island's public power advocates will be forced to settle for a partial victory in their battle to take control of the beleaguered utility.

title: At the Morgan: Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail
description: When Beatrix Potter's achievement as a writer and illustrator of books for children was set out at the Tate Gallery in London last year, people came in the tens of thousands and stood in line forever to get into the show. Substantially the same exhibition can now be seen, through Aug. 21, at the Pierpont Morgan Library. During the first half an hour of its run in New York, more than 300 visitors were admitted. And every morning, before opening time, people cluster round the steps of the library, and on every face there is a look of pleasure and shared expectation.

title: A Shrewd Return to the Leather-Rich Lap of Luxury
description: I PAID a dollar for the least expensive car I've ever owned. It was the first of two Chryslers that lived at my house, and, not surprisingly given the price, it was a fairly terrible automobile.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Braddock, Pa.;
Town Houses For the Needy
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION of 110 town houses is scheduled to begin in October for the residents of Talbot Towers, who will vacate their dilapidated public housing complex in this steel town on the Monongahela River, eight miles upstream from Pittsburgh.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COUNTY BIKE TOURS Dan and Robbin Sweeney, a young Mamaroneck couple, this month started a business called Criss-Cross Bicycle Tours. They will lead a group of about 14 cyclists around the county on a variety of routes every weekend through the end of September.

title: Plan to Add 2d Bus Lane For Tunnel Is Pressed
description: THE problem of moving 240,000 eastbound commuters across the Hudson River during rush hours every weekday morning has convinced New Jersey transportation officials to push ahead with a plan to create a second express bus lane leading into the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: The Right To Volunteer
description: JOHN C. DONAHUE may be only a volunteer firefighter in Windsor Locks, Conn., but he is willing to fight for the right to volunteer.

title: Julia Just and Michael Azerrad Marry
description: Julia Barnett Just and Michael Milsner Azerrad were married yesterday at the Washington home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Turrell Bower. Judge Joyce Hens Green of the Federal District Court in Washington officiated.

title: New Point-and-Shoot for Kodak's Anniversary
description: ONE hundred years ago, George Eastman introduced a revolutionary idea in picture making: photography for everybody. His first roll-film camera, introduced in 1888 and called the Kodak, allowed dilettantes and duffers to take photographs easily without the bother of carting around glass plates, tripods and other paraphernalia.

title: Monique Miron, Engineer, to Wed
description: Monique Miron, a mechanical engineer with Boyle Engineering Consultants in Newport Beach, Calif., and Lieut. Jonathan E. Cayle of the Navy Medical Corps, a surgical intern at the Balboa Naval Hospital in San Diego, plan to marry in August. The parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lane Miron of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IF the phrases sound familiar, it's because almost everyone has heard them countless times. ''We must have lunch [ or dinner ] '' and ''We must get together soon.'' The words are different, but they mean the same thing: nothing. Anyone who takes them as a statement of intent, who harbors the hope that the ephemeral is going to become concrete, is either naive or recently arrived from a South Sea island.

title: Long Island Interview: Herbert Beckhard; A Protege of Breuer Fights 'Faceless' Architecture
description: WHEN Herbert Beckhard designs a building, he sticks to the basics: wood, stone and concrete. Mr. Beckhard, a protege and former partner of Marcel Breuer, the Bauhaus architect who played a major role in shaping 20th-century architecture and design, is known for buildings that wed innovative design with keen attention to function.

title: Anne Cudlip Has Wedding
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Anne Simpson Cudlip, the daughter of Nancy Clapp Cudlip of Waccabuc, N.Y., and William J. Cudlip of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married yesterday to Wilfred Augustin Finnegan 3d, a son of Mrs. John G. Finnegan of Rye and Green Lake, Me., and the late Dr. Finnegan. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor performed the ceremony.

title: Watered-Down Westway, or a Great New Hudson River Park?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'IS THERE A CHIC WAY TO GO?'
description: BLUE BLOOD By Craig Unger. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: RISKY BUSINESS
description: Despite my several points of disagreement, I was moved by Susan Jacoby's piece.

title:
THEATER;
Anne Meara Arrives at the Nurse's Station
description: LEAD: Anyone whose theater memory doesn't reach back to 1957 may be surprised to hear that Anne Meara is doing Shakespeare. Yes, the Anne Meara who was Rhoda's pal and the cook at Archie Bunker's Place on television; the female half of Stiller and Meara, celebrated comedy couple of TV and the nightclub circuit, famously funny radio pitchpair who can make you think you want to dash out and open an account at the Amalgamated Bank.

title: Tiny Churches
description: To the Editor: An article on April 3 described a visit to the ''smallest church in England,'' Exmoor's Culbone Church, a building 35 feet long and capable of seating 33. England evidently has more than one smallest church. In its description of Wasdale Head and Wastwater, the Ordnance Survey's Leisure Guide to the Lake District notes that of six churches that lay claim to the title of smallest, St. Olaf's in Wasdale Head is the smallest in cubic capacity (although it exceeds Culbone's length by nine inches and claims to seat 39 uncomfortably and, on rare occasion, as many as 70).

title: Yale Moves to Make Cum Laude Mean More
description: Twenty years ago, graduating with honors from Yale University was a mark of distinction. Barely a quarter of the graduating seniors qualified for honors. Fewer than 3 percent were awarded diplomas with the highest approbation, summa cum laude. This year, however, with grade inflation, making an A is almost as common as getting a C once was. About half of the university's graduating class of 1,300 will receive honors. About 10 percent are expected to graduate summa cum laude.

title: Temple Women Win Championship
description: Penn State and Temple played again today for the women's national championship in lacrosse, and this time the Lady Owls got even.

title:
ART;
New Generation Shows Its Colors
description: LEAD: THERE is something optimistic about ''The New Generation'' as a title that makes it an appropriate choice for opening a season. A large exhibition - 21 artists, each represented by a body of work - on the theme fills the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton, marking the opening of the gallery's 23d year.

title: THE WINGS OF ADVENTURE
description: Daniel Menaker's article, ''Hell on Wheels'' (May 1), brought back memories of similar six-hour weekly drives to and from our farm in Vermont. After five years, however, I realized Mr. Menaker's dream of sprouting wings: I learned to fly and purchased a well-used four-passenger Piper airplane to speed the trip for my wife, two children and overweight dog.

title: No Letup By Gooden As Streak Reaches 8
description: The Mets, still streaking in all directions, won their sixth straight game tonight by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, as Dwight Gooden won his eighth straight by pitching a four-hitter with the oldtime mastery.

title: Giants' Minicamp Just Fine
description: Buoyed by a combination of fun and dedication that had marked their five days of spring workouts, the Giants ended their minicamp here today. They were satisfied with the play of the returning veterans, encouraged by the showing of the rookies, and, most of all, relieved that everyone had come through in one piece.

title: On Third Hand Play
description: ONE of the oldest rules of thumb in the game, dating back to whist, is ''third hand high.'' Whist-players, with no dummy in view to help them, followed this guideline blindly. Bridge players are better off and can recognize the obvious exceptions. At the first trick the third player usually preserves a high card that is poised over an honor in the dummy.

title: Music; Premieres By Kronos Quartet
description: The Kronos Quartet ended its first, sold-out and by all accounts highly successful series at Alice Tully Hall Friday night with a generous program that included three scores partly commissioned by Lincoln Center.

title: Rude Fans Ruin Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Communities Vie for Federal Grants
description: LEAD: THE final public hearing on how the county proposes to allocate $13 million of Federal Community Development Block Grant funds over the next three years will be held tomorrow night in White Plains. The amounts range from $1.4 million for a parking project in Port Chester to $6,650 for signs in North

title: THE THEORY AND PRACTICE OF ARMS SALES TO THE MIDDLE EAST
description: As Congress considers new proposals for arms sales to the Middle East, debate is again growing over the merits of such deals as a way to win friends, gain influence and preserve peace in the region. American diplomatic and military experts say that arms sales have become a test of the United States' reliability as a friend and ally and a measure of its commitment to the security of other countries. But critics of American policy say that in many cases the United States is merely contributing to regional conflicts.

title: For the Bookshelf Of the Enthusiast
description: AMONG the brightest events this spring is the arrival of a book that should spur the enthusiasm of new collectors and re-excite those for whom collecting crafts is habitual.

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: The purpose of calling balks is to protect the runner on base. A pitcher must come to a discernible stop before pitching. How can a pitcher be called for a balk when his team is going to intentionally walk the hitter? Umpires have every right to call violations of the rules and regulations of the game, but let's call them only when there is clearly an infraction. BRUCE CARY PAPIRMAN Brooklyn

title: CAMBODIANS TEST HANOI FOR SIGNS OF WITHDRAWAL
description: Friday was a National Day of Hate in Cambodia. On these annual occasions, the Government in Phnom Penh asks Cambodians to remember the terror of Pol Pot and to redouble their efforts to prevent his return.

title: Behold! We Have An Industrial Policy
description: One of the Reagan Administration's enduring legacies will be the foundation of a national industrial policy.

title: In the Days of Detente
description: Only two American Presidents - Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford - have traveled to the Soviet Union for summit conferences since the end of World War II. Here is a look at their meetings. May 1972 Moscow - Three months after a historic trip to China, President Nixon met with Leonid I. Brezhnev in Moscow. They agreed to two arms accords, the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, and the SALT I agreement on offensive nuclear weapons, the first such pact setting limits on numbers of strategic missile launchers. The Senate approved both pacts. The ABM treaty is still a matter of dispute between Moscow and Washington. June and July 1974 Moscow and Yalta - One month before he resigned because of the Watergate scandal, Mr. Nixon visited Mr. Brezhnev again. They discussed implementation of SALT I and limits on underground nuclear testing, and signed an agreement on economic cooperation. November 1974 Vladivostok - President Ford, who had pardoned Mr. Nixon in September, and Mr. Brezhnev tentatively agreed on the numbers of offensive strategic weapons each side would be allowed. This set the stage for the strategic arms limitation talks agreement - SALT II - of 1979. The treaty was signed by Mr. Brezhnev and President Carter, but it was not ratified by the Senate in the aftermath of the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in 1979.

title: Susan Lisa Alfin Weds Michael T. F. Johnson
description: Susan Lisa Alfin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Alfin of Sands Point, L.I., and Michael Thomas Finley Johnson, a son of Mrs. John H. Hapeman Jr. of New Boston, N.H., and Gardiner Porter Johnson of Dallas, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas LaMont performed the ceremony at the Community Reformed Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: METS' BULLPEN IS BACK ON EVEN KEEL
description: Dave Johnson is the first to admit it: The Mets' bullpen, which he called ''my main concern'' in spring training, is no longer his concern. It is his strength.

title: Advice for the Bewildered Graduate: Relax
description: THIS season, tens of thousands of young men and women are being awarded college degrees. At their commmencements, they and their parents are listening to rhetoric wrapped in a mantle of hope to the effect that the world is their oyster.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE IDEAL, GENUINE MAN. By Don Robertson. (Philtrum Press/Putnam, $25.) Herman Marshall, a retired 73-year-old truck driver, drinks Shiner beer with his pals at the Top of the World bar in the Houston suburb of Pasadena. Like Herman they are ''iggerant,'' relentlessly racist ''old boys with guns and hats and enormous beltbuckles,'' obsessed with the decline of their lives.

title: AN OUTSIDER JOINS THE TEAM
description: AT A RURAL COLLEGE in Michigan, Dr. Harry Edwards, the controversial sports sociologist, is delivering his first speech of a three-day, $8,000 lecture stop.

title: Hard Questions About Exhibiting U.S. Art Abroad
description: Finally awakened by the general uneasiness about the lackluster way American art has been represented abroad, the United States Government has done what it often does after being made aware of a problem: provide more money and appoint a committee.

title: 3 Bomb Attacks in Greece
description: Two bombs exploded in the Athens suburb of Nikaia early today, and a third was thrown from a car in the port of Piraeus. There were no injuries, the police said. All three attacks were claimed by a local left-wing terrorist group, Revolutionary Popular Struggle.

title: Vintage Connecticut, 1988
description: YOU won't find it on the map, but the Federal Government has designated a large portion of the state as the Western Connecticut Highlands, giving it the official stamp as a wine-making region.

title: Catherine Huse Lilly Marries Peter Frisch
description: The marriage of Catherine Huse Lilly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Lilly of London and Essex, Conn., to Peter Osborne Frisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frisch of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye. The Rev. Sharon Chant performed the ceremony.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Andover, Mass.;
New Uses for An Old School
description: LEAD: WHEN Abbot Academy, a girls' boarding school, merged in 1973 with its neighbor, Phillips Academy, the trustees of the former boys' school began to look for a way to renovate and use three historic Abbot buildings.

title: Honoring Golf's Best
description: TWO pros who are still competing are on the list of three players who will be voted into the PGA-World Golf Hall of Fame Nov. 3. Tom Watson and Peter Thomson will be enshrined, along with the late Robert Harlow.

title: Q and A
description: On Hudson Bay

title: Fund-Raisers Give Dukakis A Huge Edge
description: Behind the crusade for money that has helped push Michael S. Dukakis to the brink of the Democratic Presidential nomination are about a dozen wealthy fund-raisers drawn to him by old friendships, Greek-American pride and a desire to participate in politics at the highest level.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Grotto in Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: THE tidal wave that swept a richness of Chinese restaurants to the county seems to have subsided.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dellwood, Wis.;
Going Upscale On the Water
description: LEAD: A UTILITY with thousands of acres of undeveloped lakefront property is building better quality housing in this central Wisconsin region, where good residential construction has lagged.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: A $27.5 MILLION program to make PATH stations more usable for the elderly and disabled has been announced by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: KABUL FAULTS PAKISTANIS ON ARMS FOR GUERRILLAS
description: Afghanistan has charged that Pakistan is continuing to allow shipments of weapons to Afghan guerrillas while Soviet troops withdraw from the country.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Seven From Vatican City to Mark the Marian Year
description: LEAD: VATICAN CITY is minuscule in size, but its numismatic issues are among the most diverse and interesting in the world. It has issued a series of seven new coins to commemorate the Marian Year.

title: THE NATION: Inflation Fears; The Economy Is Looking Brighter, And to Many That's Cause for Concern
description: THE economic news was bright last week. The Government reported that surging exports cut the United States trade deficit to a three-year low in March. The dollar firmed. Factories were busier than at any time in the last eight years. The nation's purchasing agents, who order goods for their companies, predicted, by a margin of 7 to 1, that the economy would be better in 1988 than in 1987. And virtually all economists agreed there would be no recession this year.

title: Questions of Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage. What caused this problem and what can be done to correct it?

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING: ZEROING IN ON THE HARD CORE
description: In Judge Edward E. O'Farrell's municipal courtroom in New Philadelphia, Ohio, anyone convicted of drunken driving can count on one thing these days: going to jail. That is Judge O'Farrell's rule, and it is one measure of how American society's attitude toward drinking and driving is changing, even in smaller communities where people know each other and have preferred not to make an issue of such behavior.

title: W. 64th 'Liberty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sabine Jacob Weds Lance Jon Kimmel
description: Sabine Jacob, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Willy Jacob of Wilhelmshaven, West Germany, and Lance Jon Kimmel, a son of Adele Kimmel of Forest Hills, Queens, and Irwin Kimmel of New York and Westhampton, L.I., were married yesterday in Ensenada, Baja California, Mexico. Judge Maria Eugenia Campuzana de Garcia-Cacho of the Civil Register in Ensenada performed the ceremony at Villamar Las Rosas by-the-Sea.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Providing Homes for $100,000 - or Less
description: LEAD: THE Town of Brookhaven held a lottery in March to pick 16 families who would be offered new three-bedroom colonials in Coram ranging in price from $82,000 to $85,000. Russell and Jean Bailey, who were among the 132 families who had applied, were the fourth to be picked.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Grow Versatile Tree-Form Plants
description: LEAD: STANDARD or tree-form plants like roses or bougainvilleas are eye-catchers that can be used in many ways. When placed in the center of a round bed, a standard becomes its focal point. Rows of standards along garden paths form miniature alleys that create illusions of distance, and standards are ideal tub plants to decorate a patio or to frame a doorway.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: LEO V. DONOHUE;
'Our Tax Structure Is So Unpredictable'
description: LEAD: LEO V. DONOHUE, the Democratic State Auditor, came to state government in 1945 as a messenger in the Health Department.

title: Wendy Leigh Romanoff Wed to James R. Packer
description: Wendy Leigh Romanoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bernard Romanoff of Boca Raton, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to James Ross Packer, a son of Richard Packer of Norwalk, Conn., and Joan Packer of Vail, Colo. Dr. Charles Aigen, a marriage counselor, officiated at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Inflation Worries Keep on Mounting
description: This week's numbers did little to ease the nerves of anyone worried about inflation. The most-cited measure of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, showed a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in April, in line with expectations. That works out to an annual rate of 5.3 percent, up from last year, but not too alarming. What really set off the inflation fears was the trade-deficit figure for March. It was much better than expected, declining to $9.7 billion, the lowest monthly figure in three years. Another sign of economic strength was the report that industry was operating at 82.7 percent of capacity, the highest in more than eight years. A surging economy usually raises fears of price increases and a Federal Reserve Board clampdown on the money supply.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Diego;
Luring Renters To Downtown
description: LEAD: AFTER a surge in commercial development downtown, two rental apartment complexes have been built in the last year in what had been a deteriorated marina and industrial area near the city's business district.

title: Tourists Welcome at Stamford Mall
description: FOR some time, the Stamford Town Center, the huge indoor shopping complex in downtown Stamford, has used the slogan ''Just Another Reason Why It's Worth a Trip to Town.''

title: Wide Variety on the Calendar
description: FROM classical concerts to jazz sessions and, indeed, on to ''the whole world of music,'' the next fortnight will be a busy time around the Westchester Conservatory of Music.

title: Ens. R. S. Bruner Weds Dr. Alexandra Vorhaus
description: Dr. Alexandra Nicole Vorhaus, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis J. Vorhaus 2d of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Ens. Russell S. Bruner, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Nixon Bruner of Hattiesburg, Miss. The Rev. David Cockroft of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church officiated at the Riverdale Yacht Club.

title: Bold Textiles Capture the World Of Ancient Peru
description: ''To me as a weaver, Peruvian textiles have always been humbling,'' Jack Lenor Larsen said in a walk through ''The Miracle of Ancient Peru,'' the exhibition he organized at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street).

title: Gray Goods
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE VILLAGE OF OSSINING;
Planning a Yearlong Birthday
description: LEAD: THE sky over this village last weekend was robin's egg blue with no clouds in sight and on Saturday the air rang with the rat tat-tat-tat of marching bands. Croton Avenue, Main and Spring Streets were filled with floats and balloons and children clad in the clothes of the year 1813. The parade marking Ossining's 175th birthday seemed so festive, so fun-filled, so -effortless.

title: How Builders Invent Vanity Addresses
description: REAL ESTATE, according to the old saying, is location, location, location, and now some developers are slyly cashing in on a variation of the theme.

title: POSTINGS: Mixed Use in Bridgeport
description: Officials of The Bank Mart plan to redevelop a 12-acre eyesore of underused and dormant industrial buildings that is visible from their headquarters at 948 Main Street in Bridgeport, Conn. Cupped around the end of Main Street between Interstate 95, the Metro-North tracks and docks for the Port Jefferson ferry to Long Island, the jumble of buildings makes a sad contrast with the city's recent new construction.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION was scheduled to begin last week on a 1.2-mile stretch of condominiums that will permanently alter the face of the Asbury Park shorefront.

title: Today, Armenia; Tomorrow . . .
description: LEAD: To Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the large-scale disturbances in Armenia, which resumed last week after a period of relative calm, deliver a grave message. Far more is at stake than ethnics on the outskirts of his empire who demand the annexation to Armenia of the Nagorno-Karabakh area of neighboring Azerbaijan.

title: Puckering Up
description: AN APOCRYPHAL STORY HAS IT THAT IN THE early 1950's, Joseph Haspel, a founder of Haspel Brothers, the New Orleans company that introduced washable seersucker, attended a business meeting in Florida dressed in one of his firm's new wash-and-wear suits. When his colleagues doubted the properties he claimed for it, Haspel strolled into the ocean fully clad. Late that day, he turned up at a meeting looking as crisp as a freshly pressed hankie - in the same suit.

title: A Woman and a Walnut Tree: Part II
description: IN MAY 1982, my essay, ''Twins Through Time: A Woman and a Walnut Tree,'' appeared in this section.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on April 24 about school aid to Long Island incorrectly described State Senator Norman J. Levy's position on the ''save harmless'' formula, which sustains school aid despite a decline in enrollment. He favors it.

title: Mary Beth Pendley Marries Sheldon Lavell Ray Jr.
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Pendley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan B. Pendley of New Orleans, to Sheldon Lavell Ray Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray of Monroe, La., took place yesterday at the St. Charles Avenue Presbyterian Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Dean Lindsey performed the ceremony.

title: Restaurateur Says U.S. Witness Bilked Him
description: An investor in a restaurant has charged that a Government witness embezzled $200,000 from the business and that the Federal authorities are blocking efforts to recover the money.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: I took advantage of your suggestion (Travel, Oct. 18) and stayed at the Hotel des Grands Hommes (17 Place Pantheon) for $75 a night in Paris. I enjoyed a view of the Pantheon and such riveting traffic noises as to be convinced that Parisian cars are not equipped with mufflers. In fact, such noises were ever present and make me wonder why this is not the case in New York City. RENEE FEINBERG New York, N.Y.

title: A Gallery of Sternhagen Roles
description: IN Frances Sternhagen's 33 years as a stage and, sometimes, screen actress, her performances have progressed, accordise to perfection. She paid her dues by proving versatility, reliability and competence, qualities that her reviewers may have taken for granted. As her work continues to deepen, revelatory may become the operative adjective in describing her performances.

title: Panel Opposes Toxins In Anti-Lamprey Plan
description: Plans to use chemicals to destroy Lake Champlain's fish-killing sea lampreys could harm rare birds along tributary rivers in Vermont, a state-sponsored panel of naturalists has warned.

title: High Stakes
description: HOUSE OF GAMES Starring Lindsay Crouse and Joe Mantegna (in photo), Mike Nussbaum, J. T. Walsh, Lilia Skala. Directed by David Mamet. 1987. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $89.99. Rated R.

title: Mostly Mozart Series Plans Haydn Marathon
description: Haydn will play a major part in this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center. A week devoted to his music will include a daylong, eveninglong ''Haydn Marathon,'' two concerts on original instruments conducted by Christopher Hogwood, and talks by the Haydn scholar and biographer H. C. Robbins Landon.

title: RISKY BUSINESS
description: Bravo to Susan Jacoby for her common-sense remarks on the distinctions between sex and love in her article ''Risky Business'' (Hers column, April 24). I'm delighted to hear a woman say that ''Sex may precede love, follow it or have nothing to do with it,'' and that ''Sexual experience is valuable in and of itself.''

title: Juliana Van Norden Weds Craig Wynne
description: Juliana Van Norden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Montagnie Van Norden of New York, and Craig Donald Wynne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Wynne of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Vero Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: From Key West, Key Limes
description: EXACTLY how long Key lime pie has been around no one can say with certainty, although one of the young girls rolling out pastry dough at Theresa Bakery in Key West solemnly volunteered: ''Always. Even the pirates ate Key limes.''

title: New Industry Is Growing From Neglected Seeds
description: Jan Blum grasps tiny green leaves in her fingers the way a jeweler might handle an emerald.

title: Andrew Hildick-Smith Married to Dr. Jacobus
description: At the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, N.J., Dr. Claire Hughes Jacobus was married yesterday to Andrew Hewes Hildick-Smith by the Rev. John Crocker Jr., an Episcopal priest. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David P. Jacobus of Princeton. She is a second-year resident in internal medicine at the Cooper Medical Center in Camden, N.J. Dr. Jacobus graduated from the Princeton Day School, Bryn Mawr College and the Rutgers University Medical School. Her father is a physician and the president of the Jacobus Pharmaceutical Company in Princeton. Her mother, Claire Jacobus, is an editor of manuscripts and publications in the hematology department at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

title: Long Trail Preceded Woman's Rampage in Illinois
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation knew about Lori Wasserman Dann. So did prosecutors in three states. So did her neighbors and her former husband and in-laws.

title: On Honors List, Many Noted Names
description: LEAD: THE list of artists, journalists and politicians who will be gracing Long Island's colleges in this busy graduation season reads like a Who's Who.

title: A Bar Where the Food Surprises
description: PETER'S INN in East Northport may look like a neighborhood bar, but the food is certainly not pub grub. First-timers are startled to find jalapeno pasta, carpaccio, Cajun shrimp with wild rice and lobster pasta on the menu. Mixed grill at Peter's breaks the mundane mold with filet mignon au poivre, rare duck breast in a green peppercorn and brandy sauce and a grilled veal chop. Hardly bar fare!

title: IN THE MIDDLE OF L.A.'S GANG WARS
description: THE WARM SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA sun has scarcely set on Good Friday when the shooting begins. A dark sedan glides through the dusk on West 46th Street, in the heart of the urban war zone that is south-central Los Angeles.

title: 1800's Turkish Treasure Ship Found by Greeks in Aegean
description: Greek divers have found a treasure-laden Turkish warship sunk by Greek revolutionaries in the Aegean Sea in 1822.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a decline in the elephant population in Africa misidentified Dr. David Western.

title: Poverty Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: correction
description: A listing of tourist offices on May 1 with a guide to music festivals abroad omitted Barbados. The Barbados Board of Tourism is at 800 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; the telephone number is 212-986-6516.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs, Three Ways
description: NOW that the weather has finally warmed up, soft-shell crabs are coming into the market. The most common way of cooking them is simple: dust them with flour and fry them in butter. But soft-shell crabs beget a challenge to chefs, who come up with all sorts of interesting and unusual ways to prepare them.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $335,000 90 Briary Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old brick ranch; family room, basement with kitchen and wet bar, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $5,279. New Rochelle, N.Y. $282,500 66 Linwood Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 68-year-old stucco/stone Tudor; deck, den, basement with office and separate entrance; taxes $2,780. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $325,000 11 Deerfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 64-year-old brick colonial; fireplace, basement playroom, enclosed porch, patio; taxes $3,621. Darien, Conn. $286,000 210 Middlesex Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; interior newly painted, corner lot, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,961. New Britain, Conn. $118,000 28 Barnard Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, vegetable garden, 60- by 123-foot lot; taxes $1,471. Riverside, Conn. $720,000 49 Grosset Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; at end of cul de sac, playroom with fireplace in basement, 1 acre; taxes $3,948. OTHER AREAS Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $136,000 9 Lake Park Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,500. Sayville, L.I. $175,000 54 Crosby Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old high ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,200. Millburn, N.J. $220,000 33 Greenwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, c/a; taxes $3,155.

title: American Lawyers Land on Their Feet in Tokyo
description: JAPANESE, as a rule, treat lawyers with the same affection that they reserve for trade deficits. They tend to view foreign lawyers as outright afflictions.

title: Suzanne Forelli Is Married To M. H. Aubrey, Producer
description: Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Suzanne Forelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Forelli of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Michael Hansom Aubrey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stever Aubrey of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony.

title: Yanks Exhale as Relief Comes Through
description: In the aftermath of their 11-3 belittling at the hands of the Athletics Friday night, there was a measure of embarrassment in the Yankee clubhouse. Last night, there was a measure of respect regained.

title: The Cecil Taylor Enigma Is Intact, Despite New LP's
description: Cecil Taylor has been before the public - some sort of public; he has never commanded anything approaching a mass audience, despite all his critical acclaim - for more than 30 years. Yet those who admire his music, from critics to musicians to plain fans, still grope for ways to describe it.

title: Philharmonic Sets Season For 1988-89
description: Zubin Mehta, in his 11th season as music director of the New York Philharmonic - the longest tenure of any modern conductor - will lead the orchestra in 16 weeks of its 36-week 1988-89 subscription season at Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestra has announced.

title: The Day I Quit Playing Baseball for Good
description: BASEBALL was never my best game.

title: Celtics' Tradition Looming Larger
description: ''Our Birds are Better than Yours.''

title: Acoustic Mystery Under Study
description: Some topics, though by no means negligible, do not warrant lengthy discussion, and have therefore been bundled up into the following medley of short takes:

title: Making Europe a Mighty Market
description: THE battle between Europe and ''non-Europe'' is coming to a head. With less than five years to go before a self-imposed deadline, the European Community is racing to remove the hundreds of trade barriers that bedevil its 12 member countries.

title: The Subway, Palatial and Political
description: AFTER a few days of bumping along on the official Soviet bus tour, from armories to monasteries to government buildings, visitors usually grasp what they are missing in Moscow's urban scene: the familiar traffic din of a city in motion. Travelers weary of what can be an alienating, one-dimensional view of Moscow can find relief about 200 feet beneath the streets. In stark contrast to the gray city above, the bustling, graffiti-less Metro is a subterranean sanctuary adorned with crystal chandeliers, marble floors and skillfully crafted mosaics and frescoes fit for a czar's palace.

title: Gretchen Richter Marries in Jersey
description: Gretchen Van Lear Richter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart A. Richter of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul J. Massey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Massey of Bay Village, Ohio. The Rev. Polly Kasey performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church. She was assisted by Msgr. Harold Murray, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: West Midtown Development; 15 Projects Rising as 6-Year Zoning Bonus Ends
description: A SIX-YEAR zoning bonus to allow bigger skyscrapers in west midtown ended this month amid a final push by developers, who are building 15 office and hotel projects in this section of Manhattan that had rarely seen a construction crane in decades.

title: POSTINGS: N.J. Condominiums; Converting a Mill
description: In the last decade, the developer Gordon Ash has churned out mill conversions steadily. First was Roger's Mill, a locomotive erecting shop he converted into offices and a museum. Then came Ivanhoe Mill, a flax factory turned into stores, and Union Works and Argus Mill, yarn and textile factories that are now schools.

title: Sandra Lee Shaw Is Married to Gregory R. Strong
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., Sandra Lee Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Shaw Jr. of Princeton, was married yesterday to Gregory Robert Strong, a son of Moira Strong of Titusville, N.J., and Robert Strong of Washington Crossing, N.J. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Entry Runs 1-2 in Acorn
description: Centennial Farms' entry of Aptostar and Topicount swept the first two places in the Grade I, $183,300 Acorn Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont Park yesterday. Aptostar was the winner by three lengths. In taking the Acorn, Aptostar, trained by H. Allen Jerkens, took the first leg of the New York Racing Association's Triple Tiara series. Until this year, the series was named the Filly Triple Crown.

title: In The Natural State
description: LEAD: MY MIND wasn't on driving, and the parking area came up much sooner than expected. My wife, Linda, and friend, Pete Bacinski, found reason to thank New Jersey's mandatory seat-belt law.

title: He Started By Buying A Theater
description: ALL the while Martin Kaufman was growing up in Hewlett Harbor, he was in love with show business. At Lynbrook High School, he was a self-described ''bookish kid'' who got ''pushed into debates'' and acted in school plays.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SALAD DAYS. By Douglas Fairbanks Jr. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Douglas Fairbanks Sr. claimed he had been born with ''no more paternal feeling than a lion has for his cubs.'' His laissez-faire approach to fatherhood left his son with the job of supporting his mother once she had spent the money from her divorce settlement (the older Fairbanks had ''eloped'' with Mary Pickford).

title: Music; Julio Iglesias: Romance
description: Julio Iglesias was in an unusually loquacious mood Thursday evening at Radio City Music Hall, where he opened the first of nine sold-out shows. Admitting to some nervousness, the Spanish pop star spoke of his continuing eight-year struggle to learn the English language. And in a gently rueful tone, he dismissed the image of himself as an arrogant Don Juan, saying, ''You should see my skinny legs.'' At the age of, he went on to say, he prefers singing to making love. This last confession produced a collective groan of disappointment from the women in the audience.

title: Melbourne
description: To the Editor: Julian West's piece on Melbourne (Travel, April 3) was most informative but left out one important segment under Shopping. Little Collins Street, which parallels Collins Street, is Melbourne's equivalent of New York's 47th Street insofar as opal dealers are concerned. Here are to be found black opals from Lighting Ridge as well as fire opals from Coober Pedy and stones from other mines. To go into one of the dealers' shops is a not-to-be-missed experience. Trays full of opals of all sizes and colors are brought out for choosing, and to run one's hands through them is like playing with light. The stones flash their various colors like multiple rainbows. The dealers are most willing to instruct buyers about doublets, triplets and the various qualities of the stones and their origins. And their prices are much less than what one would pay in New York or even Sydney. YVONNE R. FREUND New York, N.Y.

title: Pamela Marcus, Physician, Weds Jeffrey Erskine
description: Dr. Pamela Stacey Marcus, the daughter of Dianne Wallace of New York and Alan J. Marcus of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married last evening at the Pierre in New York to Jeffrey Allan Erskine, a son of Phyllis E. Small of New York and the late Victor Erskine. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: Same Standards For the Umpires
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Abigail Robinson Wed in Greenwich To T. M. Bowers
description: The marriage of Abigail Phipps Robinson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Robinson of Greenwich, Conn., to Thomas Michael Bowers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bowers of Greenwich, took place last evening at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Albert Ginsberg performed the ceremony.

title: Center of Russian Study Struggling in New York
description: St. Sergius High School in Manhattan, one of the few secondary schools in the nation to emphasize the teaching of Russian language and culture, is struggling to survive.

title: PITCHING A PLEASNAT SURPRISE FOR YANKS, INDIANS
description: NO one expected the Yankees to have the best starting pitching in the American League East; the starting pitching, in fact, was generally believed to be the one element that could prevent the Yankees from winning.

title: CRIME
description: An unusually deft first mystery is DEAD RECKONING by Sam Llewellyn (Summit, $15.95). Mr. Llewellyn, a British journalist, seems to know everything about yachts and racing them.

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: An overwhelming yes. I can't wait to tell my grandchildren of the exploits of great umpires like Doug Harvey, John McSherry and Dave Pallone in the banner year of '88. ''But Granddad, just how far could Strawberry really hit one in his prime, and how awesome was Gooden in 1985?'' ''Sonny, those trivial feats were nothing compared to the hundreds of exciting balks I witnessed in the summer of '88.'' KEN BROWN Brooklyn

title: New Wiring for the Information Age
description: IN 1984, with great fanfare and great expectations, the Federal Express Corporation introduced a service called Zapmail. Customers could have their documents delivered door-to-door within two hours via couriers and high-speed digital facsimile systems - fax machines. It was a novel, ingenious approach to image transmission, and forecasters were quick to predict its rosy future.

title: REACH Moves Into Passaic
description: LEAD: THE public's right to use New Jersey's ocean beaches is becoming less of an issue from season to season, says Stephen Brower, a Deputy State Attorney General, because state aid has been used to prod shorefront towns to stop playing favorites.

title: FICTION
description: THE THIRD FRIDAY. By George Bellak. (Morrow, $18.95.) Hot on the heels of the Government's insider trading cases and Oliver Stone's film ''Wall Street,'' there promises to be a spate of business-oriented novels. After all, if the business of America is business, what better place to set a crime thriller for our times than on Wall Street, where fortunes are gained and lost quicker than it takes a body to fall 32 floors? This is just how George Bellak's second novel, ''The Third Friday,'' begins, as Cy Bannerman, a financial wheeler-dealer, takes a header off the terrace of his luxury high-rise. The authorities call it suicide, but his partner, Max Roberts, doesn't think so. While proving that Bannerman received an unwanted helping hand, Roberts gets to bed several of Bannerman's former mistresses. And, less pleasantly, in the wake of a number of other murders he also becomes embroiled in a mob-controlled money-laundering scheme. Unfortunately, this only sounds exciting. Billed as ''a novel of suspense,'' Mr. Bellak's book lacks one central element of the genre: tautness. In fact, he insists on telling his story in such mind-boggling detail that eventually the eyes glaze over. At one point, the reader is even informed that Roberts attends a movie in which there are ''four car crashes, two fires, a yacht explosion, and an underwater duel with spearguns.'' However, there is a bonus in this book - what amounts to an unintentional stock tip. Not a page seems to pass without a phone call being either placed or received. Perhaps wise investors would do well to put their money in Ma Bell?

title: Land-Use Decisions Via the Ballot Box
description: FOR more than a decade, Cardinal Industries of Columbus, Ohio, has kept on its sales map a big X scrawled across the city of Parma.

title: White Horses
description: To the Editor: The article about Wiltshire and other chalk horses brings back memories of using the Uffington Horse as a navigational landmark when flying over England in World War II. Several of these figures were marked on our British air navigation charts.

title: 3d Victim Identified in Manhattan Slayings
description: Detectives investigating the execution-style shootings of three workers Friday in the basement of a plumbing supplier in Manhattan identified the last victim yesterday, but said the motive for the murders remained unclear and asked for the public's help in the case.

title: Protection Of Aquifers Starts at Pawcatuck
description: AN underground water source in the Pawcatuck River Basin has become the first federally protected aquifer in the state.

title: Shell Bacteria Kill East Coast Lobsters Near Ocean Dump
description: A disease that burns holes in the shells of lobsters and crabs has cropped up in undersea canyons north of New York City's newest and only ocean dump site for sewage sludge, prompting a Federal study of whether the dumping is harming marine life.

title: Mary Olmsted a Bride
description: Mary Graves Olmsted, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Olmsted of Wayland, Mass., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Leroy Wyatt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Wyatt of White Plains. The Rev. Cassius Webb performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit. A graduate of Williams College, the bride is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University. The bridegroom, a graduate of Williams, is a sales manager in New York for the Seven-Up Company.

title: Residential Resales

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: Given the many children who follow baseball, I think strict enforcement of the balk rule sets a good example. In a broader context, may I suggest we imprison all people who double park, jaywalk or rip off tags that say ''Do Not Remove.'' JEFF VORCHHEIMER New York

title: Military Academies Are Becoming Even Tougher on Body and Mind
description: Almost 3,000 graduates of the Military, Naval and Air Force Academies will toss their hats into the air in the next couple of weeks at West Point, Annapolis and Colorado Springs, after having finished educations that are among the most rigorous in the United States.

title: Susan Hess Marries
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., Susan Sharp Hess, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hess of Waccabuc, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Robert Upton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Upton of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley officiated. The couple graduated from the University of Vermont and completed the exchange, trade, law and language program of the American-Chinese Cultural Exchanges in Shanghai. The bride is a marketing representative at International Business Machines in New York. The bridegroom plans to begin law studies in the fall.

title: Youth Center Moving to Warehouse
description: The loft building on the western perimeter of SoHo is undistinguished: a warehouse of 1920's vintage, solidly built but fallen mostly into disuse, a lonely repository for voting booths 51 weeks of the year.

title: Cottage Industry
description: Some have come from homes where ''the parent-child bond has been tattered by years of misunderstanding,'' others from homes that ''make World War I look peaceful by comparison,'' Nan Dale, the executive director of The Children's Village, has written.

title: Taking the Business Beyond Tomato Sauce
description: UNTIL a few years ago, getting a pizza meant going to the nearest pizzeria and ordering a flat pie, topped with cheese and tomato sauce. Product diversification? You could probably get sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms, green peppers and anchovies. And in New York and a handful of other cities, sometimes you could get a thick Sicilian crust. Forget most anything else.

title: Miss Longobardo Weds L. D. Langston
description: At the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Alicia Anahid Longobardo, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Guy Longobardo of Bronxville and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Lance David Langston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Langston of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Margaret Mahaney performed the ceremony.

title: PRACTICAL Traveler; Scheduling Flights to Beat Jet Lag
description: WHEN jet lag was first named, an acquaintance of mine who affected only modish problems said that she was suffering a really bad case because she had taken the shuttle plane to Washington three times in the previous week. Of course, the worst part of jet lag - flying across time zones too fast for the body to adapt - has nothing to do with one-hour trips in the same zone.

title: Middle America Can Relax
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Julie Eckhardt Weds S. I. Allen
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly, N.J., Julia Ann Eckhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Eckhardt Jr. of Tenafly, was married yesterday to Stephen Ignatius Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Allen of Erie, Pa. The Rev. John D. Potter Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: 'Phantom' Studio Turns Out Jazz Classics
description: LEAD: JAZZ is the stuff of smoky Greenwich Village basement nightclubs, not heavily trafficked commercial streets in northern New Jersey. Yet it is here -at the recording studio of Rudy Van Gelder - that some of the greatest jazz performances in the last 35 years have taken place.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Foyt Qualifies for Indy 500: A. J. Foyt raised his fist in triumph yesterday after qualifying for his 31st consecutive Indianapolis 500. The four-time Indy winner failed to complete two qualifying attempts May 14, the first of four days of time trials for the race May 29, in a 1988 Lola, then switched to a year-old Lola for his successful effort on the third day of qualifications. The 53-year-old Texan drove the first lap around the 2 1/2-mile oval yesterday at 210.669 miles an hour, then slipped progressively to 210.605, 209.113 and 208.415 for a 10-mile average of 209.696. ''I was pretty conservative and pretty safe,'' Foyt said. ''I wasn't hanging it out, I just wanted to get in the race.''(AP) Baseball St. John's Wins Big East: St. John's won its third Big East tournament title in four years by defeating Villanova, 5-0, yesterday at Muzzy Field in Bristol, Conn. The Redmen won behind the combined four-hit pitching of the starter, Tom Singer, and Glenn Bratteng, who went the final one and a third innings. St. John's went ahead in the first when Walt Heckel singled, stole second and went to third on a throwing error. He scored on a single by Bob Lambraia, who was doubled home two outs later by Mike Weinberg. Weinberg, who was named the most valuable player in the tournament, hit a two-run home run in the third, his second in two games. His seventh-inning three-run homer on Friday night capped a victory over Villanova that set up the championship. Villanova beat St. John's in the opening round of the double-elimination tournament and was unbeaten until the final two games. Villanova was the Southern Division champion of the Big East and entered the tournament with a conference record of 16-2. The Redmen, second-place finishers in the Northern Division, had a 9-9 mark. St. John's will play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Regionals next week. Fairleigh Dickinson Tops Fordham: John Picarello lined a two-out single in the 14th inning and Michael Mongiello went the distance as Fairleigh Dickinson beat Fordham, 6-5, yesterday in the second round of the E.C.A.C. Division I tournament in New Britain, Conn. C.W. Post scored six runs in the second inning to eliminate LeMoyne, 6-1, in the opener and Hartford rode a 15-hit attack to beat Maine, 8-2, in the second game. (AP) Golf Rose Leads Colonial: Clarence Rose used a burst of birdies on the back nine to surge into a three-stroke lead yesterday in the third round of the $750,000 Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth. Rose, who lost in a playoff last Sunday and has yet to win in eight seasons on the PGA Tour, broke out of a three-way tie for the lead with a five-under-par 65 that included four birdies in a stretch of six holes on the back nine. He completed three rounds in 200, 10 under par. His three-shot margin equaled the largest 54-hole advantage on the tour this year. Joey Sindelar's 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole gave him a 67 that left him alone in second at 203.(AP) Tennis Sweden Gains: Anders Jarryd of Sweden defeated Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday to enable Sweden to qualify for the final against the United States in the $750,000 World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany. Jarryd's victory gave Sweden a 1-1 tie against Czechoslovakia, and put the Swedes into the final on aggregate points. Earlier, Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia defeated Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-4, 7-6. The United States defeated Argentina, 2-1, on Friday to gain a berth in the final.(AP) Italians Sweep to Final: Claudio Panatta defeated Lawson Duncan of the United States, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday and Massimiliano Narducci beat Pablo Arraya of Peru, 6-4, 6-1, to set up an all-Italian final in the $126,000 City of Florence tournament. Panatta earned a semifinal berth by defeating Pedro Rebolledo of Chile, 6-1, 7-6, and Narducci advanced by eliminating Jaime Yzaga of Peru, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3. (AP) Bowling Cook Wins $27,000: Steve Cook took advantage of three splits by Rod Pasteur for a 193-175 victory yesterday to win the $150,000 Professional Bowlers Association A&W Classic in Phoenix. Cook collected $27,000 for his 13th P.B.A. Tour victory. Pasteur, who earned $14,000, rolled his way into the championship game by winning twice. After Marshall Holman defeated Dave Husted, 222-199, Pasteur beat Holman, 231-148. In the semifinal, Pasteur trounced Philip Ringener, 278-173 to advance to the title game.(AP)

title: Nurse, Heal Thyself
description: NOWHERE has the current crisis in nursing been more palpable than on Long Island, where the Nassau County Medical Center has been forced to deny admission to patients because of a dangerously low nurse-patient ratio. As the shortage of nurses worsens, other hospitals, across the state as well as the country, are being compelled to limit services and to turn away patients.

title: Public Authorities, Public Competence
description: New York State Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and his colleagues in the Legislature, circling a politically wounded Mayor Koch, seem intent on blocking his plan for new public authorities to finance and repair public works. The legislators may have reason to be vexed with a Mayor who bullied legislators over issues like school aid and municipal pensions. But the proposal for new authorities deserves consideration on its merits, which are substantial and applicable beyond New York.

title: A Cocaine Link To Hepatitis
description: AFTER facing its worst siege of hepatitis in at least six years, with 74 recorded cases of the Type A virus in five months, Onondaga County in New York prepared for a return to normalcy.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Charge, Sir, Is Faulty Syntax

title:
GARDENING;
How to Grow Versatile Tree-Form Plants
description: LEAD: STANDARD or tree-form plants like roses or bougainvilleas are eye-catchers that can be used in many ways. When placed in the center of a round bed, a standard becomes its focal point. Rows of standards along garden paths form miniature alleys that create illusions of distance, and standards are ideal tub plants to decorate a patio or to frame a doorway.

title: DECLINE TO GLORY
description: THE FALL OF THE ATHENIAN EMPIRE By Donald Kagan. Maps. 455 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $39.50.

title: Ethiopia Frees 7 Relatives of Haile Selassie
description: The Marxist Government of Ethiopia today set free seven members of the deposed royal family who had been imprisoned without trial since the 1974 revolution in which Emperor Haile Selassie was overthrown.

title: In Ontario All This Town's A Stage
description: TYRONE GUTHRIE, the Stratford Festival's first artistic director, had a genius for publicity, and over the years he burnished his version of the festival's beginnings in 1953 to a fine sheen. In Guthrie's story, a boy from a bucolic Ontario town was fired by the proverbial high school English teacher with a passion for Shakespeare. The boy, whose name was Tom Patterson, came home from World War II with a naive and audacious idea - he would mount a first-class professional Shakespeare festival in sleepy Stratford.

title: A New Look at Trade
description: FOR centuries, trade statistics have tracked the course of human history. Exports and imports have documented the rise and fall of civilizations. They marked the progress, for example, of mercantile Britain and Germany as well as the emergence of the United States and Japan as industrial giants.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 22, 1988
A CONTRACT ON STALIN
description: LEAD: THE REVOLUTIONIST By Robert Littell. 467 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: No. 1 Draft Pick Goes to Clippers
description: The Clippers, the ''other'' Los Angeles team, took a step yesterday toward establishing a winning identity. The troubled franchise, which last made the playoffs in the 1975-76 season when it was still based in Buffalo, won the draft lottery and the right to Danny Manning of the University of Kansas, the college player of the year.

title: Changes at Simon Home Challenged
description: MOORLAND in Montauk has not been ''Graceland'' for Paul Simon, who has endured a number of setbacks since building his home there three years ago.

title: Anne Connors Marries James Joseph Seuffert
description: The marriage of Anne Carter Connors, a daughter of Mary M. Connors of Morristown, N.J., and Dudley Edward Connors of Rye, N.Y., and James Joseph Seuffert took place yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Donald C. Seuffert of Shrewsbury, N.J., and the late Dr. Seuffert. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward J. Dillon at the Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church in Atlanta.

title: The New Guns-and-Butter Battle
description: A HUGE gap has developed between the costs of completing military programs started during the Reagan years and the money likely to be available to pay for them in the next five years. The issue facing the next President - and Congress and the military - is no longer whether military programs must be reduced, but how much and where. The gap, which could exceed $250 billion in the next five years, exists because the rapid military buildup during the first five years of the Administration, combined with tax cuts, resulted in heavy military spending that Congress and the Administration are now unwilling to finance through tax increases. But the challenge now is to make cuts without endangering America's security or weakening its military industrial base.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Clinton Housing; Shaping Four Acres in Mid-Manhattan
description: ONE by one, in the 1980's, major development sites in ostensibly offbeat locations in Manhattan have gone into construction. The Zeckendorf Organization, as developer, seems to have made a specialty of them.

title: HARD-LINE CONTRA MAY ATTEND TALKS
description: With the cease-fire between Government and contra forces due to expire in 10 days, leaders of the two armies have announced plans to hold a possibly crucial negotiating session beginning Wednesday.

title: Rollicking Rogues
description: THE GREAT McGINTY Directed and written by Preston Sturges. With Brian Donleavy (in photo). 1940. MCA Home Video. 83 minutes. $29.95.

title: Headliners; Voice in Verse
description: Call it a case of poetic justice. In a verse written 30 years ago, Howard Nemerov poked fun at the job of poet laureate, with its long hours and low pay; last week, he was appointed poet laureate of the United States, a post created in 1985. Mr. Nemerov's poem, ''From the Desk of the Laureate: For Immediate Release,'' referred to the British laureate, who is appointed for life and is expected to chronicle important events in verse. As the American laureate, appointed for one year by the Librarian of Congress, Mr. Nemerov will be paid $35,000 to give advice on poetry and an occasional reading. The tasks are not expected to interfere with his work as Distinguished University Professor of English at Washington University in St. Louis, where he has taught for 20 of his 68 years.

title: Hungary May Name New Leader Today
description: A senior Communist Party official strongly hinted today that Prime Minister Karoly Grosz would be chosen Sunday to replace Janos Kadar as party leader. He said the Soviet Union did not have a say in the choice.

title: A MOMENT OF TERRIFYING PROMISE
description: RECONSTRUCTION America's Unfinished Revolution 1863-1877. By Eric Foner. Illustrated. 690 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $29.95.

title: 'Jesus Christ Superstar': The Singing Stands Out
description: IN 1971, two major musical versions of the Bible opened in New York. One, ''Godspell,'' by Stephen Schwartz and John-Michael Tebelak, was an adaption of the Gospel According to St. Matthew. The other was the rock opera ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, about the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.

title: Poll in Pravda Explores Soviet Attitudes on U.S.
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today that most Soviet citizens surveyed in a poll believe that relations with the United States are satisfactory.

title: Ornaments Bloom, But Nature Is Better
description: THIS is the time of year for neighborhood walks and back-street wanderings in the car. Every week brings new plants and trees into bloom. Homeowners meet nature's challenge with garden and house improvements.

title: Landmark Politics
description: Secretary of the Interior Donald Hodel has taken it into his own hands to declare Whittaker Chambers's Maryland farm a National Historic Landmark. His pitch to the conservative right is a low-water mark in landmarking.

title: A 6,000-Year Trip Into China's Past
description: You start about 6,000 years ago, in the fertile plains of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and as James C. Y. Watt, who presides lovingly over the newly installed ancient Chinese collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, can tell you, the characteristics that distinguished the art treasures of China from that of other traditions are already visible.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HAMMER, by Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. (Perigree/Putnam, $9.95.) Named in part after the Socialist Labor Party's arm-and-hammer symbol, Armand Hammer made a fortune dealing with the Soviet Union and a reputation as a humanitarian and amateur diplomat. ''Dr. Hammer has managed to turn himself into a sort of living footnote to some of the principal events of his time,'' Ted Morgan said in The Book Review last year. ''Great events seen through the eyes of a minor character have a fascination for us - we can identify with him.'' THE THANATOS SYNDROME, by Walker Percy. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) In Walker Percy's novel ''Love in the Ruins,'' a Louisiana psychiatrist uses a device called an Ontological Lapsometer to measure the sickness of souls.
