In ''The Thanatos Syndrome,'' the doctor returns from prison to find his wife and former patients acting more like computers than people. ''Though the novel's surface action spins along at a brisk thriller pace . . . the real plot, as with all this writer's fiction, chronicles the continuing battle between good and evil in a modern society where both words are out of fashion,'' Gail Godwin said here last year. ''Walker Percy has the rare gift of being able to dramatize metaphysics.'' The same publisher has also reissued Mr. Percy's first novel, THE MOVIEGOER ($3.95). CULTURAL LITERACY: What Every American Needs to Know, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) In an updated version of his attack on the progressive education movement and the pragmatist philosopher John Dewey, E. D. Hirsch Jr. (aided by Joseph Kett and James Trefil) has added more than 300 items to his list of facts and concepts he believes any American should be embarrassed not to know. ''This is a delightful book,'' Robert Stevens said here last year. Mr. Hirsch, he added, ''is probably wrong. He certainly is iconoclastic; but he should be read.'' DUE EAST, by Valerie Sayers. (Berkley, $3.95.) When a 15-year-old South Carolina girl gets pregnant and the father kills himself, she announces that she is having a virgin birth. Last year our reviewer, Jack Butler, said this novel ''just wraps itself around you.'' Valerie Sayers, he added, ''has that rare knack of appearing simply to open up a reality, as if it were so clear before her eyes that she doesn't have to create it so much as invite us in.'' THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Volume One: 1902-1941. I, Too, Sing America, by Arnold Rampersad. (Oxford University, $9.95.) When this first installment of Arnold Rampersad's biography of the black poet Langston Hughes was published in 1986, our reviewer, Gwendolyn Brooks, said the book ''sparkles when it is involved with Hughes's devotion to his craft,'' and that she eagerly awaited Volume Two. THE HOUND OF HEAVEN, by Glover Wright (Jove/ Berkley, $3.95.) When a priest crucified by the Vietcong is resurrected, some Roman Catholics think the Second Coming has occurred; others believe the devil has returned. In 1986, Newgate Callendar said here that the author of this thriller ''asks us to believe a great deal. But . . . so well has he integrated theology and action, so clear and sensitive is his writing, so scary are the final pages, that 'The Hound of Heaven' goes right to the top in its genre.'' THE LAUNCHING OF MODERN AMERICAN SCIENCE: 1846-1876, by Robert V. Bruce. (Cornell University, $12.95.) The author won this year's Pulitzer Prize for history for his story of how science in the United States evolved from an intellectual backwater into the powerful presence it is today. Last year Rosalind Williams said here that while ''the general reader will find the book tough slogging,'' it succeeds admirably in providing ''a wealth of information on the people and institutions of mid-19th-century American science.'' THE LOTUS FLOWERS, by Ellen Bryant Voigt. (Norton, $7.95.) Living in Vermont and contemplating her Southern childhood, Ellen Bryant Voigt has written poems about a woman ''poised at mid-life between the gravitational pull of the past and its 'cruel perfected music' and the flaming world of the present,'' Edward Hirsch said here last year. ''Against her losses, Ms. Voigt poses a loving and fiery attentiveness to her world, balancing grief and exhilaration.'' BEVERLY: An Autobiography, by Beverly Sills and Lawrence Linderman. (Bantam, $4.95.) In her rise to the heights of the opera world, the soprano Beverly Sills never waited for destiny to hand her any favors. Last year our reviewer, Dale Harris, said her memoirs recount ''a classic American success story'' in which ''forgiveness, clearly, is not one of her weaknesses.'' BAD GUY, by Rosalyn Drexler. (PAJ Publications, $7.95.) A rather unconventional psychotherapist invites Jesus Allendez, a 15-year-old sociopath who has raped and murdered his elderly neighbor, into her home as a live-in patient. Rosalyn Drexler ''is an exotic taste,'' one reviewer said in 1982. She escalates ''actions to the absurd, by surreal exaggeration that is deft and believable because it never quite loses touch with reality.'' BEST INTENTIONS: The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry, by Robert Sam Anson. (Vintage, $6.95.) In 1985, just after graduating with honors from Phillips Exeter Academy, a 17-year-old Harlem youth was shot and killed near his home by a plainclothes policeman. Robert Sam Anson ''is interested in exploring . . . the irony that someone who had already traveled so far would end up lying on a sidewalk so close to where he had grown up, a cop's bullet in his belly,'' Robert Coles said in The Book Review last year. He praised the author for his ''well-told, melancholy'' attempt to unravel a troubling story.

title: Hempstead Strives to Change Image
description: RENOVATION, revitalization, renewal. These three R's, the goals of the Village of Hempstead nearly a decade ago, seem closer to achievement now than they were then.

title: Carla Woody Is Wed To David A. Riemer
description: Carla Renee Woody, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Woody Jr. of Roselle, N.J., and David A. Riemer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Riemer of Marblehead, Mass., were married last evening at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Erik Kolbell of the United Church of Christ and Cantor Michael Terry officiated.

title: Ex-Governor, Once in Prison, Runs for Place in Congress
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton, who served time in a Federal prison, announced today that he is running for Congress.

title: Highly Rewarding Bartok by Kocsis
description: When Bela Bartok received his training in the last decade of the 19th century, the distinction between performers and composers was not as great as it is today. Gifted students were trained in both disciplines, and Bartok, like Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev, was a piano virtuoso as well as a composer of genius. Similarly, he created an impressive body of works for piano and orchestra, largely for his own use in appearing before the public. For most listeners, these pieces are perhaps overshadowed by his immensely popular Concerto for Orchestra, his six string quartets and his often-heard Violin Concerto.

title: Dance; Balanchine's 'Bugaku' By the City Ballet
description: The heroic dancers of the New York City Ballet might have been expected to look exhausted after the unimaginable work put into the company's just-ended American Music Festival. But the dance was fresh and interesting on Wednesday, the second night of the company's return to repertory in its spring season at the New York State Theater.

title: Minnesota Lawmaker Denies Misusing Aides
description: Former aides to Representative Gerry Sikorski, Democrat of Minnesota, have accused him of requiring them to perform personal services and to campaign for him while on the Government payroll, according to two published reports today.

title: L.I. Sound: Profiles by Computer
description: SCIENTISTS are collecting thousands of soil, water and marine-life samples in an effort to develop computer models of Long Island Sound.

title: SHRINKS AND SHRUNKEN HEADS
description: THE JEALOUS POTTER By Claude Levi-Strauss. Translated by Benedicte Chorier. Illustrated. 250 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Fresh New Spirit in Bayonne
description: LEAD: BAYONNE is known for its many churches, its petrochemical industry and, according to the Chamber of Commerce, for being the second-safest city in New Jersey. But even its civic boosters do not claim Bayonne as a mecca for innovative dining, and so it got our attention when readers mentioned a new restaurant there serving imaginative Italian food.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: National Offers Free Waivers And Soft Tops

title: AMERICA'S RED ARMY
description: Jim Robbins's article, ''America's Red Army'' (April 17), provides strong evidence that the Pentagon is finally preparing its soldiers for the next war rather than the last one. What is not explained is why the National Training Center is located in the Mojave Desert. In every campaign of every war, topography, terrain and climate have played an important role. Yet, our military planners ask their forces to train against the Soviet Army on a ''rocky, moonscape desert.'' Such an environment is very much unlike that of northern and western Europe, where any major armored and infantry conflict with the Red Army is most likely to take place. This disregard of geography is not encouraging. KENNETH T. JACKSON Professor of History, Columbia University New York, N.Y.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BATTLE AND THE BACKLASH: The Child Sexual Abuse War. By David Hechler. (Lexington/ Heath, $19.95.) We are accustomed in our time to seeing dark issues like child sexual abuse dragged out to face the light of day. The journalist David Hechler contends, however, that this is one subject threatened with a return to the closet.

title: Miss Perry Wed To Bruce Welty
description: The Annisquam (Mass.) Village Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Rachel Lyman Perry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Curtis Perry of Lincoln, Mass., and Annisquam, to Bruce Edward Welty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Thompson Welty of Concord, Mass., and Isle of Springs, Me. The Rev. Fayette Severance performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Connecticut Tremblors Defy Research on Cause
description: From last Sept. 17 to Oct. 22, more than 175 small earthquakes occurred near the town of Moodus, Conn. Many were accompanied by sounds like gunshots; the strongest vibrated a van.

title: Orioles Forged Own Tradition
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INTELLECTUAL ORGIES WERE NOT FOR HIM
description: DIARY Volume One. By Witold Gombrowicz. Edited by Jan Kott. Translated by Lillian Vallee. 232 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: When Moscow Prepares to Receive Visitors
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMENCEMENTS
description: Marist College

title: On Your Own, At Least a Bit, in Moscow
description: EVERY TIME I see a red and white tourist bus cruising across Moscow, passengers staring vacantly out the window as a guide recites a numbing litany of useless facts about the city, I want to throw a roadblock in its path, jump aboard and tell the visitors they're missing one of the great dramas of their time.

title:
THE REGION: Route to the Bench;
A Career Launched at Howard Johnson's
description: LEAD: Richard J. Bartlett, a former Chief Administrative Judge of the New York State court system, now in private practice in Glens Falls, is among the people who think judges should be appointed, not elected. At a bar association conference on that issue this month he recalled how he himself became a judge:

title: Taxi Panel Head Quits for a Job in Business
description: The chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, Gorman Gilbert, resigned last week.

title: Complaint Delays County AIDS Center
description: LEAD: PLANS of the Westchester County Medical Center to open a unit to treat AIDS patients have been put on hold by the State Department of Health, which is investigating a complaint that the hospital discriminated against a carrier of the disease.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
The Better to Hear Them
description: LEAD: Supervisor William C. Harding of Somers has proposed that members of the Somers Town Board and Planning Board use small, clip-on microphones during their meetings so that their words, as well as their actions, can be more clearly weighed. He said that he had received ''numerous complaints'' from residents who have found the meetings a strain on their ears.

title: Beware of Greeks Wearing Lifts
description: AT A CLANDESTINE meeting of the Attention-Getting Headline Writers Society, the subject of Michael Dukakis was discussed in detail (''Punchy Headscribe Gang Secret Confab Targets Duke,'' as one of them reported to me in his characteristic patois).

title: MAKING SURE DOCTORS GET ENOUGH SLEEP
description: It was 4 A.M., nap time for a second-year resident who had been on duty at a Long Island hospital for 20 hours. As she dozed off, her beeper sounded. A patient was having a seizure. She gave him the drug he needed, keeping close watch on his heart monitor. To stay awake, she sang along with the radio in his room.

title: A CONSERVATIVE WITHOUT COMPROMISE
description: RIGHT FROM THE BEGINNING By Patrick J. Buchanan. Illustrated. 392 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: J. B. Carroll Weds Tacey B. Phillips
description: Tacey Belden Phillips, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Gorham Phillips of Montclair, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to James Bernard Carroll, a son of Col. and Mrs. Bernard G. Carroll Jr. of El Cajon, Calif., and Lahaina, Hawaii. The Rev. Dr. J. Yorke Peeler Jr. performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: James S. R. Rose And Amy Harless Wed in Greenwich
description: Amy Elisabeth Harless, a daughter of Mrs. Ricardo Deambrosio of Lyme, Conn., and Montevideo, Uruguay, and Theodore James Harless of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Stillman Rockefeller Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Harden Rose of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Jill Wing Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Ann Jaquett Wing, the daughter of Mrs. Rodney G. Aller of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Morgan Wing Jr., to Harold Daniel Heck Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heck of Easton, Conn., took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Swanson performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert Robbins, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Report Reveals Higher Acidity in Eastern Streams
description: A survey of streams in the Eastern United States by the Environmental Protection Agency shows that the acidification of fresh water is much more widespread than was previously known.

title: SOVIET DISMISSES TWO PARTY CHIEFS IN TENSE REPUBLICS
description: The Communist Party leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan were dismissed today after fresh outbreaks of ethnic tensions in the two southern republics, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Women at War in Comedy of Menace
description: Joan Schenkar often says she writes plays out of her dreams, and some seem born of nightmares. ''The Lodger,'' at the Theater for the New City, is a light reverie. But this nifty little number, which Ms. Schenkar wryly calls ''a comedy of menace,'' may not make everyone who wakes from it long to dream again.

title: TALKING: Managers; Keeping Control in A Co-op
description: CO-OPS commonly turn over many day-to-day responsibilities for running their buildings to managing agents. An agent, for instance, ordinarily is empowered to write checks against a co-op's bank account, to collect maintenance charges, to pay routine bills and to keep corporate records, including such vital papers as proprietary leases.

title: Outdoors; Atlantic Salmon Are Returning
description: THOSE who labor on behalf of the Atlantic salmon, which many regard as the world's supreme food and game fish, have always struggled with the difficulty of how to enlist broader public support of their effort.

title: State Waste Disposal Praised
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH New Jersey is in the throes of a waste-disposal crisis, it is far ahead of the rest of the country in solving the problem, according to four New Jersey officials who spoke at a recent conference in Washington.

title: In a Word, The Festival Was a Workshop
description: The New York City Ballet's American Music Festival presented 22 world premieres, 14 earlier ballets set to music by American composers, one company premiere and the first performance at the New York State Theater of a work (danced again by students) created originally for the School of American Ballet.

title: BOMBER BARONS AND ARMCHAIR WARRIORS
description: LEAD: IRON DESTINIES, LOST OPPORTUNITIES The Arms Race Between the U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R., 1945-1987. By Charles R. Morris. 544 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 23 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect location for one concert by the Atlanta Symphony. The concert, on Wednesday, will be at Carnegie Hall, not Avery Fisher Hall.

title: The Holocaust's Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's Who in the Conflict
description: Cambodian Government

title: Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
description: This obsessive calling of balks must come to a discernible stop. GENE SHALIT Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Need for Foster Parents Rises as Their Numbers Dwindle
description: THE two-year-old addition on the northern Westchester home was supposed to have been a playroom, but it is hard to play around the four cribs that fill the room.

title: Why Do N.B.A. Champions Not Repeat?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: POSTINGS: Town Houses; 86 Units In North Hills
description: Construction is scheduled to begin in the fall on Forestwood, an 86-unit town house complex in North Hills, L.I., which has had two development teams.

title: TRUCK RAMS A RESTAURANT
description: A truck lost its brakes and rammed a restaurant today, injuring five people. The truck was traveling down an incline in heavy rain at 6 A.M. when the brakes failed. It crashed into Frenchy's Restaurant, caving in the front and injuring Patrolman Kenneth Racine.

title: Zambians Kill Mozambicans
description: Zambian troops crossed into Mozambique this week in pursuit of right-wing Mozambican rebels, destroying two bases and killing 73 of the guerrillas, a Secretary of State for Defense and Security, Alex Shapi, said today. Mr. Shapi said the cross-border attack followed a raid by the Mozambique National Resistance on the Zambian border village of Chadiza. Eight Zambians were killed and five wounded in the rebel raid.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Police Memorial
description: LEAD: The county is planning to honor police officers who died in the line of duty with a monument to be erected next October in the plaza in front of the Westchester County Courthouse.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE bottle bill has been revived in Trenton, but not in the State House. Instead, proponents of mandatory deposits on beverage containers have taken their cause across town, to the Mercer County Courthouse, where on May 9 they presented petitions signed by 35,600 county residents calling for a county deposit system.

title: Short Shortcuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Johannes Lichtenstein, 62, Importer, Dead
description: Johannes Lichtenstein, a wine consultant and importer, died after a heart attack Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE FEMINIST BIBLE
description: The spring of 1953 was an exhilarating time for the publisher Alfred A. Knopf. His freshly printed American edition of ''The Second Sex'' by Simone de Beauvoir made the New York Times best-seller list and appeared on the way to being considered the most ambitious and brilliant study of woman ever written. For similar reasons, the period was a highlight in the life of a zoology professor, H. M. Parshley, even though his name as translator and editor of ''The Second Sex'' had inadvertently been omitted from the volume's dust jacket. But then, Alfred Knopf had told him earlier that ''translating has always been dog's work - never well paid and seldom if ever bringing the translator any glory.''

title: Correction
description: A correction in this space last Sunday misidentified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time. The record is 43.86 seconds; it was set by Lee Evans of the United States in the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE ISLAND By Gary Paulsen. 202 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $13.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Marjorie McCourt Weds
description: At St. Virgil's Roman Catholic Church in Morris Plains, N.J., Marjorie Fay McCourt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. McCourt of Morris Plains, was married yesterday to Thomas Savage Clement, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. J. Clement of Gladwyne, Pa. The bride, a graduate of the University of Rhode Island, is a medical representative in Morristown, N.J., for Abbott Laboratories. The bridegroom, a regional sales training specialist for Abbott in Andover, Mass., graduated from Washington College.

title: Anne Carswell Wed to Benjamin Tang
description: The marriage of Anne Carswell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carswell of Brooklyn, to Benjamin B. Tang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Tang of San Francisco, took place last evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Justice Richard W. Wallach of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Bruins Can't Believe Their Effort Hasn't Paid Off
description: After the Boston Bruins dropped the first two games to the Edmonton Oilers in the series to decide a Stanley Cup champion, Rick Middleton stood in a jammed locker room hallway with a faraway look.

title: MCA DRAWS ON SOME FAMOUS OLD NAMES
description: MCA classics has been making its presence felt on many fronts since it entered the classical-music fray not long ago. Musical comedy, operetta and original and licensed recordings from abroad have been among its ventures, along with some of the earliest entries in the midpriced compact disk field. Now, MCA Classics is trying another venture in the budget-price field, drawing on some famous labels from the early days of LP.

title: New Ambassador to Israel
description: President Reagan will nominate William Andreas Brown, the Ambassador to Thailand, to succeed Thomas R. Pickering as Ambassador to Israel, the White House has announced. Mr. Pickering has been the Ambassador to Israel since 1985. The White House announcement, which came Friday, did not disclose Mr. Pickering's new assignment. Mr. Brown, 57 years old, was a diplomat in Israel from 1979 to 1982.

title: A Perfect Mismatch: Separates With Snap
description: STYLE and function have been pairing up nicely of late in the form of suits that come in contrasting colors and fabric patterns. The ensembles are at once more relaxed and more eye-catching than the traditional matching suit.

title: POSTINGS: Wetlands on the Cliffs; Office Delay
description: The Lucky-Goldstar Group of Seoul, South Korea, whose 29 companies are involved in everything from oil exploration to video cassette recorders, is trying its hand at building in Bergen County and finding it heavy going.

title: Haiti Is Called Growing Hub for Drug Smuggling
description: Haiti has joined Panama as a growing drug-smuggling center, and members of its secret police are forcing their way into the distribution of crack in Florida, witnesses told a special Senate hearing today.

title: Keeping Tabs on Adjustable-Rate Loans
description: INTEREST rates are edging up, bringing new allure to adjustable-rate mortgages. In April, 48 percent of new mortgages were adjustable, compared with 22 percent in April 1987, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Borrowers are attracted by introductory rates that are often dramatically lower than those of fixed mortgages and by the knowledge that if rates go back down, they won't be locked into a high rate, said Ray Durn, a real estate lawyer in Cleveland with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.

title: Tracking the Creative Process
description: THERE are sculptures, prints and photographs by nine artists in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson's ''Progressions.'' But the objects are less the subject of the show than the ways in which they are made. Most of the items are backed up by drawings, molds, early impressions, written notes - whatever it takes to demonstrate the stages in a given technique.

title: Centers Help Make Parenting Easier
description: LEAD: WHEN Peggy Kushman's son, Scott, began having nightmares several months ago, she was not sure if he was screaming to get her attention, or whether the bugs, rats and spiders in his dreams were the manifestation of something troubling the 4-year-old.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CHILDREN'S THEATER

title: WHAT WE FELT, WHAT WE REMEMBER
description: THE INVENTION OF MEMORY A New View of the Brain. By Israel Rosenfield. Illustrated. 229 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: Kate Lind Bride Of Mark Geoffroy
description: The marriage of Kate Humbird Lind, a daughter of Mrs. Carl C. Ulstrup and John D. Lind, both of New York, to Mark Lee Geoffroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Geoffroy of Portland, Ore., took place yesterday at the Old Meeting House on the Hill in Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. Dorothy Greene, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If the deficit doesn't improve that's bad, but if it does, we have another problem. We're statistical hypochondriacs.'' - Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank on the trade deficit.

title: Guatemala Silences a Dissident TV Station
description: The Government of President Vinicio Cerezo has shut down a television station that criticized it during a news report.

title: Foreign Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: STREETSCAPES: Long Island City Power Station; A 1906 Railroad Landmark on the Queens Shoreline
description: THE city's Hunters Point development project - a combination housing-retail-office complex for the Queens shoreline just above Newtown Creek - will begin its preliminary reviews in June.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage. What caused this problem and what can be done to correct it?

title: Shore, With New Rules, Gets Ready
description: LEAD: FROM Sandy Hook to Cape May, officials of the Shore resort industry are taking a brighter view of this season's prospects while trying to dispel a pall left by last year's pollution troubles.

title: Companies Find Profits In China
description: THE president of the Farmstead Telephone Group might be based in Glastonbury, but he is doing a lot of business in Beijing.

title: Polish Business Group Gives Up Its Efforts to Obtain Legal Status
description: Members of an association of small private businesses have abandoned efforts to legally register the association, citing obstacles put up by the authorities.

title: Risen Star Outruns Filly in Preakness
description: Risen Star, a son of Secretariat, benefited from a rough early duel between Forty Niner and Winning Colors to win the 113th Preakness Stakes today at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Swinging John Henry's Hammer
description: ON THE AFTERNOON BEFORE the Dance Theatre of Harlem departs for its first tour of the Soviet Union, Arthur Mitchell, D.T.H.'s founder and artistic director, is in his closet-sized office, dancing. Jammed in among a desk, some chairs and a staircase, he stutter-steps and swivels, his arms whipping jubilantly back and forth. ''DAH-da-da-DAH-da-da-DAH,'' he says, mimicking the rhythms of the finale of ''John Henry,'' a ballet commissioned for the First New York International Festival of the Arts, which makes its world premiere at Manhattan's City Center Theatre on June 28. For Mitchell, once a principal dancer for the New York City Ballet, it's his first solo choreography since 1976.

title: Rightists in U.S. Aid Mozambique Rebels
description: A small group of wealthy American businessmen, ideological conservatives and evangelical Christian missionaries have joined forces in an effort to aid guerrillas of a right-wing movement fighting the nominally Marxist Government of Mozambique.

title: The Arts Get Ready for Summer
description: LEAD: SINCE Long Island is a ''Summer Celebration of the Arts'' - and local arts organizations swear it is - let the festivities begin. And they will today when the Long Island Arts Express, a train provided by the Long Island Rail Road, leaves the Garden City station after a 10:30 A.M. send-off of family entertainment.

title:
MUSIC;
Potential Stars In Operatic Scenes
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH officially begun only 15 months ago, the Opera/Music Theatre Institute of New Jersey, under the enthusiastic direction of the Metropolitan Opera basso Jerome Hines, has distinguished itself as one of the country's top operatic training programs.

title: Hefty, Hefty, Hefty
description: ALL that William (Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears has to do is lose a pound a day so he can play. A slip of the lip by Coach Mike Ditka on Friday let out the previously guarded secret of Perry's weight problem. Ditka said, ''I don't want a 377-pound defensive end'' while discussing switching Perry from defensive tackle to end. Ditka said his timetable will get Perry's weight down by the time the Bears open their training camp July 20.

title: Colorado Man Faces Charges In a Threat Against Jackson
description: A stockyard worker is free on bond after being arrested on Federal charges that he made a death threat against the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: In New Jersey, Town Confronts Teen-age Drinking
description: It was the night when a high school-age friend of one of her sons showed up at her door drunk and driving his father's car that Joan Houlihan decided something had to be done.

title: Social Events; Harlem Celebrations
description: Harlem at the Plaza . . . May 23 - The Studio Museum in Harlem, which is devoted to the preservation and exhibition of the art of black Americans, will celebrate its 20th anniversary at a benefit at the Plaza. Bill Cosby with be the master of ceremonies, and Representative Charles B. Rangel and others will receive awards. The black-tie evening starts with cocktails at 7, followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $300, from 212-874-4098. . . . and a Harlem School May 23 - Founded 22 years ago, the Children's Storefront at 57 East 129th provides an education for about 100 children through the seventh grade. A benefit to raise money to expand the school will start with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres from 5 to 7 P.M. in a tent in front of the school. A soul-food dinner at All Saints Church will follow, and then entertainment provided by Cab Calloway, Ben E. King, Misha Dichter, the ARC Gospel Choir, the Dinizulu African Dancers and Drummers and the Double Dutch Jump Ropers. The Dalton School will provide bus transportation from the armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street. Tickets, $300, from 212-879-3977. Briefly Noted: May 23 - Senior students at the School of American Ballet will display their talents at a 7 P.M. performance at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 66th Street, followed by dinner. Tickets, $250, from 212-877-0600. May 23 - Channel 13 will celebrate its 25th anniversary at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria, starting with cocktails at 6:30. Barbara Cook, Lena Horn, Richard Kiley, Bill Moyers, William F. Buckley and, of course, Big Bird are a few of the celebrities scheduled to appear. Tickets, $500, from 212-614-0400. May 23 - A benefit for Citymeals-on-Wheels starts with cocktails at 7:30, followed by a comedy show and dinner at the Star Fish Grill at the South Street Seaport. Tickets, $100, or $50 for cocktails and show only, from 212-577-1758. May 23 - A benefit for the Manhattan Theater Club will feature cocktails at 7, dinner at 8 and a 9:30 cabaret with Broadway performers. Tickets for the benefit, at the New York Hilton, are $200, or $50 for the show alone, from 212-645-5590. May 23 - Morgana King, Karen Akers, Tammy Grimes, Al Carmines, Justin Ross, Michael Valenti and Michele Bautier are among those expected to perform at a benefit for the Theater Off Park. Cocktails at 7:30 will be followed by a buffet dinner and the show at Ci Ristorante, 101 Park Avenue (41st Street). Tickets, $100, from 212-627-2556. May 25 - From 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. there will be a buffet, dancing, movies from the 1930's and 40's and an auction of furs, trips and jewelry at the Guggenheim Museum. Tickets for the benefit evening for the museum, $75, from 212-360-3557. May 25 - The Isabel O'Neil Foundation for the Art of the Painted Finish will hold its annual auction benefit and dinner at Sotheby's starting with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $250, or $100 for reception and auction alone, from 212-348-2120. Two at the Boathouse May 25, 26 - Founded in East Harlem in 1895, the Union Settlement now serves about 8,000 people a year with educational, recreational and job-training programs. Two black-tie benefits for the settlement will be held at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. On Wednesday starting at 7:30, seven carriages will take guests from 72d Street and Fifth Avenue to a dinner-dance. On Thursday a younger crowd will be offered boat rides during a cocktail dance from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Tickets, $175 on Wednesday; $60 on Thursday, or $70 at the door, from 212-360-8818 or 212-360-8817. Sleep-Over Benefit May 26 - The Norwegian Cruise Line's newest ship, the 42,000-ton, 1,500 passenger M. S. Seaward, will be the setting for a black-tie party to benefit the United States Olympic team. After champagne at 6:30, guests will board the ship at Pier 88, on the Hudson River near 55th Street, and dine and dance until 1 A.M. Guests may stay overnight and have breakfast aboard the ship, which will not leave its berth. Tickets, $750, which includes the overnight stay, or $500, from 212-398-7436. Harmony at the U.N. May 26 - More than 100 performers including Melba Moore, Rex Smith, Nell Carter, Heather MacRae, Jack Coleman and Chuck Mangione will perform selections from ''Hair'' in the United Nations General Assembly Hall at a benefit for Unicef. Guests will also hear material from a new score entitled ''Hair for the Next Generation.'' Cocktails start at 6:30, followed by the performance and a formal dinner-dance. Tickets, $250 for the 7:45 P.M. performance alone, $500 for cocktails and the show and $1,000 for entire evening, from 212-581-2571.

title: Congress Bill on Hate and Violent Acts Gains
description: A bill requiring the Government to keep figures on violence that is motivated by prejudice is on its way to the Senate, complete with a requirement for tabulating crimes against homosexuals.

title: Dance; Focusing on Ice Skating's Choreographic Aspect
description: The affinity between ice skating and theatrical dancing came to the fore again in an unusually creative evening presented on Friday night by two Canadians, Gary Beacom and Gia Guddat. The program also featured new solos by John Curry, the former British Olympics champion.

title: Ellen Kennedy Becomes Bride Of Timothy Flick
description: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ellen Elizabeth Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Kennedy of Bedford, and Timothy J. Flick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Flick of Lancaster, Pa. Msgr. Thomas Gartland officiated.

title: Soviet-Run Stores For Souvenirs
description: ''Not bad at all,'' Oblonsky said, tweaking the quivering oysters out of their pearly shells with a silver fork and gulping them down one after another. ''Not bad at all.'' $ ? - ''ANNA KARENINA''

title: Antietam
description: To the Editor: I read with interest ''Serene Now, Antietam'' (Travel, April 10) and searched in vain for mention of my great-great grandfather, Col. Harrison S. Fairchild, leader of the 1st Brigade (9th, 89th and 103d New York regiments), whose men forded Antietam Creek bypassing Burnside Bridge, routing a South Carolina regiment.

title:
MUSIC;
An Eclectic Mix, Through a Contemporary Prism
description: LEAD: ''For me, Alfred Schnittke is probably the greatest living composer of our time,'' the pianist Vladimir Feltsman confidently told an interviewer recently. ''That does not mean I ignore Ligeti, Messiaen or Cage, but I find Alfred's music is particularly interesting. And in the Soviet Union, he has inherited the stature that Shostakovich had before his death.

title: Recreational Dreams: Parks on Paper
description: LEAD: PICTURE yourself floating down the Windsor Locks Canal in a tour boat, or camping out on West Rock Ridge in New Haven, or spending the day at Silver Sands Beach in Milford.

title: Officer Charges Remarks Led to Demotion
description: A police lieutenant who faces demotion and a pay cut after criticizing what he said were racist attitudes here is suing town officials.

title: A Top State Deserves Professional Sports
description: THE Connecticut sports fan is homeless. I, for example, must support teams from either Massachusetts or New York. The only legitimate Connecticut pro sports franchise is the Hartford Whalers, who finished in fourth place. Connecticut is one of the richest states in the nation and could easily finance a beautiful arena for any sports team willing to play. Why hasn't it happened?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SWAPPING. By Shirley Lowe and Angela Ince. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) In the autumn of 1983, the separate worlds of Felicia Harman, a beautiful London actress, and Ann Forester-Jones, a model housewife, fall apart - and together. After Felicia's husband, Donald, kicks her out for having an affair with Ann's husband, Antony, where can Felicia go but off to Antony in the country?

title: Romancing the Stone
description: BERND MUNSTEINER is a third-generation gem cutter from Germany who devised a technique of cutting stones that bears little relation to the traditional faceting of gems. He gouges deep vertical, horizontal or asymmetic cuts into the back of a stone so that mysterious planes are revealed when the cuts are viewed through the smooth, unbroken surface. He then sets the stones into sculptural rings, pendants, pins and bracelets of gold or platinum.

title: Hoya in Preview
description: EVEN if Alonzo Mourning is not among the 12 members of the United States Olympic basketball team that will be chosen, the teen-ager is getting a lot of experience at the Olympic trials in Colorado. He is also getting a good look from the United States Olympic coach, John Thompson, who will become Mourning's coach at Georgetown this fall.

title: Kathryn Cordes Wed To Gianfranco Chicco
description: The marriage of Kathryn Cordes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Woglom of Norwalk, Conn., to Gianfranco Chicco, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Chicco of Kalamazoo, Mich., and Lodi, Italy, took place yesterday at the hotel Maxim's de Paris in New York. The Rev. Michael B. Easterling, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Prince Twice Is Still Prince Charming
description: In one of the most enjoyable and peculiar career moves of the 1980's, Prince has completed two albums so far this year. The first, ''The Black Album'' (no catalogue number, cassette only), was announced and then, just before its planned release, withdrawn from the market on Prince's orders. Albums that had been pressed in Great Britain were scrapped, but not before bootlegs of ''The Black Album'' had begun to circulate. (A cassette copy was slipped into my back pocket one night at an ill-lit belly-dance club.) Within months, its replacement arrived: ''Lovesexy'' (Paisley Park/Warner Brothers 25720, album, cassette and CD).

title: Opponents Mass on Video-Terminal Bill
description: EMPLOYERS in Suffolk County, contending that a bill to regulate video-display terminals in the workplace has already driven away prospective new companies, are waging a furious lobbying campaign to defeat the measure.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
The Battle for a Hackensack Preserve
description: LEAD: SINCE the turn of this century, 23 acres of thick woodlands in the northwest corner of Hackensack have survived untouched. The empty tract on Fairmount Avenue is a rare site in this densely populated city, and it is such an anomaly in Bergen County that conservationists have been campaigning for the last two years to protect it.

title: New Rules on Benefits For Disabled Veterans
description: President Reagan has signed legislation making it easier for hundreds of thousands veterans to receive disability benefits for exposure to radiation from the World War II atomic blasts in Japan or from nuclear test explosions.

title: Ms. Whittingham, Editor, Is Married
description: Mary Elizabeth Whittingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Whittingham of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John and St. Mary to Charles Frederick Goehring, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Goehring of Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Robert Paul Mohan performed the ceremony.

title: RANGERS' KILGUS IS PERFECT UNTIL 8TH
description: Paul Kilgus pitched seven perfect innings before Gary Gaetti led off the eighth with a double for Minnesota's only hit as the Texas Rangers beat the Twins, 3-0, tonight. Gaetti hit a hard line drive to left-center field on a 1-0 pitch. Kilgus (6-3) walked Gene Larkin, the next hitter, but struck out Kent Hrbek and got Tim Laudner to line into a double play. The left-hander struck out two, walked two and hit a batter.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A MASQUE BY MILTON When the New Haven Colony was founded in 1638, John Milton was putting the finishing touches on ''Comus,'' a masque he had been commissioned to write in celebration of the appointment of the Earl of Bridgewater as Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland. At 3 P.M. today, to comemmorate the 350th birthday of New Haven, the Yale Center for British Art is to present a concert reading of the Milton work with the original, 350-year-old incidental music composed by Henry Lawes.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HEATHERTON SINGS During more than 50 years in show business, Ray Heatherton has attracted his share of different audiences: Big Band fans who loved him when he was lead singer with Paul Whiteman (Bing Crosby was in the back-up trio); Broadway musical enthusiasts who heard him introduce ''Where or When'' in ''Babes in Arms''; radio listeners who recognized the ''Ipana Troubadour''; baby boomers who knew him as ''The Merry Mailman'' and, currently, cocktail loungers who frequent the Garden City Hotel, where he holds forth nightly. Today, Mr. Heatherton, who was classically trained, returns to his first love in a ''Spring Program of Songs'' in the hotel's Grand Ballroom. In addition to show tunes, he will put his still vibrant tenor (he's 78 years old) to work in 16th- and 17th-century folk tunes that he rarely gets to sing. The concert is at 3 P.M. Tickets, at $5, may be reserved by calling 621-8850. NIGHT NATURE

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Failure on the Plains; FOR SALE: GAS PLANT, NO PROFITS
description: The nation's first commercial synthetic fuels plant, a $2.1 billion complex, looms over the prairie near Beulah, N.D. Every day, 16,000 tons of lignite coal stripped from nearby mines is fed into a maze of pipes and throbbing machinery, where it is converted into enough gas to supply a city of nearly 250,000 households.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab. In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier. In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage. What caused this problem and what can be done to correct it?

title: Adding Warriors to the Drug War
description: The politics of drugs suddenly alters the mood of Congress. Alarmed by rising public concern over drug-related crime and corruption, members are rushing to enlist the Defense Department in a literal war on drugs. Both the Senate and the House propose using the military to stop drug smugglers.

title: HOME IS WHERE THE ART IS
description: WITTGENSTEIN'S MISTRESS By David Markson. 240 pp. Elmwood Park, Ill.: The Dalkey Archive Press. $20.

title: Dance; 'Bayadere' Double-Header at the Met
description: That the leading roles of ''La Bayadere'' can be interpreted in several different but equally valid ways was made evident Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House when American Ballet Theater offered two performances of this 19th-century classic about ancient India.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Highland Park
description: LEAD: WHILE it covers just 1.8 square miles, Highland Park, set on a bluff overlooking the Raritan River, has different faces. Its serene visage is on display along streets shaded by tall maple trees and lined with well-kept homes, where the sounds of children at play stream out of half-open windows.

title: DATA BANK: May 22, 1988
BEST SELLERS: MAY 22, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York. 2 2 11 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 3 3 5 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 4 4 5 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 5 5 29 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 6 12 2 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 7 7 10 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family. 8 15 3 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. 9 10 14 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 10 6 10 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 11 1 FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) A Detroit police detective on the trail of a series of crimes with its roots in the 1960's. 12 8 7 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) What ensues when a New York socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 13 1 PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.) An overture to the five-volume science fiction saga about the Foundation empire. 14 9 11 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 15 * 13 4 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 3 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the celebrated performer. 2 4 5 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 2 23 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 4 3 54 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 5 5 5 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 6 15 4 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former spokesman. 7 25 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 8 9 4 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 9 6 16 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) The fortunes of great nations. 10 7 28 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) Ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 11 1 TELL IT TO THE KING, by Larry King with Peter Occhiogrosso. (Putnam, $16.95.) Anecdotes about celebrities by the radio and TV talk show host. 12 10 6 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 13 11 7 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life and times of the New York lawyer and political figure Roy M. Cohn. 14 13 18 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 15 8 5 WINFIELD, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Norton, $16.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee outfielder. 16 * 14 7 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 46 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 7 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 * 4 4 BEING A WOMAN, by Toni Grant. (Random House, $17.95.) Balancing feminism and femininity. 4 14 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) On gaining and losing weight. 5 3 7 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program. 6 * 20 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes. 7 * 5 138 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) WHERE I'M CALLING FROM: New and Selected Stories, by Raymond Carver. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The great gift of this realist (no minimalist he) is the beauty of his best stories, in which a sort of bafflement is the buffer against very ordinary lives. THE GREENLANDERS, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf, $19.95.) A folkloristic tragedy of 14th-century Norse life at the edge - of change, in particular, and how they couldn't and/or wouldn't. WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY, JR.: Patron Saint of the Conservatives, by John B. Judis. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A solid, thoughtful portrait that shows a politically more serious man of private generosity and secret warmth: a gentleman in spite of himself. REVELATION, by Peggy Payne. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) This first novel, about a doubting minister, is just hokey enough for its own good, and proves that the author has the real thing: you want to find out what is going to happen. KATHERINE MANSFIELD: A Secret Life, by Claire Tomalin. (Knopf, $22.95.) An eloquent new telling of a sad old story involving neither saint nor bitch but a bewitching enigma who tried on names and moods like so many costumes. THE COLLECTED POEMS OF OCTAVIO PAZ: 1957-1987, edited by Eliot Weinberger. (New Directions, $37.50.) This homme de lettres, first and foremost a poet, offers a subtext in which the city is the site of historical catastrophe and Utopia an erotic feast. CONVERGENCES: Essays on Art and Literature, by Octavio Paz. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) An excellent collection of essays by a masterly presence in the dialogue of Latin American culture - elegantly translated by Helen Lane.

title: Young Performers in Free Showcases
description: BEFORE they scatter for summer vacations, dozens of Connecticut's finest young soloists and groups will be showcasing their talents in free concerts, two this afternoon and another next Sunday.

title: County's Libraries Reach a New Milestone
description: ''WESTLYNX'' has arrived. This is the Westchester Library System's new centralized, automated circulation-control network that will eventually give librarians immediate access to an on-line data base of updated information about every title held by 37 out of 38 public libraries in the county. The White Plains Public Library belongs to a separate system.

title: INSIDE
description: Welsh Onions, Revived

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 8 about political developments in Singapore incorrectly described a statement by eight detainees charging police mistreatment.

title: Discriminating Against the Dead
description: IT HAS been illegal for some time in New York City to discriminate against handicapped people. In January 1987 a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan extended the legal protection to the dead as well as the living.

title: Ornery - And Proud of It
description: MY MATERNAL grandmother, Annie Sparks, lived with our family during the while I was growing up. When I came home from school, after having made a detour to the kitchen to pour a glass of milk and fix a thick peanut butter sandwich on easy-to-tear white bread, I would go up to her sitting room. She would put aside her crossword puzzle - which she did in ink - and tell me stories about our family.

title: Reviews/Film; 'World Gone Wild'
description: Mad Max mania is the guiding force behind ''World Gone Wild,'' which opened Friday at the Warner theater and was greeted by only a curious few. At the very beginning of this standard-issue post-apocalyptic nightmare, a group of machine-gun-toting choirboys arrive at a desert commune full of over-the-hill hippies and proceed to mow down almost everyone in sight.

title: Soviet-Run Stores For Souvenirs
description: THE stock in the shops changes little from year to year. There are fanciful lacquered boxes, sunny amber jewelry, brightly painted wooden bowls, warm fur hats, vodkas of varying flavors and matryoshkas, the traditional nested wooden dolls. Even the mostly indifferent and occasionally rude service that characterizes Beriozkas, Soviet state-run stores accessible only to foreigners with hard currency, seems to be a constant.

title: Laura S. Schwed Weds M. G. Sirico
description: At St. George's Episcopal Church in New York, Laura Sanxay Schwed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Schwed of New York, was married yesterday to Michael George Sirico, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Sirico of the Bronx. The Rev. Gerald G. Alexander performed the ceremony.

title: DON'T CRY FOR HIM
description: LEAD: THE PERON NOVEL By Tomas Eloy Martinez. Translated by Asa Zatz. 357 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: Peanuts and Pepper
description: ''The Ballplayers have been here for hours,'' writes the poet and essayist Donald Hall, ''for batting practice and pepper and shagging outfield flies. . . . We arrive and settle with score cards and Crackerjack and peanuts and Schlitz and hot dogs.'' So it is at major league ball parks before every game, a unique atmosphere captured by Scott Mlyn and Louis Rubin in their new book ''Before the Game'' (Taylor Publishing Company, $13.95). There is anticipation, but no reason to hurry. Part of every game is what happens before it.

title: At Electronic Emporiums, It's the PC Pie
description: IT used to take at least 30 minutes to make a pizza and far longer to deliver it. So, calling pizza a ''fast food'' was a bit of a misnomer.

title: In Afghanistan, Communists Stand Alone and Divided
description: ADDRESSING the first brigade of Soviet troops to withdraw from his country last week, President Najibullah of Afghanistan offered expressions of confidence about his Government's ability to survive. But he also appealed to Afghan Communists to ''consolidate the unity of our party.''

title: IRAN IS ALIENATING LEBANON'S SHIITES
description: An increasing number of Lebanon's Shiite Moslems, among whom Iran has enjoyed wide popularity, have become hostile toward Teheran, which they blame for relentless factional fighting in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

title: For Those Who Like It Hot
description: THAI cuisine was a natural to succeed Cajun as the hot trend. As American appetites have been energized for spicy foods, the need was met by Mexican, then Sichuan and Hunan, followed by Cajun and now comes the incendiary cooking of Thailand.

title:
INVESTING;
Looking for Value in the Blue Chips
description: LEAD: THINGS have not looked so glum for blue-chip stocks in a long time. Despite strong earnings, shares in the large-capitalization companies - many of which led the market's advance for the last four years - lagged behind the smaller-company shares in the first quarter of 1988.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 24 about a record-setting human-powered flight across the Aegean Sea referred incorrectly in some copies to the hometown of one standby pilot. The pilot, Greg Zack, is from Wilmington, N.C.

title: Questions About Sterling Forest
description: INTENSITY is probably the last feeling evoked by the pristine lakes and deep woods of Sterling Forest, but the peace that surrounds this magnificent woodland straddling the New Jersey-New York border belies the intensity of interest now being generated over the forest's future.

title: Dallas Papers Settle Suits
description: The Dallas Morning News and The Dallas Times Herald have settled their lawsuits accusing each other of fraudulent circulation practices.

title: Violence Flares in West Bank
description: Violence erupted in the occupied West Bank today as the Israeli authorities opened schools that were closed for four months in East Jerusalem. The schools were reopened in an attempt to restore normal life to the city.

title: Tanner Dismissed By the Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves dismissed Manager Chuck Tanner tonight and named Russ Nixon, a manager in their minor league system, to replace him.

title: Altman Agency Tapped For Sara Lee Projects
description: The Sara Lee Corporation of Chicago has selected William Altman Advertising, a $5 million shop specializing in the arts, to handle advertising for its corporate affairs division. The agency, which also has the Metropolitan Museum account, will promote arts and philanthropic events sponsored by Sara Lee.

title: State Convention Is Disrupted
description: Georgia's Republican state convention adjourned in chaos Saturday after supporters of Pat Robertson shouted down speakers.

title: Peter V. Busatti, Tournament Director, 57
description: Peter V. Busatti, director of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Chrysler-Plymouth Classic tournament, died of cancer yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 57 years old and lived in Amawalk, N.Y.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Investment Strategy Of a Bass Draws Praise
description: LEAD: Five years after starting the investment group that bears his name, Robert M. Bass, the third brother of the four who make up the prominent investment family in Fort Worth, Tex., has hit full stride.

title: Mr Gasket Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an $838,000 gain from an acounting change.

title: Judge Rules on Koppers Bid
description: A Federal judge ruled on Friday that Beazer P.L.C.'s $1.69 billion bid for the Koppers Company could be completed if its financing were guaranteed, thereby meeting Federal stock-margin rules.

title: Japan Group To Offer Arts Prizes
description: A Japanese art society long associated with the imperial family has announced the creation of international prizes for artists that are likely to become among the most lucrative awards of their kind in the world.

title: Review/Ballet; A Revival of Antony Tudor's 'Gala Performance'
description: One of the funny things about funny ballets is that not all were originally meant to be funny. Antony Tudor's ''Gala Performance,'' which American Ballet Theater revived Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a curious case in point.

title: Hong Kong Bank Denial
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation and Midland Bank P.L.C. are not discussing setting up joint headquarters in London and Hong Kong, George Cardona, manager of corporate public affairs at Hongkong and Shanghai, said Saturday. He was commenting on a report by the Reuters news service on May 20 in which bankers and analysts were quoted as saying that such a plan would give the Hong Kong bank a safety net after the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to China in 1997. Mr. Cardona said Midland had begun managing Hongkong Bank's properties in Britain ''and this may have given rise to the report of a joint headquarters, but Hongkong Bank is not discussing moving its headquarters.''

title: Chairman of Payless Scorning Edelman Bid
description: David Stanley, chairman and chief executive of Payless Cashways Inc., thinks little of the announcement by an investor group led by Asher B. Edelman that it may seek control of the big building materials company that is based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: TV Notes
description: Minnelli's Triple

title: Stalin Protest Is Broken Up In Lithuanian Capital Square
description: Authorities broke up a gathering of about 300 people at a main square in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius today, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: Fountain Powerboat Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An End to Seasons in Book Publishing
description: As long as anyone can remember, autumn has been the big season in book publishing, the season to unveil the blockbuster novel and the talked-about nonfiction book.

title: Technical Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Moyers and a Sage Seek Meanings
description: Talk about old fashioned! ''Moyers: Joseph Campbell and the Power of Myth'' is Stone Age television: six hours in which Bill Moyers and Mr. Campbell talk to each other and hardly ever get out of their chairs. Is this boring? Sometimes it is; most of the time it is not. Pay attention and you'll be engaged. The series begins on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Celtics' Mr. Clutch Downs the Hawks
description: Red duffel bags were being lugged out of the tiny dressing room as blue and orange duffel bags were being lugged in. The Atlanta Hawks were out and the Edmonton Oilers were in, as the only visitors' room in the Boston Garden had to serve double duty in the basketball-hockey doubleheader here today.

title: Staying Dry
description: There was enough rain in the Northeast this week to draw comparisons with the Flood. At the Big East baseball tournament in Bristol, Conn., the man who played Noah was a groundskeeper, 59-year-old Anthony Guerriero, who will retire this year as Parks Department Group Leader at Muzzy Field. Guerriero's devotion to service may or may not have had something to do with divine instruction, but he managed to turn a swamp into the baseball equivalent of Mount Ararat. Somehow the tournament, even with rain delays and postponements, muddled through.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Shabuoth, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: With President of Union Ailing, Teamsters Face a Power Struggle
description: A divisive struggle is unfolding in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters over who will succeed Jackie Presser as head of the nation's largest union.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 Karoly Grosz replaced Janos Kadar as head of Hungary's Communist Party. Mr. Kadar, whom the Soviet Union installed as party leader in 1956, was elected to a new post that is meant to be ceremonial. Page A1 Man in the news: Karoly Grosz, the new head of the Hungarian Communist Party, has shown political skill and adaptability, overcoming a reputation of stolid conservatism. A6 A fear of radiation persists in Kiev two years after the fire at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant. People in the Ukrainian capital and other cities are worried about the long-term consequences. A1 Three Afghan garrisons have fallen along the border with Pakistan in the face of attacks by heavily armed guerrillas. The garrisons have been weakened by the withdrawal of Soviet troops. A1 The mood is fearful in Afghanistan. Three rocket attacks since the beginning of May have killed more than 40 in Kabul, the capital. People expect the war to continue even after Soviet troops withdraw. A12 How to oust Panama's leader from power has created a rift within the Reagan Administration. Some White House officials oppose a plan to drop drug charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. A1 Panama's leader may keep power indefinitely if he chooses, according to diplomats and Panamanian politicians. General Noriega is moving to consolidate his regime and weaken his opponents. A3 The fort at El Castillo, Nicaragua, was built to protect the colonial capital from pirates. But the sleepy outpost on a bend in the San Juan River, accessible only by boat, is now largely forgotten. A4 Debate on a trade bill in Canada begins tomorrow when the Government introduces legislation in Parliament needed to put the agreement with the United States into effect. The debate is expected to be bitter. D1 A severe economic crisis in Zaire persists despite renewed efforts by the Government to correct endemic corruption and mismanagement of the country's natural resources. A8 Reporter's notebook: At Sikh temple, uncertain song returns A5 Gorbachev, in interview, sets upbeat summit mood A13 National A14-16, B6-8 Choosing a new teamsters president to succeed Jackie Presser is dividing the union's leadership. Mr. Presser's poor health, including a diagnosis of brain cancer, has increased speculation that he will retire. A1 A bill on long-term health care is nearing a vote in the House of Representatives. The proposal, which would mainly benefit the elderly, has provoked a dispute between two powerful committee chairmen. A16 Jimmy Swaggart preached for the first time since he lost his credentials as an Assemblies of God minister. The evangelist said the scandal that led to his absence from the pulpit for three months was behind him. A15 Alternatives to imprisonment are being developed by many states confronting prison overcrowding and the high cost of incarceration. The programs are similar to ideas that were tried and largely discarded a decade ago. A14 Utopia, Tex., is close to perfect in the opinion of some of the 350 people who live there. But they concede it is not exactly what Sir Thomas More pictured in his work about the perfect society. A14 The decline in stock trading volume has created a new worry, that the stock market lacks liquidity and is more vulnerable to shocks. Wall Street fears that the market could become even more volatile. D1 Politics B7 Kitty Dukakis passionately supports the political career of her husband, Michael Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential candidate. But she has concerns of her own, and her excitability is often seen as a complement to her husband's cool demeanor. A1 Vice President Bush's school ties, as much as political philosophy, have played an important part in the efforts of a group of businessmen who raised $23 million for his Republican Presidential campaign. A1 Reporter's notebook: the bicoastal political season B7 Washington Talk B6 Mouthpieces to powerful have principles, too Regional B1-5 The killer of a Federal judge was identified as a retired New York City police officer, officials said. Charles L. Koster apparently killed Richard Daronco in revenge for the judge's dismissal of a lawsuit. A1 Calm in Pelham, N.Y., was shattered by the murder of Judge Daronco. Residents of the village, which is less than three miles from the Bronx, said it seemed as though an element of New York City had intruded on Pelham. B4 Citizen activism against crack in New York City has caused some experts to fear that the rise in rage against drug dealing in many neighborhoods may lead to increased violence. B1 Teachers who lack full qualifications run almost half of New York City's day-care and Head Start classrooms, according to a study, raising doubts about how well poor children are being prepared for school. B1 New York State's budget shortfall will be greater than $300 million, Governor Cuomo said, adding that it was too soon to say how much higher. He said he had not decided how to make up the shortfall in the $28.4 billion budget. B3 Tax agents raided a flea market in Yonkers, N.Y. The state agents issued citations and confiscated property from vendors, who are required to charge sales tax and turn it over to the state. B2 Fire devastes dreams and history in Cohoes, N.Y. B1 Continental opens new airline terminal in Newark B2

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., an international air freight forwarder, appointed R. Peter Zimmermann senior vice president and chief finacial officer. He assumes the duties of Alfred N. Tolan, executive vice president and chief financial officer, who will continue as a consultant.

title: Dodd, Mead Appointment
description: Jonathan Dodd has been appointed president of Dodd, Mead & Company, the publishing house has announced. A fifth-generation member of the family that has owned the concern for more than 140 years, Mr. Dodd joined it in 1958 after graduating from Yale and has served as vice president, publishing director and director of subsidiary rights. The company also announced last week that Kay Radtke, formerly vice president of corporate marketing, had been named associate publisher.

title: Using Arts To Help Heal The Mind
description: ''Sometimes, when I'm playing music, I can see another healthy person being formed - there's a light ahead,'' said Richie, a stocky, gentle man of 48 years. At an unusual and struggling Manhattan clinic, Richie has found a kind of peace from his chronic depression through art therapy.

title: Gasoline Prices Stable
description: Retail gasoline prices were steady in the past two weeks, according to a survey of about 12,000 service stations throughout the United States. The average national price for a gallon of gasoline on May 20 was 100.26 cents, just three-hundredths of a penny less than the average for May 6, said Trilby Lundberg, who oversees the twice-monthly Lundberg Survey of gas prices.

title: Zaire, the Manager's Nightmare: So Much Potential, So Poorly Harnessed
description: A drop of sweat slipped onto his brow, perhaps from the heat, perhaps from nervousness, as Nakambo explained how lucky he was to find a job as a private school teacher that pays $10 a week.

title: Uniquack III Rides to the Voters' Rescue
description: This year's college graduates were freshmen in high school when Ronald Reagan became the 40th President, and they will be in their middle 30's, or thereabouts, at the turn of the century.

title: INSIDE
description: Zaire: Potential Unfulfilled Zaire has immense potential and natural resources - as well as a reputation for being one of the world's most egregious examples of economic mismanagement. Page A8. New Wall Street Worry The low trading volume of recent weeks has resulted in a stock market that lacks liquidity, which could make stocks even more volatile. Page D1. Celtics Gain in Playoffs Larry Bird had 20 points in the fourth quarter as the Boston Celtics captured their basketball playoff series with Atlanta. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: In Pelham, Grief and Warm Memories
description: This village of 6,800 people in Westchester County is less than three miles from the Bronx. But the quiet in the streets, the broad lawns and the fact that most everyone seems to know most everyone else typify life ''like it is in upstate little towns,'' said Anthony Giacovelli as he left Mass this morning at the Church of St. Catharine here.

title: Texaco-Icahn Accord Seen
description: An agreement to end Carl C. Icahn's promised proxy fight against the management of Texaco Inc., and to drop the company's suit against Mr. Icahn, may be announced today.

title: Review/Concert; Celtic-Tinged Songs of Paul Brady
description: In 1980 Paul Brady moved from Irish folk music to more personal songwriting. He came up with a style that occasionally draws on traditional Irish storytelling but more often exalts private feelings to metaphorical heights, like an Irish Jackson Browne. Two of his songs, ''Steel Claw'' and ''Paradise Is Here,'' were recorded on multimillion-selling albums by Tina Turner - his main exposure in the United States. Among Irish listeners Mr. Brady has a fervent following. When he performed solo at Town Hall on Thursday, his audience hung on every note; listeners also sang him ''Happy Birthday,'' which made him blush - it was his 41st.

title: Japan's 1% Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Layoffs Start to Rise As Merger Wave Subsides
description: With the wave of retailing mergers beginning to subside, their effect is now being felt hard by those who work in this people-intensive industry. The number of people displaced from jobs is expected to be the largest in a long time because of the concurrent mergers, divestitures and internal restructurings at some of the nation's largest retailing companies.

title: Gandalf Technologies reports earnings for 13wks to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A One-Night Stand
description: Paul H. Nitze, the arms control negotiator for the United States, is scheduled to view Paul H. Nitze as portrayed by an actor in a one-night stand this evening of ''A Walk in the Woods'' at the Library of Congress.

title: Visualization: Does It Provide an Edge?
description: INCREASING numbers of athletes are turning to a sports psychology training technique known as visualization to sharpen their competitive edge. The technique involves mentally rehearsing for a competition, playing ''movies'' in the mind over and over of a superb past performance or the ideal performance.

title: Miss Greenfield Weds Thornton David Lewis
description: Ellen Greenfield and Thornton David Lewis were married yesterday at the Explorers Club in New York by Rabbi Burton Aaron Siegel.

title: Capt. John Stanley Marries Jane Kheel
description: The marriage of Jane Meredith Kheel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Kheel of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Capt. John Richard Garrett Stanley, U.S.A.F., the son of Valerie A. Stanley of Pinckney, Mich., and Everett E. Stanley of Westminster, Md., took place yesterday at the Thomas Law House in Washington. Judge Julia Cooper Mack of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals performed the ceremony.

title: A New Career, in Sales, For Old Cartoon Stars
description: YOU need a celebrity to sell a product. How about one of America's most famous businessmen? Granted, he is no Iacocca, but he is loved by the public, will not charge much, has been married to the same woman for 55 years, has a fun-loving 54-year-old son and a 47-year-old daughter, and certainly will not embarrass your company. His name is Dagwood Bumstead. Suppress the guffaw. Vlasic pickles may be close to an advertising campaign featuring the well-known gastronome in the fall, according to a spokeswoman for the company's advertising agency. Embassy Suites Hotels also might utilize Chic Young's comic creation, and one of the nation's leading antacid manufacturers is close to signing him on, says his licensor, King Features Syndicate.

title: The Age of Security
description: Assassination was a quaint idea when ''The Manchurian Candidate'' was first released in 1962, evoking places like Sarajevo and names like Czolgosz. Last week's chilling news of a plot against the life of Jesse Jackson showed again how common public violence has become over the intervening 26 years. That may be why the movie, recently re-released, strikes 1988 audiences as so plausible. Plausible in all major respects, that is, except one: the remarkable absence of security.

title: Northland Cranberries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are not available because the company went public in August 1987.

title: Fear of Chernobyl Radiation Lingers for the People of Kiev
description: Judging by Kiev's bustle and the vigorous chestnut flowers that spiral upward from its trademark trees, the city is flourishing two years after the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant drove away its children and its peace of mind.

title: Review/Theater; Prison, the Heartland And Other Subjects
description: In an evening of one-acts presented by the Working Theater at Intar Stage II, four playwrights have an opportunity to work out their dramatic problems. None of the plays can yet be considered a forward step for the author.

title: EFI Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $43,603 from a tax benefit for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $155,000 for the year.

title: Review/Rock; A Raucous Beat From a Hendrix Fan
description: The beat was the biggest thing on stage at the Ritz Thursday night for Jesse Johnson's show. Large as a passing ocean liner, and a lot more maneuverable, it filled the club and overwhelmed Mr. Johnson's guitar playing and singing. If any one thing was the point of the music, it was.

title: Horse Racing; Hot Debate Follows a Spirited Race
description: The Preakness is over, but the controversy lingers.

title: Marie Stoess Is Wed To Mark J. Schwartz
description: The marriage of Marie Louise Stoess, the director of business travel marketing at American Express, to Mark Jonathan Schwartz, an associate in corporate finance at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, took place yesterday. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated at the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: Hawks Cannot Contain Celtics' High-Flying Bird
