description: Kevin McHale repeated today what has been said many times before, ''Larry Bird just won't let you lose.''

title: Again, States Turning to Alternatives To Costly and Overcrowded Prisons.
description: Almost desperate to come to terms with overcrowded prisons and the high cost of incarceration, many states have turned to alternative penalty programs that are similar to ideas that were tried and largely discarded a decade ago.

title: Charles Sweeps Seniors Event
description: Bob Charles of New Zealand registered another virtually errorless round and captured the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative tournament today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods April Wednesday Merchandise Trade First Quarter Thursday G.N.P. First Quarter Corporate Profits First Quarter Friday Personal Income April

title: Oilers Close In On Title
description: The Edmonton Oilers were right where they wanted to be throughout the game, and their discipline put them in position to attain their fourth Stanley Cup by a novel method, a sweep of the opposition.

title: Consultants Criticized by Agency Side
description: ALVIN A. ACHENBAUM, a former ad agency executive turned consultant, came under heavy attack from a high advertising industry executive last Friday for what he purportedly has been doing to reduce agency compensation.

title: New Air Terminal, but Old Problems
description: Continental Airlines, seeking to regain consumer confidence, today opened its new terminal at Newark International Airport, calling it the most technologically advanced airline terminal in the world.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Herbalife International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Convest Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Zero Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Question Box
description: QUESTION: Have two or more members of the same team ever scored 40 or more points in a regulation game in the National Basketball Association?

title: Cajuns Ask Minority Status
description: A measure granting minority status to Cajuns has been approved by the Louisiana House of Representatives over the objections of black lawmakers who say the measure threatens black economic development, Cajuns are descendants of French settlers expelled from Canada who settled in the steamy bayou country of south Louisiana in the 1750's. The Louisiana Almanac estimates the number of Cajuns in the state between 200,000 and 300,000. The state's population is about 4 million.

title: In Kabul, Rising Fear and Cynicism
description: Near a row of carts piled high with onions, rhubarb and peppers from the surrounding countryside, two friends were talking in a crowded downtown bazaar the other day about the uncertain future of Afghanistan when all Soviet soldiers finally leave.

title: Ransom Wilson, Flutist, Receives Alabama Prize
description: The flutist Ransom Wilson is the recipient of the first Alabama Prize for outstanding work in the arts awarded by three Alabama newspapers owned by The New York Times Company. The prize, consisting of a $10,000 cash stipend and a Tiffany etched glass bowl, was presented to Mr. Wilson at a ceremony Friday night in Gadsden, Ala. Among the groups Mr. Ransom has appeared with are the New York Virtuosi, Solisti New York, the Flint (Mich.) Symphony and the Tuscaloosa (Ala.) Symphony Orchestra.

title: The Life of the Club Pro Can Be a Winning One
description: TRADITION is not kind to David Glenz the third weekend in May. It is that time every year that the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station, N.J., where Glenz is the head professional, stages one of the biggest events on its social calender: a member-guest tournament that includes 184 players.

title: Classic Auto Accessories of North America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Utility Bidders Named
description: Samuel Belzberg, the Vancouver investor, is among the bidders for part of the British Columbia Hydro and Power Corporation, the provincial government said Saturday. The company is a government-owned utility with annual revenues of about $2 billion (Canadian). The government said Pacific Rim Gas Inc., a unit of the Hong Kong and China Gas Company Ltd., is one bidder for Hydro's mainland gas division, which distributes natural gas in the Vancouver area.

title: Market Place; Utilities Favored For High Returns
description: COMMON stockholders have generally received higher returns from electric and telephone utilities over the last 16 years than from unregulated industrial corporations, a study by the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners has found.

title: Jordana Pomeroy, Student, Marries
description: Jordana Pomeroy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Harris Pomeroy of New York and Garrison, N.Y., and Tyler Gregory Anbinder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Anbinder of Washington, Conn., and New York, were married yesterday by Rabbi Bruce Goldman at the Terrace Restaurant atop Butler Hall at Columbia University.

title: Citizen Anti-Crack Drive: Vigilance or Vigilantism?
description: When the crack business struck East 13th Street in Manhattan last year, neighbors stepped in where government had failed: they began citizen patrols, staged undercover drug buys and made citizen arrests without the help of the police.

title: Giorgio Almirante, Italian Neo-Fascist, Dies at 73
description: Giorgio Almirante, who had a minor role in Mussolini's last government and was a founder and longtime leader of Italy's small but vocal neo-Fascist party, died today. He was 73 years old.

title: Jeanne Nyland Is Married To Lloyd Anthony Doran
description: Jeanne Nyland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Donald Nyland of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Lloyd Anthony Doran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Doran of Annandale, Va. The Rev. Daniel Davidson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Holy Name Chapel of the College of New Rochelle.

title: Infringements on the Right Not to Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Irving's Choices and the Lure of the Stage
description: She could be heading off to Spain to accompany her husband, one of the most successful movie makers in history, on location with his next blockbuster.

title: The Ways Writers Are Weathering The Strike
description: It is that time in May when, ordinarily, television writers are expectantly awaiting the news about scripts they have turned in for the networks' fall television shows. Instead, the 9,000 striking members of the Writers Guild of America on both coasts will be expectantly awaiting the news today from a 2 o'clock meeting in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: Caribbean Officials Criticize Outside Pressure on Panama
description: The foreign ministers of the Caribbean nations closed a two-day meeting here late Saturday by calling for an end to foreign invervention in the affairs of Panama.

title: Man in the News; Hungarian Up From Bureaucracy; Karoly Grosz
description: Karoly Grosz has become the chief of the Hungarian Communist Party largely because the country's stagnating economy is believed to require radical changes. And that fact is a measure of his political skill and consummate adaptability.

title: When a Woman Is Driven to Kill Her Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Cindy Bernhard Married
description: Cindy P. Bernhard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bernhard of Putnam Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph V. Taibi, a son of Rita Taibi and Joseph S. Taibi, both of Ozone Park, Queens. Arthur Burstein, a town justice in Putnam Valley, performed the ceremony at the Garrison (N.Y.) Golf and Country Club. The bride, a graduate of the State University at Albany, is the news systems manager at The New York Times. The bridegroom is a New York City police officer.

title: El Castillo Journal; A Crumbling Fort Sleeps On, Haunted by History
description: No edifice in Central America has seen more drama than the crumbling fortress that sits atop a bluff overlooking this strategic bend in the San Juan River.

title: Kitty Dukakis Lends Emotion To Politics but Keeps Identity
description: Kitty Dukakis does not slip easily into the fixed and adoring stare perfected by generations of political wives. She is a toucher, a talker, a woman who laughs easily and gives orders with equal gusto.

title: Rise Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEVERAL GARRISONS ARE SAID TO FALL TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: Afghan Army garrisons along the Pakistani-Afghan border, weakened by Soviet troop withdrawals, are rapidly crumbling in the face of assaults by heavily armed guerrillas, Afghan rebel officials and Western diplomats say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Wadkins Surges to Victory: Lanny Wadkins came from five shots back with a 65 to take a one-stroke victory yesterday in the Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth. Wadkins finished at 270, 10 under par. The 18th victory of his 18-year PGA Tour career was worth $135,000 from the total purse of $750,000 and pushed his earnings to $447,465 for the year. Mark Calcavecchia and Joey Sindelar tied for second with Ben Crenshaw at 271. (AP) Texan Wins Travis Tournament: Randy Sonnier, a 40-year-old pilot from Houston, defeated William Hadden of the New Haven Country Club yesterday to successfully defend his title in the 78th Walter J. Travis Memorial Tournament at the Garden City Golf Club on Long Island. TENNIS Narducci Wins in Florence: Massimiliano Narducci defeated Claudio Panatta, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4, to win the $126,000 City of Florence tournament. Narducci earned $18,680 for winning the tournament. Panatta received $9,340.(AP) Sweden Clinches World Team Cup: Kent Carlsson handily defeated Aaron Krickstein, 6-4, 6-3, to give Sweden an unbeatable 2-0 lead and the title in the $750,000 World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany. Sweden won the title for the first time in the 11-year history of the tournament.(AP) Austrian Upsets American: Unseeded Barbara Paulus of Austria upset second-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-4, 5-7, 6-1, to win the $100,000 Geneva Open for her first Grand Prix title. (AP) HORSE RACING Posen Takes Saranac Stakes: Woody Stephens returned to New York after his disappointing day at the Preakness Saturday to send out Posen to a three-quarter-length victory over Sunshine Forever in the $122,600 Saranac Stakes at Belmont Park. Posen, a 3-year-old, won for the third successive time since being switched to the grass. The son of Danzig and Michelle Mon Amour, bred and owned by Henryk De Kwiatkowski, took the lead after five furlongs and ran the mile on a yielding turf course in 1:38 2/5 under Don Brumfield. Sunshine Forever finished well for second. Blew By Em was third. TRACK AND FIELD World Record in Shot-Put: Ulf Timmermann of East Germany set a world record of 75 feet 8 inches in the men's shot-put at an international meet yesterday at Canea, Crete. The throw by Timmermann, 26 years old, surpassed the mark of 75-2 set by Alessandro Andrei of Italy at Viareggio, Italy, on Aug. 12, 1987. (AP) BASEBALL Two Victories for Fordham: Paul Darrigo hit a double and later scored on a sacrifice fly in the 10th inning yesterday to lift Fordham to a 3-2 victory over Maine yesterday in the E.C.A.C. Division I tournament at New Britain, Conn. In a night game, Darrigo scored the winning run on a double by Chris Faccio in the bottom of the 10th inning to give Fordham a 6-5 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson. In another game, Jeff Bagwell had four hits to lead the University of Hartford to a 10-6 victory over C. W. Post.(AP)

title: Met Takes 'Ring' Cycle Into the Recording Studio
description: Down on West 34th Street, cars were honking and trucks were double-parked and the afternoon seethed with the raucous bustle of midweek in New York City. But up on the seventh floor of the Manhattan Center, in the old barrel-roofed ballroom that serves as the city's premiere recording studio for classical music, a very different atmosphere prevailed.

title: Decorator Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an accounting gain of $60,000.

title: West Germans Debate Disposition of Nazi Art
description: Are paintings that once decorated the offices of Nazi officials (a) works of art, (b) historical documents or (c) symbols of darkness?

title: Biotechnology Development reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a one-time gain from the sale of Integrated Separation Systems of $73,230.

title: Tennis; French Open Starts With Strong Field
description: Virtually all of the world's best tennis players have gathered here for the French Open, the second leg of the Grand Slam and the year's most important clay-court event.

title: Slain Judge Ruled Against His Killer's Daughter
description: The man who shot and killed a Federal judge in Westchester County Saturday was a retired New York City police officer apparently seeking revenge for the judge's dismissal last week of a $2.5 million lawsuit filed by his daughter, investigators said yesterday.

title: Castle Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,980,474. The year-ago extraordinary charge is in connection with settlement of debt.

title: Two-Hit Victory For Candelaria
description: John Candelaria, who has survived 14 years in the major leagues and already endured a lifetime worth of heartache, still possesses remnants of a boyish innocence.

title: Topics of The Times; No Show, No Shame in Albany
description: Last fall's indictment of Manfred Ohrenstein, the New York Senate minority leader, on charges of putting campaign workers on the legislative payroll cast an embarrassing spotlight on Albany's job practices. The Legislature now magnifies the shame: It seeks dismissal of the charges.

title: Belling The Cat
description: Drug-itics - the demogogic posturing of candidates to appear tough on the subject of drugs -has become a new national narcotic.

title: Utopia Journal; Paradise Found? Close but Not Quite
description: All the children in Garrison Keillor's fictitious Lake Wobegon may be above average, but that would hardly suffice here in Utopia.

title: British Rail Sale Report
description: The British Government is considering selling British Rail, the national railroad system, the Economist reported in its latest issue. The plan is being worked on by a policy unit within Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office, the magazine said in its May 21 issue, which was made available today. Since Mrs. Thatcher came to power in 1979, her Government has sold billions of pounds worth of state assets, including British Telecom P.L.C., the phone company; British Gas P.L.C., and British Airways P.L.C.

title: Outdoors: Trout in Ponds
description: ALTHOUGH most fly fishermen would rather pursue their pleasure on streams and rivers, ignoring stillwater trout is a form of self-deprivation.

title: Penn State Takes IC4A Title Again
description: Penn State won its third consecutive IC4A team championship today, but Harry Grove's Nittany Lions had to sweat out the final event - the 1,600-meter relay - before they could enjoy the victory.

title: Dividend Meetings

title: Turner Scores First Victory
description: Sherri Turner birdied the last two holes today to win the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship by a shot over Amy Alcott and gain the first victory of her professional career in a women's major event.

title: Ayer Settles Army Dispute
description: N. W. Ayer, the advertising agency that created the ''Be All That You Can Be'' recruiting campaign for the Army, on Friday agreed to pay $750,000 to the Department of Justice to settle charges of billing and bidding improprieties, a spokesman for Ayer said.

title: Iran Seeking Oil Cutbacks
description: The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, arrived here today, apparently seeking support for a reduction in oil output in advance of the June meeting of the ministerial council of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Regrouped Lakers Breathing Easier
description: There was a sense of renewal amid the jubilation this afternoon as the Lakers arrived for practice at Loyola Marymount University. On Saturday, the defending world champions had taken a major step toward getting back to the championshiop round with a 109-98 pasting of the Utah Jazz in the seventh game of the Western Conference semifinals.

title: Computrac Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Czyz Loses Fight, Title Shot
description: In a battle of former light heavyweight champions, Dennis Andries finished strongly to win a 10-round majority decision today over Bobby Czyz at Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel here.

title: Militia War Abates in Beirut As Negotiations Go Forward
description: Fighting between Shiite Moslem militias slowed today as negotiators worked on the terms for the deployment of Syrian forces in the capital's battle-torn southern suburbs.

title: Lacrosse; Virginia Surprises Hopkins by 11-10
description: In lacrosse, Johns Hopkins almost always beats Virginia, but today the Cavaliers achieved a striking upset by defeating the defending national champion, 11-10, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association playoff contest.

title: Warship Weapons Secrecy Is Rooted in Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: In major championships, players in pair contests have one small advantage over those in team events: all play the same deals and have an opportunity to compare notes later.

title: Lab in Japan For Upjohn
description: The Upjohn Company will soon open its laboratory in Japan, the drug maker said today.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Commercial International Corp reports earnings for
description: b-After a gain of $148,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Reviews/Television; Espionage in 'CAT Squad' Sequel
description: The current silly season for television movies keeps clip-clopping along this evening at 9 with NBC's ''CAT Squad: Python Wolf,'' an action-adventure exercise distinguished by one of the year's more incomprehensible plots. The film does carry an eye-catching credit. It was directed by William Friedkin, who won an Academy Award for ''The French Connection.'' Not surprisingly, then, this television movie contains lots of chase scenes featuring painfully heavy breathing on the sound track. Then there are the autumn leaves that, after a vicious murder, turn blood red in closeup. That sort of thing. Actually, what we have here is a sequel to a 1986 ''CAT Squad'' that, much to everyone's surprise, chalked up a Top 10 Nielsen rating. Joe Cortese, Jack Youngblood and Steve James are returning to depict once again the characters of Doc, John and Bud, members of an elite - read covert - Counter-Assault Tactical Squad created by the United States Government. When not involved in highly dangerous and violent missions, the guys relax with touch football. They may be little more than hired killers, but boys will be boys.

title: Pressure For Tougher Fed Actions
description: In order to calm the nation's inflation fears, the Federal Reserve Board should alter its current approach of raising interest rates slowly, a number of credit market participants contend.

title: Conspirators, Trillions, Limos in the Night
description: This appears to be the season for disclosing Washington secrets, and I don't see why only Republicans should be able to play. I've got a pretty good one. Secret messages concealed on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. Whispered conversations on the Senate floor. White House limos hurtling through the wintry night to a house in northwest Washington. A bedroom -yup - on the second floor of the President's guest house, where nights earlier a visiting potentate would have been skewered by a plunging chandelier had he not been mysteriously otherwise engaged at the Watergate.

title: Topics of The Times; Campaign Reform, Unstalled
description: New York's Governor Cuomo proposes two ways to break Albany's deadlock over campaign finance reform. In March, the Democratic Assembly approved a bill, backed by the Governor, to reduce the influence of big money in campaigns by creating a system of public financing of statewide elections - for governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general and comptroller - and for the Legislature. Individual gifts would be capped at a reasonable $4,000 instead of the present $50,000. But the measure remains stalled in the Republican-controlled Senate over the scope of its coverage.

title: 2 Blacks Die in Soweto Attack
description: Two blacks were killed and 30 were wounded, some seriously, in the township of Soweto today when explosives were hurled at the meeting of a conservative black political party, the police said.

title: U.S. Judge Blocks Drug Tests
description: A Federal district judge has temporarily blocked a Reagan Administration plan to test employees of the Federal prison system at random for drug use. The testing, which was scheduled to begin Monday, would have affected 35,000 workers around the nation.

title: Review/Opera; Children Sing 'Noye's Fludde' By Britten
description: It is nice to come across a children's opera intended for children. Most serve adult needs, either as fantasies of what grown-ups think childishness should be or else as condescending exploitations of the cuteness they perceive in young innocence. Benjamin Britten works hard to establish and defend the rights of children in his brief opera ''Noye's Fludde.'' As demonstrated in a performance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Friday night, young people take principal parts and are given music that is simple and singable in familiar diatonic ways. Interest and originality are, however, not sacrificed.

title: Metro Matters; Computer Burps, Leaving Mothers To Go Hungry
description: ''I don't know how I could express hunger,'' Patricia Bennett said. ''It was not to the point where I passed out. The children always ate. Maybe I didn't. Maybe not for two or three nights. Maybe some juice during the day, but that's not eating.''

title: Review/Ballet; A Passionate Makarova In 'Swan Lake' Excerpt
description: Saturday afternoon was a time for swooning at the Metropolitan Opera House, for American Ballet Theater offered two unabashedly passionate works.

title: Labonte Sprints to a Victory
description: Terry Labonte took the lead early in the final 10-lap sprint in the Winston today and became the fourth different winner in the four-year history of Nascar's $600,000 winners-only, three-segment auto race.

title: Honduras Hurt by Border Violence
description: A blocky building of raw gray concrete rises alongside a four-lane highway on the outskirts of this nation's capital. On some floors huge panels of glass glint in the late afternoon sun. On others there are gaping dark holes.

title: New World Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary items totaling $12,557,000 that are from a gain on early extinguishment of debt and tax credits. c-Includes realized gain on investments in common stock holdings of $23,200,000.

title: SUNY Law School at Buffalo Hears Kunstler
description: When the graduating class at the Law School at the University of New York at Buffalo was trying to select a commencement speaker, the choices were Harry Hamlin or William M. Kunstler.

title: Solid Waste: The Beverage Sector Shouldn't Foot the Entire Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: First Liberty Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canada Banks' Loss Reserves
description: Canada's federal banking regulator said Friday that Canadian banks had been ordered to raise their third world loan-loss reserves to 35 to 45 percent of total loans to the developing world, from the current 30 to 40 percent.

title: When a Woman Is Driven to Kill Her Baby; Mothers Need Nurture
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Press Secretaries; Mouthpieces to the Powerful Have Principles, Too
description: Press secretaries for top Government officials often must perform a high-wire act. In their attempt to tell the truth while protecting their superiors, theyrisk a fall, as demonstrated when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d dimissed his spokesman, Terry Eastland.

title: Boardroom Business Prodcts reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
The Bird's Eye
description: BEFORE yesterday's game, someone was saying that during this playoff series against Atlanta, Larry Bird hasn't been quite the Larry Bird that we've come to know. ''You mean he hasn't been Superman?'' ''No,'' said the first person, ''I mean he hasn't been Superduperman.'' Yesterday, he was Superduperman. And just in the nick of time, scoring 20 points in the last quarter, 34 for the game, and making his important steal here, and significant pass there, and giving his teammates a sense that, well, that he wills that it could be no other way, whether it would be a 2-point victory margin, as it was, 118-116, or more, or less.

title: 'Then and Now' Spans 5 Decades of Dance
description: Jane Dudley is to present ''Then and Now,'' a program of dances spanning 50 years, Wednesday through Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. Miss Dudley was a soloist with the Martha Graham Dance Company from 1936 to 1946 and toured the United States as a member of the noted Dudley Maslow Bales Trio.

title: Dreams And History Devastated In a Blaze
description: You can smell the devastation here before you see it.

title: Environmental Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Karen Waddell Is Wed To Ida Bagus Suarsana
description: Karen Waddell, a daughter of Roberta W. Waddell of New York and the late Richard H. Waddell, was married yesterday to Ida Bagus Suarsana, a son of Jero Nyoman Suratimi and Ida Bagus Anom Buana, both of Denpasar, Bali. The Rev. William K. Fuller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Yacht Club in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: American Locker Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $6,239 loss from discontinued operations. c-Includes a $56,927 gain from discontinued operations.

title: GORBACHEV'S TONE UPBEAT ON SUMMIT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev set a positive tone for the coming Moscow summit meeting in an interview published in today's issue of The Washington Post. But the Soviet leader provided no hint of flexibility on some of the key arms control issues that stand in the way of a new treaty reducing long-range nuclear arms.

title: Kim M. Burke, a Lawyer, Marries Glenn S. Goldberg
description: Kim M. Burke, an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Semel, Boeckmann, Diamond, Schepp & Yuhas, and Glenn S. Goldberg, the press secretary to Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney, were married yesterday. Judge Joel M. Goldberg of New York City Criminal Court officiated at the Tappan Hill center in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Accord Ends Firestone Strike
description: The United Rubber Workers today reached a tentative contract agreement, ending a weeklong strike against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company. Hours earlier, union members at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company approved a new contract.

title: D'Arcy Masius Wins Hampton Inns Account
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis, has been called on to handle the Hampton Inns account after a six-way competition that lasted three months. The budget is $2 million.

title: Tax Watch; Nonprofit Groups May Face a Tax
description: COMPUTER dealers are upset that university bookstores are selling personal computers under their tax-exempt umbrella. Travel agents complain that they are being unfairly undercut by a growing number of tax-exempt groups offering discount tour packages. Drugstores are protesting unfair competition from tax-exempt pharmacies at nonprofit hospitals.

title: Koch Proposes Plan To Catch Scofflaws From Outside State
description: With scofflaws from outside New York State accounting for $265 million of the $1.4 billion in unpaid parking fines in New York City, the Koch administration is proposing a program that would target their cars for towing by city marshals.

title: 2 Powerful Chairmen at Odds As Vote Nears on Home Care
description: A bill to provide Federal funds for long-term home health care is nearing a vote in the House of Representatives, provoking a dispute between two powerful committee chairmen.

title: Black Churches, Endangered Children
description: ''The black family has been an issue in search of leadership,'' Eleanor Holmes Norton observed in an article three years ago in The New York Times Magazine. Even as she wrote, however, that leadership was starting to materialize in a familiar place: the black church.

title: When a Woman Is Driven to Kill Her Baby; A Satire of Liberalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Rift on Noriega Deepens as Bush And Treasury Chief Oppose Deal
description: American officials said today that there is a deepening rift within the Reagan Administration over how to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama.

title: Scientific Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,000 from an accounting change.

title: Teacher Says She Acted on Instinct To Save Children in Shooting Spree
description: A substitute teacher recounted today how she grabbed a deranged woman to stop her from shooting a classroom of second-grade youngsters on Friday.

title: Measuring Speed on Small Craft
description: Surfers and board sailors take their water speed seriously. Whether it is wind or wave that drives their small craft, most like to go fast. But until recently, they had to guess their speed. Now they can measure it as they go.

title: We Can't Isolate Vietnam Forever
description: Following a visit to Vietnam last month, I concluded that more than 13 years after the last American helicopters left Saigon, the United States should consider ending its isolation of Vietnam. For the first time, Congress seems ready to review American policy there.

title: Shauna M. Lehv Becomes a Bride
description: Shauna Marie Lehv, the daughter of Mrs. John Grantham Ballard of Mercer Island, Wash., and Honolulu, and Bernard M. Lehv of Herbeys, France, was married yesterday to Frank G. Binswanger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Binswanger Jr. of Philadelphia. Judge Lynne M. Abraham of the Common Pleas Court in Philadelphia performed the ceremony at Andalusia, an estate near Philadelphia.

title: Federal Express vs. Japan (Cont.)
description: It is a familiar tale. An American company tries for years to break into the Japanese marketplace. Finally, just as it thinks it is through the last barrier, it hears of other regulations that prevent it from operating in Japan.

title: 2-Year and 5-Year Notes to Be Auctioned
description: Treasury financings this week begin with today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of two-year notes and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

title: Account
description: * Sport & Health athletic facilities, Washington, to Shapiro, Hyman & Freeman, Baltimore.

title: Consensus Emerges in Panama: Noriega Has Won
description: Having weathered months of political crisis, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega now appears able to hold on to power indefinitely if he chooses, according to several diplomats and Panamanian politicians.

title: Farm Lender Revises Policy
description: Long-awaited Federal regulations to overhaul the lending policies of the Farmers Home Administration are expected to cost $8.7 billion and push as many as 65,000 farmers into liquidation or foreclosure, the agency, a part of the Agriculture Department, said.

title: Bitter Trade Debate Near in Ottawa
description: Seven months after turning Canada's economic policy around by signing a free-trade agreement with the United States, the Government here is entering a decisive phase of its battle for the agreement at home.

title: 'Gold Card' Ruling
description: Mastercard may now legally use the expression ''gold card'' in its advertising as a result of a ruling last week by Federal District Judge Charles Metzner. He indicated that the term is generic and not a trademark of American Express. A lawsuit was filed by American Express soon after Mastercard began an ad campaign for Gold Mastercard.

title: ABM Gold Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter includes a gain of $1,175,000 on the sale of securities by affiliates. The company said there was an increase in the equity in net losses of affiliates of $180,000 in the latest quarter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Wall Street is worried that volatility will increase as a result of the low trading volume of recent weeks. The market's liquidity -which allows stocks to be traded without distorting prices - is at its lowest level in two years, one investment firm says. A trader described the situation as ''very dangerous,'' and others pointed out that a marketplace with low liquidity was vulnerable to shocks. [ Page D1. ] The Fed should change its approach to monetary policy, some people in the credit markets are saying, to forestall a further steady rise in interest rates. These critics are urging the Fed to send a forceful message that would ease fears about inflation. [ D1. ] Retailing workers are feeling the effects of the recent wave of mergers, divestitures and restructurings. And although many layoffs are expected at companies like Federated, others with expansion plans, like the Limited, are looking to hire. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Continental Airlines opened a new terminal at Newark, which it called the world's most advanced. But travelers were forced to wait up to 45 minutes for their bags. [ B2. ] Firestone and the United Rubber Workers tentatively agreed on a new contract, ending a weeklong strike by 4,700 workers. [ A14. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Canada's Government is at a decisive point on the free-trade pact with the U.S. Legislation will be introduced in Ottawa this week to put the pact into effect, beginning what is expected to be one of the most bitter debates in Canadian history. [ D1. ] Honduras has staved off an economic collapse only because of large infusions of U.S. aid, foreign economists say. The country is handicapped by high labor costs, an overvalued currency, a daunting bureaucracy and its location in a war-torn region. [ D10. ] The Trans-Gabon Railroad is a hit in that sparsely populated African country, although it is far from a financial success. [ D10. ] South Africa is dragging its feet over insider-trading laws, according to Pretoria's top legal adviser on the issue. [ D6. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A proposed joint operating agreement is at the center of a debate with national ramifications. The Justice Department has been asked to approve the merger of the non-editorial operations of two tiny newspapers in Manteca, Calif. Opponents say the arrangement would set a precedent that could threaten competition. [ D8. ] Publishing has ceased to be a seasonal business, with blockbuster books due for release all year long. [ D8. ] The advertising industry is booming in India, becoming one of the country's fastest-growing economic sectors. [ D8. ] Old cartoon characters are increasingly being licensed to promote new products. Unlike human celebrities, the characters are unlikely to embarrass the sponsors. Ad Scene. [ D8. ] Agency compensation was on everyone's mind at the recent annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. One consultant, who has predicted the end of the 15 percent commission, came under particular attack. Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Stephen C. Swid came back from Cannes as a movie potentate, having bought a stake in Cinecom. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Electric and telephone utilities have provided higher returns, on average, than industrial companies, according to a new study of utility stocks. Market Place. [ D6. ] Congress will probably restrict some tax-free activities. Tensions between small businesses and nonprofit organizations have been on the rise as the tax-exempt groups expand their income-producing activities. Tax Watch. [ D2. ]

title: Commodore Environmental Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the reversal was due to job-related costs experienced in the latter part of 1987.

title: USG Details Proxy Victory
description: The USG Corporation announced yesterday that a preliminary count showed that it had won a proxy fight waged by Desert Partners L.P. to place six directors on the company's 15-member board.

title: Billy Carter Prepares to Try Experimental Cancer Therapy
description: Billy Carter left here today for the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md., to undergo a risky experimental treatment for pancreatic cancer.

title: North Castle Selected By Goodmark Foods
description: Goodmark Foods of Raleigh, N.C., has gone north for its new ad agency, choosing North Castle Partners Advertising, Greenwich, Conn., whose forte is snack and specialty foods. The budget is $3 million. The agency has begun working on a campaign for Slim Jims, a beef snack. Goodmark, which recently acquired Fleetwood Snacks, a Pennsylvania maker of cookies and crackers, also produces Pemmican and Penros meat snacks and Andy Capp's grain-based snacks.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Pacts Abroad
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is negotiating securities enforcement agreements with France, Italy, Australia and New Zealand, David S. Ruder, the agency's chairman, said Thursday night.

title: A FIERY SWAGGART RETURNS TO PULPIT
description: The defrocked evangelist Jimmy Swaggart reclaimed the pulpit at his Family Worship Center today with fire-and-brimstone fervor and an appeal for money.

title: Antipodal Dream
description: Andrew Gaze lived out a fantasy two years ago in the Georgetown University fieldhouse.

title: Black Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Car-Train Crash Kills 3
description: A car carrying six people ran into a freight train Saturday, killing three people in the car, the police said. Officials said the car struck an engine of a Burlington-Northern freight train at a crossing just east of here. The victims were identified as Robert Dean Cooper, 38, of De Soto, and Paula R. Henke, 33, and Melanie Todd, 16, both of Herrin.

title: For Leonard Bernstein, 3 Birthday Premieres
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic is to give a concert in celebration of Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday, Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, as part of its Meet the Moderns series. The Occasional Singers, under the direction of Gil Robbins, are to perform, with Lukas Foss, Tania Leon and Steven Mercurio sharing the conducting. On the program are four works by Mr. Bernstein and the world premieres of three pieces commissioned in his honor by the Ascap-Meet the Composer Commission Program.

title: John Hancock Investors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income represents net investment income. The net asset value at March 31 was $144,529,506 for the latest period, compared with $154,133,153 for year-ago period.

title: Beres Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of about $44,000 of direct moving expenses and a gain of $44,500 from the sale of assets.

title: Victoria Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
American League; Orioles Win 2d In a Row
description: The lowly Baltimore Orioles achieved a two-game winning streak for the first time this season, defeating the Seattle Mariners, 7-2, today as Jose Bautista and Mike Morgan combined on a five-hitter and Larry Sheets and Cal Ripken hit home runs.

title: Greek Quake Sets Off Slide
description: A strong earthquake rocked the western Greek island of Cephalonia today and set off a landslide near the main town of Argostoli, the police reported. There were no reports of casualties or building damage. However, the quake, which was centered almost 200 miles west of Athens and registered 5.5 on the Richter scale, ''shook everybody awake this morning'' a police officer on the island said. It was the second strong earthquake to hit Cephalonia in five days. On Wednesday, a tremor measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale shook Cephalonia and parts of western Greece.

title: Astros Top Cards With Run in Ninth
description: Chuck Jackson doubled home the winning run in the ninth inning today as the Houston Astros beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-1.

title: 5 Finalists Are Vying For Fuji Photo Business
description: Fuji Photo Film USA, Elmsford, N.Y., whose parent is the Fuji Photo Film Company of Tokyo, announced that five finalists were vying to handle its photographic and magnetic products divisions. The selection process, which began May 3, initially included eight agencies.

title: The Trade Effect
description: Do baseball players traded during a season hit better before or after the trade?

title: Angeles Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes gains from tax benefits of $14,000 and $310,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: Hitech Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Volume Cut Worrying Wall Street
description: The reduction in stock trading volume in recent weeks is giving Wall Street a new worry. With so many investors on the sidelines, traders and money managers fear that the market could become even more volatile.

title: Cuomo Says Budget Gap May Exceed $300 Million
description: As bickering flared anew today among Republicans and Democrats over the state budget shortfall, Governor Cuomo indicated that the shortfall would be larger than the $300 million figure that his administration had predicted earlier this month.

title: HUNGARIAN PARTY REPLACES KADAR WITH HIS PREMIER
description: Prime Minister Karoly Grosz became the new General Secretary of Hungary's Communist Party today, replacing Janos Kadar, whom the Soviet Union installed as party leader during the failed uprising in 1956.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''So you ask yourself: Which situation are we better off in, to have Noriega more or less in charge in Panama, and us with an indictment that we cannot do much about, but nevertheless holding onto it? Or having Noriega giving up power in Panama and leaving Panama, but also, having paid that penalty, not having the indictment hang over his head?'' - George P. Shultz. [ A3:2. ]

title: Unique Plan to Merge Papers Inspires Debate
description: A California farming town with two tiny newspapers that want to merge their non-editorial operations is becoming the center of a debate with national ramifications.

title: Thompson Makes Cuts
description: John Thompson, coach of the 1988 men's Olympic basketball team, today invited 48 players to a public scrimmage in Denver.

title: Alamco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Setbacks Can't Stall Guerrero's Ambition
description: THE Golden Age of auto racing continues Sunday with the Indianapolis 500, the annual event that defines a certain part of Americana.

title: Anniversary Festivities For the New York Pops
description: Peter Allen, Nell Carter, Carol Channing, Jackie Mason, Robert Merrill and Roberta Peters are to be guest stars at a concert celebrating the fifth anniversary of the New York Pops, Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Skitch Henderson will conduct.

title: 7-Up Official Quits His Job
description: Following his conviction last week on charges of price-fixing while working for another company, James J. Harford, who is the president of the Seven-Up Holding Company, resigned yesterday.

title: Physicians' Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Taxing Lesson at Yonkers Market
description: Armed with guns and pages from the New York State Tax Law, a team of undercover agents swept through the Yonkers Raceway Flea Market today to demonstrate that tax evasion does not pay.

title: W. S. Joyce, 75, Dies; Headed Boston College
description: The Rev. W. Seavey Joyce, a Jesuit priest and president of Boston College from 1968 to 1972, died of cancer of the pancreas on Thursday at the Campion Center Jesuit Residence in Weston, Mass., where he lived. He was 75 years old.

title: Valenzuela Crushed by Mets
description: The Mets completed their week's sweep through southern California today with a seven-game winning streak, a five-and-a-half-game lead and a two-round knockout over Fernando Valenzuela. And they even escaped the rage of Pedro Guerrero, who hurled his bat past the mound after David Cone bounced a curveball off his helmet.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Presidential Greetings
description: The process of choosing United States ambassadors is tedious, involving months of security checks by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, elaborate medical tests, obtaining agreement to the proposed appointment from the host government and, finally, securing confirmation by the Senate.

title: Gulf Applied Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $464,000. c-Net income and includes a gain from discontinued operations of $1,694,000. The company said the 1987 earnings were restated to reflect adoption of new accounting principles.

title: Million-Dollar Team Keeping Bush Campaign in the Money
description: As a senior at an exclusive New England preparatory school, George Bush saved a younger classmate from being beaten by a bully. Forty-seven years later, the events that day at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., are bringing enormous financial rewards to Mr. Bush's Presidential campaign.

title: Northeastern Wins Heavyweight Title
description: In beating Penn today to win the Joseph Burk Cup for the first time since 1983, Northeastern's heavyweight crew put together the race it lacked May 15 when it finished third in the Eastern Sprints Championship.

title: African Railroad Running a Deficit
description: For most of the 1980's, the $3 billion, 403-mile Trans-Gabon Railroad was the largest construction project in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Mary Gibbons Marries John Feinstein, Writer
description: At Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J., Mary Clare Gibbons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Gibbons of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to John Feinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Feinstein of McLean, Va. Msgr. John Corr performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Raymond Singer.

title: Rowers Transcend Difficulties to Enjoy Exercise Sublime
description: ALTHOUGH recreational rowing, meaning sculling in a single-seat vessel, is being heralded as the exercise sublime, the sport has yet to take off in a way comparable to jogging, cycling or even windsurfing.

title: Books of The Times; A Winged Terror and Childhood Crises
description: The Pigeon By Patrick Suskind Translated by John E. Woods. 115 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. Only Children By Rafael Yglesias 523 pages. William Morrow. $19.95.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Dukakis Seems to Be Savoring the Home Stretch, From Coast to Coast
description: This is the bicoastal season in Presidential politics, the days of Camden in the morning, Los Angeles at night and the rest of America from 30,000 feet. It is the final stretch of the long Democratic nominating process before the New Jersey and California primaries bring it mercifully to a close on June 7.

title: 18 Drown in Bay of Bengal
description: At least 18 fishermen drowned Saturday after their boats capsized in the Bay of Bengal off the port of Chittagong, The Bangladesh Observer reported today.

title: Control Laser International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Associated Communications Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $763,335 from sales of properties.

title: South Africa Delays Insider Trading Action, Official Says
description: The South African Government has failed to act on new laws needed to curb rampant insider trading in the stock market, Pretoria's top legal adviser on the issue complained today.

title: Reporter's Notebook; At Sikh Temple, an Uncertain Song Returns
description: The sound of Sikh hymns rang across the Golden Temple this morning for the first time in two weeks and echoed off the empty chambers and corridors of the nearly deserted shrine.

title: India's Advertising Industry Surges
description: A once-flagging advertising industry is booming in India. It has become fiercely competitive and one of the country's fastest-growing economic sectors.

title: Yanks Activate Guidry
description: Ron Guidry, who has spent the last six months recovering from surgery on his left shoulder, was activated yesterday from the disabled list by the Yankees.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Spain, which ruled the Philippines for 300 years, has offered a $70 million loan to its former colony, according to the Spanish Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez. Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines started in the 16th century and lasted until the Spanish-American war in 1898. Mr. Gonzalez said Spain would cooperate with other members in the European Community to help the Philippine economy.

title: Teachers In Day Care Questioned
description: With salaries unappealingly low and turnover rates alarmingly high, almost half of New York City's day-care and Head Start classrooms are run by teachers who lack full qualifications, a study by the Bank Street College of Education has found.

title: Hong Kong Rates
description: The Hong Kong Association of Banks said on Saturday that it had decided to leave interest rates unchanged at its regular weekly meeting. The banks' prime lending rate is currently 7 1/2 percent.

title: O'Brien Energy Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Those Who Think Young
description: Life begins at 55 at the sixth annual New York State Senior Games scheduled for June 16-19 on the SUNY campus in Cortland. More than 2,000 men and women are expected to compete in 21 sports, from archery to track and field, bait-casting to swimming, darts to shuffleboard.

title: At Accused Pastor's Church, Schism
description: More than 250 worshipers came to the nearly windowless auditorium of the True Church of God in East Harlem yesterday, as they have every Sunday, to seek the light from their minister. But this Sunday was different, because the minister, the Rev. Thomas Streitferdt, is charged with raping two teen-age members of his church.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Waiting for Liberty
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was felled by gunshots directed at President Reagan outside a Washington hotel seven years ago was back in the Oval office the other day with David Puttnam, the film producer, Robert Bolt, the writer, and Mollie Dickenson, author of ''Thumbs Up,'' the story of Mr. Brady's gallant struggle to regain his health and mobility.

title: Ad Campaign to Tell What US Magazine Is
description: US magazine is beginning a lighthearted year-long trade campaign today, aimed at dispelling notions people may have of the magazine.

title: Olympic Trials Are in Sight
description: Contenders for the United States Olympic sailing team are competing in every American regatta possible to prepare for one that counts, the Olympic yachting trials this summer.

title: Isoetec Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included $876,000 of equity in losses from Executone Inc.

title: African Debt Relief Urged
description: President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia said today that Africa would need a 20-year grace period to build its economy in order to repay its $200 billion debt.

title: China Oilfield Sees Big Loss
description: This year may be the first in which China's biggest oilfield reports an operating loss, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Veto Battle Looms
description: The long-expected veto of the omnibus trade bill is likely to come Tuesday even though the House will be in session and is likely to vote to override that same day, White House and Congressional officials predict.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; From Parking Lot To Room With View
description: Fresh off the Concorde after three days of parties and screenings at the Cannes Film Festival, Stephen C. Swid strolled last week through his estate-size office at the top of a skyscraper on the Avenue of the Americas and settled onto an expensive sofa. He had just become a movie potentate by buying into the Cinecom Entertainment Group, a small but growing film production and distribution company.

title: Continuum Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fourth-quarter loss was due to declines in revenue from the Life-70 and Life-Comm products and a lack of new licenses for the company's client-contract administration software systems.

title: The Politics of Roast Beef In Albany
description: Every legislative session, State Senator Emanuel R. Gold nibbles his way through more than 1,000 shrimp, a few hundred slices of roast beef on little rounds of rye and dozens of carrot sticks swirled in creamy white dip. It is, he says, all in a day's work.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; War on Chauvinism
description: Federal agencies are outdoing one another in designing eye-catching posters to convey messages to their employees. Last month, it was the Treasury Department, which used a poster showing two spies seated on a park bench in view of the Capitol to warn employees to ''report hostile contacts'' to the authorities.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Comcoa Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 17
description: b-Includes tax credits of $102,909 for the latest quarter and $78,215 for the year-earlier period.

title: Oil Investments By Abu Dhabi
description: The emirate of Abu Dhabi plans to make substantial investments in foreign oil companies as a safeguard against oil price fluctuations, an industry official said today. Khalifa Mohammed al-

title: Lieberman Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $453,000.

title: David Schoenbrun Is Dead at 73; Veteran Journalist for CBS News
description: David F. Schoenbrun, the witty and versatile CBS correspondent who was one of Edward R. Murrow's original team in the 1940's, died at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday morning. He was 73 years old.

title: American Pioneer Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: 4 Top Names from Nashville Visit
description: If one were searching for a quick immersion course in mainstream country music, the 1988 Marlboro Country Music tour, which arrived at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, offered just the ticket. Alabama, George Strait, the Judds and Randy Travis - four of the top names in Nashville - all performed at the four-hour marathon concert, which was a benefit for the national food-bank network, Second Harvest. The concert also was the New York debut of Mr. Travis, a 29-year-old singer and songwriter from North Carolina whose two solo albums, ''Storms of Life'' and ''Always and Forever,'' have each sold more than two million copies.

title: In Eye of Stormy Africa, Zaire Dictates Stability
description: A dozen women stood on this city's main boulevard recently, handing out leaflets criticizing the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko until the security police arrested them minutes later.

title: HOUSE APPROVES RAIL SAFETY BILL
description: The House passed legislation today that for the first time would require licenses for trains' engineers, make it illegal for crews to tamper with safety devices and give the Government a greater role in handling safety violations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone of Chicago Quits Long John Silver
description: The Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding is quitting the Long John Silver account, which bills more than $20 million.

title: Be It Highways or Fairways, Buffalo Are Not Free to Roam
description: As Angelo Abbate addressed a golf ball with a nine-iron at Hollywood Lakes Country Club, a herd of 13 buffalo addressed him with stares.

title: The Exclusive Privilege of the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Visual Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $120,000, or 6 cents a share, from utilization of a foreign loss carryforward, a loss of $498,000 and an offsetting income tax benefit of $494,000 related to the sale of the assets and business of its wholly owned U.K. subsidiary.

title: Lloyd E. Dickens, 86, Ex-Assemblyman of Harlem
description: Former Assemblyman Lloyd Everett Dickens, a self-made millionaire and veteran of Democratic Party battles, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Harlem, which he represented in Albany from 1959 to 1964.

title: The Mayor's Sound Bet on Schools
description: Though Mayor Edward Koch of New York likes to proclaim the importance of education, dollars haven't always followed his declamations. This year they do, partly as a show of confidence in Richard Green, the new Schools Chancellor. That's a compliment, and also a challenge.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no violation of human rights in the Soviet Union. They just don't exist here.'' - Sergei L. Petrov, Soviet freelance photographer. [ A12:2. ]

title: 60-Day Plant-Closing Notice Isn't the Half of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Reports Raids on Iraqis
description: Iran said its jets flew five bombing missions Monday against Iraqi positions east of Basra, inflicting heavy losses on enemy troops and equipment. The Teheran radio, monitored here, said all attacking jets returned safely from the raids on the southern front. In another report, the radio said Iranian military exercises in the Gulf of Oman continued for a second day on Monday. The exercises, involving Iran's regular army, air force and navy, will go on for several days to test their combat readiness, it said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Marie Barnard, Jane Carlson, Jane DeFeo, Charles Carlson, Michele Buslik and Barry Fisher have been named senior vice presidents at Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Talking Business: with Milstein of Burlington Coat; Discounter Curbs: A Strong Protest
description: Monroe G. Milstein, the chairman and president of the Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corporation, thinks a Supreme Court ruling this month has increased the possibility that manufacturers and full-price retailers will reach agreements that will hurt discount retailers. The decision, upholding a lower court ruling involving the Sharp Electronics Corporation and two retailers, said that a producer's agreement with one dealer to stop supplying a price-cutting dealer with merchandise did not necessarily violate the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: American Mobile Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Great American Communicaions Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,477,000. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $2,936,000 and an extraordinary charge of $523,000. The company acquired Great American Broadcasting in October 1987. The company said included in revenue in 1988 is a gain on the sale of 1.75 million United Brands common shares.

title: Phillips and Karolyi Mend Their Ways
description: Kristie Phillips's efforts to regain world-class prominence in gymnastics has taken another surprising turn. She has decided to rejoin Bela Karolyi, the coach she left in February citing a need for a change.

title: Dow Falls 11.11 as Volume Hits Low for '88
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday recorded its slowest day since Nov. 27, the Friday after Thanksgiving. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.11 points, to 1,941.48, and broader indexes were down as well.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Views Of Agencies On Canter
description: THE consulting firm of Canter, Achenbaum & Associates, whose functions include leading agency searches for advertiser clients, gets mixed reviews from some agencies it has worked with.

description: b-Net loss

title: Jackson Offers Budget Plan As Blueprint for Democrats
description: Looking toward the Democratic Party platform, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today announced detailed budget proposals that would seek to slash military spending in favor of major increases for education, drug law-enforcement, AIDS research and housing.

title: AW Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Jackson Finds a Brother In Redeemed Bert Lance
description: The phone on Bert Lance's desk rings. Jesse Jackson is on the line. Suddenly, the sleepy Southern afternoon crackles with the Democratic Presidential candidate's tales of the crowds and excitement of his Western campaign and his dreams of changing America so that people who never considered the idea of a black President would now consider it.

title: F.D.A. Approves Cervical Cap As a Device for Birth Control
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a birth control device called the cervical cap, a barrier contraceptive that is already available in Europe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Chief Named at Infinity
description: The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, a New York-based concern that owns several radio stations, said yesterday that its board had named Mel Karmazin president and chief executive of the company. Mr. Karmazin succeeds Gerald Carrus as president. The company said Mr. Karmazin's position as chief executive, a newly created position, would include responsibilities that he has held for for some time. Mr. Karmazin had been executive vice president. Infinity's radio stations include WXRK-FM in New York City and KROQ-FM in Los Angeles.

title: Zenith Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 885388 -- No Title
description: Flexi-Van Leasing Inc., a unit of the Flexi-Van Corporation, is offering $100 million of 13 1/2 percent subordinated debentures, due in 1998, at a price of par through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Sex and Moths' Spray
description: Female moths of at least two species squirt sex attractants from their abdomens like perfume from an atomizer, researchers have found.

title: Physicians Insurance Company of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $134,500 tax credit.

title: Protecting Crops
description: American and Malaysian scientists have discovered that a plant found in Malaysia has apparently learned to synthesize hormones of juvenile insects as a means of self-protection.

title: Kodak Merger Shifts Sterling Management
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's absorption of Sterling Drug Inc. ''was an intense experience for all of us,'' said Kay R. Whitmore, Kodak's president.

title: Harvard Sex Bias Case Opens With Ex-Professor Testifying
description: A former faculty member suing to become the fifth woman granted tenure in the 80-year history of Harvard Business School testified today that the academic guidelines had been manipulated to deny her tenure because of her sex.

title: A Challenge for Bush
description: It is staring right at George Bush and his advisers: a sensible, direct and politically valuable way of saying he really is his own man despite his loyalty to Ronald Reagan. And it has the added advantage of being useful to the country.

title: TM Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $520,692 from the disposal of the company's corporate communications segment earlier this year.

title: Market Place; Disappointments At Paine Webber
description: THE stocks of several major brokerage firms are trading below their book value, a reflection of the fact that investors perceive Wall Street as a potentially dangerous arena in the wake of last October's stock market crash. But no brokerage industry stock has been hit as hard as Paine Webber.

title: Equitable Real Estate Shoping Centers LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nimes Journal; With French Accent, the Fiesta's a Fete Accomplie
description: As the matador Paco Ojeda works the hulking Miura bull with his cape, the silence in the Roman amphitheater is extraordinary, as if one were at the opera in Paris. A bored Spaniard hollers ''Musica!'' - demanding that the band strike up a tune, as it might in Madrid - but his solitary appeal is drowned in a wave of French hisses.

title: Land Bank Reopens; Liquidation Set
description: The Farm Credit Administration reopened the Federal Land Bank of Jackson, Miss., today under the supervision of a court-appointed receiver, but did so only to prepare the insolvent bank for liquidation.

Sports of The Times; Lord Stanley's Cup Runs Over
description: THE National Hockey League used to worry only about the new dents and scratches that might appear on the Stanley Cup when the winning players frolicked with the cup in bars, clubs, backyards, race tracks and bedrooms.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the Beretta pistol misidentified the parent company of a Beretta competitor, Smith & Wesson. It is F. H. Tomkins, a British corporation, which acquired Smith & Wesson in 1987 from the Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation.

title: Gottschalks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $689,000.

title: Drugs as 1988 Issue: Filling a Vacuum
description: The drug issue is often central to elections for mayor or district attorney. But why have drugs become so important to the 1988 campaign for President of the United States?

title: Curbs on Sea Pollution Voted in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Legislature passed a package of bills today designed to combat the state's growing ocean pollution problems. While the lawmakers acted, the Coast Guard and the marine police monitored a three-mile skein of seaweed, household garbage and wood that appeared offshore over the weekend.

title: 60-Day Plant-Closing Notice Isn't the Half of It; Modest and Crucial
description: To the Editor:

title: For Australian Dancers, Ballet Is Not Enough
description: ''Australians are a very physical people,'' Graeme Murphy, the director of the Sydney Dance Company, said in an interview the other day. ''For many Australians, the exposure of the body on a beach has become a daily event. We're also having a great fitness craze. So, Australian audiences are quite aware of physicality. I think that the Sydney Dance Company satisfies the public's need to see physical energy projected and artistically channeled on stage.''

title: Art Scholar Gets 3 Years in Stolen Papers Case
description: Charles Merrill Mount, a 60-year-old art scholar, was sentenced today to three years in prison for transporting stolen documents belonging to the National Archives and the Library of Congress.

title: Logitek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Administration Is Ready to Name Two to Top Posts in Justice Dept.
description: Two men selected by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to fill top-level vacancies at the Justice Department have passed background checks and are ready for formal nomination, an Administration official said today.

description: Oscar and Lucinda By Peter Carey 433 pages. Harper & Row. $18.95.

Union Says Many Were Exposed To Asbestos at Kennedy Airport
description: A Federal employees union has charged that thousands of travelers and about two dozen immigration officials were exposed to dangerous levels of asbestos in 1986 during a three-month renovation of the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport.

title: INSIDE
description: Interest Is Reviving in Hydrogen Aircraft Rendering of hydrogen-powered plane that could operate both in the atmosphere and in space. Sparked in part by a recent Soviet experiment, American interest in producing such a plane is reviving. Science Times, page C1. Panama Talks Are On Again A State Department official returned to Panama to seek a deal for the removal of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. Page A3. Carrot and Stick in Zaire Zaire's President, Mobuto Sese Seko, has created stability by co-opting potential rivals. Those he cannot buy, he intimidates. Page A6. 2d Howard Beach Trial As jury selection began, an appeals court said the judge had acted improperly in holding a closed proceeding in the case. Page B1.

description: The company said the increase in both net and revenue in part reflects the results of the company's public offering of 805,000 shares of common in December 1987 and January 1988.

title: Landmark Commission Picks Theater Panel
description: The membership of a special committee to review the landmark designation of Broadway theaters, with a view to easing somewhat the regulation of interiors, was announced yesterday by Gene A. Norman, chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Review/Ballet; From Cakewalks to the Classics
description: The School of American Ballet, the New York City Ballet's official school, modestly calls its annual student performances ''workshops.'' Yet the workshop label refers more to the idea of young dancers in training than to experimentation.

title: Danish Film Wins Top Prize at Cannes
description: ''Pelle Erobreren'' (''Pelle the Conqueror''), directed by Bille August, was awarded the Palme d'Or, or Golden Palm, tonight at the Palais du Festival in ceremonies bringing to a close the 41st Cannes Film Festival. The prize to the Danish film carried with it a citation acknowledging the exceptional contribution to the film by its star, Max Von Sydow, who had been expected to win the festival's best actor award.

title: KEY RATES
Trans World Music reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
McCormick Bid Is Dropped
description: McCormick & Company today dropped its plan to acquire a smaller rival spice maker, Specialty Brands Inc., after the Federal Government moved to block the purchase, saying it would reduce competition.

title: Cablevision Plans to Acquire Wometco in a Stock Swap
description: Cablevision Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Wometco Cable TV Inc. in a tax-free exchange of common stock.

title: U.S. and Japan Seek a Pact
description: The United States and Japan will try again next week to break a deadlock over Washington's demand that Tokyo lift quotas on beef and citrus imports, United States officials said today.

description: b-Net income Year-ago 9-month figures are pro- forma. The company acquired the stock of Audio King Inc. in September of 1986 and pro-forma figures are computed as if Audio King was acquired in July of 1986.

title: Fed Nominee Announced By President
description: President Reagan said he would nominate a leading Boston banker, John P. LaWare, to the Federal Reserve Board. The appointment, if confirmed, would mean all seven governors would be Reagan appointees.

title: Production at Shell
description: The Shell Oil Company plans to increase its North Sea oil production by developing eight new oil and gas fields. A spokesman for Shell Exploration and Production, a part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said that the fields were discovered several years ago, and improved technology and recent rises in oil prices had made them economical.

title: Bridge; By Alan Truscott
description: The gods of the game sometimes play little tricks, to remind us that bridge is a difficult game of chance.

title: Moynihan Declares Bid For 3d Term
description: Declaring that social welfare issues would be his priority, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday announced his candidacy for a third term.

description: b-Included pre-tax provisions of $3,450,000 for the quarter and $11.9 million for the 9 months on note receivables; the 9 months also included a pre-tax writeoff of good will of $7,013,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $388,000.

title: 6 Hurt as Jet Skids in Texas
description: Six people, including the three-person cockpit crew of an American Airlines DC-10, suffered minor injuries Saturday when the crew aborted takeoff at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport after a warning light flashed.

title: Koch's New Diet (Again)
description: Mayor Koch, who has tried more diets than Heinz has varieties, disclosed yesterday that he was trying yet another, a liquid protein regimen that recently helped Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward lose 75 pounds.

title: Commitment to Minorities Fading in U.S., Study Says
description: The United States is moving backward in efforts to promote equal opportunity for members of minority groups, a commission of political, business, education and civic leaders said today.

title: Desperately Seeking Chanel
description: In her red-silk Chanel suit, with its brass buttons and white-trimmed pockets, Debra Sharpe has snap. But take a closer look. The hardware is the give-away. There is no trademark double-C on the buttons. Ms. Sharpe, who owns the Sharpe Gallery on Wooster Street in SoHo, is a bit of a fashionable fraud. She has her Chanel suits copied by a dressmaker from magazine tear sheets.

title: Kaisertech in Accord On Sale to Maxxam
description: Kaisertech Ltd. said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Maxxam Group Inc. for $19.375 a share in cash, or about $871.9 million.

title: Soviet Sets Shuttle For August Launching
description: The Soviet Union's new space shuttle, a reusable craft that lands on a runway, is to make its first voyage at about the same time that the United States space shuttle is scheduled to return to orbit for the first time since the Challenger disaster, an industry magazine has reported.

title: SFE Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $683,000 from the purchase of a long- standing note at a discount. c-Net loss

title: Israel Weighs Appeal by U.S. Arab
description: A Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence had his day in court today and vowed that if the Israeli Government succeeded in deporting him, he would convert to Judaism and move back to Israel under the Law of Return.

title: Thatcher's Glow Is Fast Dimming
description: LEAD: Has Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher outstayed her welcome? At first sight, No. 10 Downing Street does seem to be built on firmer foundations than does the White House. Dennis Thatcher, Mrs. Thatcher's husband, consults no astrologer; his days are spent on the golf links. The disgruntled have yet to publish books that tell all, and, since the Westland affair two years ago, no political scandal has rocked Her Majesty's Government.

title: Review/Television; Wilderness Extremists Stalk 4 Women
description: Last night, NBC's ''CAT Squad'' followed the adventures of three men as they set about foiling a South African nuclear plot. Tonight, on CBS at 9, ''Nightmare at Bitter Creek'' features four women being stalked through a mountain wilderness by white-supremacist killers calling themselves the Aryan Survival Brigade. The silly season for action-adventure television movies is clearly going to get worse before it gets better.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Will Examine Law on Child Pornography
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Massachusetts law designed to ban child pornography is so broadly worded that it violates free speech rights.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Wine Makers Bitter
description: The California wine industry's annual political invasion is under way, and the capital is already awash with cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay and charges of international discrimination. The Wine Institute, based in San Francisco, is here with its largest lobby to date, the owners of 17 California wineries, all intent on persuading Congress and the Reagan Administration that they need a little more trading room.

title: Phoenix American Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mallard Coach Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

title: SHULTZ URGES VOTE ON MISSILE TREATY IN TIME FOR SUMMIT
description: Clearly upset over Senate delays in approving the new arms treaty, Secretary of State George P. Shultz came to Capitol Hill today to plead for a prompt vote on the pact so President Reagan can take it to Moscow for formal approval.

title: Del Webb Casino To Golden Nugget
description: The Del Webb Corporation said that it would sell the Nevada Club, a hotel and casino in Laughlin, Nev., to the Las Vegas casino operator Golden Nugget Inc. for $40 million. The sale is the first under a restructuring plan proposed by Del Webb, based in Phoenix, in March to shed its leisure businesses and refocus around its real estate operations.

title: Bottom of Order Tops the Angels
description: Their combined averages do not equal what Dave Winfield is hitting these days, but tonight, as the Yankees began a 12-game, 14-day trip, Joel Skinner and Rafael Santana delivered.

title: Networks to Bid for '92 Games
description: The American television rights to the 1992 Olympic Winter Games in Albertville, France, are expected to be awarded today to either NBC or CBS.
