title: Albertson's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Sports People; Arizona Governor Hurt
description: Gov. Rose Mofford of Arizona suffered a mild concussion Sunday when she and Gene Stallings, the coach of the football Cardinals, fell from a rostrum during an anti-drug gathering in Yuma, Ariz. Vada Manager, a spokeswoman for the Governor, said she would stay home all week and do her work there. The Governor said in a statement: ''Rose Mofford took some pretty hard spills during her years playing softball and basketball. Please tell my teammates in the Legislature that I'm not out for the season.'' Stallings, whose club has relocated to Phoenix from St. Louis, said the mishap occurred as he returned to his chair after giving a preliminary talk. ''I didn't want to sit in front of her, not even a little bit,'' he said, explaining his decision to move his chair back a few inches. ''I should have looked to see how much was there, but I didn't,'' Stallings said. He said his left arm went out involuntarily as he fell, toppling the chair of the Governor. Stallings was unhurt. (AP)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apogee Enterprises Inc., Minneapolis, said Russell Baumgardner would step down as chairman after the company's annual meeting on June 28 but would continue as a director. Mr. Baumgardner, Apogee's founder, has recommended that Donald Goldfus, president and chief officer, succeed him.

title: By Design: Weekend Savers
description: There are some items that, when tossed into a weekend bag at the last minute, can make all the difference.

title: Acquisition by Vickers
description: Vickers P.L.C., a British military and automobile company, said today that it was acquiring the Imperial Metal and Chemical Company of Philadelphia for about $12 million. Imperial, the second-largest provider of aluminum plates to American newspapers, will become part of Howson-Algraphy Ltd., a Vickers subsidiary.

description: In its first acquisition move into the United States, Gold Greenlees Trott, a publicly held London-based agency, has negotiated the purchase of Babbit & Reiman Advertising, Atlanta, for $2.5 million down and additional payouts based on profits during the next four or five years.

title: The Speed of Change in Moscow
description: Again Mikhail Gorbachev appears both bold and cautious, determined to change his deeply conservative country yet uncertain exactly how. In an interview in The Washington Post on Sunday, he demonstrated his usual mix of candor and calculation. It's understandable that he seemed in his words, as in his leadership, to pick a path between impatience and conservatism. He has his eye on more than the impending summit meeting with Ronald Reagan. An unusually important Communist Party conference is only a month away. Even so, the net effect is still arresting.

title: Man Held to Act Alone In Killing U.S.Judge
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that a retired New York City police officer apparently acted alone in slaying a Federal judge at his home in Westchester County.

title: Clean Hydrogen Beckons Aviation Engineers
description: VIRTUALLY unnoticed abroad except by aviation experts, a recent broadcast by Soviet television showed an ordinary-looking airliner roaring aloft from a Moscow-area airport, trailing a stream of condensing steam instead of the usual kerosene smoke.

title: As Science Moves Into Commerce, Openness Is Lost
description: SCIENTISTS, scholars and Congressmen are raising alarms about what they see as major new assaults on the traditional openness of science, a rise in secrecy they fear may undermine the long-term progress of science and innovation.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'Did You Hear . . .?'
description: David A. Harris, Washington representative of the American Jewish Committee, is doing his part to humor those traveling with President Reagan to the Moscow summit. He has sent copies of his book ''The Jokes of Oppression, The Humor of Soviet Jews,'' to President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the principal correspondents who will be accompanying the President.

title: Silver State Mining Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Steve's Homemade Ice Cream reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Deports 226 Aliens From Jails in New York
description: More than 200 aliens serving sentences at Rikers Island and other New York City jails have been deported in the last year under a Federal and city program, officials said yesterday.

title: Universal Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Appeals Court Faults Judge In Queens Case
description: A New York State appeals court ruled last night that the judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case had acted improperly in holding a closed proceeding in the case and in planning to hold at least one more.

title: Toledo Zoo Receives Approval for Pandas
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has decided to allow the Toledo Zoo to begin exhibiting two giant pandas on loan from China while zoo officials work to produce the required export papers, the service said today.

title: Casino Won't Back Temple-Kansas
description: The Showboat Hotel and Casino withdrew today as sponsor of the Kansas-Temple basketball game on Dec. 10 because of the controversy surrounding casino support of an intercollegiate athletic event.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bonds and Notes Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed to down slightly in slow trading yesterday.

title: Two Suits Filed By 60 Families At Harlem Fire
description: Sixty families that suffered either deaths, displacement or injuries in the fire at the Schomburg Plaza high-rise apartment house in Harlem last year filed lawsuits yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan seeking a total of $414 million in damages from the city and the building's managers.

title: Gorbachev Aide Urges an Alternative to the Party
description: A key adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for creation of a nationwide ''popular front'' that would be a political alternative to the Communist Party.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A charge that Jerry Olson, the basketball coach at Iowa Wesleyan University, attempted to scalp complimentary tickets to the N.C.A.A. tournament's Final Four in Kansas City, Mo., in late March has been dismissed in a Kansas City, Mo., municipal court. . . . Rod Baker, the head basketball coach at Tufts University the past five years, has been named an assistant at Seton Hall to Coach P.J. Carlesimo.

title: New Law in Maryland Bans Sale And Manufacture of Some Pistols
description: Gov. William Donald Schaefer signed into law today a bill that makes the state the first to ban the sale of some cheap pistols.

title: Refac Technology Development Corp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $332,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a gain of $45,000.

title: Reviews/Music; New Instruments and Exotic Scales
description: This past week the American Festival of Microtonal Music, or Microfest, has been offering a cornucopia of works in virtually every contemporary style, from razor-edged academicism to post-Minimalist, with a smattering of Baroque music as a change of pace. The music is scored for both standard instruments and exotically newfangled ones, but what all the works have in common is their departure from the 12-note tempered scale on which Western harmony has been based these last few centuries.

title: Regan and Speakes Draw Fire on Books
description: Books by two former White House staff members, Donald T. Regan and Larry Speakes, should not have been published until President Reagan left office, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, says.

title: ABS Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $70,000 for the quarter and $137,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $63,000 and $65,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the quarter and $73,000 for the 6 months, tax credits of $223,000 and $412,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Boeing May Get Order From Allegis for 60 Jets
description: The Boeing Company is close to getting an order for about 60 airplanes of the 757 class from the Allegis Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, industry experts said yesterday.

title: Solitec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the 6 months, and a $77,000 gain on debt restructuring for the both periods.

title: FMC in Turkish Deal
description: Turkey signed a billion-dollar contract today with the FMC Corporation of the United States and its Turkish partner to build 1,700 armored combat vehicles, Turkish military officials said. A consortium formed by FMC and the Nurol Group will build the vehicles over 10 years in one of several joint ventures aimed at developing Turkey's military industry, they said.

title: From Carter and Ford, an American Agenda
description: Former President Jimmy Carter was ebullient. ''For the first time in the nation's history,'' he said, ''we'll have a bipartisan effort to help heal the political divisions of our election process.''

title: Hetra Computer & Communiations Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Healthcare Services of Amerca reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $841,080 for the latest quarter and $79,859 in the year-ago period.

title: Silicon Valley Water Report
description: A new study by the California Department of Health Services has concluded that ground-water pollution caused by the Silicon Valley electronics industry was ''probably not'' responsible for the higher-than-normal number of miscarriages and birth defects found in one neighborhood. Its residents had drunk water contaminated by solvents from the semiconductor plants.

title: Royce Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: In Indiana, Public School Makes 'Frills' Standard
description: Like most fifth graders, Amanda Cave spends much of her days on the three R's. But one recent day, she also worked on an architectural drawing, played the trumpet, did improvisational dancing, went on a scavenger hunt in the park and studied Spanish.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Mexico Extending Freeze
description: The Government of President Miguel de la Madrid has decided to extend for three more months a freeze on wages and prices of federally regulated goods and services,the Government news agency Notimex reported on Sunday.

title: Lakers Jump Out To One-Game Lead
description: James Worthy scored 28 points and Byron Scott had 23 as the Los Angeles Lakers turned back a second-quarter Dallas rally and beat the Mavericks, 113-98, tonight in Game 1 of the National Basketball Association's Western Conference final.

title: Sammy Davis Sr. Dies; Vaudeville Star Was 87
description: Sammy Davis Sr., a vaudeville performer and the father of the entertainer Sammy Davis Jr., died Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: PAKISTAN ACCUSED OF A NUCLEAR MOVE
description: Pakistan has test-fired a missile capable of carrying a nuclear weapon, according to an Administration official.

title: Bruins Hang On Despite the Odds
description: Randy Gregg, the veteran Edmonton defenseman, could not suppress a smile as he considered the impact his team's three consecutive victories against the Bruins might have on the fourth game of their four-of-seven-game National Hockey League final series.

title: Cambridge Analytical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Designcraft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,989,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Net income

title: Acton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $75,000 tax credit. c-Includes $12,990,000 income from a discount of indebtedess and a $4,397,000 tax credit. Year-ago first quarter net from operations includes a $7,556,000 gain from the sale of two cable television systems.

title: Policy on Ship Seizures Is Altered
description: The Customs Service and Coast Guard today altered part of their aggressive campaign against illegal drugs, a spokesman for the Customs Service said.

title: Trans-Atlantic Fares Are Cut
description: British Airways and Virgin Atlantic Airways began a price war today when they cut trans-Atlantic fares from London to increase sales in Britain.

title: Multi-Color Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
In Paris, Tout le Monde Cheers McEnroe
description: The crowd roared and jumped to its feet to welcome John McEnroe back to the big time today on the first day of the French Open tennis tournament. As admired here as any Frenchman, McEnroe nodded to his supporters, then went on to the serious work of defeating Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union in three uneven sets, 7-6, 6-1, 7-6.

title: First State Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparable year-ago quarter and 6-month net figures are not applicable because the company went public December 1987.

title: PC's on a Target Range
description: THE annual Spring Comdex computer show in Atlanta earlier this month meant a booming business for the Bulletstop, an indoor firing range in suburban Marietta where customers can rent firearms and bullets to shoot anything they please, as long as it is already dead and fits through the doors. The Bulletstop gave Comdex visitors a chance to vent their frustrations by venting PC's, printers, hard disks, monitors and manuals with lead.

title: First Central Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Met Pro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bias Is Weighed In Attack on 2 In Bronx Street
description: A man was hit on the head with a pipe and his cousin was punched outside their apartment house in the Bronx Sunday night in what the police initially characterized as a ''bias-related attack'' involving a dozen or more white youths.

title: Ex-Im Bank Record Loss
description: The Government agency that assists United States exports reported today that it had lost a record $460.9 million in 1987 and said its financial condition would remain bleak for several years.

title: N.H.L. Players Honored
description: The National Hockey League named the winners of several awards for hockey excellence at the league's annual luncheon today.

title: Sports People; Challenge for Nixon
description: Russ Nixon indicated he was undaunted by the prospect of taking over the lowly Atlanta Braves, but he acknowleded that the team's pitching problems were a major challenge for him. ''The club is struggling . . . got a ways to go,'' Nixon said yesterday in Chicago after succeeding Chuck Tanner, who was dismissed Sunday night. ''But it's not the first time I've been in this situation.'' Nixon's other major league managerial stint was with the Cincinnati Reds. He took over from the dismissed John McNamara in July 1982 and managed the Reds through the 1983 season. They finished last both years. ''I have a better grade of players here than I had at Cincinnati,'' Nixon said. ''My primary concern is to get the pitching staff going,'' he said. ''Zane Smith is a question mark and there are other question marks. The younger guys are having problems. '' Smith led the Braves with a 15-10 record last year but is 2-3 this year. He has a bone spur in his left pitching elbow. Nixon was brought in from Greenville, S.C., where he was managing the Braves' farm club in the Southern League. The Braves' scheduled game with the Cubs yesterday was rained out and will become part of a doubleheader today. (AP)

title: Review/Theater; Black Life in the 50's: Hope, Pain and Dreams
description: It is the 1950's, not yet the time for a large-scale crossover of rhythm-and-blues. With the emergence of Elvis Presley, however, more black songwriters are thinking about the possibilities of having a broad, popular appeal. At least that is the dream in Teddy's Barbershop and Records in West Memphis, Ark., the scene of Martin Jones's play, ''West Memphis Mojo'' (at the Negro Ensemble Company).

title: Exploration Co of Louisiana reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter net equals less than 1 cent a share.

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Executive Hired by G.M.
description: General Motors has hired Shirley Young, long Grey Advertising's premier consumer researcher, as vice president of consumer market development.

title: Study of Rare Syndrome Yields Clues About Brain
description: STROKE victims who suffer bizarre difficulties in recognizing faces, perceiving colors or seeing objects move are helping to support a new theory that the brain is organized along parallel pathways.

title: Friendly Bid Raised For Irving
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana yesterday increased its offer for 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corporation's stock to $80 a share from $75 in an effort to make its friendly offer more attractive than a competing hostile bid from the Bank of New York Company.

title: Gifted Parents Help Collegiate School
description: When preparatory schools raise money, they often hold auctions or organize dinner parties. Last night, the Collegiate School held a Carnegie Hall concert.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Occidental Expects Higher Revenues
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation's acquisition of the Cain Chemical Company should help increase its 1988 revenues to $20 billion from last year's $17.09 billion, Dr. Armand Hammer, the company's chairman, told shareholders at its annual meeting.

title: Dale McConathy, 48, N.Y.U. Art Professor
description: Dale McConathy, chairman of the Department of Art and Art Education of the New York University School of Education, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan, an N.Y.U. spokesman, Randi Wershba, said. He was 48 years old.

title: Allis-Chalmers Unit Sale
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Power Generation Services business for $14.5 million cash to a new company formed by the subsidiary's managers. Allis-Chalmers said sale of the unit, based in West Allis, Wis., was subject to review by constituencies in its Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding, the bankruptcy court and the Allis-Chalmers board. The unit has more than 250 workers and provides repair, replacement parts and field services for electrical utilities and selected industrial equipment.

title: Envoy Returns to Panama to Press Talks
description: President Reagan sent a senior State Department official back to Panama today to see again whether a deal could be reached to have the country's military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, give up power.

title: Barden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Centennial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Dinner Is 'Postponed'
description: Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's former chief of staff, may have more to say about the Reagan White House than he has already made public in his book about his time there as chief of staff, ''For the Record.'' He won't be saying it soon at the Metropolitan Club, whose membership includes a number of Administration officials.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, which makes electrical appliances and personal-care products, said negotiations to sell its Thermco Systems Inc. unit to BTU Engineering of Billerica, Mass., had been ended because of opposition to the proposed merger by the antitrust division of the Justice Department.

title: Kohlberg's Stake in Texaco Puzzles Traders on Wall St.
description: Wall Street traders have a mystery on their hands: why Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, one of the nation's biggest investment houses, wants more than $500 million worth of Texaco stock.

title: Poland Rejects Notion of Another 'Marshall Plan'
description: Poland's Communist leadership has rejected plans being discussed in the West under which it said Poland was being asked to make deep changes in its political system in exchange for a large infusion of financial aid.

title: Unequal Stock Class Opposed
description: The chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he believes the commission has the legal power to stop companies listed on public exchanges from issuing stock with unequal voting rights. In a letter released today, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, told the S.E.C.'s chairman, David S. Ruder, that ''the commission has the authority to mandate a one-share, one-vote rule.'' He added, ''It is time to move forward with sound and appropriate safeguards that will insure the continued participation of the American shareholder in corporate policy.''

title: Primary in Kentucky District: Hard Race Takes Nasty Turn
description: First the incumbent questioned his challenger's religious convictions and branded him a carpetbagger. Then the Democratic primary race in the First Congressional District really got nasty.

title: Boston Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Motown Records misidentified the chairman of the MCA Entertainment Group. He is Irving Azoff.

title: U.S. Judge Finds No Conflict In Law Firm's Takeover Role
description: A Federal district judge in Nashville ruled yesterday that the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company had not adequately proved its accusation that the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell improperly shared information with clients who were on opposite sides of a hostile takeover.

title: 'GOD IS WEEPING'
description: Eight-year-old Nicholas Corwin, slain in a woman's rampage through this Chicago suburb, was buried today after more than 1,000 mourners heard a rabbi say, ''We know that God is weeping.''

title: Consumers Financial Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $40,000 gain on investments and a tax benefit of $78,000. c-Net income and includes a $315,000 gain on investments and a tax benefit of $58,000.

title: Photon Technology International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 Generic Drug Concerns in Merger
description: Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc., a manufacturer of generic drugs, has merged with the Major Pharmaceutical Group, which is made up of four generic drug distributors with outlets in six states. Vitarine, based in Springfield Gardens, Queens, said the combined companies would have revenues of $120 million in 1988. Mary Beals, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said Vitarine, a private company, would be ''among the top 20'' in the growing generic drug business. Industry sales totaled $1.5 billion last year, she said.

title: In a More Open Soviet Society, Freedom Can Sprout, Then Vanish
description: When Lev M. Timofeyev's daughter was assigned a school essay entitled ''The Happiest Day of My Life,'' the 14-year-old focused on the day in February 1987 when her father came home from prison as a wave of political dissidents was released from Soviet prisons.

title: Indonesia, Spain in Deal
description: Indonesia and Spain agreed today to market aircraft jointly in the United States and discussed cooperation in agriculture, energy and tourism. The Indonesian Minister of State, Murdiono, said the two countries had agreed to form a joint marketing company in the United States to sell Spanish-designed aircraft built in Indonesia by the state aircraft company.

title: British Delay Ruling on Budd
description: British track officials today delayed a ruling on Zola Budd's eligibility to run for Britain until she returns from her self-imposed rest period in South Africa.

title: Fuji Buying Part of Treasury Dealer
description: Fuji Bank Ltd. and Kleinwort Benson Ltd. announced yesterday that Fuji had agreed to buy a 24.9 percent stake in Kleinwort Benson Government Securities Inc., a Chicago-based dealer in Treasury securities.

title: Diet Eases Transplants in Rats
description: ASTRINGENT diet alone can make a kidney acceptable to a transplant recipient if the donor is put on the special diet for two months before the organ is removed, an experiment with rats has suggested.

title: Drug Files on Noriega Disappear in Panama
description: Documents said to implicate the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in drug-related activities have disappeared from the offices of the Drug Enforcement Administration at the United States Embassy in Panama, a Government official said here tonight.

title: Sparring to Book Europe's Flights
description: As Europe follows the American lead in deregulating air travel, a high-stakes battle has broken out between United States and European carriers over an increasingly crucial market: computer reservation systems.

title: Many Newspapers Hurt by a Slump in Retail Ads
description: A slump in local retail advertising and higher newsprint prices are hurting many newspapers, according to industry analysts.

title: Southland Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Savings Unit Review Ends
description: Lincoln savings and Loan Association said today that a long examination of the savings institution by the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco had ended with an amicable but an unusual twist.

title: Texaco Still Hopeful on Icahn Truce
description: The management of Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it still hoped to avoid a proxy fight with Carl C. Icahn, the company's biggest shareholder. But people familiar with the Texaco-Icahn talks seemed less optimistic about a truce than they were over the weekend.

title: Fluorocarbon Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,049,000 from the sale of a 50 percent interest in a Japanese joint venture.

title: Film Tells Of Building Of Memorial
description: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington was planned and completed in just three years because people with widely divergent views on the war in Vietnam joined forces to support the project. In a similar way, ''To Heal a Nation,'' the television film about the building of the memorial - which will be shown Sunday on NBC - reached the screen because film makers with very different perspectives on the war were united in their commitment to the movie.

title: Neeco Inc () reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Striped Bass, In Comeback, Spur Debate Over Fishing
description: The low-slung aluminum boat, a big electric generator squarely amidships, moved in a lazy S pattern through the tidal waters of the Elk River, two poles in front sending 1,000 volts into the brackish water. Dozens of small white perch, temporarily stunned, traced a kind of wake behind the boat.

title: Van Gogh at a Discount
description: The Guggenheim Museum announced yesterday that after years of quiet negotiations, it had privately purchased a work by Vincent van Gogh ''at a fraction of what the same painting would bring at an auction in New York or in Paris.''

title: News Analysis; Some Second Thoughts On Free Trade
description: Free trade, a hallowed tenet of Western economics, is fading as a goal of American policy, as the debate over the trade bill shows. Now a minority among those who study the nation's trade policies is saying that, in an imperfect world, some second thoughts about free trade are long overdue.

title: Mets Eager to Settle Score With Giants
description: The Mets came home yesterday with a seven-game winning streak, a five-and-a-half-game lead and a yearning for revenge against the only team that has bugged them, the San Francisco Giants, who open a 13-game home stand for the Mets tonight in Shea Stadium.

title: Killing Abu Jihad Was Not Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Union Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included provision for asset writeoffs and non-recurring charges of $603 million.

title: What Drug Dealers Are Doing to America's Housing Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Myths Bring Cohesion to the Chaos of Each Life
description: THE ancient myths are not dead; they live on in the stories people tell about their own lives.

title: Sports People; Old-Timer Pitches In
description: Ron Oglesby figured his days as a pitcher were well behind him. After all, he's 38 years old and hadn't pitched competitively since 1973. But when called upon, he quickly came out of retirement. Oglesby, the pitching coach of the Riverside Red Wave, took the mound in the 20th inning of a California League game against the San Jose Giants in Riverside and wound up suffering the loss in the 6-hour-19-minute game, which ended early yesterday. After retiring the side in order in the top of the 20th, Oglesby was touched for three runs and four hits in the 21st as the Giants defeated the Red Wave, 8-5. ''I forgot the last time I pitched, maybe 15 years ago,'' said Oglesby, who hurls batting practice on a regular basis for the Red Wave. Oglesby was listed as a pitcher rather than as a coach on the Riverside roster before the game. California League teams are allowed to make such designations to fill out their 25-man rosters on a daily basis.(AP)

title: Edelman Group Lifts Payless Stake
description: An investment group headed by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman has raised its stake in Payless Cashways Inc. to 9 percent from 7.6 percent.

title: Ross Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Koch Disputes Reports on Effects of Sewage
description: Mayor Koch expressed ''strong disagreement'' yesterday with the assertion of New England lobstermen that sewage sludge from New York City's newest and only ocean dump site is harming marine life in undersea canyons.

title: From Boom to Bust: Trendy Shops Take a Fall on Columbus Avenue
description: When chic stores catering to the rich began opening on Columbus Avenue in the early 1980's, real-estate executives thought the strip on New York's Upper West Side would become a gold mine. It has not worked out that way. As one pricey boutique after another has closed, unable to attract the business necessary to pay the stratospheric rents, real-estate professionals are calling Columbus Avenue - from 72d to 86th Streets - one of the biggest retailing busts in recent memory.

title: First American Health Conepts reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Another Challenge For Weary Celtics
description: After a softening up by the Knicks and a struggle to outlast the younger, quicker and more athletic Atlanta Hawks in a seven-game series, the National Basketball Association's oldest team, the Boston Celtics, now face another challenge.

title: Children and AIDS: Drug Tests Raise Hope And Ethical Concerns
description: EARLY studies of an AIDS drug in children have recently shown promising results, indicating that the lives of many babies with AIDS can be prolonged and improved.

title: Worker Slain in Bowling Alley; Fleeing Gunman Kills Himself
description: A gunman walked into a bowling alley card room today and opened fire, killing one person and critically wounding another before fleeing and then fatally wounding himself, the police said.

title: Arnox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Banking on America's Word
description: All the World Bank's 151 members have pledged funds to increase its capital. Among the big ones, only the United States has not delivered. A House Appropriations subcommittee has refused to approve America's share. Unless the Reagan Administration bestirs itself, the result will be worldwide embarrassment.

title: Q&A
description: How do birds know when it's time to come back north?

title: College Lacrosse; Syracuse Zeroes In on Title
description: The world of college lacrosse has begun to appreciate that Syracuse may have one of the best teams in the history of the sport.

title: Has Bush Lost California?
description: Picture Vice President Bush campaigning in California later this year. Silent, well-dressed witnesses carrying placards move to the front of the crowd at every stop. They carry silhouettes shaped like offshore oil platforms and long-armed cactuses. These images, and Dukakis television spots reinforcing them, reach millions of television viewers, reminding them that Mr. Bush has chosen not to oppose Lease Sale 91, the upcoming sale of northern California offshore drilling rights, and has stayed silent on the Southern California Desert Protection Bill pending before Congress.

title: Court Refuses to Hear Appeal on Annuities
description: In a case that has caused concern in the insurance industry, the Supreme Court declined today to hear an industry appeal of a Federal appeals court decision suggesting that millions of ''fixed annuities'' sold by insurance companies are subject to Federal securities laws.

title: Cagle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,595,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss of $888,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Rex-Noreco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

Careers;
Stock Option Risks for Executives
description: LEAD: ''UNDERWATER'' stock options have become a problem for many companies, but few plan rescue efforts, according to a survey by the benefits consulting firm of William M. Mercer Meidinger Hansen.

title: Results Plus
description: College Baseball Fordham Gains N.C.A.A. Berth: Tom Levy's two-run double keyed a six-run seventh inning yesterday as Fordham overtook Hartford, 10-8, at New Britain, Conn., to win the E.C.A.C. championship and a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Patterns
description: A Designer Expands

title: Hungarians Hail Wide Broom Used to Sweep Out Old Guard
description: Politically active Hungarians, supporters and critics of the Government, today welcomed the removal of Janos Kadar from the Communist Party leadership and expressed open elation over the sweeping character of what some called a ''housecleaning.''

title: Beware a Desperate Deal in Panama
description: The Reagan Administration's Panama policy has failed - and all but a few American political leaders now admit it. Unfortunately, the last believers include President Reagan and Secretary of State Shultz and they are straying into paths of desperation and expediency. They would be better off to pause and regroup.

title: A Game for Adults
description: Most adults prefer the slower-paced types of computer games, leaving the fast-reflex, arcade-style amusements to younger players. Golf and baseball simulations, for instance, rely more on judgment and strategy than on lightning-quick reflexes. Even the most realistic flight simulators are positively contemplative when compared with games in which you blast hordes of aliens.

title: U.S. Rig Count Rises
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States increased by nine this week, to a total of 892, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 762 a year ago. The count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Datavision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: AIDS Babies' Prospects
description: A NEW study, the first to provide data on the medical prospects of infants who carry the AIDS virus, found that some were doing better than experts had expected, even after several years.

title: KIDNAPPING DEATH BRINGS CONVICTION
description: A jury convicted a 31-year-old man of kidnapping and murder today in the death of a prominent businessman who was buried alive in a box as part of a $1 million ransom attempt.

title: Boise Journal; Survival Duty in 'Raptor Capital of the World'
description: Day-old peregrine falcon chicks, hardly acting or eating like birds, gulp down chunks of fresh quail offered at the end of a tweezer.

title: U.S. CHARGES GROUP BILKED INVESTORS
description: An Atlanta-based group posing as a national prepaid legal services company took in $3 million in a nine-month period, bilking nearly 400 people who were seeking franchises, according to Federal officials.

title: Sandinistas Extending Cease-Fire by 30 Days
description: Nicaragua announced today that it was extending a seven-week-old truce to allow more time for peace talks with the United States-backed rebels.

title: Fisher Business Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $145,000 charge to reflect revised inventory counts and pricing and a $60,000 provision to increase the reserve for doubtful accounts.

title: Colombian Jet Hijacked; Gunman Vanishes
description: A man described as mentally unstable hijacked a Colombian jet with 135 people aboard today and forced it to fly to Panama and Aruba after letting the passengers off. The plane later returned to Colombia where the man vanished.

title: Baseball; Boddicker Ends Slump After 13 Losses
description: Mike Boddicker ended his team-record 13-game losing streak tonight and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Oakland Athletics, 7-3, for their third straight victory.

title: Bishops Decry Anti-Semitism
description: A committee of Italian bishops expressed ''profound concern'' today over a recent upsurge of anti-Semitic threats and violence here, warning Italian Roman Catholics not to hold Jews responsible for Israeli Government policies toward the Palestinian uprising.

title: Foreign Firms Trade in Tokyo
description: Nine foreign securities firms, including six from the United States, began trading today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Whittaker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said technology operating profits for the first 6 months of 1988 included a second quarter pre-tax gain of $3.7 million on the sale of a start-up technology unit. This gain was offset by about $2 million in second quarter pre-tax writeoffs related to certain contracts assumed in prior year acquisitions and by the first quarter pre-tax charge of $3.5 million for the costs of consolidating the company's electronic systems and microwave systems units.

title: Boy, 17, Is Fatally Shot And a 2d Youth Is Held
description: A 17-year-old boy was shot to death by another 17-year-old youth in the East New York section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Scherer Opposition Firm on Sale Plan
description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a pharmaceuticals supplier, said that it continued to reject its largest shareholder's proposal that the company be sold. Peter R. Fink, Scherer's president and chief executive, said that Karla Scherer Fink's proposal could override the company's board only if it gained 80 percent of the common-share votes.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thief Slain and Mulberry St. Grocer Arrested
description: A grocer in the Little Italy section shot and killed a man after he had tried to take money from the cash register Sunday night, the police said.

title: Alternative HealthCare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hurco Companies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $403,000 for the quarter and $600,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax benefits of $10,000 and $90,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago periods have been restated.

title: Thousands of Hindu Workers Flee Punjab as Sikhs Step Up Violence
description: Thousands of Hindu migrant workers from eastern India have fled Punjab after more than 50 of them were killed last week by Sikhs, the state's top police official said today.

title: A New Chief Executive Is Named at Symbolics
description: Symbolics Inc., a struggling technology company in the artificial intelligence business, announced yesterday that it had named Jay Wurts chairman and chief executive.

title: BRE Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a net gain on sales of investments totaling $1,353,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Albany Sees Gap of $900 Million In Budget, Tripling Earlier Figure
description: The New York State budget shortfall will be $900 million -three times what the Cuomo administration had projected just three weeks ago - and programs will have to be cut, the administration announced today.

title: Benedict P. Willis Jr. Chemical Executive, 66
description: Benedict P. Willis Jr., a former vice president of the Stauffer Chemical Company, died of colon cancer Thursday at his home in Rutherford, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
Walter G. Stackler, 83, Long Island Builder
description: Walter G. Stackler, a Long Island builder, died Friday at a nursing home in Delray Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 83 years old and maintained residences in Gulf Stream, Fla., and Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: Gordimer to Read in South African Artists Benefit
description: Four short stories by South African writers will be read at Symphony Space on Wednesday evening. The reading, which will be introduced by Nadine Gordimer, the white South African novelist and short-story writer, is a benefit for the African Arts Fund, which provides scholarship assistance for black South African artists to study in the United States.

title: Count Dino Grandi, 92, Early Ally of Mussolini
description: Count Dino Grandi, an early leader of the Italian Fascists and a close ally of Mussolini, died on Saturday at his home in Bologna. He was 92 years old and, according to a report by the state-run Italian television network, had suffered from cardiac and circulatory problems for some time.

title: Soviet Troops Said to Patrol Streets of City in Azerbaijan
description: Soviet troops are patrolling the streets of Stepanakert, capital of the predominantly Armenian region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which has been at the center of Transcaucasian unrest, a local party official said today.

title: Unimed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pop Radio Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports People; Tolentine Coach to Pitt
description: John Sarandrea, who coached Tolentine High School of the Bronx to a 30-1 record last season, said yesterday he would become an assistant basketball coach at the University of Pittsburgh. Sarandrea, 30, will replace John Caliperi, who has been named coach at the University of Massachusetts. Sarandrea said he would give Pitt, coached by Paul Evans, ''some immediate credibility in the New York area,'' where the Panthers have not recruited well. Tolentine's basketball team was ranked the No. 1 high school in the na-tion by USA Today. (AP)

title: Leisure Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $2,823,000 charge from the early retirement of debt.

title: Dress Barn Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 23
Computer Sabotage Charge
description: In the first application of a Texas law against computer sabotage, a computer programmer is being prosecuted on felony charges of infecting his former employer's computers with an electronic ''virus.''

title: Chess
description: Once again an Icelander has triumphed on home ground. Following the success of Jon Arnason in the earlier Reykjavik Open Tournament, his fellow grandmaster Johann Hjartarson won the $3,000 first prize in the Reykjavik Invitational Tournament.

title: Microsoft Offers Money-Back Deal
description: The Microsoft Corporation has announced a money-back guarantee for its Excel spreadsheet software product, saying that it was making the offer to compete with the 1-2-3 software package of the Lotus Development Corporation. Microsoft's Excel has won acclaim, but many customers are reluctant to switch because they are familiar with Lotus's 1-2-3. Both products sell for $495.

title: At 100, Journal Is Still Lawyers Forum
description: Irving Berlin was not yet born, the snow from the Great Blizzard had not yet melted and Brooklyn was still a city when The New York Law Journal made its debut. It was dedicated ''to the reporting of legal decisions, the production of topics of interest to the Bench and Bar, and the publication of court calendars and of legal notices.''

title: Carol Neilson Wilder, Speech Pathologist, 58
description: Dr. Carol Neilson Wilder, an adjunct associate professor of speech pathology at Teachers College of Columbia University, died of colon cancer Thursday at her home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. She was 58 years old. She sang professionally with the Robert Shaw Chorale and the American Bach Society. She was a board member of the Voice Foundation and associate editor of The Journal of Voice.

title: Radical Air Force Maneuver Reduces Sonic Boom Damage
description: Three ear-shattering booms mark the flight of an F-111 fighter-bomber thundering at supersonic speed just 200 feet above a test range in the Florida Panhandle.

title: Battles Erupt in Beirut as Truce Talks Falter
description: Artillery duels broke out again between rival Shiite Moslem groups today after the collapse of talks on moving 7,000 Syrian troops into the southern suburbs of Beirut to end the factional fighting.

title: Our Towns; Minister Teaches The Almighty Isn't Republican
description: The Rev. Robert Bedingfield is used to dropping out of the sky and surprising folks. As a Marine chaplain he did 200 jumps, some into combat in Vietnam, unarmed. About eight years ago he landed as pastor at the very rich Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Bunshaft and Niemeyer Share Architecture Prize
description: Gordon Bunshaft and Oscar Niemeyer, two of modern architecture's venerated masters, were awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize yesterday in Chicago. The presentation marks the first time that the award, which is given annually for achievement in architecture as an art and carries a $100,000 stipend, has been divided between two architects.

title: Western Union Posts A Big Loss
description: Reflecting the costs of its broad restructuring, the Western Union Corporation yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $625.2 million.

title: Settlement That Shuts Shoreham Is Called Less Costly by Analysts
description: A settlement between New York State and the Long Island Lighting Company that would result in the abandonment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant is likely to be less costly to Long Island residents and businesses than a public takeover of the troubled utility, independent financial analysts say.

title: Another Palestinian Is Killed By Israeli Soldiers in Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers killed another Palestinian today in the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: Tigers' Streak Snapped at 5
description: Tom Filer of Milwaukee, making his first major league appearance in three years, checked Detroit on five hits as the Brewers ended the Tigers' five-game winning streak with a 7-0 victory tonight.

title: The Way in Jersey City for 70 Years
description: When Frank Hague, starting in 1918, insinuated his political machine into every facet of Jersey City life, including the school system, he planted roots so deep that they have continued to surface to the present day.

title: Canadians Facing Fight On Trade Bill
description: The Canadian Government went before Parliament today with legislation that would put into effect the free-trade agreement with the United States. But the measure received a cool greeting, indicating it may take the Government several months to get the bill passed in the House of Commons.

title: TRADE BILL VETOED AS PRESIDENT ASKS FOR NEW MEASURE
description: President Reagan today fulfilled his pledge to veto the sweeping trade bill produced by Congress after three years of work, but he struck a conciliatory note in his veto message.

title: Chip Maker's I.B.M. Accord
description: Chips and Technologies Inc. said today that it had reached an understanding with the International Business Machines Corporation so it would not need a license for its products under I.B.M.'s patents.

title: Topics of The Times; Laxity in the Lab
description: Proper clinical testing of blood and tissue samples can provide early detection of cancer, heart disease and other life-threatening ailments. But lax oversight of lab performance has led to a frightening level of inaccuracy. Sound legislation proposed by Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, would begin to set higher standards for the $20 billion medical testing industry.

title: Newspaper's Computer Is Infected With a 'Virus'
description: A rogue computer program introduced into personal computers at The Providence Journal-Bulletin earlier this month destroyed one reporter's files and spread to floppy disks throughout the newspaper's computer system, the Rhode Island newspaper said.

title: Brawley's Mother Defies a Grand Jury Subpoena
description: The mother of Tawana Brawley ignored a grand jury subpoena today, defying New York State's first effort to compel her family's cooperation in the investigation of what the family says was the racially motivated abduction and rape of the black Dutchess County teen-ager.

title: Hogan Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $150,000 and $1,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,607,000 for the quarter and $4,185,000 for the year. Results for fiscal 1987 have been restated to include the operations of GDK Systems Inc., which was acquired in May 1987 on a pooling-of-interests basis. Fiscal 1988 revenue includes a gain of $3,603,000 from a contract settlement and related software revenue resulting from a discontinuation of a joint development project. Also, the fiscal 1988 revenue includes a reduction of $2,495,000 due to a change in the company's method for recoring maintenance revenue.

title: Citicorp Paper Rate Up Again
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, held yesterday, continued their monthlong rise.

title: Nodaway Valley Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
New Offer Made To Hambletonian
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has offered to raise the purse for the Hambletonian by $200,000 in an attempt to keep the prestigious event at the Meadowlands.

title: Honor at Yale
description: For several years, Yale University has been manufacturing an astounding number of gifted students. In 1986, for example, more than half the graduating class received honors of one sort or another. The class of 1987 slipped a bit; even so, 46.4 percent graduated with honors - 23.9 percent cum laude, 11.5 percent magna cum laude, and 11 percent summa cum laude.

title: Proxmire Assails Report on Stock Fall
description: Senator William Proxmire strongly criticized the White House working group on the stock market collapse today, calling the report it issued last week ''pitiful'' and ''very disappointing.''

title: Beijing Journal; Out She Goes, Again, Miss Ideological Impurity
description: In 1947, Daisy Wang walked away with Shanghai's last beauty crown.

title: Prab Robots reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Mafia Killer Reported Slain
description: Sicilian officials believe that the Mafia's most feared assassin, Pino Greco, has been killed, police officials said today. Mr. Greco, convicted of 58 murders at a Mafia trial in Palermo in December, was responsible for many of the Mafia's most notorious killings.

title: How Sweet They Are: Onions That Hardly Ever Bring a Tear
description: WHEN Virginia Cenedella first walked into her neighborhood bank, she did not expect to be handed a five-pound sack of sweet onions. But onion giveaways are a tradition at the University National Bank and Trust Company in Palo Alto, Calif., whose chairman, Carl Schmitt, is a particular devotee of sweet onions.

title: Lowe's Companies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,226,000 from an accounting change.

title: Glasnost May Be Glasnost, but Prison Is Prison
description: LEAD: With the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting imminent, I recall the mounting excitement in our cells at Chistopol prison when, in 1979, we heard of the coming summit meeting in Vienna.

title: Culebra Journal; Caribbean Paradise Found and Lost
description: The year was 1961. A crisis in Berlin led to a lot of saber rattling on both sides of the cold war. Marcus Knowlton, a professor of aeronautical engineering at Princeton University, studied oceanographic and weather charts, searching for a sanctuary from thermonuclear fallout if the threat of war increased further.

title: The PopLife
description: Sade Speaks Out With her silky pop-soul voice, statuesque features and aura of unruffled composure, Sade, the Nigerian-born British pop star, is a figure who often seems swathed in enigma. Contrary to widely published speculation, ''Stronger Than Pride'' (Epic Records), her first album in more than two years, is not the artistic swan song of an artist fleeing the limelight in disillusion.

title: Caesars New Jersey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Pressure Rises for U.S. Flexibility on 'Star Wars'
description: President Reagan heads for Moscow apparently determined to resist any proposals that would place limitations on the Pentagon's plans to test anti-missile systems in space. But arms control experts, including some in the Administration, are saying that he may have already lost the leeway he is seeking to preserve.

title: Clones May Speed Up Laser Printing
description: The clone makers of Silicon Valley are at it again.

title: APL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $8,159,000 from an accounting change by Fischbach Corp. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $573,000 from equity in an extraordinary loss of Fischbach Corp. The results for the latest period include on a consolidated basis the operations of Fischbach Corp., a 52.9 percent owned subsidiary acquired during July 1987, for the entire period using the purchase method of accounting.

title: Study of G.M. Cars Is Expanded
description: Federal engineers have broadened their examination of sudden acceleration in autombiles built by the General Motors Corporation, adding 1.4 million C-body cars to the 703,000 H-body vehicles already under study, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: Vehicle Sales Up By 2.6%
description: Mid-May sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 2.6 percent above the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Lessons
description: On the long sweep of green among the maples in front of the Central Middle School here is a new apple tree, put in the ground this spring to honor Tennessee's newest hero. He is not an Andrew Jackson or a Davy Crockett or a Sergeant York. He is a teacher, Terry Weeks, the national teacher of the year.

title: Plastic Peanut Menace
description: It's easy to foresee a time not too far off when garbage disposal will be a bigger threat to the world than nuclear war. There was a hint of that future in the famous voyage of the Long Island garbage last year, and there is another hint in the recent passage on Long Island of a statute aimed at stopping fast-food shops from packing their burgers in indestructible plastic foam.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Budget Battle in Albany

title: Fraternity Life Beyond 'Animal House'; Fund-Raising Work
description: To the Editor:

title: In Philippines, One Last Symbol Lies in State
description: Small stickers on the wall read ''Let him come home,'' but in the San Jose chapel where his mother's body lies in an open coffin, hopes are fading that former President Ferdinand E. Marcos will be allowed to return for the funeral.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Saturday about the Atlantis Group gave an incorrect location for the company. Its headquarters are in Miami.

title: Statesman Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $45,000 and a pre-tax loss of $1.4 million on investment and mortgage banking. c-After loss from discontinued operations of $173,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., agreed to acquire the shares it does not already own of Matrix Science Corp.

title: Harvard Says Union Organizers Broke Rules
description: Harvard University said today that it had filed objections with the National Labor Relations Board contending that union representatives acted improperly last week as office, service and technical workers voted to form a local union.

title: Parliament in the 1980's: Naughty (and Not Nice?)
description: Parliament is only in its eighth century of existence, but still the 1988 session is turning into a collector's item, with nude frolicking reported in the House of Commons shower room and, of even greater prurient interest for the avid British politician watcher, naked powerbrokering displayed on the floor of the House of Lords.

title: Properties of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $250,000.

title: Banctec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-After a charge of $711,000 from an accounting change.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Foul Air at E.P.A.
description: It appears that the Environmental Protection Agency, the Federal watchdog agency created to protect the nation from pollution, has polluted its own headquarters building.

title: What Exit Polls Don't Predict
description: To the Editor:

title: Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Budget Battle Is Heating Up In Albany
description: A major confrontation between the Legislature and Governor Cuomo seemed in the making today as they began to address ways to close what the administration says is a $900 million shortfall in the state budget.

title: Hal Riney: Small but Competitive
description: HAL RINEY & PARTNERS, which won the multimillion-dollar General Motors Saturn account, could have easily been voted the least likely competitor to succeed. And that vote would have come on size alone.

title: Rockwell to Move From Pittsburgh
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it would relocate its corporate headquarters from Pittsburgh to El Segundo, Calif., although the aerospace company plans to retain 300 workers in mostly administrative jobs at its former corporate office.

title: Harold Henning, 69, Ex-Swimming Official
description: Dr. Harold W. Henning, a former president of the International Swimming Federation and the International Swimming Hall of Fame, died suddenly yesterday at his home in Naperville, Ill. He was 69 years old.

title: EDUCATION: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''For the first time in history, principals sat down next to teachers so that they could learn together.'' This indictment of aloof school administrators comes from Judith Hodgson, director of a Philadelphia program created to bring principals and teachers together to make schools more effective.

title: Qmax Technology Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Continental Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Surprising Choice on Saturn Ads
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it had chosen Hal Riney & Partners, a relatively small advertising agency best known for its commercials for Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers, to create advertising for the Saturn, its new line of cars.

title: Crazy Eddie Loss
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., now under the control of a new board backed by Entertainment Marketing Inc., said it expects to report additional, significant losses for the fourth quarter ended Feb. 28. The company said the latest losses were caused by insufficient sales, a soft consumer electronics market, adjustments arising from the new management's completion of its evaluation of the company and certain business practices and policies of prior management. In the third quarter, Crazy Eddie had a net loss of $73 million, and for the first nine months of the fiscal year it lost $83.3 million.

title: New York City Police Are Switching to a Bullet That Is Easier to Trace After Firing
description: The New York City Police Department has stopped purchasing a type of high-velocity ammunition because of the extreme difficulty in tracing bullets to service revolvers used in police shootings, department officials said yesterday.

title: Iroquois Brands Chief Resigns and Sells Stake
description: Terence J. Fox, who took over a faltering Buffalo brewery as a young man and turned it into Iroquois Brands Ltd., which at its height was a major food, beverage and vitamin company, has resigned as chairman and chief executive. He has also agreed to sell his 21.4 percent stake for an undisclosed price.

title: Senate Leaders Move to Speed Arms-Pact Vote
description: Annoyed with the tactics that have delayed approval of a new arms treaty, Senate Democratic and Republican leaders moved today to shut off amendments by opponents of the pact so that the treaty can come to a vote before President Reagan arrives in Moscow on Sunday.

title: Fraternity Life Beyond 'Animal House'
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Lake Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metropolitan Diary
description: D EAR Diary:

title: Emmanuel Paul, Jazz Saxophonist, 84
description: Emmanuel Paul, a jazz saxophonist who played with the Preservation Hall Band for years, died Monday. He was 84 years old.

title: Hong Kong Trade Gap
description: Hong Kong's trade deficit doubled in April from its level a year earlier, the Census and Statistics Department reported today. It said the deficit was 3.39 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $434 million (United States), last month, compared with 1.70 billion Hong Kong dollars in April 1987.

title: Midwestern College Beseiged by Applicants
description: Except for the Latin motto engraved in stone above the leaded windows, the Gothic archway at Washington University in St. Louis looks for all the world like Blair Hall at Princeton. And well it might. Built in 1900, the ivy-covered towers were designed by the same canny architects who sold an almost identical set of plans to Princeton a few years earlier.

title: Hannah J. Howell, 82, Art Librarian at Frick
description: Hannah Johnson Howell, chief librarian of the Frick Art Reference Library of the Frick Collection from 1948 until 1970, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
Automotive Parts Continue to Gain
description: LEAD: THE auto industry's expansion, now in its sixth year, has far exceeded analysts' expectations. Detroit's good fortunes have also helped the auto makers' suppliers, a far-flung crowd of thousands of companies, dozens of which are publicly traded.

title: Personal Computer Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.N. CHIEF MAKING NEW GULF EFFORT
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has started a new effort to bring about a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war and restore credibility to the Security Council's attempts to end the conflict, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: Review/Film; Rugged Tasmanian Grandeur
description: ''The Tale of Ruby Rose'' tries hard to live up to the mountains and mists of Tasmania's central highlands, where it is set in 1933, but the story cannot compete with the country's rugged grandeur. Ruby Rose makes her rough home in the wilderness with her trapper-skinner husband, Henry, and a young fellow whom they have adopted. Henry is not a bad sort beneath his unshaven cheeks, and Gem, the foster son, is a sensitive lad who gets upset by the trapper's trade. ''I don't like to kill 'em,'' says Gem. ''It's part of life, boy,'' says Henry. ''Things grow and you kill 'em.'' As for Ruby Rose, she wakes nightly in terror of the dark, which is filled with animal snorts and screams. She has a mystical or merely superstitious side, and is given to sprinkling around a whitish powder of some sort and painting the walls white to keep out the darkness. She says to herself: ''Death roams in the dark. To keep away the dark is to keep away death.'' For a near illiterate woman, she sure talks fancy: ''The dark has got into the heart. There is something that must be scoured.''

title: Review/Television; Ed Flanders as Dr. Westphal in ''St. Elsewhere.''
description: The doors of television's ''St. Elsewhere'' close tonight, at least as far as further first-run episodes are concerned. After six feisty seasons of being ensconced in the midsection of the weekly ratings lists, the NBC series will say goodbye at 10 o'clock. But St. Eligius - the offbeat teaching hospital in a poor Boston neighborhood is derisively called St. Elsewhere - may get yet another lease on life as the good Dr. Auschlander mounts one final campaign to save the institution. The guys over at MTM Enterprises - specifically, the executive producers, Bruce Paltrow, John Masius and Mark Tinker - are shameless cliffhanger addicts.

title: Trade Deficit Cut Seen
description: C. William Verity Jr., Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that the United States trade deficit would be cut more than 15 percent this year, to below $150 billion. Secretary Verity, interviewed on NBC's ''Today'' program, forecast that the Reagan Administration would cut last year's $171 billion deficit to a little below $150 billion and said he believed it could be cut below $100 billion in two or three years.

title: Capital Inflow Called Helpful
description: Large inflows of foreign capital into the United States can help to increase United States productivity, a Federal Reserve Board governor, Wayne D. Angell, said today.

title: Caesars World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said its fiscal 1987 third quarter was adversely affected by an unusual pre-tax charge of $5,307,000, resulting from expenses related to a proposed recapitalization program and a hostile tender offer.

title: Hancock Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings is not available because the company did not go public until May 4, 1987, when it was spun off by Lucky Stores to Lucky Stores shareholders. The company said the latest first quarter compares to pro forma net income of $4,695,000, or 37 cents a share, on revenue of $76,488,000, which reflects the effect on interest income and interest expense of the recapitalization of the company immediately prior to the spin off in May 1987 and the estimated incremental costs of operating as a public company.

title: About New York; Tracking AIDS: Streetwise Study Of Prostitutes
description: It was 1956 and Joyce I. Wallace of Flushing, Queens, was awaiting a favorite uncle visiting from Des Moines. They had chosen to meet in Bryant Park behind the Public Library, and she was early. A man sat down beside her.

title: Financial Corp. Deal Is Seen
description: The chairman of the Financial Corporation of America said today that Federal regulators might be able to complete a deal on the sale of the company's American Savings and Loan Association unit to the Robert M. Bass Group Inc. as early as July. Last month, the Federal

title: On 'Car Talk,' Sound Repair Tips, No Charge for the Humor
description: ''HI, this is Steve from New York,'' Steve says to Tom and Ray Magliozzi. Steve's 1970 Volkswagen bus seems to run on three cylinders, but that's all right. The problem is that the ignition absolutely will not work, and he has resorted to some agonizing methods of starting the bus. He wants to know if the Magliozzi brothers, whose ''Car Talk'' show is broadcast on National Public Radio, can guess what's wrong.

title: J. C. Penney Sells New York Building
description: The J. C. Penney Company said it had sold its Manhattan quarters at 1301 Avenue of the Americas for $350 million to a partnership consisting of two national developers - Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. of New York and Trammell Crow Real Estate Investors of Dallas. William R. Howell, Penney's chairman, said the sale would result in a $150 million after-tax gain, to be recorded in August, when the closing is scheduled. Penney is moving its headquarters to Dallas.

title: They're Young and Chosen and Dancing
description: Oscar Bravo's third-grade schoolmates teased him when he was chosen to study ballet at the New Ballet School, a program sponsored by the Feld Ballet in cooperation with the New York City Board of Education.

title: Death Sentence in Missouri
description: A Missouri dairy farmer was sentenced to death today for the slaying of his wife and two nephews in September. Judge John E. Parrish followed the recommendation of the jury that convicted 37-year-old James Schnick last month and imposed the death sentence. The defendant will be the 60th inmate on death row in Missouri, where no one has been executed since 1965. Mr. Schnick was accused, but not tried, in the deaths of four other relatives.

title: Newport Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A.T.&T. Increases Its Holding in Sun
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has raised its stake in Sun Microsystems Inc. to 7.1 percent, a total of 2.48 million shares, from about 6.1 percent.

title: Sick of 'Supermoms'
description: To The Living Section:

title: Winjak Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain from a tax credit of $60,000.

title: Meow Mix Cat Food Goes to DDB Needham
description: DDB Needham Worldwide, a Ralston Purina agency since 1986, has just received its first cat food assignment. A watershed certainly.

title: No Lights, Then No Crowd; Hockey Halted for the Night
description: In the year of the playoff jinx for the National Hockey League, the league's image grew still darker tonight. A power failure in Boston Garden late in the second period forced officials to order the fans to leave the arena and then suspend the fourth game of the Stanley Cup championship series between the Boston Bruins and the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Navigators Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $13,000 for the latest first quarter and $404,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Tax-Exempt Sales Action
description: A House Ways and Means subcommittee voted today to allow museums and other nonprofit organizations to continue to earn tax-free income from mail-order sales of education-related items and moderately priced mementos, one subcommittee member said.

title: Ford Aerospace to Buy A Military Researcher
description: The Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation said today that it had reached a definitive agreement to purchase BDM International Inc., a military research company based in McLean, Va., for $34.75 a share in cash, or about $425 million.

title: Newsday Is Making a Profitable Investment in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Hijacker in Colombia Wielded Toy Grenade
description: A man suspected of hijacking a Colombian airliner to Panama and Aruba and then escaping into the night after returning to Colombia was captured Tuesday carrying a toy grenade, a military statement said.

title: Key Wedtech Witness Says He Lied
description: A key Government witness in the corruption trial of Representative Mario Biaggi admitted yesterday that he had lied to the court and prosecutors about a secret bank account containing $178,000.

title: Review/Dance; Up From Down Under, a Celebration of the Self
description: Showing plenty of nerve as usual, Australia's Sydney Dance Company came back to town last night for its third visit and with an unexpected program.

title: Julio Tanjeloff, 72, an Importer Of Gems and Precious Minerals
description: Julio Tanjeloff, an importer of gems and minerals who had a meteoric career in New York retailing in the 1970's before most of his ventures collapsed, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: A Touch of Surrealism, Ready to Wear
description: ''NOT OUT OF FASHION'' was the title of the fashion show last week that highlighted the New York Academy of Art's spring benefit for its scholarship fund. But only a few of the clothes shown (direct from Seventh Avenue) have ever been in fashion. The rest, designed by artists, architects and Off Off Seventh Avenue talents, were infinitely imaginative.

title: Giants Continue To Dominate Mets
description: So the Mets can't beat the San Francisco Giants in May. The more important matter is will they be able to beat them in October?

title: Dow Rebounds 21.05 on Blue-Chip Trading
description: Some institutional bargain hunting among blue-chip issues helped the stock market averages yesterday. But plays to capture utility dividends accounted for a large part of the volume.

title: International Consumer Brands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Art Under The (Little) Big Top
description: Two dancers are flirting. He plays the oboe as she pirouettes toward him. Then he advances toward her, leaping and doing a somersault, only to be pushed away. It could be ballet or modern dance - but it's a tightrope act.

title: Westvaco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
G.O.P. Designs a Colorful Convention
description: In the absence of any surprise about the party's nominee for President, the Republican National Committee held a news conference here today to introduce a stage.

title: Reviews/Film; Stallone's 'Rambo III,' Globe-Trotting Cowboy For the 80's Audience
description: ''The first was for himself,'' say the ads for ''Rambo III.'' ''The second was for his country. This time is for his friend.'' And the next may be for returning an overdue library book, but whatever John Rambo's reason for raising hell, there's one point that should never be misunderstood. John Rambo does not do these things because he enjoys them. He does not take any personal satisfaction in (to use just one small example) attaching a rope and a large rock to an adversary, then pulling the pin on a grenade so that it will explode as the man falls into an underground cave.

title: New Storage Function For Digital Audio Tape
description: DIGITAL audio tape, embroiled in a controversy as a consumer product, will soon come to market in another guise - as a computer data storage medium.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Michigan State Building Authority is tentatively offering $78.7 million of revenue bonds. The underwriters are led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: ACM Government Securities Fund reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The fund commenced operations on Jan. 28, 1988. The net investment income for the period from Jan. 28 to March 31 was $13,107,992, or 20 cents a share. Assets represent net assets.

title: COMMENCEMENT
description: The New School

title: KEY RATES
Punta Gorda Isles Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $1,460,000 from a tax benefit. The prior year operating net included a gain of $7.4 million from two real estate sales.

title: Four Die When Private Jet Crashes in West Paterson
description: A twin-engine airplane crashed into a hillside minutes after taking off today, erupting into flames and missing a large condominium project and several houses by a short distance.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Deportation Possible For Polish Defector Released From Jail
description: A Polish seaman who jumped ship in a bid for political asylum has been released from jail after two months, still facing possible deportation but flooded with offers of money and shelter.

title: 45-Ton Drug Cargo on Barge
description: Forty-five tons of hashish and marijuana aboard a barge in San Francisco Bay were seized by Federal agents today in what the Coast Guard said was one of the largest such drug confiscations in the nation's history.

title: Lendl Tested a Bit by No. 240
description: Ivan Lendl, ranked No. 1 among the men, and Martina Navratilova, No. 2 among the women, today led a string of veterans into the second round of the French Open.

title: ACM Government Income Fund reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The fund began operations in January 1988.

title: A Protein Is Found to Help Fight Bone Cancer
description: The natural protein interferon shows promise in controlling multiple myeloma, a lethal form of bone cancer, when used in combination with standard chemotherapy drugs, researchers said today.

title: Corn Pesticide Tests Backed
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today approved field tests of a genetically altered corn pesticide, which has the potential to reduce farm use of chemicals.

title: Ex-Envoy Indicted on Drugs
description: A former Honduran diplomat was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of smuggling and possession of cocaine with the intention of distributing it.

title: VIETNAM OFFICIAL RECEIVES U.S. VISA
description: State Department officials said today that they had granted a visa to visit the United States to Ngyuen Xuan Oanh, an American-educated Vietnamese who is a leading advocate of economic liberalization in his country.

title: How a Takeover Works
description: Governor Kean, in signing the school intervention law last Jan. 13, said, ''New Jersey is the very first state to make the moral statement that when schools fail, adults will pay the price - not just the children.''

title: Investment Magazine To Begin Taking Ads
description: For the last year and a half, Fidelity Investments has been publishing a six-a-year magazine called Investment Vision for its customers.

title: Mexican Oil Tank Fire Forces Mass Evacuation
description: At least 20,000 Mexicans fled from their homes today when a fire at an oil storage depot threatened to ignite millions of gallons of gasoline.

title: American Airlines Tightens Program for Frequent Fliers
description: American Airlines yesterday announced a major tightening of its frequent flier program, after a similar move last month by United Airlines. American's decision makes it likely that the rest of the major carriers will follow.

title: Review/Dance; Gamson In Works By Duncan
description: Annabelle Gamson describes her company, Dance Solos, as a group of solo dancers. And a program presented on Thursday at St. Mark's Church by Ms. Gamson and the six women in her group made it clear that these were, indeed, performers with a distinctive sense of style and maturity.

title:
KITCHEN BOOKSHELF;
Recipes Homey and Haute, From a Quartet of New Volumes
