description: LEAD: A SAMPLING of this season's cookbooks is solid proof that there is something for everybody, from off-the-cuff, off-the-wall zaniness to sober-sided kitchen craftsmanship. Of the many cookbooks released in recent months, a quartet stands out. Each is quite different from the others.

title: Guitarist Is Partner In a Duet
description: Gus Solomons Jr. is a lanky and loose-moving dancer with an engaging stage presence that is both good-natured and grave. He is also a dance reviewer of unfailing commitment to the art. But those qualities were seldom in evidence in a program presented by the Solomons Company/ Dance at the Joyce Theater on Friday as part of the 3-D at the Joyce festival.

title: This Trade Bill Deserves to Die
description: In vetoing the trade bill, President Reagan made the right move for the wrong reason. The quick House vote to override was just wrong - a Democratic election-year stunt. The supposed point of this massive exercise was to expand trade. Yet the bill that finally emerged is a monster of disguised protectionism that would do the opposite.

title: DDB Needham Team Gets Tourism Account
description: DDB Needham Worldwide New York and Arthur Young International, a consultant, have teamed up to win an assignment from the Caribbean Regional Development Office of the Agency for International Development, based in Bridgetown, Barbados.

title: Saul, B F Real Estate Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for early extinguishment of debt of $129,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Texaco Meeting May Get Delay
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would postpone its annual meeting by 10 days if requested by Carl C. Icahn.

title: Baker, J Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Students Turning to Nonprofit Companies for Tuition Loans
description: Margaret E. Hankard, a 23-year-old student at the University of Massachusetts, learned last year that scholarship and marriage are not always a happy union, at least as far as the Federal Government is concerned.

title: Guerrero's Wrist Slap
description: ONLY four days for flinging a bat at a pitcher. Judging by previous sentences in A. Bartlett Giamatti's baseball courtroom, notably Pete Rose's recent 30-day suspension, Pedro Guerrero got off easy.

title: The Treaty and Its Enemies
description: For a while, it looked as though several willful men could derail the Euromissile treaty and President Reagan's wish to make the treaty a centerpiece of his summit meeting in Moscow next week. Two of them are Jesse Helms and Gordon Humphrey, Republican Senators who have been trying to obstruct ratification with one niggling amendment after another.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: S. Dudley Nostrand, 80, Real-Estate Broker
description: S. Dudley Nostrand, a well-known real-estate broker in Manhattan, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: Graham-McCormick Oil & Gas Partnership reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
60-Minute Gourmet
description: MANY cooks use the terms fricassee and stew interchangeably, although there are fundamental differences between the two.

title: BID FOR TAKEOVER OF SCHOOL DISTRICT IS BEGUN BY JERSEY
description: Declaring that Jersey City's public schools are plagued by a ''cycle of failure,'' New Jersey's Education Commissioner moved today to have the state take over the district for at least five years.

title: Deere & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: The United States Olympic Hall of Fame, created in 1979, will induct five former Olympians tomorrow night aboard the M.S. Seaward at Pier 88, 12th Avenue and West 55th Street. The inductees are Bill Bradley, captain of the 1964 gold medal men's basketball team; the late Charles Daniels, winner of five gold medals in swimming in 1904, 1906 and 1908; Mal Whitfield, winner of three gold medals in track in 1948 and 1952; Tenley Albright, winner of a gold medal and a silver medal in women's figure skating in 1952 and 1956; and Jim McKay, the sports broadcaster, a special contributor. . . . Renaldo Nehemiah, the world record-holder in the 110-meter high hurdles, will run in the event in the Pepsi Invitational at UCLA June 5. Nehemiah, who set the world record with a 12.93-second clocking in 1981, will oppose, among others, 1984 Olympic gold medalist Roger Kingdom, Olympic silver medalist Greg Foster, and Tonie Campbell. . . . Francie Larrieu-Smith, 35 years old, the only American to win the L'eggs Mini Marathon in the 1980's, will compete in the 17th running of the Central Park road race June 4.

title: Editor in Chief Leaves Elle
description: Catherine Ettlinger, editor in chief of the American edition of Elle, resigned yesterday after nine months on the job, the fourth senior member of the fashion magazine's staff to resign in the last month.

title: Metro Datelines; Request by Mother Of Lisa Steinberg
description: The mother of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old who died from a beating last November, emerged from seclusion yesterday and called for a law to safeguard children given up for adoption.

title: My Career Mother
description: To The Living Section:

title: Seattle to Soviet Georgia: Salmon With Less Salt
description: Hospitality takes on new, and overwhelming, dimensions when the purveyors of good will are Government officials and food professionals here in the Republic of Georgia, and its recipients are three chefs from the United States.

title: Sandinistas Said to Prepare an Attack
description: United States and Honduran officials say Nicaraguan forces appear to be preparing to attack the contras if cease-fire talks fail to produce a negotiated settlement to the civil war.

title: Bush and Dukakis Sweep Idaho; 3 Lawmakers Win
description: Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis won overwhelming victories today in Idaho's Presidential primaries.

title: Syntex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Noriega Informer Files May Be Missing
description: Federal agents are investigating whether documents related to the drug case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, disappeared from a box of records turned over to American drug agents in Panama, according to the United States Attorney in Miami.

description: To the Editor:

description: To The Living Section:

title: SOVIET AND ALLIES SHIFT ON DOCTRINE
description: The Soviet Union and some of its principal allies in Eastern Europe have eliminated or changed longstanding doctrines over the last 13 months, nominally ending Moscow's supremacy in deciding the ideology of Communist parties.

title: Review/Opera; A Visual 'Rusalka,' Staged Purely as a Fairy Tale
description: Dvorak's fairy-tale opera ''Rusalka,'' long recognized as a masterpiece in the Slavic world, has been gaining apostles in the West of late. Thanks largely to the efforts of Gabriela Benackova, the Czechoslovak soprano who has sung the title role in celebrated concert performances and recordings, the work's expressive power and abundant lyricism have been made clear. What is still not evident, even in light of the imaginative production of ''Rusalka'' offered Monday evening at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., is the work's chance of finding a solid place in the Western opera repertory.

title: Metro Datelines; Firecracker Injures A Brooklyn Teacher
description: A 71-year-old high-school teacher was injured yesterday after a firecracker exploded in her hand, the police said. Two students were arrested in the incident.

title: Leiter Rebounds As Yankees Win
description: When the no-hitter finally faded in the sixth inning tonight, Al Leiter did not react. He simply watched Wally Joyner's single drop softly into center field, then waited for the ball to return to the pitcher's mound.

title: Mott's Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $479,685 for the latest first quarter and $595,684 for the year- ago period.

title: Dorsett Deal Near
description: Tony Dorsett, a Dallas Cowboys' running back, said he could be traded to the Denver Broncos this week, when the Broncos make a new proposal on his hefty contract. The proposal, which would retire Dorsett's $6 million annuity, is expected in the next few days, according to an interview with Dorsett in The Dallas Morning News yesterday. The latest plan put forward by Dorsett's agent, Witt Stewart, requires Denver to purchase an insurance policy that, when cashed in, would fund Dorsett's remaining annuity payments, the newspaper said. Dorsett has requested a trade because he is unhappy with his secondary role to another running back, Herschel Walker, in the Cowboys' offense. Dorsett's annuity, which pays him $300,000 per year for 20 years beginning five years after he retires, has been a hurdle in past trade talks. (AP)

title: Mesa Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bushnell to Atari
description: The Atari Corporation said that Nolan K. Bushnell, chairman and chief executive of Axlon Inc. and the founder of Atari, will be coming back to Atari ''to make more fun and games.'' The two companies declined to give details before the formal announcement next Wednesday, but sources close to the industry said it was likely that Mr. Bushnell, who invented the game Pong, intended to get back into the video game business and might license Atari to produce home versions of any new games he created.

title: Ford Chairman Backs Tax Idea
description: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company on Monday endorsed the idea of a national value-added sales tax as a method of reducing the United States trade deficit and the Federal budget deficit.

title: Kirshenbaum & Bond Picks Up 2 Accounts
description: Kirshenbaum & Bond has won two accounts that seem made for each other. One is Soap Opera Digest. The other is Joan Collins Fragrance, named for the star of ''Dynasty,'' the soapiest of soaps.

title: Guerrero Banned 4 Days, Fined $1,000
description: Pedro Guerrero, who flung his bat toward David Cone, the Mets' pitcher, last Sunday, joined Pete Rose on the National League's suspended list yesterday.

title: National Video Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: The Turf Fight In Crash Debate
description: THE prose is hard to distinguish from that in a thousand other official reports destined to disappear into the void: a boiler-plate introduction, recommendations for ''important initiatives to be implemented in timely fashion,'' a slew of scholarly appendices. But the message that the White House Working Group on Financial Markets delivered last week hit Washington like a bucket of ice water. Congress, the group concluded, cannot stop change on Wall Street and should not try.

title: House Republicans Rail at Democrats
description: The Republicans in the House of Representatives, chafing in their chronic status as the minority party, struck out at the Democratic leadership today, charging that it had abused its power and House procedures.

title: Kansas Base Again Is Army's Harvard
description: After a seven-year effort, the Army has restored this post to its pre-World War II pre-eminence as a center of military education, with a sharp new focus on the operational art of war.

title: Tighter Security For Soccer Game
description: More than 1,000 policemen will provide security when PSV Eindhoven meets Benfica Lisbon in the European Champions' Cup soccer final Wednesday.

title: Hechinger Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,930,000 from an accounting change.

title: Hondurans' Trust of Military Leaders Plummets With Drug Arrest
description: The arrest of a Honduran diplomat for drug smuggling in Miami and the detention of more than a dozen employees of the Honduran national airline appear to have shaken many Hondurans' already fragile confidence in the military-dominated leadership.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Coach Serves Notice
description: After coaching the United States men's volleyball team to victories at the 1985 World Cup and the 1986 world championships, Marv Dunphy will return to college coaching after the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. Dunphy, who in three years as coach of the United States team has a 162-27 record, will return to Pepperdine in Malibu, Calif., as men's volleyball coach, a position he held before taking the job as coach of the American team. (AP)

title: An Ear for the English of the English
description: He knows what ''O.K.'' really stands for, where ''Podunk'' actually is, and why ''Dixie'' has nothing to do with the Mason-Dixon line.

title: Eating Well
description: ONE cloud that seems to hang over an otherwise sunny hamburger-and-hot-dog-bar becue day is all the talk about burnt meats containing carcinogens.

title: Try to Stop Terrorists With 'Star Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sigma Designs reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Parents Call Reading Vital but ...
description: Nearly all parents think reading is very important to their children's success but only a bare majority report their children are very interested in reading, according to a national survey released today.

title: Metro Datelines; Mother Dies in Leap; Girl, 6, Found Dead
description: A woman from Waterford who had apparently killed her daughter jumped to her death Tuesday from the Gold Star Bridge on Interstate 95 into the Thames River, the police said.

title: Thompson Selects Surprises
description: David Robinson and Danny Manning were supposed to make the cut after a week of tryouts for the United States men's Olympic basketball team and they did. Todd Lichti and Dan Majerle were barely known, and they made it, too.

title: 'Into the Woods' Wins Award
description: ''Into the Woods'' was selected by the Drama Desk yesterday as the outstanding musical of the 1987-88 season. ''M. Butterfly'' was named best new play and ''Anything Goes'' the outstanding revival. The Drama Desk, formed in 1949, is an association of New York critics, editors and reporters.

title: What's Fresh, Crisp and Grilled?
description: WHEN it comes to grilling, vegetables often get shortchanged. All the attention goes to those juicy, sizzling steaks that send mouthwatering aromas into the soft summer air. If vegetables do make an appearance on the grill, they are usually stabbed through the heart with skewers, and included only to give color to a brochette.

title: Harper & Row Names a New Chief
description: George Craig, who had been joint chief executive of Harper & Row Publishers Inc., has been named chief executive and president of the publishing company.

title: New Company Finds Success Selling 'Champagne of Teas'
description: IN a storefront in downtown New Bedford, Mass., a 32-year-old entrepreneur, Sam Barrows, is busy packing his imported Darjeeling tea. What distinguishes Barrows's brand Darjeeling Tea from other Darjeelings is its single-estate provenance: it is one of a handful of unblended Darjeeling teas sold in this country.

title: Changes At Atlanta Symphony
description: Robert Shaw started his classical music career in New York with the Beethoven Ninth, and his return to it this week marks a farewell: Mr. Shaw is concluding his 21st and final season as music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra.

title: A French Delegation to New Caledonia Is Rebuffed
description: The most volatile issue inherited by France's new Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, grew hotter today when a French soldier shot and killed a Melanesian in the South Pacific territory of New Caledonia.

title: Tax Break Measure Gains in Albany
description: To keep the Dreyfus Corporation from moving its headquarters and 1,200 jobs from New York City to New Jersey, the Assembly today approved tax breaks for the state's mutual-fund industry.

title: Neoax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included $3.3 million of unusual financing fee charges related to an acquisition.

title: Paul Hogan Is Back to His Tricks
description: The screen success of Mick (Crocodile) Dundee is based, quite literally, on nothing. Nothing is the thing that Dundee, in the disarming person of the Australian star Paul Hogan, does best. Mr. Hogan's calm, unflappable reactions to the various facts of New York City life were the comic foundation of ''Crocodile Dundee,'' turning its mild, genial humor into box-office gold. It would be natural to expect more of the same from ''Crocodile Dundee II,'' but the sequel often lacks the sense to leave well enough alone.

title: Multi-Local Media reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest two quarters reflect $1.4 million in writeoffs for expenses associated with the start-up of new Florida operations.

title: Geothermal Resources International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $502,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a tax credit of $2,256,000 and a loss of $31,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Wine Talk
description: RUN-of-the-mill Burgundy: $30 a bottle. Middle-level 1985 Bordeaux: $27.50.

description: Golf

title: SAHARAN ACCORD: BROAD GAINS SEEN
description: The renewal of diplomatic relations between Morocco and Algeria will have far-reaching consequences in North Africa, Europe and the Middle East, North African and Western officials believe.

title: Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Thomas H. A. Lewis; Film Producer Was 86
description: Thomas H. A. Lewis, a film and broadcasting producer and writer who founded the Armed Forces Radio Service during World War II, died Friday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 86 years old.

title: Alfred C. Clapp, 84; Former Jersey Judge Led Kean Campaign
description: Alfred C. Clapp, a former New Jersey judge who managed Governor Kean's first successful gubernatorial campaign, died of heart disease Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Giving Amax New Life Is 'a Ball' for President
description: ''I've had a ball,'' said Allen Born yesterday, describing his three years as president and chief executive of Amax Inc., the large metals company based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: 9 Accused of Arranging Marriages So Aliens Could Gain Citizenship
description: Nine people were arrested today and charged in two separate schemes that provided mates - and the promise of United States citizenship - to foreign nationals in exchange for money, the United States Attorney said.

title: Must Work Be So Hard?
description: To The Living Section:

title: Corrections
description: A Health page article on May 12 about prenatal diagnosis misidentified an institution conducting research in the field. It is the medical center of the University of California at San Francisco.

description: To The Living Section:

title: Propane Truck Fire Disrupts L.I. Traffic
description: Three major transportation arteries on Long Island were closed yesterday for most of the day when a tank truck carrying as much as 3,000 gallons of propane overturned and burst into flames on the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway, causing large traffic delays and congestion.

title: Books of The Times; Writer and Narcissistic Social Butterfly
description: Capote A Biography By Gerald Clarke Illustrated. 632 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: CBS Is Awarded '92 Winter Games
description: The American television rights to the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, were awarded yesterday to CBS Sports, whose bid of $243 million exceeded the International Olympic Committee's expectation by $43 million and NBC's bid by as much as $68 million.

title: Protection for Referees
description: Big Eight basketball coaches who persist in publicly criticizing game officials next year could be suspended for one game under a policy adopted yesterday. ''At the request of coaches, the conference approved a rule stating that under no circumstances shall a coach comment publicly criticizing a game official's performance,'' said Tim Allen, the director of the Big Eight service bureau. ''It was voted that a violation of this rule would result in public censure of the individual involved. Any subsequent violation will result in a suspension for one game.''(AP)

title: Sahlen & Associates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $20,777 for the quarter and $315,777 for the 9 months.

title: Shifts at 2 Bayer Units
description: Bayer USA Inc. and the Mobay Corporation, two Pittsburgh-based subsidiaries of the chemical and pharmaceutical concern Bayer A.G. of West Germany, announced that Wilhelm C. Ostern, the vice chairman and chief financial officer of Bayer USA, will retire on Aug 1. He will be succeeded by Gerd D. Mueller, 51 years old, who is the executive vice president of Mobay, who will in turn be succeeded by Milan J. Turk, 48. Mr. Ostern, 64, will continue to head the Bayer-Mobay Foundation and serve as the honorary consul for West Germany in Pittsburgh.

title: Queen's Envoy Accused of Bludgeoning Pigs
description: Queen Elizabeth's representative in New Zealand has resigned as a leader of an animal protection group after complaints that he clubbed two pigs to death in ritual ceremonies.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; G.O.P. and Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is quoted approvingly in the first issue of a glossy 24-page magazine published by House Republicans. ''We have lost and keep losing a lot,'' the Soviet leader is quoted as saying, ''because of our failure to unshackle grass-roots initiative, endeavor and independence completely.''

title: Rolls-Royce Jet Engine
description: The chairman of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., Sir Francis Tombs, said today that his company expects to receive certificates of airworthiness for the V2500 engine next month. He told the company's first annual meeting since privatization last year that the engine would go into service in 1989 as planned. The V2500 was developed by a joint venture whose participants included Rolls-Royce, the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney unit and Fiat S.p.A.

title: Big Socialist Majority Seen in Assembly Vote
description: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Party appears likely to achieve an impressive victory in next month's parliamentary election, a likelihood that could complicate Mr. Mitterrand's search for an understanding with centrist politicians.

title: Ship Seizure Policy Is Revised
description: The Customs Service and Coast Guard have altered part of their aggressive campaign against illegal drugs, a spokesman for the Customs Service said Monday.

title: Study Finds Chemotherapy Can Be Cut by 25% for Testicle Cancer
description: The extent of chemotherapy needed to cure cancer of the testicles can be safely reduced by 25 percent, sparing men from some of the misery of the effective but difficult treatment, a study has found.

title: California Considers Cancer Warning on Alcohol
description: SCIENTIFIC advisers to Gov.

title: Thaddeus W. Hentz, Advertising Executive, 61
description: Thaddeus William Hentz, a retired vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising Inc., died of heart failure May 7 at the Head Injury Center at Highgate in Troy, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Allendale, N.J.

title: 44 Unhurt as Jet Lands at Abandoned Strip
description: A Boeing 737 jetliner making an approach to New Orleans in bad weather lost power in both engines today and made an emergency landing near an abandoned World War II airstrip six miles short of the airport.

title: Soccer Fans Riot
description: Clashes in London during an exhibition game between fans of the national teams of England and Scotland last Saturday at Wembley Stadium resulted in injuries to 90 people and the arrests of 200. Also hurt were the chances that English teams would be readmitted next season to Europe's three club soccer competitions, a leading official of the sport's ruling body for the European continent said yesterday. ''I had some mixed feelings but was rather optimistic,'' said Hans Bangerter, the general secretary of the European Football Union, in a British Broadcasting Corporation television news program from Bern, Switzerland. ''But after what happened on Saturday, I feel this is a severe setback for the cause of the English clubs,'' he said. Officials of the football union meet June 24 at the end of the European championships in West Germany to decide whether to maintain the ban imposed after the 1985 Champions' Cup final in Brussel between Juventus of Italy and Liverpool of England. At that game, 39 spectators were killed, most of them Juventus supporters caught in a stampede by Liverpool fans. (AP)

title: Dukakis, Back in Massachusetts, Relishes Role as Split Personality
description: Michael S. Dukakis was back home as Governor today, but more often than not he lapsed into the role of Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Interactive Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Nestle-Rowntree
description: Nestle S.A. has increased its holding in Rowntree P.L.C., the British chocolate maker, to 16 percent from 15 percent. British Government sources said the Trade and Industry Department would publish a decision on Wednesday or Thursday about whether the bid the Swiss company is making for Rowntree would be referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Jacobs Suchard A.G., another Swiss confectioner, holds 29.9 percent of Rowntree.

title: 2d Defendant In Racial Case Pleads Guilty
description: A defendant in the Howard Beach racial-attack case pleaded guilty yesterday to a riot charge, and court records were unsealed confirming that another defendant pleaded guilty to the same charge in a closed session last week.

title: Crack the Problem; Win Fame
description: LEAD: A most appealing irony of modern technology is that generations of intellectuals, schooled in the discipline of higher mathematics and equipped with supercomputers, nonetheless have been stumped in their efforts to solve a seemingly simple 357-year-old number puzzle.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Gephardt's Openness

title: Where Down-Home Cooking Becomes Sophisticated Fare
description: JACK McDAVID, the chef and owner of the Down Home Diner in Philadelphia, speaks with a thick Appalachian accent, says ''yes ma'am,'' and ''no sir'' and wears denim overalls, a plaid shirt and a peaked cap. He has also trained in the kitchens of La Cote Basque in New York, Lion d'Or in Washington and Le Bec-Fin in Philadelphia.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Initials First
description: The Defense Department, long suspected of fashioning an acronym for a program or weapon before actually giving it a name, appears to have outdone itself. Now comes Snort, which stands for Supersonic Naval Ordnance Research Track, a site in the California desert.

title: Rangaire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Republic American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included a 2 cents-a-share benefit attributable to the fresh start allowance of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, compared with a 4 cents-a share benefit in the year-ago period. The company also said the latest quarter included an incremental alternative minimum tax accrual of 3 cents a share.

title: Length of Average Hospital Stay Drops 22%
description: The average number of days spent by patients in hospitals fell 22 percent over a recent five-year period, the Department of Health and Human Services said today.

title: Santa Fe Shareholders Reject 'Poison Pill' Plan
description: Shareholders of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation voted today to recommend overturning a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense instituted by the company's management.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amev N.V., the Netherlands, a diversified financial services company whose American arm is Amev Holdings Inc., said Frans Roos had retired as chairman and would be succeeded by J. L. M. (Hans) Bartelds.

title: Tour Moves to Ban New Irons
description: The PGA Tour took a first step today to ban irons with U-shaped or square grooves and restrict its players to clubs with V-shaped grooves, the only modern clubs played before 1984.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Review/Theater; 'Romeo and Juliet' in the Shakespeare Marathon
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's Shakespeare Marathon, which got off to a fizzy start (''A Midsummer Night's Dream'') before shifting into low gear (''Julius Caesar''), has come to a dead halt with ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The production at the Public Theater is so devoid of pulse that it seems a form of indentured servitude. The actors, not all of them undistinguished, look as if they were being forced at gunpoint to go through the motions of performing the play so everyone can get on to the next title on the marathon checklist.

title: Networks Face a Drop In Viewing by Children
description: Network programmers are struggling with a drop in television viewing by children during the 1987-88 season and by what appear to be new tastes among young viewers.

title: Intermedics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,282,000 for the quarter and $3,976,000 for the 6 months.

title: Himont Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $21.5 million on the sales of assets.

title: Washington Talk: The First Lady; Strong Opinions With No Apologies
description: She has been vilified and ridiculed, gossiped about and even dreaded by some who work in the White House, but Nancy Reagan remains the President's most influential and trusted adviser.

title: U.S. Constitution Rejected
description: Deciding that it was best not to tinker with history, residents here have affirmed a vote by their forebears 200 years ago and have voted against ratification of the United States Constitution. ''We're not changing history,'' said Donald Spector, one of about 700 town residents who turned out for a town meeting Monday night. ''We want to preserve the fact that people have the right to vote 'nay.' '' Last winter, the town of Cornwall repudiated its ''no'' vote of 200 years ago and voted in favor of the Constitution.

title: BEHIND THE TRADE-BILL VETO
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's message to Congress discussing his veto of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988. Notice of Plant Closings

title: Northrop to Drop 700 MX Workers
description: The Northrop Corporation said it will dismiss about 700 employees working on the MX missile-guidance system in Hawthorne, Calif., by year-end as the company's engineering requirements decline. The move represents 18 percent of the 3,800-member division work force and will primarily affect engineers and support staff.

title: An Irving Suitor Gets More Time
description: The conclusion of the eight-month-old takeover struggle for the Irving Bank Corporation was further delayed yesterday when the Bank of New York Company gained more time to continue its efforts to acquire Irving.

title: New Future For Queens Warehouse
description: WHEN a group of developers bought a former Gimbels warehouse in Long Island City in 1986, their plan was to transform the huge five-story structure into a mixed-use commercial building primarily for office and furniture design tenants.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Food Notes
description: The Flavors of Kansas

title: CHANGE ON SOVIET URGED BY JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today urged ''a very different relationship with the Soviet Union'' and a recognition by the United States that a ''new order'' was emerging in the third world.

title: Robertson Backers Set North Carolina Boycott
description: Supporters of Pat Robertson said today that they would boycott next week's Republican convention in North Carolina because party regulars want to deny them influence at the national convention.

title: NASA Turns to Dynamics
description: After more than 30 years of launching its own rockets, the Government has for the first time hired someone else to do the job.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Call it invasive surgery.'' - Dr. Saul Cooperman, Education Commissioner, on state takeover of Jersey City's troubled public schools. [ A1:1. ]

title: Amerifirst Savings
description: The Transcapital Financial Corporation, the parent of the Transohio Savings Bank, agreed to acquire the Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association for $20 a share, or $230 million. Amerifirst, which had assets of $4.4 billion at the end of 1987, said it would continue to operate under its own name, but as a unit of Transohio. The merger is pending shareholder approval and clearance by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates savings banks.

title: Arthur M. Carter, 76, Afro-American Editor
description: Arthur M. Carter, a longtime editor and publisher of The Washington Afro-American newspaper, former managing editor of the Afro-American newspaper chain, and a former Pulitzer Prize juror, has died of cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Arafat Regaining Supremacy in Embattled Beirut
description: Five years after they were routed by opponents within the Palestine Liberation Organization, guerrillas loyal to the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, are regaining supremacy in refugee districts in Lebanon.

title: Murray Ohio Stock Jumps $8, to $59.25
description: Shares of the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company soared $8, to $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, indicating that investors expect Sweden's A.B. Electrolux to raise its current $52-a-share bid. Market analysts have said the offer must rise to at least $227 million - $60 a share -to be accepted. On Monday, United States District Judge Thomas A. Wiseman removed one roadblock to Electrolux's bid, but Murray immediately appealed.

title: Modest Rise for Bonds and Notes
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched slightly higher in light trading yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; Broken Glass Beach
description: A newly renovated boardwalk and improved maintenance by New York City's Parks Department is helping to restore some of Coney Island's lost luster. Unfortunately, beer bottle vandals have made strolling along the vast sand beach where Brooklyn meets the Atlantic less delightful than it might be.

title: By Tass, With Love: Your Summit T-Shirts
description: Here's the latest bulletin from Tass: The official Soviet press agency is going into the souvenir T-shirt, button, record and cassette business, just in time for the summit.

title: Ohio Power Selling 9 7/8% Bonds at Par
description: The Ohio Power Company, a unit of the American Electric Power Company, is offering $100 million of first-mortgage bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton, which won the financing in competitive bidding.

title: Vartanig G. Vartan Is Dead at 64; Times Financial Writer Since '63
description: Vartanig G. Vartan, the main writer of the ''Market Place'' column in The New York Times since 1983, died of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital early yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Orders for Durables Up For 3d Straight Month
description: Orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods increased for the third consecutive month in April, indicating strong demand for United States exports.

title: A Redevelopment Agency In California Offers Bonds
description: The Redevelopment Agency of the City of Concord, Calif., is tentatively offering $92.3 million of central Concord redevelopment project tax allocation bonds with a maximum yield of 8 percent for an issue due in 2018.

title: Norway Says More Heavy Water May Be Missing
description: Norwegian officials said today that they are looking into whether a shipment of heavy water sent to Rumania had been improperly diverted.

title: Arthur M. Kreidmann, Lawyer, 80
description: Arthur M. Kreidmann, a partner in the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, died of complications from a heart attack Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Montedison In Joint Venture
description: Montedison S.p.A., the chemicals group based in Milan, and Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, the Italian state energy company agreed today to a major joint venture in a bid to compete in international markets.

title: Another Sad Polish Joke
description: The story of Stefan Olszowski is so absurd it would be hilarious, if the ruination that he and his comrades have visited on Poland were not so sad.

title: Ames Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Preakness Debate Echoes in Print
description: The controversy over the rough early duel between Winning Colors and Forty Niner in the Preakness Stakes last Saturday intensified yesterday when The Daily Racing Form printed a rare front-page editorial accusing the trainer Woody Stephens of contemptuous and dishonorable tactics.

title: Outstanding N.A.S.D. Short Sales Rise Slightly in Month
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a small monthly rise in the ''short interest'' for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: 'Streetcar' Closes
description: ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' a revival of Tennessee Williams's 1947 drama, closed after the Sunday matinee at the uptown Circle in the Square Theater. Directed by Nikos Psacharopoulos, the play ran for 85 regular performances and 20 previews.

title: Bridge
description: Until a decade ago, the bylines of North America's major syndicated bridge columnists (Becker, Goren, Jacoby and Sheinwold) remained unchanged for a generation.

title: Review/Jazz; 'Spillane,' a Blend of American Styles
description: The composer and saxophonist John Zorn opened ''Spillane,'' the centerpiece of his last set of a four-night stand at the Knitting Factory Saturday, with a vicious screech from his saxophone. His new group, called Naked City, including some of New York's best musicians - Bill Frisell on guitar, Wayne Horvitz on piano, Fred Frith on bass and Joey Baron on drums - went into a pensive jazz mood for a moment, erupted into noise for a few seconds, then slid into a quiet section.

title: Still Out in Front: The Country Look
description: THESE days the word country means big business in American towns and cities. Country sells clothing and fabrics, groceries and restaurants, house plans and home furnishings that range alphabetically from afghans to zinc-lined dry sinks.

title: Cyanamid to Start $84 Million Cleanup
description: The American Cyanamid Company has agreed to clean up its Superfund site in Bridgewater for $84 million, company and state officials said today.

title: Samna Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $188,000 from a tax benefit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Riney Is About to Lose Account for Sterling
description: The Miami-based Austin Rover Cars of North America, which last May assigned its Sterling luxury sedan to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, announced yesterday that it would be looking for a new agnecy because Riney has been awarded the General Motors' Saturn business.

title: Carbide Trades Investigated
description: The American Stock Exchange confirmed yesterday that it was investigating the trading of put options on the stock of the Union Carbide Corporation last week.

title: Yanks Win in 10; Mets Top Giants; Yankees 4, Angels 2
description: Dave Winfield, whose night had consisted of two strikeouts and one ill-advised attempt to score from third base on a grounder to the left side, slammed a bases-empty home run inside the left-field foul pole tonight to help lift the Yankees to a 4-2, 10-inning victory over the California Angels.

title: Iraq Seeking To Expand Oil Output
description: Defying the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' attempt to restrain production by its members, Iraq is making a major effort to expand its oil output and export capacity, its oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, said here today.

title: Contract Talk
description: Danny Manning said yesterday that he deserved a big contract from the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: New Study Sees Lower Costs for AIDS Care
description: A new prediction of the nationwide cost of providing medical care to AIDS patients is slightly lower than previous forecasts despite the high cost of AZT, the only drug proved effective in treating the AIDS virus, a Government economist reported today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LAWN, patio and picnic furniture rarely receive the proper care. When it is time to store outdoor furniture in the fall, many people just fold up the portable pieces and stack them away without cleaning them.

title: Utility Sets Plan to Cut Power Use
description: New England's largest electric company today filed with the State of Connecticut a conservation plan intended to cut in half the growth in demand for electricity.

title: Nassau Prosecutor To Switch to G.O.P.
description: The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, who is the county's top elected Democrat and a strong vote-getter, said yesterday that he was becoming a Republican because of the County Democratic Party's support for abortion rights.

title: How Banquets Can Feed Ethiopians
description: The Ethiopian Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam appears bent on starving some two million people. It refuses to allow international relief agencies access to stricken areas. According to a State Department calculation, only 850,000 people are being fed out of perhaps three million threatened by famine. Colonel Mengistu has expelled the Red Cross and other humanitarian agencies, claiming that they were aiding anti-Government rebels in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre.

title: Commercial Intertech reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Senate Approves a Ban on Plastic Firearms
description: The Senate, by voice vote, today approved a bill that would ban the manufacture, sale or possession of plastic firearms and other weapons not detectable by security devices. The action clears the way for a conference committee to work out a compromise with the House, which overwhelmingly approved similar legislation earlier this month.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'High Noon' on the Hill
description: When the House of Representatives voted to override President Reagan's veto of the trade bill on Tuesday, Representative Robert J. Mrazek felt about as alone as Gary Cooper in ''High Noon.''

title: Chicago Smoking Ban Is Passed by Aldermen
description: Aldermen in the nation's third-largest city approved an ordinance today that sponsors said would bar smoking in most public areas and force restaurant owners and employers to create smoking sections.

title: U.S. Airliners Just Miss Collision; Focus of Inquiry is Air Controller
description: Two jet airliners came within about 100 yards of colliding Monday while flying in opposite directions outside radar coverage over the Caribbean, according to Government officials.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi's Net Up 23.6%
description: Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, the largest advertising holding company in the world and the parent of a number of agencies, announced its financial results for the six months ended March 31. Revenues were up 25.1 percent, to $714.3 million, from $571 million in the 1987 period. Net income rose 23.6 percent, to $40.8 million, from $33 million, or $1.18 for each American depository receipt, compared with $1 a year earlier.

title: New Clients for In-Home Shopping
description: THE living room of the country-style apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan was filled with a dozen women, mostly in their 30's. In another era, they might have been gathered for consciousness raising. But the women, most of them busy with jobs and children, were there to shop: they were looking at children's fashions sold by a new company, Clothes to Home.

title: Hughes Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings figures have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split announced last week.

title: Development Bank Offers 9 3/8% Notes
description: The Asian Development Bank is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.77 to yield 9.42 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Mother of Brawley Gets Writ for Failure to Honor Subpoena
description: A day after she defied a grand jury subpoena, the mother of Tawana Brawley, Glenda Brawley, was served with an order yesterday to explain why she failed to appear.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in some copies on Tuesday about a tenure dispute at the Harvard Business School misstated the university's procedure for tenure decisions.

title: Jordan Named M.V.P.
description: Michael Jordan, the National Basketball Association's scoring champion for the last two seasons, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; One-Man Trombone Choir
description: Albert Mangelsdorff, a West German trombonist who played solo concerts at the Knitting Factory on Friday and Saturday nights, is best known for his technique: he'll play three or four notes at once, or move a melody around over static tones. At first it's a shock to hear the sound of a trombone choir coming from one person. A few moments later, after he's midway through a blues or ballad, the technique becomes invisible, and the music appears.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Art Director Buys Way Into Agency
description: JERRY WHITLEY, an art director from Texas, has passed through quite a number of ad agencies, moving frequently. Unlike most of his peers, he has not been searching for a higher salary.

title: A Dry Perch for the Nature Lover
description: OPERATING on the design premise ''it's nice not to have to worry about a wet bottom,'' two former Outward Bound instructors turned their attention to chairs.

title: Review/Dance; Violence and Theatrics From Armitage Ballet
description: Karole Armitage's choreographic sensibility often seems akin to Expressionism. Yet she is also preoccupied with classical ballet and popular culture. Such disparate interests ought to produce stimulating dances. Yet, despite their eye-catching moments, few of her works are satisfying as totalities.

title: Spelling, Aaron Productions reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $3.5 million received as part of an agreement with American Broadcasting Co. c-Included a non-recurring charge of $750,000 related to the company's reorganization.

title: Reviews/Music; Latin-Flavored Solo Piano
description: Dick Hyman's versatility as pianist, composer and arranger keeps him so busy creating film scores (for Woody Allen's films and, most recently, for ''Moonstruck''), performing at festivals and concerts or with his Perfect Jazz Repertory Quintet, lecturing on ragtime and stride piano or serving as artistic director and in-house pianist for the annual two-week Jazz in July Festival at the 92d Street Y, which begins on July 19, that he might be expected to welcome a night off.

title: Media General Claims Victory
description: Media General Inc. said yesterday that its board nominees had apparently defeated a slate backed by the Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman. According to the preliminary count, the management slate won more than 56 percent of the votes, Media General's president, James S. Evans, said. The final report will be issued after both sides inspect the proxies. Mr. Sugarman, chairman of

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group in Deal To Buy Dutch Agency
description: The WPP Group, another publicly held British holding company best known these days for its legal problems with defectors, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the PPGH Group B.V. of Amsterdam, the fourth-largest agency in the Netherlands. It will pay as much as $71.6 million over the next five years.

title: GERMANS ARE WARY OF JEWISH SCANDAL
description: In the week since the news broke that the much-honored head of West Germany's main Jewish organization evidently helped himself to millions in money intended for victims of the Nazis, the dominant reaction among politicians and newspapers has been a nervous circumspection.

title: John David House, 83, Co-Founder of Union
description: John David House, a founder of the 110,000-member United Rubber Workers union, died Sunday. He was 83 years old.

title: AME Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Granges Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Legal or Not, Drugs Kill
description: The body of the young man looks beautiful. A funeral suit covers the bullet wounds. A choir raises a gospel lament and the preacher exhorts decent folks to fight the drug-gang warfare that has claimed the boy's life. Then suddenly, the mourners dive for cover. From a passing car, gang rivals of the dead boy restate their vengeance with new fusillades from automatic weapons.

title: Margaret M. Ryan, Editor, 70
description: Margaret M. Ryan, a retired editor with House Beautiful magazine, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 70 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: 6 Radicals Deny Charges in '83 Capitol Bombing
description: Six left-wing radicals stood in a Federal court walled off with bullet-proof glass today and pleaded not guilty to charges of bombing the Capitol in 1983.

title: Article 455788 -- No Title
description: Carl C. Icahn yesterday offered to buy Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, for $60 a share, valuing the company at about $14.6 billion.

title: Suffolk's Reckless Screen Scream
description: On Long Island and nationally, Suffolk County's legislature has developed a reputation for being out front on, for instance, smoking and bottle return laws. At other times, however, it has strained way too far out, as when it contemplated creating a county navy. Now it has passed another bizarre bill, to regulate video display terminals, that would set a reckless precedent for other jurisdictions. When the county legislators passed such a measure last year, it was vetoed. The new bill deserves the same treatment from the County Executive, Patrick Halpin.

title: Donaldson Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $465,000 and $1,093,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $244,000 for the quarter and $722,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month share earnings are restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid May 2, 1988.

title: Sahara Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hyponex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the net in the latest quarter was reduced by the carrying costs of senior subordinated debentures sold in March 1987.

title: Reviews/Music; 4 Scarlatti Piano Sonatas
description: Christine Diwyk is a pianist who plays with startling power, clarity and variety, and who puts her impressive technique at the service of consistently insightful interpretive ideas. At Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, she addressed works that ranged from the delicate to the grandiose, and from the formal to the impassioned, and retained a persuasive gracefulness from start to finish.

title: Weisfield's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Burying Bush Already? That's Silly.
description: According to the latest polls, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's biggest problem now is deciding what to say in his inaugural address.

title: Bonds and Notes Up in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and longer-term notes moved higher in sluggish trading yesterday on signs the Federal Reserve Board may have tightened credit conditions another notch.

title: Sanderson Farms reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,250,000 from an accounting change.

title: New York Philharmonic Prepares for Soviet Tour
description: ''These last few weeks, the trip to the Soviet Union is all the orchestra has talked about,'' Zubin Mehta said the other day, a few moments after leading the New York Philharmonic through a performance of the Mahler Ninth Symphony. ''The works we've been playing here the last few weeks - the Brahms Second, the Mahler -is music we are bringing with us. And in rehearsal, we can't help wondering how this or that phrase will sound in the beautiful Bolshoi Hall in Leningrad. We are all very excited.''

title: We're Not Condemned to Carbon-Based Fuels; Change to Hydrogen
description: To the Editor:

title: Commuter Chaos: Accidents and Rain
description: As flames billowed from a disabled propane tank truck on Long Island for a second day yesterday, the traffic jams the accident created symbolized a chaotic day for commuters in the New York metropolitan region.

title: 2 at Princeton Get Jail Terms For Roles in Pledge Drinking
description: Saying he would not treat the case ''as an undergraduate frolic that got out of hand,'' a judge yesterday sentenced two officers of one of Princeton University's private eating clubs to 30 days in jail for their roles in parties in February during which 45 students suffered alcohol-induced medical problems.

title: Cup in Court
description: Attorneys in gray suits took the place of yachtsmen in blue blazers for the third time yesterday to argue the future of the America's Cup. Justice Carmen Beauchamp Ciparick, presiding over a packed courtroom in the New York State Supreme Court building in lower Manhattan, began the task of deciding whether a multihull yacht can race against a monohull yacht in cup races scheduled for San Diego this September.

title: Death Ends 1,600-Mile Flight Of Learjet Stolen by Mechanic
description: A flight mechanic who did not have a pilot's license stole a private jet in Virginia early today and flew it 1,600 miles to Denver, where he shot himself to death as the authorities closed in, officials said.

title: Reviews/Music; Karen Akers Sings Ballads
description: Among the younger generation of cabaret performers, Karen Akers stands apart from her peers as an icon of cool, contained elegance. Ms. Akers, who has returned to the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) for a semiannual engagement through Saturday, possesses a dark, glowing contralto that echoes Carly Simon but without any rock inclinations. She phrases ballads with the supple care of an art singer, relying upon subtle adjustments in intonation to convey a pained sensitivity.

title: Hollywood Opens Its Summer Onslaught
description: Led by ''Crocodile Dundee II'' and ''Rambo III,'' Hollywood's summer attack troops are storming the box offices this weekend.

title: Meese Is Told He Harms G.O.P.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was told by some conservative Congressmen today that his legal troubles were causing political damage to the Republican Party and the Presidential candidacy of Vice President Bush.

title: Farley Seeks U.S. Clearance To Purchase 15% of Pepperell
description: William F. Farley, a Chicago industrialist, has asked for Government antitrust clearance to buy at least 15 percent of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the big Georgia-based textile producer said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Medicare Expansion Gains

title: Outlook for Summit: Not Much Chance of Breakthrough on Arms Accords
description: The summit meeting in Moscow may be the last chance for the superpowers to revive the prospects for completing a new strategic arms treaty before President Reagan leaves office.

title: Hanoi Plans 50,000-Man Pullout From Cambodia
description: Western diplomats said today that they had been told that Vietnam was withdrawing 50,000 troops from Cambodia by the end of this year.

title: Minstar Agrees To Bid by Jacobs
description: Minstar Inc. said it had agreed to an improved buyout offer from its controlling shareholder and chairman, Irwin L. Jacobs, valued at $400 million. Minstar signed a merger agreement under which a group led by Mr. Jacobs will conduct a leveraged buyout of the company at $31.50 a share in cash, up from a previous offer of $29.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR STATE TO SHUT SHOREHAM A-PLANT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company agreed in principle early today to sell the $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant for $1 to New York State, which will end more than 20 years of controversy over Shoreham by closing it.

title: Dr. Maurice H. Cowen, Orthopedic Surgeon, 49
description: Dr. Maurice H. Cowen, an orthopedic surgeon who specialized in sports medicine, died of multiple myeloma Monday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pretoria and Mozambique in Pact
description: Mozambican and South African officials agreed at a meeting in Maputo today to revive a nonaggression pact prohibiting support for guerrilla groups operating from each other's territories.

title: McDermott International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net of $260,000 for the quarter and a loss of $34,698,000 for the year both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $4,276,000, in connection with a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $234,153,000 and $254,707,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $4,991,000 for the quarter and year. The company said results for the fourth quarter and fiscal 1987 year have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Peace Corps Grants for Graduate Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Moves by Coastal Could Help Stock
description: THE price performance of shares of the Coastal Corporation has lagged that of less profitable competitors for some months now. Despite Coastal's record as one of the best growth companies in the energy business, investors are cautious about its debt load, which was $3.6 billion, or a steep 81 percent of total capital, last December.

title: The Only Child
description: To The Home Section:

title: Alan Paton's Admirers Are Left Confused
description: To the Editor:

title: Engineer in Fatal Crash Admits Federal Charge
description: Conrail engineer at the controls in the worst crash in Amtrak history pleaded guilty today to a Federal charge of conspiring to obstruct an investigation of the wreck.

title: Moscow Issuing Visas To Israel's Delegation
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to issue visas that would allow an official Israeli delegation to visit Moscow for the first time since the Kremlin broke off relations in 1967.

title: Passing Lie Test Said to Lead To Howard Beach Plea Deal
description: A plea deal in the Howard Beach racial-attack case was made possible when a defendant passed two lie-detector tests backing his position that he had not seen the beating of a black man, according to people familiar with the case.

title: American Stores Accedes to F.T.C.
description: The American Stores Company said it had agreed with Federal regulators not to buy any shares of Lucky Stores Inc. until Saturday. A 10-day waiting period expired today, following American's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on its $2.5 billion buyout bid for Lucky, the country's sixth-largest grocery retailer.

title: Bush Wins in Idaho in Light Turnout
description: Vice President Bush won an easy victory in the Idaho Presidential primary Tuesday, but his relatively light vote raised Democratic hopes for November.

title: Home Resales Rose in April
description: Sales of existing homes rose 4.5 percent in April, the biggest advance since November 1986, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Reason to Celebrate
description: To be present at a friend's triumph is a rare pleasure. It was mine last weekend at the opening of the new National Gallery of Canada, designed by Moshe Safdie.

title: Laser Photonics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: In Maine, 200 Years Of Jigsaw Puzzles
description: LEAD: When Anne Williams was a young girl in Arlington, Va., her family often gathered at card tables to put jigsaw puzzles together and chat.

title: Varity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $7.1 million. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary $1.6 million writeoff of investment in Massey Combines Corp.

title: Maxwell To Focus On Canada
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publishing entrepreneur, said today that he was turning his attention for the time being to Canada, where he said he planned to invest up to $2 billion (Canadian), about $1.6 billion (United States), in the next two years.

title: Farm Income Drop Seen
description: A new report by the Agriculture Department forecasts that net cash income of farmers will total $50 billion to $55 billion this year, down from a record $57 billion in 1987.

title: Celtics, Not Lights, Fail at the Garden
description: There have been some strange happenings at the Boston Garden these last eight days to go with the power failure Tuesday.

title: TV Notes
description: Presenting the Tonys Last year's Tony Awards presentation won an award itself - an Emmy - for Outstanding Variety Program. But it also caused hand-wringing at CBS by running 35 minutes beyond its two-hour schedule.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman's, a division of L. J. Hooker Retail Group, as part of its executive restructuring, named as senior vice presidents: Robin Clairfield-Tolvin, director of stores; Philip Blanco, marketing and sales promotion, and Joseph Giudice, operations.

title: Review/Television; 'Omnibus,' a Potpourri From ABC
description: ''Omnibus'' is a venerable name; it was the title of the wonderful series that ran first on CBS and then on ABC from 1953 to 1957. High art and Pop art mixed, and then along came Jacques Cousteau or Jack Benny. ABC News resurrects the series tonight with a special at 10 o'clock. It is also called ''Omnibus,'' and it is intelligent and easy and nice.

title: New Scholarship Test Sought By Albany Education Official
description: A year after the state began awarding state scholarships on the basis of grade-point averages and standardized test scores, the New York State Education Commissioner wants to develop a new and fairer test.

title: French Open; A Teen-Ager Knocks Off Mandlikova
description: The third day of the French Open brought the the first major upsets of the tournament.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ford Portrait Coming
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford is coming to Washington on June 6 with a painting of himself to be presented to the Smithsonian Institution's National Portrait Gallery. The painting, by Everett Raymond Kinstler, a gift of the Gerald R. Ford Foundation, will hang in the gallery's Hall of Presidents. The gallery already has a painting of the 38th President's successor, Jimmy Carter, and of the 40th President, Ronald Reagan.

title: Not Just Grand, but 500 Grand
description: THE design is a carefully orchestrated secret. But a trickle of information is known about the 500,000th Steinway piano, which is to make its debut at Carnegie Hall next Thursday. The instrument was crafted by Wendell Castle, a furniture designer and woodworker.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Stake in Payless
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman has again raised his stake in Payless Cashways Inc., to 9.9 percent from 9.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman did not change his previous statement that he may seek control of the chain of building materials stores, which is based in Kansas City, Mo. Mr. Edelman now controls 3.34 million Payless Cashways common shares. The Payless shares rose 25 cents today, to $22.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Review/Dance; Yeager and Bocca in Ballet Theater's 'Don Quixote'
description: American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote,'' staged by Mikhail Baryshnikov after choreography by Marius Petipa and Alexander Gorsky, is an unflagging swirl of toreador capes and gypsy skirts. The women all jump on point, the men flirt and quaff wine and there is even a little bravura dancing tucked into the proceedings. And that all came across, sometimes a little too strongly, when Ballet Theater presented the ballet on Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Future Help for Those Who Look Back
description: A CHARITABLE trust has been set up by the architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle in honor of the preservationist James Marston Fitch. Dr. Fitch, 79 years old, founded the country's first university program in historic preservation at Columbia University and currently directs preservation projects for the firm. Dr. Fitch's efforts have taken him from Ecuador to the South Street Seaport in New York. His crusty cries of ''andiamo!'' (Italian for ''let's go!'') while touring historic buildings are legendary among his students. The trust will provide mid-career professionals with money for preservation research.

title: Tenneco Wants to Sell Its Oil and Gas Unit
description: Under pressure from investors to improve its performance and the price of its stock, Tenneco Inc. said today that it planned to sell its large oil and gas operations. Analysts said the sale could bring in $5.4 billion or more.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I live in an old house with wood floors, and in one room the floor squeaks when you walk across it. Is this a major problem, or is there a simple remedy? A.It is seldom a major problem, although in rare cases it can indicate a structural defect. Squeaking is most often due to loose floorboards that move up and down when stepped on, making the edges squeak as they rub against each other.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,824,000 for the quarter and $2,620,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $117,000 for the quarter and $93,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: Robeson Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Sports of The Times; More History For the Old Barn
description: TALK about power plays. Never again will the national anthem be taken lightly. O, say can you see, indeed.

title: For Airbag's Inventor, 17-Year Wait Pays Off
description: John Pietz has spent 17 years tinkering in the laboratories of Talley Industries waiting for his favorite invention to pay off. Now, two years away from retirement, the chemist responsible for a key breakthrough in the development of automotive airbags is finally seeing his discovery become standard equipment on many cars.

title: BUSH LASHES BACK ON ISSUE OF ETHICS
description: Frustrated by the Democrats' efforts to tar him with the ethical problems of the Reagan Administration, Vice President Bush tried to make the issue boomerang on them today.

title: Harry Bade, 69, Dies; Ex-Mobil Oil Executive
description: Harry A. Bade Jr., a retired vice president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died of a heart attack Friday at the Florida Hospital Medical Center in Orlando, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Doyle Graf Awarded Hoechst-Celanese Job
description: The Hoechst-Celanese Corporation has awarded Doyle Graf Mabley its corporate advertising account following a two-month review. The ad budget is $8 million.

title: LeFrak Wins Development Right
description: The LeFrak Organization has been formally selected to develop a housing complex, with 1,200 apartments, on city-owned land on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, city housing officials said yesterday.

title: Golfer Hospitalized
description: Byron Nelson, the Hall of Fame golfer, was admitted to a hospital yesterday after he complained of dizziness and fatigue.

title: House of Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Enstar Indonesia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Angola Says U.S. Uses Zaire Bases to Train Rebels
description: Angolan military commanders have charged that the United States is using six bases in southern Zaire to train and supply Jonas Savimbi's rebels for attacks in Angola.

title: Karl A. Wittfogel, Social Scientist Who Turned on Communists, 91
description: Karl August Wittfogel, a social scientist and former Communist whose theories caused him to be denounced in Communist circles, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge
description: The world's oldest pair event, the Goldman, will be contested for the 60th time Saturday.

title: Forstmann & Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Omni magazine to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge for trade advertising.

title: Property Capital Trust (Boston) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $3,809,000 from the sale of an investment. c-After a gain of $9,455,000 from the sale of an investment for the quarter and 9 months.

title: McKesson Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $4.4 million loss from discontinued operations.

title: Moscow Plans 2d Bond Sale
description: The Soviet Union plans to sell bonds in West Germany to help finance perestroika, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of social and economic restructuring, bankers said today.

title: HELMS ENDS FIGHT AGAINST ARMS PACT
description: Outflanked and outmaneuvered, Senator Jesse Helms gave up his fight against the new missile treaty today, paving the way for a compromise agreement that could permit the Senate to vote final approval of the treaty as early as Friday afternoon.

title: Irving Bank Offer Extended
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana said yesterday that it would extend until midnight on June 8 its offer to buy 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corportion's stock at $80 a share.

title: Reviews/Music; Blues With Dash of Humor
description: Zora Young, a blues singer from Chicago, put on a casual show at Tramps on Friday night. That worked for her and against her: her backup band, led by Eddie Lusk, spent a dull hour grinding through some blues and novelty numbers. But when she came out and wandered amid the tables, singing - and complaining about how her feet hurt -she made the audience feel as if it were sitting in on a show she was putting on just for friends.

title: Moscow Parliament Revolts: Tax on Business Is Opposed
description: The Soviet legislature, normally a docile forum that ratifies the Communist Party's will by unanimous show of hands, today found itself with an unexpected tax revolt on its hands.

title: Review/Ballet; Young Dancers in Recital
description: Among the pleasures of attending the annual workshop programs by the School of American Ballet is that of seeing young dancers cope with the artistic challenges of ballets in several styles. There was much to applaud in the performances offered Saturday and Monday nights at the Juilliard Theater.

title: Brandon Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boomerang Bounces Back
description: GREAT news for fans of the 1950's. Deluged by requests from a nostalgic public, the Formica Corporation has decided to reintroduce its famous boomerang pattern, designed by Raymond Loewy and originally named Skylark.

title: Calendar of Events: Unusual Azaleas
description: Azalea Walk, Bartlett Arboretum Association, University of Connecticut, 151 Brookdale Road, near Route 137, Stamford, Conn.; 203-322-6971.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan, McGrath Ends 11-Year Tie With Aetna
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor has said farewell to Aetna Life and Casualty after an 11-year relationship during which billings went from about $1 million, to $19 million last year, and the agency could say in heartfelt fashion, ''Aetna, I'm glad I met ya.''

title: Yanks Win in 10; Mets Top Giants; Mets 6, Giants 3
description: It was easy to forgive the crowd for leaving early. It was wet and cold and unlikely to improve, although those weren't the only conditions that argued for heading to the parking lot after just seven innings. After all, the Mets were leading and the bullpen was working.

title: Quintuplets Born in Texas
description: Quintuplets were born Tuesday to a 28-year-old woman who thought she was having twins. ''They told me two,'' Maria Esther Chavez said in Spanish. ''They're fine, thanks to God.'' Mrs. Chavez said she was about 7 1/2 months pregnant when a girl was born about 1 A.M., followed by another girl, then three boys, within about four minutes. The babies' weights ranged from two pounds, three ounces to three pounds, a McAllen Medical Center spokeswoman said.

title: Metro Matters; Marcus Garvey And Ed Koch In Perspective
description: Wesley McDonald Holder chooses his words carefully, as someone might who can apply nine decades of perspective to today's political conundrums.

title: Reviews/Music; Church Organ Inaugurated
description: The Church of the Transfiguration, also known as ''the Little Church Around the Corner,'' at 1 East 29th Street, has just installed a new three-manual organ, made by Charles B. Fisk, and on Sunday afternoon John Gordon Morris gave an inaugural recital that put the instrument through its paces.

title: Equipment Trust Issue by USAir
description: USAir Inc., a unit of USAir Group Inc., is offering $166.4 million of equipment trust certificates through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The equipment trust certificates are backed by eight Boeing 737-300 jets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Zaire's politics and economy referred incorrectly to the country's living standard. The average Zairian's wages, after accounting for inflation, are 10 percent of what they were in 1960.

title: Corrigan Sees Market Flaw
description: The financial markets need stronger systems for clearing and settling trades to help reduce the risk of a large default that could snowball and tie up the system, E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The movie review and listing last Sunday on page 7 of the Television section for May 22-28 included ''The Birth of a Nation'' erroneously. The program, on Channel 13 tonight at 10, is a contemporary British drama in the ''Channel Crossings'' series, not the 1915 film.

title: Researchers Identify Subtle Biological Signs That Warn of Diabetes
description: Recent findings are giving doctors a new ability to predict who is most susceptible to the most common form of adult diabetes.

title: Reviews/Music; Pianist in Chopin and Liszt
description: Krystian Zimerman is a pianist with so much to give that one longs for him to choose his gifts more carefully. His program at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon settled into the deep ruts of familiar repertory - the Ballades and Fantasy in F minor of Chopin and the Liszt Sonata. It is territory crossed and recrossed so many thousands of times in this city and elsewhere that its beautiful prospects and startling promontories no longer startle. Through constant repetition, they have been neutralized in our sensibilities - numbing the thoughtful, soothing the short-sighted. Playing these pieces once again - no matter how forcefully - simply told us what we already know and have been reminded of too often.

title: Soviet No Longer Sees Ads as Capitalist Curse
description: ''Advertising is a means of swindling the people by foisting upon them goods frequently useless and of dubious quality,'' the Soviet Encylopedia said in the late 1940's. ''Advertising involves the popularization of goods with the aim of selling them,'' the current edition says.

title: Reagan in Finland to Rest Before Summit
description: President Reagan arrived here tonight for three days of rest before continuing to Moscow for his summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, but the traveling White House was distracted by lingering political troubles at home.

title: Commonwealth Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $33.9 million and $95.4 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, in additions to loan loss reserves.

title: Million Bullets Recalled by New York City Police
description: The New York City Police Department yesterday ordered the immediate recall of one million .38-caliber revolver bullets because the ammunition does not meet departmental specifications intended to make it easy to trace in criminal investigations.

title: Times Publisher Cites High Cost of Slowdown
description: The publisher of The New York Times said yesterday that a two-week work slowdown by unionized truck drivers had cost the newspaper several million dollars and warned that ''our options are narrowing'' for dealing with the drivers' union.

title: Women Aren't Guys
description: A young woman, a lawyer, strides into a conference room. Already in attendance, at what looks to be the start of a high-level meeting, are four smartly dressed women in their 20's and 30's. The arriving woman plunks her briefcase down at the head of the polished table and announces, ''O.K., guys, let's get started.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Failure on Panama succession talks was acknowledged by the Reagan Administration, which said it would not engage in any more efforts to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to leave the country. Page A1

title: An Amicable Parting for Man and Home
description: IT was supposed to have been a fairy tale: boy meets house, and they live happily ever after in the Hamptons.

title: Cybermedic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings for the year-ago periods are less than one cent a share.

title: Protecting Depositors, Not Bank Owners, Is F.D.I.C.'s Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Umbrellas, Parasols And Replacement Ribs
description: SHOW me someone who has to open and close umbrellas indoors all day long and I'll show you someone who isn't superstitious. ''I can't afford to be,'' said Gilbert Center, manager of the Uncle Sam Umbrella Shop, which has manufactured, sold and repaired umbrellas since 1866.

title: Etz Lavud Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
