description: The U.S. dollar figures are translated from new Israeli shekels at the rate as of March 31, 1988, which was $1 equals 1.5596 Shekels.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Brian Burns and Carol Cotton have become executive vice presidents and management directors at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/San Francisco.

title: Baseball; Leary's One-Hitter Beats Phils
description: Tim Leary pitched a one-hitter, allowing only a third-inning single by Darren Daulton, and Mike Scioscia and Jeff Hamilton each hit two-run homers tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0.

title: Soviet Lists Afghan War Toll: 13,310 Dead, 35,478 Wounded
description: The Soviet Union, ending a long silence about the exact number of its casualties in the war in Afghanistan, said today that 13,310 soldiers had been killed, 35,478 wounded and 311 are missing.

title: Renaissance Picks Editor
description: Robert Manning, 68 years old, former editor in chief of The Atlantic, has been named editor in chief of Renaissance, the Magazine for Living Well, which is expected to seek an audience of readers 55 and over who are both sophisticated and affluent.

title: Water Crisis Imperils India's Farms and Cities
description: For several weeks now, New Delhi has been struggling to assure itself of enough water this summer for its seven million citizens.

title: Rights Abuses Seen in 3 North Africa Nations
description: In the midst of recounting a severe beating by a police chief, Mohammed Guessous's voice softened to a whisper and trailed off. He had developed a headache and fatigue and had to cut short the conversation.

title: Baseball Notebook; Fans Are Getting Two Messages About Drinking
description: Baseball continues to confuse its fans. While the commissioner's office and individual clubs work on reducing the number of problems created at ball parks by the consumption of beer and other alcoholic beverages, they relentlessly hit fans over the head with messages suggesting they drink.

title: Bush's Chief Spokesman Requests Transfer in Dispute Over Strategy
description: Peter Teeley, the chief spokesman for Vice President Bush, has asked to take another senior position in the campaign. Campaign aides said the action reflected a sharp disagreement within the organization over how aggressive the Vice President should be.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: ONE of the things I like most about our neighborhood is the parades. They're good old-fashioned small-town parades, with fire engines and police cars and high-school cheerleaders carrying their pompons and kicking their legs in the air. The Mayor marches, and the Council members, and occasionally there's a minor - a very minor - beauty queen. A couple of guys work the sidelines, selling soft pretzels and cheap toys at prices more inflated than their stock of balloons, and there's a little train that makes a booming noise so loud that children cover their ears with their hands.

title: Reviews/Music; 6 Computer Compositions
description: Larry Polansky and John Bischoff, composers from the San Francisco area, offered six of their recent computer works at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Friday evening. Their approaches to computer composition could not be more different.

title: Reviews/Music; The Art Songs of Europe
description: Arden Shelton, a soprano, offered a cleverly chosen and sensitively sung program as a benefit concert for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. In her first half, she deftly covered about three centuries of Italian, French and German art songs, most of them lovelorn plaints, ending on a brighter note with Strauss's ''Heimliche Auffordering.'' The second half comprised 20th-century British and American works, in English. And although she seems to have gravitated to works with texts conceived with a decidedly male point of view, she presented the emotions they capture creditably.

title: Private Brands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Albany's Deficit Can't Be Denied
description: In California, Massachusetts and now New York, Federal tax reform has unhinged budget planning. Having failed to predict the full impact of a change in treatment of capital gains, state officials are suddenly scrambling to meet large revenue shortfalls. While election year politics make it tempting to defer the issue, New York's deficit needs to be addressed immediately.

title: The Calling of Medicine Demands Commitment
description: To the Editor:

title: Brajdas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Eaton Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shelbyville Journal; Shepherding the Flock Till the Dreaded Summer
description: At 4 feet 10, he's easy to miss, standing by the stoplight every morning and afternoon in the sun, the rain, the heat and the snow. Now, according to the regular rhythms of these early days of summer, he is about to disappear -again.

title: Behind Big Gap in Cuomo Budget: A Big Gamble Lost
description: Just five weeks after its budget was enacted, the Cuomo administration says the state will be $900 million in the red, and the story of how it came to be that way, according to state officials and independent economists, is one of politics and miscalculation.

title: Books of The Times; Cold-War Novelist Takes a Moral View of History
description: The Revolutionist By Robert Littell 467 pages. Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: Blue Mountain Owners Hail Ruling on Cards
description: Stephen Schutz and Susan Polis Schutz had cause to celebrate yesterday: a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in favor of their small greeting card company, Blue Mountain Arts, against their huge competitor, Hallmark.

title: American Pacesetter reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: MGM Grand Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $311,000 tax credit. c-Net loss The latest quarter includes results for the Desert Inn and Sands Hotels from their acquisition on Feb. 1. The company did not report revenue for the year-ago first quarter, when it was in the development stage.

title: Female Sportswriters Make Their Mark
description: Female sportswriters, who once toiled for months at a time without seeing another member of their sex, are now numerous enough to have formed a professional organization that gathered here this week for its first convention.

title: Anti-Job Bias Law for Ulster
description: Britain published a draft law today to strengthen prohibitions against religious discrimination in job recruitment in Northern Ireland.

title: Child's-Eye View From Scandinavia
description: ''NOTICE the absence of duck and bunny motifs,'' said Sandra Edwards, curator of ''Scandinavian Child,'' a small exhibition highlighting designs from Norway, Sweden and Finland at the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Profits Up at 4 Japanese Companies
description: The Sony Corporation, Fujitsu Ltd., the NEC Corporation and the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation today reported sharply higher earnings for the fiscal year ended March 31.

title: American Vanguard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nonprofit Tax Plans Advance
description: After two days of closed-door debate, a House subcommittee today tentatively endorsed a package of proposals for taxing more types of income-producing activities of nonprofit organizations.

title: Amerford International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: An Executive Changes listing in some editions of Business Day last Wednesday about Sun Management described the company incorrectly. It is an international business management concern. In addition, a listing in some editions on the accounting firm of Pannell Kerr Forster misidentified its former managing partner. He is Charles Kaiser Jr.

title: Black and White on Campus: Learning Tolerance, Not Love, and Separately
description: In Sproul Plaza, the central gathering place on the University of California campus here, students congregate in racial groups, the blacks in one part of the great flagstone expanse, the whites in another.

title: We're Not Condemned to Carbon-Based Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Aluminum Outlook
description: Aluminum output in the United States is likely to rise 15 percent this year, to 3.85 million metric tons, reversing a slump during most of the 1980's, the London office of Shearson Lehman Hutton said today. It cited declining production costs and the fall in the dollar, making American smelters more competitive. In 1986 United States production fell to an 18-year low of three million metric tons.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Healthtrust Inc., a hospital management company based in Nashville, is offering a total of $745 million in debt securities through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The four-part financing includes $365 million of zero-coupon senior subordinated debentures due in 1999, priced at $574.12 per $1,000 of bonds to yield 16.50 percent. A sinking fund beginning in 1997 will retire two-thirds of the issue by maturity. The securities are noncallable for five years and rated B-3 by Moody's Investors Service and CCC+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Manila Journal; Battling the 'Culture of Corruption' Day by Day
description: One day, a neighbor told Miriam Defensor Santiago, the Commissioner of Immigration, that there was a burglar in her house.

title: Sony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 125 yen equals U.S. $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of March 31, 1988. The share earnings are in American Depositary Share and each ADS represents one share of common stock.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are aware of our losses, and these losses have been quite heavy.'' - Gen. Aleksei D. Lizichev of the Soviet Union, on Afghanistan. [ A14:3. ]

title: George Rose Memorial
description: Actors, singers and other theater professionals will take part in a tribute to the actor George Rose at 11 A.M. June 8 at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Mr. Rose was slain in the Dominican Republic on May 5; he was 68 years old. Those appearing at the tribute, which is open to the public, will be Joseph Papp, Graciela Daniele, Rupert Holmes, Maureen McGovern, Betty Buckley, Jack Gilford and Estelle Parsons.

title: Leon Shimkin, a Guiding Force At Simon & Schuster, Dies at 81
description: Leon Shimkin, who joined Simon & Schuster as a 17-year-old bookkeeper and helped build it into one of the nation's major book publishing companies, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y. A resident of Larchmont, N.Y., he was 81 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kepke/Fink Promoting Itself in the Hamptons
description: The year-old Kepke/Fink agency, which has found the $20,000 it spent for small-space Manhattan newspaper advertising for itself so rewarding, is going to try something a little bigger, a four-color two-page spread in a newspaper that circulates in the chic precincts of Long Island's South Fork. You know, darling, the Hamptons.

title: Malrite Communications Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $399,000.

title: Royal Palm Beach Colony Inc LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Dance; Male Motion and Emotion at the Joyce
description: Terry Creach and Stephen Koester might simply be two performers who enjoy dancing together. If they are also interested in suggesting the wide range of movement and emotional coloring men can cover in dance, they proved their point in a program presented by Creach/Koester on Saturday at the Joyce Theater as part of the ''3-D at the Joyce'' festival.

title: College Extends Honor Roll to High-School Teachers
description: Cornell University today did something rare among the nation's colleges: It honored some of the high-school teachers of its top undergraduates.

title: One Blow for Liberty
description: The most abusive intrusion on the privacy of Americans - the polygraph, falsely claiming to be a ''lie detector'' - is on the verge of receiving a setback.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Oneida Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said changes in its retirement plan resulted in a reduction in net income of about $500,000 for the latest quarter, while the 1988 federal tax law changes lowering corporate income tax rates had a positive effect on earnings of $180,000.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: You are 35 years old, or maybe 55, and when you look in the mirror the worst you expect to see are some wrinkles or perhaps a receding hairline. But pimples? Shouldn't they have disappeared with adolescence?

title: Neglect Cited In the Deaths Of 4 Infants
description: A Family Court judge has ruled that a young Brooklyn couple showed ''gross negligence'' in the care of their five infant children, four of whom died of natural causes in the last five years. None of the four children lived past the age of four months.

title: Relatives Ruled Eligible to Lease Vacated Units
description: In a decision that further complicates the legal and political debate over who can inherit a rent-stabilized apartment, a New York State appeals panel ruled yesterday that live-in relatives could take over an apartment after the tenant named on a lease dies.

title: Sports People; Return to New Jersey
description: Julie Krone, the leading female jockey in racing history, will leave New York next week and ride at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J., this summer. Krone has won only two races at the Belmont Park meeting that began May 11 and called the current New York riding colony the toughest in history.

title: Dataflex reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IRAQ RETAKES LAND NEAR BORDER PORT
description: Iraq announced today that it had begun an offensive near the battered city of Basra, a southern Iraqi port on the Iran-Iraq border, recapturing territory lost to Iran east and south of the city.

title: US Truck Lines Inc of Delaware reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Singapore Political Alliance Will Challenge Ruling Party
description: Three small oppositon parties in Singapore have announced that they will form an alliance to challenge the People's Action Party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in the next election.

title: Presidential Life Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $1,395,000 for the latest first quarter and $5,254,000 for the year-ago period.

title: WOMAN'S SENTENCE IS BIRTH CONTROL
description: A judge has ordered a young woman to remain on birth control for the rest of her childbearing years because she abandoned her two young sons in a sweltering apartment last summer.

title: CNW to Sell Unit
description: The CNW Corporation said it had agreed to sell its snowplow manufacturing unit, Douglas Dynamics Inc, to Park-Kenilworth Industries for $100 million. Park-Kenilworth is a new holding company affiliated with the Grabill Corporation, a closely held suburban Chicago company. Douglas Dynamics is the nation's largest manufacturer of medium-size snowplows, sold under the Western and Fisher brands, for use on four-wheel-drive pickup trucks and utility vehicles. The transaction is expected to be closed in June.

title: Orient-Express Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,500,000. c-Net income and includes a $7.8 million pretax gain on asset sales.

title: Litton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Yields Post Modest Rise
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were modestly higher for the week ended yesterday.

title: Transplant Baby Dies
description: Michael Steward, a 10 1/2-month-old who was the last survivor among several children with rare multi-organ transplants, died Sunday of multiple organ failure. He received a liver, small bowel, pancreas and a portion of his stomach in February at Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center.

title: For 'Arbat' Author, Novel Is Yoked to Perestroika
description: Anatoly Rybakov considers it appropriate that his novel ''Children of the Arbat'' is identified with the campaign of economic and social restructuring that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has begun under its Russian name of perestroika.

title: Sports People; Out of a Job
description: Minnesota's first female high school hockey coach is out of a job after allegations that she either furnished team members under her supervision with beer or allowed them to drink it.

title: Look of a Winner Helps Dukakis Reap Support
description: Michael S. Dukakis today won the high level of praise here that is usually reserved for veteran Capitol Hill legislators, not outsiders from New England.

title: Game That Wasn't Is Talk of Boston
description: The power is back for now at the venerable Boston Garden, but all this sports-crazed city could talk about today was the night the lights went out at the celebrated arena.

title: Reviews/Music; Piano and Violin Duo
description: Therese Dussaut was to have given a solo piano recital Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, but she was apparently in the mood for chamber music instead, so she turned up with Vartan Manoogian, a violinist, with whom she played sonatas by Schubert, Debussy and Franck. By retaining top billing and keeping the piano lid open, she conveyed her intention to be an equal collaborator rather than merely an accompanist; and in her performance, she made good on that promise, bringing some exquisite texturing and detail to her performance, but by no means overshadowing Mr. Manoogian.

title: Airbags on the Way As Chrysler Gives In
description: The Chrysler Corporation's decision to install airbags as standard equipment on several car lines this year and all its domestically made cars by 1990 signals the end of a nearly 20-year battle over use of the devices, according to auto industry executives and safety advocates.

title: Farm Bank Bonds
description: Among government agency issues expected this week is a Federal Farm Credit Bank three-part bond sale totaling $3.02 billion, which was priced yesterday at par and offered through various securities dealers. An $828 million issue due Sept. 1 yields 7.25 percent, while $1.4 billion of an issue due Dec. 1 yields 7.625 percent. For $791 million of bonds due June 1, 1989, the yield is 7.90 percent.

title: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
Navy Is Seeking Ships Undetectable by Radar
description: The Navy is studying the possibility of making warships largely undetectable by radar in the same way as the Stealth aircraft, a development that would revolutionize naval warfare tactics, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today.

title: Mexican Output Surges
description: Mexico's public finances improved in the first quarter while exports remained strong and inflation dropped sharply, according to Finance Minister Gustavo Petricioli. He told the Mexican Congress Tuesday that industrial production climbed 9.7 percent after a rise of 3.1 percent in the final quarter of 1987 and a drop of 2.5 percent in the first 1987 quarter. He said public-sector external debt totaled $81.3 billion on March 31, against $81.4 billion on Dec. 31.

title: U.S. AGENCY VOTES BAN ON A DART TOY
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted today to ban most lawn darts, citing the danger of death or serious injury from the pointed metal darts.

title: Rowntree Is Offered $3.9 Billion by Suchard
description: Jacob Suchard A.G., the Swiss chocolate maker, today offered $:2.1 billion, or about $3.9 billion, for Rowntree P.L.C. if the British confectioner agrees to a friendly merger.

title: Parkway Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Marcos in Hawaiian Hospital After Suffering Chest Pains
description: The former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, is in intensive care in a hospital here after suffering chest pains, a hospital official said today.

title: Nestor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music; Collegiate Sings Verdi And Janacek
description: The Collegiate Chorale celebrated two geriatric wonders among composers at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The music was Janacek's ''Amarus'' and the Four Sacred Pieces by Verdi. Robert Bass conducted. Curtis Rayam and Karen Williams sang the solo parts.

title: State Senators and Cuomo Differ On the Urgency of Budget Deficit
description: Governor Cuomo is taking an unjustifiably dim view of the state's finances that would needlessly cost the state millions of dollars, the chief financial analyst of the Republican-led State Senate said today.

title: Rohr Industries Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Gerber Scientific Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: On June 11, 1987 the board of directors of the company declared a 3-for-2 common stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock distribution payable to shareholders of record June 22, 1987. Share earnings and shares outstanding for the three months and year ended April 30, 1987, have been restated to reflect this stock split.

title: A Portrait of an Artist's Quiet Courage
description: The early sculptures of Joan Sovern are large works with soft, sensual curves, in bronze, terra cotta and marble. The later works, smaller assemblages of stones or slate affixed to bases, are angular, stark and markedly different.

title: National Parks Urged to Ban All Concessions
description: The Federal Government should move all hotels and other concessions out of the national parks, an environmental group said Tuesday in issuing a report on what it considers the 10 most threatened parks.

title: Damon Creations Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the loss increased due to a decline of sales, and to the inclusion of $155,000 in royalty income in the year-ago quarter.

title: Where Corridors of Justice Are Curved
description: ''YOU meet a better class of criminal here,'' said Louis Varron, an employee at the North Dade County Justice Center in North Miami, the first public building designed by Arquitectonica, the Miami architectural firm known for its breezy, irreverent style.

title: Quarter's Spectacular Trade Gain
description: Sharply rising exports in the first quarter produced the most spectacular improvement in the nation's trade deficit in any quarter since the dollar began its decline in 1985, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: In Summer's Heat, Pets Need Special Attention
description: Dogs and cats have important places in millions of American families, and when summer brings hot weather and vacation travel, pets need special attention.

title: Hundreds Attend a Celebration Of Armand Hammer's Birthday
description: Shortly after President Reagan left for his summit meeting in Moscow, hundreds of people gathered tonight to celebrate the 90th birthday of one of the first advocates of United States-Soviet cooperation, Dr. Armand Hammer.

title: MEDICARE ADVANCE CLEARS BIG HURDLE
description: A House-Senate conference committee reached agreement today on legislation to protect the nation's Medicare beneficiaries against the cost of prolonged, acute illness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Review/Concert; Premieres and Bernstein
description: A few weeks ago, when Ascap held a reception in honor of Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday, the composer and conductor protested that his birthday was not until Aug. 25. Nevertheless, several early tributes have already been offered, the most recent being an installment of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's Meet the Moderns series Tuesday evening at Town Hall. For the occasion, the Brooklyn players offered four early works by Mr. Bernstein and the world premieres of three scores by young composers that were commissioned by the orchestra, Ascap and Meet the Composer.

title: Chicago Bank's Money Is Back
description: The First National Bank of Chicago has recovered the last of the nearly $70 million embezzled in a fund transfer scheme, according to officials of the bank. The remaining $19.8 million was returned by the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, along with $37,046 in interest, they said Tuesday.

title: Chairman of Santa Fe Faces Shareholder Fight
description: Robert D. Krebs, who heads the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, faces a situation that pits management against shareholders who voted against the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense.

title: Altai Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Pepperdine Player Advances: Top-seeded Robbie Weiss of Pepperdine won his first-round singles match at the N.C.A.A. individual tennis championships yesterday at Athens, Ga., but the second-seeded player was eliminated. Weiss defeated Jari Koho of Utah, 6-0, 6-0. Second-seeded Scott Melville of U.C.L.A., was eliminated by Olivier Lorin of Oklahoma, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4. (AP) Horse Racing Upset in Beaugay Handicap: Key to the Bridge, making only her second career start on the grass, slogged through a soft Belmont Park turf course to score an upset yesterday in the $86,100 Beaugay Handicap for older fillies. The winner, sent off at 7-1, beat Marimascus, another 7-1 shot, by six lengths. Just Class, the 3-2 second choice, finished nearly a length farther back in third and a head in front of Fieldy, the even-money favorite. Key to the Bridge carried 112 pounds and ran the mile and a sixteenth under Eddie Maple in 1:51 4/5. Golf Glenz Leads Dodge Open: David Glenz, the head pro of the Morris County Golf Club, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take a five-stroke lead after two rounds of the 25th Dodge Open at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J. Glenz has a two-round total of 135. Jon Kudysch of the Hamlet shot a second consecutive 70. Soccer Dutch Team Wins Cup: PSV Eindhoven won the European Champions' Cup yesterday, beating Benfica Lisbon in a penalty-kick shootout after regulation time ended in a scoreless tie at Stuttgart, West Germany. The Dutch team outscored Benfica by 6-5 in the penalty shootout.(AP)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Bankers Insurance Group Inc., Miami, said it had agreed to sell its Financial Insurance Group Ltd. unit to Allegiance Capital Partners for $:39.8 million, or $74 million, in cash and debt.

title: Pace Membership Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
description: b-After a tax credit of $221,000 and a gain of $15,000 from the repurchase of subordinated notes. c-Net loss and after a loss of $286,000 from the repurchase of subordinated notes.

title: Square Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The prior year net included an after- tax gain of about $854,000, or 73 cents a share, on the sale of a parcel of land.

title: International Mobile Mahines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: The Diplomatic Corps; African Envoys Take Their Case to Capitol HIll
description: African diplomats in Washington, many of them representing countries that are burdened with debt and are in economic distress, have hit upon a new maneuver for gaining Congressional attention. Since the lawmakers rarely go to their embassy parties, they have moved their social occasions to Capitol Hill.

title: A Commuter's Solution: Bicycle That Folds Up
description: CYCLISTS are elegant people, in the engineering sense: their solution to a transportation problem is simple and uses a minimum of energy.

title: Petroleum Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: A $44,000 Mistake, A Guilty Plea to Theft
description: A Pakistani national who used $44,000 mistakenly credited to his bank account to woo his future wife has pleaded guilty to first-degree larceny.

title: Cherokee Gets Takeover Offer
description: The investment firm Deutschman & Company said that its newly formed Green Acquisition Company had offered to acquire Cherokee Group, which makes women's footwear and other ready-to-wear apparel, for about $166 million. The $12.50-a-share offer sent the price of Cherokee stock up $4.125, to $12.125, in the over-the-counter market.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Scott Leads Lakers Past Dallas, 123-101
description: Byron Scott scored 30 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers breezed to a 123-101 victory over Dallas and took a two-games-to-none lead in the Western Conference final.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Education page on Wednesday about Washington University in St. Louis misidentified a campus building. The building shown in the photograph was Graham Chapel.

title: N.F.L. Roster Move
description: National Football League owners voted to increase rosters to 47 players and approved the conditional sale of the New England Patriots to the Reebok International chairman, Paul Fireman, before adjourning their annual spring meeting yesterday at Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Swensen's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Defense Counsel Seized as a Fake
description: A man on probation in Westchester County for impersonating a lawyer was arrested on the same charge yesterday in a Manhattan courtroom.

title: Wright Calls Republican Criticism of House Leadership 'Carping'
description: Speaker Jim Wright today rebutted severe Republican criticism of his Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives, saying, ''I try to be fair. I try to be bipartisan.''

title: Bank Outlook For Texas
description: Federal banking regulators today painted a gloomy picture of the industry in Texas and the Southwest, saying that 1988 would be ''a record bad year, the worse year since the Great Depression.''

title: Shows in Accord With Guild
description: David Letterman could return to the air and Johnny Carson would have his writers back under agreements both entertainers have reached with the striking Writers Guild of America, the union's president said Wednesday as talks resumed in the 12-week-old strike.

title: Jersey School Report Paints Portrait of a Disgrace
description: Buried in the New Jersey Education Department's eight-inch-thick report outlining the reasons for a state takeover of Jersey City's public schools are two critical subsections.

title: DeRose Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Israel and Allies Raid Lebanese Village
description: Israeli Air Force and artillery units and Lebanese in a Christian-led militia attacked a Shiite Moslem stronghold in southern Lebanon today. It was the second attack against the pro-Iranian Party of God forces in three weeks.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Images at Cannes, On and Off the Screen
description: The circus has left town. Within 12 hours of the close of the Cannes Film Festival Monday night, most of the 20,000 or so film people have departed. The huge advertising billboards along the Croisette have suddenly vanished. Concierges, waiters and taxi drivers have become polite again. The noise level has dropped by half and even the winds have stopped.

title: Clues of Stellar Explosions Found Deep in Mine, Scientists Say
description: By analyzing ore from a mine nearly a mile deep, two physicists believe they have hit upon traces of the death throes of thousands of Milky Way stars that have collapsed in the past 14 million years.

title: Panamanian Denies Noriega Talks Have Collapsed
description: A senior Panamanian official denied this afternoon that talks with the United States on the future of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had collapsed, and said the Panamanian Government hoped discussions would begin again when President Reagan returns from the Moscow summit meeting.

title: Killer Admits More Murders
description: Richard Kuklinski, who was convicted in March of murdering two accomplices in a crime ring, pleaded guilty today to two other killings and confessed to a fifth murder. In return for the pleas, prosecutors agreed to drop weapons possession charges against his 46-year-old wife, Barbara, and dismiss unrelated drug and weapons charges against his 19-year-old son, Dwayne.

title: Phone System Feared Vulnerable To Wider Disruptions of Service
description: A switching station fire that melted fiber optic communications lines, damaged computers and interrupted telephone service in the suburbs of Chicago has raised questions about whether the nation's telephone system is becoming more vulnerable to major disruptions.

title: Dow, Up Most of Day, Closes at 1,961, Off 1.16
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.16 points to close at 1,961.37.

title: Olympia & York
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. sait it would increase its stake in four companies, including the Campeau Corporation. The real estate development company also said it would increase its majority stakes in Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., Abitibi-Price Inc. and GW Utilities Ltd.

title: Year-Round Blossoms Possible Even in North
description: AMONG gardeners, part of what John Kenneth Galbraith dubbed, in other matters, the conventional wisdom holds that our pleasures begin in March with the first crocuses and end in October when frost blackens the dahlias.

title: Reviews/Dance; Dancing the Lives of Poets
description: Jerry Pearson's love of classic poetry and fiction was evident in the intelligent program his Pearson Dance Company presented Sunday night as the final attraction in the 3-D series at the Joyce Theater.

title: Cyprus to Buy A Copper Unit
description: The Inspiration Resources Corporation, a leading producer of metals and agricultural products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company subsidiary to the Cyprus Mineral Company, for about $125 million.

title: Discovery Could Speed Diagnoses of Dystrophy
description: A discovery that is expected to improve early diagnosis of forms of muscular dystrophy and prediction of the long-term outcome for children suffering from the wasting disease was reported yesterday.

title: Publicized Tranquilizer Getting Mixed Reviews
description: A drug that appeared to be a major advance over Valium and other tranquilizers when it was approved for use 20 months ago is getting mixed reviews from psychiatrists who have prescribed it.

title: Gardeners All, British Flock To Chelsea
description: From noble Queen to common daisy, the ranking fauna and flora of the kingdom are congregating brightly here this week for the Chelsea Flower Show, a 75-year-old event that has evolved from a diversion for the Edwardian aristocracy to a blockbuster for the modern gardener.

title: Dr. Peale, Nearing 90, Still Thinks Positively
description: A sign outside the town hall proclaims Pawling the ''Pride of the Harlem Valley and Home of Positive Thinking.'' It went up in 1984, soon after the Chamber of Commerce and the Rotary Club gave a testimonial dinner in the Y.M.C.A. lodge for the positive thinker in residence, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.

title: Transtechnology Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $1,010,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Suspect Is Indicted In Killing of Officer
description: A former convict being held in Philadelphia as a suspect in the slaying of a housing police officer in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday for the killing.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THERE are times when a child needs more than parents' love and guidance. When teachers notice that a child is not behaving or learning appropriately or parents see a significant change in their child's behavior, it is time to seek professional help. Where do you turn?

title: A STALEMATE ENDS FOR CONTRA TALKS
description: Contra leaders announced today that they planned to travel to Managua to open a third round of peace talks with the Sandinista Government, ending a stalemate over where the talks would be held.

title: U.S. Abandons Effort to Persuade Noriega to Yield Power in Panama
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had failed in its campaign to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to give up power in Panama, and it said it would not engage in any more talks with him.

title: Boston Blackout Brings Disbelief
description: Strained and stressed by an afternoon of thunderstorms and a steamy, emotional night inside brightly lighted Boston Garden, an ancient transformer malfunctioned Tuesday night, making the rink go black and rendering a Stanley Cup game nonexistent.

title: University Science Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue in the latest quarter is from research fees; there was no revenue from research fees in the year-ago period.

title: Blueprint For Architects
description: ATTITUDES About Architects Department: At the recent convention in New York of the American Institute of Architects, the pollster Louis Harris presented the results of a survey the institute had commissioned on what people think about architects. The survey had two parts: a poll of 1,253 members of the public and a survey of 201 leaders in the building industry, social sciences, education and government.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Summit Previews
description: Eager to know what Alexander M. Haig Jr., a former Secretary of State; Richard M. Perle, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense, or Max Kampelman, the chief American arms negotiator, think about the Moscow summit meeting? There is good news if you live in New York, Buffalo, Miami or one of five other cities.

title: Democratic Candidates Spar Over Budget Issues
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Michael S. Dukakis disagreed on economic priorities in a televised debate here tonight, with Mr. Jackson terming Mr. Dukakis a conservative who declines to describe his priorities in detail.

title: Leiter Had Minor Concerns
description: He stood in front of his locker stall Tuesday night and insisted that the common fears of being a rookie had not begun to weigh heavily on him. No, Al Leiter told the gathered audience, he never believed he might be sent to the minors if he threw poorly again.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY HOLIDAY BACH FESTIVAL

title: Soviet Moves to Curtail Communist Party's Power
description: The Communist Party Central Committee has approved proposals made public today that would curtail the power of the party and limit the term of party and Government officials, in most cases to 10 years.

title: Temco Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Opera; Graun's 'Montezuma'
description: Carl Heinrich Graun was no Mozart and his ''Montezuma'' is certainly no ''Idomeneo,'' but a new production of Graun's opera seria at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. periodically reveals pages of unexpected power. Opening night apparently did not go well, even in the opinion of Gian Carlo Menotti, the festival's founder and artistic director, but the performance I attended on Wednesday evening often leaped to life, thanks to some technically fluent, ardent singing by the mostly young cast.

title: California Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Los Angeles Is Getting Automated Trolley Line
description: A quarter of a century after Los Angeles ripped out its trolley tracks to make way for an ever increasing number of automobiles, officials have decided to build the nation's first automatic, driverless trolley line to try to get people out of their cars.

title: Youth Beats Teacher With Bat
description: A junior high school teacher was beaten unconscious with a baseball bat and seriously injured yesterday when an intruder chased and repeatedly struck him during a softball game in a Bronx schoolyard, the authorities said.

title: NATO to Ask Italy to Provide Base for 72 U.S. Fighter Jets
description: NATO defense ministers voted today to ask Italy to provide a base for 72 United States F-16 fighters to be forced out of Spain.

title: Louis Pomerantz, 68, Art Conservator, Dies
description: Louis Pomerantz, a former conservator at the Art Institute of Chicago, died of cancer on May 19 at his home in Spring Grove, Ill. He was 68 years old.

title: Executive Telecommunicaions reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region; Hudson Valley
description: In addition to the normal parades and speeches on the Memorial Day weekend, the Hudson Valley offers a wide variety of things to do: flea markets, antique shows, art exhibits, boat rides, a candlelight tour and even a demonstration of blacksmithing.

title: House Democrats Map Policy On Defense Against Missiles
description: House Democrats united today behind a policy that condemns the Reagan Administration's drive to deploy weapons in space but endorses continued work on defenses against nuclear missiles ''at a reasonable and stable pace.''

title: House Approves $1.1 Trillion Budget for 1989
description: The House today passed a $1.1 trillion Federal budget for the fiscal year 1989 after negotiators from the House and Senate solved a monthlong dispute over domestic appropriations.

title: Langley Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Barry Harris, Jazz Stalwart, Sings Colleagues' Praises
description: ''New York is supposed to be unique,'' said the pianist and tireless jazz organizer Barry Harris. ''We're going to have 150 people on stage to play and sing Bud Powell's 'Oblivion' and Tadd Dameron's 'Focus.' Where else in the world would that happen?''

title: Selected Outdoor Touring by Foot, Bus and Boat
description: In addition to more than a dozen walking tours led by city-history buffs and nature walks conducted by the Parks Department's Urban Park Rangers, there will be a variety of other outdoor tours this weekend, ranging from a 32-mile marathon walk and a sailboat cruise of the Brooklyn waterfront to a voyage past several Hudson River lighthouses. A selection of walking (and other) tours follows: Friday

title: House Defeats G.O.P. Bid To Amend Law on Contra Aid
description: A surprise attempt by House Republicans to amend a 1983 law banning the use of the C.I.A.'s contingency fund to finance future covert military aid to the Nicaraguans contra rebels failed today.

title: Pubco Corporation, Debtor-in-Possession reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
McCoy Tyner
description: McCoy Tyner, the ground-breaking jazz pianist, is appearing through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10, 11:30, and 1. Admission is $12, minimum is $6.

title: PENTAGON PARING OF 7,300 JOBS SEEN
description: A study ordered by Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci concludes that the Pentagon can eliminate 7,300 jobs from its headquarters around the world.

title: N.C.A.A. Baseball; Clemson Outlasts Fordham in 19 Innings
description: They played 52 innings just to get here. The Fordham Rams had grown accustomed to enduring frazzled emotions in three extra-inning games and two regulation ones on the way to a spot in the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament. But they could not have been prepared for what happened this afternoon.

title: Plant Closing: A Key Cuomo Victory
description: For Governor Cuomo, who had become perhaps the leading public opponent of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the agreement to close the plant is one of the most important victories of his six years in office.

title: Honda Profits Post 63.4% Rise
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its profit rose 63.4 percent in its latest quarter as revenue climbed 3.4 percent.

title: Review/Organ; Lionel Rogg in a Recital
description: Only organists today maintain the once universal tradition that performers ought to compose a bit: just imagine Itzhak Perlman, Kiri Te Kanawa or Murray Perahia coming to Lincoln Center with sonatas or arias of their own facture. But it was no surprise at all Monday evening at the Church of St. John the Evangelist when Lionel Rogg included on the program his own intelligently conceived variations on an old Geneva tune for the 92d Psalm.

title: Economic Scene; A Canadian Case For Optimism
description: IS the international economic system more stable than it looks? Even in the age of Aquarius, are government leaders more rational than they seem? Is there, in short, a case for optimism about our ability to absorb shocks and threats to the system, and, without actually solving any of the major problems we face, at least to survive them?

title: Washington Talk: Interior Department; Would Freedom Help the National Park Service?
description: Their contention is that the National Park Service has been treated like an ideological soccer ball, kicked around by political appointees of both Democratic and Republican administrations in the last 20 years. So, some members of Congress, conservationists and former park officials have begun pressing to turn the service into an independent agency.

title: The Proof in the Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Allocates More Funds To 4 Presidential Candidates
description: The Federal Election Commission has distributed $1.7 million in Federal matching funds to Presidential candidates, bringing to $56.2 million the total the Government has given out in the primary campaign this year.

title: Our Towns; Move the Suburb At Least 3 Feet To the Right
description: Anyone who understands the suburbs knows the whole idea is to get yourself a house on a grassy lot, have the place surveyed, throw up a fence as big as the the zoning board will allow, get a couple of frosties out of the 'fridge and then spend the rest of your life keeping the world's fools on the other side of that monster fence.

title: Title Defense For Brothers
description: Ron and Jerry Springer of the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., who last year shot a tournament-record 16-under par 128, will defend their title today in the 17th annual Wilson Cup at the Scarsdale Golf Club in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Vote on Arms Pact Delayed By Dispute on Interpretation
description: The Senate today settled its last major dispute on the new treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles, only to become embroiled late in the evening in a new political snag.

title: Cardis Submits Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Cardis Corporation, parent of the auto-repair chain Tuneup Masters Inc., has filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: American Standard Files for Offering
description: American Standard Inc., which is 95 percent owned by the ASI Acquisition Company, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for about $1.12 billion of debt securities to be offered through the First Boston Corporation.

title: On Stage
description: Brightman Berlin Bound Sarah Brightman, the co-star of ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' will be leaving the show June 4, the evening before the Tony Award ceremony. A spokesman for the musical said the British actress had a concert commitment with the Berlin Philharmonic orchestra at the end of June. She will be replaced by Patti Cohenour, who has been playing the role of Christine for two performances a week.

title: On Keeping the Statues New York Has and Adding One More
description: To the Editor:

title: Otis Rush
description: Otis Rush, blues singer and guitarist, is appearing at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077) through Sunday. Admission is $12, and sets are at 9:30 and 12.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of myths in people's lives misstated the relationship of three characters in Greek myth. Hippolytus venerated Artemis and scorned Aphrodite.

title: Auctions
description: A Tang Dynasty court lady, a richly glazed pottery study of a serene aristocrat seated on a bamboo stool, may rewrite the $660,000 record at auction for Tang art when it comes up for sale next week at Sotheby's. The gracefully modeled eighth-century tomb figure, owned in recent years by three major collectors of Chinese art, is one of several major Oriental works to be offered at Sotheby's and Christie's next week. The presale exhibitions this weekend were timed by the two houses to coincide with the long-awaited opening tomorrow of the Charlotte C. and John C. Weber Galleries of ancient Chinese art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Books of The Times; A Shaw Still Witty but Full of Repellent Opinions
description: Bernard Shaw Collected Letters 1926-1950 Edited by Dan H. Laurence Illustrated. 946 pages. Viking. $45.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Honoring Black Heroes
description: Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Westchester Republican, is battling the Army and Navy over whether a black soldier who fought in World War I and a black sailor who served in World War II should be awarded the Medal of Honor, to correct a ''historic injustice.''

title: S.E.C. Votes to Seek New Powers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a series of legislative proposals today that would give it the power to regulate stock-index futures and to close the nation's stock and options exchanges in the event of another market crisis.

title: Suchard's Merger Bid Rejected by Rowntree
description: Rowntree P.L.C., the venerable British candy company, today rejected a bid of $:2.31 billion, or about $4.3 billion, by Jacobs Suchard A.G., the Swiss chocolatier ''It is the board's unanimous view that the Suchard offer fails to reflect the true value of Rowntree,'' a Rowntree spokeswoman said.

title: Review/Circus; Where Magic Is Pure and Fantasy Real
description: Everything comes together beautifully in Le Cirque du Soleil, an enchanting circus troupe from Montreal that lives up to its name as a circus of the sun. More than a little poetic sunlight filled the night air Wednesday evening at Battery Park City, where a blue and yellow tent had been pitched just off West Street at Battery Place for the circus's New York debut.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Promotion May Lead To the Top at Honda
description: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company yesterday named Shoichiro Irimajiri as managing director for its worldwide manufacturing operations, effective June 30. Mr. Irimajiri, who since 1984 has been president of Honda's American manufacturing subsidiary in Marysville, Ohio, will be succeeded by Hiroyuki Yoshino.

title: Mesaba Aviation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tests Say Dioxin Level High Among Sprayers in Vietnam
description: Blood tests on 147 Air Force veterans who were assigned to spray defoliants like Agent Orange on Vietnam show ''unusually heavy'' levels of exposure to dioxin, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today.

title: Market Place; Various Factors Helping Paribas
description: A JUMP of 13 percent in five trading days would make any company's shareholders happy. In the case of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, the French financial group, it is making a lot of shareholders happy. Paribas says it has 2.6 million shareholders, making it one of the most widely held corporations in the world.

title: Put a New Swing on teh Wall Street Pendulum; Time for the Investors
description: To the Editor:

title: Field Publications Agrees To Buy Funk & Wagnalls
description: Field Publications, a division of the Field Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire all the stock of the encyclopedia publisher Funk & Wagnalls Inc.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 429 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.79 billion, to $273.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 118 institutional funds dropped $1.89 billion, to $73.52 billion. The assets of the 214 general purpose funds decreased $163.6 million, to $84.07 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds fell $63.9 million, to $115.72 billion.

title: Tribute to Malcolm X
description: In commemoration of Malcolm X's birthdate, which was May 19, 1925, the Ujamaa Black Theater has been performing ''A Tribute To Malcolm X,'' a musical written by Titus Walker. The show, which is at the Lincoln Square Theater, at 250 West 65th Street, is to have its last two performances tonight at 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $15 in advance and $17 at the door. Information: 535-4797.

title: Automatix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Next Problem: No Place to Send Its Tainted Fuel
description: New York State intends to dismantle the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, but Shoreham will probably still stand well into the next century, experts say, because there is no place to dispose of its radioactive fuel rods and reactor parts.

title: Offer Made to Take Redken Private
description: The founder of Redken Laboratories Inc., a maker of skin and hair products, proposed to take the company private for $34 a share, or about $47.6 million for the shares she does not already own. Redken's stock rose $7.25, or 27 percent, to close at $34.25 today in over-the-counter trading. The stock had risen by $2.75 on Wednesday.

title: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon Wins Mug Root Beer
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK has become agency for Pepsi-Cola's Mug Root Beer. It will be the first soft-drink account in the 32-year career of the agency's chairman, George Lois.

title: Review/Recital; Pianist's Debut With Scarlatti And Messiaen
description: The first piano sonata of George Walker, a composer now on the faculty of Rutgers University, is a lively, well-conceived essay in what was, at the time of its composition 35 years ago, something like a mainstream idiom of American composition. It fits comfortably with the music of Copland, Barber and Rorem. An energetic opening movement built on chains of fourths, a set of variations on a Kentucky folksong and a bright allegro con brio finale: all are effective and well made.

title: 3Com Losing Its President
description: The 3Com Corporation, a maker of computer networks based in Santa Clara, Calif., said today that William N. Carrico would resign as president and chief operating officer.

title: Political Memo; Bush Camp Longs for Signs Of More Support by Reagan
description: Ronald Reagan has bequeathed to his Vice President two large gifts for this election year: peace and prosperity. But George Bush's Presidential candidacy is being hurt by smaller, stickier things the Administration is involved in, and some of his supporters are starting to ask how much the White House really cares about electing Mr. Bush in the fall.

title: Sage Drilling Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $317,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $175,000 for the quarter and $511,000 for the 9 months.

title: 40 Die in Sri Lanka Fighting
description: Indian troops backed by helicopter gunships attacked Tamil rebel camps in northern Sri Lanka today in an offensive that an Indian official said has killed 30 rebels and 10 soldiers. The United News of India news agency said 6,000 Indian soldiers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Auto Racing; Another Andretti Revs It Up
description: John Andretti and his cousin Michael used to stand outside the fence at turn one at a dirt-track in rural Pennsylvania to see who could catch the clumps of dirt their fathers churned up behind their racing cars.

title: Gooden Suffers His First Loss
description: Rick Reuschel, with his receding hairline and advancing girth, has the look of a placid monk. And he has the demeanor to match. So when Howard Johnson's sixth-inning home run had cleared the wall in right field and finished rattling around beneath the scoreboard at Shea Stadium last night, Reuschel remained unflappable, his expression almost serene.

title: Review/Art; The Integration of Art And Public Architecture
description: Perhaps it is inevitable, at a moment when diverse and conflicting stylistic strategies compete for attention in both the architectural and artistic communities, that the American Craft Museum's exhibition on architectural art takes so ambiguous a stance toward its subject. The show documents various approaches to the complicated business of integrating sculpture and other forms of art into public spaces. Photographs of the Chrysler Building and Lincoln Center serve as precedents for more recent artist-architect collaborations involving Ed Carpenter, Richard Haas, Stephen Antonakos, Joyce Kozloff and several others.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: The year-ago first quarter net is restated to include a one-time gain of $176,000, or 4 cents a share, to reflect the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: KEY RATES
Advanced Products & Techologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Financier's Absence Deepens $130 Million Mystery
description: A 37-year-old Cuban-born financier known in international social circles for his charm, impeccable taste and willingness to pay almost any amount for great art has become a fugitive in what court papers describe as a $130 million swindle.

title: PAC's Remain a Pox
description: The most pernicious corruption of government today stems not from bribery, graft and sleazy deals that scream from tabloid headlines, but from conduct we as a people have blessed as lawful: the aggressive solicitation of campaign contributions from private interests who are subject to the laws and regulations made by the aggressive solicitors.

title: Crescott Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $638,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Review/Art; Ancient Chinese Arts In New Met Galleries
description: Tomorrow's opening of the Charlotte C. and John C. Weber Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a cause for celebration. Here, finally, is a place to chart the development of Chinese art from its inception to the triumph of Chinese painting. Here, finally, is a place where people can see the Chinese gift for sculpture and consider the mystery of why, at a certain point, it was virtually thrown away, never to be fully exploited again.

title: Dining Out Guide: Connecticut
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Bertrand Excellent (Dec. 6, 1987), 253 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich (203-661-4459) - A Guastavino vaulted ceiling of brick and tile, Roman arches and a sky-lighted atrium are dramatic architectural features of this restaurant in a neo-classical building. The captivating, complex menu is overseen by Christian Bertrand, a former executive chef at Lutece. Good appetizers include puff pastries filled with seafood, leeks and basil, and anise-marinated salmon. The confit of duck with chanterelles is an acclaimed entree. A new spring menu includes red snapper braised in white wine, sauteed chicken breast with spring vegetables in a basil-cream sauce and a new appetizer of timbale of smoked salmon with a julienne of endive and caviar. Most desserts are excellent. Prices at lunch are $4.50 to $11.75 for appetizers, $14.50 to $19.50 for entrees; at dinner, $4.50 to $35 for appetizers, $15.50 to $27.50 for entrees. Lunch hours are noon to 2 P.M. Friday; dinner, 6 to 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. New England Food Co. Excellent (March 20, 1988), 4 Liberty Street, Danbury (203-798-8122) - Sophisticated and moderately priced dishes on a frequently revised menu are presented by a husband-and-wife team. Everything on the small menu is freshly prepared with precision. By day, the restaurant does an active take-out business; at dinner, the focus moves to a gently-lighted, comfortable dining room that seats 20. The June menu will feature starters of minted romaine soup and seafood cakes of shrimp, scallops and scrod. Permanent stars on the entree side are pecan chicken in a sour-cream-mustard sauce and the poached fish of the day. New items include loin of lamb with barley and sauteed vegetables, and quail with peach sauce. Breads are homemade, as are the excellent desserts. Prices during the day are $3 to $4.75; entrees at dinner, $9.95 to $14.95. Dinner hours are 5:30 to 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Robert Henry's Excellent (March 1, 1987), 1032 Chapel Street, New Haven (203-789-1010) - In the former Union League Club in New Haven, Robert Henry's is an elegant high-ceilinged restaurant with marble columns, chinoiserie and comfortable seating. The owner, Jo McKenzie, and her talented chefs offer a small, inventive menu that includes starters of braised artichoke hearts in basil sauce, duck leg confit with apples and mache, and a tartar of tuna and smoked salmon served between layers of small blinis. One of the seasonal entrees is grilled duck breast with wild rice and vegetable confit in ginger sauce. There is an appealing array of desserts; a good choice is homemade ice cream in crisp cookie shells. Prices at lunch are $8.50 to $14; at dinner, $4 to $8.50 for appetizers, $19.50 to $27 for entrees. Lunch hours are noon to 2 P.M. Friday, dinner 6 to 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Three Flags Very good (Nov. 29, 1987), 544 Main Avenue (Route 7), Norwalk (203-846-4248) - This is a formal and elegantly appointed restaurant disguised by its plain exterior on a busy suburban highway. The flags of Italy, France and Greece are depicted on the logo, but the owner describes his carefully chosen menu as European nouvelle rather than Mediterranean. It boasts a baker who prepares all dinner rolls, breads and desserts in house. Starters include foie gras served on vinaigrette-dressed radicchio and greens, scallops and shrimp in champagne sauce and baked in puff pastry, and fresh crab meat ravioli with ginger sauce. Recommended entrees include the seafood combination and red snapper in papaya-butter. Other choices are veal medallions with seasonal vegetables, and capon leg stuffed with duck liver and spinach. Prices at lunch are $7 to $12.50 for entrees; at dinner, $6 to $14 for appetizers, $14.50 to $25 for entrees. Lunch hours are 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Friday, dinner 5:30 to 11 P.M Friday and Saturday, 5 to 9 P.M. Sunday. The ratings: Poor Satisfactory Good Very good Excellent Extraordinary

title: Moscow Says Its Force In War Was 100,300
description: The Soviet Union had 100,300 troops in Afghanistan at the start of its military withdrawal earlier this month, a senior army official announced today.

title: Codenoll Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An Imaginative Effort In Fallon Work for Lee
description: It is an advertising truism that parity products frequently produce very imaginative advertising - since the only product differences are created by the advertising.

title: Noriega Charges U.S. Invented Crisis
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega accused the Reagan Administration today of inventing a crisis for colonial ends and making him a ''humiliating proposal'' he could not accept while maintaining ''the dignity and sovereignty of Panama.''

title: The Talk of Jersey City; Despite New Faces, Old-Style Politics
description: This city is old brownstone and new high-rise, old-line politics and new residents and, always, opinions.

title: Suspect in Death Of Officer Says She Is Scapegoat
description: The woman indicted in the fatal shooting of a police sergeant during a raid on her apartment last month argued yesterday that the police panicked when they burst into her bedroom and were making her a scapegoat to escape responsibility for the officer's death.

title: Oilers Sweep Bruins to Win 4th Stanley Cup
description: The Edmonton Oilers' locker room, for the second season in a row, vibrated with rock music as its inhabitants sprayed champagne in all directions. And like the good teammates they are, the players took turns grasping the Stanley Cup they had so expediently defended.

title: Williamsburg Is Reopened For Cars Only
description: Two lanes of the Williamsburg Bridge were reopened to cars yesterday - in time for the Memorial Day weekend traffic crush - even though only about half of the serious corrosion points found by inspectors have been repaired.

title: Stalin's 12% Rating, and Other Truths
description: As interesting as any finding in the Moscow public opinion poll reported in today's Times is the fact of the poll itself. Think of it: A Soviet institute asks tough political and personal questions on behalf of Western clients and gets some forthright answers, for publication. Quite some evidence of Soviet change.

title: TV Weekend; A Vietnam Veteran's Mission
description: In the inspirational tradition of movies like ''Pride of the Yankees'' and everything Frank Capra ever directed, ''To Heal a Nation'' is being presented this Memorial Day weekend on NBC, Sunday at 9 P.M. This is the story of Jan C. Scruggs, the Vietnam veteran who had a vision of a national memorial that would ''symbolize the experience'' of Americans who fought in the war. He is depicted with mesmerizing intensity by Eric Roberts.

title: Complaint on Wright Is Filed
description: A formal complaint was filed with the House ethics committee today asking for an investigation to determine if the House Speaker, Jim Wright, violated House ethics rules.

title: Restaurants
description: Periyali Think of Greek food, as represented in the archipelago of New York, and the cliches abound: twirling gyros of gray lamb and foil-wrapped pita bread at sidewalk stalls; clattering coffee shops where taciturn waiters wear too-tight red vests and perpetual 5 o'clock shadows; stucco-and-plastic-flowered dining rooms specializing in skewered lamb, moussaka and mountains of iceberg lettuce with feta. Then there is that nonstop bouzouki music.

description: The door for North Korea to enter the Olympics will stay open until the last minute, and an offer to stage some events in the North is still on the table, South Korea's top Olympic official said today.

title: Public Opinion: Moscow vs. U.S.
For Nuclear Industry, Harm Is Already Done
description: The significance to the nuclear industry of Shoreham's cancellation is like having a dying horse break a leg. Nuclear advocates say the abandonment is a waste and an embarrassment, but there is not much damage left to be done to the industry.

title: Quest for a 100-Year-Old Fish
description: TOM EARNHARDT, an avid and accomplished fresh and saltwater fly fisherman, is taking his gear to China in a few days. One of his planned angling adventures is a float trip of nearly 100 miles down a wild stretch of the Zhang River in quest of various little-known trout and a salmonoid called the taimen, which can reach well over 100 pounds and live for more than a century.

title: Nostalgia in the Air as 'Hair' Comes to U.N. to Fight AIDS
description: This week was no time for a world crisis: the General Assembly of the United Nations was fully booked.

description: Several times tonight at the Boston Garden, the message board flashed ''C'mon Celtics,'' as if it were begging for a victory.

title: Lesson in the Difficulty of Forecasting
description: Back in December, the economy seemed to be falling off a cliff. The market crash colored everyone's thinking. Consumers had pulled back. Homes were hard to sell. And recession forecasts were commonplace.

Dance Festival Explores America's African Roots
description: Danceafrica has become a tradition in New York. It is a time, each spring, to bring the entire family to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for rousing dance and music by Afro-American dance companies and for the exotic African bazaar held in the museum parking lot. It has also been a time to explore the African roots of American culture as seen in the performances of innumerable Afro-American dance companies over the festival's 10-year history.

title: Key Senator Says Bork's Defeat Improved Process
description: A key Senate Republican who helped defeat the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court last year said in a commencement speech in New York yesterday that the Bork battle had probably produced permanent and healthy changes in the process of confirming nominees to the Court.

description: The specter of the Shankill Butchers, an infamous sectarian murder gang that ravaged Roman Catholic ghettos a decade ago, is rising again on the pitiless streets of North Belfast, where fear and grief are running heavy from fresh homicide raids.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Gulfstream Awarded 1989 Breeders' Cup
description: Breeders' Cup officials announced yesterday that Gulfstream Park near Miami, not Hialeah, will host the 1989 cup races, yet another blow to Hialeah's stature.

title: Automobile Airbags, at Last
description: Special cheers for the Chrysler Corporation for deciding to equip all its new cars with driver-side airbags by 1990. Chrysler's announcement, a dramatic end to a long struggle, guarantees economies of mass production for the lifesaving devices and eliminates the need for dealers to sell them as options. But the loudest applause should be reserved for promoters of auto safety who for two decades have pressed the case for airbags against the industry's determined opposition.

title: O'Connor Doesn't Want Job
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Vice President, said today that she was not interested. ''I most assuredly am not considering any other position in or out of government and do not expect to do so in the future,'' Justice O'Connor, who is 58 years old, said in a statement released by the Court. Her name has been among those that Republican leaders have listed when discussing a running mate for Vice President Bush.

title: Toyota's U.S. Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Company, the world's third-largest auto maker, opened its first United States assembly plant, with production of a white 1989 Camry sedan. The 3.7-million-square-foot plant, situated on Kentucky farmland about 20 miles north of Lexington, is the fourth United States assembly plant built by a Japanese auto maker. The factory is the largest auto plant in the United States. Toyota and the General Motors Corporation jointly operate a plant at Fremont, Calif., under the name New United Motor Manufacturing Corporation.

title: Syria Reports Iran Accord on Beirut Troops
description: Syria said today that it had reached agreement with Iran on a deployment of Syrian troops Friday in the southern suburbs of Beirut. The move is intended to end three weeks of fierce fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.

title: Hesston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Art; Entropy With Spirit in a Brooklyn Retrospective
description: The retrospective of the American sculptor Gordon Matta-Clark that has just opened at the Brooklyn Museum of Art is a good and good-looking show, one that conveys a strong sense of this artist's unique accomplishment. This is no easy task. Mr. Matta-Clark died young - of cancer at the age of 35 in 1978 - and his major artworks no longer exist.

title: New Calfed Chairman Was No. 2 at Hanover

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region; Connecticut
description: Memorial Day weekend in tradition-loving Connecticut will be anything but traditional this year. The holiday will be marked by a three-day celebration of the trolley in East Haven, a hot-air balloon regatta in Bristol, a frog-jumping contest in Cornwall and sports-car racing in Lime Rock. All this in addition to more conventional events, such as a lobster festival in Mystic and a parade in Fairfield.

description: * Amstar Corp., a producer of sugar, portable electric power tools and electronic and other equipment for military markets, said it had retained Merrill Lynch & Company to advise it on a possible sale of Amstar or one or more of its businesses or on the recapitalization of the company. Amstar is owned by management and affiliates of Merrill Lynch.

title: Review/Theater; Lesson in Self-Delusion By Professor Moliere
description: Arnolphe, the protagonist of ''The School for Wives,'' has a genius for self-deception. He thinks that by grooming his ward, Agnes, to be a simpleton, she will be eternally faithful to him in marriage. As we know, that marriage will never take place. Arnolphe's idea of bliss will backfire as soon as Agnes is confronted with the ardor of a handsome young suitor.

description: The company said the latest year includes charges of $21.5 million from the writedown of assets. The company also said the prior year includes a charge of $978,000 from the disposal of assets.

This is the schedule: Today - Women's pairs and men's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; novice pairs and 99er pairs, 8 P.M. Tomorrow - Novice pairs and 49er pairs, 1 P.M.; flighted Goldman Pairs, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; novice pairs and 49er pairs, 7 P.M. Sunday - Novice pairs and 99er pairs, 1 P.M.; Goldman Pairs final and Swiss teams, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; novice pairs and 99er pairs, 7 P.M. Monday - Flighted Reisinger Knockout Teams (first round) and 49er pairs, 12:30 P.M.; senior pairs, 12:30 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.; 49er Swiss teams. 6.30 P.M.

title: Prices Fall On U.S. Notes And Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell and short-term interest rates moved sharply higher yesterday as market participants reacted negatively to a strong economic report and additional evidence the Federal Reserve Board has again tightened monetary policy.

title: Muscovites, in Poll, Are Split On What Their Future Holds
description: After three years of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's leadership, about half of the Muscovites say they have yet to see tangible benefits from his program of economic change, according to a poll of Moscow residents conducted for The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region; Westchester

A fair and a musical revue, art exhibitions, sheep-shearing demonstrations and a grand parade are among the activities.

title: Moscow Reported to Agree To a Jewish Training Center
description: Soviet leaders have agreed to the creation of the first Jewish religious training institute in the Soviet Union in 50 years, a leading Israeli religious scholar said today.

description: Vice President Bush said today that he would make adoption of ''drug free'' programs a condition for granting Federal contracts in a Bush administration. He said he would ask states to do the same for state contracts.

title: Review/Theater; Judith Ivey in a Pre-Feminist Domestic Drama
description: William Hanley's 1962 play, ''Mrs. Dally Has a Lover,'' is the sort of talky ''kitchen sink'' drama that gives actors a chance to bite down hard on roles that offer rich opportunities for finely detailed characterization. That's probably the main reason why the talented Judith Ivey chose to star in a revival of an earnest period piece that hasn't been seen in New York since it played on Broadway in 1965 with Arlene Francis in the title role.

description: The State of Connecticut yesterday tentatively priced $75 million of special tax-obligation bonds for transportation projects.

title: Company Eases Its Policy on Logging of Redwoods
description: Under pressure from environmentalist groups, the Pacific Lumber Company said today that it would reverse its two-year-old policy of accelerated cutting of trees in virgin redwood forests.

title: Tesoro-Pentane

Under the proposal, Tesoro's common shareholders other than Pentane would exchange their shares, totaling 66.9 percent of Tesoro, for 34.6 percent of the surviving corporation plus $6 a share, Tesoro said. Tesoro said that, according to the Pentane plan, Pentane's current 7 percent stake in Tesoro would increase to at least 51 percent of the surviving corporation.

title: U.S. Seeks to Bar Tuna Merger Deal
description: The Justice Department said that it plans to file suit to block the H. J. Heinz Company's acquisition of Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., a merger that would join two of the nation's three leading brands of tuna. Heinz owns Star-Kist Foods Inc., which markets several brands of canned tuna, including Star-Kist, the nation's largest-selling brand. The department said the merger would eliminate competition, in violation of the Federal antitrust laws, in the $1 billion-a-year canned tuna business.

title: Dr. M. A. Zuckerbraun Wed to Myra K. Miller
description: The marriage of Myra K. Miller, a senior credit analyst at County NatWest Inc. in New York, to Dr. Matthew A. Zuckerbraun, a portfolio manager at Harris, Greenhouse, Kutzel, investment advisers in New York, took place yesterday at the Faculty House at Columbia University. Rabbi Alan Miller, assisted by Cantor Morris Schorr, performed the ceremony.

title: Two Booms in China Are One to Many
description: LEAD: Although China's economic resurgence has rightfully received much fanfare, little attention has been given to a raging population boom that could jeopardize further growth. Ironically, the population problem is made worse by the very prosperity that has helped China rebound from the backwardness of the Cultural

title: Judge Has Doubt About Charge in Iran-Contra Trial
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case today questioned whether Congressional immunity given Oliver L. North and two of his three co-defendants would make it a ''practical impossibility'' to try them on conspiracy charges.

title: Review/Film; Crucifixion And Gore In 'Penitent'
description: ''The Penitent'' is melodramatic enough to culminate in a crucifixion and ludicrous enough so the victim's greatest ordeal on the cross seems to be a runny nose. At best, this garbled film is a study in unmotivated behavior.

title: With Afghanistan Guerrillas: Rocket Raid in Heady Times
description: ''Long live Islam!'' Commander Lalmohammed bellowed into his walkie-talkie as the rockets, having finally found the range, crashed directly on the Afghan Army garrison at Dakka. ''Long live the mujahedeen!''

title: Reviews/Art; Antonio Segui's Mischievous Look at an Antihero
description: This is the season for a light-footed art. An art of that kind has long been practiced by the Argentine painter Antonio Segui. Born in Cordoba, Argentina, in 1934, Mr. Segui moved to France in 1963 and has lived for the last 35 years in the Parisian suburb of Arcueil, formerly the home of the composer Erik Satie.

title: Visas Extended to Help Keep Foreign Nurses
description: Bowing to appeals for help amid a critical nationwide nursing shortage, the Federal immigration agency yesterday granted a one-year extension to foreign nurses facing deportation at the end of their temporary work visas.

title: The Law; Terrorist or Insurgent? Diplomacy and the Law
description: It has been said that the world abounds with laws and teems with crimes. Now two convicted murderers argue that international laws justify whatever crimes they may have committed.
