Holiday Events Throughout the Region;
Long Island
description: LEAD: Celebrations of Memorial Day on Long Island will start tonight at 9 with fireworks by the Gruccis to honor veterans of the Town of North Hempstead at Bar Beach Town Park in Port Washington. Parking and admission are free. Fireworks will explode to patriotic music. The Capris, a pop music group of the 1950's, will also perform.

title: Perils of Polling In Soviet Union
description: The Institute for Sociological Research, a branch of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, has been conducting polls since 1969. But it is unaccustomed to asking sensitive questions.

title: Clark's Search for Hits Never Ends
description: The ball glanced sharply off the glove of the third baseman, then shot high before it dropped softly near the foul line in shallow left field. Jack Clark, his night at bat reduced to a couple of harmless grounders and a line-drive out to second, seemed satisfied that it was a hit.

title: Book Notes
description: Planning Readers' Year

title: Baseball; Evans Has a Blast on His 41st Birthday
description: Darrell Evans celebrated his 41st birthday with a home run tonight and Frank Tanana won his eighth game as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-3.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The nation's economy grew far more rapidly in the first three months of the year than had been calculated a month ago, the Government said. The report that the G.N.P. had increased 3.9 percent reinforced some economists' fears that inflation was picking up momentum. They predicted that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to increase interest rates, which the Republicans hope to avoid in an election year. But Government economists said they were not so concerned about the likelihood of inflation. [ Page A1. ] The revised G.N.P. figures are far beyond what any forecaster foresaw - and provide a reminder of the uneven art of prediction. [ D5. ] COMPANIES New York State and Lilco agreed to close the Shoreham nuclear plant, ending more than two decades of controversy. Lilco will take a $2.5 billion loss on Shoreham that will effectively relieve it from Federal income taxes for the next decade, an aspect of the plan that was assailed by some Federal lawmakers. [ A1. ] Investors reacted with skepticism to the Texaco takeover bid of Carl C. Icahn. While Texaco's largest shareholder said he would pay $60 a share, Texaco's stock rose only $3.125, to $50. That skepticism was reinforced by a report by an Icahn associate that banks would finance the takeover only if it was acceptable to Texaco's board. [ D1. ] United Airlines ordered 30 Boeing 757 jetliners and took options for 30 more, giving Boeing its third billion-dollar-plus order in two weeks. United chose engines made by Pratt & Whitney for the aircraft. [ D1. ] The name of United Airlines' owner was changed back to UAL as stockholders voted to abandon Allegis. [ D4. ] Rowntree rejected a bid of $4.3 billion by Jacobs Suchard, the Swiss chocolatier, calling it inadequate. [ D4. ] Roche, the maker of the anti-acne drug Accutane, was ordered by the F.D.A. to take strong measures to prevent its use by pregnant women. Accutane has been linked to birth defects. [ A1. ] Field Publications will buy Funk & Wagnalls, the nation's second-largest general reference encyclopedia. One industry expert estimated the price at $70 million to $100 million. [ D15. ] A Federal appeals court agreed to prevent Advil from comparing itself to Tylenol, upholding a lower court ruling. [ D15. ] A court ruling cleared the way for Allegheny International to hold its annual meeting, but a date has not been set. [ D4. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. approved proposals to give it power to regulate stock-index futures and to close down the nation's stock and options exchanges in the event of another market crisis. The proposals, approved by a 3-to-2 vote, will be sent to Congress. [ D1. ] Stock prices moved moderately higher as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.38 points, to close at 1,966.75. Broader market gauges were also higher. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasuries fell and short-term interest rates rose as market participants reacted negatively to the Government's report that the G.N.P. grew 3.9 percent in the first quarter. [ D1. ] The dollar drifted aimlessly and finished the day marginally higher against several major currencies. Gold was down 30 cents an ounce on the Comex, to $454.10 an ounce. [ D14. ] Oil futures prices advanced as technical factors spurred a late flurry of heavy buying. Meanwhile, cocoa futures plunged. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Canadians are optimistic about the international economy as they prepare to play host to next month's meeting of the Group of Seven. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]

Sounds Around Town
description: Conqueror of 42d Street Kaye Ballard: ''Working 42d Street at Last,'' the Kaufman Theater, 534 West 42d Street (563-1684 or 564-8038). The singer, actress, comedian and impressionist is still one of the most exuberant descendants of a post-vaudeville tradition in which a single entertainer does it all. In Miss Ballard's new show - her most consistent act in years - she banters with Arthur Siegel, her affable accompanist and longtime sidekick, and does sharply funny impressions assorted show business legends. She also sings little-known gems by Cole Porter (the comic ''Tale of the Oyster') and Yip Harburg (''Time, You Old Gypsy Man''), and clever new songs by Barry Kleinbort, who helped stage the evening. Shows are Friday at 8 P.M., Saturday at 5 and 8 P.M., and Sunday and Monday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $22.50. The Hi-De-Ho Man

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ray Anderson Ray Anderson, Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South, near 11th Street (255-4037). Brash, young and ready to tear the club apart, Mr. Anderson, a trombonist, is all set to have fun. Besides being a virtuoso, he's a bit of an entertainer, roaming the stage, pointing his trombone all over the place, and talking to the audience. His solos are an amalgam of mainstream jazz, avant-garde techniques and the weighty trombone tradition - including the use of the plunger, a nearly lost art. He's a brilliant ballad player, a fact often overlooked in favor of his wild style. Sets tonight and tomorrow at 9:30, 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Admission is $12, and the minimum is $6. NRBQ at 20

For a program of new and old dance by Miss Dudley, which opened on Wednesday and runs only through tonight at Marymount Manhattan Theater (221 East 71st Street), reveals that she is a first-rate choreographer of stirring humanity, humor and sensitivity.

The soloist in the Chopin will be Karen Beluso, the winner of the New York Youth Symphony Concerto Competition; and the concert is to be conducted by David Alan Miller. Mr. Miller, director of the orchestra for the last six years, is leaving his post at the end of this season to resume his activities as an assistant conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Admission is free. Information: 581-5933.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Art Rooney Sr., the 87-year-old chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers, the National Football League team he founded in 1933, underwent emergency surgery yesterday to remove a blood clot from his left arm. . . . Byron Nelson, the Hall of Fame golfer, was in good condition yesterday in a hospital in Columbus, Ohio, where he had been admitted for a disturbance of his heart rhythm. Officials at Ohio State University Hospitals said Nelson, 76 years old, would probably stay until today for observation in the coronary care unit. . . . Garry St. Jean, who worked under Don Nelson for six years at Milwaukee, is rejoining him as an assistant coach with the Golden State Warriors. Nelson, former head coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, joined the Warriors as an executive last year and is now head coach. St. Jean, now an assistant coach for the Nets, will join the Warriors Wednesday.(AP)

description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, yesterday called for a national consensus opposing ''euthanasia or assisted suicide'' for individuals who are sick, infirm, comatose or in pain.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Genuine Bistro Fare Some of the most authentic French bistro food in New York is turning up in a most unbistrolike setting. Bistro d'Adrienne is the homespun, inexpensive counterpart to the luxurious restaurant called Adrienne, both in the new Hotel Maxim's de Paris.

title: Review/Film; Pakistanis' New Lives In a Threatening Land
description: At the beginning of ''Dragon Chow,'' the camera finds Shezad (Bhasker) on a dark street in Hamburg, West Germany, and follows him home. It's a great credit to the direction by Jan Schutte, whose first feature this sad, graceful and eloquent film is, that ''Dragon Chow'' generates immediate interest in this gentle soul and the question of where he may be going.

title: Bio-Vascular Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ECONOMIC GROWTH IN FIRST QUARTER MOVED UP TO 3.9%
description: The nation's economy grew far more rapidly in the first three months of the year than had been calculated a month ago, the Government said today.

title: Bids Up for Oil Leases
description: The Interior Department said today that sales of oil leases in the Chukchi Sea off northwestern Alaska drew a record number of bids. The deparment said that 653 bids, totaling $478.2 million, were submitted on Monday and Tuesday. The Interior Secretary, Donald P. Hodel, said the bids reflected confidence that oil would be found, despite no previous leasing in the area and high exploration and development costs.

title: Sports People; Rangers Drop Kemp
description: After Steve Kemp refused an assignment to their Oklahoma City triple-A team yesterday, the Texas Rangers placed the 11-year veteran on irrevocable waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: Bank of Montreal (California) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months includes $262,900,000 and $309,150,000, respectively, pre-tax provisions for loan losses, compared with $18,717,000 for the year-ago quarter and $37,433,000 for the year-ago 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Quadrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sai Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
22 YEARS TOWARD SHOREHAM
description: The Long Island Lighting Company's efforts to build a nuclear-power plant at Shoreham have covered more than 20 years and cost more than $5 billion. April 1966: Lilco announces plans to build a 500-megawatt nuclear power plant in Shoreham on the North Shore, 55 miles east of Manhattan. May 1968: Lilco applies to the Federal Atomic Energy Commission for a construction permit. The utility predicts Shoreham will cost $70 million and be in operation by 1973. March 1969: Lilco directors approve a plan to upgrade the plant to 820 megawatts. Design problems delay the start of hearings. Shoreham is predicted to cost $261 million and be completed by 1975. Fall 1970: Hearings begin. They will include 70 sessions over nearly three years. July 1971: A Federal Appeals Court rules that the A.E.C. is not complying with environmental laws and requires that utilities file more detailed impact statements for nuclear plants. April 1973: Lilco begins construction. Lilco and Suffolk County officials start drafting emergency plans. Lilco estimates Shoreham will cost $506 million and be completed in 1977. September 1977: Lilco directors decide to supervise the project and dismiss Stone & Webster as construction manager. Lilco says Shoreham will cost $1.2 billion and open in 1980. March 28, 1979: The reactor core of Three Mile Island 2 in Middletown, Pa., overheats. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission orders expanded emergency plans. February 1983: Suffolk withdraws its emergency plans, saying a safe evacuation of Long Island is not possible. Governor Cuomo orders the state not to approve an emergency evacuation plan prepared by Lilco. November 1983: Major construction ends; Lilco says Shoreham has cost $4 billion. A panel appointed by Mr. Cuomo says Shoreham's location makes emergency planning impossible. January 1984: Dr. William J. Catacosinos, a member of the Lilco board, becomes chairman and chief executive. He says building Shoreham was a mistake and suggests it may never open. August 1985: The reactor starts up with low-power testing. December 1985: The Public Service Commission votes to disallow $1.4 billion of the Shoreham cost from its base for computing rates, saying the money was spent as a result of management mistakes. July 1986: Mr. Cuomo signs legislation establishing the Long Island Power Authority. Its charge is to consider taking over Lilco. August 1987: A Federal judge rebuffs a Lilco challenge to the power authority and declares the agency constitutional. November 1987: The P.S.C. denies a rate increase and orders Lilco to present ''reasonable plans to provide reliable electric service'' without Shoreham. December 1987: Officials from the state, Lilco and the power authority meet as a group for the first time. March 29, 1988: The power authority makes a $7.45 billion offer to buy Lilco. The offer is rejected. May 26, 1988: The State and Lilco announce an agreement in principle to close Shoreham and help Lilco regain financial health.

title: Walker Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shaer Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Belushi Story Three years and eight months after he first committed himself to the project, the producer Edward S. Feldman has seen the cameras begin rolling on ''Wired,'' based on Bob Woodward's best-selling account of the life and drug-induced death of John Belushi.

title: Nutmeg Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the sentencing of two officers of a Princeton University eating club for serving liquor to minors gave an incomplete account of the Feb. 6 incident in which 45 students suffered alcohol-induced medical problems. The 45 had been drinking at parties sponsored by several different eating clubs.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Two Share L.P.G.A. Lead: Patty Sheehan and Sherri Steinhauer each shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $325,000 L.P.G.A. Corning Classic. Sheehan, who won the tournament in 1983, hit a 20-foot eagle putt on her second hole and picked up three birdies on the back nine at the 6,062-yard Corning (N.Y.) Country Club course. Steinhauer knocked in a 40-to-50-footer on the par-5 fifth hole and added four birdies on her front nine. Cathy Morse, a native of nearby Rochester, and Lauri Peterson finished at 68. A group of six golfers were another stroke back.(AP) Glenz Recovers to Win Dodge: David Glenz, after suffering a four-stroke penalty that cost him his lead in the third round in the morning, recovered to shoot a three-under-par 69 in the final round in the afternoon yesterday to win the 25th Dodge Open by five shots at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J. He finished with a four-round total of seven-under 281. For Glenz, the head pro at the Morris County Golf Club, it was his first victory at the Dodge, which had been the only major tournament in the metropolitan area he had not won. Glenz took home an $18,000 Dodge automobile, the top prize in the $85,000 event.

title: Genex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results are restated. The company said the latest quarter includes results for Xydex Corp. from its acquisition in mid-January.

title: Texaco Up Only to $50 Despite Bid
description: Although Carl C. Icahn said on Wednesday that he was willing to pay $60 a share for all the Texaco stock he does not own, Texaco rose only $3.125 yesterday, to $50 a share. The relatively mild reaction reflected skepticism either that Texaco's board would respond favorably to Mr. Icahn's offer or that Mr. Icahn would then go forward on an unfriendly basis.

title: Sales by Kaneb
description: The Kaneb Energy Company said it would sell the oil and gas holdings of Kaneb Energy Partners, in which it is the largest investor, to Amax Oil and Gas Inc., of Houston, for $68.5 million. Kaneb also said it would sell the partnership's 50 percent interest in a coal degasification project to Sonat Inc., of Birmingham, Ala., for $68.2 million. Those two sales would liquidate the two-year-old partnership, which was founded just months before the collapse of oil prices in 1986. Amax will obtain 89.9 billion cubic feet of natural gas and 3.3 million barrels of oil and condensate, while Sonat will purchase Kaneb's interest in the Brookwood coal project in Alabama.

title: Hadco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Study Says U.S. Doesn't Need Wide On-Site Blast Monitoring
description: The Reagan Administration's position on nuclear testing verification was challenged today by a report issued by the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional agency.

title: Rostenkowski to Oppose Measure Providing Health Care at Home
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has decided to formally oppose legislation that would provide long-term health care for ill people confined to their homes. His decision gravely threatens the bill's prospects.

title: Portage Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Falconbridge Ltd. Ends Tax Dispute
description: Falconbridge Ltd. said it had ended a tax dispute with the Dominican Republic that halted shipments of nickel from that country and helped increase the metal's price to record levels. The Toronto-based company's unit there, Falconbridge Dominicana, C. por A., which produces 5 percent of the West's output, will resume production within a week after the pact with the Dominican Republic Government.

title: Yes, Kids Can Stand and Deliver
description: LEAD: Something is happening in ''Stand and Deliver,'' a film being shown in movie theaters around the country, that is not to be missed. No violence. No sex. Nobody benefits from someone else's misfortune. The movie is about education, and it is inspirational.

title: Officer Charged With Possession Of Illegal Drug
description: An undercover detective who investigated corruption in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn in 1986 was arrested Thursday night and charged with possessing and intending to sell drugs, the police said yesterday.

title: Franklin Kauffmann, A Novelist, Dies at 66
description: Franklin Lane Kauffmann, a novelist whose works include the 1964 best seller ''An Honorable Estate,'' died of emphysema in Glen Arm, Md. He was 66 years old.

title: IN TIME FOR SUMMIT MEETING
description: After four months of political infighting and debate, the Senate today gave President Reagan a victory he had been waiting for: an overwhelming vote of approval for the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 The Senate approved the arms treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land, 93 to 5. It was the first major American-Soviet arms control pact the Senate has approved since 1972. Page 1 President Reagan stressed rights in a speech calling on Mikhail Gorbachev to improve the Soviet human rights record. Mr. Reagan's speech was intended to set a tone for the summit meeting, his aides said. 1 Progress in solving regional disputes at the Moscow meeting is hoped for by American officials, who said Vietnam's pledge to withdraw 50,000 troops from Cambodia was an encouraging sign. 1 The press encamps in Moscow 5 South Korean dry-cleaning machines are competing successfully on the American market. West German and Italian manufacturers, who had pushed aside American companies, now find Korean prices much lower than theirs. 1 Syrian troops entered Beirut to enforce a cease-fire agreement. About 800 Syrian soldiers marched into the city's southern suburbs, where rival Shiite Moslem militias have fought for 22 days. 1 Labor Party elections in Israel of candidates for Parliament showed the party was moving to the left. The results of the party's first open elec tion come as polls suggest Israeli public opinion is moving to the right. 3 Prospects for the National Front in elections for France's National Assembly are not good in Marseille, according to polls. A loss would be a blow to the leader of the extreme right party, Jean-Marie Le Pen. 3 Progress in Nicaraguan peace talks was reported by Sandinista and contra leaders. Government negotiators rejected a plan proposed by the contras, but were said to be more agreeable to the proposal in private. 3 The deposed President of Panama said the United States should allow Latin American democracies to take the lead in any new talks over the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. 2 Argentines are eating less beef and smoking less. But beef consumption is still greater than anywhere else in the world. The drop in cigarette sales is attributed to a decline in real wages. 4 NATIONAL 6-10, 28 Care at nursing homes is suffering because of rising costs, shortages of nurses and government limits on spending. Homes that depend on Medicaid payments for lower-income people are in the worst shape. 1 The role of parochial schools in religious education is being questioned by a growing number of Roman Catholic educators, who argue that the church should spend more money on other programs. 1 A $299.5 billion military bill won Senate approval after Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato dropped his insistence that it include an amendment allowing the death penalty for murders by narcotics traffickers. 6 Emotional trauma in Winnetka, Ill., where a woman opened fire in an elementary school classroom, has prompted the community to provide psychological counseling and security at the school. 6 Improper prescribing of Accutane or misuse of the anti-acne drug is being investigated by the Food and Drug Administration in cases where the drug led to severely deformed babies, the agency's Commissioner said. 6 Philadelphia's Police Commissioner, Kevin M. Tucker, is resigning. Mayor W. Wilson Goode said he would select a replacement for Mr. Tucker, who is credited with restoring respect in the department, before June 10. 6 Another Justice official will leave the department. Charles J. Cooper, who heads the Office of Legal Counsel, said he was leaving for personal reasons and praised Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. 10 F.A.A. proposes more Boeing 737 inspections 8 New inmates to be tested for AIDS virus 8 Moderate exercise in pregnancy found unharmful to fetus 8 Politics 7 George Bush said he is not troubled by people pointing out that he is behind in the polls. The Vice President, who began a week of meetings in Maine, said the air made him feel combative. 7 A black advertising executive, Frank L. Mingo Jr., is working for Michael Dukakis's Presidential campaign. But he has contributed to the campaign of Jesse Jackson, whom he served as an adviser in 1984. 7 REGIONAL 29-31 Alternative sources of electricity on Long Island are being considered by Lilco after the decision to shut the Shoreham nuclear plant. Lilco said it could meet only 95 percent of the expected demand this summer. 1 The decision to close Shoreham and keep Lilco an investor-owned utility ends uncertainty about electricity supplies and costs that business leaders say has stalled economic growth on Long Island. 30 Wedtech paid Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President. A former law partner of Mario Biaggi also paid Mr. Simon, a witness testified at the Federal racketeering trial of Mr. Simon and Mr. Biaggi. 29 Four bridge workers were injured when a wooden platform they were standing on to repair beams under the Williamsburg Bridge collapsed. The four were treated at Bellevue Hospital Center and released, the police said. 29 A South Bronx clinic owes $4 million and is in danger of closing. The Martin Luther King Jr. Health Center was once among the nation's largest community health centers. 29 Bess Myerson was arrested in South Williamsport, Pa., and charged with shoplifting. The former Miss America and New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner faces trial next fall on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges. 29 A teacher beaten with a baseball bat was in critical condition as doctors tried to save one of his eyes. The attack, the fourth on a teacher in a week, prompted calls for action from their union and from Mayor Koch. 31

title: Grand Prix Track Opens
description: The two American women with the best chance of winning Olympic gold medals in track and field in Seoul, South Korea, will head the field Saturday in the Bud Light Bruce Jenner Classic, the first of 17 events on the Mobil Grand Prix circuit.

title: Damage Waivers May Go the Way of the Edsel
description: In a growing movement, at least 15 states are considering or have enacted legislation to regulate or ban collision-damage waivers for rental cars. The waivers, which release customers from most liability if the car is damaged, are an extra-cost option on all rental agreements, but they have been widely criticized as overpriced and unfair.

title: TALKING BALLET AT DACHA ON HUDSON
description: ''They are wonderful dancers,'' Mikhail Baryshnikov says, looking at Altynai Assylmuratova and Faruk Ruzimatov while three dogs cavort on the grass nearby, a fluffy cat basks in a wicker chair and the season's first mosquitoes buzz around. Despite the Hudson River landscape, it is a very Russian afternoon.

title:
Patents;
Stars Used For Satellite Navigation
description: LEAD: A method to allow satellites to navigate by taking pictures of their surroundings has been devised for the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company. One or more instruments aboard a satellite record what stars are visible and compare what is found with star positions catalogued in a computer on the ground.

title: N.C.A.A. Baseball; Stanford Rallies To Defeat Fordham
description: Facing a sudden and shocking elimination at the hands of two New York teams, the defending champion Stanford Cardinal came from behind tonight to defeat Fordham, 7-5, and stay alive in the Northeast region of the national collegiate tournament.

title: Official Who Restored Respect to Philadelphia Police Resigns
description: Police Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker, who is credited with restoring respect and confidence in a Police Department that had been riddled with corruption and inefficiency, is resigning to take a banking position.

title: New Ford Export
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would export the first shipment of Ford Probe sports cars to Japan on Tuesday. The auto is built for Ford by its Japanese partner, the Mazda Motor Company, at Mazda's plant in Flat Rock, Mich. The auto, which was introduced in the United States May 12, is sold out through October. Ford has received 80,000 advance orders for the aerodynamic small car. Ford said the first shipment of 84 autos will leave Port Hueneme, Calif., on Tuesday. The auto maker said it plans to sell 6,000 Probes a year in Japan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Securities and Exchange Commission's vote to seek wider powers incorrectly described its position on a legislative proposal involving margin levels on stock-index futures. The agency unanimously voted to consider at a later date a revised proposal that would give the Federal Reserve Board the right to review margin levels on stock-index futures.

title: McGraw-Hill to Sell Stake in Japan Venture
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in Nikkei/McGraw-Hill Inc., a joint-venture publishing company in Japan, for $283 million.

title: Future Cuisine, en Route
description: It is the year 2000, you missed breakfast and now you're stuck in traffic.

title: Lacrosse; Orangemen Are Aware The Title Isn't Won Yet
description: Roy Simmons Jr., the lacrosse coach at Syracuse, has seen enough David and Goliath stories to feel a little nervous these days.

title: Let's Add to the Rank and File of Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Dry Cleaning: A Foreign Trade Target
description: From the customer's side of the counter, the neighborhood dry cleaner is a prosaic affair, where lost tickets and missing buttons seem far removed from international trade and finance.

title: Brierley Continues Bid for Calmat
description: Brierley Investments Ltd., New Zealand's biggest company, is continuing its campaign to persuade the Los Angeles-based cement maker Calmat Company to accept a $90 million bid. Brierley's deputy chairman, Bruce Hancox, said that there had been considerable negotiations between the two groups.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Europe After the Missile Pact
description: The Euromissile treaty that President Reagan hopes to flourish in Moscow next week is a triumph of American diplomacy. But almost all changes, even those for the better, cause heartburn in the ever-fretful military alliance between the United States and Europe. As was evident last week at a meeting of defense officials at the Wiston House conference center in England, the new pact will leave European governments with some wrenching problems.

title: Doing Less, Claiming More on Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Sidelined, but Yanks Roll On
description: Don Mattingly is out for at least a week, perhaps longer, but tonight the Yankees survived nicely without him. While the Yankee first baseman suffered a strained muscle in his right rib cage that may send him to the disabled list, the team kept its momentum alive with a 5-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

title: Bess Myerson Is Accused Of Shoplifting
description: Bess Myerson, the former Miss America and New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner who faces trial on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges next fall, was arrested in a small Pennsylvania town yesterday on a charge of shoplifting $44.07 in merchandise.

title: THE TREATY PROVISIONS
description: MISSILES ELIMINATED * Land-based medium-range missiles (range: 621 to 3,418 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated over three years. * Land-based shorter-range missiles (range: 311 to 621 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated within 18 months. * Under the treaty, the Soviet Union will destroy 1,752 medium- and shorter-range missiles based in its territory and Eastern Europe. The United States will be required to destroy 867 medium- and shorter-range missiles in Western Europe. * Flight tests of the missiles to be eliminated are banned. Neither side may produce any stages or launchers for those missiles. Nuclear material from warheads and guidance systems may be retained when the missiles are scrapped. * Each party is to notify the other of the number, type and location of systems to be eliminated, as well as dates. METHODS OF DESTRUCTION * Missiles are to be destroyed by such means as crushing and burning. In the first six months, each side may also eliminate 100 medium-range missiles by launching them, unarmed, to be destroyed on impact. ON-SITE INSPECTIONS * Thirty days after the treaty goes into force, each side may conduct inspections at missile bases and support installations to verify data provided by the other side. Inspections may also be conducted after bases or support installations are eliminated, and as missiles and launchers are destroyed. For 13 years, each side may conduct ''short notice'' inspections at agreed locations: 20 a year for the first 3 years, 15 a year for the next 5 years and 10 a year for the last 5 years. SPY SATELLITES * Neither side may interfere with the other's ability to monitor compliance by satellite. SENATE CONDITION * The Senate specified that its approval of the agreement was based on the current understanding between the Administration and the Senate on interpretation of the treaty's terms and that the accord could not be reinterpreted later.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kurt Sohn, a free agent who has spent seven seasons as a receiver and punt returner for the Jets, signed a one-year contract with the club yesterday. The terms of the agreement were not announced. Last season, Sohn, the Jets' player representative, caught 23 passes for two touchdowns. . . . David Archer, the starting quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons two years ago, has signed with the Miami Dolphins. . . . The Cincinnati Reds have placed Leon Durham and Tracy Jones on the 15-day disabled list. Durham, a first baseman, was acquired from the Chicago Cubs May 18. He has a pulled muscle in his back. Jones reinjured a knee Wednesday in St. Louis. . . . Lafayette (Fat) Lever, who averaged 18.9 points and 8.1 rebounds for the Nuggets last season, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee in Denver Thursday. (AP)

title: Military Bill Voted as D'Amato Relents
description: The Senate today approved a $299.5 billion military budget measure for next year after Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato dropped his insistence that it include an amendment allowing the death penalty for murders by drug dealers.

title: Baseball; BLUE JAYS WIN WITH 2 IN NINTH
description: Juan Beniquez and Nelson Liriano hit run-scoring singles in the ninth inning tonight to rally the Toronto Blue Jays over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Film; Speaking Up For Rights Of Vampires
description: There could be advantages to having a best friend who's a vampire -all-night parties, great black clothes, contact with the afterlife. There's somthing to be said for the trendy night scene. Unfortunately, when a beautiful vampire seduces some young blood in ''My Best Friend Is a Vampire,'' he's a wholesome All-American high-school boy. They do not make fun-loving blood-suckers.

title: NATO Will Bear Cost Of Shifting U.S. F-16's
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations have agreed to share almost all of the $500 million cost of transferring 72 American F-16 fighters from Spain.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Marcos Leaves Hospital
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former Philippine President, was released from a hospital Thursday night, two days after being admitted for chest pains. Mr. Marcos was placed in an intensive care unit when he entered the hospital Tuesday night. His personal physician, Dr. Azucena Ignacio, said the chest pains were caused by arthritis or a rib inflammation. His condition improved through rest and the use of medication to reduce pain, she said.

title: Shultz Makes a Pledge To Support Soviet Jews
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz paid an emotional visit to the Jewish Community Center here tonight and pledged that the United States would never abandon the cause of Soviet Jews.

title: GUIDEPOST: Short-Term Rates
description: Since interest rates have started to rise again, many people have begun purchasing certificates of deposit with shorter maturities. This strategy assumes that rates will rise still higher in the coming months. With C.D.'s, customers have a choice of maturities, usually three months, six months or a year. The shorter the term, the lower the interest rate, but the greater the flexibility. Other savers are depositing funds in money-market accounts, so that they can benefit from rising rates with no loss of liquidity. The percentages below are national averages. JAN. 6 MARCH 16 MAY 25 TYPE OF INVESTMENT YIELD YIELD YIELD Three-month C.D. (estimate) 6.23% 5.73% 6.08% Six-month C.D. 7.08 6.66 6.81 Bank money-market account 5.82 5.72 5.70 Money-market mutual fund 7.03 6.24 6.48 (Seven-day taxable yield) (Sources: The Bank Rate Monitor and Donoghue's Money Fund Report)

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Rare Restraint in the Land of Steak
description: In a world increasingly accustomed to dire warnings about what not to eat and smoke, Argentina gives the appearance of being one of the last outposts of unfettered indulgence in beef and tobacco.

title: SYRIANS FAN OUT IN BEIRUT SUBURBS TO ENFORCE TRUCE
description: To the cheers of residents, several hundred Syrian troops moved into the southern suburbs of Beirut today to enforce an agreement to end 22 days of fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.

title: PREGNANT AND EXERCISING? KEEP IT UP, REPORT SAYS
description: An advanced new study of vigorous exercise in pregnancy indicates that moderate physical activity does not endanger the fetuses of healthy women who have a normal pregnancy.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Juan Orol, Film Director, 90
description: Juan Orol, a leading director during the golden age of Mexican cinema, died Thursday of complications from diabetes. He was 90 years old.

title: Excerpts From Speech: 'Contradictions' in East
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by President Reagan at Finlandia Hall, where the Final Act of the Helsinki accords on human rights was signed in 1975:

title: Centel Acquiring Cellular Phone Unit
description: The Centel Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy United Telespectrum Inc., the cellular telephone and paging division of United Telecommunications Inc., for $763 million.

title: Once Again, New York Fails the Handicapped
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
2 Officials Named
description: LEAD: As a result of the report by an independent commission on the progress of the automated patent system, two new posts are to be filled by the Patent and Trademark Office on June 13. Boyd Alexander of the Patent Office staff will be made project manager of the automated patent system. Thomas Giammo of the General Accounting Office will be made assistant commissioner for information systems.

title: After-Tax Income Shows Steepest Drop in 12 Months
description: Americans' disposable personal incomes edged up a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in April after a large 1.1 percent rise in March. But on an after-tax basis personal income fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, the steepest drop in a year, as tax payments took a big bite out of paychecks.

title:
Patents;
Substance Helps Make Diagnostic Heart Image
description: LEAD: A chemical substance that can help obtain a clearer image of the heart for diagnostic purposes is the subject of patent 4,746,505, granted this week. The assignees are Harvard College, the Children's Medical Center in Boston and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Books of The Times; General Lee's Horse Discusses the Civil War
description: Traveller By Richard Adams 270 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title:
Patents;
Method to Find Target Is Developed at Boeing
description: LEAD: A method of locating a target by electrical signals emitted from a non-cooperative source was patented this week for the Boeing Company. Patent 4,746,924, granted Fred M. Lightfoot, a staff engineer, describes a search from an aircraft.

title: Ad Executive Advises Dukakis on Black Issues
description: Frank L. Mingo Jr. is accustomed to charting his own path in a fast-rising advertising career. He is charting his own path in politics, too, by becoming a rare black professional who is doing volunteer work for Michael S. Dukakis rather than for the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: KEY RATES
Heinz-Bumble Bee Merger Delayed
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed with Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. to extend their merger agreement until next Friday while they consider the Justice Department's opposition to the deal. The Government on Thursday announced plans to try to block the proposed merger of two of the nation's top three canned tuna brands.

title: Ptolemaic Art
description: A major exhibition of the Ptolemaic period of Egyptian art, from 305 B.C. to 30 B.C., will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum this fall, from Oct. 7 to Jan. 2. The exhibition, entitled ''Cleopatra's Egypt: Age of the Ptolemies,'' will contain approximately 150 works from over 40 public and private collections in the United States and Europe. The works will include stone statuary and relief, gold jewelry, silver vessels, figurines in terra cotta and faience, and other objects in glass, bronze and wood.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Soviet practice does not - or does not yet - measure up to Soviet commitment.'' - President Reagan, on human rights. [ 1:4. ]

title: About Nuclear Weapons, Ignorance Isn't Bliss
description: To the Editor:

title: Economists Predict Growth
description: Economists for the nation's top businesses said today that they had raised their forecasts for growth in 1988 but that they still expect rising interest rates to push the country into a recession next year.

title: Catholic Educators Debating Future of Parochial Schools
description: With parochial school enrollment showing no sign of ending a 23-year decline, a growing number of Roman Catholic educators have begun to question the church's long-standing reliance on such schools as the bedrock of religious education.

title: Beazer, Shearson Get Summonses
description: Brian Beazer, the British industrialist, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. faced a new barrier against their $1.7 billion hostile bid for the Koppers Company when a Federal judge in Los Angeles today summoned them to a contempt of court hearing on June 6. Koppers filed papers Thursday in United States District Court in Los Angeles accusing the Beazer group and Shearson, a unit of the American Express Compnay, of violating the court's order not to proceed with their $60-a-share tender offer.

title: Oilers' Elation Fresh as Ever
description: Hockey's playoff season may have been marked by intrusions bordering on the supernatural, but when the time came for a Stanley Cup champion to emerge, the season reached its natural conclusion. The Edmonton Oilers, the National Hockey League's most talented team, retained the title with a sweep of the overmatched Boston Bruins.

title: Dow Falls 10.31 in Listless Trading
description: LEAD: Stock prices sagged yesterday in listless pre-holiday trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.31 points, to 1,956.44, and broader indexes were down as well.

title: Chase Wins Securities Case
description: A United States Court of Appeals today upheld the Federal Reserve Board's decision to allow a commercial bank affiliate to engage in underwriting and dealing in commercial paper to a limited extent.

title: Bush, at Home by the Sea, Takes Combative Stance
description: Just as Scarlett O'Hara once drew strength from the rich soil of Tara, so George Bush took heart today from the tingling salt air of Walker's Point.

title: Dance; Jaffe and McKenzie in 'Don Quixote'
description: Susan Jaffe and Kevin McKenzie took over the roles of Kitri and Basil in American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote'' on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The previously reviewed Ms. Jaffe replaced the originally announced Leslie Browne, who is recovering from an injury. Mr. McKenzie danced Basil for the first time this season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 28, 1988
description: Companies

title: Your Money; Financial Advice For Graduates
description: When Edward W. Barrett was dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism in the 1950's and 60's, he liked to give a special talk just before graduation. His advice to those about to embark on their careers: ''Start a go-to-hell fund.''

title: Nancy Gleason Is Wed To Mark Francis Rice
description: Nancy Elizabeth Gleason, the daughter of Mrs. John G. Azary of Modesto, Calif., and Thomas G. Gleason of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Francis Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Rice of Manhasset and Naples, Fla. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Dirt Stars Try the Grass
description: Nineteen 3-year-olds, 16 grass horses and the nation's leading milers will be in action this holiday weekend in four major stakes races in New York and New Jersey.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Jacksonville Journal article yesterday mislocated Jacksonville, Ill., in relation to Springfield, Ill. It is west, not east, of Springfield.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Passes Military Bill

title: New Europe Import Tax
description: The European Community this week imposed special import duties of up to 33.4 percent on Japanese computer printers, saying they were being dumped at unfairly low prices on European markets. The European Community commission said in a statement that a yearlong investigation had shown that 14 Japanese companies, among them some of the biggest names in the electronics industry, had sold printers in Europe at prices lower than those at home or below the cost of production. The Japanese companies affected by the decision include Brother Industries, the Citizen Watch Company, Fujitsu Ltd., the NEC Corporation, Seiko Epson and Seikosha.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Are Unchanged
description: Treasury note and bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday in a somnolent pre-holiday weekend session. But bill rates, after posting moderate gains early in the day, closed slightly lower.

title: Albert King
description: Albert King, the blues singer and guitarist, is appearing tonight and tomorrow at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $12.50; there is a two-drink minimum, and shows start at 9:30 and 11:30.

title: Non-Cancerous Lesions Are Removed From Koch's Face
description: Five small non-cancerous skin lesions were removed from Mayor Koch's face yesterday morning. The 63-year-old Mayor said the procedure was painless and he would not need any further treatment.

title: Market Holiday
description: Stock and commodity markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed.

title: Reds' Milner Returns
description: The Cincinnati Reds outfielder Eddie Milner, who was suspended March 30 for admitted drug use, will be eligible to return as part of an agreement reached with the Players Association, the commissioner's office announced yesterday.

title: DRUG INQUIRY SET ON BIRTH DEFECTS
description: The Commissioner of Food and Drugs said yesterday that his agency had begun to investigate cases in which the anti-acne drug Accutane led to severely deformed babies, in hope of determining whether there was a pattern of improper prescription or misuse.

title: Driver Has Right Stuff To Pilot Indy Pace Car
description: Chuck Yeager was strapped in, gunning the throttle, his narrow eyes seeing things that are hidden from most people.

title: Sports of The Times; A Matter Of Deliverance
description: Zeke could hardly speak above a hoarse whisper, so fatigued, so drained, so sorely disappointed was he.

title: Ousted Panamanian Favors Latin Role in Noriega Talks
description: The Panamanian President who was deposed by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that the United States should allow Latin American democracies to take the lead in any new negotiations over the general's ouster.

title: PRESIDENT CHALLENGES GORBACHEV TO IMPROVE HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD
description: President Reagan challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to improve the Soviet human-rights record by reuniting divided families, increasing emigration, ending suppression of religion and releasing political prisoners.

title: Putting a Lock on Plutonium
description: LEAD: The disclosure this week of a possible second case of diversion of Norwegian heavy water, purportedly to an international black market for nuclear weapons materials, is the latest reminder that tougher controls are needed to prevent nuclear power technology from being used to build nuclear weapons.

title: Company Looks for Ready Market In the Growing Korean Operations
description: Besides offering a low price and extra features, Miraclean hopes that sales of its Korean-made dry-cleaning machines will be helped by the large number of Korean families who own and operate dry cleaners in this country.

title: 10,000 New Inmates to Be Tested To Gauge Spread of AIDS Virus
description: The blood of 10,000 new inmates from around the United States will be tested this summer as part of an effort to measure the spread of the AIDS virus among prisoners.

title: Fixing Bridge, 4 Are Hurt In 30-Foot Fall
description: One day after the Williamsburg Bridge reopened, four construction workers repairing its beams were injured yesterday, none seriously, when a wooden platform they were standing on collapsed, hurtling them to a work area 30 feet below.

title: Suit Seeks the Return Of AIDS Victim's Silver
description: In a lawsuit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe has charged the New-York Historical Society with ''fraudulent conduct'' in obtaining a five-year loan of a collection of American silver from the art collector Samuel Wagstaff Jr. The museum rejects the charges.

title: Progress Seen in Nicaragua Talks
description: Sandinista and contra leaders said today that their peace talks were making progress.

title: Icahn Offer Is Rejected By Texaco
description: The board of Texaco Inc. yesterday turned down Carl C. Icahn's takeover proposal, and Mr. Icahn used that rejection as fodder in his proxy campaign, as the two sides began a battle for the votes of the company's 211,000 shareholders.

title: Semiconductor Demand
description: World semiconductor demand is forecast to rise 30.1 percent in 1988, but growth is expected to slow sharply in 1989, to 3.9 percent, the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics' Japan Council said this week. The forecast, compiled by the council based on data from semiconductor makers from around the world, shows demand growing to $42.3 billion in 1988. In 1988, semiconductor demand will grow 26 percent in the United States, 33 percent in Japan and 27 percent in Europe, the council said. Demand in other regions, primarily Asia, is forecast to rise 36 percent.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day is Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parades: Manhattan parade starts at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and West End Avenue, goes east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument. Bronx parade at 11 A.M. at Grand Concourse and Van Cortlandt Avenue East. Brooklyn parade at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and Fourth Avenue. Queens parade at 11 A.M. at Metropolitan and Ascan Avenues. Staten Island parade at 8:15 A.M. at 10th Street and Princeton Avenue. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; main post office at 33d Street and Eigth Avenue is open. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday parking rules. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways, buses on Sunday schedule; Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on holiday schedule. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. No train service in Bergen, Passaic and parts of Morris Counties. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Bridge; Playoffs to select national women's team will create scheduling conflicts for some
description: Scheduling conflicts next week will make life difficult for eight women who are leading players from the New York metropolitan region, including six who have won world titles.

title: COPING/With Watch Repairs
description: Fine wristwatches, traditional gifts for graduation and Father's Day, can appreciate in value but are generally expensive to maintain and repair.

title: Vote Pulls Israeli Labor Party to the Left
description: The Israeli Labor Party held its first open election of candidates for Parliament on Thursday, and when the votes were finally counted early today, the new list showed that the party was taking a swing to the left.

title: Strife and Debt Wrack Bronx Health Center
description: LEAD: The possibilities for good once seemed endless at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Health Center, which opened in the South Bronx in 1968. Locally controlled, publicly financed and desperately needed, the center became one of the nation's largest community health centers, serving some of its poorest neighborhoods.

title: Correction; CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Cablevision Industries' acquisition of Wometco Cable TV misstated the role of Morgan Stanley & Company. The firm served as investment bankers to Wometco.

title: Media General Wins Vote
description: Media General Inc. said yesterday that it had won a proxy fight with the Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman, who had sought to elect himself and two associates to the company's nine-member board.

title: George Gardner Hill, Minister, 68
description: The Rev. George Gardner Hill, a retired Methodist minister who served in churches in Connecticut, New York and Florida, died of prostate cancer May 20 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 68 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Legislator in Alabama Is Accused of Extortion
description: The president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has been charged with taking $10,000 to use his influence as a state legislator in an effort to help a convicted murderer win early parole.

title: Western Gain in Gold Seen
description: Western gold output is likely to rise sharply this year with increases from almost every producer nation except South Africa, the London commodity broker E.D.&F. Man said today.

title: About New York Not Quite Ready For the Ash Bin Of History
description: The scene was the Sanchez cigar store, a hole-in-the-wall place at 265 West 30th Street where a dusty wooden Indian stands inside the window and two workers methodically roll 500 Cuban-style handmades a day. Bill Terrio, a customer, gripped a handful of aromatic coronas and didn't give a hoot who minded.

title: Another Meese Aide Resigns; Department Praised in Letter
description: Charles J. Cooper, who heads the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel, announced today that he was submitting his resignation to enter private practice.

title: Inquiries Into Crazy Eddie Find False Financial Data
description: The new management of Crazy Eddie Inc. has disclosed that Federal criminal and civil investigations have found that all the company's financial statements before last November are inaccurate.

title: Theater; Revival of 'Last of Red Hot Lovers'
description: Having been a long-running Broadway success and a Hollywood movie, ''Last of the Red Hot Lovers'' would not seem to be an ideal candidate for revival, except perhaps for an all-star summer theater package. Undaunted, John Driver has staged the 1969 Neil Simon comedy at the American Jewish Theater. While the production does not uncover any previously unseen facets, it does prove that the play is - as it was - a felicitous showcase for actors.

title: Reuters Buys Part Of Australian A.P.
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said it had acquired a 48.8 percent stake in Australian Associated Press Ltd. for $:30.8 million, or about $57 million. The agreement gives Reuters and Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based News Corporation equal stakes in Australian Associated Press, Reuters said. The remaining shares, or 2.4 percent, are owned by two regional Australian newspapers.

title: First Zero of '88 for Mets
description: With two outs in the seventh inning, Darryl Strawberry stepped out of the dugout to pinch-hit. Minutes later, Kevin McReynolds also emerged. Gradually, normalcy was restored to the lineup for the Mets. The laws of probability, though, would remain elusive.

title: AIDE TO EX-BRONX LEADER TELLS OF WEDTECH PAYMENTS
description: A witness testifying yesterday in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi described an elaborate system of payments made by the Wedtech Corporation, by a former law partner of Mr. Biaggi and by a Bronx Democratic club to a former Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon.

title: Playing for Good Cause
description: Thomas Bird and Michael Bornholdt, prisoners at the Kansas State Penitentiary at Lansing, are aiming to set a record by playing tennis for 125 hours, breaking the mark of 120 hours 9 minutes listed in the Guinness Book of World Records.

title: Military Survey Faulted Eastern
description: The Air Force announced today that it had considered stripping Eastern Airlines of the right to carry military passengers but had relented because of the carrier's promise to address ''performance deficiences'' found by Air Force inspectors.

title: Theater; Laughter Amid the Ruins Of Kitsch and Junk Food
description: ''Splitsville,'' Richard Dresser's nightmarish satire of American junk culture, takes its title from a theme park that is being hastily built across the street from the Florida residence of a young married couple named Roy and Wendy.

title: Rising Above Self
description: Nixon in China, Reagan in Moscow. Why is it that to improve relations with Communists we have to have conservative Red-baiters in the White House?

title: Vatican's Playwright
description: To the Editor:

title: USG Claims Proxy Victory
description: The USG Corporation said today that it had won a proxy fight waged by Desert Partners L.P. for six seats on the company's 15-member board of directors.

title: Heart Recipient, 13, Dies
description: Eric Rutkowski, a 13-year-old Milwaukee boy became the youngest recipient of a Jarvik-7 artificial heart Thursday, but he died hours after the surgery when his lungs filled with fluid. Eric, a seventh-grade student at Sholes Middle School, died at St. Luke's Medical Center. The youngest previous recipient of the artificial heart was Christopher Larson, 15, of Esdaile, Wis.

title: COMMENCEMENT
description: City College

title: China's Appetite for U.S. TV Shows Is Increasing
description: On Wednesday nights in Shanghai, more than 70 percent of the television audience watches the American police show ''Hunter.'' This summer ''Our House'' and ''Falcon Crest'' will be added to the lives of 80 million Chinese in Shanghai and Beijing as well as Fujian and Guangdong Provinces.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: Entertainment Publications Bid
description: Entertainment Publications Inc. said that a management-led group had offered to buy the company for $21 cash a share in a deal that values the printer of entertainment discount coupon books at around $110 million. In addition to the cash, shareholders would receive preferred stock in the surviving company worth $2 a share and carrying a dividend rate of 16 percent a year, the company said.

title: Philip H. Wilde Is Married To Ann Elizabeth Michel
description: The marriage of Ann Elizabeth Michel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Michel of New York, to Philip Herbert Wilde, the son of Elizabeth Bassage of Corning, N.Y., and the late Herbert E. Wilde, took place yesterday at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Judge Louise Gruner-Gans of Civil Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company Briefs listing in some editions of Business Day yesterday about Cooper Industries incorrectly identified the company it is acquiring.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about acid fumes at a hospital in the Bronx misidentified the hospital because of information supplied by The Associated Press. It was the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map on Wednesday accompanying an article about a propane truck that overturned on Long Island incorrectly identified the area shown. It was Nassau County.

title: Elizabeth Pitney Marries Dr. Christopher Seidler
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ellen Pitney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Pitney of Worcester, Mass., to Dr. Christopher Whidden Seidler, a son of Mrs. William D. Seidler of New York and the late Mr. Seidler, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Worcester. The Rev. Charles F. Monroe performed the ceremony.

title: Hanoi Move Raises U.S. Hope For Regional Gains at Summit
description: American officials said today that Vietnam's pledge to withdraw 50,000 troops from Cambodia had raised their hopes for progress on a range of regional disputes at the Moscow summit talks.

title: Judge John Boyle Wed To Lois Marie Powers
description: Lois Marie Powers and Judge John M. Boyle of State Superior Court in Union, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Genevieve's Roman Catholic Church in Elizabeth, N.J., by the Rev. John G. Netta. The bride, the daughter of Julia D. Powers of Union and the late Thomas E. Powers, is an administrative secretary at the Schering-Plough pharmaceutical company in Kenilworth, N.J. She graduated from the Laboratory Institute of Merchandising in New York and attended Seton Hall University. Her father was the county editor at The Elizabeth Daily Journal, now The Daily Journal.

title: No-Baby Sections in Restaurants
description: LEAD: Smoking, spitting and loud radio playing are offensive and properly prohibited in public places. But now that you can finally enjoy that quiet table in the corner in a smoke-free atmosphere, you might instead find the environment polluted by an infant exercising his right to a tantrum.

title: Music; A Robert Shaw Conducts All-Brahms Program
description: Robert Shaw is retiring in style as music director of the Atlanta Symphony, leading the orchestra in two Manhattan concerts and then embarking on a European tour, complete with the full Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chorus. The first of his New York programs, Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, showed two related aspects of his musical personality to fine advantage.

title: The Met Plays Tokyo, Where It Has Ardent Fans
description: With the trappings of rock star idolatry and more than a hint of commercialism, the Metropolitan Opera - 52 singers, 72 chorus members, 103 musicians, 50 technicians and 110 tons of scenery, musical instruments and costumes -has come to Japan.

title: At Age 10, Boeing Jet Finds Niche
description: Ten years after its introduction, the Boeing Company's 757 jetliner is finally the right airplane for the times, filling the airlines' growing need for a larger, quieter and more fuel-efficient aircraft.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Mavericks Halt Lakers' Momentum
description: After enjoying two games against Dallas that looked like highlight films, the Los Angeles Lakers ran into a wall this evening. The Mavericks, reeling after two straight lopsided losses in Los Angeles, waged a desperate fight this evening and defeated the Lakers, 106-94.

title: Guido Orlando, 80, Press Agent Who Devised Outlandish Stunts
description: Guido Orlando, a flamboyant press agent, charlatan and bemedaled publicist for dozens of the wish-to-be-famous, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in California. He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Labor Dispute Embroils Westin in South Africa
description: The Westin Hotel Company, which decided last month to withdraw from South Africa, was embroiled today in a dispute with the black work force of this city's most prestigious hotel, the Carlton.

title: Polls Show Thrill for Le Pen Is Gone
description: Jean-Marie Le Pen was in a foul mood. He railed at a local newspaper - ''It's Pravda!'' - for asserting that French gypsies were angered when he showed up at their annual festival, and he denounced local electoral boards for challenging the intention of his National Front to run under the acronym Lepen.

title: Guokas a Magic Man
description: The Orlando Magic, the National Basketball Association expansion team, plans to hire Matt Guokas, the former Philadelphia 76ers coach, a newspaper reported yesterday.

title: Two Oberlin Ensembles
description: The Contemporary Music Ensemble and Wind Ensemble of Oberlin Conservatory, directed by Larry Ra=chleff, came to Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening and offered polished, animated performances of four colorfully scored recent works. Three of them were New York premieres, and two of those were by composers on the Oberlin faculty, Michael Daugherty and Edward Miller.

title: Suspect Arrested in Beating Of a Teacher in the Bronx
description: A Bronx teen-ager was charged with attempted murder last night in the beating of a high school teacher in a playground Thursday afternoon, the police said.

title: Justice Dept. Official Tangles With Panel Over Civil Rights
description: The Justice Department's civil rights chief has criticized Congress for exempting itself from civil rights laws and has denied that he lied to senators last year about a Republican challenge of voter registrations in Louisiana.

title: Aviation Agency Urges More Boeing 737 Checks
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is proposing further toughening of inspections for older Boeing 737 airliners like the one whose fuselage ripped open over Hawaii last month.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: French Open; Seeded Stopped Mainly By Rain
description: The French Open tennis tournament rolled along predictably today with comfortable victories by the top-seeded players, including Martina Navratilova, Helena Sukova and Stefan Edberg.

title: VW Sues 2 In Dollar Plot
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. is suing two former employees, who are married to each other, contending that they bilked VW out of millions of dollars as part of a foreign currency trading scheme that came to light in 1986, a VW spokesman said this week.

title: Royals Waive Balboni
description: The Kansas City Royals announced that they have placed the first baseman Steve Balboni and the outfielder Thad Bosley on waivers for the purpose of giving them their unconditional release.

title: Death Penalty Imposed on Illinois Kidnapper
description: A 31-year-old man was sentenced to death today for the kidnapping and murder of a businessman who was buried alive and suffocated before his family could pay a $1 million ransom.

title: William Dermott Moran Sr., 78, Ex-S.E.C. Regional Administrator
description: William Dermott Moran Sr., former regional director of the Secrities and Exchange Commission, died of heart failure Thursday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Superpowers vs. South Africa
description: Here's a proposal for President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev at the Moscow summit talks: Announce a cooperative approach toward southern Africa. Start a multinational effort to aid the states that border South Africa. Squelch the idea that the region is another arena of East-West rivalry. Expose the root problem - South Africa's destabilization of its neighbors. Signal unmistakably that opposition to apartheid knows no ideology.

title: Not Quite Radio City, But Backdrop Is Right
description: All the anchors have arrived, and with them, so have the soft drinks, the staples, the copy machines, the clocks for every time zone, the camera operators, the producers, a few hairdressers and a couple of cases of Oreo cookies.

title:
Patents;
Three Army Engineers Develop a Generator
description: LEAD: A manually operated electrical generation system, which has a stirrup and is nicknamed the Big Foot, has been patented for the Army. Patent 4,746,806 was awarded this week to three staff engineers at the Harry Diamond Laboratories maintained by the Army at Adelphi, Md.

title: Writers Guild Approves Pact for Independents
description: Members of the striking Writers Guild of America have voted approval of a model contract with independent television and motion picture producers, an action the union hopes will put pressure on the major studios to yield concessions to the writers.

title: Van Buren's 'Jinx'
description: LEAD: This is high season for the Vice Presidency, the only time in four years when Americans think much about the office. Unfortunately, much of the discussion is marred by obsolete stereotypes.

title: NURSING HOMES FACE PRESSURES THAT IMPERIL CARE FOR ELDERLY
description: Rising costs, an acute shortage of nurses and government limits on spending are combining to cause severe problems at nursing homes across the country, according to industry and government officials.

title: Agency Says 2 Toys Recalled Because of Choking Hazard
description: The Sweet Home Shoe House play set and the Ice Cream Doll are being recalled nationwide because small children might choke on their parts, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Friday.

title: Dance; A Tap-Flamenco Union
description: ''Espectaculo Flamenco Tap-Dance,'' presented by Casa de Espana on Thursday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, certainly was spectacular. It would have been enough to present either Cristobal Reyes, a member of Cumbre Flamenco of Spain and a gypsy dancer of great fire and originality, or Harold Nicholas, who danced as one of the Nicholas Brothers with his brother, Fayard, in movie musicals of the 1940's. But this was a rare coming together of the two very different but complementary dance forms - and a heartwarming and dazzling dance spectacle that will likely be long talked about by those who witnessed it, cheering and coaxing the dancers along.

title: Senate's Condition to Treaty
description: Following is the text of the condition attached by the Senate on Thursday to the resolution to approve the Treaty on Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces:

title: Hawaiian Airlines' Stake to Japanese
description: A Japan Air Lines subsidiary has agreed to pay about $20 million to acquire a 20 percent stake in HAL Inc., the parent of Hawaiian Airlines, the largest air carrier in Hawaii. Pan Pacific Hoteliers Inc. will purchase newly issued stock, which will represent up to 20 percent of HAL's shares outstanding, for $40 a share, HAL's chairman, John H. Magoon Jr., said in a statement. The stock purchase is subject to Government review. Federal law limits foreign ownership in United States airlines to a maximum of 25 percent.

title: Sy Oliver, 77, a Jazz Composer, Arranger and Band Leader, Dies
description: Melvin James (Sy) Oliver, one of America's great jazz composers and arrangers and a man who had a significant impact on American popular music, died of cardiovascular complications Friday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and had been suffering from cancer for a year.

title: LILCO'S FIRST MOVE: PLEA TO CONSERVE
description: Shoreham has been the centerpiece of electricity planning on Long Island for more than a decade, and so the decision to cancel the 809-megawatt plant leaves the Long Island Lighting Company with just one way to prevent brownouts in the next few years, persuading its customers to make do with less.

title: Golf; Irwin Leads on a Course to His Liking
description: Hale Irwin, who won the 1983 and 1985 Memorial Tournaments at the Muirfield Village Golf Club and finished second in a playoff with Roger Maltbie at the first Memorial in 1976, said today he did not have a love affair with this 7,104-yard course.

title: Dermatologists to Warn Of Accutane Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Stars Sign Czechs
description: Dusan Pasek and Igor Liba, hockey stars in Czechoslovakia, have agreed to multiyear contracts with the Minnesota North Stars, said Lou Nanne, the general manager of the North Stars.

title: Shootings Leave a Suburb in Trauma
description: Until a week ago, fear was a foreign emotion in this wealthy suburb north of Chicago. Children played freely, school doors were always open and violence and murder were what happened to someone else.

title: Rift Ended By Trump And Griffin
description: Donald J. Trump and Merv Griffin said today that they had again come to terms on a plan to divide up the assets of Resorts International Inc., ending a two-week deadlock on secondary issues that had threatened to destroy their deal.

title: Monte Kay Dies at 63; Founder of Nightclubs
description: Monte Kay, a recording company president and jazz entrepreneur who was a co-founder of Birdland, a nightclub in New York, died Wednesday of heart failure. He was 63 years old.

title: IMPROVISING TROMBONIST
description: The Village Vanguard can be a harsh place for young musicans. The club has terrifyingly high creative standards, two or three sets a night, six nights a week, demanding deep improvisational resources and complete assurance. Without them, a musician will die a slow, obvious death in front of the baleful pictures on the wall of the great musicians who've played there.

title: Death Penalty Needed to Combat Police Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: School Showdown in Jersey City
description: New Jersey's Commissioner of Education, Saul Cooperman, threatens to use a new state law to take over Jersey City's public schools. The law, together with Mr. Cooperman's willingness to use it, deserves the attention and support of all states worried about the decline of local schools.

title: Fierstein Keeps On Joking, on Camera and Off
description: The church hall at St. Anthony's on Houston Street was decorated with blue and white graduation streamers. People took plates full of gloopy-looking potato salad from the buffet, poured their own coffee from the urn and sat at long, uncomfortable tables that seemed to spell Bingo. So lacking in glamour, among other things, the scene hardly looked like the 1 A.M. lunch break on a dusk-to-dawn shoot of ''Torch Song Trilogy.''

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Bird Making No Excuses for His Slump
description: A cabdriver outside Boston Garden said he had heard reports that Larry Bird had undergone tests for mononucleosis.

title: Raleigh-to-Paris Flights
description: American Airlines said this week that it had started nonstop flights between Paris and the Raleigh-Durham Airport in North Carolina. The flights are the first international service from Raleigh and the airport is being renamed the Raleigh-Durham International Airport, American said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Five Share Senior Lead: Bob Charles, the defending champion, shot a three-under-par 69 to move into a five-way tie for the lead after the first round of the Sunwest Bank Senior P.G.A. Tour tournament in Albuquerque, N.M. Fourteen players were within two shots of the lead before thunder, lightning and rain forced a 59-minute suspension.

title: Replacement-Cost Insurance: More Benefits, at a Higher Price
description: As real-estate values rise, many homeowners are taking a new look at their insurance coverage and deciding whether to improve it. People who bought houses or apartments for $100,000 or less 15 years ago suddenly find that their homes are now valued at three, four and five times the purchase price.

title: Ray Kennedy, Magazine Writer, 54
description: Ray Kennedy, a prominent writer for more than 20 years at Time and Sports Illustrated magazines, died of a heart attack Thursday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 54 years old.

title: Price of Lilco Stock Reflects Relief on Wall Street
description: The complex deal that sealed the fate of Shoreham has been generally well received on Wall Street, even though the specific language of the agreement to abandon the $5.3 billion nuclear plant, including its financial details, have yet to be released.

title: VW Price Rise
description: Volkswagen United States, a unit of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said it would raise the prices of most of its vehicles by an average of 1.6 percent, or $181 each, effective June 6. The price of the 16-valve GTI is to increase the most, rising $250, to $13,245.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Affiliated Medical Enterprises, Orange, Calf., an investor-owned health-care corporation, announced that it had acquired American Health Group International Inc., Kirkland, Wash., for $100 million. The acquisition included the purchase of four acute-care hospitals and a home health company.

title: New Owner for Spurs
description: B. J. (Red) McCombs, the president of the San Antonio Spurs, became the team's majority owner yesterday after two months of negotiations with Angelo Drossos, the chairman.

title: Federal Energy Official Resigns
description: Another member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has resigned, leaving the five-member board with two vacancies and only one sitting member with a regular appointment. Commissioner Anthony

title: Wider Limits For Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange plans to act immediately on an exemption granted earlier this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission that allows institutions to hold larger positions in some options on the Standard & Poor's 100- and 500-stock indexes.

title: Deal Ends Uncertainty For Businesses on L.I.
description: The decision to close the Shoreham nuclear-power plant and keep the Long Island Lighting Company an investor-owned utility resolves years of uncertainty that academic and business leaders say have hampered the planning and investment strategies of Long Island businesses. .

title: Funeral Director Is Charged
description: A funeral home director was charged today with stealing more than $3,900 from the apartment of a welfare recipient whom her funeral home had been hired by the state to bury. The director, Concetta Cannici, 74 years old, of the DeLucia Memorial funeral home, was released on a written promise she appear in court to answer a charge of third-degree larceny, a police spokesman said.

title: Produce Brings a Harvest of Success
description: LEAD: SOMEWHERE between a mom-and-pop grocery and a supermarket is Hay Day, a chain that has created a niche as a chic country market.

title: New Haven to Celebrate Its 350th Birthday
description: IN 1638, a boatload of English settlers arrived in New Haven seeking religious liberty. Eventually the 500 Puritans purchased the land that now makes up the city, plus some of its surrounding towns, for 12 coats of English cloth, four cases of knives, 12 hatchets, 12 hoes, 12 porringers and other utensils. A yearlong observance of that event will begin next weekend.

title: ONE OFFICIAL AT JUSTICE IS DEFINITELY NOT READY TO STEP DOWN
