description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has begun laying the groundwork for what aides say will be a vigorous offensive aimed at clearing his name and repairing any damage that his problems have caused his party, specifically the Presidential candidacy of Vice President Bush. At the same time, officials have denied suggestions that the department's effectiveness has been impaired by Mr. Meese's problems.

title: K.G.B. Prevents 5 Catholics From Trying to Meet Reagan
description: The Soviet security police dragged five Ukrainian Catholics from a Moscow-bound train today, frustrating their hopes of meeting President Reagan, a leading Christian dissident said.

title: Leopard Kills Child After Escaping Cage
description: A leopard fatally mauled a 2-year-old child whose father used the animal in his rock 'n' roll nightclub act and had fought a bill to restrict ownership of dangerous exotic animals, the police say.

title: MADE FOR EACH OTHER
description: HERB 'N' LORNA A Love Story. By Eric Kraft. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Tooth Ferry Gets the Brushoff IT'S one thing to have a boat tied up in your backyard. It's another to have a 125-foot fishing trawler floating next to your house, especially a 125-foot fishing trawler in major need of repair.

title: IN HUNGARY, FLEXIBILITY AS DOCTRINE
description: The Hungarians have often been quick to take advantage of changes blowing in from the East. They proved that again last weekend when a new generation of Hungarian Communist leaders succeeded in seizing power.

title: Farmers Turn to Hog Raising for a Fee
description: Marvin and Judy Patterson and their three sons are farmers in southern Missouri's craggy Ozarks hills. Galen Miller runs a farm in central Iowa's fertile rolling plains. But all of them have much in common.

title: The Flourishing Spirit of a Long-Hidden Grave
description: MY 11-year-old son, Michael, brought big news with his return from an afternoon of playing with his friends. As he spooned a helping of mashed potatoes onto his plate, he announced they had found a grave down in the woods.

title: Former Levitt Estate Is a Showcase
description: WHAT kind of home would the man who built Levittown build for himself?

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Gawking With Gorky Intellectuals have always had a love-hate relationship with big cities, but Maxim Gorky really laid it on thick when he visited New York in 1906. He is quoted in ''America Through Russian Eyes: 1874-1926,'' edited and translated by Olga Peters Hasty and Susanne Fusso (Yale University).

title: Before the Revolution - and After
description: There were plenty of real stars on hand, including Clint Eastwood, Robert Redford and Jean-Paul Belmondo. The sometimes dangerously huge crowds pushed and shoved to catch sight of even the mini-celebrity (a would-be star) who appeared at the Redford gala in a topless and nearly bottomless evening dress. The round of luncheon, cocktail and dinner parties was a freeloader's answered prayer. Yet there was a sense of forced gaiety and dogged, obligatory optimism throughout the 41st Cannes Film Festival. The 13-day event closed here Monday night when the Palme d'Or was awarded to ''Pelle the Conqueror,'' the Danish film directed by Bille August.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: TAKE Edward Hayes's brown crocodile shoes. Well, actually you can't take them, because he won't part with them. It's not that he wears them; he hasn't had them on in years. But there they are, in a prominent place in his bedroom, where he can look at them and reflect.

title: Affordable Housing: A Planner's Reply
description: I must respond to Charles Mancini's comments [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 24 ] because they are partial to the builder and do not reflect an understanding of the East End of Long Island, which was the focus of my interview [ ''A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality,'' March 20 ] . First, East End towns have adopted comprehensive zoning amendments, ''upzoning,'' to preserve ground-water quantity and quality, and to use new growth-management techniques for open space and affordable housing.

title: Prom on Boat (Yay!) Take a Bus (Boo!)
description: NEARLY everyone in the senior class at Ridgefield High School thought it was a fine idea when the senior prom committee decided to hold this year's prom aboard a cruise ship on the Connecticut River.

title: Thinking Big at the Guggenheim
description: New York was slightly confounded last January when Thomas Krens, a farm-team player who heads the Williams College Museum of Art, was named to the prestigious post of director of the Guggenheim Museum. ''Tom who?'' was the puzzled query at Pleiades, Da Sylvano, the Canal Bar and other art eateries around town. Only a handful knew that Mr. Krens, age 41, is a powerhouse who has brought the international art scene to sleepy Williams's door, and audaciously masterminded MASS MoCA, a $50 million project aimed at converting an abandoned factory complex in nearby North Adams into the world's biggest museum of contemporary art.

title: Ex-Prisoners of War Applying for Medals
description: SINCE the end of March, when the Pentagon announced it was ready to begin issuing medals to former prisoners of war, more than 900 applications have been received from New Jersey veterans.

title: In Defense Of Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LAKEWOOD REMEMBERS An Army helicopter will drop a wreath on Lake Carasaljo in Lakewood tomorrow as the town honors four servicemen killed in Vietnam, as well as all American war dead.

title: 21 Hours of Shakespearean Drama
description: WHILE the theater in Stratford, the state's traditional spring and summer home for Shakespeare, suffers a silent season, Stamford is taking up the slack by offering 21 hours' worth of the Shakespeare's historical plays.

title:
DANCE;
Summer Festival Set to Open
description: LEAD: THE state's best-known ballet and modern-dance companies will inaugurate the 1988 New Jersey Summer Festival Saturday and next Sunday with two free performances at Waterloo Village in Stanhope.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A MOTHER'S SECRET. By Carolyn Haddad. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Ha kol biseder. In Hebrew, it means ''all will be well.'' And that's precisely what Carolyn Haddad sets out to prove in this tale of three women who survive the horrors of World War II in Poland. The novel is something of a departure for the author, who as C.

title: Cold War Recedes
description: President Reagan is on his way to his fourth spectacular summit conference with Mikhail Gorbachev. It is a stunning completion of a full cycle since the last Presidential visit to the Kremlin, when Richard Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev launched detente in 1972.

title: When It's One Absolute Right Against Another
description: WHEN Ginger and David R. Twitchell's 2-year-old son, Robyn, had a fever two years ago, they called in Christian Science spiritual healers, who visited the boy and prayed for his recovery. But five days later, after going into convulsions, vomiting and losing consciousness, Robyn died of a bowel obstruction. Mr. Twitchell held the child in his arms until he died, and then called a funeral home.

title: WHY I'M STAYING IN THE SENATE
description: My good friend Senator Daniel J. Evans explained why he is leaving the Senate (''Why I'm Quitting the Senate,'' April 17). I would like to explain why I am staying.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Coalition To Provide Funds for Housing
description: LEAD: SEEKING to spur development of affordable housing in Westchester County, a coalition of government, business and professional groups is establishing a fund to provide start-up financing for residential projects.

title: At the Summit: Realism, Not Rabbits
description: It's tempting to imagine that President Reagan's meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev this week will be a watershed, the moment when the ultimate American hawk and the ultimate Russian reformer end the cold war. But if that tense and dangerous competition is to end, it will require many summit conferences, and basic changes inside both countries. Foreign policy is usually a continuation of domestic politics and values by other means.

title: Progress Seen as Nicaragua Talks End
description: The latest round of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and the contra rebels ended tonight after significant progress had been made in the negotiations.

title: Deciding How Much Power a Principal Needs
description: HOW much leadership can a school principal be expected to provide when he is not allowed to shape his teaching staff, let alone tell a custodian to mop a floor?

title: Runaways Trouble Experts on Youth
description: LEAD: A CRY for help. That is what Beth Timmins of the Huntington Youth Bureau says of a child who runs away from what should be his most secure and safe environment: his home.

title: Cancer Survivors To Celebrate Living
description: LEAD: WHEN Phyllis M. Smith, a gynecology oncology social worker at Yale-New Haven Hospital, counsels patients, she tells them that she has walked in their shoes. Eighteen months ago, Mrs. Smith was diagnosed as having a rare type of leukemia.

title: Lois Moore Cross Becomes the Bride Of Gregory T. Willis in Connecticut
description: St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lois Moore Cross, a daughter of John Walter Cross 3d of Greenwich and the late Gracia H. Cross, to Gregory Tilford Willis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Willis Jr. of Greenwich. The Rev. Sidney Wood-Cahusac performed the ceremony.

title: Setting the Standards For Literary Masterpieces
description: GREAT books are lately a matter of politics.

title: Musical Honors
description: NEITHER lowering skies nor coinciding New York State School Music Association student auditions kept the Caramoor Center for Music and Arts from celebrating student achievement last weekend. Six high school music groups and two student soloists performed Saturday in the Spanish Courtyard, while artwork from 26 schools was on exhibit in the Tennis Pavilion.

title: 'Brawl' in Burma Takes an Anti-Government Turn
description: An argument over a gambling debt in a tea house here last March escalated into a week of rioting by Burmese students and other Rangoon residents, with estimates of fatalities ranging from two to 200.

title: A Material Girl for All Seasons - and Reasons
description: I heard a succinct description of Madonna's appeal once outside a record store:

title: A Weekend in Burgundy Of Golf and Fine Dining
description: LIKE Londoners or New Yorkers, Parisians sometimes long to flee the noise, traffic and sheer intensity of life in their city. One of the unremarked delights of Paris is how easy it is to leave. Barring a revolution or a metro strike, it's possible to get from the Place de la Concorde to a wheat field in less than an hour.

title: Susan Ladd Plans September Bridal
description: Susan Walker Ladd's engagement to William Prescott Rogers 3d, the son of Mrs. William P. Rogers Jr. of Dedham, Mass., and the late Dr. Rogers, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Delano W. Ladd Jr. of Greenwich and Madison, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Fish Plant Helping Cape May Economy
description: A HIGH-RISK business venture, begun here with $2 million in Government money, appears headed for success after only seven months of operation.

title: Upholding a Glen Cove Tradition
description: FOR more than 26 years, Restaurant Zanghi in Glen Cove has pleased Long Island palates. Under Nino Zanghi, now 80 years old, the restaurant came into prominence as a superior northern Italian establishment. Mr. Zanghi, officially retired, still grows choice vegetables for the restaurant and has been known to don his kitchen whites in emergencies.

title: Is This the Second Russian Revolution?
description: John Kenneth Galbraith has joined with Stanislav Menshikov, a Soviet journalist and economist, to write a book, ''Capitalism, Communism and Coexistence.'' The book, which was published last week, examines the strengths and weaknesses of the Soviet and American economies. Mr. Galbraith, Paul M. Warburg professor of economics emeritus at Harvard University, and Mr. Menshikov spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about the Soviet economy and the reforms instituted by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Social Events; Parties That Help Others
description: Veterans' Salute May 31 - The Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company will hold its annual awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria with a salute to Joseph Papp; Michael Fuchs, the chairman of Home Box Office; and Michel Roux, the president of Carillon Importers Ltd. Cocktails at 6:30 followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment by the comedian Robert Klein will benefit the company's theatrical programs at veterans' hospitals and shelters for the homeless. Black tie. Tickets, $250 and $350, from 212-512-1960. Garden Party June 1 - ''The Roaring 20's'' will be the theme of the Museum of Modern Art's annual benefit to open the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. The black-tie evening starts with cocktails at 7 at the Chemical Bank building at 20 West 52d Street. Then guests will walk across the street to the ''21'' Club for the same dinner that was on the menu June 1, 1928, including smoked ''north water'' trout. Around 9, the club will be ''raided'' by Prohibition agents who will herd the imbibers to the museum for the continuation of the party until 1 A.M. Tickets, $500, or $125 for the 9 P.M. party at the museum alone, and $75 for those 30 and under for the museum party alone, from 212-708-9680. Briefly Noted: June 1 - The Panel of Americans, a 46-year-old group that provides training to schools and community groups to reduce racial and ethnic tensions, is holding a cocktail party from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. at the SoHo Center, 114 Prince Street (Wooster Street). Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer will speak. Tickets, $50, from 212-463-7830 or at the door. June 1 - The National Civic League and Council on Municipal Performance will honor Governor Kean and Preston Robert Tisch, the president and co-chief executive officer of the Loews Corporation, at its annual award dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria starting with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $300, from 212-838-6033. June 1 - William F. Buckley Jr. will be the guest speaker at the brotherhood award dinner of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Pierre hotel starting with cocktails at 6:15. Tickets, $400, from 212-807-8440. June 2 - The Matthew Nash Music and Dance company returns to CSC Repertory, 136 East 13th Street, with an 8 P.M. performance and after-theater benefit supper. Tickets, $50, from 212-674-1917. June 2 - The Governor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement will hold a ''Renaissance in Pink'' party from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the New York Academy of Art, 419 Lafayette Street (Astor Place). Tickets, $50, from 212-687-2922. June 2 - Literacy Volunteers of New York City will present a benefit evening with Pat Conroy, Carrie Fisher, Toni Morrison, Kurt Vonnegut and Tom Wolfe reading from their works at Christie's. The 8 P.M. readings will be followed by a reception and supper. Tickets, $150, from 212-475-5757. June 2 - Cocktails at 6:30 followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment at the Plaza will benefit the Scleroderma Society, which seeks a cure for scleroderma, a skin disease. Black tie. Tickets, $250, from 212-684-5025. June 2 - Stop Cancer, recently formed by Armand Hammer to raise $1 billion a year for cancer research by the National Cancer Institute, will hold a cocktail party from 6 to 9 P.M. at the New York Stock Exchange Luncheon Club, 11 Wall Street. Tickets, $75, from 212-517-9044 or $85 at the door. June 2 - Prep for Prep, a 10-year-old program to prepare intellectually gifted children from minority ethnic groups to enter top college preparatory schools, will hold a formal dinner-dance, the Lilac Ball, at the Pierre starting with cocktails at 7. Tickets, $300, from 212-580-5511. June 2 - Performances by advanced students at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center will be held at the center, 1515 Broadway (45th Street). A champagne reception follows the 3 P.M. program. Other performances will be held June 3 and 4. Tickets to performance and reception, $40, at the door. Information: 212-997-1980. June 3 - To assist with the retirement problems of nuns and priests, a new group, Soar - Save Our Aging Religious - has been seeking funds through benefits including the 7:30 performance of ''Nunsense'' at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street. Champagne at intermission and at a cast party afterward. Tickets, $100, from 212-689-9629. June 3 - A formal dinner-dance under a tent at the Fulton Ferry Landing on the Brooklyn side of the Brooklyn Bridge will benefit the 145-year-old Brooklyn Hospital-Caledonian Hospital. Cocktails at 7. Tickets, $200 and $300, from 718-403-6846. Staten Island Weekend June 4-5 - On an 80-acre park on the grounds of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, with some of the finest examples of Greek Revival architecture in America, the Staten Island Botantical Garden has been developing formal gardens and natural areas, including a rose garden with more than 100 varieties. A tea dance from 4 to 8 on Saturday with the music of Lester Lanin's orchestra will open a weekend of benefit festivities for the botanical garden. Sunday from noon to 4 is family day, with tennis and cricket demonstrations, croquet and other lawn games, flower judging, a baby parade, vendors, pony rides, several food centers and a pub tent. Tickets for tea dance (dress is summer whites), $30, from 718-273-8200. Sunday admission, $1, and 50 cents for children over 5. The No. 1 bus from the Staten Island Ferry goes to Snug Harbor.

title: Ella Davila Wed to T. G. Auchincloss Jr.
description: Ella Felicia Davila, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rogerio Davila Jr. of Memphis, was married yesterday to Thomas Gore Auchincloss Jr., a son of Mr. Auchincloss of Eagle Bridge, N.Y., and Mrs. Francis A. Shields of Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. Edwin Lynn, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Castle Hill estate in Ipswich, Mass.

title: What's Carl Icahn Up To?
description: Last Wednesday, Carl C. Icahn made a $60-a-share bid for Texaco's outstanding stock, but the company's management is fighting him. Mr. Icahn, who holds 14.8 percent of Texaco's stock, will have to raise $12.4 billion to purchase the remaining shares. Although he has put $100 million in escrow as a guarantee that he will raise the money, some still doubt that he can. So far investors have reacted cautiously, and the stock rose from $46.875, prior to the bid, to finish the week at $49.375. Will Mr. Icahn's quest for Texaco succeed? Kathryn Rudie Harrigan Professor of strategic management and director of the Strategy Research Center at Columbia Business School.

title: Lisa Panken Is Wed To Michael Skinner
description: Lisa Panken, a daughter of Esther Panken of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Dudley Panken, was married yesterday to Michael Skinner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Skinner of Plymouth, Mich., and Mobile, Ala. The Rev. Alan Thompson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Raintrees restaurant in Brooklyn.

title:
GARDENING;
Containers Add Color and Reduce Care
description: LEAD: PEOPLE living in condominiums or apartments don't have the option of going out to plow the back 40 or replace part of the lawn with flowers or vegetables. For them, containers may be the only choice in gardening. There are also good reasons for homeowners with plenty of space to confine much of their gardening to containers.

title: Ann Argabright Weds Thomas Adam Seclow
description: Ann Elizabeth Argabright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Argabright of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Thomas Adam Seclow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Seclow of Westport, Conn., were married last evening at the bride's home in Orinda, Calif. Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Southfield, Mass.;
Retail Boost In Berkshires
description: LEAD: A FORMER tenant has converted one of Berkshire County's oldest manufacturing complexes, built in 1792, into a crafts and retail center called The Buggy Whip Factory.

title: Bringing Back a Bit Of the Old Neighborhood
description: NEIGHBORHOOD historic preservation projects - used by local governments in part to revitalize their inner cities - have become another source of work for historians. Local officials need them to verify the historic significance of properties and design renovations. Private owners with historic properties need to know what home improvements qualify for a tax credit.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LETTERS ON THE EQUALITY OF THE SEXES AND OTHER ESSAYS. By Sarah Grimke. Edited by Elizabeth Ann Bartlett. (Yale University, $21.50.) ''Woman by surrendering herself to the tutelage of man may in many cases live at her ease, but she will live the life of a slave.'' It was in speaking for the rights of the slave that Sarah Grimke first won notoriety, and it was the experience of being censured as a public-speaking woman that prompted her to draft ''Letters on the Equality of the Sexes'' (1838), a pioneering document in American feminism.

title: Polly Johnson Marries Mark A. Neely, Actor
description: Mary Stuart Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Andrew Neely, a son of Gaby Neely of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late C. Webb Neely. The Rev. Avery Manchester, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Marjorie Fay McCourt to Thomas Savage Clement misidentified the bridegroom's mother. She is Mrs. T. Williams Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a problem with moss growing on the bricks on my patio. I've tried using weed killer. It works, but only temporarily, and it poses a threat to the surrounding shrubs. Can you suggest anything else?

title: Skycrapers Shouldn't Look Down on Humanity
description: ''We feel that postmodern ism is over. For projects which are going to be ready in five years, we are now considering new architectural appointments.'' So I was told by a major United States developer recently. He said it as a matter of course, with the naturalness of a clothing manufacturer who tells you that he does not want to be stuck with a line of blue coats when red is in.

title: Yvette Hellman, a Lawyer, and Gary D. Ansel Wed
description: Yvette Dawn Hellman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hellman of New York, was married last evening to Gary David Ansel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Darrell Ansel of Minnetonka, Minn. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Plaza hotel in New York Mrs. Ansel, who will become an associate in the New York law firm of Shereff Friedman Hoffman & Goodman on June 13, was formerly an associate at Cravath Swaine & Moore. She graduated from the Birch Wathen School and cum laude from both Barnard College and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University. Her father, a dermatologist, is an attending physician at Mount Sinai Hospital, and he practices in New Dorp, S.I.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Turner Leads Corning: Sherri Turner, the winner of last week's Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday at Corning, N.Y., to take the third-round lead in the $325,000 Corning Classic.

title: ROOTS OF THE NURSING GAP ARE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL
description: Even as the United States opened the golden door to millions of unregistered aliens this month in a historic amnesty program, Federal immigration officials threatened to slam it shut on thousands of foreign nurses working in this country's hospitals. A deal negotiated last week in Washington will keep the door open for another year. But it was a short-term solution at best to the critical need for nurses in New York and many other cities, a shortage that some economists blamed on efforts in the early 1980's to cut health-care costs.

title: F. W. Lafferty Jr. And Hilary Eddy Married in Jersey
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., Hilary Clark Eddy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Eddy of Short Hills, was married yesterday to Frederick Wayne Lafferty Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lafferty of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David B. Earnest and the Rev. Richard G. Jordan, a great-uncle of the bride.

title: More Resisting Transfers to New York
description: AS the gap between housing costs in different cities widens, corporate relocation officials are meeting stiffer resistance to transfers from employees who fear the move will leave them paying more money for less house.

title: Recycling Isn't as Easy As It Sounds
description: I have to respond to Brenda Corbin's and Jane Feder's responses [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 17 ] to Steven A. Meyerowitz's article ''Garbage In, Garbage Out'' [ Opinion Page, March 31 ] . While all their suggestions sound easy and wonderful, the practicality of recycling is not always as simple as it seems. I heartily agree conservation begins at home, but . . . Addressing the various points: I live in a rental apartment complex in Mineola, in the Town of North Hempstead, which has a recycling law on the books. When the town began handing out orange buckets to hold glass, I wrote and called the village and the town to find out how an apartment dweller could comply with the new regulations - to no avail. We have private collection; we dump all our trash in large Dumpsters, which are then taken away in bulk. (I collect returnable bottles in a department store shopping bag, hanging under a kitchen countertop.) But the trash collector obviously does not separate the trash. We have no place to place the piles of newspapers, or glass, or cans. An apartment has practically no room for normal storage (clothes, etc.). Where on earth would we put things to take to recycling centers?

title: A 2-Year, 2-Wheeled Tour Of the Corporate Landscape
description: Apple Computer executives keep popcorn machines in their headquarters lobbies and meet in rooms named after television soap operas. Owens-Corning Fiberglas executives hand out Fiberglas business cards.

title: Room With a Nurse: Cuba's 'Health Tourism'
description: Not long ago, Olga Bencosme's doctor discovered a large stone in her left kidney and recommended that she have it pulverized by laser beams. Since there is no equipment for such a procedure in the Dominican Republic, the doctor suggested that Mrs. Bencosme go to the United States, West Germany or Cuba.

title: India's Tentative Turnaround
description: THREE years ago, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi introduced a sweeping program of economic changes more in tune with Ronald Reagan's supply side gospel than the decades of socialist orthodoxy he had inherited in India. He slashed regulations, import barriers and taxes and demanded that Indian industry modernize and learn to compete, to hasten the nation's march into the 21st century.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS FAIL TO COMPLETE NEW ARMS ACCORD
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have failed to complete one and possibly two of the three modest new arms control agreements that American officials hoped would be signed at the Moscow summit meeting, senior Administration officials said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'Bee-Line' Birthday
description: LEAD: The Westchester bus system's ''Bee-Line'' name and logo - a smiling cartoon bee zooming toward a destination - are celebrating their first birthday this month.

title: Delhi Cupola Waits 20 Years for the Mahatma
description: In the heart of this capital, behind a large monument built by the British to commemorate the dead of World War I, stands an elegant cupola that once housed a statue of King George V. The cupola is still empty, 20 years after King George was removed from his post there. Because of a continuing controversy about the structure's imperial origins, there is still no sign of the statue of Mohandas K. Gandhi that the Government had pledged to install.

title: Pistons Take 2-1 Lead In Series
description: In the Detroit Pistons' scheme of things, Joe Dumars's role first and foremost is to play defense. He's the stopper Coach Chuck Daly calls upon to try to shut down the hot scorers, be it Michael Jordan or a small forward.

title: Town Turnaround
description: To the Editor:

title: 40,000 Left Soviet in 1987
description: About 40,000 people emigrated from the Soviet Union last year and 20,000 received exit visas in the first four months of 1988, the official press agency Tass said today. It quoted Rudolf Kuznetsov, head of the visa-issuing authority, as saying relatives of about 500,000 Jews, Germans and Armenians who left the Soviet Union after World War II accounted for most of those allowed to leave for family reasons. Others were married to foreigners, he said. Mr. Kuznetsov added that 7,862 adults and 2,109 children immigrated to Israel in 1987.

title: A Fresh Air Fund Retreat for Urban Families
description: On the wooden steps of a cabin porch, Denise J. Ford and her four children sat and pondered some items they had collected in a scavenger hunt: a piece of white birch bark, a cup of pond water, a pine cone and a yellow dandelion.

title: Miss Mitchell Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Lindsay Mitchell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Beatrice Hunnewell Mitchell to Paul Scott Sperry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Sperry of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: Susan Seidelman's Recipe for 'Cookie'
description: As Susan Seidelman calmly sips her cafe au lait in a SoHo patisserie, she resembles a college student who has just cut a class rather than a director who has finished filming her latest caper.

title: Campaigning on the Issues Can Lose More Votes Than It Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tune Is 'Hands Across the Hudson' As 2 Rival Neighbors Try for Harmony
description: More than a river divides New York from New Jersey. The Empire and Garden States have often competed, quarreled and quibbled over a range of issues from Federal grants to garbage, the current topic in serious dispute. Now, however, some House members say they want to extend their hands across the Hudson.

title: Building Toward the Days of October
description: ASSEMBLING a classic car in his garage should be easy for Mookie Wilson, master mechanic, once he made the basic decision he would probably be a Met all season. He just had to uncrate the parts for the 1929 Mercedes and start putting them together.

title: Flights Over Grand Canyon Are Being Further Restricted
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has announced tighter restrictions on sightseeing flights over the Grand Canyon to reduce noise levels and improve safety.

title: A Brother Basks in Reflected Honor
description: I GRADUATED from college 25 years ago this week. It was a simpler time, when a young man (if not yet a woman) could aspire to live better than his parents, when the word ''Vietnam'' lacked emotional content and when ''civil rights'' was only a noble goal, uncomplicated by the politics of empowerment.

title: Lalonde Will Face His First Challenge
description: Don Lalonde of Canada will defend his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title for the first time Sunday against Leslie Stewart of Trinidad.

title: Previous Reagan-Gorbachev Summits
description: GENEVA Nov. 19-21, 1985

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title:
INVESTING;
Behind the Switch Into Bonds
description: LEAD: AN oft-cited reason for the stock market's recent malaise is the higher yields now available on fixed-income securities, particularly United States Treasury bonds. Investors, looking for a better return and presumed safety, are pulling funds out of equities and moving into bonds. But are bonds really a good bet now?

title: NONFICTION
description: LIFE WITHOUT FATHER: Influences of an Unknown Man. By William Wartman. (Franklin Watts, $17.95.) William Wartman focuses in this book on his search for an understanding of his father, who died when the author was a child, and on his own role as a father to his son. As his 30th birthday approached, in 1978, Mr. Wartman (who is the president of the Philadelphia Writers Organization) became aware of certain changes in himself. For months his outlook had been gloomy, his energy level low. He feared he was dying of a brain tumor, as his father had at around the same age; it turned out to be hypoglycemia, but the fear shook him up. He began to ask questions of his mother, who had always kept silent on the subject of his father's death, and other family members. He started to interview people who had also lost their fathers as children. Along the way, Mr. Wartman came to terms with his feelings about his father and realized the importance of his own son to him. In delving into his past and that of others in ''Life Without Father,'' he presents vivid, engaging glimpses into a variety of family situations. The book, written in an accessible style, sometimes slips into facile psychologizing - for instance, the author says in passing that the reason his mother was angry at him when he divorced his wife was that ''to my mother, both my Uncle Jeff and I were Wartman men who left women - as her Wartman man, my father, had left her.'' William Wartman is most interesting - and raises important questions - when he simply describes family dynamics.

title: Two Goons, One Gangster
description: ORPHANS Starring Albert Finney (in photo, left), Matthew Modine (in photo), Kevin Anderson, John Kellogg, Anthony Heald. Directed by Alan J. Pakula. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 115 minutes. $79.95.

title: 'Music Man' Hits the Right Notes
description: IN true musical comedy fantasy, Meredith Willson's ''Music Man,'' now at the Westbury Music Fair, takes a mean-spirited, fast-talking, womanizing con artist and transforms him through the power of love. The musical is on a 14-city tour and, like many of Westbury's big touring shows, is first-class all the way.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: REAL FEARS AND FEAR-MONGERING
description: MEETING THE COMMUNIST THREAT Truman to Reagan. By Thomas G. Paterson. 317 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: Yonkers Schools Assess Progress
description: LEAD: DR. ANDREW A. BEVERIDGE'S first public meeting earlier this month as the newly elected president of the Yonkers Board of Education ended inauspiciously.

title: Cedeno Arrested
description: HE'S out of the major leagues now, but apparently Cesar Cedeno is not out of trouble. The former outfielder with the Houston Astros was arrested Friday in Webster, Tex., on charges of assault, causing bodily injury and resisting arrest after the police said he attacked a woman they identified as Pam Lamon, 32, the mother of his child.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE CULTURE AND THE CABOOSE
description: LEAD: For some 150 years, locomotives, lines of track, depots and subways have served as visual emblems of an industrially transformed landscape and cityscape. It was the railroad, even more than the automobile and the airplane, that exercised a powerful and enduring hold on the American artistic imagination.

title: William W. Flanagan; Professor, 69
description: The Rev. William W. Flanagan, an assistant professor of economics at Fordham University since 1960 and dean of the School of General Studies from 1969 to 1973, died of a heart attack Thursday at Loyola Hall, the Jesuit residence on the Bronx campus. He was 69 years old.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CAPRICE. By George Bowering. (Viking, $16.95.) Remember when the good guys in westerns wore white hats and the bad guys wore black? George Bowering certainly does, and he makes good use of such cliches in ''Caprice,'' a standard revenge story set in the 1890's that throws us some clever curves. Mr.

title: An Expectant Air Hits Muscovites, Who Also Face Struggles at Home
description: President Reagan arrives in Moscow on Sunday to find a city dressed up in new foliage and fresh whitewash, a people curious and expectant but distracted by the political struggles going on in their country.

title: Beating the Price Of Electric Power
description: AT last, Frank and Ellen Magnussen can read in bed without wondering where their next ampere is coming from.

title: Scrambling For 'Bear' Keeps Guard's Fliers On the Alert
description: LEAD: HIGH over the Atlantic, Soviet reconnaissance bombers head down the East Coast on 14-hour flights between northern Russia and Cuba. On an average of once a month, they are only 100 miles from New Jersey's shores, and at those times they always have company.

title: How Shoreham Pact Evolved: Urgent Phone Calls, Town House Meetings
description: The talks that ended the 22-year impasse over the Shoreham nuclear power plant - negotiations that succeeded where a host of others had stalled -began with a newspaper article more than nine months ago.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Linden Takes On a Commercial Image
description: LEAD: FOR the last decade, Linden, once an industrial stronghold, has watched its economic base weaken as major companies reduced their operations or moved away, leaving the city to founder.

title: 2 Jersey Men Ordered To Jail in Snake Case
description: A former firefighter and a snake trainer have been sentenced to 90 days in jail each for putting three rattlesnakes in a woman's apartment.

title: Nicole Sinek Wed to Leo Arnaboldi 3d
description: Nicole Irene Sinek, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Herbert Sinek of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Leo Peter Arnaboldi 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnaboldi Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Preston B. Hannibal, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Bedford Historical Hall in Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: No Reason to Believe That Astrology Is True
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Heavy Drinking
description: When it comes time to select new members, some of the undergraduate eating clubs at Princeton University have a drinking ritual that they do not take lightly. After 45 underage students drank themselves sick at Princeton this spring, a New Jersey judge decided not to take the matter lightly either. Last week, in a ruling that shocked Princeton officials, Judge Russell W. Annich Jr. sentenced two student officers of the Princeton Charter Club to 30 days in jail for serving liquor to minors. Kenneth Simpler, the Charter Club president, and Lisa Napolitano, the social secretary, were held responsible for the overindulgence of 45 prospective club members who, after being encouraged to drink large quantities of alcohol at a ''sign in'' party, were treated for alcohol-induced ailments at the university infirmary and a local hospital.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TALLIEN: A Brief Romance. By Frederic Tuten. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) Disillusionment can sound self-pitying, particularly when the theme is revolution betrayed. Frederic Tuten's second novel is an exceptionally erudite and often witty meditation on political and erotic betrayal, but its cleverness does not outweigh its crankiness.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a problem with moss growing on the bricks on my patio. I've tried using weed killer. It works, but only temporarily, and it poses a threat to the surrounding shrubs. Can you suggest anything else?

title:
ABOUT MEN;
Courting Fear
description: LEAD: I HADN'T BEEN A judge long when I first encountered him. That morning he had stormed into a colleague's courtroom, pointed a finger at her and shouted, ''I don't want no woman judge.'' She had retreated to her chambers, calmed herself and phoned me to come to her courtroom to hear the case, mentioning not a word about this man, whom I'll call

title: Bush Tries To Rub Off The Patina
description: With some Republicans worrying aloud whether George Bush is out of touch with the concerns and the argot of average Americans, the Vice President has been eagerly trying to show that he can, in fact, relate to the common man.

title: Basic Skills Are Part of Special Education
description: Jane Goldblatt, in her May 1 letter to the Long Island editor, questions the negative response her letters have received from parents and professionals in the special-education community. She asks if what she has written is so awful.

title: Useful Lives for Obsolete Factories
description: IN the old Manchester factories where workers once toiled to produce the rolls of material that gave the town its nickname as ''The Silk City,'' swimmers now do laps in a pool. In Stamford, where rolls of wallpaper once were produced, diners now eat duck liver pate. In Deep River, residents relax in cozy apartments, carved out of a building where piano keyboards once were assembled.

title: WATER WOES: OTHER VIEWS
description: FOR an experienced science teacher who should know how to develop and research factually correct scientific and technical data, Julian Kane's ''Water Woes: End the Chaos'' was inaccurate and misleading. As an educator, his position appears to be narrow.

title: In Zaire, Rundown Resort Looks to Gorilla Tours
description: Belgian colonists found this paradise of terraced hills and sparkling lakes so enticing that when the Nazis overran Europe in 1939 and began talking of a 1,000-year Reich, some of the colonists began talking about building a Belgium-in-exile here in what they called ''the Switzerland of Africa.''

title: Realism Enters Student Publishing
description: ALTHOUGH the recent Supreme Court decision affirming schools' rights to censor student newspapers might have an overall negative impact, one unintended positive feature is that student writers will now get a more realistic view of how the publishing world works.

title: Headliners; Heavy Heart
description: Andrzej Piotr Prajzner, a Polish seaman, jumped ship in Canada two months ago only to land in jail. Mr. Prajzner, who wound up behind bars in Everett, Wash., after crossing the border and seeking political asylum in the United States, was released on bail pending appeal last week. The 27-year-old fishing boat cook said it was ''wonderful'' to be ''finally free.'' But he may yet wind up not only back in Poland, but in a Polish jail. His release from jail came amid a wave of sympathy from Seattle-area residents who contributed to his bail money after learning that Mr. Prajzner had been denied political asylum and jailed as an illegal immigrant. Mr. Prazjner, who is now awaiting a court date to appeal the asylum denial, said that if returned to Poland, he would be ''imprisoned for jumping ship and seeking asylum.''

title: 'If He Loses This Fight, No More Commercials'
description: OUT in the seventh-floor auditorium of the Manhattan Center on West 34th Street, the extras had been standing around, waiting for Mike Tyson, wondering why nothing was happening. The world heavyweight champion had interrupted training in Atlantic City for his June 27 heavyweight title showdown there with Michael Spinks to come up to do a Pepsi commercial. But now Mike Tyson emerged from backstage and was walking out of the auditorium with his wife, the actress Robin Givens, along with his mother-in-law, Ruth Roper, and their attorney, Michael Winston. ''Are you coming back?'' Tyson was asked. ''Maybe,'' he said in that high voice.

title: A Recording a Recording a Recording
description: More and more, the voice at the other end of the telephone line is mechanical. Automatic devices dial numbers, play recorded messages, receive orders and take surveys.

title: A Sudden Tumble Into a New World
description: FOR a variety of reasons, including climate, East Germany does not enjoy a reputation as a vacation paradise. But by accident it became my Club Med for two weeks - Med as in Medical, not Mediterranean. Except for the accident itself the sojourn was a pleasant experience. The idea of becoming ill or sustaining a serious injury in a foreign country is daunting for travelers. Doubts about the quality of medical care may be compounded by the difficulties of communicating in another tongue. While I had the misfortune to fall down hard and snap a large sinew in my right leg, I was lucky to have the accident in the German Democratic Republic. To begin with, I knew the language.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Luring 56 Million Ailurophiles
description: THE camera pans slowly through a softly lit living room. From atop a grand piano, a gray-striped tabby cat mews in response to a car horn, then pads down the keyboard, setting off a soundtrack of Chopin. He runs to a windowsill to greet the family - who arrive in a Volvo.

title: Cara Bachenheimer Wed in Connecticut
description: Cara Conway Bachenheimer and Neal Joseph Reynolds were married yesterday at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan, assisted by the Rev. William George, performed the ceremony.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: I feel that travelers should be warned about the SamTrans 7B bus from San Francisco International Airport, which was mentioned by Betsy Wade in Practical Traveler on March 13.

title: Old Aid Young and Vice Versa
description: LEAD: When Lauretta Freeman was the head of a Montclair day-care center, she began taking children to local nursing homes and observed a powerful chemistry: The young and old immediately hit it off, joining in games and sing-alongs.

title: In Vermont, Dogs Follow Their Noses to Porcupines
description: Something about a porcupine is irresistible to dogs in Vermont. Almost all of them simply have to chase and attack one at least once in their life.

title: Attila Zobor Married To Kerry Lynne Green
description: Grace Reformed Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kerry Lynne Green, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Garland Young Green of Perrysburg, Ohio, to Attila Miklos Zobor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Miklos Zobor of Budapest.

title: Securities Prosecutions Meet Resistance by the Regulated
description: When first blockbuster insider-trading cases were brought almost two years ago, they were hailed as a breakthrough in the effort to stop white-collar crime on Wall Street. But now some securities lawyers maintain that the Government may be endangering its goals with an overzealous pursuit of such cases.

title: Stephanie Crane Is Wed
description: Stephanie Ball Crane, the daughter of Mrs. Robert J. Catto of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Paul T. Crane, and Kenneth James O'Hara, a son of Barbara O'Hara of Norwalk, Conn., and Kieran J. O'Hara of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Somers, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. Irving S. Pollard. The bride is a public-relations specialist with Jane Matthews Promotions in New Canaan. The bridegroom, a real-estate broker, is a commercial project coordinator with Architectural Building Systems in Hartford.

title: SOVIET ARMENIANS LET IN IMPROPERLY, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: State Department lawyers have concluded that the United States is improperly accepting thousands of Armenians as refugees without any finding that they have been persecuted in the Soviet Union.

title: The Odd Couple
description: The meeting in Moscow is being put down in some quarters as pure symbolism, without hard news. But what symbolism!

title: Yugoslav Takes Medley
description: Anna Petricevic of Yugoslavia, the 15-year-old daughter of an Olympic champion, won the women's 200-meter individual medley today in 2 minutes 16.90 seconds as the three-day Sundown Swim to Seoul began.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Celebration for the United States Constitution
description: LEAD: HISTORY and art are blended impressively on a new medal issued by the United States Capitol Historical Society. The medal is part of an ongoing series and commemorates ratification of the United States Constitution.

title: Elizabeth L. McGovern To Marry in September
description: Elizabeth Laird McGovern and Philip MacLaren Johnstone plan to marry in September, the parents of the future bride, James W. McGovern of New York and Mrs. William B. Cutler of Stonington, Conn., have announced.

title: Grand Canyon
description: To the Editor: By the fourth day of a rafting trip down the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon, Franz Lidz found things ''a little dull'' and by the fifth day he ''started wishing for an escape helicopter.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ART AUCTION The artists on the East End are a generous lot; show them a good cause, be it social or political, and they usually respond wholeheartedly. The Retreat, a nonprofit, nonsectarian organization that provides counseling, emergency shelter and guidance to local victims of family violence, gains from this traditional attitude today via an auction of works donated by more than 50 painters and sculptors. The list of donors is a veritable Who's Who, both past and present, of artists in the region, with such names as Elaine de Kooning, James Brooks, Robert Dash, Paul Davis, Audrey Flack, Howard Kanovitz, Ibram Lassaw, Neil Noland and Joseph Novak among them. The roll call of celebrity sponsors includes Arlene and Alan Alda, Kay and Warner LeRoy, Gloria Jones, Barbara Goldsmith and Frank Perry. The auction is today at 11:30 A.M. at the Laundry restaurant on Race Lane in East Hampton. It will cost $50 for a chance to bid for the works, which will start at $500. 'COOL CABARET' Another tradition on the East End insists that there's a new tradition born every year. So tonight, Guild Hall, East Hampton's seat of culture, gets into the pop swing of things with the first of three ''Cool Cabaret'' concerts at the center's John Drew Theater. The opening performer is Cissy Houston, the soul, gospel, pop and jazz singer who just happens to be the mother of Whitney Houston and the aunt of Dionne Warwick, and also a founding member of the Sweet Inspirations, the 60's group that sang backup for Elvis and Aretha. Ms. Houston will be followed by Gail Wynters, a classical jazz and gospel singer-songwriter, on June 18 and Nanette Natal, the jazz singer-composer, on June 25. All three concerts are at 8 P.M. For ticket information call 324-4050. COUNTRY MUSIC

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Remember, when we came out with the 2.4 percent, how all you guys in the press called it a rosy forecast?'' - Beryl W. Sprinkel, the Administration's top economist, on the 3.9 percent rise in G.N.P.

title: SHOREHAM SAGA COMES TO A BITTER END
description: The issue that was to spell doom for the Long Island Lighting Company's $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant was first raised when Lilco sought a construction permit for the project more than two decades ago: Could Long Island be evacuated in case of a nuclear accident?

title: Headliners; Heavy Traffic
description: Something led customs agents to suspect that Rigoberto Regalado Lara, the Honduran Ambassador to Panama, was not on a diplomatic mission when he arrived in Miami earlier this month. They took a look through Mr. Regalado's luggage and reported that they found 26 pounds of cocaine. Honduras, whose military is headed by Mr. Regalado's half-brother, expressed astonishment. It dismissed Mr. Regalado from his diplomatic post, invited American authorities to prosecute him - he was indicted last week on drug trafficking charges - and all but took credit for his arrest. A Honduran communique said: ''This once again is a demonstration that the Government of Jose Azcona Hoyo is engaged in open warfare against drug trafficking.''

title: WETENSCHAP IS WAT WETENSCHAPPERS DOEN
description: FLANAGAN'S VERSION A Spectator's Guide to Science on the Eve of the 21st Century. By Dennis Flanagan. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Two Journeys
description: President Reagan's arrival in Moscow today marks the end of a long ideological journey. He has gone from a sense of anxiety over the Russians to a new confidence in possibilities for negotiation. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, too, has made a remarkable passage, from anti-American Communist boss to pragmatic leader willing to make compromises that will help him change his country's course.

title: Fresh Air Fund to Give 7,500 Children a Change
description: BACK in the early 1960's, the bus ride from New York City's Port Authority Terminal to Hamilton Square in Mercer County took about an hour and a half, but still enough time for 6-year-old Nancy Gines to come up with a new name.

title: Choosing Plants For Fall Bloom
description: NOW is the time to think about fall.

title: Apt Setting For O'Neill Sea Plays
description: In this centennial year of Eugene O'Neill's birth, a small San Francisco theater company is mounting four of his earliest one-act plays in a way that would surely have appealed to the playwright. Until June 17, the Glencairn Cycle of ''sea plays'' -comprising ''Moon of the Caribees,'' ''In the Zone,'' ''Bound East for Cardiff'' and ''The Long Voyage Home'' - is being staged with every authentic nuance that could be wished, aboard a 19th-century Pacific Coast lumber schooner moored off Fisherman's Wharf.

title: TODAY'S SUMMIT SCHEDULE
description: Times are local. Helsinki is seven hours ahead of Eastern daylight time; Moscow is eight hours ahead. 10:50 A.M.: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, leave Government guest house in Helsinki en route to airport, where they will say goodbye to President Mauno Koivisto and his wife, Taimi, and to the United States Embassy staff. 11:30 A.M.: Departure from Helsinki for Moscow. 2 P.M.: Arrival at Vnukovo Airport, where President Andrei A. Gromyko and his wife, Lidiya, will greet the Reagans. 2:45 P.M.: Arrival at Kremlin. Reagans will proceed to St. George's Hall, where they will be greeted by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa. Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan will make brief remarks. 3:15 P.M.: Mr. Reagan meets Mr. Gorbachev in St. Catherine's Hall. 4:10 P.M.: President leaves Kremlin for Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, where the Reagans will spend the night. Evening is private. TELEVISION COVERAGE ABC News, NBC News: Reports on President Reagan's arrival in Moscow will be carried live from 6 A.M. to 8 A.M., Eastern daylight time. CBS News: Live coverage from 9 A.M. to 10:30 A.M. CNN: Live coverage from 6 A.M. to 6:20 A.M., from 6:45 A.M. to 7 A.M., and at other intervals through the morning.

title: Jennifer R. Just, a Producer, Plans to Marry F. C. Darling
description: Jennifer Ramsey Just and F. Corey Darling plan to marry Sept. 10. The parents of the bride-to-be, Ward Swift Just of Paris and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Mrs. Robert Turrell Bower of Washington and Quoque, L.I., have announced the engagement. Mr. Darling is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Frank C. Darling of Orchard Park, N.Y.

title: The Sexy Image Is Out of Place In Business
description: AMERICAN women are under siege. And some of us have met this enemy before in . . . Was it 1950? 1964? The exact years seem to blur, but the image is clear and the ominous signs are appearing once more. Unless you have been on the moon or in hibernation for the last six months, you know that short skirts are back.

title: Interpretations of Stravinsky Pianola Rolls
description: The pianola is a curious mechanical instrument that figures briefly in the history of musical reproduction and also in the story of Igor Stravinsky's career. But before Rex Lawson's recital of Stravinsky pianola rolls Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall can be described intelligibly, some explication is required.

title: Television Turns Tribunal: Waldheim on Trial
description: ''All rise!''

title: On Defining Motives At Landmark Sites
description: One point in the May 15 Opinion Page article by Karolyn Wrightson, executive director of the Westchester Historical Society, needs to be clarified [ ''Designating Landmarks: Beware Hidden Agendas'' ] . She refers to some people mouthing historical preservation ''not to discover their Indian heritage but to keep open space and protect their property values from the development.''

title: Ms. Robins, an Author, Weds Daniel Caccavo
description: The marriage of Madeleine Eve Robins, the daughter of Seymour Robins of Sheffield, Mass., and the late Barbara George Robins, to Daniel James Caccavo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Emil Caccavo of Roslyn Heights, L.I., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's father. Terry Koldys, a justice of the peace in Great Barrington, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Rozelle To Wed Oct. 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pete Rozelle of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Rozelle's daughter, Anne Marie Rozelle, to Douglas K. Bratton, the son of Iris K. Bratton of Concord, N.C., and the late Carl H. Bratton. The wedding is to be Oct. 8.

title: Restoring Windowsills
description: WOODEN windowsills receive a great deal of abuse from weather. Unless they are carefully maintained, moisture can enter the wood and foster decay. The only effective repair for badly rotted windowsills is replacement, a tricky job even for experienced carpenters.

title: Flopsy, Mopsy at the Morgan
description: ''My dear Noel,'' the letter began. ''I don't know what to write to you today, so I shall tell you a story about four little rabbits whose names were Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail, and Peter.'' Written in 1893, it was from Beatrix Potter to Noel Moore, the 5-year-old son of her former governess. Miss Potter, then 27, illustrated it with drawings now familiar to generations of children around the world as ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' The letter is the crown jewel in an exhibition of Beatrix Potter's many works at the Morgan Library in New York.

title: Debt Payout Key Factor In Accord On Lilco
description: SEEKING to line up support for a negotiated settlement to keep the Shoreham nuclear plant closed, state officials have argued that restoring the Long Island Lighting Company to an investment-grade utility would save tens of millions of dollars a year, chiefly by enabling Lilco to refinance much of its $3.6 billion in debt.

title: HIGH ON THE ONE ABOVE
description: MASTER OF THE RETURN By Tova Reich. 240 pp. San Diego: A Helen & Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Informal Dining in Westport
description: ONE of the newer eateries in Westport, 3 Bay Street (subtitled ''an American Grille''), is the kind of drop-in place that can be very appealing in a small community. A friendly staff and a simple, attractive menu make for an informal alternative to fancier, special-occasion dining.

title: Freud's Father
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Chief Plans to Broaden Base
description: ASSEMBLYMAN John C. Cochrane, the new Suffolk Republican chairman, is frank about the limits of his power now that a Democrat is County Executive and the County Legislature is divided and rebellious.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $360,000 6 Lawrence Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; family room, 2 fireplaces, c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200. Bluepoint $198,000 72 Wilson Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old ranch; dining room, family room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Glenwood Landing $243,000 8 King Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; family room, basement, bay windows, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100. Lattingtown $260,000 115 Valley Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; dining room, den with fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,800. Mineola $185,000 31 Westbury Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 50- by 100-foot lot, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100. Patchogue $105,000 90 Patchogue Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; basement, sunporch; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Old Lyme, Conn. $162,500 16 Ridgewood Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, old summer cottage; fireplace, beach association fee $288 yearly, 50- by 90-foot lot; taxes $975. Mount Vernon, N.Y. $257,500 55 Harding Parkway 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old Tudor; eat-in kitchen, living room with fireplace, oak floors, .12 acre; taxes $2,800. Belleville, N.J. $125,000 112 Mill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, two-year-old condominium town house; 4-zone heating, garage; monthly maintenance $127, taxes $3,069.

title: Delicate Fleece From Alaska's Musk Ox
description: IT has been called the golden fleece of the Arctic, as soft as cashmere, as warm as alpaca. The material, Qiviut, spun from the winter underwool of domesticated musk oxen, is produced only in minuscule amounts and exclusively in Alaska. There, it is fashioned into light, lacy garments by a cooperative of native Alaskan knitters.

title: Immigration
description: To the Editor: I would like to suggest that Newark Airport should seriously consider improving and expanding the immigration procedure for incoming overseas flights. If a full jumbo jet arrives from Europe, many non-U.S. citizens have to wait up to an hour or more to clear immigration.

title: Rockefeller Family Is Honored
description: LEAD: FOR Rodman C. Rockefeller charity began at home. The 56-year-old son of the late Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller remembers ''learning to be concerned about people'' and recalls noticing as a very small child that ''The New York Times Neediest Cases was something my family spent a lot of time on.''

title: Balancing Growth and Open Space
description: IN 1761, the London artist Thomas Pownal visited the New World and sketched ''A View of the Falls on the Passaick [ sic ] in the Province of New Jersey.'' He showed a pristine wilderness, one with vast pine trees climbing up the sides of a ravine bisected by an cataract ending in a churning river.

title: Mavericks Finally Feel Right at Home
description: After suffering two embarrassing losses in Los Angeles, the Mavericks recovered a measure of respect Friday night with an impressive 106-94 victory over the Lakers.

title: Reforms Pledged at Troubled Nassau Jail
description: LEAD: STUNG by a report that found major management shortcomings in the county jail in East Meadow, Nassau County officials have promised a program of reforms.

title: Judith Bernstein Is Wed in Boston
description: The marriage of Judith Ellen Bernstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Bernstein of Minneapolis, to William Garretson Atkinson 3d, a son of Martha Logan Atkinson of Norwich, Conn., and Mr. Atkinson Jr. of Gales Ferry, Conn., took place last evening in Boston. Rabbi Albert S. Axelrad officiated at the Boston Harbor Hotel.

title:
THE NATION;
WHERE THE WHITE-COLLAR INMATE STAYS
description: LEAD: There are no cells or perimeter walls at the Federal Prison Camp at Lompoc, where Ivan F. Boesky, convicted of insider stock trading, is serving a three-year sentence. At the minimum-security prison, a continent away from Wall Street and 150 miles north of Los Angeles, inmates live in former Army barracks lined with bunk beds and cots, sleeping 6 to 40 men per room.

title: The Export Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing; European Horse First in Red Smith
description: Pay the Butler, who had won just two of 17 starts against weaker competition in France and Germany, ran down Equalize to win the Red Smith Handicap by a neck yesterday at Belmont Park and provide one bettor with the largest pick-six payoff in New York racing history.

title:
GARDENING;
Containers Add Color and Reduce Care
description: LEAD: PEOPLE living in condominiums or apartments don't have the option of going out to plow the back 40 or replace part of the lawn with flowers or vegetables. For them, containers may be the only choice in gardening. There are also good reasons for homeowners with plenty of space to confine much of their gardening to containers.

title: STREETSCAPES: Public School 72; A Big, Solid Centenarian That Still Exudes Potential
description: SCHOOL buildings had been put up in the village of Harlem as early as the 1840's. But by the 1870's the arrival of the elevated lines on Second and Third Avenues encouraged tenement and rowhouse construction, and in 1879 the Board of Education filed plans for a school stretching along the entire blockfront on the west side of Lexington Avenue from 105th to 106th Streets, the first such in the city.

title: Swimming and Friends Through Fresh Air Fund
description: LEAD: SWIMMING is one thing that 12-year-old Eddie Dietz loves, even though he has only two weeks each year to practice his stroke.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE WARSAW GHETTO: A Christian's Testimony. By Wladyslaw Bartoszewski. Translated by Stephen G. Cappellari. (Beacon, $14.95.) Published 45 years after the tragic uprising against the Nazis in one of the major Jewish communities of its day, this small (much too small) book by an eminent Polish historian is a moving mix of documentary evidence and firsthand experiences.

title: There Is Much Outdoor Work to be Done
description: WEED, plant and mow. These three deeds are important to catch up after too many days of rain. Three Days

title: Opera Tunes Up With Business
description: THE Connecticut Grand Opera season has ended, but its leaders are busy with meetings promoting the company.

title: Day Care, Child Care, Word Care
description: CHILD CARE,'' writes Lisbeth B. Schorr in ''Within Our Reach: Breaking the Cycle of Disadvantage,'' a new book being lapped up by politicians eager to show an interest in families without actually having to kiss babies, ''. . . must go beyond custodial care to provide intellectual stimulation'' and then on to ''nurturance, hugs, approval, and responsiveness.'' >Nurturance I can figure out. This cuddly new vogue term was created by the nounification of the verb >nurture (originally a noun itself, from the Latin for ''suckle, nourish'') and was coined in 1938 on the structural analogy of >governance for ''the process of governing.'' But when did the old baby-sitting day care become the hot domestic issue now called >child care? >Child care came first. In 1915, the novelist Jean Webster wrote about the need for ''modern, humane views on the subject of child-care,'' with the general meaning of ''oversight or supervision of a young child.'' Not until the Depression of the early 1930's did >day-care center come on the linguistic scene as Congressional bureaucratese for >nursery.

title: A Gain for the Bald Eagle
description: A pair of bald eagles has built a nest in Massachusetts for the first time since early this century, an occurrence that wildlife officials call a major step toward restoring a breeding population in the state. The nest was spotted in a red oak tree near the Quabbin Reservoir in central Massachusetts. It was built by a young female and by the first male eagle that the state raised and released in a six-year attempt to restore the endangered birds.

title: Lancaster County Comes to Pelham
description: NORMALLY, it is New York that goes to Lancaster County - to savor the food, buy the crafts, marvel at the anachronistic Amish and so on. In an unusual reversal, this hive of Pennsylvania tourism has come to Westchester by way of ''The Pennsylvania Germans: Decorative Arts,'' at the Pelham Art Center in Pelham.

title: OLDER MIGRANTS' YEARS OF TOIL IN SUN END IN COLD TWILIGHT
description: In a $3-a-night flophouse, as younger men share a quart bottle of malt liquor, Alberto Gonzalez is asked what he has to show for a half-century of bone-aching labor on America's farms.

title: Sweating in the Dark Over Shoreham
description: It was a bad cause - plowing under the $5 billion Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power station - that brought out Governor Cuomo's mastery of politics. Mastery is the only word to describe his accomplishment, but it is unlikely to be the last word.

title: Article 196788 -- No Title
description: A fire on the Redondo Beach pier on Friday gutted 13 restaurants and stores, causing at least $5 million in damage, the authorities said. Ken Montgomery, the city public works director, said the fire burned 34,000

title: Notebook; A Revived Salazar Fits Right In as Symbol of Tigers' Style
description: Luis Salazar is so much Sparky Anderson's kind of player, it's no wonder that it was love at first sight. Well, maybe not exactly first sight, but it was love, and Salazar is one of the reasons Anderson is at it again.

title: POETIC INJUSTICE
description: Come, Citizen Dog, we have chosen the short straw. - Henri Coulette, ''The Blue-Eyed Precinct Worker,'' from ''The War of the Secret Agents''*

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland; Rejuvenating A Landmark
description: A $280 million redevelopment plan is intended to bring new life to the landmark 52-story Terminal Tower building, since 1930 one of this city's most prominent structures.

title: REAGAN'S EVOLUTION: A CHANGE OF HEART AS WELL AS TATICS?
description: President Reagan arrives in Moscow today at the end of a long ideological journey. In the last seven years, he and his Administration have moved from virulent sloganeering to sober diplomacy, crossing a rough landscape now strewn with the ruins of myths about the Soviet Union. They have gone from a sense of anxiety about America's capacity to confront the Russians to a new confidence in possibilities for negotiation and compromise.

title: A Fresh Air Friend Brightens the Summer
description: AS Grace Razukas tells it, her son, Peter, and his Fresh Air Fund friend, Darryl Connor, used to spend summer evenings catching lightning bugs in jars. According to Peter, however, they caught them in their hands.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE AGE OF WONDER. By Michael Grieg. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) Given the current increase in the numbers of the elderly, a tale of the love between a man and woman in their 60's should make pertinent reading. If we are not that age, we shall be. What has life got in store? Alas, the retired San Francisco journalist Michael Grieg's second novel is not very enlightening.

title: Plan to Raise Starting Pay Of Teachers
description: A PROPOSAL by Governor Kean to raise minimum teachers' salaries to $22,000 for the 1988-89 school year may be in trouble.

title: An Evening of Chamber Works by Alfred Schnittke
description: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art last Sunday evening, a whole program was devoted to the chamber music of Alfred Schnittke, widely hailed in recent years as the successor to Shostakovich among Soviet composers. Four big works spanning two decades were played: a violin and piano piece called ''Quasi una Sonata'' (1968), a piano quintet dated 1972-76, a three-year-old string trio and a new sonata for piano that had its world premiere at the concert.

title: Jersey Man Is Charged in Killing Of Woman Who Had Aided Him
description: A 19-year-old man has been charged with killing a mother of four who had befriended and sheltered him and whose body was found today on the side of a road, authorities said.

title: Jennifer Gant Marries Daniel Massey Tovell
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Gant, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Gant of New Hartford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Massey Tovell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold M. M. Tovell of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Wilferd Hansel, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony aboard the sightseeing vessel Rip Van Winkle on the Hudson River off Kingston, N.Y.

title: Interest Groups, By Any Other Name
description: As a citizen of, I trust, reasonably responsible concern, I am disturbed by what I read about interest groups. And especially, as one who votes Democratic with some certainty, by what I hear of the grave subordination of past and present Democratic candidates to their influence.

title: The Art of Making A Classical Career
description: Although he has still only rarely appeared live in New York - more concerts are expected this coming season - the violinist Nigel Kennedy has attracted considerable attention, and the reasons say a good deal about careers in present-day classical music.

title: Propane Inspection: Spot Checks on Highway
description: Trucks carrying propane are supposed to conform to strict Federal and state regulations, but enforcement is generally left to spot road checks and inspections by the gas companies themselves.

title: Namibians See Soviet Talks as Way Back Home
description: In coming days, when evening settles over the plank cabins and thatched huts in the hills here, Namibian exiles will gather around their shortwave radios, straining to follow crackling and fading reports from the Moscow summit talks.

title: BENEVOLENT POSSESSIONS
description: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS By Richard Wilbur. 393 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $27.95.

title: KEROUAC AT THE END OF THE ROAD
description: I grew up in the 50's in St. Petersburg, Fla., which is probably as close to growing up in a test tube or sitcom as any natural child will get.

title: Mattingly Sidelined At Least 2 Weeks
description: The mild aftershocks of the Don Mattingly injury were still rippling through the clubhouse late Friday night. The Yankees had gotten by for one night, but now they were looking at the possibility of life - at least on a short-term basis - without baseball's best player.

title: Growth Outpaces All the Forecasts
description: Economic growth is exceeding expectations. The gross national product expanded at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the first quarter, a sharp revision from the 2.3 percent initial figure that was reported a month ago. The Administration had forecast that the economy would expand 2.4 percent in 1988. Sharply higher exports more than offset the effects of somewhat sluggish domestic demand. Such strength produces fears of inflation, but the G.N.P. report's price deflator put the inflation rate at 1.7 percent, down from 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 29, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 1 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 4 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.50.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 4 12 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 5 3 DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.50.) A private eye's trip through space and time. 6 4 THE SISTERS, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The rivalry of two sisters, a best-selling novelist and a renowned actress. 7 5 FLIGHT OF THE OLD DOG, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) Meeting Russia's challenge after it has mastered Star Wars technology. 8 4 WINTER HAWK, by Craig Thomas. (Avon, $4.95.) A Soviet plot to launch a Star Wars weapon on the eve of the signing of a disarmament treaty. 9 1 TENDER REBEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A Scottish heiress accepts the aid of a handsome rake in her search for a husband in Georgian London. 10 9 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) An Australian town where men dominate but women rule. 11 4 THE THANATOS SYNDROME, by Walker Percy. (Ivy, $4.95.) A psychiatrist searches for the cause of his fellow townsmen's strange behavior. 12 * 12 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) World War II in Europe and the Pacific and how it affects 10 people. 14 26 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.)
