Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 4 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 2 1 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 3 240 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 4 4 GRACE, by James Spada. (Dell, $4.95.) The life of Princess Grace of Monaco. 5 2 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) The information that ''every American needs to know.'' 6 4 INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. 7 81 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 8 * 2 LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI, by Nien Cheng. (Penguin, $8.95.) China's Cultural Revolution as experienced by a wealthy woman accused of spying for the West. 9 * 66 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 10 * 18 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Avon, $4.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 10 SOMETHING UNDER THE BED IS DROOLING, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 6 YOU CAN HEAL YOUR LIFE, by Louise L. Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 17 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 4 53 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 1 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Stars for a Jones Beach Musical Summer
description: Bob Dylan, Steve Winwood and James Taylor are among the performers who are to appear this summer in the sixth season of music at the Jones Beach Theater at Wantagh, L.I.

title: Island's Lawmakers Find Roles Far Away
description: LEAD: AT a recent Capitol Hill news conference, Representative Robert J. Mrazek was at center stage before a roomful of reporters, two television cameras and a newspaper photographer -none of them from New York.

title: POSTINGS: Bronx 2-Families; Church Backs 18-Unit Pilot
description: An 18-unit pilot project for a Nehemiah-style moderate-income housing program sponsored by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will break ground at Tiffany and 163d Streets in the South Bronx on Tuesday. The success of the project, in which nine two-family homes will be built for $1.385 million, will determine the prospects of a program to build 1,000 more such units in the South Bronx and 1,000 others elsewhere in the city and in seven suburban counties, at 200 units per year.

title: Woman Robs 6-Year-Old Boy At a Supermarket on L.I.
description: A 6-year-old boy, holding a fistful of nickels he had just gathered from a soda bottle return machine, was knocked to the ground yesterday morning by a woman who then stole his $3 in change and fled, the Nassau County police said.

title: No Reason to Believe That Astrology Is True; Stellar Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA BANK: May 29, 1988
To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: A Savage Painting Raises Troubling Questions
description: One of the uglier and more farcical artistic developments in recent memory has been unfolding in Chicago, where political intervention in a private competition has underlined and perhaps deepened racial divisions within the city and raised issues of First Amendment rights. It has also called attention to the appropriateness of iconoclasm when it is not directed against a person or an institution firmly in power.

title: Bronx-Ardsley Bond Fulfills Two Dreams
description: WHEN 12-year-old Angelo Romero leaves Public School 75 in the Morrisania section of the Bronx every day, he says he sometimes runs to his apartment because he is afraid of the drug dealers on the busy streets of his neighborhood. Although he likes New York City, he says he would rather live where there are fewer police cars and the air is cleaner.

title: Sutcliffe Out
description: STILL bothered by back spasms that have apparently been complicated by a torn muscle in his rib cage, Rick Sutcliffe was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the Chicago Cubs yesterday. The move was made retroative to May 21 and the Cubs replaced Sutcliffe with another right-hander, Calvin Schiraldi, who came off the 15-day disabled list.

title: Subsidized Wheat To Soviet Union
description: THE Soviet Union knows a capitalist bargain when it sees one. As a consequence, it is buying more American wheat in 1987-88 than it has bought in 15 years.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MIDDLETOWN TRIATHLON The fifth annual triathlon in Middletown next Sunday will start with a bicycle race, continue with a canoe race and end on foot - 36 miles later.

title: In Ossining, a Campaign to Save a House
description: LEAD: SOME years ago, as an elementary-school student in Philadelphia, Michael Gershman learned about John James Audubon, the famous 19th-century naturalist.

title: Putting Housing Stock to Best Use
description: INTENSIVE use of the existing housing stock is an important strategy for Westchester in combating its housing crisis. The basic dimensions of the problem are well known. The average sale price of single-family homes has soared to more than $357,000 and average condominium units sell for more than $170,000. The typical Westchester family has only three-quarters of the income needed for even a condominium unit.

title: Master of the 'Whereas And Therefore'
description: LEAD: WHEREAS Janet Lokay, an administrative aide in the office of public affairs of the office of the County Executive, is changing jobs, and whereas Ms. Lokay will begin working as an administrative aide in the County Information Center May 31, and whereas she has in her career in government written thousands of proclamations announcing everything from Frozen Food Month to Armenian Martyrs Day, now, therefore, it seems appropriate to glimpse briefly at Ms.

title: Review/Dance; Sydney Company's Version Of Mann's 'Death in Venice'
description: Graeme Murphy's ''After Venice'' for the Sydney Dance Company raises the question of how literature should be used as a source for ballets. In theory, source materials should be just that: inspirations for flights of choreographic fancy, rather than models to be slavishly followed.

title: INTO THE HEART OF THE CONTINENT
description: AN AMERICAN MEMORY By Eric Larsen. 227 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $12.95.

title: WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
description: Because it is in the best interest of CBS and the N.B.A. to have the Celtics and Lakers alternate. Whose turn is it this year, anyway? CHRISTOPHER T. MANN New York

title: In Government, a Renaissance in Record-Keeping
description: GOVERNMENT'S growing involvement in historic preservation is the driving force behind most new job opportunities in history.

title: A Chamber Festival That Continues to Dare
description: THE state's oldest, longest and most venturesome chamber music festival is getting ready for action again.

title:
DINING OUT;
In Morristown, Then Gladstone
description: LEAD: THE POLO CLUB in Morristown used to be called Cafe Beethoven. But when the owner, Douglas Falcone, acquired a liquor license about 18 months ago, he wisely changed the name, and with it the reputation, of the restaurant, and so what had been considered primarily a lunch and light-supper place could now be thought of as a serious restaurant.

title: WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
description: When anyone has reached the pinnacle of their profession, be it athlete or businessman, their thirst for that goal has been quenched. Meanwhile, in the N.B.A, the players on the remaining teams most likely practice a bit more intensely. If one thing can be beneficial in not winning, it is learning from your errors. The championship team may see itself as void of weakness; this subjectivity can produce bad habits. PAUL NEMBACH Flushing, Queens

title: Q and A
description: Going to Cuba

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Wyoming and Montana: Some Westerners Prefer Solitude to Economic Power
description: LEAD: The towering brick smokestack and a mountain of coal-black slag are nearly all that remain of the Anaconda Company smelter. While many people who worked there still call Anaconda home, their numbers have dwindled since the antiquated structure was closed in 1980. The population of Deer Lodge County, of which

title: U.S. Rent Aid for Rural Poor
description: A limited number of low-income rural families in 13 states will be eligible for housing vouchers to help pay their rent, the Department of Housing and Urban Development says.

title:
THEATER;
LUCIAN PINTILIE TENDS 'THE CHERRY ORCHARD'
description: LEAD: Not another ''Cherry Orchard?'' Move over, Peter Brook.

title: OUR MUSCLE-BOUND NAVY
description: Charles R. Morris's otherwise excellent discussion of our carrier-minded Navy has one serious flaw (''Our Muscle-Bound Navy,'' April 24). He fails to discuss the Navy's long-stated intention, in the event of war, of operating two to four carriers in a single battle group. Adapting the author's figures, this means that the battle group could launch 48 to 96 F-14 fighters carrying 288 to 576 Phoenix missiles to meet the oncoming Soviet bombers - not the 24 fighters carrying 144 missiles, which Mr. Morris says would be quickly exhausted.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a problem with moss growing on the bricks on my patio. I've tried using weed killer. It works, but only temporarily, and it poses a threat to the surrounding shrubs. Can you suggest anything else?

title: Rochester Police Killing of a Black Stirs an Outcry
description: The fatal shooting this week of an unarmed black fugitive by a white police officer has stirred a community outcry and a call by a group of black ministers for Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor in the case.

title: What Pritzker Winners Tell Us About the Prize
description: When Gordon Bunshaft and Oscar Neimeyer were named the joint recipients of the Pritzker Prize in Chicago last week, the event marked the end of the first decade of existence for the prize, at this moment the most celebrated architecture award there is. The decision of the Pritzker family of Chicago and its Hyatt Foundation to offer $100,000 each year to a notable architect gave the prize immediate credibility upon its initiation in 1979, not to mention cachet. By 1988 standards, $100,000 is still a handsome piece of change. No wonder architects have come to speak of the Pritzker Prize as their peers in science and literature speak of the Nobel - also a prize that established itself by the magnitude of its award.

title: Daily Rail Service to Cape Is Returning
description: Passenger train service to Cape Cod from throughout the Northeast will more than double this summer. Daily service is returning after a 24-year hiatus under a new agreement between Amtrak and a regional railroad.

title: Nonstop Music
description: The Maison Francaise at New York University celebrates its 30th anniversary with nonstop music from 1 to 11 P.M. today. Many musicians who have performed there over the years will play, with a new soloist or group every half-hour. Admission is free, and the audience may enter or leave at the breaks in the program. The Maison Francaise is at 16 Washington Mews. Information: 998-8750.

title: Remember When Toscanini Forgot?
description: Performing musicians do not like to talk about memory slips, even those of successful rivals. Artists are not superstitious, but why tempt fate? You do not walk under ladders unless you really want to be hit by falling pianos. And yet everyone who plays an instrument or sings or conducts knows and fears these mysterious moments of blackout. Arthur Rubinstein told me that he always approached certain familiar passages uneasily, taught by experience that the bottom could drop out at any moment. His technique for forestalling disaster was to concentrate at that point on something entirely apart from music, perhaps the good dinner he would be enjoying later. His fingers would remember where to go, so long as his head did not set up roadblocks. In effect, the pianist tricked his mind into obeying him. Interestingly enough, this phenomenon of remembering by trying not to remember has a parallel in optics: the best way to observe a bright object such as the sun is to look slightly away from it.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Andover $166,900 2 Scenic Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old contemporary; wall-to-wall carpeting, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,688. Belleville $125,000 112 Mill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, two-year-old condominium town house; 4-zone heating, garage; monthly maintenance $127, taxes $3,069. Hillsboro Township $129,900 1604 Regents Court 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old condominium town house; hardwood floors, patio; monthly maintenance $142, taxes $1,600. Montvale $410,000 6 Concord Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,248. Norwood $675,000 75 Dyer Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; full basement, underground sprinkler system, 1-acre lot; taxes $7,419. Sparta $146,900 146 Glenside Trail 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old colonial; lakeside property, deck, fireplace, sunken living room; taxes $1,956. OTHER AREAS Old Lyme, Conn. $162,500 16 Ridgewood Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, summer cottage; fireplace, beach association fee $288 yearly, 50- by 90-foot lot; taxes $975. Mount Vernon, N.Y. $257,500 55 Harding Parkway 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old Tudor; breakfast room, fireplace, oak floors, .12 acre; taxes $2,800. Glenwood Landing, L.I. $243,000 8 King Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; family room, basement, bay windows, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100.

title: GORBACHEV HAS COME A LONG WAY, TOO
description: President Reagan's trip to Moscow, the first by an American President in 13 1/2 years, is the latest in a series of milestones that have marked Mr. Gorbachev's passage from the orthodox, anti-American outlook of a provincial Communist Party boss to the non-ideological pragmatism that has shaped his policies since he became Soviet leader in March 1985.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TREASURE. By Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt, that underwater master of all seas and the hero of numerous Clive Cussler thrillers, including ''Raise the Titanic,'' is back in another adventure to make boyish hearts of every age leap mouthward. The tale begins on July 15, A.D.

title:
ART;
The Maze as Metaphor
description: LEAD: THE ancient Greek legend of the labyrinth built for King Minos of Crete to imprison the man-eating Minotaur has never lost its fascination. The maze is the very symbol of confusion and disorientation, the trap that confounds efforts to escape. At times life itself seems to be a maze, as our journey along its tortuous pathways leads to wrong turns, dead ends and unknown destinations.

title: Linda Gail Kent Wed To Howell B. Binkley
description: Linda Gail Kent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerol E. Kent of Clarence, N.Y., was married yesterday to Howell Bagby Binkley, a son of Louise Binkley of Winston-Salem, N.C., and the late John E. Binkley Jr. The Rev. Carl Thitchener performed the Unitarian ceremony aboard the yacht Binghamton in Edgewater, N.J.

title: M. I. Fleischer, Investor, to Wed Miss Patterson
description: Edward Patterson of New York has announced that his daughter Lucinda Dear Patterson and Michael Irving Fleischer will be married on June 25. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Fleischer of Vineland, N.J.

title: Sports Officials Want To Throw The Abuse Outta Here!
description: THEY work in a highly charged environment, stadiums and arenas that are cauldrons of emotion, capable of boiling over in an angry outburst whenever the whistle blows or a voice bellows, ''Out!'' And when the judgment and integrity of the officials - the men in blue or gray or black and white zebra-striped shirts - is questioned, it is often done in a manner so vile that it would be considered uncivilized behavior anywhere but on a playing field.

title: M. F. MacDonald To Be Wed in Fall To Allison J. Hart
description: Allison Jeanne Hart and Michael Francis MacDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John MacDonald of Westport, Conn., and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., plan to marry in November, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth N. Hart of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Wakefield, R.I., have announced.

title: D'Amato Urges Latin Nations to Press for Ouster of Noriega
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato urged yesterday that Latin American countries take ''concerted action'' to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama in the wake of the Reagan Administration's failure to negotiate the general's departure.

title: Katherine Flemer To Wed Next Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John W. Flemer of Kingston, N.J., and Vieques, P.R., of the engagement of her daughter Katherine Winn Flemer to William Peter Barrack, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Barrack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The couple plan to marry in October. Miss Flemer, a daughter also of the late Dr. Flemer, is an office manager for Heller Breene Design and Advertising in Boston. She graduated from Boston University. Her father was a veterinarian and the executive vice president of Princeton Nurseries, founded by her grandfather the late William Flemer Jr. The future bridegroom, who graduated from Connecticut College, is a commercial real-estate broker with Spaulding & Slye in Boston. His father is a senior vice president of Texaco in White Plains.

title: E.P.A. Finds More Areas Fail To Meet Clean Air Standards
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has designated more than 100 additional counties that must be counted as part of larger urban areas that fail to meet Federal standards for clean air. The counties are generally in suburban areas farthest from cities.

title: When Lens Shopping, The Length Counts
description: CAMERA and lens manufacturers make a big fuss in advertising about the range of their zoom lenses. No sooner has one ''wide-angle-to-tele'' lens appeared than another, even wider and longer, is announced. The question is, should one buy a lens, or the camera to which it is attached, simply because of the breadth of its focal lengths?

title: Courtney McNeil Is Bride Of Peter Thomas Hatswell
description: Courtney Bliss McNeil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robin McNeil of Weston, Mass., was married there yesterday to Peter Thomas Hatswell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hatswell of Adelaide, Australia. The Rev. David Van Dusen performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Over $60,000 Is Raised to Repair Memorial
description: More than $60,000 has been raised to repair scratches made by vandals on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, it was announced today.

title: TALKING: Assessments; The Way To Fight City Hall
description: A HOMEOWNER in Riverhead, L.I., was appalled last year to discover that the local tax assessor had decided his new waterfront villa was worth $1.3 million. This translated into an annual property tax bill of $22,000.

title: Role Models for Minority Businesses
description: ARTHUR H. XAVIER, a former international power-plant manager, now owns Uniglobe Xavier Travel Corporation, a corporate travel agency in one of White Plains's newest office buildings, at 50 Main Street. Mr. Xavier's business was well capitalized. ''Working overseas for many years, I made a very good salary and I was able to save a considerable amount of it,'' Mr. Xavier said. ''I invested my own money in the agency; buying state-of-the-art computer and office equipment.''

title: Advanced U.S. Cruiser Enters Persian Gulf
description: The United States Navy has introduced to the Persian Gulf one of its billion-dollar Aegis cruisers, among its most sophisticated warships.

title: WATER WOES: OTHER VIEWS
description: THE article ''Water Woes:

title: Julia van Roden Weds Executive
description: Julia McKay van Roden, a daughter of Amy McKay Biddle of Jamestown, R.I., and Donald van Roden of Wyomissing, Pa., was married yesterday to Andrew H. Lerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max R. Lerman of East Falls, Pa. The Rev. Thomas Guthrie Speers 3d performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa.

title: Fare Thee Well
description: ENTERTAINING GUESTS OVER A summer weekend is an undeniable pleasure, and often a considerable effort. Those hosts who tackle the challenge with grace and good will always have a strategy. Some insist on the simplest of meals. Others are sure to have at least one lunch or dinner at a local restaurant. All plan ahead, preparing a good portion of the meals in advance.

title: ON THE WEST BANK, A PEACE NON-RALLY
description: Peace Now held its first demonstration in three years on the West Bank today, and even its leaders acknowledged that the event showed how far the peace movement has drifted from Israel's mainstream.

title: Penalty Is to Quit Smoking
description: A judge has ordered a woman to stop smoking, saying that she cannot afford it because she has five children and no job.

title: A Village of Cypress and Vines
description: ON the green hills that encircle Florence, like a giant Romantic frame for the trim Renaissance architecture of the city below, there lies an ethereal village called Settignano, which has left an indelible mark on the art and literature of the Western world.

title: Surrogate Births for Pay Opposed by State Panel
description: Surrogate motherhood contracts should be declared void and unenforceable in New York and payments to surrogates and brokers should be made illegal, a state panel has recommended.

title: Surrender
description: To the Editor: Samuel G. Freedman's ''A Surrender, of Sorts, to Vacation'' (Travel, April 10) rang true to my experience. I am a stockbroker and had the ''fortunate'' experience of flying to Egypt the Friday before last October's market crash. Abetting my lack of news was the fact that I sailed on a Nile River cruise on Black Monday and did not arrive in Luxor until Thursday evening. The sights were incredible, the river calming, and I approached the point of a New Yorker's definition of relaxation.

title: Jean Santoro Weds
description: Jean Marie Santoro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Santoro of Oakdale, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony C. Marotta, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Marotta of Baldwin, L.I. The Rev. William Daly performed the ceremony at St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church in Bohemia, L.I. Mr. Marotta is a special agent with the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency in Miami.

title: NONFICTION
description: CHARLES LAUGHTON: A Difficult Actor. By Simon Callow. (Grove, $18.95.) Henry VIII, Captain Bligh, Quasimodo, Inspector Javert, Tiberius Claudius - the common denominator, of course, is Charles Laughton, one of the more respected midcentury stage and screen actors on both sides of the Atlantic. In a biography that focuses almost exclusively on the modes and motivations behind Laughton's acting technique, Simon Callow, an English actor and author, theorizes that Laughton's success with such roles ''consisted of driving himself relentlessly to reveal unpalatable aspects of his personality.'' But Mr. Callow also contends that Laughton ''doesn't ask us to identify with [ a characterization ] , because he doesn't identify with it: he is the subject of his own demonstration. His performances never console nor do they sedate: we are moved by the naked truth of them, and by the courage and self-expenditure of the man giving them.'' Mr. Callow is both probing and articulate. He meticulously describes Laughton's 90-odd roles and includes anecdotes and relevant material from reviews, original interviews, letters, Elsa Lanchester's memoir of her husband and Charles Higham's 1976 biography of the actor. But Mr. Callow does nothing to disguise his own adoration. The narrative is peppered with superlatives that cumulatively surpass credibility. Despite the author's evident bias, the reader gets a persuasive account of the madness that figured in Laughton's method. What emerges is an impassioned and dedicated portrait of an unhappy human being who was compelled to confront in his art the internal demons he repressed in his real life.

title: Klan Group Pushes Access to TV in Missouri
description: A monthlong battle over free speech on cable television here has wound up in a deadlock, with no one fully satisfied by the result, including the white supremacist who vows to press his efforts to use television to recruit converts to his brand of racial division.

title: Tulsa on Course
description: THE golf coach at Tulsa, Dale McNamara, earned an unusual distinction yesterday in Las Cruces, N.M. Her team and her daughter won National Collegiate Athletic Association women's golf titles. Melissa McNamara shot a four-under-par 70 and captured the individual title with a 72-hole total of 287 as she led Tulsa to its second National Collegiate Athletic Association women's golf crown. Jean Bartholomew of Duke was two shots behind at 289.

title: October Wedding For Alison Pavia
description: Alison Ruth Simone Pavia, the daughter of George M. Pavia of New York, Water Mill, L.I., and Cannes, France, and the late Ellen Salomon Pavia, plans to be married in October to Franz Werner Paasche, the son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Gottfried Paasche of Toronto. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's father and her stepmother, Dr. Antonia Pavia.

title: Textile Exhibition Flooded
description: A textile exhibition entitled ''The Miracle of Ancient Peru,'' at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery (724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street), has been removed because of flooding on the gallery walls. The show, organized by Jack Lenor Larsen, a textile designer and president of the American Craft Council, is to be re-installed in early fall, Mr. Merrin said.

title: Leslie Rhett Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Leslie Carrere Rhett, a daughter of Harry Moore Rhett Jr. of Huntsville, Ala., and the late Sharon Barbour Rhett, to Leonard Hearne Armistead 3d, a son of Mrs. Jack C. Massey of Nashville and the late Mr. Armistead Jr., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Nativity in Huntsville. The Rev. Dr. George B. Wood performed the ceremony.

title: A Greek Temple That Inspired Steel Sculptures
description: When we look at Anthony Caro's new sculptures, whether in the roof garden on top of the Metropolitan Museum or in the Andre Emmerich Gallery at 4l East 57th Street, it is a good idea to remember that close on 2,500 years ago, and far away, a great temple was raised for the worship of Zeus and the twinned ideals of peace and reconciliation.

title: POSTINGS: Greenbelt-Area Projects; S.I. Mall Generates a Housing Boom
description: Before the Staten Island Mall opened in 1973, the land around it, known as New Springville, supported truck farms and even boasted two private airstrips. But the advent of the mall's 178 stores sparked a housing construction boom in this mid-island location nestled inside the bend of the Greenbelt park area.

title: Preserving - and Profiting From - the Past
description: HISTORY is making a comeback.

title: Freud's Vienna
description: To the Editor: One important bit of Viennese Freudiana that Paul Hofmann did not mention in his excellent article ''Freud's Vienna Begins at Berggasse 19'' is the small Freud monument in the Sigmund Freud Park.

title: Remember the Families on Memorial Day
description: WHILE all war memorials list the names of those who died, or who fought in a conflict, I have never heard of a structure for any war commemorating the families of the deceased. Surely their suffering was almost as great as that of those who gave their lives or saw combat. I know because I belonged to one of those forgotten families.

title: Soviet Hints at a Role in Massacre of Poles
description: Radio Moscow hinted today that the Soviet Union was moving toward recognizing that its security police killed about 12,000 captured Polish officers and noncommissioned officers in a massacre that is the subject of one of the great mysteries of World War II.

title: 'The New Confessions'
description: English comic writing specializes in scrapes and escalations, mild spots of bother that turn into mounting catastrophes. The world may be represented by terrible aunts, as in P. G. Wodehouse, or inept K.G.B. men, as in Anthony Burgess, but it's the same place - not the insane conspiracy found in so much American fiction, but a realm of ridiculous or lugubrious accident, untidily going nowhere, meaning nothing. The unfortunate hero is usually either disagreeable or brainless, morally either a blank or a little on the seedy side, but we come to like him for his lamentably bad luck. He is not a victim, doesn't rise to such dignity, more like the comic who gets spattered by the pie aimed at someone else. We laugh - we laugh a lot -at his modest and unavailing gestures toward introducing order into this confusion.

title: Teachers At Seminar On AIDS
description: ''THE AIDS epidemic,'' Joan Saltzer told a group of 110 teachers here recently, ''means that what we teach them may determine whether they live or die.''

title: ART 'In the Presence of the Past': Bridgeport Exhibition
description: IT looks as if the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport is finally coming out of its shell.

title: Road Work to Resume Following Holiday Halt
description: CONSTRUCTION and maintenance work on New Jersey roads will be resumed Tuesday after the holiday hiatus, except on the Garden State Parkway. There, all lanes will remain open until Wednesday.

title:
MUSIC;
Gershwin Evenings and Mozart and Britten Operas at June Opera Festival
description: LEAD: The approaching fifth summer season of the June Opera Festival has been dubbed the ''Season of Romance'' by Michael Pratt, the festival's co-founder and artistic director.

title: ANTI-SUICIDE FIGHT PRAISED IN JERSEY
description: A two-year effort to understand and prevent adolescent suicide has concluded that school-based programs in which mental health professionals and educators work side by side can significantly reduce the number of teen-age deaths.

title: PADRES STOPPED BY CONE
description: At some point either Friday night or very early yesterday morning and therefore either before he went to sleep or before he was dismissed, Larry Bowa made out his last lineup card. Jack McKeon, seated at what was Bowa's desk as manager of the Padres, found it late yesterday afternoon.

title: Bruins Witness Bizarre Playoffs
description: The National Hockey League, an organization usually able to maintain a low profile with little effort, heaved a sigh of relief Thursday night as the Edmonton Oilers completed a sweep of the Boston Bruins to capture a fourth Stanley Cup and effectively put to rest a tumultuous season.

title: WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
description: Since 1980, out of a possible 16 different teams who could have reached the finals, only four did so. And of those, two - the Celtics and the Lakers - reached the finals a combined total of 11 times. Losing a sixth or seventh game of a close, final series by a few points after winning the previous year is no indication that the team was inferior, or that this year's winner is the new ''dominant force.''

title: Afrikaner Identity
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: EAST COAST ARTS CENTER;
Creating Theater, and a Track Record
description: LEAD: FOUR-AND-A-HALF years ago, Joe Cacaci looked at an empty old stone building and saw a theater.

title: No Reason to Believe That Astrology Is True; 'Heavenly Compulsion'
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH WITHOUT MUZAK
description: LIFE ON EARTH By Sheila Ballantyne. 174 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Penske, Filling First Row, Has Designs on Title
description: The race that annually redefines America's love for the automobile, the Indianapolis 500, will have its usual 33 cars on Sunday, its usual crowd of about 400,000 intense fans, and its usual contingent of Roger Penske-owned race cars.

title: Fortune's Hostages: There But for Grace
description: AHEAD of me on the Avenue of the Americas, a woman in her 70's, frail and holding herself up with a walker, her face lifted to the cold Manhattan rain, pleaded, ''Somebody help me, ple-e-ase. I'm hungry.''

title:
MUSIC;
An Ancient Instrument Takes the Spotlight Again
description: LEAD: From the lovelorn lutenist serenading his 16th-century sweetheart beneath her balcony to the punk-rock idols with their plugged-in, turned-on sound designed to shatter eardrums, the guitar and its relatives have been an important presence in many kinds of music over the centuries.

title: The Limitations Of Summit Talks
description: LEAD: As the Moscow summit meeting approached, Administration officials were talking optimistically about the superpowers negotiating an end to the 13-year-old war in Southern Africa. It's a nice idea: Two heads of state, picking up where lower-level diplomats broke off, agree to cut out the ideological nonsense, send their clients home and establish a just and lasting peace.

title: Giving Support To Mothers at Home
description: The article entitled ''Giving the Proper Credit for Child Care'' (Opinion page, April 24) calls attention, properly, to the lack of credit given to child care givers. Far more serious, I feel, is the lack of credit and support given to today's full-time mothers.

title: MILITARY PLANS 3-STAGE ROCKET TO BE LAUNCHED FROM A B-52
description: The Pentagon plans to build an experimental rocket that would be launched from an airplane to put military satellites into space, Government and industry experts say.

title: With Fish, Hazelnut Oil's Toasted Flavor
description: ALTHOUGH hazelnut oil is usually used in salads, its rich toasted flavor also goes beautifully with fish. The nutty taste is a perfect foil for red snapper, bass and trout or fish steaks such as halibut, swordfish or tilefish. It is even better when fresh herbs such as tarragon, thyme or basil are added.
