title: ROUSSEAU, HOLLYWOOD AND THE UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE
description: THE NEW CONFESSIONS By William Boyd. 476 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Unicef Urges Immunization
description: The number of child deaths in Africa could be cut dramatically if leaders would take a personal interest in promoting immunization programs, according to the United Nations Children's Fund. ''If the immunization program is handled under the personal leadership of the heads of state and governments of Africa, the health of children can be so improved that the 1980 child death rates will be halved by the year 2000,'' Unicef's director, James Grant, said at a news conference here Friday. African leaders are attending a meeting of the Organization of African Unity here.

title: A Painter Finds Far-Flung Influences
description: LEAD: SINCE 1967, when she first stood on a friend's roof and ''looked out on the fields that stretched as far as the eye could see,'' the East End has been a point of departure and a place ''to come home to'' for the painter Sheila Isham.

title: Bush and Dukakis Are Engaging in Early Battle Over the Jewish Vote
description: Neither Vice President Bush nor Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has yet been nominated for President, but their campaigns are reaching out for Jewish voters they expect to influence key states in November.

title: VOTE FOR THE PSYCHE OF YOUR CHOICE
description: CHARACTER America's Search for Leadership. By Gail Sheehy. 303 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Zouk, a Distinctive, Infectious Dance Music
description: Empires can sow wondrous musical hybrids. At the moment, emissaries from across France's past and present domains - Zaire and Senegal and Cameroon in Africa, Martinique and Guadeloupe in the Caribbean - are getting together in state-of-the-art studios in Paris, using American electric guitars and Japanese synthesizers and digital tape decks to assemble pop songs heard around the world. While Peter Gabriel and Talking Heads have found musicians and ideas in Paris, French-speaking performers are creating songs that can easily break language barriers - lately with dance music called zouk (which rhymes with its American variant, juke, and loosely means ''party'') that's rooted in the French Antilles.

title: Elizabeth Eckel Weds
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Haven, Elizabeth N. Eckel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ernest Eckel of Newburgh, N.Y., was married yesterday to William G. Butterly 3d, the son of Eleanor M. Butterly of Milford, Conn., and the late Mr. Butterly Jr. The Rev. John McGuire officiated. The bride is the director of permanent placement at Aubrey Thomas Inc., consultants in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Butterly is an associate in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling.

title: 8 CANDIDATES VIE IN MONTANA RACE
description: Montana's race for Governor, muddied by the withdrawal of the incumbent and the unexpected death of his principal opponent, has left the state with more candidates than it has seen in 16 years.

title: A Good Day Gathering Mushrooms
description: ''THERE are old mushroom hunters, and bold mushroom hunters but there are no old and bold mushroom hunters,'' goes the old saying, by way of explaining that mushroom gathering can be a safe and lifelong sport when practiced with proper caution. That caution is to learn from an expert and don't eat anything unless you are absolutely sure that it is not poisonous.

title: LeFrak Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Hope and Glory Starring Sebastian Rice-Edwards, Geraldine Muir, Sarah Miles, David Hayman, Sammi Davis, Derrick O'Connor, Susan Wooldridge, Jean- Marc Barr, Ian Bannen. Directed by John Boorman. 1987. Nelson Entertainment. 112 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG-13. Some sexually suggestive episodes.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a problem with moss growing on the bricks on my patio. I've tried using weed killer. It works, but only temporarily, and it poses a threat to the surrounding shrubs. Can you suggest anything else?

title: Review/Cabaret; Baby Boomers' Life Stories Played Out in Musical Game
description: ''The Wonder Years,'' an innocuous little revue that attempts to satirize the collective experience of the baby-boom generation, reduces more than three decades of cultural history to a cheery musical game of Trivial Pursuit.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE TROUBLED FACE OF BIOGRAPHY. Edited by Eric Homberger and John Charmley. (St. Martin's, $29.95.) In their introduction to this slim collection of essays, Eric Homberger and John Charmley (who teach American studies and English history, respectively, at the University of East Anglia in England) raise many fascinating questions about the biographer's craft: his relation to his subject, his cultural biases, his desire alternately to glorify, redeem, reinterpret or expose, his commitment to truth or to a shapely, ordered life.

title: Picnics and Strolls and Chamber Airs
description: ''I AM a bag of energy,'' said Ruth Glasser Sommers, the New York cellist who has just about singlehandedly organized the new Dobbs Ferry Chamber Music Festival, ''so even though it's taken an enormous amount of time and running around, when I got the idea for a chamber series in a beautiful place, I just went ahead and did it.''

title: Jane M. Daly Married To Richard M. Potocki
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Jane Marie Daly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Daly of Floral Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard Michael Potocki, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Potocki of Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. Regis Duffy performed the ceremony.

title: The South Will Fly Again
description: LUPE CAVAZOS HAS A PROBLEM with a P-82 Twin Mustang. Cavazos is director of maintenance for the Confederate Air Force, an organization in Harlingen, Tex., whose stated purpose is to preserve the combat aircraft of World War II. There are 140 planes in the C.A.F. fleet, known as the Ghost Squadron, nearly 70 different kinds, most of them American. Almost all are in flying condition. ''We're a flying museum,'' Cavazos says, and indeed every year the C.A.F. puts on an variety of air shows around the nation. But this P-82: since a landing mishap during an exhibition last fall, it has been grounded, its propellers twisted (foreground, above), the landing gear beyond repair.

title: Review/Music; A Zwilich Homage To Handel
description: Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's ''Concerto Grosso 1985,'' which opened the New York Philharmonic's final subscription concert of the 1987-88 season on Friday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall, was written to honor the 300th anniversary of Handel's birth, but its hat tips also to Stravinsky and the Neo-Classical tradition he fostered.

title: PERESTROIKA BEFORE AND AFTER: TWO VIEWS
description: LEAD: REFORMING THE SOVIET ECONOMY Equality Versus Efficiency. By Ed A. Hewett. Tables. 404 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $36.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: PERESTROIKA BEFORE AND AFTER: TWO VIEWS  In light of Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, The Book Review asked a Soviet scholar, as well as an American specialist, to discuss Ed Hewett's book on the Soviet economic system.
description: REFORMING THE SOVIET ECONOMY Equality Versus Efficiency. By Ed A. Hewett. Tables. 404 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $36.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: Excerpts From Reagan Interview by Soviet Journalists on Summit Hopes
description: Following are excerpts from the interview of President Reagan, conducted at the White House by Soviet journalists before the President left Washington. It was broadcast in the Soviet Union today. The text was released today by the White House, which translated the questions from Russian.

title: Elizabeth J. Baer Planning to Wed
description: Elizabeth Jane Baer's engagement to Mark Robert Wilson, a son of Anne Y. Wilson of Nantucket, Mass., and Peter M. Wilson of Green Valley, Ariz., has been made known by her parents, Justice and Mrs. Harold Baer Jr. of New York and Fire Island Pines, L.I.

title: MAMET'S HOUSE OF WORD GAMES
description: The most persuasive praise yet given a David Mamet play came not from the Pulitzer committee, which awarded ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' its drama prize for 1984, but from a group of popsicle salesmen. In December of 1986, a dead month in the popsicle trade, they read the play aloud at the behest of a manager who hoped to head off terminal boredom at company headquarters in a sprawling industrial park south of Los Angeles.

title: Zola Budd's Parental Visit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Line Counts in Focus
description: Along the border between science and commerce strange things happen. Crossing that shifting line, valid scientific concepts sometimes lose their character and change into promotional catchwords. A recent case of this kind occurred in video and involves what is known as the horizontal line count.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE: Twin Cities
description: One of the first signs of spring in Minnesota usually appears in early April, while ice is still on the ground - convertibles full of college students cruising with tops down, eating ice cream cones and pretending they don't have the car heater on full blast.

title: Nicaragua President to Visit New York for Talks at U.N.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua will visit New York City in early June to attend a United Nations conference on disarmament, Information Minister Manuel Espinosa said today.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE CONNECTICUT AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION;
A Century of Solving Nature's Puzzles in a Laboratory
description: LEAD: IN a sunlit laboratory in New Haven, the chief state entomologist, Dr. Louis Magnarelli, held a live tick with tongs and carefully dissected it with a needle.

title: Lauren's 72d St. Redo: But Is It Restoration?
description: IS the flagship store of Polo Ralph Lauren on Madison Avenue a fantasyland creation or a deftly restored building that brings its 1890's heritage back to life?

title: WHAT'S BECOME OF CHILE
description: CURFEW By Jose Donoso. Translated by Alfred MacAdam. 310 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: UNDER THE BEDS OF THE REDS
description: THE KGB Police and Politics in the Soviet Union. By Amy W. Knight. Tables. 348 pp. Winchester, Mass.: Allen & Unwin/Unwin Hyman. $34.95.

title: Paulo Moura, From Brazil
description: Paulo Moura, the Brazilian clarinetist and saxophonist, had a tough time presenting himself at S.O.B's on Wednesday night. His back-up band was as unrehearsed as anything that has been on the stage at S.O.B.'s -keys and rhythms seemed to clash every four bars.

title: George Michael: He'll Last
description: If asked to nominate the one contemporary pop star most likely to be as successful 10 years from now as today, I'd cast my vote for George Michael. The 24-year-old English singer, songwriter and producer is currently enjoying his third consecutive No. 1 single, ''One More Try,'' from a debut solo album, ''Faith,'' that has already sold more than 5 million copies. When Mr. Michael's current tour arrives in New York in August, we can expect the same kind of frenzy that greeted Michael Jackson's ''Bad'' tour. By the end of this year, I would wager, ''Faith'' will have sold close to 10 million copies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government has accepted every single point on the contras' list. I consider this to be a very historic moment.'' - Paul Reichler, of the Sandinista negotiating team. [ 3:4. ]

title: Action at Massachusetts U. Raises Censorship Cry
description: Amid cries of censorship, the Afro-American studies department at the University of Massachusetts here has forced out a prominent black professor for criticizing the black novelist James Baldwin.

title:
ART;
Erudite Sculpture in Montclair
description: LEAD: ERUDITION in contemporary sculpture is a rare thing, but it is a commodity that Jonathan Silver has going for him the most in his boggling installation at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: Lacrosse; Syracuse Faces Cornell in Final
description: The final score was Syracuse 11, Penn 10. Afterward, Chris Flynn, Penn's indefatigable midfielder, said: ''This was the best game of the season. We gave it our all and they beat us with three seconds left to play. What else is there to say?''

title: The Fine Art of Managing Corporate Memories
description: IN 1979, Philip Cantelon, president of History Associates, was doing research for a book at the National Archives, when he overheard a Texas state official complaining that he could not find someone to write a cartographic history of part of the state's coastline. Mr. Cantelon offered to take on the project, and the rest is, well, history.

title: The Apartment Gypsies of Manhattan
description: THE volatility of living in New York City on a shoestring visited Clara Jimenz early. Having just graduated from Barnard College and being determined to live on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Ms. Jimenz moved last summer into a co-op with a 38-year-old nurse who was renting out her bedroom for $500 a month and sleeping in the living room.

title: Limits of the Possible
description: CARDIAC INTENSIVE-CARE UNITS ARE paradoxes. They are filled with the tools to delay dying but they keep the language of death at a distance. As an intern, I worked in such a place: a small, brightly lit area, partitioned into eight cubicles and filled with an overwhelming array of electronic equipment. Watching the nurses fit a patient into one of the cubicles was like watching an astronaut slip into a space capsule, engulfed and diminished by the machinery. But such thoughts did not immediately occur to me. My job was to work hard, attend to my patients, and leave the deeper problems of philosophy for later. Those were my priorities on the first day of my intensive-care rotation.

title: POSTINGS: Islip Conversion; Gloria Was Here! Now Come Gardeners
description: Burkewood Gardens, a 223-unit garden apartment complex in Islip, L.I., was rundown even before Hurricane Gloria struck in 1985. The 1960's-vintage complex was directly in the path of the storm, and many of the trees on its 12-acre grounds were uprooted. The result ''was Long Island's version of the Sahara,'' said Arnie Lepelstat, who with Gary Brody and Kelvin Swarth is converting the complex to co-ops.

title: Tracey G. Moore Marries Kevin Howard Matthews
description: The marriage of Tracey Gail Moore, the daughter of Lillian Moore Branch of Hackensack, N.J., and Kevin Howard Matthews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Matthews of the Bronx, took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. Harold A. Young performed the ceremony.

title: WAR AT SEA
description: WITH ITS NEEDLE-NOSED bow and its wide-flared deck, the 123-foot-long New Zealand is a menacing craft, both on land, where it's responsible for the biggest ruckus in the 137-year history of the America's Cup, and on water, where it's the fastest single-hulled racing yacht ever built.

title: OUR MUSCLE-BOUND NAVY
description: Charles Morris laments the aircraft carrier's vulnerability to small antiship missiles, such as the French-made Exocet and its larger Soviet counterparts. He ignores the fact that the U.S.S. Stark (pint-sized and lightly armored, compared to a carrier) absorbed two Exocets and lived to fight another day. Although Soviet missiles pack much more punch, they are larger and more easily tracked and destroyed than the French missile. Furthermore, their launch platforms would themselves be vulnerable to attack by American defenses that extend far from the battle group's center. NAVY LIEUT. EDWARD H. FEEGE JR. Waldorf, Md.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian With West Coast Touch
description: LEAD: ONE of the bottom-line questions that help put a restaurant review into perspective is: would one voluntarily return? In the case of this spanking newcomer, you bet we would. Groupie diners who have followed David Shakin, Cafe L.A.'s chef, from Ossining's late Cafe Keenan might, however, be somewhat disappointed in the food, which bears little resemblance to the smooth, American adaptations of French cooking that Mr.

title: A Logo Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Organist Hits Wrong Note
description: About 25 people wearing Mickey Mouse ears, one in full costume, showed up at the Omaha Royals' baseball game Friday night to hear the organist who hit a sour note with an umpire the night before.

title: THE WORLD: Central American Syndrome; Whatever the U.S. Decides, Panama Faces More Disarray
description: No matter what happens to President Reagan or to American drug-enforcement policy, Panama is now in a crisis that will not end soon and that carries far-reaching consequences for the United States and the region.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A Phone Line For Information On Malaria

title: Health, Too, Is Part Of Planning a Trip
description: AS transportation becomes faster and the places open to visitors become more numerous, exotic and challenging, the possibilities of getting sick, falling victim to an accident or even dying before you can get medical help will rise too.

title: For Immigration, A Drive-In Office
description: WITH florists, dry cleaners, liquor stores, even a pawnshop, operating drive-in establishments in Houston, why not an immigration drive-in?

title: When a Strategy Falls Flat, Switch to Another
description: IN the sophisticated, complex chess of today, not even the most aggressive opening moves can guarantee that you will achieve an attack. One must, therefore, be ready to switch to alternative strategies.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: SIGNIFICANT literary or literary-related events will take place around the state in June.

title: Expos Continue The Extra Effort
description: The Montreal Expos thrive on working overtime. ''These guys think they can't be beaten in extra innings,'' Manager Buck Rodgers said after his team had defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, in 10 innings today.

title: Inside
description: Nicaraguan Talks Continue

title: A. E. I. Thomson, Antiques Trader, Wed to Lisa Reilly
description: The marriage of Lisa Ann Reilly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brendan Reilly of Windsor, Conn., and Dennis, Mass., to Allan Eric Iain Thomson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Thomson of Hornchurch, Essex, England, took place yesterday at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Windsor. The Rev. William E. Dudack performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Martha E. Moss Weds Dr. David C. DiBenedetto
description: The marriage of Dr. Martha Ellen Moss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert M. Moss of Huntington, Conn., to Dr. David Charles DiBenedetto, a son of Mrs. Joseph DiBenedetto of Belmont, Mass., and the late Mr. DiBenedetto, took place yesterday at the Glen Magna historic site in Danvers, Mass. The Rev. Alexander Tartaglia, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: French Photojournalist Freed by Afghanistan
description: A French freelance photojournalist, captured 14 months ago and imprisoned after entering Afghanistan with Moslem guerrillas, was freed today, a French official reported.

title: Civil Disobedience And Its Penalties
description: It is shocking that Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon does not recognize that blocking a person's way to prevent access to a building is a form of violence and should be prosecuted [ ''Dillon's Abortion Stand Roils Party,'' May 15 ] .

title: The Night My Mother Became a Soldier
description: IN 1944, the small industrial town where I lived, Mansfield, Ohio, was totally unified toward the war effort. Whether the idea came from the government or someone local, I do not recall, but, in any event, Mansfield rallied those of us left behind and donated enough funds to purchase a landing craft. Because my father was in the Army serving with the 108th Medical Division in the Pacific, I was sure, at age 8, that it was to be used there for the invasion of one of those islands with strange names like Okinawa, Quadalcanal or Guam. I was also sure the sooner it got over there, the sooner he would be home.

title: OUR MUSCLE-BOUND NAVY
description: I found interesting Mr. Morris's suggestion that we limit the number of carriers the Navy has. If there had been another carrier available, the F-111's probably would not have been used in Libya. However, the Air Force spent a lot of money on the F-111 program (an aircraft that had a lot of teething problems when first deployed) and the Air Force wanted a mission to show off what it had spent money on.

title: Comparison Made Easy By Computers
description: COMPUTERS have long had some impact on bridge in a variety of ways, but the most important effect is relatively new: Clubs with computers can offer their members a popular improvement on traditional match-point scoring in which an overtrick can be worth as much as a slam.

title: A New Age of Television Tastelessness?
description: In the debris of western civilization it may not be much, although probably it should have its own trash bag. Don Imus has been appearing in a television commercial for his radio talk show. ''The issue for George Bush is not the Iran-contra affair,'' he says in the commercial, ''but why he married his mom.'' What stands out in the commercial is not arrested development or terminal naughtiness, but the feeling of absolute vacancy. The commercial is too dumb to be even bad taste. At the same time, it does create in 30 seconds what now takes an increasing number of programs a full hour: the suggestion of being about something, when it's not about anything much. If Mr. Imus is witty, then daytime talk-show hosts are sensitive and Geraldo Rivera is serious and Morton Downey Jr. is a deep thinker. Television is being pulled, inexorably if it doesn't watch out, into a new kind of dumbness: coarse language, shocking pictures and empty thoughts.

title: Interned Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Papaya Salad, the Thai Cooler
description: IN Thailand, where the heat of the day is matched only by the chili-heat index of the food, people have a unique way of cooling off. It is called papaya salad.

title: India Bans the Political and Military Use of Shrines
description: The Indian Government has banned the use of shrines for political and armed purposes and stiffened penalties for the possession and use of illegal weapons, as part of its strategy to fight extremism in the Punjab region.

title: U.C.L.A. Protesters Disrupt Voting for Student President
description: Students at the University of California at Los Angeles overturned ballot boxes, upended polling booths and exchanged blows with workers Thursday to protest the disqualification of a Hispanic candidate for student body president.

title: Intended Wit
description: To the Editor:

title: JOYNER-KERSEE TIES RECORD
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who set a world record in heptathlon two years ago and became the co-holder of the world record in the long jump last year, ran the 100-meter hurdles in 12.61 seconds to equal the American record her training partner, Gail Devers, set last week.

title: AMERICA'S BLIND EYE
description: GEN. MANUEL ANTONIO NORIEGA does not often wear the uniform of the Panama Defense Forces. When he appears in public these days, he prefers to dress in pastel leisure suits or white guayabera shirts, the better to obscure his soldier's origins and show off his collection of gold chains, rings and watches. But on those occasions of state in which Panama's military strongman chooses to emerge in full uniform from his island bunker overlooking the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal, prominently displayed among the medals and decorations on his chest is one indicating that he, like many others on his general staff and scores of Panamanian officers before them, attended the School of the Americas, the training academy for the Latin American military that the Pentagon ran for many years in the Canal Zone.

title: Along the Road of the Seven Bridges
description: SUMMER visitors often find Florence's high temperatures and humidity enervating. The city's beauty more than makes up for the discomfort but travelers who need a break from the sweltering streets and crowded museums might consider renting a car and heading for the hills that surround the ancient city. A day trip along the Road of the Seven Bridges (Via dei Sette Ponti), which hugs the western slopes of the Pratomagno, is the perfect antidote to valley-trapped city heat. The total driving distance is just over 100 miles, excluding side trips on well-paved, curving, gently hilly roads.

title: Gray Areas
description: To the Editor:

title: In Soviet Hospitals, Folk Cures and Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Reflections on Martha Graham's Revolution
description: ''She allowed only verbs and adverbs in her notebook.'' So said Dorothy Bird of Martha

title: A Meatpacker Cartel Up Ahead?
description: IN little more than a year, Conagra Inc., the giant food products and grain company, has stormed to the top of the beef industry. Buying one large meat processor and a half interest in another, Conagra has suddenly become one of three companies that dominate the business.

title: Tennis; Sanchez Eliminates Injured Evert
description: For 13 years, springtime in Paris was Chris Evert's season. She won the French Open seven times and never did worse than the semifinal round in the other years. She said she loved the tournament, and this year she brought her parents and her fiance.

title: For a Novelist, a Fresh Twist: Playwriting
description: The novelist D. Keith Mano began to write his first play -''Resistance,'' which opens Friday at the Judith Anderson Theater -on a dare from his wife, the actress Laurie Kennedy. ''I know nothing about writing plays,'' says the 46-year-old author of ''War Is Heaven!,'' ''Take Five'' and five other novels. ''So whatever is worthwhile in 'Resistance' comes from the reckless way in which I started. Laurie wanted me to write a part for her, a supporting role, she said, because she's self-effacing. So I wrote it in 10 or 12 days, and I gave it to her. There was no sense in doing any rewriting at that time because I had no idea what I had written.''

title: What Right Have We To Meddle in Panama?
description: To the Editor:

title: Farm Subsidies Stifle Agriculture
description: FOR more than 50 years, American agriculture has been the nation's largest recipient of political intervention and economic aid. Agriculture has been subjected to an almost constant effort by the Federal Government to set prices, control producers and allocate capital. So far, the clearest lesson of farm policy is that members of Congress have no incentive to correct their mistakes.

title: Fiddlehead Ferns
description: To the Editor: For two years in a row, The New York Times has published items which tell of gathering wild fern fiddleheads for food in spring.

title: Illinois Bell Restores Some Phone Hookups
description: A new system has been hooked up to restore service to half of Illinois Bell's 35,000 suburban customers whose telephones have been faulty since Mother's Day. But some of the residents whose service was restored said they still had phone troubles.

title: 40 Years of Aid to Fellow Performers
description: The year was 1948. Judy Gershwin was singing rhapsodies with the Xavier Cugat Orchestra. Sandra Berle was helping her son Milton build a baggy wardrobe. Maria Cole was helping the career of her husband, Nat.

title: What's In Now? Natural Music
description: Regular concert-goers often find that listening to music through loudspeakers is a mixed pleasure, and their cavils are usually of a particular kind. It isn't that they have unreasonable expectations of reproduced music being anything like the real thing. They are willing to make allowance for the inherent and irreducible discrepancies between the music and its reproduction. What bothers them specifically - though they are often unable to poinpoint their complaint - is the alteration of vocal and instrumental timbres.

title: DRUGS IN COLLEGES: TO TEST OR NOT TO TEST; RANDOM TESTS ABUSE DIGNITY
description: NOTHING better illustrates the low regard that the National Collegiate Athletic Association has often had for the rights of student-athletes than its random drug-testing policy. There are a number of alternatives for addressing the problem of substance abuse. Unfortunately, the N.C.A.A. chooses an approach that protects the public-relations image of its member institutions but shows little or no concern for the dignity and privacy of the vast majority of hard-working young athletes who are drug-free.

title: Jackson Says Rivals Are Following His Lead
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson faces losing the Democratic Presidential nomination, but he insists he's ''winning every day.''

title: Alone, Actress Plays the Entire Cast
description: As a solo theatrical performer, Mary Louise Hickey has never shared the stage with props, scenery, costumes or other actors. Instead, she draws upon her dramatic training and on the imagination of her audience.

title: Freud's Vienna
description: To the Editor: I was interested in the article ''Freud's Vienna Begins at Berggasse 19'' (Travel, March 27). I was reminded of the visit my husband and I and our three children made 20 years ago to Freud's home in Vienna.

title: DRUGS IN COLLEGES: TO TEST OR NOT TO TEST; N.C.A.A. Plan Is Deterrent
description: THE untimely deaths of Len Bias and Don Rogers two years ago focused our attention on the tragic role that substance abuse plays in the lives of performing athletes. The tremendous pressures placed upon them to perform to expectations that are often unrealistic have created circumstances in which athletes frequently turn to drug use either to escape from these pressures or to enhance performance. In fact, the widespread use of performance-enhancing drugs has perhaps become the single most important threat to the integrity of amateur and professional sport.

title: Technology Alters Role of Nurses
description: LEAD: NURSES at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center may still give back rubs and carry bedpans from time to time. But like their counterparts elsewhere, they are more likely to be found operating sophisticated medical equipment, monitoring and adjusting drug regimens, educating patients and their families and performing a variety of functions that were not part of their jobs five years ago.

title: County Pressed on Overcrowded Jail Complex
description: ON the short list of prison pleasures, day rooms -the recreational areas available for socializing, watching television and playing cards - rank very high. But in Westchester, overcrowding at the county's correctional complex in Valhalla has forced authorities to use day rooms to house an overflowing population. Lawyers for the inmates warned last week that the situation was beginning to mirror conditions that led to a prison riot in the complex seven years ago.

title: Grand Canyon
description: To the Editor: As a veteran of three 18-day trips through the Grand Canyon on dories, I was pleased to see Franz Lidz's article (Travel, March 27). I hope it keeps others who share his need for artificial means of stimulation out of the canyon. Those of us who will never find this ''infinity of dry red rock'' boring will be left to enjoy the incomparable beauty of the voyage. Tourists who don't want ''needless repetition of scenery,'' in the words of one company that charters rafts in the canyon, should stick to Disneyland. TOBY R. SIMON Livingston, N.J.

title: Dukakis Is Unfazed By Attacks
description: When a jarring burst of thunder interrupted Michael S. Dukakis's talk at a Cranford, N.J., day care center the other evening, the normally staid Democratic Presidential candidate quipped, ''Bush is at it again.''

title: Debate on Divestment Splits U.S. Olympic Groups
description: A philosophical dispute has developed between the United States Olympic Committee and its fund-raising arm, the Olympic Foundation, over the foundation's indirect investments in South Africa. This has led to a conflict among members of the two bodies over what type of moral statement, if any, their investment strategies should make about South Africa's policy of apartheid.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: KICK THE CAN. By Jim Lehrer. (Putnam, $17.95.) ''Buddy,'' a Tennessee uncle once said to me, ''all you need in this world is a good woman, fresh vegetables and Jesus.'' This is the kind of advice Southern boys have been running away from for years, and the hero of ''Kick the Can'' is no exception.

title: In Silk Scarves, T Is for Tiffany
description: TIFFANY'S has long had its jewelry, silver and china. Now it has scarves. That may not seem like a natural progression, but the scarves' designer, John Loring, who is also the store's design director, believes it is.

title: SAINTHOOD FOR 117 OUTRAGES VIETNAM
description: The canonization in June of 117 Vietnamese and foreign Roman Catholic martyrs persecuted by 17th- and 18th-century Vietnamese rulers, has provoked angry protests from Hanoi, worsening already unstable relations between the Vatican and Vietnam.

title: How the Newcomer - a Girl! - Lost Her Status of 'Intruder'
description: I HATED my sister. She was an intruder.

title: Man Charged in Wife's Death
description: A 50-year-old roofing contractor was ordered held on $100,000 bail yesterday in connection with the slaying of his wife in their Queens home earlier this month, and authorities reported that he is under investigation in the death of a previous wife last November.

title: NONFICTION
description: SHOOTING FROM THE LIP: Essays, Columns, Quips, and Gripes in the Grand Tradition of Dyspeptic Sports Writing. By Mike Lupica. (Bonus, $15.95.) Mike Lupica, whose sports columns appear regularly in The Daily News and Esquire, is a master miniaturist. He has perfected the art of using a single mood or moment to dramatize an entire season or career. His tone is by turns enthusiastic, contentious and poignant. A man of strong passions and opinions, Mr. Lupica proudly proclaims, ''My three favorite sports are baseball, baseball, and baseball.'' Tennis, basketball, boxing and horse racing are close behind, but winter sports generally bore him, as does cricket, ''a great sport for England, a country in which people just go from one queue to another, waiting for something to happen.'' Mr. Lupica's wit can be devastating, but he is at his best when paying tribute to sports greats like the hurdler Edwin Moses or telling a story as simple as that of an avid Mets fan who happens to be blind. His newspaper columns, which make up the bulk of this collection, are tasty appetizers that leave one hungry for more, a desire satisfied by the handful of lengthier magazine pieces included here. A surprisingly sympathetic profile of John McEnroe is particularly memorable, as is the recounting of a meeting between Ralph Branca and Bobby Thomson, 35 years after Branca threw Thomson the most famous home-run pitch in New York history. Least successful are Mr. Lupica's one-line quips, taken from his Sunday column. A few of them are tasteless asides that mar an otherwise engaging and often exhilarating collection.

title: Ana Aslan, Rumanian Specialist On the Aging Process, Dies in 90's
description: Ana Aslan, a controversial gerontologist whose clinic in Rumania attracted thousands of people from around the world in search of renewed youth, died May 20 in Bucharest, according to reports from that city and Paris. She was in her early 90's.

title: Kidney-Stone Pulverizer for County
description: LEAD: ARCHITECTS at the County Medical Center in Valhalla are busy converting an old laboratory into a space that will house a sophisticated machine that pulverizes kidney stones without surgery.

title: POSTINGS: 2 Harlem Renovations; Values Going Up
description: Jacob Sebag, who is renovating two adjacent East 105th Street shells, can chart the rise in East Harlem property values from his own experience. His buildings are both four stories with brownstone facades. But Mr. Sebag, along with a partner, Enrique A. Ochoa, bought one of them, at 229, in 1985 for only $50,000; the other, at 231, the partners purchased early in 1987 for $185,000. They subsequently sold a similar building nearby for $214,000, and expect that type of building, common in the area, to sell in the current market for $250,000 to $300,000. ''The whole area is not what it used to be,'' Mr. Sebag said. One of the reasons for the change is the large number of projects like those of Mr. Sebag and Mr. Ochoa. Their gut renovation of 229 and 231 105th Street, both formerly owned by the city, will cost $1.2 million and create 12 one-bedroom apartments, two two-bedroom duplexes and two duplex professional offices. The units, priced from $145,000 to $190,000, will feature oak floors, fireplaces and individual boilers and water heaters. Work will begin in July and be completed by winter.

title: The Handsome Designs Of Old Tax Receipts
description: UNCLE Sam is certainly against sin, but the Government does not refrain from taxing sin to raise revenue. Such taxes and the stamp receipts open a broad range of collecting, which can be extended greatly to include tax stamps issued by states.

title: Lois E. Harrison, A Designer, Weds William K. Mintz
description: Lois Eleanor Harrison and William Kendall Mintz were married last evening at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens, by Cantor Richard Berman.

title:
ITALY'S TV TYCOON: Silvio Berlusconi;
A Media Empire Marches East
description: LEAD: EARLIER this month, Soviet television viewers got their first look at an American commercial - for Pepsi-Cola - as part of a Soviet experiment with foreign TV advertising.

title: Putnam Acts on Motels for Homeless
description: LEAD: IN a challenge to the practice of housing the homeless in motels, Putnam County officials have threatened to close motels that have been found to have building and fire-safety violations.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vernon, Vt.;
Nuclear Plant Eases Tax Bill
description: LEAD: THE family that buys the $250,000 contemporary Victorian home that Marshall Hansen is building in Vernon will probably pay about $1,100 a year in property taxes. If the same home were in the neighboring town of Brattleboro, the tax bill would be significantly higher. ''I would say about $4,000,'' Mr.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 1 about Brighton, England, misstated the route of the miniature Volk's Electric Railway. It runs between the Palace Pier and the Marina at Black Rock.

title: The Trench Warriors
description: WHEN Irving Bank's management sought shareholder support for a friendly merger with Banca Commerciale Italiana, its proxy adviser, D. F. King & Company, persuaded Irving to mail out blue ballots. The color, King executives suggested, would help create a ''royal'' image. Bank of New York, which was asking Irving shareholders to support its hostile bid for Irving, countered with gold ballots - a color often chosen to appeal to investors' greed. But a D. F. King vice president, Richard A. DeMay, had a ready reply. ''Even though they called it gold, we called it yellow,'' he said, hoping to portray the insurgents as cowards.

title: Accountants Sought Along Rte. 1
description: LEAD: SPRING college graduates equipped to work in computer science, sales, customer service, retail and restaurant management and, especially, accounting should have good job prospects this year along the 20-mile stretch of U.S. .1. known as the Princeton Corridor.

title: Ailing Irwin Retains Lead
description: At 3 o'clock this morning, Hale Irwin was jolted awake by the pain of a stomach attack that would leave him weak and ill through the entire third round of the 13th annual Memorial Tournament today.

title: Reviews/Music; Harpsichordist, Pianist And Tenor in Recital Debuts
description: Ketil Haugsand

title: Reagan Aides Call Human Rights 'Agenda Item No. 1' at the Summit
description: On the eve of his arrival in Moscow, President Reagan told the Soviet people tonight that he had never expected to see their country while in the White House and was looking forward to his summit visit.

title: The Hidden Lives of the 'Downtown Chinese'
description: A CHINESE immigrant himself, Peter Kwong wanted to dispel the myth that the Chinese are a model minority who look out for one another, stress educational achievement, attain successful positions in the high-tech job market and are in no need of public assistance.

title: History Buff Tracking Medal of Honor Holders
description: TOMORROW, just as he has every Memorial Day for the last six years, Henry J. Sundvik of Secaucus will visit Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia to pay homage to winners of the Medal of Honor.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Great Falls, Mont.;
Hotel Revival For Downtown
description: LEAD: A CANADIAN businessman wants to revive a landmark hotel in this central Montana city, and local officials see the plan as a key step toward rebuilding the downtown area.

title: Driver to Defend New England Title
description: It took a long time for David Loring to learn that he didn't really have to be a racing driver. But with that lesson behind him, the 37-year-old New Englander stands on the brink of his greatest racing success.

title: NEIGHBOR STATES WAGE A TAX WAR
description: Thousands of New Hampshire residents who work in Maine say they are angry that Maine offers them no benefits while it forces them to pay millions of dollars each year in income taxes. They have begun lobbying officials of both states and the Federal Government for changes.

title: Financial Planning and the Handicapped
description: A COUPLE in the Midwest recently faced a difficult time when a playground accident left their 4-year-old child severely disabled. Compounding the trauma of the accident was the need to review the family's finances to make sure that the child's expenses would be covered.

title: Growth Squeezing Princeton Corridor
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the U.S. 1 corridor, also known as the Princeton Corridor because part of it shares the 08540 ZIP code with this university community, is booming, its success is causing concern. Residents complain of congestion on the highway, their most convenient access to the New Jersey Turnpike, the Amtrak/N.J.

title: Stewart Fails Again but A's Beat Red Sox, 5-3
description: Odell Jones, who had not started a game in the major leagues since 1981, pitched a perfect game for seven and one-third innings and came within two outs of a no-hitter tonight as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Cleveland Indians, 2-0.

title: Bold Images Capture the World of the Plains Indians
description: Rooted in the ancient cave drawings of the Great Plains, the pictography of the Arapaho, Cheyenne and Sioux survives today in 19th-century ledger books, beaded shirts, quill-embellished artifacts and a hand-chiseled tomahawk. A selection of these figurative, color-splashed tribal graphics in a variety of materials - most are drawings - has been assembled in an exhibition on the art of American Indian picture writing at the Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street.

title: Steering a Daughter Past the Bureaucrats
description: MY husband and I bought our last car locally, without comparison shopping, because the dealer assured us he could transfer the plates himself at the Department of Motor Vehicles. We would not have to set foot in the place. He was as good as his word, and we breathed a sigh of relief.

title: Syrian Troops Seize South Beirut In Move to End Battles by Shiites
description: Several thousand Syrian troops took control of the rest of Beirut's southern suburbs today in the second phase of their deployment to end a street war between rival Moslem Shiite militias.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CLASSIC CAR SHOW

title: Reviews/Music; A Robert Shaw Farewell: Beethoven and Stravinsky
description: Robert Shaw was one of this country's most renowned choral directors when he accepted the directorship of the Atlanta Symphony, his first symphonic post, in 1967. In his 21 years there, he has put the orchestra on America's symphonic map - largely, although not entirely, by establishing a magnificent choral adjunct and recording a healthy sampling of the literature for choir and orchestra. This summer, Mr. Shaw is relinquishing the Atlanta podium, and this week he brought the orchestra and its 207-voice choir to town for a pair of farewell concerts.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying an article on health care for the elderly in The Week in Review last Sunday misstated a projection for the population of the United States in 2010. The correct figure is 283,238,000.

title: Celtics Favored By Officials?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Two Toys Reported Recalled Because of Choking Hazard
description: The Sweet Home Shoe House play set and the Ice Cream Doll are being recalled nationwide because small children might choke on their parts, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Friday.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: ALAN N. HOUGHTON;
'We Consider Ourselves an Option'
description: LEAD: ALAN N. HOUGHTON has been the executive director of the Connecticut Association of Independent Schools since 1974. Before that, he was himself a headmaster at an independent school for 18 years.

title: Bethesda Fountain, Where the Action Is
description: Back in the 1960's, Bethesda Fountain in Central Park was center stage for the latest in flower-power fashions. Through the purple haze of smoke, one could take in a panoply of tie-dyed shirts, Sergeant Pepper coats, fringed piano shawls and long electroshock hair styles. For many designers, the place was a bonanza. They'd arrive with their sketchpads and go back to their studios, and suddenly everybody would be wearing tie-dyed shirts and fringe shawls. It was, like, you know, a fashion revolution, man.

title: Good as Gold
description: For the second year in a row, the Hastings High School Madrigal Choir has brought home the gold.

title: N.C.A.A. Baseball; REDMEN ELIMINATED ON 2 STRAIGHT LOSSES
description: They were close enough to Omaha to see the place.

title: DioGuardi Opens His Re-election Campaign
description: A CONFIDENT Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi made it official last week, announcing that he was seeking re-election to Congress, the ''new career'' that the former accountant said ''feels comfortable to me.''

title: Kelly Ann Eschenlohr Wed
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., Kelly Ann Eschenlohr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Eschenlohr of Short Hills and Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to Jon Brian Hostetler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Hostetler of Grand Junction, Colo. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony. Mrs. Hostetler is a producer and writer with KCNC-TV, an NBC affiliate in Denver. Her husband is the chief photographer at KUSA-TV, an ABC affiliate in Denver.

title: ANGOLAN SETTLEMENT MOVES HIGHER ON U.S.-SOVIET AGENDA
description: Shortly before the Portuguese flag came down in 1975 when Angola was granted independence, three Cuban ships filled with soldiers and arms arrived to help a Marxist guerrilla army beat its rivals in civil war. Thirteen years later Cubans are still in Angola, defending the Marxist Government against attacks by many of the same guerrilla rivals, supplied by South Africa and the United States. Though billions of dollars in arms have poured into Angola in the last decade, and South Africa has sent in thousands of troops of its own, the war is going nowhere.

title: HOW TO LOSE FRIENDS AND INFLUENCE
description: FOR THE RECORD From Wall Street to Washington. By Donald T. Regan. Illustrated. 397 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.

title: Correction
description: The Long Island Guide last Sunday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Sea Cliff Chamber Players' Long Island Mozart Festival. Its number is 671-6263.

title: The Struggle in Punjab: Some Respite, No Resolution
description: The successful operation by Indian security forces this month against Sikh militants inside the Golden Temple, the shrine in the Punjabi city of Amritsar that is the holiest of the Sikh faith, has presented Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi with new problems and new opportunities in tackling extremism. It has given Mr. Gandhi a political boost at a time when his Government was under fire for being too soft on the militants, yet it will be difficult to turn this into a major achievement. The hundreds of remaining militants have the ability to strike hard, and moderate Sikhs are divided among themselves. In addition, the Government has been reluctant to embark on new political initiatives, preferring to concentrate on attacking the militants.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Restoring the Master Builder's Mansion
description: LEAD: DURING 16 years of turning white-elephant mansions into showcase houses, Carole Aronson and Arlene Travis, the founders of Mansions and Millionaires in Greenvale, have raised millions for charity, provided thousands of visitors with a rare look at privately owned estates, and in the process have saved or helped preserve many of

title: Review/Rock; The Monsters of Rock Open a 23-City Tour
description: America's stadium-rock season opened here today with a bang - or, more precisely, the nine-hour roar of Van Halen's Monsters of Rock Tour. Drums boomed, singers shouted and howled, guitars blared and shrieked as Van Halen, the Scorpions, Dokken, Metallica and Kingdom Come, five top heavy-metal bands, performed from midday into the night.

title: Correction
description: A photograph on page 28 of the Arts and Leisure section on May 15 was misidentified. It showed Lon Chaney, not Charles Laughton.

title: Michele Rudolph Weds Marc Davy Vandenhoeck
description: At the Chapel in the Woods in Mars, Pa., Joan Michele Rudolph, a daughter of Mrs. Rome Rudolph of Gibsonia, Pa., and the late Mr. Rudolph, was married yesterday to Marc Davy Vandenhoeck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Paul Vandenhoeck of New York and Guilford, Conn. The Rev. AlisonLynne Barfoot performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Martha E. Hunt Weds Clinton Francis Bogart
description: Martha Elizabeth Hunt and Clinton Francis Bogart were married yesterday at St. Paul's United Methodist Church in Houston by the Rev. James Welch.

title:
GARDENING;
Containers Add Color and Reduce Care
description: LEAD: PEOPLE living in condominiums or apartments don't have the option of going out to plow the back 40 or replace part of the lawn with flowers or vegetables. For them, containers may be the only choice in gardening. There are also good reasons for homeowners with plenty of space to confine much of their gardening to containers.

title:
FOCUS: San Francisco;
A Link To Cheaper Housing
description: LEAD: IT'S so expensive to live here that even some middle-management city employees need a subsidy to make their housing affordable.

title: Brazilian Rallies Fearful Landowners
description: For the best part of three years, as Ronaldo Caiado traveled the length and breadth of Brazil fanning the fears of farmers that their land could be expropriated, he came to personify right-wing resistance to social change under Brazil's new civilian Government.

title: WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
description: N.B.A. champions do not repeat because of the resiliency and grudge-bent determination of their archrivals. Of the five champions since 1969 who have reached the N.B.A. finals in their following seasons, four were rematched against their runnerup foes from the previous seasons. The only exception being last year's Celtics team which was dethroned by the Lakers, their longtime rivals, rather than the Rockets whom the Celtics victimized in 1986.

title: Carol Maytag Becomes Bride
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Carol Maytag, the daughter of Mrs. Kerryn King of New York and the late Robert E. Maytag, was married yesterday to Richard Reginald Madeley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Madeley of Salisbury, England. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: A MANIA FOR LISTS
description: HOUSES OF IVORY By Hart Wegner. 241 pp. New York: Soho Press. $15.95.

title: Janice Cleveland Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Janice Lee Cleveland and Dana Stanley Washburn, who are to graduate next Sunday from the University of Massachusetts Medical School in Worcester, took place yesterday at the Wellesley Hills (Mass.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Victoria Guest, assisted by the Rev. Jamie Gustafson, performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Mount Vernon, N.Y. $257,500 55 Harding Parkway 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old Tudor; living room with fireplace, oak floors, walk-in cedar closets, .12 acre; taxes $2,800. Peekskill, N.Y. $191,000 1736 Congress Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; cathedral ceilings, country kitchen, deck, cul-de-sac, .25 acre; taxes $3,224. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $390,000 Chapman Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 138-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, wrap-around porch, fireplace, 2.6 acres; taxes $5,373. Old Lyme, Conn. $162,500 16 Ridgewood Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, old summer cottage; fireplace, beach association fee $288 yearly, 50- by 90-foot lot; taxes $975. Norwalk, Conn. $385,000 12 Watering Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old Dutch colonial; fireplace, .33 acre; taxes $3,648. Trumbull, Conn. $400,000 30 Catherine Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, six-month-old colonial; large country kitchen, master suite with skylights, .5 acre; taxes $3,237. OTHER AREAS Bay Shore, L.I. $360,000 6 Lawrence Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; family room, 2 fireplaces, c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200. Bluepoint, L.I. $198,000 72 Wilson Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old ranch; dining room, family room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Belleville, N.J. $125,000 112 Mill Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, two-year-old condominium town house; 4-zone heating, garage; monthly maintenance $127, taxes $3,069.

title: Dr. Ellen Schlefer Marries M. B. Bicks
description: Dr. Ellen King Schlefer was married yesterday to Michael Barnes Bicks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bicks of New York, at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mark P. Schlefer, in Washington. Judge Louis H. Pollak of the United States District Court in Philadelphia performed the ceremony.

title: Green's Race to Rehabiilitate New York City's Crumbling Educational Infrastructure
description: In his efforts to change New York City's troubled schools, the new Chancellor, Richard R. Green, can still capitalize on political good will in the State Legislature. But with its session expected to end early in July, he will have to hurry if he seeks solutions for many of the serious problems - from the bloated, unresponsive bureaucracy to filthy, crumbling buildings.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: PASSAIC COUNTY has offered to pay $2.5 million for the 2,000 acres of Sterling Forest that lie in New Jersey, but New York State officials have made no firm decision on what to do about a much larger tract on their side of the border.

title: Groups Offer Homes to Merritt Tollbooths
description: LEAD: DRIVERS will press 35 cents into the palms of tollkeepers on the Merritt Parkway for the last time on June 24. Then three sets of tollbooths in Greenwich, Milford and Wallingford, which have withstood weather and accidents for half a century, will officially fall into hands of demolition crews.

title: Trenton Acts to Ease Medical Bills of Elderly
description: THE Legislature moved two bills last week addressing the health problems of the elderly. It also received a negative report card on a program designed to help Medicare patients avoid extra physician fees.

title: DELEGATE TALLY
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. DEMOCRATS Dukakis . . . 1,705 Jackson . . . 965 Gore . . . 384 Simon . . . 166 Undetermined* . . . 471 Total delegate votes: 4,161 Chosen so far: 3,691 Needed to nominate: 2,081 REPUBLICANS Bush . . . 1,475 Robertson . . . 52 Undetermined* . . . 234 Total delegate votes: 2,277 Chosen so far: 1,761 Needed to nominate: 1,139 * Includes some delegates whose chosen candidate has withdrawn.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN HITLER'S GERMANY: Everyday Life in the Third Reich, by Bernt Engelmann. Translated by Krishna Winston. (Schocken, $8.95.) Not all Germans acquiesced to Nazi rule, Bernt Engelmann discovered in his interviews. Many citizens actively supported Hitler; some bravely resisted. Last year in The Times, John Gross called this book ''an unusual blend of memoir and oral history. . . . The portrait of a society that emerges has many dramatic moments, but it is even more valuable for the way in which it conveys the everyday climate of life in the darkest of dark times.'' PERSIAN NIGHTS, by Diane Johnson. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) As the Shah's regime crumbles around her, an American woman living in Iran suspects that her lover works for the Central Intelligence Agency. Last year, our reviewer, Jayne Anne Phillips, said that Diane Johnson's seventh novel is ''funny, incisive, frightening and eminently skillful. In addition, it displays the Cassandra-like quality of good fiction and dovetails nicely with continuing Iranscam disclosures. . . . When we read, at a climactic moment in the novel, 'It seems the Americans are gun runners,' the words hit home with a sickening thud.'' A CONFLICT OF VISIONS, by Thomas Sowell. (Quill/ Morrow, $7.95.) Throughout history, Thomas Sowell argues, civilization has been divided between those who were convinced that people are inherently flawed (and perhaps evil) and those who believed in the perfectibility of humankind. Mr. Sowell, who casts his lot with the former, ''makes his case fairly, lucidly and persuasively,'' Fred Barnes said in The Book Review last year. He provides ''a framework for understanding social theories and politics.'' INVENTING THE ABBOTTS: And Other Stories, by Sue Miller. (Laurel/Dell, $8.95.) These short stories by the author of ''The Good Mother'' show that Sue Miller is ''adept in her depiction of the ways in which people abuse one another,'' Penelope Lively said here last year. She reports ''from a frontier, from the discontented and guilty world of divorce and the single parent, of marriage as a threatened institution.'' AMONG FRIENDS: Who We Like, Why We Like Them, and What We Do With Them, by Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (McGraw-Hill, $7.95.) ''Friendship,'' Letty Cottin Pogrebin writes, ''is a category each of us invents.'' In 1986, our reviewer, Marcia Froelke Coburn, said, ''The way [ this ] book jumps between philosophy and how-to advice is disconcerting, but the chapters about the sociopsychological aspects of male bonding, women's intimacy and male-female friendships are insightful.'' THE TIDEWATER TALES, by John Barth. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) Peter Sagamore, a blocked minimalist writer whose books keep getting shorter, is the opposite of his creator, John Barth, who has produced his most expansive novel yet. In ''The Tidewater Tales,'' Sagamore and his wife, an oral historian, sail the Chesapeake, entangling themselves in one story after another. ''This is lively stuff,'' William Pritchard said here last year, ''and Mr. Barth has never been more engaging, nor more engaged in his narrative complications.'' Also available is LOST IN THE FUNHOUSE: Fiction for Print, Tape, Live Voice (Anchor/ Doubleday, $7.95), Mr. Barth's collection of short pieces of experimental fiction, which was published in 1968. The same publisher has reissued THE FLOATING OPERA (1956) and THE END OF THE ROAD (1958), which appear in a single edition ($8.95). THE BEER CAN BY THE HIGHWAY: Essays on What's ''American'' About America, by John A. Kouwenhoven. (Johns Hopkins University, Paper, $9.95; Cloth, $27.50.) When this book of linked essays on American culture was published in 1961, Charles Poore said in The Times that its author ''is an acute and extraordinarily genial analyst of our mechanized folkware.'' It has been republished with a foreword by Ralph Ellison. THE ENIGMA OF ARRIVAL, by V. S. Naipaul. (Vintage, $6.95.) This ''haunting'' story about a young man from Trinidad who immigrates to England is so clearly autobiographical that it is curious that V. S. Naipaul insisted on making it a novel, Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ''With disarming self-deprecation he describes how in his determination to be 'literary' and to record everything except what was happening in front of his nose, he succeeded in missing the great story that he himself was part of -the postwar migration of far-flung colonial subjects to the heart of the declining British Empire.'' THE MARSHALL PLAN, by Charles L. Mee Jr. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Is the United States paying more than its fair share for defending Europe? Charles L. Mee Jr.'s history of the Marshall Plan tells how America's tangle of postwar commitments began. ''There is a wistful reassurance in being reminded of the heroic age of policy making in the years after World War II,'' A. W. DePorte said here in 1984. Though he questioned some of the book's scholarship, he called it ''good light reading for anyone who wants to learn something about the origins of that very successful American initiative.'' ONE PAIR OF HANDS, by Monica Dickens. (Academy Chicago, $4.95.) Fans of Charles Dickens might be interested to know that his great-granddaughter writes books of her own. Tiring of her life as a debutante, Monica Dickens became a domestic servant, and she describes the ordeal in ''One Pair of Hands.'' In 1939, The Times's reviewer said it is a ''unique and delightful'' essay written with ''a novelist's balance, humor and charm.''

title: A Word on the Thesis Of an Exhibition
description: If a critic makes argument against the thesis of an exhibition, that is undeniably his or her right. If, however, this argument is based on a misunderstanding of that thesis, I trust the curator has the right, indeed the obligation, to set the record straight. Therefore I, as curator, should like to do so for ''Personal Places: American Landscapes, 1905-1930'' recently held at the Sarah Lawrence College Art Gallery.

title: Traffic Problems With Moose
description: WHY does a moose cross the road?

title: Women's Panel Reflects On Gains of 15 Years
description: LEAD: WHEN Kay Bergin was named the first executive director of the Permanent Commission on the Status of Women, she thought the state agency would be a footnote in history.

title: Bowa Let Go By Padres
description: Larry Bowa was dismissed yesterday as manager of the San Diego Padres and replaced by Jack McKeon, the club's vice president of baseball operations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PHOENIX RISES AGAIN Westchester is to have its own Phoenix Theater Company, named after the Phoenix Theater in Manhattan that closed in 1982 after 29 years of Off Broadway productions. A professional troupe of 12 Equity actors from New York, with the blessing of T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, founders of the original Phoenix and board members of the Westchester group, will open what is hoped to be the first of many summer seasons at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, from July 15 through Aug. 21. Members of the company will live in the school dormitories during the season.

title: Verbatim: A Widening Gap
description: 'America is moving backward - not forward -in its effort to achieve the full participation of minority citizens in the life and prosperity of the nation. In education, employment, income, health, longevity and other basic measures of individual and social well-being, gaps persist -and in some cases are widening - between members of minority groups and the majority population.' The Commission on Minority Participation in Education and American Life, a panel whose 37 members include former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford, in a report, ''One Third of a Nation,'' released last week.

title: Towns Fill Dumps Too Fast For Plants
description: CONNECTICUT is facing a garbage paradox. Although the state has one of the most ambitious trash-to-energy programs in the nation, landfills are filling so fast, officials say, they will be topped off before incinerators for more than half the towns are ready.

title: WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
description: There are three reasons why N.B.A. champions do not repeat. One is that when a team becomes the champion, a competitive fire is lit in other very well-equipped and prominent teams who feel that they have just as much ability as this champion. Second, N.B.A. champions either lack the zeal or the same strong physical ability of the previous season. Finally, N.B.A. champions do not play to repeat but play to defend, to avoid a loss. CALEB A. BUCHANAN Brooklyn

title: DATA UPDATE: May 29 ,1988
Filipinos Fill The Visa Line To Get to U.S.
description: Late one recent night, after a week of surveillance, the Manila police rounded up 55 suspicious people who had been sleeping under the tropical baliti trees outside the United States Embassy.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Retail Space; Manhattan Rents Slide as Empty Storefronts Multiply
description: AFTER almost a decade of heady growth, store rents in many Manhattan neighborhoods are beginning to decline as landlords sitting with large blocks of space grow nervous.

title: A GUIDE TO THE DANCES OF SUMMER
description: The following is a selective list of summer dance festivals and events. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast. New York City AMERICAN BALLROOM THEATER Under the artistic direction of Pierre Dulaine and Yvonne Marceau, this company of five championship ballroom couples will perform in the premiere of ''Hernando's Hideaway,'' staged by Tina Paul, with dances by Graciela Daniele and Elizabeth Aldrich (June 22-25). (Triplex Theater, Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers St., New York, N.Y. Phone: 618-1980) ART IN THE ANCHORAGE Beginning June 11, visual and performing artists will be presented by Creative Time, an arts organization, for its fifth annual monthlong installation/performances, discussions and benefit events in the cathedral-like interior of the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage, located at Cadman Plaza West and Front Street in Brooklyn: Station House Opera, London-based performance group in ''Piranesi in New York,'' using movable platforms (June 14-18); Contraband, a San Francisco dance/ theater troupe, in ''Oracle'' (June 22-25). (Through July 18). (Creative Time, 66 W. Broadway, New York, N. Y. 10007. Phone: 619-1955) ART ON THE BEACH Another multimedia presentation of Creative Time opens on July 15, and performances and installations will be offered at an outdoor space on the waterfront at Hunters Point in Queens, across from Manhattan: Maureen Fleming, Butoh-trained choreographer (July 27, 29); XXY Dance/ Music (Aug. 10, 12). (Through Sept. 18) (Art on the Beach, Creative Times. Phone: 619-1955) ASIA SOCIETY As part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts: Suzushi Hanayagi, Japanese avant-garde choreographer/dancer, in the American premiere of ''Bitwin: Dance in Media,'' a collaboration with the video artist Katsuhiro Yamaguchi (June 15-17); Kazuo Ohno in ''Water Lilies,'' a new Butoh dance, performed with his son, Yoshito (June 28-30). (Asia Society, 725 Park Ave., New York, N.Y. 10021. Phone: 517-2742) PINA BAUSCH/ TANZTHEATER WUPPERTAL American premieres of two early evening-length dance-dramas by the German choreographer: ''Viktor,'' performed on dirt and earth-mounds (June 27-29, July 1-3), and ''Carnations,'' with 10,000 carnations covering the stage (July 5, 7-10). (Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217. Phone: 718-636-4100) CELEBRATE BROOKLYN PERFORMING ARTS FESTIVAL The 10th season of free theater, music and dance will take place at the outdoor Prospect Park Bandshell from June 22-Sept. 4. Dance events include: Bill T. Jones/ Arnie Zane & Company, Paul Thompson and Troop Three (July 22); Miami City Ballet (July 23); Ralph Lemon & Company (July 23-24); Martha Bowers, Monica Levy Performance Group (July 24); David Parsons and Company, Iso (July 29); David Dorfman Dance Company, Elisa Monte Dance Company (July 30); Caribbean Dance Festival (July 31). (Prospect Park, Prospect Park W. at Ninth St., Brooklyn, N. Y. Phone: 718-768-0699) CENTRAL PARK SUMMERSTAGE From June 17 to Sept. 4, there will be 40 free events in six separate series: Dance/Performance, New American Folk, Blues, New Music, World Music and Opera. Friday-night dance/ performance-art concerts: American Tap Dance Orchestra, Lenny Pickett, Persuasions (June 17); Kei Takei's Moving Earth, with Soh Daiko (June 24); Malombo, Beth Soll & Company (July 1); Dianne McIntyre's Sounds in Motion (July 8); Georg Osterman and Company, Smith-Shapiro (July 15); Jelon Vieira's Dance Brazil (July 22); Nina Martin Performance Company, Anita Feldman Tap (July 29); Martha Bowers Dance-Theater-Etc., Bebe Miller and Company (Aug. 5); Ralph Lee and Mettawee River Company (Aug. 12); Ping Chong and Company (Aug. 19); Quentin Crisp (Aug. 26); Paul Thompson and Troop Three, Marta Renzi and Project Company (Sept. 2). At the Naumburg Bandshell, located near the park's 72d Street entrance. (Central Park Conservancy, 830 Fifth Ave., New York, N. Y. 10021. Phone: 860-1335) CITY CENTER THEATER The Sydney Dance Company completes its two-week engagement with artistic director/ choreographer Graeme Murphy's ''After Venice'' (through Wednesday) and ''Shining'' (June 2-5). Frankfurt Ballet. Weeklong New York City debut, performing two programs of works by director William Forsythe, assisted by Amanda Miller: ''France/ Dance,'' ''Same Old Story,'' ''Skinny'' (June 14-16); ''Step Text,'' ''Red Run,'' ''Love Songs'' (June 17-19). (City Center, 131 W. 55th St., New York, N.Y. 10019. Phone: 246-8989) CONNECTICUT BALLET THEATER This 15-member troupe will perform, with guest artist Stephanie Saland, in a full-length ''Giselle,'' re-staged by Brett Raphael, artistic director (June 17-18). (Martin Luther King Jr. High School, 65th St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York, N.Y. 10019. Phone: 865-5896) MERCE CUNNINGHAM STUDIO During July and August, emerging choreographers and dance groups from across the country continue to perform in the choreographer's 150-seat studio on the 11th floor of the Westbeth cooperative building. (Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune St., New York, N. Y. 10014. Phone: 691-9751) DANCE AT THE MET American Ballet Theater's spring season continues with repeat performances of new productions: ''Gaite Parisienne,'' ''Gala Performance,'' ''The Informer,'' ''Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1,'' ''Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes''; ''Giselle'' and other repertory works (through June 11). The Royal Danish Ballet. Two evening-length ballets by August Bournonville will be presented: ''Napoli'' (June 14-16) and ''Abdallah'' (June 17-18). Paris Opera Ballet. Four different programs: Artistic director Rudolf Nureyev's staging of ''Swan Lake'' (June 21-25); a mixed bill, including local premieres of William Forsythe's ''in the middle, somewhat elevated'' and Maguy Marin's ''Lecons de tenebres'' (June 28-30, July 2); Mr. Nureyev's ''Nutcracker'' (July 1-2, 5-6); American premiere of Robert Wilson's ''Martyre de Saint Sebastien'' (July 7-9). Paris Opera Ballet School. Lecture-demonstration (June 25) and performances (June 26) by 85 students of the oldest ballet school in the world, at the Juilliard Theater in Lincoln Center. Royal Spanish National Ballet. New York debut of the company, under the direction of Jose Antonio, with guest artist Merche Esmeralda, in a program of four dances, including a flamenco version of ''Medea,'' with music by Manolo Sanlucar (July 11-16). National Ballet of Canada. Two programs: Glen Tetley's ''Ronde'' and Robert Desrosier's ''Blue Snake'' (July 18, 21-22), and John Cranko's evening-length ''Onegin'' (July 19-20, 23). (Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, New York, N. Y. 10023. Phone: 362-6000) DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM The world premiere of Arthur Mitchell's ''John Henry'' (commissioned by the First New York International Festival of the Arts) will be presented and the company premiere of Eugene Loring's ''Billy the Kid,'' along with Balanchine's ''Serenade'' (June 28-29, July 3). On the second program, company premiere of Fokine's ''Polovetsian Dances from 'Prince Igor,' '' plus Valerie Bettis's ''Streetcar Named Desire'' and John Taras's ''Firebird'' (June 30-July 2). (City Center, 131 W. 55th St., New York, N.Y. 10019. Phone: 246-8989) DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP This showcase for contemporary choreographers and performance artists will conclude its spring season with Frank Moore and Jim Self (June 1-5); Carol Clements (June 9-12); ''Fresh Tracks,'' featuring new works by Gloria Desideri, Doug Elkins, JoAnn Fregalette-Jansen, Steve Gross, Eileen Kelly and Emily Schottland (June 14, 21, 28); Even Orchestra, Australian performance group, in ''Dog Songs'' (June 16-19); the English duo Ralf Ralf makes its American debut in ''The Summit'' (June 23-26). (Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 W. 19th St., New York, N. Y. 10011. Phone: 924-0077) DANCEAFRICA Beginning tomorrow, the 11th weeklong celebration of master classes, artist/ audience forum, bazaar and concerts will open. Among more than 300 participants: Chuck Davis Afro-American Dance Ensemble (June 5-6, 8); Dance Benefit for AIDS, featuring new works by Ohio choreographers (June 7); ''12 1/4 Degrees: Primary Access,'' a site-specific performance event by Elise Bernhart and Company (June 9); ''World Dances,'' ethnic festival (June 10); Young People's Dance Festival (June 11); Sacred Dances (June 12). Most concerts take place on the campus of Ohio State University. (Ohio Dance Festival, 78 Jefferson Ave., Columbus, Ohio 43215. Phone: 614-461-1166) Wisconsin 1988 SUMMER DANCE FESTIVALSponsored by the Milwaukee Ballet, performances will be offered at the Dance Factory, a new 400-seat theater, 710 W. Virginia St., and at the Milwaukee Performing Arts Center. The artistic director/ choreographer John Neumeier returns home with his Hamburg Ballet in ''Othello'' (June 24-26, Dance Factory) and programs of a mixed bill, ''Mahler Symphony No. 3,'' ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' ''St. Matthew Passion'' (June 29-July 3, Arts Center). Also, at the Dance Factory, the Pennsylvania and Milwaukee Ballet will perform eight world premieres (July 7-10, 14-17); Milwaukee Ballet School Student/ Faculty Company (Aug. 5). (Performing Arts Center, 929 N. Water St., Milwaukee, Wis. Phone: 1-800-843-1558) The West California BALLET PACIFICA Under the direction of the founder/ choreographer Lila Zali, this 10-member classical troupe will perform at the Laguna Moulton Playhouse (June 25-28), Redlands Bowl (July 12) and will return to the grounds at the Festival of Arts to present free concerts on Sunday afternoons at 5 during July and August. (Ballet Pacifica, 1863 S. Coast Hway, Laguna Beach, Calif. 92651. Phone: 714-494-7271) ETHNIC DANCE FESTIVALThe 10th festival of ethnic dances begins Friday at the 915-seat Herbst Theater with more than 30 Bay Area companies and soloists, including Chitresh Das Dance Company (North Indian), Dimensions Dance Theater (Zulu), San Francisco Taiko Dojo (Japanese) and Theater of Flamingo of San Francisco. (Through June 12) (Herbst Theater, 401 Van Ness Ave., San Francisco, Calif. Phone: 415-474-3914) FOOTWORKSThis seven-year-old organization continues its presentation of contemporary dramas, music and dance in a 125-seat theater: Terence Stark's ''Mythos'' (June 2-4, 9-11); Choreographers Showcase, featuring new works by nine regional artists (June 24-25). (Footworks, 3221 22d St., San Francisco, Calif. 94110. Phone: 415-824-5044) JAPANESE-AMERICAN THEATERThe Japanese-American Cultural and Community Center's five-year-old 840-seat hall, located in Little Tokyo, will present: Iso Repertory (June 4); Kanya Sanjo Kabuki Dance (June 12); Tenkei Gekijo in ''Water Station,'' avant-garde (June 25-26); Grand Kabuki from Japan (July 6-10). (Japanese-American Theater, 244 S. San Pedro St., Los Angeles, Calif. 90012. Phone: 213-680-3700) JOFFREY BALLET Artistic director and choreographer Gerald Arpino will present the company in new and revival works, including James Kudelka's ''Concerto Grosso,'' Nijinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps,'' Paul Taylor's ''Arden Court,'' Arpino's ''Light Rain'' and Saint-Leon's ''Vivandiere Pas de Six.'' (July 6-17). (War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco, Calif. Phone: 415-552-8000) ORANGE COUNTY PERFORMING ARTS CENTERAn hour's drive and 50 miles south of Los Angeles, this year-old 3,000-seat theater will present the National Ballet of Canada (June 7-12), Paris Opera Ballet (June 14-19), Royal Spanish National Ballet (Aug. 9-13) and Lola Montes and Her Spanish Dancers (Aug. 27). (600 Town Center Drive, Costa Mesa, Calif. Phone: 714-556-2121) STERN GROVE FESTIVAL The 51st summer season of free Sunday-afternoon entertainment opens on June 19 at the Sigmund Stern Grove, near the ocean at the western end of the city. This festival of performing arts will include the San Francisco Ballet (July 31); ''A Showcase of Bay Area Dance,'' featuring ODC/ San Francisco, Contraband, Ellen Bromberg Dance Ensemble, Dance Art Company and June Watanabe Company (Aug. 7). (Stern Grove, 19th Ave. and Sloat Blvd., San Francisco, Calif. 94111. Phone: 415-398-6551) Colorado BALLET/ASPEN SUMMER DANCE FESTIVAL A five-week season opens with the David Taylor Dance Ensemble (June 17-18, 24-25), at the Wheeler Opera House, and continues with the Hubbard Street Dance Company (July 5-10) and the Ballet West (July 30-Aug. 6), at the Aspen High School Performing Arts Center. (Ballet/Aspen, P.O. Box 8745, Aspen, Colo. 81612. Phone: 303-925-7718) COLORADO DANCE FESTIVAL This three-week series of performances, master classes, dance films and videos and lectures begins Friday; concerts take place in the University of Colorado's Irey Theater. Scheduled presentations include: Doug Varone and Dancers (June 9-10), Llory Wilson and Dancers (June 15-16), Steve Krieckhaus (June 17-18) and Robert Davidson (June 22-26). (Colorado Dance Festival, P.O. Box 356, Boulder, Colo. 80306. Phone: 303-442-7666) SACRED DANCE GUILD FESTIVAL 88''And the Earth Shall Dance,'' a weeklong series of workshops, master classes and performances in ritual and traditional dances, hosted by the Rocky Mountain Chapter of the Guild, on the campus of the Loretto Heights College: Polynesian Evening (July 8); David Taylor Dance Company in ''An Evening of Metaphysical Works'' (July 9-10); and regional artists. (Loretto Heights College, 3001 S. Federal Blvd., Denver, Colo. Phone: 303-377-9114) Oregon BRITT FESTIVAL The annual series of theater, classical, jazz and bluegrass music and dance begins June 24 (through Aug. 30) at the outdoor pavilion; dance events will include the Eugene Ballet in ''Cinderella'' (July 1-2) and the Jazz Tap Ensemble (July 3).
