(Britt Festivals, P.O. Box 1124, Medford, Ore. 97501. Phone: 1-800-882-7488) Texas TEXAS The musical extravaganza, written by Paul Green, choreographed/ directed by Neil Hess and with a cast of 80, returns to the Palo Duro Canyon State Park's amphitheater, located in Canyon, just 16 miles south of Amarillo (June 15-Aug. 27); this will be the production's 23d season. (Texas, Box 268, Canyon, Texas 79015. Phone: 806-655-2181) Utah FESTIVAL OF THE AMERICAN WEST The 16th annual pageant of early American music, theater, dance, arts and crafts will feature more than 100 performers at various sites on the campus of the Utah State University. Dance events include the Burch Mann's American Folk Ballet, Wisdom Indian Dancers and Golden Dragon Acrobats and Musicians from Taipei (July 29-Aug. 8). (Utah State University, Logan, Utah 84322-0125. Phone: 801-750-1143) UTAH ARTS FESTIVAL The free outdoor summer series returns to downtown Salt Lake City's Triad Center with visual and performing artists, including the Elisa Monte Dance Company, Ballet West, Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company, Repertory Dance Theater, Company of Four, Utah Regional Ballet and International Folk Ballet (June 22-26). (Utah Arts Festival, 168 W. 500 North, Salt Lake City, Utah 84103. Phone: 801-322-2428)

title: Monroe D. North, 77; Ran Fruit of the Loom
description: Monroe D. North, former president of Fruit of the Loom Inc., died Tuesday at the Whitehall Boca Raton Nursing Home in Florida. He was 77 years old and had lived in Atlantis, Fla.

title: Rabbis for Russia
description: In a salutary step, the Soviet Union has agreed in principle to the opening of a rabbinical school, the first in 50 years, under the direction of a distinguished Israeli rabbi, Adin Steinsaltz. That the Russians let this be announced in Jerusalem the other day was doubtless a bit of pre-summit public relations, but the step is welcome nonetheless.

title: C. E. F. Sandmel Married To Barbara Ann Simonetti
description: The marriage of Barbara Ann Simonetti, a daughter of Mary R. Simonetti of Stamford, Conn., and the late Arthur Simonetti, to Charles Edwin Fox Sandmel, a son of Frances F. Sandmel of Waterville, Me., and the late Rabbi Samuel Sandmel, took place last evening at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated.

title: Somerville: Peace Sites a Goal
description: TWO years ago, the Borough Council here adopted a resolution proposed by then Mayor Emanuel R. Luftglass to have Borough Hall become the first government building in the world designated as a symbolic site for global peace.

title: Q and A
description: Broken Drain Pipe

title: State Seeking Ways To Send Poor to College
description: LEAD: HALF the people in Bridgeport older than 25 have not graduated from high school, according to State Higher Education Department figures.

title: On England's Saintly Border
description: THE cry of seagulls and the slow beat of the mute swans' wings as they rise from the River Tweed symbolize the haunting, isolated beauty of Berwick-upon-Tweed. The river dictates the lie of the town. It comes in a wide sweep to meet the sea, enfolding the town in a near complete embrace of water.

title:
INVESTING;
How Day Traders Cut Costs
description: LEAD: NOT every small investor has fled the stock market. One breed, the day trader, is still very active, despite a contracting, institutionally-driven market that is often subject to wide swings.

title: House Members Stake Out Positions On Ethics Charges Against Speaker
description: Charges of ethics violations against Speaker Jim Wright have set off a bitter exchange in the House of Representatives.

title: An Exhibition Of Glenn Gould Memorabilia Sheds A Little Light on A Musical Enigma
description: In the 19th century there was Emma Albani from Quebec, whose 1882 performance in ''Lohengrin'' in Berlin delighted Kaiser Wilhelm I. Since World War II, there have been Lois Marshall, Maureen Forrester and Jon Vickers, singers of international stature. But there has never been a Canadian who seized the attention of the world more than Glenn Gould, the musical iconoclast whose appearances as an international concert pianist between 1955 and 1964 enthralled audiences and critics in New York, London and Moscow as much as in his native Toronto.

title:
GARDENING;
Containers Add Color and Reduce Care
description: LEAD: PEOPLE living in condominiums or apartments don't have the option of going out to plow the back 40 or replace part of the lawn with flowers or vegetables. For them, containers may be the only choice in gardening. There are also good reasons for homeowners with plenty of space to confine much of their gardening to containers.

title: What a Difference A Digit Makes
description: IT happens at least once a week, sometimes once a day or more. The phone rings. I answer it. The person on the other end asks me to send a taxi to such and such an address.

title: Parkway to Get Barriers at Median
description: LEAD: IN response to an unprecedented number of automobile accidents on the Southern State Parkway, transportation officials have agreed to install central barriers at the most troublesome spots in the hope of stopping cars from crossing the grassy median into oncoming traffic.

title: The Pleasures Of the Parkways
description: I often travel on the parkways from Heckscher Park to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, and I must disagree with Kenneth Marion [ ''Parkways, Once Pretty, Now Pathetic,'' Opinion Page, April 17 ] . While it is, indeed, a crowded and messy world compared with the 50's, the parkways remain a highlight of modern life.

title: Hungary Assails Rumania on Village Razings
description: Hungary has charged that a vast program in Rumania to consolidate villages is intended to erase the Hungarian heritage in areas of Transylvania that were severed from Hungary after World War I. The Hungarian Foreign Ministry, which has not made a formal statement on the matter to the Rumanian Government, has given foreign reporters translations of articles from Hungary's Government-controlled press. The articles protest the program. The articles charge that President Nicolae Ceausescu has decided to accelerate a program to reduce the number of villages in Rumania from 13,000 to 6,000 and to convert the land where the villages stood to agriculture. Rural populations are to be consolidated in small agricultural towns.

title: Klecko on the Road
description: JOE KLECKO, the former Jet Pro Bowl nose tackle, made his annual pilgrimage to Indianapolis to visit his friend A. J. Foyt before today's Indy 500 . This time, Klecko also is in Indianapolis looking for a place to live. He is now a Colt.

title: Takeover in Jersey City
description: The New Jersey Constitution says the state must provide each child with a ''thorough and efficient'' education. Last week, state education officials were trying to do just that when they moved to take over the Jersey City schools.

title: For Reagans, Stately Rooms But No View
description: When President and Mrs. Reagan stay at Spaso House, they will be adding their names to a long and illustrious list of guests who have visited the yellow mansion that has been the American Ambassador's residence in Moscow since 1933.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 29, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to contemporary New York. 2 2 12 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists. 3 3 6 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested. 4 4 6 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 5 5 30 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 6 6 3 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York. 7 10 11 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a pursuit of hijackers. 8 11 2 FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) A Detroit police detective investigates a series of crimes. 9 8 4 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. 10 7 11 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family. 11 9 15 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 12 15 5 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. 13 1 SCORPIUS, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the tortuous trail of a global czar of vice and terrorism. 14 12 8 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) What ensues when a socialite sacrifices a family fortune to marry for love. 15 13 2 PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.) An overture to the five-volume science fiction saga. 16 * 31 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 17 * 14 12 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 FOR THE RECORD, by Donald T. Regan. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former Treasury Secretary and chief of staff. 2 2 6 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 1 4 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the celebrated performer. 4 3 24 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 5 6 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 6 8 5 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 7 9 17 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 8 6 5 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The recollections of President Reagan's former spokesman. 9 4 55 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 10 10 29 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 11 12 7 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 12 12 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 13 * 13 8 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life and times of the New York lawyer and political figure Roy M. Cohn. 14 15 6 WINFIELD, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Norton, $16.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee outfielder. 15 16 8 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 47 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 8 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 7 139 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 5 8 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. 5 3 5 BEING A WOMAN, by Toni Grant. (Random House, $17.95.) How to achieve a life balanced between feminism and femininity. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) QUINN'S BOOK, by William Kennedy. (Viking, $18.95.) Ardent, bawdy and alive on every page with its author's passion for Albany and the past, this rags-to-britches novel of the 19th century evokes the age of Dickens as well that of Gabriel Garcia Marquez. THE GIRL FROM CARDIGAN, by Leslie Norris. (Gibbs M. Smith/ Peregrine Smith, $15.95.) Set in a Wales and Somerset almost as good-natured as the narrators' voices, these 16 unusually sweet-tempered tales explore the mundane with grace. RECONSTRUCTION: America's Unfinished Revolution 1863-1877, by Eric Foner. (Harper & Row, $29.95.) A splendid, compelling book that traces the construction and then deconstruction of the post-Civil War period and with it the promise of real freedom. WITTGENSTEIN'S MISTRESS, by David Markson. (Dalkey Archive, $20.) The novelist, a trapeze artist with words, has written a 240-page monologue u 1/4atomomes across as a dialogue and can be parsed like a sentence. DIARY: Volume One, by Witold Gombrowicz. Edited by Jan Kott. (Northwestern University, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $12.95.) The philosophical notebook of a 20th-century writer and Polish exile who believed in bringing to light precisely what one is ashamed of. THE PERON NOVEL, by Tomas Eloy Martinez. (Pantheon, $19.95.) A vividly written fictional death's head image of a national psychosis by a journalist who left Argentina in 1975. WHERE I'M CALLING FROM: New and Selected Stories, by Raymond Carver. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The great gift of this realist (no minimalist he) is the beauty of his best stories, in which a sort of bafflement is the buffer against very ordinary lives.

title: Package Tours
description: To the Editor: My wife and I went on a ''Bard and Bolshoi Holiday,'' but there wasn't any Bard, there wasn't any Bolshoi, and there ought to be a law . . . .

title: The National Mood
description: PETULIA Starring Julie Christie (in photo), George C. Scott, Richard Chamberlain, Arthur Hill, Joseph Cotten. Directed by Richard Lester. 1968. Warner Home Video. 05 minutes. $59.95. Rated R.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kennebunkport, Me.; Historic Inn To Be Rebuilt
description: THE owners of the Shawmut Inn will soon begin a $20 million project to renovate and expand the historic inn beside the Atlantic Ocean.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Orange
description: ORANGE has a low profile, and that is just what many residents like about it. The assets of this southern Connecticut town lie in a profusion of well-tended homes and gardens and old working farms sprawled across the hilltops. Three of its schools have won awards for excellence from the United States Department of Education in the last few years. Taxes are reasonable, and it is rare to find a scrap of trash on the street.

title: IN THE '88 CAMPAIGN, THE BABY-BOOM VOTERS ARE CURIOUSLY QUIET
description: Where have all the baby boomers gone?

title: Sorting Out the Graphics Alphabet
description: BRACE yourself for an alphabet attack. We're going on a tour of computer graphics standards, which are usually described in letter triplets such as M.P.A., C.G.A., E.G.A., V.G.A. and so on.

title: Life Beyond the Kremlin
description: They are Europeans. They are Asians.

title: First Ladies' Traveling Road Show: We're Fine, Thank You Very Much
description: When they met beneath the gilded bronze chandeliers in St. George's Hall, they smiled with brittle cordiality. When they listened to their husbands' dueling proverbs, their stolid expressions melted into laughter. By the time they emerged from the towering Assumption Cathedral, Nancy Reagan and Raisa Gorbachev were holding hands.

title: Athens Journal; 30-Year Intermission Will End for Black Theater
description: The final curtain fell in the Morton Theater 30 years ago. But if you stand anywhere in the empty auditorium, amid broken wood planks and crumbling bricks, you can almost see the ghosts of black singers and comedians and hear their music and jokes.

title: WQXR to Stop Offering Reason for Stock Moves
description: Because experts' interpretations of stock market fluctuations often ''confuse rather than inform,'' New York radio stations WQXR-FM and AM will stop incorporating them into their daily stock market reports, said Warren Bodow, WQXR's president. The policy change will take effect tomorrow.

title: Moving Up
description: They make the most money and they have the shortest work weeks, so it should stand to reason that major league baseball, basketball and football players have some of the best of all possible jobs.

title: Machine Tool Orders Dropped a Bit in April
description: Orders for American-made machine tools declined six-tenths of 1 percent in April from the previous month, to $253 million, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Coroner's Report Blames Cocaine For Drowning of Illinois Boy, 10
description: Despite his family's insistence that it could not be true, a coroner's report says a 10-year-old boy drowned because he had used cocaine.

title: Runaways of 42d Street: AIDS Begins Its Scourge
description: Robert was born on Rikers Island, and his luck never got much better.

title: L.I. Doctor Is Found Slain at Starrett City
description: The body of a physician who had been stabbed in the back of the head was found in some tall grass in Starrett City yesterday afternoon by the security police at the Brooklyn housing project.

title: Harlan H. Simon Wed To Eden Michele Platt
description: Eden Michele Platt, a foreign exchange broker with Harlow Meyer Savage, and Harlan H. Simon, a foreign exchange trader with Bank America International, both in New York, were married yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr., assisted by Cantor Joseph Boardman, performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: THE MOSCOW SUMMIT: THE SOCIAL SIDE  Reporter's Notebook; Presidential Stroll: Chaos and Applause
description: While Yuri and Tatyana Ziman waited under siege in their apartment this evening, President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, took a chaotic stroll along Moscow's Arbat pedestrian mall.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albertson's Inc., Boise, Idaho, a food and drug chain, named as a director A. Gary Ames, president and chief executive of Mountain Bell, a subsidiary of U S West, Denver.

title:
Music;
Joint Recital: Osceola Davis, George Shirley
description: LEAD: In a joint recital with the tenor George Shirley at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, Osceola Davis confirmed the impression made at her recital debut a few seasons back. The young American soprano, who has been active with the Finnish National Opera, has a light coloratura voice of pleasing quality, fresh right up to the high F's of Mozart's ''Mia speranza adorata.

title: Soviet Cyclist Wins in Jersey
description: For the first time ever in an Olympic year, cyclists from the Soviet Union and the United States are holding a series of competitive meets. They met today in the 17th annual Tour of Nutley Bicycle Classic, a 50-mile race through the streets of this Essex County town.

title: Shall Tourists or Grapes Rule in the Napa Valley?
description: It was a proposal that the Florida marketing company hoped the Napa Valley vintner would find irresistible.

title: Eliza O. Webb Weds Physician
description: The marriage of Eliza Ordway Webb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., to Dr. Craig Robert Faulks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Faulks of Rocky River, Ohio, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan. The Rev. Guthrie T. Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-8

title: BRIEFING
description: Morale Check

title: Newspaper Executive Kidnapped in Bogota
description: Men firing submachine guns kidnapped a newspaper executive who was once a presidential candidate today after shooting his bodyguard, radio stations reported.

title: Amy Eppler Wed To Steven Epstein
description: Amy Eppler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Klaus Eppler of New York and Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Daniel Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett N. Epstein of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Esther Adler officiated at the Norwalk, Conn., home of Irene Hochheime, a grandmother of the bridegroom.

title: Twins Run Victory Streak to 8 Games
description: Kirby Puckett didn't know if a first-inning pitch near his head carried a message or not but he answered it with two home runs, including the game-winner.

title: Booksellers' Meeting Draws Publishing Leaders, and Imitators
description: Avon Books once boycotted the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association, saying it was not worth the six-figure cost of attending. But the publisher was soon back at the same old stand - several stands, in fact. Concluding that it had been mistaken in staying away, Avon wanted to display its wares in style.

title: Edith Newhall Weds
description: St. David's (Radnor) Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Edith Allerton Newhall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Newhall of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, to David Leslie Stuart Walters, the son of William Walters of Bozeman, Mont., and the late Mary Wilson Walters. The Rev. Rudolf A. Moore performed the ceremony. The bride is an editor at New York magazine. Mr. Walters is the art director of Premiere magazine in New York.

title: Outdoors: Bluefish Begin to Stir
description: IT was improbable but delightful. I was at Wasque Point at Chappaquiddick. The falling tide was racing to the westward, bluefish were in the rip gobbling up alewives that had only recently completed their spawning runs, and I was alone.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: FITNESS;
Sports Energy Drinks: The Facts and Fiction
description: LEAD: THE heat of summer will soon burst upon us, raising the question about what to drink in connection with exercise. The obvious answer, of course, is water. It has met man's biological needs for thousands of years and still seems adequate to the task.

title: Elaine Black Yoneda, 81, Radical Labor Activist
description: Elaine Black Yoneda, a radical labor activist during the Depression and the 1934 San Francisco general strike, died of a heart attack here on Thursday. She was 81 years old.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Gross Weds Paul Garland
description: Dr. Elizabeth Jane Gross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Gross of Sands Point, L.I., was married last evening to Paul Bennett Garland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Garland of New York. Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg officiated at the Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: Magazines Pursue Japan's Working Woman
description: The Japanese woman, for years portrayed as a cheerful housewife in a frilly apron, has a new image in women's magazines here: she works.

title: Where Have All the 20-Game Winners Gone?
description: SINCE the end of World War II, 29 pitchers have recorded 20 victories or more in a season three or more times. Roger Clemens is on his way to becoming the 30th. If he does, he would be the first to attain that level of quality pitching in the 1980's.

title: Robert J. Townsend, Ski Coach, 66
description: Robert J. Townsend, a member of the National Ski Hall of Fame and ski coach at Williams College for 22 years, died of cancer Friday at North Adams Regional Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Laura Lipitz Cherkis Is Wed to John Katz
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Laura Lipitz Cherkis was married yesterday to John Katz by Rabbi Jack Stern, a cousin of the bridegroom.

title: REAGAN AND GORBACHEV BEGIN SUMMIT PARLEY IN THE KREMLIN; 'STRIKE SPARKS' ON RIGHTS ISSUE
description: Opening his first visit to the Soviet Union, President Reagan quickly engaged Mikhail S. Gorbachev today in a heated discussion on human rights.

title: Blues; Liquid Solos and Falsetto
description: The blues guitarist and singer Albert King doesn't play a note so much as he worries it. He'll create an entire line by bending the strings of his guitar instead of moving his fingers, creating liquid solos dripping with passion. Onstage, Mr. King passes himself off as an avuncular, happy figure; in contrast, his solos sound anguished.

title: Dollar Speculators Warned
description: A senior United States Treasury official warned financial markets on Saturday not to speculate on the dollar because leading industrial nations were determined to stabilize the currency and to coordinate economic policies.

title: Strange Surges To Take Memorial
description: Curtis Strange blasted out of a bunker to within 18 inches of the 15th hole for a birdie 4, then sank a 12-foot birdie putt on 17 to win the Memorial Tournament today. He finished two strokes ahead of Hale Irwin and David Frost.

title: Major Shake-Up in Pakistan
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq dissolved the National Assembly today, dismissed his Prime Minister and accused the lawmakers of failing to maintain law and order in Pakistan.

title: Afghan Parliament Convenes With Call for End to Fighting
description: President Najibullah today convened Afghanistan's first Parliament in 15 years with a call for Moslem guerrillas to lay down their arms immediately and take legislative seats held open for them.

title: Soviet Teen-Ager Upsets Navratilova
description: Martina Navratilova has left the French Open to the teen-agers by losing today, 6-3, 7-6, to 17-year-old Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union.

title: 50 HOUSES USED FOR DRUGS FELLED
description: Bulldozers flattened 50 vacant houses over three days last week in an attempt by the Mayor's office to rid the city of buildings used as bases for drug activity.

title: Eriko Kusomoto Marries Dr. Robert John Gottner
description: At St. Patrick's Cathedral, Eriko Kusomoto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Kusomoto of Fort Lee, N.J., and Osaka, Japan, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert John Gottner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gottner of Arlington Heights, Ill. The Rev. James P. McIlhone performed the ceremony.

title: Yankees Win; Victory May Be Costly
description: John Candelaria's seventh victory of the season might have been the costliest. The Yankee left-hander, who had been the club's most dependable and most productive pitcher this season, was forced to leave tonight's game against the Seattle Mariners after five innings because of soreness in his left elbow.

title: Lori Barbanel Is Wed
description: At Congregation Adas Kodesch Shel Emeth in Wilmington, Del., Lori Leslie Barbanel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Barbanel of Tamarac, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark David Kuller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kuller of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Leonard E. Gewirz and Cantor Morris Markowitz officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is the special assistant to the director of the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Wilmington. Mr. Kuller is a patent lawyer for Hercules Inc. in Wilmington.

title: The Fame Game
description: He may not be the most famous man in America, but Don Dunphy is in the running. He has been inducted into eight halls of fame, and as far as anyone seems to know, that may be a record.

title: The Sobersided Summit
description: At last we face the possibility of a sobersided Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting. After the euphoria of Geneva, the frenzy at Reykjavik and the super-salesmanship in Washington, we approach R-G IV somewhat subdued. Pity we have to break up the team just when they're getting the hang of it.

title: Horse Racing; Seeking the Gold Captures Peter Pan
description: Seeking the Gold and Tejano ran head and head for nearly a mile before Seeking the Gold drew away to a two-length victory yesterday in the $234,800 Peter Pan Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park.

title: Catherine Keggi, Counselor, Weds
description: At the Congregational Church in Middlebury, Conn., Catherine Grant Keggi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kristaps Juris Keggi of Middlebury, was married yesterday to George Howard Hunter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Hunter Jr. of New Orleans. The Rev. A. Edward Couch performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Goddard Marries James H. Scott 3d in South
description: At St. Paul's Memorial Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va., Jennifer Goddard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Goddard of South Kent, Conn., was married yesterday to James Hamilton Scott 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Jr. of Charlottesville. The Rev. David Poist performed the ceremony.

title: Battery Park City Fell Into a Political Mudhole
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprising Stanford Eliminates Rutgers
description: The tag that has been affixed to the Stanford University baseball team -defending national champion - can be as unreasonable as it can be complimentary.

title: Westway Substitute Not on Map For 10 Years
description: Fifteen years after the collapse of the old West Side Highway and more than two years after the ambitious Westway project expired, a new replacement road is still at least a decade away.

title: Architecture Awards for Restorations
description: Several of New York City's most talked-about restoration projects, as well a shelter for the homeless in Brooklyn and a college library in Queens, have received Albert S. Bard Awards for Excellence in Architecture and Urban Design, which are presented by the City Club of New York.

title: In Experiment, Summer Job Program Tries Matching the Student to the Job
description: Most of the 30 or so students gathered in the large library of George Wingate High School in Brooklyn raised their hands when asked, ''How many of you have never had a job before?''

title: Imperfect Ending For Ojeda and Mets
description: In another moment of defeat and disgust, Bob Ojeda paused as he exited a game in April to heave his glove into the box seats. Yesterday, with everything that was important already having been thrown away, Ojeda opted not to add either his glove or his remaining patience to the mess.

title: Siaka P. Stevens Is Dead at 82; Sierra Leone Leader for 17 Years
description: Former President Siaka P. Stevens, who led this small West African nation for 17 years, died today at his home after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Metro Matters; From City Hall To President Of Lincoln Center
description: When Nathan Leventhal resigned as New York City's Deputy Mayor four years ago to become president of Lincoln Center, he received the following telegram from a law school classmate: ''Congratulations on finally getting into politics.''

title: Business and the Law; Trying State Suits In Federal Courts
description: THE year was 1809 and Chief Justice John Marshall, explaining why Federal courts should be able to hear cases involving state law, said that the Constitution ''entertains apprehensions'' that local courts are biased in favor of local citizens.

title: Books of The Times; Strength and Contemplation in Two Novels
description: After She Left By Richard P. Brickner 290 pages. Donald Hutter/Henry Holt. $18.95. The Jade Stalk By Jonathan Fast 271 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Beyond the Kremlin
description: They worry about drug and alcohol addiction, a high divorce rate and death on the highway. They are voracious readers. They love television and the theater. Here are some of the facts of life in the Soviet Union 71 years after the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Who Should Honor the Dead?
description: Flags make for wonderful parades, but waving them clouds reason and constricts sympathy. Even as President Reagan is today an honored guest in the Soviet Union, a veterans' group in a New England town has barred a group of visiting Soviet teen-agers from the town's Memorial Day parade.

title: Ouster of Texas University Chief Is Generating Charges of Politics
description: The dismissal of the president of Southwest Texas State University has led to bitter allegations of political interference in the Texas higher education system.

title: CBS Wins the Olympics: Will It Ever See the Gold?
description: WHEN word came last week that CBS had bought the American television rights to the 1992 Winter Olympics, with a bid of $243 million, industry critics immediately challenged the wisdom of the deal. Had third-place CBS, desperate for a big play, recklessly overpaid? It was noted that ABC, which perfected the Olympics as prime-time entertainment, had dropped out of the bidding early after losing money on this year's Winter Games, and that the other network with Olympics experience, NBC, had offered $68 million less than did CBS, which has not staged an Olympics telecast since Dwight D. Eisenhower was President.

title: Kristin Klein Married To William J. Donahoe
description: Mary Kristin Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Klein Jr. of Morgan Hill, Calif., and William Joseph Donahoe, a son of Col. and Mrs. Joseph Donahoe of Cincinnati, were married yesterday. The Rev. Daniel Zak, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Sacred Heart School in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Pentagon Reports Troop Cut
description: The armed forces continued to slash their active-duty strength in April to meet budget cuts, paring more than 28,500 positions from their ranks in one month, the Pentagon has reported.

title: How to Tell Psychologists From Psychiatrists
description: To the Editor:

title: Drivers, Start Your Engines
description: Have your friends ever likened your tendencies behind the wheel to those of Parnelli Jones or Mario Andretti? Have you ever wanted to test your driving skills in a car race? The Fairfield County Sports Car Club offers you that chance at its third autocross of the season next Sunday. The event, to be held in the parking lot behind Pitney Bowes in Norwalk, Conn., is open to all drivers with valid licenses, registration and insurance.

title: Pistons Lead but Still Worry
description: The usual psychological warfare was on today at the Detroit Pistons' and Boston Celtics' practices.

title: Walters in Saudi Arabia
description: Vernon A. Walters, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, held talks today with King Fahd in the Red Sea city of Jidda on the ninth leg of a Middle East tour. Mr. Walters is visiting the region to exchange ideas on the war between Iran and Iraq and other issues.

title: Old Times Square: A Block of Memories
description: If you are looking for the last vestige of old Times Square, begin at the sign of Simple Simon and the Pieman.

title: The Science of Socking It
description: THE greatest home-run hitter I ever saw was Ronnie Wolkowitz. Some people may never have heard of Ronnie Wolkowitz, but for one summer, when I was a boy, Ronnie Wolkowitz terrorized not only pitchers but old ladies carrying groceries, too.

title: Olympic Notebook; Drug Tests Scare Off Athletes
description: The use of anabolic steroids by some athletes has apparently caused organizers of the Pepsi Invitational next Sunday in Los Angeles to cancel two of the throwing events, the shot-put and the discus throw.

title: Gateway Parks Area Needs Federal Help
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealand (Minus Woolly Thinking)
description: When people in New York and Washington find out that I have recently returned from a self-granted sabbatical year in New Zealand, I can't escape. ''Tell me about it,'' they implore. ''I've been thinking about going [ working, living, retiring ] there myself. Is it as beautiful as they say? No wonder you look so relaxed.''

title: Israel Investigates Charges That Army Buried Arabs
description: The Israeli Army agreed today to investigate charges that soldiers in the West Bank buried four Palestinians up to the chest with rocks for several hours, injuring them slightly.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China will soon allow foreign banks to open branches in large coastal cities, Li Guixian, the governor of the People's Bank of China, said. Currently, foreign banks can open new branches only in special economic zones in south China. The New China news agency quoted Mr. Li as telling a meeting of bankers that China should reform its foreign exchange system, letting coastal cities borrow more short-term foreign exchange, allowing a limited number of individuals to deal in foreign exchange and allowing companies to open foreign exchange accounts.

title: Woman Is Slain While Holding Infant in Arms
description: A 43-year-old woman was shot to death in her home in Hollis, Queens, Saturday night by four young men who fired 18 bullets into the house while she was holding her 6-month-old son and talking on the telephone, the police said.

title: Marketing Wins, News Loses, on TV
description: The television news business is having an identity crisis. It arises out of conflict. The conflict is between journalism and marketing. Journalism addresses the realities of people's lives. Marketing addresses their fantasies.

title: Philby's Recruitment
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Move Aids Tiny Company
description: For years the cervical cap has been a cause celebre for a relatively small group of American feminists and health professionals. But this thimble-shaped birth control device has been little known beyond its circle of enthusiasts.

title: Transcripts of Reagan and Gorbachev Remarks
description: Following are transcripts of the statements by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan on Mr. Reagan's arrival today at the Kremlin. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by a Soviet interpreter. Gorbachev Statement

title: Crackdown on Tailgate Beers at Shea
description: Under a sky a few shades shy of Mets blue, Gary Deutch and his friends began a time-honored pre-game ritual in the Shea Stadium parking lot yesterday: They gathered at the rear of their Ford Fiesta and popped open a few cans of beer.

title: Review/Television; Film Group Tribute To Lemmon
description: Everybody loves Jack Lemmon. That's the comforting message of ''A Salute to Jack Lemmon,'' on CBS tonight at 10. The occasion is the 16th Annual American Film Institute Life Achievement Award. The all-star dinner, adorned with black ties and gowns, took place in Beverly Hills on March 10.

title: Reagan Is Said to Believe Meese Hurts Bush
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said today that he and President Reagan believe that the investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has damaged Vice President Bush's Presidential election chances.

title: Today's Summit Schedule
description: All times are local. Moscow is eight hours ahead of Eastern daylight time. PRESIDENT REAGAN 10 to 11:45 A.M. Meets Mikhail S. Gorbachev in St. Catherine's Hall in the Kremlin. Noon to 1:45 P.M. Returns to Spaso House, the U.S. Ambassador's residence. 2 to 2:30 P.M. Visits the Danilov Monastery in Moscow with Mrs. Reagan. 3:45 to 5 P.M. Meets with and addresses selected Soviet citizens at Spaso House. 7 to 9 P.M. Reagans attend a state dinner given by Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, in the Granovitaya Palata (Faceted Chamber) of the Grand Kremlin Palace. MRS. REAGAN 10 to 10:45 A.M. Visits School 1254, where she greets children and discusses the school's work. 11:15 to 11:50 A.M. Visits the grave and dacha of Boris Pasternak in the Moscow suburb of Peredelkino. 11:55 to 12:50 P.M. Visits the dacha of the poet Andrei Voznesensky in Peredelkino, where she has lunch.

title: Reds' Blunder in 9th Helps Pirates Win
description: Dave Concepcion tagged up too soon from third base to scuttle a ninth-inning rally and preserve the Pittsburgh Pirates' 4-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

title: Ms. Roberts Wed To Dr. B. D. Zevin
description: Margaret Page Roberts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Roberts of Philadelphia, and Dr. Barry David Zevin, a son of Linda Zevin and Dr. Ronald A. Zevin, both of Short Hills, N.J., were married yesterday in Philadelphia. Judge Dolores K. Sloviter of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia performed the ceremony at the Belmont mansion in Fairmount Park.

title: Reagan's TV Debut In Soviet
description: LEAD: Whatever else may lie in store for President Reagan in his first visit to Moscow, he will finally realize one dream: a full-dress solo performance on Soviet television, in a setting of his own choosing.

title: New Summit Proverb: Speak Not Russian Ill
description: Before getting down to business in the Kremlin yesterday, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev added to their summit anthology of Russian folk wisdom. Mr. Gorbachev seemed to have some trouble with Mr. Reagan's contribution, rendered in fractured Russian.

title: Dr. Harold Rusch, Cancer Researcher, 79
description: Dr. Harold Rusch, the first director of the University of Wisconsin McArdle Laboratory for Cancer Research, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Madison. He was 79 years old.

title: Downturn In Steel Predicted
description: Shipments and profits in the steel industry may have peaked after nearly two years of steady increases. Indeed, some industry executives and economists are predicting declines in the second half of this year.

title: Judy Doctoroff Weds James Anthony O'Neill
description: Judy Ellen Doctoroff, a television producer for Bill Moyers at Public Affairs Television in New York, and James Anthony O'Neill, a research chemist in the microelectronics sciences laboratory at Columbia University, were married yesterday at the Marriott Copley Place in Boston by Rabbi Albert S. Axelrad.

title: Investigation Is Opened Of Prosecutor in Queens
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that he was investigating allegations that the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, had misused city funds in connection with the unsuccessful 1982 and 1984 State Senate campaigns by his son, Thomas Santucci.

title: Maxwell Buys 67% of Printer
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell said today that the Maxwell Communication Corporation had acquired majority control of a French printing concern, Franc,ois Imprimerie.

title: Mears Wins a Checkered 500 for His 3d Indy Title
description: The Indianapolis 500, slowed all day by accidents, ended in confusion today. The only apparently clear facts were that Rick Mears won here for the third time and Roger Penske, the owner of Mears's car, made clever use of the ever-present yellow caution flags.

title: The Greening of the Red Planet
description: During President Reagan's visit to Moscow this week, his host will engage him in serious talk about a favorite subject, the stars. ''Drop 'Star Wars,' '' Mr. Gorbachev will say. ''Let's have our countries go together to Mars instead.'' Mr. Reagan won't lightly abandon his missile defense project but he might be tempted by the Mars mission, which Mr. Gorbachev has lost no time in proposing.

title: Nothing Mini About the L'eggs Mini Marathon
description: It was a Sunday morning in March, seven days before the official onset of spring. The woman in the white T-shirt was ahead of me as I eased into the final downhill of a six-mile run around Central Park.

title: To Save the Endangered Addax Antelope
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance; 2 Kirov Stars Galvanize Ballet Theater 'Bayadere'
description: Even in a ballet season that has witnessed one apparent milestone after another in American-Soviet cooperation, Saturday night's debut with American Ballet Theater by two guest stars from the Kirov Ballet -Altynai Assylmuratova and Faruk Ruzimatov - stands out as a historic occasion.

title: Clipper and Gipper And Gorbachev, Too
description: AS President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold their summit meeting in Moscow, the two leaders will be followed closely by one of their most fervent fans back in the United States: Joe DiMaggio.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING Canadian Sets World Record: Allison Higson of Canada set a world record in the 200-meter breast-stroke yesterday at the Canadian Olympic trials in Montreal. Higson, 15 years old, was timed in 2 minutes 27.27 seconds, breaking the mark of 2:27.40 set in 1986 by Silke Horner of East Germany.(AP) Meagher Places 3d and 8th: Mary T. Meagher finished third and eighth, Pablo Morales seventh and Matt Biondi 26th yesterday in the Sundown Swim to Seoul international meet in Boca Raton, Fla. No, these American world-record holders and 1984 Olympic gold medalists have not lost their skills. Instead, they are trying to peak for the United States Olympic trials Aug. 8-13 in Austin, Tex., and did not taper their training or rest for this meet. Meagher finished eighth and last in the women's 200-meter freestyle final in 2 minutes 5.43 seconds. Laura Walker of San Ramon, Calif., won in 2:01.35. Twenty-six minutes later, Meagher placed third in the 100-meter butterfly in 1:01.40. Catherine Plewinski of France won in 1:00.10, the second fastest in the world this year. Morales of Santa Clara, Calif., finished seventh in the 100-meter butterfly in 55.44 seconds; Jon Sieben of Australia won in 53.98 seconds. Biondi of Moraga, Calif., finished 26th in the 200-meter freestyle trials in 1:56.36. In the final, Artur Wojdat of Poland and Tom Stachewicz of Australia tied for first in 1:49.79. GOLF 2d Successive Victory for Turner: Sherri Turner shot a two-under-par 70 yesterday to win the $325,000 Corning Classic in Corning, N.Y., for her second consecutive victory. Coupled with Turner's victory last week at the L.P.G.A. Championship, the victory gave Turner the first consecutive triumphs on the tour this season. Turner had a four-round total of 15-under 273 and earned $48,750. Ok Hee Ku of South Korea and JoAnne Carner tied for second at 275.(AP) Charles Tops Moody: Bob Charles chipped in from the back fringe of the green on the final hole yesterday for a three-under-par 69 and a 2-shot victory over Orville Moody in the $275,000 Sunwest Bank Senior PGA Tour tournament in Albuquerque, N.M. Charles finished at 10-under 206. (AP) BOXING Canadian Retains Title: Don Lalonde of Canada stopped Leslie Stewart of Trinidad with a smashing overhand right in the fifth round yesterday of a scheduled 12-round fight in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, to retain his World Boxing Council light heavyweight title. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD St. Anthony Wins Catholic Title: Ian Jones of Nazareth moved past Paul Whittaker of Xaverian with 300 meters to go and won the 800-meter run in 1 minute 52.2 seconds, a personal best, in the 62d annual Catholic High School's Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships yesterday at Randalls Island. The winning time is the second fastest in New York State this season. Whittaker's second-place time of 1:52.6 is also a personal best and third fastest in the state. Later, Whittaker ran a 1:53.4 split on the 3,200-meter relay.

title: Bush's Top Strategists: Smooth Poll-Taker and Hard-Driving Manager
description: Robert Teeter spent 1976 trying to prove that the Republican in the White House (a congenial, decent, sometimes awkward man) was better than an unknown Democrat (a serious, smart and frugal governor with no foreign policy experience.) Thanks in good measure to Mr. Teeter's surveys and strategies, President Gerald R. Ford rebounded from 30 points behind in the polls and came close to overtaking Jimmy Carter.

title: Three Days in Managua: Discord Gives Way to Common Ground
description: After three days of peace talks that ended Saturday night, the Government and the contra guerrillas appear closer than ever to a final armistice, although the two sides are still separated by important differences.

title: Group Rides Refine Biking Skills
description: LARRY BLOMBERG of Pompton Plains, N.J., an accomplished swimmer, took up bicycling three years ago to round out his fitness and take part in triathlons. But it was not until he joined group rides that he developed cycling skills, began to fill his competitive potential and truly gained from a sport that requires more technical finesse than meets the eye.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Art and Politics; Fuentes a World Citizen at Home in Washington
description: Novelist, essayist, professor and diplomat, Carlos Fuentes is a well traveled citizen of the world. But, at curious junctures in his life, Washington has been home to him, first as the son of a Mexican diplomat posted here in the 1930's, 25 years later as a resident fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and the last few months as the Heritage Professor of Arts and Cultural Criticism at George Mason University in suburburan Virginia.

title: THE NORIEGA FIASCO: WHAT WENT WRONG
description: The collapse of the United States effort to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to step down as leader of Panama resulted from a series of miscalculations and a lack of coordination among the agencies responsible for policy toward Panama, according to American officials and diplomats.

title: Update on Integration
description: Twenty years ago, a Presidential commission warned that America was ''moving toward two societies, one black, one white - separate and unequal.'' Two decades of substantial progress in civil rights changed that course but America remains a long way from full integration. Now a new commission, headed by two former Presidents, makes clear the importance of persevering.

title: Free Trade a Joy at Quebec Utility
description: Amid the Canadian dispute over the free-trade agreement with the United States, some enthusiastic endorsements have come from Quebec, a province emerging with new confidence from an inward-looking decade under the separatist government ousted in a 1985 election. And among the Quebec backers of expanded trade, few have more to gain than Hydro-Quebec, the electricity utility that is owned by the province and that has staked its ambitious expansion plans on huge sales to New York and New England.

title: Dukakis, Afloat Off Jersey, Calls Environmental Policy 'Ridiculous'
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis took to the Atlantic Ocean off the New Jersey shore today to denounce what he called the ''ridiculous'' environmental policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: Belmont Winner Is Mum
description: The winner of the record $500,000 Pick-Six payoff at Belmont Park Saturday was a groom and former jockey's agent who invested $96, according to track officials and friends of the bettor, who has asked to remain anonymous.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: In War on Drugs, Military Has Marginal Results
description: Even as Congress moves closer to giving the armed forces more responsibility in the war against drugs, the experience of the last six years suggests that previous efforts by the military have been only marginally effective.

title: Europe Airlines See Profit Drop
description: Leading European airlines expect their profits to fall by about 16 percent this year after a dramatic 93 percent jump in earnings in 1987, the Association of European Airlines said Friday.

title: Curbing Dogs With Kindness
description: Response to New York City's anti-dog-litter law was initially good, but compliance has declined precipitously in some areas. Thus, We Care About New York Inc., a private group devoted to public cleanliness, has enlisted the help of the Girl Scouts, the city's Police and Sanitation Departments and Alpo Pet Foods Inc. to provide some positive reinforcement.

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses are also closed.

title: Shaken by Pollution, the Jersey Shore Is Seeking a Comeback
description: Pat Grosshardt, the manager of the Jolly Roger motel in Holgate, N.J., vacuumed rugs, opened windows and talked about the season she would just as soon forget: the summer of '87.

title: Retailers Suffering In Key Sector
description: Meager sales of women's apparel are troubling retailers, whose inventories are mounting as the lightest business season approaches.

title: POPE CHOOSES 25 NEW CARDINALS, INCLUDING TWO AMERICAN PRELATES
description: Pope John Paul II named 25 new Cardinals today, including two Americans and a Lithuanian whose nomination was said to reflect a determination to strengthen the Roman Catholic Church inside the Soviet Union.

title: Chinese Journalist Pushes His Ideas on 'Openness'
description: Inside the crenelated tower of Chinese journalism, where news stories are aimed not so much at the truth as at instilling a ''correct'' attitude in the reader, Liu Binyan has been an often lone knight errant, a slayer of the dragons of convention, corruption and malfeasance. And he has paid a heavy price for his outspokenness.

title: U.S. PEN Unit Fights For East Bloc Victims
description: Ivan Sokulsky, a Ukrainian poet and journalist, is in solitary confinement in a Soviet labor camp. He was arrested in 1980 and sentenced to 10 years' ''special regime'' and five years' internal exile for participating in the work of a group monitoring Soviet adherence to the Helsinki Accords.

title: GM Recall on Throttle Defect
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling 39,000 1987 model cars to find about 8,700 built with possibly defective throttle cables that may cause the throttle to stick open. The recall includes 1987 Buick Electra, Oldsmobile Delta 88 and Ninety-Eight, and Pontiac Bonneville models, the company said Friday. GM said it has received no reports of accidents or injuries related to the defect.

title: JACKSON DEMANDS HELP FOR WORKERS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, saying an absence of day care has kept hundreds of women from working at newly created jobs at Newark International Airport, urged the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey today to provide child care services for those who need it.

title: Sears Merchandiser Given a Broader Role
description: Matthew A. Howard, in his 26-year career with Sears, Roebuck & Company, has been in charge of single, large categories of merchandise. Now, as the new senior executive vice president, merchandising, for the Sears merchandise group, Mr. Howard will have his broadest assignment. It will include product developing, buying, marketing and merchandising of all products and services sold in Sears stores.

title: Piniella Changes His Job With Yanks
description: Lou Piniella, who was moved from the field to the front office last October in another of George Steinbrenner's annual Yankee shakeups, said today that he had resigned as general manager, although he intends to remain with the Yankees in a scouting and player-evaluation capacity.

title: Big Protests Mounted In Two Russian Cities
description: Policemen threw punches to break up a demonstration by about 2,000 people in Leningrad organized by a new Soviet opposition party, spokesmen said today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Scherer's Chief Weighs Buyout of Wife's Stock
description: LEAD: Peter R. Fink, the president and chief executive of the R. P. Scherer Corporation, has been put on the spot by his wife, the principal shareholder of the company. Now, he says, he is considering buying her out.

title: U.S. Princes of Church
description: James Aloysius Hickey

title: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK Parades: Manhattan parade starts at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and West End Avenue, goes east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument. Bronx parade at 11 A.M. at Grand Concourse and Van Cortlandt Avenue East. Brooklyn parade at 11 A.M. at 72d Street and Fourth Avenue. Queens parade at 11 A.M. at Metropolitan and Ascan Avenues. Staten Island parade at 8:15 A.M. at 10th Street and Princeton Avenue. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; main office is open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Parking: Sunday parking rules in effect. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on holiday schedule. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. No train service in Bergen, Passaic and parts of Morris Counties. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title: Review/Art; Lane's Romantic Paintings Depict New England's Past
description: With most visitors to the National Gallery lining up for the Gauguin exhibition that sprawls across the east wing, a museumgoer might easily overlook Fitz Hugh Lane's placid paintings, which hang in three galleries of the old west wing. These 61 canvases, many of maritime scenes at sunset, remain on view here through September 5, casting an intense and seductive glow.

title: Korean Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's current account surplus rose 41 percent in the first four months of this year from its level of a year earlier, the Bank of Korea reported Friday. The current account measures trade in merchandise and services. The surplus for January through April was $3.89 billion, up from $2.76 billion one year ago. Officials at the central bank said that, if the present pace continued, the surplus was likely to top $10 billion by the end of the year, compared with last year's record high of $9.85 billion.

title: Climbing the Walls
description: For all those times you could have climbed the wall, there's a new product that allows you to scale the heights of your living room, kitchen or office. It is designed as a practice tool for rock climbers, but its appeal may be broader than that.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Since they were swapped in the nine-player trade between the Mets and the Padres after the 1986 season, who has been the better hitter, Kevin Mitchell or Kevin McReynolds?

title: Bridge
description: Two veteran New York experts, who were playing together a quarter of a century ago, led into the final two sessions of the prestigious Goldman Pairs at the Eastern Regional Championships yesterday.

title: Nonprofits Have Unfair Edge in Marketplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Journal; '68 to '88: A Maoist's Great Leap to the Mainstream
description: When the editor of one of France's leading newspapers is reminded that two decades ago he was a Maoist firebrand, he recalls by way of riposte that a young man named Michel Rocard was so swept up in the student upheaval of 1968 that he proclaimed it ''a genuinely revolutionary situation.''

title: Dana Alison Gelb Is Married to Alan Paul Safran
description: Dana Alison Gelb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen G. Gelb of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Paul Safran, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Safran of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff performed the ceremony in the garden of the Bretton Woods Inn in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Alex Chilton's Ironic Guitar
description: Alex Chilton, the singer and guitarist, opened his show on Thursday night at the Knitting Factory by saying, ''Let's boogie.'' Few phrases have been as ironic. Launching into a blues medley - ''Te Ni Nee Ni Nu'' and ''Tip On In'' - by the guitarist Slim Harpo, Mr. Chilton proceeded to sing lines like ''Lay it on me, baby'' without any of the black affectations a listener expects from a white performer. Mr. Chilton is from Memphis; at age 16 he was the lead singer for a ''blue-eyed-soul'' group, the Box Tops.

title: West Point to Update Polluting Plant
description: The smoke is always there, usually a plume of white mist dancing 10 feet above a smokestack on the campus of the United States Military Academy, whose turreted stone buildings dot the highlands across the Hudson River from here.

title: Revived Mavericks Tie Series at 2-2
description: Suddenly, the playoff series that so many Los Angeles fans thought might be over in four games has turned into a nightmare for the Lakers.

title: Demotion Denied
description: ''I most assuredly am not considering any other position in or out of Government and do not expect to do so in the future.'' So said Justice Sandra Day O'Connor recently in a statement quashing the suggestion of some Republican leaders and other mentioners that she should fill the Vice Presidential slot on the G.O.P. ticket.

title: Talks on Strategic Arms Treaty Move Ahead, but Major Problems Remain
description: American and Soviet arms control officials met tonight to try to make headway toward a new strategic arms treaty, even as American officials stressed the difficulties ahead.

title: Dance; City Ballet Bill a Model of Diversity
description: It may be back to business as usual for the New York City Ballet but, American Music Festival or no, the company keeps pouring out its riches. In performances Friday and Saturday nights at the New York State Theater, three ballets re-entering the spring repertory suggested the wide range of expression and style of which the City Ballet is capable.

title: Bangladesh Floods Kill 5
description: At least five people have died and thousands have been forced to flee their homes because of flooding in northeastern Bangladesh, Government officials and news reports said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 30, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. steel industry's rebound may have peaked after nearly two years of rising shipments and profits, some industry executives and economists say. A downturn is predicted for the second half of this year because of weaker demand from the auto, appliance and home construction industries. There is little consensus, however, about how steep the downturn will be. [ Page 29. ] Retailers are concerned by slumping sales of women's apparel, even before the industry enters its slowest business period of the year. Sales of women's clothing fell 7 percent in the first quarter from the comparable year-ago period. Sales of men's wear, meanwhile, were up nearly 7 percent. Many of those in the industry blame a lack of excitement or innovation, but others cite the turnovers and job losses involving buyers and merchandisers that have resulted from mergers, divestitures and consolidations. [ 29. ] The securities industry is bracing for another wave of layoffs as trading volume dwindles. Estimates of the number of endangered jobs vary widely, with one study predicting more than 18,000 layoffs in New York City alone. Other forecasters see 8,000 to 10,000 job losses throughout the industry, with the most severe effects expected in New York and London. [ 29. ] April orders for machine tools declined 0.6 percent from the previous month, to $253 million, the industry's trade association reported. But the figure represents a 94.2 percent increase from the year-earlier period. Exports continued to rise sharply. [ 30. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT F.D.A. approval of the cervical cap as a birth control device may be a boon to its sole supplier, Lamberts (Dalston) Ltd., a tiny British company whose main business is distributing latex products like surgical gloves and condoms. [ 33. ] Virginia A. Kamsky is sought out by companies that hope to crack the tough Chinese market. The Princeton-educated American was among the first consultants to help guide foreign companies through China's increasingly complex maze of overlapping, and often competing, bureaucracies, ministries and institutions. [ 33. ] Hydro-Quebec stands to benefit greatly from the U.S.-Canada free-trade accord, which has received enthusiastic support in the French-speaking province. The provincial electric utility hopes to raise dramatically its sales of power to the Northeastern states if restrictions on imported electricity are curbed. [ 29. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Publishers are scrambling to offer magazines to Japan's career women, who now make up 40 percent of the work force. Four new magazines are being introduced this spring. [ 32. ] More than 15,000 exhibitors are attending the convention of the American Booksellers Association in Anaheim, Calif. The annual gathering allows publishers to showcase new titles, listen to customer complaints, sell rights to foreign publishers and line up interviews with the press. [ 32. ] Winning the broadcast rights to the 1992 Winter Olympics elated many at CBS, where morale has suffered from cutbacks. But there are skeptics. Television. [ 32. ] Many older Americans are unimpressed by marketing that concentrates on the time-saving virtues of products, a new study by the Daniel Yankelovich Group has found. According to the study, only a third of Americans in their 60's, and even fewer in their 70's, are looking for new ways to save time. [ 32. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A House panel has approved a measure that would eliminate a regulation that allows Federal courts to decide cases where only state law applies. The move intensifies a debate over diversity jurisdiction, the rule that gives Federal judges authority to decide a wide range of cases. Business and the Law. [ 30. ] Marc Goldman won a battle against New York's milk cartel, giving his Farmland Dairies access to customers east of the Hudson River. But the war has taken a new turn with the consolidation of Farmland's largest competitors into a multibillion-dollar conglomerate. New Yorkers & Co. [ 29. ]

title: The Consumer Will Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaigns That Turn Off Older Americans
description: Microwave ovens, video cassette recorders, automatic teller machines and other consumer devices are typically marketed as convenient time savers. But the companies and advertising agencies that are selling them this way may be missing out on the vast market for older Americans, according to a forthcoming study.

title: Making the Right Contacts in China
description: Pat V. Mazzarulli knows a lot about selling and buying oil. But the sure touch he displays in markets from Houston to Tokyo was, by his own admission, little more than groping when he decided there was business to be done in China.

title: TV Notes
description: Spruced-Up 'Peter Pan'

title: In a Belgian Field, 7,989 G.I.'s Are Not Forgotten
description: Every year since World War II the visitors have been coming to the American Cemetery here, first when it was a muddy field crowded with wooden markers, now when the larches and hornbeam are lush and mature.

title: A COLLEGE TRIBUTE TO A 'LONE VOICE'
description: Laurie A. Recht, a 34-year-old legal secretary who was shouted down at a public hearing in Yonkers last January as the only speaker in favor of a court-ordered desegregation plan, received a standing ovation today as the commencement speaker at the College of New Rochelle.

title: Molly Heminway Is Wed to Charles E. K. Moseley
description: Molly Lewis Heminway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Reid Heminway of Middlebury, Conn., and Charles Edward Keeble Moseley, the son of Mrs. Richard C. Miles of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles Guy Moseley, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. A. Edward Couch performed the ceremony at the Middlebury Congregational Church.

title: Wall St. Faces More Layoffs As Trading Volume Shrinks
description: Faced with dwindling trading volume and falling revenues, the securities industry is bracing for another large wave of layoffs, with the greatest impact likely to be felt in New York and London.

title: Music and Dance Series To Open in Central Park
description: Summerstage, an 11-week series of free music and dance at the band shell in Central Park, is to begin on June 17 at 8:30 P.M. with a performance featuring the American Tap Dance Orchestra, the Persuasions and the composer Lenny Pickett.

title: At Publishing Convention, Booksellers and Hype
description: It is six years since the nation's book publishers and booksellers last met in Anaheim, and the industry has undergone major changes since.

title: Hot Potato Redux
description: Dave Bresnahan batted .149 without a home run in 52 games with the Williamsport (Pa.) Bills, but he threw the meanest potato in baseball history, and that's why the minor league team will retire the catcher's number tonight. Actually, he threw the only potato in the baseball history, but it cost him his job.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Aware of your interest in Russian proverbs, let me add another one to your collection: 'It is better to see once than to hear a hundred times.' '' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 6:3. ]

title: Plane Crashes Into a House, Killing Four People in Arizona
description: A small plane crashed into a house east of downtown today, killing four people, including a 12-year-old girl who had been in a swimming pool at the residence, the authorities said.

title: Indicted State Senator Is County Party Chief
description: A state senator, under indictment on a charge that he accepted a bribe while serving as a county commissioner, has been named chairman of the Mingo County Democratic Party.

title: INSIDE
description: Mears Wins at Indianapolis Rick Mears won the Indianapolis 500 for the third time in a race slowed by accidents. The mishaps created confusion over the placement of other drivers. SportsMonday, page 35. Tourism vs. Wine-Making Vintners in California's Napa Valley are resisting development in an area where agriculture and tourism coexist in a delicate balance. Page 9. Siaka Stevens Dies Siaka Probyn Stevens, who was President of the West African nation of Sierra Leone for 17 years, died at his home in Freetown. Page 28.

title: Theater; Tammy Grimes in British-Flavored Solo
description: Near the end of the first act of her one-woman show, ''A Concert in Words and Music,'' Tammy Grimes recalls having been discovered in a nightclub by Noel Coward. ''He taught me more about acting and about life than anyone I've ever known,'' she says while prefacing a rendition of ''If Love Were All'' that is strikingly different from anyone else's. Where other singers tend to linger wistfully over Coward's self-effacing lyric about the absence of love in his life, Ms. Grimes breezes through the song, betraying only the faintest trace of pathos.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Milk Wars II: the Cartel Strikes Back
description: Just when he thought it was safe to go back into the dairy barn, Marc Goldman heard a rustling in the hay. It was the old New York City milk cartel, and its fangs were longer than ever.

title: Singapore Loses Its Perspective
description: LEAD: On May 7, the Singapore Government shocked American officials by calling for the removal of an American diplomat who it said was ''meddling'' in the country's internal affairs. The Home Affairs Ministry accused the diplomat of meeting with anti-Government lawyers ''to manipulate and instigate Singaporeans, in order to bring about a particular political outcome,'' and strongly implied that Washington was funding a prominent opposition figure planning to seek office.

title: Ex-Israeli Officers Say a Deal for Peace Is Needed
description: A group of several dozen retired senior Israeli military officers are advocating an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The occupation is being enforced by the Israeli Army.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Celtics Get Even in Odd Way
description: The adjectives used to describe today's Boston Celtic-Detroit Piston game weren't the ones usually heard in locker rooms after playoff games.

title: Beech-Nut Pays a Fine
description: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation has paid a $250,000 fine to New York State to settle charges that it sold and advertised apple juice for babies that was actually apple-flavored sugar water, state officials said today.

title: Lintas Given New Task By Phillips-Van Heusen
description: Lintas: New York, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has received a new assignment from the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation. It is for men's and women's apparel, and the billings are about $5 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: British Trade Gap Wider
description: Britain said Friday that its monthly trade deficit had jumped 27 percent, to $:1.125 billion ($2.09 billion), in April and that its current account deficit had nearly doubled, to $:525 million ($975 million). Economists said the data could mean that a recent rise in the pound's value was pricing British goods off foreign markets. The current account balance-of-payments measurement adds international earnings from banking, shipping, tourism and other services to the imports and exports in the trade figure.

title: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; REAGAN PRESSES GORBACHEV ON CHURCH AND CIVIL RIGHTS; 'SERMONIZING' ANNOYS HOSTS'
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev publicly clashed over human rights issues today as the President, quoting Alexander Solzhenitsyn, appealed for increased civil and religious liberties in the Soviet Union.

title: Reviews/Television; Minnelli In Three Brief Plays
description: Back in another of her periodic television specials, Liza Minnelli shows the kind of spunk that her fans - this one included - find disarming. Instead of offering still another hour of belted ballads, the performer has come up with three one-act plays, each of them constructed around the line: ''Sam found out.'' The hour turns out to be slight and terribly uneven. But it's different, and it provides a valuable reminder that Ms. Minnelli is an accomplished actor as well as singer.

title: COMMENCEMENTS
description: OBERLIN

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The housing industry has begun to retrench as mortgage rates move higher. As a result, builders are shying away from speculative projects and mortgage banking companies are laying off employees. Several leading economists predict that a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage will carry an interest rate of 11.25 percent to 11.50 percent by year-end, compared with 10.58 percent last week. Some economists suggest that a continued slowdown in housing might help the economy, acting as a brake on inflation by offsetting rising demand for other goods and services. [ Page A1. ] Short-term interest rates could move up again this week, if traders in the credit markets underestimated the extent of the Federal Reserve's decision to tighten credit last week, its third such move in three months. Some experts say the Fed may now be adopting a more aggressive stance. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] MARKETS The dollar moved higher in Europe, reaching more than 1.7280 West German marks. Gold prices remained level. Markets were closed in London and the United States because of holidays. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Brazil's leaders are split over economic development. President Jose Sarney has moved to open up the troubled economy by reducing rules and incentives, but a Constitutional Assembly is adopting an approach that would restrict foreign investment and expand the state's power to intervene in economic matters. [ D1. ] The U.S. and Japan agreed to make jet fighters for Japan together, a Japan Defense Agency spokesman said. Tokyo is expected to spend as much as $7 billion on 130 aircraft, which will be based on the F-16 jet made by General Dynamics. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A campaign for Israeli tourism is aimed at American Jews who have dropped plans to visit Israel because of the Palestinian uprising. Because many Israelis blame news coverage, the unspoken theme of Grey Advertising's campaign is: don't believe everything you see in the press. Grey said Israel would spend $5 million. [ D1. ] Hippocrates magazine celebrated its first year of publication with a number of prestigious awards. The bimonthly magazine has also doubled its advertising and hopes to increase its circulation by becoming a monthly in the next year. [ D12. ] J. Walter Thompson's chairman is optimistic nearly a year after the agency was taken over by WPP Group. Burt Manning says a central task is to rebuild the base of clients. Advertising. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Beazer won a round in court in its attempt to take over Koppers. A Federal appeals court removed a lower court injunction against Beazer's bid. [ D2. ] Irish Distillers rejected a takeover bid from two British conglomerates, Grand Metropolitan and Allied-Lyons. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A serious shortage of nurses is costing billions of dollars as hospitals and nursing homes take beds out of service and pay premiums to fill their staffs. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Once-glamorous biotechnology stocks are in the doldrums. Analysts say that the slump could result in increased takeover activity, but that patient investors may be able to take advantage of some bargains. Market Place. [ D8. ] One company hopes to make meetings more efficient - an area that may be one of the last frontiers for improving business productivity. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing has opened an institute that will offer its findings to other organizations. Careers. [ D12. ]

title: Rise in Mortgage Rates Is Causing A Slowdown in Housing Industry
description: Faced with higher mortgage rates and expecting them to rise further, the housing industry has begun to retrench.

title: Moscow Summit: Preaching to the Unconverted; President Meets With Dissidents, And Tea and Empathy Are Served
description: President Reagan walked up to Abe Stolar with a smile, shook his hand warmly, and said: ''I've just spoken to Mikhail Gorbachev about you. I told him we came from the same state and were born at the same time.''

title: S.E.C. Vote Is Criticized
description: Two futures exchanges said they oppose the Securities and Exchange Commission's bid to take over regulation of trading in stock-index futures.

title: A Hungarian for Too Many Seasons
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's new proposal for limiting the tenure of Communist officeholders would have benefited Janos Kadar. Had Mr. Kadar stepped down as Hungary's party chief, say, in 1976, he would have earned glowing notices for his economic reforms and for the relative political tolerance he adopted after ruthlessly crushing the revolutionaries of 1956. But in the age of Gorbachev, Mr. Kadar appears less a reformer than a grudging old functionary who stayed on for 32 years, resisting to the last his replacement by a younger man.

title: Meese Says His Defense Will Come After Report
