description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he would speak out fully in his own defense after the release of a report by the special prosecutor investigating him on allegations of ethical misconduct.

title: Run on Tapes in Indonesia
description: Thousands of people crammed into tape stores in Jakarta and on the island of Bali over the weekend to beat a June 1 ban on the sale of pirated music cassettes.

title: Indianapolis 500; Mears's Patience Pays Off for Penske
description: The morning after one of his cars won the Indianapolis 500 for the seventh time in 20 attempts, Roger Penske was orchestrating photo opportunities for about 50 people from around the world.

title: Walter A. Richards Jr., Radio and Television Writer, 81
description: Walter A. (Hank) Richards Jr., who wrote for such radio shows as ''Lights Out,'' ''Lux Radio Theater'' and ''Cavalcade of America'' and later for television, died May 23 at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Trash Mounts in San Francisco Janitors Strike
description: A strike by 1,800 janitors here entered its seventh day today, leaving downtown and the financial district strewn with trash.

title: The Couple's Guide to Competitive Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Shara B. Pulver Wed To David Alan Israel
description: Shara Beth Pulver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Pulver of New York, and David Alan Israel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip D. Israel of Chesterfield, Mo., were married yesterday at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens. Rabbi Lawrence Siebert and Rabbi Charles Preiss, a grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: At Last, a Turn in the Trade Deficit
description: It looks like the foreign trade deficit has definitively turned around. That's good news - but only because the previous news has been so bad.

title: Networks Look for News in Moscow
description: Americans devoted to television news who spent some of the sunny Memorial Day weekend in the glow of the tube were rewarded with shots of President Reagan and the First Lady in Moscow, the resplendent interiors of the Kremlin and street scenes. For part of the time we might have been watching a National Geographic special on Treasures of the Czars or Faces of Russia. The camera operators provided enough of those, particularly old faces and young ones, to fill tourist brochures until the next summit meeting.

title: Army Finds Too Many Commanders Are 'Killed'
description: The Center for Army Lessons Learned here has discovered that too many tank and mechanized infantry battalion commanders were being ''killed'' in training exercises, after which their units deteriorated and were trounced in battle.

title: Bush's Maine Neighbors Fear Change
description: In bustling Dock Square of this once tranquil seaside resort and fishing village, Vice President Bush is undeniably at home.

title: Bitter Race Focusing On Bronx Prosecutor
description: When Governor Cuomo appointed Paul T. Gentile as interim Bronx District Attorney last December, the expectation all around was that he would consolidate his position, sail on to win the nomination and election in his own right and become a permanent and powerful fixture in New York City Democratic politics like his predecessor, Mario Merola. It has not worked out that way.

title: France to Discipline Soldiers In Caledonia Rescue Assault
description: France's Defense Minister said today that several of the commandos who stormed a cave in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia to free 23 French hostages had committed ''acts contrary to military duty'' and would be punished.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: DOG SHOW Wyndjammer Is Best: Ch. Meadowlark's Wyndjammer, an Irish setter who answers to the name of Rett and who has been a consistent group winner, yesterday gained his first top award when he was named best of 1,141 dogs at the 61st Union County Kennel Club fixture in the Dunn Sports Center, in Elizabeth, N.J. The Irish setter is owned by Rose Marie Ross and Celeste Gavin. TRACK AND FIELD Williams Ties Record: Jerome Williams of Lincoln High School in Yonkers tied the meet record of 46.9 seconds in the 400-meter dash yesterday at the 32d Annual Eastern States Boys track and field championships at Randalls Island. Williams, a senior who will attend Taft Junior College in California in September, pulled away from the field to win easily over Steve Cardwell of Rome (N.Y.) Free Academy who was second in 47.9 seconds. Other impressive winning performances were turned in by John Coyle of Christian Brothers Academy, Lincroft, N.J., in the 3,200-meter steeplechase (9 minutes 22.8 seconds); Prospect Heights of Brooklyn in the 3,200-meter relay (7:50.5) and Holy Trinity of Hicksville, L.I., in the 1,600-meter relay (3:17.9).

title: Speed Control Device
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan, McGrath Tries Unusual Magazine Ad
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor has come up with an imaginative concept for its client Procter & Gamble's Bounty Microwave towels that is intended to attract reader attention in the cluttered environment of women's service magazines.

title: New York Can't Afford to Economize on Its Public Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Wrong With Massachusetts Health Plan; Medical School Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Mini-City' of Condominiums Faces Long Review Process in Westchester
description: After years of grandiose visions, sketches, studies and revisions, a billion-dollar condominium complex proposed for Davids Island, a deserted Army base off the coast here, is reaching a potentially turbulent stage.

title: New Home for Trotter
description: A Swedish horse dealer, John Erik Magnusson, said he had bought a three-quarter share of Mack Lobell, the world-record-holding trotter and last year's Hambletonian winner, for a reported $6 million from Louis Guida. Magnusson, who now stands three trotter stallions at his farm Bladingeas near Alvesta in southern Sweden, said the 4-year-old Mack Lobell would retire to stud after another two seasons of racing in the United States. The 4-year-old colt, who was bought by Guida in 1985 for $17,000, won the Elitloppet at Solvalla Raceway in Stockholm Sunday against a field that included Sweden's reigning champion, Callit. The $166,000 purse brought Mack Lobell's winnings to $2.1 million.(AP)

title: No to 'Star Wars'
description: For the last year or more, an obscure publication, ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society'' has been full of sharp debate over a political initiative by professional mathematicians who oppose military research on space defenses against ballistic missiles.

title: For Raymond Carver, a Lifetime of Storytelling
description: As a boy growing up in Yakima, Wash., Raymond Carver used to slip into his parents' room in the evening, sit at the foot of the bed and ask his father to tell him a story. ''He was a good talker,'' Mr. Carver said. ''All I had to do to get him going was ask about my great-grandfather.''

title: Our Towns; Cadets' Real Rite Is Rush Hour At the Altar
description: Cadets cannot become married until they finish their four years here. Last Wednesday, the Class of '88 graduated, and ever since, the West Point chapels have been hopping, with someone becoming married every time you turn around, 38 in the last four days alone.

title: Coveted, but Worn, Beach Reopens
description: When Babylon officials closed Gilgo Beach here last year because of severe erosion, they shut not only one of the East Coast's most famous surfing spots, they ended a summer tradition.

title: PATTERNS
description: What Went Wrong?

title: Stunt Pilot Killed in Texas
description: A stunt pilot was killed before thousands of people at an air show Sunday when his biplane crashed and skidded into a lake, the authorities said. The pilot's body was recovered from the lake shortly after noon, said Bob Newman, a trooper with the Texas Department of Public Safety.

title: Darling Outlasts Dodgers' Leary
description: The Mets didn't throw any baseballs at Pedro Guerrero last night, and Guerrero didn't throw any bats at the Mets. So, the return match never materialized.

title: Pianists to Celebrate Steinway in Gala
description: In 1853 Henry Engelhard Steinway, a German immigrant, took a loft on Varick Street and went into the piano business. The company he founded, Steinway & Sons, has become the most successful piano manufacturer in the world, and its pianos have been the instrument of choice for several generations of great performers. Recently, the company built its 500,000th piano, a standard nine-foot concert grand in a case specially designed by Wendell Castle, containing the names of the 832 pianists and 90 ensembles on the Steinway artist roster.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 Reagan and Gorbachev clashed over human rights as the President, quoting from Alexander Solzhenitsyn, appealed for increased civil and religious liberties in the Soviet Union. Page A1 President Reagan met Soviet dissidents and for 55 minutes was surrounded by the people whose plight has helped shape his own anti-Communist oratory. A1 Soviet history exams were canceled until textbooks can be revised and brought up to date with the approach to history advocated by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. History exams will be replaced by ''oral discussion of current events.'' A1 Two modest arms control accords are expected to be signed by the United States and the Soviet Union, American and Soviet officials said tonight. Limited headway toward a treaty reducing long-range nuclear arms was also reported. A12 News analysis: Human rights are a sensitive subject at the summit. President Reagan came determined to press the matter, but if he pushes too hard, he may embarrass Mikhail S. Gorbachev and slow the reforms he wants to encourage. A13 A breakdown of ideology in China has been signaled by growing tensions as the country moves with greater speed away from any conventional or historical model of Communism, and more toward a system driven by discernibly capitalist engines. A1 Brazil's economic crisis has brought the Government and a special Constitutional Assembly to loggerheads over how to change the country's development strategy. The uncertainty surrounding the economy has alarmed the country's foreign creditors. D1 Nezahualcoyotl journal: millions dwell in hope A4 Car bomb kills 20 in Beirut A5 Cuban prison life said to improve A6 Outsiders stoke Angola civil war A9 National A16-17, A20, B6-9 Higher mortgages may hurt housing, forcing the industry into a period of retrenchment, economists say. Rates will continue to rise, predict several leading economists in the housing and mortgage banking industry. A1 New Medicare legislation would shield elderly middle-class Americans from ruin by huge medical bills, in the view of health care experts and Congressional sponsors. A1 A Texas community organizer has helped build a remarkable network that is changing politics in Texas. Neither his low-income constituency nor his intense demeanor and slightly disheveled appearance peg him as a likely power. A16 Terrorists, spies and other intruders have become more adept and betterequipped at penetrating sensitive materials and guarded buildings. But officials say that advanced technology designed to keep intruders out is keeping pace. C1 Los Angeles center offers homeless rooms and hope A16 Army assesses lessons on protecting commanders A17 Politics B8 George Bush is at home in Kennebunkport, Me., where the Vice President has spent each summer for more than 60 years. There is rampant local interest in what a victory could mean to this community, straining from development and tourism. B8 The electorate is equivocal on taxes compared to the mood of the tax revolt 10 years ago that helped elect President Reagan in 1980. Voters will support tax increases only when they know how the money will be spent and approve of the goal, political observers say. B8 Jackson condemned anti-Semitism in Jersey City at a statue honoring Holocaust victims and pleaded for reconciliation among blacks and Jews. B8 Dukakis seeks to signal sensitivity on blacks B8 Washington Talk B6 Services try to hold on to pilots Regional B1-5, B11 The interim Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, in his ascension to the job has opened up a squabble for power. His integrity and judgment have been questioned, raising second thoughts about his campaign. B1 A baseball team in Brooklyn is striving to be one of two high school teams in New York City to play a championship game at Yankee Stadium. The team, The Knights of Eastern District, are from the Williamsburg section. B1 A City Councilman of Rochester returned from a 48-day absence this month saying that he was sorry, but that ''divine intervention'' was responsible for his extending an overseas business trip from three days to almost seven weeks. B4 Mayor Koch's budget cuts hurt patients by failing to meet the crises of hospital overcrowding and the AIDS epidemic, health-care advocates and public officials charge. But Koch administration officials defend the restraints. B1 The Woodstock Playhouse burned to the ground in a fire, destroying the cherished arts center that symbolized the cultural history of the Catskills. Fire officials say they believe the blaze was set by arsonists. B1 Apartment towers in New Rochelle are about to enter a potentially turbulent approval process. The billion-dollar condominium complex has been proposed for Davids Island, a deserted Army base off the coast. B3 Gilgo Beach, with a devoted crowd, has been reopened by new town officials, restoring one of the East Coast's most famous surfing spots. The beach, in Babylon, L.I., was closed last year because of severe erosion. B2 Improvements found in state's care of mentally retarded B3 Police searching for suspects in fatal beating of L.I. doctor B4 New York City police officers prepare for promotion tests B4

title: A Flaw in the Research Process: Uncorrected Errors in Journals
description: IN 1984, a medical journal reported the frightening finding that a woman had apparently become infected with the AIDS virus simply through kissing. The case was widely interpreted as evidence that the virus could be transmitted by saliva and that kissing could be dangerous.

title: Australian One of Two New Vatican Aides
description: Pope John Paul II appointed an Australian archbishop today to be deputy chief of the Vatican's most powerful office, the Secretariat of State, and named a new head of the Vatican's foreign affairs department.

title: North Korea Welcome
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Olympic Games ''is unacceptable,'' but the door for the North's participation would be left open until the last minute. Samaranch, who arrived in Seoul, South Korea, the site of the Games, for a series of meetings and ceremonies this week, said at an airport news conference that North Korea's bid to be co-host was against the Olympic charter ''and unacceptable because of its political nature.'' North Korea has said it will boycott the Games, to be held in Seoul from Sept. 17 to Oct. 2, unless it is allowed to be a co-host of the Games. Samaranch said North Korea has not responded to the I.O.C.'s offer to stage five events in exchange for dropping its demand and taking part in the Games. Describing the offer as ''a historical proposal,'' Samaranch said it would remain valid until the last moment.(AP)

title: Mass Protests Said to Flare In Soviet Armenian Capital
description: A Moscow dissident said mass demonstrations by hundreds of thousands of people flared today in Yerevan, the capital of the Soviet republic of Armenia.

title: Cherokee's Head Faces Battle to Hold Company
description: James P. Argyropoulos came to the United States hoping to become a rock musician. Instead, the Greek immigrant began making his fortune in a shoe repair shop in Beverly Hills, Calif., where his original sandal design helped start a fast-growing shoe and apparel company that had sales of $139 million last year.

title: I.R.S. Jolts a Kansas City Charity With Tax Claim Against an Estate
description: The Internal Revenue Service has shocked this city's oldest institutions with a tax claim for $201 million against one of Kansas City's wealthiest estates, that of Joyce C. Hall, founder of Hallmark Cards Inc.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: Bridge
description: Two experts who first played together as graduate students 30 years ago captured the prestigious Goldman Pairs Championship at the Eastern Regionals on Sunday.

title: N.C.A.A. Baseball; Stanford Continues To Scramble Back
description: Late in the evening of their first day of play in the national collegiate baseball tournament, last Friday, a near-elimination caused the Stanford Cardinal's status as defending national champion to seem little more than a cruel joke.

title: Rochester Councilman Under Fire for Absence
description: As City Council members here go, F. Glenn King has always stood out. He wears expensive-looking suits and jewelry and drives a white Mercedes-Benz. As a minister, he preaches on Sundays at the nondenominational First Church Divine.

title: New York Can't Afford to Economize on Its Public Libraries; Service for a Lifetime
description: To the Editor:

title: Gains in New York Care of Retarded
description: Living conditions at institutions for the mentally retarded in New York State have ''greatly improved'' in the last two decades, but many centers still fail to provide adequate teaching and recreation, a state commission has found.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Mr. General Secretary, allow me to raise a glass to the work that has been done, the work that remains to be done. And let us also toast the art of friendly persuasion, the hope of peace with freedom, the hope of holding out for a better way of settling things.'' - President Reagan. [ A14:5. ]

title: On Memorial Day, Grieving in Private
description: Len Schwende put on his United States Army uniform, the one he wore when he was an artilleryman in Vietnam 16 years ago, and joined a gathering yesterday in Lower Manhattan that was far removed from the official Memorial Day ceremonies around the city.

title: Officers in New York Cram for Sergeant and Lieutenant Promotion Exams
description: LEAD: Five years ago Bob Athanasidy, a New York City police officer, took a Civil Service examination for promotion to sergeant. He missed the eligibility score by one answer. It cost him a $9,000 pay increase.

title: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; Soviet Pupils Spared Exams While History Is Rewritten
description: The Soviet Union has canceled final secondary-school history examinations, which had been scheduled to begin today, until textbooks can be brought up to date with the candid approach to history advocated by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 29, 1988: TUESDAY Becton, Dickinson Palco Ent WEDNESDAY Fieldcrest Cannon Stanhome Inc General Dynamics Stanley Works Louisville G&E LS Starrett Co Natl Convenience Stores USF&G Corp Pennwalt Corp THURSDAY Allegheny Power Lucky Stores Atlantic Energy SPS Technologies Bear Stearns Wal-Mart Stores Brown Group Washington National FRIDAY Chubb Corp

title: Dukakis Signals Sense of Import On Black Vote
description: Michael S. Dukakis tried to signal his sensitivity to the importance of the black vote today, meeting with black supporters from around the country, playing down his differences with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and predicting a unified Democratic campaign this fall.

title: Game's Just Like Movie
description: THE new George Lucas film, ''Willow,'' has been out for little more than a week, and here's Willow: The Computer Game, an adventure-fantasy that parallels the movie's plot.

title: Dr. Alan Wolf Is Married To Dr. Paulette Ginsburg
description: Dr. Paulette Ginsburg and Dr. Alan Wolf, who received medical degrees this month from the State University Health Science Center at Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Rabbi Dale Polakoff performed the ceremony.

title: Technology Rises to Challenge of Clever Intruders
description: JUST how difficult would it be to steal the materials needed to make a nuclear bomb or to penetrate the barriers that safeguard bank transactions and vital corporate secrets?

title: World's Tallest Platform
description: Seven tugboats today began hauling the world's tallest offshore drilling platform to a site off the Louisiana coast. After its two drilling rigs are installed in the Gulf of Mexico, the platform, dubbed Bullwinkle, will weigh 78,000 tons and stand 1,615 feet high - 161 feet higher than the world's tallest building, the Sears Tower in Chicago. Shell Offshore Inc., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, estimates the total cost of the Bullwinkle project at $500 million.

title: Health-Care Budget Cuts In New York Are Assailed
description: A growing number of health-care advocates and public officials charge that Mayor Koch's budget cuts are jeopardizing patient care by failing to meet the crises of hospital overcowding and the AIDS epidemic.

title: New York Needs A New Mayor
description: LEAD: New Yorkers do not like to be reminded of their embarrassment occasioned by the nasty and intemperate campaign carried on by their Mayor against the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Democratic primary.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Hope to Recapture Momentum
description: After the Lakers had lost to the Dallas Mavericks for the second successive time at Reunion Arena Sunday, much of the talk in their locker room focused on getting out of town and returning to the friendly Forum, where they've been almost unbeatable for the last two seasons.

title: Mr. Rybakov Regrets
description: Anatoly N. Rybakov, author of a novel about life under Stalin (''Children of the Arbat,'' published in this country by Little, Brown) that has been a best seller in the Soviet Union since Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed it to come out there last year, received an invitation to dinner today in Moscow from President Reagan. But Mr. and Mrs. Rybakov had to send regrets - they are in the United States, promoting his book.

title: Moscow Summit: Looking for the Good News
description: The Summit Schedule All times are local. Moscow is eight hours ahead of Eastern daylight time. 10 A.M.: President Reagan arrives at the Kremlin and meets with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his office. 10:15 A.M.: Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev walk from the Government of the U.S.S.R. Building through the grounds to the Grand Kremlin Palace, where they hold talks in St. Catherine's Hall. About 11:30 A.M.: Probable signings of two arms-control agreements. 11:55 A.M.: Mr. Reagan arrives at Aleksandr A. Fadeyev House of Men of Letters, where he has lunch and exchanges remarks with cultural and artistic figures. 1:25 P.M.: The President returns to Spaso House, the U.S. Ambassador's residence. Mid-afternoon: Signing of several cultural exchange and other Soviet-American agreements by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. 3:45 P.M.: Mr. Reagan arrives at Moscow State University for a speech and question-and-answer session with students and faculty members in the university's lecture hall. 5:15 P.M.: The President returns to Spaso House. 8 P.M.: The President and Nancy Reagan are hosts for a dinner in honor of Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, at Spaso House. NANCY REAGAN'S SCHEDULE 9:35 A.M.: Leaves Moscow by air for Leningrad, accompanied by Lidiya Gromyko, wife of the Soviet President. 11 A.M.: Arrives in Leningrad and proceeds to the Monument to the Heroic Defenders of Leningrad. She tours a museum there and places flowers in tribute to the defenders. 12:10 P.M.: Arrives at the Hermitage for a tour of the country's most prestigious museum. 2:05 P.M.: Arrives by hydrofoil at the Petrodvorets Palace and proceeds to the Samson and Lion Fountain, where she will see a cultural performance. 4 P.M.: Leaves Leningrad for Moscow. TELEVISION COVERAGE CNN: Live coverage of President Reagan's speech at Moscow State University at 8 A.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: International Artists to Hold 7 Free Seminars in Festival
description: Seven free seminars featuring playwrights, composers, film makers and other international artists will be presented between June 14 and June 23 at three universities as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: Correction
description: A Media Business article in Business Day on April 21 about Charles E. Hayward misstated his new position at Simon & Schuster. He was named president of the publishing company's trade book division.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council

title: Moscow Summit: Preaching to the Unconverted; Excerpts From Reagan Talks to Dissidents and at Monastery democracy.
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's remarks today at Spaso House, where he met with Soviet dissidents, and at Danilov Monastery: Remarks to Dissidents

title: Israel Enlists Madison Ave. To Revive Sagging Tourism
description: Israel has a crisis in its tourism industry, so Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir decided that he wanted to become personally involved in approving a new tourism advertising campaign.

title: Moscow Summit: Looking for the Good News; Reporter's Notebook; For Soviet Journalists, Finding the Right Angle Was Never This Rough
description: The Izvestia correspondent covering President Reagan's visit to the Danilov Monastery had just checked in with a deputy editor, Nikolai I. Yefimov, and the news was irksome.

title: Dollar Gains On Continent
description: The American dollar moved higher against other major currencies in Europe today amid optimism that a technical rally would continue. The price of gold held steady.

title: How to Finance Peace in Nicaragua
description: LEAD: In late March, after their first round of talks in Sapoa, Nicaragua, the Sandinistas and the contras appeared finally to have begun serious negotiations.

title: Menu at the State Dinner
description: About 100 guests were present tonight at the Kremlin for the state dinner given by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, for President Reagan and his wife, Nancy. Here is the menu, as provided by the Soviet press agency Tass. Fresh Caviar Puff Rasstegay Assorted Fish With Lemon Stuffed Turkey Fillet With Fruits Fish Soup a la Suzdal Asparagus Cream Pike-Perch Baked With Crabmeat Loin of Veal Stewed With Vegetables Fruit Cream Parfait With Nuts Fruit Tea, Coffee Pastries, Cakes The Wines Manavi Georgian White Wine, 1985 Mukuzani Georgian Red Wine, 1985 Sovetskoye Sparkling Brut Yubileiny Armenian Brandy, 1977

title: Nelligan Plays Role Echoing Her Life
description: Kate Nelligan seemed almost to be crying. She was sitting in a seat in the empty Second Stage theater, her hands covering her face. On the stage, ready for the next performance of Michael Weller's new play, ''Spoils of War,'' was the unmade bed with which the play begins - a bed symbolic of the life of the character Ms. Nelligan portrays.

title: Orangemen Take Lacrosse Title
description: Jim Egan, left, and Brook Chase of Syracuse celebrating after 13-8 defeat of Cornell in championship game. Victory was 15th straight for the Orangemen as they went undefeated for first time since 1957. Page D16. (NYT/Joe Traver)

title: Communists Slip, Socialists Gain in Local Voting in Italy
description: Italy's Communist Party suffered a clear setback today in local elections while the Socialists advanced.

title: 7 Drown in Mississippi Outing
description: A small boat carrying eight people capsized today on a Memorial Day outing, killing six women aboard and a man who tried to rescue them, the authorities said.

title: Letter: On the Mideast; Mr. Awad and Israel's Reason for Being
description: To the Editor:

title: Outsiders Stoke Angola Civil War With Men, Weapons and Bases
description: For years, Angolans on both sides of their country's civil war have sought to obscure the international scope of the conflict. But a recent visit to four provinces showed a high degree of foreign participation.

title: Noriega Loses Support Among Poor
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega portrays himself as the champion of Panama's poor and black, but in this large working-class municipality favored by the regime there is little affection for the general.

title: Moscow Summit: Looking for the Good News; Party Meeting: A Showdown?
description: An official news weekly has echoed protesters' complaints that conservatives are influencing the selection of delegates in order to blunt Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to enact new policies at a Communist Party conference next month.

title: Checking the Spread Of a New Xenophobia
description: Economic nationalism and xenophobia in this country are approaching serious proportions, infecting a number of business and political leaders who ought to know better. Indulging these emotions is a luxury that comes with a high price tag: lowered living standards and strained relations with our trading partners.

title: Air Force and Navy Try Steps to Keep Jet Pilots
description: To train an Air Force or Navy fighter pilot to the point where he is fully ready for combat in his high-powered airplane takes more than five years and, depending on the aircraft, an investment of $5.3 million to $7.5 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aer Lingus announced that its chief executive, David Kennedy, would take early retirement at the end of the year to pursue interests in the private sector.

title: Susan Einbinder Weds Aaron Brenner, Editor
description: Susan Dana Einbinder and Aaron Michael Brenner were married yesterday at the Manor in West Orange, N.J., by Rabbi Ellen Lewis.

title: Charla Doherty, Actress, 41
description: Charla Doherty, a television actress who appeared on the soap opera ''Days of Our Lives'' for more than two years in the 1960's, died Sunday, her publicist said. She was 41 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse; Orangemen (15-0) Win Championship
description: The largest crowd ever to attend a college lacrosse game turned out today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship match between Cornell and Syracuse. The 20,220 spectators in the sweaty Carrier Dome did not see much of a contest, however, because the Orangemen scored early and often.

title: Job Description Is Confusing As Yankee Turmoil Persists
description: The job of major league general manager has become uncharacteristically unstable in recent years, which means the other teams only now are starting to catch up with the Yankees. Lou Piniella's decision to resign the Yankees' job, though, shows how far the others will have to go to catch the Yankees.

title: Changing Texas Politics at Its Roots
description: When a statewide business magazine listed the most powerful Texans not long ago, it included familiar businessmen like H. Ross Perot and T. Boone Pickens and politicians like Senator Lloyd Bentsen and Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio.

title: Science Watch; Preying on a Predator
description: Biologists at the University of California in Berkeley have discovered a microorganism that has learned to turn the tables on mosquito larvae that eat it, reversing the roles of prey and predator.

title: By Design; Shopping for Fall
description: To the uninitiated, June may seem a zany time to buy things like bright woolen coats, chemise dresses and wide-legged pants, but those with a passion for fashion know different. They have read the fall previews, and now they want to see, feel, try on and choose.

title: Thompson Seeks U.S. Comeback
description: BOARD members of the J. Walter Thompson Company and their guests will converge on the agency's Lexington Avenue headquarters in June, less than a year after the traumatic hostile takeover by WPP Group of Britain. And if Burt Manning is in the same mood as he was on Friday, they will find J.W.T.'s chairman and chief executive exuding confidence and optimism.

title: Moscow Summit: Looking for the Good News; Signing of Two Modest Arms Accords Is Expected
description: The United States and the Soviet Union expect to sign two modest arms control accords on Tuesday, American and Soviet officials said tonight.

title: Even PC's Join in Year Of the Mac
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to introduce several new PS/2 computers and an important new version of the DOS operating system software this week. The Compaq Computer Corporation is planning to roll out a significant new PC in three weeks. Several major software companies are finally getting ready to put the shrink wrap on new programs written for the OS/2 operating system. In short, June is shaping up as a busy month for the PC market.

title: Seoul Assembly Opens on Hopeful Note
description: This nation's first legislature with an opposition majority opened today, amid hopes that the session would forge a new politics of compromise and fears that it could end in stalemate and political crisis.

title: Careers; Improving The Quality Of Meetings
description: TOP executives spend 17 hours a week in business meetings, a recent study found, and more hours are spent getting ready.

title: Short-Term Rate Rise Anticipated
description: Short-term interest rates could rise again this week, after having reached their highest levels since just before the stock market crash, according to participants in the credit markets.

title: Fear No Evil
description: Gennadi I. Gerasimov, spokesman of the Soviet Union, a sophisticated man, looked straight at the American people through a TV camera in Moscow and lied.

title: Hughes Inquiry Is Reported
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company is under investigation on charges that it earned millions of dollars in improper profits on a 1983 missile contract with the Army, The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday.

title: Chess
description: To the International Chess Federation, what counts is where you live, not what your nationality is. Thus, it lists the international master Jonathan Tisdall, an American citizen, as a Norwegian player, and another American, the grandmaster Eric Lobron, as a West German player.

title: Market Place; Biotechnology Loses Luster
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY stocks, once a glamorous investment, are in the doldrums. The result, analysts said, could be increased takeover activity within the industry and bargain-hunting opportunities for patient investors.

title: Treasury to Sell One-Year Bills This Week
description: Today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills opens the holiday-shortened week, followed on Thursday by an auction of one-year bills. Tomorrow the Treasury will auction $4 billion of nine-day cash management bills, which are sold to financial institutions in units of $1 million.

title: INSIDE
description: High-Tech Vigilance Devices that read the retina like a fingerprint are among an array of security devices protecting scientific installations. Science Times, page C1. Dream Grows in Brooklyn The Knights of Eastern District High School in Brooklyn may need a miracle to become baseball champions, but they can dream. Page B1. After the Tax Revolt Voters are no longer slashing taxes and are even willing to support some increases when they know where the money is going. Page B8.

title: Boat Flips and Passenger Dies
description: A 36-year-old man was killed yesterday when a boat he was thinking of buying hit a wave and flipped over, hurling him into the water near Freeport, L.I., the police said.

title: For MGM/UA, Bidders Are Scarce
description: Few financiers love trading assets more than Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Shakespeare In Tokyo
description: The neighborhood of Shin-Okubo, nondescript and seldom visited, is an unlikely spot for a grand cultural experiment. Yet here, in full sight and sound of the railroad tracks, stands the Tokyo Globe, a reconstruction of Shakespeare's theater that opened its first season with a series of his history plays - in English and without translation.

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed.

title: Cuban Prison Life Is Said to Improve
description: American human-rights specialists, among the first foreigners to get an extensive look at Cuba's prisons, say they found a harsh system where inmates snapped to a rigid parade-rest stance when guards appeared.

title: Dutch Recover Paintings
description: The Dutch police reported recovering three paintings, including works by Vincent van Gogh and Paul Cezanne, today, less than two weeks after they were stolen from this city's Municipal Museum.

title: Grocery Store Owner Kills Robbery Suspect
description: A grocery store owner shot and killed a robbery suspect early yesterday after the store owner was wounded in an exchange of gunfire in his Bronx store, the police said.

title: What's Wrong With Massachusetts Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Top Sikh Priests Dismissed in Attack On Fundamentalism
description: The five head priests of the Sikh faith were dismissed today and accused of violating religious traditions.

title: IN CHINA, IDEOLOGY TAKES A BACK SEAT TO NEW REALITIES
description: Two months ago at an car engine plant in Henan Province, the factory's Communist Party secretary canceled the director's party credentials ''for taking bribes, arrogance and not acting according to principle.'' Enraged, the plant director dismissed the party secretary from the factory payroll ''for resisting reforms.''

title: Fire Destroys Woodstock Playhouse and Arson Is Suspected
description: A fire believed to have been set tore through the 50-year-old Woodstock Playhouse early this morning, destroying a cherished symbol of the cultural life that has made this town renowned through the Catskills and beyond.

title: Joan C. Danziger Wed in Massachusetts
description: At Temple Shalom in West Newton, Mass., Joan Caren Danziger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Danziger of West Newton, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Herz Hechtman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Hechtman of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Murray Rothman performed the ceremony.

title: Business and Health; Nursing Shortage Is Costing Billions
description: AN ACUTE shortage of nurses in hospitals and nursing homes has added billions of dollars to the nation's escalating expenditures for health care.

title: Political Truth for '88: People Will Accept Taxes, but Not for Everything
description: Ten years after the national tax revolt that Californians started in the 1970's, Americans are no longer slashing away at taxes, but they remain highly skeptical about the way their money is spent by politicians.

title: U.S.-Japanese Deal on Fighter
description: The United States and Japan have agreed in principle on a multibillion-dollar program to make Japan's next generation of jet fighters, a Japan Defense Agency spokesman said today.

title: Irish Distillers Rejects Offer
description: Ireland's top whisky maker today rejected a joint takeover bid by two British consumer-products companies, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Allied-Lyons P.L.C.

title: At Ice-Clad Volcanoes, Vigils for Disaster
description: MILLIONS of people in North and South America live in the shadow of snow-clad volcanoes, some of them ominously astir.

title: George Bush's Independence Day
description: Today's trivia question is: What happened on Sept. 30, 1968, and why should George Bush care? The answer: That's when Vice President Humphrey, in a speech in Salt Lake City, began to part company with President Johnson's policies in Vietnam. But the divorce was a shade too late. Mr. Humphrey eventually lost the race to Richard Nixon by 440,000 votes, even though he was gaining ground at a rate of 500,000 votes a day.

title: Calling It Quits
description: Terry Blocker, who battled this spring for a starting center-field position with the Atlanta Braves, has left the team's Class AAA affiliate in Richmond.

title: Arthur F. Jones Jr., Writer and Editor, 85
description: Arthur Fredrick Jones Jr., a writer and editor, died of pneumonia Sunday at the Hillcrest (N.Y.) Nursing Home. He was 85 years old and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title: Engineer Says He Has Shed 'Guilt' over Shuttle
description: Roger Boisjoly, an engineer for Morton Thiokol Inc. who argued against the launching of the space shuttle Challenger, said he has stopped blaming himself for the explosion that killed seven astronauts and is ready to go back to work.

title: Police Seeking 2 In Fatal Beating Of a Doctor, 66
description: The police were searching yesterday for at least two suspects in the robbery and fatal beating of a 66-year-old anesthesiologist whose body was found Sunday alongside a creek opposite the Starrett City housing development in Brooklyn.

title: Michael Gifford, Press Agent, 53
description: Michael Gifford, a longtime press agent, died of a heart attack Saturday while driving to the East Hampton, L.I., airport to meet her husband, Edwin. She was 53 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in East Hampton.

title: Continental DC-9 Nearly Hits Light Plane Over Cleveland
description: The pilot of a Continental Airlines DC-9 took evasive action yesterday to avoid hitting a light plane about five miles southeast of Cleveland's main airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Tuesday New Home Sales April Farm Prices May Wednesday Leading Indicators April Construction Spending April Factory Orders April Thursday None Friday Unemployment May

title: CBS Sports Trying to Find Black Announcers
description: To the Editor:

title: Redken's Founder Hopes To Take Company Private
description: Paula Kent Meehan, an actress who once played a hatcheck girl on the ''77 Sunset Strip'' television series, founded Redken Laboratories Inc. out of frustration. Allergic to regular hair spray, she sought out products she could use.

title: Horse Racing; 2d Victory for Gulch In Metropolitan
description: Gulch surrendered the lead to Afleet at the top of the stretch but reclaimed it in the final furlong to post a half-length victory and win his second successive Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; Gorbachev and Reagan Toasts: 'Man's Survival' and 'Peace and Freedom'
description: Following are excerpts from the toasts by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan at a state dinner tonight at the Kremlin. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by a Soviet interpreter. Gorbachev Toast

title: Smithsonian Names Overseer of Exhibitions
description: Anna R. Cohn has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service, which brings Smithsonian exhibitions to other museums in the United States and abroad.

title: Toronto Stock Prices Up
description: Stock prices moved higher in mixed trading today on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The composite index rose 14.10, to 3,187.20, as stocks falling in price outnumbered those posting a gain, 366 to 329. Stock exchanges in the United States and Europe were closed for the holiday.

title: Moscow Summit: Preaching to the Unconverted; A Mighty Russian Pulpit for Reagan
description: President Reagan came to Moscow determined to press the human rights issue and encourage greater change in Soviet life. But it is clear that if he pushes too hard, he runs the risk of embarrassing Mikhail S. Gorbachev and thus slowing the very transformations he wants to encourage. Nevertheless, White

title: An Earthquake Off Indonesia Causes Blackout in Australia
description: A major earthquake centered just south of the Indonesian island of Timor jolted this northern Australian city today, blacking out most of the suburbs here for about an hour.

title: Baseball; Clemens Stops Angels by 5-2
description: Roger Clemens pitched a six-hitter tonight for his ninth straight road victory and Dwight Evans drove in three runs, two with his third homer of the season, as the Boston Red Sox beat the California Angels, 5-2.

title: Diaper Import Quotas Under Fire
description: Thousands of parents are likely to pay more for diaper services as a result of import quotas the United States has quietly imposed on plain cotton diapers from China.

title: For Many, Help Is Near on Health Costs
description: Elderly middle-class Americans and their families will be the first to benefit from legislation meant to shield Medicare recipients from ruin by huge medical bills, in the view of health care experts and Congressional sponsors.

title: New Test May Predict Recurrence Of Cancer In Breast
description: BRITISH and American researchers are experimenting with what they hope will be the first reliable predictor of which breast cancers will recur or spread.

title: New Belzberg Partner Made It Big in Muffins
description: Michael Bregman, a young Toronto entrepreneur who runs a muffin chain, has teamed up with the Belzberg family to buy a hefty chunk of the stock of the International Multifoods Corporation.

title: Michael V. Gilberti Jr. Wed to Paige Tunstall
description: The marriage of Paige Brooke Tunstall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Brooke Tunstall of Summit, N.J., to Michael Vincent Gilberti Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gilberti of Fox Chapel, Pa., took place yesterday at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. George Golden, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Science Watch; Bees at Work: It's All in the Genes
description: FOR worker bees it may often be genes, not environment, that determine the individual's life work, new studies suggest.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Cubs placed the right-handed pitcher Al Nipper on the 15-day disabled list Monday because of a strained right elbow and purchased the contract of right-handed Jeff Pico from Iowa. Pico, who was 4-2 with a 2.58 earned run average in the American Association, is scheduled to pitch today against Cincinnati. Nipper, who is 1-2 with a 2.68 e.r.a., is the fifth Cub starter to go on the disabled list this season. Calvin Schiraldi came off the disabled list two days ago and Scott Sanderson, Rick Sutcliffe and Bob Tewksbury are currently on the list. . . . Dan Magill has retired after 34 years as coach of the University of Georgia men's tennis team. Magill, 67, had a record of 706-183 in dual matches. His teams won two National Collegiate Athletic Association championships and 13 outdoor and seven indoor team titles in the Southeastern Conference. The Georgia athletic director, Vince Dooley, said Manuel Diaz, an assistant to Magill since 1982, will be the new men's coach. Magill will retain responsibilities as director of the overall men's and women's tennis programs, according to a statement by the university. (AP)

title: What's Wrong With Massachusetts Health Plan; Long Waits in Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: Nezahualcoyotl Journal; In Plain of Hungry Coyote, Millions Dwell in Hope
description: Just a quarter of a century ago, there was little here except barren plains and a salty, swampy lake bed. Today, 2.7 million people live in this sprawling, jerry-rigged settlement just east of Mexico City. This place, Mexicans, with a certain ironic pride and flair for drama, often describe as the largest slum in the world.

title: For MGM/UA, Bidders Are Scarce
description: Few financiers love trading assets more than Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Critic's Notebook; In New Films, the Rich Are Gross, Even Murderous, but Not Immoral
description: Diana, the glamorous anti-heroine of ''White Mischief,'' and Rachel, the flighty love object in ''The Moderns'' are beautiful, young women who married for money. They also share the odd tendency - sensuous, silly and indolent at once - to bathe wearing their pearls.

title: In Midst of Tradition, an Evolving Race
description: Along Main Street and down to Davenport, there were banners, balloons and a sprinkling of American flags. ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' sounded from one loudspeaker, Samuel Barber's Adagio for Strings, sounded from another, but amid all the Americana at today's Kugler-Anderson Tour of Somerville, there was an international touch.

title: Homeless Center Offers Shelter With Direction
description: The merchant seaman, originally from Louisiana, says he has sailed on the liquor of Skid Row since his wife and year-old daughter died in a traffic accident 15 years ago.

title: East Beirut Car Bombing Kills 20 and Wounds 83
description: A car bomb exploded today in a crowded area in East Beirut, and the police said 20 people were killed and 83 wounded.

title: Sports of the Times; Piniella to Resist Yankee Recycling
description: NOW that Lou Piniella is no longer the Yankees' general manager, he's the obvious choice to be recycled sooner or later as the next Yankee manager. Any historian of the Steinbrenner Shuffle might assume that. And even George Himself might assume that. After all, in discussing his future as a Yankee employee with no specific role, Lou Piniella talked about managing again.

title: Accounts
description: * Zip-Pak Inc. to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners for advertising and Creamer Dickson Basford for public relations.

title: Books of The Times; Hollywood Studios and What They Stood For
description: The Hollywood Studios House Style in the Golden Age of the Movies By Ethan Mordden Illustrated. 387 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Among Sanchezes, Talent Is Relative
description: The French newspapers had called the situation ''La Famille Sanchez Contre La France'' and it has seemed as though the Sanchezes from Spain - Emilio, Javier and Arantxa - are everywhere at the French Open, knocking off seeded players and generally giving their elders a hard time.

title: AC&R/DHB & Bess Adds the Champs Chain
description: The AC&R/DHB & Bess ad agency is already blessed with a number of assignments for footwear from the Kinney Shoe Corporation of the F. W. Woolworth Company. Now the agency has been named, it announced Friday, to handle the Champs Sporting Goods chain of retail outlets, another Woolworth operation, with an ad budget of more than $1 million.

title: Magazine Finds a Niche In Medicine and Health
description: From his sunny office in this bayside village north of San Francisco, Eric Schrier, the editor of Hippocrates, acknowledged that the work involved in starting the bimonthly health and medical magazine meant that he and his employees frequently had to ignore their own advice.

title: Addenda
description: * Electric Company magazine will be called Kid City beginning in September.

title: Q&A
description: Q.If a hole of, say, three feet in diameter were dug straight through the Earth, and an object, such as a brick, were dropped into the hole, how far would it go?

title: Traditional Allies Battle Over Pandas
description: A scramble by American zoos to borrow rare giant pandas from China as a way to generate large crowds has triggered a bitter dispute among longstanding allies in the animal conservation movement.

title: Waterford Journal; Landmark Town Facing Development Challenge
description: There are more than 1,800 buildings, battlefields, ships, neighborhoods and other sites and structures on the Government's list of national historic landmarks and districts.

title: Ernst Ruska, a German Nobel Winner, Dies at 81
description: Ernst August Friedrich Ruska, an electrical engineer who shared the 1986 Nobel Prize in Physics for his invention of the electron microscope, died yesterday in West Berlin. He was 81 years old.

title: Ailing Brazil Is Divided On Economy
description: With Brazil caught in its worst economic crisis in decades, the Government and a special Constitutional Assembly are at loggerheads over how to change the country's development strategy.

title: High Ratings for One-Piece Swimsuits in Hot Colors
description: The swimsuit season is here, and there's more to celebrate than the prospect of sunny summer weekends. This year, thousands of swimsuits are in the stores, offering a variety of choices for every figure.

title: Swimming; New Wave of Success for Australians
description: When the 1956 Olympics were held in Melbourne, Australians won 8 of the 13 gold medals in swimming. Since then, although Australia has turned out such outstanding swimmers as Murray Rose, Dawn Fraser and Shane Gould, it has fallen behind the United States, the Soviet Union and East Germany in swimming success.

title: Beazer Wins Court Ruling
description: Beazer P.L.C., the British concern that is offering $60 a share to acquire the Koppers Company, said yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco had effectively removed a Federal District Court injunction against Beazer's takeover bid.

title: Weapons Cuts by Third World to Be Urged at U.N.
description: The United States and its principal Western allies will seek a pledge by developing countries to cut military spending as part of a new international consensus on disarmament at a special General Assembly session that opens Tuesday.

title: Jackson Makes Appeal For Black-Jewish Ties
description: As a soft wind fluttered off the Hudson, the Rev. Jesse Jackson solemnly placed a wreath at a statue honoring Holocaust victims and pleaded for reconciliation between blacks and Jews.

title: Review/Music; Kassav' Plays Zouk, Sound of Caribbean
description: In a concert Sunday that left no hips unmoved, Kassav' defined zouk and zouke, the noun and verb in French Antillean Creole, for the band's first Manhattan audience. Zouk (which rhymes with ''juke'') is the Caribbean's most up-to-date dance music; it comes from the cross-pollination of ritual and carnival music from Guadeloupe with other Caribbean and North American dance music and French pop, delivered with modern instruments and recording-studio precision. Zouke means to party, preferably with a zouk band and a dance floor. Kassav', a band of musicians from Guadeloupe and Martinique that's now based in Paris, played two hours of buoyant zouk that made a sweat-drenched audience at the Ritz zouke from start to finish.

title: Grit and Love Bring Team Closer to Baseball Paradise
description: For Johnny Delgado, Jose Medina, Augie Santana, Ariel Chimelis and the other boys on their high school baseball team, these days in Brooklyn fly past, one game into the next, one victory after another, each one closer to that ballplayers' paradise - Yankee Stadium.

title: Uptown Musical Fights to Keep Its Home
description: A traveling company of ''Mama, I Want to Sing'' is beginning a two-month tour of Japan. The singing, shouting, all-black, gospel-rhythm-and-blues musical will be presented in English. Meantime, the home troupe is still belting out the story of the pop singer Doris Troy in twice-a-week summer performances in the East Harlem home it almost lost - and may still lose.

title: Ciccarelli in Court
description: Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars pleaded not guilty yesterday in a Toronto court to a charge of assaulting an opponent during a game. The charge stems from an incident during a game between the North Stars and the Toronto Maple Leafs in Toronto on Jan. 6 in which Luke Richardson, a Leafs defenseman, was struck in the head by Ciccarelli. Richardson, appearing as a witness, told Provincial Court Judge Sidney Harris that during the second period he was struck by Ciccarelli's stick on the side and back of the head and in the mouth by the player's glove. The 19-year-old Richardson told the court that the attack took place immediately after he pushed the North Star forward into the boards with his stick. (Reuters)

title: People
description: * Allen Adamson has been named senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York.

title: Homer in 14th Sinks Yankees
description: Dave Henderson's home run to center field had barely cleared the fence when Billy Martin began his exit from the Oakland Coliseum tonight. The volatile Yankee manager, ejected from the game in the third inning, left the ball park moments after Henderson's shot beat the Yankees in the 14th inning, 3-2.

title: Puzzling Findings on Bottled Water in Pregnancy
description: California health officials are planning further studies in an attempt to explain puzzling results that seem to suggest that tap water might contribute to miscarriages and birth defects.
